column2: The Ensemble Chorale Society, Charles Albert McClain, director, gave its third subscription concert of the season last night at Town Hall. Soloists were Agnes Carlson, soprano; Adele Savoye, whistler, and Mr. McClain, in his capacity as tenor. Grace Roberts, pianist, and Walter Waters, organist, assisted.

The compensatory tax on all personal property purchased by residents outside the city, proposed by Mayor La Guardia to supplement the emergency relief taxes, would more than double the revenue now received from the personal property tax, which it would replace, according to estimates yesterday.

Twenty-four members of the combined track teams of Princeton and Cornell will sail for England on the French liner Normandie July 13 for their ninth meet with the OxfordCambridge team at White City, London, July 23, it was announced today by Matty Geis, coach of the undefeated Tiger squad.

Attorneys for the Ford Motor Company moved yesterday to block the efforts of the National Labor Relations Board to settle issues over its procedure out of court and to obtain a judicial inquiry into the board's decision ordering the company to reinstate twenty-nine employes whom it alleged were discharged for union activity.

Sir Hubert Wilkins has arrived at Aalesund, Norway, to hire a Norwegian crew for a new Antarctic expedition, starting in the Fall. Headed by the ship Wyatt Earp, 'for which the crew is sought, the expedition will carry two airplanes, to be flown by four American pilots.

Nine Bourse operators were charged with "attacks against the credit of the State" tonight after long questioning concerning international financial rumors,' which caused a sharp drop in yesterday's market.
Joseph (Babe) Pioli, who murdered Bill Brennan, heavyweight boxer, in 1924 and who began his

With the object of preserving unspoiled a belt of countryside around rapidly expanding London, the Hertfordshire County Council has agreed with J. P. Morgan, the banker, on-the purchase of his Wall Hall estate at Aldenham, near Watford, for [Pound]220,000.

The possibility of a race among creditors of the bankrupt Munson Steamship Company was in prospect yesterday as the result of the decision of Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe in rejecting a proposal to limit libel actions to the port of New York.

The Dauphin County Court today gave the C. I. O.'s Pennsylvania Industrial Union Council until noon tomorrow to surrender the Labor Headquarters Building it has used since it split with the State Federation of Labor.

Playing over her home course yesterday, Mrs. Ray Torgerson -set a new competitive record for women on the Queens Valley layout at Forest Hills when she won the lowgross honors in the weekly one-day Women's Long Island Golf Association tourney with a card of 41, 35-76.

Medley G. B. Whelpley was elected a trustee of the New York Trust Company at the regular meeting of the board yesterday. The directors' meeting of the Monsanto Chemical Works, Inc., scheduled yesterday has been postponed until tomorrow.
Directors of the Alabama Great Southern Railroad Company voted yesterday to pay a dividend of $3 a share on the ordinary stock. A year ago the company distributed $1.50 a share to its stockholders.
Miss Hildegarde Graham gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Miss Phyllis I. R. Gillespie, whose engagement to Alan T. Schumacher was announced last month.
The reference is to the Civil War and to what will probably be the last reunion of Union and Confederate veterans.

The Constitutional Convention was urged today by representatives of several chambers of commerce and other municipal business organizations to write provisions into the new Constitution for a lowering of "excessive" real estate assessments and the placing of a definite ceiling on the debt limit of cities.

Miss Elizabeth Chatterton Grant, daughter of Robert McQueen Grant of this city and Bryn Mawr, Pa., has completed plans for her marriage to J. Dudley Clark Jr. of this city, son of J. Dudlev Clark of Boston and the late Mrs. Clark, which will take place here on June 17 in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. The ceremony will be performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent.
By THOMAS F. BURCHILL Edson Ave, 4,366, 26.8x87.6: Henry V. Clark against Division Realty Holding Co: due, $8,321; taxes, etc., $126; to plaintiff for $7,000.

" Replanting of the Union Jack" in turbulent areas of Palestine will begin Friday with a general redistribution of armed forces. This is the first major stroke for the re-establishment of control since the arrival of Sir Harold MacMichael as High Commissioner.

A victory by Harry Jensen in the running high jump enabled La Salle Academy to win the senior team crown for the second year in a row at the ninth annual C. H. S. A. A. championship track and field meet for Manhattan, Bronx and Westchester schools on the Manhattan College field in the Bronx yesterday.

The annual music festival under the auspices of the Lake Placid Club Education Foundation will be held in the Olympic Arena at Lake Placid Saturday. Twenty-four schools from Clinton, Essex, Franklin and Washington Counties are represented, and about 1,300 participants are expected.

Dr. and Mrs. George T. Banker of Elizabeth, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary deWolfe Banker, to Robert Romaine Daly, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Daly of South Orange, N. J.

Adequate medical care for all and protection of the public against "costly, impersonal and inefficient socialized medicine" are among the objectives of the New Jersey Medical Society for the ensuing year as outlined today by the incoming president of the organization, Dr. William J. Carrington of Atlantic City.

The Equitable Auto Company and the Harwick Coal and Coke Company of Pittsburgh have filed declarations with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Holding Company Act for approval of their organization
Brooklyn College's baseball forces triumphed on their home field yesterday, blanking New York Cathedral College, 9 to O, in a game halted by rain at the close of the first half of the sixth inning.
" Washington Jitters" ends with tomorrow night's performance at the Guild Theatre, and this time the closing is official. (It had been slated to expire last Saturday, then was reprieved.)

Referring to Dr. Morris Fishbein as an accepted spokesman for organized medicine, the Medical Society of New Jersey proposed today drastic restrictions on the writings of the editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association.

Arkansas-Missouri Power Corporation-Three months ended March 31: Operating revenue $289,119 and net income after all deductions $23,113. For eleven months since reorganization on May 1, 1937, gross revenue was $1,187,444 and net income $186,418.

Herbert Hoover made a plea to youth leaders of America tonight to "build our boys to support a democratic State." Speaking on the "Cause of the American Boy" at the annual convention of the Boys' Clubs of America, of which he is chairman, the former President told of his observations of the youth movement abroad, and contrasted the Fascist program with that of the United States.

Bank clearings for the week ended on, Wednesday showed some improvement over the previous period, but continued to decline from the comparative total of the preceding year for the twenty-seventh consecutive week.

Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse is returning tomorrow from Palm Beach and will be at the Plaza. Mr. and-Mrs. William T. Aldrich and Miss Abigail Aldrich of Brookline, Mass., have joined Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Aldrich of Providence at the Ambassador.

Baron Gottfried von Cramm, Germany's top-ranking tennis star, lodged an appeal through counsel today against the sentence of a year in prison imposed on him last Saturday for violation of a statute covering moral delinquencies.

A client of Ivor B. Clark, Inc, has taken a first mortgageg of $73,800, at 51/2 per cent for five years, on the property at 3,208 Fulton St, Brooklyn. Charles F. Noyes Co, Inc, has arranged the extension of the $107,000 mortgage on 45 Moylan Place with the Mutual Life Insurance Co.
General Saturnino Cedillo, accused by President Lazaro Cardenas of plotting a revolt, told The Associated Press this morning that he had been informed Federal troops would attack him today.

Frank McDonnell of Radburn, N. J., brother of Mrs. Alice Parsons, who disappeared from her home on Long Island nearly a year ago, was fined $3 today for speeding by Police Recorder Vincent Duffy here.

Twelve smaller store merchants have accepted places on the newly formed board of advisors for the bureau of smaller stores of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was announced yesterday by Edward Kaylin, director of the bureau.

Nursing certificates were awarded last night to twenty-nine graduates of the Brooklyn Hospital School of Nursing in exercises at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. About 500 persons attended the ceremonies.

Joseph Horowitz, 42 years old, of 1,242 Simpson Street, the Bronx., was sentenced today to thirty years to life in prison by County Judge Frank H. Coyne after pleading guilty to second degree murder. Horowitz, a shirt presser, killed Morris J. Felzener of 62 West 104th Street, New York, in a field at Armonk last Feb. 13.
For the first time in this country television was used yesterday as a medium of classroom instruction and at the end of a forty-minute demonstration the experiment was voted a "great success."
Thirty members of the Bronx Board of Trade put business cares aside for three hours yesterday to make their twenty-third annual tour of that borough's parks and playgrounds.

Injunction proceedings brought by the Independent Gas and Electric Union against the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, its affiliated companies and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers were dismissed yesterday on technical grounds by Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag.

Dr. Harry Merwin, 40 years old, of 575 West 189th Street, a dentist, was killed yesterday morning when he leaned over the edge of the northbound subway platform of the I. R. T. station at 191st Street and St. Nicholas Avenue to watch a southbound train approach.

The Ford Motor Company announced today that the Federal Labor Board had declared the strike at the company's assembly plant here was illegal and as a result the strike flags were removed from the plant at 1 P. M.

Frank F. Walker of Eastman, Dillon Co., chairman of the district No. 13 committee of the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., announced yesterday the appointment of Laurence M. Marks, Stuart R. Reed and Oliver J. Troster to serve as a nominating committee

Tass (official Russian news agency) reported today that M. S. Babushkin, one of Russia's foremost fliers, and three other persons were killed Monday in an airplane crash on a flight from the Arctic region to the mainland of, Soviet Russia.

Upper Austrian National Socialists have expropriated Kamme Castle on the Attersee, belonging to a Hungarian aristocrat' and rented by Raimund von Hoffmannstahl, son of a noted Austrian writer, who received many paying guests.

Republican leaders of the Constitutional Convention have decided to submit to the people in November, in addition to substantive changes in the present basic law, a "stream-lined" rewritten version of the present Constitution, with "obsolete" sections omitted.

Franco-Italian relations seem about to pass through another crisis. When the British Prime Minister, Neville Chamberlain, decided to embark upon his "experiment" last February and negotiated a treaty with Italy, the Paris Cabinet followed suit unhesitatingly.

Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, declared today that the government was doing and had done more than its share to mitigate the relief crises in Cleveland, and Chicago. He put responsibility for these situations squarely at the doors of the Ohio and Illinois Legislatures.

THE extraordinary apparition turned out to be Edward Aloysius McGonigle Brannick, secretary of the Giants. No wonder Horace Stoneham and -Barrister Bondy have taken to calling him "Color Scheme" Brannick.

Lawrenceville School's powerful polo forces won the last game of the season today by defeating the Princeton varsity, 12-11. The score was tied thrice. Captain Rose climaxed his final Lawrenceville appearance by scoring eight goals.

Knopf will bring out June 1 "New Writing: Spring 1938," edited by John Lehmann. Stories, poems and sketches by Chinese, English, French, Geiman, Spanish and Russian writers are included in this volume, the third to be published in the United States.

Big John Whitehead, making his first start in more than three weeks, shut out the Red Sox with three singles in a game held to seven innings by rain today and the Whie Sox took the only contest of the 'curtailed series, 4 to O.

Operations of Pan American Airways thus far in 1938 have been encouraging and have shown a substantial increase in volume of traffic over the like period of 1937, J. P. Trippe, president, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders.

The Artists and Writers Golf Association held its first Spring one-day competition today with sixty prominent authors and illustrators participating in the event over the North Hempstead Country Club links. Charles McAdam and Herb Roth tied for first place. Each had a net of 71.
The Philadelphia Country Club today captured the championship of the Women's Golf Association of Philadelphia by defeating Wilmington, Del., and Merion in a threeday play-off.

An official interpretation by the Chilean Government of the law passed in 1935 relative to the partial servicing of external Chilean obligations, received here yesterday declares that the act and acceptance of the offer by bondholders "in no wise affects or modifies the original obligation of the bonds in so far as concerns the capital owed under that obligation."

Registration today under the Securities Act of 1933 of an issue of $30,000,000 of thirty-year 3 1/4 per cent debentures due on June 1, 1968, by the Mountain States Telephone and Telegraph Company of Denver gave to officials further hopes

Mayor La Guardia yesterday endorsed the campaign of the Independent Order Brith Abraham for funds for land in Palestine for the settlement of Jewish refugees. Pledging his support, the Mayor at City Hall purchased a ticket for "Palestine Night," an entertainment and dance of the order tomorrow night at the Seventy-first

A thirty-day workhouse term was imposed in Special Sessions yesterday on George F. Price, 43 years old, of 61 Oakland Avenue, Lynbrook, a part-owner of Hoffman Elias, Inc., electrical contractors, on his recent guilty plea to failing to pay proper State income taxes for the concerns!

It is understood that Italy makes the closing of the Pyrenees frontier the sine qua non condition of any resumption of negotiations with France. This condition was communicated yesterday to the Earl of Perth, the British Ambassador, by Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano.

The death of William Herr Jr., 17 years old, of 740 Tenth Avenue, who succumbed to rabies late Wednesday night in Willard Parker Hospital, was the first fatality from that disease in New York since July, 1936, it was announced yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.

As President Lazaro Cardenas is in San Luis Potosi boldly taunting the weakened war lord of that State, General Saturnino Cedillo, and prepared to disarm him and his followers with the backing of Federal troops, an important though nonmilitary revolt is gathering force in Mexico City.

The American Institute of Public Opinion has made an interesting study (the results of which are published in THE TIMES this morning) of the influence of Federal spending on the voting preference of the electorate.
Ernest Angell, until April 30 New York regional administrator for the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced yesterday that he will join the law firm of Spence, Windels, Walser Hotchkiss.

The Canadian Wheat Board will be continued for the crop year ending on July 31, 1939, and a minimum price will be set later, Trade Minister Euler told the House of Commons here today. Answering a question raised yesterday by E. E. Perley of Saskatchewan, Mr. Euler said:

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustment.

Miss Miriam Lundy of The New York Daily News, president of the New York Newspaper Women's Club, was re-elected last night at the annual meeting, held at 22 East Thirty-eighth Street, the organization's headquarters.

The story of the successful public protest against the Byrnes Reorganization Bill was read so recently and by so bright and hot a candle that it can scarcely have been forgotten. Certainly the President remembers it well and resentfully. Recalling that popular excitement

In conformity with what appears to be a general nationalist policy tending to removal of all foreign influences, police have ordered the dissolution of a Christian Scince Church which has functioned here since 1908 without interference. All services, lectures and other activities must cease.

In its last meeting before the Wages and Hours Bill comes to the House floor Monday on a discharge petition, the informal steering committee in charge of the measure laid plans today to block expected emasculating amendments from Southern opponents and any- motion for adjournment until a vote is had.

The Board of Governors of the New York Young Republican Club unanimously adopted a resolution at a meeting in the Town Hall Club last night condemning Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City in that he "arbitrarily and unlawfully deprived Norman Thomas and others of the right of free speech and assembly, guaranteed to them by the Constitution of the United States."

The Southeastern Greyhound Lines were authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to issue $254,811 of equipment purchase notes, maturing serially over three years, to finance the purchase of twenty motor buses from the A. C. F. Motors Company at a cost of $14,156 each.
Samuel Hale Pillsbury, retired Boston lawyer who was formerly a member of the firm of Burnham, Bingham, Dana Gould, died today at his home in Milton. He was 64 years old.

Following several days of declining prices abroad, the domestic producers of copper lowered the price 1 cent a pound to 9 cents late yesterday. Copper fabricators made corresponding changes in their quotations on finished products.

Representatives of the B. M. T., with whom the city and the Transit Commission are conducting joint negotiations for rapid transit unification, are insisting that the company's 198 miles of street railway lines in Brooklyn and Queens be included in the proposed unity plan, it was disclosed yesterday.

Bids will be opened at noon on Tuesday by Joseph D. McGoldrick, Controller of the City of New York, on proposals for $10,000,000 of New York City corporate stock and $40,000,000 of serial bonds, it was announced yesterday at the office of the Controller.

Conference, Greater New York Federation of Churches, Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifty-fifth Street, 10:30 A.M. "Our Church in Our City," Mrs. Norman Vincent Peale, Miss Dorothy Height, Dr. John W. Suter Jr.; Dr. Robert W. Searle.

Samuel L. Antonow has been reelected president of Yadsco Sales Corporation, it was announced yesterday. All other officers were reelected, as follows: Henry W. Wittner, first vice president and treasurer;

Recovery could be attained in four to six months, Ernest T. Weir declared here tonight, if the Administration changed its policies and adopted a program, which he outlined, to end business uncertainty and encourage private enterprise.

Leaders of finance, business and industry paid their last respects today to Edward T. Stotesbury, partner of Drexel Co. and J. P. Morgan Co., at a simple funeral service at the financier's estate. Whitemarsh Hall, near Chestnut Hill.
The Seventh Cavalry Brigade, with 516 vehicles and 3,000 officers and men, will begin tomorrow morning its longest march, and its first since its receipt of new equipment.

A "competitive fight" is ahead in the home mortgage field, Raymond P. Harold of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in Boston told 100 members of the Metropolitan League of Savings and Loan Asso-. clations last night at their annual dinner meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Miss Ethel Plotz, daughter of Mrs. Isaac I. Plotz of 441 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, and the late Dr. Plotz, was married to Norman Berman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Berman of this city, yesterday afternoon at the home of her mother. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Jacob Bosniak.

44th St, 225 W; to 4-story theatre; Central Theatres Leasing Const. Co., Inc, premises, owner; 3. F. Daly and H. H. Cashdan, engineers; cost, $10,000. 78th St, 232-34 W.; to two 3-story dwellings and restaurant; North River Savings Bank, 206 W 34th St, owner; Oscar Goldschlag, architect: cost, $5.800.

There was a slight gain in the level of business in the Pittsburgh district last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Prior to last week, business in the district had declined for six consecutive weeks, during which the adjusted index fell 7 points.
The Senate approved today a bill raising to $30,000,000,000 the limit of

Judge Kenneth Wynne of Superior Court denied today a motion by G. Leroy Kemp of Mount Vernon, N. Y., who had asked the quashing of two conspiracy indictments returned against him by the Merritt Parkway grand jury recently.

A reliefrecovery bill essentially the same as the one passed by the House last week will probably be reported to the Senate Monday, according to Chairman Adams of the subcommittee which will start redrafting the measure tomorrow.

Robert E. Barrett, president of the Holyoke Water Power Company, announced yesterday that shareholders, at a special meeting held in Holyoke, Mass., authorized the company to increase its outstanding capital stock from 24,000 shares to 240,000.

Bond groups, in their respective averages, followed along divergent courses yesterday in slightly more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Renewed strength in United States Government obligations on a relatively small turnover was a feature of the day's activities.
Lon Warneke, right-hander of the Cardinals pitching staff, was on his way home from Brooklyn today to have an 'injured right ankle X-rayed and treated by Dr. Robert F. Hyland, club surgeon.

A gift of $150,000 from Mrs. Eva Sawyer Goodman, widow of William O. Goodman, a lumber merchant, was announced by the Art Institute of Chicago. The gift, made in the name of both Mr. and Mrs. Goodman, is without restrictions.

The battle of proxies for control of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway ended today with the re-election of the present directors, endorsed by Robert R. Young, and enlargement of the board to include three representatives of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

Taking vain precautions to conceal the witness's identity, Federal authorities brought before the spy-hunting grand jury yesterday Mrs. Kate Moog Busch, who is expected to play a significant part in the government's planned exposure of an international spy fraternity created by agents of Germany.

Sunny Jim Bottomley resigned today as manager of the Chiefs of the International League and Dick Porter, veteran outfielder, was named his successor. Bottomley announced his resignation after a brief conference with Owner Jack Corbett by stating he had become convinced he was no longer able to play regularly and that he had no desire to continue as a bench manager.

Federal Judge William Clark, sitting in the Federal court here, today signed an order for the police in Jersey City and Hoboken to show cause why a permanent injunction from interfering with the sales of The New York Post in those cities should not be issued.

A luncheon in honor of Captain William J. Pedridk will be given today in the Empire State Club by the staff of William J. Pedrick Co., Inc., and officers of the Fifth Avenue Association to mark his fiftieth birthday and his twentieth year as an executive of the association.

The last of a series of five hearings on a proposed marketing agreement and order regulating the handling of milk in the New York metropolitan area will be held tomorrow morning at the'State Office Building, 80 Center Street, New York. Starting on Monday, the hearings were held at Albany, Malone, Syracuse and Elmira.
George T. Everitt, former Mayor of Hackettstown and for the last forty-five years financial secretary of the State Firemen's Association, died last night at his home here in his eighty-seventh year.

French women have Taised the distance record twice within a week. Mme. Andre Dupeyron, missing since she took off from Oran, Algeria, last Sunday, was located today near, Tel el Aham, 150 kilometers [about ninety-three miles] north of Bassora, where her plane was damaged in landing. She was not hurt.

The Bush Building, two and tenstory U-shaped structure known as 130 to 134 and 138 West Forty-second Street, running through to 133-39 West Forty-first Street, was sold yesterday at auction to the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, as plaintiff, on a bid of $1,000,000.

Lawrence A. Fernsworth, Barcelona correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES and The Times of London, was entertained at a dinner tonight by twenty foreign war correspondents on the eve of hit departure for the United States for his marriage to Isabel MacDonald of Galveston, Texas, at the Galveston Cathedral in June.

Miss Hilda Moscow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Moscow.of 55 Central Park West, was married to Louis D. Colish, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Colish of Mount Vernon, N. Y., yesterday morning at the home in Greenwich, Conn., of the Rev. Dr. Isaah Miller, who performed the ceremony.

The Federal Trade Commission won today the opening skirmish in its attempt to enforce a fourteen-yearold order against what it called "Pittsburgh plus" prices charged by the United States Steel Corporation.

Warrants for the arrest of Lieutenant Governor T. Frank Hayes, Democratic Mayor of this city, and twenty-six other persons, including five from New York, were ordered issued tonight by Superior Court Judge Ernest A. Inglis

Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran, the and/or annihilator of the city government, yesterday was constrained to reprove both James J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx, and Newbold Morris, President of the Council and Yale graduate, for misuse of "contact" as a verb.
Seven residential properties in the Bronx were bid in at auction yesterday by the Home Owners Loan Corporation, plaintiff in foreclosure proceedings against various individuals.

The Phillies climaxed an uphill battle against Cincinnati today by taking advantage of a balk and an error to score a ninth inning 5-to-4 victory. With one down in the ninth, Hugh Mulcahy singled and went to second on Joe Cascarella's balk. Herschel Martin flied to Dusty Cooke in left.

A fire which started early yesterday morning when Jares Brannigan, 46 years old, fell asleep in his home with a lighted cigarette in his mouth resulted in the death of his 7-year-old son, Martin. His daughter, Dorothy, was treated for smoke poisoning, and he was burned about the face and body in the blaze that occurred in his thirdfloor apartment at 1,776 Webster Avenue, the Bronx.

After more than three hours of stormy debate, the New York County Lawyers Association repudiated last night the recommendation of its Constitutional Convention committee favoring the creation of a State Department of Justice and the appointment by the Governor of the Attorney General and the county District Attorneys.

Renewed weakness developed in the foreign exchanges yesterday on news of the threatened breakdown of the Franco-Italian negotiations. Sterling eased 1/4 cent to $4.96 5/8 and the franc was down 3-16 point to 2.79 11-16 cents.

Chicago's relief crisis, which has closed all of the city's twenty-three stations and shortened the food allotments of 34,000 families, took another turn today as State and city officials disputed provision of funds.

The contract for alterations and the addition of two stories to the Bonwit Teller Building at 721-5 Fifth Avenue and 1-5 East-Fiftysixth Street has been awarded to William Crawford, Inc., according to Brown's Letters, Inc.

A collection of porcelain and decorative objects assembled by Mrs. Ogden Mills of New York brought [Pound]1,072 in a wellattended sale held at Christies today. A pair of Chinese rose vases with covers proved to be the most attractive item offered.

Credit men are "not upset by the present depression," which was the inevitable result of over-expansion in late 1936 and early 1937 and, barring unforeseen new developments, "we should be well on the upgrade during the Fall months," John L. Redmond of the Crompton-Richmond Company, Inc.,

His position in China little affected by the intimacy of the German-Japanese interests and the close ChinoRussian relations, the German General Alexander von Falkenhausen, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's chief foreign military adviser, continues as a trusted, active and influential figure behind the scenes of China's struggle against the Japanese.

Morris Marcus, 38 years old, of 312 Webster Avenue, Brooklyn; was found shot dead in his haberdash-. ery store at 170 Bleecker Street shortly, before noon yesterday under circumstances which led the police to believe that two, robbers committed the crime.

France gave way to Great Britain today on the last small detail of the plan to withdraw the foreign "volunteers" from Spain and reimpose international control of arms shipments to both the Loyalist and Insurgent governments.

Little items mount up to impressive sums when multiplied over and over on vast housing projects such as the Red Hook and Queensbridge developments, to be carried out by the New York City Housing Authority with the aid of Federal funds.

A demand that the city -assume the full cost of arterial highways being constructed through Queens instead of saddling part of the burden on that borough, which is only incidentally benefited by the improvements, was made-at the Board of Estimate meeting yesterday by John J. Halleran, Queens Commissioner of Borough Works, representing Borough President George U. Harvey.
Viscount Astor's Derby candidate, Pound Foolish, a son of Blanford Pennycomequick, today won the Great Northern Handicap, defeating William Woodward's Valerian Ill by a head.

This week's Federal Reserve statistics present again the ironic contrast of expanding bank reserves and declining bank credit. The excess reserves of all member banks rose $80,000,000 to $2,560,000,000, which was within $20,000,000 of the high mark reported on April 27.

President Roosevelt received an invitation from Nassau County, New York, to visit that county. during the New York World's Fair. He received from Grover Whalen a replica of the Trylon and Perisphere Buildings at the New York exposition and promised to make a preview inspection of the fair grounds and buildings as soon as possible.

Establishment of a national council, composed of representatives of business, labor agriculture and the scientific fields, to act as a permanent advisory body to the government was proposed today by Senator-Bulkley, chairman of the Committee on Manufactures.

Andrew Jackson Miller, Mayor of La Porte, 1929-34, died today after a long illness at th eage of 72. Before coming here thirty-five years ago he was in the wholesale tobacco business in Indianapolis and Richmond, Ind.

The nation's leading investment bankers called The today on both the government and follow the managements of the public utility companies to forget history and get down to work on some procedure whereby the confidence of investors in the future of the utility industry may be restored.

Saving ground on the rail all the way, Mrs. Emil Denemark's Dorothy Rock, a 6-to-5 choice, won by a length over John Hay Whitney's Upstream in the one mile of the Elks Purse today before a Suffolk Downs crowd of 13,500.

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended May 18 were announced today: LIEUTENANTS Toft, C. E., the Pontchartrain, to the Ossipee as executive officer. Porter, S. F., Academy, to the Tampa, July 1. Wendland, J. C., the Pontchartrain, to the Galatea as executive officer.
Hugh Gall, one of Canada's most famous football players in prewar years, died today of pneumonia. His age was 49.

State primaries this Spring and early Summer come so thick and fast there is serious danger of a good many Democrats in Congress running themselves out of breath. The defeat of the Reorganization Bill was followed by a rush away from Mr. Roosevelt
Heeding the plea of Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, stockholders of that company voted today to cancel the management's stock-ownership plan.

The Securities and Exchange Commission received today a request that it sponsor a WPA project in Wall Street. A delegation from the United Office and Professional Workers of America made the request. Robert Curtis, its spokesman, said approximately 10,000 brokerage workers had lost their jobs in Wall Street in the last six months.
Mr. and Mrs. Edmund J. 'Pickup of 28 Rutland Road, Brooklyn, and Westhampton Beach, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Pickup, to William Shannon Eakins, son of Mrs.

Contracts awarded this week for engineering construction continued the recent trend toward a diminution of private work and a rise in public work, as compared with last year's awards, according to the Enineering News-Record.

Chairman Madden made an able defense over the radio of the National Labor Relations Board, but his reply will hardly set at rest the principal misgivings regarding the workings of the Wagner act. When he says that eleven cases involving the board's work have been passed

Dr. Norman Bethune, Montreal surleon; Miss Jean Ewen, Vancouver, B. C., nurse, and Dr. Richard Brown, Canadian missionary and surgeon, all of them volunteer medical workers with China's Eighth Route Army, have left on a dangerous journey through Northern Shansi Province war areas to Wutaihsien, capital of the Shansi, Chahar and Hopei districts under Chinese control.

An appeal to young people of the Soviet Union to assume leadership in science and in other intellectual pursuits and to dare to smash obsolete traditions was made by Joseph Stalin Tuesday in an address to representatives of higher educational institutions at the Kremlin.

The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended May 18 were announced today: COLONEL Berry, B. S., Philadelphia, Pa., orders to Quantico revoked, about June 20 to Navy Yard, New. York, N. Y., as President, General Court Martial.

An unnamed Japanese detachment, "which was chiefly responsible for the completed occupation of Suchow Thursday noon, will make a formal entry into that city today," the Japanese official Domei News Agency reported late this morning.

Manhattan rode into undisputed possession of the leadership for the metropolitan collegiate baseball title on the wings of a three-run rally in the ninth inning that carried the Jaspers to a thrilling 8-to-7 triumph over Long Island University at Manhattan Field yesterday. The victory was the ninth in a row, the eleventh in twelve starts and the seventh in eight battles with local rivals.

Chicago and Northwestern jumped into a commanding lead in the Big Ten tennis championship tournament today by sending six and five men respectively-into the semi-finals of the six singles divisions. Rain interrupted play in the first round of the doubles.

The board of trustees of the Queensborough Public Library at a meeting last night formally accepted the triptych mural entitled "The Story of Richmond Hill," which aroused strong criticism for its modernist technique when it was completed at the Richmond Hill branch of the library at 118-14 Hillside Avenue, Richmond Hill.

At the request of William E. Collins, Special Assistant United States Attorney, Judge Mortimer W. Byers in Federal Court, Brooklyn, yesterday adjourned until Monday argument on the application of the government for the appointment of a receiver for the steamship Southern Cross of the Munson Steamship Line.
" If women were not so busy doing petty things and would fight for peace aggressively and continue to shout until world rulers heeded them, we would soon have world peace," was the message of Mrs.

I. A. Hirschmann, vice president of Saks Fifth Avenue, denounces as a "racket" the use of - "discount cards" enabling a consumer to go to a shop, showroom or warehouse to buy goods at "wholesale," in an article entitled "Only Suckers Buy Wholesale" in the June issue of The American Mercury.

Reports of excessive rains in parts of Kansas and fear of the rapid development of black rust resulted in a moderate advance in wheat futures in the early trading on the Board of Trade here today, but the bulge was used by houses with Eastern connections to sell freely.

Dr. Sinclair Smith, astrophysicist and graduate of the California Institute of Technology, died at his home here late last night after an illness of five years, which he steadfastly ignored in his scientific work. Death was due to cancer. His age was 39.

Mrs. C. Egerton Warburton, wife of a grandson of the late John Wanamaker, was treated at Bryn Mawr Hospital today for poison she mistook for a tonic she had been taking on the advice of her physician.
Edward Waldron Hicks, former State District Court judge and for many years a prominent Middlesex County Republican, died here today at his home after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

The State's public free camp sites will be opened May 28.. Special effort has been made by the Conservation Department to have the thirty. camp sites located in the Adirondack and Catskill Forest Preserve in. readiness for Memorial Day week-end.

The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, principal subsidiary of, the United States Steel Corporation, and the American Can Company have made a contract under which the former will sell and the latter will buy at least 10,500,000 base boxes of tin mill products annually until the end of 1941. The amount involved yearly is estimated to be not less than $56,500,000.

Turpentine steady, 23c; sales, 18 barrels; receipts, 648 barrels; shipments, 25 barrels; stock, 33,938 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 368; receipts, 1,859; shipments, 210; stock 105,568. Quote: B, $3.45; D. $3.65; E $3.70; F, $4.10; G, $4.35; H, I. $4.37 1/2; K. M, $4.40; N, $4.95; WG, $5.60; WW, X, $6.20.

On his own application. To take effect 12 midnight, May 24: CAPTAIN--Bernard W. Rorke, 11th Precinct, at $2,750 per annum. Appointed Feb. 7, 1903. Temporary Assignmente PATROLMEN--From 114th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, Queens, for one day, from 4 P. M., May 16:

Demand for men's wear suitings this week showed some improvement, but the amount of business booked was not large, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. Wool goods markets in general were dull.
More than 1,000 persons are expected to witness the twenty-first annual military review of the City College unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps today in the Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street

Gross assets, $10,397; net, $9,315. To Woman's Home Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcapol Church and sister-in-law, Carol S. Allen, $500 each; brother, Charles M. Allen, residuary estate. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $10,000; jointly owned property, $397. Hallam M. Richardson, attorney, 226 Willoughby Ave.

Claiming a new world's record for distance and endurance in light airplanes, Lieutenant Kenneth Kress d and Glenn Englert of Lock Haven, A Pa., landed their new-type flivverr" monoplane at the Newark Airport at 9 o'clock tonight after a round trip, non-stop flight between here and Miami, Fla.

Dr. Morris Fishbein, editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association, said tonight he was "unperturbed" about a resolution passed by the New Jersey Medidal Society seeking restriction of his writings to The Journal.

Late June or early July will bring official announcement of the trade treaty with England, according to information obtained by importers here yesterday in informal telephone talks with government officials in Washington.

The War Department released the following orders, dated May 18; COLONELS Whipple, H., Adjutant General's Department, 10 days' leave July 13. Dear, W. R., Medical Corps, Fort Belvoir, Va.; to Fort Benning, Ga, Aug. 1. Palmer, B., cavalry, Fort Knox, Ky., detailed with the organized reserves, Towson, Md., July 5.

The Boston Bees jumped over Pittsburgh into third place today by beating the Pirates 4--3, in eleven innings, to sweep the three-game series. It was the second successive overtime victory for the Bees and the sixth extra-inning game the Pirates have played in their last seven starts.

Edgehill Ave (13-3407C); W S, 169 s of 230th St, 87x87; Irene Brush to Daniel F. Mahony Jr, 780 Riverside Dr. Aldus St (10-2749), n s, 40 e of Hoe Ave, 40x100; John C. Spallone to Dry Dock Savings Institution, 742 Lexington Ave.

Marriage and Dun Pickin, two thoroughbreds from the lot consigned by the estate of the late Admiral Cary T. Grayson, brought the highest prices at a sale in the Belmont Park paddock yesterday before the races.

The Hotel Lincoln, thirty-story midtown hostelry erected ten years ago at a reported cost of nearly $11,000,000, was sold yesterday by the United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation to Mrs. Maria Kramer, wife of Max J. Kramer, builder and owner of the Hotel Edison.

Even the strictest totalitarian countries cannot prevent disagreetable information from leaking out. Copies of illegal leaflets have been brought here by travelers from Vienna, who report their wide distribution in the last few days.
The League of Music Lovers will present a concert and dance recital tonight at Town Hall. The Curtis String Quartet, Aube.Tzerke, piainst, and Martha Graham, dancer, will participate.

Ninety-one schoolboy netmen from thirty-two private and public schools will compete on the princeton courts tomorrow afternoon in the opening round of three days' play for the eighteenth annual Princeton University interscholastic tennis championship. The former two-day grind has been alleviated by scheduling the final brackets for Sunday on the near-by Pretty Brook courts.

Downs', shoes, store at 1,454 Broadway, n e cor 41st St: George A Bowman, Inc, broker. New Jersey Health Water, Inc, in 342 Madison Ave; Joseph Maslan, in 3 W 22d St; Palco Hat Co, in 47 Bond St; Herbert McLean. Purdy Management Corp, broker.

Two members of the A. Felix du Pont family of Wilmington were recuperating in the University Hospital today after undergoing operations. They were Mrs. A. Felix du Pont Sr., the former Mrs. Ann Marvel De Armond of Rehoboth Beach, Del., and Catherine du Pont, 3-yearold daughter of A. Felix du Pont

Newspapers received 61.7 of advertising expenditures in the cigarette field last year, with magazines obtaining 19.4 per cent and radio, 18.9 per cent, according to an analysis of the industry's advertising and sales by Media Records, Inc. The percentages for 1936 were 71.8, 15.6 and 12.6, radio making the largest gain chiefly as the result of Lucky Strikes' emphasis on this medium.
A sharp decline in Indian cotton quotations at Bombay exerted more pressure on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday, and the list worked off to final losses of 6 to 7 points.

Alex Dow, president of the Detroit Edison Company, addressing a meeting of the Bond Club of New York at a luncheon at the Bankers Club yesterday, said he expected there would be a "let-down" in business activity in the heavy dustries in the Summer.

An agreement on of the C future supervision and training of the Dionne quintuplets, including a provision that an architect begin immediately drafting plans for a home to house the entire Dionne family, was reached at a meeting here today of the board of guardians of the quintuplets and Oliva Dionne, their father.

Eleven of America's speed kings announced today they would roll out their race cars Saturday and attempt to qualify for what railbirds say will be the fastest 500mile Memorial Day classic ever run over the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.

Dartmouth, Cornell and Pittsburgh were singled out yesterday as the three prospective leaders of the East for the 1938 football campaign. The occasion was the annual Spring practice luncheon of the Touchdown Club held at the Midston House.
Mrs. Helen Wills Moody angrily denied rumors of a new romance today and then went out and beat Mrs. M. R. King, 6-2, 7-5, in the quarter-final round of the Surbiton tennis tournament.

Navy oarsmen, who regard rowing supremacy as their own private oyster, will have to turn back the powerful challenge of Harvard and Pennsylvania Saturday to retain their Eastern sprint title and extend the most brilliant crew record ever made by the Tars of the Severn.
The position of John L. Lewis, C. I. 0. chairman, and the unofficial participation of a New Deal Cabinet member will receive a test tomorrow in the Oregon primary election.

The elimination of high blood pressure by a surgical operation involving the' excision of one of -the kidneys, performed at the Johns Hopkins University Hospital and other institutions, was reported last week at the New York Academy of Medicine by Professor Harry Goldblatt, assistant director of the Institute of Pathology, Western Reserve University.
The new flagship of the HollandAmerica Line, the Nieuw Amsterdam, now at her Hoboken pier after her maiden voyage here, will be the setting this afternoon for a benefit flower and fashion show.

Detailed plans for the proposed East Side park and recreational areas extending fifteen blocks from Grand Street to Twelfth Street along the East River were placed before the Board of Estimate yesterday by Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan. In a letter requesting authorization, Mr. Isaacs said the park was a joint project of his office and the Park Department.
Miss Victoria Potter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Austin Potter, will be married here the afternoon of May 28 at the home of her parents to William Henry Lewis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis of Mountain

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Symington Clark of Amagansett, L. I., and Louisville, Ky., have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Jessie La Nauze Clark, to Evarts Speed Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Speed of Louisville. The wedding will take place-on June 25 in Amagansett.

The former American freighter Lockport, a nineteen-year-old vessel owned until its recent sale by the United States Maritime Commission, was towed out of the harbor yesterday bound for Germany, where it will be broken up for scrap.

A mortgage for $126,850 on 13-15 W 86th St, held by the Emigrant Bank from the Society for the Advancement of Judaism, A. T. Thompson, press, was extended to Feb 11, 1948, at 41/2 per cent. The executors of the will of Helena Necarsulmer. assigned to the Hebrew Orphan Asylum mortgages for $6,000 on 2,265 2d Ave, $8,300 on 156 E 107th St and $10,000 on 142 W 124th St.

Irrespective of politics, admirers of salient characters have an interest in the Oregon primary today. Governor Charles H. Martin, a distinguished retired major general, is a candidate for re-election. He is in his seventy-fifth year and a livelier lad doesn't breathe.
The mighty Casey of Mudville-"I never was a home-run king"--stepped from the fables of the Eager Eighties tonight to prove he couldn't hit then-and proved he can hit now.

Nineteen undergraduates have been elected to the Princeton chapter of the Sigma Xi Society, national honorary scientific group, it was announced today by Professor Luther P. Eisenhart, dean of the graduate school and president of the Princeton chapter.

Nation-wide bargains, called to the attention of the housewife by the Federal Government, are encouraging. Supplies of most foods are bigger and better--and cheaper--than they have been for several years.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

Mrs. Frances S. Ryan, only woman ward leader in the T. J. Pendergast Democratic organization, was sentenced today to three years imprisonment for vote fraud conspiracy, but the term was specified to be served concurrently with a threeyear term given for a previous conviction.

A new contract with All America Cables, Inc., published in El Universo today, provides for the payment in back taxes of $100,000 in three installments, $40,000 now, $36,000 in six months and the balance within a year.

About fifty bandits who eleven days ago sacked the town of Tzio, about five hours by automobile from Morelia, capital of President Lazaro Cardenas's home State of Michoacan, are still holding Federal troops at bay, War Department sources revealed today.

The Tennessee Valley Authority received yesterday the "go ahead" signal in its first major negotiation to buy private utility companies in the Tennessee Valley area when officials of the National Power and Light Company, a subsidiary of the Electric Bond and Share Company,
Miss Mary Armstrong, daughter of Mrs. N. S. Wyckoff Vanderhoef of 1192 Park Avenue and of Daniel W. Armstrong, also of this city, has completed plans for her marriage to Robert Amory Jr.,- son of Mr.

Three New York Stock Exchange memberships were transferred yesterday. That of Charles F. Nichols went to Frank A?? Hardy, that of J. Paul Lynch to Edward Rose of Shufro, Rose Co. and that of W. T. Coleman Carpenter to John M. Goebbels of Colgate Hoyt Co.

Arriving buyers may register in this column by telephoning LAckawanna 4-1000. RETAIL ATLANTA--Rich's, Inc. W. Fritz, mdse. mgr., ready-to-wear; Mrs. R. Fritz, junior, children's wear, corsets, house dresses, aprons, kimonos: Mrs. B. Patillo, basement, ready-to-wear; Miss A. M. Gallagher, dresses; 128 W. 31st (Kirby, Block Co.).

Representative Vinson, chairman of the House Naval Affairs Committee, cautioned the Navy Department today to see that there was no "politics". in building up the force provided in a bill for reorganization of the Naval Reserve, which is now before the committee.

Arthur Garfield Hays, counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union, made a brief impromptu speech on a public street here tonight without a permit without being arrested, deported, or interfered with in any way.
Henry L. Croll, retired vice president of the importing firm of A. Steinhardt Brother, died yesterday at his home, 255 West Eighty-eighth Street, after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

Saul Cohn, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and of the City Stores Company, Inc., of New York, told the Pennsylvania Retailers Association tonight that the funds made available to the Department of Commerce for fostering foreign and domestic commerce are inadequate.

With the Roosevelt Administration pressing for passage of its new $4,000,000,000 spending and lending program, political obesrvers are turning their,attention to a question which has been asked repeatedly since the New Deal embarked on its first program of spending for relief and recovery:

Builders planning an apartment house near Rockefeller Center added yesterday to the site by purchasing from John D. Rockefeller Jr. the five-story house on a lot 22.6 by 100.5 feet at 29 West Fifty-fourth Street.

E. H. Driggs Jr., former metropolitan amateur champion and now president of the Metropolitan Golf Association, demonstrated that officialdom is not the last stronghold of former stars as he led a field of 149 players today in the annual invitation tournament of the Garden City Golf Club.

Announcement has been made here by Mrs. James Alan MacLeod of Pasadena, Calif., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Janet Alan MacLeod of this city, to Carl Thiel Hoffman of Waterbury, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. James Adam Hoffman of Douglaston, L. I.

So much of paragraph 1, Special Orders 65, dated March 19, 1938, as continues Capt. Richard L. Bohannon, Med.-Res., on active duty with the CCC until Oct. 21, 1938, is amended so as to continue him on active duty until May 13, 1938. Capt. Richard L. Bohannon, Med.-Res., now on active duty at the Station Hospital, Fort Jay, N. Y., is relieved from further active duty with the CCC and will proceed to his home,
Captain Francis Ouimet and his Walker Cup team, all hale and hearty, arrived on the bleak Ayrshire coast this morning after a comfortable 400-mile night journey northward from London.
Two apartment houses in the Bronx, two - small dwellings in Queens, one in Richmond and one in Nassau County are among the properties reported sold by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Reports here yesterday had it that sale of United Shipyards, Inc., to the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation is as good as assured, and that ownership of the United's four plants in New York Harbor would be transferred next Wednesday afternoon following a meeting of stockholders at 11 Broadway.
The House passed today the Flood Control Bill authorizing the expenditure of $375,000,000 over a five-year period for flood control projects in twenty-three States and Alaska.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 17: COMMANDERS Clarke, P. A., Portsmouth. N. H., to continue treatment at Naval Hospital, and when discharged ordered home, relieved all active duty: orders Feb. 28 revoked. Tartre. J. A., Dental Corps, the Holland, to the Melville.
The Hamburg-American liner Columbus will arrive this morning from Germany. Passengers are the Right Rev. James de Wolfe Perry, Bishop of Rhode Island; William T. Hunter, O. B. Blanke Jr., Mrs. G. T.

William A. Wylie, former furniture manufacturer and sales representative, died on Wednesday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. E. Stanley Floor of 244 West Marshall Street, West Chester, Pa., according to word received here last night. Mr. Wylie, who had been ill several months, was 74 years old.

In opposing what they termed anti- wou social anti-moral and anti-religious propaganda, speakers at the opening session of the Catholic Press Association's three-day convention here today discussed means of not spreading propaganda of their own to counteract it.

BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions EXCELLENT GOODY SHOP SUPPLY CORP., 136 5th Ave.--Voluntary proceeding under section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $96,656 and assets of $62.334.
The number of shares of stock sold in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended May 14 exceeded the number purchased by 9,317, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Kingvulture, veteran hunter owned by Miss Patricia du Pont, added another blue ribbon to his laurels at the Wilmington horse show today. The large chestnut gelding outclassed a group of middleweight and heavyweight hunters on the opening day of the three-day show on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Norman P. Rood, Meadows on the Brandywine.

Spring blizzards in mountain areas and heavy rains in the lower country swept Montana today, breaking communication lines between many cities and halting air travel. Heavy snows on mountain passes broke down most telephone and telegraph lines into Helena and Great Falls.
Colonel Girard Sturtevant, 65, U. S. A., retired, Professor of Foreign Languages at the Brown Military Academy, Pacific Beach, since 1929, was found dead in bed at his home today by his wife.

Just how the stars will look during the ocean race from Newport to Bermuda starting on June 20 will be shown to the navigators in the contest at the Hayden Planetarium on Tuesday night. That was announced last night at the dinner of the Corinthians in the Yale Club.

Carlton L. Doncourt, teacher of manual training in the New York City schools for many years, died last night at the Flushing Hospital, Queens, after a long illness. He resided at 33-58 168th Street, Flushing.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The communication printed in THE TIMES of May 16 from Charles Abrams, and commented upon in your editorial of the same date, contains a number of statements and inferences which are confusing if not inaccurate.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith acted as chairman last night of a dinner held at the Hotel Astor in honor of Charles S. Salomon, who has served thirty-five years as a reporter for The New York Tribune and The New York Herald Tribune. About 100 persons were present, many of them old-time newspaper men and theatrical figures.

George Rowland Munroe, counsel for the New Jersey Anti-Saloon League for more than twenty-five years, died yesterday at the Marcus L. Ward Home here after more than a year's illness. His age was 68. Mr. Munroe resided for many H years in Newark and later at Hackettstown, N. J., entering the Ward Home in August. 1936.

From the old red Cornell boat house, whose modernization has failed to destroy its tradition of ancient rowing history, the crews of three universities went out today in what all hope will be final preparations for this year's renewal of the Carnegie Cup.

A decrease of $265,000 in deposits of chartered banks was shown today in the statement of the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday. Dominion Government deposits, on the other hand, increased by $709,000.

A son, the first great-grandchild of J. P. Morgan, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Skinner Clark of 5,000 Whitney Avenue, Mount Carmel, Conn., Wednesday in the New Haven Hospital, it became known here yesterday.

" Happy Returns," a revue with which C. B. Cochran marked his re-entry into the London theatre at the Adelphi tonight, evoked pleasant memories. There were extracts from previous Cochran successes and Beatrice Lillie, the star of the show, presented material 'she already had made famous. This combined to present playgoers with an opportunity to see something they had missed or wanted to recapture.

The Indians put on their heaviest attack of the season against the Senators today for three home runs, a triple, four doubles and a 15-to-3 victory, wich put them in first place in the American League.
The Boston Maine Transportation Company has failed to establish the right to a certificate as a common carrier or a permit as a contract carrier by motor vehicle, with certain exceptions,
Martin Vogel, Assistant Treasurer of the United States during the Wilson Administrations, died yesterday afternoon at his apartment in the Savoy-Plaza Hotel. He had was 60.

For the second time within six months, Vincent Forte, 20 years old, of 281 Stone Avenue, Brooklyn,' was convicted of first-degree murder in the hold-up slaying of Berle Wolkowitz, 64-year-old grocer, when a bue ribbon jury in Kings County Court, after eight hours'

After two days of debate the general council of the International Federation of Trade Unions tonight decided by a vote of 16 to 4 to reject the conditions laid down by Russian trade unions for affiliation with the federation.

Announcement has been made to friends here by Colonel and Mrs. Clyde Boyd Crusan of Jenkintown, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Helen Crusan, to Roy Bryan Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Heide Davis of Wilmington, N. C.

The exhibition of American Art, 1609-1938, assembled by the Museum of Modern Art is to open on May 24 in the Jeu de Paume in to Paris. It will include a section devoted to the development of American photography.

The Texas Oil Company reported to the United States Consulate that fourteen Chinese crewmen were sent to the hospital today with injuries suffered at the hands of a Japanese Navy party which boarded and searched a launch flying the American flag.

John Linen of the Chase National Bank heads an eight-man golf team which will represent the Municipal Bond Club of New York against a team representing the municipal bond men in the Twin Cities and St. Louis at the annual field day of the New York club today at the Lakeville Club, Great Neck, L. I.
Mr. and Mrs. Paul Forrester gave a birthday supper party last night at the Stork Club in honor of her daughter, Miss Martha Stephenson. Among the guests were Mr. and Mrs. Orson D. Munn, Mr. and Mrs.

Secretary Morgenthau gave notice today that bids would be received by Federal Reserve Banks or their branches up to 2 P. M. (Eastern standard time), on Monday on $50,000,000 of ninety-one-day Treasury bills, the customary weekly issue.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lawrence Bogert of 30 East Seventy-first Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cardine Elizabeth Bogert, to Thomas Hildt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hildt of Baltimore and Black Point, Conn.

The cultural program of the Junior Leagues of America and its contribution through hundreds of volunteers to the 148 communities in which there are leagues were stressed today by Miss Helen T. Findlay of New York, arts secretary, at a session of the annual conference devoted to the arts.

Periodic publication of the names of persons receiving relief in each New Jersey municipality, coupled with the amounts received, was urged on the Legislature today by Donald R. Stevens, president of the New Jersey Taxpayers Association, who said the publicity would eliminate "chiselers."

John Woodruff, Pitt's 800-meter Olympic champion, yesterday was formally entered in three events for the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championships at Randalls Island Stadium on June 3 and 4.

The trustees of Bronx Certificated Mortgages, First Series, sold the two five-story apartments at 1,56266 Hoe Avenue, the Bronx, to Pelemus Realty Corporation for cash above a firs t mortgage of $49,000, through J. J. Boneparth, Inc., broker.

William H. Donner, whose daughter divorced President Roosevelt's son, Elliott, asked the Board of Tax Appeals today to review a $44,749 Treasury tax assessment on his 1934 income. Gwing his residence as Montreaux, 'Switzerland, Mr.
Germany proper and German Austria will not be represented officially or by groups of pilgrims at the Budapest Eucharistic Congress. The government here strongly opposes attendance.

Supplies of most classes were below normal. Trading in traefer meats in a general way was fairly dependable and the market ruled mostly steady to slightly higher. As usual on Thursday, trading in kosher meats was limited largely to lamb, which was higher. Quotations on other kosher meats are nominally steady. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:
President Roosevelt today told Grover Whalen, director of the New York World's Fair, that he would take advantage of the earliest opportunity to inspect the fair grounds and buildings.

Mrs. J. Albert Lane of Flushing, Queens, has announced the marriage of her daughter, Miss Janet Lane, to Howard Chappel Cole of this city, on Wednesday at Keene, N. H. Mr. and Mrs. Cole will reside in New York.

Winston Guest led his Whites to an 8to-5 triumph over Tommy HiLchcock's Blue team in a Meadow Brook Club polo match today. Guest's team-mates comprised J. P. Grace Jr., J. T. Mather and J. C. Rathborne. Grace, at No. 1, led in the scoring with five goals, while each of the other players on the team bagged one apiece.

The navy is rushing work on -the world's most modern model testing plant in preparation for building a billion dollars' worth of warships. Officials said today that they'expected the new plant at Carderock, Md., to be ready, May 1, 1939,
Lumber production last week increased more than seasonally and the adjusted index advanced to 61.0 from 58.5. The figure was 92.0 for the week ended May 15, 1937.
The parents of two boys, sentenced yesterday to a horsewhipping at the hands of their fathers for stealing, condemned the court order today as "uncivilized" and declined to enforce it.
President Roosevelt assured Senator Tru.man of Missouri of his support for proposed legislation requiring automobile drivers to have licenses recognized by the Federal Government.

YELLOW JACK, an adaptation of the Sidney Howard play written in collaboration with Paul de Kruif; screen play by Edward Chodorov; musical score by Dr. William Axt; directed by George B. Seitz; produced by Jack Cummings for MetroGoldwyn-Mayer. At the Capitol.

Jamaica High, defending city P. S. A. L. champion, suffered its first defeat in seven games, one of which ended in a tie, in Section B of the Queens group when it bowed to Far Rockaway, 5--0, on the latter's diamond yesterday.

Estate, more than $10,000. To Norman M. Meyer, 277 West End Ave., $5,000: Theodore B. Baum, 175 W. 93d St.; Robert, Jack A. and Arthur C. Baum, all of 327 Mulry Lane, Lawrence, L. I.; Jules J. and Charles S. Baum, both of 365 West End Ave.; Grace W., Carol W. and Patsy A. Korn, all of 525 West End Ave.: Elliot A.

Commemorating the first air-mail flight ever made in this country--al three-mile trip between bardenCity and Mineola made Sept. 23, 1911-a modern plane lifted its wheels from the Garden City golf course yesterday and flew over the original route. to Roosevelt Field as part of the celebration of National Air Mail Week.

On the morning of Feb. 15 the court officer in the Municipal Court stepped to the microphone in the large room where prospective jurors congregate and called out the names of six men who on the previous day had been selected by counsel for both sides in a case.

The marriage of Miss Doris Baumann Wechsler, daughter of Ralph Victor Wechsler and the late Mrs. Wechsler, to Jesse Freidin, son of Mrs. Sidney J. Freidin of New York and Miami and the late Mr. Freidin,
Commercial and industrial interests here have presented a protest to President Fe erico Laredo Bru against the proposed commercial treaty with Mexico.

Evidently the Spring rush to the Broadhead is almost over, for three of us shared several miles of the water today. But the trout are still there. Not as many as there were three weeks ago, but more than enough to keep the anglers busy.

William Henry Milnor, retired New York real estate operator and an authority on title contracts, died today at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Burton E. Hamilton of Chestnut Hill, Mass., following a six weeks' illness. Mr. Milnor, who lived with his son and daughter-inlaw, Mr. and Mrs. Bennett Milnor of this city, had been visiting his daughter. His age was 84.
Continuance of the present fairtrade laws wlil "seriously impair the effectiveness of the government in dealing with the monopoly problem," Q. Forrest Walker, economist for R. H. Macy Co., Inc.,

Amid the strain that has developed between Paris and Rome, Premier Daladier proclaimed yesterday that in any circumstances France was "fully capable of assuring the inviolability of her frontiers and her empire by herself." In the negotiations with Italy the French attitude is one of seeking to adjust differences aside from the Spanish issue. [Page 1.]

Charging that his office had been "gone over" twice in the last few months, Senator Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, offered a resolution today providing that the Senate would pay a $1,000 reward for any information incriminating any one in any breaking and entering into or the removing of any material in a Senator's office or storeroom.

Philanthropic disbursements of $207,899 were made last year through the New York Community Trust, according to the annual report, published yesterday. This exceeded the disbursements of $200,794 in 1936, Ralph Hayes, executive director, said,: and it marked the twelfth time in thirteen years that appropriations surpassed the' volume of those of any prior annual period.
" Amelia Earhart Week," May 22 to 28, designed to familiarize the public with the objectives of the Amelia Earhart Foundation, was commended today by Secretary Roper. He said:

The indoor boxing season at Madison Square Garden will come to a close tonight when Solly Krieger of Brooklyn meets Glen Lee of Nebraska in the feature ten-round bout under the direction of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club.

Walt Anderson, chairman of the American Friends of the Mexican People, which has offices at 52 West Eighth Street, made public yesterday a letter from President Lazaro Cardeaas explaining the seizure of British and American oil companies' properties.
De Coursey Fales, a partner in Cadwalader, Wickersham Taft, has been elected a director of the Fulton Trust Company of New York.

A warning that when democracy fails to build individual character, a double burden falls on the church and churchsupported institutions, was given by Alf M. Landon, Republican candidate for President in 1936, at "Boston University Night" at the New England Methodist Conference in Lynn tonight.
Mrs. Alice Johnson Perrie, widow of Celsus Price Perrie, who was president, 1921-30, of James McCreery Co., New York department store, died here today at her home at the age of 62.

The unveiling of James Earle Fraser's heroic statue of Franklin in the Memorial Room of the Franklin Institute on Benjamin Franklin Parkway, Philadelphia, is made the occasion of a threeday celebration in which the progress of science is reviewed by eminent authorities.

Miss Althea Crow, daughter of Mrs. Ralph L. Crow of Pine Island, this place, was married this afternoon to Robert E. Reybine, son of Mrs. Alpheus Reybine of New Rochelle, at the Crow home here. The Rev. R.

Cincinnati at New York--Hollingsworth (2-0) vs. Schumacher (2-2). Pittsburgh at Brooklyn-Lucas (2-0) vs. Mungo (1-3). St. Louis at Boston-Davis (3-1) vs. MacFayden (2-1). Chicago at Philadelphia-Carleton (3-2) vs. LaMaster (0-3)..

The Dress Returns Control Bureau this year is handling three times as many merchandise returns as last year, and manufacturers are "voluntarily protesting" ten times as many returns as "unjustified," Louis Rubin, chairman of the bureau, declared last night at the annual meeting of Popular Priced Dress Manufacturers Group at the Hotel. Governor Clinton.

Mrs. Fannie E. Graham, for many years active in charities and women's organizations in this community, died here this morning at her home after an illness of several months. She was in her fortyeighth year.

Harold B. Taking vain Butler, director of the International Labor Office, tonight predicted an early business recovery in the United States but Warned that war is blocking world social progress and threatens to precipitate a "total collapse."

The remarkably consistent Sweet Patrice, who first impressed at Hialeah, scored her most important victory yesterday at Belmont Park when she captured the forty-first running of the Bouquet Claiming Stakes.

Raindrenched government and Insurgent troops sparred for positions today in two mountain ranges in Eastern Spain. In the Sierra de Corbalan, ten miles northeast of Teruel, Insurgents attempted to straighten their eastern front to the sea but found the way blocked by solidly entrenched government forces.

Rain, so they say, makes the flowers beautiful and when it rained yesterday the Dodgers suddenly blossomed out in a bouquet of base hits just in time to turn back the Cardinals at Ebbets Field, 8 to 4.

During the week ended May 18, member bank reserve balances increased $62,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves rose from a decrease of $78,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and increases of $12,000,000 in gold stock and $2,000,000 in Treasury currency, offset in part by increases of $6,000,000 in money in circulation, $11,000,000 in Treasury cash and $12,000,000 in nonmember deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

Donald Budge and Gene Mako, Wimbledon champions and United States Davis Cup doubles team, went through a spirited workout at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills yesterday preparatory to leaving on Wednesday for their European invasion.

The grand award, donated by Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx, was won by a Chicago collector, Dr. Clarence Hennan, for his proofs, essays and Brazilian Dom Pedro covers at the second annual National Philatelic Exhibition of the Bronx County Stamp Club, Inc., at the Concourse Plaza yesterday.

The government rested its case yesterday against Albert Marinelli, former County Clerk of New York County and Democratic leader of the Second Assembly District in Manhattan. Marinelli is on trial in Federal court, Brooklyn, on a charge of harboring Charles Falci while the latter was a fugitive from justice on a Federal indictment accusing him of election fraud.

Henry Bernstein, playwright, and Edouard Bourdet, managing director of the Comedie Frangaise, will fight a duel with swords tomorrow morning. This was the decision reached at a conference between their seconds

The Manhattan Paste and Glue Company, which plans to consolidate its Manhattan and New Jersey plants in an expansion program, has purchased a large industrial property in Brooklyn for the purpose, it was announced yesterday.

Twenty years ago last Sunday the Government opened an experimental air mail service between Washington and Newark. On the anniversary the first two pilots of that service, James C. Edgerton and George L. Boyle, who had fought wind and weather in open
The most typical senior at Wellesley, according to results of a poll just published in the Senior Year Book, is Miss Mary Bruce Taylor of Montclair, N. J.

Addressing army officers today at Villa Militar, President Getulio Vargas pleaded. for a united Brazil, immune to the threats of "powerful and audacious" powers against weak and divided nations. "Bad citizens and bad soldiers," he warned, "are giving the impression abroad that Brazil cannot govern herself."

Thompson St, 67, 25x100: Emigrant Bank to 67 Thompson St Realty Corp, Isidore Koten, president, 522 5th Ave ($20.50); buyer giving back two mtgs, a p m for $20,432, a building loan for $16,500, both due on demand. Broadway, 1,679, 25.1x15: Robert N. Golding to Antoinette M. Golding, 220 W 42d St, care Townley U. Carter (quitclaim dated last March 24).

James A. Lynch, an employee of The Newark Evening News for fifty-three years and exchange editor for the last fifteen years, died today of a heart attack at his home here. He was 68 years old and the oldest employee of the publication in point of service.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling: Gold coin and bullion...decreased [pound]32,000 Reserve in banking dept.,

William J. Bell, at 10 Tunstall Rd, Scarsdale, from George C. Buchtenkirk; Philip W. Sawn, at 5 DuPont .Rd, in Gedney Farms, White Plains from Dr. Ralph Weiler; Raymond R. Beatty Management, Inc, brokers.

Konrad Henlein, who specializes in surprise journeys, caused a new sensation. tonight. by, leaving for Austria on the eve of an invitation from Premier Milan Hodza to consider a draft of Czechoslovakia's new nationalities statute.

The Magistrates' Courts will pay the costs of their operation this year, for the first time in their history, and probably make a substantial contribution to the treasury, Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., Chief City Magistrate, said at a meeting of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club last night.

The Interstate Commerce Commission's proceeding titled "reduced pipe line rates and gathering charges" was set down today for further hearing on Sept. 14 at the offices here before Commissioner Aitchison.

A bill permitting foreign service officers who may be promoted to be Ambassadors or Ministers to. retain their career service status was offered in the House today by Representative Bacon, Republican of New York.

A town house on Lenox Hill passed yesterday to new control when Harry Payne Bingham sold his former residence at 12 East Seventy-third Street. It has been purchased for occupancy by a client of Pease Elliman, Inc.

Total sales of skins by the members of the American Fur Merchants Association in April were $1,703,332, compared with $5,390,300 in the same month last year, a decline of 66.9 per cent, according to the report issued yesterday by the organization.

Reporting member banks of the t Federal Reserve in New York City had a drop of $132,000,000 in their loans and investments for the week ended on Wednesday, according to their condition statement published yesterday.

Preparations on Fall lines of women's apparel will be later than usual this year owing to the desire of producers to obtain further action on Summer merchandise and to obtain a better basis for gauging a possible Fall upturn. Smaller interest in the August coat events was also cited yesterday as a factor.

THE DARK CAVALIER, by Virginia Rath. (Crime Club, $2.) A mystery novel. EAGLE FORGOTTEN: THE LIFE OF JOHN PETER ALTGELD, by Harry Barnard. (Bobbs-Merrill, $4.) A biography of the former Governor of Illinois.

The marriage of Miss Helen Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Cohen of this city, to Hugh Grant Straus Jr. of New York and Oakland, Calif., took place here today at the home of the bride's parents. Rabbi Joel S. Geffin of Troy performed the ceremony.

The importance of a sweeping Democratic victory in New York next November, from the national as well as the State viewpoint, was stressed last night by Postmaster General James A. Farley, State Attorney General John J. Bennett and other speakers at a rally of the Affiliated Young Democrats, Inc., at the Park Central Hotel, on the eve of its second biennial convention.

A distinguished foreign visitor to Spain long ago said, "Africa begins at the Pyrenees." A diplomat long resident in the East, as well as in Spain, said to the writer a few days ago, "Spain is half Oriental." The Spanish say the same.

The philosophy of Benjamin Franklin was recommended to leaders of affairs tonight by Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, as the only effective antidote for moral decadence, the present ominous symptoms of which are a greater threat to democracy than external enemies."

Retirement of Horace S. Tuthill as vice president of Sheffield Farms Company, Inc., was announced yesterday by Leroy A. Van Bomel, president. Mr. Tuthill, who has completed fifty years in the milk industry in New York City, will continue to be a member of the boards of Sheffield Farms Company and National Dairy Products Corporation.
The general level of wholesale prices declined slightly during the week ended on May 14, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
The largest wool dealers in the country drew sharp criticism today before a special Senate investigating committee for giving "evasive and misleading" replies concerning their marketing practices.

A ruling in the first case in this State involving the clearance of merchandise by a retailer under the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Law was handed down yesterday in the State Supreme Court by Justice William T. Collins.

The cornerstone of the Palestine Pavilion at the 1939 World's Fair was dedicated yesterday afternoon in the presence of more than 1,500 at ceremonies at which Mayor La Guardia spoke and Dr. Thomas Mann, winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1929, delivered the dedicatory address.
