Miss Clara Frances Cole of Newnan and William Mallard, son of Mrs. James Mallard of New York and Atlanta, were married here today. They left tonight for New York City, where they will sail Saturday for Bermuda. Later they will live in New York.

The Giants' spectacular drive, which for a time threatened to leave seven other National League clubs wondering what happened to their 1938 pennant, came to a dead stop yesterday when; under cover of a leaden sky, Bill Lee,
Revision of the rating method now, used to measure the educational ability of New York City's 40,000 teachers and substitutes was announced yesterday by the Board of Superintendents.

A letter read into evidence at a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing today indicated that early in 1926 counsel for two units of the so-called "Founders group" of investment companies advised against short selling of securities, speculation and commingling of cash and securities.

With one man still to be chosen to sit upon the jury which will try twenty-one Harlan County coal companies and forty-five individuals on charges of conspiring to deny the mine workers the right to organize and bargain collectively, defense attorneys requested Federal Judge H. church Ford today to transfer the case to Lexington as soon as the jury is completed.
Many members of the New York Chapter of Kenwood Alumnae and their friends have taken tables for the flower and fashion show to be given tomorrow during the luncheon hour at Chatham Walk.

The Department of Justice may or may not be able to restore democratic government in Jersey City by invoking a sixty-eight-year-old statute enacted during the carpetbag days in the South after the Civil War. But there is a more direct course which may be followed jointly or separately by the head

The "unfair and unwise" methods used by Germany, Austria, and Poland in dealing with Jewish populations, and any efforts -to use sim ilar methods in this country, were condemned yesterday in- resolutions adopted at the third day's sessions of the New York East Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church held in Hanson Place Central Church,
Yesterday's statement of the twelve-Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date.

Great slabs of beef, lamb, mutton and ham were strewn: about the dignified Council chamber in- City Hall yesterday as organized butchers strove to convince members of the Council's General Welfare Committee that the proposed bill 'for grading of meats according to United States Government standards and the licensing of butcher shops would benefit neither the retailer nor the customer.

When Luise Rainer completes the current "The Great Waltz" she will be starred in "Dramatic School," which was purchased today by MGM from John Szekely and Zol- M tan Egyed. Mervyn Leroy will produce. The film will precede "Mr. te Coronado," in which she will be pl featured with Spencer Tracy.

A female baby giant panda arrived by plane from Chengtu today and it will leave for the United States Saturday on the liner President Cleveland in charge of Roy C. Spooner, American tutor at West China Union University.

Charles Naginski of this city was announced last night as winner of the annual Rome Prize in musical composition as the result of competition -held under the auspices of the American Academy in Rome. The announcement was made by Deems Taylor, trustee of the academy and chairman of the award jury, over a nation-wide broadcast of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

" Streamlining" insurance policies as the best and most immediate public relations step that could be taken by the field was urged yesterday by Henry C. Flower Jr., vice president of the J. Walter Thompson Company, speaking at the Spring meeting of the Insurance Advertising Conference at the Hotel Roosevelt.
At the meeting of the Bronx Taxpayers' Association at the Bronx County Building tonight, Frank G. Arnold, president of the Nebraska Federation of County Taxpayers' Leagues, will be the speaker.

Walt Disney has purchased the rights to the "Alice in Wonderland" books from the MacMillan Company, Lewis Carroll's publishers, for a film cartoon, according to The Daily Telegraph. The purchase, it is said, includes the right to reproduce Tenniel's famous illustrations on the screen.

Simon W. Gerson, Communist aide to Borough President Stanley M. isaacs, testified yesterday that he had no knowledge, whatsoever of the alteration of his name in Municipal Court records in a rent case in which he was involved, an alteration which it has been stated was made to "save him adverse publicity."

A rainstorm that came on the installment plan stopped the Yankees again today and for the second time washed out a contest in the scheduled three game series. Accompanied by high winds, a drenching downpour came at noon after some of the athletes had gone to Sportsman's Park.

Gloucestershire and Surrey recorded victories in English County cricket championship matches concluded today-a day ahead of schedule. The western county defeated Kent by 169 runs and Surrey edged out Derbyshire by 68 runs.

Sixty-nine seniors and juniors in Columbia College have won King's Crowns, tokens of recognition for non-athletic extra-curricular activities, it was announced yesterday by the King's Crown advisory committee of the college. These awards bring the number of recipients for this academic year to 177.

West Point and Saint Cyr, the respective military academies of the United States and France, will be linked by short-wave radio tomorrow afternoon for a half hour during an exchange of greetings and comments between the commanders and cadets of the two institutions.
A bill introduced in the Lbuisiana Legislature today seeks appropriation of $50,000 for construction of a memorial monument over the grave of Huey Long in the shadowof the skyscraper Capitol.

The directors of the Consolidated Coppermines- Corporation have extended the contract with the American Metal Company, Ltd., for the refining of blister copper produced by Coppermines until Dec. 31, 1943, according to a letter being sent to stockholders by Boudinot Atterbury, new president of Coppermines.

George Gill set the Athletics down with six scattered hits today as the Tigers slugged their way to a 6-2 victory in the series opener. The Tigers collected eight safeties off Lynn Nelson, but six went for extra bases.
Mrs. Ernest Frederick Eidlitz gave a tea yesterday at her home, 920 Fifth Avenue, for the directors of the new National Association of Day Nurseries after their first board meeting.

Three men, held here today in $25,000 bail each on counterfeiting charges, were described by James J. Moloney, chief United States'Secret Service agent in New Jersey, as being members of the largest counterfeiting ring in the United States.

Unions affiliated with the New York joint -board of the Amalgamated Clothingl Workers of America have distributed nearly $500,000 in unemployment benefits to their members in the last five months, Louis Hollander, City Councilman, manager of the joint board, reported yesterday.
A dividend of $100 a share was voted yesterday by the Group No. 1 Oil Corporation. A year ago $50 was disbursed to stockholders.

Over the beautiful Sleepy Hollow golf course within sight of the Hudson River, a field of eighty-two women players today was led home by Mrs. James Robbins of Lawrence Farms, who posted a fine score of 43, 41-84 to win low gross honors in the women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association one-day tourney.

A system of collusive bidding and boycotting in the electrical trades by union officials who dominated the contractors and equipment manufacturers was charged yesterday against Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

Dr. Samuel S. Edmands, director of the School of Science and Technology of Pratt Institute; and Dr. August J. Raggi of 130 West Eleventh Street, a physician, were badly injured at 6 o'clock last -evening when a car in which they were riding, driven by a third-man, crashed into an electric light pole on' the Henry Hudson Parkway.

E. L. Oliver, executive vice president of Labor's Non-Partisan League, told the United Office and Professional Workers Convention today that despite Thomas Kennedy's defeat in the Pennsylvania Democratic Gubernatorial primary labor had made "striking progress."

The Lake Superior Iron Ore Association reported today there were only sixty-four furnaces in blast on April 30, the smallest number in the records of the association. During the month seven furnaces were blown

Judge Robert V. Kinkead of the Court of Common Pleas today postpondd sentence of John R. Longo until June 1, after Vito Marcantonio of New York, defense counsel, charged that members of the jury that convicted Longo had "planted" themselves on the jury to "frame" the defendant.

The standard railway unions will resort to a nation-wide strike if the carriers' managements insist on putting into effect a proposed 15 per cent wage reduction, the Railway Labor Executives Association announced today.

The Greater New York Fund has received $2,178,535 in its campaign for $10,000,000 to aid the finances of the city's private charities, it was announced yesterday at the second report luncheon of workers in the drive at the Hotel Commodore.

Mayor La Guardia intimated that he would not be a candidate to succeed himself in 1941, in a speech yesterday, welcoming delegates of the State Federation of Business and Professional Women to their convention at the Hotel Biltmore.

A Coroner's jury held, today that the crash of an $80,000 airliner in the Saugus Hills, in which nine persons were killed, was "accidental and due to faulty judgment on the part of both the pilot and co-pilot." The verdict said:

Business leases reported yesterday were featured by contracts for retail store space. A store adjoining the entrance in the Paramount Theatre Building in Times Square, between Forty-third and Forty-fourth Streets, was taken by Samuel Diamond and others for a jewelry shop. George A. Bowman, Inc., and William A. White Sons arranged the deal.

Member trading in round lots for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on April 23 rose to 23.13 per cent of total volume compared with 21.64 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

The Official ten Gazette announced today the confiscation of the funds of the Canisius Verein, a large Rhineland Catholic youth society, under the decree for the confiscation of Communist property and the funds of organizations hostile to the State.
C. J. M. Welter, Minister of Colonies, closing the upper house debate on the colonial budget, said that more than ever the best defense policy for the colonies is a humane and just administration.

The mutualization of the Charles F. Noyes Company, under which employes of the realty firm will hold most of the common stock and a larger part of the preferred shares, became effective yesterday at special meetings of the stockholders and directors.
Germany's rebuilt Davis Cup tennis team gained a 2-0- lead today over Norway in their second round European Zone series.

The fourteenth annual Westchester Music Festival, which began with a junior concert last Friday night, was continued tonight at the County Center here with a program by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conducting.

Mr. and Mrs. William H. Coolidge of this place and Manchester have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Coolidge, to F. Burnham Chapman, son of Mrs. George McMurtrie Godley of Greenwich, Conn., and the late F. Burnham Chapman of Rye, N. Y.
The Cubs, with a total of 22 hits off three pitchers, came out on top of the Phillies, 16 to 7, today in a wildslugging ball game.
April, ordinarily a month that witnesses a seasonal increase of some 400,000 employes in non-agricultural employment, saw an increase of only 70,000, according to Secretary

The Trotskyites and the Stalinites are engaged in a needless quarrel over the most effective, methods to bring about the world revolution. It is here, quite without reference to their theories and or conformity to any preconceived plan or pattern.
London was uneasy last night over Czechoslovakia as well as over the Franco-Italian situation. Reports of German troop movements toward the Czechoslovak border caused a diplomatic inquiry at Berlin.

Qualifying trials were run off In ten events today without a record being-approached but performances strengthened the opinion Louisiana State would experience little trouble winning the Southeastern Conference. track championship for the fifth time in the last six years.
Spanish Insurgent forces pushed their lines forward today at three strategic points on their front from Teruel about seventy miles eastward to the sea.

George D. Arthur Jr., in 310 E 75th St; Dr. Delavan H. Holman, in 36 E 61st St; Anne Keegan, in 400 E 50th St; Jane Waldheim, in 30 E 68th St: Mary A. Walsh, in 440 W 34th St; Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., broker.

The dueling dramatists, Edouard Bourdet and Henry Bernstein, fought for four minutes at swords' points today and left the field of honor angrier than ever. M. Bernstein stabbed M. Bourdet, director of the State-owned Comedie Francaise, in the right arm with the needle-sharp point of his epee, but the injury was slight.
120th St, 435 E, 25x101; Jacob Gundlich to Anna, his wife, 2,875 Heath Ave, Bronx (quitclaim). Fort Washington Ave, 120x107.2, William Roseman to Regort Realty Corp, 27 E 22d St; mtg $238.000.

The Carnation Gold.Mining Company and seven of its officers and salesmen are named in a fourteencount indictment unsealed yesterday in Federal Court. Two of the defendants are Robert J. Jefferson, president of the company, who lives at 532

Commencement exercises for New York City high school students will be held the week after: the schools are officially closed. Educational officials said that this unusual situation was caused by the early closing..
Removal of the old Postoffice Building on lower Broadway early this Summer and the restoration of City Hall Park as it was 100 years ago were apparently assured yesterday.

Nineteen stockholders of Seedtown Products, Inc., of Chicago, filed suit today in Calhoun County Circuit Court alleging that they had been damaged to the extent of $20,000,000 by John L. Kellogg of Chicago; W. K. Kellogg, president of the Kellogg Company, of Battle Creek, Mich.;

The swearing of the jury which will decide the guilt or innocence of the coal operators and law enforcement officers of Harlan County, on trial in Federal court here, was followed today by a dramatic move by counsel for the government.

The military manoeuvres of the City College unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps were reviewed yesterday by 800 persons at the Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. More than 850.

The issue of whether the age limit of those subject to Children's Court jurisdiction should be increased from 16 to 18 years was debated today at the annual conference of the State Association of Judges' of Children's Courts.

The upper house voted the bill limiting the proportion of Jews in industry, trade and the profession to 20 per cent today after Cardinal Seredi, the Primate of Hungary; the Catholic Bishop Glattfelder and the Evangelical Bishop Raffay had protested in the name of their churches against the governments discrimination against those baptized after August. 1919.

Laurence S. Bell, vice president of the Union National Bank of Pittsburgh, was elected president of the Pennsylvania Bankers Association at the closing sessions of its fortyfourth annual convention in the Bellevue-Stratford this afternoon.

It is doubtful if there has ever been a more striking illustration of the way in which the interests and wishes of special pressure groups triumph over the interests and wishes of the people as a whole than the success in the House and the prospective success in the Senate of the Administration's increased spending program.

Captain William J. Pedrick was honored yesterday on his fiftieth birthday and the twentieth anniversary of his executive connection with the Fifth Avenue Association, of which he is president, at a luncheon in the Empire State Club. The function was arranged by executive officers of the association and members of the staff of William J. Pedrick Co., Inc., general agent of the Equitable Life Assurance Society.
The British Ladies Golf Union today named a team of eight to meet the United States in the Curtis Cup matches at Manchester, Mass., Sept. 7-8.

A team of New York municipal bond men defeated a team of Midwestern municipal bond men by one point in a golf match at the Lakeville Club here during games of the seventh annual field day of the Municipal Bond Club of New York. Taking part in the games were 125 persons.
Mrs. Abinah Keller Schaub, who received messages from President Roosevelt, Governor Lehman and Cardinal Hayes on her 103d birthday last Dec. 27, died here last, night at her home.
Eugene G. Carbrey, real estate broker in Scarsdale and East Chester and former sales executive for the Eastman Kodak Company, died here yesterday at his home. His age was 61.
The Red Sox didn't need a Lefty Grove today, but he pitched and won his seventh game of the season while his mates battered five pitchers and crushed the Browns, 16-2.

Despite the appearance of the first corporate loan in about three weeks, the volume .of new bond financing this week dropped to $4,872,000, as compared with $7,018,000 last week. During this period last year a total of $19,748,000 in new bonds was placed on the market.
Silver King, actually Charles F. Koenig, who pitched the St. Louis Browns to championships of the old American Association in 1887 and 1888, died last night at the age of 70.

Next week will mark the beginning of an active Summer in the field of new security distribution, in the opinion of some investment bankers. Following the prolonged period of inactivity, during which negotiations came to a virtual standstill in respect to corporate

W. C. Kickemeyer, president of the Lutheran University Association, announced today that all dances would be banned at Valparaiso University next year to cooperate with an official stand taken by the Lutheran Church.

George M. Cohan is the regular nominee for the presidency of the Catholic Actors Guild, which will hold its annual election on June 17 at the Hotel Astor, it was announced yesterday. Since his nomination is tantamount to election he

United States amateur champion Johnny Goodman recovered his land legs today and rolled around the Tn course in 71 strokes to establish himself as a strong favorite for the British amateur golf championship which opens here Monday. He played the difficult first
Directors of the American Sumatra Tobacco Corporation authorized an extra dividend of 90 cents besides the regular quarterly disbursement of 25 cents on the common stock.

The report of the Joint Preparatory Committee on Philippine Affairs suggesting a gradual elimination of preferences with the United States between 1946, the date now set for independence, and 1960 was completed and signed today.

Bill Gillespie And Don Buffington, Scar borough's top-seeded netmen, paced their school. toward its second consecutive championship as the first 'three rounds of the Princeton University tennis interscholastic wound up on the Nassau courts today. The New Yorkers led their nearest contender, Hill School, 9-8 In the point standing.

The Advitagraph Corporation of Chicago, Louisville and Hollywood has changed its name to Flo-Lite Motion Picture Corporation, an announcement from the executive offices here stated today. The change is effective immediately.

The trial of Max Orloff, neckwear manufacturer accused of withholding $606.54 in payroll taxes from the State Unemployment Insurance Fund in 1936 and 1937, was postponed until next Friday when Orloff appeared yesterday in Municipal Term Magistrate's Court.

Cayuga Lake once more unleashed a gale and blew away a varsity boat race this evening when the eights of Yale, Cornell and Princeton tried to hold the final race of the Carnegie Cup regatta. The oarsmen were lucky to get back to the boathouse without serious damage.

Lieutenant Frank Caufield of Newark, N. J., military aide to Governor Blanton Winship, when notified here of the death of his sister, Mrs. T. W. Morris, in Hawaii, was determined to talk with his sister's husband.
Sir Nevile Henderson, British Ambasasdor, called at the Foreign Office here this afternoon to ask if reports of Germany's mobilizing troops and Storm Troopers on the Czechoslovak border were true.

All Akron plants of the B. F. Goodrich Company were closed today in a walk-out, which L. L. Callahan, president of Goodrich Local, United Rubber Workers of America, said had started as a protest against the retention of eight apprentice electricians while men with longer service were being laid off.

Miss Jean Berry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Hall Berry, was married here this afternoon in the garden of her parents' home to John Hunter Walton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Augustus Walton of Brooklyn, by the Rev. Dr. Archibald Black, pastor of the First Congregational Church here.

Common stockholders of Philip Morris Co., tobacco manufacturers authorized today the issuance of up to $10,000,000 in preferred stock to be used to "reduce bank loans and add to the corporation's working capital."
The Quebec Fascist party split wide open last night when Fuehrer Adrien Arcand expelled his chief lieutenants, Dr. J. G. Lambert and J. E. Lessard, and several other members.

Charles W. Horn, director of research and development for the National Broadcasting Company, pre yesterday was elected president of the New York Electrical Society at its annual meeting in the Long Lines Building of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, 32 Sixth Avenue.

For engaging in forbidden political activity in the primary campaign in Pennsylvania, ten WPA workers were dismissed and eight others were penalized before the election, Harry L. Hopkins, Administrator, announced today.
David L. Woodall, retired Bronx real estate broker, died yesterday in his home at 232 West Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, after a short illness. He was 80 years old.
The Canadian Government will spend $100,000,000 in an attack on unemployment, it was disclosed Today when supplementary estimates were tabled in the House of Commons.

Dr. Arnold Walther, assistant professor of Hittite at the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago since 1930, was found dead today in his room at 5,405 Woodlawn Avenue. Death apparently was due to natural causes. His age was 57.

While neither the Department of Labor nor the supporters of the WageHour Bill in Congress have gone to any trouble to ascertain and publicize the facts, private research has made amply clear the great extent of the differentials existing in wage rates between different sections of the country and between large cities and small towns in the same section.

Park Row, 15: to 32-story offices and restaurant; Fifteen Park Row Corp., premises, owner; I. Kudroff, architect; cost, $10,000. 8th Ave, 2,131-9; to 2-story theatre; H. S. Sonn, Inc., 342 Madison Ave, owner; same architect; cost, $15,000.

The engagement of Miss Peggy Kipp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben E. Kipp of this 'city, to Thomas Burns Drum of- Philadelphia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin'Linnaeus Drum of Lewisburg, Pa., has been announced by her parents.

Lambs and cattle weakened somewhat today which would seem to indicate that if runs continue liberal prices are destined to turn lower next week, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Hogs, however, sold actively and higher with a liberal percentage of today's receipts on direct billing to packers.
The Bureau of Mines estimated today that a daily average supply of 3,333,300 barrels of domestic crude oil would be needed to meet the market demands in June.

Construction of additional approach routes to the Lincoln Tunnel is impossible at this time because of lack of funds, E. Donald Sterner, New Jersey Highway Commissioner, has informed Governor Moore by letter.
Banging eight hits, the Athletics scored a 5-to-2 victory today that squared their series with the Tigers.

Starting in September, the evening and vocational high schools in this city will introduce a special program intended to teach students how to talk pleasantly, how to use good English and how to be at ease in the presence of potential employers, Morris E. Siegel, director of continuation and evening schools, disclosed yesterday.

President Roosevelt asked Congress today to name a joint committee to study the phosphate resources of the country with a view to insuring a continuous and adequate supply of the element necessary to all life.

While increasing the money provided by the House for the Works Progress Administration program in the coming fiscal year, a Senate Appropriations subcommittee, studying the' recovery measure, put a sharp limitation today on the manner in which Public Works funds, authorized in the same measure, should be used.

Ice companies in some 445 cities have announced their intention of using newspaper advertising during the Summer, in conjunction with the national magazine and radio campaign of National Ice Advertising, Inc., according to Donahue Coe, which has just conducted a survey.

The league-leading Indians, determined to stay in first place in the American League, bunched six hits for five runs in the second inning against the Senators today and scored their fifth consecutive victory, 6 to 3.

A total of $85,680 has been colelected by the Brooklyn Division of the Greater New York Fund since the beginning of the borough campaign on May 2, it was disclosed yesterday by Charles A. Gorman, chairman, at the first report luncheon in the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn.

George S. Mabee, former assistant to the general manager of the United States Lines, died on Tuesday in Houston, Texas, where he had recently- made his home, according to word received here yesterday. Mr. Mabee had been ill about eight months. His age was 57.
Dr. Philipp Reinhardt, , retired German industrialist, died Thursday on the Holland-Gravesend ship en route to London, according to word received here yesterday. He was 60 years old.

The "ruthless dictatorship" of Mayor Frank Hague in Jersey City was condemned yesterday by the 250 pastors attending the fourth day's sessions of the New York East Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church in the Hanson Place Central Church, Hanson Place and St. Felix Street, Brooklyn.

The Sixteen-story Central Park View apartment, on the northwest corner of 101st Street and Central Park West, was among the eleven Manhattan properties sold at auction yesterday. Sales of two other parcels, one of them the Manhattan Towers Hotel, were adjourned.
The Federal Government, in an unusual move today, accused the Supreme Court of reversing itself in the Kansas City Stockyards case and requested the court to reconsider its decision of April 25.

Cotton-mill activity declined last week, countering a rising seasonal trend, and the adjusted index dropped to 80.8 from 86.7, the revised figure for the previous week. It stood at 140.9 for the week ended May 15, 1937.

President Roosevelt asked Congress today to appropriate $23,875,000 to begin construction of thirteen naval vessels, a dirigible, a "mosquito" fleet, nine naval planes, and for improvements at three navy yards.
The rowing squads of Harvard and Pennsylvania, guests of Navy in the Adams Cup race tomorrow, arrived today and all the crews worked out on' the Severn River course.

A 17-year-old boy who had refused to halt at the commands of two pursuing policemen was shot and killed shortly after 1:30 o'clock this morning in the rear yard of 83 Miller Avenue, in the East New York section of Brooklyn.
Ignoring an earlier setback, the House Merchant Marine Committee recommended anew today that Congress subsidize vessels engaged in intercoastal commerce.

By holding the Aylesbury parliamentary division in yesterday's voting in the i third by-election since Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's resignation to be fought with its foreign policy as the main issue, the Chamberlain government has succeeded in halting its recent succession of by-election defeats.

Motion picture conference, 4-Star Clubs of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures, School of Education auditorium, New York University, 10:30 A. M. Speakers: Arthur Gale, Jack Bush and Arthur Ward.

The successful results of "foreign trade weeks," as held in the United States, were described by Eliot Wadsworth, chairman of the American section before the International Chamber of Commerce's Council, meeting here today.

Felix H. Levy, counsel to Oliver Brothers, yesterday filed a petition for review of the order of the Federal Trade Commission against the company and some ten other respondents, which alleged violation of Section 2c of the Robinson-Patman law, in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit, Richmond, Va. Mr. Levy

The Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System, including the Brooklyn Queens Transit System, reported yesterday for the ten months ended on April 30 a net income of $697,381 after Federal income taxes, depreciation, interest, etc., equal to $2.79 a share on the $6 preferred stock.
The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, and a professor in Union Theological Seminary, on Tuesday will be 60 years old.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 14 amounted to 541,813 cars, the association of American Railroads announced today.

Morris McDonald, who administered the Maine Central Railroad's affairs for nineteen years before his retirement as president in 1932, died of a heart ailment at his home here last night. He was 72 years old.
In the dullest trading for a full session since May 3, bonds on the Stock Exchange moved irregularly yesterday, with closing prices for most domestic corporate liens generally lower.

An inventory filed today in Probate Court disclosed that Edward A. Filene left an estate estimated at $2,205,084. It consists of $31,500 in real estate and $2,173,584 In per. sonal property. Mr. Filene left all

To Sports editor of The New York Times: While it seemed to me that John Kieran ably defended the various reasons Why the Schmeling-Louis fight should. be held in New York, it also seems to me that a reader's rebuttal to the letter of Hugo Kessler is in order.

Hoe Ave (11-2989), e x, 125 ft 8 of 173d St, 75x100; Gustave Comby to Pelemes Realty Corp. 122 E 42d St; mtg $49,000. Light St (17-4951), n w cor of Merritt Ave, 50x100; Edward V. Morand, referee, to Rome Owners Loan Corp.

The Census Bureau reported today the cotton-spinning industry operated during April at 85.7 per cent of capacity, on a single-shift basis, compared with 101.1 per cent during March this year and 146.7 per cent during April last year.

The Green Meadow women's golf team, playing on its home course, jumped into a temporary lead today in the Westchester interclub matches. Scoring four points against Fairview and two against Quaker Ridge, Green Meadow advanced its total to fifteen.

Dr. Ignatz Theodore Griebl, the Nazi adherent and United States Army reserve officer, who knew a good deal about German spies boring into American defense secrets but vanished before his testimony was registered, was finally found in Germany yesterday, beyond legal process.

The new flagship of the Holland America Line, the Nieuw Amsterdam, will sail at noon today for Plymouth, Boulogne and Rotterdam, carrying about 1,000 passengers on the second half of her maiden voyage.
President Roosevelt asked Congress today for a committee to study means. of conserving phosphate deposits-in order to insure the future health and economic security of the nation.

The Blooming Grove Hunting and Fishing Club is appropriately located near a place called Promised Land, but to any sportsman we know the club itself would fill all the requirements of a mythical land of promise.

A homicide charge against 16year-old Dolores Shields, of 131 Dean Strfeet, Brooklyn, in the fatal shooting of her childhood sweetheart, Charles Berger, 17, in his home at 134 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, on May 11, was dismissed yesterday in Brooklyn
Nino Bongiovanni's looping single with the bases full in the thirteenth inning gave the Chiefs a 6-to-5 victory over Newark before 1,500 fans tonight. e 1,500 fans tonight.

Mr. and Mrs. William Kennedy Jr. of this city and Huntington, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elisabeth Chesebrough Kennedy, to Fremont James Knittle of New York, de son of Mrs. Frank T. Knittle of by Salina, Kan., and the late Mr. Knittle.

The marriage of Mrs. Kathryn Marsh Smith, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Rolph Marsh of New York, to Jan C. Vieweg, also of this city, took place yesterday afternoon in the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Theodore Roosevelt used to comment caustically on the "lunatic fringe" in the public, which term the public could now most aptly use in respect to the present government.

Depart.ment store sales during the week ended May 14 were 16 per cent lower than for the corresponding week one year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. For the four weeks ended May 14 the sales were 14 per cent lower than for the corresponding four weeks in 1937.

The Civilian Conservation Corps was pictured to scientists here today as a destroyer of the "natural equilibrium of nature" and, inferentially, as a menace to many rare plants which, as "fugitive aristocrats," had struggled against odds for millions of years to retain a foothold on this continent.

Again Spain becomes the focus of the international war which flares up, flickers out, is damped down in spots, but keeps smoldering on like an intermittent fever in a weakened body. The spasmodic progress of the battle within the peninsula gives impetus to the ebb and flow of the larger struggle.

These are the departures on record as of this evening: "Of Mice and Men," winner of the season's New York Drama Critics Circle Prize (207 performances) "Hooray for What!" (199); "Washington Jitters" (twenty-four public performances following several weeks of previews); "Trojan Incident"

With retail trade continuing to decline, wholesale volume this week dropped further behind.1937 figures and was estimated at 10 to 25 per cent below the same week last year, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
Victorious in four of. five starts, Lancashire . holds a cmmanding lead in English County cricket competition.. The Lancastrians today defeated Middlesex by 113 runs.

Although she lost a set for the first time since she began her current British tennis invasion, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody today moved .into the final round of the Surrey championships by eliminating Miss Peggy Scriven of England, 6-2, 5-7, 6-3.

Master Patrick, a big, upstanding coach dog, put down in hard-running condition, was the winner today of the best-in-show title at the annual specialty show of the Dalmatian Club of America. The event was held on the grounds of Mrs. L. W. Bonney, secretary-treasurer of the organization.

A strike call based on a demand for shorter working hours has tied up 200 oil barges and put more than 600 men ashore in the last two days, according to Captain William H. Bradley, president of the United Marine Division of the International Longshoremen's Association.
Johnny Kinder and Charley Whitehead of Plainfield, defending champions, today won the qualifying medal in the third annual New Jersey State professional-amateur golf championship.

A warning that Americans should throw off the habit of passing judgment on foreign countries and devote more attention to the problems and needs of home was expressed yesterday by Bishop James De Wolf Perry of Rhode Island and the Rt. Rev. George Craig Stewart, Bishop of Chicago, both of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

Mayor Walter Mynatt disclosed today that the city of Knoxville would put up more than two-thirds of the $7,900,000 offered jointly by the municipality and the Tennessee Valley Authority for properties of the Tennessee Public Service Company.

E. H. Driggs Jr., twice victor in the Garden City Golf Club's annual invitation tournament, one of the country's oldest and most distinguished competitions, and medalist in this year's event, today made his way into the semi-final round, defeating two opponents by the same score, 5-and 4.

Plans for another row of stores to meet the expected demand near the World's Fair site were announced yesterday when Fred Whitman bought a plot 100 by 100 feet on the south side of Roosevelt Avenue, 100 feet west of 114th Street, Corona.

Fritzie Zivic, 148, Pittsburgh, knocked out Petie Mike, 150, West Side, in 2:40 of the first round of the. feature ten-round bout at the Fort Hamilton Arena, last night. A crowd of 3,000 saw the winner finish Mike, who was. substituting for Ercole Buratti, with a right
The withdrawal of the defenders of Suchow, -the objective of Japanese attacks along the TientsinPukow Railway since January, was officially announced here last night.

Arthur Kendall, 30 years old, of 62 West 106th Street, was shot and killed at 11:40 o'clock last night in 120th Street near Broadway, opposite Columbia University, when Patrolman Joseph Dugah, on strike duty near by, saw him running,

Word has been received here from Ottawa of the engagement of Miss Ailsa Craig, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Granville Craig of Packway, Boiney, Sussex, England, to Bernard Francis Castle Floud, son of Sir Francis Lewis Castle Floud, High Commissioner in Canada for the United Kingdom, and Lady Floud, of Earnscliffe, Ottawa.

The Bache collection of art at the Jules Bache residence, 814 Fifth Avenue, will be exhibited at three special showings next Friday and Ion June 3 and 10 as a benefit for the Greenwich House Music School. Cards of admission may be obtained by writing to or telephoning

Opposition to the national Progressive party, recently launched by Governor Philip F. La Follette of Wisconsin, will be expressed today by the State convention of the Affiliated Young Democrats, Inc., at the' Park Central Hotel.

Another scramble for South African goldmining shares again provided the chief interest in the stock market here today, but conditions elsewhere in the market were quiet. The difficulties between France and Italy were exerting a restrictive influence on trading. Gilt-edge issues were steady; among the foreign

Dartmouth's lacrosse team won the New England Intercollegiate League championship today by defeating Springfield, 12-6. With the score tied at 5-5 after three quarters, the Indians scored seven goals in the final period.

A flour-loading tax of 6 cents a barrel proposed by the International Longshoremen's Association, which would cost the consuming public about $312,000 a year, was staved off yesterday when Supreme Court. Justice Mitchell May in Brooklyn granted a temporary injunction restraining the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Local 138, from instructing its members to refuse to truck and handle flour not previously handled by members of the longshoremen's union.

In reply to a recent suggestion of the Fifth Avenue Association that changes be made in the rules govearning one-way express streets in Manhattan, Police Commissioner Valentine said yesterday he had "no comment, because the matter is under investigation."

Mayor Frank Hayes, who is also Lieutenant Governor of Connecticut, and Daniel J. Leary, former City Controller, surrendered to Edward J. Hickey, county detective,. this afternoon on a bench warrant issued last night by the Superior Court.

Retired Fireman Thomas J. McGrath, formerly a member of Engine Co. 13, residing at 47-06 Forty-sixth St., Woodside, Queens, died May 19. Funeral will take place from Funeral Parlor of Ed. B. Lynch, 43-07 Queens Boulevard, Long Island Citat 9:30 A. M., Monday, May 23. Interment at St. John's Cemetery. The Deputy Chief of the 11th Division shall detail one captain, one lieutenant and twelve firemen as funeral escort.
Richard M. Lederer sold to Richard Lippman of 310 E 55th St, the s e cor of 3d Ave and 73d St. 76.71/2x85, for a consideration shown as $32,500 over a mortgage for $75.000.

Speakers at the testimonial supper to Antoinette Perry and her coworkers on the American Theatre Council Apprentice Committee tomorrow night at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel will be Frank Gillmore, president of the- Associated Actors and Artistes of America; John Golden, Brock Pemberton and Herman

Irregular raiders-armed peasant - followers of General Saturnino Cedillohave gone into action in the State of San Luis Potosi and have cut the railway between Tampico and the city of San Luis Potosi, capital of the State of San Luis Potosi.

Further details of the deal by which Mrs. Maria Kramer, wife of Max J. Kramer, will assume ownership of the Hotel Lincoln, thirtystory midtown hostelry at Eighth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, were revealed yesterday.

The home-run bats of big,Babe Phelps and Ernie Koy boomed a winning tune for Van Lingle Mungo yesterday at Ebbets Field as the Dodgers topped the Pirates, 7-5, to give the Buccaneers their fourth straight setback before a ladies' day crowd of 4,749.

Reductions ranging from 2 to 8 cents a pound on viscose process weaving yarns and from 4 to 13 cents on knitting -yarns were announced yesterday by the rayon division of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., effective yesterday.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for. savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Aldersgate Sunday will be observed tomorrow by Methodists all over the world. In Lutheran churches prayers will be offered for the executive committee of the Lutheran World Convention which is in session at Upsala, Sweden. The action of the World Ecumential Council last week at Utrecht, The Netherlands in arranging for

Miss Faith Biddle Fitler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. N. Myers Fitler of Straight Lane, Wynnewood, was married this afternoon to Robert F. Morris of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ambrose F. Morris of Akron, Ohio.
Twenty-four truck loads, carrying 200 tons of Spanish gold and silver for the United States, passed into France tonight.

Injunction proceedings were instituted yesterday in Supreme Court by a group of holders of Class B stock of United Shipyards, Inc., to prevent the scheduled sale of most of the corporation's plants and assets to the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation of Delaware for $9,320, week on 000. United Shipyards owns and

The Middlesex County grand jury refused today to return indictments against Fred Claibourne Brooks, 20 years old, son of Winthrop H. Brooks, president of the Brooks Brothers, New York clothiers, and John Edward Seigel, 24,

The "hell buggies" and the scout and armored cars and other mechanized vehicles of the Seventh Cavairy Brigade roared, rumbled and snorted across several hundred miles of Kentucky and Tennessee hill country today on the start of a 700-mile mechanized march that was marked by early tragedy.

William Watson, University of Michigan star from Saginaw, cracked one conference record and also led the qualifiers in two other events today as the Wolverines dominated the trials for the'thirty-eighth annual Western Conference -track and field championships.

The cornerstone of the new Memorial Hospital for the Treatment of Cancer and Allied Diseases at York Avenue, opposite the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, the Cornell University Medical College, and the New York Hospital, was laid yesterday afternoon in the presence of a distinguished gathering of medical men and cancer authorities.
Several residential properties in White Plains and an industrial parcel. in Bronxville figured in the Westchester realty deals made known yesterday.

Leaders of the Democratic faction whose ticket won in Tuesday's primaries over that backed by John L. Lewis and Senator Guffey- turned hopefully to Washington today to find a means of harmonizing the warring elements and lacing the Republicans :with a united front in the general election.

The League of Music Lovers concluded its season last night at Town Hall with a program of music and the dance. The performers were Martha Graham, the Curtis String Quartet and the pianist, Aube Tzerko.

Off to a lower start, the stock market experienced difficulty during the rest of the session yesterday in improving its position. The closing was irregularly lower. On the average, the industrials did better than the rails, although some groups of the former classification, notably the metal issues, were generally lower.
COMING FROM THE FAIR, by Norah Hoult. (Covici, Friede, $2.50.) A novel of life in Dublin from 1903 to 1933. MODERN ENGLAND, by Cicely Hamilton. (Dutton, $2.75.)

The Society of the 307th Infantry will hold its annual memorial service at the Regimental Memorial Grove, north of the Mall in Central Park, at 2 P. M. today. Assembly will be at -the entrance to the park at Seventy-second Street and Fifth Avenue.

Another $25,000 in checks was distributed yesterday to unemployed and partly employed members of Local 117 of the Cloak and Suit Operators Union of the International Ladies Garment Workers. Members received their checks at the union's headquarters, 242 West Thirty-sixth Street.

Because of the popularity attained by their song of the same name in "Big Broadcast of 1938," Shirley Ross and Bob Hope will be seen in "Thanks for the Memory" at Paramount. The story, which is being written by Frances Goodrich and Albert Hackett, follows the song's theme. Shooting will start July 18,

Flushing High's nine scored its sixth victory - In six starts in Section A of the Queens P. S. A. L. and clinched the divisional title by blanking Bryant, .60,. at Bradley Oval, Long Island, City, yesterday.

Approval and criticism of the proposed joint Federal and State marketing order designed to equalize prices paid to producers by distributors for milk intended for the New York City metropolitan area, were voiced yesterday morning and afternoon at hearings in the State Building, 80 Center Street, and in the Hotel Commodore.
Italy will It stage mass air transportation of troops in manoeuvres near the Italian-French North African border, it- was disclosed today amid diplomatic tension between the two countries.

Roy Rudolph, formerly buyer of women's daytime and evening dresses for Lord Taylor, has been appointed merchandise manager of higher priced ready-to-wear, it was announced yesterday by Walter Hoving, president of the store. Mrs. Marie Borger has been transferred from buyer of women's and misses' suits to buyer of women's daytime and evening dresses.

A concert will be given tonight at y the New School by. the Music Teachers and Concert Artists Locals of the Workers Alliance, in collaboration -with the Spanish Committee. The program will offer chamber music, songs and instrumental solos.

W. H. Oliver, from Mrs. Kate Ruland Crigler, residence on Park Drive, South, Westchester Country Club, Rye, Westchester; W. L. Hernstadt, the Hildegarde Walwroth estate on Westchester Ave, Harrison: Walter Hirshon, from Mrs. Mary Putnam Butler, residence on Manursing Way, Rye; Prince Ripley, Inc, brokers.

William C. Potter, chairman of the Guaranty Trust Company, denied yesterday that the company had blocked the dissolution of the Chesapeake Corporation and the distribution of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway stock that it holds, as proposed by Robert R. Young.

The text of the address delivered by William 0. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, last night at the dinner of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, follows: Representatives of business and government meet tonight to hail a joint achievement and to launch a joint program.

The uneasiness ve of the last few days over FrancoItalian relations has been followed by a period of comparative optimism, thanks in many ways to the British remedy for all such incidents, "keep talking."
Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches set a women's competitive course record of 75 today at Arcola in winning low gross honors in the New Jersey Women's Golf Association one-day tournament.

Captain James Gillies, retired manager of Canadian, Pacific Steamships, Ltd., died here today at the age of 64. A native of Armadale, Scotland, Captain Gillies entered the Canadian Pacific service in 1903.

It's getting to be a habit. Another monkey wrench was tossed into the delicately attuned Giant machinery yesterday as John Vander Meer, a handsome left-hander with a blazing fireball, stopped the New Yorkers with five miserly hits while the Reds won, 4 to 0, and the Stoneham troupe was shut out for the second successive day.

Daniel Casey, Director of Public Safety in Jersey City, yesterday again denied an application by Norman Thomas, former Socialist candidate for President, for a permit to hold a street meeting in that city.

Premier Benito Mussolino's demand that the. Pyrenees frontier be closed to the passage of arms into Spain and the announcement that another meeting of the Non-Intervention Committee is to be held next week again have raised- the question of where and cc how arms and ammunition have reached the peninsula.

Richard Deans Waugh, British Empire representative on the Saar commission in 1920 and thrice Mayor of Winnipeg, died suddenly today at the age of 70. He was chief commissioner of the Manitoba Liquor Commission.

Joseph D. Piro, alias Joey York, 1,918 Lacombe Avenue, the Bronx, was arrested yesterday by Secret Service agents of the United States Treasury Department on a charge of having offered counterfeit money for sale by mail.

Contending that only one side of the controversial subject of foreign trade is presented in the "Syllabus on Foreign Trade," prepared for use in the city high schools by the high school division of the Board of Education in cooperation with a committee sponsoring the celebration of National Foreign Trade Week here, Walter R. Peabody, secretary of the American Tariff League, yesterday protested use of the syllabus in the city schools.

Mrs. Kathryn Knight Dunscombe of New York, daughter of the late Mrs. Charles D. Orth and of the late William Knight, was married to Carl F. Boker Jr., also of New York, this afternoon at Sunnywood, the home here of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore P. Grosvenor. The Rev.

Scientific instruments worth about $2,000 were stolen from the New England Science Building at Vassar College early today. Effecting entrance by smashing a rear window in the 37-year-old building which houses the departments, of botany and zoology and the greater part of the natural history collections, the thieves made their way into a laboratory and took eight valuable microscopes, a camera and a photometer.

The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation (Ithaca), a subsidiary of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, has filed application under the Holding Company Act for exemption from the requirement of submitting a declaration covering sale to the Rural Electrification Administration of $250,000 of 2.88 per cent notes to mature serially.

The National Labor Relations Board objected today to answering seventyfour questions asked by attorneys for the Ford Motor Company, the NLRB alleging that the queries comprised a "fishing expedition" into the board's affairs.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, criticized continued government spending as a means to recovery in a speech here tonight and said that the "natural" way lay through better wages and hours, through increasing private employment. He called for peace between industry and labor, pledged the cooperation of his organization and attacked unions which use the sit-down strike- and "other illegal and high-handed procedures."

A further sharp decline in quotations for cotton in Bombay served yesterday to increase the reversal of straddle accounts and prices on the Cotton Exchange here lost 5 to 7 points. For the first time this month, July touched 81/2 cents and while scale-buying limits occasioned resistance, the market encountered pressure on each rally.

City Councilman B. Charney Viadeck underwent an operation to save his right eye at the Eye Institute of Presbyterian Hospital, 168th Street and Fort Washington Avenue, yesterday. His condition was said last night to be very satisfactory. Dr. John Wheeler, surgeon
The marriage of Miss Sara Anne Kohn, 'daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Achilles H. Kohn, to Jack Tarkington Cassady, son of Elmer H. Cassady of Memphis,..Tenn., and the late Mrs. Cassady, took place

The Mayflower, which sailed into this harbor on a wintry December day in 1620, will ride the water here in a duplicate, according to plans announced by the Plymouth Historical Society. The society hopes to raise sufficient funds to construct a full-size reproduction of the famous 180-ton ship, using as a model the smallscale model now on display at the Pilgrim Hall Museum.

The top contract price for fuel oil for residence heating in the metropolitan area of New York and in New Jersey for the 1938-39 season will be 1 cent a gallon below the prices for the season just closing, it was said yesterday.

New York Methodists will commemorate officially the ti-centenaryy of the "heart-warming" of John Wesley, founder of Methodism, on Tuesday, with a meeting under the auspices of the New ni York District of the New- York Methodist Conference in the Summerfield Church, Dobbs Ferry,

A sharp attack today by Secretary Morgenthau on a more or less routine report of the General Accounting Office aroused speculation whether the controversy might be used as a peg on which to hang a revival of the government reorganization fight.

Dr. Hugo Eckener, Zeppelin builder, and Hans Dieckhoff, German Ambassador, discussed briefly with President Roosevelt today the question of making American helium available for use in German airships.

Mr. and Mrs. William Penh allow Henderson of El Camino del Monte Sol, have, announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Alice Henderson Evans, to Edgar L. Rossin of New York. The wedding will take

MANHATTAN CUSHING, ARTHUR 3. (Oct. 26, 1937). Gross assets, $8,816: net, S7,868. To Maxine Cushing, niece; Richard Cushing and William Lincoln, nephews, one-third residue each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $6,312. William S. Siemon, attorney, 149 Broadway.

Macmillan will publish on June 14 "The Autobiography of Chevalier Jackson," the British physician known for his development of the bronchoscope, the instrument with which he has saved the lives of children from every corner of the globe by removing objects, accidentally swallowed, from their lungs and bronchial tubes.
The college crews are now pulling along lustily in a rowing campaign that will culminate, as usual, with the Poughkeepsie Regatta and the meeting of Harvard and Yale on the Thames above New London.

James C. Sheridan, who was installed as Queens County Democratic leader by the intervention of James A. Farley, national Democratic chairman, in 1934, was ousted by a bare majority vote at a meeting of the county executive committee at the Queens Elks Clubhouse in Elmhurst last night.

The aims and scope of the Marketing Laws Survey, to be undertaken by the Works Progress Administration, were outlined for the first time to a convention of business men by A. H. Martin Jr., director of the survey, In addressing the third annual convention of the National Federation of Sales Executives at the Baker Hotel today.

An appeal to the members of the 148 Junior Leagues to become better informed about present-day affairs so that they may better understand their place in public welfare service and in the cultural development of their communities was the keynote of the address of Mrs. Peter L.

The five-story building at 75 Fifth on Avenue has been sold by the Gram- Ing ercy Realty Company to the Flor- ma ence Holding Corporation, Ann Fayne, president, through the Bankers Trust Company, as trustee. .

The marriage of Miss Josephine H. Macsherry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Hillen Macsherry of this community, to Francis Robinson, son of the late Colonel and Mrs. C. L. F. Robinson of Hartford, Conn., took place this afternoon at the home of the bride.

The Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company and subsidiaries, controlled by Standard Oil Company of Indiana, reported yesterday that the net profit for the first quarter of '1938 amounted to $866,340, after depreciation, depletion, normal Federal income taxes and other charges, but before possible surtax on undistributed income.

Mrs. Meredith Nicholson has arrived from Caracas, Venezuela, and is at the Waldorf-Astoria, where she will be joined on Monday by, Mr. Nicholson, newly appointed United States: Minister to Nicaragua. Mr. Nicholson, accompanied by his wife, will sail next Friday on the Santa Maria-to take up his new post in Managua.

Behind the steady pitching of Tom Coughlin, the, Manhattan College baseball team' downed St. John's, 3-1, at Dexter Park yesterday. for its tenth straight triumph and its twelfth in thirteen games this season. The Jaspers now have won eight of nine encounters with metropolitan rivals.

A trust Institution organized under the laws of the State to act as a fiduciary agent in- safeguarding the funds and securities of customers as well as brokers was-forecast for the near future by William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, in an address here last night.

When the leases of forty-two tenants of the Chanin Building, the fifty-six-story structure at 122 East Forty-second Street, expired on April 30, every one was renewed, according to Henry I. Chanin of Chanin Management, Inc.

The pay-as-you-go policy of relief financing begun by Mayor La Guardia has kept NewYork City's relief picture "healthy". in the face' of a recession that closed relief. offices in Chicago. and' Cleveland . and strained the debt structure of other communities, Welfare Commissioner William Hodson said yesterday.

A statement in its accounting series for the guidance of promotional companies was issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. It dealt with the position taken by the commission in regard to the creation of surplus by appraisal in balance sheets representing the accounts of such companies.

The Treasury Procurement Division today invited bids on the following lot of textiles: Issued May 19, to be opened May 26, for delivery July 9697-T chambray, fancy and plaids, 27-inch minimum, minimum weight 4.6 ounce per square yard, 126,300 yards.

Mayor La Guardia left last night for Washington, where he will spend the week-end. On Sunday he will attend the massing of the colors of the Military Order of the World War in the National Cathedral of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, will throw his influence behind Senator Barkley, majority leader, and against Governor Chandler in the Kentucky primary, according to reports current after he took luncheon with the President today.

Dr. August J. Raggi of 130 West Eleventh Street, attending surgeon in gynecology at St. Vincent's Hospital and visiting surgeon in gynecology at Columbus Hospital, died at 1:30 A. M. yesterday in Knickerbocker Hospital of injuries he received about 6 P. M. on Thursday

Undefeated crews from Dartmouth and American International College will meet Manhattan in a triangu- Cincinnati 4, Ne lar regatta on the Harlem River this afternoon. The varsity race, Chicago 1 over the Henley course, is to start at 5 o'clock, with a contest for the freshman crews of the three colleges scheduled thirty minutes earlier.

The General Electric Company and a local contracting concern paid more than $5,000 in extra and unnecessary costs to meet demands of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, on Triborough Bridge work, it was testified yesterday in the Federal Building before John Kirkland Clark, special master, in the injunction suit brought by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association against the union.

Philadelphia has invited bids, which will be considered on June 16, for a new issue of $5,000,000 of 31/4 per cent bonds. The issue will be dated June 16, 1938, and will mature on June 16, 1988, optional in 1958.

In a 4-to-1 decision the Appellate Division declared constitutional yesterday amendments to the law governing the private arbitration of business disputes, which became effective Sept. 1 last. The amendments curtail the legal steps which can be taken to avoid or upset an arbitration award.

The most enduring monument likely to be set up by the La Guardia administration will come not from the Mayor himself, or from Robert Moses, or even from the Board of Education, but from Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran. Parkways and playgrounds and
Certified copies of a Supreme Court order dissolving the State Banking Company of New York have been filed with the State Banking Department, the department's weekly bulletin said today.

American choral groups will contribute to the music program at the World's Fair, according to leaders in this field who spoke yesterday at a luncheon of the New York Federation of Music Clubs, held in the Hotel Great Northern, 118 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Foreign prices for copper dropped sharply yesterday on news of the reduction of 1 cent a pound here to 9 cents. Late in the day sales were made at 8.70 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports, compared with a final price on Thursday of about 9.30 cents. The volume of business was small.
The formation of the Officers Club of the Army and Navy was announced last night by Captain Roger E. Marion, Engineering Reserve Corps of the U. S. A., who has been appointed executive secretary.

Mrs. Helen Willis, 32-year-old former wife of Francis Willis, executive assistant to the president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, was found dead early yesterday morning in her one-room apartment at 10 Park Avenue.

Transactions in monetary gold involving a gain of $8,375,000 to the gold stocks of the country were reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. They consisted of the release from earmarking here of $1,050,000 gold and the receipt by import at San Francisco of $7,325,000.
H. E. Morriss's Pasch was backed down to 7 to 4 as favorite for the June 1 running of the Derby in a callover of odds at the Victoria Club tonight. In Wednesday's callover he was quoted at 2 to 1.

Louis H. Calder, president of the Taylor, Symonds Corporation, wholesale dry goods dealers, died last night at his home in Cranston at the age of 76. He had been identified with the Providence corporation for sixteen years,

Internal revenue collections for the ten months of the current fiscal year ended on April 30 amounted to $4,633,704,868, an increase of $1,089,049,676 over the corresponding period of last year, while receipts for April were $302,475,820, an increase of $2,085,872 over April, 1937, the Treasury reported today.

Photographs submitted from all over the United States, its possessions, and Canada for entry in the First Scholastic Salon of Photography were judged yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History, where the show will be opened to the public tomorrow at 1 P. M.

Governor Lehman was asked today to extend executive clemency to five men now in the Sing Sing death house. They are scheduled to die the- weeks of May 23 and May--30. The convicted men are Fred J. Hull, 50, a slayer of Samuel Drukman in a Brooklyn garage three

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $55,059,000, to be represented by one State and thirty-eight municipalities. This compares with the revised total for last week of $8,876,150. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $23,778,555.

Mrs. Sarah Brodsky, mother of Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky, died yesterday at her home, 920 Riverside Drive, after an illness of three months. She was 97 years old. Mrs. Brodsky, who was active in Jewish charitable organizations,

House members engaged in a free-for-all discussion of foreign policy today, and during the debate official comment on world problems was attacked and defended, munitions embargoes were urged, and "British duplicity" was assailed.

The suggestion, made in his speech last night to the Association of Stock Exchange Firms by the chairman of the SEC regarding custodianship of cash and securities belonging to customers of commission houses, deserves more than passing notice.

A survey taken by the national style committee of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers indicates that the current swing toward single breasted suits will carry over strongly into the Fall, and that the usual switch to double breasted for the Winter season will not take place. However,

Harry H. Field of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange has announced that a market for trading in hides for future delivery will be opened on June 13. He made the announcement to about fifty members of the Exchange and an equal number of representatives of tanners, packers, hide dealers, leather manufacturers and shoe companies.
Premier Milan Hodza today made an important statement to the editors of coalition newspapers. on the German minority situation and spoke plainly about the perils confronting Czechoslovakia.
Every town in Cuba today celebrated the thirtysixth anniversary of the nation's independence. Commerce and industry suspended activities and government departments closed.

Henry L. Hess of La Grande, who claimed Administration backing, was running a neck-and-neck race with Governor Charles H. Martin, 74-year olds retired major general, in returns tonight from the contest for the Democratic nomination for Governor in today's primary.

Early in March the President announced that he would address Congress on the urgent necessity of developing and conserving our phosphate resources. Yesterday a message was delivered which makes the expected plea for transferring our phosphate industry from Florida and Tennessee to Idaho, Montana and Wyoming.

The House passed today and sent to the Senate a bill eliminating the July 1 time limit on the making of Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation loans to FDIC-insured banks to facilitate merging or otherwise strengthening insured institutions.

Miss Robe Mary Anna Barnitz, daughter of Mrs. Eugenia Landenberger Barnitz of Bryn Mawr, was married this afternoon to John Large Fox, son of Mrs. Charles Pemberton Fox-of Fox Hollow, Spring House, and of the late Mr. Fox.

Frank E. Ellsworth, director of teacher training at Western State Teachers College, and widely known in educational circles, died this morning while being taken to Bronson Hospital. He was stricken while on his way to. his office. He was sixty-five years of age.

Unfair competition in the sale of certain cosmetic products is alleged in complaints issued by the Federal Trade Commission against Endura Corporation, Hollywood, Calif., and Pinaud, Inc., 220 East Twenty-first Street, New York City.

The Cross Brown Company collaborated with Harris Harris, Inc., as brokers in leasing for A. G. Spalding Bros. the factory building at 585 Dean Street, Brooklyn, to the Hudson Rug Refinishing and Cleaning Corporation, reported yesterday.

MAN who has never yet seen Dublin can grow homesick for the place just by reading Norah Hoult's grand new novel, "Coming From the Fair."* It's a racy, subtle, richly flavored story of Irish life, and the town on the Liffey they all call "dear, dirty Dublin" is as much a character in the book as any of the O'Neills.

The L vulnerability of Japanese cities on southernmost Kyushu Island, especially the big,Sasebo naval base, was emphasized by a dramatic Chinese "good-will" raid over Nagasaki, Fukuoka and other Kyushu cities between midnight and dawn today.

With Princeton and Columbia hit by injuries, Yale .looms larger as a chief contender in what appears to be a bitter tussle for Ivy League track laurels at the fourth annual heptagonal meet in Palmer Stadium tomorrow. Cornell, Dartmouth, be Harvard and Penn will join in the.

ON POLICE SURGEON'S CERTIFICATE To take effect 12 midnight, May 19. SERGEANT-Walter Kunze, 48th Precinct,, at $1,750 per annum. Appointed April 23, 1918. Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., May 21.

Resolutions urging the Constitutional Convention to disapprove of any proposal to extend the New York City debt limit or to suspend the right of appeal to courts for review of assessed valuations have been adopted by the Twenty-third Street Association.

Miss Constance Prehn of this city, daughter of Mr. and Mrs.. George Mason Prehn, was married yesterday to Porter Clyde Shannon, also of New York, in the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs defended yesterday his appointment to office of Simon W. Gerson, his Communist aide. At the same time, expressing a personal distaste for communism, he upheld the right of Communists in the United States to hold public office, elective or appointive.

Glen Lee, tireless middleweight battler from Edison, Neb., easily defeated the veteran Solly Krieger of Brownsville in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The Westerner, waging a determined and aggressive battle all the way, had little trouble with his Brooklyn foe and earned the unanimous vote of the judges, George Lecron and Marty Monroe, and the referee, Johnny McEvoy.

Taking of testimony in the trial of Albert Marinelli, former County Clerk of New York County and Tammany leader of the Second Assembly District, was completed yesterday in Federal court, Brooklyn, before Judge Marcus B. Campbell and a jury of eight men and two women.

Wheat prices held within a range of slightly less than 1 cent a bushel on The Board of Trade here today and all deliveries sold within a small fraction of the lowest levels of the season. The close was at net declines of 1/4 to % cent. The former on the May.

The remedy for the "complicated and chronic" disease of the country's railroads lies in the elimination of unfair competition by other means of transportation, Representative Samuel B. Pettengill of Indiana said last night at a meeting of the New York Railroad Club in the auditorium of the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

Harry K. Thaw, who was acquitted of the murder of Stanford White in 1908 after Dr. Smith Ely Jelliffe, the psychiatrist, had testifield in his behalf, appeared yesterday in Federal court as a defendant in a suit brought by Dr. Jelliffe to collect a fee of $10,000.

A colorful and spectacular flower and fashion show was held yesterday afternoon on the steamship Nieuw Amsterdam, flagship of the Holland-America Line, marking the end of a week of festivities on the occasion of the liner's maiden visit here. Unique in many respects,

The prospect of legislation at this session on easing the regulations on Reconstruction Finance Corporation loans to railroads dimmed today when the House delayed action on the reported bill after the Senate had recommitted its draft for amendment.

An end to the prolonged controversy over Philip Evergood's mural in the Richmond Hill branch of the Queensborough Public Library has been reached with its acceptance by the Queensborough Library Board, of which Louis J. Bailey, the chief librarian, is chairman.

Again handicapped by cold weather, retail trade here slipped lower during the week, in comparison with the same period a year ago. Department store executives estimated the decline at 14 per cent, compared with a drop of 12.3 per cent for the preceding week.
Secretary of Agriculture Wallace said today that under the terms of the new crop control law it was too late to invoke marketing quotas on this year's indicated bumper wheat crop.

No one in Nazi officialdom of Austrian Germany seems to know what is in store for former Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg, but a responsible government spokesman said his situation had become more serious.

George C. Mathews, member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, shared dinner honors tonight with Clem M. Collins, president of the American Institute of Accountants, at the annual dinner of the institute.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
Additional appropriations of $107,143,000 for the present fiscal year were asked of Congress today by President Roosevelt.
Hexameter, 7-year-old gelding from the stables of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Untermyer of Greenwich, Conn., took first prize in the $500 hunter stakes today at the Wilmington Horse Show.

IT is quite by accident that the number of Lord Aveling's guests happens to be thirteen, and whatever tragedies follow upon their coming together are to be charged to the circumstance that they form a most illassorted group.
Oregon's primary election held this week involved many national implications. For three years the Democratic Governor, Charles H. Martin, has condemned numerous New Deal reforms.

Eleven members of the Memorial Day committee of the Grand Army of the Republic made final arrangements yesterday for the "biggest Memorial Day parade ever held in Manhattan" and hoped for "perfect weather conditions" next Monday. They met at the G. A. R. headquarters in the Municipal Building.

THE Essex County Symphony Society will give four concerts during its third season, beginning June 6, at the City School's Stadium, Newark, N. J. An orchestra of eighty-fire will be conducted by Alexander Smallens at the first three concerts. Grace Moore, soprano, will be the assisting artist at the opening concert.

Mr. and Mrs. James M. McGarry of 430 West 119th Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Agnes McGarry, to Dr. Theodor Karl Just of South Bend, Ind., son of Mrs. Alois Just of Krems, Austria, and the late Mr. Just.

In the review of "China Fights for Her Life" in THE TIMES of April 8, Mr. Nathaniel Peffer, your reviewer, refers to the fact that I "went to China as a war correspondent last Summer after the war with China began," giving the impression-obviously unintentional-that this was my only time in China.

Motor failure during the take-off of a small plane, followed by a crash within view of spectators who were watching other planes arrive and depart, resulted in the serious injury of a young pilot and a companion at Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn. last evening.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard Updike Sherman of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Millar Sherman, to August William Nagel of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles August William Nagel.

Martin Nadelman, builder, of Great Neck, L. I., was unanimously re-elected chairman of the board of the Queens Nassau Home Builders League at a meeting of the governors last week. He is treasurer of Sterlingshire, Inc., and of the United Associates Corporation.

Every gardener needs at times,a quantity of rich earth for special purposes. Among many uses such a compost affords soil for potting flowers and plants, for coveringg delicate seeds, and for giving to transplanted plants a ready impetus to vigorous growth. Since it is not to be had. in the: garden itself,- and cannot readily be bought, the best plan is to prepare such soil and set it aside for use when needed.

Scooting around a triangle of 18 3/4. miles on Long Island Sound today, Frederick T. Bedford's new international twelve-meter yacht Nyala, launched only three days ago, easily defeated Clinton H. Crane's Gleam, last year's product of the class, and Van S. Merle-Smith's Seven Seas, which came out two years ago.

ABRAMS-Vivian (nee Martin), beloved wife of Abraham and devoted mother of Kenneth Irwin. Funeral services Sunday, May 22, 10:30 A. M., at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 2d Ave. at Penn St., New York City. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery.

TRADE reports became spottier in the week, with the average probably lower for the country. Weather conditions held down demand in many sections. Apparel sales are holding up better than the general trade figures and home furnishing volume continues to show a wide lag.

The fourth round of the annual championship series of the Interscholastic Chess League was contested yesterday at the Manhattan Chess Club. Townsend Harris Hall drew its match with De Witt Clinton, 2-2, and moved into first place.
More than 3,500 young women took mental tests yesterday for twenty-seven anticipated vacancies as policewomen with salaries of $2,000 a year.
Lieut. Col. Walter Buller, British bridge expert, died today. He was 51 years old. Colonel Buller sponsored the first international bridge match here in 1930 against a team headed by Ely Culbertson.

Grand Marshal Robert S. Heilferty of the G. A. R. Memorial Day parade and commanders on his staff will be entertained at a dinner to be given for them on Wednesday by the New York Unit of the Women's Overseas League. Miss Mary

" Nothing would tend to arouse the American people more quickly than any effort by the German Government to influence former German subjects who are now naturalized citizens of the United States," Dr. Jacob Gould Schurman, former United States Ambassador to Germany, declared today on the eve of his eighty-fourth birthday.

Harry C. Folsom of Greenwich, Conn., has announced the engagement of his niece, Miss Mary Folsom, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clyde H. Folsom of this city and Rumford Center, Me., to Carlton G. Champe, son of Mrs. George Champe of Toledo, Ohio, and the late Mr. Champe.

Miss Olivia Heather Jarrett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin S. Jarrett of New York and Shepherdstown, W. Va., was married here this afternoon in the Church of St. Philip's-in-the-Highlands to Dr. Edmund Prince Fowler Jr., grandson

Five young industrial executives, three of whom are employed in New York State, were declared today winners in a national competition for the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation fellowships for a year's graduate study in Business Administration and Economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Mr. and Mrs. Chester T. Neal of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Crist Neal, to Lloyd Wesley Roberts, son of Mrs. John A. Roberts of Akron, Ohio.

The Wage-Hour Bill is scheduled to come up in the House tomorrow for debate. Comment upon that measure up to now has tended to focus on the question of wage rates to the neglect of the question of hours.

Opposed to the holding of the 1940 Olympic Games in Japan, Dr. G. Randolph Manning, veteran officer of the United States. Football Association, controlling body of amateur soccer in this country, has tendered his resignation as a member of the American Olympic Association, it was learned last night.

A cavern with earlier inscriptions, one of which is attributable to the first century B. C., has been discovered by the Archaeological Survey of India on the top of the Rock Fort, Trichinopoly, South India.
