The government and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have decided to cooperate in an effort at long-range weather forecasting, but it will be done secretly at first.

These last few days have been given by Philadelphia to the dedication of Franklin Institute. After 100 years of service given to the advancement of science and the arts, citizens from all parts of our country and representatives of the great educational institutions have gathered here.

Guatemala contends that Great Britain owes that country a road 200 miles in length from the Atlantic Coast to the capital in accordance with a treaty concluded in 1859, and wants President Roosevelt to arbitrate the claim. The Diario Latino of this city calls upon the other Central American republics to support Guatemala with a solid front against Britain.
An exhibition of masterpieces art, from the age of Pericles to modern times, may be a feature of the New York's World's Fair, according to an announcement yesterday.

On Wake Island, in the Pacific Ocean, about 19 degrees north of the Equator and just across the International Date Line-an island uninhabited and devoid of all but the hardiest forms of vegetation less than three years ago-there blooms this Spring one of the most unusual gardens to be found anywhere.

LONDON. ALTHOUGH the National Book Fair of last November was on the whole a successful exhibition, several features of it provoked sharp criticism alike from publishers, booksellers and members of the general public.

Several flower shows, featuring tulips, peonies, iris and other perennials, are scheduled for this week. The Spring Flower Show of the Scarsdale Garden Club will be held at the Children's House on Tuesday from 3 to 10 P. M. Several children's classes are listed on the schedule, and entries are open to residents of Scarsdale, Hartsdale, Greenburgh and Upper Eastchester.

John Marbach, president of the Westchester County Realty Board, has written to the county delegates to the Constitutional Convention urging them to oppose the exemption of bond issues from constitutional limitations and asking them to give thought to the proposal that an amendment be adopted which would provide for the establishment of a State Board of Tax Review.

Mr. and Mrs. Raymond P. Morse of Scarsdale, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Morse, to Frank Bartlett Harrington, son of Mr. and -Mrs. Fred P. Harrington, also of Scarsdale.
WHEN in doubt, lead trumps. That's what they used to say in the old days of auction bridge, and that's what they're saying now in the motion picture industry. Hal B. Wallis, who is next to Jack L.
Two bills authorizing construction of three toll bridges in Long Island awaited President Roosevelt's signature today.

Another brilliant Gaelic football team, Leix, the Leinster champion, will meet a selected New York out-fit today at the Yankee Stadium. The contest, the second in the round-robin series for. the- Interna??ional Trophy, will mark the first Appearance of the invaders in this country.

Hearty approval has been given by realty, building and mortgage interests in Bergen County, N. J., to the efforts being made by the North Jersey Transit Committee to coordinate all of the existing North Jersey agencies in a concerted campaign to obtain improved transit facilities for Northern New Jersey.

The policy consistently followed by the Roosevelt Administration for the past five years toward Latin America stands at the crossroads today in consequence of the expropriation of American and British-owned oil properties by Mexico.

In its first change of quarters in seventeen years, the Van Raalte Company, manufacturers of women's gloves, hosiery, silk underwear and sportswear, leased about 17,500 square feet of space on the second floor of 417 Fifth Avenue for showrooms and offices.
Perhaps there is some connection between Ambassador Bullitt's extensive caviar purchases in Moscow and the rumor that

Jose Ramon Guitierrez, the Chilean Foreign Minister, arrived here today for a short stay as the guest of the Brazilian Government. He is repaying the visit that the former Brazilian Foreign Minister, Jose Carlos de Macedo Soares, recently paid to Chile.

A grave view is being taken today in Moscow on the eve of the municipal elections in Czechoslovakia. The opinion here is that the German Nazis, who are considered the masters of the Henlein party in Czechoslovakia, are laying the groundwork for the partition of Czechoslovakia in much the same manner as they prepared for the annexation of Austria.

Complete control of imports has been taken by Ecuador in order to aid in reducing the exchange rate of the sucre to 13.50, or lower, for the United States dollar, since the rate recently passed 14, according to the Telegrafo.

The firmness of Great Britain in her dealings with the Mexican Government with respect to the seized oil properties of British subjects is due largely to a desire to keep inviolate the time-honored principles of international commerce and to the necessity of maintaining adequate oil supplies for her navy, both of which are absolutely essential to the well-being of the British people.

As of March 31, ten lending institutions in New Jersey had done more than $1,000,000 worth of business each under the Federal Housing Administration's insured mortgage system, Thomas E. Colleton, State FHA director, announced yesterday.

Before a crowd of 34,600 which turned out for the first warm day of the New England racing season, Ogden Phipps's Teufel today-won the $10,000-added Puritan Handicap by a head from W. V. McGrath's South American importation, Peligroso II, in one of the most thrilling stretch battles seen at Suffolk Downs this year.

The following open letter to William Lescaze broaches a question of moment concerning the future of American artists and architects. The writer is Mabel Dodge Luhan, who has been identified with the artistic and literary colony at Taos, N. M., for many years:

WOODSTOCK.-This art colony is busy preparing for its coming Summer season. Besides its customary attractions for painters, writers and musicians, several new entertainment features have been added, the principal one being the Maverick Little Symphony Orchestra, formed to give a series of outdoor popular concerts, starting the afternoon of the Fourth of July and continuing on Saturday afternoons through Labor Day.

Dartforth, brown gelding from the stables of Mrs. J. W. Y. Martin, won a thrilling three and'one-half mile timber race for the Gloucester Fox Hunters Plate as the Rose Tree Spring hunts meeting closed today before 10,000 persons. J. D. Hamilton rode Dartforth.
George F. Lederer, the municipality's building superintendent since 1934, died early today at his home here after a four months' illness. His age was 34.

With the capture of Suchow Japan's armies are able to enter a new stage in their attempted conquest of China. The fall of Suchow means that the Japanese have now secured a new line of communications running north and south that may allow them to make a sustained military effort for the capture of Chengchow, important railway center, and Hankow, provisional capital of China.

Girls Service League-Tea. Leo Lentelli, speaker on "Sculpture in the Making," 6 P. M., clubhouse, 138 East Nineteenth Street. Rutherford (N. J.) Junior Woman's Club-Annual mother and daughter dinner, 7 P. M.
SUMMER travel is just ahead, with holiday trips all over the continent in prospect, and from now until after Labor Day thousands of patrons will pick up the menu in the railroad dining car.

IN "The Crowning of a King" Arnold Zweig continues his mental chronicle of the war, with no hint from the publishers as to when he will conclude it. This fourth volume leads us to a new scene: the Eastern front during the last year of the war, when the German Army, still confident

Merely by picking up a telephone and dialing a given number Weather Bureau observers will soon be able to follow the rise and fall of a near-by river. The reason for devising and installing the automatic gauges is the difficulty of reaching stations during the flood time.
Antonio Ayuso Valdivieso, publisher of the newspaper Imparcial, was arrested today for his failure to report to the government the loss of two revolvers for which he had a government permit.

Kendall Chase outlasted Earl Whitehill in an extra-inning battle of southpaw pitchers today, and Washington edged to a 5-to-4 decision in the twelfth frame to halt the winning streak of the Cleveland Indians at five games.
In an atmosphere of excitement as the result of repeated threats of the Opposition, President Arturo Alessandri reopened this afternoon the ordinary sessions of the Chilean Congress.
Opening of the first free fresco painting class in the United. States was announced yesterday by the WPA adult education program of the New York City Board of Education.

The four-story tenement house at 61 1/2 and 63 East 125th Street, east of Madison Avenue, will be sold by Joseph P. Day in the Vesey Street salesrooms on June 2, by order of Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance.
Marked interest in the promotional possibilities of television receivers was shown by department store merchandisers following the announcement a few days ago of low price equipment.
Beset by competition and unable to earn a profit, the Quincy, Omaha

The Amorphophallus Lily, called the "Sacred Lily of India," makes an unusual house plant. It needs headroom and space-for it attains a height of over seven and a half feet. This lily, which belongs to the Arum family, is indigenous to the part of Southern China bordering on India.
THE author of this book was the last Chancellor of independent Austria before its absorption by

" Gauleiter [District leader] Joseph Buerckel must achieve Austria's political, economic and cultural unification with the German Reich before May 1, 1939," reads an order issued by Chancellor Hitler on April 25.

Mrs. Donald E. Cameron of Brookline today won the Massachusetts women's tennis singles championship by defeating Mrs. Virginia Rice Johnson of the Longwood Cricket Club, 1-6, 8-6, 6-4, in a spirited match of more than two and a half hours.

WHEN on next Wednesday Bill Robinson rounds out threescore years he will put on his thin, wooden-soled dancing shoes and take a few steps just to put old Time to shame. For the passing years apparently

Historic Fort Schuyler, in the Throg's Neck section of the Bronx, reclaimed from a moldering heap of masonry and converted into a modern maritime training school through a $4,250,000 WPA project, was dedicated yesterday as the land base of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy at exercises witnessed by more than 1,500 persons.

A two-year plan aimed to remove the handicaps that a woman medical graduate encounters when she eeks an interneship will be launched this week by a committee of women doctors formed by Alpha Epsilon Iota, the women's national medical fraternity.

Costumes from remote corners of the earth and other days will be displayed together with their modern translations by American designers in the second exhibition which the Museum of Costume Art will present tomorrow evening at Rockefeller Center, 610 Fifth Avenue.
RECESSION or no recession, the season of 1937-38 has been an active and usually interesting one, both as to strictly artistic matters and as to organizational affairs of one sort and another.

The first blue ribbon of the day at the Wilmington Horse Show today went to Primvera, owned and ridden by 15-year-old Miss Ellie Wood Keith of Charlottesville, Va., in the children's conformation hunters.
Ivan Papanin, commander of Soviet Russia's Arctic ice floe campers, has completely shaken up the office management of the Northern Sea Route Administration, newspapers disclosed today.

Officers of the National Republican Club yesterday characterized as "a gesture" the resignations of Kenneth F. Simpson and Arthur A. Ballantine, former Under Secretary of the Treasury, as members of the club's executive committee in protest against recent criticism of last year's fusion by John R. Davies, president of the club.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 19: REAR ADMIRAL Richardson, J. O., Naval Operations, to duty as Chief of Bureau of Navigation, Washington, June 10. CAPTAIN
Miss Margaret Mallory has appointed a junior committee to assist in the seventeenth annual book drive of the American Merchant Marine Library Association, which was inaugurated on Thursday.

Many women are now asking themselves: "What kind of a Summer am I going to have, and have I the proper luggage?" Both for those who are going to take short breathers over the Decoration Day week-end and other week-ends, with perhaps a two-week vacation thrown in, and for those who are going to Europe there is new luggage in the shops, handsome stuff.

The stock market experienced another week of uncertainty. Prices averaged lower and trading was dull. THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks declined 2.72 points, on the basis of the closing level of 79.90, reducing the gain on the month, thus far, to 1.98 points.

Six gardens in Princeton will be opened to the public on the morning and afternoon of June 3 as the last in the series of three garden visiting days arranged by the Woman's Auxiliary of the Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey.

William Winfield Spaid of Washington, D. C., a partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of W. B. Hibbs Co. of Washington, with which he had been associated for nearly forty years, died here early, yesterday morning in the Doctors Hospital. He was 58 years old.
General business in the Dominion of Canada always reflects the current trend in the United States, but the Canadian reflection is usually conservatively toned down.

If the present attitude of Konrad Henlein as reported from London is any criterion, the prospects of agreement between him and the government of his country are brighter than at any time since Hitler's invasion of Austria.

After a conference lasting six hours between representatives of the Gulf Oil Company and other oil operators and the International Longshoremen's Association in a downtown office last night, it was considered likely that the strike that has been on since Thursday

Army defeated Fordham today in their annual baseball game by a score of 3 to 2. A capacity crowd of 7,000 filled the stands and hung on the ropes about the field. It was a battle of pitchers, with Tom Davis keeping the seven Fordham hits well scattered.

WHEN the lightning strikes three times on Broadway it isn't lightning any longer. It is a tradition. So Dwight Deere Wiman, offering three musicals in as many Springs, has given a tradition to this ivycovered sector called Times Square.

Capturing the last three events Hicksville High won the tenth annual North Shore track and field championship today by scoring 42 1/2 points to lead Port Washington by eleven, with Oyster Bay third and Glen Cove and Sea Cliff tied for fourth.
A perjury charge today faced Charles Hyslop, the man responsible for the "Earl Page" name mystery on the Democratic primary ticket.

A number of public figures, prominent in the fields of social service and child guidance, donned false whiskers yesterday to caricature school teachers, principals and guidance workers before an audience of 500 educators and social workers here.

The government wheat committee met today at the call of Premier Benito Mussolini to consider Italy's drought-created wheat shortage and authorized an increase of approximately 7 per cent in wheat prices.

A survey of the position of religious, racial and nationality groups on American college and university campuses will be undertaken by a group of Columbia University professors headed by Robert S. Lynd, chairman of the university's department of sociology and co-author of "Middletown" and "Middletown in Transition."

The sale of a note of the Carolina, Clinchfield Ohio Railway for $14,150,000 to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the proceeds to be used to meet the maturity on June 1 of a similar amount of 5 per cent thirty-year bonds of the railway, was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
Is there a neutrino or isn't there? The physicists have been discussing the question ever since the Italian physicist Fermi invented the particle to meet an urgent need.

What he calls a "new sign" in the investment field is the decision recently made by a large life insurance company, announces Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, to make loans on industrial properties.
A week of parades, exhibitions and civic parties will feature the 250th birthday celebration of New Rochelle in June, it was announced today by the Mayor's committee in charge of arrangements.
THERE are but few authors whose lives have held as little of struggle and disappointment as the one Mr. Maxwell reveals for us in his autobiography, "Time Gathered."

Continuing a controversy with the Guaranty Trust Company, Robert R. Young, chairman of the Alleghany Corporation, issued yesterday a statement in which he asserted that, by backing C. L. Bradley, deposed president of Alleghany, and John P. Murphy, deposed
Vincent J. Eck, architect for the Catholic Diocese of Trenton, died last night of a heart attack at his home, Buttonwood Park, in Shrewsbury. He was 45 years old.

Visting nurses from three societies participating in the $10,000,000 campaign of the Greater New York Fund made 881,264 calls on 159,961 patients last year, according to a report submitted to the fund yesterday by the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service, the Brooklyn Visiting Nurse Association and the Staten Island Visiting Nurse Association.

Bishop Loughlin Memorial High of Brooklyn, winner of the senior team crown for the past three years, was dethroned by La Salle Military Academy of Oakdale, L. I., yesterday in the twenty-first annual Athletic Association of Private Schools track and field championships at Baker Field.
Henry P. Chapman Jr., 21 years old, of 404 North Ridgewood Road, manager of the Lehigh University track team, who returned from college for the week-end, died early today at Orange Memorial Hospital.

Lord Nuffield, Great Britain's biggest motor manufacturer and a large-scale public benefactor, has patched up his quarrel with the Air Ministry and agreed to place his industrial resources at the disposal of the government for building war planes.

A concerted policy by North European nations toward application of the League of Nations much discussed "sanctions article," which hitherto was hampered by Finland's attitude, seems now definitely assured.

THE Westminster Festival Week, consisting of the Talbott and Contemporary Mu sic Festivals of the Westminster Choir School, opens tomorrow at Princeton, N. J. The speakers include Dr. Curt Sachs, Dr. Henry Allen Moe, Dr. Edwin Stringham, Dr. John Mackay and Dr. John Finley Williamson, president of the Westminster Choir School.
Dr. Charles Diller Ryan of New York City has purchased the sixteen-acre estate in South Wilton, Conn., formerly owned by Dr. Landen Francis Humphries.

The Naumburg Orchestra will begin its annual Summer series of four outdoor concerts on the evening of Decoration Day, on the Central Park Mall. This series was founded by Elkan Naumburg and has been continued annually after his death by his sons, Walter W. and George W. Naumburg, in his memory, as a gift to the people of New York City.

In calling attention to the desirability of storing storm sash and doors properly when taken down in the Spring, the FHA points out that if the home owner wishes to construct a special storage room in the attic, the basement, or in the upper part of the garage, funds may be obtained from a private financial institution operating under the property improvement credit plan of the FHA.

Home sales and new construction continued to show substantial activity in the New Jersey suburban sections during the past week. One of the fine residences in Montclair, at 162 Upper Montclair Avenue, was purchased by George E. Stringfellow, vice president of Thomas A. Edison, Inc., from Charles S. Barrett Jr.

BERMUDA consists largely of three bodies of water surrounded by coral. Any one who has ever been to Bermuda knows that there is a lot of water in and around it, but that fact is never so self-evident as from the air, when flying to that outlying dot in the Atlantic.

The Air Ministry-sponsored experiment aiming to prove whether or not it is possible for an aviator to stand the substratosphere lack of air pressure for a "practical" length of time ended yesterday when Dr. Richon and Airport Official M. Artola stepped from a specially constructed chamber where they had remained for forty-eight hours under conditions reproducing those prevailing at a 21,000-foot altitude.
Ambassador and Mrs. Joseph Kennedy gave a dinner party Tuesday in honor of Foreign Secretary and Viscountess Halifax.

Miss Edith Heermance, daughter of the Rev. Edgar L. Heermance and Mrs. Heermance of this city, was married to Halsey Munson Hicks, son of Mrs. Arthur W. Hicks of Summit, N. J., and the late Mr. Hicks, this afternoon at Rocky Top, the Heermance Summer place here.

In the first four months of this year, the public purchased more than $2,000,000,000 of new ordinary life insurance, according to the Life Insurance Sales Research Bureau. The bureau estimated that these sales were 21 per cent less than in the corresponding period last year.
Edward T. Stotesbury, the Morgan partner who headed Drexel Co. of this city, left to his widow, a daughter and three grandchildren his estate of undisclosed value, but supposedly worth millions.

Private utilities received specific assurances today when the Senate Appropriations Committee, reporting out a relief-recovery bill involving loans and expenditures of about $3,450,000,000, wrote into the measure drastic restrictions on government-financed utilities.

Under a bill signed recently by the President the War Department during the next four years will establish a Regular Army Reserve of about 75,000 men. Though the army has had for many years an Officers Reserve Corps, which numbers today more than 100,000 officers, it has never had an adequate enlisted reserve of men trained as soldiers.

An All-Home Economics Day will be held Monday by the students of the School of Home Economics at Drexel Institute of Technology, as the climax of the year's activities of the Drexel Home Economics and Dietetics Clubs.
The Liberal Government headed by Prime Minister Mackenzie King will seek a new mandate, possibly this year but more probably next year, on ??he issue of national unity.

Confidence in the railroads cannot be restored "until those in control of the properties do something about the wage bill," George P. McNear Jr., president of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad, asserted in his report for 1937, issued yesterday.
Desperate Chinese attacks against the Japanese forces that are pushing in increasing numbers toward the Lung-Hai Railway from Western Shantung mark the progress of Sino-Japanese hostilities.

IN many period rooms today French pieces are introduced to give that suave air which Gallic decoration at its best expresses. The graceful curves of a Louis XV chair may contribute the Parisian accent, or the straight lines of a Louis XVI sofa merge into a later Directoire ensemble.

Many luncheon parties were given yesterday in conjunction with the flower and fashion show held at the formal opening of Chatham Walk in aid of the work for the blind at the Sacred Heart Convent in Kenwood, Albany, N. Y.

Rookie Max West celebrated his promotion to the clean-up batting position today by pounding out a pair of home runs as he paced the Bees to their sixth straight victory, a 5-1 margin over the Cardinals.
Estimated expenditures for all types of building throughout the country increased 6.6 per cent during April when compared with March, according to the current issue of Building.
Although he wasn't around at the finish, Vernon Kennedy was credited with his sixth straight pitching triumph today as the Tigers beat the Athletics, 7 to 5.

British apprehension over Czechoslovakia continued today. It caused the Foreign Office to send Sir Neville Henderson, the Ambassador in Berlin, to seek reaffirmation of the assurances he received yesterday from under-officers of the German Foreign Ministry to the effect that any troop movements

Three thousand children, most of them dressed in chorister robes of differing colors and design, packed the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday afternoon for the twentyseventh annual service at which Sunday schools of the New York diocese present their Lenten collections for the national and foreign mission work of the church.

A growing interest in the study of public opinion and journalism among the student body at Princeton University is evidenced by a survey of the theses submitted as independent work by the graduating class of '38. This year,

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: This country is faced with the most serious railroad crisis in its history. The earnings of all Class I railroads available for interest for the first quarter of 1938 amounted to $19,000,000.

SPAIN in the grip of the current civil war is the locale of Max well Anderson's third original radio drama, "The Bastion Saint Gervais," to be presented in a halfhour broadcast on Wednesday night at 9 o'clock. Station WJZ will be the New York outlet.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney has announced plans for a mass meeting to be held at Mecca Temple Wednesday night to enlist American public opinion in behalf of some action to induce Great Britain to lift immigration restrictions against European Jewish refugees into Palestine.

Harvard's varsity polo team beat Yale, 8 to 6, at Myopia today. Von Stade, Harvard's number three, scored in each of the first three chukkers, and with two goals by Forbes, the Crimson led, 5 to 3, at half time. Harvard easily held its edge in the closing periods. Forbes had a total of four goals, von Slade three.

A jester and tweedledum in the pageant court of Good Queen Bess looked into the crystal ball during the dress rehearsal yesterday of an Elizabethan May festival to be given at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon by 300 gayly costumed children and young people of Union Settlement, 237 East 104th Street.

Gowned in academic robes, 361 Columbia College seniors will file in formation a week from Tuesday into tree-lined Van Amringe Quadrangle, the central setting of their four undergraduate years, to take part with faculty members in Class Day ceremonies that presage commencement.

The Nazi salute, as now observed by Germans the world over, has a pedigree extending back to Germanic tribal days. The ancient Teutons saluted with the right arm extended almost perpendicularly, whereas the fashion Adolf Hitler introduced in the days of the party's early struggles showed the right arm pitched forward at an angle of about 45 degrees-between the orthodox Roman and Olympic versions.

Vital statistics published today for last year show that French births and deaths decreased from the 1936 figures. Births decreased from 630,059 to 616,863 and deaths of one-year-olds and over from 699,896 to 688,519.

The eastern half of the United States possesses one of the richest floras of the world. Many of its trees, shrubs and herbs are acceptable for garden use. The fact that they grow "wild" does not make their decorative qualities less valuable, but Europeans were quicker than Americans to appreciate several of our native plants.

In an effort to combat the rising tide of serious highway accidents by night, which is out of proportion to the traffic volume, New York and Michigan are experimenting with methods of making road visibility better without increasing direct illumination. These experiments are described in the following articles.

Youth was challenged today by Dr. Willis R. Whitney, vice president in charge of research of the General Electric Company, to further scientific progress through greater "inquisitiveness," even "guessing."

IN advance of the opening, on June 11, of an exposition of paint ing and sculpture in the Palace of Versailles, France is issuing a 1.75franc plus 75-centimes stamp illustrating the edifice. France thus publicizes a national arts show which will have "The Age of Louis XIV" as its theme.
The City Council ratified unanimously today the proposed TVAcity purchase of electric properties of the Tennessee Public Service Company.

For detached single-family dwellings the land-planning section of the FRA recommends minimum lot widths of fifty to sixty feet. The future desirability of a home community, it is pointed out, depends to a great extent upon the method

Announcement was made yesterday of the formation of the American Woman's party with headquarters at 156 West Fortyfourth Street. The purpose of the organization, said to be nonpartisan, .is to oppose all "isms" except Americanism, to foster well-being of the people by other means than wanton waste of tax money and to support for

Abial B. Anthony, a Negro tonsorial artist of this city, claims the honor of being the oldest barber in active service in the United States. He reached his ninety-ninth birthday on May . And he is still shaving his patrons with a steady hand.

While 'others collapsed around them, Princeton's trackmen hewed to the line today and discovered that it was the straight line that led them to their first heptagonal meet championship. The Tigers, meeting totally unexpected competition from Cornell, took the lead at the twelfth event and coasted the rest of the way.

THE editors of Harper's Magazine found themselves very much disturbed by the looseness with which politicians. and publicists use such terms as democracy, liberty, equality of opportunity, local self-rule;
The Misses Cecilia and Ma e vom Rath arrived on the Columbus and are at the Gladstone. Mr. and Mrs. Earnest Elmo Calkins of 580 Park Avenue are at their Summer home near Lakeville, Conn.

In all the long category of garden plants there is perhaps no group so generally overlooked by the beginner as that known as theSummer flowering bulbs. It is a "group" in a cultural sense only, as it includes many species not related botanically.

The annual benefit bridge party and tea sponsored by the Greenwich Exchange for Women's Work will be augmented this year by a fashion show. It will be held on Wednesday at the Round Hill Country Club here.

Stephen H. Thiermann of Milwaukee has been chosen head of Haverford College's unique Janitors' school for next year. The school started in 1934 and was originally intended for the Negro kitchen-workers and janitors of the college, but this year It was expanded to include outsiders.

More than 10,000,000 barrels of fuel oil will be required to fuel the fleet in the fiscal year beginning July 1, the Navy Department announces. Contracts have been signed for the delivery of 7,979,030 barrels of oil, all earmarked for "West Coast requirements," of which 256,430 barrels are for Diesel engines at a price of $5,381,572.45.
Dr. William M. Kingsley, treasurer of New York University for thirty-four years, has resigned as chief financial officer of the university, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase announced yesterday.

What is said to be the first twostory all-masonry residence in the Flushing area of Queens is nearing completion by Town Builders, Inc., at Twenty-eighth Avenue and 156th Street and will be on exhibit next week.

THE public house is a major force in Irish life and letters. Every reader of "Ulysses" remembers with delight the ebullient scene in Barney Kiernan's pub. Every one who has seen or read O'Casey's "Plough and the Stars" remembers the strong dynamics of its barroom second act.
Eliezer Falk, for many years controller of the Mount Pleasant Cemetery of the Ethical Culture Society of New York, died on Thursday at the Knickerbocker Hospital of a heart attack.

An investigation of reports that residents of Southern States are flocking to Mount Vernon and settling down on "easy" relief, which they were unable to obtain in the South, has been ordered by Mayor Denton Pearsall Jr.

Mr. Morley, a London director and playwright, has devoted the past three months to judging the entries all through the Dominion in the 1938 Canadian Drama Festival. The final competition was held in Winnipeg last week.

An upswing in the dollar volume of Manhattan's "open-market" realty transactions, accompanied by evidence of a stiffening of values, was noted in the survey of transfers for April, according to the monthly market report compiled by the Real Estate Board of New York.

Experts rate the sulphuric acid drainage from bituminous coal mines as the most destructive of all forms of trade waste pollution. The acid destroys metal boat bottoms, boiler tubes and steel water-lock equipment.
Princeton's varsity lacrosse team wound up its season today by turning back a favored Army ten, 8-2, on University Field. It was the sixth victory in ten starts for the Tigers.

The jury which has been chosen to decide whether some of the coal companies of Harlan County hired peace officers to help them keep union organizers away was taken to the cemetery today for relaxation and exercise.
One hundred and seventy cities and towns in Britain will be visited by over 400 aircraft early next week when ten mass formation flights will be carried out by Royal Air Force.

Once the oratory of commencements is over, campuses of Eastern women's colleges will offer a wide variety of Summer intellectual fare. Children, family relations, world problems, church and social work, industrial progress, music, youth of the world, speech, personnel administration will be offered for study.
John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, declared today that his organization planned increased political activities as its unions grew in strength.

The theatrical profession will pay homage to the memory of Henry Irving at a centenary matinee of the Lyceum on Monday. A play by Edward Knoblock, "Here's to Our Enterprise"-the title is taken from the first words spoken by Irving on the professional stage-will be performed by leading players of today.

A Gershwin memorial concert, an all-Stravinsky program, two performances of Bizet's opera, "Carmen," and the engagements of several noted soloists are announced as features of the twenty-first season of the Lewisohn Stadium Concerts which will begin on June 23.
Mr. and Mrs. John English Cairns of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jaqueline Vera Cairns, to Harold A. Finley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Finley, also of Brooklyn.

To take effect 8 A. M., May 23: Patrolmen: Alfonso M. Marino, from 9th Precinct to 18th Division, assigned to duty as chauffeur. J. Wesley Lyle, from 92d Precinct to 19th Division, Office of the Chief Inspector, for duty with Bureau of Equipment. John C. Wilson. from 17th Division to Traffic Precinct F.

Miss Meredith Haines, daughter of Lieut. Col. Edgar Fremont Haines, Medical' Corps, U. S. A., and Mrs. Haines of Governors Island, has selected June 17 as the date for her marriage to Donald Frederick Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Frederick Taylor of Melrose, Mass.

Total employment in the steel industry has actually increased rather than declined as a result of the large-scale adoption of continuous rolling mills and other technological advances in mill equipment, according to a survey completed by the American Iron and Steel Institute covering a period of eleven years.
After winding up Chile's affairs in the League of Nations, from which she has resigned, Agustin Edwards, former delegate at Geneva and now Ambassador to London,

GROUP and solo shows of the waning season continue to offer New York art lovers a varied assortment of attractions in the galleries. The first of the exhibitions that are to remain for the Summer are among the newly opened shows and in these events women artists have taken the lead.

Following a course somewhat similar to that in stocks, bonds, with the exception of United States Government obligations and certain utility issues, drifted irregularly lower yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

Strains of Wagner and Schubert may replace worms and squid as bait for fish, if the results of a lengthy study made here by Dr. Maurice Klein, physician and research physicist, find acceptance among the fishing fraternity.
LILIENFELD--WEISSLER--Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Weissler announce the betrothal of their daughter, Frances, to Dr. Jack Lillenfeld, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Lillenfeld, May 22.
Photographs of many American homes will be examined during the next fourteen months in a nationwide photographic housing contest sponsored by Ethel Traphagen, publisher of Fashion Digest.

Archaeologists, digging in the proper places, find layer after layer of pottery, ashes, paving stones, coins, and the like, which tell them that they are passing through successive stages of human culture.

The blare of bugles and the beat of drums mingled with the wheeze of the calliope and the raucous voices of side-show barkers as more than 5,000 Girl Scouts marched yesterday morning along the Coney Island amusement front to Steeplechase Park, where they celebrated their seventh annual "play day" on the flying turns, the big slide and the twisting caterpillar.
The usual crop of unusual novelties is found among the hundreds of new inventions whose specifications have just been announced by the British Patent Office.

The author of the following article is a spokesman for both business and government. As a business man he is known for his first-hand knowledge of Wall Streethe was formerly a member of the Stock Exchange. His role in government promises to grow in importance-he went to Washington as a commissioner of the SEC and will soon assume the office of Assistant Secretary of the Treasury.

SOME fifteen thousand motorists are expected to pour into Nova Scotia during the coming week-end for the annual Annapolis Valley Apple Blossom Festival, May 28 to 30, at Kentville. The peninsula as a whole

George W. Loft, well-known former candy manufacturer, announced plans yesterday to divide his fortyacre estate at Baldwin, L. I., into building plots and develop a new residential community of 189 families there.

Prospective home builders and buyers in the metropolitan district are showing an interest in alumi num windows, according to reports received from eight manufacturers and distributors of this product here.
CARRARA-Mr. and Mrs. Charles, announce birth of a daughter, May 19, 1938, at Polyclinic Hospital. CHAFFIE-Dr. and Mrs. Jacob D., announce birth of a son, May 17, 1938, at Polyclinic Hospital.

The campaigns against tuberculosis and syphilis will be discussed at the annual meeting of the State Charities Aid Association and its sixty-one county and city tuberculosis and public health committees at the Hotel Commodore Tuesday through Thursday, according to an announcement yesterday.

Applications for admission to the freshman class at the Pennsylvania State College for the next academic year are already more than 21 per cent ahead of last year, according to William S. Hoffman, registrar.
Supply contracts valued at $3,768,819 were 'awarded in the week ended on May 19 by eleven Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor announced today.

John Hamilton, Republican national chairman, asserted tonight that President Roosevelt had done and contemplated doing more "to deprive the young people of their right to livelihood and to that economic security which they desire than any man in the United States."

When Premier Mussolini blurted out in his Genoa speech on last Saturday that a successful termination of the FrancoItalian negotiations would depend on events in Spain he probably came nearer speaking the truth in public than almost any other European statesman has done for a long time.
I had a child's wisdom of a thick-hilled country. Fat the land was, swiftly the seeds leapt from their planting In leafrib mold, in shallow furrows of the hanging fields.

Despite the current reaction of business, Government revenues are near an all-time peak. Several factors explain this performance. One is the multiplicity of existing taxes. Another is the imposition of higher rates under the Social Security Act.
Eight hoodlums were imprisoned today for beating Ivan Gudoff, Soviet worker who tried to protect a woman they were annoying.

Frederick H. Wood, lawyer who argued against the government in the Kansas City Stockyards case, sent today to all Senators a defense of the Supreme Court's condemnation of secretaryy Wallace's procedure in the original hearing, involving marketing fees, and denied that the court had reversed itself.

HAMILTON, Bermuda.-Between 400 and 500 members of the National Council of State Garden Clubs of the United States arrive here tomorrow on a convention cruise specially planned to enable them to see some of Bermuda's loveliest gardens.

Pelham St. George Bissell, President Justice of the Municipal Court, will be guest of honor Wednesday night at a testimonial dinner to be given by the Seventy-seventh Division Association at the Hotel Commodore.

Words of greeting in English and French, cadet songs, band music and the sounds of marching men spanned the Atlantic yesterday when radio served for the first time as the medium to link the military academies of the United States and France while citizens of the two nationss listened.

Splashing through the slop with the ease of a mudlark, Ramsey and Coppage's consistent Mucho Gusto defeated Mrs. Louise J. Hickman's Arabs Arrow in a photo finish to annex the twentieth running of the $5,000 added Kentucky Handicap at Churchill Downs today.

POSTERS which have been plastered all over the country are imprinting the new national slogan, "Fitness Wins," indelibly in the minds of every Briton nowadays. Posters of football players, white-flanneled cricketers.
THE Independent Theatre Owners Association of New York took another pot-shot at the Gold Coast producers the other day in an advertisement which appeared in a trade paper.

Lord Baden-Powell returned to England today from a search for health in South Africa. His condition was still precarious. An official reception at. Southampton was cancelled but the noted leader of the Boy Scouts of the world was able to walk down the
Monmouth County Country Club routed Princeton, 11 to l, at polo today. The Princeton. players were at a disadvantage on ponies that were no match for the Monmouth mounts.
Mary Petty Johnston and Constance Currie of New York City have been chosen members of Paint and Patches, the student dramatic association at Sweet Briar College. They are sophomores.

Anton Lang, the Christ of this little Alpine village's world famous Passion Play, was buried today. The village gave "its great son and first burger," who died May 18 in a Munich hospital, "a solemn homecoming."

THE first new exposure-meter making full provision for speed rating requirements of the ultra-speed films has been announced. Without the use of multipliers or adapters, the new meter will record light values requiring from sixty seconds to onethousandth of a second shutter speeds and aperture stops ranging from f:2 to f:32.

French anxiety over Czechoslovakia's situation is somewhat mitigated by some important considerations, of which the first is the activity and concern the British Government has shown. Another is that Prague has reported that it is confident there will be no serious disturbance and no direct threat to the frontier.
Horseshoe pitchers from Manhattan won both doubles and singles titles yesterday afternoon in the interborough play-offs sponsored by the Department of Parks.

A triple line of WPA workers and trade union members circled the WPA building at 70 Columbus Avenue, between Sixty-second and Sixty-third Streets, yesterday in protest against the rule limiting total expenditures on WPA whitecollar projects to $1,000 a year for each employee. The rule is scheduled to become effective June 30.

Plans for an educational group to work in behalf of foreign trade on a permanent basis are under discussion by the executive committee in charge of National Foreign Trade Week, it was disclosed last night.

In commemoration of the seventy-fifth anniversary of its dental school, the oldest, in point of continuous educational service, in the country, Temple University will carry out next week an elaborate schedule of academic, scientific and social activities.
ABRAMSON-LEVINE-Mr. and Mrs. Jack Levine, 436 New York Ave., Brooklyn, announce the engagement of their daughter, Ruth, to Milton Abramson of Bensonhurst.

Racking up fourteen strikeouts for a season's record in the International League, the veteran Ted Kleinhans pitched the Chiefs to a 4-to-3 victory over Newark tonight as he beat the club which discarded him two years ago.

Twelve Westchester County specialists in social, vocational and educational guidance conferred under auspices of the Westchester County Recreation Commission at the county office building here today in an effort to coordinate their activities in the approaching Summer camp season for school children.

While the German press fumed with rage today at the alleged "terrorization" of Sudeten Germans and began to hint that the Prague government was losing control of the situation, Sir Nevile Henderson, the British Ambassador, called on Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop this morning to discuss the dangerous turn events were taking.

Many British engineers whose sympathies are with the Spanish Government in Barcelona are voluntarily working overtime in backyard workshops producing motorized equipment for the use of the Loyalist forces.
The Lord Chamberlain's objections to Clare Luce's play, "The Women," because of the attitude of one of the forty women characters toward motherhood may keep the Broadway hit off the English stage.

The country home, surrounded by an acre or more of land and selling in the higher price range, has been in demand during the last month and, while builders, architects and lending institutions have been concentrating on the small house field, the market for the more expensive type of property has been quite active.

ANDY and his lion enter the season's list of children's books with the freshness of a Spring wind. Drawings and text have the genuine humor that appeals to readers all along the line from 6 years to 60.

More than 300 purchasing executives for local companies and corporations in New England left here last night by special train on the Pennsylvania Railroad for St. Louis to attend the twenty-third annual convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, which opens there tomorrow and continues through Thursday.

RECORDING every phase of city life during the day has long been the pastime of New York photographers; now the release of a high-speed film particularly adapted to night photography has reawakened interest in picturing the city at night. And with the renewed interest in night photography there has come a new definition of what constitutes a good picture of the city after dark.
THAT Gabin! He's a tough guy! After seeing me on the screen one naturally comes to that conclusion," says Jean Gabin, the Gallic counterpart of Spencer Tracy. "I admit I am not the romantic type."
A NATION-WIDE contest to determine the economy of operation of Hudson 112 cars will be launched today, according to an announcement made yesterday by officials of the company.

The shipyards of the country will nave to be reh bilitated and expanded to accommodate the tremendous volume of new building of merchant and fighting ships already under way or projected, Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission, forecast in an address here last night.

Led by Pete Grace, who counted five times, Roslyn scored a 12-5 victory over Old Westbury today in a practice polo game at Schiff Field. Tommy Hitchcock and Ivor Balding also starred for the victors. Pete Bostwick, at No. 1 for the losers, also played well and accounted for two of his team's goals.

" Open-house" programs, giving employes opportunity to take visitors through plants, have gained in favor with manufacturers in several lines in the last few weeks, and observers here yesterday suggested that this may lead to an important development in promoting good-will for industry.

With the same readiness with which two weeks ago they brought back and converted their dollars and pounds into francs, the French people this week subscribed in a few hours to a National Defense Loan of 5,000,000,000 francs for which Premier Edouard Daladier's government had asked.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in small volume, consisting principally of small lots of municipal and foreign issues that were called for payment in future months. Only a few additions were made to the list of payments in May.

Rain and cold were blamed again for a decline in retail trade which probably averaged at least 10 per cent, compared with a year ago for the country as a whole, despite gains in a few districts. With apparel lines moving sluggishly, following merchants' preparations for movement of early Summer numbers, totals also were held down by the absence of appreciable activity in such heavy goods as home furnishings, floor coverings and appliances.

A new threat to the Wage-Hour Bill took shape here tonight under the auspices of the National Grange with the starting of a movement to amend the bill by exempting from its provisions all industries engaged in the "processing" of agricultural products.

Rosemary Hall School won a leg on the trophy presented by Mrs. Ruth West Campbell, headmistress of the Greenwich Academy, for having the greatest number of Ave., points in the twenty-fourth annual junior riding meet held under the auspices of the Greenwich Riding Association at the Round Hill Club outdoor ring today.

A tall young man who spent parts of three years on a tour of prisons listening to the troubles of youths behind the bars was identified yesterday as John D. Rockefeller 3d, namesake grandson of "the richest man in the world."

Herbert Hoover drew upon the sayings of Poor Richard, "patron saint of the altogether characteristic American, the self-made man," in a slyly humorous attack upon the New Deal at a dinner tonight and in the three days of ceremonies dedicating the Benjamin Franklin Memorial of the Franklin Institute.

With President Roosevelt watching from up forward on the admiral's boat, the crimson tips of the- varsity crew from his alma mater remained in the front rank of rowing when they glinted in the sun on the Severn tonight and brought Harvard home a scant length in front of Navy. The Crimson still is undefeated.

It seems that New Jersey is not going to fight the "striped bass war" alone, for we received word from the Federated Rhode Island Sportsmen's Clubs that they are still in a "fighting mood" for legislation to protect and conserve these game fish.

The Scots-Americans, champions of the American Soccer League, today defeated the St. Mary's Celtics of Brooklyn, 4 to 2, at Scots Field. The victors will take the field with a 2-point lead tomorrow afternoon when the return match of the final double-header will be played at Celtic Park in Brooklyn.

Stocks closed from fractions to 2 points net lower in dull trading; turnover, 286,070 shares. Bonds irregularly lower in slightly more active trading; U. S. Government issues strong, public utilities firm, foreign loans mixed; transactions, $2,663,000.

Hurling the 12-pound shot 59 feet 1 1/2 inches for a new national interscholastic record and tossing the discus 151 feet 1 inch for a new meet mark, Al Blozis, burly Dickinson High School athlete, provided the sensation of the ninth annual Montclair invitation track championships today at Essex Field.
BALD-Mr. and Mrs. Myer Bald of Toronto announce the bar mitzvah of their son, Karl, Irwin Congregation Shaare Zedek, 212 West 93d St., New York City. May 28, 1938. Staying Hotel Greystone. No cards.

The Rutgers baseball team shattered a fourteen-year jinx when it defeated N. Y. U., 3 to 2, before 1,000 fans on Neilson Field today. The Scarlet last downed the Violets in 1924, when it scored by 1 to 0. Dick Steadman, right-hander, gave only five hits to post the Scarlet's sixth victory of the season.

Deputy Jean Desbons, a leader of French war veterans, today announced resignation of the French delegation from the Permanent International Committee of War Veterans because of election of the German Duke of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha to its presidency.
Mrs. Walter L. Bunnell of Westfield, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ernestine Bunnell, to Albert L. Birdsall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira D. Birdsall of Grand Rapids, Mich.

Washington State College won its sixth successive Northern Division Conference track and field meet today. The Cougars rolled up 48 1/2 points to 40 for Washington. Oregon scored 36 points, Idaho 21, Montana 10 1/2 and Oregon State College 9.

In order to make "every possible contribution to the efficient. handling of the city's affairs," the Real Estate Board of New York has appointed a committee of management experts who have volunteered their services to municipal officials and architects in connection with plans for operating the projected Criminal Courts Building, Jeremiah K. Cronin, vice president of the board, in charge of the management division, announced yesterday.

The Phillippine Islands can supply the United States with every tropical product and food "that you will need in peace or in war," President Manuel Quezon of the Philippine Commonwealth told General James G. Harbord,

Lloyd Harbor is like a New Year's resolution. The wintertime pledge to forsake Lloyd is meant to be broken. Yachtsmen profess and protest from October to May that they will find another week-end haunt for the coming season.

Racing enthusiasts from many sections of the country will attend the fourth annual race-meeting of the Fairfield and Westchester Hounds, to be held here next Saturday afternoon at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club, formerly Bowman Park.

One of the great benefits available to farmers under the amended National Housing Act is the opportunity provided to equip farm buildings with an ample water supply, points out the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau.

Renewed fears of armed conflict in Central Europe growing out of the Czech situation precipitated a serious recession here yesterday in the foreign exchange rates as all the principal foreign currencies weakened against the dollar.

Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons has announced prohibition of the export of iron ore after July 1 following the issuance of a report by the Commonwealth geological adviser that accessible deposits, capable of economic development,

Pennsylvania, thanks to pitcher George Rusznak, gained its first Eastern Intercollegiate League victory of the season today by downing Yale in the eleventh inning on Franklin field, 5-4. It was Rusznak's bat as well as his southpaw pitching arm that eventually turned the tide.

The thirty-fourth Eucharistic Congress will open here Wednesday. Catholics from thirty-seven foreign countries are converging on Budapest and among the arriving pilgrims anxiety prevailed over the possible effect of the Czechoslovak crisis on the attendance from that nation.

Close of play scores in first-class cricket matches started today follow: Somerset 158 (G. Pope five for 41); Derbyshire 135 for two, at Derby. Middlesex 440 for five (Edrich 228 not out, Allen 64 not out, Human 71) vs. Nottinghamshire, at Lord's.

British policy in Europe can be clearly stated. Its object is to free Europe from the overhanging menace of war by coming to terms, if possible, with Germany. To reach an agreement with Adolf Hitler, Great Britain is ready to pay a high price, not excluding some arrangement about colonies.

A STRANGE and picturesque Negress, Mother Catherine, established a thriving religious cult in New Orleans based upon an "anointin' uv de innards." After her "preachments" she concluded her rites by administering to her converts a full glass of warm castor oil on alternate Sundays and gave them Epsom salts in between.

Miss Jeanne Renaud, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph E. Renaud of Forest Hills, Queens, was married to Thomas Edward Shea, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice A. Shea of Riverdale, yesterday noon in the rectory of Corpus Christi Catholic Church, 529 West 121st Street.

HENRY FORD AND GREENFIELD VILLAGE. By William Adams Simonds. Illustrated. 268 pp. New York: Frederick A. Stokes Company. $2. THE custodian of Greenfield Village at Dearborn here guides the reading public not only in the Village itself (which was visited by more than half a million people in 1937) but

A cooperative seminar believed by University of Pennsylvania officials to be unique in the field of oriental studies is to be a feature of a greatly enlarged program dealing with those subjects at the university next year.
The depression has brought a new relief crisis in Illinois. Since last October the total of persons on direct relief has been climbing steadily.
Larry French held the Phillies to five hits today as the Cubs won, 10 to 1. The big left hander, never in trouble, coasted to his second victory of the year behind Chicago's fourteen hits.

Congressional sponsors of legislative proposals that would expand the authority of the Securities and Exchange Commission are concentrating their efforts at this time on moves to obtain final approval in the current session of two

The Musketeer, a dun or buckskin gelding owned by Mrs. Arthur E. Jones of Short Hills and ridden by Thomas N. Tully, was one of the outstanding performers today as the twelfth annual Watchung Riding and Driving Club two-day horse show opened on the picturesque grounds of the Watchung Stables.

Bunty Lawless, the favorite, won the King's Plate today before 20,000 at Woodbine Park. Mona Bell, the early pace-setter, was second and Cabin Gal third. Bunty Lawless, owned by Willie Morrissey of Toronto, charged down the stretch to a convincing triumph in Canada's premier horse race. 'He paid $7.95 for $2. Mona Bell, a Cosgrave Stable filly, was a length and a half back.

AS I motored up to Vogelsang, about an hour from Cologne, to visit there one of the four Fuehrer schools in Germany, I had a long conversation with my elderly guide. If ever there was a complete Nazi, he seemed to be one.

Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, forecast this week another fierce battle to prevent what he calls invasion of the rate-making and regulatory functions of governmental administrative agencies by the courts.

This week's relief crisis in Chicago, when exhaustion of funds for May checks left 91,000 persons dependent upon foodstuffs furnished by the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation, brought into the foreground one of the less-known but nevertheless important relief agencies of the New Deal.
THIRTY-THREE years ago next Saturday the sun above the Sea of Japan set-on the wreckage of an empire--charred wood, battered ships and dead bodies--as the thunder of the Battle of Tsushima died away.

FOR a shilling (25 cents) the tourist in South Wales can enter and inspect historic Cardiff Castle, one of the homes of the Marquess of Bute, who has just sold half the city of Cardiff in a sensationally large real estate deal, said to have involved about $100,000,000.

Don Buffington and Bill Gillespie virtually clinched for Scarborough High School the team championship as the fourth and quarter-final rounds of the eighteenth annual Princeton University tennis interscholastics were completed on the Nassau courts today. The New Yorkers stand 13-9 over Hill School, the current runner-up, which did not place a man in the semi-finals.

Jersey City made it two straight over the Orioles, scoring a 12-to-8 victory in the series final today. Tom Ferrick and Roland Stiles gave up eleven hits while the Little Giants belted a quartet of hurlers for the same number.

Very often these days adults don't seem to have much sense. They spend money on armaments in preference to housing. They shut down factories or go on strike when there plainly isn't enough of the things the factories make. They get themselves killed

The United States Walker Cup team and three other visiting Americans today completed their practice for the British amateur golf championship in a smother of rain, which was the only thing required to complete the setting for the match-play Lest starting Monday.

The holiday spirit has run rampant in the New Jersey Legislature this year. Did not the members take a night off in February to attend former Governor Hoffman's birthday party in New York? Did they not take three weeks off in April to celebrate Easter?

BEFORE an imposing and, if we may say so, a slightly morose assortment of local talent from the body politic, including-Mayor Frank Hague and Governor A. Harry Moore, Ben Marden opened the doors last Wednesday night of his sumptuous Riviera, on the New Jersey end of the George Washington Bridge, and therein uncovered a show which consists of Miss Sophie Tucker.
The New York University women's tennis team bowed to Savage School's representatives, 3-2, yesterday at the Arrow Head courts in the Bronx.

President Clarence A. Dykstra of the University of Wisconsin announced today that a geenral student election would be held at the earliest convenient date in an effort to settle the dispute over the editorship of The Daily Cardinal, university student publication.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

President of the Museum of Modern Art BACK in our salad days a hundred years ago the people of the United States began looking toward Paris for their artistic inspiration. Diaz and Rousseau, Harpignies and Millet became required decoration for the parlors and boudoirs of our first families.

A far-reaching recommendation that the New York City school system, in common with others throughout the State, be granted full fiscal independence with the power to levy taxes and control the educational budget, has been advanced by James Marshall, newly elected president of the Board of Education.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended May 18 aggregated $7,539,000,000, or 5 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 14 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

TORONTO.-Canadian farmers expect no relief from grasshoppers this Summer. A survey made by the Department of Agriculture at Ottawa indicates that the insects in coming months will-cover more territory than ever, some 63,000,000 acres in Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta.

President Lazaro Cardenas is fighting boldly to overcome sharp difficulties facing the Mexican regime as the result of the recent expropriation of huge United States and British oil company properties.

An increase of 10 per cent in the amount of new construction is shown by the survey for April of building in the Chicago suburban region made by the Greenebaum Investment Company. The total for April represented $2,235,828, while $2,028,093 was the March figure.

Miss Gladys Coulter Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Miller of East Orange, and George Robert Magher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Magher of Arlington, were married here this morning in the Church of the Most Blessed Sacrament by the Rev. William V. Dunn,
Policeman Edward H. Wendland, 44, was shot and killed today by one of two men suspected of an effort to rob-a cemetery caretaker's office. The killer and his companion escaped.

WHEN a report foolishly got abroad that the music from his unproduced opera was the music which he was contributing to "The Adventures of Robin Hood," Professor Erich Wolfgang Korngold shivered the timbers. on the Warner lot with a. mixture of rage and mirth.

The marriage of Miss Jeanne Marie Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard B. Smith of Central Drive, to Ernest C. Langley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Langley of Flushing, took place this afternoon at the home of the bride. The Rev. William J. Woon officiated.
Princeton University continued its undefeated Intercollegiate League tennis series when it defeated Pennsylvania today, 6-3. It was the sixth straight victory for the Princeton team.

More than 1,000 boys will participate in the tenth annual "camporee," or short-term camp, of Manhattan Council, Boy Scouts of America, at Kane's Open, Suffern, N. Y., from Saturday through the next Monday, Percy L. Dunn, borough Scout executive, announced yesterday.

Fire today swept through the main building of the Ukranian Catholic Seminary on Glen Brook Road, containing the dormitory of thirty of the schools' sixty-six students, a chapel and library, doing damage estimated at $50,000.

Once he has left the classroom, the college teacher turns his attention to a variety of hobbies as well as academic pursuits, according to a recent survey which shows that sports, arts, domestic interests, science, photography, interior decoration, politics and collecting are the leisure interests of the faculty members questioned.

Following nearly four months of experience with the practical application of the new building code formally put into effect Jan. 27 last, H. I. Feldman, architect, declares that, instead of the anticipated economies, construction on some classes of structures shows higher costs than under the old code.
In the first quarter of this year world trade lost more in volume than it gained during the previous four quarters, according to figures in the League of Nations monthly statistics bulletin today.
Although making only five hits to their opponents' seven, Harvard's freshman baseball team defeated Exeter Academy, 4 to 1, at Soldiers Field today.

Students of Hobart and William Smith Colleges began today their commencement exercises, which will end Monday with awarding of honorary degrees to Katharine Cornell, actress, and William J. Graham, insurance company executive.
Displaying marked superiority, Switzerland humbled England, 2-1, today in an international soccer match before a crowd of 35,000. A week ago the Englishmen defeated Germany, 6-3, at Berlin.

Don Budge and Gene Mako, the Davis Cup doubles champions, flashed their best practice form to date when they routed Elwood Cooke and J. Gilbert Hall in an exhibition doubles match yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.

Marking formal presentation of a membership charter in Tau Kappa Alpha, national forensic honor society, students affiliated with Georgian Court College Debating Club will be guests on Monday at a dinner on the campus here.
Governor Charles H. Martin, critic of the New Deal labor policies, was defeated for renomination in yesterday's Democratic primary by Henry L. Hess, ardent New Dealer, who had the support of labor.

Demetrios Sicilianos, the Greek Minister, will give a check for $174,000 to the Treasury on Monday as a 40 per cent payment on account of the $435,000 due in interest last year for the $50,000,000 loan made by the United States to Greece to aid in
Scoring all of its runs in the first inning today, the Navy took one of the few baseball games it has won from Georgetown in the 50-year-old series. The score was 4 to 3.

According to the newspaper Globo, Colonel Cordeiro de Faria, Federal Interventor for the State of Rio Grande do Sul, told the press at Porto Alegre yesterday that all signs pointed to foreign collusion in the Integralist uprising of May 11.

A TELEVISION scenic "effects" unit is being organized by the National Broadcasting Company. The "props" are to include a fleet of miniature battleships. It is also the duty of this department to prepare decorative titles for the shows and means of displaying them before the cameras.

Discussing some ventures in business which are called speculative, Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, declares that without a certain element of speculation there can be no real progress.

Miss Kathryn MacDonagh of Brooklyn will head the student body of the College of New Rochelle as undergraduate president, and Miss Katherine Cavanaugh of Holyoke, Mass., will assist her as president of the senior class and vice president of the student body, it was announced here today, following class and college elections held during the past week.

The senior class of Vassar College held its annual promenade dance in the Students' Building this evening. The grand march was led by the prom chairman, Mary Elizabeth Klopp of Rosemont, Pa., and Somerset Waters of Baltimore.

Several thousand persons arriving by motor from many sections of New York, New Jersey and Long Island, visited the gardens of Caumsett, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Field on Lloyds Neck and viewed the 3,000 acres of woodland and gardens in a pilgrimage in aid of Greenwich House, of which Mr. Field is president of the board of managers.
BAUM-SWARTENBERG--Mr. and Mrs. A. Swartenberg, Mount Vernon, N. Y., announce the marriage of their daughter, Helen, to Bernard C. Baum of New Rochelle, on Thursday, May 19.

With the imposition of an additional Federal tax of 25 cents a gallon, or 75 cents a case, on all liquors effective July 1, distillers are still trying to decide upon the policy to be followed in handling the levy.

Reports here yesterday indicated complaints have been filed in California under the Unfair Practices Act against the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, alleging sales below cost, and selling at lower prices in one store than in another.

The marriage of Mrs. Katharine Blackwell Cammann, daughter of Mrs. George Engs Blackwell and the late Mr. Blackwell, to H. Thomas Richardson, son of Mr. and Mrs. D. Rait Richardson of 300 Park Avenue, took place yesterday at noon at the home of the bride's mother, 1,170 Fifth Avenue.

The twenty-fourth June conference of the League for Industrial Democracy will be held from June 9 to 12 at Unity House, the country home of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, at Forest Park. Pa. It marks the first time
IT takes great courage to write on ideas. They are such treacherous things. They are a constant source of dispute. They defy successful exposition Else why do the expositors disagree so? If you wish,

Short covering induced by uneasiness over the foreign political situation was largely-responsible for a higher range of prices for wheat futures today. Although the best figures were not maintained, net gains on the Board of Trade ranged up to 3/4 cent a bushel.

SENIOR DIVISION Track Events Mile Run-Won by Howie Bulger, La Salle Academy; Don Carmiencke, La Salle M. A., second: John Troy, St. Francis Prep, third; M. Flynn, St. Augustine's, fourth; J. Frevola, Bishop Loughlin, fifth. Time -4:31.
Today's sixty-mile outboard marathon from Rutherford to Hackensack along the Passaic and Hackensack Rivers is expected to start at 3:30 from the Rutherford Y. C.

Having borrowed about $33,000,000 from the Public Works Administration for the construction of hydroelectric plants, Nebraska's "Little TVA" finds that it must borrow a great deal of additional money before it can begin to realize on its investment.

The Argentine opera season opened last night, with the American tenor, Frederick Jagel, singing Rhadames in "Aida." Mr. Jagel is the first American singer ever to be engaged directly from the Metropolitan. The few other Americans who have sung here were engaged in Italy.
Dr. Gaston Mora y Varona, Supreme Court justice, died this morning at the Fortun Sousa Clinic following an operation, at the age of 73. He was born in Puerto Principe. Camaguey Province.
On May 26 the New York Stock Exchange committee on admissions will consider the application of Archie B. Gwathmey II, to be admitted to the firm of Lapham, Davis Bianchi.

DETROIT. FLUCTUATING in sympathy with the sales trends, production of passenger cars and trucks in the United States and Canada moved upward during the past week to an estimated total of 54,564, against an estimate for the previous week of 53,842.
An unidentified airplane, believed to be a civilian machine converted to military use by the followers of General Saturnino Cedillo, bombed San Luis Potosi this afternoon.
Well-quarters tonight reported that Czechoslovakia had closed her Polish and German frontiers as the result of mounting tension and disorders over tomorrow's municipal elections.

Officers for the coming year were elected at the annual convention of the National Retail Lumber Dealers Association in Washington a few days ago. Don A. Campbell of Lebanon, Ky., was re-elected president; Carl Blackstock, Seattle, Wash., was

Development of the child through cooperation of the home and the school will be the subject of an allday educational conference of the Connecticut State Federation of the American Association of University Women, called for Wednesday in South Norwalk.

Harvard maintained its lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League by defeating Dartmouth, 13-9, at Soldiers Field today. It was a close game for five innings at the end of which Harvard led by one run. Both teams were erratic after that, but the Crimson made the most of its chances.

John L. Lewis has authorized a $50,000 grant by the Committee for Industrial Organization to aid the strike of 15,000 fur workers in this city, Irving Potash, secretary of the strike committee of the Furriers Union, announced yesterday.
