As part of the revivified Republican opposition which is being mapped for the 1938 and 1940 elections, Glenn Frank's Republican program committee is conducting a nation-wide survey of rank and file G. O. P. voters.

Winston Churchill, Helen Wills Moody and Maude Adams will be among the speakers in the morning lectures in Town Hall during the 1938-39 season, it was announced yesterday by George V. Denny Jr., president of Town Hall.

Wholesale market activity last week was marked by a good volume of reorders from stores in the South, Southwest and Pacfic Coast, according to a special summary of market conditions prepared for?? THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

Miss Jean Schmolze, daughter of Mrs. Peter Frederic Schmolze of this place, was married to William Van Houten Kip, son of Mrs. Hebert Z. Kip of Quaker Hill, Conn., and the late Professor Kip, this afternoon at the Schmolze home here. The Rev. Francis J.

Colgate bunched eight hits with two bases on balls for seven runs in the ninth inning and an 11-5 victory over Syracuse today. The barrage came with two out in the final frame to ruin Dave Coffman's splendid performance up to that time. He had held the heavy Maroon sluggers to six scattered hits.

Educational programs are being organized in many parts of the country to instruct householders regarding adequate electric wiring in the home. The educational bureaus sponsoring this work employ flexible standards of wiring adequate to meet the particular size and type of home and which also recognize varied standards of living.
THE first dated book printed in England was "The Dictes or Sayengis of the Philosophres," which issued from the press of William Caxton of Westminster on Nov. 18, 1477.
President Roosevelt, in a letter today to the directors of the Amelia Earhart Foundation, gave his enthusiastic endorsement to the movement to memorialize the lost aviatrix.

Miss Elizabeth W. Starbuck, musical comedy actress, daughter of Mrs. Lawrence Macy Starbuck of 307 East Fifty-seventh Street, New York, was married to Edward W. Burr Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Burr of Jones Park, Riverside, Greenwich, in Christ Episcopal Church here this morning by the Rev. Albert J. M. Wilson, the rector.

Approximately 2,000 savings and loan associations now protected by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation compose the "most select" group of thrift and home-financing institutions ever ever banded together, declares Oscar R. Kreutz, deputy general manager of the corporation.

When the first signs of paint peeling are noted on a tin roof the entire surface should be repainted, points out an old-time builder. He advises that the surface of the roof should be cleaned of loose scaling paint with steel wool, sandpaper, or wire brush.

The two four-story buildings at the southeast corner of Seventh Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street, in the Chelsea section, will be offered at auction tomorrow in the Vesey Street Salesrooms by B. Hollander Sons.

Mrs. R. P. Davidson is chairman of the seventh annual garden party of the Mercy Hospital League of Garden City which will be held the afternoon of June 1 on the grounds of the Garden City Hotel. The program will consist of bridge games and a fashion show, and, in the event of unfavorable weather, will be presented in the ballroom of the hotel.

Several basic principles for tax adjustment throughout the United States have been approved by the directors of the National Association of Real Estate Boards as a result of reports on the realty tax situation received from twenty-three States:

L. W. Baldwin, president of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, received $59,000 salary and other remunneration from the company in 1937, the annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed yesterday.

THIS book bears the subtitle "A Personal Record of the Third Reich." It is, to quote in summary from Dorothy Thompson's introduction, a "simple and clear picture of what it meant to be a civilized human being during the Hitler revolution."

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for May 15 showed that the ratio of the gold reserve to notes in circulation had increased from 118.72 per cent on April 30 to 121.43 per cent. The reserve ratio of gold to notes and sight liabilities was 83.77 per cent on April 30, compared with 83.01 per cent on May 15.
Charley Whitehead and Johnny Kinder of Plainfield, defending titleholders and qualifying medalists, today reached the semi-finals of the New Jersey State amateur-professional golf championship.

A gas explosion in the kitchenette of a two-room apartment on the fourth floor of 455 West Thirtyfourth Street, a seventeen-story building, yesterday at 1:20 P. M., revealed the death of Mrs. Catherine Bruni, 33 years old, the occupant of the apartment.

Syracuse started a $4,367,000 government housing project today. Wrecking crews are demolishing 200 buildings on the fringe of the city's business section. The program calls for construction of low rent units for 700 families.

Smoke signals will rise this evening from a sandy knoll in a Bronx playground and Indian war whoops will mark the opening of a twohour pageant presented by 500 costumed residents of Hillside Homes to commemorate the August day 300 years ago when Jonas Bronck bought from Chief Wampage of the Siwanoy Indian's 500 acres of Bronx territory, known as Keskeskeck.

THE United States and Great Britain approach a trade agreement; there is talk on both sides of the ocean about closer cooperation; friendship is traditional. And yet, from time to time, misunderstanding crops up, which may be due in part to a wide impression that one government is the counterpart of the other.

The engagement of Mrs. Nancy McDowell Colbron of this city, widow of David de Forest Colbron of New Canaan, Conn., to Thomas Fowler Milbank of New York, was announced today by her mother, Mrs. N. Harris McDowell.

Mayor Daniel A. Knaggs of Monroe, who attracted national attention by sending deputized citizens against a picket line at the Republic Steel Corporation plant here during the "little steel" strike last June, has declined suggestions that he seek the Republican nomination for Governor of Michigan.

The United Shoe Machinery Corporation reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Feb. 28 a net income of $10,146,152 after charges and Federal income taxes. This was equivalent to $4.24 each 2,292,548 common shares, excluding 37,041 held in the treasury, and after dividend requirements on the 6 per cent preferred stock.

Little activity was displayed today in the foreign exchange market here. The French franc was the most active currency, but the turnover was small and the rate unchanged at 177 39-64 francs to the pound, pending the next move in the government's program.
Although five of its components advanced, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity is unchanged for the week ended May 14.

PARIS-MONDIAL, the French Government short-wave station formerly known as "Radio Colonial," has been broadcasting regularly of late on the Summer wave of 15.13 megacycles between 7 and 9 P. M., daylight time.
A PLATOON of the British Black Watch regiment is stationed in Hebron--El Khalil, in Arabic-the ancient town of Abraham. They are there to reply to the attacks of Arab bands roaming in that region.

In a hair-raising finish to a baseball thriller that kept 3,000 Lawrenceville alumni, parents and students on edge, the New Jersey schoolboys scored a 5-to-4 victory over the Hill School today in their annual alumni-day battle. Hurd's single and a fumble by the Hill shortstop sent the tying and winning runs across the plate after two strikes had been called on him.
Harvard crews won two stubbornly contested races on the Housatonic today, beating Yale rivals under rough-water conditions in fast time.

LLEWELYN POWYS'S earth memories are of the beauty and wonder of life, and its evanescence. "Nothing on this earth has permanence": death comes to end all; but while life lasts there is miracle and glory.

Unsettled conditions in Europe and financial conditions here have caused the postponement of a tour of seven countries abroad, planned by the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War for this Summer.

THE coming race between War Admiral 'and' Seabiscuit at Belmont Park may not improve the breed perceptibly, but the advance literature issued from horse headquarters should give a good lift to general education in this country. The equine essays, charts, diagrams, definitions and biological statistics offered gratis under the imprint of that eminent publicist, Mr. Steve Hannagan, contain a staggering amount of information.
Dr. Ignatz T. Griebl, wanted in New York as a Witness in a spy-ring investigation, was announced here today to be awaiting trial at Bremerhaven on charges of entering Germany without a passport.

The Francis Ralston Welsh art collection, containing carved jades, three Corot landscapes and other paintings, Chinese porcelains and French eighteenth century gold boxes, has been removed from the Welsh residence, Nirvana, Devon, Pa., for auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday afternoons.

Two properties in Putnam County, N. Y., have been purchased by Mrs. Minta Phillips-Beach, New York writer, through Herbert J. Gebing, Carmel broker. The purchaser will occupy one of the places as a Summer home.
Frederick J. Dolan, Long Island builder and developer, reports considerable sales activity in Summer cottages and building plots at his Babylon Beach Estates property in West Islip.

The newspaper El Tiempo publishes an interview with the Controller General advising prudence in government expenditures, as the surplus accumulated in the past two years, totaling 5,370,000 pesos at the end of 1937, had been reduced to 140,000 pesos at the end of April.

ONE great advantage of touring in a canoe is that you cannot go fast. A day's run of twenty miles is not at all bad; only with the help of current or wind does it exceed forty; anything over sixty is exceptional and means using a fast-flowing river.

Miss Alleine Lee Dunn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eliot deWitt Dunn of South Orange, and Roy Edison Jordan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jordan. also of South Orange, were married here this evening in First Presbyterian and Trinity Church by the pastor, the Rev. George A. Edmison.
North Carolina's track stars sprang a surprise today and won the sixteenth annual Southern Conference track meet. Four new conference records were set.

Floyd Roberts of Van Nuys, Calif., a veteran of twenty-two years of racing, won the pole position today for the Indianapolis Memorial Day 500-mile race with a record-breaking qualifying run, but it was Kelly Petillo of Los Angeles who furnished the thrills for 25,000 raindrenched spectators.

An excellent opportunity exists at present for the small businessman to invest his savings in real estate where he will get a much larger return than the average 2 per cent now obtainable in banks, declares Stanley W. Russell, sales manager of the realty firm of George W. Sasse Inc.

A campaign to secure prompt action by the city on the construction of the proposed sewage disposal plant at City Island with the object of purifying the waters adjacent to Orchard Beach, was launched last week at a luncheon preceding the twenty-third annual tour of the Bronx Park system conducted by -the Bronx Board of Trade in cooperation with the park Department.
A colony of Choral Speaking will be held at Pennsylvania College for Women July 5 to 29 under the direction of Miss Vanda E. Kerst, head of the Department of Speech.
UNCLE SAM himself has withdrawn, at least temporaily, from competing in any "battle of the wave-lengths" to "peddle isms" by radio to South America.

The Abbey Memorial Chapel, a gift to Mount Holyoke College from Mrs. Emily Frances Abbey Gill of Springfield, in memory of her husband, Charles Clinton Abbey, will be dedicated Sunday morning, May 29. Preceding the dedication, the keys will be presented to President Ham by the donor at the main entrance of the chapel.

New Yorkers were invited yesterday by officials of the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park to visit the garden today to view the finest display of iris ever grown at the institution.
More than 30,000 Western New Yorkers gathered here today to celebrate their eighth annual apple blossom festival and crown their "queen of queens."

HIPPODROME OPERA "Aida," Saturday night. Mmes. Hartman, Leskaya and Ippolito, and Messrs. Wahlert, Rayner, Pilotto, Angelini and Ruisi. Conductor, Bamboschek. "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," next Sunday night.

The spread of price-pressure buying by chains and department stores in the last few weeks has already disclosed marked differences both in results achieved and in reactions of manufacturers, and these differences follow fairly closely the distinctions in types of merchandise involved, according to comment here yesterday by buyers, selling agents and manufacturers.
At least one of the more than 100 buildings in this city owned by Charles F. Noyes is being held by him as a safeguard against inflation.

With completion of the building more than three weeks away, thirty of the fifty-six suites in the new twelve-story apartment under construction at 25 East Eighty-third Street have been rented, according to John F. Hamlin,
A four-run rally in the last of the ninth failed to win for the Princeton freshmen as they fell, 7-5, before the Yale yearling nine on Brokaw Field today.

Principais-Barney Ross, Chicago, welter weight champion of the world, vs. Henry Armstrong, Los Angeles, featherweight champion of the world. Title at stake-Welterweight championship of the world. Number of rounds-Fifteen, to a decision.

Under a scorching Southern sun, more than 500 vehicles with 3,000 officers and enlisted men of the country's only mechanized brigade twisted and turned through the steep roads of the Tennessee hill country today to complete the first half of a 700-mile mechanized march.

Dr. Hugo Eckener, somewhat weary looking, sat in his suite at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel yesterday morning and told newspaper reporters that the refusal of the United States to sell helium gas to Germany would spell the end of the dirigible airship for commercial and peacetime use and would be "the greatest disillusionment of my life."

Historic buildings and monuments near the. Boston Post Road in Rye, Port Chester and Southern Connecticut will be visited by members of the Westchester County Historical Society on June 4 during their sixteenth annual pilgrimage, according to announcements distributed today by Ernest F. Griffin of Tarrytown, president.

The Auerbach Cup race, a mothboat regatta, the official opening of the beach, the Atlantic City high-score relay carnival and automobile stunt drivers will all be here for the entertainment of this resort's visitors over the Memorial Day week-end.

Miss Louise Phair Morris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Vincent Morris of Lake Drive, has chosen June 11 as the date for her marriage to Dr. Bertram B. Beneville, son of Mr. and Mrs. Prosper V. Beneville of Kenilworth Road, also of this community. The ceremony will be performed at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Boonton by the Rev. Edward L. McDonald.
A dinner dance will be held on Saturday in connection with the twoday horse show, sponsored by the Westchester Cancer Committee on the grounds of the Washington Irving Country Club here.

MOST professional writers manage to get their best work into print during their lifetime, and there is little to be gained by holding autopsies on their literary remains. John Muir, however, was not a professional writer.

Shipping men in New York were particularly interested, during the five-day visit of the new HollandAmerica flagship Nieuw Amsterdam, in D. C. Endert Jr., head of the Rotterdam Drydock and Shipbuilding Company, who constructed the liner, doing 73 per cent of all work in the plants of his company.

Construction of a forty-one ton four-engined flying boat, designed to carry fifty passengers across the Atlantic, has been nearly completed at the Boeing plant at Seattle, Wash., and the ship will be put through its test flights in the next two weeks, it was announced here last night by officials of Pan American Airways, for whom the ship was built.

Intimate records of a quarter of a century of the heartaches and the headaches, the vanities and the vagaries, the lofty ideals and the. petty aversions of many British and American poets have been acquired by the University of Chicago.

Rubber-booted, helmeted and weighted down with a rubber coat, Fireman Frank Swift of Hook and Ladder Company 32, the Bronx, ran the fastest three flights of stairs in his life yesterday to save two lives.

Paced by husky William Watson, who turned in his second straight threeeven "grand slam," the University of Michigan's powerful squad rolled up 61 1/2 points today in the thirtyeighth annual Western Conference track and field championships to retain the title it has held sixteen times since the turn of the century.
FISHING: In the career of an American political leader, a good grip on a fishing rod is almost as important as a firm handshake. All recent Presidents have been

Missouri won the Big Six track and field championship today with a total of 51 points. The defending champion Nebraska Cornhuskers were second, with 45 points, followed by Oklahoma with 42 1/2, Kansas State with 40 1/2, Kansas with 36 1/2 and Iowa State with 9 1/2.

Old Home Day was observed yesterday at the historic Billopp-Conference House, Tottenville, S. I., with an attendance of about 300 members of the D. A. R. and other patriotic societies and the presentation to the house of a five-foot bronze shrine, a gift of Representative James O'Leary of New York.

DIGGING up relies of Indian craftsmanship left behind attribal camp sites of colonial days is a favorite pastime of outdoor collectors during the Summer months. Many of these sites in the northeastern part of the United States have never yet been explored.

Virginio Gayda, editor and often an official spokesman, in today's Giornale d'Italia again protests against speeches delivered by men in official positions in the United States against the authoritarian regimes.

Miss Gretchen Scott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norris A. Scott of Merodel, Moylan, was married this afternoon to William H. Gardiner Jr., son of W. H. Gardiner and Mrs. M. Christian Gardiner of Chestnut Hill.

Moth the Pirates and the Dodgers lost decisions to Umpire Larry Goetz at Ebbets Field yesterday, but the Buccaneers finally emerged on the long end of a 5-4 count from one of the most controversial contests staged in Flatbush this year.

Since men's wear stores were previously aware that the Spring season might be a poor one and kept down their purchases accordingly, credit executives of large clothing companies reported yesterday that collections were turning up somewhat, as lighter-weight clothing has started to move.

Suggestions presented in the Constitutional Convention for amendments to the State Constitution which would increase borrowing power or taxing ability of the City of New York beyond those already possessed,

As Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain nears the anniversary of his taking over the Premiership, which actually falls on May 28, he finds himself running Great Britain in an atmosphere radically different from that of a year ago and in accordance with policies that were almost totally unforeseen then.
Dr. Joseph Boomer Walkem, one of the oldest active lawyers in Canada, died here today at the age of 95. He had been in failing health for the last few months.
Existence of rabies among dogs in several parts of Southeastern New York was reported today by the State Health Department after one death attributed to the disease.

THE Gordon String Quartet, assisted by a number of distin guished artists, will open its annual series of Summer concerts at Music Mountain, Falls Village, Conn., in mid-June. From then until October programs will be given every Sunday afternoon at the picturesque music center in the heart of the Connecticut hills.

More than 1,000 guests from the metropolitan area, Pennsylvania, Virginia and Connecticut yesterday attended the annual College Day and open house at Wagner Memorial Lutheran College, Grymes Hill, S. I.

They. called her "the freshest kid in town," but she stole the show at the annual baby parade at Fort Tryon playground yesterday. She really, wasn't "fresh" at all; she was as shy and modest as any average little girl aged 4, but she was garbed in a cellophane dress and she sat in a cellophane-wrapped float.

When displays of colorful bloom attract the eyes of hundreds of visitors to the Thompson Memorial Rock Garden during Rock Garden Week, which starts next Saturday, rock plant enthusiasts will have a chance to appraise the newer flowers which the Botanical Garden is bringing into cultivation.

PLAYS selected for the Pulitzer Prize in drama will be adapted for a three months' series of Thursday broadcasts to enliven the Summer air for those in tune with the stage of WJZ and affiliated stations.

WE thought it was a frightened younger sister, or somebody, and that she had just been surprised in the dress she was wearing-a drab, brown, unglamorous affair-when we burst recently into the elegant tower apartment of Olympe Bradna, in the Warwick Hotel.

NOT so very many years ago the generic name "tramp ships" was given to old seagoing steamers that staggered'erratically from port to port, picking up and carrying cargo according to a schedule known generally to Providence alone.

Senator Bulkley of Ohio stated today that thirty-six leaders in labor, business, agriculture and scientific fields have accepted his invitation to attend a conference here Wednesday to discuss his proposal for a "national council" to bring about cooperation between the government and other elements of national life.
THE bathing season at many metropolitan beaches starts today, and soon the sands will be crowded with New Yorkers eager to tan their faces and fill their lungs with sea air and faces with salt spray.

Annual communion breakfast, Maritime Anchor Club of the Port of New York, Hotel Astor, 9 A. M. Speakers: Harry M. During, Harry T. Foley, Gregory W. O'Keefe, Joseph F. Lamb, John J. Downing, Richard T. Duerin.
Termites are causing property owners throughout the country a loss of more than $50,000,000 annually, according to the Copper and Brass Research Association.

University of Southern California athletic heads fired their star distance runner, Louis Zamperini, from the track team today in drastic punishment for his failure to compete in the Compton invitation track meet last night.

Taking nine first places and scoring clean sweeps in four events, the Rutgers track and field team gained an 80-46 victory over Lafayette today. One track record was equaled as Lackey topped the low hurdles in 25 seconds, equaling the mark set by Tommy Allen ten years ago.

James George Weir, chief of the British commission to make a survey of American plane manufacture, sailed unexpectedly yesterday on the Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam. Mr. Weir, who arrived April 25 at the head of the mission of five men, had expected to depart Wednesday on the Queen Mary.

Dr. Emory W. Hunt, president emeritus of Bucknell University, died last night following a heart attack at the age of 76. Dr. Hunt, who had been in ill health since midwinter, was president of Bucknell from 1919 to 1931.

The marriage of Miss Katherine Mitchell, daughter. of Mrs. Arthur H. Mitchell and the late Mr. Mitchell of Princeton, to Frederick Spring Osborne of Princeton, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Hamilton Osborne of Newark, took place here at noon today in Trinity Episcopal Church.

PAID for by thousands of subscriptions averaging 20 cents each, the largest religious statue in the world, in the form of a colossal figure of the Virgin and Child, will be dedicated next year in the small French village of Le Mas-Rillier, near Lyons.
The Merchants Association of New York, one of the most influential groups in the city's commercial life, accepted yesterday the American

THE platform and objectives of the newly founded Alumni Association of the Juilliard Graduate School of Music were stated by Horace Grenell, president of the association, at a dinner given earlier this month to the administration and faculty of the school, at the Beethoven Association.

FEW people realize that priVate, miscellaneous flying is a bigger business and more important to the future of the country than airline flying," according to Jerome Lederer, chief engineer of Aero Insurance Underwriters, who has made an extensive study of private, industrial and sports flying.
SO great was the interest in and response to Dr. Andrea Majocchi's "Life and Death: the Autobiography of a Surgeon" that he was prevailed upon to write a second volume to round out the first.

The Society of the 307th Infantry will hold its annual memorial service today at 2 P. M. in the Regimental Memorial Grece in Central Park, north of the Mall. Mayor LaGuardia has been invited to speak. Mgr. Francis Walsh, wartime chaplain of the regiment, will deliver the memorial address.

Khoda, the senior honorary society at Stevens Institute of Technology, has initiated six new members. They are Henry J. Barchi of the Bronx, Carl R. Faust of Plainfield, David W. Gathman of Prospect Park, John F. Hanna of Palisades Park, William I. Johnson Jr. of Altoona, Pa., and Gustav Schwab of Roselle.

Georg von Metaxa, Viennese tennis star drafted for a berth on the German Davis Cup team, teamed with Heiner Henkel today to defeat the Norwegians, Johan Haanes and Fritz Jenssen, 6-1, 6-2, 6-3, for the clinching victory in their second-round European zone series. The German team qualified to meet Hungary in the quarter-final round at Budapest.

Captain James H. Tomb, U. S. N., retired, and Mrs. Tomb of Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Winifred H. Tomb, to Charles Duane Rice Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Duane Rice of Belmont, Mass.

President Don Beach of the Columbus club announced today that Sammy Baugh, shortstop, has been returned to the Cardinals and four other Red Birds have been released to cut the American Association team's roster to the required twenty players.

Manhattan's varsity crew won a thrilling race on the Harlem yesterday, with two newcomers to metropolitan rowing, American International College of Springfield, Mass., and the Dartmouth Rowing Club ??ighting for second place.

Doubt was expressed today at the office of the Attorney General that legislation enacted in this State recently with a view to ending price wars among retailers of various commodities is constitutional.

The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee is spending $1,000 a day for urgent emergency aid to the Jews of Austria, according to an announcement yesterday by I. Edwin Goldwasser, treasurer of the committee.

Rabbi - B. A. Tintner, in his sermon yesterday to Mount Zion Congregation, 257 West Ninety-third Street, praised the New York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church for its "fine Christian attitude toward the elimination of all un-Christian attitudes and practices among non-Jews toward Jews."

Miss Barbara Holleron, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Otto Holleron, was married here tonight at the home of her parents to Lieutenant Thomas Ryall Davis, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Davis of 126 East Ninety-second Street, New York.

Henry Young Jr., chairman of the New Jersey Assembly committee which recently investigated last November's election in Jersey City and Hudson County, urged Attorney General Cummings yesterday to include that election in the Department of Justice investigation, just announced, into the situation with regard to civil rights in Mayor Frank Hague's administration.
Nearly, eighty persons, many of them white-haired men and women, walked quietly along Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon for two hours in a silent "poster walk" protesting against "all war propaganda."
Northwestern University's football team will meet Syracuse University in an intersectional game at Archbold Stadium on Oct. 5, 1940, Director of Athletics Lewis P. Andreas announced today.

Here are the records in brief of these editors: Amory of Harvard (Milton, Mass.)--An honor student and member of Hasty Pudding, Signet. Belin of Yale (Waverly, Pa.)-A member of Berkeley College on Junior Prom Committee.

Robert H. Armstrong and Lawrence B. Cummings, writing in the May 23 issue of Barron's Magazine, present an interesting review of the housing situation and outline the chances for the success of any large-scale privately financed housing program under conditions existing today.

WE'RE out of the Red Sea and nobody seems to mind very much. This "torrid corridor" of Afro-Asian brine never comes up to reasonable expectations. There is nothing red about it under normal conditions.
Thirty-seven years after his death the body of Ethelbert Nevin, composer of "The Rosary" and other melodies, who was born and died in Western Pennsylvania, was sent today to Blue Hill, Me.

Mr. and Mrs. John H. Ward of Ridgewood have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret E. Ward, to Laurence H. Larsen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis A. Larsen of Lima, Ohio, and Harwich Port, Mass.
The fifth annual festival and finals of the composition contest of the Ernest Williams School of Music took place yesterday afternoon before a capacity audience.
THOUGH it is news when a fer-de-lance has thirty-six babies, as one did recently, according to a report of the curator of the zoo at Panama a litter of this size is far from being unusual.

Resolutions reflecting strongly feminist sympathies were adopted yesterday in the closing business session of the annual convention of the State Federation of Business and Professional Women at the Hotel Biltmore.

John Thomas Smith, one of the leading Roman Catholic laymen of the New York archdiocese, who was created a Papal Chamberlain of the Cape and Sword last Monday, died suddenly yesterday afternoon of a heart attack at his residence, 154 Greenwich Street.

A fitting climax was written in the record of the twenty-first rowing of the Carnegie Cup regatta on Cayuga Lake today when Yale defeated Cornell and Princeton in the varsity race and established a new course mark. The victory completed a sweep for Yale, whose freshmen and junior varsity won their races yesterday.
The University of Michigan has been included on Columbia's football schedule for 1941, according to an announcement by Reynolds

Scoring six runs in two innings, Williams overcame an early Amherst lead and gained a 7-4 victory over the Lord Jeffs today as Bump Hadley coasted along to a smooth seven-hit victory for the Ephs. Larry Durrell was the Williams spark plug, contributing three hits and two runs on the attack, and starring in the field.

Harry Mackenzie of Bethel, Fairfield County Republican leader, and Edward G. Levy, attorney, of New Haven, were the only two persons who surrendered today to County Detective Edward Hickey on a bench warrant charging them with

The annual Greentree Fair on Mrs. Payne Whitney's estate in Manhasset, L. I., will take place on the afternoon of June 10. Proceeds from the many divertissements, sales and games will be donated to the Baby Milk Funds of the Family Welfare Association of Nassau County and of the New York Hospital.

The new Revenue Bill, passed by both houses of the Congress more than a week ago, awaits the signature of the President. Although the bill becomes a law at the moment of time when it is signed, the income -tax provisions contained therein generally take effect retroactively -so as to apply to taxable years beginning after Dec. 31, 1937.

Taking an early lead and increasing it throughout the mile-and-a-half race, Syracuse's varsity crew defeated Rutgers by three lengths today on Lake Onondaga as 5,000 looked on. The winner's time was 8:17 3-5, Rutgers's, 8:30.

COURT ORDER: In White Plains, N. Y., last week Supreme Court Justice Abram Zoller was holding court. Ten women were on his first jury. He ordered them to appear hatless in .the jury box. The order stirred

Mr. and Mrs. Rowland Hazard of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Campbell Hazard, to Rolf Stutz, also of New York. Miss Hazard attended the Foxcroft School in Virginia, Dana Hall at Wellesley, Mass., and Mlle.

The Sunday Pictorial a weekly newspaper which paid [pound]5,000 for the serialization rights of Compton Mackenzie's biography, "Windsor Tapestry," has decided against publishing the work, which, it contends, should never have been written.

RADIO men are hopeful that television under the spotlight of the New York World's Fair in 1939 will emerge from the exposition as a new and prosperous industry to entertain and enlighten "the World of Tomorrow."

OCEAN travelers, it is indicated by a survey, are attending religious services on shipboard in increasing numbers. Equipment for the formal ceremonies of all faiths has been installed on most liners plying to and from the port of New York.

THE science of physiologyan imposing and unfinished monument-has been under construction since the days of Galen. Those portions of the edifice which are to be regarded as specifically modern rest in large degree upon the work of the great Claude Bernard.

William Woodward's Americanowned Olympus was beaten a neck today by the Maharajah of Rajpipla's Blandstar in the Derby Trial Stakes, run over the Derby distance of a mile and a half. A dozen other thoroughbreds eligible for the big race June 1 trailed these two outsiders.

In his summary before a Paris court yesterday the Public Attorney asked that the court declare itself competent and set aside the divorce of Enrique de Paats, a wealthy Buenos Aires (Argentina) business man in a case involving two American women.

THE honor of being the first winner of the newly created Town Hall Young Artist Award has fallen to Rosalyn Tureck, 23year-old American pianist, according to an announcement made yesterday by Walter W. Naumburg, chairman of the Town Hall Music Committee.

" THE bomb went boom and the glass went ping!" Thus an unidentified householder on the army reservation adjoining Mitchel Field described what happened when a flashlight bomb accidently fell near his house during the manoeuvres concluded there last week by the General Headquarters Air Force.

Harvard's varsity 150-pound crew reclaimed the Goldthwaite Cup from Yale today after it had been out of the Crimson's hands for nine years. The home eight led until the three-quarter mark, when the Elis came up, but they were beaten in a fast finish with Princeton third.

Mandatory jury service for women, amendment of New York divorce laws to include desertion as a legal ground, permanent registration of voters and collective bargaining are among the new items for support which will be considered by the New York City League of Women Voters in annual convention at the Hotel Astor on Tuesday.

Calling attention to the housing needs and possibilities in the United States, John H. Fahey, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said yesterday that Great Britain during the last seven years has gained more from experience and accomplished more in the housing field than any other country in the world.

The usual peace of the annual National Maritime Association memorial services on the Custom House steps. was. disrupted yesterday by discord, misunderstanding and the absence of one of the guests of honor.
A mentally afflicted father, his condition aggravated by unemployment and financial trouble, murdered his two children this morning and set fire to his home in a vain attempt to hide his crime.

Sales during March in a nationwide gas refrigeration selling campaign conducted by the American Gas Association Refrigeration Committee were larger than those of a similar drive in March of 1937, H. R. Sterrett, president of the New Haven Gas Light Company and chairman of the committee, said yesterday.

Five special scholarships have been awarded to talented child artists of Manhattan and the Bronx as part of a research project conducted by New York University's Clinic for the Social Adjustment of Gifted Children, it was announced yesterday by Harold 0. Voorhis, university secretary.

Nervousness over political developments in Europe strengthened the market for cotton in Liverpool yesterday and brought an initial gain of 6 points on the local Cotton Exchange, but the trading here continued to reflect selling pressure and the list ended with net changes ranging from a gain of 1 to a loss of 3 points.

ELSEWHERE in this world tomorrow will be nothing more or less than May 23, but in Indiana it will be Colo Porter Day. Signed by the Governor of that State, a proclamation says so, and bids all citizens join in honoring the man who is quite certainly the greatest composer who ever emerged from Peru, Ind.

Menow, last year's juvenile champion, captured the sixty-third Withers Stakes before 20,000 persons at Belmont Park yesterday afternoon and completed a triple for Owner Hal Price Headley and his nephew, Trainer Duval Headley.

The Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, in a statement yesterday endorsed the proposal of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America to establish an Institute of Interdenominational Studies next Fall.

With more than 4,200 on the benches, the Morris and Essex Kennel Club next Saturday again will present America's greatest dog show at Madison, N. J. In every respect it will be the world's largest, most resplendent and most perfectly presented one-day outdoor canine competition.
SUCCESSFUL child stars are not in dividuals; they are industries. Of all the strange lives fashioned by a fantastic town, those of celluloid's moppets are the most grotesque.

RECENTLY in this city Ralph Kirkpatrick, whose devoted study and special researches in the field of keyboard music of earlier centuries have carried him far, played the Bach "Goldberg" Variations on the harpsichord in Town Hall.

According to Dan Brown, president of the Farmers State Bank, the trial of the men of Harlan in Federal District Court here is the "biggest thing that ever came to London," and the folk hereabout are "mighty pleased and proud at all the publicity the town is getting."

The National Housing Act and its effect on real estate will be discussed at a luncheon meeting on Tuesday in the Town Hall Club under the sponsorship of the brokerage division of the Real Estate Board of New York.
LEONCAVALLO wrote the opera "Pagliacci" to be performed in about an hour. Wagner's "Parsifal" and "Goetterdaemmerung" are among the longest operas, requiring approximately four and a half hours.

Mrs. Saidie Orr Dunbar, who last week was elected president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, will address the New Jersey Federation of Women's Clubs at its annual convention opening Tuesday at Haddon Hall, Atlantic City. She will speak at the president's dinner to be held preceding the formal opening, that evening.

Miss Nancy Clinton Farrington, a descendant of General James Clinton of George Washington's staff, and Harvey F. Raymond, whose ancestor, Thomas Raymond, was a settler of Hartford, were married last night in St. Paul's Church in Flatbush.

A program of reform of the social-economic order in America was adopted yesterday at the New York East Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church despite the objections of a conservative minority which attacked the resolutions as a "direct thrust against the capitalist system."

Arthur E. Allen, Jamaica architect, and who has designed many of the new houses in several of the large communities in Queens and other parts of Long Island, says that home buyers today understand the methods of good construction far better than was the case a few years ago.

The engagement of Miss Katherine Maxine Alcott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Alcott of this city, to Baron Gustav Wedell Wedellsborg, son of Baron and Baroness L. Wedell Wedellsborg of Hillerod, Denmark has been announced.

WHICH is the world's oddest capital? Search for it has become the newest game with passengers on this year's cruise ships, which are making many stops at the lesser known places and providing side trips to others.

Expanded in number and volume of business by the emphasis of lower prices, but threatened with the rise of prohibitoryy" local taxation, "super" and self-service food markets are approaching a $1,000,000,000 segment of the $9,000,000,000 retail food industry of this country, according to authorities in close touch with this outstanding development in the food lines.
Miss Marion Lockwood Race, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Z. D. Race of this place, was married this afternoon to Norman Albert Schoelles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Schoelles of Niagara Falls.

Princeton's baseball team upset Cornell twice today in a Spring day doubleheader, 5-4 and 4-3. The twin victories gave the Tigers an even break in their eight Eastern Intercollegiate League games. The double triumph moved the Tigers from sixth place to fourth, close behind the leaders.

The Nationalities Statute prepared by the Czechoslovak Government and submitted to London and Paris as well as to Konrad Henlein as Prague's utmost contribution toward the settlement of the Sudeten-German problem has not yet been published but it already has been rejected in Germany.

Mrs. J. Apwood Maulding, who has charge of the division of appointments of the Interior Department, including employment appointments to the Puerto Rico Reconstruction Administration, was promoted today to director of personnel of the department.
THE author of "A City of Bells" has found in Oxford and in the Springtime of the reign of Queen Elizabeth the setting that give all her qualities as a literary artist full play.

While this week will spell finale to a majority of the women's clubs, a number of civic-minded groups already have laid plans to ignore the usual closing date and extend their programs this year far into the Summer.

Stanley White, head of the Jamaica office of the FHA, and Leon M. Schoonmaker, engineering consultant of the Queens Planning Commission, will be the speakers at the luncheon meeting of the Jamaica Real Estate Board on Tuesday in the Hotel Franklin, Jamaica.

Many of the undergraduate organizations at New Jersey College for Women held their final meetings for this year during the week and selected new leaders. Language clubs and social science organizations completed their elections.

Miss Ann Louise Clifton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Albert Clifton of this city, was married to Frank Gilbert Pfau, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius W. Pfau of Yonkers, in the Church of the Holy Cross here this afternoon by the Rev. Clarence W. Jones, the rector.
Boston University defeated Wesleyan at baseball today, 10 to 8. See replaced Petersen in the box for Wesleyan early in the third inning, after Hardiman had reached first on an error and Petersen had

A lawyer predicted today that there would be a court fight to break the will of Mrs. Eliza Black Mulholland, Peabody widow, who left an estate at more than $150,000 to her 6-year-old granddaughter, Mary Alice Gale, of Burlington, Vt., to be held in trust until she is 25 years old.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Philip Frank of 416 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Selma Muriel Frank, to Howard D. Olderman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Olderman of Ansonia, Conn.
The Princeton University golf team, in a thrilling match at the Woodway Country Club today, defeated Harvard by 5 to 4 to win the final of the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association tournament.

Under an agreement with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation the Metropolitan Water District will issue refunding bonds bearing an average interest rate of 4 1/2 per cent in exchange for $200,000,000 of Colorado River aqueduct bonds already sold to the RFC and bearing 5 per cent interest.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand.The Socialists here set out to create homes for every one, launching a housing scheme which was to put every one in comfort street. Today, while there is a housing shortage more acute than has ever smitten the country before, there is a paradox that many dwellings are empty.

Displaying brilliant all-around form, the Cavan Gaelic football team, champion of North Ireland, easily defeated the Pennsylvania Gaelic Athleticc Association team at the Central High School field today, 3 to 14.

The American Labor party, after study of the merits of the elective and appointive methods of selecting judges, has decided in favor of retraining the elective system, Alex Rose, State executive secretary announced yesterday.

In February, 1938, the Jewish Agency for Palestine spent $199,760 in Palestine for agricultural colonization, the settlement of German Jews, housing and public works, immigration and training and urban settlement, according to a report made public yesterday by the United Palestine Appeal.

The influence wielded by the New York Stock Exchange in settlements of foreign debts and the close cooperation extended by the Exchange to those engaged in negotiations to bring about such readjustments was brought to light for the first time last week in the turn of events affecting the status of dollar bonds assenting to the Chilean Government's debt plan.
Mrs. Edward Claiborne Stahlman, mother of James G. Stahlman, publisher of The Nashville Banner-and president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, died early today after a long illness.

The direct reduction mortgage home financing plan has contributed materially in maintaining real estate activity since the first of the year, according to Newell J. Nessen, president of the Quaker City Federal Savings and Loan Association of Philadelphia.

Four records fell and another was tied as Baldwin high unexpectedly captured the South Shore Athletic League track and field championship today and the three-year domination of the meet by Central was ended. Baldwin had 33 points. Central was second with 28 1/2.

IN the lately completed season of the Metropolitan Opera Association, Giacomo Puccini was represented by eight performances of two operas: "La Boheme" five times, "Gianni Schicchi" three. In the previous season it was not until the last three weeks that a few Puccini shows crept into the repertory.
Preparations have been made at the port of Gdynia to welcome a delegation of American Slovaks who will travel through Poland to attend the Slovak congress at Bratislava, Czechoslovakia, next week.

NEW ROCHELLE, one of the scores of communities that go to make up the 1,000 square miles and 10.000,000 population of metropolitan New York, is preparing for a proud and joyous birthday party this year.

THE University of Pennsylvania Choral Society and the Philadelphia Orchestra, to gether under the direction of Harl McDonald, have made a really exceptional recording of five verses from the Magnificat as set by Karl Philipp Emanuel Bach.
THE compelling quality in this enthusiastic autobiography is abundance. Life verflows the pages, and it has been the life worth living. Every sentence pulsates with the throb of red-blooded vigor.
Liberals took Dewdney Riding from the conservative column in the provincial by-election yesterday when D. W. Strachan, a former Representative, was elected.
Although the property has been on the market for more than a year, no substantial offer has as yet been made for the 600-acre Lakewood, N. J., estate of the late John D. Rockefeller.

For the eighteenth time; the smooth foxterrier champion Nornay Saddler today was awarded the title of best in show. This remarkable youngster topped an entry of 851 dogs in the thirty-fifth annual exhibition of the Ladies Kennel Association of America, held on the Mineola Fair Grounds.
Two developments of major stock market importance came hard on the heels of the address of William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, on Friday night.

AN inter-American competition has just been organized by the government of Cuba to erect in Havana a monument to the memory of Jose Marti, Cuba's greatest patriot. Conditions for the competition are published in a pamphlet that can be obtained, along with blanks for registration,

Doors are poor articles, states a builder, on which to economize, because light-weight ones suitable for interiors will, in some climates, if used for exteriors, warp and crack and necessitate replacement. When this occurs, the combined expenditures probably will be in excess of what the cost of a good door of substantial weight would have been.

IN the Tumacacorl National Monument, which contains the famous Tumacacori Mission, there will be opened to the public this Summer a new museum in which tourists will be able to study by means of graphic exhibits much of the history of the Mexican State of Sonora and the southern part of Arizona which adjoins Mexico.

Hope that welding into Hitler's Reich of millions of Austrian Catholics would produce a more tolerant attitude on the part of the Nazis has disappeared, Frank A. Hall of Washington, director of the National Catholic Welfare Conference News Service, said here today at the closing session of the annual convention of the Catholic Press Association. Persecution has increased, he asserted.

Harry Stevens, 35 years old, a Negro, who escaped last Tuesday from a Parole Board officer while being taken from the Rikers Island Penitentiary to the Parole Board offices, was captured last night by detectives of the East 126th Street station after a chase through East Harlem.

Will Britain reach her goal of a general settlement of European differences, a settlement she believes necessary for the peace of the Continent? A fortnight ago, the ink hardly dry on the Anglo-Italian agreement, the answer would have tended to be yes. Last week there was less certainty.

Secretary Woodring urged National Guardsmen tonight to take the lead in patriotic education of American youth. National Guard members, he said in a prepared address at the seventy-seventh anniversary celebration of the 101st Infantry, "have the rare opportunity to guide American youth along the path of old-fashioned patriotism."

Katherine Rawls, swimming and diving star, was married on Wednesday to Theodore H. Thompson, an aviator, it was disclosed today. Mrs. W. J. Rawls, the swimmer's mother, said that Katherine told her of the marriage by long distance telephone.

Terming the recent "tremendous growth" of the Communist party in the United States "an event of national importance" William Z. Foster, national chairman of the party, called upon its members yesterday to overcome the party's "particular weakness"--its failure to enlist the workers in heavy industries.

ABRAVE man is Dr. Cabot, who comes tilting at the windmills of self-deceit, prevarication, equivocation, evasion and all their brother and sister vices; and his Dulcinea is Lady Honesty herself, an austere lady in spotless robes, who could not even imagine a lie, much less give utterance to one.

Totally contrary to the belief very widely held that financial institutions are reluctant to lend money, C. Harry Minners, president of the Bankers Federal Savings and Loan Association, declared yesterday that such institutions are eager to make sound investments which will yield a conservative return.

Miss Lois Augusta Benedict, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Farrand Northrop Benedict of East Orange, was married this afternoon in the garden of the country home here of her parents to Dr. Edgar Eginton Stewart Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Stewart of Great Neck. L. I.
Temple went on a slugging spree today and collected twenty-four hits' to win, 25 to 0, from C. C. N. Y. Thirteen runs were recorded in the eighth.
THIS is the time of year when cotton is feted. The South has already made its gesture with pageants and balls; here in the North we fall in line with National Cotton Week which begins on May 30.

A wide range from a budget of $649.94, the lowest annual expenditure of a Barnard College day student, to a budget of $2,662.68, the highest, was announced yesterday in the report of a study of the expenditures of 112 resident and day students made by five undergraduate members of the consumer course given at the college.

An explanation and a defense of the National Labor Relations Board's action in the Ford Motor Company case were made today by Edwin S. Smith, member of the board, in a speech before the annual convention of the United Office and Professional Workers of America, a Committee for Industrial Organization affiliate.

ASENSE of proportion is an invaluable asset but one that is often unbalanced by conditions of urban life. The hurry and strain and constant impacts of other personalities are not conducive to a quiet, judicial assay of values.

TWO American women struggle for the love of a Swedish count in this novel, and if that sounds like a cheap or hackneyed story it gives an incorrect impression. It is the background and the incidental detail that give strength and interest and save the novel from tawdriness, for the three leading characters are not particularly well drawn.

Glory of God: A Letter to My Son." The book is directed to those who, unwilling to indoctrinate their children in a dogmatic creed, are yet deeply aware of the necessity of a belief in God and want to help their children to find a religion powerful enough to take hold of their minds and hearts.

Rhode Island State College won the fifty-second New England intercollegiate track and field title on Brown Field today with a total of 29 2-5 points. Boston College and Holy Cross tied for second with 23 points, Maine was fourth with 221-5 and Brown fifth with 22.

The Cadet Chapel at West Point will be the scene on June 15 of the wedding of Miss Madeleine E. Fischer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Martin Fischer of this place, to Cadet Donald D. Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Glazier Williams

Postmaster General Farley today dedicated a $2,000,000 addition to the Indianapolis Postoffice and Federal Office Building. With the addition, the building now contains 231,291 square feet of floor space and represents a total investment of approximately $4,500,000.

Francis Jay Underhill of 129 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, a retired bond broker, died yesterday at his residence. Born seventy-five years ago in Chelsea, Mass., he spent his boyhood there and then moved to Buffalo, where he engaged in the wholesale lumber business until he came to this city in 1900.

Praise for the civil service records of Governor Lehman and the State and New York City Civil Service Commission, and criticism of the World's Fair Corporation is voiced in the annual report of the Civil Service Reform Association, just made public.
Thirty-four young Britons, including three career men in the British Home Civil Service and five in similar service in the dominions, have been appointed to 1938 Commonwealth Fund Fellowships.
Cool weather has curtailed the activities for the opening of the season here this week but nearly all the members of the Park are occupying their houses and many places have been rented.

Security and commodity markets, although dull, reflected yesterday in varying degrees the increase in the political tension in Europe. The stock market was depressed from the start and finished the half-day trading period with declines ranging from fractions to more than 2 points.
Reorganization and refinancing of the Dollar Steamship Lines, Inc., Ltd., as demanded by the United States Maritime Commission, has been completed.

Thirteen fighting -planes of a type known as the "Airacuda" and of radically new design were ordered by the War Department today from the Bell Aircraft Company of Buffalo. They are to cost $3,168,265.

Whatever may be the criticism, justified or not, which has been directed at the National Labor Relations Board and the Wagner act by some employers, their counsel, legislators and others, both the statute and theagency which administers it thus far have met with the favor of the Supreme Court of the United States.

ANOTHER local art season (and the metaphor may with some appropriateness be mixed) is winding up its affairs, lowering its sails, putting its blocks back on the shelf. The season has conducted its business worthily, accomplished adventurous (charted or uncharted) voyages, built castles from A to Z, some of them down to earth, some afloat in a veritable Wolkenkuckucksheim.

The fourteenth annual Westchester Music Festival ended tonight with a concert featuring the senior festival chorus of 320 voices, assisted by several soloists, the Philadelphia Orchestra and R. C. Williamson, organist, of Rye. About 2,200 persons attended the final concert in the three-day series, held in the County Center here.

At the annual meeting of the American Association for Adult Education, which closed Wednesday, William Allen Neilson, president of Smith College and retiring president of the association, spoke of a matter that has lately troubled many persons in and out of education. It is the "jargon" that is commonly used by scholars.

As snow and rain continued today to intensify the ordinary horrors of war for the troops battling on the Teruei front in Spain, the Rebels claimed complete possession of the road running from Teruel to the Mediterranean Coast.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES in reporting the recent address of Professor Kemmerer before the savings bankers convention states that "in urging a return to the gold standard Professor Kemmerer declared that 'many of the principal countries that are today considered to be on a managed paper currency basis,

Several sales of cabins and cottages at Packanack Lake, in Passaic County, N. J., were reported yesterday by Ira C. Jones, sales manager for the development. Among the purchasers was Mrs. Loretta Schoeller of Scarsdale, N. Y., who bought the property known as Mohawk Cottage on Mohawk Trail.

Many members of society who have houses in town or who, for one reason or another, want to pass a short season on the North Shore of Long Island without adding another residence to their responsibilities find renting a place the answer to their problems, and there is a growing tendency, in the exclusive colonies along the shore from Huntington to Manhasset, to depend on a suitable Summer lease.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Pauline Moxley, daughter of Mrs. Richard Hayes Davis of Indian Hills, Louisville, Ky., and of Sampson Buchanan Moxley of Shelbyville, Ky., to Marshall Morris Bassick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Webb Bassick of The Oaks, Fairfield, Conn.

The Citizens Union asked the State Constitutional Convention today to merge the Supreme, County and General Sessions Courts in New York City and give to the Legislature the right to reorganize the District Attorney's offices within the city.

Donald Carroll, 16 years old, of 37-37 Seventy-eighth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, will go on trial tomorrow in the Queens County Court on a first-degree murder indictment charging he shot Charlotte Matthiesen, 18, his sweetheart, in a suicide compact and then weakened when it came to taking his own life.

Ground will be broken July 1 for a new dormitory at Simmons College, announced by President Beatley, as the first step in a plan designed to house all resident students eventually on a conveniently located campus.

SAN SALVADOR. BEHIND the recent issuing of a Salvadorean 3-on-5 centavos provisional commemorating the centenary of the death of Jose Simeon Canas, the Salvadorean priest who freed the slaves in Central America, is a story of interest to collectors.

One of the most popular golf tournaments of the yeah is the Joseph J. Windle Memorial, which will be held at the Cherry Valley Country Club on Tuesday.

Notices published here yesterday asked all foreigners to register with the Foreign Residents Association, which has drafted plans with the cooperation of consuls and foreign gunboat commanders for the protection of foreigners if Hankow is attacked by the Japanese.

I O. and is dominated by John L. Lewis. Second, they rejected great Administration pressure through the Federal machine and Chairman Farley in making their nomination. Third, they prevented foreclosure

Trinity College at Hartford will have as an innovation in its Summer school to be held from July 5 to Aug. 13, two courses in the coaching of college sports, basketball and track, conducted by Ray Oosting director of physical education and coach of these sports.

Support of President Roosevelt as the "outstanding champion of democracy" was pledged yesterday by the Affiliated Young Democrats, Inc., at the closing session of the organization's State convention at the Park Central Hotel.

CZECHOSLOVAKIA recently is sued a 20-kronen coin in honor of Thomas Garrigue Masaryk, the late President of the republic. The obverse shows a portrait of Masaryk facing right, and the dates 1850-1937. The design was the work of Ottokar Spaniel.

A $1,000,000 project to be Known, as the E. Stanley Jones Educational Foundation is being established on the sixty-three-acre citrus grove campus of Florida Southern College at Lakeland. Ground will be broken Tuesday for the $500,000 building, with Bishop Paul B. Kern as the speaker.
The six-story apartment building known as the Adrian, at 312-16 West Twentieth Street, near Eighth Avenue, will be offered at auction Thursday in the Vesey Street salesrooms by Henry Brady.
Dr. James M. Hamilton, who practiced in the Allegheny River Valley for sixty-five years, died yesterday at his home at near-by Oakmont after an illness of-several months. His age was 86.
THIS little volume, the record of a personal experience during the collapse of the Confederacy, scarcely merits publication in book form. Yet it is not without either interest or charm.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 20: COLONELS MacDill, L. (Lt. Col.), Air Corps, Gen. Staff Corps, one month leave, June 20, with permission to visit foreign countries. Lynch, A. J., Q. M. C., four months and ten days' leave, May 20.

Four years of industrial strife in San Francisco provide the background for a venture in community cooperation springing from the initiative of a group of the city's leading employers calling themselves the Committee of Forty-three.

When debutantes drink milk at their "coming out" parties and the tiniest hamlet in the State recognizes its obligation to provide wholesome activity to occupy the increased leisure of young people, the promotion of temperance is under way, in the opinion of Mrs. John S. Sheppard, a member of the New York State Liquor Authority.

IN the present dynamic era events move too fast for the old procedure of the encyclopaedias. "Technical and scientific progress and economic change in a single year are often as great as in an entire decade of an earlier century," the editors of the Encyclopaedia Britannica point out.

Organization of the Westchester Park Preservation Conference was announced yesterday by a committee of women to combat any attempt to abolish the Park Commission or permit the State to take control of the county parkways. Mrs. Lee Skipwith presided at a preliminary meeting at the Scarsdale Woman's Club, at which Gerard Swope, member of the Westchester County Park Commission, and Ralph A. McClelland, chairman of the board of supervisors, endorsed the movement.

AN advisory board has been named -to guide the WEVD University of the Air for the 1938-39 season opening in September. The membership comprises George Backer, secretary, American Arbitration Association; Dr. William E. Bohn, Dr. John Lovejoy Elliott, Morris L. Ernst, attorney;

LIKE a bolt out of the blue--or at least like a bolt-the National Progressive party of Madison, Wis., has struck not merely the old-line politicians but politicians of all descriptions. at a time when they are looking beyond the imminent Congressional elections to the Presidential year of 1940.

The formation of Bela Imredy's Cabinet has been greeted with such jubilation from all anti-Fascist parties from Right to Left at home and abroad that there is some danger of misconception as to the character of the new Hungarian Government.

TEACHERS who conscientiously attempt to make radio listening in the classroom worthwhile, but find the pupils apathetic, may discover several reasons for the lack of interest, according to R. R. Lowdermilk, editor of The Ohio Radio Announcer, issued by the Bureau of Educational Research at Ohio State University.
Stockholders of the Washington National Life Insurance Company approved today the proposed acquisition by the company of the Hercules Life Insurance Company from Sears, Roebuck Co.

Two artists of Hightstown, N. J., working in collaboration, have won the Treasury Procurement Division's competition for mural decoration of the lobby of the new Bronx postoffice, it was announced today.

Princeton opened its cricket season auspiciously today by turning back Haverford's eleven, 30-28, on Goldie Field. Doug Cochrane led the Tiger batsmen with nine runs and Fred Richardson gave bowling support by taking five wickets for six.

The cellar-dwelling Browns had one big inning today at the expense of Johnny Marcum to defeat the Red Sox, 5 to 3. Featured by Mel Mazzera's circuit blow, the Browns scored four runs in the fourth for the necessary offensive punch. Mazzera's homer came with one man on base.

The auction sale of vacant lots by the town of Greenburgh, Westchester County, has been set for June 18 and 21 at the Westchester County Center, White Plains, the town supervisor, William C. Duell, announced yesterday.

Countess Eleanora Colloredo-Mannsfeld, daughter of Count and Countess Ferdinand Colloredo-Mannsfeld, was married here this afternoon to Frederick W. von Meister, son of Mrs. Wilhelm von Meister of Geneva, Switzerland, and New York,
Declaring that pushcart peddlers are a menace to traffic, health and sanitation, Mayor La Guardia yesterday appealed to civic organizations to join in a drive to eliminate them from the streets.

The resignation of Carman G. Blough as chief accountant of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the appointment of William W. Werntz of the commission's staff to succeed him was announced today.

There is little likelihood that the present curtailment in rental advances will last long, warns the home building and home owning committee of the United States Building and Loan League.

Completing a quarter of a century of instruction in pulp and paper technology, the University of Maine, which gave the first collegiate courses in the field, has increasingly coordinated. its studies with the needs of the first industry in the State of Maine.

THE announcement in Barcelona last week that the Spanish Loyalist Government's Finance Minister had ordered a special series of stamps of varying denominations printed for use on mail carried by submarine between Catalonia and other Loyalist ports, owing to Catalonia's having been isolated by the Insurgent push to the Mediterranean, ushers in a wholly new phase of philately.

IN general, a rather false idea of the South American countries prevails abroad. Vaguely pictured as a sort of southern counterpart to the United States of North America, they are looked upon as a homogeneous and uniform whole.
Several changes have taken place recently in the personnel of the Cunard White Star liners through the retirement of captains and officers and the promotion of others to replace them.

THE eighth annual American Folksong Festival will be held Sunday, June 12, at Traipsin' Woman Cabin, on the Mayo Trail some eighteen miles south of Ashland, Boyd County, Ky., under the direction of Jean Thomas, Kentucky author, who founded the festival.

The Pennsylvania primary has left Democratic leaders, despite the victory of the State committee over John L. Lewis and the C. I. O., more concerned than at any time since this Commonwealth kicked over the Republican traces in 1934 to follow the New Deal.
Yale defeated the St. Andrews Club of South Orange at Rugby today, 14-4. The Jerseyites led, 4-3, at intermission, Robert Wheeler kicking a field goal from the 30-yard line.
The annual poppy sale of the American Legion and its auxiliary began yesterday throughout the nation and will continue until next Monday.

The final weeks of the club season among Long Island women's groups find several new organizing heads at the helm as the result of Spring elections and with a greater shift of officers among the executive boards and committees.

A warning to those who say "let the Communists alone, they are harmless" that they will soon hear more of them, was given by Jeremiah T. Cross, New York State Commander of the American Legion, in an address yesterday before a luncheon of the New York State Society of Professional Engineers at the Hotel Commodore.

Extended discussion of the Wheeler-Lea law will feature the annual convention of the Toilet Goods Association, which begins on Tuesday and continues through Thursday evening at the Hotel Biltmore, it was announced yesterday by Hugo Mock, of Mock Blum, counsel for the organization.

The bodies of Miss Katherine Hastings, 20 years old, and her brother, William, 22, were found this morning in their home at 452 North Harrisburg Avenue, the victims of accidental carbon monoxide poisoning.

HOLLYWOOD. IN a candid mixture of fact and supposition, Norma Shearer is returning to the screen after an absence of more than a year in "Marie Antoinette," a pictorial account of the human side of a Queen's career.

Miss Jean Marie Robinson, daughter of Mrs. Leila Jones Robinson of East Orange, was married to Dr. Charles H. Evans of East Orange this evening at the home of the bride's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. L. Edwin Waldeck, in West Orange.

The steamship President Roosevelt of the United States Lines arrived yesterday from the Channel ports with 232 passengers and one stowaway, John Charles Pitzer, 20 years old, of 1,400 1/2 West Fifteenth Street, Oklahoma City, who said he was wounded in the left leg while fighting in Spain for the Loyalists.

Baseball being a game of endless wonders, the Giants at a late hour last night were still wondering how a club goes about scoring runs. They partially solved the problem when Mel Ott propelled his seventh homer of the year into the upper right tier of the Polo Grounds yesterday to gain the plaudits of a crowd of 20,729 onlookers, who even as they applauded seemed to sense the futility of it all.

Henry Armstrong will bid for the welterweight championship of the world when he tackles Barney Ross, Chicago titleholder, in a fifteenround bout at the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City nn Thursday night.

Dr. Frederick C. Kemple, a member of the board of governors of the New Rochelle Hospital and a well-known orthodontist with offices at 580 Fifth Avenue, New York, died today at New Rochelle Hospital after a long illness.
Those who a year ago said "It can't be done" are this season trying to regain their prestige as prophets and are climbing on board the band wagon of motor boating's most spectacular speed race.

Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. of Lubec, Me., 23-year-old unemployed clerk who went to New York City three days ago to seek work, was in Tarrytown Hospital in a serious condition tonight with a stab wound he inflicted in his abdomen last night in a suicide attempt in the woods near Sleepy Hollow Cemetery here, according to the police.

COMMUNITY "Spring cleaning" is an important Boy Scout activity now in full swing. By ridding vacant lots of trash, by enlisting householders in campaigns to spruce up their properties and by removing hazards from streets and highways, the Scouts share in civic efforts to make their communities more attractive, healthier and safer for motorists, pedestrians and playing children.

The employment service of the Charity Organization Society placed 1,785 persons last year, Miss Emilie Strauss, its secretary, reported last week at a meeting of the society's council in the offices of Walter S. Gifford, president of the society, at 195 Broadway.
Seventy-five children of alumnae participated this afternoon in the annual children's day festival and baby parade on the campus of the College of New Rochelle.

St. James Protestant Episcopal Church at Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Honour Redington Dickerman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Carter Dickerman of this city, and Dune Dee, East

A recommendation to the Federal Housing Administration has been presented by the National Association of Real Estate Boards following the adoption of a resolution by the directors asking that regulations be made to permit the release of individual apartment buildings in large-scale rental housing developments from the blanket mortgage covering the development.

Sir Harold Bellman, managing director of the Abbey Road Building Society of London, one of the largest organizations of its kind in the world and who has recently made several addresses on housing conditions in various parts of the United States, visited the Green Park home community at Eighty-fourth Street and Eliot Avenue, Elmhurst, last week.

The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States voted, 151 to 130, today to omit two sections of its Confession of Faith which, according to some speakers, formed the cornerstone of the church code.

An investigation by police officials and Assistant District Attorney William F. McGuinness resulted yesterday in the exoneration of two policemen who took part in an early morning chase that ended in the fatal shooting of John Bang, 17 years old, of 30 Sunnyside Avenue, Brooklyn.

The Pullman Company filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission a brief denying allegations made by State regulatory commissions of Idaho, New Hampshire, New Jersey, North. Dakota and Utah that it was seeking. a 10 per cent increase in fares for the sole purpose of enabling it to pay dividends.

It has not been a week of brotherly love in Europe. With the Czech parliamentary elections due today, Britain has been disturbed by reports of the movement of German troops in regions adjacent to the frontier of Czechoslovakia. The new vacuum-carbon dioxide oil treatment to keep eggs fresh in storage has been applied on a commercial scale and found to be much superior to other commercial methods of shall treatment.

SAFETY education in traffic matters grows apace. The American Automobile Association announced last week that thirty-nine universities and colleges in twenty States will offer this year Summer training courses for high school teachers who wish to become instructors in automobile operation and use.
