Speculation concerning the trend in Fall prices of floor coverings was general in the wholesale market here last week, despite the fact 'that the new season's goods will not be displayed to buyers until the first week in July.

The following Foreign Service changes since April 29 were announced today by the State Department: Edwin Schoenrich of Baltimore, now serving in the Department of State, assigned as Second Secretary of Legation and Consulat Asuncion, Paraguay.

The cult of open-air dining is growing from week to week as the days grow longer and the heat in creases. It is a cult not confined to those who are vacationing in coun try cottages or mountain camps Residents of towns and suburbs dwellers in penthouses and patrons of pavement cafes all are eating out of doors.
A year ago this month Mr. and Mrs. Simon W. Gerson moved from their two-room, $30-a-month apartment at 418 East Sixth Street, Manhattan, owned by the Tompkins Square Holding Company, Inc.

A one-mile special invitation race featuring Glenn Cunningham will be the highlight of an all-sports carnival to be conducted by the German-American Sports Alliance at Randalls Island Stadium this afternoon. Track will be one of seven snorts on the extensive program.

The first advertisement by the city for bids on the sale and demolition of the old Postoffice Building at Broadway and Park Row was printed yesterday in The City Record. Bids will be received until 11 A. M.. June 10 in the office of Lee Thompson Smith, director of the Bureau of Real Estate.
The University of Chicago swept all six singles and three doubles divisions to win the Big Ten tennis championship today for the second consecutive year.

Mrs. Milton A. Bridges, regent of Manhattan Chapter of the D. A. R., who recently was elected chairman of the New York State nominating committee, was named last week as chairman of the Regents' Round Table of Greater New York.

,Opening this week of several model homes and reports of expanding building operations in many of the active residential areas of Queens and Nassau Counties, L. I., present striking object lessons, according to the developers, of the growing interest in the ownership of mediumpriced dwellings.

To prevent any possibility of a repetition of the tragic incident of last year when the St. Bernard dogs of the Hospice of Grand St. Bernard Pass, Switzerland, killed a little girl. near. the hospice, the Swiss Society for the Protection of Animals has provided extensive new kennels for the pack.

ONE record says it was a woman who first stepped ashore at Plymouth Rock. Margaret Bell, noting that the record was set down more than 150 years after the event, is willing to count the statement as tradition merely;. but it supplies her story with one of its heroines -for Mary Chilton herself was a historic character--and strikes the keynote of her book's theme.

BRITISH colonials still constitute a large portion of new stamp arrivals but their volume promises to decrease from now on because a majority of the possessions have already issued their "new reign" adhesives.

BOWMAN, GEORGE A. (May 5). Estate. less than $10,000. To Emma K. Bowman, widow, executrix, 118 W. 57th St. HARKNESS, MARY A. (May 11). Estate, more than $10.000. To Isabel Harkness, daughter, 70 West 55th St., residue, Leroy T. Harkness,- 344 Washington Ave.. Brooklyn, executor.

Creation of a separate branch of the United States Army, under a single command, to coordinate all problems of transportation of troops and supplies in both peace and war times was urged last night by Colonel William J. Wilgus, transportation engineer.

Premier Benito Mussolini's Genoa speech on May 14, in which he said he did not know whether an Italo-French agreement was possible because the two countries "are on opposite sides of the barricade" in the ish question, led to an abrupt interruption in Italo-French negotiations.

The marriage of Miss Frances Burhop, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred D. Burhop of 395 Riverside Drive, to Rolfe Pottberg, son of Mrs. Ernest Emil Pottberg of Staten Island and the late Mr. Pottberg, took place last night in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

The report of the Federal Light and Traction Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months to March 31, issued- yesterday, shows a net income of $1,603,703 after oprating expenses, taxes and fixed charges.
Five affiliated New York City railroad corporations asked the Board of Tax Appeals today to redetermine about $110,500 in income and excess-profits tax deficiencies assessed against them for 1934.
In his second of two broadcasts with the NBC Symphony Orchestra, Sir. Adrian Boult, director of the British Broadcasting Company, devoted last night's program to works of his compatriots.
One man was drowned and two others were taken to Bellevue Hospital last night after they had plunged into the East River along the lower East Side.

Benny Goodman and his orchestra will present a "swing fiesta and dance carnival" Sunday night, June 12, at Madison Square Garden, to aid the Los Angeles Sanatorium, The City of Hope. The event is in celebration of the silver jubilee of the sanatorium.
THE gangplank is down for the Caribbean and the St. Lawrence, for the Norwegian fjords and the Mediterranean, as the Summer cruise season gets under way.
THE Warners, with an appreciative glance at "The Adventures of Robin Hood," have announced a program of "action" pictures for the new season.

Miss Barbara Whitcomb King, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Earle King of this city, will be married to Lieutenant Enrique D'Hamel Haskins, U. S. N., son of Mr. and Mrs. L. A. Haskins of Brooklyn, N. Y., on June 9 in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church here.

THE case of Mrs. T. Charles Farrelly against Crockford's, Inc., and its principal stock holders, Ely and Josephine Culbertson, is on the calendar for trial tomorrow morning in the New York State Supreme Court.

Three weeks ago, in approximately 450 communities of the United States and Canada, more than 50,000 women of Protestant denominations gathered at luncheons which emphasized and dramatized their desire to act in unison to promote the solution of national and international problems.

To the Screen Editor: In the recent discussions concerning American and foreign films it seems that every one has had a fling at the subject except the person most rightfully entitled to be heard, namely, the stockholder or investor in these various mismanaged enterprises....
ONE of the last gifts that kindly Fortune can make to any man is a competent biographer and expositor. In this, as otherwise, William James has enjoyed her especial favor.

AIR-MINDED travelers who seek North Atlantic reservations will have to go down to the sea in ships for another year at least. No American or British commercial aircraft will fly to a schedule, even with mails, according to reports here.

Jeremiah K. Cronin, vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, was re-elected chairman of the management division's board of directors at the annual meeting of the division at the Hotel Astor last week.
Czechoslovakia, menaced by German intervention, called up army reserves and put 400,000 troops near the German border. Agitation in the Sudeten districts was quieted by this display of authority.
A busy week of entertaining will precede the marriage on Saturday of Miss Zaydee Dejonge and Mason Dix Harris, which will take place in Christ Church here.

More than 1.100 persons attended a testimonial dinner to Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, first woman teacher to serve as a member of the Board of Education of New York City, at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.

Early in the century the Garden City Golf Club's invitation tournament and the late Walter J. Travis were synonymous. Starting in 1902, when the event was inaugurated, the "Old Man" won it nine times, eight of his triumphs coming in a row.
The cooperation of several railroads is being emphasized as an important factor in Yale's integrated course of graduate studies in rail transportation.
Track and Field-Princeton won the Heptagonal Games yesterday for the first time, Cornell finishing second and Columbia third. Michigan retained the Western Conference championship.
THE title of this autobiography is well chosen, for the scenes of Sir Basil Thomson's activities during forty years of service to his country have been varied and widely separated.
June Week at the Naval Academy will begin on May 27, and culminate on June 2 in the graduation of a class of 439 members, the largest since 1935.
ASHEVILLE, N. C.-Six Southern States have designated college girls as representatives to attend the eleventh Rhododendron Festival here, June 12 to 19.

New Utrecht High School's runners of Brooklyn retained their championship for the second straight year in the ninth annual running of the metropolitan evening high schools' track and field championship at Pershing Field today as they beat back the challenge of Dickinson Evening, which sponsors the meet.

HAVING produced "On Your Toes" and "Babes in Arms" in the late springtime when the theatre is generally putting up its shutters, Dwight Deere Wiman has chosen the same time of year to produce his best musical comedy.

Mrs. Aline Davis Hays, textile designer, was elected president of the National League of Women Shoppers yesterday at the close of its first annual convention at the Hotel Wellington, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

Thomas E. Colleton, FHA director for New Jersey, points out that the recent clarification of Federal Housing Administration terms for insurance in resort areas should prove a stimulus to building and refinancing of properties in such localities.
More than 200 writers, meeting yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, advocated a Federal Bureau of Fine Arts.
Sir Howard W. Kennard, British Ambassador, and Leon Noel, French Ambassador, were received this afternoon by Foreign Minister Josef Beck.
Neel Enslen, radio announcer employed by the National Broadcasting Company, was found dead at 3:30 P. M. yesterday in the kitchen of his home, 80 Haven Avenue.

Three American Legion posts joined yesterday at a memorial service which drew 2,000 men, wo,men and children to the Mall in Central Park. The exercises were conducted by Lexington Post 108, Schenley Post 1190, and Department of Sanitation Post 1110.

Changes in prices of corn on the Board of Trade here last week were confined largely to small fractions of a cent to the bushel. The close yesterday showed net losses of 3/8 to 5/8 cent, with the May at 57 3/4 cents, July 58 7/8 to 59 cents, and the September 59 7/8 to 60 cents a bushel.

Harrison Tweed, president of the Legal Aid Society of New York, made public yesterday a list of lawyers who have agreed to serve, without fee, on the "senior" panel of volunteer defense counsel in criminal trials of defendants unable to engage counsel.
Eleanor King, who played the leading role in the film "The Birth of a Baby," gave birth to an eightpound boy in Doctors Hospital last night. Mother and baby were reported doing well.

A monument was dedicated here this afternoon on the grave of John James Joseph Gourgas, who in 1813 founded the Supreme Council of Northern Masonic Jurisdiction. The ceremony was in New York Bay Cemetery, Garfield and Chapel Avenues.

With several of the top-rated stars in action, the polo players of Meadow Brook, preparing for the formal opening of the club's fields next week-end, galloped through two games at Phipps Field today, one of them a round-robin and the other ending in a tie at 7-all at the end of seven periods.
The annual Summer review and exhibition drill of La Salle Military Academy's four companies was held this afternoon before an audience of more than 5,000 persons. Company B won highest honors.
Debates will open in Congress tomorrow on the two most important Administration issues since the Reorganization Bill was recommitted earlier in the session.

A committee of the Hudson County Benevolent Association, which says it has a membership of 1,800 Jews, reported yesterday that the eviction of Rabbi Benjamin Plotkin's congregation Emanu-el from the Jersey City Jewish Center was justified because of Rabbi Plotkin's radicalism.

Senator Borah urged today a system of single taxation of income from public securities. Under his proposal the Federal Government would levy upon income from its own bonds and the States on income from their own securities.
Governor Lehman paid tribute today to George Foster Peabody as the man responsible for the "full development" of Saratoga Springs as a public health resort.

Mayor La Guardia's statement of his credo' at the communion breakfast of the St. George Association of the New York City Police Department a week ago was commended by Dr. Don O. Shelton, president of the National Bible Institute, yesterday in his baccalaureate sermon to graduates and students of the institute in its assembly hall, 340 West Fifty-fifth Street.

Harry Lumley, former majorleague baseball star, who started his career under Ned Hanlon on the old Brooklyn Superbas of the National League, died in a hospital here today after a long illness. His age was 57.
Mrs. Katherine C. Gorman, widow of Judge James E. Gorman of the Municipal Court, died today in Woman's College Hospital at the age of 75.

A strike of 2,000 wholesale liquor salesmen was called yesterday by the Wholesale Licensed Alcoholic Beverage Salesmen's Union, Local 20,376, an A. F. of L. affiliate. Sol Cilento, business representative of the union, said it had received assurances of support from A. F. of L. truck drivers and warehousemen in its effort to tie up the industry.
The tendency of the franc this week on the exchange market continued steady. There was further repatriation of capital, and this resulted in sales of sterling and dollars against francs.

More than 3,000 persons gathered yesterday before an outdoor stage on the playground of Hillside Homes at Seymour Avenue and Boston Post Road, the Bronx, to see a pageant portraying the history of the Bronx from the day Jonas Bronck purchased 500 acres of land from an Indian chief 300 years ago.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 32 per cent of capacity and constituted the fourth consecutive week for this rate.

In recognition of her work as chairman of the American Theatre Council's Committee of the Apprentice Theatre, Antoinette Perry will be honored tonight at a testimonial supper at the Ritz Carlton Hotel. Other guests will be fifty volunteer workers who assisted Miss Perry in arranging the auditions at which more than 100 young players were tested.

The funeral of John Thomas Smith, a leading layman of the Catholic Archdiocese of New York, who died suddenly of a heart attack Saturday afternoon at his home, 154 Greenwich Street, in his sixty-ninth year, will be held Wednesday at 11 A. M.

The fiftieth anniversary of the dedicating of the edifice of St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Bedford Avenue near De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn, was celebrated yesterday morning by the congregation. The sermon was by the Rev. Dr. Ellis B. Burgess, president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York.

The 200th anniversary of the "spiritual birth" of John Wesley, founder of Methodism, was the occasion yesterday for tributes by clergymen here. The Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent, rector of. St., Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street, compared Wesley with Robin Hood because both brought to the neglected and oppressed a leadership similar in many respects. Dr. Sargent further said:

Friends of former State Senator George R. Fearon of Syracuse intend to start a movement to make him the Republican nominee for Governor,- it was learned yesterday. Mr. Fearon so far has indicated no desire to be a candidate and those sponsoring his boom expect to ask him for permission to present his name to the State convention.

Maude Adams will head the list of speakers in the Town Hall Club's 1938-39 morning lecture series, it was announced yesterday. The subject of Miss Adams's lecture will be "Phases of the Drama," illustrated by scenes from some plays in which she has, appeared.

For the second time in a week Rudy York hit a home run with the bases full today and gave the Tigers a 4-to-3 victory over the Red Sox. York's blow came after Jack Wilson had walked Pete Fox and Dixie Walker and Charlie Gehringer had singled in the first.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Everett Bartlett Jr. of 1,010 Fifth Avenue, this city, and Amagansett, L. I., have announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Elizabeth Irving Bartlett, to Lewis Bain Kimball, son of Mrs. Roger Nelson Kimball of New York and Kenosha, Wis., and the late Mr. Kimball.

We love to get a glimpse of a legislator in his private hours. The Appendix of the Congessional Record reports an address by the Hon. Charles Albert Plumley, Congressman at Large for Vermont, before the Columbia Historical Society in Washington.

Percy T. Oldham has been appointed manager of special sales for the By-Products Steel Corporation, subsidiary of the Lukens Steel Company, Coatesville, Pa., according to announcement issued for publication today.

The French Davis Cup team clinched its series with Monaco today in the second round of the European Zone play when Henri -Bolelli and Pierre Pelizza defeated the Monaco doubles team of Gaston Medecin and Vladimir Landau, 6-2, 6-0, 6-3.
Swift Co., meat packers, have been ordered to disestablish so-called "company unions" at their plants at Evansville, Ind., and Denver, Col., the National Labor Relations Board announced today.

The improved economic situation in the Kingdom of Norway and the favorable money market conditions there and abroad have enabled the Norwegian Government, its political subdivisions and Norwegian corporations to refund in the last three years their foreign and domestic obligations into issues bearing lower rates of interest, according to a bulletin issued by Dean John T. Madden, director of the Institute of International Finance.

ARIZONA COWBOYS, by Dane Coolidge. (Dutton, $2.50.) Stories of cowboys and prospectors in the Southwest. MY AUSTRIA, by Kurt Schuschnigg. (Knopf, $3.) The autobiography of the former Chancellor of Austria. Introduction by Dorothy Thompson.

There was no danger of European war over the annexation of Austria. The hopelessness of the Austrian case was that everybody, especially the Austrians, knew that not a finger would be lifted to save them.

Reports during the week indicated a quieter tone generally in industry. Official summaries maintain that virtually no labor reserve exists among the registered unemployed from which to meet employers' demands.

Yankee Division veterans closed their four-day convention here today by enshrining the memory of their wartime commander, Major Gen. Clarence R. Edwards, in ,permanent bronze in the Rhode Island State House.
Ted Lyons, 37-year-old right-hander, who came to the White Sox from Baylor University fifteen years ago, scored his 200th American League victory today in defeating the Senators, 9 to 2.

John J. Raskob of New York disclosed today that the old San Pedro copper and silver mine had been added to the 250,000-acre New Mexico properties held by him and Thomas C. Campbell, Montana "wheat king."

The Department of Hospitals be should select internes for city hospitals without any participation by the Municipal Civil Service Com- ly mission, according to a report of te: a New York Academy of Medicine subcommittee, made public yester- El day by Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals of New York City.

Glenn Cunningham ran the mile in 4:12.9 yesterday in winning, an exhibition race which featured the athletic program of the German Sport and Field Day at Randalls Island. The transplanted Kansan entertained a gathering of 6,000 spectators with his performance.

In defense of midle-aged workers who face the economic scrap heap, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that a loving and just God cannot be pleased with our age when it is so unkind to older people."

The phrase "Lower East Side" has had many meanings in our city's history. It has been associated with poverty, crime, congestion and bad housing; with picturesque Old World survivals, endlessly fascinating to the stay-at-home tourist;

All round compulsory price-cutting at the cost of industry was foreshadowed this week by the Nazi party's principal economic organ. Owing to the Reich's increasing indebtedness, this authority says, industry must expect a shrinkage of public orders and, when this occurs, only a lower price level will be adequate to maintain production and selling at the present high level of production.

The New York Civic Orchestra, under Josef Blatt, gave a concert yesterday afternoon at the WPA Theatre of Music. Joseph Wagner appeared as soloist in Beethoven's fifth piano concerto. Ira A. Hirchmann was the commentator.

The State Labor Department is seeking to safeguard the $100,000,000 unemployment insurance fund against "raids" by seasonal workers in periods when their industries are not operating and the workers do not expect to be employed.

Two heroes of the Revolutionary War, Lieutenant Harrms Barkaloo and Private Simon Cortelyou, were honored yesterday by nearly 3,000 persons who attended the sixteenth annual memorial service of the Robert I. Porter Post 986, Veterans of Foreign Wars, in Barka1oo Cemetery, Narrows Avenue and MacKay Place, Brooklyn.

A home-made burglar alarm attached to a poor box in the Roman Catholic Church of St. John the Baptist de Salle in Stapleton, S. I., by a priest who likes to make "gadgets," was responsible yesterday for the capture of a man believed responsible for many church thefts on the island.

Announcement was made here last night of the death on Thursday at his Winter home in Miami, Fla., of Charles D. Purroy, former Chief of the New York Fire Department and uncle of the late Mayor John Purroy Mitchel. He was 83 years old.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William H. Mann of 37-22 Bowne Street, Flushing, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Marian Mann, to Siffrein Maury Vass Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Vass of Rutherford, N. J.

The Constitutional Convention is nearing the end of its first phase, as the deadline for the introduction of proposed changes in the State's basic law is set for Wednesday. From then on, unless an extension is voted by the convention, new proposals may be submitted only by unanimous consent or from a committee as a report.

Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy will resume today an investigation of an explosion and fire that occurred in the five-story building at 1,247 Sixth Avenue at 5:05 o'clock yesterday morning. The fire caused substantial damage.

Approximately one-fourth of the World's Fair area vacated by the P withdrawal of Germany was taken last week by Portugal, which signed a contract for 25,000 square feet, was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation.

The champion Newark Bears swooped to a twin victory over their neighborhood rivals, the Jersey City Giants, today before an overflow crowd of 23,610, believed to be the largest in this city's half-century of baseball history.

With its owner and pilot, Captain Ugo V. d'Annunzio, hanging to its tail in an effort to get back in the cockpit, a monoplane ran away at Seversky Field here this afternoon and, after a series of ground gyrations, crashed into an automobile parked behind a fence at the side of the field, critically injuring a woman.

G. E. R. Gedye, THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent in Czechoslovakia, traced events leading up to the present crisis in a radio broadcast heard here last night over a network of the National Broadcasting Company.
Of the 30,469 postmaster appointments made from March 4, 1933, to May 12, this 'year, 8,229, or about 27 per cent, were women, Postmaster General James A. Farley said today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Every one will agree that the most pressing problems of this country today are the persistence of a severe depression in business and a high and probably increasing rate of unemployment. Upon the solution, or mitigation, of these problems depends our ability to deal satisfactorily with related problems of expenditures for relief, burdens of taxation and, indeed, our whole fiscal policy.

Seven hundred Jewish members of the Police Department Shomrim b Society attended their sixteenth annual memorial service for dead members of the police force yesterday afternoon at Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street.

Marking the fiftieth anniversary of his service with Abraham Straus, Frank Jackson, receptionist in the executive offices of the Brooklyn store, was tendered a scroll and a financial gift by Edward C. Blum, chairman of the board of directors, at a presentation ceremony held last Friday.
Two women and a man were killed and five other persons were injured, two critically, in a collision on Route 25 near Green Street here this afternoon.

The ending of Cuban Week, which this year celebrated the thirty-sixth anniversary of Cuban independence, was observed yesterday by the Comite Pro-Cuba in a brief ceremony at 1:30 P. M. in the plaza at 156th Street and Riverside Drive.

There were too many Delaneys on the field. The mighty men of Leix, with five Delaneys carrying much of the burden, ran roughshod over the All New York selected fifteen in the second game of the roundrobin Gaelic football series at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, winning 18 to 9, before 12,000.

Formation of a Council for Decency in Magazines to check the sale of objectionable publications, especially to children and young people, was announced yesterday by a committee on organization. The group intends to supplement the work of organizations which prosecute "legally actionable obscene periodicals," the announcement said.

Reason to be a "bit more optimistic" is found by the Jewish Correspondence-a new fortnightly organ of the World Jewish Congress here-in surveying today's attitude toward anti-Semitism as reflected by the attitude the t congress delegates found in talks with statesmen here during the League Council meeting last week.
Three memorial services were held yesterday afternoon in honor of the war dead of the "Fighting Irish," 165th Infantry, formerly the "Old Sixty-ninth."
Cotton prices moved to substantially lower levels last week. Although changes on individual trading days were small, prices went lower each day and the total losses for the week were large.

Seventeen undergraduate students in the City College unit of the Reserve Officers Training Corps attached to the band have been promoted and special service ribbons have been awarded to thirty-three students and alumni, Colonel Oliver P. Robinson,

Insurgent aviation defied highly unfavorable weather again today and effectively aided troops commanded by Generals Garcia Escamez and Garcia Valino to advance in the southernmost corner of mountainous Lower Aragon below Corbalan, Escriche and Mosqueruela.

The success of France's defense loan issue this week is ascribable chiefly to the fact that the amount was comparatively small, the interest rate high and the option of redemption every three years an attract tive provision. The whole issue was taken up by the banks, thus enabling the treasury to announce the success of the loan on the day of issue.

John W. Slocum, descendant of the 4 original patentee of Monmouth County, died this morning at his home on Cedar Avenue, Allenhurst, after a heart attack, at the age of 71. He had been in poor health for two years.
Camp Siegfried, the Nazi Summer camp at Yaphank, L. I., opened yesterday but postponed its scheduled opening ceremonies until next Sunday.
Railway receipts here continue to fall, now showing a decline of [Pound]496,000 since the beginning of the year, compared with twelve months ago.

After announcing last Friday that it would close the next night, "The Man From Cairo" found some encouragement in Saturday's receipts and has decided to play along for a while at the Broadhurst. However, there will be a cast change late this week, Viola Roache being required at a dress rehearsal of "The Two Bouquets" on Thursday

While reports from Ohio tire manufacturing centers forecast a marked expansion in shipments for the Summer replacement season, Sears, Roebuck Co., it was learned today, have reduced prices on their mailorder tire lines around 8 to 14 per cent.

The Hale property, consisting of more than 100 acres, with a fourteen-room colonial residence, at Bernardsville, N. J., has been purchased by Alfred Ely of the firm of Choate, Larocque, Mitchell Ely of 40 Wall Street. Fred W. Jones was broker in the deal.

Imports into India from the United States increased in value to $39,390,000 in 1937, as compared with $31,090,000 in 1936, while exports to the United States were $77,453,000 in 1937, and as compared with $62,282,000 in the previous year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

he first evidence to support the charge that Harlan County coal operators hired law enforcement officers to conduct a reign of terror against union officials and sympathizers is to be offered tomorrow by agents -of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Federal court before Judge P. Church Ford and a jury which it took a week to select.

The Bees forged link No. 7 in their successive victory chain today as Milburn Shoffner, 31-year - old southpaw rookie, won his own game by singling in the winning run in the eleventh inning of the series opener with the Cubs. The score was 2 to 1.
The German wholesale price index on May 11 was 105.5, unchanged from the week before.

Mr. and Mrs. Leo Totten of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edna Louise Totten, to ??ames Wilson Weaver of Philadelphia. Miss Totten is a graduate of Montclair Teachers College and Mr. Weaver of Lafayette College. The wedding will take place June 25.

Costa Rica's economic future is hopeful and recovery is under way, the Minister of Finance, Francisco Gutierrez, said in discussing the budget for the next fiscal year, in which the estimated revenues of $5,750,000 exceed by only $3,345, estimated expenses.

A taxicab got out of control in Central Park yesterday on the East Drive at Ninety-fifth Street, went through a fence, bumped over a boulder and crashed into a tree before it came to a stop. Hundreds of strollers in the park witnessed the accident.

The ten-game winning streak of the Manhattan College baseball team came to an end yesterday as the New York Athletic Club nine turned back the collegians, 2 to 1, at Travers Island. Although outhit, nine to six, the clubmen played a tight defensive game.

Motor vehicle registrations in the United States last year totaled 29,705,220, an increase of more than 1,539,000 over the preceding year, according to a summary of State reports made public today by the Bureau of Public Roads.

The American Jewish Congress, which has proposed the holding next month of a plebiscite of the Jews of the United States to create a united front against anti-Semitism in Eastern and Central Europe, made public yesterday a statement signed by 137 clerical and lay leaders in twenty-nine States condemns ing Jewish oppression as "a blot upon the civilization of our time."

Confronted with questions of church unity, minimum salaries, a compulsory retirement age for pastors and other matters of interest to the 2,000,000 members of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, as well as to those of several other denominations, the Sesquicentennial Presbyterian General Assembly will open its sessions here this week.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 81.4, which compares with 80.8 a week ago, 80.5 two weeks ago, 80.6 three weeks ago and 81 four weeks ago.

The statement of the Bank of France for May 12 shows a decrease of almost 2,000,000,000 francs in loans and discounts. Among liabilities, current accounts fell 3,000,000,000 francs while circulation rose 900,000,000. The total of sight liabilities fell 2,021,000,000 to 120,553,000,000 francs.

Mrs. Eve Bickford, wife of a wealthy Buffalo (N. Y.) business man, was forced to return to Berlin by plane today when the Home Office refused to grant her permission to re-enter Britain after a trip to Germany. The Home Office declined to discuss reasons for the ban.

Convening at Crosswicks today, 300 members of the Religious Society of Friends unanimously opposed, the pending amendment of the State Constitution to permit the return of horse racing and parimutuel betting.

Lord Robert Crichton-Stuart, son of the Marquess of Bute, and Lady DUKE Crichton-Stuart are arriving today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. Others coming are Dr. J. Lundy, A. Chester Beatty, Brig. Gen. Sir Howard Hartley, Maurice Duperray, president of Rotary International,

The capital heard with keen interest today that Justice Benjamin C. Hilliard of the Colorado Supreme Court, who conferred with President Roosevelt recently, had entered the race for the Democratic Senatorial nomination in Colorado against Senator Alva B. Adams.

A warning against going to opposite extremes was given yesterday from the steps of the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart. in Brooklyn to Roman Catholics "in their fight on communism to protect themselves" and to Jews in their fight against nazism.
Removal of Alexandra Artukhina, veteran woman Bolshevist, from leadership in the Cotton Textile Workers Union for failing to take energetic action against anti-Soviet wreckers was disclosed today.

The bert engagement of Miss Virginia Crutchfield Morgan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert McIlwaine Morgan of this place, to Robert James Carpenter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Carpenter of New Rochelle, has been announced by her parents.

Contraction in bankers' clearings continues. A further fall of 24.1 per cent in building plans in April lifts the decline in the first four months of the year to 15.7 per cent, while the rayon output still is decreasing.

World wheat prices are hovering around the lowest levels in four years, and the prospect of a record-breaking North American crop being harvested this season, combined with the inability of several potential importing countries in Europe to finance large purchases of grain from the United States, have resulted in extremely bearish sentiment prevailing among traders both here and abroad.

Harry Chapman Ford stage manager, director and playwright, and son of the owner of Ford's Theatre in Washington where President Lincoln was shot, died Saturday evening at his home in Rutherford, N. J., from coronary thrombosis. He was 60 years old.

Election of the presidents and thirty-seven other officers of Princeton University's eighteen Prospect Street upper-class eating clubs was announced today by Kenneth M. Lynch of Charleston, S. C., president of the interclub committee. The officers will serve throughout the 1938-39 academic year. They are:

Sales conference, American Gas Association, Hotel Commodore, opens 9:30 A. M., continuing tomorrow. Speakers; Hale A. Clark, Nils T. Sellman, Alva L. Palmer, Thomas J. Gallagher, Harry O. King. Luncheon, 12:45 P. M. Address by Zenn Kaufman.

The Third Division Society, A. E. F., met in the grand ballroom of the Manhattan Opera House last night to pay tribute to their chaplain, the Rev. Frank M. O'Reilly. Four hundred veterans of the division's World War days and about as many women were present at the dinner, which marked the award to Father O'Reilly of the Decoration of the Purple Heart, with an Oak Leaf.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday at her home in Washington, D. C., of Miss Marie Elizabeth Josephine Czarnomska, who was Professor of English Literature at Smith College, 1888-1904.

Whatever the actual position may be behind the negotiations between France and Italy, the financial markets in Great Britain seem to have scented some interruption in the movement toward a political appeasement in Europe. They are reflecting this feeling in their exceptional quietude and hesitation.

Change in the State Constitution to make possible a uniform method of selection of grand. and trial jurors throughout the State was proposed yesterday by the Grand Jury Association of New York County. The proposal, which would empower the Appellate Division in each judicial district to designate the Commissioner of Jurors in each county, will be submitted to the Constitutional Convention.

Dr. Frank C. Whitmore, president of the American Chemical Society, announced yesterday that the Priestley Gold Medal, highest honor of the organization, has been awarded to Professor Marston Taylor Bogert of Columbia University for "distinguished service to chemistry."

Hungary's police force received general communion today in a special preliminary to the opening Wednesday of the Thirty-fourth Eucharistic Congress. Three thousand police attended the services in historic St. Stephen's Cathedral.
After five days' selling which, however, did not attain any considerable volume, semi-panic conditions dominated the week's stock market. This situation was aggravated by international events.
Four championship contests were among the highlights today at the closing session of the twelfth annual Watchung Riding and Driving Club two-day horse show.

Showing to excellent advantage, Cherry Red, Mrs. E. Graham Lewis's sprightly 5-year-old chestnut gelding, was named the hunter champion at the sixth annual show of the Queens County Horse Show Association yesterday.

Employment conditions have improved in Sweden, according to a report received by the Department of Commerce from the American commercial attache at Stockholm, which showed that the number of registered unemployed in that country at the end of March was 19,184, as compared with 21,766 at the end of February and 27,750 at the end of March, 1937.

Making allowance for the difference in the number of working days in April of this year and last, Great Britain's foreign trade last month was not inspiring. Although the results were not exactly bad, they were discouraging. The figures were below those of the preceding month and those of April, 1937.

Three British sailors were wounded critically today when a bomb struck the 3,995-ton British merchant ship Penthames during an insurgent air raid. The ship took fire and the flames had not been subdued an hour later.

Approval of China's reported action last week in bombing Japanese civilians with pamphlets rather than explosives and a pledge of "prayerful support" for the Chinese were in a message which the delegates to the national meeting of women's organizations of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. cabled today to Mme.-Chiang Kaishek, wife of China's generalissimo.

Not far from the rumble of the Third Avenue elevated, in a section where thousands of underprivileged live, a plea for better housing was made yesterday afternoon by 300 gayly costumed youngsters who traced the development of East Harlem in the eighth annual May Festival sponsored by the Union Settlement.

Celebrating their fiftieth year as heads of the grocery chain they established, Charles and Diedrioh Gristede, co-founders of the Gristede Brothers, Inc., last night gave a "golden anniversary" dinner to more than 600 employes of the company at the Hotel Astor.

A proposal to put the American business man in a planned economic system similar to that already set up by Secretary Wallace for the farmer is being discussed by some left-wing advisers of the Administration.

The Yugoslav press does not comment today on the GermanCzech crisis, although it publishes full reports. Verme, under a Budapest date line, prints an unconfirmed report that the Hungarian Army has been ordered into readiness for eventualities.

The Interborough Rapid Transit Company has awarded contracts totaling $1,539,330 thus far for fifty new steel subway cars, materials and equipment necessary to provide express service from the I. R. T. Times Square and Grand Central stations to the World's Fair and Flushing, it was announced yesterday by Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for the I. R. T.

For the closing week of May, the tenacious art season in New York provides more than a score of exhibitions, ranging from oils, sculpture and water-colors through photography, decoration and Spanish arts and crafts.

We have frequently expressed the opinion that the proposed Federal Wage and Hour Bill, scheduled to come before the House for debate today, is unwise--that its tendency will be still further to raise production costs, to retard recovery and to intensify unemployment.

A silver loving cup, the cost of which was defrayed by contributions from mothers in the neighborhood of Tenth Avenue and West Forty-ninth Street, will be awarded this morning to Henry R. Sutphen Jr. of the Boys Athletic League. The presentation will be at "Tot Lot" (of the Boys Athletic League).
Elie Lescot, Haitian Minister, taking cognizance of the European situation, said today that inter-American cooperation "is the shield and buckler" of the small nations of this hemisphere.

The unpredictable Billy Rose presented his second variety bill at the Casa Manana last night. Everything from a surprisingly funny Bert Wheeler to Fifty-second Street swing music and Fritzi Scheff singing again her part in "Mademoiselle Modiste," has found its way into this edition of "Streamlined Varieties." After it was all over Mr.

Rebuking "those who sneer today at the men who 'fought to make the world safe for democracy, " the Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig, in an address yesterday afternoon at the annual memorial service of the Veterans of the Seventh Regiment at West End Collegiate Church, Seventy-seventh Street and West End Avenue, told the veterans that they were exponents of the highest ideals of patriotism.

The Central Committee on Lumber Standards has approved a revision of Simplified Practice Recommendation R16-29, Lumber, otherwise known as American Lumber Standards, and has sent copies to all interests for comment, the De-. partment of Commerce announced today.

With their motors "conked" and not a parachute among them, the Dodgers yesterday pancaked all over Ebbets Field and for the second successive day a crowd of more than 16,000 loyal Flatbush fans had to pick their way out of the park through the debris of shattered hopes.

Dr. Preston A. Wade, in 1,045 Park Ave, through Alfries Realty Corp. I. B. Mercadants, in 300 Central Park W. Kenneth MacKenna. in 144 E 24th St; Miles R. Price, in 16 Park Ave; Ernie Valle, Mrs. Asa Bement, in 77 Park Ave: Mrs. Elizabeth Brady, in 154 E 56th St; Lorelle O'Hara, broker.

Closing exercises Of the Congregation Emanu-EI Religious School were held yesterday morning at the temple, Fifth Avenue and Sixtyfifth Street. The Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson told the confirmation class and other students, that they "must follow the teachings of your forefathers and carry out the Ten Commandments if you would overcome anti-Semitism."

In an effort to improve circular specifications for municipal securities so that the investing public may have greater assurance of full disclosure of all essential information, the municipal securities committee of the Investment Bankers Association of America, in a report published today, has made proposals for increased self-regulation free from any governmental agencies.
A banking group headed by Chandler Co., Inc., will offer today 20,000 shares of Southern California Water Company 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $25 par value.

The greater part of Northern Styria and Carinthia has been flooded from heavy rains and melting snows during the last few days. The River Mur has overflowed its banks, causing considerable damage in Gratz, where a number are dead and many injured.

A motley assortment of young men and women, dressed for life in the great out-of-doors, carried folding boats and pushed bicycles through Grand Central Station early yesterday to ride the first hobby train this season on the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad to Falls Village, Conn., in the Berkshire Hills.

A full meeting of the British Cabinet on Sunday is sufficiently unusual to underline the gravity of the emergency the members assembled to discuss. Every Government in Europe kept vigil over the week-end while the issues of peace and war hung on developments on the Czechoslovak border.

Admittance into public life of men who take advantage of free speech to "preach a frightful doctrine of destruction and deliberately try to drive God out of the hearts of little children" was denounced yesterday by the Rev. Thomas Lester Graham, preaching at solemn mass In St. Patrick's Cathedral.
A five-point program for amendments to the Judiciary Article of the State Constitution has been forwarded to delegates of the Constitutional Convention by the Merchants' Association of New York.

Invitations have been issued by Mr. and Mrs. Clifford T. Hillman of this city for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Barbara Reed Hillman, to Albert Johnstone Davids, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest A. H. Davids of Maplewood.
The Rome-Berlin axis tonight stretched a barrier across Europe that extended to the realm of communications and retarded telephonic connections with Prague.

Substantial increases in employment and payrolls in all branches of the construction industry from the middle of March to the middle of April were reported today by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner.

A plea for economic cooperation between the American nations to solve the "very serious problem" resulting from overproduction of coffee was made this afternoon by Dr. Adrian Recinos, Guatemalan Minister to the United States, in the third of a series of good-will broadcasts conducted by the Pan American Union with the cooperation of the State Department through the facilities of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Mrs. Jennie L. Weeks Jewell, wife of Thomas A. Jewell, died early yesterday at their home, 30 Deepdene Road, Forest Hills, Queens, after a short illness, at the age of 69. She was vice regent of the Ellen Hardin Walworth chapter of the D. A. R., a member of the National Society of the Daughters of American Colonists and of the Society of Patriots and Founders.

Miss Virginia Davega, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abram Davega of 680 West End Avenue, was married last evening at the Waldorf-Astoria to Robert E. Silvers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Silvers of 924 West End Avenue. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. William F. Rosenblum.

The 300th anniversary of the founding of the New Sweden Colony in the Delaware Valley in 1638 and the establishment of the Lutheran Church on American soil was commemorated at special services here today at Trinity Lutheran Church. Manne Lindholm, Swedish vice consul in New York was a guest of the congregation.

Five hundred members of Catholic veteran and fraternal organizations marched in Astoria, Queens, yesterday in the final feature of the fortieth anniversary celebration of Lincoln Council, Knights of Columbus, Astoria.

The money market here is returning slowly to normal following on the upheaval caused by the sudden heavy withdrawal of French funds after the devaluation of the franc. This movement is proceeding at a much slower pace, even if it has not actually ceased, while both the Bank of England and the Treasury are taking steps to release credit still immobilized in the exchange fund as the result of franc sales.

Twenty-eight degrees will be presented tonight at the thirty-eighth annual commencement of the Biblical Seminary in New York, 235 East Forty-ninth Street. The address will be given by Dr. James Wallace, former president an Macalester College.

The June 1 coupons of the American tranche of the Young Loan (German Government 5 1/2 per cent International Loan of 1930) stamped "U. S. A. Domicile Oct. 1, 1935," may be sold against dollars on or after maturity at J. P. Morgan Co., New York,

After a four-year dictatorial regime, King Boris III today restored ostensible democracy when he opened the newly elected Parliament. In a speech that was much cheered he stressed the amelioration of Bulgaria's international position during the last two years.

Some weeks ago, right after the opening of the trout season in New York State, we ran a questionnaire in this column in an effort to obtain the feeling of trout anglers on certain phases of the conservation law pertaining to season openings, legal size, creel limits and restricted fly water.

Clarence (Buddy) Combs paced the Pegasus Polo Club of Rockleigh, N. J., to victory over the Monmouth County Country Club today. The score was 8 to 7. Combs galloped through the Monmouth defense for seven of the eight goals chalked up by Pegasus.

Stocks of whisky at the end of April amounted to 470,500,046 tax gallons, an increase of 48,956,460 over the same date last year, and whisky production in April of this year amounted to 8,071,383 tax gallons, a decrease of 11,045,574 from the same month last year, the Alcohol Tax Unit said today.
A decrease of 6 per cent in the number of cases receiving public general relief-that is, local as distinguished from Federal relief--and a 10 per

Ocean travel has increased in the last week as confidence in the upswing of business has grown, according to steamship agents. Previously there had been a number of cancellations caused by pessimistic reports.
A clear-cut liberal-conservative battle appeared in prospect for the Oregon Gubernatorial campaign this Fall as returns trickled in from remote precincts in Friday's primary.

MANHATTAN CARD AND PAPER CO., INC., 25 Beekman St., by Waring Central Co., Inc., for $732; C. M. Envelope Co., Inc., $106; Tension Envelope Corp., $30. John W. Simpson was appointed receiver under $1,000 bond by Judge Patterson. MOHR BROWN, INC., building supplies. 279-95 South William St.. Newburgh, by Java Brick Works, for $704; Middlehope Sand and Gravel Co., $832; Yuess Gardens Co., Inc., $3.

Italy's highly mobile Libyan troops launched a make-believe attack today toward the frontier of French Tunisia on the northwest in manoeuvres to test their war power. Marshal Italo Balbo, Governor of this Italian colony in North Africa, was in command of the manoeuvres, which were witnessed by King Victor Emmanuel.

For the first time in the history of Queen's University of Kingston, Ont., an American student has won the institute's Robert Bruce Scholarship, it was learned here yesterday. The winner is Rosalind Biggerstaff, 18 years old, of 7 Elmwood Avenue, Chatham, N. J. She is the daughter of the Rev. Robert A. Biggerstaff, minister of the Ogden Memorial Church of Chatham.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will make a film version of Charles Dickens's "Christmas Carol" this Summer for release during the Christmas season. Lionel Barrymore, who has read the story over the air each Christmas for the last four years, will play Scrooge.

Order and reorder activity quieted in most divisions of the wholesale market last week. Action in the apparel field centered on such specific types as washable sports Rocks, graduation, bridal and bridesmaid dresses, medium-price dark sheers and popular price cotton laces.

A dispatch from Para to the newspaper O Globo said about 2,000 men from French Guiana had virtual possession of the Calcoene gold washing region on the Brazilian side of the Oyapock River on the frontier between the two countries.

Soviet authorities today gave attentive regard to war-threatening developments between Germany and Czechoslovakia. By avoiding any comment that might complicate the situation, they indicated a belief that the situation was critical. The Soviet attitude was one of awaiting developments.

Miss Audrey Elizabeth Pile will have her sister, Mrs. John A. Clarke of Scarsdale, for matron of honor at her marriage to Harry J. Miller Jr., which takes place here on June 10 in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

There is needed today a church that can break, with respectability, custom and cant, the Rev. Dr. Edmund Melville Wylie, associate pastor, declared yesterday morning in the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-first Street.
Coming out of their slump like something shot out of a gun, the Giants served notice upon a gay gathering of 30,343 at the Polo Grounds yesterday that the big drought was happily over.

J. Jay Shelley, two floors in 1,600 Broadway, between 48th and 49th Sts, from the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co for bar and grill and night club to be opened about Aug. 20; L. George Horowitz, broker. Ida Lynn, Inc. millinery, store at 279 Broadway from the Frank G. Shattuck Co; William A. White Sons, brokers.

More than 220 golfers from many lands were listening tonight to the gentle rustle of the sea around the British amateur championship course, washed clean and green by the overnight deluge, and the majority doubtless were wondering whether the dawn would bring that-southwest wind with all its trials and tribulations for tomorrow's openin test.
Politics in Oklahoma must be a good deal like the Irish Sweepstakes, which is operated by drawing well-advertised names out of a

Ronney Householder roared around the Indianapolis Speedway today at 125.769 miles an hour for a twentyfive-mile qualifying run to erase the track record of 125.681 set by Floyd Roberts of Van Nuys, Calif., yesterday.
The Raven Poetry Circle opened its sixth annual outdoor exposition yesterday. The forty exhibitors are using the fence on the southeast corner of Washington Square South and Thompson Street.

Mrs. Arthur Thomas Pendleton of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ann Louise Pendleton, to Alan Brainard Pinkerton, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Alfred.Pinkerton of Bayonne.

Some importing of Belgian capital into France was reported after devaluation of the franc, but this has as good as ceased. The decline in the French franc does riot seem necessarily to imply that the belga must follow suit.

An adequate system of reviewing assessments by the local Tax Commission, and improved assessment system and the right of appeal from the local taxing body to a quasi-judicial group to be a division of the State Tax Commission are among sweeping changes proposed in the review of real estate assessments in New York City in a report made public yesterday by the City Club.

Edward Hickey, deputy district governor of the State Association of Lions Clubs, has called a meeting at Tarrytown for June 7 to form a permanent committee to campaign for a Hudson River Boulevard from New York to Albany along the riverfront.

The wide gulf between the Rightist and Leftist groups in the political field in Chile has become still deeper today as the result of yesterday's disorder in Congress. The Left Wing parties are united more closely than ever and determined upon firm opposition to the government.
There probably are Americans now planning Summer tours in Europe who are considering the inclusion of a visit to the Austria of pleasant memories.

The paradoxical nature of life -was the topic of the baccalaureate sermon preached yesterday by the Rev. Dr. J. Valdemar Moldenhawer to the graduating class of the Scudder School at the morning services of the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets.

League of Nations circles are following the Czech situation closely with rising hope that it will be kept in hand this time. This hope is based mainly on the belief that the more Prague and London make Chancellor Hitler fear that intervention means war the less he is likely to gamble.

Although the advertising field experienced considerable concern over provisions in the Wheeler-Lea act, prior to its passage, the attitude of most executives in the field has now changed to one of complete approval, recent developments have indicated.

Mayor David H. Slayback, 77 years old, conducted an intensive crusade today against Sunday motorists violating the twenty-miles-an-hour speed limit here. Supported by the ten regular policemen and fifteen deputies recruited for the crusade, the Mayor enforced the speed limit on all vehicles, including trolley cars. His object, frankly stated, was to make people obey the law--and remember Verona.

Champion Nornay Saddler repeated today. It has been the same story eleven of thirteen times in his recent shows. This black and white smooth-coated fox terrier. with a bit of tan thrown in, has been carrying everything by storm.

A net operating profit of $2,824,618 is reported by Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., and subsidiaries for the twenty-six weeks ended on Feb. 26, 1938, after all deductions except possible surtax on undistributed profits, compared with $4,040,389 for the corresponding period of the previous fiscal year.

The Class I railroads had 4,867 freight cars ordered from manufacturers, under construction in their own shops or in process of reconditioning on May 1, according to the Association of American Railroads.

Mrs. Francis J. Higginson, the former Grace Glenwood Haldane, widow of Rear Admiral F. J. Higginson, died at her home here Saturday following a brief illness. She was 85 years old, the daughter of the late John Haldane and the late Matilda Hasbrouck Haldane.

Harry Birdsall of Ardsley, N. Y., won the first annual BendixRutherford outboard marathon today over a fifty-nine mile course along the Passaic and Hackensack Rivers in 1:05:59. The race, sponsored by the Rutherford Yacht Club, was for the Vincent Bendix trophy, valued at $750. Birdsall drove a Class F hydroplane.
Convention delegates of the United Office and Professional Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate, voted today to organize insurance, financial and social service workers.
Fred Stone, whom John Golden t plans to star next season on Broadway in a revival of "Lightnin'," will make three Summer theatre t appearances in that play, it was learned yesterday.

Count and Countess Pierre du Nouy will arrive from France tomorrow and will be at the Drake. Mr. and Mrs. Franklyn L. Hutton, who passed the Winter at Prospect Hill Plantation, Yonges Island, S. C., have returned to the Waldorf-Astoria.

The New York State Department of Education has approved the association of the Mills School for Kindergarten-Primary Teachers, 66 Fifth Avenue, with Adelphi College here, it was announced today by Paul Dawson Eddy, president of Adelphi. Summer classes at both institutions will start on July 5.

Cornelius N. Bliss has been elected chairman of the board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association, Inc., it was announced yesterday. Mr. Bliss succeeds Paul D. Cravath as chairman, and was unanimously elected following Mr. Cravath's resignation from that post at the meeting.

The wholesale price index on May 14 was 643, compared with 639 and 619 in the two previous weeks. The fresh rise in prices chiefly was owing to higher quotations for farm produce, resulting from unfavorable atmospheric conditions.

Starting a campaign to bar the sale of marijuana cigarettes in Westchester County, State, county and local police made eight arrests and rounded up more than 200 persons suspected of selling or using the narcotic weed, including several high school boys and girls, late last night and-early this morning.

Movements for a reunion of Protestant denominations long divided were hailed by the Rev. Leon Merle Flanders, pastor of the Tremont Presbyterian Church, Grand Concourse and 178th. Street, the Bronx, in his sermon yesterday morning.

Reports of a concentration of Czechoslovak machine-gun units, army radio stations and field kitchens near Znaim, just north of the AustrianGerman border, were brought to Vienna today by American tourists.
Dr. Calvin Bryce Hoover, Professor of Economics at Duke University since 1925, has been appointed dean of the Duke Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, President William P. Few said today.
The martyrdom of St. Andrew Bobola was described yesterday by the Rev. Edmund A. Walsh as proof of the immemorial futility of trying to rule the Christian spirit of man by violence.
When the Central Savings Bank sold to Charles de Fabre 207-09 E 21st St for a consideration indicated as $50,000 it took back a purchase money mortgage for $37,500, due in seven years.

Beginning her second week of life. Sandra Marion Colvin, who weighed 261/2 ounces at birth has developed a "huskier crying voice." Dr. Frank E. Benekovle, attending physician, said the baby "appears to be in amazingly fine condition" and has regained the two ounces she lost during the weel.

Liquidation in May lard developed last week on the Board of Trade and the current delivery showed yesterday a net loss of 15 cents a hundredweight, compared with a week ago, while other active futures were unchanged.
The Yankees had a chance to skim into first place in the American League flag race today at the Indians' expense, but they missed it before the year's biggest baseball crowd.

For their annual evening in mem- L ory of Sholom Aleichem, who died twenty-two years ago, the Artef E Players put on at the Hudson Thea- A tre last night a varied program worthy of the great Yiddish storyteller.

The engagement of Miss Ruth Bybee Milliken of this city, daughter of Walter L. Milliken of Pinehurst, N. C., and Hyannis Port, Mass., and the late Mrs. Milliken, to George Arthur Murphy, also of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Drewry Murphy of Morrow, Ga., has been announced by her father.
The racing rule requiring an unruly horse to be placed on the outside and behind the field is likely to be suspended for the $100,000 special next Monday at Belmont Park.

Three thousand residents of Hunt's Point attended the unveiling yesterday afternoon of a seven-ton granite memorial to World War dead from that part of the Bronx. The monument-a thick, octagonal column five feet high-stands opposite Crames Square at the head of Whitlock Avenue Parkway and Hunt's Point Avenue.

W. C. McGonagle, Treasurer ofthe Territory of Hawaii, announced yesterday that he would receive proposals at the Bankers Trust Company up to June 27 for a new. issue of $2,886,000 of- improvement bonds of Hawaii.

F. W. Earnest Jr., president of Anthracite Industries, Inc., will be one of the principal speakers at the convention and exposition of the American Retail Coal Association to be held in the Hotel Sherman, Chicago, from June 6 to 11. He will discuss "Meeting the Challenge of Competition."

Twenty-four members of the graduating class of Columbia. University have been named to the annual "hall of fame" of The Columbian, student yearbook which has just been published, it was announced yesterday.

More than 1,000 persons gathered yesterday afternoon about the rock in Regimental Memorial Grove, Central Park, that bears the bronze tablets with the names of 519 men of the 307th Infantry, Seventy-seventh Division, who died in the World War.
The preliminary findings of a study of hearing made in connection with the National, Health Survey have been made public by the United States Public Health Service.

The vacant property at 1 Gramercy Park South, southeast corner of Fourth Avenue, has been sold by the All Souls Unitarian Church to Samuel Barkin Sons, investment builders, who announced yesterday plans for improving the site with a six-story apartment house.
The foreign situation this week gave rise to pessimistic rumors which had an unfavorable influence on the financial markets.

Macmillan will bring out on May 31 an American edition of Naomi Jacob's novel about a London bus driver, "The Lenient God." Nine thousand copies of the novel were sold in England in advance of publication.

Holding that most religions have been autocratic thus far, Dr. Charles Francis Potter told the First Humanist Society, meeting at 113 West Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday morning, that the time had come for religion to become democratic.

The fourth mediator to enter the fourteen-week-old fur strike admitted yesterday that negotiations for a settlement of the dispute had broken down. Dr. Paul Abelson, impartial chairman of the fur industry, said that the deadlock in the conferences, over which he presided during the past week, would not deter him from continued efforts to effect an agreement.

The very grave situation that has developed between Germany and Czechoslovakia has not taken Italy by surprise, for ever since Anschluss most people here have foreseen that Chancellor Hitler's next move would be aimed at incorporating the Sudeten Germans with the Reich.

Davidson Ave (11-3200), e s, 75 ft a of 190th St, 75x100: Pocker Aronson; Inc, to Cingold Realty Corp, 1,815 Morris Ave. Virgil P1 (14-3612). n s, 361 ft e of Olmstead Ave, 29x100: Shirley Kahn, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp.

Alf M. Landon left here today, after a week-end of fishing, to visit friends in Pittsfield. The former Governor of Kansas was driven to Pittsfield by Harold W. Mason of Brattleboro, secretary of the Republican National Committee.

Middle age and not youth is the "most dangerous period of life,"-the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, declared in his annual commencement address -yesterday morning at the church school.

Rabbi Simon Glazer of 353 Fort Washington Avenue, Jewish scholar and leader, who was rabbi of Temple Beth-El, Brooklyn, 1927-30, died last night of heart disease in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, where he had been a patient for three weeks. His age was 60.

On the Mapes motion to recommit the Air Authority Bill to the Interstate Commerce Committee with instructions to amend the bill so as to provide for the regulation of civil aeronautics by the Interstate Commerce Commission instead of by the Civil Aeronautics Authority provided in the bill, rejected 94 to 214:

Germany, Italy and Japan should not be classified as "aggressor nations" by this country when the "real enemy of Americanism is the Soviet Union," said the Rev. Peter B. Duffee of the Roman Catholic Church ofSt. Francis of Assisi yesterday morning at the sixteenth annual communion breakfast of the Fire Department Holy Name Society in Brooklyn and Queens.

William J. Cameron, spokesman for the Ford Motor Company, said in a radio address tonight that strikes were responsible for the fact that "during the last two years, when employment was the one thing most desired, more than 42,000,000

Louis Zamperini said today the reason he failed to compete in the Compton invitation meet against Don Lash last Friday was that he was underweight and was "saving myself" for the Pacific Coast Conference meet.

Night baseball will be played at Ebbets Field within the next thirty days. Larry MacPhail, who introduced the nocturnal game to the major leagues while directing the Cincinnati club and who now is executive vice president of the Dodgers, announced yesterday that a complete. lighting. system in the Brooklyn park "will be ready for operation about June 15."

Resolutions condemning communism and fascism and pledging a fight to the finish against the spread of such doctrines in this country were unanimously adopted yesterday at the annual convention of the New York Department of Jewish War Veterans of the United States.

Emphasizing the role of foreign trade and marked by official orders to "dress ship" on all American vessels in honor of Maritime Day, National Foreign Trade Week begins today with a wide range of ceremonies planned throughout the United States.

William J. Glackens, the artist, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack in Westport, Conn., at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Prendergast, with whom he and Mrs. Glackens were spending the weekend.

The faith that God understands us completely will strengthen our religious conviction, declared the Rev. Lyman V. Cady, Professor of Theology, Tsinan, China, in a sermon yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

Hugo Eugene Grieshaber, supervising constructor for the Electric Boat Company at its Groton plant for the last ten years, died at his residence here this morning, from a brain tumor, after a year's illness.

Relative stagnation among private electric utility companies last year, contrasted with an upward spurt for publicly owned electric generation, was shown today in an annual statistical report issued by the Federal Power Commission.

That General Saturnino Cedillo's followers control a far greater territory than was hitherto believed was indicated today when this writer attempted to travel the road from the town of Aitiguo Morelos to San Luis Potosi, a route that passes through General Cedillo's ranch at Las Palomas.

Emphasizing the role of foreign trade and marked by official orders to "dress ship" on all American vessels in honor of Maritime Day, National Foreign Trade Week begins today with a wide range of ceremonies planned throughout the United States.

William J. Glackens, the artist, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack in Westport, Conn., at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Prendergast, with whom he and Mrs. Glackens were spending the weekend.

The faith that God understands us completely will strengthen our religious conviction, declared the Rev. Lyman V. Cady, Professor of Theology, Tsinan, China, in a sermon yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

Hugo Eugene Grieshaber, supervising constructor for the Electric Boat Company at its Groton plant for the last ten years, died at his residence here this morning, from a brain tumor, after a year's illness.

Relative stagnation among private electric utility companies last year, contrasted with an upward spurt for publicly owned electric generation, was shown today in an annual statistical report issued by the Federal Power Commission.

St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Woodbury, Conn., in which Samuel Seabury, an ancestor of former Judge Samuel Seabury of New York, was chosen Bishop of Connecticut in 1785, will be the scene tomorrow of. the annual church service of the Daughters of the Cincinnati.

The Federal Trade Commission has ordered Colonial Dames, Inc., and Colonial Dames Company, Ltd., of Hollywood, Calif., sellers of skin preparations, either to stop using the word "Colonial Dames" or to use with them in conspicuous print the phrase "not connected with any society," the commission announced today.

Mike Cestone, Montclair's golfing lettercarrier, and Maurrie O'Connor of Branch Brook today won the third annual New Jersey State amateurprofessional championship, defeating Charley Whitehead and Johnny Kinder of Plainfield, defending champions, 2 and 1.

The Greater New York Fund has been authorized by the Board of Education to seek contributions, by organized solicitation, from all school employes of the city, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintehdent of Schools, announced yesterday.
The Supreme Court may rule tomorrow on litigation which involves a request by twenty-five States for protection against "Federal usurpation" and the "burden of Federal taxation."

An attempt was made this morning to blow up the Abrego and the Cierza, two trawlers that have been lying in the harbor of Frederikshavn for the past two years while the Danish courts were trying to decide whether they belonged to the Loyalist or the Rebel forces in Spain.

The new capital market here continues as good as closed, except for gilt-edge stocks, which, for one reason or another, cannot be delayed and for which generally there is a large underwriting market. Even in this category, however, public demand remains extremely slow, and large amounts of recent issues still are in the underwriters' hands pending subscription by more permanent investors.

Disturbed by the threat of a revolution and heeding a warning issued by the American Consul General in Mexico City, tourists are returning to the United States by train and automobiles in a constant stream, according to arrivals here today from Rio Grande border points.

IT is conventional to think of modern Germany as a totally different place from the old Germany. But read Arnold Zweig's latest novel and you will notice portentous resemblances. The title is "The Crowning of a King." Herr Zweig himself doesn't draw explicit parallels; his story is, except for an epilogue laid in the year 1926, strictly a story of the final months of the World War.
A LONG came Hank Gowdy, otherwise known as Old Goldenrod, former big league catcher and in recent years a valuable assistant to Manager Mild Will McKechnie, now of the Cincinnati Reds.

Increased production of crude oil in the Zistersdorf territory of Austria during the first four months of 1938 is reported by the Department of Commerce, which gave the total as 16,700 metric tons, compared with 10,000 during the same period one year ago.

Senator Key Pittman of Nevada, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, contends Japan must "remedy the wrong" done in treaty violations against China before the United States could sign a new nonaggression pact with her.

A. W. Robertson, chairman of the board of directors of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, announced yesterday that his company would "do its share" this year toward recovery by spending approximately $12,000,000 on new buildings, new machinery and equipment and other improvements and repairs throughout Westinghouse properties.

The Phillies drove in two runs in the last half of the ninth inning today to record a 2-to-1 victory over the Cardinals. St. Louis scored its run in the first half of the ninth. Fiddler McGee, pitching for St. Louis, and Pete Sivess for the Phils each allowed three hits each through the first eight innings.

" The personal liberty and morals of the world are in the keeping of, not geniuses but the ordinary people of the world," said the Rev. Dr Harry Emerson Fosdick in his sermon, "The High Road to Self-Re spect," yesterday morning at the o Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

A fortnight ago, in a letter to THE TIMES, Secretary Wallace charged that the Supreme Court had shifted ground in an important case involving the administrative agencies of the Government. Acting in line with this protest, Solicitor General Jackson has now formally accused the court of reversing itself and requested it to reconsider the decision to which Mr. Wallace has objected. The case is Morgan v.
Dr. Archbald H. Throckmorton, who has been Professor of Law at Western Reserve University since 1914, died on Friday of heart disease after a brief illness. His age was 62.

One of two boys who munched sandwiches at a tavern here two nights ago was identified "positively" today as Peter Levine, 12year-old son of a New Rochelle, N. Y., attorney, who was reported kidnapped three months ago.

The Blanche Lewy Joseph Memorial Prize, awarded annually to a deserving senior at Hunter College who has made progress in literature, will be given their year to Dorothy Behar, it was announced by Dr. Blanche Colton Williams, head of the English Department at Hunter.

Broken glass, a sponge, a bottle and a bone are among the odd-lot ity materials that have been endowed take with artistic distinction by Columbia University art students in threedimensional surrealistic contrivances on view in University Hall in the second annual student exhibition, opening today and continiing through July 11.

Two men were killed and three women injured critically today when their automobile skidded and struck a tree here. The men were identified as James Amend, 30, of 307 East Seventy-seventh Street, New York City, and Rudolph Neubauer, 26, of 44 Seaman Avenue, New York City.

Total expenditures of more than $120,000 in 1937, including $20,000 for "educational and organizational work," were among the figures revealed yesterday concerning the New York State organization of the Communist party. The data were made known by speakers on the third day of the tenth State convention of the party, being held at Odd Fellows Temple, 105 East 106th Street with 538 delegates present.

The engagement of Miss Ruth Bybee Milliken of this city, daughter of Walter L. Milliken of Pinehurst, N. C., and Hyannis Port, Mass., and the late Mrs. Milliken, to George Arthur Murphy, also of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Drewry Murphy of Morrow, Ga., has been announced by her father.

The directors of the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society and the 315 boys and girls residing at its cottage colony here joined forces today in celebrating the eighty-ninth birthday of Adolph Lewisohn, philanthropist and community leader. Mr. Lewisohn was re-elected president of the society for his thirtieth term at a board meeting before the festival.

Mauricio Cardoso, former Minister of Justice in the Vargas Cabinet who became Secretary of the Interior in the State of Rio Grande do Sul, was drowned today in a seaplane crash at Santos, Brazil. Albert Albrecht, a German, also died.

The New York University College of Engineering is inaugurating a "unique program of engineering education in cooperation with industrial leaders of New York and surrounding States," according to announcement issued for publication today by Thorndike Saville, dean of the college.

Erskine Hewitt, an official and a director in several corporations, youngest son of the late Mayor Abram S. Hewitt of New York and grandson of Peter Cooper, who founded Cooper Union Institute, died at his country home, Erksden, on Lake Cupsaw, Passaic County, early today of a coronary thrombosis. His age was 67.

Clad in faded blue uniforms, three veterans of the Union Army attended yesterday afternoon the twentyeighth annual service for the sailor dead of the Civil War, held at the Recreation Pier, Hudso- River and 129th Street, by the Mrs. Ella Bixby Tent, 18, Daughters of Union Veterans of the Civil War.

The United States Armys nineand-half-ton light tanks, eighty-six of which have rumbled more than 300 miles in the past two days, have clearly demonstrated their utility and endurance and are superior, in the opinion of observers here, to any other light tanks in the world.

A diversified program of entertainment has been arranged for the benefit dinner and dance tomorrow night which will mark the formal opening for the Summer season of the Japanese Garden of the RitzCarlton. A feature of the event, which will aid the McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for

A rule which prohibits its athletes from representing the university on the Sabbath cost N. Y. U. the metropolitan junior track and field championship yesterday as the title again went to the New York Athletic Club. Tallying 36 points in the nineteen-event program at Victory

Miss Evelyn Osborne Squire, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Amos O. Squire of th s place, was married here yesterday in Trinity Episcopal Church to Harvey Willard Culp of New York, son of Mrs. Frances D. Culp of Baltimore and the late Harvey Melvin Culp. The Rev. Gibson W.

The executive heads of many of 1 the greatest cities of the world, Mayor La Guardia among them, took part in a recorded broadcast last night over the Municipal Broadcasting Station of Buenos Aires in honor of the station's opening.

Police announced the arrest today of Marcos Souza Dantas, former director of the Banco do Brazil, as a suspect in the May 11 Integralist revolt. The authorities said that they found in his possession approximately $33,000 worth of "Sigma" bonds issued by the Integralistas. The Greek letter sigma is their emblem.
