11th St, 326 E. 25x94.10; Anthony Belmont to Reliance Improvement Corp, 225 Lafayette St: mtg, $15,700 ($1). Waverly Pl. 158, 23.11x97: Felice D., McLaughlin to 158 Waverly Place Realty Corp, 7 E 42d St. care Leo-McLaughlin; mtg. $15,000 ($1): latter gave mtg for $3,000 to Jacob R. Schiff.

The Wisconsin Farmer-Labor-Progressive Federation today snubbed Governor La Follette, president of the new National Progressive party, and unanimously endorsed Daniel W. Hoan, Milwaukee's Socialist Mayor, as Progressive candidate for United States Senator.

Cash collections of current taxes in the first four months of this year in the township of North Bergen, N. J., amounted to $402,748, compared with $347,642 in the same period last year, an increase of 15 per cent, according to a special report issued by Josiah M. Hewitt to holders of about $5,000,000 of the township's bonds represented by him.

For the fourth successive time golfers representing the Meadow Brook Club today turned back the teams of the Nassau Country Club, Rockaway Hunting Club and Piping Rock in the interclub matches held here twice a year.

William Childs, one of the founders of the restaurant chain bearing his name, died today at his home here. His age was 72. Since his retirement ten years ago, Mr. Childs had spent most of his time at his Somerset County home where he died.

Although estimates of the number of Americans who have gone to Spain to fight have ranged all the way from 1,300 to 4,300, a survey made here last week indicated that the correct total was probably slightly under 3,000.
Mayor La Guardia of New York told a Washington audience today that this country does not want war, "but if there is going to be an epidemic, America has a right to establish its own quarantine."

The Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Church, the oldest parish of the Episcopal Church in New York, participated in special services and delivered the sermon yesterday at the celebration of the 145th anniversary of the Christ Episcopal Church, Seventyfirst Street, west of Broadway. Christ Church parish is the second oldest in New York.

Maitland Dwight of Bedford Village and 123 East Seventy-eighth Street, New York, died today in the Mount Kisco Hospital after a fortnight's illness. He was a partner in the law firm of Prentice, Collins Dwight, 60 John Street, New York, and president of the St. Andrew's Society.

Eight undergraduate students at City College have been appointed to the associate news board of The Campus, college newspaper, and nine students have been elected officers of the college Athletic Association, according to an announcement yesterday.

Three important building developments, aimed at saving space, simplifying installation and reducing costs;, were announced yesterday by Arthur R. Herske, vice president of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Company.

Thomas J. Glynn, one-time Democratic State committeeman from Steuben County, former Supervisor of the Second District of Hornell and member of the Board of Aldermen for twelve years ending in 1936, died suddenly yesterday at his home at the age of 70.

Leading magazine publishers have organized an informal copy control committee to suggest changes in advertising copy, according to W. C. W. Durand of Macfadden. Publications yesterday, and will undertake a study of advertising in the personal hygiene field.

Louis E. Stoddard's Blackcock will carry the top impost of 156 pounds in the Greenwich Cup Handicap Steeplechase that will feature the annual race meeting of the Fairfield and Westchester Hounds at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club in Rye on Saturday, it was announced yesterday by Frank J. Bryan of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association.

Three convicts made an unsuccessful attempt to escape from Alcatrez Island Federal prison today by slugging an unarmed guard. Warden James A. Johnston said that after slugging the guard the trio attempted to seize an armed officer. This guard shot two of the convicts and prevented the break. The convicts were Thomas R.

Devotion to each other, survivors believed, led two brothers, Sydney Wilfred Stern, 60 years old, a lawyer, and Edwin Stern, 68, retired business man, to carry out a suicide pact yesterday by inhaling gas through a Siamese tube at the elder brother's apartment, 28 West Seventy-fifth Street.

Brooklyn College freshmen have once again ranked high, among the first 7 per cent, in their average intelligence quotient by the Thurstone psychological tests, according to a survey announced yesterday by Professor La Verne Buckton of the college's education department.

An evangelistic program for the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, with "every church member a practicing Christian" as its objective, was recommended here tonight by the Rev. Dr. William F. Klein of New York, a secretary of the denomination's Board of National Missions.

Europe's latest war scare caused yesterday a frightened exodus of capital from London and other European centers into the dollar in dealings in the foreign exchange market. The pound sterling was forced down to its cheapest price since March 18, at $4.94 3/4, while the franc fell to a low record here and abroad.

Mayor Franklin S. Koons of Garden City. cut a white ribbon at the entrance of the new Oppenheim, Collins Co. store at 730 Franklin. Avenue here at 9:30 A. M. today, formally opening the establishment for business.

The directors of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City voted $4,280,000 last night as the Federation's allowance for 1938 to its ninety-one affiliated institutions.

The sixty-acre farm with an old Colonial farmhouse containing thirteen rooms, formerly owned by Reeve Schley Jr., near Whitehouse, N. J., has been purchased by Quincy S. Cabot of New York. The property also includes several barns and a dairy. Mrs. Leslie Hyde, broker, negotiated the deal.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 23 unless specified: At Norfolk: Fairfax, May 20; Arkansas. At Cristobal: Brooks, Fox, Gilmer,.Williamson.

Wholesale commodity prices registered their second consecutive advance last week, according to the Index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association. This index, in the week ended May 21, was 74.7, compared with 74.4 In the preceding .week and 74.0 two weeks ago, based on the 1926-1928 average as 100.

Developments n Czechoslovakia in the past three lays tended to show that the situation "might be entering upon a dangerous phase," but at the moment t "appears to have somewhat based," Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and his Foreign Minister, Viscount Halifax, said today in identical statements in both houses of Parliament.

The body of the former vice president of the Jewish community here, Jakob Ehrlich, who died Wednesday at the concentration camp at Dachau, Bavaria, was brought here yesterday and buried in the Jewish cemetery.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 18: Decreases of $36,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, $28,000,000

Twenty-eight of fifty-one defendants indicted here last week as members of an illicit liquor ring that operated stills in Westchester County and Pennsylvania were held in bail when arraigned yesterday before Federal Judge John W. Clancy.

The old car barn of the New York Railways Company, covering the west blockfront on Lenox Avenue from 146th to 147th Street, and running 648 feet on both streets, will be replaced by a new one-story garage, according to plans filed yesterday. The new structure will be built by the New York City Omnibus Corporation from plans by F. Seaman, architect. The estimated cost is put to $250,000.

Formal announcement of the engagement of Daniel George Dodge, 20-year-old son of the late John F. Dodge, automobile manufacturer, to Loreen MacDonald, 18, telephone operator at Gore Bay, Ont., and daughter of a Manitoulin Island tugboat captain, was made last night at Meadowbrook Hall, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Alred G. Wilson.

A concerted drive is being made by mining organizations in Southernn California and Arizona to build up large and influential groups of mine operators, prospectors and engineers to resist Federal and State legislative efforts unfavorable to the mining industry.

Dan D. Coyle of Centerville, Md., president of the Princeton senior class, received nine of the honors in the annual balloting for senior class favorites, the results of which were announced today by John G. Nettleton, chairman of the 1938 Nassau Herald, the senior yearbook.

The joint resolution introduced in the Senate yesterday by Senator Bailey of North Carolina, providing for a termination on June 30 of purchases by the Treasury of foreign silver, would have the effect of reducing our silver program to its bald essentials-a sutrday to domestic producers.

Miss Patricia Rice, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Thomson Rice of this city, will be introduced to society here on the night of June 11 at a dance to be given by her parents at the Mohawk Golf Club.

One of the severest earthquakes of recent years shook Northeastern Japan for ten minutes beginning at 4:19 this afternoon, causing consternation in Tokyo and Yokohama Provinces, immediately south of the apparent epicenter. Disruption of telegraphic communications makes accurate information unavailable for the present.

With twelve jurors selected in the first day's proceedings, Donald Carroll Jr., 16-year-old boy accused of shooting and killing his sweetheart in an uncompleted suicide pact last March, went on trial for murder yesterday in Queens County Court.

A terrific explosion shook Coolsingel, Rotterdam's busiest boulevard, today. A man, supposedly carrying the bomb in a suit case, literally was blown to bits, two passers-by were seriously injured and several others suffered shock and minor injuries.

Details of a series of intricate tests in which the huge new Douglas DC-4 airliner was "flown" around the world nearly three times without leaving its hangar at Santa Monica, Calif., were revealed here yesterday in reports from engineers conducting the tests.

The Stewart-Warner Corporation announced today that in addition to the 10 per cent reduction of officers' salaries which became effective May 1, the beginning of the corporate fiscal year, a general reduction of all employes' salaries above $1,000 a year had been ordered.

2d Lt David Malikin, Inf.-Res., 301 W. 19th St., New York, N. Y., 77th Division, is ordered to active duty for a period of six months, effective June 4. at Headquarters Trenton District, CCC, North Olden and Breunig Aves., Trenton, N. J., for assignment and duty in connection with CCC activities. Date of rank, May 7.

Estate, less than $5,000. To Samuel Berliner, husband, executor, 37 Riverside Dr. BALLARD, JOSEPHINE (May 19). Estate, more than $10,000. To Antoinette K. Brown, executrix, Boca Raton, Palm Beach, Fla.

Forty minutes before the City Marshal was scheduled to evict him yesterday from his seven-room apartment at 130 West Eighty-third Street, Frank Bryson, 60 years old, who could not earn enough money by selling newspapers and renting rooms to pay the rent, was found dead on- the floor of his bedroom, a .38-caliber bullet in his right temple.

The national board of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, has decided that Hadassah should not officially participate in the proposed plebiscite set for June 25, 26 and 27 on the question of the union of American Jewish groups in "a single,

Charges that founders of the Federal Theatre Project had violated a pledge to "keep out" of the legitimate theatre district in -New York City were contained in a petition signed by twenty-two theatrical producers and producing firms and sent yesterday to-Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator; Mrs. Hallie Flanagan, national director of the project, and George Kondolf, local director.

Frank Nasmith, president of the Textile Institute, and J. R. S. Goodall, chairman of the institute's diplomas committee, both of Manchester, England, were welcomed to America yesterday at a luncheon and reception given by American members of the institute at the Hotel St. Regis. Franklin W. Hobbs, president of Arlington Mills and an active member of the institute, delivered an informal welcome.

The Mexican Government has called upon the Governors and Legislatures in all Mexican States to declare their support of President Lazaro Cardenas, Agustin Arroyo, chief of the Press Department, said today. It was understood the step was taken to allay rumors that the revolt of General Saturnino Cedillo in the State of San Luis Potosi was likely to spread to other parts of the country.

A junior committee comprised of young matrons and debutantes of former years has been organized to assist with' plans for the annual series of Yorkville Dinner Dances, which will be resumed next Winter.

Alfred Fritzche of Cleveland replaced Darwin S. Barrett Jr., also of this city, today on the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company board, which re-elected officers, including J. S. Pyeatt, chairman, and L. W. Baldwin, president.
Boston will consider tenders today for an issue of $2,000,000 of short-term tax notes, dated May 27 and due on Dec. 27, 1938.

A mild sinking spell in United States Government obligations and a fresh break in most of the Central European dollar issues following week-end developments there, featured yesterday otherwise quiet and listless trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange.

After a lapse of many years, the Hickey-Freeman line of men's clothing will be sold in John David stores, starting in the Fall season, Ralph Ladue, president of the New York chain, announced yesterday. When the stores last handled the line, it was merchandised under the John David name, but under the new set-up the chain will also have a franchise to advertise the HickeyFreeman name.
The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated May 21: MAJOR GENERAL Tschappat, W. H., Chief of Ordnane, Washington, D. C., to home and await retirement, about June 3.
Annual convention, New York City League of Women Voters, Hotel Astor, 10 A. M. Luncheon at 12:45 at which speakers will be Mayor La Guardia and eight of the city commissioners.
The Berkshire Hills colonies have had many arrivals for the Summer in the last few days.

Nearly five hours after the jury had informed the court that it was apparently hopelessly deadlocked, Albert Marinelli, Tammany leader of the Second Assembly District West and former New York County Clerk, was acquitted last night in Brooklyn Federal Court of the government's charge that he unlawfully harbored and concealed Charles Falci, one of his election inspectors, while the latter was a fugitive under a Federal indictment for election frauds.

The State Board of Dentistry announced today suspension of the license of Dr. William Levine of Jersey City for thirty days, beginning June 1, on a charge of violating a law enacted in 1934 prohibiting advertising by members of the profession.
A woman bookkeeper, L. S. Shatalina, convicted of squandering State funds on horse races, clothes and parties, was saved from the firing squad today by the Supreme Court.
The Westchester Country Club women's golf team became the new Class A champion in the Westchester division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association as the interclub series was completed today.

Prince Michael Radziwill, 68-year-old Polish descendant of the Hohenzollerns, was married today at the Caxton Hall register office to Mrs. Harriet Stewart Dawson, 57-yearold widow of a wealthy Australian business man.

Rain that continued through the morning temporarily halted operations between the Yankees and Indians today. The ninth postponement forced on the champions by inclement weather in their last nineteen games, today's rest period was viewed as a blessing in disguise.

The campaign against -the marijuana traffic in Westchester County will be extended to more road houses and stores where the cigarettes are sold or smoked and to New York City, reported source of marijuana used in Westchester, it was announced here today by Sheriff George A. Casey.

Aaron Copland, American composer, whose works have been played by most of the leading symnphony orchestras of the country, is...writing a book for Whittlesey House which they will publish in the Fall under the title "What to Listen For in Music."

Arrangements are being discussed for the immediate withdrawal from China of the German military mission headed by General Alexander von Falkenhausen as a result of the receipt by the German Ambassador, Dr. Oskar Trautmann, of a notice from Berlin calling for the retirement of the German experts.

Jersey City rallied in the sixth and seventh innings to tally five times and score a 5-4 victory over Newark in the opener of a threegame series today. The Little Giants batted Ernie Bonham, Bears' starting hurler, out of the box in the sixth and continued their attack on Phil Page in the seventh,

The Middle States Regatta Association awarded its annual regatta tonight to Baltimore for the second straight year. The forty-seventh annual event, sponsored by the Arundel Boat Club of Baltimore, will be held on the Spring Gardens course of the Patapsco River Sept. 4.

A number of large multiple dwellings figured in the Manhattan realty deals announced yesterday. In the Inwood section a client of Solomon Ginsberg bought from the Manufacturers Trust Company the five-story house at 9-21 Sherman Avenue, on the southwest corner of Sickies Street.
A sentence of fifteen to thirty years in State prison was imposed by Judge Wallace in General Sessions yesterday on Andrew Kay, 23 years old, formerly of 409 East 174th Street, the Bronx.

Announcement was made here last night of the death on Sunday of Robert W. Chapin, former resident of this city, at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Basil de Selincourt, at Kingham, Oxfordshire, England. Mr. Chapin, who was 82 years old, had been- in frail health for some months and his condition was aggravated by the shock of his wife's death last Wednesday.

Steel operations in the United States are scheduled at 29.0 per cent of capacity this week, as compared to 30.7 per cent last week, a decline of 1.7 points, or 5.5 per cent, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Frank Bowden, fourth ranking player in the East, and William Lurie gained the semi-final round in the metropolitan invitation men's tennis singles tournament as a result of victories at the Culver Tennis Club, Brooklyn, yesterday.
Stocks of ethyl alcohol in bonded warehouses at the end of April amounted to 33,076,188 proof gallons, an increase of 6,424,963 from the same date last year, the Alcohol Tax Unit announced today.

J. Edward Jones of Scarsdale, N. Y., a dealer in oil securities, today filed suit, in the District of Columbia Court, for $1,000,000 damages against two present and two former members of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag denied yesterday an application made by several Class B stockholders of United Shipyards, Inc., for a temporary injunction restraining the corporation from selling most of its plant and good-will to the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation for $9,320,000. The court's decision was announced late yesterday afternoon, several hours after the application for the injunction had been argued.

Surrogate James A. Foley ruled yesterday that Henry Huddleston Rogers 3d had no legal status in an accounting proceeding concerning the estate of his father, Colonel Henry H. Rogers. Young Mr. Rogers had attacked a power of appointment exercised by his father over a trust established by his grandfather, Henry H. Rogers.

IT was somewhat shocking to note that the pacific.Pie Traynor had been thumbed off the diamond by umpires twice within the past week or so. Only once during his long and distinguished playing career was the large and genial Pie tossed out of the day's festivities by an indignant umpire. If Pie was now going around looking for battle, the war spirit certainly had spread to strange places.

Charges against Harvard University of fostering a company union were dismissed by the State Labor Relations Commission today after Robert H. Everitt, representative of the Building Service Employes International Union, an A. F. of L. affiliate, withdrew them.

Deep-sea divers have located the wrecked Condor passenger seaplane, submerged yesterday, off Santos, after a crash. The body of Mauricio Cardoso, former Minister of Justice, according to a Santos report, rests inside the wreck.

The Honongahela West Penn Public service Company, a subsidiary of ne American Water Works and Electricc Company, has filed a decaration under the Holding Comany Act covering the reduction in ar value from $25 to $15 a share of 84,098 shares of common stock, the securities and Exchange Commision announced today.

The watch business of the entire nation is threatened with destruction unless the sale of second-hand watches, misrepresented as new by racketeer dealers, is stopped, William Wagner of New York, executive secretary of the jewelers enforcement committee, warned here today at the New Jersey Retail Jewelers Association convention.

The management committee of the Studio Club of the Y. W. C. A., at 210 East. Seventy-seventh Street, will give a reception at the association building this afternoon. The event will mark the formal opening of the roof garden for the Summer.

The Japanese soldier swallows "energy tablets" when unduly weakened by prolonged fighting, lack of sleep or enervating heat. If necessary, he inhales oxygen provided in small tubes and released into a rubber-silk bag.

Dictatorship loomed yesterday in Wall Street when the committee in charge of the Bond Club's "Stock Exchange," which is a regular feature of the annual field day, issued a peremptory decree asserting that "we have taken over all powers in exchange for our promise to do right by you," and that in so doing it had taken its "cue from Hitler, Mussolini and Stalin."

In the Supreme Court of the United States today David R. Shelton, Humphrey Statter Jr., Mark I. Avramo, Max Chopnik, Roger C. Clement, Thomas I. Sheridan, Philip Warren, Henry MacDonald, Chester Welde Cuthell and William D. Fuguet of New York were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had, Justice Cardozo not participating:

Ruling that the Board of Estimate had no power to order a payless furlough for members of the former Board of Aldermen, Supreme Court Justice Thomas F. Noonan yesterday directed the city to repay Morton Moses, who formerly represented the upper West Side, deductions amounting to $229 which had been made from his pay
The Long Island Sunday Press of Jamaica, Queens, Sunday edition of The Long Island Daily Press, has discontinued publication, William F. Hofmann; publisher, announced yesterday.

The story of the installation of the radio station on Pitcairn Island, the refuge of the mutineers of the British war brig Bounty, was related yesterday by Granville P. Lindley and Lewis S. Bellem Jr., the radio engineers.

Hope of saving the Saugatuck Valley, home of many wealthy families in the towns of Westport, Weston and Redding, was brighter tonight after a long conference with Governor Cross, who was asked to block the moves of the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company to condemn many acres of expansive estates.

Members of the housing committee of the State Constitutional Convention made a tour yesterday of slum areas in Manhattan and visited model housing developments in Brooklyn and Manhattan to get a first-hand picture of housing conditions in the city.

Having captured the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf League championship last Saturday, Princeton's strong team will seek national intercollegate laurels for the second successive year at Louisville on June 27.
King George and Queen Elizabeth were among'forty-five dinner guests entertained at the St. James Square home of Lord and Lady Astor. The Duke and Duchess of Kent were other royal guests.
The international stock market indices for May 21, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

Konrad Henlein, the Sudeten leader in Czechoslovakia, had a three-hour conference with Premier Hodza last evening on possible compromise of differences. Also, word reached Prague of further retirement of German troops in the border region. There was more optimism but still nervousness. Paris was concerned by reports from Prague that Henlein had demanded demobilization of the army reserves.
Armed British soldiers and police undertook today to drive de strikes and unemployed sympathizers from Kingston streets in a wave of labor troubles.

Mrs. Eve Bickford, an American, who was forbidden to re-enter Britain when she arrived at Croydon from Berlin by plane on Saturday, told The Daily Mail tonight that British immigration officials had accused her of being a spy.

Premier Maurice Duplessis announced today that in connection with a reorganization plan arranged by the Beauharnois Power Company with the Quebec Government, a $400,000 annual reduction in rates would accrue to consumers in the Montreal district and one of several hundred thousand dollars to the city of Montreal.

The appeal of Time, Inc., in Curtis B. Dall's suit charging libel by that publication was heard today in the Court of Appeals. The action alleged that an article in Time stated that Mr. Dall, sonin-law of President Roosevelt, had shot himself in the White House in the presence of his estranged wife and Mrs. Roosevelt.

Hungary announced Officially today that Czechoslovak authorities had raised the ban on frontier traffic. Nevertheless, the Hungarian public feeling is very tense. Hungarians always bear in mind that Czechoslovakia's Little Entente allies [Rumania and Yugoslavia] are pledged to come to her armed support in ease of Hungarian aggression.

Although the week-end war scare has abated and European capitals look with hope to Prague's negotiations with the Sudeten Germans, the relations between Germany and Czechoslovakia became, if anything, even-more critical today when German quarters reported an increasing number of border incidents in which Czech soldiers were alleged to have violated German territory.

The proposed new. Fine Arts Bureau Bill, incorporating certain features of the Coffee-Pepper and Sirovich measures, will be discussed today at. a luncheon at Sardi's Restaurant, 234 West Fortyfourth Street.

Walter E. Short, secretary of the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association, announced today 141 competitors from thirty-nine schools have entered the seventh annual State championship golf tournament to be held Wednesday at the Locust Grove Golf Club, Westfield.

Coming from behind twice during a ten-inning game that lasted 4 hours 10 minutes, the Long Island University baseball team gained a 9-to-8 victory over City College at Dexter Park in Woodhaven yesterday. The triumph was the second for the Blackbirds over the Lavender this season.

Mayor La Guardia, addressing a rally of 2,000 Department of Health employes at the Riverside Plaza Hotel, 253 West Seventy-third Street, last night, contrasted their pay with that of "political favorites" on the city payroll, whom he said he had inherited and could not get rid of.

Charles T. Brish, in 21 E 86th St: Mrs. William A. Prime, in 4 E 70th St; John J. Kelly, in 166 E 96th St; John Sailley Jr., in 530 E 88th St; Culver, Hollyday Co, Inc. broker. Lind, Shlivek, Marks Brin, in 275 Central Park W; Apartment Locating Bureau, broker.

The issue of $25,000,000 of Federal National Mortgage Association five-year, 2 per cent notes recently offered for sale by the RFC, was subscribed about fifty-two times, approximately 4,500 subscriptions aggregating $1,305,000,000 having been received, Jesse H., Jones,, RFC Chairman, announced at his press conferences this afternoon.

Mrs. Robert C. Ream of 770 Park Avenue has been re-elected president of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work, it was announced yesterday at a meeting of the board of directors at the exchange headquarters, 541 Madison Avenue.

It may be that somebody sprang the barrier too soon. Then again, it may have been that our usually alert Giants were still too engrossed with reflections upon their marvelous work the previous afternoon to note that a new day had dawned and another game was about to begin.

Four high school girls testified that they had had alcoholic drinks in the company of James H. White, health education teacher in Theodore Roosevelt High School, and several male pupil-teachers, at the departmental trial of Mr. White yesterday before a committee of the Board of Education.
Mr. and Mrs. M. J. O'Brien of New York announced today the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret E. O'Brien, to Clarence Carl Combs Jr., son of-Mr. an` Mrs. Clarence C. Combs of this place.

The number of industrial and commercial failures in the United States for the week ended May 12 was 222, the smallest number for any week since Dec. 23, when there were 209, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This figure compares with 187 in the corresponding week of 1937 and 231 the preceding week.

Board Finds He Violated His Parole-Began Crime at 8 Joseph (Babe) Pioli, 42 years old, whose criminal record covers thirty-four years, was ordered removed to Sing Sing Prison yesterday by the State Parole Board after an investigation of his activities following his arrest in a hotel in West Forty-ninth Street last Wednesday.

Clerks in the Marriage License Bureau who have been unpaid since April 1 because of a dispute over their status will receive checks on the next regular payday, paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, said yesterday.

Gross assets, $21,545; net, $6,625. To Jacob P. Aronson and Viola Lowenheim, $1,652 each: five varying bequests. Chief asset, powers of appointment, $12,522. Henry L. Schaefer, attorney, 55 Liberty St.

George Foster Sanford, a Yale football star of the Nineties who became one of the leading American coaches, died suddenly yesterday afternoon in the Presbyterian Hospital of a heart attack. He had complained of feeling poorly and on the advice of his doctor entered the hospital on Saturday for examination.

Reductions ranging from 2 to 7 cents were announced yesterday, effective last Friday, by Celanese Corporation of America, in its acetate rayon yarn prices. The action followed the reduction in viscose rayon yarn prices by-the rayon division of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., last Friday.

Without the excursions into Simon W. Gerson's communistic philosophy which characterized the legislative committee's investigation, the Appellate Division's inquiry into the circumstances of the change of name of the Manhattan Borough President's confidential examiner in the now famous $150 rent case started yesterday morning in the Supreme Court.

Substantial increase in cement imports into the United States during April were revealed today in figures made public by the Metals and Minerals Division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce. During the month 74,602,909 pounds were admitted at a value of $164,453.

Effective July 1, the maximum rate of interest commercial banks and trust companies may pay on that part of any time or thrift deposit in excess of $5,000, has been reduced to 1 1/2 per cent, according to a regulation made public yesterday by William R. White, State Superintendent of Banking.

Harry S. Hamilton, former banker and civic leader here, died yesterday at tile home of friends in Lakewood, Ohio. He was 71 years old and had moved in 1931 from White Plains to Eustis, Fla. Mr. Hamilton joined the Home Savings Bank here in 1893 when the bank was organized.

Miss Emma E. Lange, trust officer of the Bank of Montclair, who, is said to have been the first woman to hold that position in this country, died suddenly of a heart attack yesterday at her country home at Lebanon. While preparing to return to her home here Miss Lange collapsed and died within a few minutes.

In an account in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday of the annual convention of the New York Department of Jewish War Veterans of the United States it was reported incorrectly that the group had adopted a resolution favoring Statewide compulsory National Guard training for youths.

Charles Evans of Ohio State shot a 153 today to take a one-point lead at the end of thirty-six holes in the Big Ten championship golf tourney on the University of Minnesota course. Evans, Ohio State No. 2 man, posted a 74 in the morning and a 79 in the afternoon to lead Sid Richardson, Northwestern, defending his individual title, who had a 154 total.

Tippy Larkin, 135, of Garfield, the National Boxing Association's sixthranking lightweight, decisively outpointed Julio Gonzales, 134, Puerto Rico, in a feature eight-round bout tonight. Referee Gene Roman credited Larkin with five rounds, Gonzales one and called two even.

Mr. and Mrs. Amos Tuck French, who had been at the Savoy-Plaza, left yesterday for their country home, Journey's End, in Chester, N. H. Dr. and Mrs. Norman E. Ditman have come from Palm Beach to the Pierre.
The Clover Splint Coal Company, one of sixty-four defendants on trial before 'Federal Judge Ford for conspring to defeat the Wagner act, threw itself on the mercy of the court today.

An accounting filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday disclosed that Cortlandt F. Bishop, art patron, 'left an estate of $3,237,065 and that his daughter, Mrs. Beatrice B. Berle, wife of the Assistant Secretary of State and former City Chamberlain, who was cut off in the will, and who brought a suit against the estate -for $875,000, will receive $515,000 in settlement of her claim.

About 150 students in the New York School of Industrial Art, a WPA project, marched from the four-story building at 257 West Fortieth 'Street, formerly Public School 28, shortly after 11 o'clock yesterday morning when fire was discovered in a clothes locker on the ground floor.

Miss Mary Bishop Goodyear, daughter of General E. D. S. Goodyear, who commanded the Fifth Connecticut Regiment throughout the Civil War, died at her home yesterday. She was born here seventy-nine years ago and had been active in Red Cross and library organization activities.

An accounting filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday disclosed that Jacob Werthelm, head of the investment security house of Wertheim Co., 120 Broadway, who died on Nov. 14,- 1920, left an estate of $9,324,243.

The Strand and Ritz Theatres at Port Jervis, N. Y., have been leased for the Sol Brill estate through David Berk and J. Krumgold, brokers, to the Fabian Theatres, Inc., Simon H. Fabian, president. The Fabian interests now operate the Brooklyn Paramount, Fox and Strand Theatres in addition to amusement houses in Albany, Troy, Schenectady and Middletown, N. Y.

AIRCRAFT MECHANIC (AUTOGIRO), $1,860 a year, Bureau of Entomology and Plant Quarantine, Department of Commerce, Second District. Applications must be on file with the manager, Second United States Civil Service District, Federal Building, Christopher St., New York, N. Y., not later than June 1.

The Phillies overcame an early five-run lead to defeat the Cardinals, 7-6, today and sweep their two-game series. Hugh Mulcahy scored the winning run in the eighth inning. Singles by Mulcahy and Martin and Young's infield out put the pitcher on third.

Imports of raw cotton into Poland in March increased 35.3 per cent in volume and 30.3 per cent in value over the previous month. The 7,798 metric tons imported, according to a report from a commercial attachs at Warsaw, was valued at $2,256,250. Imports in the first quarter

Nat Litfin, Bronx featherweight who recently defeated Sixto Escobar, bantamweight champion, in an over-the-weight encounter, will tackle Johnny Compo, aggressive warrior from New Haven, in the top bout of eight rounds at the New York Coliseum tonight.

In view of formal petitions by the Underwriters' Service Association, Inc.; American Trucking Associations, Inc.; Safeway Lines, Inc., and other considerations, Division 5 of the Interstate Commerce Commission announced today it would reopen proceedings in which it set insurance rules for motor carriers under the Motor Carrier Act.

Liquor deliveries to retail liquor stores throughout the city were reduced yesterday as a result of the strike called Sunday by 2,000, wholesale liquor salesmen, but spokesmen for the industry asserted that there was no danger of a shortage of supplies in the near future.

Completion of the airconditioning system at Bonwit Teller's was celebrated yesterday at a meeting of the store's 1,384 employes, at which Mrs. Hortense M. Odium, president, cut a silver cord putting the motors into operation. At the same time, the specialty store's mid-season import collection was shown for the fashion press.
Two women with long service records have been nominated by the Board of Superintendents for principalships in high schools, it was learned yesterday.

A memorial service for Elon Huntington, Hooker, chemical manufacturer and engineer, who died May 10 at the age of 69 while on a vacation in Pasadena, Calif., was held at 4:30 P. M. yesterday in Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

The Republic of Cuba has filed with the. Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering the issuance of $85,000,000 of 41 per cent external-debt bonds of the republic, running from 1937 to 1977, to be offered in exchange for outstanding Cuba issues as soon as possible after the effective date of the statement, the commission announced today.

The processes of democracy are not automatic, and the mere counting of noses does not produce freedom or liberty, Dr. Clarence A. Dykstra, president of the University of Wisconsin, told members of the graduating classes of Hobart and William Smith Colleges here today.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith's statement suggesting a program for the Constitutional Convention, made public here tonight, read as follows: Since the Constitutional Convention convened I have repeatedly been asked to state what I think its program should be and-what practical results it should seek to accomplish.
The marriage of Miss Audre M. Dorson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Dorson, to John M. Gingold of London, England, will take place on June 8 at noon at the Dorson residence, 1,185 Park Avenue.

Applications for loans to business and industry have surpassed expectations of the RFC, Chairman Jesse H. Jones announced today, and at the same time he predicted an upturn in business in late Summer or Fall when the crops begin to move and pump-priming is under way.

Lord Robert Crichton-Stuart, second son of the Marquess of Bute, the wealthiest land-owner in Wales, arrived from England yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary emphatically denying that his father had sold. half the city of Cardiff, South Wales, for $100,000,000 and intended to invest the proceeds in American securities.

Crawling over the ridges of the Cumberlands and roaring into Nashville through a driving rainstorm, the 86 tanks and more than 400 other vehicles of the mechanized Seventh Cavalry Brigade completed a 150-mile march today in about twelve hours. The 3,000 officers and men of the brigade, which is completing a 700mile four-day "war drive" from Fort Knox, Ky., to Fort Oglethorpe, Ga., and return, arrived here at dusk.

After some brisk betting at the Victoria Club today, H. E. Morriss's Pasch still was favored for the June 1 running of the Derby at Epsom Downs. His odds lengthened somewhat, however, for he was quoted at 9 to 4, compared to 7 to 4 last Friday.

The National Collegiate A. A. has accepted for registration twentynine swimming records established this year, according to the official list issued yesterday by Philip S. Harburger, chairman of the record committee. Varsity contestants bettered five marks and equaled another, college 'freshmen accounted for sixteen and preparatory school students for seven.

Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan of Boston and Miss Gracyn Wheeler and Miss Dorothy May Bundy, both of Santa Monica, Calif., members of the American Wightman Cup tennis team, won their opening matches today in the Chiswick Park tournament.

Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano asked to see the new German Ambassador, HansGeorg Viktor von Mackensen, late this afternoon and had an hour's conversation with him. It is understood Count Ciano strongly urged the necessity of proceeding

To Brock Pemberton falls the honor of making the first definite announcement of a show for next season. The week of Sept. 26, he says, will bring the local premiere of Clare Boothe's new comedy, "Kiss the Boys Goodbye." He even has a home picked out for it-Henry Miller's Theatre-to which it will come after an out-of-town tryout.

The treason trial of Corneliu Zelea Codreanu, leader of the outlawed Fascist Iron Guard, began today before a military court. The indictment indicated the charge was based on his possession of secret State documents.

Delegates were arriving here tonight for the opening tomorrow of the forty-fourth annual convention of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs. Scheduled speakers include David Seabury, New York consulting psychologist; Dr....

Events in Czechoslovakia are being anxiously followed here, with special concern regarding the attitude of neighboring Russia. At the palace this morning the situation was surveyed by the Cabinet under King Carol's presidency.

Making the most of their five hits off Lou Fette, the Cubs snapped the Bees' winning streak at seven games today and held safe their second position in the National League with a 4-to-1 victory. The defeat cost the Bees a chance to move into second place and they dropped to fourth behind the Reds.
A leaking roof during a rainstorm almost forced Speaker Bankhead off the dais today when the House started consideration of the Wages and Hours Bill.

Turning in identical scores for their outward as well as homeward journeys, two teams tied for firstplace honors today in the Westchester Professional Golfers Association pro-amateur best-ball tourney over the links of the Gedney Country Club.
France this year will spend at least as much money on State and municipal improvements encouraging production as on national defense, and probably more.

Although it-clinched' Class A honors a week ago, the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club team lost a match today as the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub matches in the Long Island district were concluded.

Lancashire retained the lead in the English County cricket competition today, defeating Northamptonshire by an innings and 57 runs. The northern county compiled 322 runs Saturday and today dismissed its opponents for totals of 98 and 167.
President Roosevelt conferred on legislative matters with Administration leaders in the Senate and House, and discussed the-European and Mexican situations with Secretary Hull.

Directors of the National Restaurant Association have decided to hold the organization's annual conventions in Chicago for the next five years, Thomas D. Gibbons, assistant secretary of the association, announced today.
Two decisions greatly expanding the government's power to tax activities of the States, and thus upsetting long-established principles of tax immunity, were handed down today by the Supreme Court.

James, a dark brown 15-to-1 shol owned by W. H. Goelitz of Oah Park, Ill., made his racing debut ar auspicious one today by scoring a length-and-a-half victory over Teperwine. Oh Fudge ran third as James raced the four-and-a-half. furlong fourth race in fifty-eighl seconds over the deepest and heavi. est track of the meeting.

Wheat prices were on the downgrade today, with the July and the September on the Board of Trade here and the October in Winnipeg and' Liverpool sinking to new seasonal low levels due son tb to continued favorable crop comments and a lessening in the political tension in Europe.

Antoinette Perry, who this Winter has been in charge of the American Theatre Council's committee of the apprentice theatre, was the guest of honor at a supper held after performance time last night at the Ritz Carlton.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday it had awarded the contracts for completion of the New York approach of the George Washington Bridge and planned to have the work completed in time for the World's Fair opening next April.

A test case, to determine whether the issuance of coupons in connection with the sale of articles pricefixed under the Feld-Crawford act was initiated here yesterday when Erie Calamie, proprietor of Reinhard Brothers, tobaconists, 29 Maiden Lane, filed a plea for an injunction restraining D. A. Schulte, Inc., from issuing profit-sharing coupons with the sale of Admiration cigars.
The New York Curb Exchange admitted yesterday to unlisted trading York Railways Company firstmortgage and collateral trust thirtyyear 5 per cent bonds, extended ten years in maturity to Dec. 1, 1947.

Announcement has been made here of the marriage of Miss Janet L. Hayward, daughter of Mrs. Frank Sutton of Babylon, L. I., and of William Tyson Hayward of Danbury, Conn., to Eugene Kelly 'of Bermuda, which took place secretly last Wednesday in Towson, Md. At the ceremony the couple were attended by Miss Joan Power and Tilden Hazard. both of New York.

Former Governor Alf M. Landon of Kansas, Republican nominee for President in 1936, and Colonel Frank C. Knox, Chicago publisher, his running mate, had a fifteenminute chat yesterday with former President Herbert Hoover at the Waldorf-Astoria, where all three were Staying.

Unless all signs fail, the House of Representatives will adopt a national Wage and Hour Bill today. Yesterday five hours were set aside for debate of the measure. That is a short time for the consideration of a question of such magnitude.

With Britons anxiously watching developments in Czechoslovakia, tonight under circumstances similar to his first such broadcast immediately after the German seizure of Austria, Home Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare made another radio appeal for air raid precaution volunteers.
Abram Haitowitsch, blind Russian violinist, will give a violin recital tonight at 8:45 o'clock in the Plaza Hotel ballroom. He will be assisted at the piano by Vladimir Padwa.

The series of one-picture exhibitions held at the Town Hall Club will be brought to a close next Monday. This season's series, which began Nov. 15, has dealt with nineteenth-century trench painting and has included canvases by fourteen artists, each representative of one of several major movements, or of particular phases within a movement.

Turpentine firm, 22 1/2-23c; sales 36 barrels; receipts, 380 barrels; shipments, 540 barrels; stock 34,019 barrels. Resin, firm; sales 92 barrels; receipts 2,427: shipments, 2,104; stock, 110,424. Quote--B, $3.35; D. $5.30; B $3.55; F, $3.90: $4.10: H. $4.15: I and K, $4.20: M. $4.25: N. 4.80: WG, $5.45: and X $6.10.

The General Foods Corporation reported today to the Securities and Exchange Commission that the salaries of its principal officers were cut about in half last year. C. M. Chester, chairman of the board, received $84,000 last year, compared with $159,600 in 1936.
A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Julius G. Forstmann of 520 East Eighty-sixth Street on Saturday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.

Despite a screaming northwest wind and "typically British" conditions, America's Walker Cup team members had a grand day in the first round of the British amateur golf championship as far as it was played today.
Enough time has elapsed since the voters of Pennsylvania and Oregon chose their candidates in the Fall elections to hazard a more detailed analysis.

The Supreme Court after hearing arguments today took under advisement the dispute over whether the Labor Board can withdraw its litigation in the Republic Steel case, and presumably withheld its decision on the matter until May 31, last day of the present term.
Deputy Chief John J. Waldron, 15th Division, for 39 hours, from 6 P. M., May 23. Lieutenant Reuben Timmins. H. L. 127, for 3 days, from 8 A. M., May 23.

The leading figure in the crisis over the German minority in Czechoslovakia turns out to be the British Prime Minister. The brief and measured statement of Mr. Chamberlain to the House of Commons yesterday is remarkable as much for what he did not say as for what he said.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's speech in the British Parliament today and his tribute to France have made it clear to the world, Germany and Czechoslovakia included, that Great Britain and France have inaugurated a new policy in Europe.

Industrial buying will be resumed on praotioally all commodities by midAugust or early September at the latest, George P. Brockway, manager of purchases for the American Optical Company, Southbridge, Mass., and president of the National Association of Purchasing y Agents, said here today in opening ti the twenty-third annual convention n of the association in the Hotel Jefferson.

Mrs. Anna Minford Bond of New York, the Romaine Nichols estate at Bernardsville, N. J.: Hardwick Stires, the R. Stuyvesant Pierrepont farm home at Peapack, N. J.: Fred W. Jones, broker. Dr. Edward Goebel of Brooklyn, on West Shore Trail, from John S. Sweeney: Mrs. Hazel E. Timmins, on Tobaggan Park W: Joseph A. Gill, on Oak Parkway: A. V. Harris, on Oakwood Trail: Lake Mohawk. N. J.: rentals by the Arthur D. Crane Co.

For humiliation and other damages alleged to have been suffered because-he was threatened with the suspension of his gas service for non-payment of a bill he had protested as excessive, Victor House, former Assistant United States Attorney, has sued the Consolidated Edison Company for $20,000.

Aroused at 7 A. M. yesterday by her dog, Mrs. George H. Rosenthal followed the pet to the living room of the apartment, 35 East Ninth Street, and found her husband, a 55-year-old retired stock broker, unconscious on -the floor with his throat cut.

Relaxation of the tension over the Czechoslovak crisis-was evident in Soviet official circles today with the receipt of reports of comparative orderliness in the conduct of the Czechoslovak municipal elections. Although the atmosphere here was mote optimistic,

Undismayed by the results of some of the more spectacular "planning" they have so far advocated, the "leftwing advisers" of the Administration are now reported ready to set everything right by still more planning. But this time they will plan in earnest.

Last to finish, John Dobbs of Idlewild and Charles Mayes, unattached, posted a sensational 31, 33-64 to capture top honors in the Long Island Golf Association one-day amateur-professional best-ball tournament over the scenic Oakland course at Bayside yesterday.

An investigation of an alleged Communist conspiracy to obtain enlistment of Americans for service with the Spanish Loyalist Government was demanded today by Representative John W. McCormack of Massachusetts in letters to Cordell Hull, Secretary of State; Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, and Homer S. Cummings, Attorney General.
-Great Britain's worries about t the Davis Cup, emblem of world tennis supremacy, were ended by Yugo- New Yor: slavia today. Yugoslavia's team won all five matches in the secondround series.

Dr. James C. Wolfe, died suddenly today at his home, 47 Glen Ridge Parkway, at the age of 39. This morning he had administered an anesthetic at the Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, but complained of illness when he returned home.
Two temperance meetings were held yesterday at which addresses were made calling for support of legislation introduced in Washington to restrict liquor advertising "so far as is possible."

Mrs. Edith M. Steinberg of 30 Edwin Court, Bay Park, was in the Nassau County jail today awaiting sentence on a charge of having received $1,800 in the last year, although she had assets of about $15,000 when she applied for relief.

The building at 135-03 Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing, L. I., was sold by John Brennan to Isidor Weinberg of St. Albans, an investor. The property was held at $13,500. The Master Realty Company, broker, negotiated the sale.

THE BEST SHORT STORIES 1938, edited by Edwarq J. O'Brien. (Houghton Mifflin, $2.50.) An annual short story anthology. FREDDY FRIBBS, FLEA, by John B. L. Goodwin. (McFarlane, Warde, McFarlane, $1.50.) A story for children.

The British Government is determined to "take all possible steps in its power to protect. British interests abroad" and plans to review the entire Mexican oil situation as soon as -the former British Minister, Owen St. Clair O'Malley, reaches London at the end of May, the Earl of Plymouth, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, announced in the House of Lords today.

The playing of badminton, which has grown rapidly in popularity in recent years, is keeping many marriages from the divorce courts by attracting young couples who otherwise would be. at "cocktail parties and neighborhood petting parties," speakers said here today at the fourth annual Recreation Training Institute, conducted at the County Center by the Westchester County Recreation Commission.

Nathan Goldmann, president of Isaac Goldmann Company, Inc., was re-elected president of the New York Employing Printers Association, Inc., at the organization's annual meeting last evening at the Downtown Athletic Club.

James Stewart was borrowed today from Metro to co-star with Carole Lombard in Selznick-International's "Made for Each Other," adapted from Rose Frankin's "Of Great Riches." Jo Swerling has prepared the screen play. Shooting is scheduled to start July 1.

Net profit of the American Crystal Sugar Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries amounted to $1,234,465 for the year ended on March 31. This result allows the deductions for interest, depreciation. Federal income taxes and surtax on undistributed earnings, and, after dividend requirements on 64,358 shares of 6 per cent preferred stock, the profit is equivalent to $2.33 each on 364,017 shares of common stock.

The James Madison High nine met with a surprising 3-1 defeat at the hands of Alexander Hamilton in their Brooklyn P. S. A. L. game yesterday at Erasmus Field. A three-run attack in the sixth, featured by Travis's double, which drove in two men, upset the Black and Gold players, who suffered their second setback in six circuit games.

Recorder Albert L. Vreeland ot this city, who has a reputation for giving bitter doses to violators of motor-vehicle regulations, had to swallow some of his own medicine today. He paid a fine of $2.75 to the clerk in his court for parking without lights.
Presldent and Mrs. Roosevelt gave their annual "newspaper dance" tonight at the White House, entertaining 1,500 newspaper men and women, members of the Cabinet and their wives, and other guests..

Mrs. Margaret F Palmer, widow of A. Mitchell Palmer, former Federal Attorney General, said today that acid throwers and other persons had been trying to intimidate her, apparently because the Pennsylvania Board of Motion Picture Censors, of which she is chairman, had banned the Amkino Russian movie, "The Baltic Deputy."

Paul Adler, former governor of the New York Stock Exchange, senior partner in the brokerage firm of Adler, Coleman Co., 15 Broad Street, and well known in Jewish philanthropic circles, died in Mount Sinai Hospital yesterday at the age of 47. He underwent an operation ten days ago.
Sammy Angott, Louisville lightweight, scored a ten-round decision over Frank Covelli of Brooklyn tonight. Angott weighed 1351/2, Covelli, 132.

Automobile output declined last week against a steady seasonal trend, and the adjusted index eased to 44.0 from 44.5. For the week ended May 22, 1937, the figure was 123.2. According to the estimate of Ward's Automotive Reports, production for the week amounted

The Home Owners Loan Corporation, a Federal agency which at the depths of the depression advanced $3,000,000,000 to save distressed home owners from foreclosure, now finds itself confronted with the same problems which face all realty lending agencies in time of slack business.

Grand St, 55, 22x67; Frank Lazzaro and Joseph Brunetto to Lazzaro Brunetto Realty Corp, 55 Grand St ($10). Broome St, n w cor Eldridge St, 25x75; trustees will of Aaron Jacobs to Jacobs Holding Corp. 1.441 Bway, care Louis Friedman: mtg $18,000.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced at noon yesterday its new price list for rolled steel products and reaffirmed present prices for other steel products for the third quarter, with the exception of galvanized sheets and bolts and nuts, on which quotations will be announced later.

The three-story apartment and store building on a plot 20 by 97.3 feet at 7,212 Eighteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, was purchased by the Gotham Equities Corporation for cash. It has an assessed valuation of $13,000.

D. Sicilianos, Minister of Greece, presented to Secretary Morgenthau this afternoon his government's check for $174,336 to meet 40 per cent of the interest installments of $217,290 due Nov. 10, 1937, and May 10, 1938, on a 4 per cent loan made in 1929.

Barney Ross, who will defend his welterweight championship of the world against Henry Armstrong atthe Long Island City Bowl on Thursday night, broke camp here today. In his farewell gymnasium appearance at the Grossinger Country Club, Ross refrained from sparring, but did go through what amounted to seven rounds of exercise.

Anthony Andosca, a former taxicab driver who was one of five men indicted last March on evidence obtained by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's Rackets Bureau in alleged extortions, totaling $1,000,000, from the owners of four independent taxicab fleets for "protection," was arrested in Boston yesterday.

ADLER--Paul, on Monday, May 23, 1938, in his forty-eighth year, beloved husband of Eleanor S., devoted father of Jack and Virginia; son of Ernest and the late Laura Adler. Services Temple Emanu-El, 65th St. at 5th Ave., Wednesday morning, May 25, at 10:30 o'clock. Interment private.

Mrs. W. McFarlane Barker gave a dinner last evening in the garden of the Ambassador for Miss Mae Constance Flynn, whose marriage to Joseph Downey Barker, brotherin-law of Mrs. Barker, will take place on Friday at the hotel.

Benjamin Rosenberg, founder and former president of the Rose Lithograhpic Corporation of Brooklyn, died yesterday at the South Nassau Community Hospital. He recently returned from Miami Beach to his home, Purdy Court. Mr. Rosenberg sold his lithographic corporation some years ago.

With the formal closing Of entries yesterday, thirty colleges nominated men for the sixty-second 'annual track and field championships of the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. at Randalls Island Stadium on June 3 and 4. A total of 454 individuals his been named for the fifteen varsity events.
Members of the Unitarian Ministerial Union were urged today to seek pensions equal to those paid to retired policemen. The Rev. Louis C. Cornish

The report of the Middle West Corporation and subsidiaries, exclusive of Central Illinois Public Service Company and Lake Superior District Power Company, for the first quarter of this year, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all expenses and charges of $350,852,
Carl S. B. Fuller has resigned as assistant buyer in the grocery department at R. H. Macy Co., Inc., to join Kroger Grocery and Baking Company. Cincinnati.

The five-story loft and store buildingat 7 East Fifty--fifth Street was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. It was bought in by the trustees, Walter F. Chappel Jr. and others, as plaintiffs, for $102,500.

The Islington Corinthians, English amateur soccer team, scored a 6-2 victory tonight over an all-star array selected by the new Ontario Football Association. It was the Corinthians' sixty-sixth triumph in ninety-three games on their world tour against nineteen draws and eight defeats.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 20: REAR ADMIRALS Andrews, A., Chief of Bureau of Navlgation, Washington, D. C., about June 11 to duty as Commander of the Scouting Force.

Appointnment of the Attorney General by the Governor and the creation of judicial nominating boards in each judicial department to pick candidates for election to the State Supreme Court, were urged by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York in a series of proposals sent to the Constitutional Convention tonight.

During the first four months of 1938 the ninety-two insured savings and loan associations in New York State increased their direct-reduction home loans by $6,000,000 to a new high of $99,000,000, Nugent Fallon, general manager of the Federal Savings and Loan Corporation, said today.

Reprimanded on May 3 by the Actors Equity Association's council, which he had described as "Communist-controlled," Louis' Hallett declared yesterday that he would go through with his plan to appeal the council's decision to the Equity membership at its annual election meeting on Friday afternoon.

An investing client of Riker Co., Inc., who purchased the sixstory office building at 144-6 East Eighty-sixth Street, Yorkville, from the Manufacturers Trust Company, plans alterations, including the removal of the three upper floors, at a cost of about $50,000.

134th St (10-2563), n s, 351 ft w of willow Ave, 100x200; Bronx Grocery Building Corp to Bronx Grocery Co, 711 E 134th St; mtg $40,000. Featherbed Lane (11-2865), e s, 178 ft s of Inwood Avem, 124x104; David Schneiber to Lanwood Realty Corp, 349 E 149th St; mtg $172,000.

Billy Beauhuld, Jersey City lightweight, carried off the decision over Jimmy Vaughn of Cleveland in the principal bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. A crowd of 2,000 saw the winner score repeatedly by his sharper hitting and better boxing

The protective committee for the first consolidated general refunding mortgage bonds of the Fonda, Johnstown Gloversville Railroad filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission a plan of reorganization which proposes abandonment of the electric division and substitution of buses for this service.
President and Mrs. Roosevelt have made their traditional family wedding gift, a chest of flat silver, to Miss Anne Lindsay Clark, fiancee of their youngest son, John Roosevelt.

Buddy, first of the 350 "Seeing Eye" dogs trained to lead the blind, died at noon yesterday at the training school of the Seeing Eye organization at Morristown, N. J. With her at her death was Morris Frank, for whom she served as "seeing eye" for the last ten years on travels which led. the. pair over 150,000 miles in the United States.

The reports from the salt water front seem to be improving every day, and those who fished Long Island and New Jersey waters over the week-end seem to have been unusually lucky. Out at Montauk Frank Tuma and Louis Chilar are taking stripers from the surf with their usual regularity, and we hear that Samuel Sternberg of New York went out to get Frank to show him-how it was done.

Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott said yesterday that he would appoint eighty-six officers and 280 men in his department on June 1, in line with the expansion program involved in the three-platoon, system.

Profit-taking on straddles supplied contracts during early trading on the local cotton exchange yesterday, and the July broke below 8 1/2 cents for the second time since January. Buying power, however, furnished resistance, and this develops ment caused the list to hold within an unusually narrow range to end with losses of 1 to 3 points.

The Adjutant General released the following orders today. These officers, having qualified, are placed on duty: acharis, Lt. (JG) Casper, to report to the commanding officer, N. Y. N. M., for assignment to 12th Fleet Division, deck duties only.

Scoring six runs in the first inning, the Northeastern baseball team collected seventeen hits from three pitchers to defeat Harvard, 10 to 8, on Soldiers Field today. The new yellow baseball, used for the first time in Greater Boston, proved generally satisfactory.

A petition urging approval of the proposed amendments introduced by Senator Wagner which would expand the powers of the United States Housing Authority was sent yesterday by the City-Wide Tenants Council to the Senate Committee on Education and Labor.
Conversion to 10 per cent cash and 90 per cent in new certificates was offered today to holders of original claims amounting to $720,300 in the old Fidelity Savings and Loan Association.

Columbia's hopes of adding the I. C. A. A. A. A. outdoor track title to the indoor titles it has won the past two years were severely impaired yesterday by the discovery that the ailing Ben Johnson, Lion captain and intercollegiate sprint champion, had the measles.

Brazil lifted today all exchange restrictions regarding imports from the United States, the State Department announced. The department received a telegram from Ambassador Jefferson Caffery at Rio de Janeiro

Speeding-up of the service for the patrons of restaurants and hotels is possible as of new improvements, in mechanical gas equipment, several speakers declared yesterday at the opening session of a two-day convention of the American Gas Association Hotel, Restaurant and Commercial Sales Conference.

Eugenio Cardinal Pacelli, papal Secretary of State and papal legate to the Eucharistic Congress beginning- Wednesday, was welcomed with the pomp and magnifi; cence befitting a prince of the church when he arrived from Rome today.

Incorporation in the proposed new State Constitution of a broad phrase which would empower the State to participate in any activity to "promote any public purpose" was urged today by the Citizens Union in a final list of recommendations to the Constitutional Convention.

Governor Elmer A. Benson tonight ordered the National Guard be held in readiness for possible service in Duluth, where police dispersed a picket line before The Herald-News Tribune newspaper plant with tear gas earlier in the day.

Stockholders of the Dunbar National Bank, at a meeting held yesterday at 11 A. M. in the bank's main office, 2,298 Seventh Avenue, approved voluntary liquidation of the bank's business as of May 31. This action was pursuant to a resolution of the directors announced on April 18.

The balance sheet of the Seaboard Air Line Railway Company as of Dec. 31 last shows total assets of $297,510,711, compared with $296,213,895 on Dec. 31, 1936. Profit-andloss deficit amounted to $63,490,507, against deficit of $57,913,461. Current assets were $11,230,424

A renewed demand for gold-mining shares was the feature of an otherwise dull stock market here today and Western Holdings was a favorite. West African mining shares were generally firm but, due to reports from Wall Street, Rhodesian coppers weakened.

Ten days of lawlessness which extended from Florida to Northern New York and included assault, robbery and the shooting of two policemen, ended here yesterday with the capture of two escaped convicts, one of -whom is alleged to have been an aide of Al Capone.

A strike of barge employes of six of the fourteen oil transportation companies, which was called last Wednesday by the United Marine Division of the International Longshoremen's Association, was settled yesterday morning and about 600 strikers returned to work. The companies which made agreements are independents.

Mail orders received in the local merchandise markets yesterday were light in volume, with considerable emphasis on off-price goods, manufacturers and resident offices reported. Despite reports that manufacturers were making up goods sparingly, some bargains were available in the local market, it was said.

Mrs. Mary Kingsbury Simkhovitch, president of the National Public Housing Conference, has sent a letter to President Roosevelt expressing the hope on the part of that organization, that Congress will act favorably on the President's recommendations that additional funds be provided for slum clearance and low-rent housing projects. Mrs.
On their own applications, to take effect 12 midnight, May 22: CAPTAIN Joseph A. Murray, 7th Precinct, at $2,750 per annum. Appointed July 9. 1901.
Eric Etherington has joined the sales department of B. W. Pizzini Co. Sprayregen Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced the opening of a branch office at 790 Broad Street, Newark,

The interest rate on Treasury bills touched a new low level' today of 0.025 per cent, continuing the downward trend which started about a month ago with the desterilization of gold and other money-easing policies of the Administration;

The whereabouts of Benjamin Brown, organizer of the cooperative factory and homestead near Hightstown, N. J., remained unknown yesterday to members of his family there and in New York, who asked police to send out an alarm for him as a missing person. He is 56 years old.

A $185,000 mortgage for ten years on-the 7-story apartment house under erection at the n w cor of 165th St and Walton Ave, Bronx, has been placed for the Garant Building Co, Inc. owner, by Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc. broker.

New York Giants vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Polo Grounds, 157th Street and Eighth Avenue -............... 3:15 P. M. Brooklyn Dodgers vs. Chicago Cubs, at Ebbets Field, Bedford Avenue. and Sillivan -Place, Brooklyn .... .........3:15 P M. Jersey Giants vs. Newark Bears, at Roosevelt Stadium, Danforth and West Side Avenues, Jersey City..... ... 3 P.M.

Unanimous approval of the proposed national constitution of the Communist party in the United States, which would require all members to be citizens or declare their intention to become citizens and to pledge themselves to work for the preservation "of democracy and peace" was voted yesterday at the closing session of the tenth State convention of the party.
A great manhunt was under way tonight behind the lines of Insurgent Spain for 900 of 1,500 prisoners who escaped from the Insurgent San Cristobal prison at Pamplona in a spectacular uprising.
Reorganization Petition I. ALTMAN FURNITURE CO., INC., retailer, 137 Essex St.-Voluntary proceedings under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law, listing liabilities of $16,454 and assets of $20,750.
The Bankers Athletic League will hold its annual officers' golf tournament on June 8 at the Shackamaxon Country Club, Westfield, N. J., the league announced yesterday.
An avalanche of votes forced the House to take up the Wages and Hours-Bill today and the controversial measure was started on the way to what was freely predicted as certain passage tomorrow night.

More than 1,500 Bronx tobacco dealers sent a petition to the City Council yesterday protesting continuation of the emergency tax of one cent on each package of cigarettes as the Council prepared to reenact the city's relief tax program at today's meeting in City Hall.
Dr. Ignatz T. Griebl, American citizen wanted in New York as a witness in the spy ring inquiry, was fined sixty marks here on Saturday for coming to Germany aboard the Bremen without a passport.

A large number of the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday were for quarters in the midtown section of Manhattan. Among them was one for the entire eighteenth floor of the building known as 341 Madison Avenue, which was signed by American Factors, Ltd., prominent sugar plantation agents, merchants and insurance agents, whose main offices are in Honolulu, Hawaii.

Professor Howard W. Haggard of Yale University warned in an address last night before the Medical Society of the County of New York at the New York Academy of Medicine that the medical profession "must either make the necessary adjustments to change or be swept aside."
Laundry owners who have failed to meet the State minimum wage schedules were warned yesterday by the State Labor Department that they have two weeks in which to comply with the law.

Seven-year-old Andrew Savo of 73 North Fourth Street, Brooklyn, was pulled out of the East River, at the foot of North Fifth Street, last evening by Walter Wisnowski, 42, of 123 Greenpoint Avenue, an unemployed laborer.

George B. Calkins Jr., '39, of Hubbard Woods, Ill., has been re-elected captain of the Princeton fencing team for the 1938-39 season, it was announced today by Coich Hubert Pirotte. New 'officers for the Princeton Fencing Association and the award of two proficiency cups also were announced.

One hundred women, representing settlement houses, mothers' clubs and trade union and civic groups, met yesterday at luncheon in the Town Hall Club to adopt a resolution endorsing the Federal recovery-relief bill and to issue an "open letter to the women of America," urging them to press their Senators by mail and telegram to vote for the bill.

Three apartment houses at 52 to 60 Crary Avenue, Mount Vernon, Westchester County, have been sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to a syndicate headed by Jacob Feder, Bronx builder. They front 131 feet on Crary Avenue and eighty feet on East Sidney Avenue and were acquired through the H. C. Black Realty Corporation, broker.

A garden luncheon and fashion show will be given on Thursday in the Park Lane Gardens to aid the Irvington House Thrift Shop and the home for cardiac children at Irvington-on-Hudson, N.. Y. Subscribers are requested to bring discarded clothing and other articles, which will be used for resale at the Thrift Shop.

Stocks closed firmn and mixed in slowest trading since Sept. 4, 1934; turnover, 328,020 shares. United States Government bonds quiet and lower, other groups irregularly lower; transactions, $4,345,400.

Since the letter of Frederick H. Wood, published in the columns of THE TIMES of May 15, commenting on Secretary Wallace's letter of a week earlier may leave some confusion as to certain points, I wish to clear these up.

The safety record of New York City continued to improve last week i and week-end, according to figures given yesterday by the Safety Bureau of the Police Department. Declines in accidents, fatalities and injuries, compared with the 1937 period, were reported.

Waivers were asked today on "twelve or thirteen" Cardinal baseball players, including Slinging Sammy Baugh, in what President Sam Breadon termed "an emergency effort" to bring the club within the twentythree-player limit.
World production of raw opium in 1936 was twice the world's legitimate needs, according to a report made public by the League of Nations today.

Governor Cross received the requested resignations today of John D. Thoms as Statute Revision Commissioner, and Joseph H. Lawlor as Athletic Commissioner. Both are from Waterbury. It was reported that State Senator Matthew A. Daly of New Haven would resign as County Commissioner.
Theodore R. Nathan, assistant general manager of the Dreier Hotel chain, will address the Fifth Estate Club tonight at the Hotel Piccadilly. His subject will be operating a big city hotel.

and Senegal Parcel post for Gold Coast, Sierra Leone and Liberia. South America, West Indies, Etc. BUENAVENTURA (Panama Railroad), Port au Prince May 30 and Cristobal June 2 (mails close 1 P. M.), sails from W. 25th St. Letter mail and printed matter for Haiti. Also parcel post ESSO BOLIVAR (Standard Oil), Aruba, May 31 (mails close 5:30 A. M.), sails from Pier 6; Bayonne. Letter mail and Printed matter for Aruba.

Charles S. Howard's Fair Knightess, a stablemate of Seabiscuit, came back to the races at Belmont Park yesterday after a rest from her campaign in California and showed a fine flight of speed as she led a field of five good sprinters in the Handspring Handicap at six furlongs and paid 6 to 1.

A 78 by Miss Helen Sigel, 20-year-old Philadelphian, won the medal today in the qualifying round of the annual Philadelphia women's golf championship. Miss Sigel's 40, 38-78 was a stroke better than the 41, 38-79 posted by Mrs. Norman M. Lack of Wilmington, Del., winner of the Philadelphia title in 1932-33.

Mrs. Caroline Abbott Keyes, wife of Homer Eaton Keyes, editor of the magazine Antiques, died yesterday afternoon of a coronary thrombosis at their residence, 30 Sutton Place. She was -born in Cleveland sixty-two- years ago, a daughter of the late Major Willard Abbott of the Union army and a maternal granddaughter of Moses Younglove, pioneer developer of Cleveland.

Some obstacles to the growth of the National Progressive party are evident, even in the State of its origin. A convention of the Wisconsin Farmer-Labor Progressive Federation, composed of the Progressive' and Socialist parties, the two great labor organizations, three associations of farmers, the railroad brotherhoods and the Workers' Alliance, has nominated Mr. Daniel W. Hoan, the able, upright, veteran Socialist Mayor of Milwaukee, for Senator, much against his will. Mr.

The plight of the child victims of the civil war in Spain was described as "one of the blackest tragedies of our time" by Claude G. Bowers, United States Ambassador to Spain, in a broadcast last night from SaintJean-de-Luz, France, over the NBC red network.

At the request of the three principal odd-lot-dealer firms in the financial district, the Brookings Institution of Washington, D. C., will make a study of the odd-lot-dealer system- on the New York Stock Exchange. The survey, it is understood, will be started on or about Aug. 1.
The Italian liner Roma is due here today from Mediterranean ports with 377 passengers. the majority of whom sailed more than a month ago for a tour of the wine and spirit centers of Italy.

James F. Manning, former vice president of George A. Fuller Company and for many years engaged in the building and marble quarrying business, died yesterday at his home in Eudora, Va., at the age of 75. He was born at Paeonian Springs, Va.

District Attorney Fred J. Under asked the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors today to offer a reward of $1,000 for information--on the whereabouts of Mrs. Alice Parsons, "dead or alive." Mrs. Parsons wife of William Parsons, vanished from her home at Stony Brook last June.

Mrs. Rita O'Donovan Olcott of 17 Sutton Place and Saratoga Springs, N. Y., widow of Chauncey Olcott, well-known tenor, will be married to Ralph Stuyvesant Brown, a descendant of Peter Stuyvesant, within the next several weeks.
Following is the text of the statement on the German-Czec1h situation by Prime Minister Nevifle Chamberlain in the House of Commons today:

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on May 14 amounted to 304,198,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines. Compared with the figures of the previous week, this total represents a decrease of 1,550,000 barrels, comprising a decline of 1,743,000 barrels in stocks of domestic crude but an increase of 193,000 barrels in stocks of foreign crude.

A photograph of the twelve jurors in the Harlan County trial reveals at a glance one of the basic factors in the case. Here, as in earlier instances of labor troubles in the Appalachian region, we have the ancient tradition of the mountain folk superimposed on the modern industrial tradition.

With "streamlining" of the State Constitution already in progress as the Constitutional Convention tonight entered upon its seventh week, former Governor Alfred E.
