Smith, honorary president of the body, issued a statement discouraging too extensive changes in the organic law and urging the convention to concentrate on a six-point program which he offered.

The Bolte Nursery, comprising thirty-three acres of land with old saltbox type home in Upper Stepney, Fairfield County, Conn., has been purchased by Charles V. Wiggen of Brooklyn and Westport. The purchaser will make the place his residence.

The price of lead yesterday was reduced 25 points by the principal sellers. The American Smelting and Refining Company lowered its. price to 4.25 cents at New York and the St. Joseph Lead Company reduced its price to 4.10 cents at St. Louis, and to 4.30 cents at New York.

Lucius R. Eastman, formerly president of Hills Brothers Company, manufacturers of Dromedary food products, has been elected chairman of the board of the company, and William F. Redfield, formerly vice president,

Drivers will slow down to twenty miles an hour when entering Verona (New Jersey, not Italy), or Mayor David H. Slayback, 77 years old but still active, will know the reason why. "This," explained Mr. Slayback to some of his Sunday captives who had been intercepted at speeds of between twenty and sixty miles an hour, "is a town, not a prairie."
The award of three major prizes in the School of Public and, International Affairs at Princeton University was announced today by Professor de Witt Clinton Poole, director of the school.

Metropolitan Baking Corporation sold to Frank Sklar the three-story flat and the two-story bakery building at 208-10 Webster Avenue, Jersey City, on a plot 50 by 100 feet. The new owner gave back a purchase money mortgage for $16,400.

Secretary Henry A. Wallace was charged today by Elton L. Marshall, Kansas City lawyer and former Solicitor of the Department of Agriculture, with attempting to place upon the preceding national Administration responsibility for the government defeat before the Supreme Court in the stock yards case.

Appointment of Malcolm B. Galbreath as director of the State School of Agriculture at Morrisville, effective July 1, was announced today by the Board of Regents. He will succeed I. M. Charlton, who will retire June 30.

Two Federal court hearings on allegations of suppression of civil rights and freedom of the press by Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City were postponed until later in the week yesterday by Judge William Clark in Newark.

The 118th annual commencement of the General Theological Seminary started last night with an evensong service in the Chapel of the Good Shepherd, 175 Ninth Avenue. The Right Rev. William Leopold Essex, Bishop of Quincy, Ill., delivered the baccalaureate sermon.

It was not altogether the city of a dream. Life there wasn't entirely made up of sitting at an outdoor cafe on the Graben or the Karntnerstrasse and watching the crowd drift by; or dancing to the music of a gypsy orchestra; or shopping in the Kohlmarkt.

A majority of more than 20 to 1 against the President's pump-priming program was recorded yesterday in a poll taken by a citizens committee in Scarsdale, Westchester County, to sound out the sentiment of voters on the question.

Trading opened only fair to slow on most classes of traefer meats. Steer beef sold steady to lower, fresh pork strong to higher, other classes mostly unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats was slow at steady to lower prices. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

Mexico's internal affairs and their effect on the United States' foreign policy, as well as the "delicate" political situation in Europe, were discussed at a lengthy conference between President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull this afternoon.

Dr. Marcus C. Hankinson was reelected president of the Brooklyn Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor at the organization's annual meeting last night in its quarters, 401 State Street, Brooklyn.

A fourteen-passenger Eastern Airlines plane ripped through an iron fence at the northern end of Central Airport here at 8:25 A. M., today when the pilot,. Mac Johnson, misjudged the field in attempting to land in a heavy ground haze.

Quasijudicial agencies of the government, which were under fire in the recent decision of the Supreme Court in the Kansas City Stockyards case, won a victory today when the court held that intermediate orders of the Federal Power Commission that were not of a conclusive or affirmative character were not reviewable by a Circuit Court of Appeals.

An official announcement yesterday made known that the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company one of the larger units in the Amerclan Telephone and Telegraph Company system, would proceed immediately with plans for the registratiohand sale of a new bond issue amounting to about $25,000.000.

A syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers and Glore, Forgan Co., have agreed to underwrite an offering of 77,873 preferred shares of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., subject to certain terms and conditions, as part of a newly authorized issue of 100.000 shares.

An order entered a year ago against La Salle Extension University of Chicago requiring it to cease and desist from representing directly or indirectly, through use of the words "extension university" or "university" in its corporate name,

By a vote of 13 to 6 the Senate tonight passed the resolution for a constitutional amendment to legalize pari-mutuel betting at race tracks. The question now goes to the voters, but it was uncertain whether the referendum would be held at the general election in November or at a special election later.

Bernard J. Feely, a director of the Brooklyn Federal Savings and Loan Association and former president of the old United Liquor-Dealers' Association of Kings County, died on Sunday at his home, 430 Fiftyeighth Street, Brooklyn, after a brief illness.

Frank A. Wells, building contractor and chairman of the Ocean Township Municipal Committee for the last twenty-one years, died today at his home in Oakhurst, near here, at the age of 60. He built many of the show places in this area.

Three residential properties, formerly owned by the Home Owners Loan Corporation in the Bronx, have been sold through the real estate brokerage firm of D. Houlihan Sons, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

The Reds and the Dodgers continued their headlong dashes in opposite directions in the National League pennant race yesterday as Cincinnati toppled the Brooklynites, 6 to 4; at Ebbets Field and vaulted into third place. The Dodgers, with nowhere else to go except down, landed practically on the shoulders of the hapless Phillies, half a game out of the cellar.

Cornelius F. Burns, former Mayor of Troy, died at his home here today at the age of 78. He had been confined to his home by illness for many months. A native of Troy, Mr. Burns served eight terms as Mayor of the city. First elected in 1911, he was thrice re-elected, holding office until 1919.

Apparently somewhat nonplussed over the inclusion of an amendment in the Relief-Recovery Bill limiting the use of funds for projects competing with private industry, Senate Administration leaders today marshaled their forces to modify this proposal as debate on the bill got under way in the Senate.' Other leaders predicted outright defeat of the amendment if it retains its present form.

A recital on the polychord, instrument invented by Evangelos Tsamourtzis, will be given tonight at Town Hall by They Kaisari-Aranghi. The second symphony of William Schuman will be a feature of the concert of the Greenwich Orchestra tonight at the Federal Music Theatre.

By dropping their fourth straight game, 10-4, to the Cubs at Ebbets Field yesterday, after giving Van Lingle Mungo a 2-0 lead in the first frame, the Dodgers fell to a new low in prestige for the season. There were only 5,142 paying fans present, but they were something less than polite after the now flameless fireball ace had pitched a homerun ball to little Augie Galan in the fourth with the bases filled.

Italy eliminated Poland in the second round of Davis Cup tennis play today as Vanni Canepele defeated Ignacy Tloczynski in the final and deciding singles, 6-2, 6-1, 2-6, 6-2. Italy's margin was three matches to two.

The Federal Screw Works nas called for June 13 a meeting of stockholders to vote on a plan of reorganization and recapitalization. Holders of each $1,000 of unsecured convertible 6 1/2 per cent notes, of which $1,737,000 was outstanding on Dec. 31, would receive $500 in new 5 per cent mortgage bonds and fifty shares of new preference stock.

Former Attorney General Robert H. McCarter, chief counsel for the Young Assembly Investigating Committee, started his argument today before the Court of Errors and Appeals in an appeal of a Chancery ruling that held the committee's work was unconstitutional.
President Roosevelt made known his opposition to a $212,000,000 appropriation item for paying farm parity benefits and conferred during the day with legislative and administrative aides.

ADLER-Paul, on Monday, May 23, 1938, in his forty-eighth year, beloved husband of Eleanor S., devoted father of Jack and Virginia; son of Ernest and the late Laura Adler. Services Temple Emanu-El, 65th St. at 5th Ave., Wednesday morning, May 25, at 10:30 o'clock. Interment private.

Dr. Francisco Castillo Najera, Chile Mexican Ambassador to the United States, flew into Brownsville this afternoon from San Luis Potosi, taking with him, he said, bases for negotiation of a settlement of the oil question with United States companies.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick awarded yesterday a new issue of $50,000,000 of New York City serial bonds and corporate stock to a banking group headed by the National City Bank at a net interest cost of 3.1309 per cent.

Pointing to the need for early payments in the condemnation proceedings of the Red Hook housing project to ease the burdens of many large families that are without funds to obtain new homes, Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood awarded in record time in Brooklyn yesterday a total of $532,967 for 133 parcels involving eighty-nine ownerships.

Supreme Court Justice John H. McCooey in Brooklyn denied yesterday an application by several Class B stockholders of United Shipyards, Inc., for a temporary injunction restraining the corporation from selling most of its plant and good-will to the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation for $9,320,000.

Captain Stanley Scott, master of the steamer Stancroft, was arrested tonight on a charge of having violated the British law forbidding British vessels to carry arms or war materials to either side in Spain.
The Italian liner Roma, which arrived yesterday, brought 200 American liquor and wine importers who toured Italy as the guests of the vine growers and wine makers.

The Court of Appeals reversed today a judgment and granted a new trial in an action by the State Street Trust Company, appellant, against Ernst Ernst, accountants, to recover losses alleged to have been caused by a certified balance sheet.
Copies of the catalogue have been received here for the auction sale of the art collection of the late Mortimer L. Schiff, which will take place at Christie, Manson Woods, London, on June 22 and 23.

The identity of the person who supplied the name Samuel W. Gilgon to conceal the name of Simon W. Gerson in a $150 back rent case in Municipal Court last March was hidden behind replies of "perhaps" or "I don't remember" when the Appellate Division completed yeslerday examination of the four principals.

The report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on April 30, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all operating expenses, taxes and charges, of $13,336,676.

The American group of the Societe des Architectes Diplomes par le Gouvernement Francais awarded last night its "Medal to Laymen" to Edward S. Harkness, philanthropist, for "distinguished service in the advancement of art and architecture."

The League of New York Theatres has informed Actors Equity that a majority of its members have -accepted the proposed code for regulation of ticket speculation. Equity expects. to receive formal notification of the acceptance in a few days and will then start the machinery to incorporate the code

The question of the retirement of the German military advisers from China's service is still being studied because officials are unwilling to release them from their contracts. The German Embassy issued yesterday a formal statement that the Berlin government "expressed a desire that the Chinese Government's advisers should be allowed to cancel their contracts and return to' Germany."

The Bill of Rights Committee of the Constitutional Convention, after debating for an hour behind closed doors the proposal of District Attorney Henry Hirschberg of Orange County for elimination from the law of the present prohibition against lotteries and gambling, decided to put off for two weeks a vote on whether to report or kill the proposal.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 21: CAPTAINS Knapp, J. H., staff, Commander Scouting Force, to Navy Yard, Portsmouth, N. H., in July. Rose, D. W., Newport, R. I., to staff, Commander Scouting Force, as Force Paymaster.

Edward J. Hughes, Secretary of State, announced today that brokers and investment dealers who renew their Illinois licenses on July 1 will be required for the first time to file financial statements prepared and certified by outside accountants instead of by their own staffs.

Methodists in the city and throughout the country celebrated yesterday the 200th anniversary of the conversion of John Wesley, which took place at 8:45 P. M. in London on May 24, 1738, at a small meeting held in a shop on Aldersgate Street.

The United States Steel Corporation has booked orders aggregating about $2,000,000 for tin plate, tin bars and coils from the Toyo Kohan Kaisha (Oriental Steel Plate Company) and the Toyo Seikan Kaisha (Oriental Can Manufacturiner Company), it was learned yesterday. The materials are to be delivered this year.

Considering the importance of the issues involved, the State Constitutional Convention has been attracting little attention since it held its first session seven weeks ago yesterday. Perhaps this is because the controversial proposals have immediately been hustled into committee, and of what the committees are up to there is little to report.

The joint liquor conference recently formed to seek means for halting sales at less than prices fixed under Feld-Crawford law contracts affects only the 1,800 package stores in New York State and has no bearing upon the operations of the 14,894 "on-premise" licensees, which dispense 70 per cent of the liquor sold in the State,

Forty-six representative business men have accepted invitations to confer here tomorrow with Senator Bulkley on his proposal to establish a National Council which would act as a permanent advisory agency for the government, it was learned today when additional acceptances were announced.

E. L. Wayman, president of the Ritter Dental Manufacturing Company, Inc., said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that business in the dental field had about reached a stabilization point and that he was a little more hopeful" for the remainder of the year, although "much would depend upon political moves."

Seven city commissioners and 300 members and guests of the New York City League of Women Voters heard a review of municipal affairs, yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, in which he disclosed that he had persuaded Park Commissioner Robert Moses to take over the plan for a municipal art center that he hopes to complete in his administration.

The Italian light cruiser Quarto anchored here today with Admiral Maranco di Moriondo aboard. While unconfirmed officially it is probable that ten members of General Francisco Franco's commission, invited to be guests at Premier Benito Mussolini's demonstration of solidity with Insurgent Spain on May 29, will travel to Italy on the cruiser.
The House acceded to the expressed wishes of President Roosevelt tonight and passed the Norton Wages and Hours Bill after the longest sitting of the present session.
The Court of Appeals, deciding today a case brought by the Board of Education of White Plains against the city's Common Council, in litigation over the 1938 budget, ruled in favor of the council.

Television will eliminate a major obstacle, but not the only one, to the broadcasting of satisfactory art programs, according to Dr. Bernard Myers of New York University's Department of Fine Arts, who spoke today before the American Federation of Arts, which is holding its annual session here.

Spokesmen for the merchant marine, banking, industry and the Port of New York urged further development of foreign trade as a two-way activity in addresses at a luncheon meeting yesterday of the City Club, 55 West Forty-fourth Street, held in connection with the city-wide observance of Foreign Trade Week.

Dr. George F. Warren, head of the Department of Agricultural Economics and Farm Management in the New York State College of Agriculture at Cornell and former monetary adviser to President Roosevelt, died today at the age of 64 in Memorial Hospital of multiple tumors of the liver with hemorrhages. He had been ill since December.

Listing of the following securities has been authorized by the New York Stock Exchange: 43,744 additional shares of Celotex Corporation common stock, 150,000 shares of General Foods Corporation $4.50 cumulative preferred stock, 572,142 shares of Grand Union Company common stock, 77,873 shares of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., 5 per cent convertible cumulative preferred stock, Series A, and 77,873 additional shares of Philip Morris common stock.

JUST before the War Admiral-Seabiscuit race went up in smoke this observer was making a serious study of the subject. A chat with Major Algernon Daingerfield of the Jockey Club brought from that genial and courtly gentleman of the old school the remark that the race was introducing something new to the turf in this country.

Customers should have adequate opportunity to protect under-margined accounts, even in cases where the broker is not required legally to extend it, Charles H. Meyer, a lawyer, said yesterday in an address to the Senior Margin Clerks' Section of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms at the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

President Roosevelt indicated today that he was opposed to a $212,000,000 appropriation item in the Recovery Bill to finance farm parity payments on wheat, corn and cotton and that any such benefit payments should be financed out of receipts from processing or excise taxes on the commodities, as was done under the original Agricultural Adjustment Act.

Canada's foreign policy consists in minding its own business so far as its obligations as a member of the League of Nations and the British Commonwealth will permit, declared Prime Minister Mackenzie King to an attentive House of Commons and crowded galleries today.

Employes cannot be loyal and d voted to a company if they do not understand the background, the aims and the uses of the company and its products, Dr. Victor L. Short, president of the Institute of Human Science, told the American Metal Trades Association at a luncheon meeting yesterday, preliminary to the association's annual meeting, which begins at the Hotel Biltmore today.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,175,750 barrels, compared with 3,362,200 in the previous week, a decline of 186,550, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 142,350 barrels fewer than the calculation of 3,318,100 daily by the Bureau of Mines for May.

Rudolf Rabea, secretary of the German Embassy, today visited the chief of police at Nictheroy, across the bay from Rio de Janeiro, seeking information about three Germans detained on suspicion that they were involved in the May 11 revolt.

Representative Jerry J. O'Connell of Montana, whose scheduled openair meeting here recently was called off on the ground that extensive violence might 'result, will come to Jersey City Friday night to address an open-air meeting, it was announced. today by the Hudson County Committee for Labor Defense and Civil Rights.

Criticisms of government policies as hindrances to business recovery and a warning of a possible deflation in agricultural values were voiced today at the concluding session of the Illinois Bankers Association by congressional, business and farm leaders.

The administrative reconstruction of Austria was announced today, profoundly modifying the provincial system which originated before the Habsburg dynasty. At the same time the Austrian local government was considerably reduced in anticipation of total absorption into the Reich.

The Adjutant General released the following orders today: These officers, having qualified, are placed on duty: Thompson, Lt. Col. Andrew H., Quartermaster Corps, is to report to the State Quartermaster for assignment to State staff.

Judge Ernest A. Inglis in Superior Court here/today set June 21 as the last day for Lieutenant Governor Frank Hayes, the five-term Mayor of this city and twenty-six others to file preliminary defense motions. They are accused by Special Prosecutor Hugh M. Alcorn of conspiracy to loot the City Treasury of over $1,000,000.

In his office at Police Headquarters yesterday afternoon Commissioner Valentine accepted a bronze plaque which will be awarded annually to the precinct that has contributed most toward the reduction of unnecessary noise.

The Court of Errors and Appeals branded as taboo today the shouting of the word "scab" from a sound truck as a form of picketing, but did not rule that sound trucks should be banned altogether from labor disputes. This opinion was contained in a decision arising from the strike of the American Newspaper Guild at The Bayonne Times in Bayonne. The strike has since been settled.

The Rev. Aaron Carroll Stuart, pastor of the Presbyterian Church here, died Sunday in the hospital at Cornwall. He was born sixtyeight years ago in Goff Mills and educated at Hamilton College and Auburn Theological Seminary. His first pastorate was in Owasco, N. Y.

Miss Jean T. Boulware, 16-yearold student of the University of California, has won first. prize in the annual student essay contest of the Students International Travel Association, it was announced yesterday at the organization's American headquarters, 11 West Fortysecond Street, by its director, John C. Dengler Jr.

At a meeting of the directors of Remington Rand, Inc., an interim dividend of 20 cents a share was authorized, payable on July 1 to stockholders of record of June 10. On March 25, the company distributed 25 cents a share. The company also announced that reductions in the payment of salaried employes will be made on June 1 ranging from 5 to 25 per cent. No cut will be made in hourly rates.

A large benefit dinner, dance and entertainment served last night to formally open the outdoor Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for the Summer season. The McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Children was the beneficiary of the opening celebration, which taxed the capacity of the al fresco garden and the adjoining Oval Room.

An incipient wave of terror In Barcelona, Spain, that might have had serious repercussions has been nipped in the bud by the firm action of the government and the demand of jurists headed by the Supreme Justice of the Catalan courts, Jose Andrea, that the authority of the law shall be applied to bring the guilty to justice.

A trail of bright red paint, which was plastered on historic Plymouth Rock on May 8, led police to a near-by town where a construction job was in progress, and tonight ended in Pittsburgh, with the arrest of a construction crew foreman.

Pensioned On their own applications. To take effect 12 midnight, May 23: PATROLMEN--John E. Cunningham. 18th Division, M.O.D.D., at $1,500 per annum. Appointed May 4, 1908. To take effect 12 midnight, May 31: Henry Halblaub, Traffic Precinct A, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Oct. 2, 1905.
The Treasury Procurement Division announced today awards of contracts for a total of 68,000 yards of textiles, for delivery by June 30.

The death sentences of Michael J. Mooney and James Murphy were commuted to life imprisonment today by Governor Lehman. They were under sentence to die Thursday for the fatal shooting of Ralph Ferro, a Brooklyn druggist, in a holdup at 107 Court Street, Brooklyn, on July 5, 1937.

On the basis of a report filed by Charles S. Moore, examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission, it appeared probable today that the Boston Stock Exchange would be permitted to expand its unlisted trading department to include several important issues now traded in the New York markets, including the New York Stock Exchange.
The University of Minnesota's well-balanced team of four won the 72-hole Big Ten golf championship today. Sid Richardson of Northwestern shot 305 to retain his individual title.
The Glen Ridge Conference Committee, a nonpartisan organization, dedicated to the cause of filling the municipal offices with well-qualified candidates, marked its twenty-fifth anniversary today.

Reduction in retail prices in *xact proportion to increasing productivity in industry is the best way to obtain a more satisfactory distribution of wealth, Harold G. Moulton, president of the Brookings Institution, told a meeting of the Phi Beta Kappa Alumni in

The consistent 8-year-old gelding Pastry, who seems to improve with age, gained one of his most decisive victories in the featured Troubador Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday when he was first by five lengths at the end of a mile and a sixteenth that was packed with excitement.

Trading was generally only fair to slow. The lamb and fresh pork markets were uneven, other classes were steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated all markets to be weak and lower. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

A large apartment consisting of ten rooms and four baths has been leased at 40 East Eighty-third Street by Carl H. Pforzheimer Jr. of Purchase, N. Y., Pease Elliman, Inc., broker who negotiated the lease, reported yesterday. Details of other leases follow:

Louis Rudisch, a chemist-inventor at 65 Fulton Street, was discharged yesterday in the Felony Court after his lawyer, Harold O. P. Frankel, former assistant district attorney, had told Magistrate Andrews the grand jury had exonerated him in the recent theft of $22,000 worth of plantinum and iridium from the Amtorg Trading Corporation, the Soviet Government agency in this country.

Dr. Samuel Sumner Edmands, director of the School-of Science and Technology at Pratt Institute, died in Knickerbocker Hospital at 4 A. M. yesterday as the result of injuries received in an automobile accident on the Henry Hudson Parkway last Thursday.

Sumner Welles, under-secretary of State, told the Presbyterian Social Union of Maryland tonight that Americans harmed the cause of world peace by condemning the purely internal policies of-foreign nations.

The government's German spy investigation, which already has indicated possible diplomatic involvements, was further complicated yesterday when Dr. Hans Borchers, Consul General of Germany, disclosed that Dr. IgnatzT. Griebl received permission to practice medicine in Germany on April 15, or about a month and a half after he was involved in the case.

Methods of accounting, which credited the Interstate Hosiery Mills, Inc., with almost $2,000,000 in fictitious profits in the period from 1934 to 1937, for no apparent reason were described yesterday in Attorney General Bennett's inquiry into the affairs of the company.

To the C. S. Robinson Aerial Surveys of Rochester, and Aerial Explorations, Inc., of Long Island City, have been awarded contracts by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration to conduct aerial surveys of 16,975 square miles 'in New York State.

William Dunning, one-time noted newspaper man who wrote campaign speeches for several Presidential candidates, died here this morning at the age of 85 after a long illness. He had been a Summer resident here for thirty-seven years and a permanent resident for more than ten years.

President J. D. Arosemena announced through the Diario Nacional today that not one cent of interest on Panama's 51/2 per cent bonds of 1923 would be paid until the United States pays arrears of the canal annuities.

Miss Louise Watts gave a luncheon yesterday in the Terrace Restaurant at Sherry's for Mrs. Morgan Grace Jr., Miss Maud Watts and the Misses Cynthia and Alicia Grace, who Arrived recently-from Jamaica, B. W. I., to visit Mrs. 1 IMorgan Grace Sr. in Great Neck, L. I.

Bently Warren, president of the Boston Providence Railroad, whose lease the New York, New Haven Hartford System proposes to disaffirm, proposed in the Federal'court this afternoon that resection of the lease be deferred two years or until a reorganization of the system had been effected.

Tazio Nuvolari, Italian auto driver who won the Vanderbilt Cup at the Roosevelt Raceway in 1936, is due to arrive today on the Conte di Savoia of the Italian Line.' He plans to go to Indianapolis for the 500-mile race there Memorial Day.

A letter in which Rumania's disbanded Fascist Iron Guard allegedly sought material and moral aid from German Nazis was attributed today to Corneliu Codreanu, Iron Guard leader on trial before a military tribunal on charges of espionage and high treason.

The Adolph S. Ochs Memorial Post, American Legion, will conduct a memorial service for Adolph S. Ochs, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, 1896-1935, on Sunday morning in Mount Hope Cemetery, Westchester County.

Under the heaviest foreign selling in several months, prices on the Cotton Exchange broke 12 to 16 points yesterday, to end with the lowest quotations of the year. Soon after the opening on Jan. 3 last the July delivery changed hands at 8.37 cents a pound, and, after touching 9.40 cents in February, did not reach 8.37 cents again until yesterday.

It may be an exciting prophesy or it may be just a case of playing hookey from "the school," but Frank Tuma of Montauk took a seven-pound bluefish from the surf at Ditch Plains Monday night. For the past two weeks Frank has been taking five or six striped bass a night out of the surf, but the bluefish was a pleasant surprise.

The Rev. Dr. Henry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, was honored on his sixtieth birthday at a dinner last night in the church's assembly hall attended by nearly 500 members of the congregation.

The American Car and Foundry Motors Company has received orders for omnibuses driven by HallScott horizontal engines as follows: Five from the Virginia Electric and Power Company, Richmond, Va.; three from the Vermont Transit Company, Burlington, Vt., and one from the New York State Railways.

The Philippine Government signed a contract yesterday for 20,000 square feet of ground in the Court Of States area of the New York World's Fair and made known its plans to spend $600,000 on its exhibits.

Net operating income of the five railroads to report for April showed a decline of 83.4 per cent from the total in April, 1937. The roads are the Kansas City Southern, Southern Pacific, Texas Pacific, Bangor Aroostook and New York, Chicago St. Louis.

City officials and leading citizens of New York joined with the Broadway Association and the Outdoor Cleanliness.Association last night at a dinner-dance at the Hotel Astor in celebrating "Broadway's 325th' birthday" and starting a "campaign to beautify and promote all Broadway" for the World's Fair.

Onkel Franz Frisch, the Jolly squire of New Rochelle, brought his sadly deflated Gas House Gang around to the Polo Grounds yesterday and the spectacle was one to make even the heavens burst into occasional tears.

The National Assembly today approved a bill, proposed by Commonwealth President Manuel Quezon, which would abolish the $500 monthly pension granted eighteen years ago to General Emilio Aguinaldo, insurrection leader who has become a strong critic of the Presldent.
BENEATH THAT ARMOR, by Elizabeth Frayne. (Arcadia, $2.) A romantic novel. HAPPY-GO-LUCKY, by Mrs. Harry Pugh Smith. (Arcadia, $2.) A novel by the author of "Peter Pan's Daughter."

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 24, unless specified: Bagley, Guantanamo, to Navy Yard, Norfolk, Va. Fairfax, at Norfolk, May 20. Marblehead, at Chinwangtao. Omaha, Menton to Villefranche. via Marseilles.

Thirty-five students received certificates and diplomas last night at the commencement exercises of the National Bible Institute and the Union Missionary Trading Institute, 340 West Fifty-fifth Street.

John R. Davies, president of the National Republican Club, and George E. Sokolsky, recently elected a member of its executive committee, left the way open yesterday for Arthur A. Ballantine, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, to continue as a member of the executive committee.

After recovering from their losses of the previous day, the foreign exchanges yesterday afternoon dropped in a fresh spasm of alarm over the Central European crisis. The pound sterling went to its lowest pride since Sept. 29, at $4.941/2 and closed there, off 3/8 cent.

In anticipation of heavy automobile traffic over the Memorial Day week-end, Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, yesterday urged motorists to observe the utmost caution on the highways. His statement was part of a letter of commendation to William F. Humphrey, president of the Tidewater Associated Oil Company, for the automobile safety campaign it is directing in the Eastern States.

A United Air Lines passenger plane, bound from New York to Chicago with ten persons aboard, crashed in flames on a swampy and wooded terrain about eight miles south of Cleveland tonight. All ten were killed, apparently instantly.

The American I. G. Chemical Corporation showed for the fiscal year ended on March 31 net earnings of $4,186,110, including a profit of $502,291 from sales of securities and after deductions for taxes, $1,311,896 debenture interest and other charges, according to the annual report made public yesterday by D. A. Schmitz, president.

Leases in the vicinity of Times Square with a variety of commercial enterprises were reported yesterday. In an expansion move necessitated by the extension of the organization's interests, the National Exhibition Company, owner of the New York National League baseball team, has leased the entire floor in 100 West Forty -second Street, on the southwest corner of Sixth Avenue.

MANHATTAN FLIEGE, LOTTA (Sept. 17, 1936). Gross assets, $39,098; net, $38,558. To Beatrice Fliege, niece. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $31,525. George H. Fox, attorney, 27 Cedar St. FLIEGE, SOPHIA (Sept. 27, 1936). Gross assets, $71,442; net, $68,870. To Beatrice Fliege, niece. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $57,461. George H. Fox. attorney. 27 Cedar St.

Elmer Peter Kohler, Seldon Emory Professor of Organic Chemistry at Harvard, died today at Phillips House. He was 72 years old. Recognized authority on and teacher of organic chemistry, one of his first research students at Harvard was James Bryant Conant, now president of the university.

A program of expansion and modernization planned for this year by the United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation will get under way Friday with the opening of a new Whelan drug store on the southwest corner of Fifty-second Street and Sixth Avenue, Allen L. Woodworth, president of the firm, announced yesterday.
Peace prevailed today at The Duluth Herald News-Tribune plant, where police yesterday used tear gas to disperse a picket line and permit the resumption of publication after seven weeks' suspension.

Gift of a fund of $5,000 to establish a prize for poets in honor of Harriet Monroe was announced at the University of Chicago tonight preceding the dedication of the Harriet Monroe Library of Modern Poetry at the University.

An enforced vacation of "six or seven weeks" was in prospect today for Catcher Al Lopez of the Bees, whose right thumb was fractured yesterday by afoul tip off the bat of Second Baseman Bill Herman of the Chicago Cubs.

The crowd of notables attending today's opening at the Jeu de Paume Museum in the Tuileries Gardens of the exhibition of "three centuries of American art" was so large that a few minutes after the gates opened it was difficult to get a view of the exhibits and it soon became impossible to circulate.

Clouds Hill, Cottage in Dorset, where Colonel T. E. Lawrence ["Lawrence of Arabia"] was living when he suffered the motor-cycle accident in 1935 that resulted in his death, has been presented to the nation by his brother, A. W. Lawrence, it was announced today.

Miss Dorothy Bundy of Santa Monica, Calif., a member of the United States Wightman Cup tennis team, on reached the third round of the Middlesex championships today when she defeated Miss B. M. Smith of England, 8-6, 6-3.

Mrs. Anna de Camp Camacho, member of a Morris County family that operated iron mines in the eighteenth century, died suddenly today at her home here in her eighty-first year. She was the widow of Leopold A. Camacho, a New York mechanical engineer, who died last year.

A warning that "all sorts of social schemes" represented by a "juggling" of the letters of the alphabet cannot alone safeguard the country's future was voiced today by the Rev. Dr. Jesse M. Bader of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

A banking group composed of W. E. Hutton Co., Kidder, Peabody Co., Johnson, Lane Space Co., Inc.; Scott Stringfellow, Schoellkopf, Hutton Pomeroy, Inc., and Blyth Co., Inc., will offer today $3,500,000 of 4 1/2 per cent debentures of the National Gypsum Company of Buffalo.
Plans for the tenth annual competition of the American Institute of Steel Construction to select "the most beautiful bridges of steel" in this country last year were announced yesterday.

Marion Butler, who was one of the youngest men ever to sit in the United States Senate. was reported near death today at Washington Sanitarium in Takoma Park, Md. Mr. Butler, now 75 years old, represented North Carolina as a Populist Senator from 1895 to 1901.
Colonel Josef Beck, Polish Foreign Minister, and Mme. Beck arrived today on an official visit to return that of Foreign Minister Rickard Johannes Sandler to Warsaw last Summer.
Three dwellings in various sections of Staten Island were reported yesterday as having been sold by Cornelius G. Kolff, Inc., broker.

Nearly five hundred persons attended the funeral service yesterday morning in St..Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street, for Edmund C. Lynch, a partner in the investment banking firm here of Merrill, Lynch Co., who died on May 12 in London at the age of 52 years.

Members of the New York Young Republican Club declared last night in favor of making the fight in the State election next Fall on State instead of national issues in adopting a platform for Submission to the convention of the New York State Association of Young Republican Clubs at Niagara Falls on Friday and Saturday of this week.
Nat Litfin, 123 3/4, the Brqnx, outpointed Johnny Compo, 124, New Haven, in the main bout of eight rounds at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 5,500 saw Litfin triumph.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE SEVENTH CAVALRY BRIGADE; En Route to Fort Knox, Ky., May 24.The nation's only mechanized cavalry moved out of a muddy bivouac near Nashville this afternoon and started north for a 150-mile allnight march across two States to its home station.

Loomis J. Grossman, operator who recently purchased the Chatsworth Apartments, six-story structure at the corner of South Third Avenue, Mount Vernon, Westchester County, has resold it to an investing client of Armstrong Armstrong, Inc., broker.

Marking the first offering of any quantity at a fur sale, American Persians and caracul furs were put under the hammer yesterday by Lampson, Fraser Huth, Inc. The skins sold well, touching a top of $6.75.
Eastman Dillon Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that William Morris Tilden had been appointed manager of the Municipal Bond Department of their Philadelphia office.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey of New York County was revealed today as having rejected a request from up-State sources that he be a candidate for the Republican nomination I for Governor this Fall.

A new drive during the coming year for repeal of the "unjust and discriminatory" Federal excise tax of 10 per cent on cosmetics was recommended yesterday by H. L. Brooks, president of the Toilet Goods Association, which began its annual convention at the Hotel Biltmore.

The contract for completion of the Soldier Field stadium was awarded today to the Lundoff Bicknell Company of Chicago by the Park District Commissioners. The contract calls for erection of a new administration building and a new bank of seats at the north end of the stadium at a cost of $1,477,792.

The theory that the sun's lack of activity caused the 1928-32 depression and the present recession was advanced today by Professor Harlan True Stetson, speaking to 1,500 delegates to the three-day convention of the Massachusetts Federation of Women's Clubs here.

Estimatess made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board disclosed that there was another slight decrease in unemployment between March and April, bringing the number of unemployed in the latter month to 10,166,000. Included in this total were 2,995,000 workers in the WPA and CCC.

IT'S all perfectly simple. Don't let any one tell you-one of those dangerous agitators, for example-that the old social system has broken up and can never be made whole again. Certainly it can; or at least so says a pleasant and magnificently cheerful novel called "Kindling,"* by one Nevil Shute.

Election of officers in eight Columbia University alumni groups was announced yesterday by Clarence E. Loveioy, alumni secretary of the university. The Society of Forty-niners, composed of graduates who attended Colmbia before 1897, when it was situated at Madison Avenue. and Forty-ninth Street, elected Ernest A. Cardozo of New York president.

The husband of the late Marilyn Miller, musical comedy star, received today a spouse's rights to a portion of the actress's $64,000 trust fund in a ruling by the Court of Appeals. The tribunal held unanimously that the trust fund reverted to the actress's estate and said that the husband, Chester Leo O'Brien, to whom she was married in 1934, was entitled- to- a share.

A strike of crews employed on the barges of the eight member lines of the Petroleum Carriers. Association. was settled early yesterday morning after a conference of several hours between officials of the companies and the United Marine Division of the International. Longshoremen's Association, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor.

It is good news for everybody that Justice Cardozo is recovering from his long illness. Already he is allowed to read a little in those old philosophers, historians and poets that have been the recreation of a mind profoundly versed in the law. His books and many of his opinions are literature, and of the best. The perfection of his style might stir the envy of professional writers.

Dr. Pierre le Comte du Nouy, director of Advanced'Studies at the Sorbonne and a noted biophysicist, arrived yesterday from France on the French liner Paris to study the organization of scientific research here, especially in regard to its connection with industry.

The Federal Housing Administration's program of mortgage insurance should go a long way in leveling out future periods of depression in the realty financing field, Professor Ernest M. Fisher, representing the FHA, declared yesterday in a discussion of the efforts being made by that agency to encourage new residential construction on a sound basis.

The Yankees left here tonight with nothing but sad memories of their first visit with Ossie Vitt's Indians. They sustained their second defeat in as many games and are resting uncomfortably in third place, a game behind the Red Sox. They look hopefully, however, to the series which starts in Detroit tomorrow.

Governors Island 2d Lt. Lynn J. Searles, Inf.-Res., 501 Allen St., Syracuse, N. Y., 1st Division, is ordered to active duty for six months, effective May 24, at Headquarters Schenectady District, CCC, Schenectady, N. Y.,. for assignment and duty in connection with CCC activities.- Date of rank, May 10, 1938. Lt. Col. Louis E. DeForest. Qm.-Res., 235 E. 22d St., New York,

Manhattan 55th St, 411 W. 25x100: to 1-story garage: Karies Holding Corp, 332 E 149th St, Bronx, owner; L. M. Rothman, architect; cost, $5,000. Alterations 12th St, 16 W; to 4-story residence: Fred V. Field. premises, owner; W. Lescaze, architect; cost. $4,000. 79th St, 121 E; to 5-story residence: George Whitney, 23 Wall St, owner; Cross Cross, architects; cost, $4,000.

The Suffolk County grand jury heard evidence today against six directors of Camp Siegfried, the Nazi camp at Yaphank, and the German American Settlement League, Inc., which operates the camp, all of whom were arrested on the technical charge of having failed to register with the Secretary of State at Albany -the names of oath-bound members.
More than 600 exhibits were displayed by the members of the Cedarhurst Garden Study Group at their annual flower show held today at the Lawrence Village Park clubhouse.

When Nelson Eddy completes "Sweethearts" with, Jeanette -MacDonald, he will be teamed with Ilona Massey in "Love Carnival," Metro announced today. The film will be an adaptation of Ferenc Molnar's "A Testor." Melville Baker and Hans Kraly are preparing the treatment and Robert Z. Leonard will produce.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 23: BRIGADIER GENERAL Major, D. K. Jr., Hawaiian Dep't, to command 1st Brigade, Ft. Wadsworth, N. Y. COLONELS Moss, J. A., F.A., four months and four days' leave, May 26. Latrobe, O., Cav., on month and eight davs' leave July 23.

An innings and 51-run victory by Middlesex over Nottinghamshire today broke a three-team tie for second in English county cricket. Lancashire had retained top place yesterday by defeating Northamptonshire. Hitherto tied with Middlesex, Surrey drew a first-class match with the touring Australians.
The stock market here toddy developed a firmer tendency on the easing of international tension, but, except in the South African mining group, there was little expansion of business.

Escaping death when his plane nose-dived about 1,000 feet and cracked up on a truck farm at Plainville, Frederick Steg`aier Jr., 22 years old, was taken to the General Hospital where he was reported suffering from head and leg injuries and shock.
With no market for the spinach crop in Racine County because of a twentythree-day strike at the Frank Pure Food Company's plant at Franksville, discouraged farmers today began plowing under the crop.

Milton F. Petrie has retired from H. G. Einstein Co. and Arthur W. Sesselberg, Exchange member, has been admitted to W. B. Hibbs Co., according to the bulletin of the New York Stock Exchange. Directors meetings of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, the New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad

The number of new measles cases in this city declined for the week ended last Saturday, indicating a definite downward trend in the prevalence of this disease, it was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.

A number of the properties involved in the Manhattan Realty deals announced yesterday will be altered or improved by the new owners. The three four-story tenements at 318-22 Bleecker Street, adjoining the corner of Grove Street, on a plot 62.6 by 27.5, have been sold by the Centennial Realty Corporation to D. M. Gallo.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today called a hearing for June 9 on an application for a report on a recapitalization plan of the Birmingham Gas Company, Birmingham, Ala., and a declaration with respect to solicitations under the plan.

A summary showing most commodities at or near good "buying zones" furnished the background against which purchasing executives from all sections of the country today reported that a major revival in business can be touched off at any time by a spark of encouragement.

A gift of $25,000 from the General Motors Corporation headed the list of contributions to the Greater New York Fund announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, president of the organization, which is seeking $10,000,000 to, supplement the finances of private health and welfare agencies. The Bank of Manhattan contributed $12.000.

The passage of the House Wage and Hour Bill last night creates a curious parliamentary situation. A wage-hour bill was passed by the Senate on July 31 last year. The House Labor Committee struck out everything after the enacting clause and wrote an entirely new bill of its own.

Marking something of an Innovation in advertising agency copy, Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., is taking space in one newspaper this morning to announce that there are many bright spots in the business picture and to emphasize those of its clients whose business is running ahead of last year.
Brigadier General Duncan A. Major Jr. commander of the Twenty-first Brigade at Schofield Barracks, Hawaii, was assigned today to the command of the First Brigade, with headquarters at Fort Wadsworth.

The Earl of Perth, British Ambassador to Italy, saw Count Galeazzo Ciano, Foreign Minister, for a half hour this evening and informed him of the latest developments in the Central European situation, as seen from London.

Richard Irvin, head of Richard Irvin Co., bankers and commission merchants, 198 Broadway, died Monday at his home, 46 East Ninety-first Street, of arteriosclerosis at the age of 69. He had been ill for five months.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary sails today for Southampton via Plymouth and Cherbourg. Among the passengers are: Sir Reginald and Lady DormanSmith, Lady L. M. Beattie and Miss R. D. C. Beattie, Colonel W. W. T.

Harvard's 150-pound varsity crew, winner of the Goldthwaite Cup in last Saturday's triangular regatta with the Yale and Princeton lightweights on the Charles River, will compete in the Royal Henley in England in July. William J. Bingham, athletic director, said he would cable the crew's entry tomorrow.

Harrison F. Wilmot, president of the firm of Wilmot Cassidy, Inc., manufacturing chemists, in Brooklyn, died on Monday at his home, 308 Adelphi Street, in his fifty-first year. He was born in New Brunswick, Canada, and was graduated from the Bradford Textite School in Boston.
Lawyers and doctors taking notes crowded the divorce court to hear the first batch of insanity cases under the recent Herbert act. [This act makes insanity one of the grounds for divorce.]

The "Catholic Bus Bill," which was an issue in the 1936 Gubernatorial campaign because originally vetoed by Governor Lehman, was declared unconstitutional today by the Court of Appeals, voting four to three.

A golf match featuring Bobby Jones of Atlanta and Attorney General Cummings, one of officialdom's most expert golfers, was a washout today. Cummings blew two holes. Some of Bobby's putts were all wet.
A. A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, will be a speaker at the annual meeting tomorrow of the National Industrial Conference Board in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
R. C. Cline, senior custodian officer at Alcatraz Prison, died today at Marine Hospital here from wounds inflicted by three convicts who attempted a break yesterday.

Monty Stratton, the ace White Sox righthander, who previously had pitched only one inning since hurting his throwing arm in training March 27, returned to regular duty today and his mates celebrated the occasion with a sixteen-hit bombardment that routed Washington, 10 to 3.

MANHATTAN ABRAMOWITZ, ZISE (Feb. 2). Estate, not more than $5,000. To Alvin Abramowitz, grandson, 856 West End Ave., $1,000; Ritta Abramowitz, 2,095 Creston Ave.; Samuel Abramowitz, 2,086 Creston Ave.; Goldie Abramowitz, 856 West End Ave.; Benjamin Abramowitz, executor. 15 W. 81st St., and Jennie Abramowitz, executrix, same address, children, residue equally. CUMMINGS, GEORGE E. (April 20). Estate, more than $10,000. To Marian W. Cummings, widow, executrix, Bay Head, N. J.
There was a further decline in industrial production in April, reflecting chiefly reduced activity in the cotton textile and lumber industries, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Postponement until Oct. 9 of the International Fishermen's races off Boston was announced today by the -American Race Committee.

An attempt by Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, to get the proposed 2 per cent tax on bookmakers' gross receipts before the Council yesterday failed when Democratic members objected to its immediate consideration because it was not in bill form.

A 57-year-old White House mail clerk, William Buchly, was held by police tonight, accused of tampering with White House mail. District Attorney David Pine'said the man would be charged with petty larceny at an arraignment in police court tomorrow.

Treasury officials, who have studied the Supreme Court decision that salaries of Port of New York Authority officials were subject to the Federal income tax, tentatively concluded that today such levies would be retroactive where they had been levied but remained unpaid.

Paul B. Rogers, airplane designer and engineer, died here yesterday at the age of 41 years. He started his career here as designer for the Glenn L. Martin Company. After several years he became chief engineer of the Great Lakes Aircraft Company and then vice president in charge of engineering.

Forty-four Harlan County coal operators and peace officers on trial before Federal Judge H. Church Ford on a charge of conspiring against union labor leaned forward in their seats this afternoon when the government called as its second witness E. J. Asbury, superintendent of the Black Mountain Coal Company.
A funeral service for William Childs, one of the founders of the Childs Restaurant chain, was held this morning at his residence, House in the Woods, on the old Army Road here.

The Hoboken Bank for Savings sold to the Bodee Realty Corporation the four-story store building at 130 Washington Street and the fivestory brick store building in the rear, known as 133 Bloomfield Street, Hoboken. The bank took back a purchase money mortgage for $52,150.

A sudden "disquieting" increase of [Pound]22,000,000 in Great Britain's adverse balance of trade with the United States during the first four months of this year will have to be taken into account in negotiating an Anglo-American trade treaty, Oliver Stanley, president of the Board of Trade, told the House of Commons tonight.

Eighteen double-headers were listed by National League President Ford Frick yesterday to absorb postponements and tie games, The Associated Press reported. The list, including all postponements up to and including MaY 22:
After a two-hour charge by Justice A. Larkin, a Supreme Court jury received tonight the case of former Mayor George J. Zimmermann, who was accused on, eight felony counts.

Canadian business moved in a leisurely fashion in the first four months of the year, according to the Bank of Montreal. "In a general way," the bank says, "it is estimated on the basis of the government's official figures. that the current business level is not more than 8 per cent below the level which prevailed in the same period in 1937.

Miss Mary Eileen Ahern of the Windermere Hotel here, former Indiana State librarian, died on a train Sunday near Atlanta, Ga., on her way home. Miss Ahern, who was about 75 years old, was editor of the magazine Libraries for thirty-six years before her retirement in 1931.

Development of new strategy by the opponents of the "private competition" amendment and drives to earmark nearly two-thirds of the $1,450,000,000 PWA loan and grant fund were the highlights in the Senate's second day of consideration of the Relief-Recovery Bill today.
Two hundred tons of gold and silver from the Bank of Spain valued at approximately $32,000,000 arrived here today and will be shipped to the United States tomorrow aboard the Normandie.

Under the direction of Secretary Ickes the Public Works Administration has allotted $144,569,298 to the construction of 277 electric power projects in various parts of the country. This is a small figure compared with the aggregate value of the nation's privately owned utilities.

In a direct challenge to recent action by the "conservative" wing of the Protestant Episcopal Church, a conference of the Liberal Evangelicals adopted by unanimous vote yesterday a resolution calling for "liberalization" of the attitude of the clergy of the Protestant Episcopal Church toward the administration of Holy Communion.

David E. Lilienthal, a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority, said today that ultimate purchase by the TVA of utility properties in the South may end some of the litigation challenging the constitutionality of the government agency.
Fifty-five students at Hunter College have been elected to Phi Beta Kappa, national honorary fraternity, it was announced by Professor Marjorie Anderson, president of Nu Chapter at Hunter.
The body of Solomon Rubin, 29 years old, of 615 Rugby Road, Brooklyn, was found hanging from a rafter beneath the Boardwalk, near West Eighth Street,

Rollie Stiles, veteran right-hander, turned in a magnificent mound performance today to give Jersey City a 2-to-0 victory over Newark in the second game of the series. The Jerseys also annexed the series opener yesterday.

Miss Margot Garrett, daughter of George Angus Garrett, is in New York to complete, with the selection of her wedding gown, the arrangements for her marriage on June 29 to Luis Mariano Zuberbuhler, Second Secretary of the Argentine Embassy here.

Reorganization Petitions 241 WEST 34TH STREET CORP., operating Pennsylvania Building, 225-41 W. 34th St.-Voluntary proceedings under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law in which a reorganization plan is proposed providing for the formation of a new corporation and the issuance of stocks and bonds in the new company in exchange for old securities. The petition lists as the main liability outstanding mortgage bonds aggregating $3,220,000. The realty is assessed at $3,900,000.

For the moment, at least, private dwellings seem to be furnishing one of the brightest spots in Manhattan realty activity. Several East Side houses have just passed into new hands, and other deals involving this type of property are reported pending in that neighborhood, which boasts of some of the most palatial residences in the world.

The question of steel prices at this time is regarded as purely academic by the automobile industry. Automobile makers have continued to taper off production and in six to ten weeks may begin to shut down some of the plants preparatory to retooling for 1939 models. Last year the shut-downs began in August and lasted but two weeks.

While efforts to increase cable rates were generally defeated at the International Cable and Radio Conference held in Cairo last February and March, numerous problems continue to face American communications companies and users, Francis T. Cole, who attended the conference as a delegate, yesterday told the luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club of New York at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Sir George and Lady Schuster of London and Middle Barton, Oxon, England, who have been traveling In the West, are at the WaldorfAstoria. They wif! leave today for Canada and will return here June 1 for a brief stay before sailing for England.

Robert Nathan's "The Barly Fields," a collection of five novels, will be brought out by Knopf June 20. The book will contain an introduction by Stephen Vincent Benet and a new preface by Robert Nathan.

Mr. and Mrs. William Charles Harmon Jr. of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Harmon, to George F. Hetfield, son of Judge Walter L. Hetfield Jr. and Mrs. Hetfield, also of this city.

Two mortgages held from the J. S. Modernization Corp., Saul Olshansky, vice president, have been consolidated by the East River Savings Bank to make one first lien for $47,000 on 215 W 80th St, and extended to May 1, 1942, at 3 1/2 to 4 1/2 per cent, to be amortized $235 quarterly.

Konrad Henlein, Sudeten German leader, departed from Prague yesterday, leaving his negotiations with Czech Premier Hodza hanging fire. At his Monday night talk, it was understood, he was not conciliatory and yesterday Prague's optimism decreased, particularly when new.. German troop movements were reported.

Declaring that salesmen will be the most important factor on the road to recovery, Arthur W. Ramsdell, director of sales of the Borden Company and recently elected president of the Sales Executives Club of New York, yesterday urged its members to take leadership in the drive for business recovery.

The Athletics bunched ten of their eleven hits in four innings today to gain a 6-1 victory over the Browns and a sweep of their rain-shortened series. Lynn Nelson, hurling steady ball, allowed the Browns only five safeties. Beau Bell's double in the second and Mel Mazzera's single paved the way for the Browns' only score.

The dollar volume of retail financing of new passenger automobiles showed a decrease of about 55 per cent for April, compared with the same month last year, but an increase of 8 per cent from March, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce reported today.

William Fahnestock Jr., a member of the New York Stock Exchange, was divorced today by Virginia Fahnestock of Montecito, Calif. She charged extreme cruelty. They were married at White Plains, N. Y., July 5, 1932, and separated last June 29.

A bill introduced in the Senate by Senator Harry Byrd which would release companies not situated in the District of Columbia from paying license fees for salesmen there has attracted considerable attention from national companies.

The Women's Metropolitan- Golf Association tournament for the Joseph J. Windle Challenge Cup, held over the Cherry Valley course today, was won by Miss Carol Cassidy of Crestmont. Despite threatening weather, a field of 153 started in this match play against par, with Miss Cassidy being the lone competitor to finish 1 up. The winner shot an 85 and had the aid of a seven-stroke handicap.

Harry K. Thaw, who was acquitted of murdering Stanford White on the ground of insanity, testified yesterday before Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum and a jury, in a defense of a suit brought against him by Dr. Smith Ely Jelliffe,

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Due to the present pessimistic outlook for business, the lack of clarity and permanence of governmental policy, the uncertainty of future taxes and labor troubles, there are few opportunities for young men who are not only anxious but desperate for work.

Mystery still surrounds yesterday's explosion in the center of the city. A passport found among torn garments at the scene of the explosion appeared to have been issued in Czechoslovakia to a man named Novacs, but it is belived to be a forgery.

While George A. Casey, Sheriff of Westchester County, was investigating reports that marijuana addicts were obtaining that drug in candy, beer and whisky, Major Garland Williams, head of the Narcotic Bureau here, arraigned six Negroes, one of whom, Algeria June Clark, arrested with the others on Monday night, is believed to have been a supplier of marijuana to resorts in Westchester.
Secretary Morgenthau today invited bids on the usual weekly issue of $50,000,000 of ninety-one-day Treasury bills, to be sold to the highest bidder on the usual discount basis.
More than 62,000 persons in Cleveland crowded into a baseball park on Sunday and rejoiced to see the local Indians

The $238,000 first mortgage on 481 Ft Washington Ave has been extended for the Regort Realty Corp, W. Frederick Troger president, for a term of years at 4 per cent. Nehring Brothers, Inc, broker, arranged the extension.
Joseph I. Montel has joined James Felt Co., Inc., as vice president. S. Stanley Sogg Co., Inc., have been appointed agents for the recently erected apartment house at 68 East Fifty-fifth Street.

Charles V. Bob, mining engineer and promoter who helped to finance one of Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd's expeditions to the Antarctic and later was tried three times in Federal court on charges of mail fraud, with a jury disagreement each time, was indicted again yesterday on similar charges.

Two New York men. with established reputations in. their fields, have been selected by the Board of Education's buildings and sites committee to fill the new posts created as a result of the board's reorganization of its bureau of construction and - maintenance, James Marshall, president, announced yesterday.

Barney Ross, world welterweight champion, arrived in town yesterday from his training camp at the Grossinger Country Club, Ferndale, N. Y., and entertained a large crowd at Stillman's gymnasium while putting the finishing touches on preparations for his fifteenround title fight with Henry Armstrong at the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City tomorrow night.
With a total of more than 1,500 entries the Devon horse show and country fair got under way today. Despite intermittent showers during the day the opening drew a good crowd.

An application by the Lehigh Valley Railroad to abandon 18.99 miles of the Elmira Cortland branch line in Chemung and Schuyler Counties, N. Y., and to operate under trackage rights over the Erie's line between Waverly and Elmira, about 18.55 miles, was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
The General Theological Seminary of the Protestant Episcopal Church will hold its 118th annual commencement exercises this morning in the Chapel of the Good Shepherd, 175 Ninth Avenue.

In his last practice session preparatory to leaving for Europe, Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., the national amateur tennis champion, defeated Elwood Cooke Jr. of Portland, Ore., yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, 6-2, 2-6,. 6-3.
France will spend 11,000,000,000 francs on public works during the next three years in fulfillment of the second part of Premier Edouard Daladier's recovery program, approved by the government today.

Invitations have been issued by Mr. and Mrs. F. Harper Sibley for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Jane Harper Sibley, to Gordon Auchincloss 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Auchincloss of New York.

The twelve outdoor swimming pools operated by the Department of Parks will be opened for the season on Saturday. Until June 25 the pools will be open from 10 A. M. to 6 P. M., and after June 26 from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M.

Keynoted by a telegram from President Roosevelt expressing the hope that their "deliberations will be fruitful of wise counsel and constructive action," the International Association of Garment Manufacturers opened their annual convention here today to discuss new problems that have arisen in the past year and to consider the future.

Great Britain's grim preparations to meet enemy bombing attacks took another step forward today with the appointment of a Home Office committee to prepare a detailed program for the evacuation of civilians from congested centers.
The Unitarian Laymen's League today announced the election as a vice president of Arthur E. Morgan, former chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

Bradley Lewis, Salem-Crescent, defeated William Kozak, Tamaqua K. of C., in a 160-pound special bout at the Downtown A. C. last night before a capacity crowd. Two other specials were on the program. In the 135-pound division Tony Ferrara, unattached, beat Dick Powell, Tamaqua K. of C., and William Speary, Philadelphia, triumphed over Frank Oliver, unattached, in the 126-pound class.

Many motor boat owners in waters around New York feared they were facing a crisis yesterday when it became known that Federal marine authorities suddenly and without any advance notice had begun to levy $200 fines for violations of a 41-year-old, but long dormant, law requiring motor craft to display lights at night when moored.

The Administration is using every ounce of pressure it possesses to retain Section 201 of the pump-priming bill. This means the Administration is employing all its political strength to scrap with one hand the utilities settlement it is writing with the other.

In recognition of his distinguished service "in promoting international peace and commercial good-will," Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American Airways, received the gold medal of the American Arbitration Association yesterday at a luncheon meeting attended by more than 500 persons associated with aviation and foreign trade at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

United States Government obligations were an exception yesterday when most classes of bonds drifted to moderately lower levels in slightly more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. In the corporate list a fairly long list of underlying public-utility issues were vulnerable to selling, resulting in losses from fractions to about 2 points.

DeWitt Phillips, real estate man of Brooklyn, surrendered on charges of conspiracy in the Merritt Parkway land purchases here this afternoon and was freed on $1,000 bond posted by Mrs. Ella Crawford of Darien.

Mrs. Edward Ehrbar of 30 Sutton Place gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza at which the engagements were announced. of her daughter, Miss Kathryn Loretto Ehrbar, to Edward Albert Hodge. and of Miss Myra Perris to Edward Ehrbar Jr,, son of the hostess.

A Foreign Office spokesman tonight announced that France had asked the United States for diplomatic support to prevent war between Germany and Czechoslovakia. The French move, however, encountered a cool American reception.

It was a gala -light last night at Public School 11, in Twenty-first Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, as the 2,000 children of the school and their parents and teachers thronged the auditorium for a Parade of Pupil Hobbies.

The Bees wiped out a 9-1 lead with three late rallies today to defeat the Reds, 10-9, and oust them from third place in the/National League standing. Boston, now on the heels of the Giants and Cubs, used five pitchers and Cincinnati four in the affair and much of the Bees' success was due to the relief flinging of Billy Weir and Dick Errickson.
United States Supreme Court Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo observed his sixty-eighth birthday quietly here today at the estate of Judge and Mrs. Irving Lehman.

For the American contingent the British amateur golf championship developed today into something in the nature of a civil war. In the early morning, when the ball was bobbling a bit on the greens, Johnny Fischer of Cincinnati went down to defeat before Charley Yates of Atlanta, who laid him a dead stymie on the nineteenth green.

The quarterly report of operations of the Mortgage Commission Servicing Corporation shows payment of taxes of $22,409,000 to the City of New York in the last three years, most of them in arrears; the rehabilitation of properties aggregating more than $30,000,000 and the establishment of a norm for the modification of capital structure and interest requirements in loans which are backed by real estate.

William Lurie came through with, an upset triumph over Frank Bowden yesterday to become the first to enter the final round of the metropolitan invitation tennis tourney on the courts of the Culver Tennis Club in Brooklyn.

Rockwell Kent, Arthur Byron and Donald Ogden Stewart expressed approval of the proposed Fine Arts Bureau Bill yesterday afternoon at a luncheon for theatre folk at Sardi's Restaurant, 234 West Fortyfourth Street.

A feeling of cautious optimism over the outcome of the Czechoslovak crisis gained strength today as Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain reported to the King on the part that the British Government played in the recent excitement.

Annual convention, National Metal Trades Association, Hotel Biltmore, 10 A. M. Morning and afternoon sessions today and tomorrow. Commencement exercises, General Theological Seminary, 175 Ninth Avenue, 10:30 A. M. Speakers:

Little Frankie Strafaci of Lakeville, whose failure to gain a place on the Walker Cup team drew a good deal of criticism, yesterday came through with one of the greatest exhibitions of his career as he set a new competitive record of 32, 35-67 for the exacting St. Albans course to capture low gross honors in the Long Island Golf Association's one-day amateur competition.

Nine Bush Terminal Company buildings, comprising the blockfront on the north side of Fortyninth Street, between First and Second Avenues, Brooklyn, have been leased by Wm. W. Fitzhugh, Inc., lithographers. A total of 70,000 square feet of space is involved.

Thomas McConnell, president and general manager of the Hampton Company, textile manufacturers of Northampton, Mass., died here today at the age of 77. Mr. McConnell, who had been ill for a year, came here last March. His widow, Mrs. Bess McConnell, will accompany the body to Northampton.

The $100,000 special race between War Admiral and Seabiscuit, sched-uled next Monday, was declared off yesterday at Belmont Park because Seabiscuit's legs were bothering him and he probably would not have been able to do his best.

Company reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission, made public yesterday through the New York Stock Exchange, revealed an upward trend in salaries for the chairman and president of the Crucible Steel Company.

Prices of wheat continued to decline today and showed little rallying power, the close in all markets being at about the low point, with net losses of 1 3/8 to 2 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade, all deliveries of futures being in new low ground since April, 1934.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Anthony Forsyth of Bronxville, N. Y., and I Lakeville, Conn., have announced i the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pauline Elizabeth Forsyth, to Barry Stuart Richards, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry William Richards of London, England. The ceremony will take place June 3 at the Fcrsyth country home in Lakeville.

Rain failed to stop the action in the Meadow Brook members polo today, and three games were completed despite a windswept drizzle that made for anything but fast conditions. One of the contests was played on Schiff Field in Roslyn and the others on the Phipps estate in Old Westbury.

" Murals for the Community" is the title of a large WPA Federal Art Project exhibition that opened with a preview at the Federal Art Gallery, 225. West Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon. Beginning today the work selected for this showing may be seen by the public. The exhibition will remain current until June 16.

Through Vice President C. V. Whitney of the Westchester Racing Association, which operates Belmont Park, Charles S. Howard late yesterday made the following statement concerning the cancellation of next Monday's race between his Seabiscuit and Samuel D. Riddle's War Admiral:

A curfew was again declared in Jerusalem tonight as a result of a series of incidents this morning, when within an hour and a quarter twenty-six Casualties occurred, including ten Jews, one of whom was fatally injured, and fourteen Arabs and two Russian nuns.
With the piping of the Scottish national music, the bridegroom and best man in the plaid of their clan, Miss Geraldine Griffin of Albany today became the bride of Alan E. Cameron of Oban, Scotland.

A signed statement: by Donald F. Carroll Jr., 16 years old, describing how he killed his sweetheart last March because she was to become a mother was read into evidence yesterday at the boy's trial for murder in Queens County.Court.

Private John J. Cubetta, 19 years old, of 3,644 Holland Avenue, the Bronx, was on his way back to Fort Hamilton yesterday when he was arrested charged with having commandeered his major's automobile on Saturday for a few days' absence without leave.

29th St, 315-317 E, 40x98.9; Mabel Mordhurst to Anna Frey. 1,881 Concourse, Bronx; 1st mtg $26,000, 2d $22,250 ($1). 9th Ave, 790. 25x100: Lester Marcus to Ray Blecher, 227 W 52d St, care Nathan Sugarman; mtg $20,000, consid $20,400. 86th St, ?? 136.4 e of 5th Ave. 17x100.8 1/2x irreg; George H. Pendleton to Gerald D. Nelson et al. Dobbs Ferry, N. Y.; mtg $34,000 held by grantees.
Captain Ogden Wilkinson, a SpanishAmerican, War veteran, who was with the Intelligence Service during the World War, died at his home here yesterday after a long illness. His age was 75 years.

First public reaction to the Borah-O'Mahoney bill now pending in the Senate, which is widely regarded as one of the most farreaching legislative proposals in recent times, is shown by a survey just completed by the American Institute 'of Public Opinion.
When the Liverpool steamer berthed at Dublin port early this morning, it had aboard as a saloon passenger the United States Secretary of the Interior, Harold Le Clair Ickes.
Dr. E. H. Killheffer of E. I. du Pont de Nemours., Co., Wilmington, Del., was elected president of the United States Institute for Textile research at a luncheon at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.
Spanish Government forces reported tonight that they had split the left flank of the Insurgents' northern army in Western Catalonia.

Mr. and Mrs. Lewis M. Isaacs of the Hotel Elysee and Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hermine Alich Isaacs, to Robert L. Popper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Popper of 270 Park Avenue.

What was described, at least in part; as a "local optical illusion," last evening colored the buildings of Manhattan deep purple and lavender and temporarily turned ugly neighborhoods into shimmering fairyland cities.

Ex-Governor Alfred E. Smith opposed three proposals introduced in the Constitutional Convention today when the final rush of such measures to beat tomorrow's deadline began. The proposals provided. for extensive changes in Section 7, Article VII, which was enacted for the protection of the State's forest preserve in the Adirondacks and the Catskills.

Miss George-Ann Jackson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Jackson of 778 Park Avenue, has chosen June 15 for her marriage to Jonathan Slocum, son of Dr. and Mrs. C. Jonathan Slocum of Beacon; N. Y. The ceremony will bE- performed in the First Presbyterian Church here by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. J. Valdemar Moldenhawer.
Philip A. Goold Jr., '39, of New York City, quarter-miler, has been elected captain of the 1938-39 Princeton track team, it was announced today by Coach Matty Geis.

Nine directors were elected yesterday at the annual meeting of Trade Association Executives in New York City at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Those serving one year are Stewart C. Comeaux, Institute of Leather Cloth and Lacquered Fabric Manufacturers; Joseph C. Fitts, Heating, Piping and Air Conditioning Contractors' National Association, and James L. Fri, Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A., Inc.

Brazil eased today the exchange restrictions on imports from the United States. The exchange director of the Bank of Brazil, Tancredo Ribas Carneiro, said this meant Brazil would carry out the BrazilUnited States trade agreement.
