Steel ingot output last week held to the level of the two previous weeks, although the normal seasonal trend was upward, and the adjusted index eased to 40.0 from 40.4. For the week ended May 22, 1937, the figure was 120.4.

Manifesting some of that pioneering spirit which brought him yesterday the gold medal of the American Arbitration Association for "distinguished service in promoting international peace and commercial good-will," Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American Airways, advocated a broad program of training in foreign trade for American youth.

Burmese civil aviation authorities report that the aircraft wheel and part of an undercarriage found off the southern shore of Sye Island in May, 1937, have been positively identified by the Lockheed Corporation of Los Angeles, Calif., as part of the plane flown by Sir Charles Kingsford-Smith when he disappeared on a flight from England to Australia in November, 1935.

Pitcher Joe Cleary singled in the eighth inning and gave the High School of Commerce nine a 2-to-1 decision over George Washington High in a Manhattan-Bronx P. S. A. L. game at Washington Stadium yesterday. Cleary, in chalking up his fifth triumph of the season, allowed only two hits and fanned eight.

The first session of the auction of the library of the late Francis Ralston Welsh, Devon, Pa., brought $8,374 - last night at the ParkeBernet Galleries. A set of John Gould's "The Birds of Australia" went to Frank Walters for $475.

Frau Edgar L. G. Prochnik, wife of the former Minister from Austria, has gone into the trousseau and lingerie business. She said today that she had accepted a position as the Washington representative of a New. York firm and-if the family is still here in the Fall-she intends to add dress designing as a sideline.

Valentine Everit Macy, philanthropist and former president of the Westchester Park Commission, who died at Phoenix, Ariz., on March 21, 1930, left a net estate of $30,255,879, according to a transfertax appraisal filed yesterday. Two sons and a daughter and their children are the principal beneficiaries.

A group of Pennsylvania political leaders and officials of the C. I. O. who were active with the GuffeyLewis faction in the recent Democratic primaries met here today and decided, it was reported, to ask Chairman Farley of the National Committee to act as party peacemaker with the aim of a Democratic victory in the State in November.

The Borden Company, milk distributors, presented bronze plaques yesterday to four of its branch managers whose drivers had the best vehicular safety records for 1937. The presentations were made in Police Commissioner Valentine's office.at Police Headquarters..

Adolf Keifer, 65years old, a manufacturer of Stuttgart, Germany, arrived yesterday at the end of a cruise said to be unique in recent travel history. Mr. Keifer, who is totally blind, had just completed a tour around the-world on the Hamburg-American liner Reliance, accompanied by his daughter, Mrs. Elsa Oppenlender, who acted as his "eyes" and described events and sights of -the 39,000-mile voyage.

After several hours of questioning yesterday - in the office of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Louis Koch, 50 years old, of 665 Prospect Avenue, the Bronx, and Leo Rosenthal, 40, of 601 West 113th Street, were taken into custody as material witnesses for the trial of J. Richard (Dixie) Davis, disbarred lawyer, in the alleged Dutch Schultz policy racket conspiracy.

Several large apartment rentals in the Park Avenue district were reported yesterday by Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers. Among these was a suite of thirteen rooms and four baths at 1,175 Park Avenue, taken for a long term by Paul T. Kammerer Jr., lawyer.

The amended reorganization plan for the Radio-Keith Corporation was submitted yesterday to George W. Alger, special master, at a hearing in the Bar Association Building which was adjourned, after the examination of two witnesses, until June 8. After the witnesses, both accountants, had testified,

Shudders must have run up and down the spines of the professors who heard Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of Harvard's astronomical observatory, shamelessly put the discovery of new collections of stars on a factory basis. Fiftytwo dollars a hundred for new galaxies, $9 for a nice, new, raw, variable starthat's how the practical Shapley thinks of the universe.

Turpentine steady, 22-22 1/4c: sales, 71 barrels receipts, 720 barrels; shipments, 21 barrels; stock, 35,618 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 401: receipts, 2,682; shipments. 818; stock, 112,318. Quote: B, $3.35; D, E, $3.50; F, $3.85; G $4.05; H, I, $4.12 1/2; K, $4.17; M, $4.20; N. $4.75; WG, $5.40; WW, X, $6.10.

Charges that the proposed joint Federal and State marketing agreement and order regulating the handling of milk in the metropolitan area would result in an increased price to the consumer and serious overproduction were put forward by milk distributors yesterday at the resumption of the hearing on it in the State Building, 80 Center Street.

From nearly every part of Christendom today devout Catholics are moving to this city for tomorrow's opening of a great Eucharistic Congress, in which biennially Catholicism proclaims and renews its faith.

All classes of livestock closed active and strong to higher as compared with the opening today, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. The late hog trade was especially good and fully as high as Monday.

The violence that has marked the strike of 15,000 fur workers, members of the International Fur Workers Union, resulted yesterday in the indictment of six men, two of whom were characterized at the office of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey as officials of the union.

C. C. Williams, president of Lehigh University, announces that the anthracite conference held at the university in April was such a success that it will be made an annual affair under the joint sponsorship of the university and Anthracite Industries, Inc.

Mrs. Eugene F. Suter and Mrs. Maurice R. Hahn, both of New York City, obtained divorces here today. Mrs. Suter was Mrs. Audrey Wellington Bingham when she married Mr. Suter of New York and Paris at the country estate of her brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. John T. deBlois Wack, at Westport, N. Y., on July 5, 1931. Mr. Suter is president of Eugene, Ltd.

Among the Bronx properties reported yesterday as having been sold was the four-story apartment house on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 645 Bryant Avenue, which was purchased by a client of J. Howard Katz. The T. C. Burke estate was the seller. Sale was for cash above a mortgage of $43,000 at 4 per cent for five years.
Mrs. Sally Dunbar Plunkett of New York. filed a $200,000 alimony suit in Superior Court here today against her former husband, Paul Plunkett, Greenwich and New York sportsman.

The final tabulation of the entries for the twelfth annual fixture of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club to be held Saturday at Giralda Farms, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge in Madison, N. J., was announced yesterday.

A subcommittee of the newly formed magazine publishers' copy control committee, mentioned here yesterday, has been formed to act as intermediaries with agencies or advertisers on the question of obtaining changes in copy which may be suggested by the committee as a whole.

President Lazaro Cardenas, conceding that "part of the State of San Luis Potosi is still insurrectionary," late today issued a proclamation to the people of the State calling upon all in the "disloyal camp" to lay down their arms and return to their homes.

Americans' thirst for carbonated drinks has increased so much that the bottling industry has been having difficulty installing machinery fast enough to take care of the demand, Roy H. Crane, assistant general sales manager of the Liquid Carbonic Corporation, Chiago, said today at the annual convention of the Illinois Pharmaceutical Association.
A springtime festival of folk dancing by children turned the old sheepfold near the Tavern-on-the-Green in Central Park into a colorful scene yesterday.

Akbar, the Central Park Zoo's 500-pound lion was making his first sea voyage last night, surveying the hold of the Royal Netherlands line freighter Calypso, bound for Laguaira, Venezuela, from the traveling crate to which fate-and Park Commissioner Moses-had consigned him.
An attempt was made tonight to kidnap Viscount. Nuffield, Britain's best-known automobile manufacturer, from his office in the Cowley factory near here.

" Quintet," a composition for strings and piano, by Arthur Farwell of the Michigan State College faculty, received its premiere here today at the Westminster Choir School in the second day's program of the contemporary American music festival of the school.

The Constitutional Convention was called upon today by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, and George Meany, president of the State Federation of Labor, to defeat proposals which would tend to classify unemployment insurance in the State as a relief measure.

Alvia Kerr Brown, manufacturer and banker, died Sunday in his apartment at the Windermere East Hotel. He was 84 years old. Born in Iowa, Mr. Brown's first job was driving a mule for $1 a week. In 1892 he came to Chicago as manager of the American Press Association.

To the twenty-two Broadway producers who charged on Monday that the Federal Theatre Project competed unfairly with the commercial stage, the local administrative office of the project replied yesterday that the WPA shows assisted rather than hurt the Broadway theatre by stimulating interest in playgoing.

Democratic members of the City Council manoeuvred Mayor La Guardia into a position yesterday where they hoped he would be forced to commit himself on the record-changing case involving Simon W. Gerson, aide to Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan.
Otis Skinner, dean of American actors, was seriously ill at his home on the Green here today with his daughter, Cornelia Otis Skinner Blodgett, actress, at his side.

The practice of stopping the clock in the Legislature so that body can adjourn on the date set even when its session runs overtime, would be barred under a proposal submitted to the Constitutional Convention by Donald L. Brush, a delegate.

Robert Moses (Lefty) Grove scored his eighth consecutive pitching triumph of the season as the Red Sox nosed out the Tigers, 5 to 4, in a loosely played game today. The victory enabled Boston to take second place behind the Indians.

The Grand Opera Choral Alliance, which last week lost its American Federation of Labor charter to the American Guild of Musical Artists, will appeal on Monday to the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, parent body of all entertainer unions, for a return of its jurisdiction.

The world production of tin in the first quarter of this year was 43,200 tons, against 46,300 in the first quarter of last year, according to the International Tin Research and Development Council. In March the output was 16,300 tons, against 13,000 in February.

The roof garden of the Hotel Astor was filled last night for the formal opening for the season. The roof has been arranged to resemble a garden on the French Riviera. The sunken dance floor is bordered by railed double terraces decorated with close-trimmed hedge, flowers, plants and other greenery. Electrically illuminated "ribbons" of water flow from fountains at opposite ends of the garden.

Miss Helen Sigel, Philadelphia Country Club, set the pace in the second round of the annual Philadelphia women's golf championship today with a 7-and-6 victory over Miss Peggy McCloskey, Whitemarsh Club.

Chilean authorities are confronted for the first time with the necessity of considering wide-scale importation of coal in order to avoid the paralyzation of many industries, it was admitted this afternoon when partial results of an investigation being made revealed the impossibility of increasing the output of Chile's mines.
A German military training plane was seized by French authorities today when it was forced down in French territory after having flown over France's Maginot Line of steel and concrete fortifications.

State Treasurer William H. Albright of Woodbury and State Controller Frank J. Murray of Orange, who were re-elected by the Legislature last week to serve three-year terms, received their oaths of office today from Supreme Court Justice Clarence E. Case in the Senate chamber of the White House.
The day having passed without a repetition of dangerous incidents along the Czechoslovak border, Germany concentrated all diplomatic and propagandistic efforts on two objectives.

Student government and senior class officers for the next college year were announced at Stoneleigh College here today, with Edith R. Ronian of Middletown, Conn., and Beth Eaton of Schenectady, N. Y., as president of each group, respectively. Others chosen were: Student Government--Betty Blood,

With the subject of syphilis no longer taboo, the State is faced with an expanding program of diagnosis and treatment which is seriously hampered by inadequate facilities and personnel, it was reported yesterday at a conference of up-State local health committees at the Hotel Commodore.
Dr. Lazarus Karp, prominent Richmond physician and vice president of the Zionist Organization of America, died suddenly of a heart attack in his home last night at the age of 53 years.

John P. Kerwin and the Kerwin Auto Sales and Service, Inc., of 6,323 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, pleaded guilty yesterday in Special Sessions Court, Brooklyn, to charges of failing to file city sales tax returns. Kerwin was released in $1,000 bail and both he and the corporation are scheduled for sentence on June 21.
A proposal for unification of the Canadian Pacific and Canadian National Railways to solve Canada's railway problem and relieve its debt burden,

The possibility of the isolation of the measles virus and the preparation of a therapeutic serum that will permit vaccination against the disease was outlined in a paper read today before the Academy of Medicine on behalf of Dr. Harry Plotz, head of the laboratory at the Pasteur Institute.

Miss Eleanor Andrews Barrett, daughter of Mrs. Ashleigh Drake Halliwell of this city and Colonel Leonard Lovering Barrett, U. S. A., retired, will be married here to Giles Newton Montgomery, son of the Rev. Dr. George Redington Montgomery and the late Mrs. Montgomery of Noroton, on June 25 in St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church. Dr. Montgomery will perform the ceremony.

Three deaths, the first in Jamaica's three-day strike of various groups of workers, occurred today when police attempted to disperse a crowd of strikers. A mother and one of her sons were killed and a second son was fatally wounded when the police opened fire to break up the crowd.

Total revenues from sales of manufactured and natural gas in March was $74,608,700, compared with $76,232,300 a year before, a decrease of 2.1 per cent, the American Gas Association reported yesterday.

The American Irish Historical Society presented to Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral and vicar general of the archdiocese of New York, a copy of an eight-century Irish manuscript last night in appreciation of his lifelong activity in behalf of Irish-American affairs.

Electric power production last week increased slightly, but not enough to offset seasonal and longterm trends. The adjusted index eased to 90.4 from 90.6. The figure was 106.4 for the week ended May 22, 1937.

The National Security League announced yesterday that at its annual meeting on Tuesday at its headquarters, 45 West Forty-fifth Street, it re-elected Lieut. Gen. Robert Lee Bullard, United States Army, retired, as its president. General Bullard has been president since 1925.
Two Americna-owned horses, J. E. Widener's Unbreakable and William Woodward's Valeria III, were included today among the twenty-four final acceptance for the English Derby at Epsom Downs on June 1.

Dr. Alexander L. Prince, eye specialist and author of many articles in medical and scientific journals, died here today on his fifty-fourth birthday. He was graduated in 1910 from the Yale Medical School, where he later taught, and during the World War he served in France with the university's medical unit, Dr.

The United States Department of State is contemplating an enlarged service on coffee statistics through contacts and other resources of the foreign service, the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange disclosed yesterday.

The Rev. Samuel Hershel Bowyer, former pastor of the Walnut Hills Baptist Church here, died at his home in Niantic, Ill., after a long illness, according to word received here today. He was 75 years old.
A registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by an independent mortgage bond committee for Chicago, North Shore Milwaukee Railroad Company bonds became effective today.

Tazio Nuvolari, Italian automobile racing driver and winner of the 1936 Vanderbilt Cup. race, arrived in New York yesterday aboard the Italian liner Conte di Savoia en route to Indianapolis, where he plans to witness the annual 500-mile speedway classic on Memorial Day.

Miss Miriam Rafferty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Rafferty of this place, was married this morning to Earl E. McEvoy of Los Angeles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. McEvoy of New Rochelle, in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Gregory, Harrison. The Rev. Joseph Krug performed the ceremony.

A national survey of employment trends in the metal trades industries holds out the hope that the depression may be touching bottom, according to a report made public yesterday at the fortieth annual convention of the National Metal Trades Association at the Hotel Biltmore.

Politics boiled over in the Senate yesterday. Anti-New Deal Democrats denounced Harry L. Hopkins, the WPA chief, for taking sides in the Iowa primary contest, and some of them began to organize a campaign to protect themselves against what they viewed as reprisals at the polls in other States. They said the New Deal was hunting for candidates to oppose Congressmen who went against the Court Bill.

Clarence Philander Linville, a prominent metallurgical engineer with the Calco Chemical Company of Bound Brook, died this morning in the Elizabeth General Hospital. Death was due to pneumonia, which followed an operation. He was 59 years old.
The deadline for the introduction by individual delegates of proposed changes in the State Constitution brought a flood of measures to the clerk's desk in the Constitutional Convention today.

Johns Hopkins University receives a legacy of $50,000 in the will of Edmund Calvert Lynch, partner in the investment banking firm of Merrill, Lynch Co., 40 Wall Street, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Mr. Lynch died in London on May 14. His estate is estimated to be in excess of $6,000,000.

Despite the discouraging current situation, the steel industry is looking for at least a moderate upturn by August, according to the Iron Age. The publication states that some encouragement has been derived from the defeat of John L.

Mrs. Arthur J. Nash, widow of a partner of the late Louis C. Tiffany in the manufacture of favrile glass, was born in Birmingham, England, eighty-seven years ago, a daughter of William Taylor, builder of the Euston railroad terminal in London. Surviving are four sons,

Acting swiftly and without warning, the New York Stock Exchange's board of governors moved yesterday to place short sales of odd lots on the same basis as short sales of round lots, effective on June 1.

A symposium on "Mural Painting in America" will be held this evening at 8:30 in the Federal Art Gallery, 225 West Fifty-seventh Street, where the show called "Murals for the Community" opened yesterday. The chairman of this evening's program, to which the public is invited, will be Burgoyne Diller, head of the mural division in the New York Region.

James M. Mathes Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., has been elected president of the 1939 Palaeopitus, student governing body of Dartmouth College. He will succeed Robert Archibald. Herbert Mattlage of Douglaston, L. I., will become vice-president; Kenneth A. MacDonald of Quincy, Mass., secretary, and Bertram R. MacMannis of Larchmont, N. Y., treasurer.

The flight of Dr. Ignatz T. Griebl in the German spy investigation continued yesterday to develop facts that the authorities found irreconcilable with their pattern of the case as they delved deeper into the circumstances of the physician's trip abroad and of his getting refuge in Germany just before he was to be a grand jury witness.

Miss Frieda S. Miller, director of the division of women in industry and minimum wage of the New York State Department of Labor, and Carter Goodrich, United States Labor Commissioner at Geneva, were appointed today as government delegates to the twenty-fourth conference of the International Labor Organization at Geneva on Tune 2.
Count and Countess Charles de Ferry de Fontnouvelle have returned from France and are at the St. Regis. Mrs. Edward - B. McLean is expected from Washington at the Waldorf-Astoria today.

Wesleyan's baseball team turned back the Trinity nine, 4 to 3, in a well-played game today. A triple by Horn, first baseman, scored Sundstrom with the winning run in the eighth inning after Trinity had tied the count at 3-all in the previous frame.

Frederick E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad, told stockholders at their annual meeting here today that increases in freight rates granted recently by the Interstate Commerce Commission probably would amount to between $12,000,000 and $13,000,000 for the Central this year.

Retail sales of new passenger automobiles advanced about 6 per cent from March to April, but with adjustment for seasonal factors the preliminary adjusted index figure of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce for these sales decreased slightly from 61.0 in March to 60.0 in April, the Department of Commerce announced today.
The Very Rev. Bonaventure Zoller, for more than fifty years a priest of the Franciscan Order of Minor Conventuals, died here today after a long illness. His age was 81.

Settlement of the strike of 15,000 fur workers by this morning was predicted yesterday by Dr. Paul Abelson, impartial chairman of the fur industry, who has been mediating between the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc., and the International For Workers Union. A tentative agreement has been reached.
William S. Brown, president of General Drivers Union No. 544, A. F. of L., was shot and killed as he sat in his parked car on a street near the union headquarters just before midnight tonight.

As the result of an amendment to the banking law adopted at the recent session of the State Legislature, savings banks now are in a better position to compete with insurance companies for loans on apartment buildings in New York.

President Roosevelt conferred today with Governor Earle and Charles A. Jones, Democratic nominees for Senator and Governor, respectively, in Pennsylvania, in an effort to bring about harmony between warring factions of the party and assure a Democratic victory in the. November elections.

Robert J. Murray of 59 Johnson Place, Woodmere, Queens, died yesterday in the Nassau Hospital, Mineola, after a short illness. His age was 42. -He was manager of the Rockaway Beach branch office of the Queensboro Gas and Electric Company, president of the Nassau County Fire Chiefs Council and treasurer of the Union Free School District, No. 14.

The Rev. Eugene Smith Morey, retired Methodist minister, died here today at South Street Inn. Born sixty-one years ago in Geneva, N. Y., Mr. Morey was educated at Lima Seminary, Lima, N. Y., and the University of Rochester.

Harry Hopkins, the Works Progress Administrator, may inadvertently have performed the best public service of his career when he remarked yesterday that were he voting in the Democratic primaries in his home State of Iowa, he would oppose Senator Gillette for renomination in favor of Representative Wearin.

Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Untermyer's Hexameter, a brown gelding from Greenwich, Conn., ridden by Miss Patricia Bolling, also of Greenwich, stole the spotlight at the Devon Horse Show today by annexing two blues, making a total of three to date in this show.

" Ladylike" costumes in black, characterized by simplicity of silhouette and the discreet use of trimming, were the choice of American garment manufacturers from among the designs recently -shown at the midseason Paris. openings, judging from import collections just. received here. Daytime clothes were frequently trimmed only with self or contracting fabrics, and the feeling for the "all black" or "black and white" outfit. seemed to have revived.
Sixtyseven years ago the late Governor Theodore F. Randolph signed a bill creating the State's first police agency, the New Jersey Detective Association.

Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, former chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, testified for five hours today before the Congressional committee investigating the TVA in support of his charges of dishonesty and lack of integrity on the part of the remaining TVA directors, Chairman Harcourt A. Morgan and David E.
When the plot against Austria had been duly carried out, we believe it was the learned and amiable Herr Goebbels who cried

A banking group headed by the Mellon Securities Corporation and Dillon, Read Co. will offer today $19,000,000 of bonds and notes of the San Antonio Public Service Company, marking the first public financing for that company in ten years.

Greater sales effort toward the replacement of obsolete gas equipment in homes everywhere was recommended today to the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers, in convention here, as a means of opening up a wide selling market, of giving industry a strong normal stimulus, and making possible a great saving for consumers.

Mrs. Carrie Emerton Orvis, wife of Edwin Waitstill Orvis and a leader in charitable and club work, died yesterday in her home, at 205 West Eighty-ninth Street, after a brief illness. She was 78 years old.

The Seventh Cavalry Brigade completed the first great mechanized march in American military history this morning when 516 vehicles rolled into Fort Knox after four days on the road and delivered a smashing dawn "attack" against the Tenth Infantry Brigade.

The Colonial Legislature voted to Governor Sir Edward Denham today the power to declare a state of emergency if the situation growing out of Kingston's increasing labor trouble should warrant such action.
Trading was generally only fair to slow in local markets yesterday. Steer cuts were weak to sharply lower, old crop lambs weak to lower, fresh pork cuts uneven, other classes traefer meats steady.

George Lovett Kingsland of this city, Lenox, Mass., and Palm Beach has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of his daughter, Miss Marian Kingsland, to Count Hans Christoph Seherr-Thoss, elder son of Count and Countess Hermann Seherr-Thoss of Dobrau, Silesia.

Seeking to continue free bus operation for parochial school children in the face of a Court of Appeals decision last Tuesday barring the use of school funds for that purpose, Mayor La Guardia ordered the bus operation continued yesterday and arranged for the Welfare Department to take over the operation in the Fall.

A super-microscope, using electrons and photographic tracers, is reported to have been invented in the famous Siemens-Halske laboratory here, producing an enlargement of 100,000 times. To date, Germans claim, enlargement of only 2,000 times were possible.

The government rushed more troops to San Luis Potosi today as the followers of General Saturnino Cedillo remained in control of a large territory in that State and continued to menace Federal communications with the United States.

Electrical equipment for the sewage disposal plant on Wards Island, most of which had been completely assembled and wired in the General Electric factory, was rewired by electrical union men at an additional cost of $17,550, according to testimony yesterday in the injunction suit against Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

Charles Loring Brace, secretary of the Children's Aid Society of New York from 1890 to 1928, died Tuesday at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif., according to word received here yesterday. He was 82 years old.

More than 500 labor leaders and members of trade unions attended last night a dinner in the Hotel Edison at which cups were awarded for the best showing made by labor unions and employers in the union label parade held on May 14 under the auspices of the Central Trades and Labor Council and the Central Union Label Council, both affiliates of the American Federation of Labor.
The city of Detroit, through John N. Daley, Controller, will receive, up to June 8, tenders of its callable refunding bonds in the amount of approximately $850,000, it was announced yesterday.
A case of a fish catching a fisherman was reported by the tuna fisher Bijo, which returned to port here to inform the authorities of the disappearance of a Costa. Rican, Laureano Villareal.

Czechoslovakia will not countenance the appearance of German troops on her soil for any purpose whatever and will defend to the last man the democracy for which her people long have struggled, it was declared yesterday by Julius Brabec, the new Czechoslovak Consul General here, who arrived on the Italian liner Conte di Savola to take over his duties.

Dr. Robert Kilburn Root, dean of the faculty of Princeton University, counseled the graduates and theologians of the General Theological Seminary yesterday to employ their study of the Christian religion in clarifying the confused thinking of the present day.

The Government easily beat the Opposition's motion for an Independent inquiry into the state of Great Britain's air defense in the House of Commons tonight by a vote of 329 to 144. The vote was taken after a debate in which the main point was Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's chiding of the Opposition for insisting on comparing the British air force with Germany's.

In the great spaciousness of the Heldenplatz (Heroes' Square) this afternoon the thirty-fourth Eucharistic Congress, the world's outstanding religious pageant and largest demonstration of faith, was formally opened with the reading of a papal Bull contrasting the attraction of "eternal and unchanging ideas" with the "failure of agreements and alliances."
William J. Martin, for more than forty years GA: an Albany druggist, died today. He was proprietor of three large drug stores and had been in business since his youth. For years Mr.
Mrs. Aaron Louis Treadwell, wife of the retired Professor of Zoology at Vassar College here, died after a long illness this morning in. her home, adjoining the campus. Her age was 72.

Charged with receiving unlawful fees, totaling $250, on the alleged stipulation that he would testify on behalf of Alexis Dawydoff of 855 Park Avenue in a homicide case growing out of a automobile accident, Detective Thomas F. Lillis, 56 years old, of 2,300 University Avenue, the Bronx, was arrested last night while he was on duty at the West Thirtieth Street Station.

Conditional approval of a WPA project for construction of a $6,490,950 seaplane base, with two hangars and other facilities, at North Beach Airport, New York City, has been given by the Bureau of Air Commerce.

Ex-Mayor George J. Zimmermann, who was Buffalo's Chief Executive from 1934 until Jan. 1, last, was convicted in Supreme Court today on six counts of an indictment charging that he sought or took illegal fees while in office.

President Roosevelt joined with the Presidents of Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Peru and Uruguay today in sending messages to Presidents German Busch of Bolivia and Felix Paiva of Paraguay urging that they accept a proposal to be made tomorrow at the peace conference in Buenos Aires, Argentina, for a definitive settlement of the Chaco controversy.

Mrs. Kate Kettleman Bradt, widow of James P. Bradt, died Tuesday night at her home, 706 Riverside Drive, after a long illness, at the age of 78. Her husband was general manager for the Columbia Phonograph Company in Canada and had held official posts with the same company in Berlin, London and New York.

10th St, 390 E; to 6-story tenement and stores; Edith B. Halsey, 304 E 5th St, owner; M. Perlstein, architect; cost, $6,000. 4th St, 339 W; to 4-story tenement and store; Grenvil Realty Corp, 42 Broadway, owner; F. S. Keller, architect; cost, $6.000.

The forty-foot cabin cruiser Nanuk, owned by Charles Hamill, New York textile manufacturer, was destroyed by explosions and fire here last night shortly after it had been launched on Long Island Sound for the Summer.

G. LeRoy Kemp of Mount Vernon, N. Y., indicted land agent of the State Highway Department in the purchase of the Merritt Parkway right-of-way, will go on trial in Criminal Superior Court here June 14 before Judge Alfred C. Baldwin.

The owners of 20,000 restaurants in New York City and all milk dealers have been notified by the Department of Health that beginning next Wednesday they will not be permitted to sell milk to consumers except in the regular sealed individual bottle or from, certain dispensers approved by the department.

Eleven graduates at the Naval Academy have received letters from the superintendent commending them for their officerlike qualities and positive characters contributing to the development of naval spirit and loyalty within the regiment.

The steamer Innisfallen carried Harold L. Ickes, United States Secretary of the Interior, and his bride across the Irish Sea tonight toward the Continent. Mr. Ickes, 64-year-old widower, and his wife of a day, the 25-yearold former Jane Dahlman of Milwaukee, boarded the ship here as "Mr. and Mrs. Woods."
St. Mark's defeated the Groton nine today in ten innings, 3 to 2. Trailing, 2 to 0, going into the eighth, St. Mark's tied the count on hits by Moore, Bradley and Townsend.

When the Manufacturers Trust Co sold to the Vinmaur Corp, Maurice Levin, president, the building at 144-46 E 86th St, about 51 ft wide, adjoining the s e cor of Lexington Ave, for a consideration indicated as $335,000, the buyer gave back two purchase money mortgages, a first for $200,000 at 4 1/2 per cent and a second for S110,000 at 3 per cent, both due ten years hence with quarterly amortization.

Elaborate arrangements by Konrad Henlein's Sudeten German followers turned the funeral of Georg Hoffman and Nikolas Boehm, the two Nazis who were killed last Friday after having defied an order to halt given successively by three poLicemen in accordance with emeragency regulations, into an imposing ceremony today.
" Amstel," an unproduced play by Jacques Deval, which was purchased by RKO some time ago, was placed on active schedule today, with Cary Grant and Joan Fontaine assigned the leading roles.

A heavy frost in this area early today destroyed thousands of dollars worth of fruits and vegetables in Orleans County alone. The mercury hit 38 at 5:30 A. M., a low mark last recorded in 1917. The Orleans County Canning Company estimated 35 per cent of the tomato crop had been destroyed.
Five more drivers qualified today for the 500-mile Indianapolis Motor Speedway race on Memorial Day, bringing the number of certain starters to nineteen.

Although 618 members, more than a majority of those active in the New York Stock Exchange, signed petitions asking that the institution close on May 28, giving a three-day week-end over Memorial Day, the board of governors decided yesterday that business should continue as usual on that day.

Lamb market closed 25 to 40 cents lower today and the steer market turned weak to lower at the close. Demand for strictly choice and prime steers, especially on shipping accounts, narrowed due to an unsatisfactory dressed trade in the East and the approaching holiday. Hogs, however, sold actively and higher but weakened late, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.
Charles (Chick) Evans, the only man ever to win the national open, national amateur, Western open and Western amateur golf titles, said farewell today to major competitive golf.

Rumors of war again oppressed the European exchanges yesterday, driving most of them to the lowest prices in a. year or more and, by consequence, lifting the dollar to its highest exchange value in-that period.

The Indians drove home four runs in the seventh inning against Boston today and stretched their American League lead to three full games over the Red Sox. The score was 6 to 4, with Mel Harder giving only seven hits.

Sales increases during April were. scored by twenty-six out of sixtysix sections of local department stores, while reductions in inventories under the corresponding month last year ranging up to 31.2 per cent were noted for all but four departments, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Mrs. Mary A. Scheff, widow of Charles P. Scheff and long an active member of the Seventh Assembly District Democratic Club in Brooklyn, died on Tuesday night at her home, 680 Ovington Avenue, after long illness.
A banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. will offer today to the public $998,000 of State of South Dakota 3 3/4 per cent Rural Credit Refunding bonds, dated June 15, 1938, and due June 15, 1951.

Miss Louise Virginia Nunn of this city and Louis Franklin Kemp of Great Neck, L. I., whose engagement was announced last October, took out their license yesterday at the Municipal Building and plan to be married on June 4 in Grace Church here.

Arguments on the appeal of the Young Assembly investigating committee from the decision of Vice Chancellor Kays which declared its activities void because of alleged infringement upon the judicial functions was concluded before the Court of Errors and Appeals today.

Rosenbaum Brothers, Inc., with headquarters in Chicago, announced today they had leased the millionbushel Illinois Central grain elevator here after "decision by our company that the drought years are Fended."

Seiiorita Anita Lizana of Chile, who holds the United States women's singles title, defeated Miss S. G. Chuter of Great Britain, 6-3, 6-1, today in the third round of the Middlesex singles tennis tournament.

President Roosevelt has approved a $2,540,000 outlay for further control and eradication of mosquitos and other insect pests in the lowlying areas of New York City, particularly in Queens, Lieut. Col. Brehon Somervell, WPA Administrator here, revealed yesterday.

William B. Hand, a Union Civil War veteran, died Tuesday in New Lebanon, N. Y., according to word received here yesterday. His age was 95 years. Born in Hudson, N. Y., Mr. Hand enlisted in a New York State infantry regiment and fought in the battle of Gettysburg and other engagements.

Blasting the offerings of three pitchers, the City College baseball team defeated Brooklyn College, 17 to 3, at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. It was the Beavers' second victory of the season over the Brooklynites.
Prices of copper moved sharply lower yesterday in the export market. Some sales were reported at 8.35 to 8.40 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports, the lowest for the current movement.

Miss Ruth C. Lovell, daughter of Earl B. Lovell and the late Mrs. Lovell of this place, will be martried on June 25 in the First Baptist Church here to Charles R. L. Hemmersley, also of Montclair. The Rev. Dr. Albert B. Cohoe,
President Roosevelt signed today the $15,000,000 La Foilette-Bulwinkle bill to provide Federal aid for eradication of venereal diseases.

Weymer Jay Mills, author and birth editor, who had lived in Italy and England for the last fifteen years, died this morning in a hospital in Munich, Germany, after a lingering illness, according to word received here by his sister, Mrs. Dwight can Kirkby. He was born in Jersey City fifty-seven years ago.

of grade-crossing elimination and other improvements on the, Long Island Railroad between East New York, Brooklyn, and Jamaica, Queens, was voted yesterday by the City Planning Commission at its meeting in City Hall.

James J. Hines, dominant Tammany leader and dispenser of Federal patronage in New York, was arrested yesterday in the office of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey and charged with being a member of the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer gang in the policy racket.

A duplex apartment of fourteen rooms and six baths in the building at. 895 Park Avenue has been leased by Mrs. Lea F. Singer of Philadelphia through Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc., brokers. Other residential leases announced yesterday were;

Sources close to the White House indicated today that President Roosevelt would sign the Tax Bill before leaving the city tomorrow night and would issue a statement criticizing what he regards as shortcomings of the measure.

E. Simms Campbell, Negro artist, whose drawings appeared in magazines, lost a Supreme Court application here today to compel mortgage trustees to sell a twelve-acre estate in Mount Pleasant to him for $18,500. Through his counsel,

Mrs. Sally Bridges, wife of Senator H. Styles Bridges, died in the Margaret Pillsbury Hospital here of a cerebral hemorrhage this afternoon while a swift army plane was flying her husband from Washington to her bedside. Her age was 35.

The index of deliveries of rayon woven fabrics in the greige to the consuming trade for April was only slightly greater than for March, the seasonal slackening in demand which usually develops in May having started this year almost immediately after Easter, accordingly to the monthly review issued yesterday by the National Rayon Weavers Association.

A warning that "too many na- the tions" are heading straight for disaster through reliance upon policies of economic autarchy and that "the very survival of Western civilization" is dependent in large measure on the rebuilding of international trade was sounded last night by Cordell Hull, Secretary of State.

On his own application, to take effect 12 midnight, May 24: PATROLMAN-Charles E. Kerrigan, 18th Division,. 12th Detective District, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Aug. 26, 1912. Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., May 26:

Because of lower sugar prices, higher taxes and a decline in sales, earnings of the Holly Sugar Corportion for the fiscal year ended on March 31 fell below those of the previous year, according to the annual report released yesterday by Wiley Blair Jr., president.

The Staten Island Edison Corporation filed yesterday with the Public Service Commission a new schedule of electric rates, estimated to save consumers on Staten Island about $500,500 a year. The reduced rates will be effective on June 1.

Rudy York and Hank Greenberg, Detroit's devastating home run duo, put on a supercolossal exhibition of their specialty act today to the delight of 17,000 rooters, but very much to the distress of the Yankees.

Adjournment of Congress, whenever it comes, will mean money for Vice President Garner. He is making a book on the date. Taking all comers, Senators and newspaper men, "Cactus Jack" bets he can come nearer to the adjournment date than any one.
Colonel Henri Drecq, one of the army engineers who planned and supervised the construction of the Maginot defense line along the German frontier, died on Monday in a Paris hospital.

Sharp attacks on milk distributors by representatives of consumers and farmers and a threat that 90 per cent of the farmers in the New York milkshed would. strike if they did not get quick price relief were made yesterday at a hearing on the proposed joint Federal and State marketing agreement and order regulating the handling of milk in the metropolitan area.

COMMERCIAL PAPER Yesterday. Tuesday. For the beat names ..... 1% 1% The quotations are for four-six months paper. To Show Coat Lines June 21 Members of the coat division of the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., will not show their Fall lines before June 21, according to announcement made yesterday by Samuel L. Deitach chairman.

Mr. and Mrs. George C. Hollister of Lawrence Park, Bronxville, N. Y., gave a birthday dinner last night at the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for their daughter, Miss Patricia Hollister. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Burditt, the Misses Eleanor Sewell, Maren Lee,

Twenty-six members of the class tus, of 1938 and four special students junior will be graduated tonight at the New commencement exercises of the Calhoun School, to be held in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street. The program will begin at 8:30 P. M. Academic honors will go to Joan H. Amberg and Lee Eitingon.

The Public Investing Company, Philadelphia, an investment trust, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering 300,000 shares of $1-par-value cashable capital stock, of which 61,483 will be reserved for conversion of the original stock outstanding and 288,517 will be offered at the market for estimated cash proceeds of $915,905.

Contributions to the Greater New York Fund passed the $3,000,000 mark yesterday. With nearly onethird of the $10,000,000 goal in hand, James G. Blaine, chairman of the campaign committee, announced that the drive would continue beyond June 2, its scheduled closing date, to insure maximum vollections in behalf of private welfare and health agencies.
Confirmation that War Admiral would start in Saturday's Suburban Handicap against Pompoon and others was forthcoming yesterday from Peter A. B. Widener, steward of the Belmont Park meeting. Mr.
The Presbyterian Church in the United States of America was called upon today to lead Protestant denominations in raising a fund to aid victims of "Hitler's anti-Semitism."

The stock market was heavy in tone throughout yesterday, reflecting weaknesses in commodities, lower share prices abroad and the continued uncertainties over the foreign and domestic political situations. Losses for the main body of stocks ranged from fractions

Plans for alterations were announced yesterday in connection with sales of houses in Manhattan. The two four-story tenement buildings at 171 and 173 East Ninetieth Street were to be converted into apartments of one and one-half and two and one-half rooms as the result of the sale of the houses by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Jourmire Silverman.

An agreement through which a conference committee would write an elastic wages and hours bill contraining geographical differentials was understood to have been reached today by opposing Senate factions.

Eighty-nine students will receive certificates this morning at the fiftieth annual commencement exercises of the Ballard School, Young Women's Christian Association, 610 Lexington Avenue. Mrs. Jacob Riis will address the graduates.
A flat denial was given this morning by the United States Embassy here to a story, reported issued by French sources and disseminated by American and other news agencies and correspondents,

The Securities and Exchange Commission would be made a party to each bankruptcy proceeding under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act by action of one section of a bill revising the statute which was reported favorably today by the Senate Judiciary Committee

Election of Richard G. Woodbridge 3d, '39, of Wilmington, Del., as chairman of The Nassau Lit, Princeton undergraduate literary magazine, was announced today. Everett F. Goodman, '40, of New York City, was named business manager; John P. Chamberlain, '39,

Mlle. Amecle de la Grange, daughter of Baron Lighted Amaury de la Grange and Baroness de la Grange, the former Emily Sloane of New York, was married last Saturday to Marquis Aymard de Nicolay, in the Church of St. Thomas d'Aquin.

The use of mechanical recording machines in testing candidates for teaching licenses in the New York City school system, tried out experimentally by the Board of Examiners, has proved a handicap to prospective teachers, Dr. Joseph K. Van Denburg, chairman of the board, reported yesterday.

Several multi - family houses changed hands in the Bronx realty deals announced yesterday. William Mulcahy, an investing client of J. J. Boneparth, Inc., brokers, bought the six-story elevator building at 1,672 Davidson Avenue, on a plot 100 by 100 feet, for cash above a first mortgage of $146,000.

Hartley Robbins, private secretary to Murry Guggenheim, New York industrialist and financier, died in Mountainside Hospital here this afternoon soon after he arrived at the building to visit a friend, who is patient.
Joseph H. Jordan, publisher of The Duluth Herald-News Tribune tonight announced the end of the eight-week strike called April 3 by the Lake Superior. Newspaper Guild.

Despite the fact that it failed to capture one first place on the thirteen-event program, DeWitt Clinton High School retained the team championship with a total of 17 points at the annual Public Schools Athletic League senior high novice track and field meet at General George W. Wingate Field in Brooklyn yesterday.

Play in the British amateur golf championship today did not quite go according to the book. The casualties among the Walker Cup men were heavy and now the United States and Great Britain can muster only four apiece.

Federal Judge Murray Hulbert, presiding yesterday at the trial of eighteen defendants accused of conspiracy to violate the narcotic laws, dismissed the indictment as to two -- Vincent Vallone of Houston, Texas, and Charles La Gaipa. of 273 East First Street.

Professor George F. Warren will be remembered hereafter, not primarily for his useful investigations as head of the Department of Agricultural Economics and Farm Management at Cornell, but for the strange chapter in which during 1933, while holding the position merely of unofficial adviser to President Roosevelt, he virtually conducted the five months' manipulation downward of the dollar's gold value.

The cornerstone of the Belgian pavilion of the World's Fair was laid yesterday. afternoon by Count Robert van der Straten-Ponthoz, Belgian Ambassador to the United States, as representative of King Leopold III. Three hundred persons attended the ceremonies, which were broadcast by. short Wave to Brussels, where the event was also celebrated. and to the Belgian Congo.
Sipplies of iron on May 1 at furnaces and at docks on Lake Erie-33,876,333 tons-were the largest in history for this date, the Lake Superior Iron Ore Association reported today.
Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy will return to the United States next month to be present at the graduation of his son, Joseph P., Jr. from Harvard. He plans to sail on the Queen Mary June 15.

The Ford Motor Company's balance sheet as of Dec. 31, 1937, filed today with the Massachusetts Commissioner of Corporations and Taxation, showed an increase in profit and loss account of $5,419,264, to a total of $608,085,936, as compared to $602,666,672 a year before.

Public Safety ComAissioner Daniel Casey of Jersey City, N. J., made public last night a letter to the Hudson County Committee for Labor Defense and Civil Rights denying that organization a permit to hold a meeting tomorrow evening at Pershing Field, Jersey City, where Representative Jerry O'Connell, Democrat, of Montana, was to speak.

Open opposition to the projected sale of the -Sixth Avenue elevated line to New York City for an agreed price of $12,500,000 developed yesterday with the formation of an independent bondholders protective committee for the 4 per cent bonds of the Manhattan Railway Company.
FAITHFUL STRANGER AND OTHER STORIES, by Sheila Kaye-Smith. (Harper, $2.50.) A collection of new tales of the Sussex countryside.
Gross income of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union was $5,847,957 in 1937, thelargest in its history, said the annual report made public today by the executive board.

Embellishing his own high-grade pitching performance with a home run that soared even higher, Prince Hal Schumacher added still further to the woes of the once merry Onkel Franz Frisch by hurling the Giants to their second straight triumph over the invading Cardinals at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

Army defeated Penn State, 6 to 2, today, scoring all its runs in the second inning. Penn State tallied in the fourth when Nanney, after allowing only one blow, weakened and lost control, but Lough, who relieved him, held the visitors scoreless to the end.

Depressed by weakness in the cotton markets in both Liverpool and Bombay, coincident with a lower wheat market here and a break in sterling exchange, prices on the Cotton Exchange declined about $1 a bale yesterday to end with net losses of 16 to 19 points.
Behind Deacon Danny MacFayden's seven-hit pitching, the Bees today gained their fourth overtime victory in their current home stand by defeating the Reds, 2-1.
A Mozart-Wagner concert will be given tonight at the Carnegie Chamber Hall by Thelma Jerguson, soprano; Henry Blanchard, baritone; Barbara Farnsworth, mezzosoprano, and Paul Eisler, pianist.

With the net deficit for the current year standing at about $1.360,000,000 to date, and little expectation of substantial change between the present time and the end of the fiscal year, Treasury officials were confident today that President Roosevelt's revised budget forecast in January would be substantially fulfilled.

Although rumors are circulating abroad regarding the arrest of 180 Storm Troopers here and of the consequent departure of Joseph Buerckel, Reich Commissioner for Austria, for Berlin to report, no confirmation is obtainable.
The first gold medal to be awarded by the National Bureau for Blind Artists, Inc., was presented last night to Lily Pons, Metropolitan Opera soprano, for "distinguished service to the blind."

The value of merchandise exports from the United States in the first four months of the current year exceeded the value of merchandise imports by $435,312,000, in contrast with an import balance of $131,163,000 in the same period of last year, the bureau of foreign and domestic commerce of the Department of Commerce announced today.
Jimmy Adamick, Jack Kearns's heavyweight protege from Midland, Mich., tonight knocked out Al Ettore of Philadelphia in the fourth round. Adamick weighed 190 1/2 pounds and Ettore 194.

What can already be called one of next season's major events had its first hearing yesterday when George S. Kaufman, surrounded by Moss Hart and the Sam H. Harris office staff, read his and Mr.'Hart's new play-the one that is more or less about the theatre from 1900 to 1930.

" Fishke Der Krumer," a Yiddish play by Chaver Paver, has been announced as winner of the first prize of $700 in the play contest conducted by the Artef Theatre and Icor, a Jewish organization interested in cultural activity. A second prize of $300 went to Louis Miller for "Mr. Man," also a Yiddish play.

Mrs. Richard H. Swartwout was among those diving luncheons yesterday in the Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton, which was opened for the Summer season. Her guests included Mrs. Kingdon Gould, Mrs. Bryce Wright Turner, Mrs. Joseph B. Long, Mrs. C. Douglass Green and Mrs. Stuart McNamara.

A total of 12,400 copies in the first seven days after publication is the sales record of "Writers Take Sides." This is the book published by the League of American Writers in which 418 leading American authors express their views on the Spanish war.

Increased public aid to tuberculous families in the lower income groups and concentration on finding adult cases are the most direct ways to reduce tuberculosis mortality more rapidly, speakers declared at yesterday's sessions of the conference of State and local committees on tuberculosis and public health of the State Charities Aid Association at the Hotel Commodore.

A price war among several downtown package stores on bar gins and some whiskies, together with announcement of the settlement of the two-day strike of the liquor salesmen, featured the liquor trade here yesterday.
A new record for the Hollis Stakes, which was inaugurated in 1915, was set yesterday at Belmont Park when North Riding, from the Howe Stable, sped down the Widener chute in 1:09 3-5 for six furlongs.

Failure of the right engine in flight, followed by the loss of power or complete failure of the left engine of the twin-motored United Air Lines' plane last night caused the ship to crash and burn within sight of Cleveland Airport, bringing death to ten persons, the company and Air Commerce Bureau experts declared today.

The objection of the Administration to the decision of the Supreme Court in the Kansas City Stockyards case is really based up the "political philosophy of a votalitarian state and not of a free people," Frederick H. Wood,

Several large upper-floor rentals and a number of stores were listed among the business leases reported yesterday. The Agfa Ansco Corporation, dealers in photographic equipment, have leased an additional floor in the building at 245-49 West Fiftyfifth Street, making four floors which the firm will occupy there.

Eugene B. Gartlan, for twentytwo years principal of Public School 42, Washington Avenue and Claremont Parkway, the Bronx, died Monday at the Samuel Bowne Memorial Hospital, Poughkeepsie, N. Y., after a four months' illness.

Ten percentage points are all that separate the Dodgers and the cellar position in the National League, although they are actually a game behind the Phillies. Plunging further downward yesterday at Ebbets Field, the not-so-merry men of Burleigh- Grimes hit a new low as they succumbed meekly to Larry French of the Cubs, 7 to 2.

Gold-mining shares again were a prominent feature today in a generally unsettled stock market here. Despite profittaking, South African mining securities advanced, but the West African group, after a firm start, lost ground.

The first of a series of meetings to foster better relations between the United States and South American countries was held last night in the clubhouse of the New York Athletic Club on Central Park South.
Berlin announced yesterday the lodging of a "sharp protest" in Prague against frontier violations by Czech military planes and listed six such incidents. [Page 1.]
Soviet Russia is ready to join France in defending Czechoslovakia in case of aggression and is ready

Saying he was acting at the request of the trustees of the Power Authority of the State, Charles Poletti, Supreme Court Justice, announced today that he would introduce at the Constitutional Convention a proposal which would "forever" guarantee public ownership, possession and control of the State's water power resources.

In recognition of his 800-page book, "The Daily Newspaper in America," Dr. Alfred M. Lee of the Institute of Human Relations of Yale University has won the 1937 Research Award of Sigma Delta Chi, national professional journalistic society.
The White Sox touched off a home-run barrage today to come from behind for a 7-to-4 victory over Philadelphia in the opening game of the series.
A sailor sitting on the topmast of a steamship in Nagoya Bay was killed in a freakish aviation ac' cident.
Allan P. Kirby of Jersey City asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for permission to serve as a director of the New York, Chicago . St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad.

A telegram from Secretary of mob State Hull praising Juan S. Trippe, president of Pan American Airways, for strengthening friendship among the American nations was made public yesterday by the American Arbitration Association.

Yesterday's decision of the Court of Appeals in declaring unconstitutional the Catholic school bus bill brought three proposals before the Constitutional Convention today to amend the Constitution so that free transportation for parochial school children may be continued.

Prince Louis Ferdinand of Germany, son of the former Crown Prince, and his 'bride, the former Grand Duchess Kira, daughter of the Grand Duke Cyril of Russia, are arriving today from Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen and are on their way round the world.

A new and fast steamship line to operate between New York and Rio de Janeiro, Santos, Montevideo and Buenos Aires, and provide an "unexcelled steamship service between New York and South America," will be established on or about Sept. 1.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The meeting of writers who voted to indorse the proposed Federal Bureau of Fine Arts, briefly reported in your issue of Monday, really deserved more detailed treatment than you gave it,

Charles A. Wagner, member of the North Jersey District Water Supply Commission and campaign manager for Mayor Frank Hague and Governor Moore in their recent elections, died last night of pneumonia at his home here. He was 73 years old.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 24: COLONEL Olmstead, D., Signal Corps, Ft. Monmouth, N. J., to duty as Commandant, Signal Corps School, Ft. Monmouth, N. T., Aug. 1.

The Bank of New York and Trust Company, the oldest bank in New York, is planning to drop the last part of its present title and revert to the name "Bank of New York," which it carried for the first 138 years of its existence.

Alonzo J. Powers 2d, 29 years old, of 1,125 Park Avenue, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions to stealing $1,666 from the Arbor Inn Club at Princeton University. Powers, a graduate of the university, became treasurer of the club, with an office here, in July, 1936, and the thefts took place between October and December of that year.

Eleven students will be graduated this afternoon at the annual commencement exercises of the Collegiate School, to be held at 5 P. M. in the West End Collegiate Church, 245 West Seventy-seventh Street. The school was founded more than 300 years ago by the early Dutch settlers.

LOFTSMAN, Navy Yard, Charleston, S. C.; salary, $7.39, $7.87, $8.35 per diem, no allowances. Applications must be on file with the recorder, Board of Labor Employment, United States Navy Yard, Charleston, S. C., not later than June 23.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:

The annual general meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute here today, other than bringing out some of the technical problems of the industry in this country, is expected to result in a general pronouncement regarding the future policies of the industry.

Arthur M. Hyde, Secretary of Agriculture under Herbert Hoover, said today that the United States faced another and possibly more devastating depression under the Roosevelt Administration. Mr. Hyde said at a Republican rally here last night:

The Treasury Procurement Division today invited bids on a total of 57,704,900 yards of textiles as follows: Issued May 26, to be opened June 6, for complete shipment Sept. 1, except as otherwise indicated in proposals--700-T, percale, shirtings patterns, 1,031,000 yards; 701-T, birdseve, 1,284,500 yards.

At the request of defense counsel, Federal Judge William Clark granted today a delay of a week for the appearance in Federal Court here of Ellis Parker Sr., former Burlington County detective, and his son, Ellis Parker Jr., in connection with their appeal from an order of Judge Clark ordering their removal to Brooklyn for trial on indictments charging the kidnapping of Paul Wendel:

A plan for the organization on a national scale of department and specialty store buyers into groups classified according to the major merchandising divisions was initiated yesterday at a meeting of the board of directors of .the merchandising division, National Retail Dry Goods Association, at the association's offices, 101 West Thirty-first Street.

William James Mackey, assistant treasurer of the New York Trust Company, with which he had been associated since 1897, died at his home here this afternoon after an illness of two months. He was born in Brooklyn sixty-two years ago.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Cecil Horner of 21 East Tenth Street, this city, and Stonington, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Horner, to George Henry Miles Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Miles of New York and Rumson, N. J.

Jeremiah F. Connor, who was appointed by Surrogate James A. Foley in October, 1936, to investigate the claim of Robert E. Thomas, 29-year-old Hollywood actor, that he was the son of Putnam Bradlee Strong, son of the late Mayor William L. Strong, and Mary Augusta Strong, known, on the stage as May Yohe, filed a report yesterday holding that Thomas was not the son of either.

President Roosevelt discussed the Pennsylvania political situation with Governor Earle and Charles A. Jones, signed the $15,000,000 bill for a campaign against venereal diseases and sent to the Senate the nominations of Rear Admiral -James O. Richardson to be Chief of the Bureau of Navigation and Captain Walter B. Woodson to be Judge Advocate General of the Navy.

Helped by the higher freight rates granted early in the year by the Interstate Commerce Commission, aggregate railroad returns for April compiled yesterday showed an improvement compared with previous reports.

Another of the yachts built for the Bermuda race next month was launched today at the shipyard of the Luders Marine and Construction Company. She is the Escapade, a yawl designed by Philip L. Rhodes of Cox Stevens, for Henry G. Fownes.

BROWN, ANNA E. (Oct. 25, 1937). Gross assets, $14,834; net, $9,413. To Mary L. Brown, sister. Chief assets, real estate, $12,750. Sidney Meyers, attorney, 119 Nassau St. McALPIN. EDWIN A. Jr. (June 27, 1936).
Members of the International Typographical Union began voting t throughout the country yesterday in a sharply contested election to name an international president for the next two years.

Seven medals and four other prizes were presented last night to students in the Columbia University School of Architecture at the annual reunion of the school's alumni in the Columbia Men's Faculty Club, Morningside Drive, at 117th Street. Four of the medals went to Carl E. Stover of 540 West 123d Street, a senior.

The four members of the election board of the Twentieth Precinct of the Fourth Ward here were acquitted today of charges of ballot tampering and conspiracy in an election fraud by a jury in Atlantlo County Common Pleas Court before Judge Palmer M. Way.
The decline in bond values was accentuated yesterday in slower trading on the New York Stock

Davidson Ave (11-3199), w s, 200 it n of 184th St, 150x100; Van Rock Holdings, Inc, to Sam Elias, 374 E 10th St. Tibbett Ave (13-3406A), w s, 196 ft n of 230th St, 149x49; Broadfield Realty Corp to Terron Realty Corp, 2,061 Broadway.

Now that the "slinks" are almost out of the river, the men who prefer fishing for Atlantic run or "bright" salmon are awaiting word from their favorite guides on the Miramichi. The run is expected any day now.

With Cardinal Hayes presiding and many members of the-clergy among 2,000 persons present, a funeral service for John Thomas Smith, a leading Roman Catholic layman of the New York Archdiocese, was held yesterday morning in St. Peter's Church, Barclay and Church Streets.

AFTER the Seabiscuit withdrawal from the proposed big race at Belmont Park, Uncle Mike Jacobs was all a-flutter and sought a hasty report on Barney Ross and Henry Armstrong. He was assured by their trainers that neither fighter was weak in the knees and both were ready to go to the post. So the fight will go on, weather permitting.
The Phillies today won their third straight game by a one-run margin, beating Pittsburgh, 2 to 1, as Bucky Walters conquered Jim Tobin in a pitchers' battle for his fourth victory of the season.
Clarence Doser of Merion, Jimmy Thomson of Shawnee and Terl Johnson of Plymouth, Pa., today qualified for the -national professional golf tourney to be played here in July.

The Japanese troops' occupation of t Lanfeng on the Lung-Hai Railway 150 miles west of Suchow is expected soon because of reports that Japanese troops had advanced west along the Lung-Hai line and also south from the Yellow River.

Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, was raked over the coals in the Senate today for his statement endorsing the Senatorial candidacy of Representative Wearin of Iowa. Mr. Wearin seeks the seat held by Senator Gillette, Democrat, who opposed President Roosevelt's proposals to reorganize the Supreme Court.

It goes without saying that every normal human being who does not live on a South Sea island wants to do so. It should have been equally obvious that every South Sea islander wants to live somewhere else. Yet one learns with something of a shock that Pitcairn Island, romantic home of the descendants of the Bounty's mutineers, can seem tedious.
Raoul P. Ferbos, a retired cherry importer, died Tuesday night in the Richmond Memorial Hospital at Princes Bay, S. I., after a long ill-ness. He was 62 years old and resided at New Dorp.

The further issuance of the 3 per cent bonds registered by the Conversion Office for German foreign debts in September, 1936, to be offered in exchange for interest coupons falling due from 1934 to Dec. 31, 1936, held by American investors in German industrial and municipal
A pencil drawing of Benjamin Franklin by Benjamin West was sold for $850 yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries. Dr. A. S. W. Rosenbach was the purchaser.
Rookie Southpaw Howard Mills, making his bow as a major league starting pitcher, hurled masterful ball for thirteen innings today to give the Browns a 4-to-3 victory over the Senators.

Hunter College's Athletic Associa- College. tion awards and numerals were announced yesterday for this term. Winners of the awards are Audrey Backer, for interest in sports; Juliet Brussel and Lillian Piller, for special merit.
Six Insurgent planes swooped down upon Alicante today in a fierce bombing that killed at least 250 persons and wounded more than 1,000.

Its disorganizing effect on industry has compelled the French to make a still further modification of their fortyhour-week law. As part of Premier Daladier's recovery program the fortyhour-week formula has been converted into 2,000 hours a year in each occupation. This will permit an elastic application in seasonal trades and the recovery of lost time because of strikes and holidays.

Senators interested in railroad legislation said today that they had abandoned hope for a compromise to permit approval at this session of more liberal loans to railroads by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

LOUIS ADAMIC'S "My America"* seems to me an extraordinarily honest and absorbing book. It is a huge, sprawling thing-about 300,000 words long-and entire chunks could have been sliced away in the editing without affecting the whole in any apparent respect. But with all its diffuseness, it is probably one of the high spots of the current season.

Protesting over the action of the Board of Education in failing to renew the contract of Thomas O. Treharne, assistant principal of Poughkeepsie High School, some 1,000 students went on strike here this afternoon.

The Philadelphia branch of the American Hosiery Workers was eliminated today as a joint defendant in the $1,171,000 damage suit brought by the Apex Hosiery Company against city and county officials as a result of a sit-down strike in the plant last Spring.
Stockholders of United Shipyards, Inc., approved yesterday at a special meeting the sale of the property and business of the company to the Bethlehem Shipbuilding CorDoration for $9,320,000.

Removal of restrictions on Jewish immigration into Palestine, so that this "natural refuge" might be opened to victims of persecution in Europe, was urged last night at a meeting in Mecca Temple, 133 West Fifty- fifth Street, arranged by the Pro-Palestine Federation of America.

A bronze and silver plaque, commemorative of his services to members of the Seventy-seventh Division in the A. E. F., was presented last night to Pelham St. George Bissell, president justice of the Municipal Court, at a dinner tendered in the Hotel Commodore by the Seventy-seventh Division Association.

Stewart Berkshire, Deputy Commissioner of Internal Revenue and head of the Treasury Department's Alcohol Tax Unit, told the House Ways and Means Committee today that the Treasury favored the enactment of a 25 cent per gallon floor tax on distilled spirits in the hands of retailers.

BRADSHAW, INGOMAR R. (May 1). Estate, more than $10,000. To Mary Nicking, sister, 1,307 South Proctor St., Tacoma, Wash., 4-28ths residue; Mrs. Walter McKenney, niece, 44 Morningside Dr., 3-28ths residue, furniture, books and clothing; Olga Bradshaw, 95 Arthur St., Ridgefield Park, N. J., 4-28ths residue and 1-3 of 1-28th residue; Arthur W.

A middle-aged housewife of motherly appearance crocheted a doily today while sitting as a juror in a murder trial here before Acting County Judge James W. Bailey, whose home county is Putnam. The attorneys and the two defendants made no protest and the judge said it would be "ridiculous" to object. Women can crochet and listen at the same time, he asserted.
Otto W. Spidel, city forester for twenty years and responsible for the planting of the shrubs, flowers and trees of Milwaukee's parks and boulevards, died today.

Mrs. W. Barrett Brown of Edgar Mr. Manor, Greenwich, entertained at a dinner tonight preceding the opening of the cinema-concert series sponsored by the Greenwich Unit of the New York Junior League. Her guests included Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Dixon of New York,

The annual report for 1937 of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which was issued yesterday, describes the general. policy of the Federal Reserve Banks last year as having been one of maintaining an ample supply of funds at low rates of interest. Emphasis in this policy, the bank says,

Buying programs for the remainder of this year should be based on the assumption that business activity will increase and commodity prices rise in the coming months, Roger W. Babson, economist, said today in a message read at the third day's session of the twenty-third annual convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, in the Hotel Jefferson here.
Pete Scalzo, 127 3/4, Astoria, gained the decision over Georgie Karkella, 128, Brooklyn, in the feature eightround bout at the Queensboro Arena in Long Island City last night.

Rain prevented play in two first-class English cricket matches today and curtailed play in others. The Australians' start against Hampshire at Southampton was postponed until tomorrow, and the Sussex-Somerset match at Taunton also was delayed a day.

Ernest W. Boissevain is with Baker, Weeks Harden as assistant manager of their office at 6 Lothbury, London. The Chase National Bank has been appointed registrar for the common stock of Triumph Explosives, Inc.

Fur merchandise for August sales purposes will be available within three to four weeks if the tentative agreement for settlement of the fifteen-week fur strike is ratified at membership meetings of both the manufacturers' group and the union to be held this morning, Louis White, president of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimmings Manufacturers, Inc., said here yesterday.

To the currently expanding means of musical expression, the polychord, introduced to this country last night in Town Hall, must now take its dubious place in a world that has next to nothing to express. It is the invention of Evangelos Tsamourtzis,

Thomas Newhall of this city, a former partner in Drexel Co. and now vice president of the Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company, was elected today a director of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, succeeding Percival Roberts Jr., who resigned recently.
The State Supreme Court in a six-to-one decision today put a serious obstacle in the way of the projected grand jury investigation of the Earle administration and Democratic party leaders.
Shipments of pneumatic casings in April amounted to 3,199,363 units, compared with 2,877,660 in March and 5,560,453 in April, last year, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association.
Officials of the Fox Valley Jockey Club said today Ben Jones, trainer of Lawrin, had withdrawn the Kentucky Derby winner from the $12,000 added Illinois Derby Saturday.

The relief crisis in Chicago and a few downState communities was relieved today when Governor Horner signed bills, sped through the Legislature, increasing the State's direct relief allotments to an .all-time peak of $3,400,000 a month. The increase of $500,000 was released at once for immediate needs.

A supplemental grant of $608,331 from the Federal Social Security Board dissipated yesterday the threat of payless paydays for the administrative staff of the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department.

Judgments totaling $58,151 against Ludwig Baumann Co., Inc., 500 Eighth Avenue, for alleged failure to make full sales tax returns from Sept. 1, 1935, to June 30, 1937, were filed yesterday by William Reid, City Collector.

The international executive board of the United Mine Workers of America accepted the resignation of William Green today and in a formal resolution charged that he had "betrayed" his own union and the principle of industrial unionism for which it stands. Mr. Green resigned in February.
More than fifty spokesmen for business and agriculture met here today on invitation from Senator Bulkley to discuss the formation of a national council to advise the government.
Cotton production last year amounted to 18,945,022 bales, the highest on record, the Crop Reporting Board of the Department of Agriculture announced today.

The New Bedford (Mass.) Fish Company asked the United States District Court today for an injunction to force the Philadelphia local of the United Sea Workers, A. F. of L, affiliate, to handle the company's shipments in this district.

Montgomery St, 21, 20.1x75; trustee of will of George Graham to Frieda Kirschenbaum, 25 Montgomery St, consideration, $2,200. 4th St, 266 E, 24.9x96.2; Henry Lichtig to Dry Dock Savings Institution; consideration, $1,000, foreclosure.

Mrs. Francis P. Garvan of Roslyn House, Roslyn, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mabel Brady Garvan, to Robert Philip Noble. Miss Garvan-daughter of the late Francis P. Garvan, is a granddaughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Anthony N. Brady of Albany
Mrs. Eleanor Vanderburgh Morrison, president of the Aeolian Choir and member of the Contemporary Club here, died suddenly in her home yesterday at the age of 41.

Happy Chandler, Governor of Kentucky, has called Mr. Barkley, his rival for the Senatorship, "a stranger." The Governor is strongly convinced that Mr. Barkley ought to be weaned from Washington and gradually acclimatized in his old Kentucky home. Panting for the adjournment of Congress, Mr. Barkley is sometimes able to spend a weekend among the home folks.

In a deal involving an aggregate of more than $1,000,000 in rentals and taxes, the F. W. Woolworth Company has obtained a long-term lease, to take effect July 1, 1939, on the properties known as 320-22 Jackson Avenue and 148 Claremont Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., it was announced yesterday.
79th St. 303-5 E, two 4-story tenements, 55x102.2 x irreg; Bank for Savings in the City of New York against Bella Carasso; due, $83,994; taxes, etc. $1,000; to plaintiff for $20,000.
