The American Academy in Rome announced yesterday that its Rome prize in architecture this year, the William Rutherford Mead Fellowship, had been won by Erling F. Iversen, a 27-year-old Princeton student.

Mrs. John French of Greenwich, Conn.,-was elected president of the Young Women's Christian Association yesterday morning at the annual meeting at national headquarters, 600 Lexington Avenue. Mrs. French succeeds Mrs. Frederick M. Paist of Wayne, Pa., president for the last six years.

The library of the late Francis Ralston Welsh of Devon, Pa., which was sold Tuesday and yesterday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, realized $14,261. The two highest prices at the final session last night were both paid by Mrs. Ben H. Freedman.

In a ruling today on the maximum fees which may be paid to trustees and others rendering services in consection with the reorganization of the Utilities Power and Light Corportion in the Federal court in Chicago, the Securities and Exchange Commission in some instances sharply reduced the amounts for which application had been made.

The College of Pharmacy of Columbia University will hold its 108th annual commencement to night in the McMillin Academic Theatre, Broadway and 116th Street. Sixty-eight members of the graduating class will receive degrees.

Commencement exercises for the graduating class of the New York Chapter, American Institute of Banking, will be held tonight in the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street. Certificates will be bestowed upon 224 graduates.

The marriage of Miss Genevieve Marian Heide, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Louis Heide of 210 Riverside Drive, to Edward John McCrossin Jr. of Brooklyn, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. McCrossin, took place yesterday morning. Lighted tapers and peonies were used to decorate the Church

Donald F. Carroll Jr., 16-year-old boy on trial for murder, took the witness stand in his own behalf yesterday in Queens County Court, admitted the killing of his 18-yearold sweetheart last March, and insisted that a desire to save her life after he had fired a bullet through her heart prevented his taking his own life as well.

Gas Advisers, Inc., New York City, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application for approval as a mutual service company to perform services for subsidiaries of the Cities Service Company.

In the wake of the country's leading women tennis players, who are in England preparing for the Wightman Cup matches, Donald Budge and Gene Mako sailed yesterday on board the United States liner President Roosevelt.
Marius Russo, youthful lefthander, hurled Newark to an 8to-2 victory over Jersey City today. Russo fanned twelve Little Giants, walked four and gave six hits as he registered his fourth victory.
All deliveries of wheat in the leading world markets, with the exception of the May at Winnipeg, dropped to new low levels for the season today.

Twenty or more of former Sheriff Theodore R. Middleton's deputies were gathered at the Harlan County Court House on the day that Bennett Musick, son of a union organizer, was murdered, said Clinton C. Ball, former jailer and a political enemy of Middleton, today in a hillbilly brogue so-thick that even natives had trouble following his recital.

James J. Hines, known as Jimmy by thousands of residents of the Eleventh Assembly District, on the upper. West Side, has been a shadowy figure in New York politics for more than ten years, and has sometimes been considered the unofficial leader of Tammany Hall.

In so far as they embarrass the State Department, the public speeches delivered by members of the Administration condemning or criticizing either the regime or the policies of other Governments justify the rebuke implied in the Baltimore speech of the Under-Secretary of State.

It is important to keep clearly in view the real responsibility of Congress in the matter of the TVA inquiry which was begun yesterday. The joint committee is not investigating a quarrel between executives which is only incidentally the affair of Congress.
The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the following from New York had withdrawn their registrations as over-the-counter brokers or dealers:

Miss Lois Bradley, daughter of Mrs. Mark Spaulding Bradley of this place, will be married to John Goodwin Tracy, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Dwight W. Tracy of The Hartford, on June 11 in the Asylum Avenue Bapntist Church. Hartford.

A home run with two on in the sixth inning by Korny Kornowitz featured Manual Training High's victory over St. Michael's, 8-1, at the Parade Grounds, Brooklyn, yesterday. The game brought together a Brooklyn P. S. A. L. nine and a Brooklyn C. H. S. A. A. team.

Faced with the prospect of returning to Germany because she had failed to certify that she would not become a public charge, Luise Wolf, 37-year-old German Jewish woman, plunged to her death yesterday morning from the fifth floor of the Clara de Hirsch Home for Working Girls, 225 East Sixty-third Street, where she had lived since her arrival here on April 19.

The forty-seventh general meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute will convene this morning for a one-day session in the Waldorf-Astoria and will hear addresses by some of the leaders of the industry. The morning session will be devoted to talks by the president. T. M. Girdler,

Miss Ann Carroll Meem, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Grant Meem, was married this afternoon to Edward Beale McLean Jr., son of Edward Beale McLean and Mrs. Evalyn Walsh McLean. The ceremony was performed by Mgr. Edward Buckey
Dartmouth blanked Yale, 10-0, today, sending nine runs across the plate in the sixth inning, of their Eastern Intercollegiate League game.

The Queen Mary, flagship of the White Star Cunard Line, will complete two years of service while at sea tomorrow on the way to Plymouth, Cherbourg and Southampton. She sailed yesterday with nearly 1,500 passengers and with arrangements for a celebration which will be held tonight at midnight.

Four held a Arabs were shot early today in Haifa in different parts of the city. ard Josep] One was killed instantly, another the JewisH died in a hospital and two were seriously wounded. A communique CHILE said the assailants were believed to be Jews.

Fourteen oil companies and eleven executives now awaiting trial in Madison, Wis., on charges of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Law have decided to enter pleas of nolo contendere and to pay maximum fines

Funeral services for Erskine Hewitt, grandson of the late Peter Cooper, son of the late Mayor Abram S. Hewitt and a director of many corportions, were held at 10 A. M. in yesterday in Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church.

An unusual set of tidal and shipping conditions held the Italian liner Conti di Sovoia at quarantine all day yesterday with her 900 passengers, while several hundred persons waited on the pier to meet incoming friends and relatives or went to the movies until docking time.

In its midsummer salesbook now in the mail, Sears, Roebuck Co. have cut prices on comparable lines which appeared in the January catalogue by an average of 12.01 per cent. The decreases range through all of the nineteen merchandise lines represented in the book.

When the British King and Queen visit here at the end of June the French authorities will protect them as well as the Italians protected Chancellor Hitler. The police already are checking up on residents of houses lining the various routes along which the monarchs will travel to various functions.

Argentina today celebrated the 128th anniversary of its revolution by publicly repudiating fascism and other forms of ideological dictatorships and strongly demanding a complete return of the democratic republican form of government.

Ten girls will receive diplomas tonight at the commencement exercises of the Scudder-Collver School, to be held at the Hotel Plaza. George Swan of Temple University will speak and James Ely of Rutherford, N. J., will present the diplomas. The school is at 35 West Twelfth Street. Miss Jean Clark is valedictorian.

Mrs. Mary D. Burgin, in 140 E 56th St; Mrs. Cornelius Tiers, in 157 E 72d St; Henry Young, in 240 E 79th St; William Simmons, in 45 E 82d St; Dr. A. Louis Brush, John A. Frank, in 55 E 86th St; Hugo Rubink, in 355 E 86th St; Leopold S Berendt, in 53 E 96th St; Albert E. Heyman, in 1,349 Lexington Ave; Duff Conger. Inc, brokers.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe, denying a request made by Carlos W. Munson to interene in proceedings to' reorganize the Munson Steamship Line, said that he would refer his claim for an equitable lien against the company to a special master.

The marriage of Miss Helen Kay Brown, daughter of Mrs. Alma V. Brown of 2 East Eighty-sixth Street and the late Dan R. Brown of Los Angeles, to Howard Richard Grode, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Grode of Oyster Bay, L. I., took place yesterday afternoon in the Brick Presbyterian Church.

Denying all charges of administrative "dishonesty" in the conduct of TVA, made by former Chairman Arthur E. Morgan, the two remaining directors, Chairman Harcourt Morgan and David E. Lilienthal, charged him today with attempting to "sabotage" the TVA in the interest of the private power companies.

The United States Steel Corporation in an amendment to its registration statement covering a proposed offering of $100,000,000 of debentures filed under the Securities Act of 1933, has named 102 underwriters who will distribute the issue and the amount of the debentures to be Anacc handled by each. Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., will head the large group.

Midshipmen John E. Dacey of Biloxi, Miss.; Paul M. Schultze Jr. of Roswell, N. M., and Frank C. Jones of New London, Conn., in that order, were announced today as the honor scholars in this year's graduating class at the Naval Academy. They will receive commissions as ensigns upon graduation and will enter the line of the navy.

The sale of Thomas Hardy's library, which began in Hodgson's rooms in Old Chancery Lane today, brought [Pound]2,700. The sale will end tomorrow. Comprising numerous autograph presentation copies of first editions and manuscripts, the list of items included in the Hardy sale reads like a catalogue of English fiction during the last half century.

Stanton St, 325-327, 29.10x81.4 1/2; Medora Gehben Cox et al to Ernest J. Gehben, 526 E. 16th St. 40th St, 328-332 W. 75x98.9; Joyce Bushel to Mutual Life Insurance Company; consideration $10,000, foreclosure.

A formal, written proposal by the Mexican Government for compensating the American oil companies for the expropriation of their properties of an estimated value of $150,000,000 was submitted to the State Department today by Francisco Castillo

" The Coming Victory of Democracy," Dr. Thomas Mann's examination of the conflict between democratic and fascist ideas in the world today. with a statement of his faith in the eventual triumph of democracy, will be published by Knopf June 20. Knopf also has ordered a new printing, the fourth, of Dr. Mann's newest novel, "Joseph in Egypt."
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reseve Banks showed the reserve note circulation for the System as a whole to be the lowest of the year to date.

A military tribunal today sentenced Corneliu Zelea Codreanu, leader of Rumania's outlawed Iron Guard, to ten years of forced labor and subsequent loss of civil rights for seven years. The court trying him on treason charges returned its verdict after three hours' deliberation.

Charley Yates or Atlana aione among the American contingent in the British amateur championship has survived today's rain, wind and bursts of extraordinarily good golf that alternately drenched, chilled and cheered large and patient galleries.
Dr. James Buchanan Seaton, Bishop of Wakefield, died here today at the age of 70 on the eve of celebrations marking the jubilee of his Yorkshire diocese.

The number of changes in the State Constitution proposed by individual delegates to the Constitutional Convention reached a total of 652 this morning and from this time on, suggestions may be submitted by delegates only through unanimous consent.

The "Volks Auto," which is intended to do for Germany what the early Ford did for popularizing the automobile in the United States, will cost 990 marks, according to an announcement here today. The- cheapest German car now costs almost twice as much.

The Japanese Government was greatly strengthened yesterday when the Cabinet was shaken up and four of the most powerful figures in the country became members to stand side by side with Prince Fumimaro Konoye, Premier.

Three judges, after listening yesterday afternoon to thirty determined boys and girls read poems of their own writing for the better part of two hours, decided, in less than thirty minutes' conference, that 16-year-old Clara Brussel's "The Idiot of the Park" had won first place in the thirteenth annual poetry contest of New York City high schools.

A block of 207 unimproved lots in the Throgs Neck section of the Bronx were bid in for $1,000 by the plaintiff at auction yesterday. These parcels are located on East 177th Street, Eastern Boulevard and Brinsmead, Huntington, Balcom, Graff, Lafayette, Barkley and

Dr. Thomas Lathrop Stedman, physician and a distinguished author on medical subjects, died yesterday at the Home for Old Men and Aged Couples, 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, after a brief illness. He was 84 years old.

Three important facts concerning the strength of the new third patty formed by the La Follette brothers are revealed in a national survey just completed by the American Institute of Public Opinion. The institute asked voters in all sections: "Have you heard of the new National Progressive party led by the La Follette brothers? Do you think you would like to join it?" The results show:

Robert T. Anderson, operator of amateur radio transmitter W9MWC, Harrisburg, Ill., has been selected for the 1937 William S. Paley Amateur Radio Award, it was announced yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System.
German exporters have greeted with enthusiasm the statement by Economics Minister Walther Funk that he intends to ease exchange restrictions on genuine German business men engaged in foreign trade.

The story of the collapse of the Insull financial empire was retold in a 1,000-page report and transcript of testimony filed today with Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson by- Garfield Charles, special referee in bankruptcy.

The Italian press for the first time came out in support of Germany's attitude toward Czechoslovakia after the Reich Ambassador had had a long talk with Foreign Minister Ciano. Yet most of the newspapers said a peaceful solution was possible, although they thought serious danger still existed. They protested the idea that Britain and France had won a diplomatic victory. [Page 1.]

Thirty-five students will be graduated at the annual commencement exercises of the Professional Children's School, beginning at 11 o'clock this morning, at the Morosco Theatre, 217 West Forty-fifth Street.

IT was an excited office boy who rushed in with the news. He said the fight had been postponed and he couldn't have put more importance in his tone if he had come bearing word that the Spanish strife had ended or the Japanese Army was withdrawing from China.

Although the Supreme Court on Monday upheld a Labor Board order directing reinstatement of 4,000 strikers at Remington-Rand plants, another effort was made today to protest the Second Circuit Court finding which the high court sustained.

Members of the Bond Club of New York will receive today a complete program for the club's annual field day to be held at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club on June 10. The filing of amendments to security prospectuses, it was commented, has developed into enough of a nuisance to prompt the field day committee to issue its program in a form similar to those "headaches."

A three-quarter mile run has been listed on the program for the annual Princeton invitation track meet on June 18, it was announced today by R. Kenneth Fairman, acting graduate manager of athletics, who also released the complete schedule of events. Entrants for the six track and field tests have not yet been determined.

With tear gas and flailing clubs, police cleared a crowd of 4,000 United Rubber union workers and sympathizers early today from a two-block-long stretch of Market Street at the gates of Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company's vast plant No. 1.
Making his run at dusk, Kelly Petillo of Los Angeles won a place in the starting line-up today for the 500mile Indianapolis Motor Speedway race on his third and last qualifying trial.

The New Deal "elimination committee" appeared today to have selected the Iowa primary on June 6 as the setting for the next battle in the campaign to rid the Democratic high councils of less-than-100-per-cent followers of President Roosevelt.

Form players suffered a severe setback at Churchill Downs as the Enza-Vita Stable's Beach Ensemble defeated the Woolford Farm's Robert L., prohibitive public choice, by a slim neck in the Cherokee Purse, today's six-furlong feature.

A class of fifty will receive diplomas this afternoon at the graduation exercises of the Lincoln School of Teachers College, Columbia University, to be held in the auditorium of the school. 425 West 123d Street.
Large increases in deposits of the Dominion Government and of chartered banks were shown today in the Bank of Canada's statement for the week ended yesterday.

H. R. Seddon, Professor of Veterinary Science at Brisbane University, declared at the Australian Veterinary Science Congress that painstaking research had revealed that an unidentified winged insect' caused the new cattle disease known as "three-day sickness." This malady is so serious, although brief, that when herds are affected production ceases, necessitating that dairymen in infected areas buy canned milk for domestic use.

Thirteen undergraduates have been named to the Student Hall of Fame of New York University's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance for outstanding work in extracurricular activities and high scholarships, it was announced yesterday. The list includes:

John G. Winant's election as director of the International Labor Office to succeed Harold B. Butler, who has resigned, seems to be generally expected in International Labor Organization circles now following reports from Washington that the Administration favors it.

The Rev. Dr. William T. Walsh, rector of St. Luke's Church, will be the speaker this afternoon at the commencement exercises of the Scoville School for Girls, at the MacDowell Club, 166 East Seventythird Street.

Rioting started late this afternoon at the plant of the American Brass Company as employes started to leave for the day and fifty persons were injured. Among them were four policemen who were taken to hospitals after one of them had accidentally discharged what he believed to be an empty tear-gas gun.

Following declines through the 8 1/2-cent resistance level on Tuesday, liquidation on the Cotton Exchange gained momentum yesterday and pirces broke another $1 a bail to end with losses of 13 to 17 points.

A syndicate headed by Henry Litvin bought the five-and-one-halfstory apartment house at 693 East 236th Street, the Bronx, containing twenty-six suites. The sale was negotiated by Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., brokers,

More than 250 Barnard College seniors will become alumnae unofficially tonight at the traditional step singing ceremony, the opening event of senior week, when the senior class president, Edna Jones, gives her cap and gown to Elizabeth Jackson, the president of the new senior class.

Dr. Douglass Southall Freeman, 52, editor of The Richmond, Va., News-Leader and Pulitzer Prize winning historian, suffered cuts and bruises; his daughter, Miss Mary Freeman, 21, was seriously injured, and their Negro chauffeur, Howard Carter, was killed in a truck-automobile collision today.

Following yesterday's German protests of alleged Czech violations of the German frontier in three places, the Czechoslovak official news agency today handed to the German official agency a list of no fewer than thirty-four violations of the Czech frontier by German planes.

In Alaska the inhabitants hold a Yukon sweepstakes as often as Nature permits, which is once a year. The lucky person guessing nearest to the exact moment when the ice will start down-river gets a prize. This year, if memory serves, the pool came to $15,000 and went, by poetic justice, to a happy couple who needed that amount, or a little less, to get married on.

The abolition of war is not only possible but certain, according to a resolution adopted yesterday by the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War at its Spring board meeting in the Y. W. C. A. Building, 600 Lexington Avenue.

The income of the General Motors Building at Broadway and Fiftyseventh Street increased more than $40,000 a year on May 1, as compared with May 1, 1937, the Charles F. Noyes Company, agent, reported yesterday.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Winifred Goodman, daughter of Mrs. Claude Layton Goodman of Newport News, Va., to Ensign Charles H. Turner, U. S. N., son of Mrs. George Turner and the late Mr. Turner of Savannah, Ga.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Those editors who are crusading for State lotteries in the name of righteousness remind me of the old jingle: I damn the sins I have a mind to, And ask for those I am inclined to. Like everything else in this era of the "smart life," morality is being streamlined.

Gold-mining shares continued as an active feature in the generally quiet stock markets here today. Western Holdings was in strong demand and West Africans attracted firm support. Gilt-edge issues were quiet, but the tendency was toward firmness. Foreign bonds mostly were unchanged. Transatlantic stocks were uncertain and International Nickel closed lower.

Industrial production and originating freight shipments after allowance for seasonal factors advanced moderately last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh, but the volume of trade reflected a further pronounced drop and as a result the adjusted index of business declined fractionally.

A thousand high school students today ended a strike begun yesterday in protest against the dismissal of Thomas O. Treharne, assistant principal, as about 200 pupils in a similar school in South Glens Falls, N. Y., "walked out."

The Negrin Government in Barcelona has dismissed its two remaining international divisional commanders and has given orders that all international brigade commanders also are to be relieved of their commands, the writer learned from some returning foreign officers here today.

Syracuse closed its lacrosse season today with a 17-to-9 victory over the University of Toronto. Sophomore Bill Ritch headed the victors' attack with five goals. The Orange had a 9-to-5 lead at half time and increased the margin after the intermission.

The Semple School, 351 Riverside Drive, will hold its fortieth commencement tonight at the Hotel Plaza, with Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck and the Rev. Nathan Seagle, rector of St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, as speakers. Mrs. T. Darrington Semple, founder and principal of the school, will preside. A reception and dance will follow the presentation of diplomas.

The Nieuwe Rotterdamsche Courant, which eschews sensations, announces this evening that evidence indicates Soviet secret police activity behind Monday's Coolsingel explosion, in which a foreigner named Novacs was killed. According to the Newspaper, Mr. Novacs was probably a leader of the Ukrainian Nationalist movement and therefore on Moscow's blacklist.
Meat is going up in price. With the exception of veal, all cuts of all meats average 6 cents a pound more than they did three months ago. Veal has dropped about 2 cents a pound.

A Federal Highway Appropriation Bill carrying $507,500,000 was reported to the House and Senate by a conference committee today. It is expected to be approved an early date and sent to the White House for approval.

Frank O. Lowden, former Governor of Illinois, said on his return from Europe yesterday that Republican prospects for 1940 appeared much better than in 1936 and that the country was losing confidence in the "new philosophy" of the present Administration.

Willett H. Clark, brother of the late Eugene C. Clark, who twenty-five years ago was president of Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company, which has mills here, died today at his home. Mr. Clark, who was associated with the Smith concern for fifty-seven years, had headed the weaving department.

Unanimous agreement-with the notable exception of Russia-on the new British formulae for evacuation of foreign "volunteers" from Spain and isolation of both warring groups from imports calculated to carry on the war was reached today in the first Fruitful meeting the Non-Intervention Committee has held in many months.

A net income of $1,761,491 was reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on March 31 by the Todd Shipyards Corporation and its subsidiaries. The income, which does not include the equity in earnings of the Todd-Johnson Dry Docks, Inc., amounting to $214,829, is after depreciation, Federal income taxes and surtax on undistributed profits.

Mrs. Rose Abraham, widow of Abraham Abraham, who founded the firm of Abraham Straus, died yesterday at her home, 875 Park Avenue, after a brief illness at the age of 86. A native of New York, Mrs. Abraham was the daughter of Elias Epstein and Charlotte Friedman Epstein.

Defense psychiatrists testified in the Queens County Court yesterday that Donald F. Carroll Jr., 16-yearold high school student, was insane, but psychiatrists for the State declared him sane when he shot and killed his 18-year-old sweetheart, Charlotte Matthiesen, March 24, in the Carroll home at 37-37 Seventyeighth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.

Average daily sales of chain drug stores in April were 4.7 per cent lower than April, 1937, and 2.8 per cent up from March of this year, according to preliminary estimates made public today by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

H. E. Morriss's Pasch was back at 2 to 1 today in the Derby betting. In a Victoria Club callover last night odds against the favored colt's winning next Wednesday's classic were lengthened to 5 to 2, but leading bookmaking establishments quoted him at 2 to 1 today.

The New Theatre League will hold its biennial conference here for two days, beginning June 10. On that night the league will sponsor two one-act plays to be acted by Negroes-Langston Hughes's "Don't You Want to Be Free?" to be performed by the Harlem Suitcase Theatre, and Alice Holdship Ware's "Mighty Wind a'Blowin,' " in which the New Haven Progressive Players will be seen.

With the acceptance yesterday of the entry of Tom Berkeley of U. C. L. A. the total colleges in the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A; track and field championships at Randalls Island Stadium a week from today and tomorrow has mounted to thirty-one.

A conference with Roswell Magill, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, has been arranged for next Wednesday in Washington for the Attorneys General of several States, as well as for representatives of- Port Authorities and Port Commissions throughout the country, it became known here today.
Highway engineers and members of Congress from four States exchanged assurances of cooperation today in a move to build an express highway between Jersey City and Washington.

Russia is slowly closing her gates to foreigners by reducing the issuance of visas, according to reports received here. The admission of visitors has not been stopped entirely, but the application of a stricter policy is noticeable. The reason is assumed to be connected with the internal situation in Russia.

B. A. Tompkins, vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, has been elected a director of the Babcock Wilcox Company. The Chase National Bank has been appointed registrar for common stock of Triumph Explosives, Inc.
Furniture production has shown comparative stability for four consecutive months, according to a bulletin issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants.

Urging rapid agreement on a program between retailers and toilet goods producers for self-censorship to- prevent violation of the Federal Trade Commission Act and the new Wheeler-Lea law, Irving C. Fox, counsel for the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said yesterday
Although they got only six hits off Bob Carpenter, the Chiefs beat Jersey City, 4 to 2, in their series opener before 4,300 tonight. Syracuse bunched four blows for three runs in the third.
Reaffirmation of the 1923 "triple agreement" among Princeton, Harvard and Yale regarding the conduct of athletics was announced simultaneously last night by the presidents of the three institutions,

Commencement exercises of Miss Hewitt's classes, of 74 East Seventy-ninth Street, were held yesterday afternoon at the Junior League Clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street. Miss Caroline D. Hewitt, principal, and Miss Barbara Symmes, alumnae president, spoke. Miss Joyce Ward,

Dr. Nikolai Sokoloff, national director of the Federal music project, today was granted a leave of absence by Mrs. Ellen S. Woodward, assistant WPA Administrator, to enable him to accept a recently extended invistation to conduct the Seattle Symphony Orchestra during part of the 1938-39 concert season.

Sales of stocks in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on May 21 exceeded purchases by a narrow margin, 4,350 shares being sold on balance, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. The price trend on the basis

The fact that the advocates of the Federal wage-hour measures have virtually ignored the bad experience of France with the forty-hour week law has already been remarked upon. But what is even more astonishing is that the advocates of the new national minimum wage requirements give no evidence of having studied this country's own experience with such regulation under the NRA.
Elihu Root, one-time Secretary of State and Secretary of War, left a net estate of $2,921,350 when he died last Feb. 7, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. A daughter,

20th St, 312-16 W: 6-story apartment, 49x92; Helen V. Kelchner, trustee, against Marshillver Realty Corp.; due, $93,424; taxes, etc $1,215; to plaintiff for $78,500. Water St, 260-1/2; two 5-story tenements and stores, 77.2x30.5x irreg; Frank W. Kraeger against Ida A. Kraeger; due, $23,132; to plaintiff for $15,000.

' Twenty-two students will be graduated this morning at the commencement exercises of the Spence School, 22 East Ninety-first Street. Dr. Roswell Gray Ham, president of Mount Holyoke College, will be the speaker.

Insurgent air raids on Alicante Wednesday, as reported by The Associated Press, killed 250 persons and wounded more than 1,000-that is, they hit about one out of every forty-eight of the city's inhabitants. Many of the victims were women, lined up to buy food.
Effective pitching by George Caster ended a brief White Sox winning streak at three games and gave the Athletics a 4-to-1 victory today and an even split in the two-game series.

An indictment which placed Tammany leader James J. Hines in the councils of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer's policy racket, and depicted him as a kind of vice president in charge of protection against the law, was handed up in Supreme Court yesterday by an extraordinary grand jury.
A banking group composed of B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc.; Minsch, Monell Co., Inc.; Colyer, Robinson Co., Inc., and Van Deventer, Spear Co., Inc., has obtained $550,000 of general fund

Sales and leases of dwellings in scattered sections formed the bulk of realty transactions reported yesterday in Manhattan. The three-story dwelling at 235 East Seventy-second Street, on a plot 17.6 by 102.2 was sold by James O. Post to Theodore S. Miller,

Jack Wilson held Cleveland to five hits, one of them a ninth-inning home run by Ken Keltner, to pull Boston within two games of the leagueleading Indians today. Jimmy Foxx's tenth circuit blow contribute to the 8-4 victory.

Governor Earle's Constitution Commemoration Committee found itself today without a place for its observance of Ratification Day on June 21, when Mayor S. Davis Wilson refused the use of Independence Hall.

William Asip, a detective for more than thirty years, died early yesterday at the Holy Family Hospital after suffering a heart attack while attending a Catholic Charities dinner at the Columbus Club, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn. His age was 59.

The general level of wholesale prices rose during the week ended on May 21, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index of the bureau, based on the 1926 average as 100, was 78.2, compared with 77.8 on May 14 and 87.4 on May 22, 1937. Sharp increases in prices of farm products and foods accounted for the rise.

Justice Department officials said today that they had found no evidence of violation of a Federal law in the disappearance of Mrs. Alice McDonnell Parsons from her Long Island squab farm in 1937 and turned over their records to local authorities.
This week's Federal Reserve statistics repeated the familiar story of expanding bank reserves and contracting bank credit with extra emphasis in the way of some new records for recent years.

Mrs. Jean Pardee Clark, first woman member of the New Haven Board of Aldermen, organizer of amateur theatrical companies and magazine and newspaper writer, died last night in St. Raphael's Hospital after a two days' illness.

In a move obviously calculated toward healing the seventy-five year schis in American Presbyterianism, a General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America today elected a Southerner as its Moderator, for the first time in forty-six years.

Messages of congratulation came to Marlborough House from all parts of the world today as Queen Mary celebrated her seventy-first birthday. Warships and government buildings throughout the country were decorated in her honor and a royal salute was fired at all military establishments.

Dr. John F. (Jafsie) Condon, of Lindbergh case fame, traded in his old automatic yesterday, bought a new revolver and took some target practice, for which he received a high rating. He also joked with reporters who caught up with him.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 24: CAPTAINS Root, E. S., Puget Sound, Wash., on July 6 t6 duty as Chief of Staff and Aide, Commandant 11th Naval District, San Diego. Stanley, E. D., Washington, D. C., to duty with Peruvian Government, in May or June.

Dr. Josiah Meigh, 67 years old, former borough physician and president of the Somerset County Medical Society, was found dead with a bullet in, his head and a pistol In his hand this afternoon in the basement of his home here.

The marriage of Miss Fay Devereux Keith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Slack Keith of 1,060 Fifth Avenue and Brightwaters, L. I., to Donald Francis Haggerty of Larchmont, N. Y., took place yesterday morning in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.

Fieldston Rd (13-3415R), w s, 72 ft no of 252d St. 72x125; John J. Kennedy to William J. Schumacher, 1 Lafayette Ave, Peekskill, N. Y.; mtge, $15,000. Rombouts Ave (17-49-50; 11-3-69), s w cor of Light St. l 100x20; also Lafontaine Ave, e s, 84 ft s of 180th St., 15x100;

Both communist and fascist systems have an "inherent disrespect for human personality," the graduating class of the New York Chapter, American Institute of Banking, was told last night by the Rev. Dr. Lloyd E. Foster, minister of Calvary Church, East Orange, N. J. The exercises for the class of 224 were held at the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twentyninth Street.

The rain jinx which stymied Barney Ross in September, 1934, as he faced a defense of his world welterweight title against Jimmy McLarnin, overtook the Chicagoan again yesterday and forced a postponement of the scheduled fifteenround bout in defense of the crown against Henry Armstrong, world

The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, will be the speaker tonight at the commencement exercises of the Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music, 120 Claremont Avenue. A total of 102 students will receive degrees and diplomas.

Mrs. Elizabeth Bonnell Wick, widow of Myron C. Wick; a pioneer steel manufacturer of Youngstown, Ohio, died here today at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Thomas E. Hardenbergh, at the age of 82. Mrs. Wick, who had been visiting here since Saturday, lived in Youngstown.

The Senators rode a home-run wave to a 12-to-10 victory over the Browns today in a slugging contest that sent seven pitchers to the showers. It was a big sixth inning that sent the victors on their way. The score was 4-to 2 against them when Zeke Bonura hit for the circuit.
Mlle. Jadwiga Jedrzejowska, Polish champion, defeated Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan of the American Wightman Cup tennis team, 3-6, 6-3, 6-2, today in the fourth round of the Middlesex tournament.

Rain wiped out the third and concluding game of the series between the Giants and Cardinals at the Polo Grounds yesterday and sent the bewildered Gas House Gang scurrying out of here in almost record time.

The four-story dwelling with store at 204 Fourth Avenue, on the southwest corner of Sackett Street, Brooklyn, was sold by the Bank for Savings to Guy Nimmo, who will use the property for his own occupancy when alterations are completed.

President Roosevelt made known that he would announce his action on the Tax Bill in a radio address at Arthurdale, W. Va., tomorrow. He conferred with Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, on railway legislation, Senator Duffy on the political situation in Wisconsin and the nation and discussed the plight of Chinese refugees with Father Jacquinot de Besanger. He departed tonight for Arthurdale.

Crooning Water, owned by Mrs. James Cox Brady of New Jersey, probably will go to the post favorite in the Mianus Plate at a mile and a half on the flat at the meeting of the Fairfield and Westchester Hounds at Rye tomorrow. The Mianus is the last race on a card of six.

Patrolman Edward Fogarty, 56 years old, a familiar figure at Broadway and Liberty Street in the financial district where he had been directing traffic for several years, committed suicide early yesterday in his home at 746 Hancock Street, the Bushwick district of Brooklyn. He had been under treatment for a nervous ailment.

Claude M. Baker of San Francisco, strong supporter of the American Federation of Labor, held a substantial lead yesterday in returns of the election for president of the International Typographical Union against Charles P. Howard, incumbent and secretary of the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook, who signed the bench warrant under which James J. Hines was arrested yesterday, made a special trip from Albany late Monday night to be in New York City Tuesday morning to sign the papers.

Miss Frances Myra Strauss, daughter of Mrs. Lester W. Strauss of the Hotel Raleigh and the late Mr. Strauss, was married to Dr. Henry L. Lichtenberg, son of Mrs. Elias Lichtenberg of this city and the late Mr. Lichtenberg, yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Olcott by the Rev. Dr. William F. Rosenblum.

Net aggregate operating income of the first thirty-three railroads to report for April showed a decline of 68.2 per cent from the corresponding total for last year. In March, these companies showed a decline of 75.3 per cent on this basis.

Hogs closed active today and all interests got into the trade where the market weakened. All slaughter classes of cattle cleaned up well after a slow opening on fed steers and yearlings. Lambs sold steady, with native springers up to $9.25 and odd lots higher, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

MANHATTAN BABBITT, LUCIE C. (April 20, 1937). Gross assets, $340,681; net, $307,057. To Eleanor Babbitt and Genevieve B. Smith, daughters, jewelry, household effects, wearing apparel and one-third residue each; Theodore Babbitt, son, household effects, personal effects and one-third residue: Theodore F., Thomas C.

A Federal court jury last night returned a verdict for $750 in favor of Dr. Smith Ely Jelliffe, alienist, against Harry K. Thaw. Do. Jelliffe sued Thaw for $10,000 plus interest from 1908, for services in Thaw's trial for the murder of Stanford White, in which he was acquitted on the ground of insanity.

Each of the following Corps of Engineers Reserve officers is ordered to active duty, effective June 17, at Fort Du Pont Del., for training: 1st Lt. Edward A. Hammer, 342d Engrs., general service, 166 Schaeffer St., Brooklyn. N. Y.
Ending a twenty-six-day extra session Congress adjourned at noon today until the next session convenes July 20.

Rear Admiral Thomas Pickett Magruder, retired naval officer, whose gallantry under fire in Cuba during the Spanish-American War won him fame, died of a heart attack today. His age was 70. Funeral services will be held here tomorrow. Burial will be in Arlington National Cemetery.

The New Jersey Federation of Women's Clubs, at its forty-fourth annual convention at Chalfonte-Haddon Hall here, went on record today in favor of prohibition on loans and credits to aggressor nations, reciprocal trade agreements and uniform marriage and divorce laws.

A delegation of more than 100 American Slovaks landed today at Gydnia from the Polish liner Batory with the original of the wartime "Pittsburgh Declaration" announcing the Czechs' and Slovaks' decision to form the Czechoslovak State.
President Roosevelt signed today a bill authorizing the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to waive its claims for assessments against the stockholders of insured banks which fail.

James Forbes, American playwright, died of heart disease here today in a private clinic connected with the Municipal Hospital. He was 66 years old. Mr. Forbes had been in Bad Nauhelm taking the waters for about ten days and when his condition rapidly became worse he was hurried to the hospital here.

Richard Tobin McDonough, a featured radio guitarist, who had been heard on numerous Columbia and National Broadcasting programs, died on Wednesday at the Leroy Sanitarium after an operation. He lived at 324 East Forty-first Street. His age was 34. He was an alumnus of Georgetown.

Commencement exercises of the Horace Mann School for Girls will be held tonight in the Horace Mann auditorium at Broadway and 120th Street. Dean Marjorie Hope Nicolson of Smith College will be the speaker. Forty girls will be graduated.

Former associates in the ministry and the laity participated yesterday in the dedication of a new chapel in the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue, between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets, which was constructed in memory of the Rev. Dr. George Alexander, pastor of that congregation. for forty-six years.
Judge Albert S. C. Millar personally wrote a sign today which American Federation of Labor pickets could carry in their parade in front of a restaurant.

The army and the navy should be used whenever needed to end labor trespassing, particularly in sit-down strikes, Senator Josiah W. Bailey of North Carolina, outspoken critic of the New Deal, declared here last night. He addressed an approving gathering of manufacturers and inindustrialists at the annual dinner of

Pursuing their inquiry into the flight of Dr. Ignatz T. Griebl, a leading witness in the spy investigation who found refuge in Germany, Federal officials yesterday subpoenaed Captain Adolf Ahrens of the liner Bremen and several of his crew to appear today before the Federal grand jury.
Representative Treadway of Massachusetts introduced a resolution today to provide for a joint committee to work out "some fixed principle of taxation."

Manhattan ADLER, PAUL (May 23). Estate, more than $20,000. To Eleanor S. Adler; widow, executrix, 993 5th Ave., household, personal effects, remainder in onethird of $250,000 and life estate in twothirds residue; Ernest Adler, father, 948
Somewhere in the Pacific, pursued by the Coast Guard cutter Shoshone, are three Santa Cruz High School youths who stole a 52-foot yacht yesterday and started out to see the world.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 25: BRIGADIER GENERAL Shinkle, E. M., assistant to the chief of ordnance, three months' leave, June 1, with permission to visit foreign countries.

The air of secrecy with which business men surround reciprocal buying will sooner or later prompt a thoroughgoing Congressional investigation of the subject, which "is likely cause considerable embarrassment to some company executives," Dr. Howard T. Lewis, Professor of Marketing, Graduate School of Business Administration, Harvard University, warned purchasing men at the closing session of the twentythird annual convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents in the Hotel Jefferson here today.

CAPTAINS OUTRAGEOUS, by Morton Gill Clark. (Morrow, $3.) An account of a voyage from Tahiti to Cannes in a chartered yacht. MAN THE SLAVE AND MASTER, by Mark Graubard. (Covici, Friede, $3.50.) A biologist's vision of the future of society.
Walter Senior of California today was appointed coach of the junior Davis Cup preparatory squads of the Middle States Tennis Association by Harry Wieland, president of the association.

A Federal court order that would prohibit Jersey City authorities from interfering with the exercise of five of six civil rights which the C. I. O., the American Civil Liberties Union and affiliated organizations and individuals said had been denied them was tentatively agreed to yesterday after a day-long hearing in Newark.

Railway. and bus terminals, airports and other transportation centers will be thronged today and tonight with New Yorkers planning to spend the three-day Memorial Day week-end away from this city. Additional travelers will leave tomorrow and Sunday.
Spanish Insurgent planes tonight destroyed a group of houses near the international railroad station here in combined bombardment of Cerbere and Portbou, Spain, only 100 yards across the border.

Mr. and Mrs. John B. Aspegren entertained with a dinner last night in the roof garden of the Pierre for Miss Phyllis I. R. Gillespie and her fiance Alan T. Schumacher. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Bruce F. E. Harvey, Mr. and Mrs. John W. Delafield, Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Evans, Mr. and Mrs. Spencer Eddy Jr.,

Officials of several intercoastal ship lines left last night for Washington to protest before a Maritime Commission hearing today against the proposal of the International Mercantile Marine Company to transfer the five ships of the Baltimore Mail Line from the transatlantic to intercoastal service.

The strike of 15,000 fur workers, which began with a lockout fifteen weeks ago, was ended yesterday with ratification by members of the International Fur Workers Union and the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc., of a new three-year agreement brought about through the mediation of Dr. Paul Abelson, impartial chairman of the industry.
From the mines of Harlan County there came today a string of union members to point accusing fingers at men the government charges with plotting a reign of terror against them.

The British Government is now particularly preoccupied by the problem of Poland. It is held that that country may well hold the key to peace or war in Central Europe at present. It is an undisputed fact that Chancellor Hitler last week-end received a warning from Warsaw that he must not expect Poland to remain neutral if Britain joins France to resist German invasion of Czechoslovakia.
Edith Montlack, pianist, will give a lecture-recital on modern composers this evening at the Biosophical Institute, 23 West Eighty-seventh Street.

A contra-seasonal decline in lumber production last week lowered the adjusted index to 58.7 from 61.0. The figure was 93.8 for the week ended May 22, 1937. Shipments rose sharply from the preceding week's totals, and orders also were higher, according to the special reports wired to THE NEW YORK TIMES by the various regional...

John J. Casale, 'Inc., a trucking concern operating in New York and vicinity, was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to issue $581,976 of equipment purchase notes, of which $281,976 will be issued in substitution for notes now outstanding, and $300,000 for the financing of new equipment.
Manager Joe McCarthy gave his Yankee batting order an overhauling today, moving Joe DiMaggio up to third place and restoring Lou Gehrig to the cleanup spot.

President Roosevelt informed Representative Charles A. Buckley of New York today that he had no intention of discontinuing WPA whitecollar projects in New York City and that the Works Progress Administration had made provision to continue them.

The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement covering $33,000,000 of 3% per cent bonds and an issue of convertible debentures of not more than $42,303,840, nor less than $39,063,195, naming seventy-seven underwriters.

Sage Chapel on the Cornell University campus was crowded today for funeral services of Dr. George F. Warren, head of the department of farm management, New York State College of Agriculture, Cornell University.

Inscolt ran away with the featured Rockford claiming purse at the Aurora race track today, scoring by four lengths over Mannerly, with Almac third. Jockey L. Lake rushed Inscolt away alertly and never relinquished the lead.
One British constable and six Arab rebels lost their lives today in a combat between police and rebels. Early in the afternoon a mine was found near the Jewish colony of Herzlia.

The executive board of the United Mine Workers of America declared today its complete support of the National Labor Relations Board and the National Labor Relations Act, and "condemned the combined attack which has been made on the NLRB by reactionary employers, press and courts as an attack upon the rights and the interests of labor and the American people as a whole."

Street sweepers in the busy sections of all boroughs have been starting work at 4:45 A. M., two hours earlier than usual, since last Monday, in order to have the streets clean before heavy traffic and parking develop, William J. Powell, Deputy Commissioner of Sanitation in charge of street cleaning, said yesterday.
An auction sale of the Francis Ralston Welsh collection of procelains, jades and other art objects brought $9,677 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 742 Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon.

The American Merchant Marine Library Association, of which Franklin D. Roosevelt is honorary president, is winding up this week its annual "book drive." Last year, according to Robert D. Franklin, its librarian, it "placed over 250,000 books and 150,000 magazines aboard approximately 1,250 ships." Sailors seem to read nearly everything that average persons on shore do. They like adventure stories,
A romance which blossomed three years ago culminated today in the marriage of Yehudi Menuhin, the violinist, and Nola Ruby Nicholas, Australian beauty.

Senator Barkley, majority leader, told the Senate today that he would make a statement outlining the power policies of the Administration when the "private competition" amendment to the Relief-Recovery Bill came up for discussion. The statement, he said, would be made with the approval of President Roosevelt.

Buddy, first of the "Seeing Eye" dogs, is dead. She will long live, however,. in the hearts of those who have seen her and her fellow blind leaders bring new hope, new confidence, one might almost say a new life, to their human companions.

Six corporations whose stocks are actively traded on the New York Stock Exchange have accepted the invitation of the Chicago Stock Exchange to list their shares here, Thaddeus R. Benson, president of the Exchange, announced today.

This department receives any number of fish stories-they flow in by the score. But never before have we received a fish-hawk story, and if it proves to be authentic in all details it will be in the nature of a story-to-end-stories.

If there is indignation in the Senate over the interference of Harry L. Hopkins in the Iowa primaries, the reason is not hard to understand. Mr. Hopkins has charge of the spending of Federal relief appropriations. There are in Iowa thousands of voters who are the direct beneficiaries of WPA outlays.

Conditions in the world today seem much as they were 300 years ago when the Collegiate School, the oldest in Manhattan, was founded, the Rev. Dr. Edgar F. Romig, pastor of the West End Collegiate Church, told graduates of the school at their commencement exercises yesterday.

The Niagara Hudson Power Corportion system announced yesterday the adoption of a standard plan of retirement to become effective on June 1. The plan is regarded as an additional step in the unification of the Niagara Hudson system, according to Alfred H. Schoellkopf, president of the parent concern.

Joseph B. Ely, former Governor of Massachusetts, has come to the Biltmore from Springfield. Mrs. Beeckman J. Delatour of Fairway, Pawling, N. Y., is visiting her mother, Mrs. Wilfrid N. O'Neil at 112 Central Park South. Mrs. Wynne R. Sewell of Paris and Pittsburgh is at the Vanderbilt. She will sail next Wednesday on the Normandie.

During the week ended May 25 member bank reserve balances increased $94,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $9,000,000 in money in circulation and $100,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Bank and increases of $13,000,000 in gold stock and $4,000,000 in Treasury currency, offset in part by

A group of Chicago educators, authorities on international law and others telegraphed tonight to Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, protesting against his speech at Baltimore Tuesday in which he admonished Americans to cease their condemnation of the internal policies of other nations, "regarding which we have no rightful concern.".

Supreme Court Justice William Harman Black, who tinkers with mechanical gadgets as a hobby, has obtained a patent on a new safety razor, it was disclosed yesterday. The new razor is a perfection of earlier types which the justice patented.

The marriage of Miss Evelyn Macon Talcott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Pickard Talcott of New Rochelle and Happy Hollow Farm, Brewster, N. Y., to William Abbott Sturgis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Abbott Sturgis of Plandome, L. I., took place here this afternoon in the Kent School chapel the bridegroom is a Kent School alumnus.

The battle between Chinese and Japanese forces for Kaifeng, Lung-Hai Railway city and ancient former capital of China, has developed into the biggest engagement so far on the railway since the fall of Suchow.

A tabular summary that has just come to hand, while the Senate is debating another four billion dollar spending bill, will impress two things strongly on any who examine it. One is that the WPA, whose chief-Harry Hopkins-has just openly entered Democratic primary politics, represents the largest grant of executive power the world has ever known.

The Actors Equity Association will hold its twenty-fifth annual meeting at 2 P. M. today in the Astor. Arthur Byron will be elected president, Bert Lytell first vice president, and twelve councilors will be chosen. Only one post is being contested, that of the councilor to represent the WA Federal Theatre. John Lorenz and Samuel S. Bonnell are the candidates.

The problem of helping a community stripped of telephone communication was. solved by the city's police radio cars yesterday when a phone cable was severed accidentally in the Greenpoint district of Brooklyn.

Miss Maude Wilmot Gatling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Lawrence Gatling of Gastonia, N. C., was married here at noon yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church to Wilfred Bellinger Boney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel E. Boney of St. George, S. I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Martin D. Harding Jr.

The Cardinals announced tonight that Pitcher Si Johnson had been sent on option to the Cards' Rochester farm in the International League, Outfielder George Stainback had been sold outright to the Philadelphia Nationals and that Southpaw Roy Henshaw would remain on the Cards' roster.

Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo overruled yesterday contentions made by Kenneth F. Dayton, Budget Director, that $1,800 a year was adequate pay for General Sessions Court attendants, and ordered the city to pay two recent appointees at the rate of $3,000 a year.

A three-year contract covering 1,098 employes in the operating and maintenance department of Rockefeller Center has been signed by the management with the Building and Construction Trades Council, A. F. of L. affiliate, acting-in behalf of the council's building and maintenance division, it was announced yesterday.

Pinker Morrison, Inc., literary and dramatic agents, in 515 Madison Ave.; Talman Bigelow, Inc., broker. M. C. Lundin Co., general contractors, in 342 Madison Ave.; Clayton E. Chase, office equipment, in 381 4th Ave.: First Aid Supply Co., in 3 W. 22d St.; Herbert McLean Purdy Management Corp., broker.
Demand for an amendment strengthening the basic right of-the freedom of the press came today as the Constitutional Convention recessed for the Memorial Day week-end.

Luncheon, American Patriots, Iroquois Hotel, 49 West Forty-fourth Street, 12:30 P. M. "Stop the Red Steam Roller," John A. Lyon. Luncheon, Alumni Association, Law School of Columbia University, Law- I years Club, 115 Broadway, 1 P. M. Harold R. Medina, guest of honor. Address by Judge Frederick E. Crane.
The Dartmouth Athletic Council today awarded varsity letters to members of the champion lacrosse team, as well as to players on the golf and tennis units.

Nearly 1,000 persons, attending a dinner last night in the Business Systems Building on the World's Fair Grounds at which plans for the proposed Temple of Religion were outlined, pledged themselves to work as a "Committee of 1,000' to raise funds for the temple, which Charles H. Tuttle, the principal speaker, described as an "affirmative reassertion of American ideals."

The Senate leadership averted a threatened filibuster over the House Wage and Hour Bill today by reaching agreements by which Southern opposition. was placated and the measure was sent to conference by unanimous consent.

Six specialty organizations will hold exhibitions of their breeds in various towns in New Jersey today. They will bench a total of 846 dogs. Four of these events will be judged by foreign experts invited to this country especially to make the awards.

The war that has been going on within the Japanese Government over the conduct of the war in China has resulted in another victory for the military as against the civilian point of view. The shake-up in the Cabinet puts three well-known army leaders in key posts.

William P. Horn, 55 years old, of 20 Chester Avenue, Mount Vernon, a securities dealer with offices at 120 Broadway, was drowned at about 11 o'clock last night despite the efforts of two policemen to rescue him after he had fallen off the stringpiece at Pier 10, at the foot of Old Slip, East River. Mr. Horn is survived by a widow and son, Edward A. Horn.

Prince Louis Ferdinand of Prussia, grandson of the exiled former Kaiser, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen with his bride, who was the Grand Duchess Kira of Russia, daughter of the Grand Duke Cyril, pretender to the Russian throne.

PATROLMEN--Walter C. Ferris, from Precinct 68 to Precinct 79; Edmund F. O'Donnell, from Precinct 68 to Precinct 88. Temporary Assignments For fifteen days, from 8 A. M., June 1: LIEUTENANTS - Thomas P. Browne, from 46th Precinct to 19th Division, office of the Chief Inspector.

The total of loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City fell $62,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $7,500,000,000, the smallest figure since Feb. 27, 1935, according to the weekly condition statement of the banks, issued yesterday.

Henry Richard Gibson, believed by his family to have been the oldest living former Congressman, died yesterday. He was more than 100 years old. It wasn't certain whether he was born on Christmas Eve of 1836 or 1837-a difference which Mr. Gibson always dismissed as "nothing to worry about."

Ganson Purcell, director of the trading and exchange division of the Seucrities and Exchange Commission, and James J. Caffrey, New York regional administrator for the same body, were on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and will be there today.

The character of the bond market was little changed yesterday from conditions which have prevailed since the start of the week. Prices continued to decline in relatively light trading volume, again reflecting the absence of ready support rather than of any aggressive liquidation.

The Nieuw Amsterdam, flagship of the Holland America Line, maintained a speed on her first eastbound Atlantic crossing equal to that which she made on her maiden westbound run, according to a cablegram received yesterday from Frans C. Bouman, managing director of the line, to officials in New York. Mr. Bouman is making the round trip on the vessel.

The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended May 26 were announced today: MAJOR Anthony, R. C., San Francisco, detailed as an assistant quartermaster, June 15, and ordered to San Diego. as Base Property Officer.

The scope of employee interest in the Greater New York Fund was indicated in an announcement yesterday by James G. Blaine, chairman of the campaign for $10,000,000 to supplement the finances of private social agencies, that more than 1,000,000 workers in this city were now making group subscriptions to the fund.
Albert C. Baur, former chief of the stocks and bonds division of the City Finance Department, died suddenly yesterday morning at his home, 114-73 178th Place, Saint Albans, Queens. His age was 60.

Manhattan Alterations 48th St, 155-9 W; to 3-story theatre; estate of Joseph Leblang, 527 5th Ave, owner; H. H. Cashdan, engineer; cost, $10,000. 35th St, 409 W; to 5-story tenement; estate of William F. Islee, premises, owner; J. H. Knubel, architect; cost, $4,000. 36th St. 406 W; to 5-story tenement;
Charles P. Tilton, building contractor and former bank director here, died today in an ambulance en route to the Atlantic City Hospital from his home at 6,201 Ventnor Avenue. His age was 57.

Big Ed Dudley of Philadelphia and Ky Laffoon, the Chicago Cherokee, ripped eight strokes off par today with a 63 to beat Lawson Little and Jimmy Demeret, 6 up, snatching the lead at the end of the first round of the $4,600 Inverness invitational best-ball matches.
The House Rules Committee presented a watch and knife to Chairman O'Connor today in "appreciation of his long and useful service."

Sixty-eight diplomas of Graduate in Pharmacy and sixteen prizes for scholastic achievement were presented last night at the 108th annual commencement exercises of the College of Pharmacy of Columbia University, held in the McMillin Academic Theatre, Broadway at 116th Street.

Class day and commencement exercises will be held today at the Gardner School for Girls, 154 East Seventieth Street, for ten girls. Athletic awards will be presented at the class day exercises in the morning. Dr. Elbert K. Fretwell of Columbia University will address the graduates at the commencement ceremonies at 8 P. M.

The first Dunrovin Music Festival, under the auspices of the Chamber Music Society of America, will be presented at the Playhouse of Dunrovin, Ridgefield, Conn., on three consecutive Saturday afternoons, June 18, 25 and July 2, it was announced yesterday by William Matheus Sullivan.

Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, former national champion, put an end to the sensational march of Miss Helen Sigel through the thirty-first annual Philadelphia women's golf championship at the Merion Cricket Club today by defeating her Philadelphia Country Club team-mate, 4 and 2, in the semi-final round.

Marshal Philippe Petain, greatest among the French survivors of those who forged the Allied victory in the World War, told French war veterans in a speech at Caen today that they must unite as they did in 1914 if they were going to prevent their victory from being turned into a defeat.

Retired Police Lieutenant John F. McNamara of 101-27 118th Street, Ozone Park, Queens, died yesterday at his home at the age of 63. Lieutenant McNamara, a World War veteran, was one of the fifty-seven members of the Police Department retired' last December because of an age limit regulation.
The Junior Republican Committee of One Hundred gave its annual Spring supper dance last night at Le Coq Rouge. Special divertissements featured the evening's program.

An estimated 22,000 Communists, who had paid from 40 cents to $1.10, filled Madison Square Garden to the last seat in the balcony last night to open vociferously the tenth biannual convention of the Communist party, U. S. A., which will continue through next Tuesday.

A pair or former state cnampions, Miss Maureen Orcutt, Curtis Cup appointee, and Mrs. William Hockenjos of Crestmont, teamed in the Women's New Jersey State Golf Association two-day best-ball tournament and took the lead for low gross honors with a 74.
Mr. and Mrs. Devereux Milburn of Westbury, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Gordon Milburn, to Arthur Delano Weekes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Weekes of Oyster Bay.

Former President Herbert Hoover, as guest of the National Republican Club at 54 West Fortieth Street, discussed last night the state of the nation under the New Deal and explained, for the benefit of about 200 members of the club, his views on general Republican party policy with an eye to the 1938 and 1940 cmpaigns.
Rebel followers of General Saturnino Cedillo have moved south of San Luis Potosi into the State of Guanajuato and early today cut the main rail line between Mexico City and the United States.
A bankruptcy sale of Richard Whitney's prize-winning herd of Ayrshire cattle, together with his string of thoroughbred hunters and personal property, was set yesterday for June 24 at 1l A. M.

Robert J. G. Boothby, Conservative member of the House of Commons, said tonight he was willing for Britain to negotiate a war-debt settlement with the United States "if necessary" to restore economic prosperity.
The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended May 25 were announced today: LIEUTENANTS Anderson, E. A., the Cayuga, to engineering training duty that vessel.

Sank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday throughout the country remained substantially below the total for the corresponding period last year for the twentyeighth successive time. Clearings for the twenty-two leading cities of the country, according to Dun

Wilfred (Lefty) Lefebvre limited Colgate to seven hits today as he hurled Holy Cross to a 14-1 triumph, its seventh straight. It was also Lefebvre's seventh victory in a row this season. Herb Bracken, with four safeties, paced the Crusaders' 21-hit attack on three Colgate pitchers.

The Print Department of the Brooklyn Museum will open today an exhibition of color prints in various techniques by four young WPA artists. It will be current through Sept. 5. The artists represented are Russell T. Limbach, Augustus Peck, Louis Schanker and Hyman J. Warsager. This afternoon,

John G. Oglesby, former Lieutenant Governor of Illinois, died today in his home at Elkhart, near here. He was 60 years old. Mr. Oglesby had been ill for three weeks. At his death he was vice president of the Springfield Marine Bank.

A. E. Faulkner, president of the Woodmen Aocident Company, Lincoln, Neb., was elected president of the Health and Accident Underwriters Conference at the final session of the organization's annual meeting today.
The East River Savings Bank has disposed of two properties in Flushing, L. I., near the World's Fair grounds, it was announced yesterday. One will be improved with an apartment house.

The directors of the Standard Bank of South Africa, Ltd., have voted a dividend for the half-year ended on March 31 at the rate of of 7 per cent, plus a bonus of three shillings a share, payable in British currency, subject to British income tax, according to word received here yesterday by the New York agency th of the bank.
Clare G. Fenerty, Philadelphia barrister, will receive the honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters at the annual commencement of St. Francis College on Monday.

The greatest American naval force ever assembled in the Atlantio Ocean will mobilize in West Indian waters early next year and, for the first time since 1934, the annual fleet battle manoeuvres will take place east of the Panama Canal.

The new indictment which named James J. Hines yesterday as a member of the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy racketeering gang dropped the name of a former patrolman previously indicted, Daniel L. Smith.

The twenty-second annual commencement exercises of the Lenox School will be held this morning in the theatre of the school, 52 East Seventy-eighth Street. Miss Olivia Green, principal, will confer diplomas upon fourteen girls. The address will be given by Mrs. Jessica Garretson Cosgrave, founder of the school. The exercises are scheduled at 11 A. M.

Under our conditions of traffic a long week-end, such as that about to open, unfortunately means a peak in the accident toll. The Greater New York Safety Council and the automobile clubs of America and New York have all issued timely warnings to drivers and pedestrians to take special care that Memorial Day this year be not marred by an increase in deaths and injuries.

Retired Fireman Charles J. Carroll. formerly a member of Engine Co. 260, residing at 2,316 Tilden Ave., Brooklyn, died May 25. Funeral will take place from Cooke Funeral Parlor, 1,218 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, at 9:30 A. M., Friday, May 27.

Robert R. Young, chairman of the boards of the Alleghany Corporation and the Chesapeake Corporation, holding companies of the old Van Sweringen transportation system, applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to hold the position of director of the Pere Marquette Railway, and generally, in addition to the position of director, any office or offices with the Chesapeake Ohio Rail- 16 way or its subsidiaries.

Miss Elizabeth Baldwin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Baldwin of this place, was married tonight at the home of her parents to Miron Canfield Meadowcroft, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Harry Meadowcroft of Boonton and grandson of the late William Henry Meadowcroft. The Rev. A. Philip Tuttle, pastor of the Parsippany Presbyterian Church, officiated.

Further warnings that the farmers in the New York City milkshed were on the verge of a serious strike if they did not get an immediate improvement in milk prices were voiced yesterday at the end of the hearing in New York on the proposed joint Federal and State marketing agreement and order regulating the handling of milk in the metropolitan area.
Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, and his bride arrived here today after an overnight trip from Ireland.

Members of the New York Stock of the Exchange presented yesterday to Charles R. Gay, who retired from FDI its presidency last week, a silver salver made in London in 1767 by Act William Grundy, a noted silversmith.

The report of the International Hydro-Electric System and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after operating expenses and charges, of $1,856,491, compared with a net of $1,443,333 in the twelve months to March 31, 1937. Gross operating revenues of the system for the period were $65,445,448, against $65,030,613 in the preceding comparable period.

Trading was very uneven, active to slow. Unseasonally cool weather retarding country business for coming holiday. The lamb market showed strength, fresh pork cuts sold unevenly, other classes were weak to lower. Early trading in kosher meats was light with lamb stronger and other classes about steady. Conditions, as reported by

Trading was very uneven, active to slow. Unseasonally cool weather retarding country business for coming holiday. The lamb market showed strength, fresh pork cuts sold unevenly, other classes were weak to lower. Early trading in kosher meats was light with lamb stronger and other classes about steady. Conditions, as reported by

Inactivity in the capital markets in recent months was reflected today in' an analysis by the Securities and Exchange Commission of registration statements becoming effective in April, under the Securities Act of 1933.

Blame for declining consumption of cotton goods was laid to the industry itself by Dr. Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute, in an address tonight at a dinner meeting of the International Association of Garment Manufacturers.
The Communist party newspaper Pravda reported today that Navy Commissar Peter Alexandrovich Smirnoff had urged the Soviet Baltic fleet to be ready for action in case of an attack on Leningrad.
The Communist party newspaper Pravda reported today that Navy Commissar Peter Alexandrovich Smirnoff had urged the Soviet Baltic fleet to be ready for action in case of an attack on Leningrad.

It is now reasonably certain that the Federal Theatre Project will be getting around to Mr. Shaw's "On the Rocks" some time during the week of June 6, the theatre being Daly's. There will be another preview there tomorrow night, and others on Tuesday and Friday of next week.

A memorandum opposing a bill that would provide for a Federal system of unemployment compensation for railway employes, prepared by Wayne C. Taylor, acting Secretary of the Treasury, was placed in the record today as the House Interstate Commerce Committee opened hearings on the measure.

There is no basic economic reason for prolonged duration of the present depression, but it will continue until changed governmental policies restore the lost confidence of investors, T. M. Girdler declared yesterday at the forty-seventh general meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Stocks of merchandise on hand in department stores of the New York Federal Reserve District were 10 per cent lower at the end of April than at the end of the same month last year, and apparel store stocks were 8 per cent lower, according to the monthly review

Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, chairman of the Board of Education's instructional affairs committee, took issue yesterday with the report made by the Board of Examiners that the use of mechanical recording machines has proved a failure and should be discontinued.

Alfred M. Landon, Republican Presidential candidate in 1986 and titular leader of the party, has consented to address the annual convention. of the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs, it was announced here tonight. Mr. Landon will speak at the annual banquet Saturday night.

After a two-hour debate in which both communism and Nazism were vigorously assailed, the House by a voice vote today passed a resolution providing for the appointment of a seven-man committee to investigate un-American propaganda in the United States.

Capital-stock fire insurance companies have a $2,000,000,000 stake in the American economic and industrial system, according to Paul B. Sommers, president of the National Board of Fire Underwriters in an address last night before the seventy-second annual meeting of the board at the Hotel Plaza.
The flow of new money into the Manhattan realty market has been holding up better during the recent months of business recession than many other indices of real estate activity.

Mrs. E. F. Whalen of Westchester Hills and Miss Lois Mathews of Hubbard Heights won individual honors in the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association tournament at the Scarsdale Golf Club today, but neither Westchester nor Fairfield was able to get another leg on the silver cup competed for each year on a team basis.

Wheat futures in the world markets, except the May delivery at Winnipeg, dropped to new low levels for the season today on continued weakness in the May and fairly persistent.liquidation in all deliveries.

Chairman John Hamilton of the Republican National Committee has issued the following statement: "The day after the Pennsylvania primary election I called attention to a story in THE NEW YORK TIMES to the effect that Democratic National Chairman Farley had intervened in the Democratic Pennsylvania contest as the price of a promise from John L. Lewis, chairman-of the C. I. O., to support Senator Alben W. Barkley against Governor A. B. Chandler in Kentucky.

Selznick- International announced today that Maude Adams had signed a contract with the studio to star in a picture to be made in the Autumn. The actress came to Hollywood some weeks ago and made a series of screen tests with the idea of appearing in "The Young in Heart." The tests were so successful and Miss Adams's enthusiasm for the medium so great that negotiations were Iinstituted which led to today's announcement.

Miss Dorothy Parsons Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hoyt A. Moore of 898 Park Avenue, has completed plans for her marriage on the afternoon of June 29 to James Wilson Tower, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Tower of this city and Falmouth, Mass. The ceremony will be performed here in the Central Presbyterian Church by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers.

The Summer camp on Upper Twin Lake, Central Valley, N. Y., of the Abbott E. Kittredge Club for Girls of this city will begin its nineteenth season this week-end. The camp is non-sectarian and non-commercial.

The Royal Society of Canada learned today from Dr. D. A. Scott of Toronto of a variation developed in the production of insulin that requires less frequent doses, a fact welcomed by the diabetic patient.

The 111-year-old congregation of St. James Lutheran Church, the oldest of the denomination holding worship in English, will abandon its present edifice at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street after the 11 A. M. worship on Sunday, June 5.

The annual convention of the American Institute of Banking, the educational section of the American Bankers Association, will be held in Louisville on June 6 to 10, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harold Stonier, educational director of the institute. About 2,000 bankers are expected to attend.
Idle Miss, 4-year-old filly, made it four victories in a row when she was first in the featured Little Neck Handicap yesterday at Belmont, where rain and wind failed to alter the consistency of form.
In a great wave of religious fervor Budapest, the most picturesquely situated of European capitals, held tonight a river pageant more beautiful than any within memory.

The British Government introduced in the House of Commons today a bill to empower the Board of Trade to hoard vast quantities of food and other supplies "essential to the vital needs of the community in the event of war."
