James J. Hines, Tammany leader of the Eleventh A. D. in Manhattan, will be forced to resign his leadership regardless of whether he is acquitted on the lottery indictments prepared against him by District Attorney Dewey, according to the general opinion of Tammany members yesterday.

Dr. John Jacob Abel, professor emeritus of pharmacology at the Johns Hopkins Hospital, died today from a cardiao condition. A week ago he celebrated his eighty-first birthday and the same day was notified of his election to foreign membership in the Royal Society, London. It was the culmination of a long series of honors.

Earl Browder, geneneral secretary of the Communist party, sums up his party's position on democracy in a few words: "We are definitely opposed to force or violence. We point to the historical fact that violence in a period of change is always caused by a reactionary minority resisting the outcarrying of the majority's will."

Michael J. Furey, hero of a train wreck at Bridgeport, Conn., twenty-seven years ago, died here today at his home at the age of 79. He was a retired conductor on the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad and estimated that he had traveled 2,000,000 miles during forty-six years of service.

In accordance with the New Jersey Fair Trade Law, as recently amended, the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, on June 1, will specify 15.3 cents a gallon, including tax, as the minimum retail price for its trademarked gasoline known as Essolene, the company stated yesterday. A contract is being

Miss Peggy Elmes and Thomas Hastings Cooke will be married the afternoon of June 6 in St. James Episcopal Church. The Rev. James A. Paul will perform the ceremony. Miss Elmes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Frederick Elmes of this city, will have her sister, Miss Cecily Elmes, for her maid of honor.

The Paragon Stable's Deep End staved off a terrific stretch drive by Marty Madden's Wise Counsel to annex first money iii the six furlongs of the Newspaper Photographers' Purse, six-furlong feature of today's rainy program at Suffolk Downs. Despite the weather, a crowd of 12,000 saw the program.

George Gru of 50 Court Street, one of the oldest active attorneys in Brooklyn, requested an indefinite adjournment in Kings County Court yesterday for his client, Lawrence Ambrose, 27 years old, of 49 Parkville Avenue, Brooklyn, charged with petit larceny and forging a $32 check.
Directors of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company at a meeting yesterday took no action on a dividend due at this time on the common capital stock. On March 28 the company paid 25 cents a share.
The Italian light cruiser Quarto left here this morning for Italy carrying ten members of the commission that will represent the Insurgents next lini's demonstration for General Francisco Franco.

On a bid of $1,000 at a foreclosure sale the southwest corner of 2d Ave and 43d St, 100.5x75, was conveyed. by the referee to Harry Casper, and he gave thereon to the Continental Realty Investing Co, Inc. a purchase-money mortgage for $729,000, payable May -1, 1943, 4 1/2 per cent, and Mr. Casper then conveyed the parcel to Crico, Inc. of 19 E 47th St.

Miss Elizabeth Clark Shaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Shaw, was married to Alexander Milton of Newark, N. J., son of Mrs. Jeannie Milton and the late Alexander Milton, yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Riverside Church.

The Senate Appropriations Committee was accused yesterday by Mrs. Charles L. Hulswit, one of the founders of the "Women's Rebellion," an anti-New Deal movement, of having extensively altered the testimony she gave before the committee in Washington last Thursday.

A document bearing the signature of Thomas Lynch Jr., signer of the Declaration of Independence from South Carolina, was bought by Gabriel Wells for $3,500 yesterday at the second session of a sale of Americana, autographs and first editions at the American Art

The competitive battle between gin and rum in the Summer drink market, in which the former still leads by a wide margin but with the latter gaining, will be intensified this- year, current advertising plans of leading companies in both fields indicate.

The metropolitan area got its share of blue ribbons during the third program of the Devon horse show, which was held today in a sea of water and mud. Heavy rains started falling shortly before noon, but the competitions went on just the same.

President Roosevelt decided in an unexpected move today to tell the country by radio tomorrow what he thinks of the new tax bill and how he has disposed of the measure. Although he is expected to sign the bill, his actual disposition of the measure will remain an official secret until he speaks.

A protest presented to Preident Federico Laredo Bru against the proposed new silver issue of $20,000,000 and the levying of additional taxes to balance the budget now in preparation was made public today by the Cuban Chamber of Commerce and the Havana Produce Exchange.

Earnings of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., for the first four months of this year are about onethird less than those for the same period in 1937, John A. Brown, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday. He said he hoped conditions would not cause further deterioration.

Further heavy liquidation on the Cotton Exchange yesterday ran all deliveries below the 8-cent level, but an abrupt recovery ensued and erased most of the early losses to leave the list 4 to 7 points lower than Thursday's close. With little rain in the Belt and failure of the textile situation to improve, both foreign and domestic liquidation
United Air Lines officials confirmed today the eyewitness accounts that the luxury sleeper plane which crashed Tuesday night killing ten, was afire before it plunged to the ground.

Peter Hanke, known here as the "village blacksmith," reported today that he had been robbed of $6,500 he had buried in the ground near a weeping willow tree that spreads over his blacksmith shop on Bayshore Road.

Renewal of the one-cent New York City tax on cigarettes, which expires on June 30, will be vigorously fought by the Retail Tobacco Dealers of America, Inc., it was stated yesterday by William A. Hollingsworth, who was re-elected president of the organization at its annual convention being held at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

A jury of married men, most of them fathers, acquitted Donald Carroll, 16-year-old Queens high school boy, of the murder of his 18-yearold sweetheart, Charlotte Matthieson, after two hours and fifty-six minutes of deliberation yesterday afternoon in Queens County Court.

Sharp declines in prices of wheat, cotton and copper-pushed The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices down six-tenths of a point to 80.5 on Wednesday. A week before the index was 81.1 and a year ago it stood at 94.2. Most commodities are now in the lowest ground since 1934.

Without denying the right of a government to declare war, the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America- refused today to countenance the incorporation in the denomination's Confession of Faith of a specific clause sanctioning resort to arms.
Senator Copeland reported agreement by House and Senate conferees today on legislation to apportion a share of future subsidized ship construction to Pacific Coast and Gulf shipyards.
Top honors for the second successive year in the national specialty show of the German Shepherd Club of America were-captured today at the 102d Cavalry Armory by Ch. Pfeffer von Bern.

A big third inning, when they scored five runs on two hits, gave the Chiefs their second straight victory over Jersey City tonight, 10 to 5. Tom Baker walked seven men in less than three innings, putting the game out of the Little Giants' reach.

Mrs. Charlotte Aldrich, who for many years had been active in private charity work in New York and Allenhurst, N. J., her Summer home, died yesterday at her apartment in the Hotel Plaza at the age of 86. Mrs. Aldrich was the widow of William Paine Aldrich, owner of New Jersey textile mills.

The annual report of the American Enka Corporation, rayon manufacturer, covering the year ended on Jan. 2, shows a net income of $2,517,539 after expenses, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges, including $150,000 surtax on undistributed profits.

Bolstered by a contingent of 458 amateurs, one of the largest on record, 1,223 golfers have entered the 1938 national open championship. The entry is the third largest in the 42-year history of the tournament. It was bettered only last year, when the record was set at 1,402, and in 1936, when there were 1,277 contenders.

Department store sales in the week ended May 21 were 14 per cent lower than for the corresponding week in 1937, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. For the four weeks ended May 21 sales also were 14 per cent lower than for the same four weeks one year ago.

Holding that the city's sales and personal property taxes do not apply to purchases by shipping lines of bunker fuel and Diesel engine oil from refining plants in New Jersey, the Appellate Division in a unanimous decision yesterday ordered the city to return $26,662
Honors and medals were awarded last night at the commencement exercises of the Gardner School for Girls, 154 East Seventieth Street. Dr. Elbert K. Fretwell of Columbia University gave the address.
The engagement of Miss Ellen wight Reid, daughter of Mrs. John eid, formerly of New Rochelle, ??. Y., and the late Mr. Reid, to nthony Dey Eastman of Pomfret, onn., son -of Professor and Mrs.

Governor Lehman moved today to prevent a repetition, in this State, of the difficulties between labor and public officials which have plagued the regime of Mayor Hague in Jersey City, pledged himself to the maintenance of free speech and, by inference, criticized the state of affairs across the Hudson River.

Friends of Senator Gillette of Iowa sought without success today to overcome the appearance of Administration support for Representative Otha D. Wearin, his chief opponent for renomination in the Democratic primary on June 6.

In a very small turnover on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on April 30, member trading in round lots for their own account fell to 19.47 per cent of total volume, compared with 23.13 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. Total volume was 2,670,010 shares sold against 4,694,570 in the previous week.

The Rev. Dr. Malcolm E. Peabody, rector of St. Paul's Church, Chestnut Hill, said' today that he had asked Bishop Edward E. Coley of New York for more time to decide whether he would accept election as Bishop Coadjutor for the Central New York Episcopal Diocese.
A possible hint of early adjournent of Congress came today with the introduction of the usual resolution under which the House arranges to clear its slate with speed in closing days of a session.
Frank Restuccia, who operates a money exchange agency at 501 West Fifty-first Street, was held up and robbed of $1,600 in his office at noon yesterday by two armed thugs.

The Rev. Howard D. McGrath, 41 years old, the newly appointed pastor of Grace Methodist Church, West 104th Street, between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, and his wife were guests at a formal reception of welcome Wednesday evening in the church parlors. One of the speakers was the Rev. Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin, pastor of the neighboring West End Presbyterian Church.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor, prior to their departure from Paris to take up their residence on the Riviera, were the guests at an official dinner tonight given in their honor at the British Embassy by Sir Erie and Lady Phipps.

Lester Geers, State's attorney of Madison County who gained national prominence in the conviction of the seven kidnappers of August Luer, Alton banker and meat packer, five years ago, died today at his home here. He was 57 years old. Death was due to coronary thrombosis.

Longshoremen at all ports have resumed loading tin clippings, scrap iron and tallow for Japan and Germany. This action followed mass meetings at which leaders said their embargo had served to demonstrate it was against the conscience

For the third time within a week Champion Nornay Saddler today was declared best dog in show. This superb smooth foxterrier, owned by the Wissaboo Kennels of James M. Austin of Westbury, L. I., and handled by Leonard Brumby, captured the highest honors in the fiftyseventh specialty show of the American Foxterrier Club.

The text of President Roosevelt's address here today was as follows: At last after many attempts I have succeeded in coming to Arthurdale-and I greet you as friends because you are Mrs. Roosevelt's personal friends and because I have heard so much about you.

Although inventories of many stores are considerably reduced, wholesale buying decreased last week, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Cold and rainy weather slowed retail sales and caused a further decline. Industrial production barely held even with the preceding week.

Clarence Clark of the Forest Hill Field Club, Johnny Farrell of Baltusrol and Bert McDougall of the Essex Fells Country Club tied today with scores of 141, one under par, in the thirty-six-hole sectional qualifying test for the National Professional Golfers Association championship.
Queen Elizabeth will reopen the Norwich Cathedral cloister tomorrow, unveil statues of herself and King George VI and sip a cup of mead.
Charles W. Galloway of Richmond, Va., was elected today president of the Association of Transit Equipment Men of the Middle Atlantic States. He succeeded A. T. Clark of Baltimore.

Bethlehem is the mecca of many give Bach devotees in attendance at the Thirty-first Bach festival, which ICK opened a two-day session this afternoon in Packer Memorial Chapel at Gue Lehigh University. Twenty-four States and England, 'Ontario, Canada and Chile are represented.

The impact of the recession- has been much less severe in this city than in the nation as a whole, according to statistics made' public yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator.

As if by order, the German press today ceased abruptly its blasts against Czechoslovakia and the western democracies it accused of proCzechoslovak sympathies. The lull in the war-like talk was said in official quarters to be the is lear result of Chancellor Hitler's firm determination to preserve peace in denied spite of "provocations" by the Czechs.

Announcement was made here today by Secretary of Agriculture Wallace that the Farm Security Administration has concluded lease arrangements with Greenhills Consumer Services, Inc., which will operate and manage the commercial center at Greenhills, suburban housing project on the outskirts of this city, as a consumer cooperative.

The government claimed today to have broken the revolt of General Saturnino Cedillo when the rebel leader's plane was grounded twelve miles north of the city of San Luis Potosi. General Cedillo was reported to be fleeing on foot with only one companion.

The Bank of Canada-central bank of this Dominion-which was owned privately when first established in 1935, but of which the government took control in 1936 by a dominating issue of stock, is to be completely nationalized, according to a statement in the Commons today by Prime Minister Mackenzie King.

Banfi Products Corporation, 206 Spring Street, New York, has entered into a stipulation with the Federal Trade Commission to discontinue certain allegedly misleading representations in the advertisement of its products, the commission announced today.

Prices of listed bonds on the New York Stock Exchange continued to decline yesterday in slightly more active trading. Little support appeared among the more active secondary railroad and power and light issues as prices yielded fractions to 4 points over a broad list.

Mrs. Lina E. Arronet, translator in the State Department of Education for the last twenty-six years, died today. She was the widow of the Rev. Alex Arronet of Gloversville, an African missionary who died twenty-five years ago.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Warren Brown, daughter of Offley T. Brown of this place and the late Mrs. Brown, to William Franklin Ward Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Ward, also of Fanwood, took place this evening in the Scotch Plains Baptist Church.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey of New York notified the annual convention of the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs late tonight that any attempt to endorse him as Republican Gubernatorial candidate would be "directly contrary to my wishes."

Japan has gained her strongest government in many years by yesterday's changes in personnel. There had been demands for changes for some time, but Premier Fumimaro Konoye waited until the' Suchow victory.
A movement to seed American Walker Cup players in future British amaLeur championships has started here since the defeat of Johnny Goodman and Johnny Fischer by team-mates.

Wall Street banks yesterday received letters from William McC. Martin Jr., acting president of the New York Stock Exchange, asking their cooperation in the institution's study of the suggestion that a central depositary for securities in "Street names" be established.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.;

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called for June 10 a hearing on an application by the Byllesby Corporation for an order declaring it not be be a holding company within the meaning of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

Shareholders of the McCollFrontenac Oil Company whose votes have been sought by differing factions in the concern met for a few minutes today before their annual meeting was adjourned for the second time within as many days. June 2 was set for the next session.

The country has a new tax law. As a result of that law the undistributed profits tax, with its heavy and often prohibitive penalties on industrial growth, and even on common prudence, has been reduced to a point where it now exists only in nominal form.

Leases of office, showroom and store space centered Yesterday in the midtown section of Manhattan where buildings added a variety of businesses to their rosters. The activity included contracts for doctors' offices.
Puerto Rico's longshoremen won annual wage increases estimated to exceed $500,000 through their six-week strike commencing early in January, by the award that the arbitration board made public here.

Divers city bigwigs and private citizens of credit and renown have united with the Broadway Association and the Outdoor Cleanliness Association to dine and dance in celebration of the "three hundred and twenty-fifth" anniversary of Broadway's birthday.

One of the first "dividends" of the cooperative enterprises at Greenbelt, Md., is that declared by the children's co-op store at the government's resettlement project there, it was learned here yesterday. The "gum-drop" co-op, as it has become known, rolled up a reserve of $12 after six weeks'

Miss Emily Katherine Yale Samuels, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Gurney Samuels of Maplewood, was married this afternoon in Morrow Memorial Church here to Robert Edwin Niebling, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Niebling of South Orange. The pastor, the Rev. Dr. John E. Charlton, performed the ceremony.
Two Norwegian freighters collided in a dense fog about forty miles off Sandy Hook early yesterday morning, opening a five-foot hole in one ship and damaging the other.
Charles Yanowsky, alias Harry Alberts, 32 years old, who served a term in Alcatraz, was sentenced yesterday to two to four years in ti Sing Sing by General Sessions Judge Bohan.

The Rev. A. Powell Davies, pastor of the Community Church of Summit, N. J., and former president of the Liberal Ministers Club of New York, warned the New Jersey Federation of Women's Clubs today against the belief that the democracies of the world must combine and fight it out with the Fascists or be overwhelmed individually.

Foster Cline, regional administrator of the Denver office of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has resigned, effective on July 1, to resume the private practice of law in Denver. He will be succeeded by Howard N. Lary of Gilman, Col., now a member of the staff of the Denver office, the SEC announced today.
President Roosevelt told the nation today that he would permit the new tax bill to become law without his signature, the first time that such a course has been taken in his administration.

Ward's Automotive Reports in today's summary discerns a continued "slow seasonal decline" in automobile production, and the current week's assemblies at 45,120 units compares with 46,810 last week and 132,425 this week a year ago.

WHEN they packed up and left this area the St. Louis Cardinals were a gloomy group. The Gas House Gang seemed completely deflated. The team as entombed in sixth place. Something should be done about that. It has cut down the available supply of fun in the world.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 26: BRIGADIER GENERAL Tyner, G. P., General Staff Corps, four days' leave, May 27 COLONELS Harmon, M. F. Jr. (Lt. Col.), Air Corps, Hawaiian Dep't, to Air Corps Tactical School, Maxwell Field, Ala.
Drastic changes in the enforcement provisions of the Wages and Hours Bill will be urged upon the Congressional conferees.

At the request of the applicants, the Federal Power Commission has postponed until 10 A. M., Sept. 1, the hearing scheduled for June 3 on the interlocking directorate applications of twenty officials in the Consolidated Gas. Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore System.

A group of 2,000 low-cost homes for workers in Rio de Janeiro will be ready for occupancy by the end of 1939, it was announced today by the Minister of Labor. The homes will be sold for $1,000 and $1,500. They are of four rooms each and are equipped with a radio.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The International Arbitration League of London has sent me here to confer with leaders of public opinion on the advisability of holding a third Hague conference.

A woman's chance reading of an old newspaper was credited today with identifying the "unknown" Confederate soldier of the Battle of Gettysburg who died of lockjaw while retreating with Lee's army seventy-five years ago.

Turpentine firm, 22 1/2c; sales, 112 barrels; receipts, 531 barrels; shipments, 3,369 barrels; stock, 33.715 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 118; receipts, 2,903; shipments, 6,578; stock, 11,815. Quote: B. $3.35; D. $3.50; E. $3.55; F. $3.90; G. $4.10; H. I. K; $4.25; M. $4.30; N. $4.75; WG, $5.40; WW and X, $6.20.

Mrs. Jane White Fuller of Bedford Village, N. Y., daughter of Ernest Ingersoll White of Syracuse and Fayetteville, N. Y., and the Late Mrs. White, was married yesterday to Cass Canfield, president of Harper Brothers, publishers, at a civil ceremony in this city.

S. E. Comstock, chairman, and B. C. Olney, president of Snider Packing Corporation, told stockholders at their annual meeting in Rochester, N. Y.. that substantially higher costs of labor, taxes, raw materials and supplies were not recoverable at present prices.

It has usually been taken for granted that a genuine "war scare". would find its immediate and strongest expression on the world's stock markets. It did so, to a considerable extent, when Hitler's army seized Austria on March 14.

Chinese reports indicate that smashing blows have been delivered to General Kenji Doihara's crack Fourteenth. Division of the Japanese Army by counter-attacking Chinese forces in and around Lanfeng, 150 miles west of Suchow.
Louis Schiller Jr., former Naugatuck town clerk, was found guilty on two counts of embezzlement by agent, this afternoon in Criminal Superior Court.

Representatives of Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Iceland and Finland today pledged their governments to a common neutrality in wars between other States. They signed a declaration embodying a new set of neutrality rules based on The Hague conventions of 1907

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City rejected yesterday a tentative agreement reached by Corporation Counsel James A. Hamill with the C. I. O., American Civil Liberties Union and affiliated organizations for a Federal court decree prohibiting Jersey City authorities from interfering with the exercise of civil rights the plaintiffs said had been denied them.
The Argentine Government is studying the advisability of putting all import trade on a quota basis. If quotas are instituted, United States trade will be the heaviest sufferer.

America's leading racing and acrobatic pilots were flying their qualifying trials and rehearsing stunts here this afternoon for the opening tomorrow of the three-day program of the Pacific International Air Races.

Miss Doris Lindeman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eduard C. Lindeman of High Bridge, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Gessner of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Gessner of Escanaba, Mich., by the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise in his study, 40 West Sixty-eight Street.

Promptly at 10 o'clock this morning more than fifty experts from the United States, Canada and European countries will begin judging most of the 4,213 dogs competing in the twelfth annual all-breed show of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club.

Trading in wheat futures slowed up materially today, prices holding within a range of about 1 cent a bushel. Selling attributed to hedging against Australian wheat now afloat on the ocean at the opening on the Board of Trade here was offset to a large extent by buying,
John Franklin, vice president of the Baltimore Mail Steamship Company, said today that he expected a net annual profit of at least $200,000 for the line in its proposed intercoastal service.

The first of three special showings of the Bache collection of art at the residence of Jules S. Bache, 814 Fifth Avenue, was held yesterday as a benefit for the Greenwich House Music School. The exhibition was arranged by the Bache benefit committee of the school.

Dr. Joseph William Mellor, distinguished scientist and ceramic physicist, died in London Tuesday at the age of 69. Formerly he was principal of the pottery school in the "Potteries District" of Staffordshire. As secretary of the Ceramic Society he traveled to many pottery centers in Europe and the United States.
Hogarth's "Morning" and "Night"-two of the set "Four Times of the Day"brought [Pound]2,520 in a sale of fine paintings at Christie's today. Private interests purchased the paintings.

Arthur Byron, veteran stage and motion picture actor, was elected Bouquets," g president of the Actors Equity Association at the union's twenty- is by Eleano fifth annual meeting yesterday afternoon in the Hotel Astor. many others results of the voting will not be announced officially until today, but French, Ga Mr. Byron was unopposed and his Chisholm, M election was conceded.

Miss Edith M. Schmidt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Schmidt of Maplewood, was married tonight to Francis F. Tentschert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Tentschert of East Orange, in the Disciples of Christ Church, East Orange. The pastor, the Rev. L. Ward McCreary, officiated.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: My attention-has been directed to certain newspaper and magazine articles concerning one Dan Casey, an old-time ballplayer, who is seriously established as the original of the immortal Casey of Ernest Thayer's masterpiece, "Casey at the Bat"' All this is utterly absurd.

An eight-foot putt' that hung on the lip of the cup for a split second, then dropped in for a par 4 today enabled Alex Watson; Scottish-born pro at the Hudson River club, to lead the field of district qualifiers for the National Professional Golfers Association championship.

A parade of 20,000 marchers, of whom 4,500 are Italian residents, will open New Haven's fortnight's tercentenary celebration tomorrow. The parade's ranks will be swelled by units from other Connecticut cities, including a score of fire companies.
Supreme Court Justice Edward Riegelman in Brooklyn denied yesterday the application of William Yoost, representing himself and other Class B stockholders of United Shipyards, Inc.,
Representative H. V. Teel, Democratic House member for seven successive terms, died today while at work on his 1,200-acre farm ten miles south of here. He was 68 years old.

Vernon Kennedy, wiry screw-ball hurler, came back today to the diamond where he pitched for three years and, with the aid of a timely offense by the Tigers that included a 440-foot park-record homer by Hank Greenberg, defeated his old White Sox mates, 5 to, 2, on six hits for his seventh consecutive victory.

An ancient stagecoach, which, according to legend, once gave General Grant a runaway ride, was bought today by Henry Ford. The vehicle, which traveled from the Hotel Ponemah to the Ponemah Railroad station, bounced along at a great rate of speed when the general was in it.

Dr. Allen Buckner Kanavel, 62-year-old surgeon and former president of the American College of Surgeons, was killed today when the automobile in which he was riding overturned after collision with a truck on the Bishop Highway, eight miles north of Mojave. He was a resident of Chicago, but had been living in Pasadena.

As law officers of at least a dozen States prepared to meet here next week to discuss moves to prevent retroactive income taxation on thousands of State employes, it was understood tonight that the administration, for the present at least, disapproves any attempt at drastic application of such back taxes.

With a present enrollment of 75,000, the Communist party in the United States has had an 87 1/2 per cent membership increase in the last two years, it was reported yesterday at the second session of the party's tenth national convention.
Bill Lee and Gabby Hartnett sank the revamped Pirates, 5 -to 0, today and carried the Cubs to within two games of the first-place Giants, who were idle, in the National League.

More than 1,000 pastors of Protestant churches and rabbis of. Jewislr congregations in all parts of the United States will preach tomorrow on the theme "Keep America Out of the War," it. was announced yesterday at the headquarters of the Fellowship of Reconciliation, 2,929 Broadway.

The thirty-third annual commencement exercises of the Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music were held last night in the auditorium of the school, 120 Claremont Avenue. One thousand or more persons were present.

Keron F. Dwyer, a former Assistant Attorney General and a member of the bar for more than twenty years, was suspended from practice for three years by order of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday.
Mrs. Liza Rabinowitz, 47 years old, of 3,840 Lyme Avenue, Sea Gate, one of fifteen residents of the private colony who were arrested last Saturday for picketing in protest against a $5 beach tax.

A ninety-day moratorium on public speeches by politicians and business men, accompanied by the latter's return to the task of getting new business, was urged by Representative Bruce Barton of New York at the annual convention of the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers here today.

The United States Steel Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to the company's registration statement covering its proposed issue of $100,000,000 of ten-year debentures due on June 1, 1948, giving the interest rate at 3 1/4 per cent.

DOUGHERTY, GEORGE N. (Jan. 9. 1936). Gross assets, $16,900; net, $14,412. To Edwin Clark. nephew. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $12,000. Ambrose C. Hindman, attorney, 27 William St.

Bernard Goldfarb, president of the Regent Drug Stores, Inc., of 1,016 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, was sentenced yesterday in Special Sessions Court, Brooklyn, to thirty days in the workhouse for failure to pay city sales taxes of about $1.200 for 1937.

Cooperating retail stores are expected to spend considerably more in newspaper advertising this year for National Cotton Week, starting on Monday, than they did last year, according to estimates by officials in charge of the promotion. The sum expended last year was said to be in excess of $2,000,000 and this year an additional 25 per cent may be spent, it was said.

To the astonishment of all political parties, including his own, and of the country generally, Prime Minister Eamon de Valera asked for dissolution of Parliament tonight. Thus Eire faces her second general election within ten months.
Parades and exercises in-honor of the nation's military dead will be held today and tomorrow in all parts of the city as a prelude to the more extensive celebrations, on Monday.

The Automobile Club of New York, the State affiliate of the American Automobile Association, won a test case yesterday to allow drivers to stop beyond the white lines for pedestrians when it is necessary to do so because the traffic signals are otherwise obscured.
High real estate taxes are stifling home ownership, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, which has completed a survey of thirty-three principal cities of the country.

Miss Lucille Phillips McGean today became the bride of Herman Scheyhing of New York at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Walton M. McGean. Dr. Joel B. Hayden of Western Reserve Academy officiated. Miss Jean McGean, sister of the bride, was maid of honor. John Leyren of New York was best man.

Charges that assets worth $6,207,000 were removed from the portfolios of six investment trusts and replaced with securities of dubious value, following a change in the management control of the trusts, were made by John J. Bennett Jr., State Attorney General, in an action brought yesterday in the Supreme Court.

Bill Terry, manager of the New York' Giants, and Jimmie Wilson, manager of the Philadelphia Nationals, were interviewed over WNYC be by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine last night to stimulate interest in the fire-police ball game on June 11.

At the traditional step singing ceremony, following an all class party last night, more than 250 Barnard College seniors unofficially became alumnae. The seniors in cap and gown marched in academic procession from Barnard Hall to Milbank Quadrangle on the campus, where members of the sophomore clss where members of the sophomore class gave each senior a rose.

A Federal grand jury returned indictments here late today charging three large automobile companies with conspiracy to violate the Sherman Anti-trust Law. The indictments named General the Motors Corporation, Ford Motor Company and Chrysler Corporation, their affiliated finance companies and fifty-nine individuals.

The current exhibition at the Macbeth Galleries is of more than passing interest, especially to collectors, since. it is made up of water-colors and oils by. Winslow Homer that have just become available. With but a few exceptions, these are examples from the collection that was assembled by Winslow's brother, Charles Savage Homer. When the brother died,
The American Prix Femina Committee has selected three books to be sent to Paris for consideration by the central committee, which will select one of them for the Prix Femina award.

Harry E. Ward, chairman of the advisory council, New York Chapter, American Institute of Banking, and president of the Irving Trust Company, announced yesterday that the council had been increased to sixteen members by the election of four additional members.

Frank S. Lockwood, a retired newspaper man and commercial artist, died on Thursday at his home, 1,837 Haring Street, Brooklyn, at the age of 79. Mr.-Lockwood entered the newspaper field as a young man on the old New York World and over a period of thirty years he worked on newspapers in St. Louis, Baltimore and Winston-Salem, N. C. He quit newspaper work twenty years ago to become a free-lance commercial artist.
Ed Dudley of Philadelphia and Ky Laffoon of Chicago retained their lead today in the $4,600 fourth annual Inverness best-ball golf tournament, although they split even in a pair of matches.

Bondholders of the Beauharnois Power Corporation, Ltd., approved today a reorganization plan evolved to provide for the amended-contract with the Ontario Hydro-Electric Power Commission. The contract also was approved.
Postmaster General Farley, speaking here this afternoon at a meeting of Democratic leaders, indicated that he wanted Goyernor Lehman to be a candidate for re-election.

Blakeen Jungfrau, a pure white poodle bitch, who has a long record of victories in specialty and allbreed shows, today was crowned best of breed in the exhibition of the Interstate Poodle Club held on the estate of Ogden H. Hammond.

Salem Knight, Mrs. C. M. Paterno's 3-year-old gelding, and Relay, Morton W. Smith's 5-year-old gelding, both of Greenwich, were winners on the opening night's program of the Connecticut State Horse Show in the \New Haven Arena tonight.

Ruth Strauss of New York was the winner tonight in the annual hoop-rolling contest at Smith College, wherein 400 seniors competed, wearing caps and gowns. Miss Strauss will be the first bride of her class, according to the collegiate tradition, and received a bridal bouquet of gardenias and lilies of the valley.

Samuel Seabury was elected president of the New York Law Institute at its 111th annual meeting yesterday afternoon at 120 Broadway. Mr. Seabury was unopposed. Three vice presidents were named: William Nelson Cromwell, Henry W. Taft and Frank L. Polk.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed on the eligible list of holders of licenses for service, as indicated, in junior high schools, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted license, as indicated:
The Yankees walloped their Eastern League farmhands, 10 to 2, today in an exhibition game that had to be called after seven innings because of interference from the overflow crowd of 8,000.

The marriage of Miss Anne Radford Trott, daughter of Mrs. Sydney Burnett Trott of this city and the late Mr. Trott, to Dr. William Garland Talmage of Succasunna, N. J., son of Mrs. William Walter Talmage of Petersburg, Va., and the late Mr. Talmage, took place here at noon today in Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church.

Tiebout Ave (11-3143), s e cor of 184th St, 113x64; Remlok Leasing Corp to Midway Realty' Corp, 2,200 Valentine Ave; mtg $33,000. Wilder Ave (17-5059), e s, 325 ft a of Nereid Ave, 50x97; Vito Perito to Anthony Marra, 4,372 Wilder Ave. 147th St, 464 e (9-2291); Kabee Realty Co to Meta M. Albers, 1,456 Dean St, Brooklyn.

Seven starters were named yesterday by Brutus Hamilton, coach of the University of California track team, for the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. championships at Randalls Island Stadium on Friday and Saturday of next week.

Government pressure on Paramount Pictures to eliminate all pacifist preachment in "Men With Wings," a history of aviation which William A. Wellman is producing and--directing, has brought a rewriting of the final twenty pages of dialogue.

Don Bradman's mighty bat gave the great Australian cricketer his sixth world record today. When he made 145 runs, not out, against Hampshire, Bradman became the first player twice to exceed 1,000 runs in May, opening month of England's cricket season.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Interest in wool continues at low ebb and prices are slightly softer. In the West, more or less of a stalemate exists, with buying small and scattered, at prices barely steady.

Two parcels of vacant land in the immediate vicinity of the New York Catholic Protectory grounds in the Bronx, upon which the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company will erect its housing project, were among the deals announced yesterday.

At the nineteenth hole in the semifinal round of the British amateur golf championship this evening, after Charley Yates had had his countrymen on tenterhooks in a match lasting well nigh four hours, he rammed down an eight-foot putt for a birdie 3 and victory over the British Walker Cup player, Hector Thomson.
12th St, 413 E: 6-story tenement, 24.4x 103.3; Title Guarantee and Trust Co., trustee, against 415 E. 12th St. Corp.; due, $17,139; to plaintiff for $1,000. By JAMES R. MURPHY
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for alterations to numerous structures in Manhattan and Brooklyn. Architects also filed for new houses in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens.

Several New York drama critics, I whose proclivities include writing books, acting, and spending time in Vermont, were travestied yesterday morning by members of the Professional Children's School at the twenty-fourth commencement exercises.

The government's spy investigation took a sensational turn last evening when United States Attorney Lamar Hardy arrested a political officer of the German National Socialist Party, a second radio officer, the pastry cook and a steward, all employed on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, as material witnesses following a daylong session of the grand jury.

An investing client of J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker, purchased the three-story apartment at 53 Twenty-second Street, West New York, N. J., from the Hudson Trust Company. There are nine suites of three and four rooms in the building, which will be altered by the new owner.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,203,000 bales, against 1,197,000 a week ago, 1,196,000 two weeks ago, 1,215,000 three weeks ago and 928,000 a year ago, of which American 797,000 bales, against 794,000 a week ago, 800,000 two weeks ago, 820,000 three weeks ago and 400,000 a year ago.

A landscape by Jean Baptiste Caille Corot, "Le Passeur de l'Ile Saint-Ouen," was bought by Frank Schnittjer for $16,000 at the third and final session of the auction sale of the Francis Ralston Welsh collection of porcelains, jades and paintings at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., yesterday afternoon.

If concessions are to be made in the pending Canadian trade treaty with the United States, Canada should be "asking and not giving," the Canadian Chamber ofCommerce Trade Conference was told today by Harry J. Carmichael, vice president and general manager of General Motors of Canada.

W. Warren Barbour, long an announced aspirant to the Republican nomination for the United States Senate, officially entered the race today when his campaign manager filed petitions of candidacy with the New Jersey Secretary of State's office.
The directors of the General Electrio Company voted yesterday a dividend of 20 cents a share on the capital stock. This is a reduction of 10 cents from the last disbursements, on April 25.

James Russell, rated one of the best soccer half-backs who ever played in Canada, died yesterday at the age of 62. Born in Scotland, he played football with several of his native land's important teams, including Vale of Leven, before coming to Montreal thirty-six years ago.
The Amerian Trust Company and Bankamerica Company obtained yesterday $3,747,110 of registered warrants of the State of California on a 0.75 per cent interest basis, plus a premium of $1,663.72.

A slackening in the volume of engineering construction work is reelected in the week's report of awards compiled by The Engineering News-Record. Compared with the same period of last year, the total of all awards, $32,850,000, is off 43 per cent from the $57,616,000 reported in 1937.

The successful marketing of the first obligations of the first national mortgage association organized under recent amendments to the National Housing Act, has brought many inquiries from various sources as to the possibility of organizing more such companies with private capital.

Statements by Secretary of Commerce Roper and Under-Secretary of State Welles. urging the importance of continued operation of-the Munson- Line ships in the service between New York and the east coast of South America, were made public here yesterday by the Maritime Commission.
Three agreements between Great Britain and Turkey, whereby the latter will spend ??10,000,000 as a result of a guarantee of credits by the British Credit Export Department, were signed yesterday.

MOST Americans would like to see' the Chinese kick the living daylights out of the invading Japanese. It is a sympathy based on admiration for the valor of China and a profound contempt for the motives of Japan.

Arthur Eisen will join Jay-Thorpe, Inc., as merchandise manager on June 6. He formerly held a similar position with Hattie Carnegie. The Consulate General of Colombia in New York advises that all shippers must renew the registration of signatures of persons authorized to sign consular invoices on their behalf, not later than June 15, according to the Merchants Association.

The State Tax Commission entered an assessment of $4,318,709 today against the Maryland rolling stock of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, overruling the road's claim that the equipment was tax-free by provision of the charter of 1827.

Laying the groundwork for evidence seeking to link Harlan County deputy sheriffs with the murder of a union organizer, government witnesses testifying before Federal Judge H. Church Ford added kidnapping today to the crimes attributed to the coal operators and peace officers who are on trial here on charges of criminal conspiracy.
William E. Buffington, former Controller of the Postoffice Department, died here on Wednesday at his brother's home at the age of 65. He came here several weeks ago after becoming ill in Miami, Fla.
Funeral services were held at 4 P. M. today for Rear Admiral Thomas Picket Magruder, retired, who died yesterday. Burial will take place tomorrow at Arlington National cemetery.

Orders for fabricated structural steel booked in April amounted to 92,130 tons, for the second successive monthly gain, compared to 84,257 tons in March, to 57,144 tons in February and to 80,320 tons in January.

Memorial Sunday will be observed tomorrow in all churches. There will be peace sermons at the request of the Greater New York Committee on Keep America Out of War. Posts of the American Legion will attend services in several churches. Catholic pastors will preach along the same line at the suggestion of the Union of Prayer for Peace.

A third man died today from burns inflicted in an explosion of a chemical liquefaction unit at the Belle plant of the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Company. A blood transfusion failed to save Leon S. Alden,

A warm welcome was extended today to six delegates of the Slovak League of America and more than 100 members of the Slovak organizations in the United States affiliated with the league who are on their way to attend the Slovak congress at Bratislava, Czechoslovakia.
President Roosevelt was in Arthurdale, W. Va., inspecting a government project and speaking on the Tax Bill.

The grounds of the World's Fair will not be open to the public today under a new schedule announced yesterday that restricts visitors to Sunday from 2 to 8 P. M. Formerly the fair gounds were open on Saturday and Sunday but it was decided to omit one visiting day to enable the employes to get a needed day off.

The will of Edward Tuck, American philanthropist, resident of France for fifty years, who died on April 30 at Monte Carlo, France, in his ninety-fifth year, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday, made generous provisions for institutions, societies, relatives, friends and employes. The value of his estate was not estimated.

A certificate of authority has been granted to the Trade Bank of New York, 225 West Thirty-fourth Street, to operate a personal loan department at 72 Second Avenue, Manhattan, the State Banking Department announced today.

Mrs. Marjorie Speers Browning, widow of Gilbert Browning of this city, will be married to Selwyn Bywater of this city and Greenwich, on June 4 in Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street. The ceremony will be followed by a reception at the country home of the prospective bride's cousins, Mr. and Mrs. George Arents, in Rye, N. Y.

Six men will be ordained into the rabbinate and. two, honorary degrees will be conferred tomorrow morning at the thirteenth annual commencement exercises of the Jewish Institute of Religion at Carnegie Hall.

Albert E. Jessurun, Chicago food broker, who led the fight against "rent hogs" in Chicago in 1921,:-died today of a heart attack in Madison, Wis., where he had been visiting friends. He was 73 years old.

The Australian Veterinary Association's conference here was told today that the results of experiments by the Council of Scientific and Industrial Research with vaccine prepared from the germ of pleuropneumonia had shown that it gave cattle immunity for a year at least.
The first of three lectures on structural welding at the New York Building School will be given on Tuesday evening by William A. Hoffberg, consulting engineer.

A contra-seasonal spurt in cottonmill activity last week sent the adjusted index forward to 87.2 from 80.8. The index stood at 141.9 for the week ended May 22, 1937. Sales of print cloths this week were estimated at 40 per cent of production, which,

Christie R. Bohnsack, who was program director of WNYC, the municipal broadcasting station, from the time it was organized in 1924 until January of this year, brought suit yesterday in Supreme Court to obtain his reinstatement.

Prompted by discouraging weather reports, Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S. C. yesterday decided on a second -postponement of the world welterweight championship bout between Barney Ross, Chicagoan, who holds the title, and Henry Armstrong of California, holder of the world featherweight crown.

A threat of strikes assuming almost the proportions of a general labor holiday hung over Akron tonight as an aftermath of bitter fighting early this morning between police, sheriff's deputies and striking .members of the United Rubber Workers of America, in which eighty were injured, at least one gravely.

An alleged fugitive was shot and a young woman passer-by wounded yesterday when the police raided a rooming house at 162 State Street, Brooklyn. The raid resulted in six persons being arrested as burglars, receivers of stolen goods and narcotic addicts.

Miss Diana Maria Gerli and Daniel Nelson Adams were married yesterday afternoon in St. James Church, Madison Avenue at Seventy-first Street. The Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, rector of the church, assisted by the Rev. James A. Paul, associate rector, performed the ceremony before an altar adorned with vases of calla lilies and syringas.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert B. Dewey have come to the Ritz-Carlton from Washington. Mrs. Oren E. Taft of Cedar Brae, Watch Hill, R. I., is at the St. Regis. Mr. and Mrs. Fitz Eugene Dixon of Elkins Park, Pa., accompanied by Mrs. John Blakeley, have come to the Waldorf-Astoria.
The marriage of Miss Ruth Doudiet, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Er nest A. Doudiet of Brooklyn, to Frank Cash Stockman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank J. Stockman of Maplewood, N. J.,

In a strong baritone voice, Adolph Lewisohn observed his eighty-ninth birthday here today by singing operatic arias in French, German, Italian and English. Reporters, seeking an interview, had to wait while he finished an aria from La Traviata.

Heroes Square in the heart of Budapest, almost a quarter-mile deep and half as wide, is a great sea of faces at midnight as this dispatch is being written. Each face represents a man kneeling in supplication before God, absorbed in adoration of the Blessed Sacrament.

Exports and imports of the United States by classified groups of merchandise during April, as announced by the Department of Commerce, are compared herewith with those of March, 1938, and April, 1937. Exports as given in the subjoined tables cover only domestic exports, not foreign goods re-exported.

Mr. Birchall's account of the deeply religious fervor of the vast open-air congregations assembled in the Square of the Heroes in Budapest for the solemnities of the Eucharistic Congress is a welcome relief from the rest of the news from Central Europe.
Metropolitan Museum of Art. "The Sanctuary at Delos," Stuart M. Shaw, 11 A. M.; "Late Gothic Sculpture," Harry D. M. Grier, 2 P. M.; motion pictures, 2:30 P.-M.

The Court of Appeals has handed down a decision modifying an order of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn and the Kings County Surrogate's Court by striking out a direction that Edward H. Wilson, trustee of the Brooklyn Bar Association, and John J. Kean, assistant district attorney of Brooklyn, must pay $29,305 to the estate of Joseph Auditore, stevedore, who died in 1920.

Miss Mae Constance Flynn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Flynn of Brooklyn was married to Joseph Downey Barker, son of Mrs. Alfred Barker of New York and the late Mr. Barker, yesterday afternoon in the Embassy Suite of the Ambassador.

It was officially announced today that President Ignaz Moscicki, who is in residence at Spala, received last Wednesday MM. Madejczyk, and Wojcik, prominent member of the Piast, the moderate section of the Peasant party.
What is now the Brace Memorial Newsboys House on Chambers Street started out eighty-five years ago as the Newsboys LodgingHouse.
Sentiment in Congress over President Roosevelt's Arthurdale speech was as mixed tonight as it was originally on the new Tax Bill.

The Treasury today sold its weekly issue of discount bills at an average price equivalent to 0.025 per cent interest, the same average price that was obtained on a similar issue at the beginning of this week. As a rule the bills are sold each Monday, but they were marketed today because next Monday is a legal holiday.

The proposal of the Mexican Government for compensating American oil companies for their expropriated properties involves an arrangement of selling the concerns' oil at a price fixed at a percentage below the market price over a period

Miss Charlotte Glutting of Rock Spring, Eastern champion, and Miss Alice Rutherfurd of Baltusrol won the Women's New Jersey Golf Association best-ball tourney with a gross score of 152 for the thirty-six holes of play that ended at the Green Brook Country Club today.

The Social Security Board restored to Oklahoma today Federal grants for assistance to aged persons, dependent children and the blind. The grants were cut off in March when the board found that the administrative machinery for the operation of the State social security plan did not conform to Federal standards.

President Roosevelt signed today a bill authorizing construction of the Long Island loop bridges by Suffolk County, N. Y. The measure would authorize collection of tolls on the bridges, provided a sinking fund was created to amortize the construction cost within forty years.

In an Associated Press dispatch from Albany, dated May 17, printed in THE TIMES on May 18, it was stated that "telegraph liquor delivery" was prohibited by the Court of Appeals in a unanimous decision on appeal by Gifts by Wire, Inc., of New York City, holding the procedure violative of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law.

Conferences today of officials of the Electric Bond and Share Company and its subsidiaries and Tennessee Valley Authority officials cleared the way for the drafting of a final contract covering the joint purchase of the Tennessee Public Service Company facilities in the Knoxville, Tenn., area by Knoxville and the TVA.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 27 unless specified: Sarawak to Brunei: Canopus, Pigeon, S-36, 37, 38, 39, 41. At Annapolis: Salmon, Savannah.

Two cases of cholera have developed in Shanghai refugee camps, while the Pootung area just across the Whangpoo River is at present ravaged by this dread Asiatic scourge and the death toll is mounting daily.

A report of the Reynolds Investing Company certified by indepeend ent auditors covering the period of two months and eighteen days ended March 18, 1938, or the date when present directors took office, shows a net operating loss of $25,654 after interest, amortization of discount and expense on 5 per cent debentures and Federal and State taxes.

United States Representative 'Jerry O'Connell, attempting to make an antiHague speech in a Jersey City public park without a police 'permit, was seized tonight by the police, held for an hour and then put 'on a Hudson tube train. for Newark.
Federico Paez, who resigned as President of Ecuador last Oct. 23, today took refuge in the Chilean Legation after the government had ordered his arrest to face charges of misuse of public funds.

Seven armed Arabs today entered the Arab village of Miska in Southern Palestine and captured seven leading villagers, whom they took out and shot. Four died immediately and the three others are dying.

Richard C. Gill, author and explorer, sailed on the Grace liner Santa maria last night for Ecuador, where he will head the Gill-Merril Ecuadorean Expedition to study rare native drugs used by head-hunting Indian tribes. C. H. S. Merril of Boston, who financed the expedition, did not make the trip.

Paragraphs 2e and 2f, Special Orders 90, dated Dec. 10, 1937, are amended so as to C include the following changes: Paragraph 2e, add Lt. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, C. E. Paragraph 2f, add Major Herbert W. Beyette, Q.M.C.
Miss Eleanore Marienne Grushlaw, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Israel Grushlaw of 271 Central Park West, was married to Robert Stuart Holzman, sorr of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S.

C. I. O. leaders today threatened a twenty-fourhour general strike in the Detroit area in retaliation for what they termed police brutality in a clash with pickets in which fifty-five persons were injured yesterday.

Pedestrian fatalities accounted for more than 61 per cent of the State's total traffic deaths in the first four months of this year, Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, indicated today.

A cool, rainy morning had the effect of slowing up trading in the wholesale markets. Slaughter house business was fair to slow. The beef market was mostly unchanged. Veal cuts were weak to lower, lamb slightly stronger, fresh pork cuts steady to lower. Early trading in kosher meats indicated the beef market to be uneven, veal slightly stronger, lamb higher. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

George Weinberg and Harry (Big Harry) Schoenhaus, two of the gangsters indicted as co-conspirators with Tammany Leader James J. Hines and others in the operation of the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenhelmer policy racket told Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora yesterday that they were of guilty as charged.

The Killearn Farm horses, owned by Alfred Maclay of Millbrook, N. Y., dominated the fourth program of the Devon Horse Show today. The oval was a sea of mud from the heavy rains of yesterday, but riders and horses both gave high-class performances.

Trout fishermen from Eastern Pennsylvania and Western New Jersey will be glad to hear that the big mayfly hatches are now coming out, and if the weather will only hold clear over the week-end the fishing should be fine in these areas.

Although the demand for apartments in Manhattan during the early Spring of this year was relatively quiet, rentals in recent weeks have shown considerable activity and buildings under the management of Pease Elliman, Inc., now show vacancies averaging less than 6 per cent, according to S. R. Firestone, vice president.

Dr. William Stroud, Cavendish Professor of Physics at Leeds University from 1885 until 1909 and coinventor with the late Professor Archibald Barr of a variety of range finders, died today in Torquay at the age of 78.

Preston Ware Orem, a music writer and critic, died of a heart attack yesterday as' he conducted the Mastbaum Vocation School orchestra in the first playing of his most recent composition. "Out of the West." He was 73 years old.

As a result of last night's air raid on Cerbere, in which all the bombs fell on the French side of the frontier, slightly wounding three persons and wrecking two houses, Premier Edouard Daladier has decided to strengthen French border defenses.
Amateur racing comes back to the metropolitan district today with the fourth annual meeting of the Fairfield and Westchester Hounds at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club at Port Chester, N. Y.

Nineteen foreign countries are listed in the current issue of Commerce Reports, the official foreign trade magazine published by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, as inquiring for the purchase of American goods of a wide variety.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $73,990.400, to be represented by two State and thirty-three municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $61,551,110 for this week. .
The Plain Dealer will say tomorrow Branch Rickey, St. Louis Cardinals' vice president, "is out to 'get" Kenesaw M. Landis, Baseball Commissioner.

A virtual insistence that he was still chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority was contained in a letter from Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, replying today to charges made yesterday before the Congressional committee investigating the TVA by his successor, Dr. Harcourt A. Morgan.

New York State is about to begin spending $40,000,000 for construction of public buildings, hospitals, schools and prisons, utilizing funds authorized under the bond issue voted by the people. at the last election.

The appearance of two major loans lifted the total of new bond financing this week to $66,181,000, the largest volume since the period ending April 22, when $76,048,500 in new issues was marketed. This compares with only $4,872,000 in bonds offered last week, and with $5,035,000 floated during this week last year.

Coach George Eastman's Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School squad of Brooklyn got off to a fine start in the defense of its team championship in the city C. H. S., A. A. track and field meet by winning three of the first four places in the 220-yard low hurdles test held at Ohio Field yesterday.

Several steel companies will observe the Memorial Day holiday, it was learned yesterday, and the weekly figures of operating rates to be issued on Tuesday therefore should show some decline from the 29 per cent figure for the current week.

From California, that fruitful mother of projects for the individual and the general good, comes a declaration of policies worthy of its environment. Mr. Alfred A. Wright of Los Angeles anounces his candidacy for the Demo- to cratic nomination for Representative in Congress of the Fourteenth District.

An indictment charging extortion, bribery and accepting an unlawful fee was handed up yesterday to General Sessions Judge Cornelius F. Collins by the New York County grand jury against Detective Thomas F. Lillis on the complaint of Alexis Dawydoff of a former Russian imperial family.

The disappearance of Miss Elsie Custes, chief clerk at the offices of the Public Works Administration here, was reported to the police yesterday by officials of the Eastern Steamship Company. Miss Custes was missing when the company's liner Acadia left Bermuda on its return from a cruise started last Saturday.

Reconsideration by all Jewish welfare groups of their original objectives and readjustment, in the light of new and changing conditions, of their activities and methods of approach to present-day problems were "next steps" urged as primary essentials to successful endeavor at today's sessions of the Conference of Jewish Social Welfare by leaders of the organization and two allied associations participating in the annual meeting.
Deals for houses in Harlem and on Washington Heights in which operators figured as principals were announced yesterday.

A preliminary estimate of business activity in New England for April indicates a sharp drop from the figure for 1937, the New England Council reports. The index for April was 79.1 per cent of estimated normal, which compares with 79.9 per cent in March and 113.9 per cent in April, 1937, the high point of last year.

The stock markets here generally were quiet today, while profit-taking caused a mackening of the demand for gold mixing shares. Gilt-edge issued were firm and among the foreign loans Czechoslovak bonds found some support.

The amount of government bonds that may be outstanding at any one time was increased from $25,000,000,000 to $30,000,000,000 today when President Roosevelt signed a bill which the Treasury said would give it more flexible financing powers.

Retired Engineer of Steamer Thomas F. Shea. formerly a member of Engine 284, residing at 572 72d St., Brooklyn, died May 26. Funeral will take place from his late residence at 9:30 A. M. Monday, May 30. Interment at Holy Cross Cemetery.

An electrical engineer whose contracts included the White House lighting system as well as important projects here committed suicide because he had been "ruined financially" by Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, according to testimony yesterday in the injunction suit against the union.

Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane of the Court of Appeals criticized "the ill-feeling which-is manifested on all sides in human relations as they exist today" in addressing members of the Alumni Association of the Law School of Columbia University at a luncheon yesterday in the Lawyers Club. 115 Broadway.

A hearing to determine whether 1,098 employes in the operating and. Th i maintenance department of Rocke. feller Center wish to be represented in collective bargaining by the Building and Construction Trades Council of the A. F. of L.
Wreckage resembling that of an airplane was sighted about thirty miles southeast of here this morning by the steamer Selma City, en route from Portland to Norfolk.

Hog prices snapped up to a new high since April and uncovered a top of $8.95 today. Trade interest appeared to believe that the early Summer low point was passed. Lambs and cattle held steady on a thoroughly active week-end market, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

Negotiations between RKO and Alexander Korda for Sabu, the lad in "Elephant Boy," for the leading role in Rudyard Kipling's "Gunga Din," were canceled today when RKO refused Korda the services of Ginger Rogers for that of the boy.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 25: COMMANDER Biesemier, H., Washington, D. 0., about June 1, to command the Phelps.

Crosstown traffic using the Seventy-ninth Street transverse road in Central Park was disrupted for about ten minutes at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon when an eighteeninch water main beneath the surface was shattered by a blast of dynamite set off by workmen in removing rock in the park for a sewer construction job.

The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today exemption from the registration provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act to the Phelps Dodge Corporation on the ground that the company was only incidentally a holding company and did not derive any matrial part of its income from a utility company.

Miss Janet Law Patrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George N. Patrick of Troy, N. Y., was married this morning to Kirkwood A. Tischler of New York, son of Otto E. Tischler of New Rochelle, and the late Mrs..
A beaming Mayor La Guardia inspected $225,000 of new police equipment yesterday and incidentally treated about 35,000 passers-by to an unscheduled motorcade.

A sentence of ten to thirty years was imposed in Federal Court here today on Stanley Jasosky, 19 years old, of 637 Market Street, Newark, who had entered guilty pleas on two counts charging he wrote extortion letters to Murray Levine of New Rochelle, father of the kidnapped Peter Levine.

On their own applications, to take effect 12 midnight, May 31, 1938: LIEUTENANT-Timothy Lynch, 1st Precinct, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed June 14, 1904. PATROLMEN To take effect 12 midnight, May 27:

The rain-filled skies beclouding the beginning of the Memorial Day week-end grew darker yesterday for twenty-five members of the City Council whose vacation plans were upset by a peremptory message from Mayor La Guardia calling them to a special meeting at 1 o'clock Tuesday afternoon in City Hall.

The number of young women seeking work in this city has increased fivefold since last Spring and there are fewer jobs available, Mrs.. Margaret Davidson, supervisor of the- girl guidance bureau of the Girls Service League, 138 East Nineteenth Street, reported yesterday.
Mayor S; Davis Wilson backed down today in his refusal to let Governor Earle's Constitution Commemoration Committee use Independence Hall June 21 for a celebration of Ratification Day.

Mr. William Strang, chief of the Central European division of the British Foreign Office, has been sent to sound out Berlin and Prague on the possibility of establishing an international commission to help keep peace o?? the Czech-German border.

To obtain closer cooperation between the Department of Health and the Board of Education, a committee of representatives of both departments has been established. Problems relating to the welfare of the pupils will be handled as a coordinated undertaking.

Estate, $500. To Julia Blatt, widow, executrix, 250 W. 85th St., life estate in residue; six specific bequests. FOSTER, FRANKLIN J. (April 21). Estate, more than $5,000. To Eleanor B. Foster, 661 Lincoln Ave., Orange, N. J., widow, executrix, residue; one specific bequest.
President Roosevelt signed today a bill to pay $19,030 to the estate of F. Gray Griswold of New York as reimbursement for money seized during the World War under the Trading With the Enemy Act. Mr.

Ever since Hitler rose to power we have heard of a "Volksauto" or "people's car" which was to be so cheap that every German workingman could afford to buy it and speed into the country of a week-end. Fluctuating as it did from 700 to 1,200 marks, its quoted price became an indication of oratorical favor.

A long controversy between Massachusetts and Georgia over the extradition of prisoners flared anew today when Governor E. D. Rivers refused to turn over to this State's authority a Boston man charged with nonsupport of his wife and children.

Ira Hall of Terre Haute, Ind., today joined the list of starters for the Indianapolis 500-mile automobile race on Memorial Day as the field was increased to twenty-eight, five short of the maximum. Hall, one of five drivers to qualify between showers, was timed at 118.255 miles an hour.
Retail trade here this week held at about recent levels, with expansion of consumer demand for Summer merchandise restricted by cold and rainy weather.

Dr. John Brewster Hubbs, retired Episcopal rector, died last night at the age of 71. He was a former chaplain of Hobart and William Smith colleges here and a former rector of St. Peter's Episcopal Church. He was a native of Elnora, N. Y.
Former Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas expressed confidence in an address here tonight that the United States would "muddle through in a way' democracy has of coming through these periods."

Stocks closed firmer at irregularly lower levels after prices declined moderately; turnover, 760,710 shares. United States Government bonds steady in smallest full day's dealings since Sept. 11, 1930; other bonds lower; transactions, $4,837, 300.

The New York Buddhist Church gave a purchase money mortgage for $11,000, due five years nence, to the Bowery Savings Bank when it bought 171 W 94th St. Samuel Sason sold to Maria Campagna 326 E 73d St taking back a purchase money mortgage for $8,000, due in three years at 5 ner cent.

Five members of the crew of the whaling factory ship New Sevilla went mad and five others disappeared over the side of the vessel, Michael O'Brien of Halifax, a member of the crew, who returned home after the vessel arrived in Scotland, said today.

Donald C. Barnes, president of the Engineers Public Service Company, announced yesterday that on next Tuesday the utility holding company would effect certain major changes in its capital accounts. The changes, it was indicated, had been requested by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Woodruff Randolph, secretarytreasurer of the International Typographical Union, announced tonight unofficial returns of the I. T. U. election, held Wednesday and Thursday, had been received from approximately one-half of the 900 local unions.

The Yonkers Electric Light and Power Company and its parent concern, Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., yesterday filed an application with the Public Service Commission for authority to issue $9,515,000 of 3 1/2 per cent debentures to mature June 1, 1948.

Twentythree officers and directors of the Associated Gas and Electric system have resigned interlocking directorates involving about 135 directors ships and officerships in the Associated Gas group of companies, the Federal Power Commission announced today.

G. Le Roy Kemp, indicted land agent on the Merritt Parkway, will be tried in Superior Court. here in June on a charge .of common law conspiracy in sharing, in $86,000 in parkway land sale commissions with Samuel H. Silberman of Stamford and Thomas N. Cooke of Greenwich.

8th St, 394 E, 27.9x97.6; Esther Brovender et al to Sam Klein, 394 E 8th St (quitclaim). Lafayette St, w s, block from Astor P1 to 8th St, 149.1 on former, 159.1 on latter; Enos S. Booth to Title Guarantee and Trust Co, as trustee; consideration, $462,500 (foreclosure).

The visit of the officers of the gunboat Erie, just ended, is cited by the Chilean press as the most recent reflection of the cordial spirit now linking Chile with the United States as a result of President Roosevelt's "good neighbor" policy.

Gotham Equities Corporation (Joseph K. Alliger and Hyman Ratner) has purchased the two-story dwelling at 333 Avenue W, Brooklyn, for cash. The house occupies a plot 20 by 100 feet, contains three apartments and carries an assessment of $7,300.

Late this afternoon on the Harlem River course which runs along the Speedway wall, the curtain will descend on the short-distance racing of the year's. college rowing, except for some few informal races. Harvard and Columbia, in two races, will clear the decks and set sail for New. London and Poughkeepsie, respectively, after today's regatta.

Foreign exchanges, in the face of renewed apprehension over the Central European situation, failed yesterday to maintain the gains registered on Thursday and all the principal European monetary units except the belga declined in terms of the dollar.

Mr. and Mrs. John Davis Lodge of Oakfields, Mill Hill, near London, England, have announced here the engagement of Mrs. Lodge's sister, Miss Gloria Braggiotti of this city, to Emlen Etting of Philadelphia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emlen Pope Etting of Southfield, Haverford, Pa.

The marriage of Miss Madeline Heckenbleickner, daughter of Mrs. Ingenuin Heckenbleickner and the late Mr. Heckenbleickner, to Lieutenant Erickson Snowden Nichols, United States Army Air Corps, took place here tonight at the home of the bride's mother.
Johnny Vander Meer, his fireball looking like a BB shot. outpitched Bill MCGee tonight to give the Reds the first league night game of the season, 2 to 1, against the Cards in ten tense innings.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 21 amounted to'545,808 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 3,995 cars, or 0.7 per cent, more than for the preceding week, but 229,266 cars, or 29.6 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 137,598 cars, or 20.2 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

The government again accused the Supreme Court today of reversing itself in the Kansas City stockyards case. In a brief filed with the court Solicitor General Robert H. Jackson asserted that the court's reference in. its April ruling to -a tentative report by a trial examiner "constitutes an unqualified reversal of its previous decision" in May, 1936.

Net operating income of the first fifty-eight railroads to report for April declined 70.1 per cent from the total for April, 1937. This compared with a drop of 68.2 per cent shown by the first thirty-three companies to report. Heavy declines in earnings by some large railroads brought up the percentage of decrease.

The need for young persons to be genuinely educated and equipped with the power to use their own F minds was stressed yesterday morning by Mrs. Jessica Garretson Cosgrave, founder of the Lenox School, 52 East Seventy-eighth Street, in her address at the school's twentysecond annual commencement exercises.

Charles M. Hay of St. Louis, counsel for the Railway Labor Executives Association, today challenged the report submitted by the Bureau of the Budget to the House Interstate Commerce Committee, opposing the bill to establish a Federal unemployment compensation system for railway employes.

A registration statement covering $2,522,000 of general mortgage bonds, series I, due in 1967, proceeds from the sale of which will be employed for capital expenditures, has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933 by the Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation, Rochester, N. Y.

Joseph Stalin, general secretary of the Communist party, and Premier Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff are now candi- from dates for the Supreme Soviets of every one of the eleven constituent republics and of the twenty-two autonomous republics forming the Soviet Union.

The executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, which has been in session here since Monday, decided late today that it could best work for peace within the ranks of labor by.. staying with the C. I. O., at least for the time being.

Operators of four drug stores here were permanently enjoined today by Supreme Court Justice John Van Voorhis from selling any of the products of Eli Lilly Company, drug manufacturers, at prices under those established by the company.

The Cunard White Star liner Georgic, leaving today for Cobh, Southampton, Havre and London, will have as passengers fourteen members of the Dublin Abbey Theatre Players, headed by F. R. Higgins, managing director.
Senate is discussion of the Relief-Recovery Bill dragged through a fifth session today with. no action taken except the offering of new earmarking and other amendments to be voted upon later.
The leader of an expedition of women climbers, envisaging the feat of climbing25,600-foot virgin peaks in the Eastern Himalayas, will leave here in two weeks. She is Miss Edgar Jones.

Twelve members of the three lower classes at Hamilton College will open the annual commencement exercises when they compete June 10 in the McKinney Prize Declamation contest. The appointees are: Junior--W. Allenby Jones, Utica;

The marriage of Miss Mary Washington Hotchkiss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Stuart Hotchkiss of East River, to Sydney Messer Williams Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Williams of Wellesley, Mass., and Peterborough, N. H., took place here at noon today in Center Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Oscar E. Maurer, who was assisted by the Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving of Trinity Church, Boston.

The most trying period they have faced in years confronts industrial buyers in the next two to three months, George A. Renard, secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, stated here yesterday on his return from the twenty-third annual convention of the organization in St. Louis last week.
