Sales of coal stokers, according to the Stokers Manufacturers Association of Chicago, increased by nearly 30 per cent in 1937 and indications are that in spite of generally unsettled business conditions, 1938 will prove a very satisfactry year for the industry.

A third dawn-to-dusk air link between North and South America will be forged tomorrow when Pan American Airways begins preliminary scheduled flights from Miami, Fla., to Maracaibo, Venezuela. Carrying only commercial cargo

TESTS aimed to determine the distance ultra-short waves cover will be conducted by the Naval Research Laboratory at Anacostia, D. C., from June 3 to 18 and July 23 to Aug. 6. The Navy Department is interested in the distance at which these transmissions may be heard and is requesting that persons observing the tests notify the laboratory by mail or otherwise.

SO far this season there have been nineteen benefit performances for the Stage Relief Fund, opening with a Tuesday matinee last September of "Babes in Arms" and including a Thursday showing in December of "The Fireman's Flame."

The effects of farm legislation on the nation's food supply will be discussed at a meeting on Wednesday evening sponsored by the Women's National Republican Club, at the clubhouse, 3 West Fifty-first Street. speakers will be Jared Van Wagenen, a trustee of Cornell University, and H. W. Jeffers, New Jersey dairyman. Mr. Van Wagenen's topic is announced as "The Truth About Secretary Wallace and Our Daily Bread."

The value of buildings of all types throughout the country for which permits were issued was 13 per cent higher in April than in March, but 24 per bent lower than in April, 1937, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins announced yesterday.

The Wesleyan nine defeated Connecticut State today, 6--4. Bogue and Sonstroem singled in the first inning and Bogue scored on a bunt by Horne. and a double by McCabe then talied Sonstroem and Horne. McCabe, who had three safeties, hit another double in the fifth and counted when Daddario doubled to center. Grosvenor checked a State rally in the seventh.

Behind the airtight pitching of George (Lefty) Rusznak and Walt Shinn's batting, Pennsylvania gained an easy 7-2 victory over Columbia in an Eastern Intercollegiate League baseball game on Franklin Field today. The yellow ball was used here for the first time and was found effective.

The number of mail orders received in the wholesale market last week was slightly larger than in the preceding week, according to a special summary of market conditions prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyer, but the quantities of merchandise

The 277-acre estate formerly owned by John P. Argenti at Stockbridge, Mass., in the heart of the Berkshire Mountains, has been purchased by Artur Rodzinski, conductor of the Cleveland Symphony Orchestra, reports Previews, Inc.

IT is still true that a majority of car owners do not carry insurance and are not financially responsible if involved in an accident even when the injured person may be permanently crippled and his dependents permanently pauperized.

and Mrs. William Grant Palmer of Valley Haven, this place, formerly of Scarsdale, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Louise Palmer, to John Knipe Herrmann, son of Mrs. Charles Edward Herrmann of Scarsdale and the late Mr. Herrmann.
Insurgent troops fighting down the highway from Teruel to Sagunto today reported the capture of Puerto Escandon, a key position on the way to the Valencia coast.

Sharply divergent views as to the practicability of the Wages and Hours Bill passed by the House last week, and as to its constitutionality, are expressed in special reports prepared by members of the Trade and Commerce Bar Association, which were issued to the membership yesterday.

The Federal Savings and Loan Associations of Metropolitan New York have a record volume of funds available for home loan investments, reports Harold N. Brodhead, public relations chairman of the group.

Robert (Bob) Lannon, varsity end at the University of Iowa the past three seasons, has been appointed assistant football coach at Syracuse University, Lewis P. Andreas, director of athletics, announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP).--Field offices reported to the Public Works Administration today the receipt of 106 new applications for loans and grants totaling $44,998,173.

John Lorenz, regular candidate for the council of the Actors Equity Association, defeated Samuel Bonnell, independent nominee, by a vote of 645 to 327, according to the result, announced yesterday, of Equity's annual election on Friday. Mr. Lorenz will serve as the councilor on WPA Federal Theatre matters. The contest between Mr.

A $130,000,000 public works program, drafted by the city administration, was transmitted yesterday. to Colonel M. E. Gilmore, regional director of the Public Works Administration. The Federal agency was asked by Budget Director Kenneth Dayton, representing Mayor La Guardia, to assume 45 per cent of the cost of the program.

Representative Havenner, Democrat, of California, made Congressional history today even if he did not establish a precedent. He turned back to the government $1,200 allowed him for traveling expenses, saying that he did not feel justified in keeping the money.
DETROIT. WHIILE new car sales are showing some improvement in various parts of the country, there has been no material change in production rates during the past week.

A 136-MILE non-stop, sealed-clutch run from the 100-degree heat of Death Valley to the zero cold of Whitney Portal, 8,371 feet above sea level, was made recently under the official observation of the A. A. A. by a stock Oldsmobile Six sedan equipped with automatic safety transmission, it was made known last week.

Former and present students of Professor Ross G. Harrison, biologist, who has been cited as "one of the most famous discoverers and teachers of the New World," gathered today to honor the scientist, who will retire from active teaching next month after thirty-one years of service on the Yale faculty.

Alexander Murdoch, director of the municipal Department of Public Works in the cabinet of Mayor Harry A. Mackey, died yesterday in Fitzgerald-Mercy Hospital, Darby, after an illness of three weeks. He was 76 years old.

The Sales Executives Club of New York will have a symposium on sales manuals at its weekly luncheon in the Hotel Roosevelt on Tuesday. William Rados of the sales training staff of Anthracite Industries, Inc., and former sales education director for American Radiator, will discuss contents.
The end of the short distance college rowing for the year came on the Harlem River early last evening with Harvard's great crew turning its prow toward New London and Yale still undefeated.

The story of man and his healthhis fight against disease and the hazards of life-will be portrayed to "the man in the street" in the $400,000 Medical and Public Health Building now nearing completion on the World's Fair grounds.

BELMONT--Un Carnet de Bal: Harry Baur, Francoise Rosay.* CAMEO--Soviet newsreel program; Country Bride, Russian film, opens Wednesday. CAPITOL--Yellow Jack: Robert Montgomery*; Three Comrades: Robert Taylor, Franchot Tone, opens Thursday. CONTINENTAL--Girl in the Street; Three on a Week-End, opens Wednesday. CRITERION--Gangs of New York: Charles Bickford. 5TH AVE. PLAYHOUSE--John Ericsson, Victor of Hampton Roads.*

Property sales in many lake areas contributed materially to the real estate activity in the metropolitan district during the past week. The largest of the many transactions was the sale of the country home of the late Dr. George F. Kunz at Mohegan Lake, Westchester County, near Yorktown Heights.
Andover won the forty-third annual track meet from Exeter by 82 to 44 today continuing a run of consecutive victories since 1931.

Miss Victoria Potter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Austin Potter of this place, was married to William Henry Lewis Jr. of Mountain Lakes, N. J., at the home of the bride's parents this afternoon. The Rev. Philomon Sturgis Jr. officiated.

A machine that dates, times and calculates the tariff and indicates the origin and destination of longdistance telephone calls, making possible for the first time the extension of automatic telephony over great distances, has been developed in Europe, it was reported here yesterday by the International Telephone and Telegraph Company of New York.

THE authors of this personal narrative begin the book with a novelist's skill. Easily, almost casually, on page 1, you learn that a young man and his wife are about to journey by canoe from San Diego down the west coast of Mexico and Central America to Panama.

Pickets on horseback made their appearance at the Bridge Plaza here and along Route 4 this morning as striking drivers of the Garden State Bus Line sought new methods of bringing their case before the public.

There were 314 of us aboard the Mandalay, passengers and crew on the first trip made by the excursion boat this season. Some of us had begun the return trip to New York with misgivings, for fog began to close in around us not long--perhaps fifteen minutes--after we had left Atlantic Highlands.
Senator Harrison challenged in the Senate today the accuracy of President Roosevelt's description of the new tax law which the President refused to sign.

Miss Kirsten Hesselgren, one of the four women members of the League of Nations Committee on the Legal Status of Women, to which Miss Dorothy Kenyon of New York was also appointed, will arrive in this country on June 26 with an official delegation to the tercentenary of the landing of Swedes in Delaware.

General rainfall in England today disrupted the first-class cricket schedule, with only five of the scheduled ten matches starting. No play was possible between Nottinghamshire and Hampshire, Derbyshire and Sussex, Yorkshire and Kent, the Australians and Middlesex, Cambridge University and the Army.

Proposals contemplating substantial changes in the forest preserve section of the organic law which were introduced this week are expected to bring into the Constitutional Convention a renewal of the conflict, in progress for years, between advocates and opponents of a policy that would open the way for application of scientific forestry to the State's far flung domain of wild forest lands.

The medal of the United States Volunteer Life Savings Corps for exceptional bravery in the rescue of a drowning person has been won by John Murray Begg, 34 years old, of 50 Sutton Place, it was announced yesterday. Police Commissioner Valentine will present the medal to Begg at Police Headquarters. on Thursday at 11 A. M.
Navy triumphed today in its annual baseball game and track meet with the Army before a large gathering here for June week, which officially got under way after the athletic contests.

Minus the services of Captain Ben Johnson, who spent the afternoon jogging leisurely on the sidelines, the Columbia track team bowed to N. Y. U. by 74-61 in the duel meet between the metropolitann rivals at Baker Field yesterday. The outcome. might be termed a mild upset, although. the Lions, with Johnson idle, realized early that they faced no set-ups.

Miss Isabelle Ann Newmiller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Newmiller of this place, will be married on June 24 to Alan Durand West, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar A. West, also of Montclair. The Rev. Dr. George C. Vincent, pastor of the Union Congregational Church here, will perform the ceremony at the Women's Club of Upper Montclair.

IT has long been evident that the health of the American dance and ultimately its very life de pend far less upon what goes on in the tight little circle of New York concerts than upon the conditions which are found to exist in the rest of the country.

SENATE TREAT: The present Congressional session has been notable for specialties on the Capitol's restaurant menus. Senators and Representatives have seen to it that products for which their States are notable have been served free to members of the two houses.

IT was a red-headed Irish boy who went with Vasco da Gama, according to Mrs. Kent's story, and a very good story she has made of it, too. What particularly recommends this tale of that first sea voyage around the Cape of Good Hope to India, aside from its historical interest, is the intimate, highly personalized aspect she has given to it through the eyes of her boy hero.

The Communist party has just published its first nation-wide form of pledge for all party members. Particular interest attaches to the pledge because of its bearing on the frequently asked question: Can a Communist consistently take oath as a public officer in the American democracy?
OUT in Hollywood they are still telling the story of when Sam Pokrass and Gregory Ratoff, both ostensibly Russians and both dialecticians, finally met on the Twentieth Century-Fox lot.

Contending that the Brazilian soprano Bidu Sayao, by her singing in the United States, has strengthened Brazilian-American artistic relations, Brazilian art lovers, intellectuals and officials plan a rousing welcome for her when she returns in June.

With the recall of General Alexander von Falkenhausen and the thirty to forty other German military officers serving as advisers of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Chinese armies, the German Government has once more proved its feeling of alliance with the Japanese Empire, bound to it by bonds of common hostility against Soviet Russia.

Bert Hall, war-time aviator, received an award of $40,000 in commissions for his services in selling twenty airplanes to the Chinese Nationalist Government in 1931. A jury ruled in favor of Hall yesterday.
Emir Abdullah, ruler of Trans-Jordan, today emphatically denied any ambition to become King of Palestine and Trans-Jordan.

In a meet sparkling with outstanding individual performances and "iron man" stunts, the University of Southern California rolled up 643-5 points today to win the Pacific Coast Conference track and field championship. The victorious Trojans displayed The same crushing power that had swept them to the top in every meet this season.

Fred S. Auerbach, vice president, treasurer and secretary of one of Salt Lake City's largest department stores, died today at the age of 47. He was born here, the son of Samuel H. Auerbach, founder of the Auerbach Company. He was graduated from Cornell in 1912.

The winners of residence fellowships at the MacDowell Colony, Peterborough, N. H., for the coming season have been announced by the MacDowell Association. The fellowships are awarded annually to seven of America's most promising artists, writers or composers.

The increasing use of long-term, amortized mortgages is encouraging the purchase of homes and helping to stabilize real estate values, George C. Johnson, treasurer of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, declared last week at the meeting of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board.

The Mutual Savings Bank Group Committee for Erie Railroad bonds, representing eighteen mutual savings banks holding $9,639,500 of bonds and equipment-trust certificates of the Erie Railroad Company and subsidiaries, was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to intervene in the reorganization proceedings of the Erie under Section 77 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.
The Costa Rican Government has requested Mexico to negotiate with the Spanish Loyalists in an effort to save the former Costa Rican Vice Consul at Barcelona, Jose Romero, from execution.
After another stormy year the Supreme Court of the United States will adjourn next Tuesday and move off to Summer vacations for study and the reading of briefs.
Stocks the of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week that ended on May 21 totaled 302,597,000 barrels, according to figures compiled by the Bureau of Mines.

Miss Joan Ryerson, only daughter of Mrs. Donald M. Ryerson and the late Mr. Ryerson, was married today to George Washington Wales Brewster Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. George W. W. Brewster of Boston, in the Church of the Holy Spirit, Lake Forest, by the rector, the Rev. Herbert Prince.

With attendance in the financial district unusually small, share prices firmed up yesterday in the slowest session of the year but one. Gains were confined chiefly to fractions, with a few issues up 1 to 2 points.
Three hundred trade unionists and members of the youth division of the Workers Alliance picketed the central offices of the Welfare Department at 902 Broadway for two hours, beginning at 10:45 A. M.,

Dutch Leonard knuckle-balled the Senators to a 3-to-2 victory over the Red Sox today. Although Boston got ten hits, the Washington hurler scattered them with good effect. The Senators gathered twelve blows off young Jim Bagby in the seven innings he worked.

" Cavalleria Rustioana" and "Paagliacci," tonight. The former with Mmess. Leskaya, Ippolito and Falco, and Messrs. Radaelli and Kalafatich; the latter with Mme. Marie Doro and Messrs. Rayner, Pilotto, Angelint and Kalafatich. Conductor, Bamboschek.

IF it were possible to neglect the social and philosophical implications of this curious novel, it might be reported quite simply as a smooth. eventful and engrossing story of an English banker who escaped from his nerve-shattering routine by ded-icating himself to a humanitarian undertaking.

Quiet conditions again ruled today in the foreign exchange market here, with sharp improvement in the belga to 29.27 1/2 to the pound providing the feature. The dollar was a trifle weaker at $4.949-16 to the pound, largely because of slackening of Continental European pressure to buy dollars.

By a record-breaking series of broadcasts to the United States, England, Ireland, Hungary and other countries, an American priest, Dr. Joseph F. Thorning of Mount St. Mary's College, Maryland, has become an outstanding figure at this year's Eucharistic Congress.

PROBABLY, said Helen Hayes to a San Francisco interviewer the other day, she will do "The Merchant of Venice" in New York next season. And the likelihood increases with the news that she will not go out again in "Victoria Regina" next Autumn.

After several years of negotiations between South Dakota and the Federal Government, the Bad Lands Monument, the latest of. the national parks of the country, now only waits the proclamation of the President to make it a Federal park.

Tottering on the edge of the National League cellar, and staggering beneath the load of a five-game losing streak, the Dodgers today granted themselves a reprieve by shading Casey Stengel's Bees, 6 to 5. But they certainly went about it "the hard way."

SCANDINAVIA has beckoned here to two open-eyed travelers whose names, as author and illustrator, have been associated heretofore with France Mr. and Mrs. Oakley spent two Summers in Norway. Sweden, Denmark and Finland,
Germany and Hungary divided their first two singles matches as play in the third-round European zone Davis Cup competition was resumed today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES is to be congratulated on the recent editorial on the necessity of a new deal for the enlisted personnel of the army. It is indeed to be regretted that the War Department and the Bureau of the Budget could not see their way clear to whole-hearted support of this long overdue increase.

The Westminster Choir School's annual Talbott Festival, at which more than 400 singers joined in a massed choral concert of early church music, was held this afternoon In the Princeton High School auditorium.

WASHINGTON.--Boys and girls receiving National Youth Administration aid from the Federal Government come from families whose average annual income is about $700, according to figures recently placed before the House Appropriations Committee.
From Germany there came to Lakehurst today a letter which brought substantial cheer to two local families to which the Hindenburg disaster a year ago spelled bereavement and suffering.

Mrs. William E. Dodd, wife of the former United States Ambassador to Germany, died today of a heart attack in her bed at the farm in Purcellville, Va., where she and Dr. Dodd had been living in retirement since he resigned his post in Berlin early this year. Her age was 63.

The marriage of Miss Sedohr Barbara Rhodes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Travis Rhodes of this city, to Thomas Hendrick Allen, son of Judge William Allen of the Court of General Sessions, took place yesterday morning in the Church of the Blessed Sacrament, 152 West Seventy-first Street.

Members of society in the North Shore colonies from Huntington to Manhasset who center their activities in yachting and its social features at the clubs and on board the craft, will take advantage of the three-day holiday to start a season that gives promise of brilliance and gayety.

TRACK EVENTS One-Mile Run -Won by Jerry Barnett. Bishop Loughlin; John Troy, St. Francis Prep, second; Michael Flynn, St. Augustine's, third: Vincent Johnston, St. Augustine's, fourth; John Sheridan, Bishop Loughlin, fifth. Time-4:42.8. 100-Yard Dash--Won by Frank Splllane, Bishop Loughlin; Jerry Harley, St. John's Prep, second; Jim McCormack, Bishop Loughlin, third; William A. Duffy, Bishop Loughlin, fourth; William McCabe, St. John's Prep, fifth. Time--O:10.6.

Elias Preiss, chairman of the United Palestine Appeal in Manhattan and active during his life in Jewish religious and philanthropic affairs, died of coronary thrombosis early yesterday in his home at 90 Riverside Drive. He was 48 years old.

HANKOW, China, Sunday, May 29.--Chinese forces continue to attack the Japanese in the Lanfeng sector, 135 miles west of Suchow, in their effort to consolidate the gains of the last few days and to administer a telling blow to Lieut. Gen. Kenji Doihara's Fourteenth Division which has been enveloped northwest of Lanfeng. Seven thousand Japanese are said to be facing annihilation.

Miss Katherine Wentworth Chamberlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lafayette Ray Chamberlin, was married in the Unitarian Church here this afternoon to Eliot Butler Willauer of New York by the Rev. George Hale Reed.

The granite monument for the Delaware tercentenary celebrations, executed by the Finnish sculptor Vaeino Aaltonens at the order of the Finnish Government as a present to the American nation, has been sent to the United States.

Police looked on tolerantly today while a group of youths hung signs reading "FDR-You're Preparing War-Fight It" on the White House fence. Members of the group said they represented a youth committee against war which is attending a national anti-war congress here.

Miss Marjorie Burkhard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marion G. Burkhard of Garden City, was married here this morning in Christ's First Presbyterian Church to Robert E. Snowden Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Snowden, also of Garden City. The ceremony was performed by the Pastor. the Rev. Frank M. Kerr.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Dart Jr. of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Martin Dart, to Richard Irving Lewine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving I. Lewine of New York. The announcement was made at a tea given by the prospective bride's parents at their home this after noon.

High school graduates under 17 years of age who intend to take up employment are required to apply for registration at continuation school during the week of June 13, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced in a general circular last week.

Tax experts of the Treasury Department apparently are convinced that the recent Supreme Court decision holding that salaries of officers of the Port of New York Authority are subject to Federal income tax has paved the way for a re-examination by the court of the question
Guy H. Eaton, instructor at Phillips Academy here, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Phyllis Towne Eaton, to Fulton Freeman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Freeman of Pasadena, Calif.
Dr. Frederick Martin Luther, who served on the staffs of St. Luke's and Polyclinic Hospitals, New York, for twenty years, died today at his home in nearby Allenhurst at the age of 84.

Suit was filed in Federal Court yesterday for a permanent injunction to prevent the sale of the United Shipyards, Inc., to the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation, Ltd., for $9,320,000. Although United Shipyards was the only defendant named,

Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Brieghel Ross of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eva Ross, to Dr. Gordon Vail Stoddard of East Orange, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Osborn Stoddard of Detroit, formerly of Madison, N. J.

The marriage of Miss Lillian Letitia Bardusch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Evans Bardusch of Maplewood to Thane Lewis Bierwert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard L. Bierwert, took place this afternoon in the garden of the bride's parents' home.
A handful of men close to the White House is marking anti-New Deal Democrats for "oblivion" and undertaking to say how the party shall be reorganized, Senator Wheeler of Montana charged today.

Secretary Wallace's hobby is practical genetics--the science of heredity applied to the farm. He showed on his own farm how better corn could be bred by applying Mendelian principles. Millions of bushels of corn are raised in accordance with his methods. Now he is advocating better farm animals, bred, as it were, to order.
Announcement was made yesterday by the Title: and Mortgage Liquidation Bureau of the State Insurance Department that, since the creation of ts real estate sales division in July, 1935,

The United States Public Health Service published last week the findings of a hearing study--the first scientific effort to measure the hearing of a representative group of the general population with instruments of precision.
Declining prices characterized the security and commodity markets last week as the business and financial communities scanned the horizon for indications of improvement in trade and industry.

MANHATTAN COHEN, AMY WHITTON (May 9). Estate, more than $10,000. To Roger Vale Haeth, son, executor, Lawrence, L. I., residue; Mellnor M. Hersh, son, Fort Wayne, Ind., interest in $20,000 trust; Lillian H. Heath, Lawrence, L. I., $5,000; Montefiore Hospital, Bronx, and Chest and Foundation of-the Fur Industry, 224 W. 30th St.. $1.000 each.

Chalres Ellis McPhail, well known in Eastern golf, was stricken with a heart attack this afternoon while playing on the Five Farms course of the Baltimore Country Club and died shortly afterward at the Union Memorial Hospital. His age was 58.
In an effort to reduce the expenditures of Williams College's social organizations, treasurers of the fifteen fraternities and the Garfield Club have agreed upon a plan for cooperative buying.

More than half of the courses offered by the Department of Philosophy at Brown University have shown marked registration gains this year, and in some cases the classes have doubled in size, Professor Curt J. Ducasse, chairman of the department, reported today. Collectively, the department show a registration gain of 49 per cen. over last year.

IF H. G. Wells had invented the sort of psychic dicta phone described in "The Thought - Reading Machine" it would promptly have become the weapon of imaginary dictators in their mighty effort to track down and suppress "dangerous thoughts."
A model electrically - equipped home will be opened on Grove Street and Windemere Road, Applegate Park, Montclair, N. J., by Montclair Builders, Inc., next Sunday.

Further changes in the Park Row Building at 15 Park Row, in the City Hall Park area, will be made as the result of the leasing of the ground floor, sub-basement and second floor in the structure to Patterson Brothers, hardware dealers, who have occupied their present quarters at 27 Park Row for eighty years.
Canton suffered today the most severe bombing since the outbreak of the war. About 600 Chinese were killed and probably 1,000 were wounded according to reliable estimates.

Scoring 63 points, the athletes of Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School of Brooklyn captured the senior team title for the fourth year in a row at the twelfth annual city Catholic High Schools Athletic Association track and field meet at Boys High Field yesterday.

Coney Island is opening another season this week-end-its first under the supervision of Park Commissioner Robert Moses and possibly the last in its traditional character as a gaudy playland typifying the American resort a la roller coaster, hot dog, baby doll and midway sideshow.
WITH the return of the vacation season many photographers plan to purchase new cameras, and, in making a selection, face the difficult task of choosing from among 150 varieties on the market.

Roger Williams, vice president of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, and Mrs. Williams announced today the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eveline Wilbur Williams, to Saxon W. Holt Jr. of Norfolk, son of Lieut. Governor and Mrs. Saxon W. Holt. The wedding will take place in the Autumn.
With seventeen words, Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Director, touched off the. spark needed to put spirit into what was moving along near the finish as a pretty listless Iowa primary campaign.

JEAN CHARCOT was the first French naval officer who (since Dumont d'Urville in the middle of the nineteenth century) explored the Arctic and Antarctic Oceans and brought back a wealth of scientific data, highly useful for the advancement of many branches of knowledge.

Here are the principal activities of the commencement programs in colleges and universities in the Eastern States and the near-by South. Summaries of the high points of the exercises in institutions in the metropolitan area and New Jersey were printed a week ago.

Fresh Meadow (70)-Final of Stock Exchange twoball mixed foursome tournament: Miss Constance Meirowitz and H. Rosenberg defeated Mrs. A. Baar and F. Leiberman, 6 and 5. Garden City C. C. (71)-Semi-final round of Decoration Day tournament, Class A: D. Anderson defeated R. S. Bean, 7 and 6: T. C. Hughes and J. W. Gallagher finished even, 36 holes. Class B: S. Romola defeated J. DeWitt, 1 up; Dr. F. Bean defeated Dillmeier, 4 and 3.

In a twenty-mile race on Long Island Sound today Frederick T. Bedford's new international twelvemeter Nyala was distanced by two of the older twelves. The occasion was the annual regatta of the Riverside Yacht Club, which was the second of the Sound championship series.

In the present upset international situation, Polish official circles insist that Poland's position is unchanged. Nothing has happened to make her alter her policies of good neighborly relations with Germany, a balance between Russia and the Reich with complete independence of outside influences.

ENGLAND'S great classic race, the Derby, on June 1, is to be televised. Obtaining of permission for the telecast was a triumph for BBC diplomacy. The Epsom Grandstand Association, the controlling body, refused to give permission,

The new tax law, which became effective at midnight, wipes out a group of "nuisance taxes" and revises business taxes. On July 1 the Treasury will stop collecting these taxes: Tooth paste, soaps and other toilet articles, 5 per cent;
The Czechoslovak crisis has brought a fresh teat for the AngloFrench alliance. How London and Paris view the success of their joint efforts to keep the peace is told in the two dispatches below.

The band, with the sudden excitement of brass, marches bravely into the center of the field, spells out "Welcome" while still on the march and roars into "Crash Through the Line of Blue"-- Crisp November air shuts down over the color and noise of the country's greatest extracurricular madness, intercollegiate football.

A strange series of lights and flares at sea that indicated a vessel in distress was reported yesterday by officers of the government survey yacht Oceanographer, formerly the Morgan yacht Corsair. The Oceanographer, in command of Captain F. S. Borden,

The text of the platform adopted today by the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs is as follows: The Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs, Inc., in convention assembled, does hereby adopt the following program as its policy during the coming year:

Miss Cynthia Clews Wrightson from Orange, N. J., enjoyed a most successful openingday campaign as the sixth annual Rockwood Hall Horse Show got under way today on the grounds of the Washington Irving Country Club. The 17-year-old entrant carried off three blues, one second, one third and a pair of fourth places following the completion of the morning and afternoon sessions.

The matter of selecting a team of six big game anglers to represent the United States in the coming international tuna matches for the possession of the Alton Sharp Trophy is one that presents considerable of a headache to every one concerned in the selection.

Twenty-six juniors will carry the daisy chain at the traditional class day exercises of the College of New Rochelle next Saturday, it was announced today by Miss Kathryn MacDonagh of Brooklyn, newly elected president of the student body and president of the junior class.

It was reported at the Detective Bureau late tonight that Robert Nixon, 18-yearold Negro, had confessed to murdering two women and criminal attacks on five others in Los Angeles as well as to the killings of Mrs. Florence Castle and Mrs. Florence

Lincoln's dirty shirt is the "giveaway" on a new group of counterfeit $5 bills. John S. Sinclair, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, warned the public today that the bogus currency is fairly deceptive in appearance.

SOME letters from New York friends. One from a college woman of considerable intelligence, with the nonchalant remark, "This is all very well about geography, but where in heck is Colombo or Columbus anyway?"

A MATCH between two teamsof-four, in which the scoring is by total points, about in the same way as rubber bridge is scored, is generally believed to be the fairest test of skill in contract bridge competition.

OLD POINT COMFORT, Va.Featured by an overnight sailing race from Gibson Island, Md., to Old Point Comfort, plus power-boat competition for the coveted Virginia Gold Cup, preliminary plans for the Hampton Regatta, which annually attracts yachtsmen from all sections of the Atlantic seaboard, are nearing completion.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Adams Reiner of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Estes Reiner, to Burton William Teague, son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Teague, also of East Orange.

Visitors to the New York World's Fair of 1939 who are curious about the New York business woman and the responsibilities of the jobs she holds will find a number of business offices and manufacturing plants opened to them through an arrangement being planned by a committee of business women under the auspices of the American Woman's Association. The plan.
Miss Zaydee Dejonge was married here this afternoon to Mason Dix Harris of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Vincent A. Bennett in Christ Church.
The national Lawyers Guild today made public the result of the Guild's recent national referendum on United States foreign policy, in which the membership voted for lifting the embargo against Spain,

Miss Doris Robinson, daughter of Mrs. Walter J. Scott of this city, has selected the night of June 14 as the -date for her marriage to William Cochran Fitch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Fitch of New York and Washington. The ceremony will take place in the First Presbyterian Church here and will be followed by a reception at the home of the prospective bride's mother.

MAXWE LL ANDERSON, gifted with high intelligence in play writing, brought his radio season to a close with a thoughtful, colorful and timely twenty-five-minute original drama, "The Bastion Saint Gervais," written specially for broadcasting.

Next Friday afternoon Miss Eleanore Davis, daughter of Mrs. Edward Parsons Davis and the late Mr. Davis of New York, will be married to Pemberton Hutchinson Lincoln of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Lincoln of Elkhorn, W. Va., in St. James Episcopal Church here.

Ten firemen were overcome by smoke as more than 100 others fought to control a fire discovered just before noon yesterday in a twostory brick building occupied by the Screen-Droge Paper Company at 17-19 Waverly Avenue, Brooklyn.

Recent sales of public lands and two large parcels of privately owned timber at prices ranging from $2.50 to $4.50 an acre recall the time when at public sales of parts of the State's vast forest domain millions of acres were auctioned at 12 1/2 to 25 cents an acre.
PRAGUE (By Wireless). RECENTLY I stood on a public platform facing 43,000 disciplined yet fanatical men and women tense with awaiting the deliberately delayed thrill of Konrad Henlein's arrival.

Guilford S. Jameson of this city announced today that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had approved a loan to the South Carolina Utilities Company to finance an expansion program. This is the first approval by the RFC of a Loan of this kind since Congress recently liberalized the law pertaining to lending.

Ky Laffoon of Chicago and Big Ed Dudley of Philadelphia, captain of the United States Ryder Cup team, made a runaway of the fourth annual Inverness best-ball golf tourney today as they won two matches and assumed a 7-point lead with two rounds to play.
Dr. and Mrs. Gerald A. Hiatt of this city, formerly of Indianapolis, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marguette Hiatt, to Henry Schnull Fauvre of Wellesley, Mass.

New decorative ceiling papers are being used by many home owners to change the apparent height of various rooms, points out the FHA, which states that the strongest effect of height can be obtained by using a large patterned paper on the ceiling and continuing it downward for about 18 inches on each wall, a strip of border paper covering the lower edge.

Frederick van Note of New York, vice president and controller of the Southern Pacific Company, asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to serve as a director of the St. Louis Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railroad. The line is controlled by the Southern Pacific.

Miss Myrtle Elizabeth Hillman, daughter of Mrs. Myrtle Lewis Hillman of this community and Walter P. Hillman of Long Beach, Calif., was married in the chapel of St. John's School here this afternoon to David Gaines Kingsley, son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Kingsley of Boonton.

Officers and directors of the Great-Northern Railway were re-elected yesterday, with the exception of Nicholas Terhune of New York, vice president, who will retire on June 1 after fiftyone years of service. W. P. Kenney,

PROFESSOR MOHOLY-NAGY, at Pratt Institute the other day, talked about the education system employed at the New Bauhaus in Chicago. This progressive school, you will remember, opened last year. It is patterned after the famous original. Bauhaus founded by Walter Gropius in 1919 at Weimar and subsequently moved to Dessau.

More than 4,000 tickets were refunded and 1,500 prospective auditors turned away from the New York Hippodrome as a performance of "Aida" was about to start last night, owing to the failure of two rival groups of union choristers to reach an agreement as to which should sing.

AN outstanding feature of the Benjamin Franklin Memorial Philatelic Exhibition which closed last Wednesday at the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia was a display of about a hundred stamps of the first three issues of Haiti from the private collection

Mr. and Mrs. John Naudin of Gloversville, N. Y., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty G. Naudin, to John Francis McGrath Jr., son of Judge John McGrath of Waterbury, Conn., and the late Mrs. McGrath.
THE thirteenth annual session of the Bread Loaf Writers Conference, sponsored by Middlebury College, will be held at Bread Loaf, Vt., from Aug. 17 to Aug. 31. with Theodore Morrison as director.

The training ship Empire State of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy will sail on an annual cruise on Tuesday, carrying 130 cadets. On the 9,105-mile voyage, lasting until Sept. 1, the ship will visit Bermuda, Washington, D. C., and Newport News,

Ontario's gold mines produced bullion valued at $7,748,169 in April, the gold bulletin issued by the Ontario Department of Mines reveals. This is the third best month in the Province's history, having been exceeded only in March, when output was $8,013,494, and in December of last year, when output was $7,774,581.

OPARIN, who is associate director of the Biochemical Institute of the U. S. S. R. Academy of Science, is easily the most scholarly authority on the question of the problem of the origin of life as treated by the scientists.

Customary motions to adjourn have brought most of the women's organizations to a temporary halt for a Summer recess, but several events of the closing season stand forth upon which their affiliates may dwell with some measure of satisfaction until they foregather again in the Autumn.

Bright skies and soft breezes drew thousands of children and adults to the twelve open-air swimming pools operated by the Park Department in the five boroughs when the bathing places were opened for the season yesterday at 10 A. M.

Public property in forty centers throughout the country is showing improved landscaping this Spring as Junior Leagues are following the A example in community planting set four years ago by the North Mianus Garden Club, near Greenwich, Conn.

Although the question of jurisdiction remained undetermined, representatives of District Attorney Dewey's office questioned survivors, officers and members of the crew of the sunken steamer Mandalay last night and early today, in an effort to determine whether negligence had figured in the loss of the excursion boat.

Greeted by German bands and al fresco singing, members of German singing societies from Northeastern cities arrived here today for the triennial saengerfests. It was the first time since 1903 that the singing societies of the Northeast Saengerbund had met here.
ON simultaneous lists, both Columbia and Victor bring together a pair of their particularly bright stars, and we have a couple of superb violin-piano sonata recordings.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Archibald Reid of this place and Chicago of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Reid, to James Garth Gray, son of Lynn C. Gray of Portage, Wis., and the late Mrs. Genevieve Donovan Gray.

The public's acceptance of the mutual mortgage insurance, system was demonstrated recently by the successful offering of the first obligations of the Federal National Mortgage Association, according to Stewart McDonald, Federal Housing Administrator.

William M. Redfield, a musician who arranged "Alexander's Ragtime Band" and the score of "Watch Your Step" for Irving Berlin, died Friday at his home, 104-19 211th Street, Bellaire, Queens, after a year's illness, at the age of 71.

Next month will be the most strenuous in the annals of women's metropolitan golf. Starting next Thursday, the intersectional team matches for the Golf Illustrated trophy will be played over the Century Country Club course as a curtain raiser to the thirty-eighth annual women's metropolitan championship, which is also scheduled over the links in Purchase beginning June 6 and ending on the eleventh.

Fifty chain teas during June have been arranged under the auspices of the Women's Division of the United Palestine Appeal to enlist women workers in raising the.$175,000 quota assigned to the group. Mrs. Eugene Untermyer and Mrs. Abraham Wechsler are co-chairmen of the division, with Mrs. Harry M. Weiss, chairman for Manhattan.

Members of the House Appropriations Committee said today that the final Deficiency Appropriation Bill for this session would total more than $300,000,000, one of the largest in recent years, exclusive of those carrying relief funds.
Many properties in Kings, Queens and Nassau Counties were reported yesterday as having been sold by the Mortgagees Realty Service, Inc., real estate division of the Home Title Guaranty Company.

Miss Agnes Elizabeth Walsh, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Patrick Walsh of this place, will be married to Robert Cook Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Paddock Wilson, also of Middletown, on Saturday by the Rev. John J. Hanning in the rectory of St. John's Church.
Stephen L. Porter, formerly with the Prudence Company and the First Madison Corporation, has opened his own realty brokerage and management office at 10 Depot Plaza, White Plains.
Lawrenceville and Peddle tied with 59 points apiece, while St. Benedict's scored. 34 to- take- the third position in the twentieth annual New Jersey private school track meet today.

On Sept. 9, 1936, seven weeks after the Spanish civil war began, the International Non-Intervention Committee was formed in London. It agreed during the following Winter--even while some of its member nations furnished munitions and men to the opposing armies--to intercept the further arrival of volunteers and arms by an international land and sea patrol.

Peter E. Bennett, president of the Mortgage Corporation of New York, in recently discussing realty conditions, declared that the field of business for the larger number of real estate brokers who do not participate in construction and development, is narrowed to the sale, rental, management and mortgage brokerage of existing homes and structures.

Monticello College is celebrating its centenary this week-end. One hundred years ago the first students were admitted to this Illinois institution for the education of young women. Ruth Bryan Owen Rohde, Miss Mary Emma Woolley,
A yachtsman's age can be guessed pretty safely by the type of cruising he does on a June week-end.

THE recent manoeuvres of the General Headquarters Air Force again showed the need of a Department of Air to separate the nation's air forces from domination by older branches of the ground and sea forces, Cy Caldwell contends in the June issue of Aero Digest, an aviation magazine of which he is associate editor.

Most retailers will begin the placing of initial Fall orders for staple merchandise next month, and indications are that the early volume will cover at least 50 to 60 per cent of Fall requirements or quantities to take care of retail needs until early October, retail and buying executives here reported yesterday.

PRE-HOLIDAY trade fell considerably short of expectations last week. In some sections adverse weather conditions were held chiefly to blame while in others it was just a case of all-around poor business. Retailers have not much hope of seeing the. tide turn until there is a positive development on the upside.

The owners of at least fifty boarded-up properties throughout the city have decided to rehabilitate them in cooperation with Mayor La Guardia's Committee on Property Improvement, Bernard F. -Hogan, chairman of the committee, announced yesterday.

Speaker Bankhead said today he would name Representative Dies, Democrat, of Texas, chairman of a seven-man House committee to investigate "un-American" propaganda activities. He will appoint the other members next week.

A NEW chapter in New York-Chicago rail travel will open on June 15 when the Twentieth Century Limited of the New York Central and the Broadway Limited of the Pennsylvania make their bow in striking new streamlined dress as the nation's first all-room trains.

Miss Margaret Tucker, daughter of William B. Tucker of this city and the late Mrs. Tucker, was married to Lewis E. Bodenweiser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elias Bodenweiser of Irvington, at the Tucker residence here this afternoon.

Soviet spokesmen have continued to evince concern all week over the possibilities of a general war blazing up from the Czechoslovakia situation. As seen from here the emergency is less urgent than it was last week but the powder barrel stays open.

LATE season activities in the galleries continue as May glides into June,with group and one-man shows both in evidence and with oils, water-colors, sculpture, drawings and photography all playing parts in the offerings of the past week. Most of the newly opened shows are current through the present week or longer.

BOCA GRANDE, Fla.-This sequestered and aristocratic island village, long known as headquarters for tarpon fishing, is again astir with anglers who have come from many parts of the country to try their skill against the games of more than 600 varieties of fish that swim in Florida waters.
Formal opening of baccalaureate week at Georgian Court College will be observed tomorrow with the academic procession on the woman's college campus.
The United States has notified Great Britain that she is willing to abandon the idea of eighteen-inch guns. but wants a limit of 45,000 tons set on proposed battleships.

FELLOW-WORKERS, the revolution has come. The first counter-offensive of the famous against the invasion of their privacy by chroniclers of the fact that Tootsie Wootsie, an eyeful, was seen drinking with Homer Hotstuff, a glamour boy, in Chez Dive, was waged last Wednesday when, at 19 East Fifty-second Street, the Elbow Room was opened.

Mrs. Mary Borthwick Risley of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Borthwick, was married yesterday morning in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church to Douglass Crockett Findlay, son of Mrs. Robert Findlay of Denver, by the Rev. Daniel Edgar Weeks.

With nine new apartment houses, a postoffice, a church, several groups of stores, and an addition to a garage under construction between Seventieth Avenue and Seventy-sixth Road, on either side of Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, L. I., that section presents one of the most active areas in the entire metropolitan district.

Charley Yates, young Atlantan, won the British amateur championship by defeating Cecil Ewing of Ireland, 3 and 2, in the final. Playing before 7,000 over the Troon links in Scotland, Yates scored a birdie on the thirty-fourth hole to end the match. The American trailed during the early stages but rallied to go 1 up at the seventeenth. He was never behind for the rest of the way.

IT is a formidable task to fill revue theatres such as the Lyceum or the Coliseum, but there are some who probably overestimate the difficulty of playing in them. Examples of how to entertain huge and remote audiences have lately been given us by Sir Seymour Hicks in "Money Talks" at the Lyceum and by Sir Oswald Stoll's collection of variety turns, chiefly an ice-skating spectacle, at the Coliseum.

Dr. Robert Burlingham, 50-yearold son of Charles C. Burlingham, former president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, jumped fourteen floors to death yesterday from the library of the home of his family at 860 Park Avenue.

Some 500 retail furniture stores will shorten their hours during the Summer months, James B. McMahon Jr., executive vice president of the Associated Furniture Dealers of New. York, announced yesterday. The schedule calls for closing at 6 o'clock on Tuesday and Friday evenings during June, July and August.
Vague hints of some modification of the exchange control law, which is seriously interfering with American business in Japan, were expressed today by Finance Minister Seihin Ikeda.
Members of many royal families will gather here for the first royal marriage held in Paris for years, when H. R. H. Eugenie of Greece, Princess of Denmark, weds Prince Radziwill of Poland.

To take effect 8 A. M., June 1: LIEUTENANT William V. Judge, from 13th Precinct to Borough Headquarters Squad, Brooklyn - Richmond, assignment changed from Desk Duty to Supervisor of Patrol in uniform.

Frederick G. Clay, New York attorney, shot and killed himself this morning in his home at 4 Lincoln Road, Thomaston, according to the Nassau County police of the Sixth Precinct. Sergeant John Razulis, who investigated, said Mr. Clay shot himself in the chest while he was in bed.

Miss Heyda Golanda De Haan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sytze Marten De Haan of Laredo, Mont., was married tonight to Anthony J. Fokker Jr., son of Anthony J. Fokker of Amsterdam, Holland, and the late Mrs. Fokker, at Underclyff Manor, the estate here of the bridegroom's cousin, Anthony H. G. Fokker, airplane designer.

Entries from the Oldtown Stables of Mrs. F. F. Dibble of Newbury, Mass., captured most of the awards tonight at the Connecticut Horse Show. In the model saddle horse class the brown mare The Shadow annexed the blue. The bay gelding Timothy Dexter was second.

Chicago's fast-stepping Cubs. crushed the slipping Pirates today with a nine-run rally in the seventh which was good for a 9-to-3 victory, their ninth triumph in ten games and the Pirates' eighth defeat in ten.

President Roosevelt served notice last week that the next session of Congress would be called upon for a complete revision of the Federal tax system. He did so in a speech at commencement exercises for thirteen high school seniors of Arthurdale Homesteads, a model community in West Virginia built as a New Deal project for the rehabilitation of displaced coal miners.

New York University will open its 106th graduation program this week with a series of academic and social events leading up to commencement exercises June 8 on Ohio Field, it was announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of the university.

A MONTH before Harriet Monroe died, in 1936, she told Eunice Tietjens that the magazine Poetry "had already been published for a longer period than any other publication devoted to the art of poetry in the history of English literature."

The growing resentment of the Carlists in Spain against the Falangists' [Fascists] "foreign inspired policies" is stated by prominent Carlists in Paris to have been the cause of the recent outbreak in a Rebel concentration camp at Pamplona where prisoners mutinied, killing their jailers with arms said to have been furnished to them by the local population.

In a picturesque setting, with the orange and blue colors of Giralda Farms adorning virtually every object on the spacious grounds, the Morris and Essex show was held under cloudless skies today with thousands and thousands of canine lovers crowding about the judging rings throughout the day.

Painting and sculpture from forty-eight States have been selected for the third annual exhibition of American art, which will open at the American Fine Arts Society galleries, 215 West Fiftyseventh Street, on June 15.

Before a large alumni crowd, the Peddle School nine today defeated its traditional rival, Blair Academy, 9--6. While the netmen marked time until Monday due to wet courts, Peddie's golfers tied the Lawrenceville squad, 4 1/2--4 1/2.

" He's wilder than a hawk,." bellowed Bert Daniels, the Manhattan coach, "he'll fly out of there soon." But Hank Borowy, Fordham's sensational sophomore pitcher, did not fly out of there even though it looked for a few tense moments in the ninth inning that he might not finish the Ram-Jasper baseball game that attracted an overflow crowd of 6,000 to the Maroon field yesterday.

Women who are not financially compelled to work could, by their withdrawal from business activity, materially improve the economic situation. This is the consensus derived from the answers of young business women to whom a questionnaire embracing this, among other timely topics, was directed under Young Women's Christian Association auspices.

BENJAMIN--Mr. and Mrs. Philip D. (nee Ruth B. Levy) joyfully announce the arrival of Richard Alan, on May 22, at Woman's. Hospital. BREITLER--Mr. and Mrs. Julius Breitler (nee Dorothy Engelman) announce the birth of a son, Alan Louis, May 25, at Yonkers Professional Hospital.
The Supreme Court will adjourn for the Summer next Tuesday, after an eight-month term which produced a series of opinions sustaining Roosevelt Administration laws and activities.
Salesmen in men's shops never forget that they have to have in stock what they call women's merchandise-things that appeal to wives who shop for their husbands and are subsequently exchanged.

WASHINGTON.--With about 4,000 students in its classrooms, the graduate school of the Department of Agriculture has the largest enrollment in its history. Established in 1920, with Congressional approval, the school provides graduate training in many subjects for government employes.

THE Silvermine Guild Music Festival Association, Inc., sponsored by the Connecticut State Federation of Music Clubs, will hold its second annual festival, Aug. 1821, on the Guild grounds and the adjoining estate of Laurence Bennet, at Silvermine, Norwalk, Conn.

The Supreme Court had under consideration today for the third time a petition by Thomas J. Mooney, seeking release from San Quentin penitentiary, where he is serving a life sentence for complicity in the 1916 -San Francisco Preparedness Day bombing.

The coming week is a busy one for the 190 seniors of New Jersey College for Women who will receive baccalaureate degrees next Saturday at the close of Senior Week. Informal parties and picnics balance formal receptions, baccalaureate and commencement exercises in the program planned for the graduating class.

Except for dangerous frontier incidents and mutual protests and recriminations, the tension between Germany and Czechoslovakia, which last week flared up into a regular war scare, has apparently returned to its more quiescent but chronic state.

A number of properties in Connecticut were reported yesterday by Previews, Inc., as having been sold. At New Canaan, the eight-room house with two acres of land formerely owned by Mrs. Warrent Matthews was purchased by Florence P. Pettit through Baldwin Co., brokers of that town.

JUST over five hundred years ago a country girl called Joan of Arc determined to drive the English out of France. She laid aside her needle. She seized a sword. She buckled on a man's uniform and rode astride a war horse. She went forth conquering and to conquer.

Aster growing has been made a paying hobby by a woman with a home in near-by country. Last year she cleared more than $50 from a bed only 10 by 12 feet. She describes her interesting experience for this page.

This week's hearings before the joint Congressional committee to investigate the TVA have cleared the air. Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, removed as chairman and member of the Authority by President Roosevelt in March for "contumacy" in refusing

It has been known for a century that electric charges follow nerve impulses, but it was only about ten years ago that it became possible to measure the equivalent action of the brain. The measurers found to their astonishment that even when no impulses are sent into the brain nerve cells nevertheless beat electrically just as the heart beats mechanically when we are asleep.

Three Manhattan properties will be sold at auction this week in the Vesey Street salesrooms by B. Hollander Son. One is the five-story loft building at 676 Broadway, on a plot 28.6 by 130 feet, to be sold Tuesday as the result of an action brought by the State Mortgage Commission and the Title Guarantee and Trust Company against the Marcbrei Realty Company and others to satisfy a judgment of $79,654.

Lew Hutchinson, chairman of the Alberta wheat pool, said today that executives of the Saskatchewan and Alberta wheat pools were considering a return to a system of selling their grain through a pool unless the Dominion Government establishes a wheat board that will buy wheat regardless of the price and sell it on a participation basis.

Buying for investment and home occupancy in the Asbury Park section of the New Jersey shore area has been the outstanding characteristic of realty activity in that locality this season, reports the T. Frank Appelby Agency of Asbury Park.

Long Island University's baseball team scored a 7-1 victory over Brown today. Tom Nash, making his first start as a Brown varsity pitcher, had difficulty controlling the ball and was retired in the fifth after the bases were loaded and none out Nash issued nine passes and hit one.

The case of Dr. Friedrich Funder, former editor of the Vienna Reichspost and dean of Austrian journalists, who is now in the concentration camp at sachau, near Munich, is attracting much attention among the journalists attending the Eucharistic Congress here.
Americans in France, headed by Ambassador William C. Bullitt, will join tomorrow in honoring the 30,321 World War American soldiers and sailors buried in French soil.

Members of the faculty at Hunter College have published more than 200 books, articles, reviews, reports, poems, plays and translations in the last year. The result of an annual survey was announced yesterday by Dr. Blanche Colton Williams,
Cornell ended its lacrosse season today, beating Pennsylvania, 9--2. Bob Brennan of Geneva was the star of the Cornell team, shooting seven goals.

EDWARD STARTZ, announcer for Holland's pioneer shortwave station, has, after a recent tour of America, returned to the PCJ "helm" to conduct the broadcasts flashed from the rotating aerial system at Hilversum.
BY such a book as this we can measure the progress of democracy and the slow, often painful growth in this republic of that just

WASHINGTON, May 28.--An urgent reminder for Germany and Czechoslovakia to observe their obligations under the Kellogg-Briand pact and compose their difficulties by peaceful means was issued unexpectedly by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today in a statement referring to the Central European situation as "critical."

Registrations are being made for the fifteenth season of Juniper Lodge, a Summer residence at Chocorua, N. H., for graduate students and faculty members of Smith College and women of the Graduate School of Yale University.

The five garden clubs of Yonkers--John Burroughs, Luther Burbank, Tapawingo, Morsemere, and Park Hill--will have a flower show on Thursday from 2 to 9 P. M. and on Friday from 9 A. M. to 5 P. M., at the Yonkers Museum in Trevor Park, 511 Warburton Ave. Mrs. Charles E. Marks is general chairman.
Henry A. Rusch of 21 East Sixtysixth Street, New York, died here this afternoon of a heart attack at his Summer home on Center Island. He was born at Long Branch, N. J., sixty-eight years ago.

The Ministry of the Interior today promulgated a law designed to prevent civil servants from joining Nazi organizations. At the same time police ended supervision of members of the Hungarian Nazi party.

Alumni Day will be celebrated by the Alumni Association of Stevens Institute of Technology on Saturday, June 11. There will be a luncheon meeting at the Union Club in Hoboken, a campus parade in costume at 3 P. M., the president's reception at 5 P. M. and a band concert and dance at 8 P. M. at Castle Stevens.

Miss Harriet Goodwin Browne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Burt Browne of New York, was married to William Leeson Pollok, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Condell Pollok of Leonia, N. J., yesterday afternoon in St. Paul's and St. Andrew's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Lloyd C. Wicke, pastor of the Methodist Episcopal Church in Leonia.
Rookie Bill Cox and Sugar Cain, White Sox right-handers, walked twelve batters in a six-inning game stopped by rain today and the Tigers won their second straight game from the Chicagoans, 9 to 1.

While trading on the Cotton Exchange continued yesterday to reflect an undercurrent of nervousness, fluctuations were less extensive, and the two-hour session passed without a repetition of Friday's running break.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas.Beginning Friday and continuing for three days Corpus Christi will stage a celebration known as "Buccaneer Days," recalling the early period in American history when Alvarez de Pineda, the Spanish buccaneer, sailed into Corpus Christi Bay and gave that body of water its name because the religious fiesta of Corpus Christi corresponded to the day of his ship's arrival.

Now would be the time to raise the old Jacobite toast: "To Charley, over the water!" That triumph at Troon must have been some fun for young Yates from Atlanta. It was his first trip abroad, his first whack at a British championship, and he came off with the crown. Good for Charley!

Rising before the American Association for Cancer Research Dr. Madge T. Macklin (University of Western Ontario) made it pretty plain before the American Association for Cancer Research that hereditary influence cannot be disregarded in solving the cancer problem.

Miss Kathleen King, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence King of Kingdom Come, this place, was married at noon today at the home of her parents to William Foote Whyte, son of Professor and Mrs. John Whyte. The Rev. Merrill Fowler Clarke of the New Canaan Congregational Church performed the ceremony in the presence of the families and a few friends.

The Bach B minor mass was again the feature of the annual Bach Festival held today at the Packer Memorial Church at Lehigh University. It was sung by a chorus of 260 men and women from all walks of life who have been training under Dr. Bruce Carey, conductor, since last November.

The Republic of Panama announced yesterday through G. Lopez Fabrega, Counsel General in New York, that the interest due on June 1 on its external secured dollar 5 1/2 per cent bonds maturing on June 1, 1953, will not be paid.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Benjamin Hurewitz of this city of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Helen L. Hurewitz, to Reuben R. Natelson, son of Mrs. Bernard Natelson, also of Elizabeth, and the late Mr. Natelson.

THE news that Maurice Lehmann, prominent French stage producer, has turned to the cinema, only goes to strengthen my belief that the stage has much to offer to the screen.

The mysterious disappearance last week of goldenhaired Betty Hobbs, 4 years old, appeared to have been explained tonight by a police announcement that the child was believed to he alive in Ohio, and that a woman was under arrest charged with kidnapping.

Spark won the Suburban Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday, with Pompoon a nose behind, and with War Admiral on the sidelines. One of the greatest renewals of the historic stake found 25,000 observers, including officers of the Westchester Racing Association and the State Racing Commission in various stages of delight and indignation.

The rentals to be paid by the F. W. Woolworth Company' for the property it leased recently at. 320-22 Jackson Avenue and 148 Claremont Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., will be on a percentage basis, according to details of the lease revealed yesterday by Max Z. Hurwitz, owner of the property. Rentals and taxes will amount to $1,000,000, he said.

SIX operas in English will be sung by the Chautauqua Opera Association this Summer at Norton Hall, Chautauqua, N. Y. The organization, now enterIng its ninth consecutive season, will have Albert Stoessel and Alfredo Valenti as artistic directors. Alberto Bimboni and Gregory Ashman will conduct.

Captain John Reginald Beardall, United States Navy, and Mrs. Beardall of this city, announced today the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Beardall, to Yellott Fitzhugh Hardcastle Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Yellott Fitzhugh Hardcastle of Haverford, Pa., and Easton, Md. Captain Beardall has been on duty here for the last two years as aide to Secretary Swanson.

Mayor La Guardia sent letters to all his department heads yesterday asking them to stop the growing practice under which city employes take part-time jobs in addition to their regular employment at substandard wages, to the detriment of those in private employ.
Although they have been on the market for several years, only in the last few months have men's shorts with patented snap fasteners started to sell freely, licensees reported here yesterday.

More than 1,000 members of the adult evening classes in preparation for citizenship will receive American flags from twelve metropolitan chapters of the Daughters of the American Revolution at a naturalization rally on Wednesday evening, at Julia Richman High School, Second Avenue and Sixtyseventh Street.
Vincent Astor, who has arrived here with rare tropical fish after a 21,000-mile cruise in the South Seas in his yacht the Nourmahal, will send some of the specimens to Baltimore tomorrow by airplane.

Premier Edouard Daladier today invited all Reserve officers in the Paris region-about 20,000-to help police and troops assure the safety of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth during the British sovereigns' state visit June 28 to July 1.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Darling Bergmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Charles Bergmann of 101 Central Park West and Falmouth, Mass., to Cecil Robert Hutchcroft of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis G. Hutchcroft of Mediapolis, Iowa, took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Riverside Church.

Throngs estimated at 100,000 to 150,000 crowded the bedecked New Haven streets today as the city celebrated the landing of its founding fathers 300 years ago, with a parade, military review, brass band cavalcade and elaborate historical floats, in all of which'20,000 marchers formed the central unit.
After being at work for seven weeks the Constitutional Convention is approaching what should be its midway mark if plans of its leaders to bring its labors to a close by the end of July are realized.

BEES make honey in the Luxembourg Gardens, and sometimes strangers to Paris are surprised to hear their buzzing, even in busy streets quite far away. It is a curious country sound, says Richard Le Gallienne, to be met with "among the shopping crowds of the most sophisticated city in the world."

The weekly Literary Supplement of The Times of London lately devoted its twelve pages to the literature of Scotland, present and past. Its articles recognize "the Scottish Renaissance of the last ten to fifteen years," but point out also that, although not "subservient to the doctrines of the post-war world," and rarely using "techniques of morbid psychology," the mood of national depression has colored both prose and poetry.

Miss Anne Callan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles James Callan of this place, has selected June 22 for her marriage to Charles Russell O'Brien, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Francis O'Brien of Harlingen, N. J. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. Joseph L. McCann in St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville.
Presentation was made yesterday of three $100 awards to the winners of the national contest of the Women's Press Club of New York at the annual president's day program in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Luther Boone Bewley, last American director of a Philippine government bureau, resigned today. He had been Director of Education since 1919. President Manuel Quezon immediately appointed Mr. Bewley his technical adviser on education.

The martial roll of drums, the blare of bugles and the tramp of marching feet echoed through midtown Manhattan yesterday as 7,400 men, women and children paraded from Thirty-ninth Street and Eighth Avenue to Madison Square Park in a demonstration under sponsorship of the Memorial Day Peace Parade Committee.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Duffy of 19 East Eighty-eighth Street and Point Pleasant, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susanne Iuiffy, to John Motley Lauer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Chadwick Lauer of Brooklyn.

Away back in the early days of the New Deal when the National Recovery Administration was thriving, certain officials still in the government service learned something about administration of rigid codes. Today they are attempting to transplant into - whatever wages and hours bill Congress sends to the White House some of these lessons in the hope that enforcement will not prove impossible.

A full field of thirty-three cars was completed today for Monday's 500mile Indianapolis Motor Speedway race.

Miss Frances Dupont, daughter of Mrs. John A. Dupont of this place and the late Mr. Dupont, was married here today to Horace William Tremper Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Tremper, in the chapel of Morrow Memorial Church.

What was described as "the most important and far-reaching step yet taken by the Federal Government to compel sound and lasting residential construction" will become effective in New York City and the adjoining territory on Wednesday, when the more stringent construction requirements of the Federal Housing Administration are put into operation.

The twenty-first annual celebration of field day and float night at Smith College took place today. Climaxing the program of Spring sports presented during the afternoon by the Smith College Athletic Association, the final crew races and the parade of floats, decorated according to a new theme, "Holidays," were held on Paradise Pond before a large crowd tonight.

The socalled "aristocrats of labor" who handle the throttles on the nation's locomotives and the humblest track walker on the maintenance of way have joined together in a threat to strike if the carriers mako effective their request for a 15 per cent wage reduction.

Professor Shirley G. Patterson, member of the Department of Romance Languages at Dartmouth College since 1915, died today at the Brattleboro Retreat, Brattleboro, Vt., of a heart attack. He was born in New York fifty-three years ago.

A second selected group of college graduates has successfully completed a year's training as interness" in government departments, Frederick M. Davenport, president of the National Institute of Public Affairs, announced today.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Holden Knight, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Francis Knight, to Harvey Joseph O'Hare, son of John A. O'Hare of Troy, N. Y., took place here this afternoon at the home of her parents. The Rev. James Holland Beal of Emmanuel Church here officiated.

Miss Eleanor Tillard Gibson, daughter of Mrs. Edwin Martin Gibson of this city and the late Mr. Gibson, was married to Gerald S. Foster, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. S. Foster of Stoneleigh Park, Westfield, this afternoon at the Monday Afternoon Club, here. The Rev.
Kent's powerful first crew swept away to a two-length victory over Tabor Academy today on a mile course in 4:46. It was the winners' last race before they invade England for the Henley Regatta.

Calling upon the four newly ordained rabbis to lend positive leadership to their people in an age in which civilization is at "the turning of the road," Dr. Nathan Stern, rabbi of the West End Synagogue, New York City, delivered the baccalaureate sermon at the commencement exercises of the Hebrew Union College, America's oldest rabbinical seminary, here this afternoon.
Miss Lisa Lawrence Renshaw, a debutante of this year, was married here this afternoon in St. Mark's Church to Charles Henry Mills Jr. in a blue, white and green floral setting.

Homes of moderate size designed to fit the needs of young couples, but capable of expansion or rearrangement of room uses to meet the needs of a growing family are being demanded by many prospective home buyers these days, and builders are seeking to meet this demand.

Joseph Skoloff of this city has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Fannie Skoloff, to Hyman M. Jacobs, also of Newark.

Motivated originally by the effects of the economic depression of the early Thirties, the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, after four years of consideration, acted today, through its General Assembly, to assure minimum salaries to about 2,000 of its ministers receiving less than a "living wage."

The dollar volume of wholesale trade declined 18 1/2 per cent in April, compared with the same month of 1937, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce reported today from a study of reports from 1,900 wholesalers.

With the prospect of fair weather today but of rain tomorrow, New Yorkers bent on spending the threeday Memorial Day week-end away from the city were up early yesterday to crowd railway and bus terminals, airports and other transportation centers.

An organized sales campaign to dispose of 365 properties owned by the Home Owners Loan Corporation in Brooklyn and in Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties, L. I., has been undertaken by the fiftytwo contract management brokers in charge of the Long Island properties of the HOLC, it was announced yesterday.

Leave of absence for seventeen days, effective on or about May 31, to terminate not later than June 17. is granted 2d Lt. Barnet Arkon, FA.-Res. Upon the expiration of this leave Lt. Arkon, now on active duty with CCC Co. 3,215, Camp S-115 (N.Y.), Indian Lake, N.Y.

Miss Ruth A. M. Schmidt of Brooklyn has been awarded the fellowship of the New York City Panhellenic for which eighty-five candidates competed. She is an X-ray technician, a graduate of Erasmus Hall High School and the Washington Square College of New York University.

It took a Ponce jury fifteen minutes to return a verdict of not guilty against a policeman, Narcisa Miranda, charged with the murder of Juan Torres, a 16-year-old garage worker during the 1937 Palm Sunday riots.
Minister of Propaganda Joseph Goebbels today announced the establishment of annual national music prizes of $4,000 each for the best young German pianist and violinist.

Mr. and Mrs. Elbert E. Bellows of this place have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Mae Bellows, to Paul Munger Cantwell, son of Mrs. John Miles Cantwell of Malone, N. Y., and the late Judge Cantwell. The wedding will take place here on July 30.
Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah R. Morris of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edna Morris, to Thomas A. Kennedy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Kennedy of Lincoln, N. J.

The first annual Pacific International Air Races opened with tragedy this afternoon when Ralph Johnson, veteran Los Angeles flier, was killed during a stunting exhibition. His plane crashed in front of the stands and burned.

Negotiations to obtain $3,000,000 from the PWA for the erection of a community center in the Bronx were begun last week as a result of a conference between Mayor La Guardia and James J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx, it became known yesterday.
Czechoslovakia was born on Oct. 28, 1918. Today, less than twenty years later, Czechoslovakia is the burning problem of Europe.

Dona Concha Espina of San Sebastian, Spain, author, and Lord Hugh Pattison Macmillan of London, Lord of Appeal in Ordinary to the Government of Great Britain, have been elected honorary corresponding members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, according to an announcement made yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the academy.

The third annual football game sponsored by the New York Herald Tribune for the benefit of the Tribune Fresh Air Fund will be staged Wednesday night, Sept. 7, at the Polo Grounds, it was announced yesterday by Stanley Woodward, Herald Tribune sports editor and manager of the game.
