In a bow-on collision with a Bermuda-bound cruise ship, the excursion steamer Mandalay, with 274 passengers and a crew of forty aboard, sank at 6:15 o'clock last night near Craven Buoy, in Lower New York Bay about one mile south of the Narrows.

With Art Kenney pitching in top form, Holy Cross set down Harvard today, 8 to 1. The Crusader southpaw allowed three hits and struck out twelve. In addition he paced his team-mates at bat with three clean hits. The box score:

Fifty per cent of the Hunter College graduates who have applied for positions since the beginning of the current school year have been placed by the college's Bureau of Occupations, Miss Josephine Hammond, vocational counselor, anndunces.

The engagement of $4,497,000 gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This lifted the total of gold taken in England for United States account in the current movement that began about a week ago to $10,761,000.
When Summer-flowering bulbs are mentioned most gardeners immediately think of gladioli, dahlias and cannas.
The Greenwich Kennel Club will have the field to itself on Saturday for its ninth annual show. This year a special feature is to be made of the obedience tests and the children's handling classes.

Plans for a new building to house the Army Medical Library and Museum, the world's largest collection of medical books, records and relics, are approaching completion, according to Major Gen. Charles R. Reynolds, surgeon general of the army.

Handling his assignment over the muddy Suffolk Downs track with ease, Mrs. Parker Corning's Thanksgiving, 19to-10 favorite, captured the $7,500 added Constitution Handicap today, beating the Medway Stable's Upslala by two and a half lengths.
Dominion Governments provincial and municipal financing in Canada during May was the largest for the month in five years and aggregated $192,293,969, according to Wood, Gundy Co., Ltd.

Cliff Melton and Carl Hubbell, currently the two greatest leftists performing under one banner, gave new impetus to the Giants' latest uplift movement by polishing off the Phillies in both ends of a double-header at the Polo Grounds yesterday while a gathering of 26,476 roared approval.

The quarterly report of the Alleghany Corporation disclosed today that that railroad-holding company took a loss of $29,612,125 in the sale of stock to the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company, one of the Alleghany family.
The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners approved today a sale of $1,000,000 first and refunding 3 1/4 per cent mortgage bonds due in 1966, by the Public Service Electric and Gas Company.
THE twenty-fourth annual exhibition of the work of the students of the Clarence H. White School of Photography it now on display in Mezzanine Gallery 3 of the R. C. A. Building, Rockefeller Center.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Marion Eisenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isidor Eisenberg of Jersey City, to Rabbi David L. Silver of Harrisburg, Pa., son of Rabbi Eliezer Silver of Cincinnati and the late Mrs. Silver.

An international fencing competition on the order of the Davis Cup matches in tennis has been arranged, it was announced yesterday by Harold Van Buskirk, president of the Amateur Fencers League. Edgar Fremont Higgins, deacon emeritus of the Washington Heights Baptist Church, for fifty years cashier and general manager of Jeremiah Skidmore Sons, New York coal dealers, and a member of a pre-Revolutionary New York family, died yesterday at his home, 600 West 235th Street, the Bronx, at the age of 81.

Koki Hirota's disappearance as Foreign Minister and the succession of General Kazushige Ugaki in that post this week can only mean a strengthening of Japanese foreign policy, particularly as it concerns China.

WASHINGTON. SOME two months hence civilaviation IN this country will find itself being regulated in way that were never dreamed of ten years ago. By that time the McCarran and Lea bills will have been combined to become the-law of the land and the new Civil Aeronautics Authority will have been established. The law will become operative sixty days after the President signs it.

Their ranks thinned by three deaths during the past year, only five or six Civil War veterans will ride as guests of honor in the Memorial Day parades on Monday in the cities, villages and towns of Westchester County.
A large number of persons are visiting the Crescent Homes development -at De Kalb land Cypress Avenues, in the Ridgewood section of Brooklyn, reports Herbert- Messer, sales director.
With attention focused on the annual Riverside Drive parade of the Grand Army of the Republic, Memorial Day exercises honoring America's soldier dead will be held tomorrow in the five boroughs.

To the growing list of Germany's known and officially accused spies in this country were added last night the names of Werner George Gudenberg, who specializes in aviation defense secrets, and Dr. Ignatz T. Griebl, the former Nazi leader, hitherto described merely as a helpful witness.

The mass introduction of American methods of preparing canned and other foods with the object of increasing production, improving quality, reducing costs and eliminating waste has been ordered by the Commissariat for the Food Industry.
After a lapse of five years, the invitation grass court tournament of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club was revived today to usher in the season of the Eastern Association.

National Progressives of America, the new political movement founded by the brothers La Follette, is growing through its swaddling days with volunteer nursing and the dimes and dollars of charter members.

ALEXANDER--Mr. and Mrs. Alex, 250 Argyle Road, Brooklyn, announce daughter Jean's confirmation, Sunday, June 5, Union Temple, At home after 8. No cards.
With Morris and Essex and the various specialty exhibitions matters of canine history, exhibitors will have just one more full month of outdoor competition before the usual July vacation.

Police today said that the body of a man found dead in a downtown hotel May 18 had been identified as that of a Richard Brophy of New York and they were investigating the possibility it might be that of a man who accompanied Admiral Byrd on his first South Pole expedition.

In a unanimous decision the Appellate Division reversed yesterday the recent ruling of Justice Philip J. McCook of the Supreme Court that the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs and Stablemen, Local 807, A. F. of L., must submit to arbitration its demand that trucks entering New York City from other points be driven by its members.

Disquieting news from Europe and the general business recession at home have combined to reduce the volume of North Atlantic traffic carried thus far by the principal ship lines, according to passenger traffic managers.

With the driver unconscious at the steering wheel and dying from a heart attack, a hose truck of the Newark Fire Department rolled two blocks down Ferry Street tonight without causing damage, although it passed several cars going in the opposite direction.
Honorary degrees will be conferred upon five persons by the University of Pennsylvania at commencement exercises June 15.
The name of the man slain in Monday's explosion was reyealed tonight as Eugen Konovalec. He was a leader of the Ukrainian Nationalist movement and chief. of the Ukrainian Press Agency in Berin.

THE Communist Party of America, which is holding its convention in New York, is a political organization recognized as legal in the United States. It has 75,000 dues-paying members who hope to see socialism replace capitalism as the basis of our political system.

Higher accident rates and lenient motor vehicle laws in many Southern and Western States. prompted Greater New York Safety Council to caution Eastern drivers today "to be on the defensive and watch out for the other fellow when touring other parts of the country this Summer."
Peter J. Markey was appointed editor of the 1939 edition of The Koran, freshman guide book of Manhattan College, it was announced last week by Maurice Brimo, class president.

The Czech Army, the dramatic partial mobilization of which last week altered the course of political developments in Central Europe, is sometimes decried as a young army in existence only twenty years. The effect of the war upon Japan's export trade can be summed up as a marked but not yet serious depression. In the import columns danger signals are showing.

WORD having gone round that Billy Rose was reviving vaudeville at his Casa Manana eating emporium, this department hurried around for a personal inspection. For the death of vaudeville several years ago when the Palace grounded the circuit always seemed like an unnecessary extremity.

The international Eucharistic Congress, now fast drawing to a close, divided its activities today into many small gatherings, largely sectional. This morning there were early masses in all the churches, swelling the total celebrated during this congress to several thousand.

A FEW miles above Poughkeepsie, where the wooded hills that line the Hudson open up a bit, stands the village of Hyde Park. Down from the farm lands winds a somewhat ragged country road to a little country railroad station. Only a few feet beyond the tracks flows the Hudson, wide, almost calm, steel-gray in the morning chill, a river here little changed since Henry Hudson himself first sailed its waters.

A number of new leaders have emerged among the feminine groups in Westchester as the result of Spring elections, bringing in with them new staffs to direct the activities being planned for the coming season.

The second consecutive session of the Supreme Court in which the New Deal has been upheld by a chain of decisions, with only a few broken links, passes into history next Tuesday. During the long, harmonious session there was again no repetition of past scenes when New Deal issues repeatedly lost.

In an extraordinary communication to the British scientific weekly, Nature, Professor J. Stark, Nobel laureate and one of the most distinguished living German physicists, asserts that "the predisposition toward pragmatic thinking occurs most frequently in men of the Nordic race" and that the Nordics, to whom we owe our scientific progress, have been held back by non-Aryan dogmatism.

PRACTICALY all of the nation's twenty-six national parks have opened their gates for the Summer season and already are receiving early visitors. Majestic Yellowstone, containing more than 2,000,000 acres of mountains and woodlands,

Two securities brokers who had been arrested in criminal cases were enjoined permanently yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman from further dealing in securities in this State. The injunctions were obtained on the complaint of Attorney General Bennett.

The marriage of Miss Tasha Tudor Burgess to Thomas Leighton McCready Jr. of New York and Redding took place here this afternoon at the hilltop Summer home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Rosamond Tudor Burgess of this place and Boston. The Rev. Raymond Cunningham of Hartford performed the ceremony, for which Jimmie Griffin of Weston, fiddler of old-fashioned tunes, played the wedding march.

The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee contributed $33,000 last year to the 0. S. E. (Society for the Maintenance of Health of Jewish Populations) for the aid of 178 medical and health institutions in Europe, according to a report yesterday.
Navy's lacrosse team displayed its vaunted attack at Michie Stadium today and defeated the Army, 10 to 3, before 3,000 spectators, to gain an undisputed claim to the national collegiate championship.

On Prague's historic Hradcany Castle, seat of the government, still flew last week the red, white and blue flag of Czechoslovakia, and the river Moldau, celebrated by the composer Friedrich Smetana, flowed peacefully through the ancient land of Bohemia. A major threat to Czechoslovakian independence had, for the moment at least, been averted.

Dealer response to the 1939 radio models shown by leading companies for the first time last week was considerably better than had been expected, sales managers of the various companies reported yesterday.

Kenesaw M. Landis, commissioner of baseball, approved today the release by the Cardinals of Pitcher Silas Johnson to Rochester of the International League provided the Cardinals fulfill their salary obligations to the veteran hurler.

Stocks closed steady and fractionally higher in second slowest Saturday's trading since September, 1934; turnover, 216,880 shares. United States Government and other bonds firm and mixed in the smallest turnover since July 13, 1918; transactions, $1,838,900.

Most cotton mills have been unable to reduce costs sufficiently to meet the decline in cloth prices and are now operating at a loss, accountants said yesterday. They pointed out that while some reductions have been made in overhead, they have been insufficient to meet the rise in overhead-per-unit occasioned by the lower production rate.

The colorful Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championships, coming back to Randalls Island Stadium for a second year, will be staged for the sixty-second time on Friday and Saturday. Unless all signs and portents fail, the University of Southern California will mark its return to Eastern warfare and the I. C. 4-A. meet after a two-year lapse by capturing the team championship.

Miss Cornelia Weston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Faraday Weston of this place, has chosen June 23 for her marriage to Phillip Cummings of Lake Placid, N. Y., son of Mrs. Addie Cummings and the late Harry Foster Cummings of Hardwick, Vt. Only members of the two families and a few friends will attend the ceremony and reception which will take place in the chapel at the Lake Placid Club.

A preview of the 1938 version of Princeton's alumni reunion festivities is afforded by the twenty-fifth year record of the class of 1913, issued today with a roster of the national 'figures whose classes will be celebrating their major reunions at the June commencement.
A week ago Ireland was in the calmest of political waters. There was not a suspicion of party squalls to ripple the surface and the idea of a general election never seemed so remote.

Forty-seven fellowship and scholarship awards, varying in amount from tuition to $1,200, have been made by Radcliffe College. Thirty-eight of the recipients have already done graduate study, while nine are receiving the bachelor's degree this June. The awards are as follows:

With super-markets cutting into chain stores volume apparently to a greater extent than into that of independents, national manufacturers selling through chain outlets must revise their merchandising and advertising practices to obtain the best results from this newer type of distribution, Roland W. Estey, business counsel, said here yesterday.

WHY should State-of-Maine people leave home when they can make a "mendacious" journey in a trailer around Maine itself, and see all those places with foreign names--Paris, and Athens, and Naples, and Troy, and so on and on?

Governor Albert B. Chandler at Campton, in the mountains of Eastern Kentucky, and Judge Brady M. Stewart of Paducah began simultaneously the long-expected attack of Chandler forces on alleged use of Federal agencies in Kentucky's pre-primary Democratic Senatorial race.

The behind-the-scenes force of Mexican politics has been brought to the fore once again through the guerrilla war started against the Cardenas government by the armed peasant followers of the ex-General Saturnino Cedillo, for decades the warlord of the North Central State of San Luis Potosi.

Charlie, the educated bass, was back at Captain Harold Thomas's slip today, but not alone. "Charlie has brought the family along this Summer," said Thomas as he blew a whistle. From beneath the dock a shadowy form emerged, rose to the surface and gingerly accepted from the captain's fingers a choice crawfish.

More-than 150 Barnard College seniors and their escorts attended the senior ball in Barnard Hall on the campus last night. A midnight supper was served in the hall which was decorated in old rose and gold, the class colors. The dance was the last to be given for the students this season.

THE title given this book in England, "Some Versions of Pastoral," is more accurately descriptive of this collection of papers than is the American title which suggests a unity the book does not possess.

The liquor license held by the Olicrom Corporation for the Hotel Oliver Cromwell at 12 West Seventy-second Street, near Central Park West, has been canceled because a person not mentioned in the permit was allowed to avail himself of the license, it was announced yesterday by the State Liquor Authority.

An improved method for treating lumber to resist termites and rot, by which the vulnerable points of a house are treated with a solution known as chromated zinc chloride, has been developed jointly by E. I. du Pont de Nemour Co. and one of the leading wood-preserving operators.

Governor E. D. Rivers, New' Dealer, announced tonight he would run for a second term, leaving the United States Senate race to former Governor Eugene Talmadge and. Senator Walter F. George, both of whom have opposed certain Roosevelt policies.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday at his home in Cincinnati of Albert G. Adams, who retired in 1937 after thirty-five years as treasurer of the West Africa Mission of the Presbyterian Church.

VITALITY is inherent in the word "cooperation." and so the title of this book must be arresting to all who have a feeling for words. Its fundamental implications cover a field as wide as virtually all human achievement. and in its broad meaning it would be an ambitious subject for a writer.

Mrs. T. Handasyd Cabot has come to the Ambassador from Dublin, N. H. Count and Countess Giuseppe Cippico, who passed the Winter at the Waldorf-Astoria, sailed yesterday on the Conte de Savoia for their home in Rome. They will return in the Autumn.

Present indications are that appropriations at this session of Congress will total almost a billion dollars in excess of last year's sum. Appropriation bills carrying $10,355,131,879 already have become law or are pending, in the Senate or House.
THIRTEEN years have passed since Alla Nazimova abandoned the screen to resume stage trouping in her Ibsen repertoire.

I do not believe that any complete constitutional revision will have the support of the public * * * hat we need, and all that we need and .that we can possibly get out of this convention, is favorable action on perhaps a dozen revisions, each one of which should be submitted separately this Fall.

A study of the reliability of various types of statistical data as indicators of expansion in general business after periods of depression, which has been made by Wesley C. Mitchell and Arthur F. Burns, shows that total liabilities of business failures,
Interest in the bond market was at such a low ebb yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange that total trading in all groups was the smallest amount in almost twenty years, or since July 13,

BERMAN-STEIN-Mr. and Mrs. C. B. Stein of 5 East Ave., Larchmont, N. Y., announce the engagement of their daughter, Dorothy, to Mr. Bernard L. Berman, son of Mr. and the late Mrs. Herman Berman, formerly of New Rochelle, N. Y.
Many parties were held in connection with the race meet of the Fairfield and Westchester Hounds held here today at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club.

Behind the splendid proching and hitting of Lester Berkowitch, Abra ham Lincoln High gained its seventh straight Brooklyn P. S. A. L. triumph and its seventeenth victory in a row yesterday, beating Bushwick. 7--2. at Lincoln Field.

Gross estate, $44,275; net, $39,961. To mother, Mary Hay Nye. Chief assets, jointly owned property, $25,728; miscellaneous property, $13,102; stocks and bonds, $5,430. J. Franklin Tausch, 12 East 41st St., Manhattan, attorney.

Frank Feeney of Philadelphia, international president of the Elevator Constructors, Operators and Starters Union, American Federation of Labor affiliate, and once a figure in Philadelphia politics, died today at his Summer /home here at the age of 67.

Colonel Harold Lee, deputy genoral manager of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, said yesterday that real estate interests need have no fear of the corporation's policy in selling real estate, as it is "mindful of the need for stabilization of the market."

TELEVISION will never be of any practical value applied to symphony concerts, in the opinion of Sir Adrian Boult, music director of the British Broadcasting Corporation and conductor of the BBC Symphony Orchestra.

Despite the trend in some sections of Westchester County toward the erection of medium-priced home groups, the substantial demand, according to many brokers, is still for homes of the moderately higherpriced type.

The charge that an attack on Sam Macri, assistant regional director of the C. I. O., at Pershing Field, Jersey City, Friday night was a deliberate attempt to incapacitate one of their chief witnesses in the C. I. O.-American Civil Liberties Union injunction suit against Jersey City officials was made yesterday by a C. I. O. special counsel.
One of the flowers associated in our minds with a pool is the wild European iris, Pseudacorus. In its native haunts it grows in marshes or along streams.

THE day after tomorrow will mark the end of another theatre season, May 31 being the date on which the drama's year is shoved briskly into the files. Not that there is any great reason for the date--this time, for example, the season is closing on the premiere of "The Two Bouquets"--but it has to end

The General Council of the International Federation of Trade Unions, meeting in Oslo, has rejected a proposal for admission of the Soviet trade unions into the federation and instructed its executive committee to abrogate negotiations for a "united front" with the Russian organizations as inconsistent with democracy.

The Art Students League announced yesterday the winners of its annual Summer high school scholarship competition. The five winners will be entitled to attend one class every day in the week at the league from September to next May.

Canadian scullers and two Buffalo (N. Y.) high school eights shared honors in the fourth annual interscholastic regatta on Lake Carnegie today as Harvey Hutcheons, senior single-sculler, added American laurels to his Canadian title and Lafayette High turned back a strong California crew in the senior eights.
Into the conflict of many opinions over the Harrison-Thomas bill for Federal aid to education, the week has brought fresh opposition to the bill in the form of an article by J. B. Edmonson,

Miss Nina Vitale, granddaughter of the late Countess Giusseppina Barbaro Vitale, member of an old Venetian family, and Leonard Brooks Elms, a law student at the University of Virginia, were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Professor and Mrs. Harry Rogers Pratt.

GOOD books at minimum prices are effective means of promoting adult education and are a boon for those who have always relied on reading for solace and stimulation but have been scuttled by the depression. This makes the various low-priced libraries with their well-edited books cultural assets of great potentiality.

IT is written in the Book of Ecclesiastes: "For what hath a man of all his labor * * * wherein he laboreth under the sun?" And it is this question which Sarah Gertrude Millin attempts to answer in this profound and subtly woven novel of England and Africa.

LIFE, as the saying goes, is just an what you make it. Some are content with a prosaic existence in the business world, while others seek the things which th are said to lie just beyond the horizon. Arthur B. Menken, son of S. Stanwood Menken, the attorney, is one of the latter, so he became a newsreel camera man.

Since last September, when New York admitted women to jury duty, somewhat later than several other States, approximately 12,000 women have enrolled for duty as jurors in this city, and registration still continues at the rate of thirty to forty a day.

BECAUSE of higher accident rates and less strict motor vehicle laws than in New York, in many Southern and Western States, the Greater New York Safety Council last week cautioned Eastern drivers to be on the defensive when touring in other parts of the country this Summer.

The James Memorial Chapel of Union Theological Seminary was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Dr. Dorothy Loomis Frame, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. James Everett Frame, to Charles Billings England.

Assailing the New Deal for its "divergent, contradictorY and irreconcilable" policies, former Governor Alf M. Landon of Kansas called upon his party tonight to dedicate itself to a program to "free this country from all oppressive dictation," whether by government, industry, finance or labor.

WASHINGTON.--Of the women seeking work at public employment offices, one-third are more than 40 years of age, according to the United States Employment Service. Though women of the middle years find it difficult to find employment

Retail trade last week was sharply lower than a year ago in virtually all sections of the country. The losses were in some cases attributed to cold and rain, but unemployment and poor general business were probably more important

THE Berkshire Festival of Chamber Music, to be held under the auspices of Mrs. Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge, Sept. 21-23, at South Mountain, Pittsfield, Mass., will mark the twentieth anniversary of these annual events. Composi tions to be presented by the many ensembles listed will be about equally divided between standard works of the repertoire and creations in the modern idiom.

Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Lewenthal of 35 West Ninetieth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Lewenthal, to Fred A. Weller, son of Mrs. Henry J. Weller of the Bronx and the late Mr. Weller.

Older men usually are beaten by youngsters in sprints but are often victors in long-distance races. Why this should be so Professor Walter B. Cannon of Harvard's Medical School explained to the members of Mount Sinai's staff last week.

KINGSTON, N. Y.--The appearance of a score or more nomad trailerites daily on routes leading from this Catskill Mountain gateway forecasts a busy season in the uplands, where accommodations in any of the State's public campsites are free.

Chaminade High School, showing surprising strength in the running events, captured the Nassau County Conference track meet on the Westbury High School Field today. The winners rolled up 39 points to top Baldwin, Freeport, Hempstead, Westbury and Sewanhaka.

The Westchester Country Club opened its season here today with a dinner dance. The hosts included Mr. and Mrs. W. B. Anderson, Mr. and Mrs. R. E. Lancaster, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Paterno Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wilder, Mr. and Mrs. Milton Thwaite, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Haggerty, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Dow and Mr. and Mrs. Paul Landis.
Phil Mooney of Chicago, star halfback and baseball player at Georgetown University in 1928, '29 and '30, died in Mercy Hospital tonight of a streptococci infection. He was 28 years old.

RECOGNIZING the propaganda importance of the screen, the government has exerted pressure on Paramount and compelled the studio to rewrite the ending of "Men With Wings" to eliminate the note of pacifism on which the picture had intended to end.

William E. Parsley, veteran real estate man, who since 1931 has been associated with the Manufacturers Trust Company as supervisor of the commercial department in charge of office and loft buildings owned by the bank, will join the real estate firm of O. A. Robertson, Inc., on June 1, it was announced yesterday. He will be in charge of the sales and brokerage departments.

Despite the recession at home and the threat of war abroad, hundreds of students and teachers are planning to spend their Summer vacations going to school in various parts of Europe. Local colleges and universities have arranged more educational tours to Europe than ever before.

Athletes from Sacred Heart School won major honors in the thirty-second annual Catholic Schools Athletic League outdoor track and field championships yesterday at Wingate Field, Brooklyn. They captured the senior crown, finished tied with St. Cecilia for the junior title, placed second to that team in the midget championship and then received the point trophy, having totaled 64 points in the three divisions.

Mlle. Jadwiga Jedrzejowska of Poland today defeated Miss Dorothy May Bundy of Santa Monica, Calif., member of the American Wightman Cup tennis team, in the women's singles final of the Middlesex championships, 7--5, 6--2.
Henry Wheeler de Forest, lawyer, capitalist and philanthropist, died today in his country home, Nethermuir, here, after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Rotch of 197 Commonwealth Avenue, this city, and Hill Top Farm, Middleboro, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Morgan Rotch, to Dr. Charles Lee Buxton of New York, son of Mrs. Edward T. Buxton of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Buxton.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur S. French of Ridgewood, N. J., and Ticonderoga, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith French, to Kenneth Charles Doty, son of former Mayor and Mrs. Frank R. Doty of Wald?vick, N. J.

More than 1,000 lessons in English were given last year to foreign-born mothers and 325 visits made to their homes by the Women's Society of Riverside Church, which has completed twenty years of Americanization work. The Christian fellowship committee of the church, of which Mrs. Charles D. Biehle is chairman, is sponsoring the movement to bridge the cultural gap between American-born children and their foreign-born parents.

Furniture of various styles and periods, table appointments, oriental art, paintings and prints, tapestries, textiles and oriental rugs the property of various owners, including Gerald B. Stretton 2d of New York, will be sold at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries on Thursday morning and afternoon.

Plans for a moderate-cost residential development in Riverside, Greenwich, have been announced by Nordholm Updike, builders, of Greenwich. The development will be located on three and one-half acres of land on Hendrie Avenue, purchased from the Luke B. Lockwood holdings.

HORATIO SEYMOUR is one of the also-rans of American history. A man twice Governor of New York, six times the Democratic nominee for that office, Democratic standard-bearer in the 1868 Presidential campaign, he was for at least three decades a political personality attracting national attention.

Donald F. Carroll Jr., 16 years old, who was acquitted Friday in the Queens County Court in Long Island City of the murder of his sweetheart, Charlotte Matthiesen, 18, was committed. yesterday to Bellevue Hospital for mental examination.

A new association of speed boat pilots is to be organized provisionally today and tomorrow at Atlantic City during the fraternizing there of the drivers on hand for the second annual Auerbach race on the holiday afternoon.

DURING the past ten years Louis Adamic has been coming to the front as one of the sharpest-eyed observers and most penetrating social commentators we have. A native of Yugoslavia, as the many readers of "The Native's Return" remember, he has retained something of the wideeyed quality of a man from Mars. Yet he knows the United States as well as if his ancestors had come over in the Mayflower.

LOS ANGELES. TESTED more thoroughly than any other transport aircraft in the history of aeronautics--and yet still earth-bound--the Douglas DC-4, world's largest landplane, will make its maiden voyage sometime this week, probably on Wednesday, engineers of the huge airliner announced in Santa Monica.
Cordial demonstrations were held here today before the Czechoslovak Legation in honor of President Eduard Benes's birthday. The Yugoslav-Czech Friendship League held a meeting in a large hall.

America's policy of neutrality in Spain means that we shall not send military supplies to either army. It does not mean that we must not send help to the sick and dying children on both sides of the battle line.
WHEN the amateur photographer goes traveling this year he will not journey alone. Railroads, steamship lines and even haycart owners are vying for his patronage and that of his fellows.

Wilfrid Seagram, an actor well known in the English and American theatre, died yesterday in the Medical Arts Center Hospital following an operation for an abdominal ailment. Mr. Seagram was 54 years old and lived at 160-32 Twelfth Road, Beechhurst, Queens.

The United States Ambassador and Mrs. Kennedy entertained at a dinner party in the embassy Wednesday. The guests included the Brazilian Ambassador and Dona Gina Regia de Oliveira, the Chinese Ambassador and Mme. Quo, Sir Robert and Lady Vansittart, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Millard, Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Sanford, Lord and Lady Greville, Lady Colefax. Arthur Hays Sulzberger,

THE safari with which this novel deals is quite a de luxe affair, with its own electric-light plant, a fleet of trucks and cars and all the comforts of home, including a generous supply of champagne and other wines and liquors.

Miss Ann Louise Whitlock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard Palmer Whitlock Jr. of this city, was married to James Home Harris Jr., also of Elizabeth, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James H. Harris, at the Westminster Presbyterian Church here this afternoon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Otto W. Buschgen, the pastor, who was assisted by the Rev. Robert Lee Bull Jr., rector of Trinity Episcopal Church.

Dr. Kurt Lewin of the Iowa Child Welfare Research Station of the University of Iowa told the Midwestern Psychological Association that "in autocracy the social tension seems to be due to lack of freedom," whereas "in laissez-faire systems tension seems to be due to the anarchic structure of the situation which prevents long-range planning and lacks meaningful time perspective for the group and the individual."
New York University's baseball team returned to the victory column with a 7-2 triumph over N. Y. A. C. at Travers Island yesterday. It was the ninth success of the season for the Violet.

A sea tragedy that might have cost many lives was averted last night, according to many rescued passengers of the Mandalay, because of the strategy and expert seamanship of Captain W. B. Cornning of the Acadia after the collision in lower New York Bay.

While a typical drama of a shipwreck was being enacted in New York harbor last evening, the usual crowds strolled idly in the Battery or gazed over the water, unaware of anything more than the usual Saturday night scene.

Arthur E. Dooley, '39, newly elected president of the Student Council, heads the list of student officers for 1938-39 announced this week at Fordham College. Three classes and twenty-five campus organizations have named leaders for next year.
Germany and Italy reached an agreement today on economic, financial, shipping and travel problems arising from the German absorption of Austria.

BLACK MOUNTAIN, N. C.--To provide places where people may enjoy natural beauty and recreation, North Carolina is now engaged in the establishment of a well-ordered system of State parks which will serve to supplement the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, in Western North Carolina and East Tennessee, and the proposed coastal national park on "The Banks" of Dare County.

The-structural steel work on the tall apartment building being erected at the southwest corner of Seventh Avenue and West Twentieth Street has been completed, but the tenants in the adjoining buildings had to look up at the giant framework to make sure the work was done.
Grain prices crumbled steadily today as the result of general liquidation by holders of future contracts, short selling and a lack of aggressive buying. All deliveries of wheat, corn,

NIKOLAI SOKOLOFF, director of the Federal Music Project, has been engaged to conduct the Seattle Symphony Orchestra in a series of eight concerts next season in Seattle, Wash. The season will open Nov.

Joseph Murray of Sioux City, Iowa, walked out of the State penitentiary here today under an Executive respite granted by Governor Cochran and will receive unconditional freedom after the State Board of Pardons meets June 8.

Mayor Harold H. Burton said today that funds to feed Cleveland's 78,000 direct-relief cases would be exhausted Tuesday and no further aid could be given them unless the Ohio Legislature appropriates funds.

Among some of the vital problems requiring not only consideration but practical action by the real estate interests of the country, in the opinion of Dean Joseph H. Willets of the Wharton School University of Pennsylvania, are a lightening of the disproportionate tax burden, better zoning and planning of cities, lower costs of building construction and public policies to encourage and facilitate the demolition of houses in blighted areas.

A total of eleven persons injured in the collision, most of whom were thrown to the deck when the crash occurred, was listed by the police. None of the injuries was believed serious, and all were expected to leave the hospitals by this morning.

A new tire plant in which Henry Ford expects to produce a complete automobile tire within four hours from the time crude rubber arrives from the East Indies, is now in operation in Dearborn. E. F. Wait, plant manager, said today that tire making in many factories now requires a week. Automatic handling of matrials in the $5,600,000 Ford plant which spreads over four and a half acres is credited for the speed.

Most clouds have at least a silverplated lining. Gardeners who are complaining of this Spring's continued cold weather and repeated rains fail to realize that these conditions are ideal for the planting of many subjects which ordinarily would have had to be discontinued by this time.
THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity reacted for the week ended May 21, and now stands at 76.0, as against 76.3 for the preceding week and 109.2 for the comparable week a year ago.

Senior class day exercises of Marymount College will be held tomorrow under the direction of Miss Joan Lalley, president of the senior class. Miss Mary Brophy will read the class poem and Miss Lalley, the class history.
Although outhit, the Yale varsity nine conquered Amherst, 7 to 5, today, bunching blows in the sixth and seventh innings to snap a fourgame losing streak.
With triggers set to shoot on the slightest provocation, a safari of some fifty determined young men--and a few women--set out yesterday afternoon to scour darkest Manhattan for big game.

The marriage of Miss Evelyn McLean Wallace, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Davenport Wallace of this city, to Frederick William Coates, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward William Coates of Wethersfield, Conn., took place here tonight in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church.

POUGHKEEPSIE, May 28.--A long black touring car rolled through the gray-stone gate posts of Hyde Park House early today at and President Roosevelt had returned again to his boyhood home on the Hudson.

Bowing to a personal request from District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, the Erie County delegation at the annual convention of the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs withdrew today its resolution endorsing him as the Republican Gubernatorial candidate in the Fall elections.

Jewish War Veterans of the United States, forty-third national memorial services. Parade from 110th Street and Fifth Avenue to Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, 9 A. M. Services at Temple Emanu-El, 11 A. M.

Carl E. Milliken, former Governor of Maine, and Mrs. Milliken of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith L. Milliken, to William E. Wade Jr. of Passaic, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wade of Rockland, Me.
To the Music Editor: Somewhere will be the new Salzburg of the world--a treasure of music, symphony, opera, chamber music, great voices and great instrumental soloists in the Summer.

Five meet records were broken and a sixth was equaled as Good Counsel High School of North Newark retained its group 2 New Jersey prep school track and field championship ad Seton Hall of South Orange dethroned Newark Academy as group 3 titleholders in the annual meet today at Essex Field. One hundred and fifty-one athletes, representing 'thirteen schools, competed.

James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, who was indicted through the efforts of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey as a member of the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer gang in the operation of a $100,000,000 a year policy racket,

A new type of variable pitch propeller for airplanes flying in the stratosphere or high altitudes has been developed in the research laboratories of the General Electric Company, according to a series of three patents (Nos. 2,118,652-3-4) just granted to Nicholas E. Groeneveld Meijer of Schenectady, N. Y.

The Mural Artists Guild, Local 829, has notified Grover A. Whalen president of the New York World's Fair, that its members would not work on murals designed by nonunion artists. The general executive board of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers of Amer ica went on record that all artists designing mural paintings must be affiliated with the Brotherhood.
Czechoslovakia's pro-Nazi German minority and the government suddenly resumed negotiations today. The surprise conference created general optimism on the eve of municipal elections.

Boyne, 6-year-old bay gelding by Harvest Worthy, owned by Dunbar W. Bostwick, Old Westbury, L. I., and driven by Harry Whitney, trotted a mile in 2:05 3/4 at the Hambletonian Club matinee at Good Time Park today. It was the fastest performance of the season.

Brunswick School's commencement exercises were held in the school auditorium today. Members of the graduating class were Henry S. Houghton Jr. of Stamford, Conn.; Robert R. Landsiedel of Westport, Conn.;
Eighteen hundred fur floor boys and shipping clerks, at a meeting yesterday in the Manhattan Opera House, voted to ratify the settlement made in their behalf by the Furriers Joint Council, a C. I. O.

George McAneny, chairman of the board of the New York World' board of the New York World's Fair, sailed on the Italian liner C??te di Savoia yesterday to confer with heads of eight foreign governments on their participation in the exhibition. He will visit Italy, France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Sweden, Norway, Denmark and Great Britain.
Increasing popularity of Summer cooling, with well water is reported by the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau. The method is simple and requires no complicated equipment.

THE long reign of Pope Leo XIII, that longest of all of Plus IX, did not produce larger contemporary bibliographies than has the uncompleted pontificat of Plus XI's sixteen years. Perhaps the chief reason for this is that people today are more eager to learn of personages and events before either have run their course.

New Jersey's voters are to decide at a special election whether the State's Constitution shall be amended to sanction the pari-mutuel system of betting on horse races, but there was uncertainty today as to when the balloting would take place.
The Works Progress Administration announced today that at the end of February last 1,164 airport projects were in operation, including fortyone new ones undertaken to aid aviation.

It used to be supposed that the sun is burning up like so much fuel. When the mathematicians took out their pencils and figured how much fuel would be required to deliver the amount of heat that the sun is known to radiate they found that seven million billion tons of coal would have to be burned every second.

AN experiment is being tried at one of the leading auction houses here, the out come of which may have an important bearing upon the traffic in books. It is an occasion in honor of the forgotten collector, the man who spends thousands of dollars. not just for a single book, but over a period of years for a whole library.

Miss Virginia Chason, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel H. Chason of 843 Park Avenue, was married to Frank Johnson Holschuh, son of Louis W. Holschuh, also of this city, and the late Mrs. Holschuh, at a home wedding here today.

The estate consisting of a twentythree-room house with 200 acres of land on Lee Road, Stockbridge, Mass., formerly owned by Frank L. Warrin Jr. of New York and Paris, has been purchased by Edward H. Acton of Shawinigan Falls, Que., Canada, who will take possession about June 10.

Subject to several limitations and taken in conjunction with additional information, certain statistical series offer fairly trustworthy indicators of general business when revival may be expected, according to a study by Wesley C. Mitchell and Arthur F. Burns, issued yesterday by the National Bureau of Economic Research.

Pointing a movement unique in American public administration, seventeen associations of public officials have set up joint headquarters in their new building on the south front of Chicago's Midway. Occupation of the new structure on a site provided by the University of Chicago marks

ACTIVITY in the field of the American mural is nowadays continuous on a nationwide scale. Those of us who are onlookers could not expect to keep at all times au courant with a government undertaking so vast and complex. But at intervals visualized reports are made available here.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson, rabbi of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, preached a sermon there yesterday morning. opposing the coming referendum of the American Jewish Congress, of which the Rev. Dr.
THE Postoffice Department last Wednesday released photo graphs of the promised Constitution and New Sweden (Delaware) commemoratives and the fifth unit in the "Presidential" or regular series.

Georgetown's baseball team scored all its runs in the first four frames to down Princeton, 5-2, on University Field today. Mike Petroskey gave the Tigers only seven well-spaced singles to record his twenty-third victory in twenty-five starts over three years of varsity hurling.

Memorial services for Admiral David Glasgow Farragut, first admiral of the United States Navy in the Civil War, were conducted yesterday afternoon at his grave in Woodlawn Cemetery, the Bronx, by members of Mrs. Ella Bixby Tent 18 of the Daughters of Union Veterans.

Howard Warren Comstock of 135 North Seventh Street, who wrote the plays "Stepping Sisters" and "Doctor X" died today after a long illness at the age of 38. He was born in Fall River and had lived here all his life except for five years in New York.

The establishment in Van Cortlandtville, near Peekskill, of a new preparatory school patterned after the Kent School in Connecticut, was announced yesterday by the Rev. Frank C. Leeming, rector of St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church, Peekskill,
Declaring that he had fulfilled his duty to the Republican party, Thomas E. Broderick informed the county committee last night that he was resigning as committee chairman, to take effect at once.

Fritz Mahler, conductor, will be the musical director of the Dunrovin Music Festival to be given under the auspices of the Chamber Music Society of America at the Playhouse of Dunrovin, Ridgefield, Conn., on three successive Saturday

More than 1,000,000 underprivileged children in this city would benefit from trips to Summer camps, but fewer than 100,000 are likely to have the opportunity, Douglas P. Falconer. executive director of the Greater New York Fund, was informed yesterday by experts attached to private welfare and health agencies.

" The process of economic readjustment proceeds apace, with a major contribution afforded during the last weeks of May by a further crumbling of commodity prices," according to the monthly Industries Service review issued by Fenner Beane, New York Stock Exchange members.

Coach Harvey Case's Sayville High team topped a field of twenty-one to capture the fifth annual La Salle Military Academy outdoor track and field championship meet today. The Purple and Gold squad annexed three first places and presented enough balance to total 49 points, twelve more than Patchogue, which finished second.

Thomas J. Kain, since 1915 assistant secretary and treasurer of the Association of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, with which he had been associated since 1895, died yesterday at his residence, 354 East Twenty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, at the age of 65.

An exchange of young business men by this country and Europe "to tie up and analyze methods of transacting business and commerce in order to compare ideas" is asked by the board of directors of the Brooklyn Young Men's Chamber of Commerce.

Officials of the General Motors Corporation, Ford Motor Company and Chrysler Corporation would be taken into "nominal custody" on brand jury indictments charging them with conspiracy to violate the Sherman Anti-Trust Law, District Attorney James R. Fleming said today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The two most tragic occurrences in Washington during the past few weeks seem to me to be these: First, the utter inability of government and business to find any common ground. Second, the further indulgence in the theory that only by pouring more billions into relief channels may be found the way to the Abundant Life.

Sales by the pulp and paper Industry in the first quarter of 1938 declined 17.58 per cent, compared with the same period in 1937, but because of higher costs, taxes and charges, the net profit was 89 per cent lower, a survey of eight leading companies reveals.
EXPERT: The District of Columbia Bar Association staged its annual outing one day last week, featuring a golf match. Prominent among the players

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, c., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.
Gifts of $100,000 to Ithaca College during the year were announced today by President Leonard B. Job to alumni attending the annual reunions and to undergraduates.
An international handicraft exposition under the auspices of the German Labor Front opened today with displays of handwork from twenty-six nations.

The majority of voters in the United States favors legal rather than illegal betting on horse races, according to a nation-wide survey made by the American Institute of Public Opinion, the results of which were announced yesterday.

Mrs. Grant Taylor Ham of Mount Vernon, Ill., who is now visiting here, gave a reception and tea yesterday in the Garden of the Ambassador, at which she announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Helene Elizabeth Ham, to Ferdinand Van Siclen Parr Jr., son of Ferdinand Van Siclen Parr of this city and the late Mrs. Parr.

A long season for the International Six-Meter yachts that will terminate with three major series against European skippers in the Fall, began today at the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club. There will be racing here tomorrow and Monday.

Secretary Hull did not exaggerate last week when he described the dangers of autarchy, or absolute sovereignty and national self-sufficiency. As he pointed out, the development of order under law and the growth of international commerce have been two of the principal forces in shaping the growth of Western civilization,
The Museum of Costume Art, of which Irene Lewisohn is president, ended yesterday the first week of its second annual exhibition, on the top floor of the French Building in Rockefeller Center.

Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Untermyer's Greenwich (Conn.) combination of Hexameter ridden by Miss Patricia Bolling gained a leg on the Clarence H. Geist Challenge Trophy today in capturing the blue in the Corinthian class, feature of the fifth program of the annual Devon horse show. The event was open to all hunters.

Voicing condemnation of the pyramidingg" of taxes on tobacco products, which were described as reaching "monstrous proportions," and calling for the creation of a national fair trade compliance committee to deal with "loss-leader" selling, eight resolutions were adopted yesterday
The Police Department held its annual memorial services yesterday for members who died overseas in the World War or who were killed while protecting life and property in this city.

A new test for the proper pasteurization of milk, which enables a non-technically trained inspector with a compact field kit to detect in ten minutes at the milk plant a raw milk content of as little as one part in a thousand, was announced yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, City Health Commissioner.

Showing in the form expected of a representative of a real working breed, the Old English sheep dog, Champion Ideal Weather, owned by Leonard Collins of Toronto and handled by Alf Loveridge, received the best in show award at the twelfth annual all-breed exhibition of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club today.
TIME, as Einstein or Sophocles or Anon remarked, is relative. The astronomer thinks in terms of millions of years, the antiquarian in terms of thousands, the biologist in terms of hundreds.
Rollicking, carefree Charley Yates was hailed today as the new British amateur golf champion by every homeowner from Bobby Jones down to old "T. J.," his favorite Negro caddy.

Fresh from his triumph in the Gafden City Golf Club invitation tournament a week ago, R. E. Knepper and his partner, C. H. Jennings of Roaring Gap, N. C., today led a field of forty-nine pairs home in the qualifying round of the annual Spring four-ball invitation tourney at the Meadow Brook Club.

ROME. DESPITE economic and other stress, there has been no dearth of excellent music in Rome this season, and no lack of adequate public patronage, radio competition notwithstanding. As happened elsewhere during the slump, one notes here a tendency to take refuge in music as a relief from the tension of the day. Apart from this, the Roman music panorama continues of wide range and interest.

Eighteen Americans captured by the Nationalists [Insurgents] almost two months ago while fighting with the International Brigade in the EbroTortosa sector are. now in the concentration camp at San Pedro de and Cardena, just outside Burgos, but after four weeks of trying, the writer still has not obtained permission from the military authorities to see and talk with them.

Staging a four-run rally in the seventh inning, the Baltimore Orioles registered a 6-to-3 triumph over the Newark Bears today. Johnny Wittig went the distance for the visitors and granted only four blows, including home runs by Charlie Keller in the third with one aboard and by Bob Seeds in the ninth. It was the thirteenth circuit smash of the year for Seeds.

JUNE beckons the musicians and the microphone to the open-air bandstands. The first of four Summer concerts by the Naumburg Symphony Orchestra on the Mall in Central Park will be broadcast by WQXR tomorrow night from 9 o'clock to conclusion of the performance.

The text of. Senator Harrison's speech in reply to President Roosevelt was as follows: Mr. President, nothing is more distasteful to me than to become involved in a controversy with any member of my own political party; certainly it is even more unpleasant for me to differ with my own President.

LONDON.--Every year on the British railways about 200 passengers stop trains by pulling the communication cord. In the great majority of cases they do so as a result of genuine distress, such as sudden illness or accident. In other cases they incur the "penalty for improper use"--$25.

The initial effort by a Federal agency in carrying out the func tions of a central mortgage bank is being watched by mortgage financiers throughout the country with keen interest, points out Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association

Fifty student members of the staff of Bulletin, the undergraduate newspaper at Barnard College, were guests at the annual luncheon of the paper yesterday in the Music Room of the Hotel Biltmore. Marion Paterson, editor for 1936;

The engagement of Miss Elaine Clearwater Plitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Plitt of this place, to John Hamilton McCallum, son of Mrs. Donald Campbell McCallum of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Rev. Mr. McCallum, has been announced by her parents.

Negotiations were begun today between the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and striking members of the United Rubber Workers of American, whose mass picket lines were dispersed Thursday after rioting in which eighty were injured by bullets. clubs and tear gas.

BRITISH colonials continue to occupy the center of the philatelic stage abroad. "New reign" postal paper arrived from five English possessions last week, two of the most attractive series coming from Sierra Leone, Africa, and Trinidad and Tobago, West Indies.

LIKE Yeats's recent "A Vision," itself an earlier book rewritten, these three little verse plays are more interesting for the light they cast for us into the mind of a poet of genius than for anything intrinsically exciting in themselves. Originally, and successfully, produced in prose.

The fourteenth annual Victor Herbert Festival, sponsored by the Gaelic Musical Society of America, will be held tonight at 8:30 o'clock at the Central Park Mall. Selections of his works will be sung by the Victor Herbert Festival Singers, accompanied by the New York State Symphonic Band, under the direction of Giuseppe Creatore.

AN interesting alteration project is in progress at the southwest corner of Fifth- Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street. The Renaissance room of the old Hotel Gotham is being made over to provide for five stores on the avenue side in "unobtrusive" fashion, so that from the outside the change in appearance of the building will hardly be noticed.

Miss Madeline Florence Ebert of New York, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Richard Ebert of New Rochelle, was married at noon today to Howard Henry Speck of New York, son of Daniel Richard Speck of Annville, Pa., and the late Mrs. Speck, in St. Paul's Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Dr. Frederic Wamsley performed the ceremony.
Something was said in this column the other day about regions and regionalism. It was by way of being an attempt

The Swedish Match Company reported yesterday for the year ended on Dec. 31 a net profit of 14,828,903 kronor, including a profit of 5,407,510 kronor on exchange. The profit was after taxes, interest, a 10,000,000-kronor write-off of bonds, a 4,433,695-kronor

Plans for a new group of retail shops on Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, Conn., adjacent to the Franklin Simon store, were announced yesterday by Paul Drukker, president of the Pauls Lane Corporation, owner of the property to be improved.

THOMAS MANN declared recently, in a lecture at Carnegie Hall on 'The Coming Vic tory of Democracy," that he regarded America as the future home of culture. He spoke of the blighting influence of fascism on the spiritual resources out of which art and culture must grow and he observed that men and women of talent in some countries abroad would continue to seek in America a place to live and work.
Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Goldstein of Baltimore have announced the engagement of Mr. Goldstein's sister, Miss Ruth Goldstein of this city, to Richard Moskin, son of Mrs. Julius Moskin of Brooklyn.

As law officers of at least a dozen States prepared to meet here next week and discuss moves to prevent retroactive taxation upon thousands of State employes, it was understood that the Administration disapproved, for the present at least, any attempt at drastic application of such back taxes.
The Argentine rayon-weaving industry established a record for production in 1937, according to statistics reported to the Department of Commerce. Production of rayon goods

" And they lived happily ever after." It has been true for a year at least of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, the first anniversary of whose wedding falls next Friday, June 3. For both of them the year has flown swiftly.

R. O. H. Hill, owner of the new coastwise class sloop Lucky Star, has a new rating for her, and figured yesterday that had time allowances been raced on she would have beaten Drake H. Sparkman's new week-ender. Southerly by approximately a minute in the opening-Sound championship regatta at Larchmont a week ago.

One of the best protections against the ravages of the ordinary moth is a properly constructed cedar closet, where Winter blankets, furs and, cloth clothing may be stored, many home owners are discovering.

FOR a month, July, 1914, the whole world watched with breathless suspense what was going on in the hitherto little-known kingdom of Serbia. Now Czechoslovakia appears as the storm center whence come showers of thrilling and appalling news. Will 1938 repeat 1914? Will the month of June. 1938, unfold itself as did July, 1914? Let us look behind the curtain to try to understand what is going on.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--The Auerbach Cup race, a moth boat regatta, a flower mart, an air meet and an automobile stunt drivers' contest are all scheduled for the coming week, augmenting the programs of the Steel Pier and the Million Dollar Pier, the theatres, night clubs and hotel grills.
The United States Women's Lacrosse Association started its national tournament with four games today on the field of the Rye Country Day School.
Stricken while galloping a horse at Churchill Downs today, Harry Louman, 36, jockey and exercise boy, fell from his mount, Tyr, as he attempted to pull up and was dead when other workers reached him.

The "purge" is on of Democrats in Congress rating anything below 100 per cent in their support of the President. It is being conducted by the President's young storm troopers in full sight and sound of the White House. And it is being aided by the President's administrators who, responsible only to him, have unlimited powers of decision over the allocation of the billions spent for relief.

Governor La Follette disclosed at a press conference today that he would confer with "liberal leaders" in three New England States next week relative to the new political party, which he announced late last month.
Seniors at the Pennsylvania State College have approved as their class gift to the college a multiple astronomical observatory composed of nine small observatories.

Mayor Wilson, defeated at the primary election by Governor Earle for the Democratic Senatorial nomination, said today that he had written to Senator La Follette, chairman of the Senate Civil Liberties Committee,

The boom of Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, for the Democratic nomination for Governor will receive no support from the Democratic State organization headed by Postmaster General James A. Farley.

The cottages and grounds of the Children' Village at Dobbs Ferry will take on a picnic aspect on June 8 when an outdoor fete will be given to aid the maintenance of the little community and school for unadjusted boys and girls.

DISCUSSING radio before a recent meeting of the Federal Communications Commission Bar Association in Washington,. Mark Ethridge, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, said that the broadcasters want only the censorship of public opinion and good taste.

The motto of the American Rose Society reads, "A rose for every home-a bush for every garden." But much of America-dominantly urban-does not have the gardens for the rose bushes, and therefore to provide "a rose for every home" the municipal rose garden has come into existence.

A collection of rare maps, drawings, photographs and books, illustrative of the development of garden cities from the fifteenth century to the present time, is on exhibition in the Avery Library, Columbia University.

THE opening of the Empire Exhibition at Glasgow has suddenly put Scotland on the front page. It has made the people of England more keenly aware of the existence of their neighbor across the border, and has stimulated their interest in what she has to show them outside the fair grounds.

Professor and Mrs. Hugh Findlay Chase of Columbia University and Nervis, Irvington-on-Hudson, have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Barbara Brownell Chase, to Robert Stebbins Smith of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Conrad Smith of Buffalo.
ALTMAN-GOLDWASSER-Mrs. Lillian K. Goldwasser announces the marriage of her daughter, Natalie. to Dr. Leon L. Altman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry H. Altman., Friday, May 27, Brooklyn.

Myle J. Holley, president of the Board of Trustees of the village of Peekskill, said today that he had received Governor Lehman's request for a conference concerning Peekskill's ordinance forbidding the distribution of handbills and announced that he had sent a telegram to the Governor accepting the invitation to confer at Albany Tuesday afternoon.

In an effort to induce the Federal Government to lift the Spanish embargo on arms, more than 150,000 men and women, representing various social, political and labor groups, have gone on record within the last two months against the existing neutrality law, the Rev. Herman F. Reissig, executive secretary of the Medical Bureau and North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy, reported yesterday.

A double by Manager Dick Porter, after Remorenko had tripled in the eighth, dissolved a 2-all tie and gave the Chiefs a 3-to-2 victory over Jersey City tonight. It was the third in a row for Syracuse over the Jersey Giants.

Professor and Mrs. Hugh Findlay Chase of Columbia University and Nervis, Irvington-on-Hudson, have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Barbara Brownell Chase, to Robert Stebbins Smith of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Conrad Smith of Buffalo.

Behind the labor racketeer there is always the political leader, Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan told members of Local 442 of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, A. F. of L., at a celebration and concert last evening at Washington Irving High School, Irving Place and Seventeenth Street.

Splashing through mud and rain, Gov. Chandler, 3-year-old son of Reigh CountSaucy Sue, captured the $12,000 added Illinois Derby today before a drenched crowd of 15,000 spectators, who backed the winner down to an 8-to-5 favorite.

Investigation by the Department of Justice of charges that Mayor Hague and other officials of Jersey City are denying civil rights guaranteed by the Constitution draws attention to a statute enacted by Congress more than a half century ago but since seldom invoked.

Three new opponents appeared on Bucknell University's 1938 football schedule of eight games announced today by Dr. B. W. Griffith, graduate manager of athletics. Georgetown, George Washington and Gettysburg replace Ursinus, Lebanon Valley and Villanova.

Assigned to the problem of creating a "movie star's boudoir," sixtyfive students of the Art Schools of Cooper Union Institute have evolved a number of rather unusual settings, Esmond Shaw, assistant art director at the institute, announced yesterday.

The marriage of Mrs. Emma Parmelee Townsend of East Orange to Frank Wilmer Lawrence of Greenwich, Conn., took place at noon today in the home of the bride's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. John Warren Danforth of East Orange. The Rev. F. Randall Williams, rector of the Church of St. Andrew, performed the ceremony.

Funds raised on June 17 at 2,000 "bowl of rice parties" to be held throughout the United States for Chinese civilian relief will be handled by a committee of nine Americans prominent in religious and business affairs in China.

Herman F. Reissig, executive secretary of the Medical Bureau and North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy, reported yesterday.

A double by Manager Dick Porter, after Remorenko had tripled in the eighth, dissolved a 2-all tie and gave the Chiefs a 3-to-2 victory over Jersey City tonight. It was the third in a row for Syracuse over the Jersey Giants.

The limitations of monetary management have been illuminated again glaringly in recent weeks in which, in the face of an unprecedented effort on the part of the monetary authorities to stimulate credit expansion, the volume of outstanding bank credit has shriveled to the lowest point in several years.

Mrs. Helen Belle Sneider Geddes, first wife of Norman Bel Geddes, stage and industrial designer, died here last night at her home, 161 Sagamore Road, after a year's illness. She was about 44 years old and before her marriage in 1916 resided in Toledo; Ohio. She was graduated from Smith College in 1913.

It took all of Colonel Bill Terry's acumen and foresight, plus a gorgeous eighth-inning home run by Mickey Haslin, to convince Jimmy Wilson's tail-end Phillies at the Polo Grounds yesterday that they must not interfere with the pennant operations of their superiors.

Fifteen Princeton varsity and freshman trackmen received Keene Fitzpatrick Medals for proficiency, improvement and effort in their respective events during the Spring season, it was announced today by Matthew T. Gels, coach of the undefeated varsity.
Baccalaureate services were held at Georgian Court College today with the Rev. John S. Middleton, Professor of Philosophy at St. Joseph's Seminary, Yonkers, delivering the address.

Parades and special ceremonies will mark the observance tomorrow of Memorial Day in more than a score of Nassau County villages. Largest among these will be the observance in this village where a parade of more than 2,500 members of various organizations will terminate at Soldiers' Monument, in Greenfield Cemetery.
Last week's home business and dividend reports were satisfactory, but views on export and world trade outlook are gloomy.

" Good homes" were called an offset to the "push for acquiring things," which would wreck the country and the world, in a baccalaureate sermon at Bryn Mawr College tonight by the Rev. Dr. Robert R. Wicks, dean of the University Chapel at Princeton.

Confident of wide Republican gains in the Fall Congressional elections, Alf M. Landon was the guest of fellow party members here tonight. While he would make no definite estimate of the expected gain of seats in the House of Representatives, Mr. Landon said it would be sufficient to check New Deal policies..

The added influence of the United States "linked in a loose alliance in the League of Nations" would have restrained today's "saber rattling" of nations and the "vicious aspirations of modern dictators," Edward C. Rybicki, president of the State Conference of Polish Clubs, - said yesterday.

The recent "black-out" at Farmingdale, L. I., in the army air manoeuvres was cited yesterday as "dramatic" evidence of a rising spirit of militarism in the United States by the Rev. Phillips Packer Elliott of the First Presbyterian Church, Henry Street near Clark Street, Brooklyn.

Winter sunshine is a little hotter and brighter than Summer sun. This paradox was shown here today in the records of a new pyrheliometer, which measures the intensity of sunlight simultaneously from all disections.

Rush Nycum Harry, retired treasurer of the New York Central Railroad, died at his home here today following an illness of eight months. He would have been 72 on June 8. Mr. Harry was born in 1866 at Bedford, Pa., the son of Benjamin F. Harry and Susan Nycum Harry.

Communism and the German and Italian brands of fascism were denounced as "mortal enemies of democracy" in a resolution adopted today by the 500 delegates attending the thirty-second annual convention of District Three of B'nai B'rith, embracing the States of New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware and West Virginia.

Mr. Otha D. Wearin, endorsed for the Senate by Harry L. Hopkins, has come with seeming suddenness into national fame. Those who have watched his career know that this was inevitable. After graduation from college he helped his father run the farm.

Time changes our holidays, as it changes all things. When General Logan asked the Grand Army posts, seventy years ago, to set aside May 30 "for the purpose of strewing with flowers or otherwise decorating the graves of comrades who died in defense of their country during the late rebellion," he held out no conciliatory hand toward the South. The wounds were too fresh.

The administration received a warning today from Senator Wheeler, Democrat, of Montana, that the Democratic party would risk losing the Presidency in 1940 unless Roosevelt leaders quit taking sides in the party's primary contests.

The Governors Island polo team crushed the Monmouth County Club of Eatontown, N. J., 10 to 2, yesterday at Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island. The victory was the third in three home games for the army riders, whose attack was led by Bob Shillaber, with four goals.

Memorial Day sermons in numerous churches throughout tHe city yesterday emphasized the conclusion that the World War had accomplished none of its purposes and that its dead could best be honored by making another such war impossible.

Edward W. Hobler of Stamford, Conn., has been elected president of next year's senior class at Princeton University, it was announced today by Dan D. Coyle, '38, of Centreville, Md., chairman of the undergraduate council. Officers for next year's junior and sophomore classes also were announced.
General Victor Vuillemin, chief of the French Air Force General Staff, and four officers of the French General Staff arrived today for a week's consultations with British air force leaders.

Commander William N. Thomas, chaplain of the academy, commended to the 439 members of the Annapolis graduating class in the baccalaureate sermon this morning the advice of Paul to Timothy, "keep the great securities of your faith intact."

Miss Patricia Woolsey will have her sister, Mrs. Kenneth MacLean, the former Miss Sara Pickett Woolsey, for her matron of honor at her marriage to Lionel Stewart Jackson, which takes place here the afternoon of June 16 in Christ Church.

Country clubs both on the North and South Shores are having three days of festivities. Members of society who have not yet opened their country homes are occupying the available suites while they take part in the golf and tennis matches and entertain at luncheon, tea and,dinner today and tomorrow.

Nazi leader Albert Forster told a party rally at near-by Zoppot today that the Nazi party had absorbed the last remaining opposition in Danzig's Parliament, leaving 70 Nazis and two Poles in the chamber.

Two men were arrested today after an explosion last night in a house in which two women were injured. Bombs and revolvers were found in the house. One of the women, who was seriously injured, was Miss Bridie Dolan, 27, a Republican leader.

The New York A. C. baseball team dropped its second game in successive days yesterday, bowing to Seton Hall, 9-8, at Travers Island. A 5-run attack in the first inning gave the collegians the lead and they remained in front all the way.

Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Andrew Lauer of this place have sent out invitations for the marriage of his daughter, Miss Vivien Frances Lauer, to Cadet George William Rhyne of the United States Military Academy, which will take place the evening of June 16 in the Central Presbyterian Church here.

Focusing their attention on the national and State elections this year, official delegates to the tenth national convention of. the communist party in the United States renewed their demands yesterday that all progressive forces unite in a solid democratic front to defeat the "reactionaries."

The second batch of municipal elections in Czechoslovakia passed off today without the reporting of any incident. This correspondent motored through several German villages in the Sudeten areas in which elections were held today and found conditions completely normal apart from the military preparations, which were maintained.

Indifference and the defeat of ambition were attributed yesterday by the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker at Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, to "failure to share the experience of personal deliverance."

Adolph S. Ochs, late publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was praised yesterday morning -as "a marshal of peace" who led "an army of knights of the pen" in the service of mankind.

The question uppermost in the minds of Congressional leaders as they prepare for another legislative week is whether President Roosevelt is going to attempt to force a governmental reorganization measure through Congress during the remaining days of the session.
The Republican offensive in Catalonia, launched on a fifty-mile front between Balaguer and the Pyrenees last week, appears today to have fizzled.

Deputy Sheriff Christopher F. Plunkett, a familiar figure in Tammany politics to three generations of residents on the West Side of midtown Manhattan, died early yesterday in his home, 332 West Fortyseventh Street, after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

Admiral Claude C. Bloch, Commander-in-Chief of the United States Fleet, instructed all navy craft along the Pacific Coast today to keep watch for the ketch Tira, believed to be carrying three. Santa Cruz (Calif.) youths.

The Federal Symphony Orchestra, under Antonia Brico, gave a concert yesterday afternoon at the WPA Theatre of Music. Harry Farbman, violinist, was the assisting artist, and Dr. Sigmund Spaeth the commentator. The program comprised the overture to Weber's "Oberon," Lalo's "Symphonie Espagnole," with Mr. Farbman as soloist, and Dvorak's "New World" symphony.

Nearly 1,000 Boy Scouts, representing sixty troops from Manhattan, are encamped outside this village for two days of living in the open and on their own in a practical demonstration of theoretical scouting knowledge they picked up during the Winter.

The marriage of Miss Mary H. McKelvey, daughter of the Rev. William M. McKelvey and Mrs. McKelvey, missionaries in India, to the Rev. Dean Newton Dobson Jr., son of the Rev. Dr. Dobson and Mrs. Dobson of Maplewood, will take place June 15 in the Congregational Church, Hartford, Wis. Dr. Dobson will perform the ceremony.

Joe Burk of the Penn A. C., the greatest of all American scullers, gave a remarkable display of his talents on the wind-swept Harlem River yesterday in his last competitive appearance before sailing for England and the Diamond 'Sculls.

The evidence of moral decay is appalling among the privileged as well as the underprivileged, the Rev. Jule Ayers, associate pastor of Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, declaied in his sermon there yesterday.

The Criminal Court of Appeals today upheld prison sentences imposed by a lower court on four Nazis accused of attempting to set fire to the building of an anti-Nazi newspaper and trying to throw incendiary bombs in a theatre during an anti-Nazi play. Both attempts were made in 1935.

A procession of 500 candidates for the bachelor's degree in eight branches of Columbia University marched yesterday afternoon from the Low Memorial Library to St. Paul's Chapel to take part in the baccalaureate Sunday service that ushered in the celebration of Columbia's 184th commencement.
