The statement of the Bank of France for May 19 shows the same ease in the money market that prevailed in the previous week. Discounts and loans again fell heavily. From 16,382,
Japanese excluded from Panama by the nationalization of the fishing industry have not given up hope of establishing a base for their fishing fleet at Costa Rica's Pacific port Puntarenas.

German Davis Cup hopes soared today when the Viennese player, Georg von Metaxa, scored the deciding victory in the quarterfinal round series with Hungary. Von Metaxa, whose play has added new life to the German team, defeated George Dallos of Humgary, 6-2, 3-6, 6-3, 6-2, for Germany's third point, making the score 3-1.
French military authorities opened an investigation today into flights by German planes over the Maginot Line fortifications near the French town of Sarreguemines, on the Franco-German border.

A posthumous message "to the churches of America" from George Grey Barnard, the sculptor, was made public yesterday at a memorial service at All Souls Universalist Church, Ocean and Ditmas Avenues, Brooklyn, by the minister, the Rev. Cornelius Greenway.

The final game for the international Gaelic football trophy will be played today when Cavan meets Leix at the Polo Grounds. A crowd of 30,000 is expected to witness the match which will bring together for the first time in this country two teams from Ireland.

W. Morgan Churchman, member of a well-known Philadelphia family and an investment banker with offices in the Otis Building, died yesterday at this home in Whitemarsh after an illness of four months. He was 57 years old.

Champion Lle Wol Lah Son, handsome red chow owned by Mrs. A. V. Hallowell of Delphia, Pa., and handled by Dr. Hallowell, was named best in the Penn-Jersey Chow Chow Club specialty show today. Mrs. Frederick R. Humpage of North Wilbraham, Mass., judged the sixty-three- entries.
Prices of lard, both futures and cash, dropped last week to the lowest level since 1934 on the Board of Trade, largely in sympathy with grains and other commodities.
The French wholesale price index on May 21 stood at 645, compared with 643 and 639 the two previous weeks. The increase was due to a rise in the national products price level.
The full cotton market here developed more activity than usual last week but at the expense of prices, which dedined to new low levels for the calendar year.
Barney Ross and Henry Armstrong, who hope to meet in the ring at the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City tomorrow night, brought their preparatory work to a close yesterday. Ross,

Mrs. Margaret K. Breslauer, in 64 E 86th St, through Samuel A. Herzog, broker. Max Miller, in 1,070 Park Ave; Dr. Henry A. Cromwell, in 8 E 96th St; Frederic Ullman Jr, in 8 E 96th St; through Sharp Nassoit Management Corp; Edgar A. Levy, broker.

Mr. and Mrs. William J. Flynn of 35 McClellan Street, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Marie Flynn, to Robert H. Devlin, son of Peter J. Devlin, also of the Bronx, and the late Mrs. Devlin.

The best contribution the Jew can make to American life is to be "loyal to the mandates of his faith," Dr. Israel Goldstein, rabbi of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, declared yesterday morning at the closing exercises of the congregation's religious school at the B'nal Jeshurun Community Center, 270 West Eightv-ninth Street.

A year ago the rapidly mounting balance against the United States in its foreign trade was causing much perplexity. During the four first months of 1937 merchandise imports exceeded exports by $132,600,000; in spite of which fact our net import of gold reached the sum of $611,700,000 and of silver $18,170,000.

One fact the revolt of General Saturnino Cedillo, agrarian leader in the State of San Luis Potosi, has brought to the surface is that union oil workers in the fields have sent complaints to the newspapers over alleged moves to amalgamate the unions. The press suppressed the complaints.
The influence of the latest Central European crisis on the markets this week was somewhat similar to that produced by Germany's seizure of Austria, which caused something approaching panic.

New York now has a poet laureate, or at least the New York high schools have. Sixteen-year-old Clara Brussel has just won the distinction with a gallant and sensitive effort to which she gives the Wordsworthian title of "The Idiot of the Park." As a reward she receives a scholarship for a poetry class at City College.

An investigation of widespread box-office frauds in the WPA Federal Theatre Project came to light yesterday after nine employes of the WPA circus had been questioned for three hours at the Glenwood Road police station in Canarsie, Brooklyn.

The first annual Earl Prize of $50 has been awarded to Miss Ruth Delisky, member of the class of January '38 at Hunter College, according to an announcement by Professor E. Adelaide Hahn, head of the Department of Latin and Greek. The prize is for excellence in the study of Greek.

Pauline Weissberger, women's wearing apparel, store at southwest corner of Madison Ave and 58th St from Joseph Durst; Pease Elliman, Inc, brokers. Downey Wright, Inc. upholstery and furniture, store at 21 W 45th St from Frank G. Shattuck Co; Curtis-Johnson, Inc. broker.

Japanese forces are being rushed from north of the Yellow River and westward from Kweiteh along the Lung-Hai Railway to reinforce the troops commanded by Lieut. Gen. Kenji Doihara for what is expected to be one of the most important battles of the war.

In an exhibition match for the benefit of John Martinelli, injured halfback, the New York Americans and the St. Mary's Celtics of Brooklyn played to a 3-3 tie before a crowd of 2,000 at Starlight Park yesterday.

For the sake of stimulating votes by the 1,000,000 women in New York State who failed to cast a ballot in 1936, although eligible, femnine leaders of the Democratic, Republican and American Labor parties have reached an agreement to send out speakers to present to women's organizations, on a triparty basis, the issues of the forthcoming campaign.

France's financial markets were dominated this week by the darkening of the situation in Central Europe. Although the war scare which was in the foreground a week ago had receded, the repatriation of French capital had virtually ceased,

By the end of the week financiers were regarding the international outlook with less pessimism than on last Monday and generally approved the conciliatory attitude adopted by the Daladier government toward both the Czechoslovak and Spanish problems.

Miss Theresa A. Grossman, 21 years old, of Camden, 'was killed and her fiance, Paul Moss, 24, also of Camden, was seriously injured today in an automobile crash here. They were to have been married in the St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church here on June 11.

The Pope delivered to the Eucharistic Congress in Budapest this morning a message broadcast from his study at Castel Gandolfo in which he prayed that God might confirm the hope of humanity for better times and might "dispel the clouds that seem to threaten new storms."

The baccalaureate exercises at Marymount College this afternoon, which followed the senior class day program, consisted of the blessing of the senior class day tree on the campus, followed by the presentation of awards to students outstanding in extra curricular activities during the past four years.
The tenth printing of Lin Yutang's "The Importance of Living" (Reynal Hitchcock) is off. the press, bringing the total to 190,000 copies, including the Book-of-theMonth Club.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis W. Noland of Saratoga Springs have sent out invitations for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Margaret Reeves Noland, to George Walker Frost of Bethesda, Md., son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Frost of Haddonfield, N. J., on June 18 at Bethesda Episcopal Church. The Rev. Irving G. Rouillard will perform the ceremony.

Weakness in wheat was the dominating influence in the corn market last week and futures on the Board of Trade here declined 4 to 4 1/4 cents a bushel, a new low level for the season, with the July closing yesterday at 54 5/8 to 54 3/4 cents; September, 56 to 56 1/8 cents, and December, 53 7/8 cents. The last represents the crop which will be harvested this Fall.
British retail trade sales in April were 11.4 per cent above the same month the year before, following a decline of 3.7 per cent in March.
Mr. and Mrs. Jere S. Smith of Maplewood have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Elizabeth Smith, to Knowlton D. Read Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Read of South Orange.

THERE is nothing serious in the difference between Yale on the one side and Harvard and Princeton on the other regarding a starting date for football practice, but it is the opinion in this corner that fair Harvard and esteemed Princeton made a slight move in the wrong direction.

Selections from the 1937-38 exhibitions held by New York artists will be presented in a preview from 4 to 6 P. M. tomorrow in the Municipal Art Galleries, 3 East Sixty-seventh Street. The exhibition will be opened to the public at noon on Wednesday and will continue through Sunday, June 19.

A nation-wide round-up of Communists and suspected Communists on Dec. 5, 1936, became known today when a police ban on the news was lifted. It was revealed that more than 1,300 men and a number of women were arrested after the conclusion of the Berlin-Tokyo anti-Comintern pact on Nov. 25. 1936.

Thomas F. Sutherland, Ontario's Deputy Minister of Mines, died here today of a heart malady from which he had suffered for two years. He was 59 years old. Born in Nova Scotia, Mr. Sutherland was the son of the Rev. John Sutherland.

Miss Mary Dake Mairs, daughter of Mrs. John Dows Mairs of 148 East Forty-eighth Street, has completed plans for her marriage to John Francis Smith Jr., son of Mrs. John Francis Smith of Frederick, Md., which will take place June 17 in St. Bartholomew's Church.

The most dangerous enemy on earth of Christian principles is the dogma of nationalism, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick said yeSterday in his Memorial Day sermon at the Riverside Baptist Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

Anger Estate, Inc, sold to the 243 E 14th St Corp the 5-story building at 243 E 14th St for a consideration indicated as $4,500 over a mortgage for $32,500 and took back a purchase money mortgage for $1,500.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Victor Donaldson of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Isabel Donaldson, to Charles Frederick Junod, son of Mrs. Charles F. Junod of Pelham Manor and the late Mr. Junod.
Speaking today at the Suresnes Cemetery at a-memorial service for United States soldiers buried there, Ambassador William Bullitt said:
Faced with the possibility that the world will have a wheat crop far in excess of prospective needs, prices in leading markets plunged last week to the lowest levels in the last few years.
Corine Bonife, 11 years old, of 302 Sixth Street, and her 9-year-old brother, Albert, who were missing from home for twelve hours, were discovered yesterday morning on Sixth Street between Avenues A

The special committee which has been trying for four days to agree on a candidate for Stated Clerk of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America held a last-minute conference tonight, and it was reported that the choice had been made.

Members of the 165th (Old SixtyNinth) Regiment, National Guard, and the Sixteenth United States Infantry, with more than 500 friends and relatives, attended a solemn high memorial field mass for deceased members on the parade ground at Governors Island yesterday.

In expressing satisfaction from the pulpit yesterday that both the Episcopal Bishops of New Jersey have "fearlessly and plainly denounced the abominable un-Americanism of Mayor Frank Hague," the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie, rector of Grace Episcopal Church, said this country needs further "the grace to laugh at the Daughters of the Revolution."

President Roosevelt attended St. James Episcopal Church today and was so well pleased by a part of the sermon delivered by the rector, the Rev. Frank R. Wilson, that, at his suggestion, a part of it was repeated.

Slammin' Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., and Vie Ghezzi of Deal, N. J., "came from nowhere" on a rain and wind-swept course today to capture the fourth annual Inverness best-ball golf tournament and take $1,300 in prize money.
John Cormode, vice president of the American Mail Line, announced yesterday that operations would be abandoned June 30. "We can't go on making nothing but losses," Mr. Cormode said.

Modern oracles are found in dictators who wish to be served but not to serve, and also in our own government, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray said in his sermon yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (Little Church Around the Corner), 1 East Twentyninth Street.

The Communist Party of New Jersey held a picnic at Linwood Grove here this afternoon to raise funds to "fight" Mayor Hague. More than 1,000 men, women and children attended the outing, the adults each paying twenty cents admission to the picnic grounds.
The lastplace Browns backed up the excellent hurling of Buck Newsom with a dozen hits off four Cleveland pitchers today to wind up their home stand with an 8-to-6 victory over the Indians.
R. H. Bradley, who said he had been doing a $1,000,000-a-year piemaking business, has closed up shop, blaming a union affiliated with the A. F. of L. for the shutdown.

Rain descending on the final procession of the Eucharistic Congress this afternoon just after its leading ranks reached their places in Heroes Square somewhat marred the closing scene of the congress.

David insure Carlson and E. J. Doyle of New Haven, Conn., with a total of 776, won the long-range two-man team match in the rifle division, a feature event of the third annual competition of the Association of New Jersey Rifle and Pistol Clubs, today on the State ranges here.

Youthful anglers from all parts of Monmouth County down in Jersey will flock to Spring Lake next Saturday to participate in the annual trout fishing derby which is sponsored by the Monmouth Federation of Sportsmen's Clubs.
A gift to the New York Public Library by Gabriel Wells of The Four Gospels in Russian, with silver binding, has been announced by Robert J. Lingel, chief of the acquisition division of the library.
A special tax on all city employes not residents of New York City was proposed yesterday by James J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx, in a letter to the City Council.
Prince Pietro Lanza di Scalea, Vice President of the Senate and Under-Secretary of Foreign Affairs immediately before the World War, died here today at the age of 74.

In formation has been received here that on Wednesday fifteen kilograms of gold (about $16,800) were shipped from Veracruz for New York and 750 kilograms (about $845,000) for London. Paper notes, the amount of which is not known here, also were shipped.

" No age ever had a greater longing for voices of conviction than our own," said the Rev. Dr. Jarvis R. Morris, president of the Polytechnic Institute of Puerto Rico, in his sermon yesterday morning at the West End Presbyterion Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.
Lifeguards rescued 185 movie extras who became exhausted trying to swim with their clothes on to qualify for minor roles in a gambling ship picture here today.
The "father of the American foreign service" is keeping this government informed hourly of developments in the tense situation centering about Czechoslovakia.

Mayor Lee D. Schroy tonight accused leaders of the C. I. O. of inciting to riot and armed rebellion against public authority and pledged that the entire police force of this city would be mobilized Tuesday at the gates of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company plants if necessary to prevent disorder.

Olin Whitney Smith, since 1926 secretary of New York State Colleges of Agri- Of culture and Home Economics at Cornell University, died today in Memorial Hospital after a week's illness. His age was 53.

Edward Rogozinski, 22 years old, of 211-11 Forty-fifth Road, Bayside. was drowned this morning when the rowboat in which he was preparing to fish in company with his brother, William, and Edward Boerkel, was upset at the mouth of Millneck Creek.
The fourteenth annual Victor Herbert Festival of the Gaelic Musical Society of America was held last night on the Mall in Central Park before an audience of several thousand persons.
The money market here witnessed last week a series of heavy month-end credit demands. Day loans today were quoted at 2 3/4 to 3 per cent.

Virtually blasting her way in wind and sea over nineteen miles of Long Island Sound, F. T. Bedford's new Nyala defeated the other International twelve-meter yachts in a special regatta held today by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.

Philadelphia's defending champions completely outplayed and easily defeated Westchester, 14 to 3, as the second day of play in the sixth annual Women's United States round robin lacrosse tournament was concluded on the field of the Rye Country Day School today.

Walter Wanger has taken an option on the picture rights of "The Biography of Postmaster General James Farley," which will run serially in a national magazine in the Fall. The option price on the film rights was not learned, although it is understood that the magazine rights brought $125,000.

Sheriff Newman De Bretton reported today that he and seven deputies arrested thirty-six men last night after they had stormed the sulphuric acid plant of Consolidated Chemicals, Inc., scene of a sixteenday strike.
Plans for altering two tenement properties on the lower East Side were announced over the week-end when the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank sold two buildings on Pike Street. The buyer,
Eye-witnesses reported today that German secret police had spirited Dr. Kurt Schuschnigg, former Austrian Chancellor, out of Vienna's Belvedere Castle to "somewhere north."

Cotton prices broke sharply last week. The near-by July delivery on the New York Cotton Exchange fell to the lowest level since Dec. 8 and at the low point of the week it was 147 points from the high level of 9.28 in February.

Today, eyes that like to watch speed-perhaps 170,000 pairs of them, for the contest draws the largest crowd of any sporting event in America-will see the running of the annual 500-mile automobile race at the Indianapolis Speedway.
David Sklar of Brooklyn broke 100 straight targets today to achieve the all-bore championship and eclipse a world record for high-overall shooting in the ninth annual New York State shoot.

A moving picture being shown last night at the Fox-Fabian Theatre, Flatbush Avenue and Nevins Street, Brooklyn, was stopped for twenty-five minutes while about twenty patrolmen and detectives searched the house for a "bomb" reported to have been placed in the theatre.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 30 per cent of capacity, down 2 points from the rate of the last four preceding weeks.
Sao Tang Pao, news organ of the younger Chinese army officers, carries a report today from Hong Kong that Japan has asked Germany for a big supply of arms and many airplanes.

As if the projection and completion of Government hydroelectric plants were not enough to undermine confidence in privately owned utilities, J. D. Ross, administrator of the Bonneville project on the Columbia River, has filed a schedule of rates which dwarf even those fixed by Ontario for Niagara Falls power.

The rescue of three native fishermen from a sloop without sails off the island of Aruba in the Dutch West Indies by the Grace Line steamship Santa Paula was related yesterday in a radiogram received in the company's office at 10 Hanover Square from its agent at Baranquilla, Colombia.

An accumulation of small grievances, union prestige in the C. I. 0. affiliate, the United Rubber Workers of America, and a political line-up that labor, since last Fall, has regarded as a challenge, constitute the background of the bitter rioting of Goodyear workmen here last Thursday.

Six elderly men in the blue uniforms of the G. A. R. paid tribute to their departed comrades yesterday at memorial services held by the Ladies of the Grand Army of the Republic in Grand Army Plaza, Fifty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue.
The National Maritime Union will start today a campaign to obtain about 35,000 harbor and river workers on the Atlantic Coast as members of the union, a C. I. 0. affiliate.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 72.2 on May 25, compared with 73.2 a fortnight before, 73.3 a month ago and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

The provision of the State Unemployment Insurance Law that workers whose joblessness stems from an "industrial controversy" must wait ten weeks before qualifying for benefits does not apply to workers discharged for union activity, the Unemployment Insurance Appeal Board ruled in a decision made public yesterday.

Here is the starting line-up for tomorrow's 500-mile automobile race. The table shows the car number, driver, number of cylinders, rear or front drive motor and number of cubic inches piston displacement.

The marriage of Miss Christine Engelke, daughter of Dr. Charles Engelke of Waterbury, to Badger Perrin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Perrin of Medford, Mass., will take place at the Engelke residence June 18. The Rev. Dr. Robert E. Brown of Oberlin College, former pastor of the Second Congregational Church here, will perform the ceremony.

Parade and review, Grand Army of the Republic, from West Seventysecond Street and West End Avenue to Riverside Drive, north to Ninetysecond Street, past reviewing stand at Eighty-ninth Street and Riverside Drive, 9 A. M. Robert S. Heilferty, grand marshal.

Depression in the commodity markets here was accentuated last week by the drop in the price of Czech copper to the lowest point since August, 1935, and the fall of wheat below 6s a bushel for the first time since August, 1936. Wheat, however,

Ludwig Lewisohn and Dr. Stephen S. Wise, president of the Jewish Institute of Religion, discussed persecution of the Jews yesterday morning at the thirteenth annual commencement of the institute at Carnegie Hall.

Performing amid the beautiful surroundings of the Washington Irving Country Club, Gar Ann, 6-yearold bay mare owned by the Wynfromere Farm of Greens Farms, Conn., captured the hunter championship at the sixth annual. twoday Rockwood Hall.

Mrs. John F. Bowles has purchased the large Georgian-type residence and two acres of land on Zaccheus Mead Lane, Greenwich, Conn., from Donald F. Updike. The property was held at $80,000. She gave her residence on Bush Avenue in exchange.
Last week's stock market here witnessed rapidly alternating, although insignificant, advances, declines and little change in the general level.

A shouting, booing crowd of about 2,000 anti-Nazi pickets, some of them chanting "Down with Hitler!" milled about in front of California Hall, traditional meeting place of German groups, as the Pacific Coast German-American Bund opened its first convention here tonight. There were two minor fist fights.

Samuel Heilner, retired coal merchant, died at his Summer home, Seawood, here today. He was 82 years old. Mr. Heilner, for many years head of the firm of Percy Heilner Son, one of the East's oldest coal distributing-companies, was born in Philadelphia, the son of Percival and Caroline Van Campen Heilner.

The Yankees tried strategy, trickery and a flight into the higher brackets of learning in a bold bid to conquer the lowly Athleticss before 15,000 today at Shibe Park but it was all in vain. As a result they dropped to fourth place, below the Senators.

Miss Madeleine Huson Davidson, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ezra D. Davidson, was married to Martin Allen Pond, son of Mrs. Clifford A. Pond and the late Mr. Pond, yesterday afternoon in the Congregational Church here.
Miss Elizabeth Charis Goddard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Allen Goddard of Cheshire, will be married to Gregory Nelson Tyack, son of Mr. and Mrs. Urban N. Tyack, also of this place, on June 25.
Several Memorial Day observances were held in Westchester County today, although most of the events are scheduled for tomorrow.

Bob Seeds, who made history a couple of weeks ago when he hit seven homers in two days, staged another slugging show today in pacing the Newark Bears to a double victory over the Baltimore Orioles, 13 to 8 and 8 to 2.
How far markets we're governed last week by sudden intrusion, during the Czechoslovakian incident, of uneasiness over Europe's political situation, it would perhaps be hard to say. To stock markets,
Although the City was not greatly impressed by the latest of France's fiscal and recovery decrees, it sees in them determination by Premier Daladier to press forward with his program, which,

George Tappan Whitney, former Professor of Philosophy at Princeton University, died suddenly of a heart attack yesterday afternoon at his home here. His age was 67. Surviving are his widow, Laura B. Whitney, and a sister, Mrs. Winfield Hammond of Royalton, Vt.

Mrs. Rose Sanford, 23-year-old wife of Henry Sanford Jr., shot and killed herself this morning in her home in Timothy Lane here. Mr. Sanford, a writer for sports magazines, told the authorities he was eating breakfast on the first floor of the two-story house when he heard a shot upstairs.

Governor Cross, tracing Connecticut's 300-year history in the achievements of her leaders in various fields, reminded today that this and future generations should "be faithful as were they" to their country and their God.

The Chinese bodyguard of a Chinese lawyer shot and killed his employer and a fellow-guard today and then committed suicide in a crowded street in the heart of the International Settlement. The police said his motive was patriotism.

The American Museum of Natural History's $250,000 "flying laboratory," constructed here for exploration work in the interior of New Guinea, will take off Wednesday on the first leg of an 8,000-mile flight to the Dutch East Indies, Richard Archbold, flight commander, announced today.

Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, who is in his fifty-second year as rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, and who is Vicar General of the Archdiocese of New York, will be 82 years old today. He is one year and one day older than Pope Pius XI, who will be 81 years old tomorrow.
Sunday morning, after reaching its peak on Saturday, May 21, the Czechoslovak war scare had almost entirely vanished from the minds of competent business men here before the opening of the new week.

Homer Martin, international president of the United Automobile Workers of America, in an address at the special Memorial Day services of the Community Church yesterday morning, in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, declared this country was in serious danger of being involved in war if led to commit "one or more of several national blunders."
Mayor David H. Slayback, despite his 77 years, devoted twelve hours today to his campaign to make Verona a twenty-mile-an-hour town for motourists.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,142,973,650. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills.

A dwelling and sixty-two acres of land in Warren Township, Somerset County, N. J., have been bought by the Hollow Hills Club, Inc., of New York City, from Mr. and Mrs. George W. Cole for a Summer camp.

Captain Wood D. Beegmy, commander of the Third Battalion Combat Train, 192d Field Artillery, died today in the Stamford Hospital at the age of 47. Born in Dayton, Ohio, Captain Beeghley had made his home here for fifteen years.

G. D. Conant, Attorney General of Ontario, has notified the International Railway Company of Buffalo, N. Y., that any attempt on its part to proceed with its contemplated rebuilding of the Falls View Bridge across the Niagara River may result in the Ontario Government taking restraining action.

Scoring three runs in the eleventh inning, the Jersey City Giants salvaged the final contest of their four-game series with the Chiefs tonight, 7 to 4. Horne's double with two out and two on won the game, and Herman added a single to complete the scoring.

Bound with copper wire and so mutilated as to be unrecognizable, the body of 12-year-old Peter Levine, kidnapped last Feb. 24, drifted ashore today at Davenport Neck, a headland juttin; into Long Island Sound.

In the final session of the annual Connecticut Horse Show, Hallow Gold, 5-year-old chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. William J. Kennedy of Southborough, Mass., tonight won in the middle and heavyweight hunter class, with Relay, 5-year-old chestnut gelding belonging to Morton W. Smith of Greenwich, second.

The German wholesale price index on May 18 stood at 105.4, against 105.5 on May 11. In the first four months of this year the highest point reached by the German wholesale price index was 105.8, on March 2.

Professor Charles Darwin Adams, who retired more than ten years ago as head of the Greek Department of Dartmouth College, died here last night at the Summer home of his son, Robert E. Adams. His age was 81 years.
Addressing war veterans assembled at Perigueux tonight, Marshal Henri Petain, the hero of Verdun, repeated his call at Caen for the French nation to ??waken.

Florida will begin tomorrow the second attempt to send a group of Tampa peace officers to prison for the kidnapping and flogging of Eugene F. Poulnot thirty months ago. Five former Tampa policemenonce convicted and sentenced to four years each in the State penitentiary-will have a second trial, ordered by the State Supreme Court.

War-mongers are agitating for a new world-wide war. because they are convinced that the hour has arrived for amassing new fortunes, the Rev. Edward L. Hughes, AmerIcan secretary of the Union of Prayer for Peace, declared yesterday morning.

Hugh M. Tate of Knoxville, Tenn., former Interstate Commerce Commissioner, died at his home here late today after several months' illness. His age was 55. Mr. Tate was appointed to the commission in 1930 by President Hoover and served a seven-year term.

Secretary Hull's solemn reminder that the Kellogg-Briand pact binds Germany and Czechoslovakia to settle the Sudeten question by "pacific means" is intended to emphasize that Washington is not disinterested in the "critical situation" in Central Europe.

Floyd (Arky) Vaughan, former National League batting champion, smashed a home run and a double today to give Fred (Red) Lucas, veteran Pirate right-hander, a 2-1 victory over Larry French of the Cubs.

Discussion within committees of the Constitutional Convention has developed a sharp difference of opinion on the question of writing into the basic law a provision to permit the State to pay for part of the cost of unemployment insurance.

" With Summer just ahead, the steel market seems to be drifting without definite indication of a trend," the magazine Steel says this week. "Buying and consumption hold fairly steady at less than one-third the industry's capacity, with a slight tendency downward.

Arthur Hendrix of Lakeland, Fla., and Elwood Cooke Jr. of Portland, Ore., gained the final round of the invitation tournament of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today. They will play tomorrow at 3:30 o'clock following an exhibition scheduled for 2:30 by Chairman Louis B. Dailev.

The members of the color guards of forty-five posts and auxiliary bodies of the American Legion of New York County attended memorial services yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Holy Cross, 329 West Forty-second Street. The posts of the police, fire, sanitation and other city departments were among those represented.

Colonel Benjamin O. Davis, highest ranking Negro officer in the regular army, arrived here yesterday to be the guest of the 369th Infantry. N. Y. N. G., of which he expects to assume command shortly.. Colonel Davis,

Bob Weiland allowed the Reds two hits today to break the Cardinals' sevengame losing streak during their eastern trip and win, 3 to 0. Not a Redleg got as far as second base and only three went to first.
Thomas F. School, on Mott's Cove Rd., Roslyn, L. I., from Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Patchin; Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers.
Joe Louis thrilled a large crowd at his training camp today when he dropped Murray Kanner, one of his sparmates, in the second round of their two-round drill.
Nearly 3,000 members of the Queens County American Legion, led by County Commander Fred Schroeter, participated in the Memorial Day celebration in the Musie Grove at Forest Park yesterday.
Mr. and Mrs. Leon Boequeraz and their daughter, Miss Suzanne Bocqueraz, have come from Oakland, Calif., to the St. Regis. They will sail Wednesday on the Normandie.

Senator Norris said today that he believed the Tennessee Valley Authority should hasten its allocation of power costs on TVA dams so that a definite yardstick for measuring private electric rates could be fixed.

Declaring that America's great industrial order always has been a fascist system and that it has never been democratized, the Rev. Dr. Charles S. MacFarland, general secretary emeritus of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, said here today that industrial leaders are "now coping with John L. Lewis because they

Polo activity reached a new high for the current Long Island season today as many high goal stars, headed by Stewart Iglehart, one of the nation's top-ranking players, participated in four matches in this vicinity.

The brilliant ring career of Champion Ideal Weather, old English sheep dog, owned by Leonard Collins of Toronto, came to a close today when the big dog with the bearlike walk captured the best in show special at the Wissahickon Kennel Club's twenty-sixth annual exhibition.
About 200 holiday campers narrowly escaped drowning early today when a cloudburst broke a fish hatchery dam and sent water up to ten feet. deep rolling over the campsites in Roaring River State Park.
The Group Theatre's next new show-and almost certainly it will be Irwin Shaw's "Quiet City"-is due in New York about mid-December, it was disclosed yesterday.

The French liner Normandie is due today from Havre via Southampton and among her passengers are: Dr. Harry Plotz, laboratory chief of the Paris Pasteur Institute; General Sawada, Japanese military attache at Warsaw, and Mrs. Sawada; Colonel Norbert Champsaur, French air attache at the embassy in Washington; Stefan Czarnecki, Nicaraguan Consul in Warsaw, and Bernardo Molinari, orchestra conductor, and Mrs. Molinari.

Ernie Koy's solid single on Lou Fette's first pitch, scoring Goody Rosen from third base, broke up a pitching battle in the thirteenth inning, giving the Dodgers a 1-to- triumph over the Bees today and a sweep of the two-game series.

More than 2,000 persons attended the "departure ceremony" for five Jesuit missionaries and six missionary scholastic last night at the Church of St.Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street.

For a full five hours and fortyfive minutes, 23,400 assorted jitterbugs and alligators-more conservatively known as swing music enthuslasts - cavorted yesterday at Randalls Island Stadium to the musical gymnastics of twenty-fiye swing bands, vainly bucking the lines of police and park officers who were sworn to protect th swing maestros from destruction by adulation.

One pilot was killed and two others narrowly escaped when three out of seven planes were forced down during the second major event of the Pacific International Air Races here late this afternoon, repeating the tragedy that opened the show yesterday.

Liberty is not a trophy that once won can be kept but something that every people and every generation must fight for, United States Senator Robert F. Wagner told 3,000 Jewish War Veterans and their friends, gathered yesterday in Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at Sixty-fifth Street, for their forty-third annual memorial services.

Cletus Poffenberger shaded Monty Stratton in a hurlers' duel today as the Tigers defeated the White Sox, 2 to 1, before a crowd of 16,000 and swept the three game series. Poffenberger yielded only four hits, all singles, for his fourth victory.

The names of Civil War and Spanish-American War veterans of New York who died since last Memorial Day were read off to the accompaniment of drum beats last night at a memorial service in the Church of the Strangers, 309 West Fiftyseventh Street.

The did center of interest in the Harlan coal labor feud shifted today from London, scene of the anti-union conspiracy trial of operators and former or present deputy sheriff mine guards, to Harlan itself, eighty miles away.

Another step toward carrying out the provisions of the Anglo-Irish agreement has been taken with the completion of arrangements for the surrender to Ireland of Cork, 'one of three "treaty ports" over which Britain retained jurisdiction under the 1921 treaty.

A rare sketch of Yale College, done in 1813 by Baroness Hyde de Neuville, who shared her husband's American exile and later returned with him when he was appointed French Minister to the United States, will be presented to the public for the first time in the forthcoming issue of the Franco-American Review, a quarterly devoted to the cultural and historical relations of France End America.

While United States Coast Guard and New York harbor police were searching the choppy waters of Newark and New York Bays today for 14-year-old Riccardo (Tex) Rideout of Leonia and his twelvefoot home-made outboard motorboat the youngster was safely at anchor in a cove off Great Kills, S. I., "waiting for the wind to blow itself out."

With memories of war in the past and with hope for peace in the future thousands of members of veteran and patriotic organizations began the celebration of Memorial Day yesterday throughout the city and environs.

In the regular weekly shoot of the North Jersey Gun Club today, A. B. Blood, D. P. Earle, M. H. Apgar, Dr. W. H. Pruden, J. L. Flagg and W. M. Frederick annexed prizes in the first fifty. Apgar, M. J. Cushman, Frederick, Blood and A. Marshalek won the trophies in the second fifty. Blood and W. D. Hogan tied in the yardage handicap.

The marriage of Miss Helene Doris Rosenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Rosenberg of 239 Central Park West, to Leslie Ralph Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham H. Schwartz of Cedarhurst, L. I., took place last evening in the Sert Room of the WaldorfAstoria.

A newspaper report announced today that Y. Kampyeff, former head of the Armenian Silk Trust, had been sentenced to death on charges of wrecking in silk production at the behest of Japanese and Italians.

Miss Anne Lauder Greenway has completed plans for her marriage to John Sloane Griswold, son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. S. Griswold of New York and Black Hall, Old Lyme, Conn., the afternoon of June 25 at Kincraig, the estate at Mead's Point here of Miss Greenway's parents, Dr. and Mrs. James C. Greenway.
Stocks lower on the week in quiet trading; turnover, 3,059,140 shares. United States Government and other bonds irregularly lower; transactions, $24,650,475.
A child was killed and considerable damage was wrought when, an earthquake shook the Kushiro district of Hokkaido early yesterday. Nine houses were destroyed and others were damaged.

President Roosevelt "alone cannot stem the tide of international propaganda, he must have the active interest and hearty support of all Americans," asserted Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. yesterday afternoon at a memorial meeting of the Kings County American Legion in Prospect Park, Brooklyn. About 5,000 attended.

Italy today celebrated both "The Day of Solidarity for Nationalist Spain"-announced last week by the Fascist party's secretary general to emphasize Italy's determination to see General Francisco Franco through to final victory-and the twelfth Fascist levy, which consists of the promotion of Fascist boys and girls from one grade to another in youth organizations and from the youth organizations into the party ranks.

Miss Janet Beal, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Starr Beal of this place and Chicago, and John Lawrence, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin W. Lawrence of Rutland, were married here yesterday afternoon at Cider Mill Farm, the Summer home of the bride's parents.

Rain of near cloudburst proportions, accompanied by hail and electrical disturbances, early today caused damage in this extreme Northwest Arkansas area estimated at more $1,000,000 by Joe Morris, Street Commissioner.

Tribute was paid to the dead of all American wars this afternoon when the Affiliated Veterans of Passaic County held a memorial service in Laurel Grove Memorial Park.- Several thousand persons attended, including members of thirty-five veterans' organizations.

Virtually every known occupation is represented in the list of contributors to the $10,000,000 campaign of the Greater New York Fund, James G. Blaine, campaign chairman, announced yesterday in making public contributions totaling $120.80 from the household employes of Mrs. E. Parmalee Prentice and Mrs. Frank Presbrey.

More than 500,000 salespeople in more than 50,000 stores throughout the country will throw their support to National Cotton Week, which gets actively under way tomorrow and will continue through Saturday, according to a statement issued for publication today by Charles K. Everett, of the Cotton Textile Institute.

As a national and local representative of his city, Mayor Angelo J. Rossi of San Francisco appealed yesterday to the people of New York to back San Francisco's effort to obtain additional intercoastal ships linking the East and West Coast ports.

Alglers using their automobiles instead of orthodox tackle to catch fish gave Warden Lenox Henderson a new worry today. The method, he said, was to hook a naked wire' to a spark plug and dangle it in the water.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The interesting reply of Stewart McDonald to my letter published May 16 brings up two important phases of FHA large-scale housing policy: one concerned with its insurance of loans on Federally subsidized low-rent projects and the other with insurance of loans on non-subsidized commercial undertakings.

The absorption of individual freedom by political powers was criticized by the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, pastor of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at Twenty-ninth Street, in his sermon there yesterday.

Teenactment of an amendment to the Housing Act increasing from a half billion to a billion dollars the funds for slum clearance and low-cost housing at the disposal of United States Housing Authority was urged tonight in a speech over the Mutual

Flashing the same effective stroking that gained them top honors in the qualifying round, Rudolph E. (Rudy) Knepper and his veteran partner, C. H. Jennings, representing the Garden City Golf Club, today won their way into the topflight final of the Meadow Brook Club's annual Spring four-ball invitation golf tourney.

Fundamental changes will be made in the Foran Labor Relations Bill when it is reported out of committee in the Assembly Tuesday night, it was said today after a five-hour executive session in the office of Vincent J. Murphy, City Commissioner and secretary of the New Jersey State Federation of Labor.

Miss Priscilla Danvers Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Thompson of 50 Holley Place, Torrington, has completed plans for her marriage to the Rev. Bradford Wells Ketchum, which will take place in Trinity Church here on the evening of June 11.

The arrest of a former Peruvian diplomat, wanted by American authorities and the police of many nations as the key man in a huge international narcotics smuggling ring, was disclosed today by Harry J. Anslinger, United States Narcotic Commissioner.

A squadron of thirty-eight German military airplanes commanded by General Helmuth Forster arrived today at the aerodronme near here. The squadron includes thirty bombers, seven transport planes and one plane for the squadron leader. They carry forty-five officers and 200 men.

Deploring the fact that "Christians have changed greatly since the time of Christ," the Rev. Joseph A. Tytheridge, preaching yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, warned contemporary followers of Christ that "you cannot succeed in the practice of your religion unless you see eye to eye with the apostles."
The Leith Ross delegation for revision of the AngloGerman payment agreement of November, 1934, was the center of last week's financial interest here.
Memorial services for John (Bud) Fraser, Brooklyn aviator, who fell to his death last Winter in the Hudson opposite West Point, were held today on the river bank near where his plane was last seen.
Mrs. Constance Eriksen Trevor of New York was married to Dr. Henry Haskell Levy here this afternoon by Justice of the Peace William S. F. Fiske.
Wesley Ferrell pitched his seventh victory of the season against the Red Sox today and the Senators moved into third place ahead of the New York Yankees. The score was 5 to 3.

WHILE we are remembering things on this Memorial Day, especially what happened in Chicago last Memorial Day, we might give a thought to what happened in the same city fortyodd years earlier, in May, June and July, 1894, when the bloody Pullman strike was being fought out and John P. Altgeld was Governor of Illinois.

A national resettlement committee, to centralize the task of resettling refugees from Germany at points distant from the congested areas in the East, was formed here today at a meeting of members of the National Coordinating Committee for German Refugees.

The completion of a streamlined locomotive capable of a speed of 110 miles an hour by the October Revolution Locomotive Works was announced today. Quantity production will be started after it has completed a 3,750-mile trial run.

The favorable international relations of the American countries rest upon the principle that the strong do not dominate the weak, and of noninterference with the internal problems of other nations, General Eduardo R. Hay, Mexican Foreign Secretary, said today in a radio address from Mexico City.

Responsibility for last week's "panicmongering" was fastened on international "Marxist-Jewish war-baiters in Prague, Moscow, Paris and London" by Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels in a defiant speech before Chancellor Hitler and 56,000 Storm Troopers here today.

The attitude of Christians toward the problems of today was likened to that of the disciples after the ascension of Jesus by the Rev. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.
Auerbach, Frederick Bennett, Alfred Berg, Henry Bizjak, Theresa Burlingham, Robert Byrne, Anna M. Caffuzzi, Elisa Clay, Frederick G.

There will be a Federal investigation of the collision that sent the excursion steamer Mandalay to the bottom in forty feet of water Saturday night after the Bermuda-bound cruise ship Acadia had sliced into it in a fog in the lower harbor.
For a long time the British have assumed a rather superior attitude toward the blight of American kidnappings.

One of the counts in the indictment that charges Tammany Leader James J. Hines and others with operating a lottery in the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy racket, is based upon a raid conducted by police on a penthouse apartment at 19 East Ninety-eighth Street Feb. 19, 1934, it was established yesterday.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.8, which compares with 81.4 a week ago, 80.8 two weeks ago, 80.5 three weeks ago and 80.6 four weeks ago.

John Boyle, assistant State's attorney, announced today plans for prompt trial of two Negro vagrants in the killing early Friday of Mrs. Florence Johnson. She was beaten to death with a brick when she was awakened by robbers in her flat.

The Glidden Company, manufacturer of paints and allied products, announced today a net profit of $12,570 for the first half of its fiscal year, ended on April 30, compared with $1,683,254 the year before.
Mrs. F. W. Knolhoff of this place announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jean Knolhoff, to Frederick W. Doolittle Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Doolittle of Garden City, at a tea this afternoon.
Judge Trogan, owned and driven by Frank Maynard, won the Class A trot and pace, feature event at the opening of the 1938 season at the Carmel Driving Park today.
John L. Lewis is certainly old enough to have studied Lord Chatham's famous speech in defense of the American Colonies,
Ernest Hemingway, American author who has been writing on the Civil War in Spain for the North American Newspaper Alliance, returned yesterday in the French liner Normandie.
Round table luncheon, Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street, 12:30 P. M. "The Ideological Aggression of Fascism and Its Bearing on American Foreign Policy,-" Johannes Steel.

Frank Boyce, 43 years old, died in St. Peter's Hospital here today several hours after he had been shot by his wife, Nora, 43, because he had threatened to evict her and their oldest son, Raymond, 21, from their home on Marlboro Road, Old Bridge, N. J.

Wilfred Chappin of Missoula, Mont., and Randall Arthur Williams of Leadville, Col., who said they had left the Spanish Government's International Brigade and made their way into France, were lodged in jail here today after being landed from the liner President Harding as stowaways.

While pursuing a speeding motorist on the Henry Hudson Parkway at 2 A. M. today, Motorcycle Patrolman Melvin Williams of Motor Cycle Squad 1 was killed instantly when his cycle crashed into the rear of another car at 247th Street.
With the markets in the North closed for the Memorial Day holiday the New Orleans cotton market was called upon to absorb the nation's cotton business.

There were 37,098,084 telephones in the world on Jan. 1, 1937, or 5 per cent more than the previous peak, reached in 1931, according to a report released yesterday by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

The GermanCzech crisis growing out of the Sudeten issue continues to monopolize German editorial comment. Although Saturday's statement by Secretary of State Cordell Hull of the United States on the critical situation in Central Europe has received a respectful hearing, it has served to stimulate the flow of press recrimination.

This country must do more than teach people to read and write if it is to stop the increase in "racketeering, moral depravity and insanity," declared Secretary of Commerce Roper in an address prepared for delivery tonight at the commencement exercises of Loyola university.

Commencement exercises of the Highland Manor School for Girls will be held at the school here tomorrow. The Rev. Dr. Alexander Cairns will be the speaker. The valedictory will be by Evelyn Potechin and the salutatory by Natalie Hamburger. Arlene Kannar will head the commencement procession.

The marriage of Miss Helen Claire Brill, only daughter of Abraham Brill and Mrs. Brill (Magistrate Jeanette G. Brill), to Dr. Harry Gordimer, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Gordimer of the Bronx, took place last evening at the home of the bride's parents in Brooklyn.

Secret informal meetings of the three groups in the International Labor Office Governing Body today on the eve of its session seemed to assure the election of John G. Winant of the United States to succeed Harold B. Butler as director or the office.
THE LENIENT GOD, by Naomi Jacob. (Macmillan, $2.50.) A novel of modern London. THE LORD HELPS THOSE . . ., by Bertram B. Fowler, (Vanguard, $1.75.) A study of the cooperative movement in Nova Scotia.
Miss Jandyra Vargas, eldest daughter of President Getulio Vargas and Mrs. Vargas, will be married tomorrow to Ruy da Costa Gama,a pilot of the Pan American Airways Brazilian Company.
Automobile production declined less than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 45.9 from 44.0. The figure was 133.6 for the week ended May 29, 1937.
The first royal marriage in Paris for years was held at noon today when Prince Dominique Radziwill of Poland took as his bride Princess Eugenie of Greece, who also is a Princess of Denmark.

Sir Thomas Inskip, Minister for the Coordination of Defense, announced in the House of Commons tonight that the British Government had completed all its preparations to raise a conscript army the day war was declared.
Three members of the American Women's Wightman Cup tennis team easily won their-first-round matches today in the St. George's Hill tournament at Weybridge.

Pope Pius XI will pass his eighty-first birthday quietly tomorrow in his Summer palace overlooking Lake Albano. Except for low mass in his private chapel and reception of a few of his intimate associates, the Pontiff expected scarcely to mark the day.

The nation's capital today celebrated its seventieth Memorial Day with impressive ceremonies. At the Arlington Amphitheatre, where the chief services were held, thousands of spectators gazed across a sunny, wind-blown landscape at equal thousands of flag and flower-decked gravestones scattered over the hillsides around the tomb of the Unknown Soldier.

Mrs. Elizabeth Wilmot Newcomb, founder and first president of the Stony Wold Sanatorium, died at her home here today after a prolonged illness at the age of 78. Her husband, Dr. James Edward Newcomb, professor of laryngology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, New York, died in 1912. No members of her immediate family survive.

Viennese still are unaware of the fate of Dr. Kurt Schuschnigg, former Chancellor. Official circles still are reluctant to confirm the report-fully verified by other sources-that the former Chancellor has been removed from his former residence in Belvedere palace.

Memorial Day parades and exercises were held throughout New Jersey yesterday. Governor A. Harry Moore praised the democratic ideal and assailed communism before 5,000 persons at Camp Merrit in Dumont.

One of the most important decisions of his administration faced President Roosevelt tonight as he left here to go to Washington, where he will meet at the White House tomorrow the -leaders of his party in Congress to discuss the chances of successfully reviving the Government Reorganization Bill. at this session.

A scathing attack on many proposals submitted to the Constitutional Convention is contained in a letter sent by Supreme Court Justice Meier Stein brink of Brooklyn to James L. Dowsey, chairman of the convention's Committee on Counties and Towns, and made public here today.

Manufacturers and retailers of wearing apparel and allied businesses predominated in the lists of commercial rentals submitted yesterday. Most of the new leases were for units in midtown, while a number of renewals were reported in the downtown section.

Five persons were named yesterday by Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, as a special committee "to investigate the whole problem of street obstructions and encroachments, from old cigar store Indians to sidewalk cafes." The committee will present to Mr. Isaacs proposals for improving conditions.

The British Museum paid ??640 for 116 leaves of a volume printed by William Caxton in the fifteenth century at the sale of the Ham House library held at Sotheby's today. By the purchase the museum acquired the remaining pages of its mutilated volume of "The Book of Divers Ghostly Matters,"

The graduating class of Columbia College will gather with faculty members under the maples of the Van Amringe Quadrangle on the university campus this afternoon to participate in Class Day exercises, the last academic ritual before the university's 184th conferring of degrees tomorrow evening in South Court.

The Tigers, with the home-run twins, Rudy York and Hank Greenberg, in top form vanquished the Browns, 10 to 9, in the opener, but lost the second game of a Memorial Day double-header today to Les Tietje's six-hit pitching, 3 to 0.

When Music, heavenly maid, was young she had a sweet, serious, religious way with her. If architecture was frozen music, music was melted architecture. She had, as it were, a dying fall. She soothed the savage breast, softened rocks and bent the knotted oak. She crept into the listeners' ears, as the moonlight slept upon the bank; soft stillness and the night became the touches of sweet harmony.

The theatrical season officially ends tonight, but unlike the finale of most years it will depart on a premiere. This occasion is the first American showing of "The Two Bouquets," a Victorian comedy by Eleanor and Herbert Farjeon, with music picked up from the

United States Ambassador Joseph D. Kennedy today led Americans in England in exercises commemorating Memorial Day. With many of his staff he attended memorial services in historic St. Margaret's, the church of Westminster Abbey.
Ed Clancy scored on an error with none out in the last half of the ninth to give the New York Athletic Club nine a hard-earned 3-2 victory over the Hamilton Baseball Club yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. Paul C. Johnston, pastor of the Third Presbyterian Church of Rochester, and the Rev. Dr. William B. Pugh, minister of the First Presbyterian Church of Chester, Pa., became today the nominees for Stated Clerk of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

After a journey through Manchukuo and North China the writer, for the first time since the outbreak of hostilities nearly eleven months ago, begins to doubt that Japan will emerge profitably victorious from this unde dared war.
Czechoslovakia decreed tonight some form of military or defense service for her entire population between the ages of 6 and .60.

Dr. Harry Plotz, laboratory chief of the Parts Pasteur Institute, who recently made important discoveries for treatment of measles, arrived yesterday on the French liner Normandie to attend the twenty-fifth reunion of his class at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University.

There will be no immediate changes in the Japanese Foreign Office personnel, reliable informants said today, but before long Vice Foreign Minister Kensuke Horinouchi, formerly Consul General in New York, will proceed to Washington as Ambassador. Hirosi Saito,

By winning two of the last three holes, John E. Parker Jr. of Canoe Brook, former metropolitan amateur champion, and A. W. Betts of the home club captured the final of the Meadow Brook Club's invitation best-ball golf tournament from the Garden City Golf Club team of R. E. (Rudy)Knepper and C. H. Jennings today, 1 up.
Miguel Fleta, tenor, who in 1923 was hailed as a second Caruso upon his New York debut with the Metropolitan Opera Company, died today at Corunna.

Properties on the upper West Side furnished the bulk of the realty activities in Manhattan reported yesterday. The six-story elevator apartment at 282 Northern Avenue, just north of the George Washington Bridge,

Interesting changes are taking place in many New Jersey cities within commuting distance of Manhattan. The problems of taxation, as they affect both the owners of valuable residential land and the municipal

The Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science, known as the University in Exile, will confer eight degrees of Master of Social Science tonight at its third commencement exercises at -the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.
Uncle Dyke Garrett, the 96-year-old mountain preacher whose hundreds of converts included Captain Anderson (Devil Anse) Hatfield, was buried today in his native hills after a simple funeral service.

The Lake Placid-Marcy Hotel at Mirror Lake, Lake Placid, N. Y., has been leased for a term of years by the Imperial Management Company, Inc., from the Fabian Operation Corporation of New York, Albert M. Greenfield Co., Inc., brokers in the transaction, announced yesterday.

James A. Farley, Postmaster General and chairman of the Democratic National Committee, was one of the guests today at the graduation exercises of Marymount School here. He was accompanied by Mrs. Farley and their younger children, Ann and James Jr., who came to see the Farleys' eldest daughter, Betty, who is 15 years old, receive her diploma in the graduating class of nineteen. Today also was Mr. Farley's fiftieth birthday.

The death in Spain of David Doran, political commissar of the American Lincoln Brigade, fighting with the Loyalists in Spain's civil war, was reported by cable to the New York headquarters of the brigade yesterday. Details as to the time or place of his death were not given. He was 29 years old.
The Newbrook Stables' brilliant 3-yearold trotting colt Blair turned in the outstanding performance of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey's opening matinee at Weequahic Park today.

THOSE disappointed thousands who couldn't squeeze or squirm their way into the Yankee Stadium yesterday missed a lot of fun. The show included a bout between Jake (Panther) Powell of the Ruppert battalion and Joe (Killer) Cronin of the Fenway Millionaires.

The Department of Commerce reported today that Argentina ranked next to the United States and Canada as a supplier of lard to the market in Liverpool, England, in the first quarter of 1938. A communication from the United States Consulate at Liverpool, made public here, said:

The long-distance speedway fan championship went .to Sir Victor Sassoon, owner of the Cathay Hotel, Shanghai, China, who flew 30,000 miles in a round-about trip to see the annual 500-mile race today Sir Victor was pressed by Mr. and Mrs. J. H. Staines and their daughter, Hazel, of Perth, West Australia. They wound up a 22,000mile world tour here.

A downward trend in the dollar volume of wholesale and retail foods sales throughout the country marks the closing days of May, according to the American Institute of Food Distribution in its weekly report, issued for publication today.

Pointing out that some retailers "are not aware of the existence of advertising law as a State criminal statute and that this law is now being enforced actively by the Bureau of Weights and Measures of the Department of Markets of the City of New York," H. J. Kenner,

Sir Louis Beale, British commissioner in charge of Britain's display at the New York World's Fair of 1939, and John Easton, joint architect for the British pavilions to be erected at the exhibition, will arrive today from London on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania.
Samuel Graham Jr., former local manager of the RFC, died here on Saturday after an illness of several months. His age was 59.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Elisha M. Friedman's remarkably able summation of the railroad problem in your issue of May 22 certainly deserves more than passing interest. As he says, its long-term solution will involve statesmanship, leadership and a sense of obligation of a high order on the part of managers, labor, investors,

The National Industrial Conference Board, Inc., of 247 Park Avenue, New York, was accused in a letter today by H. R. Tolley, Administrator of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, of making "gross misrepresentations" in a bulletin it issued on April 12.

Hexameter, a brown gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs- Alvin Untermyer of Greenwich, Conn., was adjudged the champion hunter of the Devon horse show which closed late today after six days of keen competition.

John W. Pitney, '39, of Far Hills, N. J., has been elected captain of the Princeton crew for next season to succeed Philip LeBoutillier, '38, of New York, it was announced today by Coach Fred Spuhn. Fulcher P. Smith, '39, of Cumberland, Md., was named manager.
The following one-family houses in the Bronx have been leased for the Home Owners Loan Corporation through D. Houlihan Sons, brokers: To Joseph O'Brien, 2,433 Yates Avenue; Henry Schiesser,

With Huff Hadley pitching sixhit ball and driving in what proved to be the winning run with the first of his two singles, Williams College regained the Little Three baseball title from Amherst by scoring a 6 to 3 victory over the champions before a capacity crowd on Weston Field today. Moving Into the lead with a run in the first inning, the Purple was never heated.

As a result of the investigation of last week's Rotterdam bomb explosion, The Netherlands' police say they have good reason to suppose many Russian secret police activities in recent years have been initiated in this country.

More than 1,000 former residents of this community, some of whom came from California, Alabama and Texas, marched in a parade here today that closed the three-day Rockaway Homecoming Celebration. The procession was headed by Miss Genevieve Grow, who was elected Homecoming Queen by popular vote.

More than 100,000 persons watched the Bronx Memorial Day parade yesterday. The police said the crowd was the largest at a Memorial Day celebration in that borough in recent years. The parade was under the direction of the United Veterans Memorial and Executive Committee of the Bronx.

The United States Women's Lacrosse Association ended its national round-robin today with the defending champion, Philadelphia, emerging as the only unbeaten team. The Philadelphians routed New York, 13 to 0, in their final game on the field of the Rye Country Day School.

Recent discussions in this space of the adverse effects on recovery of Section. 201 of the spending bill, now before the Senate, have evoked much correspondence. The following excerpt from one letter illustrates the type of citizen most affected by Section 201, which would permit both loans and gifts (to municipalities) for the purpose of erecting power plants to compete with existing private facilities.

A Memorial Day crowd of 20,352 spent more than seven hours today at Forbes Field to see the Pirates take a seventeen-inning game by 5 to 4 from St. Louis and then drop the second contest to the Cardinals, 9 to 6.

The feeling is crystallizing in those circles in London best qualified to express an opinion that a visit to the United States by the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, which had been thought definitely shelved, has once more become a possibility.

Joint opposition by the entire American labor movement to the wage cuts being made in industry, with "vigorous resistance and strike action" if necessary, was urged in a resolution unanimously adopted yesterday by the delegates to the tenth national convention of the Communist party in the United States.

Dartmouth scored four runs in the fifteenth inning to defeat the University of Vermont nine by 9--7 in a four-hour battle before a crowd of 2,000 today. Vermont struck back with two in its half of the frame. Woodman then pulled down a fly in short left with the tying runs aboard to end the rally.

Legislation will soon be introduced in Parliament to lay the groundwork for the most ambitious housing scheme ever proposed in Canada. Reports are that the bill contemplates loans to municipalities for low-rent housing projects that may
Belgium defeated India, 4 to 1, in their Davis Cup tie concluded today, and will next meet the winner between Sweden and Yugoslavia in the semifinals of the European zone.
" White Collars" will be remade by Metro. Franchot Tone is tentatively scheduled for the lead and Joseph Fields and Jerry Chodorov have been assigned to prepare the screen play.

Marvin (Bud) Ward and Ray Billows, both of whom have been off form since landing here, today strengthened the United States hopes in the Walker Cup matches with par-shattering performances over the old St. Andrews course.

Although Federal and local law enforcement agencies redoubled their efforts today to find the kidnapper and slayer of 12-year-old Peter D. Levine, there was little indication here that the case was materially nearer solution as the result of the discovery of the boy's mutilated body yesterday.

WASHINGTON (Science Service).-Iridium, a heavy noncorrodible metal used in electrical contacts, fountain pen points and as a hardener for dental gold, comprises more than one-fifth of the platinummetals content of some of the Platinum Creek, Alaska, placer deposits, reports Dr. J. B. Mertie Jr. of the Geological Survey, who described his studies of the Alaskan platinum mines to the Geological Society of Washington.

Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, addressing a Memorial Day throng of thousands on this historic battlefield, warned today that the nation faces "another Gettysburg." The- Michigan Senator said that this time "the crisis is civil-not military."

Communists attending the tenth annual convention of the party and eight women whose husbands, sons or brothers have been killed fighting with the Loyalists in Spain, held exercises and laid wreaths G yesterday at the Eternal Light Madison Square.

The record baseball crowd which attended the double-header at the Stadium yesterday enriched the Yankees by $57,451.82. Their share of the gross receipts of $91,610.75 totaled $57,205.97, to which was added $245.85 for service charges on complimentary tickets.
Some weeks ago we mentioned a weekly luncheon club whose membership comprised all kinds of anglers with all sorts of theories.

The Athletics divided a doubleheader with the Senators before 35,724 paying spectators today, a record crowd for the season at Shibe Park. Six runs in the first inning gave Washington the opener, 9 to 4, while six in the fourth clinched the second. game for Philadelphia, 9 to 1.
The Senate Military Affairs Committee made public today a report approving legislation which would compel every one having net wealth' of $1,000 or more to lend money to the government in wartime.

ATHA--At Newark, N. J., at her home, 389 Clifton Ave., on Monday, May 30, 1938, Helen Kimball, widow of Benjamin H. Atha, and mother of Stuart K. and Kimball Atha. Funeral service private. BAUERLE--William H., on May 29, beloved husband of Minnie and father of William H. Jr. and Charles and Mrs. Clara Knothe, Mrs. Anna Thimmel, Mrs. Carrie Freund, Mrs. Minnie Bauer, Mrs.

Crossbow II, sturdy son of Crusader and Slow and Easy, carried the devil red and blue silks of Warren Wright's Calumet Farm to a narrow victory in the $5,000 added Crete Handicap at Lincoln Fields today, winning by a nose from the favorite, Preeminent.

Patrols from four scout troops received "high standard" ratings this afternoon at the wind-up of the annual "camporee" of the Manhattan Council of the Boy Scouts of -America at Kane's Open, a campsite at Tallman, near here.

The Naumburg .Orchestra gave the first of its annual series of Summer concerts last night on the Mall in - Central --Park. Rosario Bourdon conducted. Frances Shapiro, talented young violinist, was the soloist. A holiday crowd of some 4,500 enthusiastic-listeners attended.

Hungary opened her St. Stephen's commemorative year in observance of the 900th anniversary of the death of her patron saint and first king here today with magnificent religious and civil ceremonies rivaling those of the International Eucharistic Congress, which closed yesterday.

THIRD MITARY AREA The following Reserve officer, recently promoted is assigned to unit indicated below: To 310th Infantry (78th Dlv.), Englewood Military District, 1st Lt. Carl F. Rupp, Inf.-Res., 210 36th St., Union City, N. J. The following prospective R. O. T. C. graduate of Mississippi State College, State College, Miss., is assigned to the organization indicated below effective upon acceptance of appointment as 2d Lt. Inf.Res.
The Harvard baseball team bowed to Brown, 1--0, today in a fourteeninning battle, one of the finest seen on a Brown field in many years.

In Times Square, at the Eternal Light in Madison Square, at Grant's Tomb and the Soldiers and Sailors Monument on Riverside Drive and elsewhere in the city, patriotic organizations laid wreaths and paid tribute yesterday to the dead of America's six wars.

Buying activity in the New York wholesale market last week centered on Summer merchandise. Among the items selling in fair volume were spun rayon and novelty synthetic spectator sports outfits, in all price ranges, medium price to cheaper lace dresses, popular-price wash frocks, white and pastel suits, cheaper white mesh gloves and white handbags, and beach and play wear of all types. Graduation,

A turnout of 150,000 spectators on Bedford Avenue, Eastern Parkway and the Grand Army Plaza greeted the seventieth annual Memorial Day parade in Brooklyn yesterday morning. The spectacle they watched was considered one of the best in history of the event, for 15,000 veterans with escorting bands marched in it.

Japan had a raid scare when two mysterious planes, supposed to be Chinese, flew along the whole western side of Kyushu island last night and early today. All the region was "blacked out" for three hours.
Japanese troops at San-yi-chai, Lowang and other points near Lanfeng held out desperately against continuing heavy Chinese attacks yesterday.
Topped by the crowd of 83,53 that packed the Stadium, yester day's eight major league doubleheaders drew a total of 331,34' fans, according to The Associates. Press.

Walter von Tresckow will become today president of Young Ottley, Inc., investment counsel, it was announced yesterday. He will succeed James Ottley, who is to become chairman of the executive committee.

Americans throughout the nation and in all parts of the world paid tribute yesterday to those who gave their lives for their country. [Page 1.] Thousands assembled for the nation's rites of memory at Arlington Amphitheatre to hear Senator Walsh call for defense of democracy. [Page 2.]

Problems arising from exchange difficulties in foreign markets will be discussed at the forty-third annual Credit Congress of the National Association of Credit Men, which will meet in San Francisco next Sunday to Friday, the association announced yesterday.

The election of Paul R. Vervoort of the Commercial National Bank and Trust Company as president of the Bank Credit Associates of New York was announced yesterday. He succeeds Edward Adams Jr. of the Grace National Bank.

Yesterday, 21,361 Flatbush fans cheerfully paid their money into the Ebbets Field till with considerable confidence that the Dodgers would flatten those cellar-dwelling Phillies in both ends of the Memorial Day double-header.

Miss Peggy Porter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fitz John Porter of 27 East Sixty-second Street, has chosen June 22 as the date for her marriage to Nicholas Vedder Poole, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Poole of this city and Franconia, N. H.
Great Britain is trying to work out an international plan to prevent killing and maiming of civilians by airplane bombing, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain informed the House of Commons today.

A new issue of $550,000 of Township of Weehawken, N. J., 31/4 per cent general funding bonds, dated April 1, 1938, and due on April 1, 1941 to 1951, will be offered today by B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc.; Minsch, Monell Co., Inc.; Colyer, Robinson Co., Inc., and Van Deventer, Spear Co., Inc.

Village parades preceded exercises at various shrines to the war dead throughout Nassau County today as thousands of persons paid tribute to the memory of the soldiers and sailors who died in service.

A joint tribute from forty American hospitals associated in the three-cents-a-day type of service plan was received tonight by 100 similar organizations in Britain at a reception held in Westminster Hospital.

A four-acre plot on Sunken Meadow Road, Fort Salonga, L. I., and another at East Northport, were sold for the Bradley and E. B. Hendrickson estates, respectively, through Raymond Smith, Oyster Bay broker, who also arranged the sale of the Coombs house on Bayside Avenue, Oyster Bay.

End of the strike against the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and resumption of work tomorrow were voted overwhelmingly tonight by 3,000 members of the Goodyear local of the United Rubber Workers of America.

Meadow Brook formally opened its polo season today with a game on the field where the international matches take place, and Stewart Iglehart led a Long Island four to victory over Tommy Hitchcock's Greentree side, 9 to 7, in six fast and interesting periods.

A representative group of persons prominent in society attended the second program of races of the holiday week-end at Belmont Park yesterday, when the largest gathering of the season was recorded. As on Saturday, when 25,000 persons attended, the Turf and Field Club was the scene of many parties.

Making hits count when they were needed most, New York University captured the unofficial metropolitan college baseball championship yesterday by defeating Fordham. The Rams, favored over the Violet in the latter's final game of the season, outhit their University Heights foes, but had to accept a defeat by 8 to 4 at Ohio Field.

Cash gifts and bequests totaling $200,445 have been made recently to New York University, it was announced yesterday by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase. The money will be applied chiefly to research and, scholarships.

Barney Ross, Chicagoan who holds the world welterweight crown, and Henry Armstrong of Los Angeles, the world featherweight champion, will battle fifteen rounds, or less, tonight, weather permitting, in a ring struggle that will see an unprecedented page written in pugilistic history or a continuance of the old regime in the 147-pound division.

Henry Miller, counsel for the Federal Trade Commission, will discuss the commission's procedure under the increased powers conferred by the Wheeler-Lea bill at the conference on business conditions to be held at the Roosevelt Hotel today and tomorrow by manufacturers of beauty-parlor equipment, furniture and supplies.

Victor Dyrgall of the Millrose A. A., New York City, captured the annual National A. A. U. fifteen-kilometer run in 49 minutes 45 seconds today. He finished two seconds ahead of his team-mate, Eino Pentti. Johnny Kelley of Arlington, Mass., winner here a year ago, came in third in 49:50.

The $1,000,000 exhibit of the Brazilian Government at the New York World's Fair 1939 will include a pavilion of tropical design, also a tropical garden and an aviary filled with tropical birds. Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, announced yesterday that the project had been approved by the fair's Board of Design.
The estate on Hardscrabble Road, Pleasantville, N. Y., formerly owned by Mrs. Emilie W. Speyer, has been purchased by Frank Rubenstein, president of the F. Rubenstein Stores Corporation.
Daniel V. Gallery, Chicago attorney and an assistant corporation counsel under former Mayor Dever, died today at the age of 72.

Miss Helen Gay Rand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leroy-Henry Rand of Brooklyn, will be married to Dr. Sidney Edward Lenke, son of Mrs. Melchior Lenke, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Lenke, on June 8 in the Embassy Suite of the Ambassador.
The Belgian National Bank today reduced its bank rate from 4 to 3 per cent. Improvement of the monetary situation under the new government of Premier Paul Henry Speak was given as the reason.

Bernardino Molinari, Italian conductor, arrived yesterday on the French liner Normandie to direct radio concerts of the National Broadcasting Company's Symphony Orchestra. Mme. Molinari accompanied him.
