Interest in municipal elections has reached a new high in the world-wide attention focused on the balloting in Czechoslovakia. Everywhere citizens who don't waste a thought on the vote in the neighboring town watch anxiously to see what happens in towns they never heard of in a region until recently no more than a smudge of mountains on a map.

Mrs. Harry W. Berryman of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Margaret Berryman, to James Clifford Blanchard Jr., son of. Mr. and Mrs. James C. Blanchard, also of East Orange.

A Philadelphia team representing the General Electric and Ardmore Cricket Clubs conquered a picked eleven from the Cosmopolitan, New York and Interstate Leagues of New York at Innisfail Park yesterday. The margin was fifteen runs. C. H. Archer of the visitors made top score of -23, then captured 5 wickets for 14 runs.
The State Supreme Court today gave a judgment of $2,279.91 to a Negro tenant farmer. against his white landlord on the ground that the latter charged usurious interest on a cotton crop loan.

While F. T. Bedford's new twelvemeter sloop Nyala yesterday was winning her second out of three championship races in the Long Island Sound series, a professional sailor in the crew of Clinton H. Crane's Gleam was washed overboard.

Bestin-show honors at the Delaware County Kennel Club's ninth annual all-breed fixture today went to the white-and-orange-marked pointer champion Pennine Paramount of Prune's Own, owned by Mr. and Mrs. A. Biddle Duke of Tuxedo Park, N. Y. Pennine Paramount scored among 621 dogs.

Mrs. George Frederick Shrady of 328 West Eighty-seventh Street has announced the engagement of her grandniece, Miss Muriel Vivian Eckhoff, to James Fergus McRee Jr., son of Mr. McRee of Seattle and of the late Mrs. Walter R. Herrick of St. Louis and this city.

Officials revealed early today that 5 1/2-year-old James Bailey Cash Jr. had been kidnapped from his bed at Princeton, twenty-five miles south of Miami. Two ransom notes were left, one demanding $10,000 for the return of the boy.

Citing him as "a pioneer in the fight to prevent waste of our -resources of natural gas and petroleum," the University of Miami tonight conferred the honorary degree of Doctor of Science upon Henry L. Doherty of New York, president of Cities Service Company.

The 500-ton steamship Falco sailed for the Virginia Coast today to hunt for $4,000,000 worth of treasure believed to be lying in the hold of the steamer Merida, which sank off the Virginia Capes in 1911.

Brookville (72)-Flag tournament, Class A: David P. Seaman, 18th green; L. M. Bonnewell, short of 18th green. Class B: W. Anderson, 18th cup; H. A. Burns, short of 18th green. W. F. Johnson made a hole-in-one on the 130-yard eleventh with ? mashle niblick.

A Castillian. army corps under General Jose Varela today continued its rapid advance southeast of Teruel toward Sagunto on the coast, according to a communique issued by Nationalist [Insurgent] general. headquarters.

After a month and a half during which France has been ruled by decree powers granted Premier Edouard Daladier, Parliament will reconvene tomorrow in what the goverment hopes will be a three-week session.

Paul Edwards, administrative officer of the five Federal Arts Projects here, announced last night that eight men and a woman, employes of the WPA Federal circus, had been suspended in connection with the -investigation into the alleged diversion of VPA box-office funds.

Protesting against the threatened imposition of a floor tax of 25 cents a gallon on distilled spirits, Gene Tunney, chairman of the board of the American Distilling Company, has written a letter to each Senator and member of the House of Representatives.

Colonel Sir Maurice P. A. Hankey, who, as secretary both of the Cabinet and the Committee of Imperial Defense and clerk of the Privy Council, probably has wielded more power than any other civil servant in the history of the British Government, is retiring to accept the lucrative post of a director of the Suez Canal Company.

The right arm of big Bill Lee came through with its second successive shut-out and its third in his last four games before a crowd of 41,216 today to give the Cubs a 3-to-0 triumph and an even break in a double-header with the Reds. Cincinnati won the opener behind Paul Derringer, 7 to 3.

In the quietest trading of the year prices improved on the local Stock Exchange today. As the New York market was closed, local interest was confined principally to the cheaper gold shares, which registered irregularly higher prices.

MOST of us have at least heard of the Xavierian cooperative movement in Nova Scotia. Here at last is an expert's appraisal: Bertram B. Fowler's "The Lord Helps Those It might also be called an expert's paean of appraisal-but concerning the author's point of view, more later.

The National Maritime Union will abandon this week a referendum of its members on the adoption of a new wage agreement with the Atlantic passenger and freight lines and seek negotiations with the lines for a substitute agreement, it was learned yesterday.

Mrs. Emily Havemeyer Potter, wife of Edward Clarkson Potter, former member of the New York Stock Exchange, died here early today in the North Country Community Hospital, where she recently had undergone an operation. Her age was 72.

With a few exceptions, advertising volume for the month closing today will present a picture little changed from the April totals, most media registering sharp decreases, according to estimates in the field.

National needs in the field of health and medical care will be considered at a National Health Conference here from July 18 to 20 under the direction of the President's Interdepartmental Committee to Coordinate Health and Welfare Activities.
Four Brooklyn youths were rescued from Gravesend Bay yesterday afternoon by the crew of the Coney Island excursion steamer Hook Mountain, which was carrying 200 passengers.

Bob Feller and Johnny Allen each scored his sixth victory of the season today as the Indians took a doubleheader from the White Sox, 5 to 2 and 8 to 1. A crowd of 38,618 saw the games in the Municipal Stadium.

Two students from the metropolitan area were recipients of scholarships awarded at the thirty-ninth Clarkson commencement held here today. The Levinus Clarkson Scholarship of $100 went to Lambert Chapin of Maplewood, N. J., one of the ten seniors who was graduated with honors.

General Vincenzio Perez Soto, former head of Venezuela's oil-producing State of Zulia, arrived here recently with a visa for Venezuela, according to a report from Costa Rica, where he has resided since the death of President Vicente Gomez.

Miss Marian Kingsland and her fiance, Count Hans Christoph SeherrThoss, whose engagement was announced recently, were in the group of seventy-five members and guests who attended the sixty-fourth annual Memorial Day luncheon of the Lenox Club today.

Although Wesleyan outbatted Yale nearly three to one today, the Elis won, 6--5, in an unsteady battle which lasted nearly three hours. Frank Cotter allowed Yale only four safeties, but passed seven. Moe Jubitz fanned fourth en Wesleyan batsmen in spectacular fashion, but gave four walks, hit two batsmen and made a wild pitch, while being touched for eleven safe hits.

The largest crowd in baseball history, 83,533, saw the Yankees beat the Red Sox at the Stadium, 10--O and 5--4, and take second place. Jake Powell, New York outfielder, and Manager Joe Cronin of Boston were ejected from the first game because of a fist fight on the field which they resumed under the stands.

Inspired to lofty action by the largest crowd in the history of baseball, a gathering that fell just short of 84,000 for the sole reason that no more could possibly jam their way iii, the world champion Yankees blazed a gaudy trail back to their lordly estate by overthrowing the Red Sox in both ends of a double-header at the Stadium yesterday.
Australia's run of high scores which netted the touring cricketers 4,506 runs in eight matches ended today.

Rear Admiral William R. Shoemaker, retired, who directed the navy's battleship convoys for United States troopships in the World War, died at the Mare Island Navy Yard Hospital here today. His age was 75.

As rain fell at Epsom Downs, forecasting a probable wet racing strip, H. E. Morriss's Pasch weakened as the big favorite in the Derby Wednesday, his price going from 2 to 1 to 5 to 2 in the next to last call-over.

Mrs. Mary Ellen Dunn, mother of Philip Dunning, Broadway theatrical producer and author, and of Caesar Dunn, playwright and screen writer, died here today of a heart ailment at the home of her daughter, Mrs. William T. Lee, at the age of 80. Another son. Charles E.

The greatest crowd movement this year reached a peak last night as the three-day Memorial Day holiday came to a close with a rush of travel almost as large as on the Fourth of July or Labor Day, last year.
Mr. and Mrs. Stanton Mott of this city and Shore Meadows, Southold, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Raegener Mott, to Ernest Wilhelm Stawitz.

Mrs. Alice King Gade, whose Lake Forest, Ill., home was a favored place for social gatherings in the first two decades of this century, died yesterday at the American Hospital in Paris, it was announced here by her brother, Charles Garfield King.

Delivering a sharp attack on 15,000 unlicensed peddlers on the streets of the city, Markets Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr. said yesterday that he would seek legislation to deprive himself of the power of issuing licenses to these men, in an effort to drive them off the streets.

Two mysterious incidents hinting at sensational developments later took place late this afternoon here in Federal court after a parade of witnesses told of measures they said were employed by Harlan County coal operators and deputies to harass union miners. Both incidents appeared to have to do with weekend activities but objections from the defense kept the story off the record for the present.

John K. Starkweather of Starkweather Co. has been nominated for president of the Bond Club of New York as successor to Nevil Ford of the First Boston Corpora, tion. The election will be held at the annual meeting on June 29.

Details of performance capabilities and launching plans for the world's largest airliner, the 83,000pound Boeing Superclipper, which will be launched for its first sea runs on Puget Sound today and begin its test flights tomorrow, were disclosed here yesterday by Pan American Airways.

Plans of the Maritime Commission for the inauguration of its new passenger steamship service to the east coast of South America, on which the first trip is scheduled for about Sept. 1, were reported today.

One of the most important bills from the al standpoint of the public health that Congress has had to consider has remained deadlocked in a conference of the Senate and House for more than nine months, and unless an agreement is reached before Congress adjourns, it will have been defeated.
Fifty veterans of the Italian Army in the World War refused to march in the Memorial Day parade here today when they were not permitted to carry an Italian flag.

Seagoing members of the American Legion had a taste yesterday of the salt-water weather they experienced twenty years ago in the Navy and Marine Corps when a fresh southeast breeze an hour's sail out of Brooklyn set the U. S. S. Tattnall a-pitching and a-rolling as every destroyer will.

Maeline and Annibal were the stake winners at Belmont Park yesterday, surprising most of the 30,000 persons who composed the largest crowd of the year despite the cancellation of the $100,000 special race originally set for the holiday.

Riding high, wide and handsome into the Hub with a five-game winning streak, our Giants had virtually nothing left at the completion of today's holiday twin bill with the Bees. For this one-day invasion terminated disastrously for the National League pacesetters, who, for their time and efforts, wound up with the wellknown double-0.

Spectacular independent strength of the May wheat future on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange was the high light of world wheat dealings today. Maximum losses of more than 12 cents a bushel in the cash month future in little more than a week were turned into a net decline of only 5 1/4 cents at the close.

A moderate, steady Easterly made the third and last regatta of the holiday week-end series conducted by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club a treat today after yesterday's punishing conditions, and F. R. Coudert's thirty-two-footer Notus, Briggs Cunningham's sixmeter Fun and Miss Dorothy McGee's boat Kandahar used it to advantage.

When the State Constitutional Convention resumes its sessions tonight it will be facing the second and hardest part of its job. It has 652 proposed amendments on hand. Somehow or other it must sweat these down to a minimum on which the majority can agree and which can be submitted in intelligible form to the voters next Fall.

A sharp fall in gold-mining shares was the fea-' ture of a generally uncertain stock market here today. Western Holdings suffered a severe setback, but some Kaffirs were steady. Gilt-edge issues were firm while foreign bonds were steady, on the whole. Transatlantic stocks were quiet but they had a good tendency.

Today, the hundred and nineteenth anniversary of Walt Whitman's birth, Stokes announce that they have contracted with John Erskine for a new interpretation of the poet's life and work. The title of the study, "What Belongs to the Day," is taken from a poem in "Leaves of Grass." Stokes will publish it Sept. 15.

Mrs. Jeannette M. Cochran, wife of Representative John J. Cochran of Missouri, died of a heart attack early today in a beach-front hotel where she and Mrs. A. C. Dorey, a Washington friend, had been staying for two days. Her age was 52 years.
Two men were injured tonight when an airplane crashed at the Moorestown Airport. They were Murrell Morgan, 26 years old, of Gloucester Heights, N. J., the pilot, and Joseph Spada, 24,

Robert Holland, 4 years old, was suffocated and his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Brantley Holland, and four other persons were severely burned early this morning when fire destroyed their two-story frame dwelling in the Lincoln Place section of this village.

Suspicious that Henry Heckel, 46 years old, owner of a bakery and with private bath, $65 per restaurant at 96 Myrtle Avenue, month up. De luxe suites Brooklyn, was putting poison in his coffee, Joseph Gennaro, 56, of 103 East Third Street, shot him in the chest at 7:30 A. M. yesterday. Phone LExington 2-2300 Heckel was taken to Cumberland Hospital where he died ten hours later.

A strong ??a for retention of the Senate Wages and Hours Bill provision for a five-man administrative board, and the extreme latitude given this board to prevent dislocation of industry and further unemployment, was made tonight by Senator Thomas of Utah.

UNITED STATES MARITIME PERSONNEL REPRESENTATIVE, $2600 a year, United States Maritime Commission. Applications must be on file not later than June 30 if received from Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming and not later than June 27 from all other States. Competitors will be rated on the subjects listed below. which will have the relative weights indicated In subject 2,

The Marine Midland Trust Company of New York has been appointed fiscal agent and registrar under the National Gypsum Company indenture to secure $3,500,000 of 4% per cent sinking-fund debentures due on May 1, 1950.

The potentially inflationary character of the recent steps taken by the government to increase bank reserves may actually tend, for the time being, to prevent expansion of credit and the general business revival that they were intended to promote, says the Guaranty. Survey, published today by the Guaranty Trust Company.

Miss Anne Harrington, daughter of Mrs. A. Barnhart Harrington of the Homestead, Kew Gardens, was married to Professor Dillwyn Fritschel Ratcliff of the University of Cincinnati yesterday afternoon in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

Canadian newspapers, by an amendment to the Criminal Code introduced to- stabbed day in Parliament by the Minister of Justice, are to be made subject to the same restrictions as obtain in Great Britain with regard to the reporting of divorce and other judicial proceedings.

Five years after Whilmer Allison triumphed here, Elwood Cooke added his name to the list of winners of the Gillespie Cup today. In the final round of the invitation grass court tournament of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, the first held since 1933, the sturdy little player from Portland, Ore., defeated Arthur Hendrix of Lakeland, Fla., 6-4, 6-2, 6-2.

Starting this week, the Constitutional Convention will enter the second. phase of its work. With the deadline for introduction of proposed constitutional amendments by individual delegates reached last week, the convention, when it reconvenes tomorrow night, will be ready to start consideration of the 652 proposals now before the convention committees.
June week, the commencement period at the Naval Academy, was carried forward today with a variety of events.

Dr. Isaac N. Tekulsky, New York dentist, won today the Sea Girt allaround trophy at the closing day of the Association of New Jersey Rifle and Pistol Clubs third annual tournament here. Dr. Tekulsky posted a score of 192.

In an open meeting of fishermen, H. D. Sizemore speaking for the Sailors Union of the Pacific, declared that sailors would back, 100 per cent,' all component A. F. of L. unions in Alaska in all jurisdictional disputes, picket line or no picket line, with the C. I. O.

Despite a threat of the Ontario Government to take legal proceedings to halt the work, twenty men continued today to strip the natural rock for foundations for a new structure to replace the Falls View Bridge over the Niagara River.

Claiming ownership for their clients, agents of the Bank of Spain here have asked that a large consignment of "securities and silver" which was shipped last week on the Normandie to the Federal Reserve Bank in New York be held pending in?uirv.
Count Paolo Thaon di Revel, finance minister, told the Senate today that Italy's nickel coinage soon will be replaced by coins made from a special alloy composed exclusively of metals found in Italy.

With the rose and the lily And the daffadowndilly The lads and the lasses a-sheepshearing go. Americans dote on rural England. Did any of them happen to see a bit of it "in a glade in the depths of Hyde Park" the other day? There was a shearing competition among members of the National Federation of Young Farmers Clubs.
As the outstanding event of Memorial Day observance in Sing Sing prison today, a bronze tablet in memory of Mrs.Kathryn Lawes, wife of Warden Lewis E. Lawes, was dedicated at the recreation building.

An additional contribution of $15,000 from the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., to the Greater New York Fund was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, president of the fund. The company previously had contributed $35,000.
Frederick Bartholomae, an early operator of motion picture theatres in Chicago, died suddenly today in Crown Point, Ind., after marching in the Memorial Day parade there.

Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, is in the North Country Community Hospital here with an acute throat infection, it was learned tonight. Dr. Victor McCuaig, staff physician, said that Mr. Hopkins's condition was "excellent," although he was running a temperature of 101, and that he would surely be able to leave the hospital in a few days.
Prime Minister and Mrs. Neville Chamberlain attended a large dinner party given tonight at the Embassy by Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy and Mrs. Kennedy in honor of the Duke and Duchess of Kent.
Memorial Day exercises were held yesterday in Kings Park, Jamaica, following a parade of 1,500 former service men along Hillside Avenue.

Floyd Roberts, 38-year-old aviation engineer of Van Nuys, Calif., streaked around the 2 1/2-mile Indianapolis Motor Speedway today at recordbreaking speed to win the annual 500-mile race by five miles in the twenty-sixth running of the classic. Roberts, scoring his first major victory in 22 years of racing, most of them on dirt tracks, was never farther back than fourth after the first fifty miles.

A copy of what is said to be the only Arabian work of scientific importance carried back to Europe by the Crusaders has been placed on deposit in the Princeton University Library by Robert Garrett, '97, of Baltimore, a trustee of the university. The book has been added to an extensive Oriental collection already lent by Mr. Garrett.

" Hello," boomed the grinning man in the prisoners' dock. "Hello yourself, but I asked you your name," snapped the Recorder's Court clerk. Apologetically the stranger identified himself as James Hello, 42, and pleaded guilty to a loitering charge.

Commander Ernani Amaral Peixoto, Federal Interventor for the State of Rio de Janeiro, announced today that plans had already been accepted by the States of Rio Grande do Sul, Sao Paulo, Bahia, Pernambuco and Minas Geraes for the formation of a nation-wide nonmilitary organization to be known as the National Legion.

A class of thirty-seven girls will be graduated this year at Miss Beard's School here. Thirty-five will receive diplomas and two will get certificates at the commencement exercises June 6. The Rev. Dr. Boyd Edwards, headmaster of the Mercersburg Academy, will be the speaker.
Martin Buxdy of Miami won the Connecticut tennis championship for the second successive year today by turning back Bernard Coghlan of Pacific Palisades, Calif., 6-1, 6-4, 5-7, 6--2.

In the best-played and most spectacular game of Gaelic football ever unfolded on this side of the Atlantic, Cavan and Leix battled to a 7-7 tie at the Polo Grounds yesterday and thereby caused considerable confusion.

Work will start immediately on renovation of two Manhattan public bathhouses and tentative dates have been set for the beginning of renovation of two more in the same borough in June, according to an announcement yesterday by the Department of Parks.

Newspaper publishers were admonished to "preach the gospel of reasonable conservatism and fair dealing," in the annual report of Ted Dealey, publisher of the Dallas News-Journal and president of the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association in convention here today.

Betty Jane Hobbs, 4 years old, object of a police search for ten days, came home today and the Goundry Street neighborhood turned MemorialDayinto a jubilee. Friends and relatives jammed the birds, but Hobbs home all day and tiny formed th Betty Jane, dressed in white, was the center of interest.

Charles H. Roemer, president of the Industrial Commission of this city, was elected president of District 3 of the B'nai B'rith Lodge today at the closing session of the thirtysecond annual convention here.

In reply to the President's criticism of the new tax law, which was allowed to become a law without benefit of his signature, Senator Harrison reviewe the record of the Democratic party in Congress on this important measure. He pointed out that the final draft of the law was approved in the House of Representatives by more than 90 per cent of the Democratic members.

Colonel and Mrs. Francis L. V. Hoppin will return this week from Europe and will be at the SavoyPlaza before going to Newport. Mrs. William T. Hildrup Jr. has returned to the St. Regis after several weeks in Washington. Edwin C. Wilson, counselor of the United States Embassy in Paris, and Mrs. Wilson are expected to arrive here next week.

More than 12,000 war veterans, public officials and members of patriotic organizations marched today in Memorial Day parades in the four cities and the larger villages and towns of Westchester County. Encouraged by clear weather, crowds of record size lined the curbs and later attended services at soldiers' graves.

Seventy-three students will receive diplomas at the commencement exercises to be held by the Horace Mann School for Boys at 3 P. M. today. Dr. Levering Tyson, president of Muhlenberg College, has been invited as the speaker.

Paul Wenzel, who was president of the Liederkranz Club of New York for three terms, died here today at his home, 675 North Terrace Avenue, of a heart ailment. Born in Germany seventy-one years ago, he had lived in the United States since boyhood.

As hundreds in the Waltham Memorial Day parade turned eyes left toward his house in tribute and salutation, James F. Ward, 90, of 206 High Street, last member of the John A. Hawes Post, G. A. R., died today from a heart attack.

Miss Frances Taylor Hallam, daughter of Mrs. Robert Gaston Hallam, was married here this afternoon to Henry Charles Hurt of New York at the home of her mother by the Rev. John R. McLean, pastor of the East Dallas Presbyterian Church.

The banking firm of M. M. Warburg Co., Hamburg, Germany, a private partnership established in 1797, will henceforth be known as M. M. Warburg Co. Kommandit Gesellschaft, according to word received by correspondents of the bank here.

Immediate enactment of the Federal Wage and Hour Bill without amendment by the Senate was urged yesterday afternoon by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, in an address over the Columbia Broadcasting System.
The Chief of the Rumanian General Staff General Jonescu arrived this morning for a conference with the Polish General Staff. Such conferences are held periodically.

Dana B. Hellings, Grand Master of Masons in the State of New York, made public yesterday the annual list of appointments to ofAces and committees in the Grand Lodge. Mr. Hellings, Buffalo attorney, was elected at the 157th annual communication May 5, succeeding Jacob C. Klinck.

Pat Dengis of Baltimore today won the Lawrence-to-Salisbury Beach Marathon, outrunning Mel Porter of Newark, N. J., who was second, by approximately a mile. His time for the 26 miles 385 yards was 2 hours 30 minutes 27 3-5 seconds.

Mrs. Mary T. Dann, widow of Edward Grant Dann, former president of E. G. Dann Co., men's furnishings, died yesterday at her home, 355 Riverside Drive, of a cerebral hemorrhage, after an illness of four months. Born in Ireland sixty-three years ago, she had lived in this country since 1887. She was a daughter of Professor Michael Fahy, headmaster of a boys'

After they had flown almost wing to wing for the 150 miles, Earl H. Ortman of Los Angeles nosed out Colonel Roscoe Turner this afternoon to win the Golden Gate Exposition Trophy in the concluding event of the first annual Pacifio International Air Races and set a new speed record for closed course racing. He averaged 265.5 miles an hour.

President Lazaro Cardenas tonight declared the rebellion of General Saturnino Cedillo and his peasant followers had been stamped out by the swift concentration of Federal troops in the State of San Luis Potosi.

A world conference on new theories in modern physics opened here today under the auspices of the League of Nations International Institute of Intellectual Cooperation. Professor Ignaz Moscicki, Poland's President, himself a noted scientist, was represented at the opening by Education Minister Wojciech Swietoslawski, Professor of Physics in Warsaw.

The Eastern Cooperative Wholesale, Inc., in the past twelve months tripled its membership of cooperative town and city retail societies and in 1937 doubled its business in groceries and household articles, Leslie E. Woodstock, manager, reported yesterday to 320 group members from ten States at the annual meeting of the group.

The banking firm of M. M. Warburg Co., Hamburg, Germany, a private partnership established in 1797, will henceforth be known as M. M. Warburg Co. Kommandit Gesellschaft, according to word received by correspondents of the bank here.

Immediate enactment of the Federal Wage and Hour Bill without amendment by the Senate was urged yesterday afternoon by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, in an address over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

After they had flown almost wing to wing for the 150 miles, Earl H. Ortman of Los Angeles nosed out Colonel Roscoe Turner this afternoon to win the Golden Gate Exposition Trophy in the concluding event of the first annual Pacifio International Air Races and set a new speed record for closed course racing. He averaged 265.5 miles an hour.

President Lazaro Cardenas tonight declared the rebellion of General Saturnino Cedillo and his peasant followers had been stamped out by the swift concentration of Federal troops in the State of San Luis Potosi.

A world conference on new theories in modern physics opened here today under the auspices of the League of Nations International Institute of Intellectual Cooperation. Professor Ignaz Moscicki, Poland's President, himself a noted scientist, was represented at the opening by Education Minister Wojciech Swietoslawski, Professor of Physics in Warsaw.

The Eastern Cooperative Wholesale, Inc., in the past twelve months tripled its membership of cooperative town and city retail societies and in 1937 doubled its business in groceries and household articles, Leslie E. Woodstock, manager, reported yesterday to 320 group members from ten States at the annual meeting of the group.

Idlehour, the 110-room country mansion built by the late William K. Vanderbilt more than a third of a century ago, at Oakdale, in Suffolk County, L. I., will be opened on July 1 by the Royal Fraternity of Master Metaphysicians as a retreat for study and rest.

Charging that the Federal Railroad Unemployment Insurance Bill, sponsored by the standard railway unions, is "untimely," the Association of American Railroads opened an attack on the measure today at a hearing before the House Interstate Commerce Committee.

The elements weren't too kind to the anglers, fresh water or salt, over the holiday week-end, and many who went out to Long Island and other salt-water points took one look at the sea and decided to go another day.

Seventy-four students will receive diplomas and degrees tonight at the forty-eighth annual commencement exercises of the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy of Long Island University, to be held at the Brooklyn Academy of Music at 8:15 o'clock.

The directors of Hearst Consolidated Publications, Inc., voted yesterday to defer the payment of the quarterly dividend on the 7 per cent Class A shares of the company normally payable on June 15. Dividends on this stock are cumulative.

A committee of five utility executives headed by James F. Fogarty, president of the North American Company, representing fourteen utility systems which recently sent to the Securities and Exchange Commission a letter offering to seek common ground for cooperative action in the administration of the Public Utility Act of 1935, met with the commission today for more than two hours for an exchange of viewpoints.

To take effect 8 A. M., June 1: LIEUTENANTS-Assignment to desk duty continued: Rudolph Busch, from 6th Pct. to Ist Pct.; Harry C. Bilms, from 1st Div. to 6th Pct. PATROLMAN William Smith, 87th Precinct, assigned to clerical duty.

With Mr. Justice Black alone dissenting (a dissent which might perhaps have been foreseen), the Supreme Court yesterday rejected as "futile" the Government's argument for a rehearing in the Kansas City Stock Yards case.

" The Blue Water School," in the person of Captain William D. Brereton Jr., commanding the U. S. Brooklyn, delivered a metric broadside yesterday to those recondites of the campus who hold that the naval officer is lacking in culture.
Baron Theodor von Cramer-Klett, a Papal Chamberlain, benefactor of the Benedictine Order and long prominent in Bavarian Catholic affairs, died yesterday at the age of 63.

In an effort to stimulate home building through removal of the idea in consumers' minds that construction costs are excessive, the Producers Council, in conjunction with the American Builder magazine, is developing a campaign for use by local contractors, supply men and other building interests in newspapers.

The report of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., and subsidiaries for the twelve months to March 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income, after all expenses and charges but before foreign exchange adjustments, of $5,962,268, compared with $5,714,274 in the preceding twelve months.

In the Federal Trade Commission's -new building at the apex of Constitution and Pennsylvania Avenues at thy foot of Capitol Hill the words "Robing Room" have disappeared from the door of one of the anterooms to the main hearing room on the fourth floor.

Clipping three strokes off par for the east course at the Winged Foot Golf Club on his last round, young Richard Chapman, Greenwich amateur, today paced a field of seventy-four golfers in the sectional qualifying round of the national open championship.

The Chinese air force scored heavily against Japanese planes over Hankow and Lake Poyang yesterday. Twelve Japanese combat planes were brought down during an air battle over the city between twenty-six Japanese raiders and probably double that number of Chinese fighters.

56th St, n s, 200 ft e of 2d Ave 114x100.5 irreg; John e. Spallone to Supt. of Insurance, as liquidatorof Lawyer Mtg. Co; consid $1,000, foreclosure. Academy St, 578, 40x100; The 578 Academy St. Corp, William f. Githens, pres., to Five EightyAcademy St., Inc, 717 Flatbush Ave, B'klyn ($40), John Bottjer, pres., the latter giving a p m mtg for $20,000, due next Nov. 1, 41/2 per cent.

He's a great. little fighter, this Henry Armstrong from Los Angeles. He beat a great little fighter in true fighting style last night in the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City to become the first ring warrior in pugilism's long history ever to hold the world featherweight title and the world welterweight crown at the same time.

Albert B. Kurtz, 41 years old, a lawyer, of 1,981 Honeywell Avenue, the Bronx, who was an assistant district attorney in New York County for thirteen months, beginning in March, 1926. pleaded not guilty in General Sessions yesterday to an indictment alleging attempted larceny, offering a false paper for filing and producing a fake heir in a will case in the Surrogates' Court.
Mrs. Louisa Houston Allen Bland, widow of Meigs Bland and daughter of the late Judge John J. Allen of Botetourt County, Va., a captain in the Confederate Army, died here today at the age of 77.
Renewed weakness in commodity prices last week resulted in a downturn in the wholesale price index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association following advances in the two preceding weeks.
Lawrin and Dauber were among entries announced today for a special $50,000 added 3-year-old American championship race to be staged at a mile and a quarter over the new track here June 29.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation informed the Interstate Commerce Commission today that because its loans to the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad are secured adequately, it should be "accorded treatment consistant with its position."

Because of its potentially great economic effect, it is important that the new capital gains tax should be understood even by persons who are never likely to be called on to pay it. Senator Harrison is correct in pointing out that the President in his recent speech showed that he was misinformed concerning the nature of the new tax.

The State Education Department has decided that "bright beautiful" and other young disciples of the Negro cultist "Father Divine," who recently transferred to Ulster County public schools, may be compelled to leave their "heavenly" names outside..

Neville Miller, former Mayor of Louisville, Ky., is slated for the presidency of the National Association of Broadcasters to succeed Mark Ethridge, vice president and general manager of The Louisville Courier-Journal, according to the current number of Broadcasting.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 25:
Negotiations between British and German delenations over Anglo-German trade relations continued today, but the experts are still deadlocked on the question of Austria's debts to Britain.

Ending a parade of short-priced winners, Mrs. A. M. Creech's veteran mare, Crout Au Pot, raced to a neck viotory in the featured Ivanhoe Purse at Lincoln Fields today. Crout Au Pot paid $23.20 for $2 in a five-horse field.
A swift and terrible foray by a squadron of tri-motored Insurgent bombers took a heavy toll of dead and injured today in the crowded Catalan town of Granollers, sixteen miles north of Barcelona.

Flotations of new securities in May, although slightly larger than in April, were in the smallest volume for that month since 1933. Offerings last month aggregated $130,765,000, of which $114,540,000 represented forty-four bond issues and $16,225,000 five stock issues.
Captain George W. Yardley, master of the Dollar liner President Hoover, which ran aground near Formosa, Japan, last year, died at Marine Hospital yesterday. He was 58 years old.

A total of $20,332 in contributions by Barnard College alumnae to the Alumnae Fund was reported for the last year by Mrs. Bernard Heineman, chairman of the fund, at the annual meeting of the associate alumnae, held in connection with the commencement reunion at the college yesterday.

Gabriel Tyman, 39 years old, of 176 Grand Street Extension, Brooklyn, who pleaded guilty on May 16 in Special Sessions Court, Brooklyn, to violating the State Welfare Law by accepting about $1,197 in home relief funds while he was employed as a shoe salesman at a salary of $25 a week,

Exporters here shipping merchandise to Ecuador were striving yesterday to get additional information regarding her decision to control imports and foreign exchange. The decree, published on May 19, applies on all goods received or in transit after last Monday.

A couple of weeks ago, Ed Rivers, Georgia's ardently New Dealist Klansman Governor, visited the White House to discuss ways and means of destroying politically Georgia's conservative Democratic Senator, Walter F. George.
The international rubber regulation committees slashed today export quotas of producers for July, August and September to 45 per cent of the basic allowed shipment figures from 60 per cent.
Everybody agrees that a good literary style is one which is suited to the occasion. For instance,
Eighty-five students, comprising the largest class to be graduated from Seton Hall College here, will receive diplomas at the eighty-second annual commencement tomorrow in the college's quadrangle.

Imports of gold received at the Port of New York in May amounted to $3,752,000 in two shipmentsone of $2,869,000 from England and one of $883,000 from Belgium. These were the smallest gold imports since February. In April $27,673,300 of gold arrived here, and in May, 1937, $123,482,900.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, gave his annual dinner last night at his home, 60 Morningside Drive, for the prospective recipients of honorary degrees at the university's commencement exercises to be held today.

Dr. Herbert W. Mumford, dean of the College of Agriculture at the University of- Illinois for the last thirty-seven years and marketing expert, died in Burnham City Hospital here today. His age was 67 years.

A marriage of international interest took place yesterday afternoon in the Byzantine chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church Miss Mary Meredith Nichols, a descendant of William Tuckey Meredith, an officer on the Hartford with Admiral Farragut, became the bride of Jonkheer Florus Marcel van der Does, who is descended from Heere van Noordwijk, a general, Who, in 1574, commanded the troops of the burghers at the siege of Leyden.

Although still declining to contribute to the cost of the actual evacuation of foreign "volunteers" from Spain, Soviet Russia today offered to pay her share of the preliminary work of counting foreign combatants and getting everything in readiness for their withdrawal.

Louis A. Johnson, Assistant Secretary of War, and Mrs. Johnson have come from Washington to the Biltmore. Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. Frick of Sewickley, Pa.,are at the Madison. Captain John Henry Gibbons, U. S. N., retired, and Mrs. Gibbons have arrived at the Pierre from Washington.

SHANGHAI, May 31.--The seriousness of Shanghai's cholera menace was officially noted today when the Japanese consul general, Shinrokuro Hidaka, notified the consular body that beginning tomorrow the passage of uninoculated persons except foreigners into Hungjao, Pootung and Nantao would be forbidden.

Gerald R. Macintyre, a representative of British banks in New York for many years, died on Sunday at Roseau, Dominica, British West Indies, according to cable dispatches received by friends here yesterday.
The executive committee of the Federal Reseve Board's open market committee conferred today with Secretary Morgenthau on plans for the Treasury's June 15 financing. No announcement was made.

Six of the twelve persons who were temporarily suspended in connection with the investigation of diversion of box-office receipts from WPA theatres and circus projects have been permanently suspended pending further disposition of their cases, Paul Edwards, administrative officer of the five Federal art projects In this city, announced yesterday.
Figures issued by the Barcelona Government April 11 gave the total of Loyalist casualties in air raids as 10,709 persons killed and 15,320 injured.
When the Dodgers return from the Western trip started yesterday they will join the Cincinnati Reds in introducing night baseball to metropolitan fans.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Bernard M. Baruch's plea for minimum wages and maximum hours would be more convincing if it were supported by at least one actual example in which such rigid labor conditions permanently increased incomes or employment. Recent important evidence is all to the contrary.

The four buildings comprising the Hotel Devon, at 55 and 59 West Fifty-fourth Street and 68 to 74 West Fifty-fifth Street, have been sold by American Newspapers, Inc., a William Randolph Hearst corporation, through William A. White Sons to a client who will operate the hotel.
Woodruff Randolph of Chicago, secretary-treasurer of the International Typographical Union, said today that unofficial returns from 682 of the 850 locals in the May 25 election showed for president:

Charles A. Bay, United States Consul in Seville, who has been in Burgos, Spain, denied in a telegram to the State Department today that he had said that "when Americans enlist and fight under a foreign flag they cannot expect our government to worry about what happens to them thereafter," as reported in a dispatch from Burgos in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Sunday.

Each of the following Cavalry Reserve officers is ordered to active duty effective June 17, at Fort Myer, Va,, for training: lst Lt. Leo R. Marshall (303d Cavalry), 31 Sherman Ave., Yonkers, N. Y. 2d Lt. Robert H. Collins (302d Cavalry), 165 Halstead St., East Orange, N. J. 2d Lt. Carroll A. Evans (301st Cavalry), 101 Wabash Ave., Kenmore, N. Y.

ALBNY, May 31.--Turning aside from its ordinary business, the Constitutional Convention devoted its entire session tonight to exercises in commemoration of another constitutional convention at which a group of patriots, meeting at Poughkeepsie 150 years ago, ratified the Constitution of the United States on behalf of their commonwealth.

Plans were disclosed over the week-end by officials of States and political subdivisions for the sale later this month of more than $21,000,000 of tax-exempt bonds. Tenders will be considered on June to by officials of the State of KenLucky for $7,500,000 of bridge revenue bonds, to be dated June 1, 1938, and maturing July 1, 1948, redeemable July 1, 1939.
Allen E. Throop, general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission, issued today an opinion clarifying a previous opinion of the same office of Dec. 2, 1935, designated "release 41,"

Mayor La Guardia, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine and Fire. Commissioner John J. McElligott will speak at noon today in City Hall Plaza at the presentation of forty-three valor citations to heroic members of the Police and Fire Departments.

Special Notice Announcement is made to the Department of the action taken by the trustees of the Honor Emergency Fund, at a special meeting held on Friday, May 27, in unanimously passing a resolution increasing from $100, to $200, the death benefit given to the widows or nearest of kin of members of the Department killed in the performance of duty.

Except for a brisk advance in the obligations of International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange continued dull, with values again drifting to moderately lower levels.

Through her husband, Richard A. Knight, as attorney, Mrs. Dorothy Ledyard Knight of New York and St. James, L. I., filed papers in Surrogate's Court here today asking removal of the United States Trust Company as executor of the estate of her father, Lewis Cass Ledyard Jr., on charges that it had "fraudulently" paid out more than $300,000 of the $14,000,000 estate and "negligently" failed to collect more than $200,000 in loans due.

A knack for remembering how words look on a page and her mother's careful tutoring helped win the national spelling title today for 12-year-old Marian Richardson, a shy Indiana farm lass with long blond curls.

The thirteenth annual award of the Interstate-Intercollegiate Pistol Association championship prizes were received yesterday by the team of the New York Police Department. Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine accepted the prizes on behalf of his team.

A libel and complaint was filed yesterday by the Shepard Steamship Company, a Maine corporation, against the cargo vessel, Sea Thrush, her engines, etc., and thirty-one members of her crew. In the complaint the company states the vessel is being illegally held by the members of the crew and asks they be ousted and the vessel returned to the steamship companywhich owns it.

In the United States Court of Claims today the following proceedings were had: ANNOUNCEMENTS B-154-Emil Olson. Judgment for plaintiff, $141,422.22, with interest on $72,499.98 from May 31, 1938, until paid. Opinion by Judge Littleton.

Dr. Elbert C. Lathrop has been elected a vice president of the Celotex Corporation, it was announced yesterday by the company. He was with Celotex as director of research and development from 1925 to 1932, when he resigned to become technical director of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, paper manufacturer.

This country should adopt the British system of taxing improved real estate on its income or use value instead of on a basis of the original cost or reproduction cost of buildings, in the opinion of Dr. Joseph E. Goodbar, head of the Society for Stability in Money and Banking.

Roar and Great Union, both the property of women owners, yesterday won the featured races at Belmont Park, where the Panique Purse was divided into two divisions. Mrs. C. S. Bromley is the owner of Roar, who scored by a length at 1 to 2 in the first division, in which the time was 1:13 1-5.

Manhattan Alterations Broadway, 1,220; to 8-story and penthouse lofts, showrooms and stores; Shire Realty Corp, 307 5th Ave, owner; Levy Berger, architects; cost, $80,000. 82d St, 157 E; to 4-story dwelling; Sidney Howard, premises, owner; William Geoffrey Platt, architects; cost, $5,000.

A broad plan for development of the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Basin was submitted to the Canadian Government by. Secretary of State Cordell Hull today in the form of a draft treaty which would be used as the basis for the negotiation of a definitive treaty.

William Randolph Hearst came out about even with the Federal tax-collecting authorities today when the Board of Tax Appeals disclosed that he had agreed to pay a 1929 income tax deficiency of $243,354, and the government had agreed that he overpaid his 1930 income taxes by $242,759.
In an atmosphere of good humor and political calm the French Parliament met again today for a short Summer session, after which it will be adjourned until November.

Public opinion, as measured in a nation-wide survey, overwhelmingly endorses the 'principle that any wage-hour legislation passed by Congress should provide for a wage differential among the various geographical sections.
Miss Helen Pedersen of Stamford, seeded No. 1, advanced to the third round today in the women's singles of the New England tennis

Stocks closed firmer with moderate losses after drifting down near lows of current movement; turnover, 404,060 shares. United States Government bonds steady and slightly lower, rail group lower, other issues irregular; transactions, $4,068,100.

Are Iowa Democrats more puzzled, exasperated or amused by the issue involved or, rather, thrown in from the outside and to be disposed of next Monday? Representative Otha D. Wearin, adopted sore against his will by Mr. Harry Hopkins, has sought to represent himself as a tried and true New Dealer and the favorite of the Administration.
Evidence of expanding business for varied types of commercial and industrial firms was found in. reports yesterday showing that many such concerns are taking larger quarters.
Memorial Day dawned on quite a number of Americans who still can rattle a few coins in their pockets and evidently like to spend them.

Commodore Henry Wenderoth of the Morrisania Yacht Club in City Island and William Murray, a club employee, received medals of the United States Volunteer Life Savings Corps at City Hall yesterday from Councilman Charles E. Keegan for their rescue of two fishermen from Eastchester Bay last Armistice Day.

It was officially announced tonight that for mer Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg, who has left his Belvedere apartments, was still in Vienna under "honorable detention," thus disposing of rumors that he had been sent to Leipzig or elsewhere in Germany.

Steel operations for the current week are scheduled at 26.1 per cent of ingot capacity, compared with 29 per cent the previous week, a drop of 2.9 points, or 10 per cent, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The annual report of Remington Rand, Inc., released today by James H. Rand Jr., president, reveals an increase of 28 per cent in the net profit and 8 per cent in the sales volume for the fiscal year ended on March 31.

Formation of two security concerns, dissolution of one firm and changes in various others were announced yesterday. Stern, Wampler Co., Inc., has been formed to take over the business and investment supervisory service of Lawrence Stern Co., Inc.
Fred C. Morgan, et al., v. the United States of America and the Secretary of Agriculture. Petition for rehearing. (May 31, 1938.)
One of Times Square landmarks, made notable principally because it houses a cut-rate theatre ticket agency and the George M. Cohan Theatre, will be sold at auction tomorrow.

PRINCETON, Fla., May 31.--A packet of $10,000 in small bills was dropped in a country road today in an effort to ransom 5-year-old James Bailey Cash Jr. from kidnappers who seized him in his sleep Saturday night.

As a further step in placing its outstanding dollar bonds on a definite service basis, the Republic of Poland and several of its political subdivisions will offer today a settlement on the twenty-year '6 per cent dollar loan of 1920, of the Province of Silesia 7 per cent bonds of 1928 and the city of Warsaw 7 per cent loan of 1928.

Sister Mary Bernardetta, the former Miss Grace York, a member of the Order of the Sisters of St. Joseph of Brentwood, L. I., for thirty-nine years, died on Monday in St. John's Hospital, Long Island City.

Confronted tonight with the combined opposition of affiliates of the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization to the Senate bill outlawing sitdown and stay-in strikes, the Assembly arranged for a public hearing on the measure next Monday morning.

John Gildea, former St. Bonaventure back, has been secured from Cleveland by the New York Football Giants, it was announced yesterday by John V. Mara, president of the local eleven. Gildea comes to the . Giants in exchange for Art Lewis.
Preparations were completed last night for a $2,000,000 furniture and home furnishings sale by Hearn's today at its warehouse at Sixth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today Horace G. Marks, Edwin J. Lukas, Louis Zimmerman and Oscar Garcia-Rivera of New York were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had Justice Cardozo not participating:

Indoor audiences for the first time will be able to study the sun by means of a "solar periscope." Visitors to the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History in June will have this opportunity, it was announced yesterday by Professor William H. Barton Jr., executive curator. The first performance, will be this afternoon.
Three associated railroads elected chairmen here today while rumors grew of a possible $25,000,000 loan and reorganization plan for a fourth, the Erie Railroad.

CHAPIN, ALFRED C. (Oct. 2, 1936). Gross assets, $641,771; net, $608,916. To Charlotte S. Chapin, widow, personalty and life estate in residue; Grace Chapin Fish; daughter, personal effects and remainder in residue; three specific bequests. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $523,366. Gould Wilkie. attorneys. 1 Wall St.

CLYDE DAVIS must have had a good time writing what he calls "The Great American Novel - -,"* and the chances are at least even that you will have a good if somewhat confusing time reading it. Mr. Davis is the Buffalo newspaper man whose first novel, "The Anointed," was a Book of the Month Club selection last Summer.

Brig. Cen. Milton Fennimore Davis, president of the New York Military Academy, died today after an illness of several months. He was 73 years old. He had been associated with the academy since 1909 and before that had a long army career and was known as an explorer and mountain climber.
Miss Katrina Falck, daughter of Frederick McQ. Falck of Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to J. Nevin Schroeder Jr., son of J. Nevin Schroeder of Old Top Farm, Bird-in-Hand.

The Rev. Dr. R. B. Kuiper, Professor of. Practical Theology and chairman of the faculty of Westminster Theological Seminary, Philadelphia was elected Moderator of the fourth General Assembly of .the Presbyterian Church of America at its opening sessions here today.

The coldest May 31 in fifty-four years was recorded today at the Weather Bureau here. A minimum early morning reading of 41 degrees was accompanied by reports of frosts a few miles from the city and freezing temperatures in some sections of New England.

A declaration that Norway reserves the right to maintain complete neutrality in any War resulting from action by the League of Nations, of which she did not approve was voted unanimously by the Legislature today.

Pope Pius, observing his eighty-first birthday today, spent the greater part of the morning at his desk, granting the audiences that are a part of his usual routine. Only in the afternoon did he. concede himself a period of complete rest.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 27: Ely, Lt, Comdr. H. F., Washington, D. C. to continue treatment at Naval Hospital Washington, D. C., and when discharged from treatment, ordered home, relieve all active duty.

Hogs closed 10 to 15 cents lower today with demand fairly dependable at the downturn, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Lambs were higher due to decidedly small salable receipts.

Detective Thomas F. Lillis, 56 years old, formerly of the West Thirtieth Street station, pleaded not guilty to extortion yesterday in General Sessions and Judge Collins released him in $1,000 bail, to await trial.

The shipment of 186 tons of silver that arrived here on the Normandie on Monday, consigned by the Spanish Government to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, was transferred by armored car under a heavy police guard yesterday evening to the old United States Assay Office at Wall and Nassau Streets.

Whether they like it or not, all producers and managers will probably have to adhere next season to a code outlawing ticket speculation. As tentatively decided upon yesterday by the council of Actors Equity, there will be one code for members of the League of New York Theatres and one for non-members.

Mrs. Mary Ellen Cunningham, a leader in Catholic charitable, social and educational circles for more than twenty-five years and the wife of Daniel F. Cunningham, vice president of the Rockaway Savings Bank, died of pneumonia yesterday at her home in Far Rockaway. She was 66 ears old.

Stressing individuality "in an age when every American wears the same kind of clothes and reads the same comic strips," Dr. Levering Tyson, president of Muhlenberg College, yesterday advised seventythree boys graduating from Horace Mann High School for Boys to "be courageous and intelligent" in finding opportunities "in a period of world adjustment today."
John F. Tippett, former president of the International Products Corportion here, died on Monday at his farm at Middletown, Del., according to word received here yesterday.

Ange Pitou, the imported French juniper who impressed followers of hunts meets with his victory in the Greenwich Cup race at Rye, N. Y., last Saturday, will make his next start at the Spring meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association at Roslyn. L. I., June 11.

For the first time in this district, a Federal grand jury returned an indictment yesterday charging violation of the so-called Federal Anti-Racketeering Act, passed in 1934 to put teeth in the government's prosecution of conspiracies to restrain interstate trade, which until now have been undertaken under the relatively mild Sherman Act.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 31, unless specified: At New London: S-20, May 29; Semmes. Brunei, to Southern Philippines: Canopus, Pigeon, S-36, 37, 38, 39, 41. Allegheny, Philadelphia to Navy Yard, Washington. D. C.

Mrs. Christine Biddle Fish, member of a prominent Philadelphia family and the wife of Edwin A. Fish, partner in the brokerage firm of Smith, Barney Co., 14 Wall Street, died yesterday afternoon in- the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness.

E. W. Kimmelberg, first vice president of Albert Frank-Guenther Law, Inc., is rounding out this week a half century of newspaper and advertising agency service. In June, 1888, he started as a messenger with a small agency at 8 Broad Street, present site of the New York Stock Exchange. Mr.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month amounted to 14,007,564 shares, the smallest turnover for May in fourteen years, or since 1924, when sales totaled 13,441,600 shares. It was also the smallest turnover of any month since September, 1934.

The marriagee of Miss Muriel Arline Epp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Engelbert F.Epp of Brooklyn, to George Matthews Byers, also of Brooklyn, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. David Kenneth Byers, took place last night in Epiphany Lutheran Church.

President Roosevelt returned from Hyde Park and conferred with Congressional leaders on the legtive program and with Administration aides on rural relief. He signed the bill creating additional judgeships.

The stock market here was quiet and generally dull today and most sections lost ground. Gilt-edge issues made headway, however, while among the foreign bonds Brazilian issues and Austrian 7s were firm.

29th St (17-4832), n w cor. of Lowerre Pl, 97x25; Emma M. Reimers to Louise Fuchs, 833 E 223d St. 150th St, 733-35 E (10-2642); Julius J. Gans, referee, to Jane H. Bautz, 1,273 North Ave, New Rochelle. Morris Ave, 479 (9-2336); Antonio Mangieri to Central Savings Bank; mtg $10,000.

With their best outdoor performances for 1938 as a barometer, quite a few of the athletes entered in the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. championships at Randalls Island Stadium on Friday and Saturday are capable of creating new records in their specialties.

Unlike Austria, Czechoslovakia will not give up her independence without a costly struggle, even if it should mean a general European war, Jan Benes, retired cabinetmaker of Milwaukee and brother of Eduard Benes, Czechoslovakia's President, predicted yesterday.

Loss of lives of firemen and damage to fire equipment in accidents must stop even if the engines have to make full stops at street intersections, Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott said yesterday to eighty-six newly promoted officers of the Fire Department.

Back at his desk today after an extended week-end of relaxation at his Hyde Park home, President Roosevelt dedared a moratorium on news and ley. conferred with Congressional and administrative chieftains on the status of his legislative and work relief programs.
The line-up for tomorrow's 159th running of the Derby, with owners, jockeys and odds quoted in the final callover at the Victoria Club tonight, follows:

The death of Louis Zangwill, author and lecturer at Holland-on-Sea, Essex, was announced today. He was 68 years old. He was a brother of the late Israel Zangwill. In recent years he concentrated on lecturing, chiefly on Jewish matters.

The marriage of Miss Edna Ellender of New York, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Theodore E. Ellender of Brooklyn, to Howard Bayer, also of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Bayer of Deal, N. J., and Miami, Fla., took place last night at the home of the bridegroom's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Golding, 275 Central Park West.

A retrospective exhibition, being a review of the season's activities in miniature, opens today at the Municipal Art Galleries. It constitutes, moreover, a novel show by itself, owing to the method of selection employed.

The National Labor Relations Board won an important victory today when the Supreme Court, in a five to two decision, held the Third Circuit Court of Appeals without jurisdiction to halt the case against the Republic . Steel Corporation after a transcript of the board's proceedings had been filed with the Circuit Court at Philadelphia.

This beautiful city in the Danube Valley was the scene today of a great gathering of Hungarians in honor of Hungary's patron,-St. Stephen, whose relic, his embalmed right hand, was brought here from Budapest in a gold-finished railroad coach. Hungary this week is commemorating the- 900th anniversary of his death.

The Board of Superintendents has placed a drastic curb on the amount of outside teaching for pay members of the New York City educational staff may do, it was announced yesterday. In a new set of regulations, to take effect this Fall, the board voted to set limits to the extra-curricular teaching now practiced by many principals, supervisors and administrators.

Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association of New York, announced yesterday that 100 members of the association have addressed letters to him endorsing the stand taken by the association in welcoming the proposal of the American Federation of Labor for cooperation between management and labor.

A full-length movie, running nearly an hour and a half, went on the television airways last night. Listeners and lookers-in over a radius of more than forty miles from middle Manhattan followed the dramatic action of Alexander Korda's production, "The Return of the Scarlet Pimpernel."
Mrs. Helen Wills Moody and Miss Dorothy Bundy moved into the third round of the St. George's Hill tennis tournament today. Mrs.

Not being able to finish that play of his, Marc Connelly has pinned "The Two Bouquets" on the lapel of the impending Summer season. This is the accumulated Victorian operetta that Eleanor and Herbert Farjeon put together out of oddments of nineteenth century music, much to the delight of London audiences last season.

Banks are experiencing difficulty in maintaining the volume of their earning assets, notwithstanding the large volume of funds which they have available for use, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in its monthly review, published yesterday.
Back in 1925--June 1 was the exact date--the late Miller Huggins, then managing the Yankees, sent Lou Gehrig in to pinch hit for Pee Wee Wanninger. He hasn't stopped playing since.

A crew with hand scrapers, hose, soap and brushes will begin today a campaign to clean up Broadway that is expected to expand into a city-wide movement under the direction of Outdoor Cleanliness Association.

Charles H. Tuttle of New York City has been named chairman of the committee on penal law and criminal procedure of the State Bar Association, it was announced today by Joseph Bosch, president. The personnel of the committee includes:

With 180 cadets of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy aboard, the training ship Empire State was towed from her pier off Fort Schuyler yesterday and began the first lap of a 9,000-mile training cruise.

The second and concluding day's sale of the first portion of fine books from the famous Ham House library brought a crowd of bibliophiles and dealers to Sotheby's today and lifted the total for the two-day auction to [Pound]18,788.

Under the circumstances it is only fitting that the Yankees won yesterday's ball game with the fading Red Sox at the Stadium. For this was no ordinary contest. Rather, it was an occasion which called for a victory and the McCarthymen were happy indeed to take this one by a 12-5 count.

" The Miracle," which has been on the Warners schedule every year during the past several seasons has again been brought forth, this time with Bette Davis as a nun. The play was first produced in 1911 by Max Reinhardt and in 1924 Morris Gest brought it to the United States.
Exhaustive questionnaires regarding their financial condition have been sent to the specialists of the New York Stock Exchange by the Exchange's committee on floor procedure.

The five-foot length of copper wire that was fastened about the waist of 12-year-old Peter D. Levine when his body floated ashore from Long Island Sound Sunday night was probably of foreign origin, it developed yesterday as the search for the kidnapper and murderer of the boy was continued without concrete resuits.

Captain Francis Ouimet today interrupted his task of training the United States Walker Cup team and motored with several members of the American party to the St. Andrews Cemetery, where he placed a wreath on the grave of William Norman Boase, former chairman of the Royal and Ancient Club.

Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson denied a temporary injunction yesterday to holders of about 3,000 shares of Class B stock of United Shipyards who sought to restrain the sale today of substantially all assets of the corporation, exclusive of cash and accounts receivable, to Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation, Ltd.

Buildling and construction contracts in Queens County during April showed a substantial rise over the previous month, thus continuing an upward trend which has been prevalent since the first of the year, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation.

Plans have been completed by Miss Marcia Bacon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald F. Bacon of New York, for her marriage to Kurt Kellmuth Langsam, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emery Bernhardt Langsam, also of this city, which will take place the night of June 16 in St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church in East Sixtyninth Street.

The House began today consideration of a new food and drug bill to replace the 1906 act, but adjourned before reaching a test on the controversial question of whether Federal courts should be permitted to enjoin orders issued by the Food and Drug Administration under the measure.

Noting that differences of opinion on foreign political events were creating- "mutual suspicion" among religious groups here, the executive committee .of the National Conference of Jews and.Christians called yesterday upon Americans of all races and creeds to abjure attempts to arouse one group against. another and to reject all propaganda designed to injure any group.

Many times America has been immeasurably enriched because of tyranny and intolerance in other lands. Pilgrims, Huguenots, Germans leaving their native land. after the abortive revolution of 1848, fugitives from Czaristic oppression in Poland and Russia,

Cardinal Hayes will take part tomorrow in laying the cornerstone of Gerard Hall, a new library and dormitory building at Marymount College here. The building has been named in honor of Mother Gerard, president of the college.

The United States Army's part in smashing the international German spy organization- now under investigation was told to the Federal grand jury yesterday by four officers who handled various aspects of the case.
No one who has been in Hungary recently has failed to note that a large section of its population lives in the shadow of great apprehension.

GENEVA, MAY 31.--The Governing Body of the International Labor Office accepted today "with much regret" Director Harold B. Butler's resignation and recorded "its sincere gratitude to him and its high appreciation of the very great services he has rendered the International Labor Organization since its inception." It decided to elect his successor Saturday.
Irving D. Buttler, Tax Assessor and former Mayor and Councilman of this borough, died this morning in Peck Memorial Hospital, Brooklyn, after an illness of five weeks. He was 42 years old.

Barney Ross weighed 142 pounds and Henry Armstrong 133 1/2 for the fight in the Madison Square Garden Bowl last night. Arthur Donovan was the referee and Billy Cavanagh and George Lecron were the judges. The fight by rounds:

James Stewart, captain of the freighter Lossie bank of the Bank Line, and Usope .Bin Bakar, a Malay and the' ship's carpenter, were 'found not guilty yesterday by a jury in the Federal court, Brooklyn, after trial on an indictment. charging them with conspiracy to smuggle eleven Chinese into this country.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., head a nation-wide banking group which will offer today a new issue of $33,000,000 of Commonwealth Edison the Company first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, Series I, due on June 1, 1968. The bonds will be priced at 102 1/4 and accrued interest.

Due to the holiday, the number of visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday was considerably less than in the preceding week. The total was also below the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

The present period of chaos in the world represents a great opportunity for social scientists, Dr. Alvin Johnson, founder and chairman of the Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science, known as the University in Exile, declared last night at the third commencement of the faculty at the New School or Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

The War Department released the following orders today dated May 28: BRIGADIER GENERAL Major, D. K. Jr., ordered to command San Francisco Port of Embarkation, Ft. Mason, Calif., instead First Brigade, Ft. Wadsworth, N. Y.; previous orders amended.
The The drive of Congress for adjournment went into high gear today with the announcement by Democratic leaders of the two branches that no revival of the Reorganization Bill would be attempted.

Turpentine steady, 22c; sales 75 barrels; receipts 773 barrels shipments 99 barrels; stock 34,311 Resin firm; sales 343; receipts 2,622; shipments 1,355; stock 114,406. Quote: B, $3.25; D, $3.50; E. $3.55; F. $3.90; G, $4.10; H. I. $4.17 1/2; K. M. $4.20; N. $4.75; WG, $5.40; WW, X, $6.10.
Mrs. Lucinda Davis Goldsborough Ballard obtained an uncontested divorce here today from William Fitz-Randolph Ballard, New York architect. She charged cruelty.

Mayor La Guardia and other city officials attended the opening last night of this Summer's free open air dance concerts on the Mall in Central Park, given by the WPA Federal Music Project in cooperation with the Department of Parks.
The proposed commercial treaty between Cuba and Mexico was rejected by the Cabinet today. No reason was given for this action on the pact, which has been under discussion for some time.

The problem of the relationship of quantum mechanics to the theory of relativity and the point where the two overlap occupied today the second session of the International Conference on Modern Physics, held here under the auspices of the League of Nations International Institute for Intellectual Cooperation.

" The United States in World Affairs in 1937," a review and interpretation of America's contemporary role in international affairs, is being issued by Harpers June 8 and will be the fifth volume published in this series. It is written by Whitney H. Shepardson in collaboration with William O. Scroggs.

Walter Hagen failed to qualify for the national open yesterday and that just about tells the tale of heartbreaks and surprises that annually mark the sectional qualifying tests for America's biggest golf tournament.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had: PATENT 3923 and 3924-Walter L. Kauffman 2d v. Nicholas L. Etten and John A. Hoke. Nichols L. Etten v. Walter V. Kauffman 2d and John A. Hoke. Opinion by Judge Garrett. The Board of Appeals decision affirmed.

On the eve of commencement members of the senior class of Bryn Mawr College' prepared tonight to join the ranks of the alumnae by giving the steps of Taylor Hall, the college administration building, into the keeping of the juniors at the traditional "senior singing."

Fletcher W. Rockwell, president of the National Lead Company, was elected yesterday chairman of the Patino Mines and Enterprises Consolidated, Inc., at the annual meeting of the latter company, to succeed the late Edward J. Cornish. Dr. G. W. Thompson of National Lead was elected a director of Patino Mines in place of W. C. Beschorman, resigned.

The net operating income of Class I railroads in the first four months of the current year was $28,791,805, compared with $195,872,531 in the corresponding period of 1937, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
The Cunard White Star liner Franconia returned yesterday from her tenth annual cruise round the world which began on Jan. 6 from New York.

WASHINGTON, May 31.--Despite Democratic accusations that the National Emergency Council has "degenerated" into a New Deal campaign agency, the Senate today approved increase of the $250,000 House appropriation for the organization by $600,000.

Steel ingot production declined more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index eased to 39.1, its lowest point since the first of the year. It stood at 40.0 for the preceding week and at 122.0 for the week ended May 29, 1937.

In an unusual move, the Supreme Court agreed today to reconsider a patent suit ruling of May 2 from which Justice Black alone dissented. This was the case where, in a 5 to 1 division, the court, through Justice Butler, upheld the validity of certain patents held by the so-called "Radio Patent Pool" on vacuum tube amplifiers.

The Virginia Coal and Iron Company has called for redemption on July 1, at par, $10,000 of purchase money mortgage and deed of trust 5 per cent 50-year bonds, due July 1, 1959, of Keokee Consolidated Coke Company. The bonds, to be chosen by lot, will become payable on July 1 at City Bank Farmers Trust Company, successor trustee.

Governor Moore today vetoed a bill advocated by small grocers to prohibit the sale of merchandise below cost. The grocers sought to prevent chain stores from making sales,as "loss leaders" to attract trade.

To encourage understanding and peace between Japan and the United States, a 400-page almanac of articles, photographs and color plates dealing with subjects of common interest to both nations. has been published in English and circulated here under the title of "America and Japan in Amity and Trade" by the influential Osaka Mainichi.

In sharp language and with only one dissent, the Supreme Court justices refused today to grant a rehearing in the Kansas City stockyards case out of which has arisen a heated controversy over whether the courts may restrict the activities of governmental administrative agencies. Justice Black was the sole objector. Justices Cardozo and Reed did not participate in the case.
Dr. Mary G. Williams, retired Professor of Greek at Mount Holyoke College, died here last night at the age of 74. She retired as head of Mount Holyoke's Greek Department in 1929.
E. R. Bradley's Bar Fly and Donald Christmas's Accolade accounted for the co-features of today's program at Suffolk Downs before a crowd of 11,099.

" That was my last fight," said the badly beaten Barney Ross in his dressing room last night. "I've been around a long time, and I've been on top most of that time, and I guess I'll have to step down.

Alfred C. Chapin, former Mayor of Brooklyn and a former Democratic Representative in Congress, left a net estate of $608,916, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. He died on Oct. 2, 1936.

Tariff revisions were announced today by the Japanese-created Nanking and Peiping regimes, effective June 1. It was stated tariffs were lowered to the level existing after Jan. 1, 1931, subject to amendments made in Peiping in January.

ALLEN--Suddenly, at Westfield, Mass., May 30, 1938, William Henry, 3d, beloved son of William H., Jr., and Mabel C. Allen of 185 Elmwynd Drive, Ofange, N. J. Service at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Centre St., South Orange, on Thursday afternoon, June 2, at 4 o'clock. Interment Detroit, Mich.

Offended by Mayor La Guardia's methods in submitting a veto message on the City Council resolution rebuking two Municipal Court Justices involved in the name-changing case of Simon W. Gerson, Communist aide to Borough President Isaacs, fourteen members of the Council adjourned the special meeting called by the Mayor yesterday before his veto message could be read.

Miss Emily Miller Parkin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Rogers Parkin of Spruce Farm, Bound Brook, N. J., has completed plans for her marriage to Frank B. Martin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin of Plainfield, N. J., which will take place July 1 in the Presbyterian Church of Bound Brook.

The cottonseed oil futures business on the New York Produce Exchange for the fiscal year ended on May 31, maintained the high volume of trading witnessed the year before and continued to attract new interest, through realization of its hedging possibilities, John McD.

WITH his face well lathered, Joe (Killer) Cronin of the Fenway Millionaires, who Participated in a two-round bout with Jake (Panther) Powell of the Yankees on Decoration Day, was doing a cautious job of shaving yesterday. Call me War Admiral," said the Killer with a laugh. "I was scratched."

Apparently confronted with a fresh dilemma in the already acrimonious State and Church issue in the Philippines, President Manuel L. Quezon is quietly sitting on the compromise Assembly bill, recently approved, that would provide for religious instruction in the public schools.
