Governor Victor Fernandez Manero of the State of Tabasco reported today that four Catholics had been killed and one Catholic and one policeman had been wounded when police dispersed a street demonstration by Catholics in favor of reopening the churches in Villahermosa, the State capital.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Augustine L. Humes of 960 Fifth Avenue of the engagement of Miss Hildegarde Graham, daughter of Mrs. Humes, to Robert Dudley van Roijen of The Hague, Holland.

Annual meeting of the American Jersey Cattle Club, Waldorf-Astoria, 10 A. M. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Three Centuries of French Domestic Silver," Ethelwyn Bradish, 11 A. M.; "The American Wing," Alfred Busselle Jr., 3:30 P. M.

CHICAGO, May 31 (AP).--When Dizzy Dean carries his $185,000 salary arm back to the hurling mound for the Cubs he'll do so as a starting pitcher and not in a relief role, Manager Charley Grimm decided today.

Governor Philip F. La Follette of Wisconsin, who recently launched the Progressive party as a national party at a meeting in Madison, was in this city yesterday. He called on B. Charney Vladeck at the Presbyterian Hospital, where the majority leader of the City Council and member of the American Labor party is recovering from an eye operation.

Authoritative sources said today that Czechoslovak troops were being withdrawn gradually from the German border region. An undisclosed number of technical specialists, mobilized along with other troops when Nazi-Czechoslovak troubles flared May 21, already have been recalled.

Deaths, accidents and injuries in traffic in the city limits continued to decline last week and week-end as compared with the corresponding periods last year, an analysis by the Safety Bureau of the Police Department showed yesterday. For the week the comparative table was as follows:
The carnival of England, the historic Derby, will be run and won at EpSom Downs tomorrow by H. E. Morriss's Pasch--if the experts are right.

Public hearings will begin before Judge William Clark in Federal Court in Newark this morning on the omnibus injunction proceedings brought by the C. I. O. and the American Civil Liberties Union to restrain Mayor Frank Hague and other Jersey City officials from interfering with their constitutional rights of free speech, press and assembly.

Abraham Lincoln High's nine, which clinched the Brooklyn P. S. A. L. championship last Saturday, recorded its eighteenth straight triumph, eight of which have been scored in the league, by downing Boys High, 4 to 1, in a tournament game on Lincoln's diamond yesterday.
Farnam P. Caird, president of the Rensselaer County Republican Club since 1926, died in Bronxville yesterday after an emergency abdominal operation. He was 61 years old.

With favorable weather in most of the cotton belt over the Memorial Day holiday and distinct weakness in New Orleans and abroad, prices on the Cotton Exchange here broke yesterday to new low levels. A loss of nearly 1/4 cent a pound represented a decline of about $5 a bale in ten days.

The Atlas Corporation's report for the six months ended on April 30, released for publication this morning, shows the asset value of the common stock at about $9.44 a share, compared with $13.36 a share on Oct. 31, 1937, the date of the last issued statement.

Estate, more than $10,000. To Ada Frances McCowan, sister, 472 Weetamoe. St., Fall River, Mass., specific real property and life estate in 1,000 shares F. W. Woolworth common stock; Laura B. Smith, daughter, Lynchburg, Va., and Oscar F. Douglas 3d, son, 910 5th Ave., life estate in one-half residue each and contingent interests in rest of residue each. Irving Trust Co.. 1 Wall St.. executor.

O. and the American Civil Liberties Union to restrain Mayor Frank Hague and other Jersey City officials from interfering with their constitutional rights of free speech, press and assembly.

Abraham Lincoln High's nine, which clinched the Brooklyn P. S. A. L. championship last Saturday, recorded its eighteenth straight triumph, eight of which have been scored in the league, by downing Boys High, 4 to 1, in a tournament game on Lincoln's diamond yesterday.
Farnam P. Caird, president of the Rensselaer County Republican Club since 1926, died in Bronxville yesterday after an emergency abdominal operation. He was 61 years old.

Mrs. Charles P. Bispham, one of the organizers of the "women's rebellion" against pump-priming, was ordered by her physician, Dr. Charles F. Morrison, to take an enforced rest at Tuxedo Memorial Hospital this afternoon.

ALBANY, May 31.--Mayor Myle Mayor Myle J. Holley of Peekskill, at a conference today with Governor Lehman at which the latter expressed the belief that a Peekskill ordinance barring distribution of handbills was unconstitutional, refused to recede from his position that he would uphold the ordinance until it could be passed upon by the courts.

BOSTON, May 31.--The market for automatic hot water and steam heating equipment in old houses is potentially as large, if not larger, than the new construction market, H. Merwin Porter of Minneapolis, president of the Heating, Piping and Air-Conditioning Contractors National Association, told 300 contractors from every section of the country at the association's annual convention here today.
ASSIGNMENT DOWN EAST, by Henry Buxton; (Stephen Daye, $3.) Stories about Maine people, recorded by a newspaper reporter.

Both Phipps Fields were occupied by Meadow Brook players tonight, with a round robin on the old field and a match game on the new. The players, preparing for the various club championships, galloped through the practice sessions at a brisk pace.

A readjustment plan for dollar bonds of the Province of Mendoza, Argentina, released yesterday for publication today, provides that holders of the $4,327,000 of external 7 1/2 per cent bonds of the province dated Dec. 1, 1926, and due on June 1, 1951, will be entitled to receive an equal amount of readjustment bonds dated Dec. 1, 1937, and maturing on Dec. 1, 1954.
Edward A. Conger of Poughkeepsie is slated for appointment by the President as United States judge in the Southern District of New York, it was reported yesterday.

Adopting a new constitution which has a preamble declaring for the first time that the party "defends the United States Constitution," delegates to the tenth annual convention of the Communist party in the United States brought their biannual meeting to a cheering, whistling and singing close last night.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Winthrop Neilson of this city and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of Miss Emily Harold Alsop, daughter of Mrs. Neilson, to John Frederick Jordan, son of Mrs. John Jordan Jr. of Erie, Pa., and the late Mr. Jordan.

Wheat futures fluctuated in erratic manner today within a range of about 2 cents a bushel. A sharp recovery in Liverpool following a bad decline on Monday, when markets in the United States were closed, combined with continued wet weather over the Winter wheat belt, resulted in relative firmness for a short period after the opening on the Board of Trade here.

The newly organized Ballet Russe de, Monte Carlo will give its local season at the Metropolitan Opera House Oct. 12-30 with a repertory of thirty-five ballets, it was announced by S. Hurok, manager of the company, just before he sailed today on the Normandie. Mr.

With pencils gripped firmly in their fists and fortified by dictionary and thesaurus, Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran, the Cato of City Hall, and Borough President James J. Lyons, the Cicero of the borough of -universities, resumed their battle over one word, contact.

The main bout of eight rounds, scheduled to have been fought between Orville Drouillard, Canadian lightweight, and Irish Eddie Brink of Scranton, Pa., at the New York Coliseum last night, did not take place when Brink failed to enter the ring. A crowd of 1,800 was present.
A joint concert by the Madrigal Singers and the Negro Melody Singers will be given tonight at the Federal Music Theatre.
Wrecking crews will begin this morning to raze the first of the 161 buildings which must make Way for the $16,500,000 low-rent housing development in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Rockhill are to give a dinner here tomorrow night at Crane Hill in honor of their guests, Mr. and Mrs. John J. Lincoln of Elkhorn, W. Va., whose son, Pemberton Hutchinson Lincoln, will marry Miss Eleanor Davis Friday in St. James Episcopal Church.

Effective today, Arthur Dinsdale joins Morner Productions, Inc., as vice president in charge of production. His activities will include radio programs, sound slide films and industrial motion pictures.

Few observers eleven months ago would have dared forecast the situation revealed by Mr. Hallett Abend in his series of eyewitness deports from China, the second of which is published in THE TIMES today.
Columbia University will confer 4,826 degrees in course and 147 certificates and diplomas today at its 184th annual commencement ceremonies. The exercises will start at 6 P. M. in South Court.

Six weeks ago the Roosevelt Administration waved a magic wand and excess bank reserves rose spectacularly toward the highest mark on record. The move was part of the President's new pump-priming program.

A delegation of prominent shipbuilders, naval architects and marine engineers will sail today on the United States liner Washington to attend an international conference of ship designers and builders in London from June 16-18 and an engineering congress in 'Glasgow from June 21-24.
Most Presidents have thought in the phrase used by one of them when he said he "had Congress on his hands." Most Presidents have been glad to note the advent of every adjournment day.

Slaughter of most classes fully normal for Monday. Trading in traefer meats somewhat uneven; some cuts met with good demand, others sold slow. Steer hinds and ribs ruled strong to 50c higher; steer cuts steady to $1 higher; veal hindsaddles steady; Spring lamb carcasses steady. to 50c higher, old crop steady to slightly higher; Spring lamb cuts steady to $1 higher; pork cuts mostly steady.

before maturity were in the smallest volume for any month since June, 1934, and the smallest May figure in four years. Last month's prepayments aggregated $25,083,Bonds called for payment in May 000, as compared with $40,212,000 in April, and with $134,925,000 in May, 1937.

The establishment of a non-profit foundation for the care of children's feet was voted yesterday at the final session of the forty-second annual convention of the Podiatry. Society of the State of New York at the Hotel Concourse Plaza.
The touring Australian cricket team drew With Middlesex today for its fourth deadlock in nine games this year on English soil. The other five matches ended in innings victories for the Aussies.

The peacetime listing of every British man and woman for possible service if war is declared has been considered by the government, but has been rejected on the ground that the administrative difficulties entailed would outweigh the advantages, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain told a group of his Conservative colleagues from the House of Commons today.

The government yesterday filed a libel against the steamship PanAmerica and the Munson Line, owners of the vessel, in a foreclosure of a preferred mortgage on the ship of $759,500 given by the Munson Line in 1925, when it purchased the steamship from the government.

A puzzled jury in Federal court here today heard one witness, called by the government to tell how coal operators and peace officers conspired against unionization of miners, testify that he had been overwhelmed with kindness after he joined the United Mine Workers of America.

Offering counsel and good wishes to 346 seniors of Columbia College at their Class Day exercises' yesterday afternoon, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, repeated his forty-year-old definition of a liberal education and reaffirmed his belief that such training as he advocated, together with moral constancy, was a vital ingredient of personal success and the progress of civilization.

The condition of Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, who is in the North Country Community Hospital suffering a throat infection, was said tonight by Dr. C. Victor McQuaig, specialist who is attending him, to be "quite satisfactory." Dr.

New strikes were reported today in many parts of the island, with intimidation of workers at several places. Strikers paraded at Montego Bay, Anotto Bay and Port Maria, virtually suspending business in those places. There was some looting at Port Maria.

Mrs. Carl Weiler gave a luncheon yesterday in the St. Regis Roof for Miss Elisabeth M. Fawcett; whose marriage to William E. Robertson will take place on Saturday in St. Bartholomew's Church. Other guests were Mrs. Alfred L. Fawcett, mother of the bride-elect; Mrs. Dean C.

The engagement of Miss Prunella Stack, leader of the Women's League of Health and Beauty, to Lord David DouglasHamilton, oarsman, boxer, mountaineer and airman, was announced today. The marriage is expected to take place this year.

Thirty-three seniors at Notre Dame College on Grymes Hill, Tompkinsville, S. I., received Bachelor of Arts degrees yesterday afternoon at the fourth annual commencement held on the lawn of the institution.
Assurance that there has been no serious hitch in the Anglo-American trade negotiations was given in the House of Commons today.

The house at-335 Pleasant Ave. 18 1/2 feet wide, was sold by Ettore Nocentini and his Wife to Benedict Salimbene and his wife for a consideration shown as $3,000 over three mortgages aggregating $5,081, the buyers giving back a p. m. mortgage for $2,700, due in five years at 2 per cent.
Burgess Meredith, the actor, issued a protest yesterday when he learned that his name had been used on pledge cards in a fundraising campaign of the Federal Arts Committee, 112 Park Avenue.

The 2,000,000 members of the Presybyterian Church in the United States of America, through action by the denomination's 150th General Assembly, were lined up today in support IN of "the persecuted of all the world."
Four well-known cafes in the Kurfuerstendamm patronized chiefly by Jews were raided last night by squads of policemen who said they were looking for "criminal elements."

The Securities and Exchange Commission has granted an application by the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, a subsidiary of the New England Public Service Company, for exemption from the requirement of filing a declaration in connection with issuance and sale of $750,000 of first mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds, Series C, due Aug. 1, 1960, and 4,000 shares of common stock, no par value.
Branch Rickey of the Cardinals watched Paul Dean work out late today and then announced he would make no decision on the ailing pitcher's future before tomorrow or Friday.
The Senators downed the White Sox by 5-4 today, scoring the winning run on Buddy Lewis's sharp single with two out and Myer on second in the ninth inning.
CASTLE IN THE MOONLIGHT, by Anne Stewart. (Gramercy, $2.) A romantic novel. HOOT OWL CANYON, by Archie Joscelyn. (Phoenix, $2.) A Western novel. THE MOST POWERFUL MAN IN THE WORLD, by Glyn Roberts.

Four college students from the United States and Canada have been chosen by the National Recreationt Association from 115 candidates to be apprentice fellows in municipal recreation, it was announced yesterday by the board of directors after the annual meeting held at the Gramercy Park Hotel.

Southern California's power-laden track and field squad, the favorite to capture the team crown in the sixty-second annual intercollegiate A. A. A. A. championships at Randalls Island Stadium tomorrow and Saturday, yesterday reached New York on its first transcontinental track pilgrimage since 1935.

The City Council at its meeting on Tuesday will act upon an amendment to the city's Administrative Code prohibiting the distribution of handbills, cards and circulars prepared as commercial advertising matter.
Three firemen were injured, seven persons were rescued and damage estimated at about $125,000 was caused by fire which swept a threestory building in the business section early today.

An organization formed to work for reduction of tolls at the Holland Tunnel and other tunnels and bridges under control of the Port of New York Authority filed notice of application for a certificate of incorporation at the Hudson County Clerk's office here today.

Prince and Princess Louis Ferdinand of Prussia, who have returned to the Biltmore, were the guests of honor yesterday at a tea given by Albert Morris Bagby in his apartment at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Shepard Dillingham gave a luncheon at the Plaza.

The formation of a committee to look after the interests of the Pennroad Corporation, a railroad holding company, was announced yesterday. The voting trust under which a management selected by the Pennsylvania Railroad directs the holding agency will expire next May.

A sheet of brown paper, sandwich wrappings and a stained stick were studied tonight for a lead in the kidnapping of 5-year-old Jimmy Cash as Federal officers questioned an unemployed carpenter about the case.

Rose Lolita Long, only daughter of the late Senator Huey Long and Mrs. Long, became this evening the bride of Dr. Osmyn William McFarland, a young surgeon whose courtship began five years ago, when they were Summerschool students at the University of Wisconsin.

If confusion and burdensome expense are to be avoided, audits of stock brokers' accounts required by the various regulatory authorities must be coordinated as to time and scope, according to recommendations made to the Securities and Exchange Commission by J. S.
James G. Stahlman, president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, assured Southern publishers today that the first Southern newsprint plant would be erected at Lufkin, Texas.

The average employee gift to the Greater New York Fund in its campaign for $10,000,000 to supplement the finances of private welfare and health agencies is $3.36, James G. Blaine, chairman of the campaign committee, announced yesterday.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Mrs. Fay McMillen Macpherson, widow of Edwin Allan Macpherson of Buffalo, N. Y., to Charles A. Tattersall of New York, formerly of Niagara Falls and Buffalo, which took place here on Saturday at the home of Dr. and Mrs. W. E. Crow. The ceremony was performed by Bishop Harry T. Moore of Dallas.
Anglo-German trade negotiations going on here for the past week have been postponed for Whitsun. They will be resumed next week, the British having proposed their transfer to London.

For the fourth successive year, Brooklyn Automotive Trades annexed the team honors in the vocational high school track and field championships, held under the auspices of the P. S. A. L. at Wingate Field, Brooklyn, yesterday.

One-family, homes in the better residential sections of the city will be protected against cheaper structures by the new zone known as a "G District," which was established yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
Felix Serafin of Scranton today shot a 38, 37-75 to finish first in a play-off to determine four qualifiers for the national professional golf tourney here in July.

Arguments were heard in court here today in the case of the late Mrs. Eugenia Sutherland Gifford, a wealthy American, who, -in a letter- addressed- to the United States Consul, asked that her property -be placed in charge of an Italian dancer, Constantino Gabazzi.

The 'Merritt Parkway, from New Canaan Avenue, Norwood, to the New York line, will be opened for the July 4 traffic, William J. Cox, State Highway Commissioner, told the Parkway Commission meeting here today. .

Finance Minister H. H. Kung issued a nation-wide appeal for stricter economy today in a speech to a conference of bankers assembled here. He urged the Chinese people to eschew luxuries, smoke fewer cigarettes, wear simple clothing and use less kerosene and electricity.

Thirty-one members of the crew of the Shepard Line-freighter Sea Thrush, in dungarees and other attire that denotes a seaman, sat in Federal court inBrooklyn yesterday and heard counsel-for the line plead' for immediate hearing of charges that the men illegally controlled the ship.

Extra dividend disbursements in addition to the regular quarterly payments were announced yesterday by two companies. At a meeting of the board of Mead, Johnson Co. the directors authorized an extra dividend of 75 cents a share and the regular quarterly dividend of. 75 cents to holders
James Bruen, the 18-year-old Irishman who is a newcomer to Walker Cup golf, has played himself into the very center of the picture of these preliminaries.

Arguments for a brief, clear and general grant of home-rule power to the city will be made before the Cities Committee of the State Constitutional Convention in Albany this afternoon by Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, and Reuben A. Lazarus, his assistant.

Generalissimo Francisco Franco is unsympathetic to the establishment of any foreign political ideology, particularly nazism, in Spain, Cardinal Goma y Tomas, head of the Spanish hierarchy, told this correspondent in an interview here.

A proposal to change the closing hour for trading on the Chicago Board of Trade from 1:1 P. M. to 2-P. M; daily except Saturday has been ordered submitted to a vote of members by directors of the Exchange.

While no date has been set for the initial conference, it is the hope of the Securities and Exchange Commission that it will be possible to begin round-table conferences here before the end of next week with representatives of the New York Stock

Dr. Julius H. Parmelee, director of the bureau of railway economics of the Association of American Railroads, told the House Interstate Commerce Committee today that the Federal unexmployment compensation bill sponsored by the standard

Television will reach the public this evening when four stores in the metropolitan area will put demonstation receivers on view. The instruments, made by Communicating Systems, Inc., will be shown in Bloomingdale's in Manhattan, Abraham Straus in Brooklyn and Piser Co. in the Bronx and will receive "telecasts" from the transmitter atop the Empire State Buildini.

Magistrate Frank Oliver yesterday released a man brought into Bronx Magistrates Court charged with playing policy with the statement that "the court ought to quash proceedings where it is shown that the prisoner is a mere bettor."

WASHINGTON, June 1(AP).--President Roosevelt signed amendmebnts to the new Crop Control Law today, increasing this year's national tobacco marketing quotas 2 per cent and providing for redistributioh of unused-cotton acreage allotments.

An action to cancel advances in excess of $11,000,000 made by the Delaware Hudson Company to its subsidiary, the Hudson Coal Company, in the last eleven years was instituted yesterday in Supreme Court by William B. Scofield as the owner of five $1,000

Late in April the Japanese authorities in Manchukuo uncovered a widespread plot for an insurrection by Manchukuo's Chinese army and took drastic action just in time to avoid serious fighting and bloodshed.
The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania awarded yesterday to' C. J. Devine Co. an issue of $60,000,000 of 1 1/2 per cent tax-anticipa'tion notes, Series DT, on a bid of 100.928008.

Hermann G. Place, In 955 Park Ave; Dr. Edward B. Wix. Barbara Bowlin, Charles Fox, Natalie Young, in Town House, 108 E 38th St; N. A. Berwin Co, Inc. brokers. Mrs. William H. Taylor, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc, in 149 E 73d St: Mrs. C. F. Nazare-Aga, through Brett Wyckoff, Inc. in 10 E 85th St:

Joseph F. (Uncle Joe) Cox removed his straw hat, mopped his brow and pointed to a laughing, happy throng of 5,000 orphans frolicking about yesterday in Coney Island's Luna Park. "Did you ever see such a cheerful sight?" he asked.

Uncertainty whether government spending will promote business is the reason business is hesitant, Joseph A. Bower, executive vice president of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, said yesterday before the Life Managers Association of Greater New York.
For the third successive season Schubert operetta productions will be presented by Fortune Gallo in open-air performances at Jones Beach Stadium, Long Island, and Randall's Island- Municipal Stadium.

Dr. Abraham Lefkowitz, legislative representative of the Teachers Guild and long the center of school controversies in -the local educational system, was nominated yesterday by the Board of Superintendents for the position of high school principal.

A dinner commemorating the fiftieth anniversary of the ordination to the priesthood of Mgr. John L. Belford, pastor of the Church of the Nativity, Madison Street and Classon Avenue, Brooklyn, was given last night at the Columbus Club, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn. About 1,200 persons were present.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Helms, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Helms of Camp Hill, to Gordon E. Bolter, son of Mrs. Carl Eggers of New York and the late Edward Bolter, took place here tonight in Trinity Lutheran Church.
Three Californians, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, Miss Alice Marble and Miss Dorothy Bundy, won straight-set victories in the third round of the St. George's Hill tennis tournament today.
Eight New York girls and ten Northern New Jersey girls are members of the senior class at Sweet Briar College and will be candidates for degrees at the commencement exercises on June 14. They are:
President Roosevelt asked Congress today to appropriate an additional $6,000,000 for the War Department to buy anti-aircraft materiel. The type was not specified.
Wayne Godard, star tackle on the Southeast Missouri State Teachers College team for four years, looked forward today to a professional football career in the "big time."

Pleading for industrial peace to allow business to start production again, Charles R. Hook, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, today termed government interference with private enterprise as a blight on progress.
Spanish Rebel representatives here exchanged notes today with the Foreign Office providing for the reciprocal appointment of representatives to be known as General Agents.

In accordance with its notice of March 12, the New York Stock Exchange struck from the list yesterday twenty-five issues of nineteen foreign issuers who had failed to register under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 1 (AP).--Democratic State Chairman David L. Lawrence said today Senator Joseph F. Guffey was reunited with the Pennsylvania Democratic organization, from which he split in the recent primary campaign. The union, he said, would be formally cemented at a State committee meeting tentatively set for June 14.

The American Jewish Committee, 461 Fourth Avenue, issued a statement yesterday announcing that it "disavows and disassociates itself from the proposed election and socalled referendum recently announced by one of the many organizations consisting of Americans who are Jews."

The New York Railroad Club will hold its annual outing at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, N. Y., on next Thursday, Charles A. Gill, president, announced yesterday. As general chairman, Frank J. Foley has charge of the outing. Samuel F. Pryor Jr. is vice chairman.

The bond market underwent a complete reversal of form in somewhat more active trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. After a long period of steadily declining prices , the fixed-interest obligations took a cue from the improvement in stocks and staged the broadest recovery in several weeks.

Twenty cleaners were busy early yesterday with brushes, mops scrapers, soap, water and chemicals on the sidewalk on the east side of Broadway between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets to mark the start of what the Outdoor Cleanliness Association hopes will be a permanent cooperative program to improve the appearance of the sidewalks and streets of the city.
Robert Miller, 29 years old, of 595 East Fourth Street, Brooklyn, plunged to his death at 12:05 P. M. yesterday from a washroom on the twelfth floor of a building at 130 West Thirtieth Street.

Japan is rationing herself with terrible sternness to pay for the war with China. Presumably the poorest of the world's "have-nots," the nation has been blowing an estimated $5,000,000 daily through her guns and rifles since the "incident" began on July 7, 1937.

Means of coordinating and improving the mechanism of peace in the Western Hemisphere will be considered, by the International Conference of American States at Lima on Dec. 8 under the program approved today by the governing board of the Pan American Union.

The Chinese Foreign Office announced today that the Chinese diplomatic representatives in America and Europe had been instructed to draw the attention of foreign governments and the League of Nations to the civilian casualties resulting from the Japanese bombing at Canton.

The German-American Settlement League, operator of the Nazi recreational field Camp Siegfried, at Yaphank, L. I., and six officials of the league were indicted today by the Suffolk County grand jury on charges of violating the State Civil Rights Law by failing, as an oathbound organization, to register the names of members with the Secretary of State.

A bereft father's testimony that his membership in the United Mine Workers of America cost him not only his job in a Harlan County mine but possibly the life of his infant son as well brought a defense motion for a mistrial today

In a General Sessions trial which started thirty-four days before, Emanuel Seideman, 42 years old, and Harry Rower, 40, facetiously known in the financial district as the "Bucketeer twins," were convicted yesterday on fourteen felony counts of grand larceny and bucketing the orders of customers of a defunct brokerage concern.
Dr. Clarence Little, former president of the University of Michigan, will be the guest speaker at the commencement exercises at the Birch Wathen School, 149 West Ninety-third Street, this afternoon.

The 10,000,000th car to. use the Henry Hudson Bridge across the Harlem River crossed the span at 4:05 P. M. yesterday, with Thomas E. Stapleton of 2,287 University Avenue, the Bronx, behind the wheel.

Only one upset was recorded in the men's singles of the New England tennis championships today when sixth-seeded Barney Welch of Maryland went down, 6-4, 6-4, before the masterful stroking of Howard Stephens of Yale.

Sixty-four nurses will be graduated this afternoon at the commencement exercises of the Presbyterian Hospital School of Nursing, to be held at 4 P. M. in the garden of the school, 622 West 168th Street. The Rev. Dr. Arthur L. Kinsolving, rector of Trinity Church, Boston, will be the speaker.

We may yet see Secretary Wallace being sued for violation of copyright by the American Automobile Association. An earlier Roosevelt was President when this famous organization of motorists in 1902 took for its legal trademark the AAA in recent years diverted to such different purposes.

Demands that distillers halt rect sales to department stores, hotels, clubs and chain restaurants, that discount rates be standardized and special deals discontinued have been submitted to distillers here by the New York Wholesale Liquor Dealers Association and are now being discussed with company executives, it was learned yesterday.

The Bank of Mexico is taking steps to change the wording on its currency so as to eliminate the present obligation .to redeem the notes "in cash" and to make them payable simply ;'to bearer," without specifying in what medium payment is due, it was learned yesterday.

With one accused German spy on the high seas in successful flight, as are several others, from the government's espionage inquiry, J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and United States Attorney Lamar Hardy clashed yesterday over responsibility for their escape.
Tom Baker, youthful Jersey City speed-ball pitcher, held the Baltimore Orioles to one hit today and hurled the Jersey Giants to a 7-to-1 victory.

After having driven her automobile through a military protection zone en route to Carlsbad, Miss Unity Freeman-Mitford, 23-year-old British friend of Chancellor Hitler of Germany, was subjected to a thorough five-hour examination by Czechoslovak authorities early today.
Prince Tokugawa, traveling to London to attend the Red Cross international congress, left his private car at Regina this morning suffering from fatigue.

Saverio Turiello, 147, Italy, showing his best during the early stages, earned the decision over Harold Brown, 147 1/2, Chicago, in the featured ten-round contest at the Queensboro Arena last night before 1,000 fans.

John D. Clark, who for many years held various executive positions in the motion picture industry and who for the last six years was general manager of distribution of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, died early yesterday morning in the Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, N. J.
Mike Valentine, 48-year-old boxing manager and promoter, collapsed yesterday afternoon while walking along West Forty-fourth Street with Johnny Rinaldi, his young lightweight protege.
The city prison in Brooklyn should be displaced by a new structure, Commissioners John L. Schoenfeld and Edward R. Cass of the State Commission of Correction recommend in a report submitted today.

The American Civil Liberties Union has been frequently accused of defending only the liberties of labor and the radicals. It is particularly reassuring, therefore, to find it protesting now against the punitive use of income tax returns by the committee headed by Senator Minton for the ostensible

Formation of a new trade association to be known as the American Manufacturers of Beauty Products was approved yesterday at the closing session of the. conference of producers of these items held at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The International. Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday that net additions of 20,850 telephones were made in the first four months of 1938 by its telephone operating companies in nine countries, or 16 per cent more than the gain for the corresponding period last year.
The House adopted today without a record vote a bill to displace the thirtytwo-year-old Pure Foods and Drugs Act, opening the way for possible enactment of this legislation before adjournment.

The Mills School for Kindergarten Primary Teachers will hold its twenty-ninth annual commencement this morning at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street. Dr. Paul Dawson Eddy, president of Adelphi College, will be the speaker. Fifty-two students will receive diplomas.

Licensing of all men and women who serve food in public places, in an effort to curb stomach disorders spread by intestinal parasites, was urged yesterday at the opening session of the third annual convention of the National Society for the Advancement of Gastroenterology. About'100 physicians from all parts of the country are attending the conference, which will close today at Squibb Hall, 745 Fifth Avenue.

A Chicago Mercantile Exchange membership has been posted for transfer to Lucius P. Ordway Jr. of Redmond Co., New York City. Stanley Keith of Chicago has been elected a director of Blair, Bonner Co. and will make his headquarters in their office.

Seven evening newspapers published by Westchester Newspapers, Inc., of which J. Noel Macy is president, announced today an increase in price to 5 cents a copy, effective next Monday. The present rate is 3 cents. Home delivery charges will be advanced slightly.

When-issued rights of Philip Morris Co., Ltd.,Inc., have been admitted to New York Stock Exchange dealings, with prices listed in variations of 1-16 point. Voting trust certificates for Grand Union Company common stock, $1 par value, will be admitted to the list today, when dealings in the shares themselves will be suspended.

Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins, sailing for Europe yesterday on the United States liner Washington, declared that the current business recession had brought about serious problems in relief and unemployment, but that the country's relief program and the unemployment insurance plan had greatly alleviatedd the situation.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday his formula for keeping "crooks and punks" away from the World's Fair next year when he spoke before several thousand persons at the annual presentation of valor medals to members of the Police and Fire Departments.

A group of officials, including two of Grover A. Whalen's assistants, made an aerial survey yesterday of the site of the New York World's Fair of 1939 to study existing traffic arteries, those in course of construction and other details.

Among the accusations made by Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, deposed TVA chairman, against a fellow-director, David E. Lilienthal, one was that the latter had deleted certain paragraphs from the minutes of an Authority meeting on Nov. 2, 1933, after they had been signed by the two other directors.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday the election of Otis A. Thompson, president of the National Bank and Trust Company of Norwich, Norwich, N. Y., as a Class A director to fill the unexpired term, ending on Dec. 31 next, of the late Edward K. Mills.

Cardinal Hayes presided here today at the annual commencement exercises of Marymount College and conferred bachelors' degrees upon twenty-eight young women. Before the graduation ceremonies the Cardinal officiated at the laying of the cornerstone of Gerard Hall, the third unit in a building program which was started in 1933.

As a result of a 3-to-2 decision today by the State Supreme Court, Ely Culbertson, bridge expert, must stand defendant again in a suit for foreclosure of a $75,000 mortgage on his property in Ridgefield.

The 150th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America ended its sessions today with condemnation of the "needless destruction" of lives and property of noncombatants in China and with informal endorsement, through thunderous applause, of a plea to shop shipments of scrap iron from this country to Japan.
Voters of Bronxville, in Westchester County, are overwhelmingly opposed to. President Roosevelt's pump-priming program, it has been shown by a poll now almost completed. John H. Galloway,
Washington strongly protested to Tokyo yesterday against the Japanese refusal to permit American missionaries and business men to repossess their properties in the Shanghai and lower Yangtze areas.

David V. Wall, veteran stage and screen actor, who was Mary Pickford's leading man in the film version of "In the Bishop's Carriage," died early yesterday morning at his residence, 509 Amsterdam Avenue, after a long illness, at the age of 68.

Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons has always shown a surplus, but a record is indicated by the figures for the past eleven months. The customs excise showed pound44,580,794 (Australian), which was pound4,499,401 (Australian) more than that of the corresponding 1936-7 period and pound3,613,014 (Australian) greater than the year's estimate. The Postoffice revenue was pound15,253,761 (Australian), an increase of pound929,109 (Australian).
BOSTON, June 1 (AP).--Righthander Charley Wagner kept ten enemy hits scattered today to gain his first major league victory, a 6-3 decision for the Red Sox over the Browns.

Admiral Shen Hung-lieh, chairman of Shantung Province and former Mayor of Tsingtao, who dynamited Japanese factories valued at $100,000,000 before evacuating the city in January, has sworn never to leave Shantung. He has organized a guerrilla army to harass the Japanese.
The House "liberal bloc," composed of thirty-two Representatives, decided today against a proposal to "invade" Jersey City for a speech-making campaign in opposition to Mayor Frank Hague.

Members of an association of Remington Rand Company employes, organized after the reopening of plants following a 1936 strike, themselves struck briefly today in four cities in protest against a Supreme Court decision.

The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered today all Class 1 common carriers of property by motor vehicle operating in parts of New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware, as defined in its rate investigation case known as Mc-20, to file on or before June 13 income statements for 1937 and the three months ended March 31, 1938.
Harry L. Hopkins advocated today "important adjustments" in the distribution of future increases in the national income to stimulate consumer buying power.

Images of the spots on the sun, brought down to earth by means of mirrors and a reflecting telescope, were cast on a screen for the first time yesterday when the Hayden Planetarium publicly put into use its newly constructed coelostat.
The Right Rev. David Lincoln Ferris resigned as Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Rochester at a diocesan meeting here today.
Louis Lipsky, vice president of the American Jewish Congress, replied last night in an address
Although he did not testify, Mayor Frank Hague was the "star witness" at the opening session here today of the Jersey City "freespeech" trial before Federal Judge William Clark.

Locations for business occupancy along and near Madison and Fifth Avenues were involved in a number of. the commercial rentals announced yesterday. In the building formerly occupied by Fortnum Mason, British specialty firm, at 697 Madison Avenue,

Harold Wonson and Bill Maxson pitched Dartmouth to a double victory over Columbia today, clinching second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate- Baseball League and also keeping the Indians in the running for the championship. The scores were 4-1 and 6-5.
The address of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, delivered at the 184th commencement of Columbia University, follows: Ideas and principles, as well as kings, can abdicate.

To the victor went the spoilswith a vengeance. Henry Armstrong, first gladiator in ring history to hold the world featherweight and welterweight championships at the same time, was around and about yesterday, receiving the adulation of his friends and admirers, as plans went ahead for his attack.on the third title which the California Negro has set as his goal.

While sales figures were not available, "very satisfactory" results were reported yesterday by Hearn officials at the furniture and home wares sale being conducted by the store at its warehouse at Sixth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.

LONDON, June 1.--Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, who is known to feel that a restoration of Anglo-Italian friendship is being hampered by continuance of the Spanish civil war, is considering a new attempt at mediation to end the conflict, it was disclosed tonight.
The "bright" salmon are now running up the St. John River in New Brunswick, according to reports from the Province received yesterday. The first non-resident to take

The Rockefeller Foundation has made a grant of $18,000 to aid American University in developing its plan of bringing government employes of Latin-American. Republics to Washington to study public administration and the activities of the Federal Government.
Marxist members of the population run pretty close to their capitalistic neighbors in taste on the lighter side of life, an informal poll of the Communist party leaders indicate.

Robert Moses, Park Commissioner of New York City and chairman of the Committee on Highways and Parkways of the Constitutional Convention, told The Knickerbocker News by letter today that in his opinion he had not "missed a thing by being absent from Albany during the period of raffling off seats, distributing the loaves and fishes, and introducing bills most of which the authors know will not receive serious consideration." He went on:
The Rev. Hugh P. Cullum, rector of the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church here for the last thirty-four years, died today at the rectory after an illness of several years. His age was 76.

Sir James Irvine, principal of St. Andrews University in Scotland, sailed yesterday for Glasgow on the Anchor liner Cameronia, after spending two weeks at the Benjamin Franklin Institute in Philadelphia.

Close to 500,000 persons converged upon the historic Epsom Downs course today to see the Derby won by Bois Roussel, bred in France but owned by Peter Randolph Louis Beatty, son of the British admiral of Jutland fame and grandson of Marshall Field of Chicago.

Officials of the Treasury Department confirmed today a report that under a series of four arrangements for purchases of silver made with China since 1936, the Treasury will have taken more than 250,000,000 ounces of silver from China between the beginning of the agreements and July 15.

THERE was more than a faint tinge of football in the Garden Bowl program the other evening. Barney Ross and Hammering Hennery Armstrong went to work like a guard and tackle disputing the right of way on the gridiron. It was not only toe-to-toe but head-to-head and shoulder-to-shoulder through much of the evening.

A vacant plot, 114 by 110 feet, at the southeast corner of 177th Street and Beach Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by the Sun Realty Corporation through J. Clarence Davies, Inc. It is in the vicinity of the Catholic Protectory site which has been acquired by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for a housing project.
Heavyweight Champion Joe Louis worked six strenuous rounds today in preparation for the defense of his title against Max Schmeling June 22.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith attended the official opening yesterday afternoon of the International ORT exhibit in a room on the sixth floor of the Empire State Building.

Spark plug trouble today postponed until late tomorrow afternoon the first test flight of the Atlantic Clipper. The flying boat, biggest commercial plane ever constructed in the United States, was moored to a barge in Elliott Bay while engineers and mechanics of the Boeing Aircraft Company labored to have it ready to begin taxiing tests in the morning.

Whatever democracy is, we know what it isn't. We know we can't find it in the dogma laid down by Herr Goebbels and quoted by President Butler in his address at Columbia University last evening: "There is no freedom of the individual--there is only freedom of peoples, nations or races, for these are the only material and historical realities through which the life of the individual exists."
Five steamships sailed yesterday for Europe between noon and midnight with 3,800 passengers, which is considerably lower than the number in the corresponding midweek sailing a year ago.

Dr. Amos O. Squire, Westchester County Medical Examiner, announced yesterday after consultation with Dr. Alexander 0. Gettler, New York City toxicologist, that he was convinced that 12-year-old Peter D. Levine was decapitated before his body was thrown into Long Island Sound, from which it was recovered Sunday.
Behind the five-hit pitching of Johnny Vander Meer the Reds sent the Dodgers down to a 4-1 defeat today in the opener of a three-game series.
Two Germans were wounded in a saloon brawl in Eger near the German border last night after a Czech sergeant, Wenzel Toman, had demanded a Czech folk song from the orchestra.

The wheat market showed a considerable resistance to bearish influences today, opening about unchanged in the face of weakness in Liverpool only to decline about 1 1/4 cents a bushel on selling induced by Mrs. E. H. Miller's report to Shields Co. suggesting a possible aggregate wheat crop of 1,046,000,000 bushels,

George Ripperger, for fourteen years postmaster of Long Island City and for a longer period chairman of the Queens County, Republican Committee, died in his home, 33-40 157th Street, Flushing, yesterday. He was 77 years old.

Further details were announced tonight for the reorganization of the "Ostmark," as the National Socialists prefer to call Austria. Apparently Austria will serve as an example for remodeling the Reich.

The Chicago Stock Exchange announced tonight the expulsion of H. S. Mills from membership and the suspension for one year of the membership privileges of William S. Mills Jr. Both men are members of the firm of H. J. Mills Co. of this pity.

Claudette Colbert's next film for Paramount will be "Midnight," by Edwin Justus Mayer and Franz Schulz. Shooting will start Aug. 1 with Arthur Hornblow as producer and Mitchell Leisen directing; the screen play is being prepared by Charles Brackett and Billy Wilder. The picture will replace "Are Husbands Necessary" on Miss Colbert's schedule.

The Securities and Exchange Commission heard evidence today on applications -by the York Railways Company and the Edison Light and Power Company for orders declaring them not to be subsidiaries of the NY PA NJ Utilities Company, the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation or the Associated Gas and Electric Company.

A daughter, their second, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Moore of 588 West 215th Street on Tuesday at the Lying-In Hospital. Mrs. Moore is the former Miss Maidee Berkeley Finke, daughter of Mrs. Detmar H. Finke of 2 Beekman Place and the late Mr. Finke of Bremen, Germany.
The Long Island Women's Golf Association sought diversity from its usual type of one-day tournament by staging a point par event over the Piping Rock Country Club course today.

Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., head a nation-wide banking syndicate in the offering to be made today of $100,000,000 of United States Steel Corporation ten-year 3 1/4 per cent debentures due on June 1, 1948 The debentures will be priced at 100 and interest. Including the long list of- underwriters,

Commercial and industrial failures were higher than a year ago in each of five groups in the week ended May 26, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Gains in comparison with the previous week were shown in all groups except the wholesale division. The detailed comparisons follow:

A noticeable decline in consumer demand for strapless evening gowns, rendering it doubtful that this fashion will carry over into the Fall season, was one of the major style trends revealed in an analysis of May buying activity released yesterday by Lord Taylor, New. York department store.

Plots in the Chelsea section of Manhattan have been assembled as the result of transactions announced yesterday by brokers. Another building operation will be undertaken- in the vicinity of Seventh Avenue and Twentieth Street where a site has been acauired by Harold I. Litwin.
At a board meeting of the Associated Actors and Artistes of America yesterday afternoon, the appeal of the Grand Opera Chorus Alliance was denied for re-trial and re-hearing.

Plans for a National Display Week, in which retailers will be urged to "clean up" and modernize their window displays, were launched last night at a banquet-of the International Display' Executives Association, held in conjunction with an exhibit of display matrials and fixtures, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Nine Bronx.properties were sold at auction yesterday, two of them being bid in by the City of New York in tax lien sales. Among the other parcels were an entire blockfront on Burke Avenue, between Wickham and Brunner Avenues,
A new American proposal for developing the St. Lawrence waterway met opposition today from many of the Senators who blocked the $500,000,000 project four years ago.

Former Mayor George J. Zimmermann, convicted last week of having received while in office unlawful fees from an insurance broker, received a sentence today of two to five years in Attica State prison.
ANDERSON--On Tuesday, May 31, 1938, Margaret E. Anderson of 553 48th St., Brooklyn. Services at the Fairchild Chapel, 86 Lefferts Place, Brooklyn, on Thursday at 2 P. M.

More than 1,000 Japanese troops have crossed the Yellow River to reinforce Lieut. Gen. Kenji Doihara's Fourteenth Division, which has been besieged by encircling Chinese forces for a week north of Lenfeng on the Lung-Hai Railway west of Suchow, according to Chinese official reports.
The Eastern Steamship Lines, Inc, at a hearing today asked the Maritime Commission to grant it an operating differential subsidy for vessels to be operated between New York and Boston and Bermuda.

First step toward the organization of a separate division at Graham-Paige Motors Corporation to handle the Graham-Bradley tractor has been taken. Robert C. Graham, executive vice president, announced yesterday the appointment of E. J. Harrington as sales manager of the tractor division.

The problem of the individuality of elementary particles and its relationship to quantum statistics in Pauli postulate was dealt with in a paper submitted by Professor Brillouin of the College de France to the International Conference on New Theories in Modern Physics at its third session here today.

Congress completed its work today on one of the smaller "recovery" items when the House approved a conference report on a highway authorization bill providing for the expenditure of, $507,500,000 in the two fiscal years beginning July 1. The Senate had previously adopted the report.

Engineers of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation of Buffalo, N. Y., will come to France to assist and advise in making American-model military planes, it was announced to the Aviation Commission of the Chamber of Deputies today by Air Minister Guy is Chambre.

Federal Judge Thomas W. Slick ruled today that fifty automobile industry executives named in antitrust law indictments returned last Friday must appear personally in court here for arraignment. Several are expected to appear within the next ten days to post bonds of $2,500 each.

What with one thing and another, including the waning season and the approach of warm weather, the Mercury Theatre will close "Heartbreak House" on June 11 instead of 18. The play will then have had forty-nine performances, and -the Mercury will have been in existence exactly seven months since the Armistice night premiere of its "Julius Caesar."

Mayor La Guardia used the June relief appropriation voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate to prod the City Council to expedite the Council's approval of new emergency tax bills for the year July 1, 1938, to June 30, 1939.

The engagement of $571,000 gold in the Netherlands for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York by local commercial banks. This will be the first transfer of gold from the Netherlands to this country since last August, when a shipment of about the same amount was made.

Daily average sales of general merchandise in small towns and rural areas showed an increase of more than the usual seasonal amount from March to April, the Department of Commerce reported today The department's adjusted index figure for these sales was 112.3 in April, compared with 105.8 in March.

John Ringling, circus owner who died several years ago, left an estate valued-at $23,462,732, appraisers reported today. His circus stock was valued at $650,102 and stock in the Circus City Zoological Garden, Inc., at $616,595.
Hyman Marcus, 45 years old, of 1,270 Gerard Avenue, The Bronx, paid what amounted to a $50 fare to get into the Grand Central subway station yesterday afternoon.

Parker Corning's Unfailing, who won the Lawrence Realization last Fall, flashed one of his best performances at Belmont Park yesterday to capture the fortieth running of the Harlem Claiming Stakes and run one of the fastest miles of the meeting.

Hank Borowy and the Fordham nine achieved two season-long objectives as the Rams came from behind to eke out a 4-3 ten-inning victory over Long Island University at Fordham Field yesterday. The sensational sophomore pitcher tied the Fordham record made by Kenneth Auer in 1932

Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, "disowned" certain employes of the Board of Elections yesterday after the commission had placed them in the unclassified branch of civil service.

Operations of the Diamond Match Company and its subsidiaries in the three months ended on March 31 resulted in a net profit of $502,528 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges, according to a statement issued yesterday. After dividend requirements on the 6 per cent preferred stock, the profit was equivalent to 39 cents each on 700,000 shares of no-par common stock.

The National Labor Relations.Board today filed with the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals in Covington, Ky., two motions asking for permission to withdraw the Ford Motor Company case or that the case be remanded to the board for further proceedings.

On the ground that flexibility is essential, the President yesterday requested that "no restrictions" be placed on his power to spend the enormous funds that will be made available by the new pump-priming bill. This is essential, he said, if the Goverment is to achieve its purpose of "putting the greatest number of unemployed to work in the shortest time."
Unusually favorable health conditions here, which have characterized the year 1938 to date, continued during the week ended May 28, Health Commissioner Rice reported yesterday.

The American Communist party has just concluded its national convention in New York with the adoption of a new party constitution affirming devotion to democracy and American principles of freedom. This is in line with the slogan that "Communism is twentieth century Americanism" and the frequent invoking of the names of Jefferson, Paine, Jackson and Lincoln.

The Emigrant Bank took from Harry Harils a mortgage for $12O000, due in fiveyears at 41h per cent, on 215-17 W 27th St. Rose Barsohn bought- the house at 325 Fi 93d St from the Central Savings Bank for $18;000;,-giving back a purchase money mortgage for $16,000, due in five years at 4-per cent, and- then conveying the parcel to Elizabeth Johnson of 209 E 87th St.
President Roosevelt sent a letter to Senator Adams asking that the Relief-Recovery Bill be made as flexible as possible to put the greatest number of unemployed to work in the shortest time.
With Charley Keller pacing a thirteen-hit attack with a homer, two singles and a double, the Newark Bears handed-the Syracuse Chiefs a 7-to-3 setback today.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Is it possible that a committee of the United States Senate in all seriousness has recommended legislation to "Draft Wealth for War" as reported in THE TIMEs this morning? .

Federal Judge Oliver B. Diclsjnson declared today that"only a miracle" could keep the $95,000,000 Philadelphia Reading Coal and Iron Company in business and that State or Federal aid was the only hope.

Sister Pancratia, sister superior of St. Anthony's Hospital, Woodhaven Boulevard and Ninetieth Avenue, Woodhaven, Queens, died at the hospital on Tuesday. Sister Pancratia, the former Johanna Sanders, was born seventy-six years ago.

Dr. and Mrs. John Munn Hanford of 70 East Ninety-sixth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Crosby Hanford, to Charles Fyfe Stewart, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edgar Eginton Stewart of Great Neck, L. I.

Judge John J. Freschi of the Court of General Sessions will give the commencement address tonight at the forty-sixth annual exercises of the New York Law School, to be held at 8:45 in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.
Dr. George G. Bohrer, a practicing physician here for thirty years, died on Tuesday night of a heart attack in his home at 241 West Ninety-seventh Street. He was 61 years old.

Pleas for a closer relationship between Brazil and the United States were made last night at a dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria tendered to the newly appointed Brazilian Ambassador, Mario de Pimentel Brandao.

Guy Fawkes, the A. C. Norris 4year-old colt that was beaten Saturday in the Inaugural Handicap, came back today to win the feature race at Agawam Park. Guy Fawkes, ridden by Jimmy Lynch, broke on top and was never headed while being clocked in 1:05 2-5 over five and a half furlongs. Cycle, from the Howe stable,

Thomas H. MacDonald; chief of the Federal Bureau of Public Roads, was appointed today chairman of the United States delegation to the Eighth International Road Congress at The Hague, June 18 to July 2.
Secretary Wallace ordered today a reopening of the Kansas City Stockyards case to remedy the procedural defect which was the basis of the Supreme Court's decision on April 25.
Mrs. John I. Kane, who had been prominent in social and charitable work here, died today in her home, Woodlawn, here, after a long illness.

The Rev. William R. Kelley, superintendent of schools for --the Catholic Archdiocese of New York, will inaugurate the first session of the finals of the Catholic School Music Contests this afternoon at 2 o'clock at Town Hall.

Plans have been completed by Mise Barbara Adams, daughter of Mrs. Rand Adams of 1,245 Madison Avenue, for her marriage to Hugh Howard Butler. son of Mr. and Mrs. James Fenwick Butler, which will take place the afternoon of June 14 in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. Dr. George P. T. Sargent.
Dauber beat eight other horses in the $70,000- Preakness on May 14--and some one beat Dauber's trainer, Richard E. Handlen, to the $300. vase awarded to the winner.

Arrangements have been completed by the French Ministry of Public Instruction and the New York Board of Education to facilitate an interchange of letters between high school pupils of this city studying French and those of France in the English classes.

An investigation of the official conduct of Magistrate Overton Harris, under fire often during his seven years on the bench, will be begun today by the Bar Association's committee on criminal courts, law and procedure. The full membership of the committee, of which Timothy N. Pfeiffer is chairman, will meet to discuss the matter at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

Methods of reducing the cost of milk production rest largely with the individual dairy farmer, 0. E. Reed, chief of the United States Bureau of Dairy Industry, declared yesterday at the seventieth annual meeting of the American Jersey Cattle Club, held in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Representatives of groups of breeders from many States re-elected Perry B. Gaines of Carrollton, Ky., president of the organization.

The development of a toleration of differences and a spirit of service to the community are the most important accomplishments of a college education today, Dean. Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College said in her address to more thane 1,000 guests and 244 graduating seniors at the class-day exercises in Barnard Hall yesterday.

Miss Eleanor Schwarz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer H. Schwarz of this place, was married today to Walter Rittenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rittenberg of New York. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents by the Rev. Dr. Nathan Stern of New York.

B. Altman Co. filed yesterday plans for altering the department store property at 355-371 Fifth Avenue. The plans were prepared by William Wilson, architect, who estimated the cost at $250,000. Other plans were submitted as follows:
Knut A. Wallenberg, Swedish Foreign Minister during the World War and one of the founders of the International Chamber of Commerce, died tonight after a brief illness at the age of 85.
Edward E. Bridges, son of the late poet laureate, Robert Bridges, has been appointed to succeed Sir Maurice Hankey as Secretary of the Cabinet, it was announced today.

Operations will suspend at four distilleries of the Schenley Products Company, Lester E. Jacobi, vice president in charge of production, announced yesterday. The suspension is in accordance with an earlier statement that future production of whiskies would not exceed quantitles sufficient to replace withdrawals for current requirements.

In a plea for international morality, Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State, told the graduating class of Bryn Mawr College today that "the way of Christianity" was the "only direction" in which he could see hope for reaching "permanent solutions" of present-day "seemingly insoluble national and international problems."

Another tract of land close to the site of the World's Fair has passed into the hands of developers for improvement with small dwellings. Situated within the four blocks bounded by Utopia Parkway, 200tht Street, Twenty-sixth and Twentyninth Avenues, in Bayside, the property consists of 127 lots.

Treasury officials and a committee representing twenty States discussed tonight proposed legislation to Prevent retroactive taxation of the salaries of State and local officials and employes. No announcement was made, but it was learned that the Treasury

Flushing High School's baseball team routed Jamaica, 9 to 1, at Jamaica Stadium yesterday in the first game of a two-out-of-three play-off series between the two schools for the Queens P. S. A. L. title.

Members of the varsity baseball squad and four trackmen received major letters when Spring sports awards were announced- at St. John's University yesterday. One hundred and five insignia were distributed to the members of the baseball, track, tennis, golf, fencing and rifle teams.

Trial of the government's suit to enjoin the Aluminum Company of America and sixty-two subsidiaries and affiliates from alleged violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law began yesterday before Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey.

Up against the American League's leading pitcher, the world champion Yankees were just a lot of futile swingers for seven innings yesterday at the Stadium. When they finally did get around to solving Vernon Kennedy's slants in the eighth and ninth, it was simply too late, and the Tigers coasted to an 8-4 victory.

Prevented by "a high wind from docking tonight, the Queen Mary was obliged to cruise off port while 280 passengers, waiting. to board her for New York, were stranded without accommodations in the maritime station here.

Wanted on an indictment containing eighteen counts of grand larceny and seven of petty larceny Philip Savery, alias Jack Reilly, 37 years old, a former convict, was arrested last night after a spectacular chase over ten rooftops during which the police fired six shots in the Bedford section of Brooklyn.
Chief Justice Hughes was the only member of the Supreme Court on the winning side in every case decided this term.

As victory follows victory for the Labor Relations Board in the decisions of the Supreme Court, it cannot be too often repeated that all that the court passes upon is the constitutionality of the Wagner law or the procedural validity of the board's acts.

Kurt Schuschnigg, three months ago Chancellor of Austria, has been taken secretly from the Belvedere Palace in Vienna, nobody knows where. Nobody knows what is in store for him. He committed the crime of loving

Postmaster General James A. Farley and Frank C. Walker, former chairman of the National Emergency- Council, are expected as guests today at the graduation exercises of the Marymount School, 1,028 Fifth Avenue.

Yesterday's Weakness in Wall Street, combined with the fact that interest in Great Britain was centered on the Derby, caused all-round dullness on the stock market here today. Giltedge issues were strong but among the foreign bonds German bonds fell off.

The cattle, veal and hog slaughter wa normal for Wednesday, lamb kill light Some traefer meats met with a good de mand, others sold slowly. Steer hinds an ribs were fully steady to strong; steer cut mostly steady to slightly higher; vea hindsaddles steady;

Macomb G. Foster of 44 West Seventy-seventh Street, vice president of Fairchild Brothers Foster, manufacturing chemists, died yesterday afternoon of a heart attack in his office at 76 Laight Street. He was born in this city seventy-eight years ago.

The slackening in trade and industrial activity during May signifies that the Spring season is drawing to an early close, without much to look back upon in the way of seasonal pick-up, according to the National City Bank's monthly review of econnmic conditions.

The $5,000,000 claim of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation against Harley L. Clarke, its former president, is worthless because of Mr. Clarke's personal financial position, counsel for the deposed utility promoter sought to show today at a hearing before Harry N. Gottlieb, special master in chancery.

Airtight pitching by Art Kenney gave Holy Cross a 6-0 victory over Yale today, making twenty-eight innings without an earned run off the Crusader's delivery. He fanned nine and gave four scattered hits. Kenney also defeated Yale last month at Worcester, 9--4.

WASHINGTON, June 1.--In a letter construed by some legislators as an effort to block a general earmarking drive, President Roosevelt today asked the Senate to make the pending relief-recovery appropriations as "flexible" as possible in administration in order to put the greatest number to work in the shortest time.

Japan received its second reprieve from the Canadian Parliament within a week when, during private-bills hour last night, the second attempt of A. W. Neill, Liberal member from Vancover Island, to exclude Japanese or to make it difficult for them to gain entry into Canada was frustrated by a vote of 89 to 37.

Reduction of $3,500,000 annually in the earnings of the Chicago District Pipeline Company was proposed today in a brief filed by the Illinois Commerce Commission with Benjamin J. Morris, commission examiner.

The Chase National Bank headed the successful banking group yesterday in the sale of $11,494,000 of relief, funding, court house and sewer bonds of Boston, Mass. The syndicate obtained the issue on a bid of 100.1099 for 2 3/4s, or at a net interest cost to the city of 2.7359 t per cent.

The sixth annual convention of the Edison Electric Institute will be opened at Atlantic City on Monday and will continue through Thursday of next week, it was announced yesterday by Charles W. Kellogg, president. Utility men from all parts of the country will assemble for the four-day meeting
Pennsylvania set up a moving laboratory today to test every spring and-well in this battlefield community as a safeguard against disease during the coming Blue and Gray reunion.

When the tenth annual convention of the United Lutheran Synod of New York meets in the Lutheran Church of the Reformation, Rochester, N. Y., on June 13-16 a report will be presented for adoption advoeating sex education and more stringent marriage requirements.
The Spanish Insurgents' swift-moving drive from Teruel south toward the Mediterranean today rolled government defenders back to within about twelve miles of Valencia Province.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey announced yesterday the indictment of six members of an investment trust ring, with indications that more indictments were to follow, for the looting of seven investment trusts with assets of more than $16,000,000 within the last year.
Colorful ceremonies attended the bestowal of prizes and an exhibition of seamanship at the Naval Academy today before a large crowd of visitors.

Turning in the superb clocking of 4:23.3 in winning the one-mile open test to create a new meet record, Leslie MacMitchell, George Washington High School star, once again stole the spotlight as the annual Manhattan P. S. A. L. track and field championships were staged at Baker Field yesterday.
LONDON, June 1.--For the first time in history a crooner gave "boop-a-doop" refrains tonight at the Derby Night ball at Buckingham Palace.
Serenity and harmony in the ranks of the Democratic women of the State as their annual conference opened here today gave promise of a smoothly functioning unit in the coming campaign.

The Peddie School baseball team conquered Bordentown Military Institute today, 9-6. Joe Hall pitched superbly for the visitors, allowing only five scattered hits until the ninth, when he weakened to the extent that four Cadet runs were scored.
The Athletics loosed a home-run barrage today to beat the leagueleading Indians, 9. to 5, Lynn Nelson recording his fourth victory of the season against one defeat.

With Colonel Bill Terry still working frantically at the controls, the Giants, recently stalled offensive machinery showed just a spark of life today and a termendous effort, almost born of despair, managed to score one run.

Wally Hammond, idol of English cricket crowds, captained England against the Rest in the test trial starting at Lord's today. When Gilbert Allen became ill yesterday Denis Wilcox, Essex, was made captain of the Rest. Morris Nichols, Essex fast bowler, replaced Alien.

So rapid is the pace in the development of aircraft that the layman constantly finds himself at liberty to enjoy new speeds,new comforts and new distances in air travel which, it seemed only yesterday, were but the stuff of dreams.

Briefs were filed today with the United States Circuit Court of Appeals on behalf of the stockholders of the old Central Republilc Bank and Trust Company seeking to have set aside a Judgment of $14,000,000 rendered against them a year ago by Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson.

Cardinal Hayes will preside and confer degrees this afternoon at the commencement exercises of Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart on the campus at Convent Avenue and 133d Street. The graduating class numbers sixty-four.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Page, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Randolph Page of 127 East Sixty-second Street, New York, and of Bethel, Conn., was married here this afternoon in Christ Church to Joseph Hurd Hodgson, son of Mrs. Joseph E. Hodgson of Bethel and the late Mr. Hodgson. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Raymond Cunningham of Trinity Church, Hartford.
George R. Holahan Jr., lawyer and prominent Catholic layman, died yesterday at his home, 1,111 Albemarle Road, Brooklyn, after an illness of several months. He was 50 years old.

The Swedish Venetian Blind Corporation, which has factories in Los Angeles, Chicago and New York, will transfer its Eastern plant to North Bergen, N. J, where it has bought a plant on Dell Avenue from the Barozzi Drying Machine Company. J. I. Kislak. Inc.,

The report of the National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all expenses and charges, of $8,969,138, compared with $7,591,190 in the twelve months to March 81, 1937.

Faith in democracy and in its preservation by education and the ideals of the American people was voiced yesterday by three university presidents and a United States Senator at the annual Columbia University alumni luncheon in John Jay Hall.

Discussion by Walter M. W. Splawn of the Interstate Commerce Commission of the proposed law to provide a court with jurisdiction over railroad reorganization has aroused interest in Wall Street. The old receivership process for recapitalizing a railroad

Announcement has been made by John Goodwin Tracy of this city of the engagement of his sister, Miss Virginia Goodwin Tracy, to William Pope Gillette, son of Mrs. Charles Howard Gillette of West Hartford.

Payrolls of the American steel industry in April amounted to $47,809,000, about 7 per cent below the March total of $51,386,000, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, which says the decline reflected both the smaller number of working days in April and the fact that operations were at a lower rate than in March.
Following a decline of nearly $5 a bale in the last ten days, prices on the Cotton Exchange rallied sharply more than $1 a bale yesterday and closed around the top, with gains of 16 to 20 points.
The sixth-place Cardinals resembled the powerhouse of former seasons as they slugged out a 9-to-4 victory over the cellar-dwelling Phils today.

One of the largest multi-family properties in the Dyckman section to change hands in recent months passed to new control yesterday when the six-story elevator house at 1 Sickles Street, opposite Public School 152, was bought by David S. Meister.

With only a moderate increase in the trading volume, the stock market scored a sizable recovery yesterday, the best in more than three weeks. Many leading issues were up 1 to 3 points, and one or two did better than that.
Mrs. A. D. Faxon and J. A. Mitchell of Echo Lake today won the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's mixed foursomes tournament at the Crestmont Golf Club. Mrs. Faxon had an 87: and her partner 77.
Making a hurried trip down from Hanover, where he is completing his sophomore year at Dartmouth, Wilson Flohr, one of the district's leading youngsters, today annexed the qualifying medal

Charging that the Communist party aimed to control transport and labor "so that it could paralyze the country in event of war," a special commission reported to the Legislature today that the organization's prime objective was to. rouse to a militant or revolutionary mood organized labor and the unemployed.
The Board of Tax Appeals today elected Eugene Black, a Texas Democrat, as chairman upon the expiration of the term of C. R. Arundell, an Oregon Republican.

Continuing its 300th birthday celeration, New Haven tonight was host to several thousand visitors who thronged the Coxe Memorial Field House of Yale University, which had been transformed into an exposition center and housed 224 booths displaying products of the Elm City from a toy engine to hardware, clocks, firearms and ammunition and corsets.

The White Sewing Machine Corporation has addressed a letter to holders of its preference and common stocks saying that no dividends can legally be paid on either class of stock until the existing capital deficit has been eliminated, and that while a substantial number of stockholders has assented to the plan of recapitalization of March 5, many have not made their wishes known and must act if the plan is to succeed.

Columbia University closed its commencement exercises yesterday with the presentation by President Nicholas Murray Butler of 4,826 degrees and 147 certificates at a graduation ceremony before an audience of 20,000 alumni, relatives and friends assembled in South Court on the campus.

Echoes of' the days before the Wagner act made it illegal for employers to discharge workers for joining a union were heard yesterday at a National Labor Relations Board hearing on charges of unfair labor practices against the Western Union Telegraph Company.

Charles Millard Pratt, philanthropist, former director of the Standard Oil Company and former president of Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, left a net estate of $20,004,812, according to a report filed in Kings County Surrogate's Court yesterday by David F. Soden, State transfer tax appraiser.
Harrison Souder of this place, consulting and mining engineer, died last night of a heart ailment in his Summer home at Duxbury, Mass. He was 67 years old.
Governor A. Harry Moore and Mrs. Moore returned to Sea Girt this afternoon and reopened the "Little White House," Summer executive mansion on the National Guard reservation here.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,098,650 barrels, compared with 3,175,750 in the preceding week, a decline of 77,100, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Decline in business in Canada during the past few months was due largely to the influence of the United States on Canadian thoughts and activities, F. C. Brown of Vancouver declared in his presidential address at the opening luncheon of the Canadian Manufacturers Association's annual meeting here today.
