John Bruce Thornton, 50 years old, who was arrested a week ago in the neighborhood of Viscount Nuffield's office at Cowley, has been charged with possession of firearms with intent to endanger life.
Erwin T. Jones, district claim agent of the New -York Central System, with headquarters at New York, died yesterday in his home in Yonkers, N. Y. He was 66 years old.

The question whether the Constitutional Convention should take action on two proposals to grant to the Legislature the power, if it so desired, of establishing a system of automobile accident compensation insurance similar in principle to the workmen's compensation plan now in force was debated today at a public hearing of the convention's Judiciary Committee.

WASHINGTON, June 1.--The fact that Lawrence Camp, Federal District Attorney at Atlanta, today became a candidate for the Democratic Senatorial nomination to succeed Senator George of Georgia and that his candidacy is reported to have the blessing of President Roosevelt, aroused added resentment among Democratic Senators who believe the Administration is seeking the scalps of those who opposed the bill to enlarge the Supreme Court.

Trial of the French dressmaking firm of Marcel Rochas, Inc., and of Guy Gueron De Font-Joyeuse, mainager of the corporation's New York shop at 32 East Sixty-seventh Street, on an indictment charging smuggling, began yesterday before Federal Judge William Bondy and a jury.

The Washington Star said today that the Justice Department was investigating complaints that the American Medical Association and the District of Columbia Medical Society had violated anti-trust laws in opposing "group health" programs.
Sharply reproving Czechoslovakia for her allegedly hostile attitude toward Hungary, Foreign Minister Koloman de Kanya discussed foreign policy at length in Parliament today.

The dismissal of Dr. Alan R. Sweezy, and Dr. J. Raymond Walsh, Harvard economics instructors, a year ago, was both unwise and unjust, but was not prompted by their labor activities or their economist and social views, a committee of eight senior members of the Harvard faculty stated in a report to Dr. James B. Conant, president of the university, made public tonight.

A pending royal visit to the Italian Tyrol and allocation of numerous public works funds, coming, after German absorption of Austria, were seen today as increasing evidence that Italy is trying to increase the allegiance to her of this region with its 250,000 Germanic inhabitants.

German nationals intending to visit or take up residence in the territory of the Union of South Africa hereafter will be required to have their passports visaed. Notification to that effect has been made to the Reich Government, which is expected to retaliate with a corresponding measure.

That the radically different House and Senate wage-hour measures have gone directly to conference is to be regretted for two reasons. It will prevent that thorough study and debate of which the whole proposal is desperately in need and which it has never received.

Expansion of its cash purchase plan for merchandise whereby it will deposit with retailers or other merchants the amount of money the shopper intends to spend was announced yesterday by the Morris Plan Bank of New York. According Plan Bank of New York.

The storm over the "indiscretion" by Sir Thomas Inskip, Minister for the Coordination of Defense, Monday night was quieted today by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, who assured the House of Commons that the government has no plan to draft labor in the event of a general war.

The banking committee. of the Constitutional Convention reported out favorably today to the convention the McCall proposals which would eliminate from the State Constitution three obsolete sections dealing with the issuance of notes by State banks.
James Peters, former WPA superintendent at the Pelham Bus Terminal, and five officers and employes of Twentieth Century Bus Operators, Inc., and New York Brown Line Motor Tours, Inc.,
An interesting landmark closely linked to the days when Fourteenth Street and Union Square boasted of being the-theatrical center of Manhattan was turned over to wreckers yesterday.

The Phoenix Securities Corporation --announced yesterday that it had completed arrangements to anticipate- its commitment to purchase by July 21 certain securities of the United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation for which deposit receipts were issued by the Chase National Bank.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today a public hearing tomorrow at its offices in New York to determine whether the registration of J. Albert Haines, 150 Broadway, as an over-thecounter broker or dealer should be revoked or suspended.

Franklin and Marshall College gave diplomas to 139 men at the commencement exercises today. Professor Carl J. Weber of Colby College gave the commencement address and received the honorary degree of Doctor of Letters. Other honorary degrees were awarded as follows:

A class of fourteen received diplomas yesterday at the commencement exercises held on the lawn of the Shore Road Academy, Ninetyfourth Street and Shore Road, Brooklyn. Henry P. Molloy, president of the trustees, spoke, and his daughter, Harriet, a graduate, gave the address of welcome.

Mr. and Mrs. John L. Montgomery will give a tea dance on June 30 at their home in Oyster Bay for Mrs. Montgomery's daughter, Miss Florence Wardwell, who will be introduced to society during the Winter.

The State Catholic Welfare Committee informed leaders of the Constitutional Convention today that its recent letter, which had been interpreted as putting the church on record as opposed to all forms of gambling, had been misunderstood.

Miss Marjorie Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. D. Hayes Murphy of West Hartford, was married to Gerard Hassett Morrissey of Milwaukee, son of Dr. and Mrs. Michael J. Morrissey of West Hartford, today in the Church of St. Thomas the Apostle, by the Rev. John F. Callahan.

California's hard-hitting baseball Bears defeated Cornell today, 7-1, for their eleventh victory since they left Berkeley, Calif., in mid-May. The game was called on account of rain in the first half of the sixth after the visitors had scored another run, which did not count.
A policeman was killed in Brooklyn early this morning by a shot fired by another policeman in an attempt to halt a robber suspect running from a building where a burglary had been reported.

John R. Longo, 24-year-old antiHague Democrat, who was convicted May 6 of violating the election laws, was sentenced this afternoon by Judge Robert V. Kinkead in Quarter Sessions Court to serve nine months in the Hudson County penitentiary.
The Annalist reported yesterday that its weekly index of wholesale commodity prices had declined on Wednesday to the lowest level since May 19, 1936.

Miss Alberta Edwards, daughter of Mrs. Alfred Belmont Edwards of Plandome, L. I., and the late Mr. Edwards, was married to George Parker, son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Parker of Brooklyn, last night at Sherry's. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. William W. Bellinger, vicar of St. Agnes' Chapel of Trinity Church.

The last lingering doubt whether the United States might harvest a recordbreaking crop of wheat this season was dispelled today when four leading statisticians issued their estimates of the prospective yield.

All the monuments symbolizing the "Second German Reich" - the empire founded by Bismarck in 1871-are being removed from their present positions centering around the Reichstag Building and are being transferred to the center of the 'Tiergarten around the roadway intersection known as the Great Star.

Paul B. Sawyer, president of the National Power Light Company, told shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday in Jersey City that, in view of business conditions, it might be wise for the management of the company to reduce the amount of dividends which it draws from subsidiaries and that therefore the cash available for common dividends of National Power Light would be reduced.

The Berlin newspaper Angriff tonight published an extra edition in which the entire front page was devoted to "Goering as a Father of a Family-a Day with Uncle Hermann." The occasion of the extra was the birth to Frau Hermann Goering, wife of the Field Marshal, of her first child, a daughter, who will be named Edda.

The Barnard School for Girls will hold its forty-second commencement exercises at 11 A. M. today in the gymnasium of the school at 554 Fort Washington Avenue. Dean Irving H. Berg of the College of Arts and Pure Science of New York University, will give the address. The valedictorian will be Jane Meyer and the salutatorian Florence Drysdale.
Frank M. Jost of Woodbridge, N. J., has been elected captain of the 1939 Manhattan College baseball team, it was announced yesterday by Herbert M. Kopf, director of athletics.

With Southern California rated as a top-heavy favorite for the team laurels and a throng of sectional titleholders among the entrants from thirty-one colleges, the sixtysecond Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. outdoor track and field championships will begin a two-day stand at Randalls Island Stadium this afternoon.

When the liner Hamburg arrived here this morning her captain, T. H. Koch, voluntarily called police headquarters, explaining that Werner George Gudenberg, wanted in the United States on a warrant charging him with being a spy, would be handed over to the Reich police as a stowaway The chief of police told Captain Koch he had no interest in the case, since no request had been received from the United States to arrest Gudenberg.

White St, 41, 26.41/2x100; Frank Zuckerbrot to trustees will of Ellen R. Morgan, 1,045 Park Ave; consideration, $6,000; foreclosure. 57th St, s s, 195 ft e of 6th Ave, 25x100.5: excrs will of George D. Cochran to Pelham L Cochrane et al, Haldenhof, Kitzbuhel, Austria.

Dr. Vannevar Bush, vice president and dean of engineering of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was elected president yesterday of the Carnegie Institution of Washington at a special meeting of-the board of trustees at: 522 Fifth Avenue. He is in his fortyninth year.
Dr. Henry 0. Reik, physician, author, medical lecturer and educator, died of a heart ailment here today at his home, 56 Sterling Avenue, at the age of 70.

The New York region is twenty to twenty-five years ahead of London in city planning, particularly with respect to public improvements and its efforts to control the height and density of building, Dr. Thomas Adams, British planner and author, declared yesterday.
Meadow Brook polo players galloped through four more games on the club fields late today, with the pace noticeably increasing as the date for the opening of the club championship draws nearer.

The controversy that flared over the omission of the singing of "God Save the King" at Union Day ceremonies May 31 and caused Richard Stuttaford, Minsister of the Interior, to submit his resignation subsided tonight after a government statement had been issued giving equal status to the national anthem and "Die Stem van Suid Afrika."

The Treasury revoked today a group of dumping penalties which had applied to Canadian wheat flour and a number of products from other countries. Officials said there has been no dumping of the products for more than five years.

Pending final decision by Police Commissioner Valentine, Patrolman Joel L. Kashuck, who had been under suspension since April 11, when he was charged with having shot himself at the East 126th Street station, was restored to duty by Third Deputy Police Commissioner Michael A. Lyons at the end of a departmental trial yesterday.

The stock markets here were more active today, and a tendency to rise was evident in most sections. Gilt-edge issues again were a strong feature, while among the foreign loans German bonds were well supported.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Mrs. Florence T. Hartshorn, daughter of Mrs. Alton T. Terrell of Overbrook, Orange, Conn., and the late Mr. Terrell, to Clarence A. Earl Jr. of 210 East Sixty-eighth Street, this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence A. Earl.

From a sickbed in the North County Community Hospital, where he is recuperating from a throat infection, Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Works Progress Administrator, answered "definitely no" today to an intimation in Congress last week that he was a member of the Socialist party.
A class of thirty-five seniors will receive diplomas tomorrow morning at the commencement exercises here of the Briarcliff Junior College.

Trade Minister W. D. Euler today told the Canadian Manufacturers Association there is "a really perceptible trend in the revival of industry" from the "slight recession" that had taken place in the last year.

Arriving buyers may register in this column by telephoning LAckawanna 4-1000. RETAIL AARON, Pa.--J. Allen; Miss Strauss, children's cotton coats; Miss M. Propper, women's, children's silk. cotton dresses, sportswear; 225 W. 34th (Mandelbaum Buying Service). ALLENTOWN, Pa.-Daniels; Mr. Rosen, ready-to-wear; 225 W. 34th (Marizon Rosenberg Co.).

Hans Paul Baron von Wolzogen, a friend and interpreter of the composer, Richard Wagner, died today at the age of 89. Baron von Wolzogen, playwright, critic and composer, wrote extensively of Wagner and of Baireuth.
Another new yacht for the Bermuda race this month was launched yesterday at the Nevins shipyard in City Island. She is the Blitzen, a sloop designed by Sparkman Stephens for Richard J. Reynolds.

Former Dictator Federico Paez, who was deposed by the present military regime, has escaped over the Colombian border with a diplomatic passport, according to a report published in the Telegrafo today.

The committee on criminal courts, law and procedure of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York began an investigation of the official conduct of Magistrate Overton Harris yesterday afternoon at a meeting at the Bar Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

The slaughter of those classes usually dressed kosher was light, due to the approaching Jewish holiday. Trading in traefe meats was somewhat uneven; some meats met with a good demand, others sold slowly. Steer hinds and ribs were fully steady to strong.

President Roosevelt delivered the graduation address at the Naval Academy at Annapolis. The Senate debated the ReliefRecovery Bill, defeating the "private competition" amendment and the Hatch amendment to prohibit WPA officials from participating in political campaigns;

Mayor Frank Hague issued a statement today declaring once more that he would fight to a finish in his struggle against Communists and the C. I. O. "in spite of the C. I. O. dough bag raised by collecting dues from misled workers."
There is more than one way of abdicating. President Butler has just said that democracy begins to abdicate

LONG ISLAND 8, NEW JERSEY 7 Miss Maureen Orcutt, New Jersey, defeated Mrs. Harry McNaughton, Long Island, 3 and 1; Miss Charlotte Glutting, New Jersey, defeated Mrs. Sylva Annenberg, 4 and 3; Mrs. William Hockenjos, New Jersey, defeated Mrs. R. M. Torgerson.

Death Announced Retired Fireman Garrett Kearns, formerly a member of Engine Co. 252, residing at 20-47 41st St., Long Island City, Queens, died May 31. Funeral will take place from Funeral Parlor of Charles Weydig Sons, 20-68 Steinway St., Long Island City, at 8:30 A. M., Friday, June 3.
In the final week of May business in the Pittsburgh district fell to a new low level for the year, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.
Dr. George Barton Cutten, president of Colgate University, will be the speaker tonight at the thirtyfirst commencement exercises of the Riverdale Country School on the campus at Riverdale-on-Hudson.

Secretary Roper and Representative Bloom of New York are being featured here in full-page advertisements by a local department store as part of a "sell now" campaign, originated by Mr. Bloom, who copyrighted the slogan but who offers it free to any store which will cooperate with him.

Livable Homes, a new organization headed by Gladys Miller, interior decorating editor of Mademoiselle, instructor in interior decorating at New York University School of Retailing and president of Service Programs, Inc., is planning a cooperative campaign for the home furnishings field in newspapers, magazines and radio.

Trade association executives in the women's grament and allied industries protested yesterday that "overloaded inventories" could not be made the basis of a "sell now" campaign as manufacturers' stocks in these lines were extremely low.

Only two of the nine Democratic Senators who helped to defeat President Roosevelt's bill to enlarge the Supreme Court and are up for renomination in this year's primaries are without active opposition from candidates supposedly sponsored by the Administration.

IRELAND is Eire now, and at strange peace with England. The bloodswept days of The Trouble-seem a long time ago. But Louis Lynch D'Alton gives those days a good deal of turbulent vitality once more in this short, violent novel, "Death Is So Fair."

President Roosevelt, according to reports widely circulated here tonight and believed by many to be authentic, intends to seek revision of the National Labor Relations Act at the next session of Congress.

Sixty-two laundries-thirty-four in the Bronx, twenty-three in Queens and five in Richmond-are listed in a legal notice published in today's newspapers for failure to comply with the laundry wage order issued last month under the new State Minimum Wage Law.

Thomas C. Brown, who retired last March as a justice of the Domestic Relations Court after more than thirty-three years as a judge in courts here, died yesterday at St; Vincent's Hospital, West New Brighton, S. I., of a heart ailment.
Declining bank credit in the face of expanding bank reserves continued to be reflected in the banking statistics this week.

Lawrence Jennings in 200 Brewster Rd, Scarsdale; Robert E. Farley Organization, broker. Mrs. F. Grosvenor Smith, Charles f. Flaccus residences in Hewlett, L. I.; Beatrice L. Renwick, Inc, and Burr McAuley, co-brokers.

Some improvement in business conditions has developed recently and the outlook contains certain- encouraging factors, Alvin E. Dodd, who was yesterday re-elected president of the American Management Association, declared in his report to the membership of the annual business meeting at the Hotel New Yorker.

Miss Phyllis Almy Gallatin, a descendant of Albert Gallatin, Secretary of the Treasury under Presidents Madison and Jefferson, and William Appleton Aiken, who is of distinguished New England ancestry, were married yesterday afternoon in St. James Church, Seventyfirst Street and Madison Avenue.

The League of Nations received today formal notification of Chile's withdrawal for reasons announced at the last Council session [failure to act on her request for removal of the Covenant's coercive provisions to win back resigned members.]

Certificates were presented to twenty-five graduates who completed :the four-year course at the seventeenth annual commencement 'exercises last night of the New York Stock Exchange Institute at the. Exchange Luncheon Club.

Best quotations on the Cotton Exchange yesterday were registered at the opening, when a sharp recovery in Liverpool and an estimate by a Chicago house of 9,815,000 bales on 25,935,000 acres stimulated buying operations in several directions. However, as July approached the 8-cent level liquidation by the long interest in the near delivery weighed on the market, and a setback left prices with final losses of 4 to 5 points.

The Public Service Commission of New Hampshire urged the Interstate Commerce Commission today to refuse to reconsider its decision against increasing passenger-coach fares from 2 cents to 2.5 cents a mile.

A four-run rally in the eighth inning, capped by Bill Holm's single, scoring Buddy Rosar with the winning run, gave Newark a 7-to-6 victory Mae over Syracuse today. It was the sixth victory in a row for the Bears.
The engagement of $3,031,000 gold abroad for shipment to this country, $2,750,000 being- taken in England and $281,000 in India, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Declaring that "the world's outstanding problem is poverty," Frederick Leggett, president of the International Labor Office Governing Body, opened the twenty-fourth International Labor Conference here today.

Mayor La Guardia has forsaken the Arrow Brook Country Club and its fifty acres at the southern edge of the World's Fair site as a Summer City Hall and instead will establish his- office in the city's exhibition building right in the center of the fair area, it was revealed yesterday.

More than 350 pianists, aged 4 to 24, are competing in the New York section of the fifth annual National Piano Playing Tournament which started at the Hotel Biltmore on Wednesday and will continue through tomorrow.

The text of President Roosevelt's address as prepared for delivery to the midshipmen was as follows: A quarter of a century ago I began coming to graduation exercises at the United States Naval Academy. I find It a good custom and I hope to be following it occasionally when I have reached the age of the oldest admiral on the retired list. As a retired Commander-in-Chief of the navy I could do nothing else.

Furniture manufacturers can reduce prices only in the event that public buying and resulting increases in orders from retailers are sufficient to bring a substantial gain in the production rate, which would reduce manufacturers' costs, Thomas F. Murtagh, manager of the New York Furniture Exchange, said here yesterday.

Floyd A. Beatty has resigned as senior vice president in charge of plant operation for the Lewis Foundry and Machine Company. Frank L. McCartney, vice president and manager of the Chicago division of the Norwich Pharmacal Company, has been elected president to fill the unexpired term of Robert S. Eaton.
Several branches of the advertising field are considerably disturbed as the result of threatened State and city regulations of their activities. The proposal to embody in

A report from Hsinking, credited to theGerman Transocean Service and published in the local press, is to the effect that the Government of Manchukuo is sending a Propaganda mission of twenty members to visit El Salvador.

By JAMES R. MURPHY Roebling Ave, 2,860, dwelling, 25x95; Home Owners Loan Corp against Charles Booth; due, $5,288; to plaintiff for $5,100. By JAMES J. DOOLING Pugsley Ave, dwelling, 25x111.6; Home Owners Loan Corp against People of the State of New York et al; due, $4,695; to plaintiff for $3,000.

The Mountain States Telephone and Telegraph Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $30,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent thirtyyear debentures, naming thirtyseven underwriters and the amount underwritten by each as follows:

Albert Barnett, father-in-law of John R. McCarl, former controller of the currency, and regarded as one of western Nebraska's wealthiest men, died last night after a two months' illness. He was 82 years old.
Miss Lily Pons, Metropolitan Opera star, and Andre Kostelanetz, radio orchestra conductor, were married at the home of the bride in Silvermine this afternoon.

The degree of Bachelor of Science in Naval Architecture and Marine Engineering was conferred yesterday on ten young men at commencement exercises of Webb Institute of Naval Architecture, Sedgwick and Webb Avenues. the Bronx.

With its star twirler, Joe Cleary, permitting only two hits and striking out ten, the High School of Commerce nine beat Seward Park, 12-1, at Washington Stadium yesterday, and went into a tie with Morris High for the ManhattanBronx P. S. A. L. title. Cleary also excelled at the plate, contributing a triple, double and single.

Now, in the June days, fishing for the Atlantic salmon comes to its height in the clear, cold rivers of Eastern Canada. On the Restigouche, the Matapedia and the Grand Cascapedia in the Gaspe region, and the rivers on the north shore of the St. Lawrence (here widening to mighty proportions as it nears the sea), such as the Godbout and the Mille Vaches, kingly fish will be rising to deftly placed flies.

The general level of wholesale prices declined in the week ended on May 28, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, was 78.1. compared with 78.2 on May 21 and 87.4 on May 29, 1937.

Nearly 1,000 boys and girls, resenting nineteen choruses and choirs of Catholic schools of Greater New York and vicinity, competed for prizes yesterday in the first session of the finals of the annual Catholic School Music Contests at the Town Hall.

Contending that the shoe industry here has little to fear from foreign competition under the trade agreement with Czechoslovakia, Frank J. Rosner, secretary of the American-Czechoslovak Chamber of Commerce, Inc., yesterday asserted that. liberal concessions were given by the Czechs in exchange for the shoe favors obtained through the treaty.

The North River Savings Bank took a new mortgage for $15,000 from the A. L. E. X. Realty Corp, Harry Domb. president, and this has been consolidated with a prior mortgage to form one lien for 520,000 on 15-17 Clinton St and extended for five years at 5 per cent.

A new plan of reorganization for the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company was filed today in the Federal District Court here by the reorganization managers, Albert M. Greenfield, Edward Hopkinson Jr., representing underlier interests, and John A. McCarthy.

Czechoslovak authorities explained-today that the five-hour detention of Miss Unity FreemanMitford, daughter of Lord Redesdale of England and a friend of Chancellor Adolf Hitler, was but a part of the routine inspection of all travelers passing through military defense zones.

Negotiations for the entry as individuals of members of the Socialist party of the State into the ranks of the American Labor party, which have been going on for months, have progressed to the point where definite action one way or another will be taken within the next few weeks, it was Said last night.
Both in Czechoslovakia and in Spain the worst moments of danger seem to be over, Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet felt able to assure the Foreign Affairs Committee of the 'Chamber of Deputies today.

The auction sale of furniture and decorative appointments of Gerald B. Stretton 2d of this city, and other owners, brought $10,118 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 742 Fifth Avenue, yesterday. The items were sold at a morning and afternoon session.
None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low figure for the year, but the ratio of reserve at the New York bank was at a new high point for 1938.

The following Marine Corps changes dated Juhe 1 were announced today: COLONEL Parsons, H. L., staff. commander-in-chief Asiatic Fleet, to headquarters, Department of Pacific, San Francisco, Calif., about July 10.

Counsel for Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, was granted today an alternative writ of mandamus by Chief Justice Thomas J. Brogan of the Supreme Court under which the right of Director of Safety Daniel Casey to deny speaking permits will be tested.

Three women, known to their fellow students in the New York University School of Architecture as "The Three R's," will reflect a new trend in careers for women when they are graduated with honors in architecture from the university Wednesday.

Replying to a protest by Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania against a proposed 15 per cent reduction in the wages of unionized railroad employes, J. M. Davis, president of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, made public yesterday a statement which he sent to Governor Earle and in which he contended that the reduction would increase employment.

Mr. Roosevelt declared his intention last Tuesday not to say anything in public about the claims of primary candidates that they had his support. But this intention couldn't be made retroactive and a kind word from Washington is easily magnified.

General Kazushige Ugaki, the Foreign Minister, told the Cabinet yesterday: "I pray that the fighting services will feel no concern outside their own province but concentrate with an easy mind on fighting so a maximum may be obtained in the field.

The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today a proposed operating agreement between the Railway Express Agency, Inc., and tne Southern Railway Company and affiliates, together with other Southeastern rail carriers, in so far as it provides for a pooling and division of earnings within the terms of the Interstate Commerce Act.

Continued deflation in outstanding bank credit to the lowest levels in more than three years was recorded in the condition statement as of Wednesday of weekly reporting member banks of .the Federal Reserve in New York City, published yesterday.

Miss Margarita Noble, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Noble of Greenwich, was married to Dr. Howard P. Serrell, also of this place, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Paul Serrell of Montvale, N. J., in the Round Hill Community Church here this afternoon. The Rev. Harold E. Wilson, the pastor, officiated.

Davidson Ave (11-3199). w s. 200 ft n of 184th St. 150x100; Van Rock Holdings, Inc, to Diana Properties, Inc, 295 Madison Ave. 175th St (11-2952), s s. 236 ft e of Prospect Ave, 45x142; Liam Holding Corp to Morgreen Realty Corp, 349 E 149th St: mtg $33,000. Boston Rd (92307), e s, 84 ft n of 146th St, 28x78; Sarah Schoen to Harry C. Bryan, 395 Webster Ave, New Rochelle: mtg $11,500.
Leases for apartments in tne bighteen-story apartment house now 2 inder construction at 2 Sutton Place South have been made from I 'he plans with Dr. Edward G. PickIs, EH. McHugh, Thomas D. Cairns.

The Treasury's June quarterly financing plans were announced today by Secretary Morgenthau, but he did not disclose what type of security would be offered on June 15 in exchange for the $618,056,800 of 2 7/3 per cent notes which will mature on that date. No "new money" will be sought.

America, as people are fond of saying, is a young country. It is less than four and a half centuries since we were officially discovered, less than a thousand since Leif Ericson made his informal landing.
Police Lieutenant Thomas F. Kelly, 50 years old, whose wife, Lucy, was a sweepstakes winner Wednesday, filed application yesterday for retirement from the Police Department.
John A. Campbell, an outstanding Trenton banker and pottery manufacturer, died at his home here today as a result of a heart attack suffered two weeks ago. His age was 82.

THERE was a rumor that Father Knickerbocker' was charged with apathy toward outdoor intercollegiate track and field competition and that the fair city of New York was now standing trial with the holding of the I. C. 4-A games at Randalls Island. Mr. Ass. Bushnell, late of Princeton, was asked to come out from behind his desk and explain matters.
Immediate steps by Japan to comply with demands that Americans regain their property in Chinese territory now occupied by Japanese troops were reported in official quarters here-today.

The Mexican Congress continued today to revolt against President Cardenas's policies as the majority bloc of the Congress adopted a resolution providing for an investigation of conditions on the government community farms in the Laguna cotton and wheat region.
Assurance that Japan has no territorial designs on Australia is made by K. Miyake, Japanese vice consul, in a long letter to the press. In it he said:

The business building at the corner of Bergenline Avenue and Fortieth Street, Union City, N. J., was sold by Eva-Birmbaum to Rose Meyer for investment. It was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $36,000 held by the Hudson Trust Company and will be altered. Frank J. Cascardo, Inc., was the broker.

The accused became the accusers today at the trial of forty-four individuals and nineteen corporations charged with conspiring to prevent unionization in the rich coal fields which line the forks of the Cumberland River.

Defeats of the medalist and a former titleholder featured the first two rounds of match play in the thirtyieventh annual New Jersey State amateur golf championship at the Canoe Brook Club today. Both these highlights came in the opening round of the tourney.
Andrew B. Smith, who retired as president judge of the Susquehanna County Court on Jan. 1 after twenty years on the bench, died at his home here today.

THREE COMRADES, as adapted by F. Scott Fitzgerald and Edward E. Paramore from the book by Erich Maria Remarque; music by Franz Waxman, with lyrics by Bob Wright and Chet Forrest; directed by Frank Borzage; produced by Joseph L. Manklewicz for Metro-GoldwynMayer. At the Capitol.

Nearly 200,000 patent models which inventors of the nineteenth century wracked their brains and wore their fingers to the bone to devise, and for which Congress twelve years ago appropriated a sum to get rid of in order to save further storage fees, changed hands Wednesday, it was announced yesterday.

Mrs. Helen Wills Moody was shunted to the sidelines in the St. George's Hill tennis tournament today by 24-year-old Miss Ruth Hardwick, the English girl who came so close to beating her in the same tournament three years ago.
AMERICAN YEARS, by Harold Sinclair. (Doubleday, Doran, $2.75.) A historical novel tracing the life and growth of a frontier town. THE AYES HAVE IT, by A. P. Herbert. (Doubleday, Doran, $2.)

An agreement was reached yesterday between the International Paper Company and Bowater's Paper Mills, Ltd., of London, England, for the purchase by Bowater's of the entire common share capital of the International Power and Paper Company of Newfoundland, Ltd., of Corner Brook, Nlfd. Richard J. Cullen, president of International, announced the agreement here.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am one among the hundreds who attended the recent meeting on the World's Fair grounds at which plans for the proposed Temple of Religion were outlined, and I was-astonished to learn that, in this day and age; the spiritual leaders of America have lost sight of the fact that there are other religions besides those of Christianity' and Judaism.

A building loan of $110,000 has been arranged by Ackman Co., Inc., with the Sterling National Bank Trust Co on the six-story apartment to be erected on the e s of Hull Ave, 100 ft s of E 204th St, for the Amdor Realty Corp.

Paul Edwards, administrative officer in charge of the five WPA Federal Arts Projects in this city, absolved yesterday the. present administration of the Federal Theatre Project of any responsibility for the abuses disclosed in the current investigation of alleged diversion of WPA box-office receipts.

United States Government obligations were quick to respond to the announcement by Secretary of the . Treasury Morgenthau that June financing would be restricted to a refunding operation and will involve no new money borrowing.
Plans for altering tenement houses in scattered sections of Manhattan were announced yesterday in connection with sales of the properties.

Opposition to any change in the existing home rule statutes which would permit municipalities to exercise control over the State's educational system was expressed today by the representatives of teacher and parent associations at a noisy public hearing before. the Cities Committee of the Constitutional Convention.

A charge hig that lobbyists had attempted. to in- A fluence decisions of the Federal of Communications Commission affect- the ing radio broadcasting was made in to the House Rules Committee to- wit day by George H. Payne, a member of the commission.
William H. Howard has been named advertising director of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., it was announced to yesterday. He will be responsible for production of store advertising.

The 229th annual commencement exercises of Trinity School will be held at 3 P. M. today in the auditorium, 139 West Ninety-first Street. Twenty-nine boys will receive diplomas or certificates, which will be presented by M. E. Dann, headmaster. Dr. Richard M. Gunmere, dean of admissions at Harvard University. will be the sneaker.
Richard Archbold, scientist, and his crew of five took off from San Diego Bay in the big flying boat Guba today for Honolulu, their first stop -en route to New Guinea.

President Roosevelt has signed a bill providing for creation of the Saratoga National Historical Park. The measure authorizes government acquisition by purchase and condemnation of all land, structures and other property in the battlefield area, including that part of the battlefield belonging to New York State.

Twenty-four boys will be graduated tonight at the fifty-second commencement exercises of the Barnard School for Boys, West 244th Street and Cayuga Avenue, Fieldston, the Bronx. The Rev. Dr. George H. Smyth, '95, of the Hitchcock Memorial Church, Scarsdale, N. Y., will speak, and former Justice Sydney A. Syme, '95, chairman of the board of trustees, will welcome the guests. Dr. William L. Hazen, founder and headmaster, will preside.

In a ceremony in front of 1,775 Broadway, the Outdoor Cleanliness Association presented yesterday its third annual award for "outstanding cleanliness" to E. A. Dannemann, president of the National Transportation Company, part of the Parmelee taxicab system.
The School of Nursing of Presbyterian Hospital held its forty-fourth annual commencement yesterday in the garden behind its building at 622 West 168th Street, adjoining the Medical Center.

A special train is being chartered by the City Wide Tenants Council to carry a delegation of persons interested in public housing to Albany, where a public hearing on proposed constitutional amendments will be held on Thursday, June 9, in the Assembly Chamber.

Grand Ave, 2,487 (11-3213); Bessie Brotman to East River Savings Bank: extends mtgs to May 1, 1943, at 5 per cent; $121,500. Jennings St, 862 (11-2965); Elizabeth Donnelly to Unlo Dime Savings Bank; extends mtg to May 1, 1943, at 5 per cent; $45,750.

The Hansa of the Hamburg-American Line, arriving today from Hamburg and channel ports, has as passengers Mr.' and Mrs. T. E. Hough, Mrs. William vom Rath, Miss Eleanor vom Rath, Dr. Karl Wilhelm Wolfgang Ostwald, Dr. Robert Luther, Frederick E. Mueller, Rudolf Nagel, Mr. and Mrs. Morrill Wiggin, Miss Else Harnish and Mr. and Mrs. V. R. Hill.
Scoring 42 points, Public School 18 of West Brighton won the team championship at the Richmond P. S. A. L. senior division track and field meet at Curtis Field, St. George, S. I., yesterday.

Discussion of Mayor Hague's tactics in "muzzling" opposition factions in Jersey City shattered the tranquillity of the annual conference of Democratic women of New York State in their closing session this morning.

The engagement of Miss Mildre Pope, daughter of Mr. and Mr Arthur Richard Pope of 480 Par Avenue and Madison, Conn., Henry Hill Pierce Jr. has been ar? nounced by her parents. Miss Pope attended the Brearle School and Vassar College and wa? introduced to society in the season of 1932-33.

Japanese reinforcements continued their westward advance today toward the beleaguered Doihara division northwest of Lanfeng and were reaching a point about 25 miles eastward of Lanfeng, according to the Japanese military spokesman today.

Admissions by Stephen Paine, partner of Paine, Webber Co., New York Stock Exchange brokerage house, that months before public suspicion arose the firm had held evidence of the doubtful nature of two transactions it had financed were the highlights of the Securities and Exchange Commission hearings in the investment trust scandal, which opened yesterday.

Dutch Leonard pitched six-hit ball today, Zeke Bonura went on a batting rampage and the Senators walloped the White Sox, 7 to 1. Bonura, traded to Washington by the Sox this. Spring, cleaned the bases with a double in the first inning.

Reputable lawyers must form a united front against the vilifiers of the legal profession, against delinquent and unethical lawyers and against groups which would encroach on their field, General Sessions Judge John J. Freschi told graduates of the New York Law school last night at their commencement exercises at the Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

Fed steers and yearlings closed active and steady today with prices at season's high time, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. The market retained its early advance of 15 to 25 cents. Hogs closed active at 10 to 15 cents higher and lambs were strong to 25 cents higher, springers getting up to $10.

Reflecting the steady decline in imports which has been under way since the first of the year, duty collections at this port in May were 42.5 per cent below last year, it was learned yesterday at the United States Custom House.

Concerted action by Catholic newspaper men and writers in many countries for the release from a Nazi concentration camp of Dr. Friedrich Funder, dean of Austrian editors, is expected as a direct result of a statement issued here today by the International Union of the Catholic Press.

Results of automobile inspections in New Jersey- were described yesterday by James J. Shanley, chief of the inspection division of the New Jersey Motor Vehicle Department, at a joint luncheon meeting of the commercial vehicle section of the Greater New York Safety Council and the American Society of, Safety Engineers at the Hotel Astor.

Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone today assessed fines of $360,000 and $25,000 costs against thirteen major oil companies and eleven of their officials on charges of illegally fixing the margin of profit for independent wholesale gasoline jobbers in the Midwest.

Mrs. Hortense L. Nathan, for fourteen years a teacher in New York City public schools, died on Wednesday at the Hospital for Joint Diseases at the age of 36. Born in New York, Mrs. Nathan was the only daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Lebenstein. She lived at 235 East Twenty-second Street.

Manhattan Alterations 1st Ave. 826-38: to 1-story offices and laundry; Wilson Co, Inc. 818 1st Ave, owner; E. Palmer, architect; cost $15,000. 5th Ave, 1,006: to 6-story educational building; American Museum of Natural History. Columbus Ave and 72d St, owner; E. Kebbon, architect; cost $20,000.

John Murray Begg, a former Harvard sculler and boxer, class of '24, received yesterday a silver medal to help him remember a morning in January, 1937, when, clad in evening clothes, he plunged into the East River to save a woman from drowning.

The government will have to spend [Pound]2,410,500 more on the navy during 1938 in addition to [Pound]123,707,000 already provided, according to a supplementary estimate issued today. Out of the new appropriation [Pound]1,773,000 will be used to begin construction on two battleships, seven cruisers, one aircraft carrier, three submarines and a number of miscellaneous craft.
The Dutchess County Pomona Grange has voted to ask Governor Lehman for an investigation of what the grange said were "rising relief costs" in President Roosevelt's home county.

Making his thirtieth rescue when he pulled a homeless Negro from the Hudson River yesterday afternoon, Patrolman William G. Neumann of the Police Marine Division maintained his record of "never losing a person" The had set out to save.
Owen Anderson of Hollywood, Calif., opened the French hardcourt tennis championships today by scoring a surprise victory over the French Davis Cup player, Pierre Pelizza. The score was 6-3, 6-3. 7-5.

Commencement exercises at Mis Fine's School will be held here tomorrow. Dr. Henry N. McCracken. president of Vassar College, will address the class. Twenty members of the graduating class and two post graduates will receive diplomas. Katherine B. Shippen, head of the school, will be in charge.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert White o? Mount Vernon, N. Y., and Myrtl Beach, S. C., have announced th engagement of their daughter, Mis? Margaret White, to Carl Howar? Meyer, son of Mrs. Amandus Meye. of Bronxville and the late Mr Meyer of Hamburg, Germany.

Establishment of what was described as the first Buddhist Church in this State and one of the first in the eastern part of the country was revealed yesterday with the announcement that this religious group had purchased a home on the West Side of Manhattan foruse as a place of worship and as an educational center.

With cheers for "those who are about to leave us," the Naval Academy sent another class of its sons to bluewater service today as President Roosevelt urged the 435 graduates to broaden their knowledge of all factors in modern civilization.

Announcement by Schenley Products Company of the closing today of its Stagg plant at Frankfort, as part of a program including three closings elsewhere, revealed that few of the State's sixty-seven distilleries are operating. Fifty-sevenhave closed since Jan. 1.

The development of a new technique which makes it possible to diagnose with greater accuracy the disorders of the intestinal tract, including cancer, was described yesterday by Dr. Moses Paulson of the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine at the closing session of the annual convention of the National Society for the Advancement of Gastroenterology.

Out of the varied disputes which arise between landlords and tenants, two-'court decisions of unusual interest bearing on tenement rent payments were announced here yesterday. Both rulings favored the tenant.

LONDON, June 2.--S. B. Kagan, the Russian delegate to the NonIntervention Committee, today reported definite modifications of the uncompromising attitude his country had taken last week regarding the new British proposals for the withdrawal of the "volunteers" from Spain and the cutting off of supplies of munitions from both parties in the civil war.

A rock-bottom minimum wage of 25 cents an hour was one of the major suggestions laid today before a Senate-House conference committee struggling to reconcile differences on wage-hour legislation. No industry affected by the bill would receive exemptions from this figure.
The Reichsbank's statement as of June 1 shows bal the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of I marks;

The rumor that has been going around in fishing circles to the effect that there are "only" small weakfish in Peconic Bay is certainly without foundation. We went out there yesterday to see for ourselves, and, although there are plenty of small fish, there are enough big ones to make the fishing as interesting as any angler could desire.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 2, unless specified: At Philadelphia: Brooks, Childs, Fox, Gilmer, Williamson. Antares, Canal Zone to San Diego. Bushnell, Survey Area to Coco Solo. Charleston, at Corpus Christi.

Page Power Company, Luray, Va., has filed an application under the Public Utility Holding Company Act for exemption from the requirement of filing a declaration for the issuance of 1,400 shares of no-par value common stock for $70,000 to Republic Service Corporation, of which it is a subsidiary.

MANHATTAN BERKELHAMMER, ASHER D. (May 23). Estate, more than $20,000. To Fanny Berkelhammer, widow, executrix, 160 W. 95th St., residue. BRADT, KATE K. (May 24). Estate, more than $10,000. To Ahrevia W. Monahahn, niece, executrix, 706 Riverside Drive; Catherine Plastow, niece, 20 Laurel Hill Terrace; Harry Jordon, nephew, 50 W. 105th St., one-third residue each.
Cleveland's poor relief administration was criticized today as lax and wasteful in a special examiner's report by Joseph T. Ferguson, State Auditor.

In his own handwriting President Roosevelt has written to President Howe of Hampton Institute this note concerning the reproduciton of Washington's desk made in the institute trade school and presented to Mrs. Roosevelt and the President when she made the recent anniversary address here.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Frank B. Eddy of Worchester, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Rosamond Eddy, to Alvin M. Josephy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin M. Josephy of 245 East Seventy-second Street. The wedding will take place in this city early next month.

A check for $1,432, representing a refund of the sales tax levied by the city on the proceeds received by Neysa McMein of 2 West Sixty-seventh Street, from publications for reproductions of her drawings, was received by her yesterday.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures in l many cases are subject to final adjustment.

In spite of Japan's shortage of steel, occasioned by growing war needs, the South Manchuria Railway will continue a vigorous new building program for at least another three years, announces its vice president, Takuichi Ohmura.

Under dictatorships women, "in only too true measure, resume the status of serfs and chattels,". Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, said today in his baccalaureate address to the graduating class of New Jersey College for Women.

THE PIRATES OF PENZANCE. an operetta in two acts. Libretto by W. . Gilbert. Score by Arthur Sullivan. Staged by Edwin T. Emery. Orchestra directed by Henry W. Meyer. Revived by the Federal Theatre Project.

Although paying a handsome tribute to Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain personally and to Britain generally for concluding the April 16 agreement with Italy, Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano today stressed very emphatically that the whole Italian foreign policy was based on collaboration with Germany and with the "strong and noble Japanese people."

Miss Helena de Kay Gilder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rodman Gilder of 108 East Eighty-second Street, and Dr. Robert Allan Phillips of this city obtained a marriage license yesterday at the Municipal Building. They will be married on Thursday at the home in Syosset, L. I., of Miss Gilder's parents.

Joey Fontana, 126, Bensonhurst, knocked out Sammy Crocetti, 127, South Brooklyn, in two minutes of the third round of a scheduled eight-round feature bout at the Fort Hamilton Arena last night before a crowd of 2,800 persons.

The two-acre estate of Florence Oberlaender, at 6 Avon Road, Larchmont Ridge, Larchmont, has been sold to Milton Gladstone, New York attorney. The residence is a large English-type building of stone. Mr. Gladstone plans to make it his permanent home. George Howe, Inc., broker, arranged the sale.

After ignoring "repeated written and oral representations" made by the American Ambassador at Tokyo, the Japanese Government has made a significantly prompt reply to a firm note of the State Department demanding immediate restoration to their rightful owners of American properties and institutions held by Japanese military authorities in the occupied zones in China.
To the surprise of a great many, including the owner and trainer, Handcuff was beaten in the $12,675 Coaching Club American Oaks yesterday at Belmond Park by Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords's Creole Maid.

Turpentine firm, 22-22 1/4 c; sales 35 barrels; receipts 562 barrels; shipments 150 barrels; stock 35,315 barrels. Resin firm; sales 411 barrels; receipts 2,909 barrels; shipments 100 barrels; stock 119,637 barrels.

Dr. Robert Berman, senior labor economist in the Division of Social Research, Works Progress Administration, died on Tuesday at midnight after a long illness. His age was 41. Burial took place today in Quincy, Mass., the family home.

Long Mrs. Island retained the Golf Illustrated Trophy when its team of women players tallied 20 1/2 points against 17 for New Jersey and 7 1/2 for Westchester in the intersectional championship matches today at the Century Country Club.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Schwarz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer H. Schwarz, to Walter T. Rittenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rittenberg of New York, took place here this afternoon at the home of her parents. The Rev. Dr. Nathan Stern of New York performed the ceremony.

NEWARK, N. J., June 2.--Jersey City ministers and hail owners who testify against Mayor Frank Hague in the C. I. O. "free speech" case will receive the protection of the court against intimidation, Federal Judge William Clark announced from the bench today.
Secrettary of the Treasury Morgenthau today. called the foreign trade of the United States "the only bright spot in the business picture."

John Thomas Smith, Catholic layman who was honored, by. Pope Pius XI less than a week. before his death on May 21, left an estate estimated at nearly $3,000,000 and no will, it was revealed yesterday in Surrogate's Court when his, nearest kin applied for administration:

Corporations were urged, yesterday by former Governor Alfred E. Smith to make the financing of social services "a part of their business," lest government step in and force them to assume the burden through increased taxes at double the cost of private charity.

As a result of irregularities in the administration of the city's morgues, formal charges have been lodged against William M. Ward, Superintendent of Mortuaries, who was suspended in February, and George F. Turner, his assistant, has been dismissed, it was announced early this morning by Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals.

New Yorkers may take pride in a tribute paid our city yesterday by Dr. Thomas Adams, British planning specialist and well known here as director of plans and surveys for the massive study made by the Committee on the Regional Plan of New York and Its Environs.

More and mroe the major policies of the New Deal are shaped and perfected in the back rooms of the White House. In periods of uncertainty the President charts his course after general consultation with other high officials.

Miss Eleanor Greenway, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Greenway of Syosset, L. I., was married to Dr. Lester C. Huested of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred P. Huested of Glen Falls, N. Y., yesterday in the Church of the Transfiguration. The rector, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray., officiated.
Temporary broad changes, due to the delivery yesterday of the new Dominion of Canada $140,000,000 cash and conversion loan, were noted today in the Bank of Canada's weekly statement.

The veil of obscurity which hitherto has enveloped seventeen Central Park Zoo animals will be removed. this afternoon when a hundred or more public scnool children participate in the joyous ceremony of providing them with names.

Samuel Insull Jr. received aggregate remuneration of $51,041 as assistant to the chairman of Commonwealth Edison Company in 1937, the company's annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission showed today.

The government plans to introduce a bill at this session of Parliament encouraging private employers to give, to both industrial and farm laborers, vacations with pay, Ernest Brown, Minister of Labor, announced in the House of Commons today.
A bill containing amendments to the Walsh - Healey act, which would cover most Federal contracts, was favorably reported today by the House Judiciary Committee.

Insanity among the divorced is four times as frequent as among the general population, according to a study presented yesterday at the annual meeting of the Eugenics Research Association.at the American Museum of Natural History.

A less. than seasonal decline in lumber production last week raised the adjusted index to 60.1 from 58.7. This compares with 95.8 for the week ended May 29, 1987. Shipments and orders were also lower for the week, according to the Special reports wired to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Federal Judge Murray Hulbert imposed yesterday prison sentences ranging from eighteen months to two years and fines of $5,000 on seven of twelve defendants who had been found guilty of conspiracy to flood New York, Louisiana and Texas with narcotics.

Captain Nathanael Greene Herreshoff, known in the yachting world as "the Wizard of Bristol" for his designing and building of America's Cup defenders, died this morning at his Bristol home. He had been ill for a year. His age was 90.

The report of the Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on April 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income after all operating expenses, taxes and charges, of $3,754,415.
The railroad relief bill, framed as an amendment to the RFC Act, is stymied in the committees of Congress, and only through the influence of the President can it be rescued.

A new step in the principle of rocket-ship control was disclosed today in Eden Valley, the huge saucer-shape outdoor laboratory near here where Dr. Robert H. Goddard of Clark University is working on the world's first sounding rocket.

The twelve-story Fitzgerald Building and the George M. Cohan Theatre, which occupy the southeast corner of Broadway and Fortythird Street, were bought in at auction yesterday by the New York Life Insurance Company, the plaintiff, on a nominal bid off $100,000.

Batsmen did not find rungetting easy in today's play of the cricket test trial between England and "The Rest." After disposing of their opponents for 298, England's players lost four wickets for 204 runs.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling;

The National Labor Relations Board held today that about 125 employes of the Electric Boat Company at Groton, Conn., who engaged in a one-day sit-down strike in February, 1937, and who were fined about $3 each for trespass, should be reinstated as the company had violated the Federal Labor Relations Act.

Temporary Assignments INSPECTOR-George W. Heitzman, 15th Division, assigned in command of the Borough of Queens, in addition to his other duties, for 3 days, from 8 A. M., June 1, during the absence of Deputy Chief Inspector with leave.

Fred J. Hull, who was convicted as the hired killer in the Drukman murder case, and who was to have been sent to the electric chair tonight at Sing Sing prison, received a commutation of his sentence this morning from Governor Lehman.

Lever Brothers Company, Cambridge, Mass., has entered into a stipulation with the Federal Trade Commission agreeing to discontinue certain misleading representations complained of by the commission, it was announced today.

A man who entered their apartment with a key yesterday morning shot Anne Picone, 16 years old, and Josephine Martini, 33, as they slept and then fled from the building at 37-75 Sixty-fourth Street, Woodside, Queens.

Miss Hildegarde Graham and her fiance, Robert D. van Roijen, were e guests of honor at a dinner given last night in the Pierre Roof by Baron Max E. Gevers. Also in the e party were the Misses Jeanie Van Norden, Phyllis and Eileen Gil- n lespie, Virginia French, Marian Kingsland and Valerie Graham;

George M. Cohan and "I'd Rather Be Right" are in the "last weeks" of their Broadway run, the Sam H. Harris office announces; while no official closing date has been set, it is believed that the show will stay at the Music Box until July 4 or so. Then a vacation for Mr.
Governor Sir Edward Brandis Denham of Jamaica died here today after an abdominal operation on Tuesday at the Public General Hospital. He was 62 years old.

The rival Walker Cup captains, without previous collaboration, today simultaneously handed to Henry Gullen, secretary of the Royal and Ancient Golf Club, their respective pairings and line-ups for tomorrow's Scotch foursomes.

Ten mine workers lost their lives today and five others were seriously injured when a gas explosion occurred in the Red Ash vein of the Butler Colliery, operated by the Volpe Coal Company in Pittston township.

The Cardinals made free with the offerings of three Philadelphia hurlers today to win their second straight game from the Phillies, 12 to 5. Enos Slaughter and Joe Medwick teamed to lead the seventeen-hit attack.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:
Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Binder of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Ann Binder, to Edwin Spurr Hall, son of Mrs; Alfred Bates Hall of Lakeville, Conn.,

The Bancamerica Company and the American Trust Company, both of San Francisco, purchased yesterday $3,000,000 of registered warrants of the State of California at 0.75 per cent, plus a premium of $1,416. The warrants will be dated June 6 and will fall due on or about Aug. 31, 1938.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Wyckoff Brower of Plainfield have sent out invitations for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Euphemia Brower to Charles Todd Newberry Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Newberry of Irvington-on-Hudson, N. Y. The ceremony will be performed on June 23 in the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church, this city, by the Rev. Dr. John J. Moment, the minister.

Universal today announced a second picture for Charlie McCarthy and his sponsor, Edgar Bergen, to follow the almost completed "Letter of Introduction." He will be seen later in the year in "Charlie McCarthy, Detective," an original tale by Robertson White and Darrell Ware.

New York's first International Film Festival will open on July 1 and continue through Aug. 31 at the Fifth Avenue Playhouse, according to an announcement yesterday by Martin J. Lewis, operator of the theatre. Forty-four outstanding films representing the cinematic tastes of sixteen countries will be shown.

The lease of the land in the three blocks between Forty-eighth and Fifty-first Streets, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues part of the site of Rockefeller Center, which is held by Rockefeller Center, Inc., from the trustees of Columbia University, under a lease dated Oct. 1, 1928, has been amended so that the net annual rental during the year commencing June 1, 1938, as fixed .by the lease will be reduced by the amount of $500.000.

Peruvian troops on the border attacked a small group of Ecuadorcan soldiers, taking prisoner one officer and two soldiers, according to the newspaper Prensa tonight. [Official reports said two Ecuadorean soldiers were killed, according to The Associated Press.]

The International Tin Committee reduced today the quarterly quota of free export contingents from 55 to 45 per cent. The 10 per cent surplus resulting from quota reduction will be held in a pool controlled by the cartel as a price "buffer."

A jury of eight women and four men convicted Mrs. Julia M. Barker, once wealthy Detroit real estate operator, of manslaughter today, for the fatal shooting Jan. 15 of Mrs. Edith Mae Cummings, her business associate.

GOVERNORS ISLAND 2d Lt. Sterling Ronal, Inf.-Res. (temporary address: West Virginia University. Morgantown, W Va.), 200 West 57th St., New York, N. Y., First Division, is ordered to active duty, effective June 17, at Fort Knox, Ky., for training. Date of rank: June 17, 1938. He will revert to an-inactive status on June 30.

Brig. Gen. Walter C. Short was transferred by the War Department today from command of the Second Infantry Brigade at Fort Ontario, N. Y., to command of the First Infantry Brigade at Fort Wadsworth, succeeding Brig. Gen. Laurence Halstead, who retired on May 31.

The Mexican Government is planning to hire Texas and Oklahoma oil operators to drill Mexican oil lands on a contract basis, 'it was reported here following the sudden departure of Miguel Aleman, Governor of Veracruz, Mexico's biggest oil-producing State.
Near-by waters, the ocean, the coastal bays and the Sound are now yielding shelifish--scallops clams--and lobster and soft shell crabs in height of the season quantities.

During the week ended June 1 member bank reserve balances increased $29,000,000. Additions to member bank reserve arose from a decrease of $90,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and increases of $10,000,000 in Reserve bank credit, $13,000.000 in gold stock and $2,000,000 in Treasury currency, offset in part by increases of $76,000,000 in money in ciyculation, $6,000,000 in Treasury cash and $5,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

A class of forty girls will be graduated tonight at Finch Junior College, 61 East Seventy-seventh Street, at the first commencement the institution has held as a junior college. Professor Harry A. Overstreet of City College will give the commencement address. Jessica G.

A long delayed invitation to address the Constitutional Convention has been declined by Governor Lehman with thanks, it was disclosed today. Although the matter has been under discussion since the last month of the recent legislative session, the invitation was not delivered to the Governor by the Republican leader-' ship of the convention until Tuesday of this week.

Park Avenue and other East Side locations attracted many of the new tenants listed in the reports of apartment rentals submitted yesterday. A suite of eleven rooms and four baths at 1,040 Park Avenue was leased to George A. Percy by Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc.,

Representing the first attempt on a national scale to gather factual data From retail stores on the information customers wish to see on labels on merchandise, a preliminary report was issued yesterday by the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, and is now being sent to member stores.

BOSTON, June 2 (AP).--Jim Bagby Jr., pitching in masterly fashion, scored his third victory of the season for the Red Sox today when his team-mates pounded three St. Louis pitchers for fifteen hits and a 6-1 verdict.

Today's tidings from the American Rhineland should iron out at least one furrow among the many that have been creasing the brows of Larry MacPhail and Burleigh Grimes. For the Dodgers broke a three-game losing streak by beating Bill McKechnie's Reds, 11 to 5.
Meeting, Home Economics Bureau of the New York State Department of Education, Hotel Commodore, 9:30 A. M.

Miss Helen Pedersen of Stamford and-Miss Millicent Hirsh of New York won the Women's New Eng- t land doubles tennis championship today by defeating Miss Argyll Rice of Hartford and Miss Edith Moore of Montclair, N. J., 1--6, 6-3, 6-2, in a blazing final match.

Bribery, conspiracy and the falsification of WPA records in a fraud W that cost the government at least $24,000 are charged in an indictment returned yesterday by a Federal grand jury against ten defendants, including a WPA official and a WPA employee.

Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin has been designated by the Appellate Division, First Department, to try all suits for the reduction in real estate tax valuations in Manhattan and the Bronx, it was announced yesterday.
Graduating exercises for the two elementary units, of the Ethical Culture Schools were held yesterday; with eighty-five boys and girls receiving certificates.

The ability gained at college to adapt academic knowledge to the solution of individual problems and those of the world at large will be the true test of the education obtained at Barnard College, Helen Raebeck, a graduating senior, said in her address at the traditional ivy ceremony held for the thirty-fourth time yesterday at Milbank Hall on the campus.
The Giants, sorely pressed for a second baseman, offered today to trade Wall, Berger, outfielder, and Lou Chiozza, second baseman, to the Pirates for Pep Young.

Several West Side dwellings figured in the realty transactions reported by Manhattan brokers yesterday. Among the properties involved was the four-story brownstone house at 14 West Eighty-fifth Street, which changed hands for the first time in twenty-nine years.

After the announcement yesterday that the International Tin Committee in Paris had fixed the tinproducing quota fpr the third quarter 45 per cent of standard tonnages, quotations for the metal on the New York Commodity Exchange, Inc., advanced sharply. Final prices showed net gains of 100 to 110 points.

Clearings at banks this week were curtailed by Memorial Day, and total Transactions again receded in the week-to-week comparison, causing the twenty-ninth consecutive dip from the level of the corresponding week of last year.

Arthur E. Bestor Jr., Yale '30, of New York City, Assistant Professor of History in Teachers College, Columbia University, has been awarded the John Addison Porter Prize of $500 at Yale University for his essay, "American Phalanxes: A Study of Fourierist Socialism in the United States, With Special Reference to the Movement in Western New York."

The Rev. J. Harvey Murpny or Hudson, N. Y., was elected president of the general synod of the Reformed. Church in America at the annual conference of the group which opened here today. Four hundred' delegates and members from all parts of the nation are registered for the six-day session.
Dr. Joseph A. Lanahan, for the last three years medical supervisor of the New York City Hospital on Welfare Island, died here today after an illness of two. weeks. He was 64 years old.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, his two brothers, Philip and William, and Frank C. Walker, former chairman of the National Emergency Council, were among the guests yesterday at the graduation exercises of the Marymount School, 1,028 Fifth Avenue, where Mr. Farley and Mr. Walker had daughters in the graduating class.

Mrs. Placidia White Knowlton of Boston and Thomasville, Ga. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robb White of Thomasville and former wife of John Knowlton, was married here today to Henry Field curator of the Field Museum in Chicago.
An agreement on a meaure establishing voluntary arbitration of maritime labor disputes and prohibiting foreign construction of American vessels was reached today by Senate and House conferees.
The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended June 1 were announced today: LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Awalt, T. Y., the Modoc, to command the Nemesis, as commanding officer, July 1.

Rollie Stiles, veteran right-hander, pitched the Jersey City Giants to their second straight victory over Baltimore today. The score was 4 to 1. Stiles limited the Orioles to five hits, three of which came in the first two innings. He fanned three and did not issue a base on balls. It was his fifth triumph of the season.

The Cleveland Indians rallied in the last three innings today to beat the Athletics, 10 to 5. evening the series at a game apiece. Successive home runs by Hal Trosky and Ken Keltner, first up in the seventh, broke a 3-3 tie and started the Indians on their way to triumph.

Neville Travers Borton, who was for many years in charge of the Egyptian postoffice, died yesterday at the age of 67. During the World War he served in the army under General Sir Edmund Allenby, who thought so highly of Mr. Borton he directed him to lead the triumphal procession entering Jerusalem after its capture in 1917.
Engineering construction awards made last month dropped 22 per cent below those for the same month of last year, according to The Engineering News-Record.
The Scudder School will graduate 104 students this morning at its forty-third annual commencement, to be held in the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street.

Commencement exercises for a graduating class of twenty-two girls were held yesterday at the Dalton Schools, 108 East Eighty-ninth Street. Dr. Hu Shih, Chinese philosopher, was the speaker. Miss Helen Parkhurst, headmistress of the school. presented the diplomas.
Mrs. Earl A. Ross of Bonnie Briar won the low gross prize in the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association one-day tournament at the Hudson River Country Club today after a tie.

Miss Katharine Leigh Elkington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Le Roy Grape Elkington of this place, was married tonight in St. Luke's Episcopal Church here to H. Ezra Eberhardt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ezra Eberhardt of Maplewood. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Luke M. White.
An address on "Positivist and Realist Currents in the Philosophy of Physics," a general and clear review of the progress of contemporary physical science, was read here today

Declaring that he believed there was no danger of war in Europe, Ambassador Fulvio Suvich of Italy, an an address before a group of bankers and business men at the offices of Calvin Bullock, New York investment firm at 1 Wall Street, defended yesterday the trend of Italian economic policy toward selfsufficiency.
The Scudder School will graduate 104 students this morning at its forty-third annual commencement, to be held in the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street.

Commencement exercises for a graduating class of twenty-two girls were held yesterday at the Dalton Schools, 108 East Eighty-ninth Street. Dr. Hu Shih, Chinese philosopher, was the speaker. Miss Helen Parkhurst, headmistress of the school. presented the diplomas.

Malcolm P. Ferguson, vice president of the Eclipse Machine Company of Elmira, N. Y., a subsidiary of Bendix Aviation Corporation, was named today vice president and general manager of Bendix Products Corporation here. He succeeds Victor W. Kliesrath, formerly vice president of engineering and general manager.

Premier Bela Imredy spoke on the problem of the German minority in Hungary in Parliament today, saying that there were now two categories, one that respects the laws and interests of the State and another, he was sorry to say, that disseminates "Aryan" propaganda and engages in extremist activities.

With Freddy Schieh outriding Ken McCombs in the drive down the stretch, the Medway Stables' Motley today won the Lafayette Purse, mile and a sixteenth feature at Suffolk Downs to pay $14.60 for a $2 mutuel ticket.

The highly geared Yankee machine found pitchers and hitters working with commendable efficiency yesterday as the New Yorkers took both. ends of a doubleheader with the Tigers at the Stadium, thereby gaining valuable ground on the American Leagueleading Indians and shaking loose from the second place pursuit of the Senators.

Fifty-five doctors of medicine and twenty-five nursing graduates will receive their degrees and diplomas this afternoon at the seventy-eighth commencement exercises of the New York Medical College and Flower Hospital School of Nursing at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Alma Meighen, niece of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred H. Caspary of 17 West Sixty-eighth Street, to Marvin Buchanan Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs., Oliver Edward Davis of the Bronx, took place yesterday noon in the Church of the Transfiguration. The Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray performed the ceremony.

Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, attributed much of Mayor Frank Hague's power to his control of the WPA in Jersey City in a speech yesterday before the City College chapter of the American Student Union.

Those surprising Bees moved within a game and a half of second place and within four of the National League leading Giants today by defeating the Cubs, 6 to 2. The victory was the Bees' twelfth in their last fifteen games.
The recent series of mass arrests here ended today with the arrest of a few violators of currency regulations.
Law today must work with great groups, Adolph A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, told forty-five graduates at the commencement exercises of the Cornell Law School today.

Greater reverence. for the laws of God and man was urged yesterday afternoon by Cardinal Hayes at the commencement exercises of the Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart held in the new gymnasium on the campus at Convent Avenue and 133d Street.
Several properties in Brooklyn, including a factory and houses, were sold yesterday by the estate of Virgihia A. Kleine through Mozor Co., brokers.

When elementary and high school diplomas are awarded at commencement exercises this month, sixty "bedside" ceremonies will be held for students who have been unable to attend their regular classes, Dr. Adela J. Smith, assistant director of health education, in charge of the, division of physically handicapped children, disclosed yesterday.

This week cotton sold at 7.71 cents a pound, which our financial pages report to be the lowest level in history in terms of the old gold dollar. In June, 1932, the price declined to 5 cents, but on the gold value now in effect this would be equivalent to 8.45 cents.

Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Lorillard Barbey of Tuxedo Park and Palm Beach are at the Plaza. Mme. Jan de Chelminski of Carlton House will sail today on the Statendam for Europe, where she will remain until the early Autumn.
In "Twilight in Vienna," an early Fall publication on the Houghton Mifflin list, Willi Frischauer tells the story of his country from the end of the World War to the recent Anschluss.

Despite determined opposition by minority shareholders and an attempted injunction, the Texas Corporation ST succeeded today in obtaining control of the McColl-Frontenac Oil Company of Canada and electing its own directorate.
Prime Minister Michael Savage today told a deputation from the Defense League that, in the event of war, conscription in New Zealand would not start with man power.

James L. Crider who has been with Lord Taylor for five years, recently assistant glove buyer, has joined the Hochschild, Kohn Co. department store in Baitimore as employment manager, beginning Monday, June 6.

Driving toward a final vote on the threebillion-dollar Relief-Recovery Bill, the Senate today rejected the amendment of the Appropriations Committee to prohibit PWA financing of municipal power systems which would compete with privately owned plants.

Emil A. Gallman of Newark, secretary of the New Jersey Building and Loan League, said today that reorganizations, mergers, consolidations and eliminations had reduced the league from 1,563 units in 1932 to 1,392 now.

Holders of fractional scrip certificates for the first mortgage 5 per cent convertible bonds, the 5 per cent convertible preferred stock and the common stock of the Cosden Oil Corporation will be notified today that the securities reserved against these certificates have been sold and that the net proceeds from the sale are now on deposit with the company's agents for distribution.

A bill, prepared by experts of the Treasury and representatives of the Attorneys General of twenty-six States to prevent retroactive Federal income taxes on 780,000 State employes throughout the country, was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Lonergan.

Thaddeus R. Benson, president of the Chicago Stock Exchange, said today in his annual report that there would be no revival of activity in the security markets nor a resumption of business recovery until the public had regained its "normal faith in the economic and political future."

United Office and Professional Workers of America, Local 16, In 239 4th Ave; Ernest Mills, lingerie novelties, additional space in 20 E 30th St; Associated Toy and Doll Co, in 186 5th Ave; Carstens, Linnekin Wilson, Inc, brokers. Samuel Drecktor, real estate, in 342 Madison Ave.: Dr. Bruno Kaufman and Dr. J.

Francis Edward Powell, president of the American Chamber of Commerce at London, England, died here tonight of a heart attack while visiting relatives. His age was 70. Mr. Powell, a native of Cincinnati, had made his home in London since 1901. He was a former chairman of the Anglo-American Oil Company.

Charles Neuls is the new marbles shooting champion of the five boroughs of New York City.
