He has a brand-new sweatshirt bearing the green sycamore leaf insignia of the Park Department and a gold medal to prove it, Charles, who is 12 years old and lives at 581; East 140th Street in the Bronx, won his title yesterday afternoon in the final play-offs at Heckscher Playground, Central Park.

PRINCETON, Fla., June 2.--Numerous reports of a "break" in the Jimmy Cash kidnapping case caused recurring flurries of excitement tonight in this village while some 2,000 men searched in vain for trace of the 5-year-old child over an area of eighty square miles.
Spanish Government and Insurgent troops fought steadily today along the Teruel - Mediterranean highway without appreciable gains.

Directors of the Locke Steel Chain Company yesterday declared an extra dividend of 10 cents on its common stock in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 30 cents. Other dividend announcements made yesterday follow:
Stocks closed steady and mixed after slight early gains; utilities higher, leading industrials fractionally lower; turnover, 457,530 S shares.
" To what extent hesitation among buyers because of the price situation may have influenced the downward trend of business in the last two weeks is difficult to determine," Iron Age says this week.

A sit-down. strike of American seamen, called suddenly yesterday morning, remained in effect nine hours, with resulting delay in the loading of ships throughout the harbor and in the departure of three ships carrying mail to the Near East, Central America and Puerto Rico.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company paid $4,000,000 for the property of the New York Catholic Protectory in the Bronx to provide the major portion of the site for a vast garden apartment community, it was learned yesterday.

In the Church of the Ascension here this afternoon Miss Betty Louise Main, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David John Main of this city, was married to Henry Wilder Keyes Jr. of Boston and North Haverhill, N. H. The Rev. Henry S. Foster performed the ceremony.

Lyn wood (Schoolboy) Rowe who was the backbone of the pennant drives, of the Tigers in 1934 and 1935, passed out of the major leagues yesterday. The big righthander, who moved up from Beaumont in the Texas League to a hero's role for two years, went quietly back to Beaumont on option.

Thaddeus R. Benson, president of the Chicago Stock Exchange, said today in his annual report that there would be no revival of activity in the security markets nor a resumption of business recovery until the public had regained its "normal faith in the economic and political future."

Mr. Powell, a native of Cincinnati, had made his home in London since 1901. He was a former chairman of the Anglo-American Oil Company.

He has a brand-new sweatshirt bearing the green sycamore leaf insignia of the Park Department and a gold medal to prove it, Charles, who is 12 years old and lives at 581; East 140th Street in the Bronx, won his title yesterday afternoon in the final play-offs at Heckscher Playground, Central Park.

PRINCETON, Fla., June 2.--Numerous reports of a "break" in the Jimmy Cash kidnapping case caused recurring flurries of excitement tonight in this village while some 2,000 men searched in vain for trace of the 5-year-old child over an area of eighty square miles.
Spanish Government and Insurgent troops fought steadily today along the Teruel - Mediterranean highway without appreciable gains.

Mrs. Dorothy Andrus of Stamford, Conn., only American woman entrant, won her first match in the French hard-court tennis championships today and Don Budge and Gene Mako, United States Davis Cup players, advanced in doubles without playing as the second round was completed.

Pension Investigation Questionnaire cards, in connection with the annual investigation of the widows on the pension rolls of this department, are forwarded this date to deputy chiefs for distribution to the battalion chiefs in whose districts the pensioners reside.

Realty activity stimulated by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's purchase of the Catholic Protectory grounds in the Bronx continued yesterday with. the sale by Frank Baumann of a vacant plot 145 by 143 feet at the junction of Unionport Road and Olmstead Avenue. The plot is a block south

The President's plans have prevailed in the Senate and both branches of Congress have now given their approval to another experiment in Government "pump-priming" to be financed with more borrowed money. Time alone will show whether this new spending will generate a temporary boom or whether the prospect of

The marriage of Miss Anna deBaun Foss Jewett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. D. Lawrence Jewett 2d, to Thomas Howard Wolf of New York, son of Mrs. Louis Ellinger of Valley Cottage and of James Stanley Wolf of New York, took place here tonight at the home of her parents.

Saying that "God is a reactionary" and that "nature decrees relentless competition," George B. Cutten, president of Colgate 'University, last night attacked social security, equality and governmentfostered cooperation as contrary to the biological law of survival of the fittest.

Madison St. 28, 24x125: David Steckler to Rosa Ragone, 5 Madison St; consideration $5,000, foreclosure. Mercer St, 29, 24.8x100: Georgette De Grove Fahnestock to Elisa Imperatrice, 90 Thompson St ($4).

Strapping Charley Whitehead of Plainfield and Mike Cestone of Branch Brook, one of Uncle Sam's mail men who travels a route in Montclair, are the two who will battle it out over a thirty-six-hole route on the Canoe Brook course tomorrow for the New Jersey State amateur golf crown.

Mrs. Noah Doreen Lynch Wyckoff of 125 East: Seventy-fourth Street, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur William Lynch and widow of Clarence Wyckoff of this city, was married yesterday afternoon to Charles Unger Caesar, also of New York, in the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas. The Rev. Robert B.

Serious developments behind the barriers of secrecy surrounding the German spy inquiry were indicated last night when United States Attorney Lamar Hardy arrested as material witnesses two captains of allied German steamship lines, along with a one-armed designer of United States Navy destroyers.
William Forbes Haynes, former member of the New, York Stock Exchange, died of a heart ailment this morning in his home here. His age was 42.
Treasury officials said today the fiscal year closing this month would have the smallest Federal deficit since 1931, although the new spending program probably would triple the shortage next year.

The marriage of Miss Pauline Metcalf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace B. Metcalf of this city to Francis Richard Crave, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Crave of Salem Centre, N. Y., took -place this afternoon at the North Avenue Presbyterian Church here. The Rev.
Spanish Insurgents fought desperately today to hold positions won at a heavy cost of lives and munitions as the power of the government's defenses blocked their Teruel-Mediterranean offensive.

Refusing to reveal his accomplices and resenting charges that he was one of a clever gang of forgers, Bertram M. Campbell, 51 years old, a former security salesman, coolly maintained silence yesterday in General Sessions as he was sentenced to serve a term of five to ten years in Sing Sing for his part in a $150,000 bank forgery plot.

Sarah A. Venerable, a social science teacher at the Eastern School here for more than thirty years, died today in Pa'il Kimball Hospital, Lakewood, N. J. Miss Venerable was stricken while visiting a cousin, Mrs. Edwin B. Hopkinson of Toms River, N. J., with whom she formerly resided in Maplewood.

Mayor La Guardia asked the Cities Committee of the Constitutional Convention today to write into a new home rule amendment several safeguards to protect the city against encroachment on its powers by the State. At the same time the Mayor repeatedly told the committee that the "simple, concise" language of the bill sponsored by Howard C. Kelly, Republican of New York, appealed to him.

Two dealers testified before the Federal Trade Commission yesterday that cement companies in the New York area refused to sell them Portland cement, one after he established a truck company to buy at the factories and reduce his retail price and the other because he imported foreign cement.

The city asked the Public Works Administration yesterday for a loan and grant of $70,850,000 to build a vehicular tunnel from the Battery to Hamilton Avenue in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn. In transmitting plans for the project to Colonel M. E. Gilmore, regional director of the Federal

The Consolidated Gas Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore, after a meeting of its board of directors yesterday, announced that the company's forthcoming issue of $18,000,000 of 30-year 3 1/4 per cent first refunding mortgage bonds, Series 0, had been sold to six insurance companies at private sale.

Mrs. George Farr Oberge of Upsala, Haverford, Pa., has announced to friends here the engagement of her daughter, Miss Boudinot Atterbury Oberge, to Lieutenant Charles Hansford Kendall, U. S. N., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Kendan of Baltimore.

Net profit of the Reynolds Metals Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries for the quarter ended on April 2 amounted to $157,603 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges, but before surtax on undistributed income.

In a four-to-one decision the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the Manufacturers Trust Company must answer a suit for $42,865 based on oral agreement it is alleged to have made in 1924 to repurchase at cost securities it sold to Martin Rothschild.

The twentieth anniversary of the rectorship of the Rev. Lucius A. Edelblute at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Apostles, Ninth Avenue and Twenty-eighth Street, will be celebrated at both the 11 A. M. and the 8 P. M. services tomorrow.

Miss Isabel Mary La Monte, daugh:er of Mrs. M. Brewster La Monte of this place, and George Vaill La Monte of Bound Brook, was maried tonight in St. Peter's Episcoal Church here to Stephen Stuart car Chamberlain , son of Dr. and Mrs. Aims R. Chamberlain of Maplewood.

Modern bathroom fixtures installed by Mrs. Calvin Coolidge in her new home were ordered disconnected today by the city plumbing inspector, Carl Eddy. As a result Mrs. CoolIdge may be delayed in moving in. The inspector said the fixtures failed to comply with an old local statute. Members of the Master

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,173,000 bales, against 1,203,000 a week ago, 1,197,000 two weeks ago, 1,196,000 three weeks ago and 917,000 a year ago; of which American 777,000 bales,

The Macy Thanksgiving parade design contest conducted for students of public, private and parochial schools in the city will close today. Designs for the three divisionsof the contest-balloons, floats and costumes-may be submitted in person at the contest headquarters on the fourth floor of the store up to 5:30 P. M. If mailed,

Theodore Kiendl submitted yesterday to the Appellate Division a report of his inquiry as a referee into the circumstances surrounding the substitution of the name Samuel W. Gilson for that of Simon W. Gerson, Communist aide to Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs, in a Municipal Court opinion delivered by Justice John J. O'Rourke.
This was the status of the legislative program today when Congress completed five months of the present session: Bills enacted--Tax revision, naval expansion, Federal aid for...

A "united front program" to combat the "inroads upon the business of cotton garment manufacturers" represented in the governmentfinanced cooperative project at Hightstown, N. J., was urged in a letter sent yesterday to 500 members of the industry by

Mrs. Marian Mayer, in 975 Park Ave, and Mrs. Charles Rosenthal, in 70 E 77th St, through Edgar Ellinger, Inc; Lucius Wasserman, through Associated Managers, Inc, in 451 West End Ave; Judge Leo B. Schwarz, through Pease Elliman, Inc, in 600 West End Ave; Frances R. Jaffin, broker.

THIS was at the breakfast table and just between Bing and Black Mike, otherwise known as Coach Miller and Manager Cochrane of the Detroit Tigers. Because of his sunburned face, his benevolent air and the fringe of- frostbitten hair that clings to his otherwise denuded sconce, the rich Red Sox with whom he used to labor gave Coach Miller the added nickname of "Father Divine."

Counsel for the C. I. O. arid the American Civil Liberties Union called Director of Public Safety Daniel J. Casey to the witness stand this afternoon as an "unfriendly' witness in their suit before Federal Judge William Clark for an omnibus injunction restraining the Hague administration from violating constitutional guarantees in opposing the C. I. O.

Speaking before seven Todhunter School graduates and about 300 friends and relatives who attended the commencement exercises yesterday, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt advised the students about to leave school not to "dry up by inaction," but to go out and get first-hand contact with conditions as they exist in the community.
In a somewhat more active market member trading in round lots for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange rose of 23.44 per cent of total volume in the week ended on May 7, compared with

Contracts for construction of four steel cargo steamships were awarded by the Maritime Commission today to the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company. They will be standard, steam propelled vessels, 435 feet long, of 13,900 tons displacement and 151/2 knots speed, for operation in foreign trade. They, will cost $2,080,000 each.

Davidson Ave. (11-2861) e s, 175 ft n of Featherbed Lane, 100x100; Fordboro Realty Corp to Tillie Youngstein, 1.760 Anthony Ave; mtg $146,000. Bailey Ave (12-3268), w s, 137 ft s of 234th St, 140x321; Chase National Bank to Catherine R. Kelley. 1 Parkman P1, Dorchester, Mass.

Drayton Cochran, son of the late Gifford A. Cochran, turfman and industrialist, was thanking his lucky star today that the second mate of a tanker was unable to sleep in his bunk as the ship steamed down Long Island Sound near the Long Island shore early last night.

With its $50,000 newspaper advertising campaign starting this month, the New York State Publicity Bureau is preparing to distribute more than 100,000 pamphlets. describing the State's attractions for visitors, according to Allan Reagan, director.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Any medical man or surgeon will tell you that the only way to cure or heal is to remove the primary cause of trouble. That makes sense, and so far as the trouble can be remedied or eliminated it works. But any compromise fails.

President Roosevelt has approved loan contracts totaling $57,577,000 for slum clearance projects in eight cities, including $3,643,000 for Buffalo. According to Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, these will provide new and decent housing at low cost for more than 44,000 slum dwellers.

Gloria Vanderbilt, who is now 14 years old, was graduated from the Greenville School, a pre-preparatory institution near here. this afternoon. Gloria, who completed the eighth form and won distinction in the study of French, joined the 200 pupils of her class and the lower forms in a program of field games. Greenville does not give diplomas.

The curiosity of a 7-month-old baby girl over a dangling aerial wire on a roof where she was getting an airing resulted in her death yesterday morning. She caught hold of the wire, slipped from her mother's arms and fell sixteen stories to a rear courtyard.

Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, called upon the American people in a speech here tonight for "strong and united" backing of a program to restore throughout the world the principles of "order under law." The rise of "international anarchy" and "savagery" makes urgent the need for action to reverse "the present disastrous trends," he declared.

As the members of the present first and third classes of midshipmen, about 1,100, embarked on the battleship squadron today for a Summer practice cruise which will take them to three European countries, they carried a warning from Rear Admiral Wilson Brown, superintendent, against "discussions of any matter which is the subject of political, religious or international controversy."
Federal agents fruitlessly ran down half a dozen-new leads in the kidnapping of James Bailey Cash Jr. today as search for the boy extended south to the tangled morasses of the mangrove keys.

A 4-year-old girl was found dead in bed in her home, unattended by her parents, at 955 Rossville Avenue, Rossville, on the west shore of Staten Island, at 9:45 o'clock last night. Across the chest of the child, Dolores Swincone, were six red welts, which indicated, the police said, that she had been beaten with a strap.

It might pay some of the advocates of the widespread doctrine that ever and ever higher wage rates are a sure recipe for recovery to learn what some of the best economists have written on the subject. One of the facts that economists have discovered over and over again is that when a commodity or a service is forced by

The Chinese military spokesman declined yesterday to say whether the Chinese would attempt to hold Kaifeng at all costs against the Japanese troops which for the second time in three weeks are almost in sight of the city's wall to. the south.

John R. Ridgway, chairman of the board of the Investors Syndicate, Minneapolis, died today at his home at the age of 52. Reared on a farm and educated in the public schools at Columbia, Mo., Mr. Ridgway and a group of associates in October, 1925, bought a controlling interest in the Investors Syndicate of Minneapolis and he was elected president.

Paramount Pictures, Inc., reported today that Marlene Dietrich, screen actress, received aggregate remuneration of $370,000 in 1937. The report to the Securities Commission also disclosed that Ernst Lubitsch, Paramount producer, received $260,833 and Claudette Colbert $248,055.

James Speyer, banker and philanthropist, plans to retire soon as head of the 101-year-old investment banking firm of Speyer Co., it was learned yesterday. Mr. Speyer, who will be 77 years old next month, plans to devote his time to his other interests.
Within the arched cupola of St. Joseph's oratory four men fell to death today as they worked at. the finishing touches of the great dome.

The third week of the trial of Harlan County coal operators and peace officers closed today as the ninetieth witness, a miner who said his skull had been dented by one of the deputy sheriffs on trial, stepped from the witness stand.

Exchange of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in May aggregated $22,410,426,189, a decrease of 6.7 per cent from the preceding month and of 15.8 from May of last year. It was the smallest turnover for a May since 1933.

Metropolitan Museum of Art, 11 A. M. "Pompeii: Rome's Hellenistic Heritage," Stuart M. Shaw. American Society for Race Tolerance "Inter-Racial Luncheon of One Thousand," Hotel Commodore, 12:30 P. M. Speakers: Bishop Francis J. McConnell, Representatives Bruce Barton, Joseph A. Gavagan, Samuel Dickstein and Emmanuel Celler, Mrs. Maria McLeod Bathune, Walter White, Professor Bernard D. N. Grebanier, Mrs. Dorothy Greiner.

A town house of unusual design on the East Side figured in a deal announced yesterday by brokers. It is the four-story American basement residence with black and white facade at 186 East Sixty-fourth Street on which Mrs. Tuckerman Draper, decorator, is said to have spent close to $200,000 when she erected It several years ago.

Miss Bethany Ann Beckwith, a photographer's model, and Winthrop Gardiner Jr., a descendant of Lord Lion Gardiner, who received a King's grant of Gardiner's Island in 1639. were married yesterday afternoon in the Central Presbyterian Church by the assistant pastor, the Rev. Jule Ayers.

Miss Martha'- Barrows Knowles, daughter of Mr. and-Mrs. Raymond L. Knowles of this place, was-married this evening to Victor John Pollock, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Francis Pollock of Springfield, Mass., in the Reformed Church here.

The administrative committee of the American Labor party refused approval yesterday of the Socialist party's request for admission of its members into the Labor party ranks. Further consideration of the situation was turned over to Alex Rose, Labor's State executive secretary.
Ward's Automotive Reports estimated today the current week's production of motor vehicles at 26,980 units, compared with 45,120 last week and 104,136 a year ago.

Advocates of dirigibles for military use lost the first round of an effort to appropriate funds for construction of a new one today when a House Appropriations subcommittee rejected President Roosevelt's recommendation that $500,000 be appropriated toward the $3,000,000 estimated necessary to begin construction.

Two splendid triumphs in hunter classes by the 4-year-old bay gelding Camp,' owned by Mrs. Norman K. Toerge of Locust Valley, L. I., were among the features as the annual two-day Tuxedo Park Horse Show opened today.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petition SAFFERMAN DESK CO., INC., 66 W. 48th St.-Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law, listing liabilities of $12,378, exclusive of capital stock, and assets of $15,039.

The navy made secret tests today of a new "shell-proof" hull by exploding charges of dynamite against it on a raft in the Delaware River off the League Island. Navy Yard. Torpedo explosions were simulated by means of dynamite blasts sent against the specially designed steel caisson, built like a section of a ship's hull, which may revolutionize battleship construction.

An appraisal of the personal property of Harvey S. Firestone at $3,696,502 was filed in Probate Court today. This did not cover life insurance and possible other assets covered by prior trust agreements. Stocks and securities held by Mr. Firestone at the time of his death in February at Miami, Fla., were

Dr. Thomas H. Reed of New York will direct research activities in connection with the Republican Program Committee's audit of New Deal policies. He also will be in charge of arrangements for the committee's Summer conference in Chicago next August, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Glenn Frank,

An emphatic protest against the ruthless bombing of civilian' populations in Spain and China as violative of ele mentary principles of humane conduct in modern civilization was made by the United States today.
Should the State-Federal milk marketing order not become effective a strike of dairymen in the State would ensue, according to Stanley Piseck, Newport dairy farmer, who led the 1933 milk strike.

Raymond Marien, accountant whose handling of financial statements for Interstate Hosiery Mills, Inc., has been under investigation by Attorney General Bennett for four months, was reported incorrectly in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 25 to have pleaded guilty to a charge of forgery.

Dr. William K. Gregory, curator of the department of comparative anatomy of the American Museum of Natural History, will sail today on the American South African liner City of New York, accompanied by Dr. Milo Hellman, research associate in physical anthropology of the department.

One branch of the Federal Government that has shown increasing evidence of cooperation with industry is the Securities and Exchange Commission. This is emphasized again in the statement of Chairman Douglas after a discussion with William Martin Jr., acting president of the Stock Exchange, that there will be no "cracking down"

Former Senator Marion Butler of North Carolina died today in nearby Takoma Park, Md. He was 76 years old. Mr. Butler served three parties during his political career. He contributed to the formation of various farm organizations, including cotton and tobacco cooperative marketing associations. His home was in Elliott, N. C.

The story of two shipmasters, frantically manoeuvring their vessels in a vain attempt to avoid collision in a dense fog was unfolded yesterday before a board of inquiry of the Federal Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation, appointed to study the crash of the Eastern Steamship liner Acadia and the excursion ship Mandalay.

As this session of Congress nears its end, Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, has struck a "bluewater balance sheet" of the Merchant Marine for the benefit of Congress and the country. Much has been accomplished during the past year. But much remains to be achieved.

For weeks and weeks the WPA toiled to prepare a very attractive pamphlet citing the beauties of Fort Schuyler and the advantages of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy which is located there. However, to the despair

J. P. Morgan, president of the Murray Hill Association, made up of property owners and residents of the Murray Hill district, announces that the twenty-fourth annual meeting of the organization will be held on June 15 in the Pierpont Morgan Library, 33 East Thirty-sixth Street.
The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "There is a little business in wool, in driblets. On the whole, the market continues uncertain and dispirited and the same is true in transatlantic markets.

James B. French of 1,900 Albemarle Road, Brooklyn, manager of the Ace Film Laboratory of New York, died yesterday of a heart attack in the Erie Railroad Terminal in Jersey City, N. J. He had come from his Summer home in West Milford, N. J.
The death sentence was pronounced today by a military court at Haifa on two of three Jewish youths accused of firing at an Arab bus in Northern Palestine about a month ago.

Police battied tonight with 300 anti-Fascists who attempted to break up a meeting of the Canadian Nationalist party. One officer was slightly injured when struck by a picket sign and two demonstrators were arrested.

Mrs. Edith M. Steinberg, 48 years old, of 30 Edwin Court, Bay Park, L. I., widowed mother of three children, received a sentence of six months in the Nassau County Jail today for having made fraudulent statements to obtain relief funds from the county Public Welfare Department.
George E. Gardner was named operations manager of Northwest Airlines, Inc., yesterday, according to an announcement by Croil Hunter, president and general manager of the line. Mr. Gardner, who

Miss Elizabeth F. Bauer, who as a child accompanied her father's infantry company for many months during the Civil War, died last night at the Irvington General Hospital at the age of 83. Her father, Captain John F. Bauer, who organized his own company of volunteers with the Forty-first New York Infantry, was taken seriously ill during an engagement.

Morton Bodfish of Chicago, executive vice president of the United States Building and Loan League, told the New Jersey Building and Loan League here today that, unless Federal housing were confined to the underprivileged, it would destroy the ideal of home ownership.

William A. Earl, vice president of the New York Athletic Club and general attorney and associate manager of the New York office of the Hartford Accident and Indemnity Company, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home at 241 Central Park West. He was 52 years old.
153d St (9-2399) s a, 25 it w of Melrose Ave. 100x100; Walpark Building Co to New York Life Insurance Co, 51 Madison Ave; installments, at 4 1/2 to 5 per cent; S130,00.

Disturbed by recent attacks made upon it by Dr. Emil Altman, chief medical examiner of the New York City schools, the Retirement Board yesterday requested Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, to investigate the charges that incompetent and insane teachers were allowed to remain in the school system.

Evidence that funds are becoming more plentiful for financing of sound real estate investments and residential building projects is to be found in a study of the mortgage records of the savings banks of Brooklyn and Queens for recent months.

The principal foreign exchanges advanced strongly against the dollar yesterday after their weakness of the last few days. Strength was especially pronounced in the Belgian belga and the Netherlands guilder. The former rose 6 1/4, points to 16.95 3/4 cents, which brought it above its parity for the first time in many weeks. The guilder gained 5 1/2 points to 55.22 cents.

Three of New York State's fifty-seven CCC camps will be closed on June 30, and fifty-four continued until September, according to the revised program for six months from April 1, announced today by Robert Fechner, director of the corps.

Mr. Crosby Gaige, a gentleman with both a mind and a taste of his own, has bought, at what probably is a bargain price to him, some 200,000 models which were cleared out of the PatentOffice by order of Herbert Hoover, then Secretary of Commerce. Possibly Mr. Gaige may be right in thinking that these farm implements,

An agreement was reached today by which E. J. Phelan of Ireland withdrew his candidacy for the International Labor Office directorship in favor of John G. Winant of the United States, who already had a majority pledged to him and who now will be elected without opposition tomorrow by the governing body. Mr. Phelan, who

Charles Pipitone has purchased for his own occupancy the twelveroom dwelling at 222 Thirty-third Street, in the Woodcliff section of North Bergen, N. J., from the Hudson Trust Company through J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker. The new owner will build private garages at the rear of the plot and renovate the house.

Representatives of four Remington Rand Employe Association units, in a resolution adopted here today, asked a "stay of enforcement" of a National Labor Relations Board order reinstating 4,000 strikers at the company's plants.

Sixty-six railroads operating in the South, East and Middle West asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for permission to readjust rates on cream and milk shipped by passenger trains. The railroads maintain the proposed revisions would remove inconsistencies and would bring about both increases and reductions.
For the second straight day the Indians today went on a batting spree in the late innings to score an uphill 10-to-5 victory over the Athletics.
The Yankees had one big inning yesterday at the Stadium in their farewell game against the Tigers, but the way the club is going now one inning suffices.

A Communications Commission examiner recommended today that the Debs Memorial Radio Fund, Inc., which operates radio station WEVD in New York City, be allowed to acquire for $85,000 the property and license of Fifth Avenue Broadcast' ing Corporation, license of WFAB, also in New York City.

The slaughter of all classes, except hogs, was light, and the market on transfer meats ruled steady to higher. Steer hinds and ribs were strong to 50c higher; veal hind-saddles mostly steady; lamb sharply higher. Early trading in kosher meats indicated steer chucks and plates steady;

Henry Fonda and Louise Platt will be featured in Walter Wanger's film version of "Personal History," which is described as "inspired by Vincent Sheean's novel of the same name. The camera should start turning within three weeks, with William Dieterle directing from a screen play by John Howard Lawson.

Harry Goldwater of 2,785 University Avenue, the Bronx, a veteran hotel executive and cousin of S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of the Department of Hospitals, collapsed and died in the lobby of an apartment hotel at 17 West Sixty-seventh Street yesterday afternoon.

An indictment charging assault with intent to kill and causing an explosion with intent to injure was returned against Patrolman George W. Rogers, 41 years old, of the Bayonne Police Department today by the Hudson County grand jury. The indictment was presented to Common Pleas Judge Thomas F. Meany.
Edward E. Wyman and William F. Goulding were appointed yesterday vice presidents of the CurtissWright Corporation, Guy W. Vaughan, president of the company, announced. For ten years Mr.
The District Court here heard today in camera the suit of Mme. Guy Baer against her husband, a Swiss painter, and the former Cornelia Vanderbilt, whom she named as corespondent.
A young Negro whose hands and clothing were flecked with fresh blood when he was arrested has confessed slaying four women and a young girl, police said today.

Trade Somewhat Better in Week A degree of improvement featured retail trade here this week, with weather conditions more favorable and shoppers responding more freely to some Summer promotions, mainly in women's lines.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Osborne Coates of Philadelphia of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sibyl Baldwin Coates, to William F. Sanford of this city, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard C. Sanford of New Haven, Conn.

Ray Schweizer, sophomore slow curve artist, made his debut as a varsity hurler today by going the route for Princeton to turn back the powerful University of California nine, 4--3, in a closely played contest on University Field.

A new charge of inciting another man to conspire with him to kidnap Viscount Nuffield was brought at Oxford police court today against John Bruce Thornton, 50 years old, who was arrested on May 24 outside Lord Nuffield's motor factory at Cowley.

The Court of Appeals today reaffirmed its decision upholding the conviction of Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania and his henchmen on charges of compulsory prostitution when it denied a motion for reargument of the racketeer's appeal.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered about $1 a bale yesterday and ended with net gains of 17 to 19 points. Better foreign markets following recent weakness and a decline of almost $5 a bale, together with persistent moisture in parts of the Eastern Belt, furnished the incentive to release buying power.

Bidu Sayao, Brazilnan soprano or the Metropolitan Opera Association, will sail today for a concert tour of South America. The second annual Spring concert of the Rockland County Symphony Orchestra, Harry A. Alshin conducting, will be held this evening in the auditorium of the Nyack High School, Nyack, N. Y.

Temporary Assignments SERGEANT James P. Diamond, from 81st Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, Kings, for 5 days, from 8 A. M., June 3. PATROLMEN-Henry Myslik, from 14th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, N. Y. City, for 2 days, from 4 P. M., June 1.

Special promotional efforts and the arrival of warm weather are increasing the sales volume of Goldblatt Brothers' ten stores in the Chicago district, Nathan Goldblatt, secretary and treasurer, said today.

Wally Hammond signalized his selection as captain of England's test cricketers for the match against the Australians at Nottingham, June 10, by scoring a century for an England eleven in the trial with The Rest today. The match at Lord's was drawn.

Rain is falling in torrents, breaking the six-month drought that parched fields and threatened to exhaust the city water supply drawn from a chain of shallow, fresh-water springs. The water supply has been turning brackish and the government had requested householders to economize in its use.

A fund of $223,479 has been provided by the estate of Jacob Fox, who died Dec. 17, 1935, for assistance to German Jewish refugees, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Distribution of the fund was left to the discretion of trustees named by Mr. Fox in his will.
Department store sales during the week ended May 28 were 19 per cent lower than for the same week one year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Cloudy weather with little change in temperature was forecast for today and tomorrow, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock (E. S. T.) last night. The disturbance that was forming over the East Gulf States on the preceding map advanced northeastward to the North Carolina coast, the pressure at Wilmington being 29.84 inches.

Miss Diana Kissel, a daughter of Mrs. Stephen D. Hurlbut of New York and Lenox, Mass., and the late Rudolph H. Kissel Jr., was married yesterday afternoon in St. James Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, to J. Lawrence Barnard, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Augustus Barnard of- 129 East Seventy-first Street.

Supporters of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's "realistic" foreign policy were cheered today by the government victory in the West Derbyshire by-election. This victory evens the count with the Opposition on the four by-elections that have been fought out on foreign affairs since the resignation of Anthony Eden.

The Supreme Court is an example of the "courage which is needed today if enlightenment is not to become a fiction in the United States," the Rey..Dr. Edgar F. Romig, minister.of the West End Collegiate Church, told graduates of the Scudder School yesterday at their commencement- exercises in the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street.

Former Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg was married to Countess Vera Fugger von Babenhausen by proxy on Wednesday in the church of the Dominican Fathers here, it was revealed today. Dr. Schuschnigg was not permitted to go to the church personally nor was the ceremony possible at his place of detention because no Catholic priest has been allowed to visit him since March 11. ince March 11.
Dr. Irving Fisher, Yale economist, isto be the graduation speaker at the. commencement exercises on Monday at Proctor Academy. The boys in the graduating class come from nine Statesi and are:

By a process of elimination sixtyfive patrolmen and detectives cornered a lone bandit yesterday in the B. M. T. carbarns at Rockaway and Hegeman Avenues, Brooklyn, after he had stolen $2,100 in cash and checks from a live poultry market, engaged in a running gunfight with two patrolmen and taken refuge in a maze of thirty-nine trolley cars.
The United States imported $13,600,845 in gold in the week ended on May 27, compared with $16,420,817 in the previous week, the Department of Commerce said today.
Bowled over for six runs in the second inning, the Giants spent another very trying afternoon today as they sought with might and main to overcome this latest obstacle dropped right in their path.

German Busch, President of Bolivia, in a message to President Roosevelt today, expressed the hope that the proposal of the mediation commission: in Buenos Aires for a final peace settlement- in the Chaco would assure "durable and prosperous peace."

France proclaimed martial law in the Sanjak of Alexandretta in Northern Syria today in order to suppress the disorders that have been occurring as the date for the plebiscite there to determine whether the district shall be Arab or Turk approaches.

President Roosevelt confirmed today reports that he would send a commission to Great Britain to study the workings of the British Trade Disputes and Trade Unions Act of 1927, but said published versions of the commission's duties were regrettable and were cockeyed where they related to possible amendment of the National Labor Relations Act.

Frederick and tw Strong Moseley, founder and retired president of the Boston brokerage firm of F. S. Moseley Co. and a former director of the National Shawmut Bank, died today at his estate, Maudslay, in Newburyport. He was 86 years old.

The Columbia Grammar School held its 174th commencement exercises last night at the American Woman's Association clubhouse, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street, for a graduating class of twenty-seven. Student speakers were Murray J. Latz, William E. Wolfsheimer Jr., Theodore Ploeger and Alfred Antkies. The school is at 5 West Ninetv-third Street.

The Royal Dutch Company, holding organization for the Batavian Petroleum Company and the AngloSaxon Petroleum Company, Ltd., reported yesterday for 1937 a net income of 87,617,256 florins, or about $48,338,440, which was equal, after dividend payments on the 4 per cent preference shares, to 17.38 per cent on the 503,624,000 florins of ordinary stock.

Six records were shattered and one was tied as Evander Childs retained its Bronx Senior High Public Schools Athletic League track and field team championship at the annual games held at Macombs Dam Park yesterday.

One hundred and twenty-nine professionals, forty amateurs and one player whose status is undetermined, according to the U. S. G. A., are scheduled to start out in the national open golf championship on the Cherry Hills course, Denver, next Thursday morning.

Miss Dorothy Goepel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Goepel of Greenwich, was married to Nathaniel Warner, son of Mrs. Anne -Pearson Warner, also- Greenwich, and the late Robert L. Warner, formerly of Cambridge, Mass., this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church, here. The Rev.

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that total net borrowings on collateral of memers at the close of business on May 31 amounted to $459,363,905, a decrease of $7,402,624, compared with $466,766,529 on April 30.

The new Clipper built by the Boeing Aircraft Company for Pan American Airways nearly capsized in Elliott Bay here tonight during its second water-handling test. Twice the right wing tip sank about twelve feet as Edmund T. Allen, test pilot, sought to turn- tail to the wind and return to mooring.

A contract for alterations estimated to cost about $125,000, in the apartment building at 11-13 West Eighty-first Street, has been awarded to Mose Goodman, according to Brown's Letters, Inc. The plans for the work, which will be done for Hayden House, Inc., were prepared by Herman M. Sohn.

Robert R. Young and Allan P. Kirby, dominant figures in the Alleghany Corporation and the Chesapeake Corporation, top holding companies in the railroad empire founded by the late Van Sweringen brothers, received permission today to hold additional railroad directorships.

Seven more residential properties in the Bronx were bid in yesterday by the Home Owners Loan Corporation, as plaintiff in foreclosure actions against various individuals. The details of these and two other sales are as follows:

Pentecost will be observed tomorrow. With Pentecost there will be observed Christian Unity Sunday, this being at the request of a joint executive committee of the American Sections of the Universal Council on Life and Work and the World Conference on Faith and Order. In all Catholic churches in this

Mrs. Hannah McCormack, mother of John McCormack, Irish tenor, died at her home in Monkstown, County Dublin, yesterday after a long illness at the age of 82. Mrs. McCormack, a shy woman, seldom shared the limelight with her famous son.

Writs of reasonable doubt were signed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo for Samuel Weiss and David Goldberg, officials of Donnie Frocks, Inc., who recently were convicted in Special Sessions of filing false State income and franchise tax returns and sentenced to indeterminate terms in the penitentiary.

Two long distance telephone calls from London to the Duke and Duchess of Windsor on their first wedding anniversary today indicated the British royal family had remembered the former Edward VIII in exile.

Mayor La Guardia's choice of a Summer City Hall was in doubt yesterday when Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation, signed a lease for the Arrow Brook Country Club in Forest Hills, Queens after the Mayor had about decided to make his Summer headquarters in the City Building at the World's Fair.

Governor La Follette of Wisconsin told Dartmouth students and faculty tonight that neither the Republican nor Democratic party had the solution to the future of America. He made an extemporaneous speech after being introduced by President Hopkins, and when his talk was over he was held far into the night by the audience of 2,000 who asked questions on vital subjects of the day.

Miss Elizabeth Silliman, daughterof Mrs. Edward Kent Leech of this' city and Germantown, Philadelphia, and the late Alfred Day Silliman -of -Philadelphia, will .be married today in Hamilton, Bermuda,. to Arthur Laurence'Norton of that place, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Laurence Norton of Boston.

The four-story and basement factory building at 47 to 51 South Fifth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Standard Brands, Inc., to Russo Brothers, who will use it for the storage and distribution of paper stock.

The Gazette, Montreal's first newspaper and one of the oldest on the Continent, celebrated its 160th birthday today. A special edition reviewed the Gagette's history from the time of its founding, June 3, 1778, by Fleury Mesplet. He started-the publication

The funeral of Baron Wilhelm von Ketteler, young German diplomat who disappeared mysteriously from Vienna the day following the annexation of Austria and whose body was found in the Danube a fortnight ago, was held on the'family estate here Wednesday.

The Italian liner Roma sails today for Mediterranean ports with 550 passengers, including Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Berkson, William B. Douglass Jr., Mr. and Mrs. W. J. Goodrich, James S. Bowdoin, Vincent B. Earley, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur S. Van Winkle, Mrs. Mary W. Longstreet, Mr. and Mrs. S. R. Inch, Mr. and Mrs. Hugo R. Lehrfeld, Mrs. Marcel Y. LeRoux, Hpward D. Rothschild, Mrs. Sumner Rhoades and Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Jay Wurts.

Numerous reports indicating disappointing yields of Winter wheat in parts of Texas and Oklahoma and private advices asserting the yield in Kansas would be considerably less than anticipated, based on the general appearance of the crop, started a buying

Voluntary hospitals are assuming an increasingly disproportionate share of the burden of caring for indigent patients and unless government aid is forthcoming soon a "grave community problem will result," Howard S. Cullman, president of Beekman Street Hospital, warned today.

Plans for the Triboro Tuberculosis Hospital on the grounds of the Queens General Hospital were filed yesterday for the Department of Hospitals by Eggers Higgins, architects, who estimated the cost at $3,400,000. The plans provide for a twelve-story brick hospital and administration building on a plot 436 by 209 feet on Parsons Boulevard, between Goethals Avenue and Eighty-second Drive, Jamaica.

The General Electric Company announced yesterday that it had decreased by 2 per cent its cost-ofliving adjustment plan, reflecting the decrease in the cost of living index as published by the United States Department of Labor. The company has been paying 5 per

The marriage of Miss Jean MacKinnon, daughter of Mrs. Frederick Johnson of 840 Park Avenue- and Palm Beach and the late Archibald Angus MacKinnon, to George-Albert Zabriskie 3d, took place yesterday in the apartment here of the bride's mother and stepfather, Mr. Johnson.

The silver medal of the Life Saving Benevolent Association of New York was presented yesterday to Captain Gilbert C. Bown of the steamer Lillian Luckenbach for a rescue at sea last December. Herbert L. Satterlee, president of the association, presented the medal and cash awards totaling more than

John S. Cordell, formerly general manager of the Cities Service Refining Company, has been elected vice president and general manager of the Cities Service Oil Company of Pennsylvania, it was announced yesterday.

Presldent Lazaro Cardenas is preparing to pass through the heart of the rebellious territory of San Luis Potosi between the capital of that State and Tampico, the press here reports. The President plans to travel in his green train. The entire route is being heavily guarded by cavalry, and he is carrying a trainful of troops.
The Jersey City Giants made it three in a row in their series with the Baltimore Orioles today, winning by 2 to 1.

The Appellate Division unanimously ruled yesterday that Thomas W. Lamont, as head of the International Committee of Bankers on Mexico, must submit to an examination on activities of the organization before the trial of a suit by Louis Gallopin, a Swiss citizen, to recover $49,324 from the committee.

Herschel V. Johnson, counselor of the American Embassy in London, was appointed today chairman of the United States delegation to the whaling conference which will convene in London June 13 to study the results of the 1937-38 whaling season and consider the modification or extension of the final act of the conference of 1937.

Ten modern principles, in line with the Ten Commandments, were outline by Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, wife of the Governor, in an address-over the Mutual Broadcasting System yesterday. The speech was part of the Shevuoth program of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee. Je ws- begin tonight celebration
Ford Frick, president of the National League, yesterday ordered a replay of the disputed CincinnatiSt. Louis game on May 14.
Bill Lee, the Cubs' tall right-hander, pitched his way to within one game of the National League record for consecutive shut-outs today by blanking the Bees, 4 to 0, on three hits.

Fulton Supply Co, ship supplies, in 22 Fulton St; Ney H. Thom, Ney C. Thom and Hom Lee, restaurant, in 129 John St; Murray, Olson Co, hardware and electrical supplies, in 51 Vesey St; Joseph Rubin, woolen clippings, in 334 Bowery St; Charles F. Noyes Co, broker.

Degrees will be conferred upon 187 seniors by New Jersey College for Women tomorrow morning at Its seventeenth annual commencement. The degree of Bachelor of Arts will be conferred upon 136 students, that of Bachelor of Science upon 43-and that of Bachelor of Letters upon 8. Dr.,Robert C. Clothier.

Miss Onny Melmo, 88-year-old domestic who had been in the employ of the family of Redmond Keresey of Lawrence, L. I., for sixty-eight years, died yesterday of a heart ailment while visiting at the home of her nephew, Edward McColgan, who lives at 208 East Sixty-third Street.

The $6 preferred stock of the Swiss-American Electric Company has been stricken from the list of the New York Curb Exchange. Each share of stock is exchangeable for one share of new 5 per cent preferred stock of the company, plus 50 Swiss francs in cash.

The New York Telephone Company, largest operating unit in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company system. reported yesterday a net gain in telephones in service during May of 4,040, compared with an increase of 13,840 instruments in May, 1937.

Donald Carroll, the 16-year-old Queens youth recently acquitted of the murder of his sweetheart, by Charlotte Matthieson, has been found to be sane by Bellevue Hospital psychiatrists, it was reported yesterday and he may be freed today.

Minneapolis, Minn., will enter the market on June 23 with $1,675,685 of various-purpose bonds. The issue will be dated July 1, 1938, and will mature from July 1, 1939 to 1948. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 6 per cent. Proceeds from the sale of these bonds will be used for water works, paving, storm drain, land acquisition and special street improvement.

Two mortgages held by the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Co from the 6th Ave and 55th St Corp, Clarence F. Waldman, president, were consolidated as one lien for $380,000 on the ?? w cor of 6th Ave and 55th St, due July 1, 1942, at 4 per cent.

Patrolman John Deaver of the Brownsville precinct, Brooklyn, who accidentally shot and killed Patrolman James B. Fisher, 53 years old, of the same precinct, early yesterday morning in an attempt to halt a robber suspect in front of 389 Herzl Street, Brooklyn, was exonerated yesterday by police officials and the Kings County District Attorney's office. The suspect,

Arthur L. Cook has been named acting director of the School of Science and Technology of Pratt Institute, Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday by the board of trustees. He succeeds Dr. Samuel S. Edmands, the director, who died May 24 of injuries received in an automobile accident.

To facilitate new financing by issuing subscription rights to security holders, corporations having stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange were advised yesterday that the time limit to permit holders to exercise their rights had been reduced from twenty days to fourteen days.

The business property on the southeast corner of Main Street and Lexington Avenue, White Plains, Westchester, has been sold by The New York Life Insurance Company to the Pensy Holding Corporation, Isidore Wolff, president, for cash above a first mortgage of $150,000 which runs for ten years.
Secretary Wallace, acting again under the Packers and Stockyards Act, today ordered Swift Co. to cease "unfair, unjustly discriminatory and deceptive" practices in the sale of its products.

John Damiano, 54 years old, the Washington Heights race horse bookmaker, accused of having induced another man to substitute for him in Special Sessions last Thursday to be sentenced on a bookmaking charge, was arrested yesterday in his home at -529 West 179th Street, on a bench warrant.

Recovery of 25,000 shares of stock in Narragansett Race Track valued at $125,000 and owned by Walter O'Hara, former manager of the Pawtucket, R. I., track, and his wife, was announced today by the police.

Among the 336 candidates for the Bachelor of Science degrees to be conferred at Virginia Polytechnic Institute's commencement exercises Monday are Alfred Knobler and Robert T. Franzel of New York City; Walter

In announcing here yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Stock Exchange had formed a round table group for the solution of common problems, William 0. Douglas, chairman of the SEC, said yesterday that "the day of the crackdown on Wall Street is over."

Brooklyn business establishments and their employes have contributed $144,581 to the Greater New York Fund, it was announced yesterday at a report luncheon -of thefund's Brooklyn division in the Hotel St. George.

Louis Rubin, for three years executive director of the Popular Priced Dress Manufacturers Group, has been elected executive chairman, in addition to his present duties, it was announced yesterday. The group. represents more than 250 leading dress producers in the lower price brackets, doing an annual wholesale business of $150,000,000.

In his first statement on public affairs since he returned home from a recent Eastern trip which took him to Washington as a White House visitor, Henry Ford said in an interview today that nothing has happened in recent weeks to change his conviction that "we are going to have the greatest era of prosperity and happiness we have ever known."

The New York Maritime Council--maritime labor unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization-announced last night that it would invite spokesmen of the Federal Government and of shipowners to confer on problems of labor jurisdiction in the shipping industry.

The Clifford Odets "Golden Boy" is the only play departing the Times Square area tonight, leaving the Belasco Theatre after giving its 248th performance there. On Wednesday, fifteen members - of the company will sail for London on the President Harding, to spend the Summer on Shaftesbury Avenue before going on tour here in the Fall.

The four-story dwelling at 32 West Seventy-first Street will be altered, following its sale by the estate of Willie C. Bergh to Reuben B. Goodman and Jayne Goodman Weaver. Assessed at $39,500, the property was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $18,000 at 4 1/2 per cent.

Judge Robert P. -Patterson of the Southern District of New York is under consideration by the Administration for elevation to the Second Circuit Court of Appeals, it became known today, while Edward Conger of Poughkeepsie is in high favor at the White House for nomination to the Southern District bench.

The bronze figure of a discus thrower. located for some years in Central Park near Fifth Avenue and Eighty-second Street, northwest of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has been removed to a point near the Municipal Stadium at Randalls Island, the Department of Parks announced yesterday.

The hog market opened higher today but when shipping demand was satisfied, prices reacted. Another small run of lambs came into the market and prices rose 25 to 50 cents a hundredweight, closing fully $1 higher for the week. Fed steers, yearlings and heifers sold steady in a clean-up trade.

General Seishiro Itagaki was formally appointed War Minister today. General Gen Sugiyama, the retiring War Minister, becomes a member of the Supreme -War Council, which amounts to retirement, since the council is an advisory rather than executive body. General Count Juichi Terauchi's fate is at present unknown.

Officers and directors of the General Motors Corporation in April reported receipt as bonuses of common stock of that corporation with an aggregate market value of about $1,000,000, according to a summary or transactions in April in equity securities by officers, directors and principal- stockholders made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Paramount Pictures, Inc., was named defendant in a copyright infringement action on file today in Federal Court and growing out of the production of the motion picture "The Plainsman."

A funeral service for John D. Clark, general manager of distribution for Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, was held yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Henry K. Post, pastor of Christ Reformed Church, Newark, N. J., at the Arthur K. Brown Funeral Home, 57 Park Street, Montclair, N. J. Mr. Clark died on Wednesday at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair at the age of 47.

Miss Barbara MacGay Leggett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Cox Leggett of 402 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn. and Craig Bield, Redding Ridge, Conn., was married to Dr. Otto Emile Billo of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Billo of Glen Ridge, N. J., last night in the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church.

That hardy, everblooming favorite of the international money markets, the rumor of another cut in the gold value of the dollar, has cropped up again with renewed vigor this week. According to word received
Miss Peggy Lashanska Rosenbaum and. Peter Gerald Lehman, whose marriage will take place on. June 16 at Sherry's, obtained their, marriage license yesterday at the Municipal Builing.
Stocks drifted listlessly and closed fractionally lower in slowest trading since 1934 and the second smallest trading since July, 1923; turnover, 284,850 shares.

The Senate Judiciary Committee moved definitely today toward removing any threat of Executive domination over the proposed investigation of monopolistic practices. The committee agreed tentatively to take from the resolution

A delegation of thirty members of the textile industry in Germany were visitors on the floor of the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday morning. The delegation, which is sponsored by the German Government, has just spent several days in many of the New England textile centers.
Lightning killed two spectators and injured six others, one seriously, in a spectacular storm that blotted out the first round of Kansas City's $5,000 golf tournament today.

Banks and insurance companies were the principals in most of the transactions involving. Brooklyn properties announced yesterday. The Brooklyn Savings Bank sold through H. D. Agar, Inc., brokers, to an investing client the

The Trade Union Act of 1927, which will be studied by a commission for President Roosevelt, was passed as a direct result of the general strike in May, 1926. It is the latest, most drastic and best known of British laws regulating industrial relations.

Twenty-nine offenders, including two women, who in the last five years have forfeited bail bonds on indictments for various felonies, one for manslaughter, in amounts of $15,000 down to $500, were indicted yesterday by the New York County grand jury under the rarely used bail-jumping law, involving felonies.
Cotton exports to Germany, which had been paid for with compensated [Aski] marks, were suspended today by the Bank of Brazil. Germany already had placed orders for 62,000 tons, this year's quota.

Walter Evans Edge, former United States Ambassador to France, and Mrs. Edge are at the Ambassador. Mr. Edge will leave today for Quebec on a fishing trip. Mr. and Mrs. Samuel G. Ordway and members of their family will pass the Summer in East Hampton, where they have taken the George Roberts place.

A judgement in favor of the plaintiff that a Mexican divorce in absentia is not valid in the case of a couple married in Paris was handed down today by a Paris tribunal in a case that affects two American women and their Argentine husband, Enrique de Paats.

Secretary Wallace called on State and local relief organizations and similar agencies today to advise him on "the extent of unfilled need for food and clothing among people on relief," to open what is expected to be the biggest surplus commodity purchase and distribution program thus far undertaken by the Federal Government.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Augustus Maxwell Rode of Brussels, Belgium, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maxine Rode, to Norman Bishop Bullard, son of Mrs. Mary Bishop Bullard of Guilford, Conn., and Henry Milton Bullard of New Haven, Conn.

New York Yankees vs. St. Louis Browns, at Yankee Stadium. 161st Street and River Avenue, Bronx .................3 P. M. Jersey Giants vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Roosevelt Stadium. Danforth and West Side Avenues, Jersey City........ 3 P. M.

A memorial service will be held at noon Tuesday at St. James Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, for Francis Edward Powell, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in London, England, who died of a heart attack at the age of 75 Thursday night while

With their younger children tucked away in bed, but with their husbands and older children on hand to cheer them, a group of Bronx women of assorted ages undertook last night the role of shy June graduates in the auditorium of the Evander Childs High School.

Peekskin's ordinance prohibiting the distribution of handbills does not apply to anything except commercial advertising, Magistrate Salvatore T. Gambino ruled tonight and dismissed charges against four members of the American Labor party who were arrested May 7 for distributing copies of the Bill of Rights in a test of the measure.
The North American Administrative Committee of the World's Sunday School Association will hold its annual meeting on Tuesday, beginning at 10 A. M., at the headquarters, 51 Madison Avenue.

Final awards of $81,000 for the Red Hook housing project were granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood in Brooklyn, bringing the total condemnation price to. $1,476,882. The owners asked for $1,724,403, and the city's realty experts appraised the value at $1,363,144.

There is a certain vague connection between the speech delivered last night by the American Secretary of State before the Bar Association of his native State of Tennessee and the reports that the Prime Minister of Great Britain is considering a tender of British good offices on a double front--to mediate-between Chind and Japan and
A walk to Bob Seeds with the bases full forced Mickey Witek across with the winning run and gave the Bears an eleven-inning victory over Syracuse tonight, 5 to 4. Reginald

Joseph Gevaert, Belgian Commissiner General to the World's Fair, and Mrs. Gevaert entertained at dinner last night in the St. Regis Roof. Another dinner in the St. Regis Roof was given by Mr. and Mrs. Theodore P. Dixon for Miss Constance P. Looram and Theodore P. Dixon Jr., whose marriage will take place today.
May I not contribute my 2 cents' worth to "Casey at the Bat," in'the shape of the enclosed copy of a letter I wrote in 1935 at. the time of the passing of DeWolf Hopper?

Mrs. Henry Ashton won a tricolor for the outstanding exhibit in the cultural class in the glower show of the garden section of the Bronxville Women's Club here today in the club's auditorium. She exhibited a double bloom peony.

Miss Eleanore Davis, daughter of Mrs. Edward Parsons Davis of this place and the late Mr. Davis of New York and Great Barrington, was married to Pemberton Hutchinson Lincoln of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Lincoln of Elkhorn, W. Va., this afternoon.
The second annual Spring flower show of the Herald Tribune Junior Garden Club Council will be held from noon to 5 P. M. today in the auditorium of Wanamaker's store, Broadway and Ninth Street.

In full-page newspaper advertisements and billboard appeals Mayor Frank Hague urged residents of Jersey City today to participate in a demonstration of "Americanism" Monday, the feature of which will be a parade.

Within a few hours after his arrival in this country from Germany, Odin vom Busecker Schloss, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Sydney F. Heckert of Santa Barbara, Calif., was named best of breed at the Shepherd Dog Show of New England held at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club today.

Glowing reports by Canadian bankers on the character and ability of Alexander B. Beverly of Toronto influenced the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation to sell the Continental Securities Corporation to the group which is charged with having looted it, Gerald Beal, president of the Schroder Company, declared yesterday at the Securities and Exchange Commission's investment trust hearing.

President Roosevelt will make two speeches, with only an hour between them, when he visits the- New York World's Fair grounds on June 30, the White House announced today. The first speech at 2 P. M. will mark the laying - of the cornerstone for the Federal Building, while the second will follow an hour later and be made to the National Educational Association.

A contract for twenty-six Model G-31 short-range amphibian airplanes, with spare parts, was awarded by the War Department today to the Gruman Aircraft Engineering Corporation of Bethpage, L. I., for $1,412,916.80.

Charles W. Goetchius, vice president and treasurer of the American Surety Company of New York and the New York Casualty Company, died yesterday at the Caledonian Hospital, Brooklyn, after a short illness. He was 67 years old.

Carrying a total of $3,722,905,000 in new money, reappropriations and authorizations, the 1938 ReliefRecovery Bill passed the Senate late last night by a vote of 60 to 10 after nearly two full weeks of debate.

About 160 members of the Bond Club of New Jersey attended yesterday the club's annual Spring field day at the Suburban Golf Club at Union, N. J. The attendance was said to be the largest in the history of the outing.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler today decreed the confiscation without compensation of all products of "degenerate art" displayed in museums or collections accessible to the public and owned by German citizens.
The Ecuadorian Cabinet, composed of army officers, resigned tonight in the midst of an Ecuadorian-Peruvian crisis because the Ministers said. their place now was in the ranks of the army.

Sir Hugo Cunliffe-Owen's Rockfel completed a sweep of Great Rritain's classics for 3-year-old fillies Today by winning the 160th running of the Oaks. Rockfel also won the One Thousand Guineas, run at Newmarket in April.

The home and gardens of Mr. and Mrs. Howard L. Aller here formed the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Pauline Elizabeth Forsythe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Anthony Forsythe of New York and Lakeville, to Barry Stuart Richards of London and Dean Manor, Kent, England.

Aside from the irregularly easiertrend of prices, the most notable characteristic of yesterday's stock market was the extreme dullness. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was only 284,000 shares, smallest for a full day since Aug. 20, 1934, and second smallest since July 16, 1923. In fact,

The flotation of several major loans swelled the volume of new bond financing this week to a total of $205,394,000, the largest for any similar period in more than two years, or since the week ended May 1, 1936, when $237,315,000 in new bonds were marketed.

Mr. and Mrs. William De Forest Manice gave a dinner with dancing tonight at Edgewood House, their home here, to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of their marriage. Mrs. Manice is the former Miss Harriet Ferry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Hayward Ferry of New York.

The marriage of Miss Hildegarde Marburg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis C. Marburg of this place, to Howard H. Hennington, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Hennington of Rochester, N. Y., took place here tonight at the home of the bride's parents.

The third annual Catholic School Music Contest finals ended yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall. Ten choruses and twelve orchestras, including instrumental ensembles, representing parochial high schools of New York City and vicinity, participated.

A Criminal Court grand jury today indicted George (Bugs) Moran, former gang leader, and nine associates, one a woman, on charges of conspiracy to issue $500,000 of counterfeit checks of the American Express Company.

Mrs. Alice Henderson Evans, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Penhallow Henderson of El Camino del Monte Sol, was married to Edgar L. Rossin of New York this afternoon. The ceremony was performed by District Judge David Chavez Jr., in the garden of the ranch home in Alcalde of Miss Mary Cabot Wheelwright of Boston.
Several letters have been received from anglers and prospective anglers wanting to know more about the "ouananiche," that member of the landlocked salmon tribe.

Ch. Marlu Marigold, from the Marlu Farm Kennels of Maurice Pollak of West Long Branch, N. J., today was awarded the trophy which carried with it the title of best in show of the annual Summer specialty exhibition of the Welsh Terrier Club of America. The silver trophy was offered by the Halcyon Kennels.
The New Jersey Women's Golf Association weekly one-day tournament, held at the White Beeches Golf and Country Club today, drew a field of sixty-six contestants and was

The marriage of Miss Margaret Parkhurst, daughter of Mrs. May Argue Parkhurst of New York, to Rawson Atwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Desler Atwood of Brooklyn, took place here tonight in the Georgian Room of the Garden City Hotel.

There is no doubt whatever that this generation has ringside seats at the greatest show ever produced on earth, Dr. Frank Kingdon, president of the University of Newark, told fifty-five members of the graduating class of the New York Medical College and twenty-five nursing graduates of Flower Hospital at exercises yesterday in the grand ballroom of the Hotel WaldorfAstoria. No other generation,
In the merger of the Nat Rosenthal-Flanagan Associates, the coat department will be supervised by Harry G. Flanagan with the assistance of Sig Meltzer and Jack Rosenthal.

A protective committee for the defaulted $20,000,000 National Public Service Corporation 5 per cent gold debenture issue was directed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman to explain its activities to a group of depositors who have brought suit to replevy $11,660,000 in debentures left with the committee.

IT is the actual stories of people with names and faces and personalities that are convincing when all the graphs and all the figures about them have failed. That is why Louise Armstrong's absorbing account of her, three years' experience as a relief administrator may do more to make Americans see what the life of other Americans on relief is like than a whole cycle of statistical oratory.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 2: MAJOR GENERAL Lynch, G. A., Chief of Infantry, one day's leave, June 13, and ten days' leave, June 18.

Justices DeLuca, Brady and Kozicke in Special Sessions yesterday suspended sentences of six months each in the workhouse they had just imposed on five Negro members of Local 239 of the C. I. O. Cleaners, Dyers, Pressers, Drivers and Allied Trades Union in the tossing of two stench bombs last Fall into two Washington Heights cleaning
Wes Ferrell, master of the "nothing-ball," pitched the Senators to a 5-to-1 victory over the slipping White Sox today. Al Simmons helped Ferrell with his bat, whacking a home run and a double.

MANHATTAN FOX, JACOB (Dec. 17, 1935). Gross assets, $602,775; net, $355,273. To German Jewish Refugees, $213,479; Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, $5,000; Catholic Charity, $2,000; Protestant Charity, $2,000; Ethiopian Government, undetermined; Sophie Fox, divorced wife, $5,000; Victor H. Fox, son, $5,000 and $100 per month for five years; Helen K. Fox Florence Diamond and Jeanette

A mass meeting of 1,000 Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company strikers "filed without action" today a proposal by officials that they return to work for ten days at the pay rate in effect before a 10 per cent cut was ordered. In this way,

Herman Goodstein, an attorney of 10 East Fortieth Street, has been appointed by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo as temporary receiver of the estate of Andrew Carnegie Whitfield during the pendency of a separation suit brought by Mrs. Elizabeth Whitfield, it was disclosed yesterday. Mrs. Whitfield reported about April 15 that her husband had disappeared after leaving on a trip in his plane.

Six contestants participated in the finals for Zone 1 in the oratorical contest held last night under the direction of the Americanism Committee of the American Legion, Department of New York, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
The Ragusan Credit Union, 2,173 Eighty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, has filed an organization certificate for examination, the State Banking Department announced today.

The government's long-pending suit to recover $25,316,000 from the Bethlehem Steel Corporation because of alleged exorbitant profits on World War contracts was dismissed today by Judge Oliver B. Dickinson of the Federal district court

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Page of 165 East Sixty-fifth Street and West Hills, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mollie Page, to Anderson Fowler Hewitt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Shepard Hewitt of 58 East Seventy-eighth Street and Lloyd's Harbor, L. I.
The Dodgers, very close to the bottom of the National League, today made Mild Will McKechnie, manager of the Reds, very sad indeed.
The Cardinals finally downed the fighting Phillies in the eleventh inning today, 8 to 7, for a sweep of their three-game series.

From Zurich, Switzerland, Klaus Mann has sent to Houghton Mifflin a chapter entitled "End of Austria," which, the publishers say, will constitute an important section of the forthcoming book, "Escape to Life," which he and his sister, Erika, have been at work on for several months. Erika Mann, who
Buying in wholesale markets was hesitant again last week, revealing the persistent caution which has kept volume down all year, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.

President Roosevelt. agreed to make two speeches at the New York World's Fair June 30, one at the laying of the cornerstone of the Federal Building and another to the National Educational Association. He confirmed published reports that he would appoint a commission to study the British Trade Unions Act, but denied that

Edward A. Weeks Jr. of Beacon Hill, editor of The Atlantic Monthly since 1928, will succeed Ellery Sedgwick, retiring editor-in-chief. Mr. Sedgwick, in announcing his retirement after thirty years in the June issue of the magazine, wrote that he was handing his position over to the "first mate."

It was with proprietary interest that 100 pairs of eyes stared at eighteen assorted animals in the Central Park Zoo yesterday, for they were the eyes of youngsters from public schools who had thought up names for the heretofore anonymous anteaters, zebras and other captives.
George Forrest, who built one of the earliest telephone, sets after Alexander Graham Bell invented the instrument, died today. He was 92 years old.

Cotton-mill activity declined last week more sharply than expected on the basis of normal seasonal trend, and the adjusted index slumped almost 6 points to 81.3. The figure was 87.2 for the preceding week and 146.8 for the week ended May 29, 1937.

The first attempt of the New Deal "elimination committee" in Washington to rid the Democratic high councils of less-than-100-per-cent followers of President Roosevelt encountered today an open uprising of the Iowa Democratic organization.

Conferees on the Wages and Hours Bill reached a first agreement today by. approving a basic minimum wage rate of 25 cents an hour for industries in interstate commerce, with the proviso that no administrative agency which might later be approved could lower this "floor." They also adopted a series of provisions regulating child labor.
Society horse enthusiasts from all parts of the metropolitan district came here today for the opening of the annual Tuxedo horse show. Nearly every box was filled at the afternoon session.
The State Board of Dental Examiners warned yesterday that group dental practice on a contract basis for fixed annual fees was illegal in this State.

A young research scientist, Richard Archbold, in a fourteen-ton, $250,000 flying laboratory, alighted on the waters of Pearl Harbor here today with five associates on an eighteen-hour flight from San Diego, Calif.

Professor Lorenz Boehler, head of the Vienna Workers Hospital and well-known bone surgeon, today denied reports circulated abroad that the efficiency of the popular Vienna Medical School had suffered by faculty changes since Austria's annexation by Germany.

The fifty-foot yacht Co-ed, owned by A. C. Hoffman, Newark beverage manufacturer, was destroyed by fire in the Shrewsbury River here tonight. The yacht, valued at $75,000, was tied up at a dock at the Sea Bright Yacht Club.
President Manuel Quezon signed a bill today cutting from $500 to $50 the monthly pension, granted his chief political rival, General Emilio Aguinaldo.

From the University of California comes the news that Dr. Herbert M. Evans, known the world over for his work on the pituitary gland, has succeeded in obtaining an approximate increase of 70 per cent in yield of the growth hormone in the anterior lobe of the gland and a fivefold increase in impotency.

AMID the spires and gargoyles of two crowded Gothic acres, Frank Loyd's Villon piece began suddenly an late the other night, taking advantage, we were told of a full moon and a lack of spectators. We discerned a hundred spectators, at least, and no moon at all.

A Negro picked up for questioning in connection with the molestation of a 19-year-old college girl was spirited away from City Hall by State police tonight when a mob, estimated at 2,000 persons, gathered around the building threatening the man.
Secretary Roper suggested today a world-wide economic conference "in which nations would cooperate for the equitable distribution of the basic raw materials of the world."

ALDRICH, CHARLOTTE G. (May 27. Estate more than $10,000. To Edith A. Biscoe, daughter, executrik, 180 E. 79th St., Grace E. Radway, daughter, Brookline, Mass., and William P. Aldrich, son, Montclair, N. J., one-third residue, each; Charlotte Monell Finch, niece, Rutherford, N. J., $3,000; Annie V. Marble,

The following is the chart showing how the Belmont Stakes was run at Belmont Park yesterday: FIFTH RACE--The Belmont Stakes; $25,000 added; 3-year-olds; one mile and a half. Start good; won driving; place same. Went to post 4:18, off 4:25. Winner, ch. c., by Milkman--Peake. Trainer, G. M. Odom. Net value to winner, $34,530; second, $5,000; third, $2,500; fourth, $1,000.
