Homer Folks, secretary of the State Charities Aid Association, New York, and Dr. Kendall Emerson, managing director of the National Tuberculosis Association, are among eleven men from New York City who will participate in the annual meeting of the National Tuberculosis Association, starting here on June 20.

At the offices of the Seaboard Air Line Railway here it was said today that the election on Thursday of W. H. Coverdale of New York as president and chairman of the board would not affect the receivership of the company.

BIRSH--Claire. Sinai Temple. Mount Vernon, N. Y., June 5, Sunday, 9:30 A. M. At home 3 to 6. No cards. BOLEY--Dr. and Mrs. Henry B. Boley announce the confirmation of their son, Herbert Alfred, Sunday, June 5, Union Temple. Reception at home, 2-6, 135 Eastern Parkway; no cards.

THE "homespun leisure-time activities of farm people" make the material of this book. And, although the informative little volume bears the formal-sounding subtitle of "A Study of the Rural Arts Program of the Agricultural' Extension Service," the author wisely strings her chapters from the beginning upon the human theme.

Don Budge and Gene Mako, the United States Davis Cup aces, ambled into the third round of the French hard-court tennis championships today, but most of the other American entries found the going difficult.

The Rev. Dr. Frank N. D. Buchman, leader of the Oxford Group, observing his sixtieth birthday in London, told 2,000 followers in a radio-telephone message late today to their "house party" here that "America, must rearm morally."

Western Pennsylvania Chapter 13 of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers, with a territory covering all counties of Pennsylvania west of that in which Harrisburg is located, has been created by the governing council of the institute. J. W. Cree Jr. of Pittsburgh

This is the first of a series of articles describing small gardens in and around New York, and telling how their owners have succeeded in overcoming the problems they met and finally achieved success.

MEMBERS of the Oxford Movement are celebrating a birthday this week-end. Not an anniversary of the movement itself but the sixtieth birthday of the man who in 1921 founded at Oxford, England, a group he called "A First Century Christian Fellowship." That man is Dr. Frank N. D.

Although Czechoslovak production of steel ingots during April was maintained at the level of the preceding month, the further decline recorded in the pig iron output indicates that the continued downward trend in the local iron and steel production is not merely of a seasonal character, according to a report to the Department of Commerce by the American commercial attache at Prague.

WITH confidence in keeping with her position as the Keystone State, Pennsylvania has set out to call the attention of tourists, vacationists and sportsmen to the widely varied--and, in many cases, little known--scenic and recreational attractions to be found within her borders.

Miss Elizabeth Rogers Roberts, daughter of Justice Owen J. Roberts of the United States Supreme Court and Mrs. Roberts, was married today to Charles Hamilton of Greens Farms, Conn., son of Mrs. Burgoyne Hamilton of New York and the late Mr. Hamilton.
COVENT GARDEN opened with "The Magic Flute"--a hazardous choice if we pause to consider how vulnerable the opera is in some respects.

Commencement week in the College of Mount Saint Vincent at Riverdale will conclude with the baccalaureate service today, commencement exercises on Tuesday, and a receptions by the Alumnae Association on Wednesday.

WITH a record of 40,000 miles since Jan. 11--10,000 miles farther than any previous A. A. A. sponsored truck run-the Chevrolet long distance dependability truck swung east and south last week, it was announced. Average speed for the run was announced as being 32.43 miles an hour.

The College Track Coaches Association of America voted yesterday to return the dates of the intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championships to the last Friday and Saturday in May instead of the first June week-end, in effect for the first time this year.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Mills Fawcett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred L. Fawcett of 1,184 Union Street, Brooklyn, to William Elder Robertson, son of Mrs. John L. Robertson of Baltimore, and the late Dr. Robertson, took place here yesterday afternoon in St. Bartholomew's Church. The Rev. Dr.

Major William Kennelly has been authorized by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, Robert Westaway and Isabelle J. McDonald, executors of the Frederic A. Juilliard estate, to sell at auction on Monday, June 13, in the Vesey Street rooms, six realty parcels owned by the estate in Tuexdo Park.

The manuscripts of Pearl S. Buck's novels are to be given by her to the rare-book collection of RandolphMacon Woman's College, it was announced today at the annual meeting of the Randolph-Macon Alumnae Association here by Miss Bess Masten of Pelham, N. Y., a member of the Rare-Book Committee of the association.
Nine wer graduated today at the thirty-first commencement of Rumsey Hall School, held in Library Hall. A musical program was given and the speaking contest was held for the Edward B. Whitney Prize.

AFTER some years of flying in a pilot's cockpit we learned the other night for the first time that transcontinental travel on a sky sleeper is not all sleep. When the berth was made up, a comparatively quiet compartment became noisy.

The honorary degree of Doctor of Letters was conferred upon Mrs. Anna Lalor Burdick of the staff of the United States Office of Education at Washington at commencement exercises of the Rutgers University School of Education this afternoon.

INITIAL test flights of a twoplace cabin amphibian, with power plant located in the hull rather than in the nose, were begun last week at the Pan American Airways base in Port Washington by the Spencer-Larsen Aircraft Corporation of Farmingdale, L. I.

Physically handicapped pupils, crippled as the result of infantile paralysis, have been helped to regain partial use of withered muscles and limbs through a health education program now being given at the Seward Park High School.

THE proletarian novel lost some of its promise in Poland last Autumn with the untimely death of 28-yearold Zbigniew Unilowski, who died in the midst of completing his long, autobiographic novel, "Twenty Years of Life," a work which if finished would have given Polish fiction a new character in Kamil Kurant, the boy of the Warsaw streets.

President Roosevelt signed a bill today appropriating $900,000 to finance the Federal Government's participation in the forthcoming celebration of the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Battle of Gettysburg. Most of the money would be used to defray the traveling expenses of the aged veterans of the conflict.

Trustees of the University of Delaware today honored two faculty members on the eve of their retirement. Dean Winifred J. Robinson, head of the Women's College since 1914, and Professor Elisha Conover, for forty years teacher of ancient languages, will retire June 30.
THE most notable tribute paid to the memory of James Bryce on the centenary of his birth has been an article in The Glasgow Herald by D. W. Brogan.
FIVE singers will make their American debuts during the season of the San Francisco Opera Association, Oct. 7-Nov. 3, in San Francisco, Calif.

Confirmation of reports of substantial damage to the Winter wheat crop in parts of Kansas was received today in the form of announcements of disappointing threshing returns from the extreme south-central part of the State, where combines showed yields ranging from six to eight bushels to the acre, with a test weight as low as 39 pounds to the bushel.

Alfred Heller, 55 years old, of 54 East Fourth Street, received burns of the face and hands last night in a fire in his fourth-flooriflat. Heller was found unconscious by Captain Dennis Lane of Hook and Ladder 9, who carried him to the street.

In The Journal of the American Medical Association Drs. Edward C. Reifenstein Jr. and Eugene Davidoff of Syracuse, N. Y., report that they used benzedrine sulphate in treating twenty-eight patients suffering from delirium tremens and other mental afflictions brought on by alcohol.

J. B. Kremer of New York City and he Montclair, N. J., was elected president of the 'Dickinson College Alumni Association today. Other features of today's alumni program were the Phi Beta Kappa meeting, class and fraternity reunions and a sing on the Old Stone Steps tonight.
THIS volume is an attempt to answer the contention of Mises, Hayek, Robbins and other "orthodox" economists that economic accounting would be impossible under pure socialism.

Providence College will open its sixteenth commencement week program tomorrow with a baccalaureate mass. The Rev. Jeremiah T. Fitzgerald, O. P., vice president of the college, will be the celebrant and the Very Rev. John J. Dillon, president, will preach the baccalaureate sermon.
The 106th commencement program of New York University will be opened at 4 P. M. today with baccalaureate exercises in the chapel of the Gould Memorial Li brary at University Heights.

Across the benches of the House of Commons last week British M. P.'s debated such questions as: What effect would high explosive bombs have if dropped on derisely populated London? What would London do' if its telephone system were put out of order?
The collapse of an iron guard rail at Fort Totten, Bayside, Queens, brought death to two WPA workers on May 27 and put two others in the military hospital for brief periods, it was learned yesterday.

Dean Ignatius M. Wilkinson of the Law School of Fordham University warned here today that many conditions and trends are pointing toward a dictatorship in the United States and urged that lawyers take the lead in educating the public to a better understanding of the purposes of the constitutional system.
June and warm weather have brought activity at lake and shore developments in the metropolitan area to a high pitch.

Bonds called last week for redemption prior to maturity were in the largest volume for the period in a month and consisted principally of industrial and public utility issues called in their entirety.
The princely total of $1.50 in a dormant account in the Bergenfield National Bank is the only reminder of this community's experiment with the Townsend Recovery Plan a year ago.

Dedication of the new library at the University of Virginia, a memorial to the first president, Edwin A. Alderman, and bearing his name, will be held Monday, June 13, before the commencement exercises, Dr, Dumas Malone of Harvard is to give the dedication address.
Fingers have been pointed at the United States as far back as one can remember for a land which outrageously spoils its children.

The executive committee of the Federal Council of the Church of Christ in America at a meeting Friday called on commercial, financial, labor and transportation groups "to make sacrifices" to permit the stopping of shipments of "essential war materials" to aggressor nations.

A provision for the regulation of billboards along State highways will be recommended to the Constitutional Convention's Committee on Highways, Parkways and Grade Crossings when it opens its hearings here tomorrow, it was announced yesterday by the New York State Automobile Association.
The County Court upheld today an ordinance of this residential and college town banning all commercial amusements.
Fourteen winners of scholarships totaling more than $7,225 are announced by Swarthmore College, two of the largest awards having been established this year by young alumni.

ANY time we see the names of three writers listed on the Screen credits we experience slight premonitory tremors along the serrated ridge of our spine. When the names of four appear, the column (spinal) takes on certain of the aspects of a fretful bucksaw.

Down at the Custom House a mystery is confounding three of Collector Harry M. During's righthand men, Jacob L. Levine, Philip Komet and George Sager. They are known to thousands of New York pleasure-boat owners because they staff the Motor Boat Registration Bureau in the Custom House

Miss Elisabeth Anne Cole, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Rufus Cole of Cohomong Wood, Mount Kisco, was married this afternoon in St. Matthew's Church here to William George Frederick Botzow, son of Mrs. F. Alexander Krause of Orange, N. J., and of. the late Hermann E. Botzow. The Rev. Arthur Ketchum, rector of the church, performed- the ceremony.

The cogs of New York's vast and complex governmental machinery, the upkeep of which costs the people more than $500,000,000 annually, will be portrayed in graphic manner by exhibits in the city's World's Fair building, according to a portfolio prepared by the commission established by the Board of Estimate.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

Speaking at the 137th annual commencement exercises of Washington and Jefferson College last night, Dr. Robert E. Speer of New York declared that "a false concept of democratic principles has squeezed us down to a common mediocrity," and advocated for the graduates a three-fold creed of "truth, hope and unity."

The markets showed general improvement during the short session yesterday. Leading stocks moved up from fractions to 21/2 points on the Stock Exchange, and the turnover was 306,000 shares, heaviest of any Saturday since May 7.

A SMALL United States Army post, possibly in Nebraska, is the scene of this tale of multiple murder. The narrator, Katherine Cornish, is a visitor to the post; most of the other characters are army men and their wives and daughters. Even Katherine is engaged to a young lieutenant stationed there.

An eight-pound baby seal was born yesterday in the Central Park Zoo, the first such arrival there in ten years. Head Keeper Harry Kinney discovered the newcomer just before 7 A. M., stretched contentedly at its mother's side in the seal tank.

Dr. William E. Dodd, historian and former Ambassador to Germany, will return to his alma mater, Virginia Polytechnic Institute, to make the graduation address at the sixtysixth commencement exercises Monday. About 336 Bachelor of Science degrees and about forty-nine Master of Science degrees are to be conferred.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn. -- Knoxville, the gateway from the West to the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, expects 100,000 visitors to attend the annual Great Smoky Mountains Festival and Wild Flower Pageant scheduled to open here Wednesday and continue through Friday.

A home decorator points out that the leading motifs today for decorating the interiors of homes are: Regency, Swedish Modern, Exposi.tion Modern, Colonial, Victorian, Eighteenth Century French and Eighteenth Century English.

Marvin (Bud) Ward of Olympia, Wash., bettered the great Bobby Jones's amateur record for the St. Andrews course today by shooting a 67 in the morning round of his match in the Walker Cup series with Frank Pennink of England. Jones's mark is 68.
BEAUTIFULLY carved and mellowed antique wall paneling, from the more pretentious homes of colonial days, is now appreciated as much as- fine antique furniture.
D. Webster Lied of Denver, Pa., established a new world record in the .410-gauge event of the fifth annual North South championship skeet shoot today. He broke 97 out of 100 birds.

Plans have been completed for the annual Westchester Fete, sponsored by the Westchester chapter of the women's division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York.

Several billboards in Jersey City advertising an "Americanization Day Parade and Demonstration" and bearing a large photograph of Mayor Hague were defaced during Friday night by persons who painted the word "Bunk" in large letters and large green swastikas under the Mayor's photograph.
Returns, from 1,301 of the 1,860 precincts in today's Democratic primary gave Senator Robert R. Reynolds 192,565 votes and Representative Frank W. Hancock Jr., his opponent for renomination, 137,743.

Experts in the newer education make much' of the theory of converting work or what used to be looked upon as work-into play. If a task which the child considers uninteresting drudgery can only be turned into a game, then the day is saved and all is well.

Unless the week-end brings more definite indications from Washington of President Roosevelt's personal preference for Representative Otha D. Wearin, or some other unforseen development arouses the independent New Deal vote in the State, Senator Gillette will enter Iowa's primary Monday a favorite for the Democratic nomination to succeed himself.

The great Wearin-Gillette battle developed to a rapid climax of sound and fury in Iowa this week. There have been some spirited contests, but there has not been anything like this since Smith W. Brookhart went roaring through the tall cornfields.
Two supporters of President Roosevelt and an Administration critic campaigned today for the Senate seat of Walter F. George, who also seeks renomination.

Another string of defaults on war debts is expected on installments falling due on June 15 Notices of amounts due have been sent out by the State Department and Estonia replied today with a default on her

Miss D'Arcy Atwater, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Atwater of this place, became the bride of William Hunter Perry Jr. of Exeter, N. H., son of Mr. and Mrs. Perry of Cambridge, Mass., in St. Paul's Episcopal Church here this evening.

Lively discussion of possible candidates for this year's State election has begun in political quarters of New York. The election, regarded as the most important in many years, is being approached by the Democrats with confidence and by the Republicans with something like hone.

The members of the United States Walker Cup team will be honored at a luncheon June 14 at the Downtown Athletic Club, it was announced yesterday. The Metropolitan Golf Association, with the approval of the United States Golf Association, will sponsor the affair.

The National Broadcasting Company presented a third conductor in as many weeks when Bernardino Molinari, director of the Auguste?? concerts in Rome, took over last night's regular broadcast of the symphony orchestra from Radio City. It was the Italian conductor's debut under these auspices; he is scheduled for the next two broadcasts.

The interior of the Union Square Savings Bank, 20 Union Square, corner of Fifteenth Street, has been completely modernized and equipped with an air-conditioning system under the direction of Voorhees, Gmelin Walker, architects, with Ronald R. Pearce as consultant.

The premiere of "Gentlemen Unaffraid," an operetta based on the Civil War, opened the Municipal Theater's twentieth season last night before an audience that included Secretary of War Harry H. Woodring, who was present as President Roosevelt's personal representative.

What started out to be an exceptionally strong lawn tennis tournament turned into a squash racquets competition today as Frank Shields, Charles Hare of England and other tennis notables gathered here for the annual invitation doubles fixture of the Rockaway Hunting Club.

Veteran French Moroccan troops and Fo elgn Legionnaires patrolled the Sanjak [State] of Alexandretta tonight under martial law, with 30,000 Turkish troops said to be across the border watching their efforts to keep order.

Recent changes in the Japanese Cabinet indicate, despite strict censorship and distortion of news from the China front, that morale in Japan is disturbingly low. The Japanese public has never been allowed to learn of the reverses which have met the arms of the empire.

The convention of the National Education Association, to be held in New York City June 25 to 30, will be the most important assembly of educators in the United States this year, according to C. N. Nichols, executive director of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau of the Merchants Association of New York.
A tract of about eight acres has been purchased by the developers of the Homestead Village community in Basking Ridge, N. J., from the Ludwig Sutrb estate.
Miss Frances A. Baker, this city's outstanding parallel-street advocate and its long time benefactor, died today at the. age of 93.. She had been-ill for -several months with bronchial pneumonia.

Historic Christ Church here was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Amanda Bogardus Werth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Robert Werth of Alexandria, and Ensign John Nathaniel Boland, U. S. N., son of Commander Micajah Boland, Medical Corps, U. S. N. (retired), and Mrs. Boland of Virginia and New York. The Rev. Harry Lee Doll performed the ceremony.
Mobile guards and militiamen today joined special police patrols in combating mounted disorders among striking workers in rural sections of Jamaica.

Declaring he was "sick of life," S. Williams, 29 years old, of 203 West Seventieth Street, was found lying semi-unconscious in front of 65 Washington Street at 11 o'clock last night by Patrolman Maurice Faller of the Greenwich Street station.

The dogged run of a game but tired winner carried- him so wide through Belmont Park's stretch yesterday that a claim of foul was lodged, but Mrs. W. Plunket Stewart's Pasteurized survived this hazard as well as the stern challenge leveled by William du Pont Jr.'s Dauber.

Fred Berry, former president of the Bronx Board of Trade and vice chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement, states that much interest is being shown by owners in the opportunities now available for obtaining the necessary funds and assistance to make renovations and improvements to all kinds of properties.

The marriage of Miss Jane Osborn, daughter of Mrs. Donald Goodrich North and granddaughter of the late Colonel and Mrs. Norris G. Osborn of this city to James Hamilton Gould, son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Gould of Old Lyme, Conn., took place this afternoon in Marquand Chapel of Yale Divinity School. The Rev.

Wholesale dry goods business in May measured up to last year in unit volume. May made the best relative showing for the year to date, but buying is still conservative and mostly in small lots, with forward orders greatly restricted.

Outdistancing the field to the first turn, Mrs. Emil Denemark's Finance romped to a length and a half victory over Mrs. S. Orr's Orinoco in the $10,000 added Paul Revere Handicap today before a crowd of 26,572 at Suffolk Downs.

Competing in weather that would have had the Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce shuddering in horror, Southern California won the sixty-second championship of the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. in a miserable drizzle at Randalls Island Stadium yesterday, turning the trick with ridiculous ease as it captured its eighth team title.

A PLAN for increasing the volume of automobile travel on a world-wide scale was unfolded last week when P. J. Prochazka, well-known Czechoslovak motor authority, visited New York to discuss with American automotive and oil officials the possibility of establishing a string of auto service stations to girdle the globe.
Stephen Vincent Benet of New York City, Pulitzer Prize winner, will read a special tercentenary ode, which he has composed, at a special "State and Yale Day" program in Woolsey Hall Monday evening.

Baron Maximilian Hugh Converse von Romberg, polo player and flier, was killed today just after noon when his small cabin plane plunged into the North Shrewsbury River off Lewis Point, Fair Haven. He had been circling the area of the Red Bank Airport for several minutes, attempting to get down through a high fog to a landing.

Keen rivalry among advertising agencies for the account of the Florida Citrus Commission was concluded yesterday with the announcement that the commission had selected Arthur Kudner, Inc., as its agency.
The kitchen, in many respects, is the most important room in the modern-type home, points out W. S. Lowndes, director of architecture and building in the International Correspondence Schools.

MISSIONARY ladies are estimable persons but not, as a rule, shapely ones; nor do they usually possess large, lustrous eyes, or smiles that light up the landscape. These attributes belong to Margaret Lockwood, Gaumont's newest "find," and were the principal reasons why Margaret has been converted from a girlhood ambition to convert the heathen, and has become a screen star at the age of 19.

Class Day exercises at Skidmore College' today took the form of garden party which followed the presentation of the customary program. The official senior costume represented the peasantry of many European countries, and the Sophomore Guard of Honor,

STOCKHOLM -- Returning home from a lecture tour in America under the auspices of the Delaware Tercentenary Commission, the Swedish economist Professor Eli Hechscher deplores the current myth that Sweden is some sort of Utopia. He found Americans far too romantic about this country, he writes, and pleads for more accurate information and saner appraisals by the United States.
Ambrose O'Connell of Washington, Assistant Postmaster General, was named president of the National Notre Dame Alumni Association at the annual alumni banquet here tonight.

Federal Attorney Lamar Hardy said yesterday he had "every assurance" that the two German merchant marine captains held in $2,500 bail each in the Federal grand jury spy investigation would be available when wanted.

A historical outline of its progress was given at St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church in Colonial Heights tonight by Judge George W. Smyth of the Westchester Children's Court, a vestryman, at a dinner in celebration of the church's 140th anniversary.
Sidney S. Coggan, former varsity player at Harvard, won first prize in the weekly rapid-transit tournament at the West Side Y. M. C. A. Chess Club with a score of 10--2 yesterday.

Designs that retain their sharpness and original luster on fabrics even after repeated washing, laundering and pressing are described in a patent (No. 2,119,150) just awarded to two British inventors, Harold H. Bowen and Victor H. Majerus of Bradford, England.

Bob Johnson, slugging outfielder, today drove in four tallies with his eighth and ninth home runs of the season to lead the Athletics to a 94 triumph over the White Sox. It was Chicago's tenth straight setback.

Home financing by savings and loan associations in the United States during April totaled $62,621,000, reports Corwin A. Fergus, director of the division of research and statistics of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
Educators should be constantly alert. President Baxter of Williams College believes, to prevent the human wastage caused by maladjustment of youth to college life.

Miss Janet Porter Boomer, daughter of Mrs. George Andrew Boomer of Waterbury, was married to Lawrence Bigelow Barnard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy A. Barnard of Worcester, Mass., here this afternoon in the chapel of the Second Congregational Church. The Rev.

The appeal of a grizzled farmer's complacent countenance, the grimness of a lifeless -tree against a bleak sky, .and the inspiration of a church organist at the keyboardeach as captured by the camera-won prizes yesterday for three high school students at the first annual photographic competition and salon at Pace Institute, 225 Broadway.

The alumni association of the Webb Institute of Naval Architecture held its annual dinner last night at the Aldine Club, 200 Fifth Avenue. Sixty persons attended, including L. N. Prior, who was graduated with the institute's first class in 1897. Edward Laing was toastmaster.
Turpentlne firm, 22/c. Sales. 146 barrels; receipts, 593 barrels; shipments, 75 barrels; stock, 35,833 barrels.

Warm weather, following unseasonably cold conditions during the Spring months, appreciably onlivened business in all lines along the Pacifio Coast during the past week. Department stores report Increasing sales of women's apparel, especially suits and hats.
Clarence Dykstra, president of the University of Wisconsin, joined his class reunion at the University of Iowa today, but only after he had ridden into town "on his thumb."

The 140th anniversary of the entry into the United States Armyof Captain Irving's company, Second Regiment of Artillerists and Engineers, 1798, was celebrated yesterday by the lineal descendant of that unit.
A woman who registered Friday as Miss Anne Jordan of Branford, Conn., was found dead at 6:30 o'clock last night in her room at the Hotel Commodore, a victim of hanging.

WORLDLY: The New York State Education Department decided last week that youthful disciples of Father Divine must leave their "heavenly" names outside the school door. The decision resulted from a Kingston judge's inquiry. Asserting that "heavenly" names injured school discipline, the judge remarked: "One can imagine what will happen to the discipline in a school where a teacher is required to address a boy as 'Great Bear' or a girl as 'Bright Beautiful.'"

THE news this morning is an American opera on the nottoo-distant horizon. An opera by an American composer, wedded to a text that is written by an American author and that concerns an American subject. Principal names are, in order, Douglas Moore of Columbia University, Stephen Vincent Benet and "The Devil and Dan'l Webster."

With the regular Fall openings of furniture and floor coverings lines less than a month away, speculation regarding price trends at the twin showings in Chicago the week of July 4 was general in the wholesale market here last week.
The sight of a young man pursuing a squirrel through the leafy reaches of an oak tree in Bienville Square gave Policeman M. Marshall a start.

A guarded note of praise for the policies of Mayor Hague of Jersey City was sounded yesterday by Rabbi B. A. Tintner of Mount Zion Congregation in his Sabbath sermon at the Free Sons Temple, 257 West Ninety-third Street.

School will not close for some 8,000 of New York City's youngsters this Summer, for on June 29, three weeks earlier than last year, the WPA Elementary School Activities Project, cooperating with the Board of Education, plans to open forty Summer play schools, scattered through the five boroughs.

The somber lines of an American ama are being written today on 8,000 new college diplomas. They tell the story of war between others and sons--a war for jobs. On the one hand boys under 25 ars old just out of school.

The question of ownership of the $2,000,000 silver shipment from Loyalist Spain that arrived here Monday on the French liner Normandie consigned to the Federal Reserve Bank in New York, became the subject of court action yesterday.

May was the third consecutive month since the amendments to the National Housing Act went into effect last February to show an increase in the value of applications for mortgage insurance received by the New Jersey State FHA. Thomas E. Colleton, State FHA director,
Interest in plants of the cactus type has grown swiftly. One sees it everywhere. There are' large plantings and there are tiny dishgardens. For the house or sunroom

Continuance of the depression, accompanied by a drastic fall in commodity prices, has given rise in financial markets here and abroad in the last week to active conjecture over the possibility that the government may once more resort to devaluation of the dollar in an effort to check the deflation along the lines followed in 1933.
American citizens are "either hypocrites or just plain ignorant," Merle Thorpe, editor of Nation's Business, told the Utah Bankers Association tonight.

Which is the safest way to travelby train, plane or car? The Spring crop of spectacular air accidents, followed by a holiday framed in the familiar headlines of highway fatality, raises the issue afresh.

PARIS.--"Every budding Napoleon is rushing into print, drawing lessons from mechanized warfare as practiced in Spain. Well, sir, they all make me tired." The speaker held forth at a sidewalk table in front of the Cafe de la Paix.

Fifty private organizations and four New York City departments recently completed a series of conferences under the auspices of the Public Education Association on the subject of cooperation between social service organizations and the schools.

Better weather and heavy advertising by three store groups catering to the medium and low priced trade lifted the volume of retail sales above the week preceding and narrowed the decline from 1937 to between 10 and 12 per cent.

BULGARIA recently issued a 50stotinki (centime) coin of aluminum bronze. The coin is slightly smaller in size than our one-cent piece and its value in our currency is less than 1 cent. On the obverse is shown the crowned arms of Bulgaria supported by two lions.

AN interesting dwelling is nearing completion at the end of a cove on Pines Lake, in New Jersey, for Arthur W. Hayes. It is being erected by Richard Southman, contractor, from plans by Carl H. Weckers on a plot of about one acre.

THE same'West Coast source that sent in a bulletin the other day on the new George S. Kaufman-Moss Hart play (how it deals with the theatre; 1900 to 1930) now obliges with another report the title is "Fabulous Invalid," and its story is not only about the theatre but in one, the action taking place in various parts of a New York playhouse.
Miss Elizabeth Neville Walker, daughter of Mrs. Neville Walker of this city, was married today to Louis A. Gerber Jr. of Milwaukee, son of Mr. and Mrs. L. A. Gerber of Nutley.
June Week will start Monday at the United States Military Academy and will continue until the graduation exercises on Tuesday, June 14.

A MONG the latest Soviet publications dealing with the history of Russian music, there is one Which has attracted general attention in Moscow. It is Peter Ilyich Tchaikovsky's "Correspondence" with P. I. Jurgenson.

Dr. A. C. Smith, botanist, associate curator of the New York Botanical Gardens, and Robert P. Snedigar, zoologist of the American Museum of Natural History, the two remaining members of the Terry-Holden Guiana expedition, which was sponsored by the American Museum of Natural History and the New York Botanical Gardens with the cooperation of Mrs. Franklin S. Terry of Black Mountain, N. C., have returned to civilization after eight months in the British Guiana jungle.

John L. Elliott, senior leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, sailed from Southampton aboard the Champlain Thursday after a month spent in Vienna and Berlin obtaining freedom for two Austrian colleagues arrested during the German invasion.

The Manhattan Railway Company, owner of the elevated lines operated by the Interborough Rapid Transit Company under a 999-year lease, will 'appeal tb the Unitd States Circuit Court of Appeals tomorrow for a stay preventing the city from selling on June 30 its $9,000,000 tax lien on the elevated properties.

One of the inherent weaknesses of the income tax is that in periods of business depression the revenue from it shrinks with the national income. This is sought to be overcome by increasing tax rates; but Treasury statistics prove that in such periods increased rates do not necessarily produce increased revenues.

The pamphlet report of the Norfolk Southern Railroad Company, for 1937, issued yesterday, showed net loss of $323,541 after taxes and charges, compared with a net deficit of $391,645 in 1936. The balance.

WITH refugees from Spain and Austria now streaming into France, there is heightened in terest in Paris in the colonies of political outcasts, headed by the "White" Russians, which have grown up here since the-end of the World War.

The War Department released the following orders today. dated June 3: COLONELS Wesson, C. M., Ord. Dept., appointed as Chief of Ordnance, with rank of major general. Latrobe, O., Cav., Towson, Md., be retirement, Aug. 31.

Miss Irene Pettus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Pettus, and Philip K. Crowe, son of Earle R. Crowe of Oakstone, Wilson Point, South Norwalk, Conn., and the late Mrs. Katharine McClellan Higgins Crowe, were married here today at the Pettus estate on the St. Louis Country Club grounds.

Reports to Washington make the fact increasingly evident that nature and politics are conspiring to put Federal farm authorities to the supreme test in this first year of the new agricultural program as defined by the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938, which became law in February.

Indian Broom won the $15,000 added Marchbank Handicap today, defeating his stablemate, Whichcee, by a nose in a photo finish in the closing program of the Tanforan Spring meeting. Star Shadow the favorite, was third.

The city's 18,000 police will help the 1,000 inspectors of the Department of Sanitation in a continuous campaign to make the city's streets cleaner, William F. Carey, Sanitation Commissioner, said yesterday.

An interesting innovation in the program of the Springfield Horse Show to be given at the Eastern States Exposition in Springfield, Mass., Sept. 19 and 24, inclusive, will be the New England championship class for three-gaited saddle horses.

Danger to the very fabric of our democratic institutions in the widespread failure of the American educational system to provide an equality of opportunity will be stressed in a study by Dr. Newton Edwards of the University of Chicago, which will be published next Fall as a report to the American Youth Commission.

Large-scale emigration from Denmark across the Atlantic, halted by the reduction of American immigration quotas, was resumed today when thirty-five families, comprising 187 persons, sailed for Venezuela.
THE unforgivable sin in the United States, if you believe what publicists and politicians say, is to

The desk and chair at which Philip Hale, music critic, worked during forty years has been given by his widow to the University of New Hampshire for use in a fine arts and music appreciation center projected for the second floor of the remodeled Hamilton Smith Library Building.

THE little Revolution of Thermidor, of July, 1794, described in much confused detail by Dr. Sieburg in the latest study of Robespierre, remains only a small, climactic part of the even more obscure complex of elements and parties,

THE Dunrovin Music Festival will be held the afternoons of June 18 and 25 and July 2 at Dunrovin, Ridgefield, Conn., under the auspices of the Chamber Music Society of America. Compositions by Mozart will be featured, at least one work of that composer finding a place on each of the programs.
Mrs. Edwin R. Moore, wife of the managing editor of The Waterloo Daily Courier, died of heart disease this afternoon at the age of 65.

With the aid of lead, Harvard physicists hope to trace the earth's history back further than ever before into the ages following this planet's birth from the sun. For a timepiece scientists have used uranium-lead, a "dead" endproduct of uranium's disintegration. Because they know how long it takes uranium to "die," they can tell how old a deposit is from the proportion of live uranium and inactive uranium-lead found side by side.

More than 650 homes erected at a cost of approximately $4,000,000, were sold during May by members of the Queens-Nassau Home Builders League, it was announced yesterday by A. B. Wolosoff, president of the league.

Although certainly unwelcome to the over-the-counter dealers, there is an inescapable corollary to the present love-feast between the Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange. If the SEC is satisfied with the motives and management of the Exchange and believes that the trader will be protected in his dealings with the Exchange,
Ready for the opening of their annual meeting on Monday, the vanguard of representatives of 3,800 Christian Science churches in various parts of the world arrived here today.
A suicide by gas, according to the police, Edmund Jerome Quinn, 49 years old, was found dead at 8:15 o'clock last night in his three-room apartment on the fourth floor of 33 East Forty-third Street.
SECRET construction of a mammoth bombing plane intended for substratosphere operation by the Army Air Corps is under way in a West Coast plant, it was ascertained last week at Wright Field.
Ordinary trucks, virtually unguarded, will haul a billion dollars' worth of silver from New- York City to West Point in the next few days.
Carl W. Ackerman, dean of the Columbia University School of Journalism, made a plea today for preserving freedom of public opinion in the world press.

Holy Cross outscored Harvard, 13 to 5, in the rain today, thereby sweeping their annual two-game baseball series. Walter Klarnick, a sophomore, pitched the entire game for the Crusaders and was in trouble only when Bob Gannett hit a homer with three on in the eighth.

QUEENS PAPE, EDWARD (April 29). Assets, $21,153 gross, $13,167 net. To father, Lulgi Papa. Outstanding holdings in cash. Joseph J. Pettinato, attorney, 25-95 Steinway St., Long Island Cit. STAFFORD, GRACE L. (Oct. 1). Assets, '51,818 gross, $43,936 net. To friends, Susan Burnside and Mary Handcock, $500 each; sister, Delphine Hackett, $8,522; sister, Cecelia Purcell, $8,777; niece, Ruth Lynch, $8,592; niece, Grace Coghlan,

The Adjutant General released the following Orders today: These officers, having qualified, are placed on duty: Kutner, 2d Lt. Samuel J., to report to comManding officer 244th C. A. for assignment to Batt. F. Connelly, 2d Lt. Raymond J., to report to commanding officer 245th C. A. for assignment to Batt. L.

Dick Van Wagoner in the half-mile and the Sayville High medley relay team set new records as the Purple and Gold annexed its second major title in two weeks, capturing the thirty-fifth annual Suffolk County Class A track and field championship today.

Voicing approval of the city administration's plan to rid the streets of itinerant peddlers, the West of Central Park Association announced yesterday that it is forwarding a number of suggestions to accomplish this end to several city officials.

ONCE more in the history of China a hostile warlike nation has poured her hordes of fighting men bent on conquest and glory through the passes and gates of the Great Wall, the immense man-made barrier built to protect the populous cities and rich plains of North and Central China against invasion from the Mongolian and Manchurian plains.
The Roman Catholic episcopate in Peru has issued a pastoral letter to be read from all pulpits Sunday with the object of discouraging Catholics from becoming members of Rotary clubs.
AN Outstanding question before the broadcasting industry this week is super-power--to be or not to be? The Federal Communications Commission opens a hearing on this all-important topic tomorrow,

Representatives of more than 250 real estate, taxpayer, civic and trade associations throughout the city will meet at the Hotel Commodore tomorrow evening under the auspices of the newly-organized Real Estate Taxpayers Federation.

Prospects of an early increase in government spending for commodities, housing and public projects stimulated trading in cotton yesterday and, in sympathy with outside markets, prices at one time improved 10 points.

C. F. Sheldon of Siwanoy and F. Rowley of Garden City posted a 71 for the low medal score in the qualifying round of the Rumson Country Club seventh annual invitation four-ball best-ball golf tournament today.

The fifty-third annual commencement exercises of Wagner College will he held on Tuesday on the campus of the institution at Grymes Hall, S. I. The speaker will be Dr. Guy Everett Snaverly, executive secretary of the Association of American Colleges and former. president of Birmingham Southern College.

The engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Margaret Clowe, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Garrett Marcellus Clowe of this place, to Frederic Alliger Wyatt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Austin Wyatt of Harrisonburg, Va., was announced by her parents today, the twentyfifth anniversary of their marriage. The young couple will be married on June 25 in the Dutch Reformed Church here.

Under the terms of the recently enacted Revenue Act, rental housing corporations with mortgages insured under. Section 207 of the National Housing Act are granted full exemption from the tax on undistributed profits, Stewart McDonald, Federal Housing Administrator, pointed. out. yesterday.
Expansion of the present Dominion Housing Act and institution of a program of construction of low-cost housing were proposed in Parliament today by Finance Minister Dunning.

THE great salt-water procession is now under way, from North Carolina to Maine, and everyday now will find thousands of new anglers joining the parade from a hundred sportfishing centers along this stretch of coast.

Investment Company of AmericaMay 31: Net asset value $15.39 a share on the common stock, reflecting adjustment for 100 per cent stock dividend and 50-cent cash dividend, both payable on June 30, compared with $32.03 a share on April 30, and $59.30 a
President Roosevelt seems destined to go down in history as the American Chief of State who more than any other exercised a strong and even direct influence on Canadian affairs.

Retail trade in this district showed some improvement after the holiday, but thin was not deflected in the wholesale field. The week's volume was approximately per cent above last week, but 8 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago.

The American public's demand for water, reports the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau, has brought into existence within a century 7,100 public water systems, which deliver 1,000,000,000 cubic feet daily at the turn of a faucet. Americans use more water than any other people in the world.
Although business failures continue to run at a high level, the rate of increase over 1937 has been declining since the start of the year, it was pointed out yesterday.

Some large lending institutions have shown a tendency to put their mortgage servicing business in the hands of real estate firms, and Pease Elliman, Inc., has taken over from local and out-of-town institutions and individuals for this purpose mortgages aggregating $2,816,250 and certificate issues amounting to $124,000 since Jan. 1, according to Elbert S. Barlow, vice president.

Displays of miniature bouquets and arrangements of tiny flowers at recent flower shows occasioned so widespread a desire to experiment likewise that many a woman planter is planning to include many small flowering plants in her garden this season.

At the annual commencement today of St. Albans, the National Cathedral School for boys, nineteen members of '38 received diplomas by the Right Rev. James E. Freeman, Episcopal Bishop of Washington, and eight others received certificates.
IRON MAN: Baseball fans last week stepped up to the plate for some statistics. The occasion was the 2,000th consecutive major league game in which Lou Gehrig, Yankee
The Cardinals' winning spree was broken at four games today by Casey Stengel's Boston Bees, who collected fourteen hits for an 8-to-5 victory in the first of a four-game series at Sportsman's Park.

The commencement address at Rectory School was given today by George Emlen Roosevelt of New York, president of the Parents Association, John Bigelow, head master, awarded diplomas to Hyman L. Battle Jr. of Rocky Mount, N. C.; MacDowell Botts of Santa Fe, Arthur D. Champlin Jr. of Providence, Gilder D. Jackson 3d of Philadelphia, Richard A. Mittnacht of Old
Threatening weather failed to keep local horse enthusiasts and their guests away from the horse ring today where the closing events of the annual Tuxedo Horse Show were judged.

The Sheffield Farms Company, Inc., opened its new $2,500,000 milk depot and distribution plant at West Fifty-seventh Street and Eleventh Avenue yesterday and replaced its horse-drawn vehicles with gasoline and electric delivery wagons throughout Manhattan south of 145th Street.

Hank Borowy lost an opportunity to score his eleventh consecutive victory without a defeat this season and thus set a new Fordham pitching record when rain, which had .fallen throughout, caused the cancellation of the Maroon's game with Yale in the last half of the fifth inning today.
Swift Co., will appeal the order issued yesterday by Secretary of Agriculture Wallace directing them to cease certain trade practices, it was indicated today.

Traditional reunion, class day and graduation exercises will make up the program of Princeton University's 191st commencement festivities as announced today by Wilson Farrand, '86. chairman of the commencement committee.

Plans for the twenty-seventh Summer session at the College of William and Mary have been announced by Dr. K. J. Hoke, dean of the Summer School. The session will run for nine weeks, beginning June 20.

Pope Pius had been at Castel Gandolfo exactly a month when he entered his eighty-second year on Tuesday. His health has derived such benefit from the greater quiet and more salubrious air that he enjoys at his Summer residence that he often refers to his stay there as "providential."

THE Screen Playwrights and the Screen Writers Guild, who hate each other with a clear, clean hatred, are again actively engaged in a bitter feud which is providing the rest of the industry with mild entertainment.

The Kansas City Federal Reserve Bank reported department store sales here last week were 16.8 per cent under a year ago, Denver off 5.4 per cent, Oklahoma City off 2.4 per cent, Tulsa off 7.2 per cent, Wichita off 40.8 per cent.

Announcement of the engagement of the Rev. Dr. Alvin E. Magary, pastor of the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, at South Oxford Street, Brooklyn, to Miss Marion Janet Clayton, organist there, was made yesterday They will be married on June 21.

Miss Helen Pedersen won the women's New England tennis championship today by defeating Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio, Texas, in straight sets, 7-5, 6-1. Rain halted the contest for the men's championship after Howard Stephens, unseeded entry from Yale, had taken two out of three sets from Elwood Cooke of Portland, Ore., seeded fifth. The score was 6-1, 7-5, 0-6. The match will be continued tomorrow.
Real Summer weather has contributed its sluggish influence to the already backward business of the Eleventh Federal Reserve District, and a further slump in sales developed.

Miss Margaret Douglas Gribbel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Griffin Gribbel of Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to Cortlandt van Dyke Hubbard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Arnold Hubbard of Walpole, N. H.

Reversing their action of the previous day, the foreign exchanges weakened yesterday in terms of the dollar. The pound sterling lost 1/8 cent to $4.94 13-16 and the franc was down 1/8 point to 2.77 3/4 cents.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Elaine Inscho, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Seymour Inscho of New York, to Dr. Arren Calvin Buchanan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arren Calvin Buchanan of Temple, Texas, took place here last night in the chapel of the Riverside Church.
Sixty-eight athletes participating in three Spring sports at Lehigh University have earned letters and numerals, according to an announcement by Colonel Nelson A. Kellogg, director of athletics.

President Manuel Quezon stepped cautiously across religious, fences yesterday when he vetoed the Compulsory Religious Instruction Bill, which was insistently pressed through the National Assembly/ by the Catholic Church.
Two thousand alumni filled Archbold Gymnasium to capacity tonight for the alumni dinner, Kum Bak Show and dance which closed the annual alumni day at Syracuse University.
John Flanagan, famous early century weight-thrower and a triple Olympic champion, is dead in Ireland, his brother Tom Flanagan announced here today. John was 70 years old.
At the meeting today of the trustees of MacMurray College President C. P. McClelland announced a gift to the college by James E. MacMurray of Pasadena which has a potential value of $1,000,000.

A large marquee was erected in the garden of Sycamore Lodge, the estate here of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Brion, for the marriage this afternoon of their only daughter, Miss Lucille Louise Brion, to William Juhring Broadhurst.

Payments to farmers for livestock at the Chicago Stock Yards last month aggregated $20,184,000, an increase of $81,000, or 0.4 per cent, over payments in May a year ago. The disbursements were for 707,787 cattle, calves, hogs and sheep, or 19.3 per cent more animals than correspondingly in 1937.

With the elimination-at least for the moment-of the danger of invasion from Germany because of the lightning rapidity of Czec hoslovakia's frontier troop concentrations, it is important to see how far this threatened outpost of democracy can defend itself against the financial warfare that the world expects to see take the form of steady economic pressure by Germany.

De Witt Clinton chess players, setting the pace in the Interborough High School Chess League championship tournament, were held to a 2-2 tie by Stuyvesant in the sixth and semi-final round at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday.

THE villain still pursues the Virtuous' damsel while the handsome hero dangles from crumbling cliffs or miraculously escapes from horrible fates to give to the villain that ultimate trouncing which he so richly deserves.
THE BOY DAVID. By J. M. Barrie. With a preface by Granville Barker. 159 pages. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $2. Text of the play in which Elisabeth Bergner appeared in London in 1936.

Doubleday, Doran Co., Inc., pub: fishing corporation that has owned and operated Country Life Press, a printing plant here since 1910, has sold the establishment, it became known today, and will maintain a book-publishing concern only, with main offices in New York.

Training for a new profession, that of appraiser of the efficiency of city and county governments, is to be started in September at the University of Denver under a grant for the first year of $29,000 from the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation of New York.
Dr. Godfrey Lowell Cabot has donated $647,700 to Massachusetts Institute of Technology for research which is to discover, if possible, how the energy of the sun may be used practically.
The wide open spaces of the Drury Lane stage will be used to tell one of Edgar Wallace's stories, "Sanders of the River," a new Basil Dean production, which opens for business on Thursday.
Herman C. Doman, formerly president of the H. C. Doman Company, now the United States Motors Corporation, died today following a heart attack at the age of 80.
The New Jersey Building and Loan League ended its thirteenth annual meeting in the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall here today on a note of optimism. About 1,000 delegates were present.

Mrs. Marian G. MacDowell, widow of the American composer, Edward MacDowell, and founder of the artists' colony at Peterborough, N. H., received the honorary degree of Doctor of Letters here this morning at the seventeenth annual commencement of New Jersey College for Women. Baccalaureate degrees were awarded to 187 undergraduates of the college.

Allegheny College led in a field of six in the first intercollegiate golf tournament attempted in the district of Meadville, Pa., recently. Moving ahead on the second nine, the home forces won with a total of 355, topping Grove City, which finished with 356.

Police tonight placed a heavy guard about the home of Stanley Parrack, 37-year-old Royal Air Force aircraftsman, who was fined [Pound]25 in magistrate's court for forcing his 7-year-old son to hold hot coals in his hands as a punishment.
Edward S. Brown, New Bedford banker, died today at his home following a heart attack. His age wa 84.

Another spectacular game of Gaelic football is expected this afternoon when the Cavan and Leix fifteens of Ireland meet for the International Trophy at the Polo Grounds. In a preliminary, Cork and Galway will cross sticks in hurling at 2 o'clock.
Brig. Gen. George E. Kemp, former postmaster of Philadelphia who also served a term as City Treasurer, died of heart disease today at the Naval Hospital. He was 72 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Field were hosts tonight at a supper dance at Caumsett, their estate at Lloyd Neck, in honor of Mr. Field's son, Marshall Field Jr., and his fiancee, Miss Joanne Bass, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Perkins Bass of Peterboro, N. H., and Tucson, Ariz., whose marriage is to take place on June 20.
AN open letter to William Lescaze, by Mabel Dodge Luhan, recently published on the art page of THE TIMES, called attention once more to a question which has been repeatedly stressed in these columns.
Eight rounds of boxing and five rounds of calisthenics gave Max Schmeling a busy program today as the German continued his training for the match Joe Louis in the Yankee Stadium June 22.
With Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie heading the list, the Metropolitan Golf Association has announced its honor roll and the ratings of 1,582 players, whose handicaps range from scratch to 30.

A three day conference on educational problems in Canadian-American rela tions will be held here jointly by the University of Maine and the Carnegie Endovment for, International Peace starting June 21, Dr. Arthur A. Hauck, president of the university, announced today.

Some of the nation's best women golfers tested the sporty Oakhurst Country Club course today and their efforts were good enough to make the galleries predict a tip-top battle in the women's Trans-Mississippi tournament next week.

WASHINGTON. -- Score cards for the June brides' biscuits have been issued by the Bureau of Home Economics. The biscuits are rated on shape, crust and volume, texture, grain, color and flavor. Perfect score is 100.

INDICTMENT of eighty-six officials of automobile and finance companies in South Bend, Ind., last week on charges of violation of anti-trust laws has raised the question here of just to what extent the public will benefit should the government prove its case and present alleged practices be ruled illegal.
Conracts for supplies valued at $9,719,83 were awarded in the week nded on June 2 by fourteen Fedral agencies under the provisions f the Publio Contracts Act, the departmentt of Labor has anounced.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Carson Taliaferro of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Madge Blanding Taliaferro, to Carl Gettus Morrison of Elizabeth, N. J., son of Mrs. May Morrison of Pittsburgh.
THE mosquito-traditional enemy of tourists, campers, sportsmen and vacationists generally--is due for something of a setback in the metropolitan area during the coming Summer season.
BUCKLEY--Mr. and Mrs. Vaughn D., announce birth of a daughter, May 30, 1938, at polyclinic Hospital. CACCAVO--Mr. and Mrs. Guerino, announce birth of a daughter, May 27, 1938, at Polyclinic Hospital.

Eugene F. Poulnot, 42-year-old pressman and head of the Florida Workers Alliance, told a Criminal Court jury today how he was abducted thirty months ago outside the Tampa police station, flogged, tarred and feathered.

Joseph E. Davies, Ambassador to Russia, and Mrs. Davies returned to Moscow today from the Black Sea, where the Ambassador made a second and final extensive inspection tour before leaving the Soviet Union for his new post at Brussels.
FEW travelers making even a short visit to the northern rim of South America miss the mountain drive between La Guayra to Puerto Cabello, two of Venezuela's busy ports on the Caribbean Sea.

Premier Milan Hodza and members of the Cabinet's political cornmittee are devoting all their time to drafting the nationalties statute that is to place the relations between the Czechs and minorities on a legal basis.

Eleven institutes of international relations, conducted by the American Friends Service Committee in cooperation with the Council for Social-Action of the Congregational Church and local committees, will be held on college campuses throughout the country this month.
Plans for the first systematic study in this country of the air's ozone content, the result of which may provide a basis for long-range weather forecasting, were announced here yesterday.

In opening this year's motor show at Capetown, General Smuts, Minister of Justice, after observing that he looked forward to South Africa, in the not too far distant future becoming one of the great tourist countries in the world, sharply criticized the motor trade.

AOMI JACOB'S novels show a steady growth in technique, in characterization and in the ability to attract. She has been gradually and somewhat tentatively qualifying for a place among those writers who are able to interpret English idiosyncrasies to the English themselves and to outsiders.

IT is a pleasant surprise to find that after completing his last cycle of Beethoven symphony re-recordings with the Vienna Philharmonic and before the blight fell on that organization, Felix Weingartner was able to slip in at least one more full-length work for

Women's organization should take a stand to make sure that our democratic form of government will endure, Mrs. Elsie M. Graff of Richmond, Va., chairman of the Virginia branch of the National Woman's party, said today. She declared that action was necessary to avert a catastrophe.
The Giants, gyrating strangely at the top of the National League, cut more fancy capers today before taking another plunge that has all their followers holding their breath.

LIGHT from the full moon, which under normal conditions appears to aid short-wave reception, has during the past three months shown small proof of its ability to act as a "booster stage" to the radio set, due, it is believed by observers, to the severe magnetic storm cycle noted close to the full-moon periods in March, April and May.

After loading the new Boeing Clipper for its third taxiing test late today Robert J. Minshall, chief engineer of the Boeing Aircraft Company, said that further attempts to taxi or fly the big flying boat would be postponed until tomorrow.
Seeking a four-day renewal of friendships and memories of a quarter of a century ago, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology class of 13 returned today for its twenty-fifth reunion.

Dr. Amos O. Squire, Westchester County Medical Examiner, announced at his office here today that a pathological and microscopic examination of the torso of Peter Levine gave no clue as. to the cause of death, nor could it be determined how long the boy had been dead or how long his body had been in the water.
A series of dramatic announcements revealed to the world this week how determinedly Great Britain is now preparing to defend herself should war again sweep over Europe.

There is to be more of a split this year between the sailing and motor races of the yachting department of the New York Athletic Club out to Block Island. Instead of a getaway on the same day, the sailing division will start at 8 P. M. on July 8,

Opened last Fall, the Jane Addams Vocational High School in the Bronx, designated by the Board of Education as the central school for beauty culture, is now training about 400 girls in the art of making women more attractive. In the opinion of its founders, the school has filled an important need in the city's educational system.

Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, raised $610,000 for its Palestine projects in the first eight months of its fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Samuel J. Rosensohn, acting national treasurer. This is the largest amount collected in any similar period in the last twenty-five years.

Despite the present sag in automobile production, with weekly output running about 60 to 65 per cent under last year's volume, the industry has its attention focused steadfastly on the much publicized goal of Charles F. ??, research chief of the General Motors Corporation, who confidently looks for the registration of $7,000,000 passenger cars by 1960 in this country.

CONGRESS is beginning to look toward an early adjournment so that its members can go home and get ready for the November elections. The whole membership of the House and thirty-two Senators face the voters.

Due to the improvement in share prices yesterday the stock market was able to show a small gain on the week. The bond market, however, was far more interesting. New bond offerings were the largest of any week in more than two years.

I. Montefiore Levy, lawyer, makes the suggestion that the government grant funds to the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement and to the Demolition Bureau of the Tenement House Department in order to aid in the removal of slum areas.

Motorists gaze with interest at a big plant on the front lawn of Clarence V. Mason, a farmer here. Some stop to examine it more closely and to ask its variety. They have difficulty in believing, when they are told, that the plant, which stands about four feet high and has huge green leaves and large red blossoms, is made of cement.

Ex-President Hoover's remarks on the social philosophy of Benjamin Franklin have evoked some difference of opinion. It seems to arise, in letters to THE TIMES, from divergent views of the applicability 'of Franklin's aphorisms to our complex social structure of today.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Rosenzweig of 142 East Seventy-first Street of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hilda Rosenzweig, to Mark H. Johnson of this city and Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Johnson of New York.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has continued its downward movement, easing to 75.7 for the week ended May 28. It stood at 76.0 for the preceding week, while for the comparable week a year ago the figure was 109.7.
Commencement exercises of Bard College of Columbia University were held today for a graduating class of twenty-two.

ROBERT T. ANDERSON, owner of amateur radio station W9MWC of Harrisburg, Ill., has been selected by the board of judges for the Paley Amateur Radio Award for 1937, and will be'presented with the trophy at a luncheon on Thursday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.
TODAY I have before me ten volumes representing the rich and colorful life work of a man who is still in the prime of a career of vigorous activity.
