CONTINENTAL--3 on a Week-End: Margaret Lockwood. CRITERION--Gangs of New York: Charles Bickford.* 55TH ST. PLAYHOUSE--Courier of Lyons: Pierre Blanchar. FILMARTE--They Were Five: Jean Gabin. LITTLE CARNEGIE--Moonlight Sonata: Paderewski.*

Mrs. Reba Cole Stiles, wife of Dr. Henry W. Stiles, who retired last Fall as Professor of Anatomy at Syracuse University, died last night at a nursing home here at 28 Oxford Road after a long illness. She was 68 years old and lived on Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale. Mrs.

Weather conditions improved retail sales in urban centers last week, and showed the reverse effect to a slight degree in rural communities. The week continued the upturn begun in the previous week, with department store sales unofficially up two points in the index.

The marriage of Miss Jane Herrmann, daughter of Mrs. Charles Edward Herrmann and the late Mr. Herrmann, to William Edwin Hill Jr., son of Mrs. Hill of Orienta Point, Mamaroneck, N. Y, took place here at noon today at the home of the bride's mother.

The American League leading Indians walloped the Senators, 11 to 4, today. Hitless in the first three innings, Cleveland hopped on Elon Hogsett in the fourth, scoring eight runs. Washington had picked up a run in the first frame and another in the third.

Miss Polly Peters, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Volney Peters of Flushing, Queens, and Dorset, Vt., was married at noon yesterday to Anthony Kohout Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kohout of East Rockaway, L. I., in the Dutch Reformed Church. Flushing.
About this time each year, as the sun moves farther north daily and the heat and humidity begin to rise to the alarming point, the minds of 531 Congressmen turn to thoughts of home.

William H. Harris, 52 years old, superintendent of an eleven-story office building at 245 West Fiftyfifth Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, leaped eleven stories to his death yesterday morning from a rear fire escape og the structure.

Plans for a nationwide campaign to. stimulate home building by showing that the modern house offers greater value to the prospective home owner than ever before were announced yesterday by Joseph B. Mason, Eastern editor of The American Builder magazine.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I think we all feel that the entire country owes a debt of gratitude to Senator Harrison and his associates for the work they have done in connection with the revision of our tax laws.

A new "chivalry window," installed in the antechapel of St. George's School as a gift from the alumni, was dedicated today at an alumni day service attended by faculty, students and about 100 graduates.

Nearly 250 representatives of community, parent, student and labor groups attended an educational conference sponsored by the Teachers Union yesterday afternoon at the Russell Sage Foundation Building. i30 East Twenty-second Street.

The new Diesel liner Oslofjord, built in Bremen for the Norwegian America Line's transatlantic service, sailed from Oslo and Kristiansand yesterday and after calls today and tomorrow at Stavanger and Bergen, will begin her crossing of the Atlantic. for New York.
Retail trade in the Sixth Federal Reserve District this week was 2 to 4 per cent over the previous week but was 8 to 12 per cent below a year ago. Demand for clothing and home furnishings was slow.

Experts in the field of home construction, maintenance and operation will cooperate in a series of lectures and demonstrations on homemaking to be given in conjunction with the Westchester County Better Homes Exposition for 1938 which opens Wednesday in the County Center at White Plains.

Last year's winning combination of Martin Issler of Rock Spring and W. Halsted Taft of the home club today advanced to the semi-finals of the Montclair Golf Club's second annual member-guest best-ball tournament.
Announcement was made today by Mrs. Willing Balch of this city of the engagement of her niece, Miss Nathalie Contee Thomas Whiting, to Dr. Hugh Grigsby Whitehead Jr. of Baltimore and Norfolk, Va.

JUNE has lifted the curtain on the Summer Theatre of the Air. Presentation during the past week of "Craig's Wife" by George Kelly opened the series of Pulitzer Prize plays and the next on the card is "Anna Christie" by Eugene O'Neill, scheduled for WJZ's stage on Thursday from 10 to 11 P. M.

The report of the United States Department of Agriculture here shows that all classes of livestock closed the week at steady price levels today. Supplies and sales were small, but there was a weak undertone to the hog market.

The five-mile easterly approach to the Triborough Bridge, for which the Board of Estimate appropriated $5,800,000 last week, will be completed in time for the World's Fair, James J. Lyons, Borough President Of the Bronx, announced yesterday.
John Henry Gray, 54, formerly of Lowell, Mass., wanted for questioning in the axe slaying of Paul Barris, 24, and his stepbrother, Earl Cullen, 4, was taken into custody today at Lebanon, N. H.,

A new procedure in the fine arts examination to be held soon for high school teachers by the Board of Examiners has been proposed in a letter sent to Dr. Joseph K. Van Denburg, chairman of the board, by Charles J. Hendley, president of the Teachers Union.

Pittsburgh club officials disclosed today that, at the request of Brooklyn, they have consented to let the Pirate-Dodger game of Tuesday, June 21, in Brooklyn, be played at night instead of in the afternoon.

By slamming Tot Pressnell's first pitch to him on a line far into right center field to score Bill Brubaker from third base, Lee Handley today gave the Pirates a 4-3 victory in the eleventh inning and shattered a twogame Dodger winning streak.

In the opinion of a builder, if a new plaster wall has to be decorated immediately, it may. be sized and calcimined. In general, however, new plaster walls should be given at least two months' time in which to dry-out before attempting to decorate.

Annual communion breakfast of the Holy Name Society of the Brooklyn and Queens Department of Sanitation, Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, 9 A. M. Speakers: Mayor La. Guardia, Commissioner William F. Carey, District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan.

Samuel Untermyer, lawyer, civic leader and transit expert, was reported "much improved" yesterday at his home, 927 Fifth Avenue. Mr. Untermyer, who will be 80 years old tomorrow, has been in poor health recently, but despite that handicap has been active in his work as a Democratio delegate to the Constitutional Convention in Alany.

Opposition to the proposal to dump vast quantities of the city's ashes and refuse on the marsh islands of Jamaica Bay is gathering force, a survey indicated yesterday, while William F. Carey, Commissioner of Sanitation, still defends the plan as feasible and one which will not interfere with recreational development of the area by polluting its waters.

Across the maps in war offices throughout the world there march phalanxes of pins as military men of all nations follow the shifting tides of the world's two wars. For, from the battles of the Spanish civil war and the campaigns in the Far East there are being derived lessons of value to the military art -lessons that may well play a part in shaping the course of military things to come.
IT is fifty-one years this month since young Anne Sullivan took charge of the education of the blind and deaf child Helen Keller. It is a year and five months since the beloved teacher died.

Charles H. Kelly, vice president for twenty-eight years of the Manhattan construction firm of George A. Shedden, Inc., died yesterday after an illness of nine days at his home here. He was 68 years old.

Mrs. Selina C. Cornish, widow of Edward Joel Cornish, chairman of the board of the National Lead Company, left half her residuary estate to build Christian Science churches, it was disclosed here tonight by Lasater Terrell, member of the New York law firm of Alexander Green, who is staying over the week-end.

The New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations will hold. its fifty-first annual convention on June 15 to 17, inclusive, at Saranac, N. Y. More than six hundred delegates from 216 member groups in all parts of the are expected to be present.

TILL Eulenspiegel as he was known in Saxony, or Tyll Ulenspiegel, as Flanders which also claims to be his birthplace, spells it, has come down to us from the fifteenth century as one of the most nimble witted rascals of tradition.

The second annual junior Spring flower show presented by the Junior Garden Club Council of The New York Herald Tribune was held yesterday afternoon in the auditorium of John Wanamaker's, Broadway and Ninth Street.
Reports through foreign sources at Hankow said today that Chinese resistance along the Lung-Hai Railway in Central China had collapsed.

In the face of sharp criticism by the May grand jury and some members of the medical profession Mayor Wilson declared today that he would retain Dr. Wilbur P. Rickert as superintendent of the Philadelphia Hospital for Mental Diseases, at BYberry.

The Italian Tyrol acclaimed Crown Prince Humbert and Crown Princess Maria Jose today in an official welcome designed to show that this region, despite its Teutonic population, is Italian in sentiment.

For President Lazaro Cardenas matters have taken a decided turn for the better as a result of the ??ashing of the remnants of the power of ex-General Saturnino Cedillo in the State of San Luts Potosi This does not imply that the Mexican strong man's Problems are solved. Obviously, deep-rooted economic and international difficulties cannot be ironed out in a day.

Performer from approximately forty universities and colleges were entered tonight for the annual Central Collegiate Conference outdoor track and field championships to be run in the Marquette University Stadium Friday afternoon and night.

There werr ninety-seven craft; the largest number of the season, out in the Knickerbocker Yacht Club's championship regatta today. They had none too pleasant going in rain and fog, but a breeze from northeast by east enabled them to carry on.
IN all parts of the country educational centers have been competing for attention by staging exhibitions designed to celebrate great figures or events in history and literature.

Subway riders may see advertising posters again soon. Jules S. Freund, executive secretary of the State Mediation Board, announced yesterday that substantial progress toward a settlement of the strike of employes of the Collier Advertising Service had been made and that he was confident of an early agreement.

An 18 per cent increase in the amount invested in savings, building and loan associations during the first quarter of this year as compared with the same period of 1937 has been reported by 998 associations, the United States Building and Loan League announced yesterday.

Cooper Union will hold its seventyninth annual commencement Thursday night in the Great Hall of the Union, Fourth Avenue and Eighth Street. Degrees and certificates will be awarded to 128 graduates of the Institute of Technology, pay Art School,

Five English men defied tradition and regulations today by vaulting the rail surrounding Plymouth Rock to gambol about the historic stone as fellow-members of the Honourable Artillery Company of London looked on.

Substantial progress in overcoming the disorganization of industries and the breakdown of the State-planning apparatus that became apparent at the beginning of this year is indicated in an ambitious production program for the third quarter of this year, just approved by the government. It calls for total industrial production averaging 28 per cent higher than the third quarter of 1937.

The Board of Realtors of the Oranges and Maplewood will hold its annual golf tournament and outing on. Thursday at the Cedar Ridge Country Club, Livingston, N. J. Herbert Rumrill is chairman of the committee in charge.
Broadshouldered Charley Whitehead, 26-year-old Plainfield star, today proved that they do come back in golf when he annexed the New Jersey State amateur title for the second time in three years.
Bonds reflected a somewhat steadier undertone yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Moderate improvements were registered among the secondary and more speculative issues.
NOW that the long Winter has finally relaxed its grip on Alaska, tourist traffic to the northern peninsula begins in earnest.

IT begins to look as if the impetus of the safety campaign being waged on so many fronts was having tangible effect. Although one should not be inclined to crow too soon, 15 per cent reduction in the nation's traffic fatalities over a period of six months-with each month showing a substantial reduction compared with the corresponding month of last year--is cause for good cheer.
The New York Athletic Club will stage its annual Spring track and field games at Travers Island on Saturday, with the probability that it will be another banner show.

Charged with use of a threat in an effort to extort $2,000 from Mrs. John C. Lyons of Stockbridge, widow of a banker, Benjamin S. Mercer, 62, WPA employe; pleaded guilty today in District Court and was held for the grand jury.

The stall gate method of starting, as against the barrier method, has been favored by a vote of 694 to 444, according to an announcement yesterday by Herbert Bayard Swope of the New York Racing Commission, who has conducted a poll for the purpose of making a study of starting conditions in this country.

Great strides are being made in the protection of family health through the elimination of backsiphonage and cross-connections in residential plumbing, according to a plumbing sanitation bureau survey.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--More than 100 of the leading fencers in the East are expected here to compete in this resort's first fencing tournament on June 18 and 19.

St. Paul's Episcopal Church was the scene of a double wedding this afternoon when Miss Molly Spotswood Castle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilmot Wail Castle, became the bride of Arthur Otis Poole, son of Mrs. Harry Otis Poole,

FAST emerging from the stage of scaffolding and lumber piles, a dream city is spreading and taking shape on San Francisco Bay, a city which by next February will be known as theolden Gate International Exposition.
BRILLIANT--LOBER--Mrs. Fanny Lober of Brooklyn, N. Y., announces the engagement of her daughter, Lillian, to Mr. George Brilliant of Bournemouth, England.

Police Commissioner Valentine dismissed two patrolmen yesterday, one for a series of infractions including drunkenness, and the other for continued absence from duty. Patrolman John J. Feeley of the West Thirtieth Street station, a patrolman for thirteen years, was dismissed on nine charges over a period from June, 1937, to last month.

Fred' M. Lewis, president of the Roosevelt Salesmen's League during the unsuccessful Gubernatorial campaign of Colonel Theodore Roosevelt Jr., died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home, 2,450 Broadway. He was 64 years old.

WASHINGTON (Science Service).--So that transcontinental air passengers will sleep more soundly and not be awakened each time their sleeper-planes land, three-wheel landing gears are to be fitted to some large air transports now building.

The marriage of Miss Frances Ellena Scudder, daughter of the Rev. Walter T. Scudder of 547 Riverside Drive and South India, to Dr. Charles Stedman Glisson Jr. of Hawkinsville, Ga., took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Riverside Church.
Great Britain at long last has laid the hoodoo of the Walker Cup, and Anglo-American golf will be a better game for it.

It is currently believed in France that, especially since the annexation of Austria to Germany, there is no real enthusiasm in Italy for the Rome-Berlin axis and all that might entail. Some say that Premier Mussolini's daughter Edda, wife of the Foreign Minister, Count Ciano, was the inspirer and principal artisan in linking Fascist and Nazi fortunes and that II Duce himself has been only halfhearted in his approval.

WHAT Premier Edouard Daladier and his government are trying to do is to get more work and enterprise out of the French people. It would of course be an easy enough business if this country were not firmly and fundamentally democratic in construction and individualist in spirit. All that the government would have to do would be to apply the lash in the different forms that it is applied elsewhere.
There is an increasing prospect that Britain will place larger orders for American airplanes than had been expected when the British air mission returned from the United States early this week.

President Roosevelt, about to name a commission of labor, industry and public representatives to study the workings of the British Trade Disputes and Trades Unions Act of 1927, has focused attention on the British system of handling labor disputes.

Joe B. Bates, Democrat, won by 2,400 majority from Dr. James Cecil Sparks, Republican, today in a special election to fill the vacancy in the Eighth Kentucky Congressional District, according to unofficial returns complete from all but one of the twenty counties in the district.
Robert John, a consulting engineer with laboratories at West End, Long Branch, N. J., died yesterday in his apartment at the Hotel Roosevelt after two years illness at the age of 62.

When 100 top-notch players tee up at the Century Country Club, Purchase, N. Y., tomorrow, in an attempt to wrest the metropolitan championship from Mrs. Harry McNaughton, the former Miss Marion Turpie, they will face a most difficult task.

ON BORROWED TIME--Friday afternoon at the Longacre Theatre. This is a special performance in aid of the Actor Fund of America. Dudley Digges and Pater Holden are the two chief players in the Paul Osborn dramatization of the Watkin novel. The tickets are tax-free.

Canning and the late Mrs. Jane Hitchcock Canning of Youngstown, Ohio, were married here today in Epworth Methodist Episcopal Church by the Rev. Roland L. Luerich, the pastor.

The Marquis and Marquise de Chambrun and their son and daughter-in-law, the Count and Countess de Chambrun, are at the Pierre, and will depart shortly for their home in Paris. William Labrot has joined Mrs. Labrot at their home in Bermuda. Mrs. Stanley Matthews Lawson has come to the Biltmore from Cincinnati.
Eire is now in the midst of a general election and, with polling day less than a fortnight away, leaders of all parties are busy conducting intensive campaigns in all constituencies.

To The Screen Edttor: We hope that Paramount Pictures realizes the importance of its surrender to governmental propaganda. In allowing the factor of possible non-cooperation to influence.its intention in the film "Men With Wings," as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 29, Paramount has set a dangerous precedent.

HERE in this aloof and comparatively safe America so many earnest readers struggle, from day to day, with the jig-saw puzzle of confused Europe and perhaps become discouraged as the pieces refuse to go together and reveal the clear picture of what is going on.

Governor Chandler took under consideration today a third plea for clemency for four officers and members of the United Mine Workers of America sentenced 'to life after the "Battle of Evarts" in Harlan County on May 5, 1931.
The Maryland Yacht Club opened the Chesapeake Bay regatta season today with two days of racing scheduled for motor and sail craft.

ALTHOUGH the annual statistics coldly printed on this page last Sunday recorded another recession in the theatre business, the season has left a remarkably warm impression on the minds of theatregoers. From the point of view of general interest and enjoyment this has been the best season New York has had for some years.
Bathtubs which are set in recesses are featuring doors at the side which open to reveal shallow shelves, convenient for storing soap, lotions and similar articles.

Austin Prokop, 17-year-old swordsman from Stuyvesant High School, emerged victorious in the first annual tourney held under the auspices of the Interscholastic Fencing Alumni Association at the Washington Irving High School gymnasium last night.

Miss Claire Augusta Bryant, daughter of Mrs. Ella D. Bryant, was married this afternoon at the Mt. Fern Methodist Episcopal Church to Donald Charles Kitchell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ross Kitchell of Morris Plains.
Today New York Civic Orchestra, WPA Federal Music Theatre, 1:30 P. M. Conductor, Eugene Plotnikoff; soloist, Henri Deering, piano; commentator, Danton Walker. Rachmaninoff program.

Mrs. Nellie Tayloe Ross, director of the mint, told Wisconsin Democrats at a rally today that government resources are marshaled as never before in warfare against age-old evils hampering mankind's progress.

Tom Girdler, chairman of the Republic Steel Corporation. told alumni of the Case School of Applied Science today: "We actually have not begun to see the extremes to which Left Wing planners would go if given a free hand.

Travelers whom kind fortune has led to the Dordogne region will smack their lips reminiscently over the 67cent luncheon Mr. Percy Philip describes with such relish in an article from Perigueux in THE TIMES Magazine today.

At the age of 60 when most persons prefer to talk of the "good old days" rather than of the future, James Stevenson Cushing, a retired farmer with twenty-five years' experience behind the plough, is ready to pound himself a new career behind a typewriter in a newspaper office.

The Cubs climbed within a half game of first place in the National League today when Larry French turned in a six-hit, 5-to-1 victory over the Phillies while the league-leading Giants were losing to the Reds.

Five records were broken and another equalled as the Red and White athletes of Freeport High captured the annual Nassau County interscholastic track and field championship today at the Port Washington High field.

Discussing some of the suggestions recently made for the improvement of housing conditions for families of low income, Charles Partridge, chairman of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board's subcommittee on housing, declared yesterday that of the various proposals submitted to the State Constitutional Convention the measure presented by Joseph Clark Baldwin seemed to be the best.

An exclusive quarter-acre of alfalfa, grown especially for the occasion, was harvested today by a crew of farm hands who included Vice President Garner, a dozen members of Congress, an admiral, a general and about 500 others.

Surrogate James A. Foley signed a decree yesterday granting the right to administer the three-million-dollar estate of the late John Thomas Smith, resident of the lower West. Side, to four cousins who filed affidavits Thursday as the nearest surviving kin of the decedent.

Baker of 325 East Seventy-second Street, New York, was married here this afternoon in the Unitarian Church to Thomas Corwin Mendenhall 2d, .son of Mrs. Charles E. Mendenhall of Madison, Wis., and the late Professor Mendenhall, wellknown scientist.

Miss Henrietta A. Fox, principal of publio School 146, Brooklyn, for nearly four years and connected with the school system since 1889, died on Friday at her home, 325 First Street.
J. B. Potter, general manager of the Wilkes-Barre Railway Corporation, died suddenly at his home in Huntsville today after a heart attack. A native of Whitehall, N. Y.,

Boston University, paying its first visit in a racing shell to the waters of New York, defeated Manhattan and Rollins College in the Henley distance varsity race that closed the local rowing seasonn yesterday.
Holiday influences ruled today in the foreign exchange market here and movements were small. The dollar closed a shade weaker at $4.94 3/4 to the pound sterling.

Veterans' groups planned to be observers tomorrow when Camp Nordland, the German-American volksbund camp at Andover, observes its first anniversary. August Klapprott, president of the New.Jersey division of the bund, said Fritz Kuhn, national leader, would speak.

More than 1,000 delegates, representing candy manufacturing companies in all parts of the country will attend the fifty-fifth annual convention of -the National Confectioners Association, opening for four days at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria tomorrow.

The Relief-Recovery Bill has passed the House and the Senate and is now in conference. In an effort to present the fundamental facts about the unemployment situation which the measure is designed to relieve, THE NEW YORK TIMES framed the following questions to be submitted to the various government departments in Washington concerned with the relief and recovery problem. The answers are therefore official.

An important decision defining the duty of a property owner to make the use of the sidewalk adjacent to his premises safe for traffic or to give warning of danger, was recently rendered by the Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court, Second Department, points out Samuel R. Schneider of the New York bar.

Aubrey Williams, deputy administrator of the WPA, blamed monopoly tonight for many of the nation's economic ills. He spoke before the National Federation of Settlements in place of Harry L. Hopkins, who was unable to appear because of illness.
BUSY day. The Marnix arrived around 11 A. M., gliding slowly into what looks like the world's largest and most beautiful seaport between dozens of little Battery Islands.
TRUMBULL WHITE was a war correspondent during the Spanish-American War and was present at the

Installment selling in this recession as in the 1929 depression has proved its ability to withstand business and industrial setbacks. Losses to department stores and other retailers still average less than 1 per cent on sales, according to authorities in this field.

Of all Chancellor Hitler's works the one that is so far commanding only universal praise and admiration, not only of Germans but particularly of foreigners, is the great network of high-speed, crossingless, doubletrack, long-distance motor highways that is beginning to criss-cross the German landscape and is rapidly tying "Great Germany" together.

YES, it seems, the time has come for every Equity member--and all who aspire to that lofty station--to turn his thoughts to the theatrical emporia which are within ear-shot of mooing cow neighing mare and crowing rooster.
Faced with a list of approximately 300 varieties of the Oriental Poppy, how, can any one pretend that this perennial cannot be used harmoniously in his garden?

A lifetime spent in the dry goods business has convinced 83year-old John H. Anderson that styles may change but women do not. "I've been waiting on women since I was a lad of 15," says Mr. Anderson, "and they're just as fussy as they were seventy years ago."

The removal of Victor A. Christgau as State Administrator of the Works Progress Administration by Harry L. Hopkins in compliance with demands of the Farmer-Labor party leadership leaves Minnesota confused as to the role of the national Administration in the State primary campaign.

IT sounds contradictory, but it is nevertheless true, that though Jean Jacques Rousseau is convicted by modern research of romanticizing his behavior, of telling premeditated untruths and twisting disagreeable realities into beauty of form,

A strong and aggressive program by the country's savings and loan associations is necessary, declares Dr. W. H. Husband, member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, if they are to meet the problem and seize the opportunity for increased business afforded by the present housing shortage.

THE years of this novel are, indeed, American years. Mr. Sinclair has written a panorama of pioneering, a story of the frontier of Everton, Ill, from 1830-56, that is genuinely organic to its time, its place and its people.

A FLAMING crown of fire, five miles in diameter and 4,000 feet above the floor of this beautiful Alpine valley, is the spectacle that will thrill crowds of Summer tourists and others in this little resort on a midsummer night late this month.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has granted an application by the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, of the Associated Gas and Electric system, for exemption from the requirement of filing a declaration covering issuance of a $250,000 note carrying 2.88

After two years of study in limited markets here and abroad, the applance and merchandise department of the General Eiletric Company has decided to offer a comlete electric floor conditioning service, it was announced yesterday.

I foresee the independence of India in another two or three years," Mohandas K. Gandhi told this reporter in an exclusive interview from his bed in a seaside bungalow near Bombay, where the leader of the Indian masses directed the momentous conferences aimed at of fecting Hindu and Moslem unity in India.
Joseph K. Willing, lawyer and civic leader, 49 years old, died today at his home in Elkins Park.
William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said in a radio address tonight that his organization was interested only in helping business and was not "out to destroy" it.
The American Civil Liberties Union asked the Labor Relations Board today to clarify the employer's rights of free speech under the Labor Relations Act.

A sharp reply to the recent warning of Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, that the American people endangered peace by assailing the domestic policies of foreign nations was made yesterday by Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the New York Methodist Area, who termed such talk "exasperating" and asserted that "we have a perfect right to speak out."

Izvestia today reported the exposure by the NKVD [secret police] of a spy ring in Leningrad headed by a woman dentist identified only by the initial K. The number involved was not given and as to their fates it is said they received "merited retribution."

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Elizabeth Weller, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Weller of Orange, to John Rolston Westendorf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus E. Westendorf of Upper Montclair, N. J., took place this evening in the home of the bride's parents.

The Tuesday evening performance during the regular test period from 8 to 9 o'clock will be a marionette show arranged by the Federal Theatre division of the WPA. In addition Irving Caesar will sing safety songs and there will be a one-act dramatic sketch, "The Game of Chess."
FLOWERS will soon be in full bloom in the Arctic. On the most northerly island of the North American Continent, Ellesmere Island. stretching to within 400 miles of the North Pole.

Close-of-play scores in firstclass English cricket matches started today follow: Middlesex, 572 for eight wickets (Robins 137. Price 69, Smith 68 not out, Edrich 62, Hulme 56); vs. Sussex, at Lord's. Gloucestershire, 221 (Alien 52, Hazell four wickets for 42); Somerset, 167 for one wicket (Gimblett 67, Lyon 55 not out), at Taunton.
Opening of the New England University College at Armidale. New South Wales, an apparently innocent enough move, has far-reaching implications fbr Australian education.
Manufacturers of all types of grocery products will gather at Hot Springs, Va., tomorrow and Tuesday for the mid-year meeting of members of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America.
In the Book Review of May 15 Fred T. Marsh reviews "Free Land" not as a novel but as one of the "human documents (that) cannot be dismissed by the social historian."

The present inquiry into the activities of German spies in and near New York is one of the most extensive spy hunts this country has seen since the war. The storyrevealed bit by bit much in the manner of a mystery story--has developed as follows: ...
A monument and tablet in memory of Chief Daniel Nimham, Revolutionary War Indian, who aided the Americans, was unveiled here this afternoon, a gift of the State to Dutchess County.

EDWARD L. RYERSON Jr. was elected president of the Chicago Orchestral Association at a recent meeting, succeeding Charles H. Hamill, who was made honorary president of this controlling body of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra.

Reports from Seville received here today are to the effect that marked unrest is increasing among Insurgent troops in the city, particularly among the staff officers attached to General Gonzalo Queipo de Llano's headquarters.

PANAMA is joining the list of American and European countries which, with a constitutional form of government, are postally commemorating the Constitution of the United States in response to the suggestion made last year by

Eightythree enlisted men of the Navy and Marine Corps passed the examinations in April for admission to the Naval Academy. This is the largest number who have qualified for appointment by the Secretary of the Navy since 1930.

Princeton topped Penn's nine in both games of an Eastern Intercollegiate League double-header on Franklin Field today. The Tigers won the first game, 4--3, and followed with a 5-2 victory to sink the Red and Blue deeper in the cellar as the losers ended their circuit campaign.
THE officers of the American Contract Bridge League have prepared figures proving, they say, that the game of bridge is directly responsible for $250,000,000 in annual sales for American merchants.

Seward Park and Abraham Lincoln gained the final round in the city P. S. A. L. title handball championship yesterday. The former, the Manhattan division winner, vanquished James Monroe, the Bronx champion, 3--2, at Macombs Dam Park, while Lincoln subdued Tilden, the Section 1 Brooklyn ruler, 4--1, at Lincoln Field.

Lowering a ceiling does not entail any serious structural problem. Along the joists in the old ceiling small holes are cut at intervals of about three feet so that spikes can be driven into the sides of the joists.

Two youthful thugs who bound their victim with her own silk stockings and gagged her with one of her husband's handkerchiefs held up and robbed Mrs. Pauline Engel, 38 years old, in her apartment at 5,501 Snyder Avenue, Brooklyn, at 11 o'clock yesterday morning. They escaped with $81 in cash, three rent checks and a large quantity of jewelry.

A dispatch from Copenhagen to THE NEW YORK TIMES March 10 said that Denmark's famous gymnastic system, developed by Niels Bukh, would be adopted in Germany and that leaders of German provincial and local athletic organizations would study in the Bukh academy.

Miss Elizabeth R. Gracy, daughter of Mrs. Leonard R. Gracy of Montclair and the late Major Gracy, and Thomas Ramsey Kenny, son of Mr. and Mrs. T. Frederick Kenny of Buckingham, Quebec, were married this afternoon in St. Luke's Episcopal Church here.

The financial condition of the railroads is serious and, in some cases, alarming, F. E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad, said in a letter to Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania made public yesterday.

NOT so long ago this department dwelt on the complete absence of variety in many a night club floor show. Out of the mailbag has come a memorandum from an entertainer who offers an explanation for that state of affairs. As follows:

Miss Eleanor Cameron, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm John Cameron, was married to Albert Edwards Case Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Case of Westfield, N. J., last night in Immanuel Church, Westerleigh, S. I. Palms and lighted tapers provided a background for the ceremony, which was performed by the Rev. Daniel Weeks of the Fifth

The twenty-first annual open tennis tournament for the Brooklyn championship will begin this morning at 10 o'clock at the Terrace Club, and as many matches as possible will be run off to make up for time lost yesterday, when rain washed out the first round.
The Edmonton Bulletin said today that the Alberta Government had defaulted on a debenture issue of $2,000,000 bearing interest at 4 per cent and due on June 1.

The problem of household help was discussed last week in the United States Senate. Domestic service training is among the projects proposed under the huge new work-relief appropriation, and the Senators heard--as every housewife knows--that competent help is hard to find.

The action of the Appellate Division in creating a special term of the Supreme Court to hear certiorari proceedings for the review of realty tax assessments was praised yesterday by Lawrence B. Elliman, president of Pease Elliman, Inc., and chairman of the committee on certiorari proceedings of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, one of the groups which long have urged such action.

It was a week ago tonight that kidnappers seized slumbering James Bailey Cash Jr. from his bed, and his father, commenting publicly. for the first time, said today he and his wife had abandoned hope that they ever would see their only child alive again.
The Misses Ruth and Theda Simpson, daughters of Mrs. William Ewell Simpson of this place and the late Rev. Mr. Simpson, became brides this afternoon in a double ceremony at the home of their mother.

Police issued a warrant today for the arrest of Lawrence Gough, 31-year-old former waiter and short order cook, sought for questioning in connection with the murder of Laura Krenrich, a 38-year-old beautician, whose body was found crammed in a chest in her apartment.

A strange case of a woman who successfully posed as a man, and as a decorated civil war hero at that, has been brought to light at Novosibirsk, and the woman has just been sentenced to five years' imprisonment and confiscation of all her property.

About 100 members of the Westchester County Historical Society arrived in Greenwich today for their sixteenth annual pilgrimage. The automobile caravan was met at the Putnam Cottage, of Revolutionary War fame, by First Selectman Eugene S. Loughlin, who gave an address of welcome.

The State Labor Relations Board formally certified yesterday the Building Maintenance Craftsmen of the Building and Construction Trades Council, an A. F. of L. affiliate, as collective bargaining representative for 1,098 maintenance workers at Rockefeller Center.

The annual daisy chain ceremony and presentation of tokens of membership in the senior honor society occupied students of the College of New Rochelle this afternoon. Graduation exercises will be held Monday afternoon.

GUSTAV V. Sweden's tennisplaying sovereign, will attain the age of 80 years on Thurs day of next week, and his government will give him a birthday gift in the form of stamps bearing his portrait and inscribed with the dates 1858 and 1938.

Theodore E. Ferris, naval architect, announced yesterday that the new freighter Quaker, built at the Pusey Jones yards in Wilmington for the Philadelphia and Norfolk Steamship Company, received her sea trials off the Delaware Breakwater on Friday.
Honorary degrees will be conferred by Pennsylvania Military College Tuesday upon Attorney General Cummings. Others to be honored are Judge Chester H. Rhodes of the

The Sweet Pea and Rose Show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society will be held tomorrow and Tuesday under the auspices of the Horticultural Society of New York, at 598 Madison Avenue, New York City. It will be open to the public on Monday from 2 to 10 P. M., and on Tuesday from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M.
The La Salle Military Academy trackmen from Long Island defeated Admiral Farragut Academy today in a pouring rain, 51 2-3 to 28 1-3. Graves of Farragut won the

REGARDLESS of class, money or political affiliation, every audience at every show says practically the same things. Regardless of class, money or political affiliation, the spontaneous adjectives are "swell" and "lousy" thrown at the same work by opposing views, each side believing he recognizes "real values."

King George's former home, before he had any idea that he would be called upon to ascend the throne, is to let. The house, 145 Piccadilly, was the first British royal residence to open direct onto a public thoroughfare or bear a street number. And it is the only house with. a number in which a British King lived and reigned, says The London Sunday Express.

Seton Hall College here will limit registration in September to prevent-too rapid expansion and promote closer contact between teachers and students, according to its president, the Rev. Dr. James F. Kelley.

The first of a series of meetings of property owners in the headquarters of the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement at 90 Park Avenue will be held at 11 A. M. on Tuesday to consider rehabilitation of old structures fronting on Tompkins Square, Bernard F. Hogan, chairman of the committee, announced yesterday.

THE festival of the International Society for Contemporaneous Music will be held June 17-29, in London, England. It is seven years since the festival was last staged in that city, where it is being held in conjunction with The London Daily Telegraph and Morning Post and substantially supported by the British Broadcasting Corporation.

RETAIL sales eased further last week in most sections of the country, according to reports received here, and trade volume, therefore, appears to be running currently at not much above the 1934 level.
With minor exceptions, retail trade continued to show sharp declines from a year ago last week, and in some sections the drops were the sharpest in several months.

The hunts season on Long Island will open Saturday with the Spring meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association at Roslyn on the estate of Charles V. Hickox. Entries for the six events comprising the program and the demand for box seats and parking reservations indicate that the meet will be the most successful the association has held in many years on its Long Island course.

Retail trade, as measured by department store sales in Boston, was a bit better last Week, running only about 4 per cent under a year ago, whereas for the several preceding weeks the loss had been about 8 per cent.

Dr. John W. Studebaker, Federal Commissioner of Education, will be the speaker at the commencement of Muhlenberg College Monday. Dr. Studebaker will receive the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws. Reuben J. Butz of Allentown, president of the college board for twenty-five years, and Dr. John A. Schaeffer, president of Franklin and Marshall College, will be similarly honored.

Eighteen Barnard College students will attend the fifth camp leadership course to be given at Barnard Camp, near Ossining, N. Y., from tomorrow to June 20 under the direction of Miss Margaret Holland of the physical education department.

IN parks and picnic groves, on camp sites and farmland, Boy w Scouts are staging "camporees" these week-ends. Camporees mean chances for the lads to live on their own for one or two days afield, in normal patrol formation, during which period adult judges appraise the Scout camping skill.

Clark University, enriched since June by the addition of a new gymnasium and looking forward to a new auditorium and library, held commencement exercises on the lawn of President Atwood's home today, awarding 107 degrees, including three honorary degrees, as follows:
Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, addressed more than 500 pupils and visitors today at the annual children's day program of the Dobbs Ferry Children's Village.

Miss Tacie Nairn Sergeant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Sergeant of this place, was married here this afternoon in Grace Church to Briscoe Baldwin Ranson 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Briscoe B. Ranson Jr. of Maplewood.
Given a hustling ride by Albert Schmidl, Sturdy Duke, the property of R. S. McLaughlin of Oshawa, Ont., scored a surprise victory in the $2,500 added Belle Isle Handicap at the Fair Grounds today.

Despite the business decline in the latter part of 1937, the bad-debt loss ratios of representative mem ber companies of the National Association of Credit Men reveal these wholesalers, manufacturers and bankers had a better loss record last year than in the reputedly more prosperous 1936, according to a survey released yesterday by the asso ciantion's Economic Credit Council.
A Lyceum Theatre audience was thrown into a panic tonight when a lone gunman arose as the final curtainfell and shot a Chinese official of the International Business Machines Corporation.

Two invasions of Europe will be started from New York this month by American speedboat drivers in hopes of bringing back some of the world-famous trophies, but the personnel of one of the parties suddenly became in doubt yesterday.

THERE was a great track and field meet at Randalls Island yesterday, but only a scattered assortment of hardy track fans saw it. To the great grief of the I. C. 4-A officials, the expected crowd didn't arrive. Instead of that, to borrow the Bromfield title.

IN April, 1925, John L. Baird, an obscure young Scotsman, gave the first demonstration of television. Awed spectators crowded around his televisor in a pitch-black room, and on a screen measuring about 4 by 2 inches saw a doll and a barely recognizable face.
Senior Week will begin Thursday morning at Manhattan College when members of the graduating class will gather in De La Salle Chapel for the two-day retreat held annually for the outgoing class.
The reception committee of the American Women's Club gave its annual tea this week at the clubhouse for new members who include Mrs. Eldon F. LeP. Power and Mrs. C. R. Merrill.

A group of Westchester club women have arranged for a series of sixteen lectures for housewives and prospective brides on problems concerning the home, to be given in conjunction with the annual Westchester County Home Show which opens Wednesday at the County Center here.

The Edison Electric Institute will open its sixth annual convention here Tuesday. Business sesions will continue for three days in the municipal auditorium and headquarters will be at the Hotel. Traynmore.

THE cattle kingdom, long the happy hunting ground for romancers, has of recent years enjoyed the more prosaic attentions of historians and economists. Few chapters of our history, indeed, combine more happily dramatic interest and historical significance.

The twelfth convention for the revision of the Constitution of New Hampshire has asked the electorate to decide in November if they want graduated income and inheritance taxes and a sales tax; also, whether absentees shall be allowed to vote in the
Having cocked a suspicious eye at the Federal Theatre Project since its inception in 1935, Broadway might well have had a change of heart last week and said "Move over."

After a widespread police search for him had failed, Raymond Swinscoe, 39-year-old WPA worker, who disappeared from his home at 995 Rossville Avenue, Rossville, S. I., about 10 P. M. Friday just as his
Ten persons were injured, three seriously, in an automobile collision yesterday afternoon at 188th Street and the Grand Concourse, the Bronx.
Senior Week at Hunter College will begin this Friday, June 10, when senior class night will start a week of gala affairs. The senior dance will be held the following evening at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel.
Retail sales in local department and specialty stores during the last weel lagged considerably behind last year, according to this week's sum mary of the Federal Reserve Bank

THE coming of the Lunts is very good and very bad for us--bad, at any rate, for those unthinking disparagers of our native product who -assume that all the American theatre is as good as this and that our lamentably contrasted average makes backwoodsmen of us all.
Rain yesterday forced the postponement of the Yankee-Browns engagement at the Stadium, paving the way for a double-header this afternoon, with the first game starting at 2 o'clock.

Plans for the first multi-family housing project in New York City to receive a commitment of insurance under the section of the National Housing Act authorizing mortgage insurance by the FHA on rental projects up to $200,000 were announced yesterday by.Thomas G. Grace, State FHA director.

Miss Irene Alba, 22 years old, a waitress, of 34 Prospect Street, Brooklyn, told the police yesterday that she had been kidnapped at 1 A. M. by two strangers and taken to Jersey City as the result of her complaint of extortion against Andrew Barcia, 30, of 134 Bridge .Street, Brooklyn.

A CONFERENCE of all dancers to discuss the possibilities of establishing a Fine Arts Bureau in the Federal Government has been called by the Federal Arts Committee and a number of interested dancers for Friday evening.

The series of garden parties for the benefit of the Youth Consultation Service of the Church Mission of Help, arranged by the Queens and Nassau Advisory Committee, will be concluded with the opening to the public of Mrs. James Tisdale's gardens at Stony Brook, L.

General Malin Craig, chief of staff of the army, gave the commencement address to the sixty members of the Basic Class at the Carlisle Army Medical Field Service School at exercises held in the War Department theatre here this morning. Surg.

Conferees on the Wage-Hour Bill adjourned this evening without having made noticeable progress toward a compromise between the widely diverse Senate and House bills, but there were indications that sentiment was swinging toward a flexible standard under the administration of a control board or administrator, after the general pattern set in the Senate bill.

The Bay Parkway baseball team rallied with six runs in the seventh inning to defeat the House of David, 9 to 6, at Ebbets Field yesterday before a crowd of 4,500 persons. The contest, played in a steady rain, was held for the benefit of the Brooklyn Masonic Free Employment Service Bureau.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Allen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Warner Allen of 97 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, to Richard Zellner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Philip Zellner, also of Brooklyn, tool place yesterday afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church of Brooklyn.

The Scarsdale Realty Board reports that during May its members sold in that section of Westchester County eighteen homes and six building plots, in addition to leasing twenty-four dwellings and renewing leases on thirteen homes.
The Hudson County eleven of the Brooklyn Cricket Club, which holds the New Jersey State Cricket League title, today defeated Bloomfield by 64 runs in a league fixture at Watsessing Park.

The annual 22.6-mile race around Absecon Island for a leg on the Judge Emil Auerbach trophy will be held tomorrow afternoon, rain or shine, provided the ocean is not too rough. This year's race, the second, was originally scheduled for Decoration Day, but was postponed because of high waves.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy E. Clock, daughter of Mrs. Earl Russel Clock of Clear Lake, Iowa, and New York, to Edward H. Wack, son of Mrs. George Wack of New York, took place here last night in the apartment of the bride's mother at 285 Central Park West.

The marriage of Miss Anne Francoise Charlton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Charlton, to Theodore William Eselgroth, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edmund A. Ehiers, took place this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church with the Rev. Gerald A. Cunningham officiating.

At commencement exercises to be held next Saturday morning, a class of sixteen will be graduated from the Newman School for boys. Diplomas will be presented by Bishop Moses E. Kiley of the Trenton Diocese. Douglas Jerrold, English author and publisher, will deliver the commencement address.

There is no law, of course, against cruising along Great South Bay and adjoining channels to the Peconics in any other month than June. But somehow or other this is the time of year when hundreds of craft in yacht-club fleets turn to fishing.

THERE are two factors in the Czechoslovak situation which cannot be fully appreciated from a distance. One is the natural protection the Czech border affords and the way in which the Czechs have made the most of their position.

Thomas E. Colleton, New Jersey FHA director, stated yesterday that on June 1 last the grademarked lumber requirement under the FHA regulations had been in effect in that State for one year and its results had been highly successful.

Definite indications that large companies are looking for a business revival in the Fall was given last week, when a start was made by a few organizations on merchandising and promotional plans for the last four months of the year.
William H. Little has been elected to captain the Northeastern University baseball team for next season, it was recently announced by Coach Herb Gallagher. Lornts Nilsen was selected manager.
A FEW days ago there met very quietly in Washington a group of key highway men from New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Maryland and Delaware at the behest of Representative Ira Walton Drew of Pennsylvania.

A crowd gathered tonight to peer through the windows while the Nat Joneses turned on their lights. Current from the Tennessee Valley Authority's Wilson Dam, at Muscle Shoals, transmitted to Memphis via Pickwick Dam, came into the bungalow of the Jones family, the first customers of the Memphis municipal distribution system.

Alarmed by an outbreak of "vicious and brutal assaults" on home relief investigators by disgruntled relief recipients, Welfare Commissioner William Hodson made a personal visit to Harlem Court yesterday to plead for judicial aid against the attackers.
IN this, his second novel, Clyde Brion Davis, author of "The Anointed," presents the bitter comedy of a newspaper man who hoped to write a great novel.

Mr. and Mrs. Luther Loomis Killam of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Killam, to Joseph Farley of Greenville, Calif., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Allen Farley of Rochester, N. Y.

Six and a half tons of spinach will await the appetites of Boy Scouts of Greater New York who attend the Ten-Mile River Scout camps at Sullivan County, N. Y., this Summer, according to Boy Scout officials.
The regular art auction season terminates this week. There was one sale last week--that of the Gerald B. Stretton collection at the Parke-Bernet Galleries-and there will be two this week.

THIS is the season when the average photographer turns at least a part of his attention to gold toning. The Winter's crop of prints; though long since taken, are still material for experimentation and, in addition, warm weather has brought many pictures ideally adapted to the process.

The National Association of Dress Manufacturers is urging recognitoin by New York City authorities that shipments to retailers made through packing companies are in interstate commerce and therefore not subject to the gross sales tax.

POSTMASTER GENERAL FARLEY'S announcement that a three-cent stamp is to be issued "in commemoration of the centennial anniversary of the establishment of the Iowa Territory under the Territorial form of government" is another logical step in

Miss Barbara Hill, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Miner C. Hill of 108 East Eighty-sixth Street and Oyster Bay, L. I., was married to John E. Siegel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Siegel, also of New York, yesterday afternoon at the Pierre by Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman.

The birdies of golf sang for Johnny Revolta of Milwaukee down the home stretch today and he scored a sparkling 68, five under par, for the first eighteen holes of the $5,000 Kansas City fifty-four-hole open tournament to tie Lighthorse Harry Cooper.

Peekskill, a Hudson River town of about 17,000 people, was a center of controversy last week as a result of an ordinance, passed in 1936 at the request of the Merchants Association, against the distribution of handbills on the streets. The purpose, it was said, was to prevent littering.

Miss Valerie Ferry Nash, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Broadbridge Nash of this place, was married this afternoon in the Cathedral of the Incarnation to Marshall Konopak Skadden, son of Marshall Henry Skadden of Toledo, Ohio, and the late Mrs. Skadden.

The bright hopes raised when, immediately after the conclusion of the Anglo-Italian understanding: on April 16, negotiations were opened with France for a similar understanding do not seem likely to be realized in the immediate future.
THIS is the first comprehensive study of the one-time Ishmaelites of the Southwest who for 300 years were a scourge to all who come within their range.

Over-expansion in city development may be just as uneconomical as over-crowding, points out Harland Bartholomew, director of the St. Louis regional plan and former president of the American City Planning Institute.

The mechanical employes of The Associated Press have designated Division 14 of the Commercial Telegraphers Union, an A. F. of L. affiliate, as their-sole collective bargaining representative in a national election, the National Labor Relations Board announced yesterday.

The Chamber of Commerce of the United States, expecting that another effort for general revision of the tax law will be made at the next session of Congress, today advised taxpayers to insist that any new measure should contain provisions "favorable to business progress" included in the present act.

Vaudeville staged a comeback yesterday-in marionette form, and with a lesson of safety for New York City's school children. The Federal Theatre (WPA) Marionette Workshop presented the premiere of its new ten-act vaude ville puppet show, "String Fever,' under canvas on the Police Ath letic League playground lot a Twelfth Street and Seventh Avenue.

Of Federal officials who head divisions and bureaus, or who hold responsible positions in the executive service, more than 200 are women, the Civil Service Commission points out on a survey of women in the Federal service.

June warmth lured President Roosevelt to a week-end cruise in Chesapeake Bay and the Potomac River. He set sail from the Naval Academy anchorage here this afternoon aboard the government yacht Potomac. He expects to land at the Washington Navy Yard tomorrow evening.
Complete abolition of the Austrian Patent Office and its patent system is indicated in an ordinance issued by the German Ministers of Justice and Interior, it has been learned here.

The buying public today is showing a tendency to give greater consideration than formerly to the economic justification of home ownership, according to George I. Noyes of San Francisco and regional appraiser in that locality for the Home Owners Loan Corporation.
Eugene Carpenter of Newark drove his veteran trotting star, Hollyrood Perry, to a straight-heat victory in the feature event of the matinee at Weequahic Park toddy.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges, but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

One of the largest of the 2,000 Bowl of Rice Dinners to be given simultaneously on June 17 throughout the country will be a "Night in Old China" party in Chinatown here.

THE name of Charles Coburn has stood so long in the theatre as a monument to what might be called the classical spirit that it was a distinct shock to us recently to discover, in the course of an interview, that it was actually Charles we were talking to

A new Italian language daily newspaper, opposed to the "Fascist policy" of the II Progresso and II Corriere, published by Generoso Pope, will be published next month, Vito Marcantonio, former Representative, disclosed yesterday in an address.

Pale and grave from his experiences since March 24, when he shot and killed his young sweetheart, 16-year-old Donald F. Carroll Jr. walked out of the Queens city prison yesterday to be received by his family and the parents of the girl whose death he had caused, Charlotte Matthiesen, 18.

With construction work in progress on about $10,000,000 in largescale housing projects in the New York City area carrying more than $7,000,000 in FHA moitgage insurance, and with applications for $17,000,000 in additional projects now on file, the rental housing division of the FHA is facing a huge task in studying and altering plans and inspecting building operations.
The announcement of the President that a special commission will be sent to England this Summer to make a thorough study of the British Trade Union Act is a promising development.

Shooting of the annual New York State National Guard and New York State Rifle Association matches began at Camp Smith here today with seven events. The matches, in which nearly 1,000 marksmen will participate, will be continued all next week under the direction of Lieut. Col. Henry E. Suavet, executive officer.

Pope Pius XI was voted the "greatest leader of the world today" by the senior class of the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel here, according to results of the annual senior poll made public today. John Galsworthy was voted the favorite author; Norma Shearer the favorite actress, and "Shadow and Substance" the favorite play.

O. E. Bennett, chief petroleum engineer of the Continental Oil Company, reports to the American Petroleum Institute that at Tepetate, La., he has succeeded in obtaining 40 per cent more petroleum from pools by maintaining the natural underground pressure.

JUNE being the month that brings new radio sets, a number of 1938-39 instruments appeared during the past week with outstanding developments, revealed as remote-control tuners, antennas incorporated within the cabinet, "pre set" tuning and new styles in automatic push-button "dials."

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Emmens of Philipse Manor, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Kederich Emmens, to Charles Brown Atwater, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Atwater of Elizabeth, N. J.

Reorders arrived in larger numbers in the wholesale market last week as retailers replenished shrinking stocks, according to a special report on market activities prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

Less than a good nose separated the winner from 'Leading Article, B. P. Woodson's outsider, who finished second, and Crossbow II of the Calumet Farm.

The council of the Pennsylvania State College Alumni. Association voted' unanimously today in favor of changing the name of the institution to the Pennsylvania State University. Members were also unanimous in feeling that the identity bf Penn State should not be changed, however.

Miss Cornelia Trumbull Taylor, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. Roy Ivan Taylor of this city, was married this afternoon to Edward Kenneth Hadden, son of Mrs. Harry N. French of 1,095 Park Avenue, New York, and the late E. Kenneth Hadden.

FRANCISCO COTILLO, as a caterer from Naples, is credited with introducing spumoni to this country. As a father he introduced this country to his 7-year-old son, Salvatore, in 1895, and the son became Justice S. A. Cotillo of the Supreme Court of New York State and the first Italian-born citizen to sit that high on the American bench.
A star torn from the flag of the 17th Connecticut Infantry during the Battle of Gettysburg will be restored to the flag if Governor W. L. Cross of Connecticut is agreeable.
A dance was held tonight at the Ardsley Country Club for the benefit of St. Faith's House, Tarrytown. Mrs. Ellsworth R. Littler and Mrs. George F. Gentes were in charge.

Kross reported yesterday that an experiment in the rehabilitation of venereally diseased women released from the Women's House of Detention had proved sufficiently successful to warrant its use by all the magistrates sitting in Women's Court for a test period of at least six months.

A marked increase in interest in the Southern Junior and Boys net tournament, which is scheduled to be held in Memphis June 14-17, has been reported by Ramsay Potts, who is in charge of junior development in the South for the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

Having meals outdoors under the trees is one of the joys of Summer. The very nature of dining outside, forsaking the four walks of the dining room for air and space and unadulterated sunlight, calls for something special in the appearance of the table. The freedom of out-ofdoors dining is expressed in the table accessories now in the shops.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 2: CAPTAIN Toulon, A. J., Washington, D. C., to staff, Commander Scouting Force, June 15. COMMANDERS Jones. C. H., to staff, Commander Battle Force, as assistant operations officer, instead the Nashville.
WALTER WANGER has first call on the screen rights to "The Biography of Postmaster General James Farley," which will be published this Fall in the American Magazine on the installment plan.

Having provided two matches for the chess championship of the world, the first of which was won by Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam and the second, the return match, by Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, chess enthusiasts of The Netherlands are preparing more entertainment in the form of an international masters tournament.

Matthew R. D. Owings, 71, an insurance broker for. the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, felltoday from a window of the company's offices on the eighteenth floor of the State Bank Building. The body was found in the first floor court of the building.

J. Colonel John P. Bubb, Infantry, Newark, N. J., June 22 to Aug. 14.
Forty-five gunners took part in the H. W. Dreyer memorial shoot over the Jamaica Bay traps of the Bergen Beach Gun Club yesterday and the victor was G. C. Schwalb, Class B. with 121 out of 125.
Affected by the combination of adverse economic and weather conditions, retail trade here last week did not improve.

AN outline map of Fall fashions has been drawn by Paris couturiers in their midseason collections. They may add more color and finish in their August showings, fill in the open spaces with tiny details and sensational beauty spots or alter certain style boundaries, but the ground plan is already established.

Training in the art of concentration and rapid reading, begun experimentally in February at Columbia College for a group of fourteen poor readers in the freshman class, has resulted in a 100 per cent improvement in seven of the students, Dean Herbert E. Hawkes announced yesterday.

J., this afternoon in the Presbyterian Church here. The Rev. Charles G. Sewall of Tryon, N. C., former pastor of the church, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. John D. Gregory, the present pastor.

Copeland, chairman of the Senate Committee on Commerce, to appear at a hearing at 10:30 A. M. in Washington tomorrow for discussions on the proposed marine bankruptcy legislation.

On the heels of the condemnation by the United States and Britain of bombings of civilian areas the Japanese yesterday launched another severe airplane raid on Canton Casualties were put at 700 dead and 1,300 wounded, adding to the toll of 750 killed and 1,350 injured on May 28.
From Spain there lately come rumors of renewed dissension between the Falangist and Carlist wings of the nominally united Nationalist movement backing General Francisco Franco.

Sir Eric Phipps, the British Ambassador, in a talk with Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet today, reported on the plan of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain of Britain for mediation of the Spanish conflict.

Eighty-two students have received diplomas and certificates from the Fieldston School, the high school and preparatory unit of the Ethical Culture Schools, during the "week of commencements" which will close tomorrow.

Professor Sigund Freud, 82-year-old "father psychoanalysis," left Vienna by ain today, telling friends that he tended to go to London and later New York.

Mrs. Arrigo Righi of New York died here yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage at the home of her daughter, Miss Mamie Dickson. Funeral services will be held tomorrow afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church. Burial will take place in Glenwood Cemetery.

In the debate on the Relief-Recovery Bill this week the question of the Federal power policy played an important part. On Thursday the Senate rejected the Appropriations Committee amendment to prohibit PWA financing of municipal power sysstems which would compete with privately owned plants.

One person was injured and several other passengers were shaken up yesterday at 9:40 A. M. when an empty Third Avenue elevated train backed out of the yards at 129th Street and Second Avenue and crashed into the rear of a southbound Second Avenue train. The injured passenger, Mrs. Jose De Leggia, 58 years old, of 2,303 Belmont Avenue, the Bronx, was taken home after being treated for shock at the 125th Street station.

A GREAT deal of pontifical nonsense has been written about swing music, and yet no one has been able to say very clearly what it is. You either have it in your blood, or you have not. You can't approach it via the mind; you can't learn to appreciate it. It's a mood, an intoxication, a special form of escape, a flight from the constraints of civilization to the abandonment of fierce primitive rhythms.

Thirty-two members of the United States Senate and 435 members of the House of Representatives are to be elected next Fall. That fact was of major importance last week to at least 467 men on Washington's Capitol Hill. It ran through debate and stirred controversy within the Democratic ranks.

The aircraft manufacturing industry of the United States outshone all other industries of the country in the first quarter of 1938 by showing a gain of 82 per cent in net profit over the 1937 period, while sales rose 73 per cent. A French girl convicted of spying for Germany during the World War and sentenced to life imprisonment was freed today when she promised to become a nun.
Two large estates, one in Greene County and the other in Westchester County, will be sold at auction within the next two weeks by Joseph P. Day.

Widespread window displays and newspaper advertising were effective in two important respects in the celebration of National Cotton Week, which closed yesterday, in that they stimulated current sales and they enabled the public to visualize,

Secretary of State Cordell Hull's speech pledging American cooperation in a peaceful settlement of controversies as well as the British plan to mobilize world opinion against the bombing of civilians have met rather an ironic reception in Germany.

With public hearings on reenactment of the New York City tax of 1 cent per package on cigarettes scheduled for the latter part of this week, strong protest against renewal of the levy will be voiced by local tobacco retailers, it was reported in the trade here yesterday.

Ten new records were established and another equaled as 570 athletes, representing sixty-five high schools, competed in the twentieth annual New Jersey State High School track and field championships today at Essex Field.

Proposals to abolish free transportation of freight on the State barge canal system that have been submitted to the State Constitutional Convention will be opposed by New York shipping interests at a public hearing on Wednesday in Albany.

Miss Barbara Reed Hillman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford T. Hillman of this place, became the bride of Albert Johnstone Davids, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest A. H. Davids of Maplewood, at the First Presbyterian Church here today.

Michel Negrin, 17-year-old son of Dr. Juan Negrin, Premier of Spain, and Juan Alvarez del Vayo, 17, son of Julio Alvarez del Vayo, Spanish Foreign Minister, left the International school here today to return to Barcelona, where they intend to seek commissions as pilots in the army aviation corps.

LOOKING at one of today's giant four-engined bombers it is difficult to realize that it was only thirty-five years ago that the Wright brothers first raised their flimsy biplane into the air at Kitty Hawk, N. C. The first flight in the history of the world lasted but a few seconds.

The Cunard White Star motorship Britannic arrives today from Europe with sixty British delegates to the International Rotary convention to be held in San Francisco June 19 to 24. It is headed by T. Warren.

The motion picture is almost as symbolic of American life as the little group around the parlor table in the evening used to be. It is a huge part th of the cultural medium in which we swim. A drive for better pictures is a recognition of the cinema's importance.

The Cubs moved into first place in the National League today by defeating Philadelphia, 7 to 1. Tex Carleton, hurling steady, eight-hit ball, gained his sixth victory. The Cubs collected a similar number of safeties, but theirs were more timely.

Governor La Follette of Wisconsin said in an interview here today that an indefinite continuation of the present emergency program of the national administration would lead to inevitable collapse and a lowered standard of living.

The successful use of insulin shock therapy to relieve mild forms of epilepsy--opening a new and as yet uncharted field for research in the treatment of mental diseases--was reported here today by Dr. William G. Lennox of the Boston City Hospital and Harvard Medical School as hundreds of experts gathered for the annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association. hiatric Association.

The Rev. J. V. Moldenhawer, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of New York'City and a trustee of Skidmore College, told gradutaes in his baccalaureate address today that "the American the tradition lives still in our land this day as a belief in liberty and personal responsibility and common humanity, as against all the haughty and objectionable theories that deny these values."

THE CONTESTANTS E. A. Berumen, Jose R. de Capriles, Miguel A. de Capriles, Norman Lewis, Ted Gold, Kevis Kapner, Salle Santelli; Marcelle Bramerel, Gosca Anderson, Nino Maniaci, Albert Ferro, Frank Ohlson, August von Munchhausen, Saltus Club; Reginald Weber, Philip Weidel, Irving Ashworth, Hugh Alessandroni, Winslow Cornett, Robert Driscoll, Norman Armitage, Fencers Club; Wallace
Prime Minister Eamon de Valera told a Mallow audience last night that "there is one more important thing than proportional representation, and that is a good, solid, stable government."
Ptomaine poisoning put six players of the American Association Kansas City baseball club under the care of physicians today. They were stricken while en route from Indianapolis.

It has now been definitely ascertained that it was German Junkers planes that bombed Barcelona and Granollers last week, provoking a renewed British protest to the Spanish Rebels. The attacks 6n Valencia and Alicante, however, apparently were made by Italian planes frnm Maiorca.

Holy Name Societies of Brooklyn and Queens held two impressive rallies yesterday, bringing together more than 55,000 persons in a mass manifestation of.faith. There were 30,000 participants in the services at Ebbets Field, Brooklyn, and 25,000 at the Madison Square Garden Bowl in 'Long Island City.

Sales of exhibit space at the New York World's Fair 1939 in May aggregated $1,086,629, a record never before equaled by any other international exposition in a comparable period, it was disclosed yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation.

Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoye will shortly call a five-Minister conference of the Premier, the Foreign, War, Navy and Finance Ministers, with the intention of mapping out a stronger policy toward China.

From the dictators of Europe to the man in the street in this country the world is in the grip of the gambling spirit, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, said yesterday.
The trial of Harlan County coal operators and former peace officers enters its fourth week tomorrow with two side issues overshadowing all the testimony thus far.

For the fourth year in a row, the national outdoor epee championship went to a member of the de Capriles family when Miguel A. de Capriles prevailed over thirty-three opponents, to win the title at Travers Island yesterday.

The New - York Civic Orchestra, under Eugene Plotnikoff, gave a concert given over to works by Sergei Rachmaninoff yesterday afternoon at the WPA Theatre of Music. Henri Deering, pianist, was the assisting artist, and Danton Walker the commentator.

Long Island University will award 127 degrees at the commencement exercises tonight at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The commencement address will be given by Bruce Bliven, editor of The New Republic, who will speak on "The Press, Propaganda and Public Opinion."
Hopes entertained in the Netherlands for a speedy recovery in France suffered a slight-setback recently.
Declaring that American interests and institutions are more threatened by the "political monster" of fascism

The expulsion of the Jews from their native land was denounced yesterday as "un-Christian" by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral and Vicar General of the Archdiocese of New York in a sermon delivered in the presence of Cardinal Hayes, who presided on his cathedral throne.

The baccalaureate service beginning the commencement exercises of New York Military Academy, held this afternoon in Davis Memorial Chapel, was conducted by the chaplain, Captain John F. Hagen, who also addressed the graduating class.

Soviet Russian icebreakers reported today that they had reached the first of a score of ships frozen fast in Arctic ice all Winter. The icebreaker Yermak radioed she had led another icebreaker, the Rusanoff, and two other ships out of the ice into open waters.

Little sins that people find hard to shake off keep them from attaining maturity of the spirit, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, said yesterdays in his morning sermon.

In the fluctuations of dollar-sterling exchange now taking place is reflected the play of circumstances, such as constantly changing views of the European situation, variations in the London price of gold and the influence of the United States trade balance.

The "lost" Forty-third Division of the Loyalists is not coming out of Spain. Its situation is as invulnerable as a military position can be; there is an abundance of food and other provisions and enough ammunition to enable the division to carry on until the government sends more. The soldiers,

With brake linings apparently hopelessly gone, our plunging Giants swept downhill without interruption today as Bill McKechnie's Reds, behind their 22-year-old left-handed sensation, John Vander Meer, bagged their second straight game of the series, 4 to 1.

Pennsylvania Railroad Garden Club Fourth Annual Flower Show at Y. M. C. A. in Pennsylvania Station, noon to 8 P. M. Presentation of E. H. Harriman Memorial Medals for 1937 at luncheon of the American Museum of Safety, Hotel Commodore, 12:30 P. M.

Bettering its score of last year, Troop A of the 101st Cavalry of Manhattan, firing today in the New York State National Guard rifle matches here at Camp Smith, retained the Sayre Pistol Trophy by shooting the winning score of 95.90 oit of 100 against five other team entries.
Charles Henry Bickell, assistant to the president of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company, died at his home here yesterday after a short illness. He was 69 years old.

Trapped in a sedan that crashed through guard rails and plunged into Tarrytown Lake at 3:30 o'clock this morning, Erna Sophie Sumersille, 23-year-old secretary in a Manhattan law firm, was dead on arrival at Tarrytown Hospital, despite heroic efforts by Police Lieutenant Harry B. Cramer, who dived twelve times into the cold water before recovering her body.
