Approximately 39.7 per cent, or b $2,203,819,360, of the $5,557,600,752 of P foreign dollar bonds outstanding at the end of last year was in default, according to the fourth annual report of the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., made publie today. Latin America,

After the turn of the month, the money market became fluid with the day-loan rate 2 3/4 to 3 per cent. Although the Reichsbank's credits in the last week of May increased by the large sum of 838,000,000 marks, there were signs that the expansion caused by the Austrian Anschluss was slackening.
Recent visits by the writer to Weihaiwei and Chefoo, two northeastern Shantung ports, further confirmed the conviction that the Japanese were effectively holding only garrisoned towns and cities.

A demonstration hailed as the largest communion breakfast ever held in New York taxed the capacity of the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, yesterday morning after placing a heavy burden on the facilities of the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary, Hicks and Degraw Streets.

More than 70,000 followers of the Slovak autonomist movement paraded in Bratislava today, shouting demands for autonomy. At the head of the procession an automobile carried a huge placard bearing a copy of the Pittsburgh agreement.

In the midst of European turmoil and dissensions France is putting all her strength into the effort of conciliation and into the attempt to prevent a recourse to violence, Premier Edouard Daladier said today at Lyon.
The Right Rev. Thomas E. Molloy, Bishop of the Diocese of Brooklyn, presided at dual ceremonies at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church this afternoon in the presence of more than 1,000 persons.

Dr. Carl C. Thomas, scientist and inventor, died at his home here today at the age of 65. He was an associate in engineering research at California Institute of Technology here and was engaged in experiments on steam control.

A policy of cooperation to shut off economic aid to aggressor nations is recommended by the Methodist Federation for Social Service, of which Bishop Francis J. MdConnell is president, in a statement to be sent tomorrow to the organization's lay and clerical members in the country.

Three cross-sections of New York's jumbled life, cut from Manhattan Island at Times Square, Greenwich Village and the East Side, were held up yesterday as "The Part of New York I Like Best," by three winners in the second annual essay contest for high school students held by the Grand Street Boys Association.

The Rev. Dr. George Stewart, pastor of the Presbyterian Church of Stamford, Conn., delivered the baccalaureate sermon in the Ford Auditorium here today for the 104th commencement exercises of the Peekskill Military Academy.

A searing flash of lightning killed a woman and her 13-year-old daughter and injured three others, including her husband and another child, at 4:35 P. M. yesterday as they ran for shelter under a tree in a downpour of rain that interrupted a baseball game in Weequahic Park, Newark.

A. G. Keller, Professor of the Science of Society at Yale University, has a new book on the Knopf Spring list. Called "Brass Tacks," it is a non-technical examination of traditional social values-how they arose, why they are maintained and why they are of value in a time of stress.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have just read the letter from Judge Steinbrink addressed to James L. Dowsey, chairman of the Constitutional Committee on Counties and Towns, in which Judge Steinbrink attacks the proposal to deal along the lines of the Workmen's Compensation Act with the problem of accidents caused by automobiles.

The other day we put a friend, Lee Wulff, aboard a ship bound for Newfoundland, where he's going to spend a-month salmon-fishing and two months proving his theory that there are giant tuna and broadbill in those waters. What a trip!

Dutch views of the situation in the United States remain gloomy because of the persistent downward trend in business activity there in virtually all branches of industry and trade, the depressed tone of the commodity markets and the failure of the desterilization of gold and the reduction to a minimum of bank reserves to bring about any increase in credit demands.

Graduation exercises of the Edgewood Park School will be held here tomorrow morning. The commencement address will be made by George A. Wiley, associate commissioner of the New York State Education Department.

A sweeping victory for Senator Robert R. Reynolds was conceded by his opponent, Representative Frank W. Hancock Jr., today as late returns from the Democratic primary for the Democratic Senatorial nomination pushed Mr. Reynolds's ma- the jority to more than 90,000 votes.

Many people in the world today are searching for a god who does not exist, the Rev. Dr. William Hubert Rogers, pastor of the First Baptist Church, Broadway at Seventy-ninth Street, said yesterday in his morning sermon.

J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N. J., and A. W. Macpherson of the West Side Tennis Club of Forest Hills defeated Charles Hare and B. W. Finnigan in the final round of the Rockaway Hunting Club tennis doubles tournament today. The score was 2-6, 6-4, 6-1.
Cardinal Hayes will preside at the thirty-first annual commencement exercises of the College of New Rochelle tomorrow, when Mgr. Francis W. Walsh will confer degrees upon the 150 graduates. Dr.

The Rev. John Henry Finn, instructor of St. Francis College and former Lieutenant Commander of the United States Navy, died today at the Franciscan monastery of the college at the age of 55. He had been ill a year.

Neither the markets nor the business position changed in character last week. Industrial production was somewhat lower. Average commodity prices hardly changed. The stock market was moved up on Saturday, through circulation of the familiar "rumor" (always promptly scotched) of fresh devaluation of the dollar.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.5, which compares with 80.8 a week ago, 81.4 two weeks ago, 80.8 three weeks ago and 80.5 four weeks ago.

ProducProduction of most minerals in the United States in 1937 exceeded that of the preceding year and several records were established, notably in crude and refined petroleum, aluminum and sulphur, the Bureau of Mines has reported to Secretary Ickes, according to an announcement today by the Department of Interior.

The Japanese Army has been scoring a series of victories of such military significance that foreign military experts here believe the Chinese Government must evacuate Hankow within the next six or eight weeks.

BERK-On June 4, Mary Agnes (nee McGurty), beloved wife of Charles B., devoted mother of Charles, Thaddeus, Thomas, Alice and May Berk; sister of Mrs. Alice Hindelong, Thomas, Timothy, James and the late Frank and Peter McGurty. Funeral from residence, 208 West 105th St., Tuesday, June 7, at 9:30 A. M.;

More than 300 members of St. James Lutheran congregation from many parts of the city attended final services yesterday in the church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street, before the edifice is turned over to the Emigrant Industrial. Savings Bank to satisfy interest arrears on a first mortgage.

Led by a graduate of the class of 1875, more than 1,000 New York University alumni will return today to their alma mater for activities in connection with the university's 106th commencement exercises Wednesday morning on the University Heights campus.

An amendment to the State Constitution that would make buildings erected on private property subject to regulation and control from an esthetic standpoint under city planning is advocated by the City Club of New York in a report made public yesterday.

Stumpy Stemwart's double scored' Funderberg after two men had been retired in the ninth and gave the Fort Hamilton baseball team a 4-3 decision over Brooklyn College yesterday at the Army Reservation in Brooklyn.
The German wholesale price index on May 25 stood at 105.4, unchanged from the week before. The May cost-of-living index rose to 125.9 from 125.6 for April.

Daily average sales of grain futures on the Board of Trade here last week were 30,400,000 bushels, an increase of 400,000 over the preceding week but 19,100,000 less than in the corresponding week in 1937.

Police Lieutenant Bernard (Barney) McGowan, attached to the West Sixty-eighth Street station for the last five years, died of pneumonia last night in St. Elizabeth's Hospital after a week's illness. He was 61.
The United States and Great Britain will announce shortly an agreement on the size of new superbattleships and the heavy guns that they will carry, a State Department official said today.

After ten years in the laboratory, a device for landing airplanes at airports regardless of weather conditions will be put into operation this week at the Union Air Terminal here and later at four or five other fields throughout the country.

Of all the signs of the hide-and-seek, To touch-and-go attitude of the United States toward international cooperation, the most interesting to date is the election of an American as director of the International Labor Office in Geneva. The Labor Office is an organ
Postmaster General James A. Farley praised the New Deal tonight as a business aid. Speaking at the annual convention of the New York State Elks Association, he said:

The Treasury's announcement of the Government's June financing, with the somewhat unusual advance statement of its purposes at the quarterly financing in September, shows that, at all events, immediate increase in the public debt will be held down as far as possible. The $618,056,800 of 2 7/8 per cent...
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss June Elisabeth Dings, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Edwin Dings of this place, to Paul H. Fox, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Fox, also of Scarsdale.

Protective labor legislation either should be withdrawn or made to apply to both sexes, Miss Marie Meeker of Baltimore, vice president of the Industrial Council of the National Woman's party, said today.
Three of the thirty-eight who were graduated yesterday by Teachers College, St. John's University, Lewis and Willoughby Avenues, Brooklyn, received two awards apiece.

If the track is fast, War Admiral, Samuel D. Riddle's undefeated 3year-old champion of 1937, will start in the Queens County Handicap, feature today at Aqueduct, where the twenty-one-day meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club will get under way.

Adjournment of the Seventy-fifth Congress by next Saturday is now the aim of leaders in both chambers. The chief obstacle appears to be the Wages and Hours Bill, which has been in the hands of conferees since Thursday.
Two speakers, addressing the Duke graduating class today, told their listeners what their role must be if they are to have a share in building a better world. More than that,

Shavuoth services were held yesterday.by Reformed and Orthodox Jews. The holiday, which corresponds to Pentecost in the Christian calendar, is also known as the Feast of the Weeks, the Festival of the Giving of the Law and the Feast of the First Harvest.

A duel between Ruben de Leon, leader of the Cuban Revolutionary party and Senator Ramon Vasconcelos, Liberal party leader and noted journalist, was fought at an estate near Havana this morning. Both participants were slightly wounded.
Emblems of camping excellence were awarded to outstanding Boy Scout troops of Brooklyn as the borough's eighth annual Camp-oree ended yesterday at Fort Hamilton Reservation.

For participation in six outdoor sports this Spring, 238 undergraduates at the University of Pennsylvania received either varsity letters, junior varsity insignia or freshman numerals, according to an announcement by H. Jamison Swarts, chairman of the awards committee.

Mrs. Robert Johnson Jenckes of East Haddam, Conn., formerly of Providence and Santa Barbara, Calif., has announced to friends here the engagement of her daughter, Miss Betty Jenckes, to Robinson Smith of New York, son of F. Goodwin Smith of Hartford, Conn., and the late Mrs. Mary Roberts Smith.

A demand for Japanese control of the British Crown colony of Hong Kong, voiced by Motorjiro Sugiyama, a member of Japan's House of Representatives, today was reported in Japanese Domei news agency dispatches from Nagasaki.

Six boys have won four-year scholarships in the Xavier High School of the College of St. Francis Xavier, 30 West Sixteenth Street, in the semi-annual scholarship and entrance examinations, the college announced yesterday. More than 800 boys from Catholic, public, and private schools took the examinations.

James Carstairs of Philadelphia has been elected chairman of the board of Carstairs Brothers Distilling Company, Inc., according to announcement issued for publication today by the company's board of directors.

With a grand total of 43 hits to show for an afternoon of fun for 17,250 fans, the Cardinals and the Bees split the St. Louis season's first double-header today. The Cards won the opener, 6 to 5, and Boston took the nightcap, 10 to 3.

Detectives of the Missing Persons Bureau yesterday broadcast a State-wide alarm for Elizabeth Grant of 157 Vermilyea Avenue and Mary Quigley of 153 Vermilyea Avenue, both 13 years old, who have been missing since Friday afternoon. The girls,

David Genaro, former vaudeville headliner, whom many fellow-performers called "the inventor of the cakewalk," was found dead yesterday afternoon in his bed at the Somerset Hotel, 150 West Fortyseventh Street, where he had lived intermittently since 1908.

One man was killed and four other persons were injured at 3:15 P. M. today when a car driven by Seth T. Cole of Catskill, former Deputy State Commissioner of' Taxation and Finance and a member of the Constitutional Convention, was in a head-on collision with a car driven by Arthur Richardson of Pottersville.
The week started off under the more favorable impression caused by relaxed tension over Czechoslovak affairs, and the Bourse was firm on Monday. This tendency did not, however, continue.

Newark maintained its double-header pace by defeating the Orioles in both ends of today's twin bill. The Bruins came from behind to win the opener, 11 to 9, in ten innings and captured the nightcap, 8 to 3.

All deliverles of lard sold at new low levels for the season early last week mainly because of liquidation by longs in sympathy with the break in grains, but a rally of about 1/2 cent a pound followed when grains and the hog market turned upward.

Playing through the climatic extremes of a driving rainstorm and bright sunlight, Leix routed Cavan yesterday at the Polo Grounds in the play-off of last week's 7-7 tie, vanquishing the champions of Ulster, 15 to 2. While a crowd of 8,000

Tony, a yellow-head parrot who comes from San Antonio, Texas, is a jovial old bird, with a cheerful hello for everybody and a habit of humming to himself. With a reputation of that sort his activities over the past week-end were all the more disturbing to Tony's owner, Mrs. Olaf W. Anderson of 11 Slocum Place, Flatbush, Brooklyn.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull's speech was favorably received in League of Nations and International Labor Organization circles, which welcomed it generally as "another milestone" on the road from isolationism to world organization which, it seems to them, the United States has been following "consistently if slowly" since its failure to apply the Neutrality Act in the Far East.

Prince and Princess Dominique Radziwill, who were married on Monday in Paris, will arrive today on the Ile de France and will be at the St. Regis before going to Newport. princess Radziwill is the former Princess Eugenie, daughter of Prince George of Greece.

Jules Bledsoe, Negro baritone, who first attracted wide attention by his singing of "01' Man River" in "Showboat," gave his first American recital In many years last night at Town Hall, with Carl Diton at the piano.

Denials that any agreement had been reached between the Investment Bankers Association of America and the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., concerning possible methods of organizing a national association of security dealers and brokers under the Maloney bill were issued yesterday by Francis E. Frothingham, president of I. B. A., and John K. Starkweather, chairman of its special committee that has been studying the possibilities of such a step if the bill should become law.
The Maine Monument located on Malecon Drive was struck by lightning and badly damaged during the wind and rainstorm that lashed the city this afternoon.

God does not demand to be welcomed into the heart before he will enter, nor does He scorn to deal with men who do not recognize Him, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick said yesterday in his morning sermon at Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.
Senator Bone of Washington, an administration Democrat, urged today that Senator Nye, North Dakota Republican, be re-nominated and re-elected.

The Ninth District mobilization of the American Legion this afternoon brought together more than 3,500 members of military units and war nurses who took part in a parade following a conference at the State armory.

The first race of the season for Atlantic Class craft at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club today was captured by Ralph E. Brush's Sirocco, with Van Wyck Loomis's Hound second. A southwest wind made ideal conditions for sailing.

Worship of God must precede service to man if we are to fulfill our duty to either one, the Rev. John Heron of Glasgow, Scotland, minister-in-residence for the Summer months at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets, said yesterday in his morning sermon.
With next Saturday night's performance of "The Circle," its sixtyfourth since Mr. Brady revived it at the Playhouse on April 18, the Maugham comedy will end its latest visit to Broadway.

On Thursday afternoon the Westchester County Republican organization will hold a meeting at the Casino at Playland, when it is expected that former Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley of Yonkers who was the' last Republican nominee for Governor beaten by Governor Lehman, will be nominated for County President.

Charles F. Shelden Jr. of Siwanoy and Fitch Rowley of Upper Montclair today defeated Uzal H. McCarter of Aldecress and T. S. Colkett of Merion, Pa., 3 and 2, to win the Rumson Country Club's seventh annual invitation best-ball golf tournament.

Organizations interested in housing amendments before the State Constitutional Convention have bee asked to send representatives to a luncheon meeting to be held by the National Public Housing Conference on Thursday at the Hotel De Witt Clinton in Albany.
The Costa Rican Government will buy two electric locomotives at a cost of $150,484 from Germany for the Pacific Railway on account of its increasing traffic.
On the whole it has been a rather depressed week on the stock markets here. Less troubled by European politics, the B markets are turning to other directions for guidance. What they see,

Morrison Mann MacBride, Ontario's Minister of Labor, died today of a heart attack. His age was 60. Mr. MacBride joined Premier Hepburn's Liberal government last Fall after re-election as member of the Legislature for Brantford. For several terms he was Mayor of Brantford.

Nine airplanes coming from Spain dropped bombs in France, interrupting a railroad and endangering a hydroelectric plant. Their identity was not learned. Premier Daladier ordered a patrol of the border by French planes and pursuit of any aircraft crossing it.
Thunderstorms played all around the Meadow Brook Club today, but held off long enough to permit the Greentree and Aiken Knights polo teams to put in a game on the old No. 4 field in the hollow.

Construction of the building that will represent the country's leading manufacturers of men's apparel at the New York World's Fair, arid to be known as "MAN, His Clothes, His Sports," will begin on July 18, according to announcement issued for publication today by William C. Segal, executive secretary of the Men's Apparel Quality Guild.
All deliveries of corn on the Board of Trade'here sold last week at the lowest prices of the season, scattered liquidation being under way.' Reports,

Representative E. J. Hart, speaking here today at the thirty-eighth commencement exercises of St. Peter's College, declared that "within America there are hosts of men and women who seem disposed to change our system of government by sacrificing their personal liberty for economic security."

Announcing additional contributions to the Greater New York Fund, James G. Blaine, president of the $10,000,000 campaign, said yesterday that large business concerns in the city were evidencing a disposition to Increase their gifts to insure success of the drive.

Seabreeze Terrace, the home here of the late Mr. and Mrs. James A. Trowbridge, will be the setting for the marriage of their granddaughter, Miss Barbara Joan Trowbridge, to Kevin Gelshenen Rafferty the afternoon of July 2.
Hundreds at an Oxford Group house party in historic Stockbridge to??n hall tonight heard a call to turn their efforts toward "changing" business in the drive for a "spiritual revolution" in America.
In financial circles and, to a degree, among the more fiscal-minded of the general public, attention is being centered on France's internal political situation as well as on international affairs.

Dr. Arthur M. Kane of 219 Congress Street, Brooklyn, a surgeon who had practiced in Manhattan and Brooklyn since 1894, died yesterday in the Post-Graduate Hospital of pneumonia at the age of 71. During the last three years his professional activities had been greatly decreased by failing health.

James Talcott, Inc., has been appointed factor for the Union Hosiery Corporation, High Point, N. C. A dinner-meeting to welcome Julius Brabec, the new Consul General of Czechoslovakia in this city, and to bid farewell to Emanuel J. Hajny, commercial consul here, will be held on Wednesday by the American-Czechoslovak Chamber of Commerce, Inc., at the Bohemian National Hall restaurant, 321 East Seventy-third Street.

The Essex County Symphony Orchestra will give the first concert of its Summer series tonight at the City Schools Stadium in Newark, N. J. Grace Moore, soprano, will be soloist. Alexander Smallens will conduct.

The attempt of the Mormons to take their unemployed off relief rolls and WVPA lists has failed, Hebber J. Grant, 81-year-old president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, said today in an interview.

Arthur Joseph Lewis, a railroad man of this city, walked out of Beth Israel Hospital tonight and described how it felt to be struck by a bolt of lightning and remain conscious and partly paralyzed for fifteen minutes while those around him were afraid to offer aid.

High Spanish Insurgent sources reported today that Generalissimo Francisco Franco had held an urgent meeting of his military leaders after fights between Insurgent and Italian officers at Malaga and Saragossa.
Harold E. Cobourn, a State Senator, was fatally injured today in an automobile accident as he returned from an election campaign tour.

Elwood Cooke of Portland, Ore., won the tennis championship of New England today by defeating Howard V. Stephens Jr., Yale senior from St. Louis, in the last two sets of. a match that began yesterday but was rained out at the end of the third set.

To the relief of a much-depleted ringside coterie, a regular dog went best in show today at the sixth annual fixture of the Longshore Kennel Club, held on the grounds of the Longshore Beach and Country Club.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary is due late today from Southampton via Cherbourg. Passengers are Mrs. George Widener, John H. Szekeley, the Duchess of Leeds, Sir Douglas Alexander, Sir Andrew Lewis, F. D. Butler, British consul at San Francisco; Dr.

Two buildings in Harlem were acquired for investment in a deal announced over the week-end. The transaction involved the two six-story houses, each on a plot 40 by 100 feet at 222 and 226 West 140th Street, which were sold by the Kinetta Holding Corporation, Louis Lipman, president, to an investing client of Max Lustig, attorney.

Leases of one and two-family dwellings in the Bronx have been negotiated by brokers for the Home Owners' Loan Corporation. Homes were rented for the Federal agency by D. Houlihan Sons, Inc., as follows:
The White Sox broke their ten-game losing streak by defeating the Athletics, 8 to 2, today, then lost the second game of a double-header, 7 to 6.
Stock Exchange, Stocks slightly higher, because of- Saturday's gains, in smallest five-day week's trading since July, 1934; turnover, , 2,008,880 shares.

A record crowd for this training camp, estimated at more than 5,000, watched Max Schmeling pound through eight rounds of boxing today in preparation for his championship fight with Joe Louis on June 22. The German provided a sensational drill. Joe Mack,

English and journalism awards have been announced at Hunter College for this year by Dr. Blanche Colton Williams, head of the Department of English. Seven prizes for writing and one for literature will be given to three graduating seniors and five undergraduates.

JUST as he was about to sit down and start typing (this was yesterday afternoon and the office was as quiet as a grave), this reviewer had a visit from his personal devil, a formal individual with short horns, pince-nez and long tail. After preliminary greetings had been exchanged and certain private matters touched upon, there was a brief silence. Then the visitor spoke.
Mrs. Mathilde E. Reynal Thebaud, one of the founders of the Colony Club, died yesterday in the Neurological Institute, Fort Washington Avenue and 168th Street.

Success or failure of the first attempt of the so-called New Deal "elimination committee" to rid the Democratic party of less-than-100-per cent followers of President Roosevelt, and particularly those who stood against his Court Enlargement Bill last year, will be determined by the voters of Iowa in the Democratic primary tomorrow.

The April death rate, 11.8 per 1,000 population, was the lowest on record for that month, Dr. J. V. DePorte, Director of the Division of Vital Statistics, of the State Department of Health announced today. This was the sixth consecutive month that mortality was exceptionally low.

Railroad freight rates on coal shipments from the West Virginia and Kentucky coal fields ;to tidewater should be based on the cost of transportation service plus a fair return on investment, instead of on what the traffic will bear "as now seems to be the case," John Carson, consumers' counsel of the National Bituminous Coal Commission, urged in a brief filed yesterday with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

James O. Schwank, who retired two years ago as superintendent of the New York Fire Patrol, salvage corps maintained by insurance companies, died on Saturday in St. Mary's Hospital, Reading, Pa. He was 64 years old.
Sir Hubert Wilkins, explorer and flier, arrived here today for a five-day study of Soviet data on the Arctic in preparation for another attempt to reach the North Pole by submarine.

Greta Garbo will return to Metro in the Autumn to make her annual picture, according to word received by the studio. As a result Jacques Deval has been called on to prepare the screen play of "Ninotchka," a comedy about a Soviet business representative in Paris.

Miss Grace Hayward, daughter of Mrs. Charles Burton Hayward and the late Mayor Hayward of this place, has selected June 14 for her marriage to Lewis Mack, son of Mrs Lewis Charles Mack of Somerville, N. J., and the late Mr. Mack.

ALBANY-John G. MyerS Co.: P. J. Carbine, laces, embroideries, handkerchiefs, ribbons; A. R. Wade, piece goods; 11 W. 42d (F. Atkins). BALTIMORE-May Co.; Miss L. Bernstein, dresses; 1,440 Bway. BOSTON-Benjamin Kraft Bros.; S. Salsukoff, close-outs Summer dresses; 101 W. 37th (A. E. Littman).

Sales of repossessed houses by the Franklin Society increased last month, according to Paul Delmont, vice president, who said the increased activity represented a rise of 18 per cent. The average sale price last year was $2,900 and had risen this year to $5,000, he reported.

A proposed State law allowing cities and villages in Illinois to tax all businesses in order to raise funds for relief would put unfair burdens on industry and seriously retard recovery, Chicago business leaders declared today.

Mature judgment is reflected in the extent to which we learn "to welcome rather than resent the fact that life is uncertain," the Rev. Phillips Packer Elliott of the First Presbyterian Church, Henry Street near Clark Street, Brooklyn, told 660 graduates of Pratt Institute in a baccalaureate sermon yesterday afternoon at Emmanuel Baptist Church, Lafayette Avenue and St. James Place, Brooklyn.
The New York Americans and the Brookhattans played to a 3-3 tie in their soccer match at Starlight Park yesterday before a crowd of 3,000. At halftime the Americans led by 2-0.

On the ground of the world's outlook for crops and the relatively large stocks in England, Germany and elsewhere, the Institute for Trade Research declares that an advance in wheat prices can be expected in the near future. It adds, however, that any
Relief Pitcher Willis Hudlin drove out a looping double in the tenth inning today to give the Indians their second victory in two days over Washington. The score was 5 to 4.

The recall by Berlin of China's German military advisers is expected to be effective within the next few days as the result of discussions of the German Ambassador, Dr. Oskar Trautmann, with Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.

Sir Edward Bacon, curator of the King's Philatelic Collections at Buckingham Palace, died today at the age of 77. For more than fifty years Sir Edward was prominent in the British stamp world. He was chairman of the expert committee of the Royal Philatelic Society.

FIRST ROUND Louis Fribourg defeated Karl Hagen, 6-1, 6-3; Simon Miller defeated Simon Feldman, 6-0, 6-2; Edwin Luchs defeated William Colwell, 6-2, 6-2; Ramey Donovan defeated Carl Schweikhardt, 6-2, 6-0; Max Spiegel defeated Michael Bittner, 6-3, 4-6, 6-4.
Federal agents sought through wholesale questioning today a clue to lead them to kidnapped Jimmy Cash, or his body, and to the abductors who collected $10,000 ransom.

Fill-in and promotional merchandise occupied the attention of the wholesale market last week, although some commitments - were made for Fall staples, and confirmations came through in greater number on boys' items for preschool selling.

The French wholesale price index on May 28 stood at 644, compared, with 645 and 643 in the two previous weeks. The gold index of raw materials was 39.3, against 39.8 and 40.7 one and two weeks previously.

Twelve prizes have been awarded In the second annual poetry contest conducted in New York City hospitals by Barnard College students interested in poetry, under the auspices of the New York City Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.
Vernon Kennedy mowed down the Red Sox, 10 to 4, today for his ninth consecutive pitching victory as the Tigers evened the series and snapped the Boston three-game winning streak.

A baccalaureate service held at Trinity Lutheran Church, Stapleton, S. I., last evening marked the opening of the fifty-third annual commencement week of Wagner Lutheran Memorial College of Grymes Hill, Stapleton.

The Christian way is rather simple, clear, positive and challenging, the Rev. John Walter Houck, pastor of the Pilgrim Congregational Church, Grand Concourse and 175th Street, the Bronx, said in his sermon yesterday.
S. T, Bledsoe, president of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railroad, predicts larger earnings for the road in May and June than in any previous month this year.

Miss Virginia MacDonald Prout will have Miss Shirley Moore of Summit for her maid of honor at her marriage to Frederick Gilbert, which will take place here the afternoon of June 25 in Calvary Episcopal Church.

The Ten Commandments are operative always and everywhere, the Rev. dr. Albert J. MacCartney, pastor of the Covenant First Presbyterian Church of Washington, said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

Speaking at an American Legion service in Locustwood Memorial Park, Delaware Township, today, Colonel Hugh Kelly, secretary to Governor Moore, declared too many persons in this country were looking to Germany, Italy and Russia for guidance.

Three artists have been added to the previously announced list of soloists for the concerts this Summer at Lewisohn Stadium. They are the violinists, Mischa Elman, John Corigliano and Arnold Belnick, 13-year-old New York-born exponent of the bow.
ADVENTURES IN GOOD EATING, by Duncan Hines. (Adventures in Good Eating, Inc., Chicago, $1.50.) A directory of eating places along American highways.
Oats, rye and soy beans for future delivery declined early last week on the Board

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,092,828,650. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills.
France's revenues for the first four months of this year amounted to 13,131,000,000 francs, compared with 10,824,000,000 in the corresponding period of 1937.

Tetsuo Nakano, apanese Davis Cup player, defeated Gene Mako of California, 6-1, 6-3, 4-6, 6-0, today in the third round of the French hard-court tennis championships. Except in the third set the Japanese was far too steady from the back court for his husky opponent.

Although some automobile companies continue to run fairly large schedules, the industry as a whole is now reconciled to a poor year and no sharp pturn in advertising is expected before the introductory campaigns for the new models, starting in October, according to agency executives.

Criticizing those who term others of different opinion "subversive" and "un-American," Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, urged tolerance and openmindedness as essential to our form of. government in delivering the baccalaureate address to thirty-two candidates for degrees at the New Jersey College of Pharmacy at the Mount Pleasant Baptist Church here this morning.

Beaten almost beyond recognition, Thomas A. O'Connell, 32, former newspaper man, was found dead in Institute Park early today. Medical Examiner John H. Ward said that O'Connell, who had been in frail health several years, died of a fractured larynx.
Job opportunities for Columbia College graduates are 50 per cent fewer than last year, Robert F. Moore, university secretary of appointments, announced yesterday. No one type of job is most

Stocky Tony Penna of Dayton, Ohio, blazed a trail six under par at Hillcrest in the final round of the fifty-fourhole Kansas City open golf tournament today to finish with a total of 212 and the $1,200 first prize of the $5,000 purse.

A movement for an unprecedented display of the American flag on Flag Day, June 14, is being conducted by the United States Flag Association, it was announced today by Colonel James A. Moss, president general of the association.

The refusal of President Conant of Harvard to reinstate Dr. C. Raymond Walsh and Dr. Alan R. Sweezy was attacked by two members of the faculty tonight as "falling far short of any conception of democratic justice or wise educational policy."

Miss Louise Carnegie Miller, eldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roswell Miller of 9 East Ninetieth Street, and granddaughter of Mrs. Andrew Carnegie and the late Mr. Carnegie, steel manufacturer and philanthropist, has completed the plans for her marriage to J. F. Gordon Thomson.

As its June financing program the Treasury today announced a combined offering of bonds and notes in exchange for an aggregate of $1,214,472,900 of Treasury notes maturing this month and in September, placing on the new securities in each instance the lowest interest rate which has been quoted on government obligations of similar maturities.

" The greatest privilege requires the greatest duties," the Rev. Dr. Frederick R. Griffin of the First Unitarian Church of Philadelphia told the Swarthmore College graduating class in the baccalaureate sermon this morning.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. During of 972 Woodycrest Avenue, the Bronx, gave a reception at their home yesterday at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rita Patricia Durning, to William James O'Prey of Brooklyn, son of James O'Prey of New York and Belfast, Ireland, and the late Mrs. O'Prey.
Acquisition on option from the Cardinals of Paul Dean, right-handed pitcher and brother of Dizzy Dean, was announced tonight by Business Manager Bob Tarleton of the Dallas Steers of the Texas League.

The engagement ofMiss Carol Sherman Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Strong Wilson of this place, to Axtell Byles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Axtell Julius Byles of Ardsley-onHudson, has been announced by her parents.

Christianity is not merely the belief in a past Jesus, but it is the renewal of the experience of Jesus living and working in us, the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent, rector of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftyfirst Street, said in his morning sermon yesterday.
Dr. Henry Turman Byford, for many years one of Chicago's leading gynecologists, died today at the age of 84. His widow, two sons and a daughter survive.

The cotton market here was more active last week and price fluctuations were wider than recently. In the Memorial Day holidays in the Northern and Western markets a good deal of trading sought the market here.

The Cunard White Star motor ship Britannic arrived yesterday from the Channel ports bringing 365 passengers, which included 87 delegates to the Rotary International Convention to be held in San Francisco June 19 to 24. Thomas Warren, president of Rotary International, was in charge of the group.

Scoring a brilliant three-under-par 67, Martin Issler of Rock Spring and W. Halsted Taft of the host club won the Montclair Golf Club's second annual member-guest bestball invitation tournament today.

A deficiency of college-trained men in public life, the business world and international relations, resulting in a "welter of confusion's and caused by a "clash of ideologies," was emphasized yesterday by Dean Irving H. Berg of the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science at baccalaureate exercises in the Gould Memorial Library on the uptown campus.

Joseph Cece, builder, bought eleven and a half acres on Palmer Avenue, Bronxville, N. Y., from Gertrude Crosby and others for improvement with six and seven room dwellings. The property is assessed at $28,000 and the houses will be financed under the Federal Housing Administration plan, according to Frederick J. Feuerbach's Sons, brokers in the deal.

The statement of Fritz Kuhn, leader of the German-American Bund, a Nazi organization, that a delegation of the Bund's Ordnungs Dienst (Storm Troopers) had been invited to march in Mayor Hague's planned "Americanism Rally" in Journal Square tomorrow night was dedared tonight by the Mayor's secretary to be untrue.

Mrs. Charles L. Hulswit, one of the organizers of the "women's rebellion" to stop excess governmental spending, announced today she was starting a nationwide campaign to defeat at the polls all Senators and Representatives, regardless of political affiliation, who voted for the pumppriming bill.

As in the case of the United States and all other major nations, draft legisnation has been prepared in England which would mobilize the whole strength of that country in the- event of war. Gone into the discard is Liddell Hart's-passionate conviction that never again would Britain throw mass armies into the field.

All indications in the steel industry point to continued dullness and no factors have appeared to furnish a basis for expectation of improvement, the magazine Steel says this week. Continuing, the summary reads in part:

BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions JONETTE KNITTING MILLS, INC., 648 Broadway.-Voluntary proceeding under section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law, listing liabilities of $95,319, exclusive of capital stock, and assets of $163,041. The corporation operates a plant at Haverstraw.

Forsythe Associates, Inc, Oscar Slone, 173 Henry St, president, bought from the estate of Mary E. Blodgett the parcel at 168 Rivington St, for $15,000, giving back a purchase money mortgage for $14,500, due in five years at 4 per cent.
Although the relative calm of the Sudeten-German dispute induced a moderate recovery in securities here last week, business circles are nervous, fearing new foreign trade trouble.

Offering will be made today by W. C. Langley Co. and H. M. Payson Co. of 7,000 shares of $100-par-value 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the St. Joseph Water Company for the account of its parent company, the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc.

The National Maritime Union announced yesterday that an effort had been made to resume collective bargaining negotiations with the American Steamship Owners Association. The union presented six points on which alterations are suggested. These points are based

Charles J. Herold, president of the Polygraphic Company of America, lithographers, printers and publishers, died yesterday at his residence, 123 Waverly Place, after a brief illness, at the age of 49.

Raymond Swinscoe, 39-year-old WPA worker, who was arrested at his home, 995 Rossville Avenue, Rossville, S. I., early yesterday morning after police had searched for him since Friday for questioning in the death of his 4-year-old daughter, Dolores, was held without bail yesterday on a charge of homicide.

Some day civilization will see a society which is classless, Dr. Arlo Ayres Brown, president of Drew University, predicted in his baccalaureate address before graduates of Brothers College and Drew The ological Seminary this morning in Madison Methodist Church. Dr. Brown's topic was "What Do Ye More Than Others?"

When the regular army turns out for practice marches these days the beck layman who watches or reads about it or sees it in the motion pictures may and conclude that the days of the army the horse and the army mule are over. This isn't true.

THREE of the four managerial changes in the big leagues have worked out well so far this season and the fourth is doing about as well as could be-expected. The fourth is Gabby Street, the Old Sergeant, who was handed the job of trying to rally the St. Louis Browns to the point of capturing seventh place or some such advanced position.

Fifty Japanese airplanes bombed Canton for an hour this afternoon in relays, concentrating on government buildings and also the railway stations at Taishatou and Wongsha. The Wongsha station suffered severe damage and the track was torn up.

Stewart P. Coleman, Countess de Menasce. in 950 Park Ave; Charles S. Ashley, John Taylor Boyd, in 145 E 52d St; Mrs. Michael Hart, 920 5th Ave; Carpenter Realty Corp, broker. Mrs. J. E. Stephens, in 309 w 86th St through Albert M. Greenfield Co.
On the Committee Amendment (to the Relief-Recovery Bill) to increase to $750,000 from $250,000 the appropriation for the National Resources Committee, adopted 59 to 18:
The National Conference of Investors is forming State units with a view to influencing legislation in favor of the railroads, Robert Meyers, secretary, announced yesterday.
The Bill of Rights committee of the Constitutional Convention may vote on Tuesday to outlaw in this State the use of evidence obtained through wire-tapping, it was disclosed today.
Confronted with what is regarded as an exces sive world supply of grain, the price of wheat dropped last week to the lowest levels in almost five years.

The government's successes during. the term of the Supreme Court which closed Tuesday are summed up in a report compiled by the Department of Justice. This showed that of 114 cases argued and decided on the merits, the government won 92 and lost only 22.
A sharp upturn in business conditions by early Fall was predicted today by William S. Knudsen, president of General Motors Corporation, who stopped here on the way to Detroit.

William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador, was among the crowd of friends and admirers to greet Professor Sigmund Freud today on his arrival from Vienna, where life under the Nazi regime became too difficult for the "father of psychoanalysis."

The retiring American Ambassador, Joseph E. Davies, paid farewell calls on Mikhail Kalinin and Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff at the Kremlin this afternoon before departing for his new post at Brussels, and unexpectedly had an interview with Joseph Stalin, who has talked with few other foreign envoys here.

Last week's stock market here opened on a dull note. There was some activity in Farbenindustrie in consequence of its dividend increase, but the cheerfulness here was counteracted by emigrant selling.

Mrs. Allan F. Odell of Essex Fells, N. J., has announced the gagement of her daughter, Miss Louise Odell, to James McCay Flounders of Wilmington, Del., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Evans Flounders of Rising Sun, Md.
Foreign Minister Carlos Concha said today that economic and political reasons necessitated the establishment of trade between Peru and the United States "on an equitable and firm basis."

(Figures in Parentheses indicate par) Brookville (72)--Match Play handicap against par, Class A: Fred Guertler, 3 up: George Meredith, 2 up. clas B: James Kelly, 2 down; H. J. Miller, 4 down. Cherry Valley (72)--Medal Play handicap, Class A: E. H. Driggs Jr., 74--2--72; C. W. Barrett, 84--11--73. Class B: R. Smutny, 93--17--76; M. T. Gleason, 91--14--77.
A dust storm rivaling those of the United States Dust Bowl struck the central part of Japan's Hokkaido Island today.

Captain Peter A. Murchie, one of the senior commanders of the Cunard White Star Line, has retired at the age of 61 after being thirtythree years in the company's service. This makes a total of seven captains of the line who have been retired recently on reaching the age limit of 60 years.

The proposal of the Maritime Commission that dual subsidies be granted to rival American ship lines operating between ports of the United States and South Africa is attacked in a brief filed with the commission by the American South African Line, Inc., and released here yesterday.

Churchgoers "who sit in pews, watch, wait and criticize," were described as "religious spectators" in a baccalaureate sermon for the graduating class of St. Joseph's College for Women at Queen of All Saints Roman Catholic Church, Lafayette and Vanderbilt Avenues, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon.

Because of the approach of the holidays, last week's business in Germany was quiet. Bankruptcies in May numbered 154, against 178 in May, 1937. The number of hours worked in industry in April was 18 per cent higher than in April, 1937.
Sixty-seven students of Upsala College here will receive Bachelor of Arts degrees at the forty-fifth commencement, which will be held tomorrow at 2:30 P. M. on the campus.
European currencies recently have gone through periods of comparatively with nervous activity in close connection of G with events in and around Czecho- If Slovakia. Although the fears

Major Waclaw Makowski and four other Polish fliers landed here this afternoon from Rome, completing a 16,500-mile flight by a roundabout route from California. A large crowd welcomed them at the airport.

Interval Ave (11-2974), ? e s, at w s of Fox St, 97x95: Ethel Morrison to 1,242 Intervals Ave Corp, 175 Lexington Ave, 156th St (10-2655), n e c of Forest Ave, 35x100; Stern-Green Realty Co, Inc, to Porson Realty Corp, 516 5th Ave; mtg. $35,250.

The New York Medical College and Flower Hospital will build and equip at a cost of $1,500,000 a tenstory building in the rear of the Fifth Avenue Hospital within the next fifteen months, it was announced yesterday by Charles D. Halsey, president of the board of trustees of the institution.

It has been nearly twenty years since work was stopped on the new Central Public Library in Brooklyn. Under Mayors Hylan and Walker the aborted structure sadly faced the elements. Librarian Milton J. Ferguson said, was "the second oldest uncompleted ruin in the world, the first being the Tower of Babel."
Commenting on the election of John G. Winant as director of the International Labor Office, The Times of London in an editorial today points out the importance of the post as an agency for peace.
What this country needs is not a good five-cent cigar a but a good five-cent word to replace such fifty-cent alien importations as
The latest semi-official statistics available in the furniture manufacturing industry today gave no hint of recovery from the. slump that is almost a year old.

Mrs. Isaac A. Hourwich of 14 Washington Place East has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her youngest daughter, Miss Ena Hourwich, to Edward Kunzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Kunzer of Richmond Hill, Queens. The wedding will take place on June 24.

In a hodge-podge of every kind of weather except a real blow and sea fog, the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club today held the first of its special Sunday race series. There was a fleet of sixty-two starters, and most of them finished sailing through two thunder squalls, among other things.

Miss Josephine Sheffield Daniels, daughter -of Mr. and Mrs. Harold P. Daniels of this city and Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, has chosen the afternoon of June 25 for her marriage to Charles Belknap Lockwood of New York.

Rain, hail, darkness and the Browns all combined to ruin the day fdr the Yankees and 32,714 fans at the Stadium yesterday. The first game lasted so long it was impossible for the teams to start the scheduled second, though by the time the teams got around to it there were few who would have relished more.

Tests of the new Boeing clipper designed for Pan American Airways' transocean air service were indefinitely suspended late this afternoon when the big ship struck a log during a taxi trial in Puget Sound and damaged one of its hydro stabilizers, according to Boeing officials.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Lyon Kent of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Kent, to L. Richard Fried, son of Nathan Fried of this city and the late Mrs. Fried.

Denison Dean Dana, stepson of William Hall Walker, one of the founders of the Eastman Kodak Company, committed suicide by hanging this morning in his photographic darkroom over the garage in the rear of his home at 161 South Woodland Street. He was 62 years old.
Premier Benito Mussolini's newspaper, Popolo d'Italia, today taunted France as having a "sick" government in which Italy found it useless at present to try to reach an agreement.

Senator McNary, minority leader, indicated today that Republicans would make the Senate's vote against restricting political activity by relief employes a major issue in this year's Congressional campaigns.
Harold I. Baker, Andrew Hughes and Amos S. Treat have formed the general securities firm of Baker, Hughes Treat at 40 Wall Street.

George F. Ryan, formerly vice president and wholesale manager of Taussig Day Co., Inc., of St. Louis, has been made vice president and chairman of the board of the Banning Company, investment securities house here, John Banning, president, announced today.
Lady Gen V, owned by David Gerli of New York City and driven by Arno Apel of Ventnor, N. J., today won the Auerbach. Cup race for motor boats in a 22.6-mile circult of Absecon Island.

The Rev. Dr. Henry C. Wasmund celebrated the fortieth anniversary of his ordination yesterday at Trinity Lutheran Church, in Middle Village, Queens. The celebration was in conjunction with- the seventy-fifth anniversary of the founding of the church.

At the regular weekly shoot of the North Jersey Gun Club today the winners in the first fifty-bird event were J. L. Flagg, A. B. Blood, Mrs. M. Conde, W. G. Torrance and H. C. McCloskey. In the second fifty, A. F. Streelman, M. H. Apgar, Dr. W. H. Pruden, Dr. H. A. McLean and McCloskey took the prizes.

Appointments to the staff of the Princeton Summer camp for underprivileged boys were announced today by William J. Watson of Trenton, undergraduate director of the camp. It was also announced that $9,115.50 had been received toward the $11,526 camp budget.

The Federal Royalty Company of Phoenix, Ariz., filed suit in Civil District Court here yesterday against the Barnsdall Oil Company of Wilmington, Del., for one-twenty-fourth of the oil being produced from 1,840 acres of land in the Harang oil field of Lafourche parish, Louisiana.

More than sixty members of the Trinity Choir Alumni Association, including several white-haired men who had entered the choir more than sixty years ago, returned yesterday to sing at their sixteenth annual service in the Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street.

Herman Kretchmar, newspaper man, dramatist and novelist, died yesterday in Israel Zion Hospital, Brooklyn, following an illness of several weeks. He was 55 years old. Mr. Kretchmar, whose pen name was Liliput, was a. member of the staff of the Jewish Daily Forward for nearly twenty-five years.

Reserves of phosphate rock in the United States are Henormous" and likely to last 1,600 years at the present rate of production, according to Bertrand L. Johnson and K. 'G. Warner, Federal experts, writing in the Minerals Year Book of the Bureau of Mines.
A gradual change occurred last week in the comments on the prospective yield of Winter wheat in Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas.

Leonard Hartman, 1937 Winner, gained the third round of the twenty-first annual open tennis tournament for the championship of Brooklyn, which opened yesterday, by defeating George Smith at the Terrace Club of Flatbush. Hartman, second seeded player, had little trouble putting out his rival, 6-1. 6-0.
The first example of a table on which mummies were embalmed has been brought to the Egyptian Museum from El Quarna [Thebes] in Upper Egypt.

A city fireman, a rabbi and a physician are among those who will receive the Bachelor of Laws degree at the thirty-sixth annual commencement of the Brooklyn Law School Thursday morning in the Albee Theatre, Brooklyn.

Stanton St. s w cor Norfolk St. 100x50; William J. Jones to Dry Dock Savings Institution; consideration $1,000; fore-closure. 24th St. 427 W. 25x98.9; Max Scobie to Isaac Joffe, 34 W Houston St; mtg. $21, 750 ($1.50).

" Southern California has a combination," said Brutus Hamilton, coach of the University of California track forces, "that could beat any two teams in the meet." That statement was made before the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. championships were staged at Randalls Island Stadium over the past week-end.
President Juan D. Arosemena inaugurated a new normal school-at Santiago de Veraguas today after a blessing by the Papal Nuncio, Carlo Chiarlo.

Declaring that "social desirability" never should be a criterion for admitting a tenant to a low-cost housing development, Councilman Howard H. Spellman expressed sharp criticism yesterday of the methods used by the city in operating Williamsburg Houses in Brooklyn, a $14,000,000 development fostered by Mayor La Guardia.

In the earlier part of last week cotton prices continued their downward trend, but subsequently they strengthened and more than regained these losses. At the close of trading on Saturday active future deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains for the week of 14 to 20 points.

The Maritime Commission announced tonight that it would open bids at noon Tuesday for the reconditioning of three liners it expects to acquire from the Panama Pacific Line for "luxury service" to South American ports.

Pronouncements here for international prices, both official and private, are pessimistic. Unsatisfactory developments recently in German exports are attributed to the decreased buying power of overseas producers of materials and foodstuffs.

Under the auspices of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, thirty members of the Council of Citywide Religious Education Workers will hold a retreat and conference at the Mortimer L. Schiff Boy Scout Reservation at Mendham, N. J., beginning today at 4 P. M.

A fairly heavy earthquake shook Tokyo at 2:23 o'clock this morning. MANILA, Monday, June 6 (AP)--Inactive since 1928, Mayon volcano, near Legaspi in Albay Province, began erupting Friday night, causing widespread alarm among the region's inhabitants, officials here were notified today.

No more permits will be granted for meetings in Newark's parks except to "patriotic and military organizations," City Commissioner Joseph Byrne Jr., who issued the permit for last night's attempted Socialist rally in Military 'Park, said tonight in a. statement attacking Norman Thomas.

Insurgent soldiers tell the story of a large dog that defended a government machine-gun nest after its masters were killed. An officer leading the Insurgent force that wiped out the machine-gun crew was impressed by the bravery of the animal that stood by the silenced gun, growling and barking as the Insurgents closed in.

The Eastern Polo League opened its season yesterday with eight of the twelve teams in the circuit seeing action. The newly organized Pegasus Browns of Rockleigh, N. J., the Bethpage Shamrocks, the Blind Brook Knights and the Ramapo Blues were victors.

Official reports from San Luis Potosi say that at the hamlet of San Juan del Meco near the border line of the States of San Luis Potosi and Tamaulipas, Federal troops attacked a group of Cedillistas and captured several persons including Anita Laguna, alias Maria Montano, common law wife of the rebellious General Saturnino Cedillo, and also some of General Cedillo's servants.

Now is the blessed season when the Se "Having a wonderful time-Wish you were here" post cards begin to flutter home. For the next three months just those who can afford it will be slipping not away to mountain or shore, to solitudes

Syracuse stopped Jersey City's winning streak at four straight today by taking the second game of a double-header, 1 to 0, after losing, 2 to 1. Long John Gee limited the Little Giants to three hits to notch his shutout in the nightcap.

Although Although the sudden heavy withdrawal of French funds from the market here after the recent devaluation Dep of the franc definitely reduced. foreign balances in this city, the credit situation has returned to its former condition of abnormal ease.

The United States was one of the governments asked by Britain to cooperate in preparing a small international commission to investigate bombings in Spain, it was learned today. There has been no official announcement of Washington's reply but it is reported here that the State Department sent a refusal.

Acting Governor C. C. Woolley of Jamaica announced yesterday that the government would embark immediately on a [Pound]500,000 "back-to-the-land" scheme as a step toward solving unemployment. Land will be sold on easy terms.

Unloosing a seven-hit, six-run barrage against-three pitchers in the sixth inning, the Dodgers came from behind today to score a 10-to-5 victory over the Pirates and even the series at one game each before 6.800 Forbes Field fans.

With all agencies of the city government cooperating in an effort to end assaults on home relief investigators, Welfare Commissioner William Hodson said yesterday that between twenty-five and thirty members of his staff had been set upon by disgruntled relief recipients or applicants for public aid in the last six months.

A broad study of what he calls "the seven deadly sores" of the present economic situation will be proposed in seven concurrent resolutions which Representative Barton of New York plans to introduce in th House tomorrow.
The moon, Harold Spencer Jones, an astronomer, said today, has jumped its track. "And it's all the earth's fault," the astronomer told a meeting of the Royal Observatory of Greenwich.
Dr. Sam Higginbottom, president of Allahabad Christian College in India, - discussed conditions in India yesterday at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue at 105th Street.

Nation- $2 wide production of steel ingots last fo week was estimated here at 30 per th cent of capacity on the basis of a ac five-day week, the mills having observed Memorial Day although it is not regularly a steel-mill holiday.

LITERARY genius is generally thought to be a frail and eggshell thing, to be treated gently lest the thin porcelain of the spirit: crack. Gently and with reverence and great forbearance. PoorJohn Keats-think of what the Philistines did tohim in 1820.

President Neilson of Smith College gave the address to members of the graduating class at the 109th commencement exercises of Abbot Academy this morning when fqrty-nine graduates received diplomas and certificates from Miss Marguerite Hearsey, principal.

The directors of the United Corportion met-yesterday to consider a dividend on the $3 cumulative preference stock, but took no action on the payment due at this time for the three months ended on June 30. It was announced that
In a low-scoring match between the touring Australian cricketers and Essex, the visitors won today by 97 runs. The Antipodeans were dismissed for totals of 145 and 153, Essex scoring 114 and 87.

Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt was a garden party hostess to 600 women at her home, Oakland Farm, in Portsmouth, this afternoon. They were the officers and members of the executive committees of the women's Republican clubs of the State, the women members of the Legislature and of the State central committee and the wives of the Republican Mayors of the State.

Mr. and Mrs. Leopold Weiss of 23 West Seventy-third Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helene Weiss, to Henry Dorin, son of Mrs. Barnet Dorin of this city and the late Mr. Dorin.

Fifty Japanese airplanes continued raids on Canton yesterday and civilians again were the chief sufferers. Casualties were estimated as high as 1,500. A moving picture house was hit and scores were buried.

Leroy Clark Palmer resigned yesterday as president and a director of Franklin Simon Co., Inc., and no successor was chosen. Mr. Palmer's letter of resignation, read at a meeting of the board of directors, revealed that he had submitted a resignation last January, but had been asked to remain with the store until the close of the Spring season.
One man was injured and thirteen women and five men were arrested late yesterday in a clash in front of the Park Central Hotel between sympathizers of the Loyalist and Rebel forces in Spain.
More than 21,000 students attending the day and evening sessions of City College will face final examinations during a seven-day period to begin on Thursday, it was announced yesterday.

The New York Stock Exchange Moved yesterday to further the spirit of the Conway reorganization report when it solicited the assistance of the out-of-town members and their associates in helping the new administration of the institution to develop greater unity and common understanding and to give its policy the national point of view.

An inauguration reception of the Helios Club and a program on the Greek stage in the gardens of Sunnyhill Farm, the estate of Countess Bronislava du Brissac near this village, will take place on Saturday afternoon. The Right Rev. Frank

The cornerstone of the new $500,000 Rose Memorial Library was laid at Drew University here this afternoon in a ceremony witnessed by more than 300 students and visitors.! The event was part of the annual Alumni Day program in 'connection with commencement.

In the first quarter of this year he Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation and its subsidiaries had a nt profit of $468,311 after Federal and State income taxes, depreciaion, depletion, leaseholds abanloned and surrendered, and other charges. The profit was equal to
British Government told the State Department' today that four young Americans who fled from Spain as stowaways on a British ship would be sent back to the United States.

Despite a marked decline in dollar volume of building permits issued in the five boroughs during May, the city's figures for the first five months of 1938 continue to hold a comfortable lead over the same period last year.

Patrolman James B. Fisher, who was accidentally shot and killed last week when he attempted to frustrate a hold-up, received an inspector's funeral yesterday. Chief Inspector Alexander C. Anderson represented Commissioner Valentine at the services, which were
The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 4: COLONELS Smith, T., Cav., to retirement. Parker, C., F.A., Hawaiian Dept., to Headquarters, Governors Island, N. Y.

Several East Side buildings changed hands in the Manhattan realty deals announced yesterday. After an ownership of more than fourteen years, Mrs. Hannah Monahan has sold the five-story apartment house at 55 East Eightyeighth Street, between Madison and Park Avenues, to Norman S. Riesenfeld. real estate operator.

Stocks closed easier-at slightly higher levels after extending Saturday's gains moderately; turnover, 467,330 shares. United States Government bonds quiet and higher, other groups irregular in smallest dealings in twenty years; transactions, $3,262,275.

Diplomas will' be conferred upon ten graduates of the Child Education Foundation Training School at its twenty-first commencement exercises, to be held at 8:30 P. M. tonight 'in the assembly room of the Child Education Foundation, 535 East Eighty-fourth Street.

The graduating class of Russell Sage College for Women was told today by Mark Sullivan that a "new school' in this country wished to "abandon" individualism and substitute "collectivism," with the accompanying danger that people would become ants in a hill or bees in a hive.
David Lloyd George declared tonight that Britain's "twittering little protests like a frightened Dird" to -the Spanish Insurgents over bombings of British ships were becoming a world joke.

After he had taken the witness stand in his own behalf, William M, Sohreier, 28 years old, of 212 East Seventh Street, was held in $500 bail by Magistrate Earl A. Smith in Yorkville Court yesterday afternoon for trial in Special sessions on a charge of practicing medicine without a license.

The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals denied today a Ford Motor Company request for oral arguments Friday on issues arising through its contest of a National Labor Relations Board order against the company.

Miss Kathryn Louise Huber, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick William Huber of 113 East Broadway, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Robert Joseph Fletcher Jr., son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Fletcher of New York, in St.

The Jeffersonian doctrine of - States' rights was expounded tonight to the delegates of the Constitutional Convention by James W. Wadsworth, former United States Senator and now a Representative in Congress.

Sir Hubert Wilkins, who searched many months' for Sigismund Levanevsky and five companions who vanished in the Arctic wastes last August on an attempted flight from Moscow to America, arrived here today for a three-day stay as a guest of the Soviet Government. He expressed the belief that all hope was not lost-for the Levanevsky party.
Among the passengers arriving on the Ile de France of the French Line last night were Prince Dominique Radziwill and his bride, the former Princess Eugenie of Greece.

United States publishers who buy their newsprint from Canadian concerns will have to pay $50 a ton for the rest of this year. This price level, which has been in force for the first six months of this year, has been agreed on for July-December newsprint.

The House resolved itself today into an informal committee of critics on the merits of Howard Chandler Christy as an artist and finally rejected a resolution which would have commissioned the painter to decorate one of the few remaining bare spots in the Capitol with a picture to be called "The Signing of the Constitution."

The Brookmeade Stable's National Anthem will carry top weight of 155 pounds in the Bowman Steeplechase Handicap at about two miles over brush which will feature the Spring meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association at Roslyn, L. I., Saturday.

Miss Eleanor J. Mixsell, daughter of Mrs. Austin D. Mixsell of this city and the late Mr. Mixsell, a vice president of the Bethlehem Steel Company, has completed plans for her marriage to Stuart E. Hockenburg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edson J. Hockenburg of Harrisburg, which will take place here on June 18 in the Pro-Cathedral of the Nativity.

C. S. Wilcox, chairman of the board of the Steel Company of Canada, died suddenly at his home today. His age was 82. Charles Seward Wilcox was born at Painesville, Ohio, March 16, 1856, the son of Aaron Wilcox and Jane Morley Wilcox. His father was a native of Killingsworth, Conn.
Ruf Gonzalez, a typographical expert employed for the last fourteen years by The New York Herald Tribune, died yesterday at his home, 362 West Twenty-second Street, of a heart attack. His age was 46.

Mrs. Malvina Thompson Scheider, personal secretary to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt for fifteen years, was resting comfortably tonight at the Vassar Brothers' Hospital here after undergoing an appendix operation.

Three honorary degrees will be conferred tonight at the commencement exercises of St. Francis College, Brooklyn, to be held in the Loughlin Hall of the Bishop Loughlin High School, Vanderbilt and Greene Avenues, Brooklyn.
The Bawl Street Journal, annual newspaper of the Bond Club of five New York, will be issued on Friday simultaneously with the club's annual outing at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club. While the 600

Two defendants in the Harlan conspiracy trial testified against themselves by proxy today after Judge H. Church Ford had ruled that by failing to protest against testifying when called before the National Labor Relations Board, they forfeited their right to the protection of the Fifth Amendment.

Major Gen. Ernst Udet, famous German war ace, established a new record for military pursuit planes when he flew a new Heinkel single seater at 634.37 kilometers (393.94 miles) an hour at Rostock on Sunday.

With a sharp break in cotton quotations in Bombay and the best week-end weather to date this season throughout the South, prices on the Cotton Exchange were set back almost $1 a bale yesterday to end with losses of 15 to 17 points.
Peter Plate, real estate broker, of Yaphank Road, this village, who had been active in Suffolk County realty circles for the last thirteen years, died today of a heart attack at the age of 35.

The first baby giant panda to become a resident of New York Citya female cub, six to eight months old, aptly named Pandora-is scheduled to arrive Friday afternoon -by airplane, and will be transported immediately to the Bronx Zoo--to be housed in a special air-conditioned cage, officials of the New York Zoological Society.announced yesterday.

After asking the public for suggestions for a civilian Cabinet, Provisional President Alberto Enriquez appointed Luis Enrique Escudero as Minister of Government; Dr. Carlos Ayala Cabanilla, Public Welfare; Teodoro Alvarado Olea, Education; Gabriel Martinez, Finance, and General Guillermo Freile. War.

Mary Brewster Jennings, through Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, fifth floor in 778 Park Ave; Paul Reimers, through Duff Conger, Inc, in 4 E 64th St; Brett Wyekoff, Inc broker. Sarah MacIssac, in 47 E 64th St; Samuel A. Herzog, broker.

MANHATTAN HAMMOND, ROSE (May 23). Estate, $4,000. To Edmund Burke Jacobs Jr. and Nancy R. Jacobs, 34 14th Rd., Broad Channel. L. I., $1,000 in trust each; Rose H. Jacobs, granddaughter, petitioner, 34 L 14th St., Broad Channel, L. 1., $200.

More than 150 representatives of the various groups comprising the Real Estate Taxpayers Federation, Inc., the recently formed "realty union," met last night in the Hotel, Commodore and agreed- on plans for a mass meeting in the Washington Irving High School oh the evening of June 13.

Abrogation of a contract with the WPA for labor on a West Orange streetwidening project was threatened here today by the Essex County Board of Freeholders unless alleged "incompetent, inefficient, dilatory and insubordinate workers" are replaced with competent workers by Friday, according to a resolution adopted by the board.
The big seaplane that Richard Archbold, expedition leader, is flying from California to New Guinea, took off here at 5 P. M. today and headed for Wake Island, 2,309 miles away.
Christine M. Kauffman of Milesburg, senior in arts and letters, was graduated from the Pennsylvania State College today with a perfect academic average.

An exhibition of industrial craftsmanship and arts and crafts development among public school students will open today at Junior High School 184, 37 West 116th Street, it was announced yesterday by David Goldwasser, principal.

A bill to require that Federal courts appoint the Maritime Commission or a nominee it approves as trustee or receiver of any bankrupt American shipping line in foreign commerce met violent opposition today before the Senate Commerce Committee.

An Anglo-Scottish final in the Empire Exhibition soccer tournament was assured tonight when Everton defeated Aberdeen, 3-2, before 25,000 at Ibrox Stadium. The victor will oppose Celtic, conqueror of Hearts in the other semi-final, here Friday evening.

Executives of the Museum of Costume Art, which closed its second annual exhibit in La Maison Frangaise in Rockefeller Center yesterday, announced that 4,500 persons had visited the galleries during the two weeks of the showing.

The annual report of International Power Company, Ltd., for 1937, issued today, shows a consolidated net income amounting to $1,398,442, against $1,113,831 in 1936. After deducting $41,180 as nft expenses of the holding company, a balance of $1,357,262 remained.

Claire Windsor of the silent days is to return to the screen under the auspices of Monogram in "Barefoot Boy," based upon the John Greenleaf Whittier poem. Shooting started today with Jackie Moran in the title role and with Marcia Mae Jones and Ralph Morgan. Karl Brown is directing from a script by John T. Neville.

The average interest rate on Treasury bills rose to 0.040 per cent on the first offering today of $100,000,000 of bills, under the new bill program, from an average of 0.025 per cent that was bid on the $50,000,000 issues sold on Friday and on Monday of last week.

The Canadian Government has drafted a national unemployment insurance law to be submitted to Parliament as soon as the Provinces approve it, Prime Minister Mackenzie King told the House of Commons today. It is unlikely,

W. D. Blatner of Chicago, secretary of the Associated Retail Confectioners of the United States, asserted today that John L. Lewis, C. I. 0. leader, was "the recognized power behind the throne" of the National Labor Relations Board.

Asserting that passage of the bill sponsored by the Department of Markets for the compulsory grading of meat would result in higher prices to the consumer and would benefit no one, the New York State Association of Retail Meat Dealers adopted a resolution opposing it yesterday at the concluding session of their forty-fifth annual convention at the Hotel New Yorker.
Pensioned On his own application, to take effect 12 midnight, June 3: LIEUTENANT-Thomas F. Kelly, 12th Division, at $2,000 per annum; appointed Oct. 9, 1911.

John Ringling North told 1,600 employes, actors and 'other members of the Ringling Brothers, Barnum Bailey Circus tonight their "greatest show on earth" faced a shutdown unless a wage cut and other economies were effected.

A large industrial property, a twenty-four-family apartment house and a number of other residential parcels of the multi-family and one and two-family types, have recently changed hands in New Jersey, according to reports received yesterday.

Through a legal manoeuvre Democratic interests were foiled today in a plan to get possession of a small part of the land on which the clubhouse of the Union League, stronghold of Republicanism, is situated.

Miss Jean Chatfield Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Clinton Clark of Binghamton, N. Y., and Ewing Butler Hawkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Wallen Hawkins of Pelham Manor, N. Y., and the Chatham, this city, obtained a marriage license yesterday at the Municipal Building.

Governor A. Harry Moore of New Jersey will be the commencement speaker here tomorrow at the graduation exercises of the Admiral Farragut Academy. Diplomas will be presented to seventy-three graduates by Admiral S. S. Robison, superintendent of the Academy.

Charles Franklin, counsel for the Manhattan Railway Company, owner of the elevated lines operated by the Interborolugh Rapid Transit Company under a 999-year lease, yesterday requested Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson at an I. R. T. receiver's hearing to withhold action until July 15 on the I. R. T. receiver's motion to disaffirm the lease.

In response to President Roosevelt's request of April 29 for an investigation of "monopoly and the concentration of economic power," the Senate Judiciary Committee today ordered reported favorably the O'Maboney resolution to create a joint legislative and departmental "national economic committee" to make such a study.

New York University will introduce a new note in its 106th commencement exercises tomorrow, when Hilliard Warren Caming, 18 years old, of New York City, youngest honor society graduate of the 1938 class, leads the academic procession carrying the silver torch, emblematic of academic purpose.
The Federal Government came to the aid of Cleveland in its relief problem tonight with $60,000 and stayed, at least for several days, the threatened closing of relief stations.

Alfred Hitchcock, British film director, arrived last night on the Queen Mary of the Cunard White Star Line on his way to Hollywood. It will be his first visit to the film capital in his eighteen years' association With the picture business.
Wollmar Filip Bostrom, Swedish Minister to the United States, received the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws today at the University of Delaware commencement.

After months of negotiations, Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, announced today that the commission had agreed to give the Dollar Steamship Lines, Inc., of San Francisco, an annual operating subsidy of about $3,000,000 over a five-year period.

The Very Rev, Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, announced yesterday that the program of the Department of Education in the university's Graduate School-had been modified to give teachers and prospective teachers additional opportunities for advanced specialization in teaching, supervisory and administrative activities.

The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill to impose a 25 cents a gallon tax on liquor in the possession of wholesalers and stores July 1, when the liquor tax provision of the new revenue law goes into effect.

Carl S. Hamersley of 105 West Seventy-second Street, president of the Hamersley Manufacturing Company, paper manufacturers, died yesterday afternoon yesterday afternoon in the Lenox Hill Hospital, after a long illness, at the age of 65.
