Lost battalions are bound to figure more prominently in future warfare. The reason would be, first, the increasing speed of mechanized

With Mayor Frank Hague leading the demonstration a throng estimated at half of the more than 300,000 residents of Jersey City joined tonight in an "Americanism" parade and rally designed by the Mayor to show his critics that his city is solidly behind him in his fight on what he calls "the Reds."

Makoto Den, director of the Board of Tourist Industry of the Japanese Government Railways, arrived in New York yesterday to arrange for Japan's exhibit at the World's Fair and to extend an invitatiop to Americans to visit Japan's Grand International Exposition in Tokyo in 1940.
Officials of three city departments strove in vain yesterday to fathom the mysterious disappearance of two tons of old copper sheeting from Rikers Island, home of the new city penitentiary.

" I had some drinks," was the explanation given today by James A. Mollison, transatlantic flyer, for an escapade at Le Touquet Saturday night for which the French police detained him today on a charge of "dangerous flying."

The Daniel Guggenheim Medal for 1938 has been awarded to-A. H. R. Fedden, chief engineer of the Bristol Aeroplane Company of England "for contributions to the development of aircraft engine design and for the specific. design: of the sleeve valve aircraft engine," Major Lester D. Gardner, secretary of the board of award, announced yesterday.
Par at Cherry Hills faced' further threats today as another-troupe of golfers hauled their bags out to the milehigh course where the national open starts Thursday.

The stock market started with a fair show of confidence yesterday, reached its peak at midday and sold off in the late trading to close irregularly higher. Gains for most of the -leading issues were limited to fractions.

Mrs. Anne de Smolianinoff Frelinghuysen obtained a divorce here today from George Griswold Frelinghuysen of Princeton, N. J., on grounds of cruelty. They were married on Dec. 12, 1934, in Los Angeles.
Mrs. Henry Hazeltine Holmes of Wayland, Mass., has announced the marriage of her daughter, Miss Frances Holmes, to Dr. Henry B. Garrigues, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Garrigues of Conshohocken, Pa.

Henry A. Hacker, alias Hatten, 50 years old, of 2,432 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, was speedily convicted in Special Sessions yesterday of offering to be a bogus witness in an accident suit, and was remanded to the Tombs by Justices McInerney, Voorhis and Brady for sentence next Monday.

The charge that the Aluminum Company of America has a monopoly of bauxite, alumina or virgin aluminum is "utterly ridiculous," William Watson Smith, Pittsburgh lawyer, said yesterday in outlining the defense in the government's suit to enjoin the company and its affiliates from alleged violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.

Senator O'Mahoney's joint resolution, providing for the recess investigation into monopolistic practices which the President asked Congress to make, is about ready for passage. The subject is legitimate and important.

The marriage of Miss Maude Kramer Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Riley Lee of this city, to John Bradley Bliss, son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Bliss Jr. of Yonkers, will take place on the night of June 18 at the Contemporary Club here.

Cautious buying appeared probable as the Boston Shoe Fair, major market event of the shoe industry, opened here today under the auspices of the New England Shoe and Leather Association. Fall lines of men's, women's and children's shoes were shown by 394 manufacturers in 526 sample rooms at the Hotels Statler and Copley-Plaza and the Parker House.

Pennington School will hold its ninety-ninth graduation exercises here tomorrow morning. Dr. J. Edgar Clark, president of Wheaton College, will speak. Forrest D. Moore Jr. will be valedictorian and Robert L. West salutatorian. Dr. Francis H. Green, headmaster, will present diplomas to forty-eight graduates.
The Radio Corporation of America opposed today legislation which would require the Communications Commission to consider "public interest" in allotting international broadcast bands.

The weekly comparison tables of the Safety Bureau of the Police Department, issued yesterday, showed declines in the city's traffic accidents, fatalities and the number of persons injured last week and week-end compared with figures for the corresponding' periods of last year.

Border newspapers published today an interview with Sefiora HiginiaCedillo vda. de Gonzalez, sister of the fugitive rebel General Saturnino Cedillo, in which she charged that Mexican Government officials had forcibly deported her from Mexico.

A single magnolia blossom more than twenty inches in diameter "stole the show"--in spectacular interest, at least-at the annual twoday sweet pea and rose show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society, which opened yesterday in the rooms of the Horticultural Society of Ney York at 598 Madison Avenue.
Mrs. Frances M. Wieler, cashier of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, 365 Madison Avenue, died yesterday at her home, 314 East 201st Street, the Bronx, after an illness of several months.

County Judge Frank H. Coyne today ordered a middle-aged Port Chester carpenter, who said he was "too proud to accept relief," to permit his five children to receive shoes from the-Port Chester welfare department so they can go to school. Two have been absent since April 21 due to the lack of shoes, truant officers reported.

Wagner Lutheran Memorial College will graduate the largest class in its history this morning at its fifty-third commencement exercises on the campus at Grymes Hill, Staten Island. The class consists of thirty-nine members. Twentyfive will receive the degree of Bachelor of Arts and fourteen that of Bachelor of Science.

A threat which might jeopardize efforts of Congressional leaders to adjourn the session this week came-tonight from a group of Southern Senators dissatisfied with the turn of affairs in the Wages and Hours Bill conference committee.

The Adjutant General released the following orders today: These officers, having qualified, are placed on duty: Allen, 2d Lt. Judson William, to report to commanding officer, 14th Infantry, for further assignment to Company A.

The most serious wave of pricecutting in its history afflicts the food and grocery industry at the present time because of the drive for volume being conducted by super-markets, bargain wholesalers, free-lance peddlers and others, the American Institute of Food Distribution reported yesterday in its weekly summary of business conditions in the grocery field.
Charles A. McManus, superintendent of the Yankee Stadium, was rushed to St. Elizabeth's Hospital yesterday, suffering from an abdominal ailment.

In an address today at the thirty-first commencement exercises of the College of New Rochelle, Cardinal Hayes urged the 151 graduates "to resist the worlds created artificially by men and women and sanctify your lives in the service of God."

With a $500 reward offered, police today were continuing the search for jewelry valued at $30,000 which was lost by Mrs. Mary Schweinert of 42 Riverside Drive, New York, in the Apollo Theatre, New York Avenue and the Boardwalk, here last night.

Dr. Wilbur E. Saunders, headmaster of Peddie School, gave. the address tonight at the annual commencement exercises of the Prinoeton Country Day School. J. Howard Murch, headmaster, announced the following award:

In its first academic year, just completed, the Jewish Culture Foundation of New York University has increased its membership from ten students to more than 500, according to the annual report of Abraham I. Katsch, executive director of the Foundation, released for publication yesterday.

Experiments in a tunnel fifty feet beneath Chicago streets, under the direction of Arthur H. Compton, Nobel Prize winning physicist of the University of Chicago, have shown that cosmic rays penetrating to that level are heavy electrons, known as barytons, it was reported today.

Automobile production declined sharply last week. With allowance for the holiday, daily average assemblies dropped off more than seasonally and the adjusted index slumped to its lowest point since the week ended Nov. 24, 1934.
The Rev. Matthew Leo Carolan, Professor of Latin at Providence College and a member of the first class to graduate from that institution in 1923, died at St. Joseph's Hospital early today.

With foreign markets closed in observance of the Whitsuntide holiday and a-large number of local foreign exchange brokers away on their annual field day, dealings in the foreign exchange market here yesterday were extraordinary quiet.
Stockholders of United CigarWhelan Stores Company approved yesterday the granting of an option to the president of the company to buy 225,000 shares of authorized common stock.

No nation is stronger than the moral fiber of its people, and can become truly great and permanent only to the extent that spiritual qualities are cultivated and permitted freely to operate in the government of their lives, the Christian Science board of directors warned today at the annual meeting of the Mother Church, the First Church of Christ, Scientist.

The greatest danger to democracy lies in the "acceptance by an inert people of encroachments on their constitutional rights," Governor Lehman told 1,008 graduates and 7,000 spectators this morning at commencement exercises of Syracuse University, held in Archbold' Stadium.

Plumbing fixtures in Mrs. Calvin Coolidge's new $25,000 home remained disconnected today. as Mayor William H. Feiker announced that he would seek repeal of a city ordinance requiring venting plumbing installations.

Leon Pettigrew,- ybung Fresh Meadow assistant pro, and Stuart Scheftel of Sands Point teamed in excellent. fashion to win the weekly Long Island P. G. A. amateur-pro best-ball competition today over the Wheatlev Hills Golf Club's course.
The Cash family returned to business today and this hamlet slipped into routine ways amid fading hopes for an early solution of the kidnapping of the young boy, Jimmy Cash.

Joseph F. Barton, political reporter and former director of publicity for the democratic State committee, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Highland Park. He was 61 years old. He was 61 years old.
An investigation into the loan Shark racket in Brooklyn was reccommended by Judge George W. Martin yesterday as he swore in members of the June Kings County Grand Jury.

An independent stockholders protective committee formed to represent preferred and common stockholders of the Reynolds Investing Company, Inc., and to support the new management in opposing steps now being taken to throw the company into bankruptcy under; Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act was announced yesterday by-George Armsby,- chairman of the committee, for which Carter, Ledyard Milburn rare counsel.

The bite of a wood tick, carrier of Rocky Mountain spotted fever, was blamed today for the death of Frank H. Reim Jr., 16 years old, of Clementon, a junior in Haddon Heights High School. He died last night in

An attempt to fly by ground contact o through a terrain and in weather conditions making such a flight im- t possible was given today by the of- n ficial board of inquiry of the Bureau of Air Commerce as the probable cause of the crash on May 16 near Saugus, Calif., in which a new Lockheed transport plane, being a flown for delivery to Northwest Airlines, Inc., was destroyed and the nine aboard killed.

In a unanimous decision here yesterday the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, Second Circuit, affirmed an order issued by the Federal Trade Commission against L. C. Mayers Company, Inc., 385 Madison Avenue, commanding it to cease and desist from the practice of "wholesale-retailing." The case was said to be the first of its kind ever brought to court.

America urgently needs a more favorable political and economic situation in which productive science can join with capital and labor in bringing back prosperity, Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, told 1,500 alumni at their dinner tonight.

More than $2,538,758 a year is being spent on the diagnosis and treatment in hospitals and clinics here of patients suffering from venereal diseases or their complications, it was pointed out yesterday by the' Welfare Council of New York City.

According to a report from Washington, the long-debated super-battleships which the United States and Great Britain are about to construct will have a tonnage of 45,000 tons and carry 16inch guns. The agreement represents

The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today a loan by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation of $2,122,000 to the Galveston, Houston Henderson Railroad under certain conditions relating to continuance of the contracts under which the Missouri-Kansas-Texas and International-Great Northern operate over the Galveston, Houston Henderson, and to guarantees of the latter's obligations.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, not including the companies 50 per cent owned, had 56,144 employes on its payroll at the end of last year, and of these, about 20,000 were in foreign countries, according to the company's annual report to employes, issued yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia narrowly avoided signing an innocent-looking tax bilt yesterday which, by the broad scope of its language, would have wiped out the 3 per cent city sales tax, the keystone of the city's emergency relief tax program.

New dates for the American Yacht Club's annual cruise were announced yesterday by F. H. Hibberd, the race committee chairman. Instead of starting on Sunday, Aug. 7, the first run to Port Jefferson will be on Thursday, Aug. 4.

Miss Jane Margaret Greaves, daughter of Professor, Hubert Greaves of Yale University, was married here this afternoon to Alan Cornwall Smith, son of Judge and Mrs. Edwin A. Smith of West Haven, in the chapel of St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

Reports quoting Motojiro Sugiyama, member of the Japanese Diet, as saying that Japan must control Hong Kong caused no concern here tonight. Indeed, most naval and diplomatic circles had not heard such reports.
Dr. Louis Martin, head of the Pasteur Institute, returning today on the Normandie from the dedication of the Franklin Memorial, paid tribute to American science.

Grace Moore received an ovation from 18,000 New Jersey music lovers when she appeared as soloist with the Essex County Symphony Orchestra at City Schools Stadium here tonight in the first of this year's series of four weekly concerts.
President Roosevelt conferred with legislative leaders and talked with T. F. Rhea, campaign manager for Senator Barkley in the Kentucky primary race.

William A. Wachenfeld, Essex County Prosecutor, announced today that he was investigating the disturbance in Military Park Saturday night when Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, was pelted with eggs and an attempted protest meeting against the acts of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City was -broken up by men who identified themselves as war veterans.

Tonnage sales in the grocery manufacturing field, particularly in nationally branded items, have not shown any tendency to decline substantially in the first six months of this year despite the present business condition, members of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America reported at the opening of the association's midyear meeting here at the Homestead Hotel today.

Eighty men allegedly affiliated with the Transport Workers Union of Greater New York, reinforced by about 150 seamen, established a picket line at Pier 56, Hudson River yesterday afternoon to protest the use of taxicabs of the Allied System by passengers of the liner Laconia.

The Rev. Robert Jacquinot de Besange, Jesuit missionary who formed the safety zone between Chinese and Japanese troops in the Nantao section of Shanghai, told yesterday the story of its creation and of plans being made to press for the extension of the principle. of neutral districts in international law.

An officially sponsored bill to restrict the use of ships. as hotels in Bermuda ports was introduced today in the newly elected Assembly. The Governor, Lieut. Gen. Sir Reginald Hildyard. had called a special session of the Legislature to deal with the question, which he described as "a matter that concerns almost the very existence of these islands."

Speaking at the commencement exercises of Skidmore College this morning, Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General in the United States Public Health Service, appealed to the graduates for the deveopment of "that heretofore unworldly quality of a social conscience which in the roaring teens and twenties was relegated to minlaters of the goapel, to a few educators and to the impractical men of science.

Many peasants took part in the "people's holiday" demonstrations organized throughout the country by the Peasant party during the Whitsun week-end. Meetings, however, were not authorized in several counties or in the large cities.

Ruling that County Clerk Vincent K. Drury of Richmond was entitled by law to appoint a third deputy after he had submitted a budget providing salaries for only two, Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler yesterday directed members of the Board of Estimate to fix a salary "as they may deem proper" for the third appointee.
Mgr. Rafael Guizar y Valencia, Bishop of Veracruz and one of Mexico's most widely known churchmen, died today at the age of 60.
A few details but no quotations from United States Ambassador'Joseph E. Davies' conversation with Joseph Stalin at the Kremlin yesterday were learned today.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Samuel Weschler of Flushing, Queens, of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eleanor Weschler, to Dr. Alfred J. Cantor of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Cantor of Syracuse, N. Y.
Twice postponed by rainstorms, the Veterans' Garden Party, given annually at the White House, took place today under smiling skies in the late afternoon of a perfect June day.

A petition seeking to disqualify Surrogate James A. Foley from passing on litigation involving the estate of Irving I. Bloomingdale, vice president of Bloomingdale Brothers, who died Oct. 15, 1929, was filed yesterday in Supreme Court in behalf of Mrs. Geanne Hughes Bloomingdale Butler. his widow. The petition revealed that

Ifor Jones, Westfield (N. J.) organist and music instructor, was elected today conductor of the Bach Choir Association of Bethlehem, the first choral society in America to produce Bach's Mass in B minor in its entirety.

Our Commissioner of Sanitation, Mr. William F. Carey, wants to transfer his garbage-dumping operations to the marsh islands of Jamaica Bay when he has to surrender Riker's Island next Spring. It appears that
Frederick Brown, president of the Hospital for Joint Diseases, yesterday laid the cornerstone for the institution's $750,000 out-patient department building.
Ignazio Pagliaro of Mount Vernon, real estate operator and builder, died Saturday in the Lenox Hill Hospital after an illness of seven months. He was 62 years old.

Fincob Corp, Reuben Coblens, treas, conveyed 531 W 151st St, 41.8x100, to Marcus Leudan of 1,860 Billingsley Terrace Bronx, at an indicated valuation of $2,000 over a mortgage for $40,000, and he gave back a mortgage for $3,000, due June 1, 1939, and he then transferred the parcel to the Nisan Corp, subject to the $40.000 mortgage.

Faculty members and students of the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy of Long Island University attended a funeral service yesterday at the Neiberg Funeral Chapel, 141 Ludlow Street, Manhattan, for Charles Bertram Lucks, 21 years old, who Bertram Lucks, 21 years old. who

Defying all their detractors and confounding the false prophets, the Dodgers headed for St. Louis tonight with half their Western trip completed and carrying the record of four victories in six intersectional battles.

The government was able, largely because of its sweeping credit-easing measures taken earlier this year in sponsoring continued easy money, not only to carry out its huge June refunding operation on the best terms on record for such maturities, but also to give holders of the maturing notes the most generous offer in recent years.

David J. Daly, lawyer and a leading Catholic layman, died Sunday atholic layman, died Sunday of a heart attack at his home; 735 East Twenty-second Street, Brooklyn, after having been Ill a week with pneumonia.
Mrs. Minnie E. Hendrix, past president of the Federation bf Women's Clubs here and a prominent member of the Order of the Eastern Star, died here last night.
After a week of frantic tugging, Commander Bill Terry finally got his parachute open today to check the (Giants' alarming descent.
E. R. Bradley's Bar FIy and the Rosedale Stable's Kentucky Blues accounted for the feature races at Suffolk Downs before 14,156 spectators today.
Adjustment of the Boeing Clipper was still going on here tonight and the time for the first test of-the big flying boat was undecided.
Joe Louis didn't have any boxing scheduled today in the course of his preparations for his June 22 heavyweight title defense against Max Schmeling, but he-got plenty of exercise.
Miss Betty Jameson of San Antonio, Texas, scored a 78, one :under women's par, to win the medal and become an odds-on choice to retain her women's transmississippi golf championship.

Charging that the publicity identifying him as the Tammany leader of the lower West Harlem district for, many years had created in the public mind the false impression that he and "most district leaders" had been involved in "sinister and unlawful actions," James J. Hines sought yesterday a change of venue for his trial on the Dutch Schultz policy racket indictment.
Trading in futures on the nation's three organized Cotton Exchanges amounted to 3,216,300 bales in May, compared with 3,129,900 in April, the Commodity Exchange Administration announced today.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended June 2 numbered 226, compared with 247 for the preceding week and 146 for the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
Hot ashes from the erupting Mayon volcano fell tonight upon towns in Albay Province, sending inhabitants in headlong flight to safety.

THE regulars at the race tracks-ordinarily view the jumping events with feelings varying from bare tolerance to complete disdain. They consider the steeplechases a trifling and sometimes disorderly interruption of an important order of business.

Putting aside a plan to inject their fight for parity freight rates into the current wage-hours controversy in Congress, Southeastern Governors and public service commissioners pushed the campaign vigorously today through other channels.

Overruling objection that screen writers should not be considered employes under the National Labor Relations Act since their work is creative and professional and because they receive relatively high salaries, the National Labor Relations Board today held that the long standing dispute between Hollywood screen writers and motion picture producers should be adjusted by an election.

An active market featured hogs and lambs, prices working higher. Strictly dry-fed steers and yearlings also got dependable outlet, but buyers continued to penalize all cattle that showed much grass, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

Official opening of the new Ontario Paper Com- , pany's newsprint mill at Comeau Bay, 300 miles below Quebec,. will take place at noon next Saturday, with Premier Duplessis of Quebec officially declaring the mill open for business.

A bill which had already passed the Senate was passed by the House today authorizing an increase in the enlisted strength of the Air Corps from 18,400 to 21,500 men to provide for additional needs under the Air Corps building program.

A number of multi-family dwellings and a two-story taxpayer in the Bronx were reported yesterday as having changed hands. Among them was the forty-four-family apartment house on a plot 90 by 106 feet at 2,487 Grand Avenue, which was sold by Alfred N. Crane to the London Estates, Inc. Sale was for cash above a first mortgage of $121;500. Isidor Tankus, broker, negotiated the deal.
Mrs. Sarah Houston Henry, a philanthropist and art petron, died at her home in Chestnut Hill today after a short illness.

A campaign to raise $50,000 for a permanent foundation in memory of Joseph Barondess, labor leader and leader in Jewish welfare work, was started last night at a dinner at the Hotel McAlpin in commemoration of the tenth anniversary of his death.
Mayor La Guardia's decision on whether to locate the Summer City Hall in the city building at the World's Fair or in the Arrowbrook Country Club was still in abeyance last night.

A special meeting of holders common shares of the Gatineau Power Company has been called for June 10 in Montreal for the purpose of authorizing the company to issue debentures in an amount not to exceed $13,000,000 at an interest rate of not more than 5 per cent.

Because beavers don't bear nine young there will be no beaver and nine little ones, representing the Dominion and the nine provinces, over the peace arch at the entrance of the Parliament Buildings here.

St. Bonaventure College conferred 103 degrees today at the annual commencement exercises held in Butler Memorial Hall. Three of the degrees were honorary. 'Lowell Thomas of New York, author and radio commentator, was made a Doctor of Letters.

Nine Democratic Senators who were aligned last year against the Administration's Supreme Court plan are candidates this year for re-election. Every one of the nine will apparently encounter, as Senator Gillette encountered yesterday in Iowa, opposition which is inspired or endorsed by an important group of the President's advisers.

Permission to conduct a club to foster interest in an R. 0. T. C. unit for Brooklyn College was granted last night to 200 students of the college by the Board of Higher Education at its regular monthly meeting held in the City College School of Business, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street.
The names of six stellar milers who will compete in the fifth annual Princeton invitation track meet on June 18 were announced today by Asa- S. Bushnell, director of the meet.

Colonel Theodore Roosevelt Jr., national chairman of the United Council for Civilian Relief in China, estimated yesterday that there were 60,000,000 civilian refugees in China, most of them without food and facing epidemics constituting the greatest health danger that the world has known since the Black Death of the Middle Ages.
The Legislature passed tonight the revised Appropriations Bill, authorizing expenditure of $39,256,036 in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

Miss Margaret Mosler Pearce, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Matthew C. Pearce of East Orange, has chosen the afternoon of June 18 for her marriage to William H. Potter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence H. Potter of Orange. The ceremony will take place in the North Orange Baptist Church, Orange.

Both contending parties in the old Slovak capital of Bratislava invoke the name of America to fortify their demands. At a great meeting on Sunday Father Hlinka, leader of a party which has been clamoring for autonomy since the republic was founded, referred repeatedly to the principles of American democracy. So did Premier Hodza,

Nursing Sister Cecily Jane Pope of the Royal Red Cross died here today at the age of 75. She was a daughter of the late William Pope, a father of Canadian Confederation, and a niece of the late J. C. Pope, one-time Minister of Marine and Fisheries. The late Sir Joseph Pope was a brother.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Annersley Murray of Pelham Manor, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Dorothy Murray, to Edward Brandon Lyman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Lyman of Scarsdale, N. Y.

Thirty-one students will be graduated here tomorrow night at the commencement exercises of the Concordia Collegiate Institute, which is owned and operated by the Missouri Synod of the Lutheran Church.

The French liner Ile de France will sail today for Havre via Plymouth. Among those on board will be Joseph Gevaert, Commissioner General for Belgium to the World's Fair, and Mme. Gevaert, Nadia Boulanger, French composer;
The wheat market failed today to receive much encouragement from outside buying, and the demand from shorts also was less aggressive than recently, for covering in the past few days has been heavy.
Mrs. William David Hamilton of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Margaret Jean Hamilton, to John Condit Ward, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest L. Ward, also of East Orange.

St. John's University in Brooklyn will hold three commencement ceremonies today in the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Lafayette Avenue and Ashland Place, for the graduating classes of five of the seven schools of the university. A total of 335 students will receive degrees.

A six-story apartment house is to be erected on the northeast corner of Spuyten Duyvil Parkway and Fieldston Road, the Bronx, at a cost of $600,000, according to plans filed yesterday by Boak Paris, Inc., architects, for Arlington C. Hall, owner.

The conedition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 1: a decrease of $39,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans and an increase of $25,000,000 in loans to brokers and dealers in securities; a decrease of $78,000,000
An ordinance designed to maintain order in labor troubles and defining peaceful picketing was adopted by a 3-to-2 vote by the Little Falls Township Committee tonight after a two-hour hearing.

Premier Milan Hodza delivered an impassioned plea for unity between Czechs and Slovaks today to a gathering of Slovaks in Bratislava. It was a gathering even bigger than the crowd of 70,000 that assembled yesterday when Father Andreas Hlinka, leader of the Slovak Catholic People's party, advanced an autonomist demand for Slovak self-government within the framework of the republic.

It used to be possible to date the beginning of Summer by the burgeoning of straw hats. Some fine Monday morning the usual sober grays, blues and blacks would almost all have disappeared, and one swam along a city street in an undulating swell of flattopped straws, with here and there a panama drifting like kelp in the tide.
Television transmission over a distance of 220 miles was reported today from Middlesbrough, Yorkshire.

Xavier High School of New York totaled 7,755 points to lead the scorers in all classes in the 1938 national intercollegiate rifle matches while heading the high school division in .he tournament conducted by the War Department, it was announced yesterday at the Second Corps Axea Headquarters on Governors Island.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 3: CAPTAIN McDonnell, W. N., Med. Corps, Mare Island, Calif., to Naval Retiring Board, Board of Medical Examiners and Naval Examing Board for Officers of Medical Corps, Washington, D. C., in July.

A town meeting voted tonight by 256 to 118 to reject offers of the Bridge port Hydraulic Company to pay to the town $65,000 or\$50,000, under separate proposals, for replacement of roads to be wiped out in the Saugatuck reservoir project.

Brazil led all other countries in purchases of 'arms, ammunitions and implements of war. from the United States in May, having obtained export licenses with a face amount of $1,494,824, according to figures issued by the State Department today.

Shareholders of the Beauharnois Power Corporation, Ltd., approved yesterday a plan of reorganization, already approved by the bondholders, providing for an increase in capitalization and a proposal to transfer assets to the Beauharnols ILight, Heat and Power Company.

Mayor La Guardia and James G. Blaine, president of the Greater New York Fund, were the principal speakers at a City Hall Park rally for the fund at noon yesterday, at which preliminary contributions of $108,000 were received.

Stanley M. Isaacs, Manhattan Borough President who has been criticized in recent months for his appointment of Simon W. Gerson, Communist journalist, as his assistant, was listed as a speaker yesterday at a Madison Square Garden meeting on Thursday evening to protest the embargo on goods to Spain.

The objective of United States foreign policy-stable and lasting peacecannot be gained through a policy of isolation, and this country must be "prepared, if necessary, to withstand the aggression of the lawless," Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State, said in a radio address tonight over a National Broadcasting Company network.
The "Annual of Bookmaking," an illustrated report on bookmaking in America during the past decade, will be issued on June 21 as a special publication of The Colophon, a book collectors' quarterly.

Central Europe's tennis stars gained five places in the quarter-final round of the French hard court championships today and produced a player who carried World Champion Don Budge to five grueling sets before the California redhead could survive.
The week-end was disappointing to many salt-water anglers who prefer quiet waters and a lot of sunshine, but most of the reports on catches were favorable.

Surviving the hardest challenge of his victorious career, War Admiral yesterday took the Queens County Handicap with Snark slowly falling back at the finish of the mile after he had been lapped on the son of Man o' War at the furlone pole. It was at the opening
Some readers may grow tired of hearing about Norman Thomas's unsuccessful attempts to talk in New Jersey. But not those readers who understand the issues involved.

Professor and Mrs. David G. Samuels of this city have received a cablegram from Balboa, C. Z., announcing the marriage of Miss Marian Hughes of Mount Carmel, Pa., to their son, David Griffiths Samuels Jr. of Chuquicamata, Chile, in the Baptist Church at Balboa last Friday.
Miss Gloria Braggiotti of this city has chosen June 20 for her marriage to Emlen Etting of Philaielphia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emlen Pope Etting of Southfield, Haverford, Pa. The ceremony will take

The six-family house at 1,152 Gates Avenue and the four-family and store structure at 2,981 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, have been sold to clients of William G. Kittelberger, broker. John Bruning and Rebecca Koop were the respective sellers.

Because of the Jewishb holiday, Shabuoth, the lamb kill was very light, and practically no cattle or vealers slaughtered. Slaughter house supplies of traefer meats were light and this market ruled steady to higher. Steer hinds and ribs were strong to 50 cents higher, veal hindsaddles steady, lamb fully steady with Friday's, sharp advance, pork cuts steady to slightly higher. No kosher market, and prices quoted are nominally steady with Friday's close.

With retail trade spotty last week, stores confined their mail orders yesterday to orders for "fill-ins" and promotional items, according to manufacturers and resident offices. Regular beach wear items, however, were more active.

A list of honorary student appointments for the 191st commencement of Princeton. University was announced today by Dan D. Coyle of Centreville; Md., president of the senior class. The class valedictorian and salutatorian were not named.

Between shots at John L. Lewis and "imported philosophies," William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today leveled criticism at New Deal policies, particularly "continuous spending" and the "badly administered" Labor Relations Act.

A suit brought by Giovannia Farrelly of 1,158 Fifth Avenue against Ely Culbertson, contract bridge -expert, for an accounting of the funds of Crockford's, Inc., the bridge club they founded at 14 East Sixty-second Street, went on trial yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo without a jury.

Dr. George W. Hartman, editor of The Social Frontier, swill be the speaker tomorrow morning at the commencement of Scarborough School here. Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip, president of the trustees, and Howard W. Nudd, head of the board of administration, also will speak.

An absentee from the women's metropolitan golf championship since 1934, Miss Maureen Orcutt began her quest for her sixth district title by finishing in a tie for medal honors today with an 80 at the Century Country Club.

An intimation telegraphed yesterday by Premier Aberhart to Prime Minister Mackenzie King that the withdrawal "of essential services" by the Alberta banks would force the Alberta Government to take action of its own "to safeguard the welfare of our people" and

Roses, peonies and iris predominated at the fourth annual Spring flower show of the Pennsylvania Railroad Garden Club held yesterday in the Y. M. C. A. branch in the Pennsylvania Station. More than 300 gardeners from Long Island, New Jersey and Pennsylvania entered exhibits.
The construction of bicycle paths along the Westchester County parkways was proposed today by Dr. Benjamin F. Barnes, Yonkers supervisor, at the June meeting of the County Board of Supervisors.

Jake Mooty held the Little Giants to seven hits today and enabled Syracuse to score a 4-to-i -victory. Mooty had only one. bad Inning, the sixth, when Jersey City made two hits and its only run. He fanned two and walked two.
The ninety-one-family apartment house at 139-06-18 Thirty-fourth Road, corner of Leavitt Place, Flushing, L. I., has been sold in one of the largest Queens deals in recent months.

A cast of four sightless young women, representing the New-York Guild for the Jewish BIind of 200 West Seventy-second Street, finished among the finalists last night in the Community Drama Spring Tournament staged by the Federal Theatre Project, a representative of the Guild announced last night.

Pleas of not guilty were entered today in Suffolk County Court before Judge L. Barron Hill to indictments charging the German-American League, Inc., as a corporation and six of its directors with violating Section 5a of the Civil Rights Law of New York State.

Rod Munday, professional,. and Howard Schanzer, representing Metropolis, coordinated in splendid style today to take first-place honors in the Westchester Professional Golfers Association bro-amateur best-ball tourney over the difficult Fenway course.

Jay F. Carlisle, farmhouse at Roslyn, L. I., from Clarence S. Mackay; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, brokers. William Neville, on Lloyd Court, West New Brighton, Staten Island, from the Corn Exchange Bank and Trust Co; Cronelius G. Kolff, Inc, broker.

Moral rearmament throughout the world, based on the principle of absolute unselfishness, was advanced today as a paramount necessity to defeat the present international hostility and disquiet by Dr. Frank Buchman, leader of the Oxford Group.
The police have notified theatre operators that their shows must end promptly at midnight on Mondays, Wednesdays, Saturdays and Sunday and 11:30 o'clock on Tuesday, Thursdays and Fridays.

Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Froessel reserved decision in Brooklyn yesterday on the application of the Sea Gate Association for continuance of a temporary injunction restraining the Sea Gate Tenants Association from picketing the Sea Gate residential community in Coney Island in protest against a $5 fee for use of the beach.

Nine mysterious military planes that flew over and bombed French territory near the Pyrennes frontier yesterday positively did not belong to the Nationalist [Spanish Insurgent] air force, declares a vigorously worded official statement made public tonight by Generalissimo Francisco Franco's general staff.

Common Pleas Judge Robert V. Kinkead reserved decision today on an appeal for a new trial for John R. Longo, 24-year-old Democratic political opponent of Mayor Frank Hague, who was found guilty May 6 of filing fraudulent nominating petitions in last November's primary and sentenced to nine months in the Laurel Hill County prison at Secaucus.
The Federal Theatre Project's production of "On the Rocks," which has been backing and filling for several weeks, now is scheduled to open at Daly's Theatre the evening of June 15.

Mr. and Mrs. George W. Sherer of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Julia Sherer, to Stewart E. Ritter Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ritter, also of this place. The wedding will take place in the Autumn.

The stockholders of the International Mercantile Marine Company at their annual meeting yesterday in Hoboken voted approval of the sale of the ships Virginia, California and Pennsylvania of the Panama Pacific Line to the federal Maritime Commission for operation in a service to South America that the government plans to start early in the Fall.

Twenty per cent less litter is being thrown on the sidewalks of clean-up, when uncounted thousands of bits of gum and other debris were removed by a squad of cleaners from several blocks in the area, according to J. Le Bloas Marlaine. Mr. Marlaine is executive vice president of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association, sponsor of the said drive.
Cardinal Hayes, as president of the College of Mount St. Vincent, will preside and confer the degrees this afternoon at the commencement day exercises of the college on the campus at Riverdale.
Arthur will M. Betts was elected chairman of the Chicago Stock Excharige's Board of Governors today. Under a new constitution, the governors will choose the Exchange's first salaried president soon.

Two men who were alleged to have pushed a woman into the East River at the foot of Fulton Street early yesterday after an automobile trip from the Bronx were held without bail after pleading not guilty before Magistrate Ford in Felony Court.

What little interest developed in the bond market yesterday was centered in United States Government securities, where the initial response to the Treasury's refunding offer was one of enthusiasm and general satisfaction on the part of the financial community.
Edwin Elmer Russell, vice president in charge of purchasing of the J. I. case Company died suddenly today at ST. Luke's Hospital. He was 69 years old.

A strike of electrical workers employed by the Long Island Lighting Company was threatened today when members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers notified Governor Lehman that a "serious public emergency" might arise if contract negotiations failed. The union, an A. F. of L.
The league-leading Cubs outlasted. Philadelphia today in a free-swinging battle, 10 to 8, and retained their half-game margin over - the Giants.

Last Friday The Montreal Gazette was a hundred and Sixty years old. It was founded by the universal Dr. Franklin. In 1778 the Americans were still nursing the hope that Canadian Frenchmen might be induced to join them against Great Britain.
Samuel S. Bent of White Plains, a New York and Westchester architect, died on Sunday in the New York Hospital, New York, after a brief illness. His age was 46.

News has been received in this city from1. most authoritative sources that Dr. Frederick Scovel, attached to the American byterian . mission at Tsining, Shantung Province, was wounded seriously by a Japanese soldier either June .2 or. 3.
Sevenhit pitching by Marius Russo enabled the Bears to register their third straight victory over the Orioles tonight, 8 to 3.
Seniors of beaver College held their Class Day exercises today on the eve of commencement, when degree will be presented to 136 young women and certificates to eleven.
Death Announced Retired Captain John H. Travers, formerly a member of H. L. Co. 111, residing at 124-21 Hillside Ave., Richmond Hill, Queens. died June 5.
Trailing 7-2 going into the last half of the seventh, the Red Sox today put on three rousing rallies to nip the Tigers, 8 to 7, and carry off the odd game of the series.

The State Planning Board suggested to-day in a report to Governor Moore and the Legislature that a major part of the Hackensack meadows be developed for a recreation critter "nine times the size of Central Park in New York."

Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, expressed the hope at his press conference today that there might be some favorable action in the direction of uniform bank examinations in about a week.
A mental patient who escaped from his guard at 6:30 P. M. yesterday in the Pennsylvania Station, amid hundreds of homegoing commuters, was the object of a wide police search last night.

A major part of the American school system, equipped with teachers alleged to be unfit and adhering to a rigid curriculum for all children, was declared here today to be an "actual cause" of juvenile delinquency.

Spanish Insurgents reported tonight their forces had encircled Albocacer, center of Government resistance, blocking the southward drive toward Castellon de la Plana and Valencia. Dispatches from the front said capture of the town was "only a matter of time."

Steel production in the United States declined in May for the third consecutive month, while operations of the industry this week are scheduled at 26.2 per cent capacity, a slight increase over the rate of 26.1 per cent of last week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

After assuming an early lead of more than 8 to 5 in Iowa's Democratic Senatorial primary, Senator Guy M. Gillette early today was pulling steadily ahead of Representative Otha D. Wearin, spearhead of the New Deal "elimination committee's" first attempt to unseat those Senators I who stood against President Roosevelt's courtenlargement bill- last year.

A new record for safe passenger travel was established by the Class I railroads of this country during 1937, John Stilwell, president of the American Museum of Safety, announced yesterday. He reported that twenty-seven passengers were killed-fewer per million passenger miles than in any year since records were made available by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
Dr. Albert Einstein today blamed a "serious weakening of moral thought and sentiment" during the last century or so for the "barbarization of political ways in our time."

Yehudi Menuhin, youthful violinist, arrived here last night aboard the Ile de France after a triumphal concert tour of Europe, accompanied by his bride, the former Miss Nola Nicholas of Melbourne, Australia, and members of his family.

The general synod of the Reformed Church in America today went on record as favoring increased control of the liquor traffic, smaller appropriations for army and navy next year, the stamping out of gambling, with special emphasis on bingo, and prohibition of munitions exports.

Miss Tatiana Conus, daughter of Mrs. Gregory Iswolsky of this city and of Jules Conus of Paris, will be married to Prince Guido Colonna, Italian vice consul at Toronto, tomorrow at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Fairfield Osborn, 207 East Sixty-first Street.

Miss Elizabeth E. Stone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Stone of this place, will be married on June 24 to Leslie Leonard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Claude A. Leonard of Hillside, N. J. The wedding will take place in St. John's Episcopal Church, Montclair.
Frank J. Knell was elected yesterday president of the New York Cotton Exchange. Robert J. Murray was chosen vice president and Clayton B. Jones. treasurer.

Fresh from his victory at Hartford, following his winning of the Orange invitation tournament, Elwood Cooke started in quest of another tennis cup yesterday as he made his first appearance in the Brooklyn championship at the Terrace Club of Flatbush.

The New Jersey Professional Golfers' Association's first one-day proamateur tournament of the season was won by Peter James and Chase Sanderson of the Madison G. C. with a best ball of 64 today. The event, staged today at the Forsgate C. C., attracted a field of fifty.

The 299-foot submarine Sargo, her hull gay with international code flags and- bunting, was launched today at the shipyard of the Electric .Boat Company. Mrs. 'Chester W. Nimitz, wife of Rear Admiral Nimitz, assistant chief of the Navy Bureau of Navigation, christened the craft.
At afternoon exercises held in the stadium before thousands of parents, friends and alumni, 833 students received fifteen classes of degrees to end Duke University's centennial commencement.

Among the contracts for commercial space in buildings throughout the city reported yesterday was one for 20,000 square feet in the structure at 68 Jay Street, Brooklyn, which was taken by the Hano Paper Company, manufacturers and distributors of paper products, notebooks and school supplies. The lessee will have the use of a railroad siding. The C. Grant Keck Organization was the broker in the deal.

The backwash of war brought Valencia an unexpected blessing today-thousands of pounds of fresh fish. Insurgent air raiders, soaring away from Government pursuit planes, unloaded their bomb-racks in order to gain altitude quickly.

The Rev. Edward C. Tamblyn, retired pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church of this village, died suddenly at his home today of a suddenly at his home today of a streptococcus infection. He was 53 years old.

Following complete occupation of Kaifeng, Honan's provincial capital, yesterday morning the Japanese forces presesd on and were said to have forced their way an additional fourteen miles westward along the Kaifeng-Chengchow highway, paralleling the Lung-Hai Railway, to a point only twenty-five miles eastward of Chengchow, the junction of the Lung-Hai and Peiping-Hankow Railways.

Mrs. Joel Ellis Fisher gave a dinner last night in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for Mr.. and Mrs. Joel Ellis Fisher Jr., who will sail soon for Europe. Mr. Fisher will spend a few weeks at Chamonix, then will return to New York. His wife and children

Wheat growers of the United States face a gloomy outlook for the next year, it was indicated in information brought by Washington experts to the four-day regional conference of Agricultural Adjustment Administraction officials and field workers that opened here today.

The estate on Rochelle Road, Larchmont, Westchester County, formerly owned by Anthony J. Daino, has been purchased by Mrs. Alice B. Jordan, president of the Postal Life Insurance Company. The property consists of a large stone mansion on attractively landscaped grounds. George Howe, Inc., was the broker in the sale.

Arthur Stately, 35-year-old WPA worker who has been sought by the police for questioning in connection with the shooting of two women last Thursday in an apartment at 37-75 Sixty-fourth Street, Woodside, was arrested yesterday as he sat on a bench waiting for a bus at Hillside Avenue and Little Neck Road, Queens Village.

Current business conditions in all lines of industry and in the automobile business in particular can be improved by a changed attitude and a proper analysis of the situation, A. E. Barit, president of the Hudson Motor Car Company, told distributors and dealers in the New York zone at a luncheon meeting at the Hotel Astor yesterday. Mr.
Mrs. Lena White, mother of George White, producer of George White's Scandals, died Saturday after a brief illness at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Gertrude Aber, at the age of 87.

The-American press is still doing "a remarkably good job" despite the many pressures upon it, Bruce Bliven, editor of The New Republic, declared last night at the eighth annual commencement exercises of Long Island University held in the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

A nation-wide poll of member stores of the National Retail Dry Goods Association revealed yesterday that 89 per cent will increase their Father's Day promotions this year over those of 1937, while only 4 per cent said they would curtail efforts and 8 per cent indicated the same degree of activity as for last year.

John H. Hersham, 48 years old, a retired business man, committed suicide last night in his room at the Hotel Knickerbocker, 120 West Forty-fifth Street. There was a bullet wound in his right temple and a 32 caliber revolver in his right hand. according to the police.

In an effort to speed up the granting of modernization loans through the liberalization of FHA rules, theMayor's Committee on Property Improvement has arranged for Charles McGehee, deputy administrator of the Federal Housing Administration, to come to New York for a conference on Friday with loan officers of lending institutions here.

Countess Alexandro Mercati, who will leave next week for her home in Paris, will give a tea on Thursday at the St. Regis for Prince and Princess Dominique Radziwill, who are here on their wedding trip.
Mrs. Clarence E. Brown of Sussex, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Gladys K. Brown, to William C. Ogburn Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Ogburn of Greensboro, N. C.

Urging a balanced budget, Henry H. Heimann, executive secretary of the National Association of Credit Men, asserted today that "we will never get under way on a sound recovery program until we live within our income." He told 2,000 delegates
Among the Syracuse seniors who received degrees today were Mrs. Harry P. Smith and her son, Durwood Smith. Mrs. Smith received a Ph. D. and her son a B. A.

Prospects of extended conference hearings on the Relief-Recovery Bill, which undoubtedly will delay the hoped-for adjournment this week, arose today in the House as the conferees went over the seventy-six Senate amendments.

The United States Government's deep interest in regulating by a world convention hours and working conditions of motor transport. workers was stressed today by its delegate, Miss Frieda S. Miller, in the Interna tional Labor Conference committee dealing with this problem.

Zeke Bonura drove a long double against the right-field wall in the eleventh today to break up the second successive, extra-inning game between the Senators and Indians. The score was Washington 5, Cleveland 4.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe, who was named arbitrator in January, 1937, when an action to reorganize the Associated Gas and Electric Company under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act was dis- an missed under a stipulation that the company pay reasonable counsel fees, recommended yesterday the payment of fees and disbursements amounting to $266,302.

The Nassau County Chapter of the American Red Cross. which is celebrating its twenty-first anniversary, sent greetings to other chapters in the country that also are observing the anniversary during a luncheon today at the Elks Club here.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial, "Bluewater Progress," states that the chairman of the Maritime Commission has struck a "bluewater balance sheet" of the merchant marine for the benefit of Congress and the country. As you add, much besides

A forty-man track team will be sent abroad by the Amateur Athletic Union this Summer for competition in Europe and South Africa, it was announced yesterday by Seeretary-Treasurer Daniel J. Ferris, Another team' may tour South America..
The eight largest farm implement manufacturers of the country were accused today of dominating the entire industry. In a report to

Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. P. Elmer of 16 Newlen Road have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Darice Dunham Elmer, to John McDiarmid, also of Princeton. The wedding will take place on July 6.

Miss Peggy Elmes, a descendant of John Winthrop, first Governor of the Massachusetts Bay Colony, and Thomas Hastings Cooke, a member of a family that has been identified with Hawaii for many years, were married here yesterday afternoon in St. James Episcopal Church by the Rev. James A. Paul, the acting rector.

The splendor of 300 years of American military history passed across the greensward of Boston Common this afternoon as the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company of Massachusetts, assisted by other famous units from both sides of the sea, celebrated its tercentenary before 20,000 spectators.

Behind the airtight pitching of Dick Cleary, who fanned five and yielded only one safety, All Hallows downed Mt. St. Michael, 1-0, in a play-off game at Fordham University Field yesterday to capture the Bronx-Westchester division title of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association. Kenny's single in

Chief of Detectives John L. Sullivan said tonight that Robert Nixon, 18-year-old Negro accused of slaying five women, had confessed on attack on Miss Virginia Austin of New York, an artist, for which another man is serving a prison term.

Frank D. Waterman Jr. was elected yesterday to succeed his late father as president of the L. E. Waterman Company, fountain pen manufacturers. Frank D. Waterman Sr., who headed the company for thirty-seven years, died last month. Elisha H. Waterman

The Ottynier Society's Shevuoth services in the basement at 169 Suffolk Street were interrupted yesterday morning when a fire started at the side of the altar. While six prayer-shawled members carried out the Torah scrolls, about forty other worshipers fled to the street.

City Hall was crowded to capacity tonight with taxpayers who came to protest the $4,000,000 rise in the 1938-39 assessment roll, the first valuation placed on local properties under the Board of Assessors of Nassau County acting under the new county charter.
Funds for the service of two Austrian international loans have been withheld since the Nazis took over Austria, according to announcements by the loan trustees today.

Permission for Dr. Sigmund Freud to leave Austria for London was obtained from the Nazi authorities in Germany through the combined efforts of three associations of followers of Dr. Freud in this country, England and France, it was learned here yesterday.

Premier Daladier personally saw to it yesterday that the airplane patrol of the Franco-Spanish border was reinforced, following the bombing of a railroad and a hydroelectric plant the day before. Nine planes coming from Spain drew fire from anti-aircraft guns and retreated over the border without dropping bombs. [Page 1.]

Debits a to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended June 1, which included five business days in most of the reporting centers, aggregated $6,850,000,000, or about the same as the total reported for the preceding week and 18 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year, which also included five business days in most of the reporting centers.

Robert F. Straub, vice president of the Bunge North American Grain Company, was elected president of the New York Produce Exchange at the annual election yesterday. Mr. Straub succeeds John McD. Murray, who is retiring after serving two terms as head of' the Exchange.
Major C. B. Grace, son of the famous cricketer always known in England as "W. G.," fell dead on a cricket field today just after he had hit fast ball to the boundary for four runs.

H. Alexander of 42 West Thirtieth Street, New, York, trading as Staibrite Letter Company, has stipulated to discontinue certain misleading representations in the sale of sign and letter numbers, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

Miss Isabel Dick McDonald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Colin Farquhar McDonald of this city, will be married to Lawrence A. Fernsworth of London, Spanish war correspondent for The Times of London, with headquarters at Barcelona. in St.Mary's Cathedral here on June 22. Miss McDonald became acquainted with Mr. Fernsworth in 1933 while visiting friends in Spain.
Mayor La Guardia may sigh a little if his plan to improve his golf in the ample spaces of the Arrow Brook Country Club has to be given up. Otherwise his loss will be the general gain.

Maine still belongs technically to the United States. Senator Minton ought to know that the down-East workers of iniquity are getting busy. If he will go to Isleboro and observe the house sheltering the ferryboat that runs between that town and Lincolnville he will see on its ridgepole a hoary old sinner of a gull named Cleek.

A blonde young woman who has testified twice before the Federal grand jury's spy inquiry was identified last night as Eleanor Boehne, a graduate of Hunter College who also studied at the University of Berlin. Mist Boehne is regarded

The power of the Cardinals broke forth today as the Red Birds battered the Bees into submission, 11 to 2. Roy Henshaw, the southpaw Baseball Commissioner K. M. Landis insisted the Cardinals keep, pitched classy, six-hit ball as his mates pounded three Boston hurlers for fourteen hits, three of them homers.
Knocked down for a count of 5 in,the fourth, the Yankees climbed off the floor to flatten the presumptuous Browns, 6 to 5, at the Stadium yesterday.

Miss Isabel Dick McDonald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Colin Farquhar McDonald of this city, will be married to Lawrence A. Fernsworth of London, Spanish war correspondent for The Times of London, with headquarters at Barcelona. in St.Mary's Cathedral here on June 22. Miss McDonald became acquainted with Mr. Fernsworth in 1933 while visiting friends in Spain.
Mayor La Guardia may sigh a little if his plan to improve his golf in the ample spaces of the Arrow Brook Country Club has to be given up. Otherwise his loss will be the general gain.

Maine still belongs technically to the United States. Senator Minton ought to know that the down-East workers of iniquity are getting busy. If he will go to Isleboro and observe the house sheltering the ferryboat that runs between that town and Lincolnville he will see on its ridgepole a hoary old sinner of a gull named Cleek.

A blonde young woman who has testified twice before the Federal grand jury's spy inquiry was identified last night as Eleanor Boehne, a graduate of Hunter College who also studied at the University of Berlin. Mist Boehne is regarded

The power of the Cardinals broke forth today as the Red Birds battered the Bees into submission, 11 to 2. Roy Henshaw, the southpaw Baseball Commissioner K. M. Landis insisted the Cardinals keep, pitched classy, six-hit ball as his mates pounded three Boston hurlers for fourteen hits, three of them homers.
Knocked down for a count of 5 in,the fourth, the Yankees climbed off the floor to flatten the presumptuous Browns, 6 to 5, at the Stadium yesterday.

Wholesale commodity prices as measured by the price index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association were at the lowest level last week. reached in the current recession. This index in the week ended June 4 stood at 73.8 per cent of the 1926-1928 average, representing a decline of 17 per cent from the 1937 high point.
Mrs. Georgie McClure Lee, philanthropist and founder of the Igleside Home for Girls in Revere, died today at her home in Back Bay. Her age was 67. age was 67.
Italo Colonello, 194A/4 pounds, of Italy scored a one-sided victory over George (Big Boy) Brackey,. 2223/4, of Buffalo in the feature eight-round bout at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

The State Education Department is committed to a new policy of relaxing the scholastic standards which must be attained by a student before he may take part in school athletics, it became known today.

The elimination of all dangerous grade crossings in the city, including those on the much discussed Atlantic Avenue line of the Long Island Railroad, was recommended and a. definite move toward that end was made at public and executive hearings yesterday of the Highways, Parkways and Grade Crossings Committee of the State Constitutional Convention.

The Board of Liquidation of State Debt of Louisiana has awarded the issue of $8,612,200 of refunding bonds of the State to a banking group headed by Edward Jones Co. of New Orleans at a net interest cost to the State of 3.37588 per cent.
Jackie (Kid) Berg, veteran English battler, will meet Johnny McHale, Astoria welterweight, in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Caparsie Stadium tonight. The semi-final, also listed for eight

Nineteen graduates of the Teacher Training Department of the Ethical Culture Schools received diplomas last night at the commencement exercises in the auditorium of the Ethical Culture Society at Central Park West and Sixty-third Street.

In the week ended last Saturday the city's death rate fell 9.5 per 1,000 population, a record low for the year to date, it was reported yesterday by Dr. William H. Best, Acting Health Commissioner. This was the more remarkable in view of the unseasonable weather, Dr. Best pointed out.

Recipients of fourteen Kosciuszko Foundation scholarships for 1938 were announced yesterday by Dr. Henry Noble Mac Cracken, president of the organization. Seven scholars will take the graduate course in Polish history and culture this Summer at the Universities of Warsaw, Poznan and Krakow.

Sixty-two of 431 laundries in Brooklyn were cited yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, as refusing to pay their women and minor male employes the legal minimum wage of $14 for a forty-hour week. The names and addresses of the violators will be published in some newspapers andannounced over the radio from some stations today, in accordance with the law.
John K. Weeks of New York has just returned from Bimini, where he spent fifteen days fishing for tuna and Marlin, and reported some interesting fishing.

Reenforcea by the youthful Alex Kampouris, Cincinnati's gift to Colonel Bill Terry, the Giants came to grips with their arch rivals, the Cubs, today with a feeling of security such as they had not known in many weeks.
Vice President Garner lost $1 betting with a newspaper man. He bet that Congress would adjourn today.
Four Randolph Field flyers were killed today in two airplane crashes within a few minutes of each other near the main field.

Miss Yaltah Menuhin of Los Gatos, Calif., 16-year-old sister of Yehudi Menuhin, violinist, and William Stix, 26, a St. Louis' attorney, were married yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora after the justice had sinned an

In expectation of a flood of new applications for Public Works allotments, President Roosevelt served notice on prospective applicants today that their chances would be improved if they dispensed with attorneys and paid representatives and made their requests directly to the PWA.

The Home Group of Insurance Companies and Home Insurance Company of New York led contributions by corporations and firms with a gift of $10,000 announced yesterday by the Greater New York Fund, which is seeking to raise $10,000,000 to supplement the budgets of private welfare and health agencies.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Church of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Charlene Church, to Charles F. Pfeifer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Pfeifer of New York.

Abbatoro made every post a winning one in capturing the fifth race, feature of today's card at the Fair Grounds. The 5-year-old gelding from the stable of Mrs. Thomas C. Stevenson covered the mile and sevety yards in 1:462-5 to finish two and onehalf lengths in front of L. C. Young's Ho. Royal Vintage finished third.
Roy J. Dunlap, managing editor of The St.. Paul Dispatch and The Pioneer Press for the last ten years, died today of a heart attack suffered Sunday.

Friends of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, son of Mrs. Margaret Emerson and owner of a large string of race horses, divulged tonight plans for his approaching marriage to Miss Manuela Hudson, a niece of Charles S. Howard of San Francisco, owner of the race horse Seabiscuit, and Mrs. Howard. Neither Mr. Vanderbilt nor Miss Hudson was reached for confirmation.

The League of Nations is now in the position of having recognized Haile Selassie as Emperor of Ethiopia, as regards payment of Ethiopia's dues to the League, after most of its members have either recognized King Victor Emmanuel as its Emperor or asserted, as in the recent Council, their right to recognize him, whenever It suits their interests.

Joseph W. Hanson Jr., an employee of the Williamsburgh Savings Bank, Brooklyn, won the first prize, $00, in the national public speaking con-test - of- the - American- Institute of Banking last night.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., headed the successful banking group yesterday in the sale of a new issue of $5,000,000 of road, bridge and park bonds of Allegheny County, Pa. The group received the award on a bid of 102.099 for 2 1/2s. The bonds,

The Browns beat a fifteen-hit tattoo on four Senator pitchers today, winning, 11 to 8. Little Harlond Clift, St. Louis third sacker, -belted out four hits and drove in five runs. The Senators contributed four errors, three by Third Baseman Buddy Lewis.

The volume of commercial tonnage under construction or under contract to be built in Atnerican shipyards increased about 62 per cent in the last year, according to a survey published yesterday by the American Bureau of Shipping.

H. N. Brailsford says in his London letter to The New Republic that Prime Miniter Chamberlain and his supporters neveer tire of describing themselves as dedicated to peace and reconciliation. And, says this distinguished British journalist, "if one accepts their conception of peace, their boat is jusstified."

Trading was fair to slow. The lamb market was strong to higher; steer cuts mostly steady to lower; other classes mostly unchanged. The first kosher markets since last Friday opened slowly with beef steady to lower, veal steady to weak, lamb strong to higher.
Miss Katharine Darlington Johnson of Annapolis has completed plans for her wedding on June 25 to Lawrence Terry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Terry of Short Hills, N. J.

The "Art for the Subway" exhibition, previously shown at the Museum of Modern Art and at the Transport Workers Union, is now at the Theodore Roosevelt High School, 500 East Fordham Road, in the Bronx. Besides sketches, details,

A main event of the eighteenth annual field day of the Bond Club of New York on Friday at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club will be the annual golf tournament between investment bankers of New York and Philadelphia.

Testimony that American cement manufacturers maintain lower prices in Boston and in Brooklyn, where the foreign product is landed, than in other cities nearer the Eastern plants, was given yesterday before the Federal Trade Commission in a hearing on the government's charge that the Cement Institute and seventy-five member companies conspired to eliminate Price competition.

The Federal Trade Commission today made public proposed. trade practice rules for the- roll leaf manufacturing industry, said to have annual sales of about $950,000. Opportunity to the industry to protest the proposed rules will be -afforded at a hearing in the commission's offices on June 22. The rules,

A week ago it was generally believed that the principle of wage differentials had been accepted by conferees of both the Senate and the House and would be incorporated in the Wage-Hour Bill. Now it appears that the supporters of wage differentials have won their "principle" and surrendered its substance.

Mrs. Anna Weschler of 142-23 Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eleanor Weschler, to Dr. Alfred J. Canton, a member of the staff of the Lenox Hill Hospital, Manhattan.
Bob Johnson's bid for his eleventh home run of the season fell a yard short today, and the Tigers made off with a 5-4 victory over the Athletics in the opener of a three-game series.

The Senate of the University of Chicago, acaemic ruling body of which all full professors are members, has diacted its committee on policy to Study the administrative methods Itroduced by President Robert M. Eutchins.

Commencement exercises of St. John's University, Brooklyn, will be concluded today with two ceremonies at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Lafayette Avenue and Ashland Place. More than 600 degrees will be awarded at the two exercises.

Daniel J. Casey, Director of Public Safety for Jersey City, took sole responsibility today for denying permits for street meetings to the C. I. O. and the American Civil Liberties Union, and said Mayor Frank Hague had nothing to do with it.

Earnings of the Aluminum Company of America since its inception through December, 1934, averaged about 9 per cent on its average assets, William Watson Smith, counsel for the company, told Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey yesterday. Mr. Smith was continuing his opening address in a trial of the government's action to enjoin the company and its affiliates from violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.

Mrs. Sadie Leslie Monsson, a 50-year-old widow who lives in Brooklyn on a $30-a-month Federal pension and the earnings of her daughter as a WPA worker, made known yesterday the contents of two letters she has received from government agencies.
The Savage School for Physical Education will hold its thirty-ninth annual commencement exercises at 8:30 P. M. tonight at the Ethical Culture Auditorium, 2 West Sixtyfourth Street.

The spearhead of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's Insurgent infantry smashed through government defense lines in Castellon Province today to enter the broad river valley leading to Castellon de la Plana.

Two important developments in the field of grocery distribution became apparent here today as members of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America continued their discussions of trade problems. The meeting closed late this afternoon.

Asserting that a suspended sentence was not punishment, Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. sharply criticized yesterday the high number of such sentences in violations of the labor law, the sanitary code and in illegal peddling. His comments were made in his annual report of the city- magistrates' courts for 1937.

Despite the failure of New Deal forces to defeat Senator Guy M. Gillette of towa, who was the first to seek renomination among the nine Democratic Senators who opposed the Roosevelt bill to enlarge the Supreme Court, President Roosevelt today defended the support given the New Deal candidate, Representative - Otha D. Wearin, by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator.

Miss Margaret Leach, daughter of Mrs. Charles Leach of this city, will be married to Travis Edward Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Travis Eugene Harris of West New Brighton, S. I., on June 25 in the Noroton (Conn.) Presbyterian Church.
Professor Hugo Hergesell, for many years president of the German Aeronautical Society and later president of the International Commission of Atmospherio Research, died Sunday at the age of 79.

The New England Power Association Will redeem on Aug. 9, at 102, Utilities Associates 5 per cent debentures due on April 1, 1949, Frank D. Comerford, chairman of the board of New England Power, announced yesterday.

A three-alarm fire, the cause of which was not learned, damaged the roof and considerable equipment today at the R. C. A. Television Building, which houses an experimental laboratory and storerooms at River Road and Seventeenth Street, here.

As a result of the Waterbury Grand Jury investigations and report, bench warrants were issued for five legislators, charging them with legislative bribery under an old law which carries a maximum penalty of ten years in prison and $2,000 fine.

Despite what is regarded as a lack of enthusiasm by the United States for the British suggestion for an international commission to investigate the bombing of Spanish open towns, the government is still hopeful that the project will be realized.

New York University will celebrate its 106th commencement on Ohio Field of the University Heights campus at 10:30 o'clock this morning with the conferring of 4,100 degrees in course, seventythree certificates, seven alumni awards and eight honorary degrees.

Degrees were presented to forty-four members of the graduating class of Lincoln University today. The Rev. Dr. John S. Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbeterian Church, New York, warned them that they must face the challenge of Industrial despair, economic inequality and international conflict.

The Metropolitan Insurance Company was ordered by the New York State Labor Relations Board yesterday to bargain collectively with the Industrial Insurance Agents Union, Local 30, C. 1. 0. affiliate, which was selected recently by the company's agents to represent them in negotiations.

The sixth season of the Stage Relief Fund closed Sunday night, having grossed $36,624, or an average of $1,831 for each of the twenty special performances during the season, it was announced yesterday.

Despite the continuing heavy downpour in the Kaifeng and Chengehow areas, coupled with a Yellow River flood around Lanfeng, twenty-five miles east of Kaifeng, the Japanese Army is keeping up its rapid advances toward Chengchow,

The Apparel Credit Women's Guild; composed of office managerss in the dress industry, was oroganized last night at a meeting in the Hotel McAlpin. - The group's program calls for exchange of information on credit, taxes, welfare work, employment, advertising, publicity and hospitalization. Officers elected included Lillian Adler of Burgundy Frocks, Inc.,

American business has prospered in China and has "gone on" despite war outbreaks, Dr. Julian Arnold, United States Commercial Attache at Shanghai, told the National Association of Credit Men at its annual congress here today.
Frank E. Taplin, coal and rail financier, died today of a cerebral hemorrhage, with which he was stricken ten days ago while at work. He was 62 years old.

Edwin C. Wilson, Counselor of the United States Embassy in Paris, and Mrs. Wilson, who are to arrive tomorrow on the Manhattan, will be at the Plaza. Mr. and Mrs. B. Sherman Fowler of 28 East Seventieth Street will sail today on the Queen Mary to pass the Summer in Europe.

Under a lowhanging canopy of storm clouds that obscured the picturesque back drop of the Rocky Mountains and drenched the treacherous terrain of Cherry Hills, the line-up for the forty-second national open golf championship underwent a shakeup today.

Playing for the first time this year following a Winter of polo in the Philippines, young Earle A. S. Hopping was knocked out by a fall in the third period of a pracce match at Phipps Field .in Old Westbury late today and may be out of action for some time as a result.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court is to be asked today by the city and some of the larger savings banks to determine whether the Murray prior lien law, enacted at the 1937 session of the Legislature, is constitutional. The law was adopted to obviate a shortage in low-cost housing by permiting the city to improve old-law tenements in certain instances.

Twenty-four nurses will be graduated at the sixty-first commencement of the New York Hospital School of Nursing to be held at 4 P. M. today in the auditorium of the nurses' residence at York Avenue and Seventieth Street.

The annual Prize Day at Pomfret School will be held Friday, with a service in the Clark Memorial Chapel at 10:30 A. M. The general exercises and awarding of scholarship prizes and diplomas will follow in the Hard Auditorium.

Prest dent Roosevelt will have at his immediate disposal nearly $1,500.000,000 as soon as the Relief-Recovery Bill becomes law, if the Senate version survives the deliberations of the conference committee.

The six-story apartment house on a plot 100 by 131.6 feet and containing thirty apartments and 139 rooms at 726 Ocean Avenue, corner of Beverly Road, Brooklyn, was sold by Charles Walzer, operator, to Schaefer Kahonowitz, Inc.
