Officials of the Works Progress Administration have called upon their representatives in New Jersey for infornation as to the basis, if any, for reports that WPA workers in Hoboken were ordered by their foremen to participate in Mayor Hague's "Americanism parade" in Jersey City last night.

Robert E. Gross and Cyril Chappellet, president and secretary, respectively, of the Lockheed-Aircraft Corporation, were elected-today directors of the Menascoo Manufacturing Company. They will fill vacancies caused by the resignation of W. R. Atwood and William Keith Scott.

An investing client of Julius H. Zieser, attorney, purchased the three-story apartment house on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 36 Van Wart Avenue, White Plains, Westchester County. Sale was for cash above a $61,750 first mortgage at 5 per cent. The property contains sixteen apartments and four garages and has a reported annual rent roll of $10,500. David S. Meister was the broker.

Middlesex and Leicestershire moved ahead of Lancashire in the English County cricket championship today. A 10-wicket victory over Sussex put Middlesex at the top, while Leicestershire, undefeated in three starts, holds a slight advantage over the Lancastrians, who lost to Yorkshire by eight wickets.

William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange, Commission, today urged holders of com mon stock of utility companies in voluntary reorganizations, where circumstances appeared to dictate such a course as equitable, to content themselves with less than they might have been able to obtain in w the days when reorganizations were effected "without check or restraint"

Henry J. Cochran, who for twenty years has been an executive of the Bankers Trust Company, will soon become president of the Franklin Savings Bank, it was announced yesterday by the trustees of the savings bank. He will succeed James R. Trowbridge, who has tendered his resignation as president of Franklin Savings, effective on Aug. 1.
The General Synod of the Reformed Church of America turned down today a proposal looking toward organic union of the Reformed and Evangelical Churches. of America.
Vincent Dell'Orto, 129, Italy, received the verdict over Paul Lee, 126, Indianapolis, in the featured eight-round contest at the New York Coliseum last night before a crowd of 6,500.

Rumors that the government would fix the loan price on wheat at a considerably higher basis than expected turned a weak wheat market into a decidedly strong one today. Although the reports In regard to the loan figures were not confirmed, they were circulated widely and had much effect in stimulating buying.

With the Health Department determined to enlist the city's voluntary social and health agencies in the drive against venereal diseases, with the Welfare Council standing behind the Health Department and Mayor La Guardia in turn commending the Welfare Council, a good start has been made in realizing locally Surgeon General Parran's encouraging admonition:

The Right Rev. J. Blair Larned, Suffragan Bishop of the Long Island diocese, gave the commencement address at the exercises of the Cathedral School of St. Mary, held this afternoon in the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation here. The sixteen graduates were:

Ely Culbertson, contract bridge expert, testified before Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo in Supreme Court yesterday that he had lost $56,000 in Crockford's, Inc., at 14 East Sixty-second Street, a bridge club he founded with Mr. Giovannia Farrelly of 1,158 Fifth Avenue.

After a week of water tests the new Boeing Capper took off on its first flight early this evening. After circling Puget Sound and Seattle, test pilot Edmond T. Alien steered the flying boat to Lake Washingtoh and alighted there.

Announcement was made here yesterday of the death on Sunday in Rome of Mrs. Grace Saunders Miller of 53 East Seventieth Street, widow of Andrew J. Miller, a partner in- the banking house of Hallgarten Co., who died last Fall on the Conte di Savoia en route to Italy. Mrs. Miller,

Ralph H. Robb, Boston attorney, surrendered here yesterday in the office of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey. He pleaded not guilty to grand larceny charges, as one of six persons indicted last week in connection with the alleged looting of the Continental Securities Corporation and other investment trusts.

Paramount is to expand its British activities and coordinate them wirth the studio's Hollywood schedule. David E. Rose, who resigned a week ago as vice president of Samuel Goldwyn Corporation was named production chief today for Paramount's London operations.

The auction sale of the modern library of Robert Dunning Dripps of Germantown, Pa., brought $1,282 at the morning session yesterday and $913 in 'the afternoon, at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh -Street.

A drought "worse than any in 100 years," combined with unseasonable frosts, insect pests and plant and domestic animal diseases, has created a "very alarming" agricultural situation in Europe, Howard D. Salins of Chicago, managing director of the Flax and Fibre Institute of America, said yesterday. He returned Monday from a twomonth trip abroad during which he made an agricultural survey for the institute.

Frank Buonofiglio, alias Bucky O'Neill, 40 years old, of Mt. Vernon, and James Raimo, 35, of White Plains were acquitted this afternoon of the charge of fatally shooting Robert Lawrence Volpi, alias Big Bob Mason, in a road house in North White Plains seven years ago. The case was heard by a jury before Acting County Judge James W. Bailey.

More than $14,000,000 of gold reached here yesterday from foreign ports. Of this amount, $6,346,000, consisting of $5,355,000 from England and $991,000 from India, was consigned to local commercial banks and, represented arbitrage transactions.

Several parties have been planned for Miss Jean Chatfield Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Clinton Clark of this city and Binghamton, N. Y., and Ewing Butler Hawkins, whose marriage will take place on Saturday in St. Bartholomew's Church.

Honorary scrolls for "distinguished public service" were presented yesterday afternoon to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Park Commissioner Robert Moses at the class day exercises of the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science and College of Engineering in the Gould Memorial Library Chapel on the University Height's campus.

Premier Hepburn said today the Ontario Government would ask the Dominion Government to refuse approval of plans for a new Falls View bridge to replace the Niagara Falls span swept away last January by ice.

Dwight School for Girls in Englewood will hold its forty-ninth commencement exercises at the school here at 11 o'clock tomorrow morning. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers, pastor of Brown Memorial Church in Baltimore, will give the address. A class of twenty-four young women will be graduated.
The Mandates Commission of the League of Nations will meet tomorrow with Palestine among the territories to be examined.

With the exception of the Giants, who always have looked upon the plan with disfavor, all of the National League clubs have agreed to play a night baseball game at Ebbets Field this season, it was announced yesterday by Brooklyn officials. The Giants, too, were invited to play under the lights, but refused.

Members of the joint PrincetonCornell track squad which will compete against a combined OxfordCambridge outfit in London on July 23 were announced tonight by R. Kenneth Fairman, acting graduate manager of athletics at Princeton and Henry S. Godshall, assistant director of athletics at Cornell.

Millinery sales in March and April showed an average increase of 3 per cent over the same months last year, according to the results of a survey of the books of a number of representative manufacturers, issued yesterday by the Millinery Stabilization Commission.
Frew Hall, travel agent, died yes terday in his home at 101 East Seventy-fourth Street, after a long illness. He was 48 years old.

" To meet today's challenge to women, one must make up her own philosophy of life, have a sense of humor and be mentally alert and fit physically, mentally and spiritually," said Dr. Lillian Gilbreth, consulting engineer, of Montclair, N. J., in an address to -the graduating class of Keuka College today.
All over Eire today political parties nominated candidates for the general election ten days hence. No fewer than 214 were nominate i for 134 seats.
Stocks closed irregular after early firmness in listless trading; turnover, 371,980 shares. United States Government bonds irregularly lower, other groups steady and mixed; transactions $4,788,300.

Miss Audrey Anderton gave a luncheon yesterday in the Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton. Her guests included Mrs. Henry O. Havemeyer Jr., the Misses Anton Dunn, Evelyn Bruen, Marian Gray, Leslie Larned, Dorothy McGee and Marian Kingsland.

Bert Presser, garage operator of 513 West 130th Street, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Grover Moscowitz to serve a year and a day in jail after his conviction on a charge of filing false claims with the government for payment of wages to truck and stationwagon drivers under a WPA contract.

One more death was added yesterday to the toll of strikers. In this case the police fired into a crowd that attacked them in the parish of Trelawny. This brought the number of deaths since the strikes began early in May to twelve.

The New York Maritime Council, as spokesman of the C. I. 0. maritime unions, asked representatives of ship lines and Federal bodies yesterday to confer with its representatives .in an effort to prevent an outbreak of labor troubles in shipping.
Commencement of New York University, University Heights, 10:30 A. M. Luncheon, Kiwanis Club of New York City, Hotel McAlpin, 12:30 P. M. Address by Godfrey M. Lebhar.
George D. Woods of Philadelphia was elected president of the National Office Management Association today at its nineteenth annual conference here. The conference ends tomorrow. H. L. Wylie

After widespread protest had developed over a proposed amendment to the Administrative Code barring the distribution of commercial and advertising handbills, the City Council voted yesterday to refer the amendment to its finance committee with the proviso that a public hearing be held before further action is taken.

The world champion Yankees, with Charley (Red) Ruffing on the firing line, faced the seventh-place White Sox, a team which had lost eleven out of its last twelve starts, yesterday at the Stadium before 6,576 fans.
Meeting opposition not quite so pail hard to handle as that in his last ter outing, B. F. Whitaker's Masker ran another good race yesterday to take the featured Gotham Class C Handicap at Anueduct.
Twelve-year-old Bobby Collier is alive and well today and can thank Betsy, Chesapeake Bay dog whose mastery of water and absolute obedience to her master's orders saved him from drowning.

30th St, 445-51 W, 100 ft front; also 442-54 W 31st St, 133.4 ft front; Joseph Greenberg to Emigrant Bank; mtg $493,000 held by bank. 39th St, 421 W, 25x98.9; Alois L. Ernst to trustees' will of Bernhard Lichtenstein, 444 E 91st St, care Julius B. Lane, deed dated Oct 22, 1926.

Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches, five-time champion, not only won her opening match in the women's metropolitan golf championship at the Century Country Club today, but she also captured the medal for which she and Mrs. Harry McNaughton tied in yesterday's qualifying round.

Decision was reached yesterday to work out a proposed agreement for the reduction of unjustified returns to producers in the popular price dress field at a meeting of the vendors' relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and representatives of the dress returns control bureau of the popular price dress manufacturers' group.

Captain Gordon W. Haines, U. S. N., one of the officers who had a prominent part in the laying of the North Sea mine fields during the World War, died in Savannah, Ga., this morning, according to word received by the Navy Department.
In a blaze of color the annual national convention of the Shrine,opened today with a great parade in buntingbedecked Memorial Coliseum.

Cayetano Coll y Cuchi, who acted as legal adviser to Puerto Rican stevedores during the recent waterfront strike and the settlement negotiations, today announced his retirement. He- asserted that labor, although it had gained a sweeping victory over the steamship companies, was not proceeding in an orderly manner.
Five French aviation experts will sail tomorrow on the Normandie to enlist American help to bring France's military airplane industry on a level with that of Germany and Italy.

The Evander Childs High School squad accounted for seventeen places to show the way as qualifying trials in nine events for the city senior high P. S. A. L. track and field champions-ips were held at the General George W. Wingate thletic Field in Brooklyn yesterday.

Twelve jurors who are to pass on the case of Thomas J. Bohan, 39 years old, brought back from Chile eighteen months ago to answer an old murder indictment, were selected from a blue-ribbon panel yesterday in General Sessions, so expeditiously as to draw comment from the bench.

The long awaited publication of the details of the government's proposals for a new minorities statute seems to be drawing near. Today the council of experts appointed by the government to prepare a new language law began discussing the final draft. which will be laid before political representatives next week.

Too much can easily be read into the renomination of Senator Gillette in the Iowa Democratic primaries. For instance, some conclusions firmly stated here today by various persons include-that the Republicans will surely carry Iowa in November;
Charles P. Root, who participated in the early development of the automobile industry and was one of the organizers of the Chicago Motor Club, died yesterday.

Mrs. Rose Gisnet of Brooklyn was elected president of the Women's American ORT at a meeting yesderday in the Empire State Building. Other officers elected were Mrs. Jean Rubinstein, Mrs. Pauline R. Smith, Mrs. William Lowenstein, Dr. Sarah R. Kelman, Mrs. Henry Mindlin,

The business morals of America were pictured "at a low ebb" and business itself was held largely to blame for the present economic recession in speeches today before the convention of the American Retail Coal Association.

Unless industry will "voluntarily" solve the problem of the wideswinging economic cycle, governmeent "will be compelled to exercise its helpful and reasonable influence," Governor Frank. Murphy of Michigan said yesterday afternoon at commencement exercises for three schools of St. John's University, Brooklyn, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

John Torrio, former henchman of Al Capone who is serving a sentence in Alcatraz for violation of the income tax law, has offered the government $10,000 to "compromise his criminal liability" for alleged failure to pay the government $73,000 owed as taxes for the years 1933, 1934 and 1935, the United States Attorney's office revealed yesterday.

Though psychologists and psychiatrists still argue about the validity of psychoanalytic theory and practice, not one among them but will rejoice that Sigmund Freud has found a haven in England. His case is especially hard.
W. J. Howey, who had helped develop Florida citrus industries and was a former Republican candidate for Governor, died today at a sanitarium in Umatilla, Fla. He was 62 years old.

Two separate proposals to overcome the depressing effect of the present system of government buying of cotton textiles on the cloth markets were being discussed in Worth Street yesterday and will be officially presented in Washington in the near future, it was reported.

Seven officers and delegates of Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Stablemen and Helpers of America, who were indicted last week on charges of engaging in racketeering activities in the trucking industry, pleaded not guilty yesterday before Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell and were held in bail totaling $55.000.
Today is the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Harlem Savings Bank, one of the largest mutual institutions in the city and the only savings bank to be established here in the Civil War years.

The six-story apartment and stores structure at 602-610 West 141st Street, near Broadway, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms to the Greenwich Savings Bank, as plaintiff, for $200,000.
THE BLACK ARROWS, by Francis Beeding. (Harper, $2.) A novel of adventure. COCKNEY PAST AND PRESENT, by William Matthews. (Dutton, $2.65.) A short history of the dialect of London.

Louis Weinstock, secretary-treasurer of the Brotherhood of Painters, District Council 9, has been eliminated as a candidate to succeed himself, it was learned yesterday. The post of secretargy-treasurer carries with it the leadership of the 12,000 painters in Manhattan and the Bronx.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today set a hearing for June 25 on an application by the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation to consider the payment on Aug. 15 by that corporation of $1,627,175 of dividends on its cumulative 6 per cent preferred stock, Series A; cumulative stock 5 per cent series and 5 per cent cumulative preference stock. The company, it is understood, seeks permission to pay these quarerly dividennds out of current earnings.

Massachusetts today notified State job holders that they have the right to organize and bargain collectively, provided any organization they form or join accepts as a principle that State employes shall not in any manner participate in a strike.

A total expenditure of $641,800 is contemplated in the construction of 174 small homes in Queens for which plans were filed yesterday. One group of seventy-seven is projected for South Elmhurst, at a cost of $346,500, and another of fifty for Laurelton. costing $140,000.

Two properties in Putnam County, N. Y., were involved in deals reported yesterday by Herbert J. Gebing, Carmel broker. One was the Harold Casey farm on Holmes Road, Ludingtonville,' which was purchased for occupancy by John F. Reilly of New York.

Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., had consolidated net earnings of $5,663,221 for the fiscal year ended on March 31 after interest, provision for depreciation and Federal taxes, including $34,220 excess-profits tax and $463,957 surtax on undistributed income, according to the pamphlet report to be made public today by O. H. Chalkley, president.

Asserting that no pressing need had been shown for the immediate conversion of Eighth and Ninth Avenues into one-way streets, the Appellate Division granted yesterday to the Eighth Avenue Coach Corporation a temporary injunction restraining the city from making the change effective pending trial of the company's action for a permanent injunction.
Plans to evaluate the New York City junior high school program to determine whether the traditional eight-year elementary school shall be officially displaced by the newer six-year school have been

Sales of copper abroad were made yesterday at from 8.65 to 8.83 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports. This compares- with about 8.65 cents when trading stopped on last Friday afternoon for the' Whitsuntide holidays.

What's happening in Canton is a nightmare realized. This is what the shuddering imagination reels from when it pictures a great city bombarded from the air. For twelve days, without respite, Japanese planes have dumped death and destruction into swarming streets and crowded tenements.

An appeal to the colleges and unmversities of this country to give free tuition and scholarships to student refugees who, because of their "belief in democracy," have been driven out of fascist universities was made yesterday by fifty-seven college professors.

Norman Thomas, who was pelted with eggs and tomatoes and prevented from delivering a speech in Military Park, Newark, by organized groups last Saturday, will appear before the Newark City Commission today to make a formal protest and urge an investigation of the actions of the police in failing to give him adequate protection.
In contrast to the 1939 World's Fair here, San Francisco's Pageant of the Pacific next year will isolate exhibits relating to 'the work of women to emphasize their progress and' achievements,

The 100th commencement of Pennington School was held here today for a graduating class of fifty-one. Dr. J. Edgar Park, president of Wheaton College, was the speaker. Dr. Francis H. Green, headmaster, presented the following prizes and awards:

WPA art projects in painting were praised for "bringing mural painting into its own, heritage in this country" and for freeing art from the "anemic patronage of the museums" and giving it the "living patronage which sustained it in the Middle Ages" at a dinner meeting

Hundreds of home-going workers scrambled for safety at 5:30 P. M. yesterday at Second Avenue and Fourteenth Street. when a bus out of control mounted the curb, struck a newsstand and carried it with the girl attendant inside and two customers for fifteen feet before it crashed against an electric light pole.

With buying at the Boston Shoe Fair swinging into full stride today, it became apparent that Boston has- become an expanded market in volume shoes bought by large mail-order, chain and department store groups. Principal buying today was on "fast

Former United States Senator Joseph S. Frelinghuysen is considering running for the Republican nominication for United States Senator in the September primary against former United States Senator Warren Barbour, it was learned here today.

An invention was announced today as likely to revolutionize cigarette manufacturing. A Hungarian, Stephen Tamas, has developed a process for dispensing with cigarette paper, using instead a wrapper made from' -the tobacco plant.

Two fellowships of $500 each, for the graduate course in personnel administration at Radcliffe College, have just been awarded to Miss Rebecca Connolly of Pittsburgh and Miss Elinor M. Wilson of Urbana, Ill.

The committee to award-the playwrighting fellowships of the Rockefeller Foundation was announced yesterday. The three members chosen by the Dramatists Guild were Kenyon Nicholson and Katharine Dayton, as representatives of the Guild's ranks; and John Golden, as a manager to represent the theatre as a whole.

The campaign of the New Deal "elimination committee" to purge the Democratic party of less-than-100-per-cent followers of President Roosevelt, notably those who opposed his courtenlargement- program, was bogged down today in the black lands of Iowa.

The Emigrant Bank sold to Birch Realty Corp, Paul A. McGolrick, president, the house at 528 E 13th St, 25x103.3, for about S15,500, taking back two mortgages, due on demand, a p. m. for $15,380, a building loan $16,200.

After a stubbornly contested competition in which the two leading contenders were forced to negotiate forty obstacles, Lieutenant T. S. Riggs of the United States Military Academy was awarded the individual military championship of the twentieth annual West Point horse show today. The exhibition opened this morning and will continue through tomorrow afternoon.

Headed by Blue team led by Bil Mrs. Agnes Lamme, formerly the ranking player of the Eastern Association, a field of fifty-two started out in the invitation tennis tournament of the Manursing Island Club this morning. When Lester Cummings had marked up the last score late in the afternoon, there were only twelve left in the running, four of them holding brackets in the quarter finals.
Daniel D. Curran, New Orleans banker and former president of three railroads, died here last night after an illness of several weeks. He was 83 years old.

A New York report that paintings by Rembrandt are being removed from German galleries because of the Dutch master's predilection for Jewish types and scenes has provoked considerable merriment in official museum quarters here.

Acceptance by the Congressional Conference Committee of a compromise on the Wages and Hours Bill offered by Southern Senators appeared probable tonight' after a canvas by House conferees had found general sentiment in its b favor.

By a vote of 16 to 6, the City Council adopted yesterday a report of its housing committee containing strong criticism of Mayor La Guardia's housing policies, after lengthy debate in which Newbold Morris, President of the Council, was threatened with removal from office.

Joseph Caronia, blind student in the College of Arts and Sciences of St. John's University, Brooklyn, was graduated cun laude with the degree of Bachelor of Science in the Academy of Music yesterday afternoon.

President Roosevelt said today that in selecting candidates to fill the twenty-four judgeships created recently he would adhere as far as possible to his rule against appointing men over 60 years of age. He said he had violated the rule only twice and that in each instance the appointee had agreed to retire at the age of 70.

Earnings of the Stardard Oil Company of New Jersey in the first four months of this year were about 21 or 22 per cent below those for the corresponding period in 4937, W. S. Farish, president and chief executive officer, told stockholders today at their annual meeting here. From the viewpoint of the earnings, Mr. Farish said, April was worse than March and February.

Dr. Earl E. Cummins, Professor of Economics at Union College and unsuccessful candidate for Congress on the Democratic and American Labor tickets in 1936, died here today after a long illness. His age was 41.
Congress has been working so long that the Government Printing Office is running short on cash for printing the Congressional Record, the daily report of activity on Senate and House floors.

Three officials of the District of Columbia started a four-day inspection yesterday of the highways in metropolitan New York to get pointers to aid in solving traffic problems in the nation's capital.

Dr. Edwin Herbert Lewis, who was a member of the first faculty of the- University of Chicago and, from 1913 to 1935, dean of the faculty of Lewis Institute, died yesterday in Palo Alto, Calif., friends here were informed today.

Registration of visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday was well above the preceding week. However, the total was considerably less than in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listing in THE TIMES. The arrivals numbered 587, as against 309 in the previous week and 762 in the same period last year.

The Bolivian Government has decided to establish its own customs facilities at Arica, Chile, which will be served by Bolivians, it was announced this afternoon in conjunction with a report that a branch of the Bolivian Central Bank would also be established there to look after credit and monetary problems.

A joint conference composed of senior members of major Congressional committees and leaders of industry, lator and finance should be held in Washington through this Summer to devise a program for the economic welfare of the country, Mayor La Guardia told 1,000

" Newspapers put on the world's greatest show," Zenn Kaufman, sales consultant, yesterday told the weekly luncheon of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt. Discussing "Showmanship in Business,"

Canada, which nearly went to war with the United States in 1830 over the question of where the boundaries of Maine began and those of Canada ended, was asked in Parliament today to annex five square miles of Maine territory, but by the peaceful processes of diplomatic negotiation.

C. Albert Jacob Jr., vice president of the Mathushek Piano Company, was elected president of the National Piano Manufacturers Association yesterday at the organization's annual meeting at the Hotel New Yorker. Mr. Jacob succeeds L. P. Bull, vice president of Story Clark Company, Chicago.

Albert Israel, through Byrne Bowman, Inc., in 1,111 Park Ave: Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc, broker. Edward F. Darell Jr, in 116 E 63d St; Samuel A. Herzog, broker. John Stafford, in 51 E 97th St; Walter Samuels, Inc, broker.

TRANSFERS IN THE BRONX Homer Ave (14-3610), s s, 200 ft w of Castle Hill Ave, 37x100; Stateboro Holding Corp to Rosie Sherman, 1,163 Hoe Ave. 183d St, 669 E (11-3088): Lucy Riccio to John H. Gambardelll, 633 E 186th. Bailey Ave (12-3264), w s, 182 ft s of 230th St, 208x194; Thema Rosen to Philip Rosen, 2,834 Heath Ave; mtg $25,000.

Gifts of $10,000 from the Davison Fund, Inc., and of $2,000 from the Cleveland H. Dodge Foundation, Inc., have increased the local contributions to the China Civilian Relief Fund being sent through the American Red Cross to $52,842, it was announced yesterday.

While Germany continues to focus the attention of the world on the alleged terrorization of the Sudeten Germans and other nationalities in Czechoslovakia, the League of Poles in Germany has submitted to the German Government over the weekend a lengthy memorandum charging that the Polish minority in Germany is also subjected to all sorts of economic, cultural and religious oppression and discrimination, and in some cases to boycott and physical violence.

The segregation of the sanctions obligations of the League of Nations covenant into an optional clause was suggested last night by Clark M. Eichelberger, director of the League of Nations Association, in a discussion of the reorganization of the League broadcast over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Twenty Brooklyn College co-eds received major "B's" from Dr. Adele Bildersee, dean of women, yesterday at the semi-annual dinner of the Women's Athletic Association. Most of the awards went to the basketball team, which received eleven major letters. The swimming team came next with five and the fencing squad won four.

The Ocean City Coast Guard announced tonight that it would continue tomorrow its search for the body of Warren Smith,67 years old, former superintendent of the Ocean City, Water Company, who apparently was drowned last night when the rowboat from which he was fishing in Great Egg Harbor Bay was overturned in the choppy water.

That the police have no power to limit the number of pickets on a picket line was the ruling made yesterday by Magistrate Charles Solomon in Bridge Plaza court, Brooklyn, contradicting a ruling by Magistrate James E. Finegan in the same court last Thursday.

The noon session of the Constitutional Convention today provided more fireworks than all of the previous sessions combined, and the outburst was regarded as a forerunner of continual debate at future sessions.

About eighty-five members of the Honourable Artillery Company of London arrived at the Grand Central Station last night from Boston for a sight-seeing tour before embarking for their London homes Saturday.

Edwin R. Dibrell has been appointed chairman of the administrative and promotion committee of Apparel and Accessories Associates, Inc., which is-organizing plans for participation of the apparel and fashion industries in the New York World's Fair. This was announced yesterday-by Joseph Love,

Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, awarded degrees today to 581 members of the graduating class, and then appealed to these new alumni not to allow their careers as students to finish with the presentation of their diplomas.
J. W. Haskett, reserve army pilot, and his radioman glided to earth as quickly as possible after finding a two-foot snake on their plane.

Carl H.. Pforzheimer of Purchase, New York investment broker and former chairman of the Westchester County Commission on Government, is being considered by Democratic leaders as a nominee for President of the county, it was learned here today.
House and Senate conferees on the Postmaster Appointments Bill today reached an agreement which provides a long step forward in applying the merit system.

Communist appeals for the cooperation of the Roman Catholics of the United States to make common cause were denounced here tonight by Dr. Edmund A. Walsh, S. J., vice president of Georgetown University and regent of the School of Foreign Service.

In four days 444 newspapers have sent requests to the American Association of Advertising Agencies for the material prepared by the group to explain the service which advertising renders to both business and-the consumer. The individual advertisements, the first of which will appear in newspapers, beginning on June 16,

Mrs. Kate Read Blacque, who died in Paris, France, on April 3, 1937, left an estate of $1,758,061 gross and $1,657,640 net. The principal assets were securities. Helen R. Parker, a niece of Short Hills, N. J., and Charles V. Blacque of Cannes, France, a nephew, each receive one-third of the residue.

Francis Biddle, chairman of the Labor Board which preceded the National Labor Relations Board, probably will be named counsel for the joint committee to investigate the Tennessee Valley Authority, it was indicated tonight after the committee had devoted most of the day to a study of possible appointees to that post.

Three officials of the bankrupt B. E. Buckman Company, an investment house in Madison, Wis., were sentenced today to prison for selling unregistered securities in violation of the State blue sky law. They had entered formal pleas of no defense.

The newspaper Universo prints an official statement today that Peruvian troops continue to occupy Ecuadorean border farmlands invaded on June 1, and that an officer and two soldiers arrested in the first clash are not yet released.

The remarks of the Rev. Dr. Charles Trexler concerning the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank at the final service in St. James Lutheran Church, Seventy-third Street and Madison Avenue, on Sunday, do not express the views of the trustees of 'the church, according to a statement yesterday by Robert Louis Hoguet, president of the bank, which is taking over the church to satisfy interest arrears a first mortgage.

" American Literature Past and Present, a Book of Facts," is the title of a volume in preparation under the editorial supervision of several authorities on American literature. It will be published by Scribner.

Japan in- Widow," a st tends to carry out air raids on such cities as Canton and Hankow "with even Greater vigor," Rear Admiral Noakuni Nomura, chief of the special service section of the Japanese Navy,. declared today.

New regulations for marriage licenses which require that after July 1 both persons submit statements that they have been exaimined and are found free of syphilis-in a communicable stage were announced today by Dr.

Thirty-nine seniors at Wagner Lutheran Memorial College on Staten Island were graduated yesterday at the annual commencement exercises in the college auditorium on Grymes Hill. More than 500 persons, ineluding friends and relatives of the graduates, witnessed the ceremonies.

At a time when many sound arguments are being advanced to show that a buyer gets a better house today than in previous comparable years for the same amount of money, the study on costs of stand-ard frame and brick dwellings just completed by the Building Construction Employers Association of Chicago is of considerable interest, particularly in view of the fact that conditions in the construction industry here and in Chicago are much the same.

British and French trustees of 1933-34 loans to Austria entered a strong protest in Berlin today against nonpayment 'of monthly interest installments due June 1. Britain, France, Italy and other European countries are guarantors of the capital and interest of the loans, but it is understood Italy did not sign today's protest.

The graduation exercises of the ?hoir school of St. Thomas Protesant Episcopal Church will be held tomorrow evening in the new gymLasium and classroom building, whichh has recently been added to he school, largely through the phil?nthropy of Charles Steele, senior varden of the church at Fiftyhird Street and Fifth Avenue, and partner in J. P. Morgan Co.

Frederick Landseer Maur Griggs, whose etchings and drawings of architecture are represented in the Boston Museum and at Harvard University, died today at Chipping Campden, at the age of 62. Preservation of Chipping Campden, one of the most beautiful old towns in the Cotswold hills, was largely due to his. efforts.

Appointment of Henry Markwalter as operating agent of the Munson Line ships that have been seized or will be seized by the Federal Government as protection of loans of about $2,000,000 was announced yesterday.

The State Departiment of Education dismissed today the appeal of Miss Jeanette Fund from the action of the New York City Board of Education in refusing to recommend her for a license as a teacher of music in day high schools.

The Bill of Rights Committee of the Constitutional Convention rejected a proposal to remove the anti-gambling provision from the Constitution, and by the same vote, 8 to 7, refused to report a "search and seizure clause" designed to outlaw the use of evidence obtained by wire-tapping.

Roundtable discussions between the Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange over the program for reorganizing the Exchange may be resumed in New York on either Thursday or Friday. No definite time has been set, but William O. Douglas,

A number of full-floor rentals featured the reports of commercial leasing submitted yesterday by brokers. In the building at 127 Madison Avenue, Franks-Horton Draperies, Inc., took the entire seventh floor, and the Colonial Wall Paper Company, Inc., leased the second floor in 12-14 West Forty-sixth Street,
The Rev. Dr. Vincent G., Burns of 1,104 Buckingham Road, Palisades, N. J., filed suit yesterday in Supreme Court against his brother, Robert E. Burns, author of "I Am a Fugitive From a Chain Gang."

A committee of members of the New York Curb Exchange will commence on Monday studies of the advisability of permitting non-member brokers and dealers to participate in commission business done on its floor. In announcing the membership of the committee of eight men, Fred C. Moffatt,

The Federal grand jury investigating the international German spy organization continued yesterday to question Christian Danielson of Bath, Me., one-armed designer who has been employed on United States Navy destroyers, and four enlisted men of the army.

President Roosevelt asked the Senate today to include in the second Deficiency Bill, now pending in the House, an additional $50,000 deficiency item which would be used by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to meet expected costs of running down the Florida kidnappers of the Cash boy.

The voters here, who have been - stoically attempting to elect two. trustees to the local school board for the last month, went. to the polls today for the fourth time and almost laid the jinx: they put one candidate into office, but at least one other election will be necessary to fill the second vacancy.

Prospects for friendly cooperation between the electric utility industry and the Federal Government are growing brighter, some 2,000 members of the Edison Electric Institute were told here today by their president, C. W. Kellogg, head of the Engineers Public Service Company of New York.

Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross Society, will sail today for England on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, accompanied by Mrs. Davis. Miss Virginia Gildersleeve, dean of Barnard College; Mrs. Alfred M.

A group of prominent architects, home developers and town planners from all parts-of the country will meet at the World's Fair site today to make the awards in a contest for designs for a completely gas-equipped "Liberty Home."

Bids for reconditioning the Panama Pacific liners Virginia, California and Pennsylvania, which will form the nucleus of a new New York-South American fast passenger service, were opened by the Maritime Commission today.

Edwin Joseph Wattson, who gave New York City as his address, walked into a police station this morning, confessed that he had stowed away on the liner Queen of Bermuda in New York Saturday, and asked for a meal.

A photo decision was required to give Colonel E. R. Bradley's Bootless his third straight victory- over the Suffolk Downs oval in the North Shore Purse. featured mile and seventy-yard allowance race, today before a crowd of 12,000. At the end of the journey the 5-year-old son of Black Toney had a nose in front of Mrs. Emil Denemark's Genie Palatine and returned $3.60 for $2 in the mutuels.

WhenThomas K. Gilmore, 41 years old, a World War veteran, arrived -at Sing Sing this afternoon to be sent to the electric chair the week of July 17 for killing Milon Warner, a merchant, in a robbery in Middletown, N. Y., he refused to give the name of his close relatives.

Twenty diplomas were presented to graduates of Kimberley School here at the thirtieth annual commencement exercises today in Unity Church. Dr. Robert R. Wicks, dean of University Chapel, Princeton. gave the address.

President Roosevelt signed an executive order extending the life of the National Emergency Council to June 30, 1939; conferred with Postmaster General Farley on the outcome of the Iowa primary election and kept a number of appointments of a personal nature, including an informal visit with Prince Louis. Ferdinand of Germany and his wife, Princess Kyra, formerly Grand Duchess of Russia.

The school children of America must be taught to think "in human terms" if we are to avoid the wave of nationalism now engulfing the world, Dean Christian Gauss of Princeton University declared last night at the twenty-first commencement exercises of the Child

Factory, sales, of passenger cars and trucks for May were estimated yesterday by the Automobile Manufacturers Association at 211,300 units. Domestic sales by retailers for April were placed at 228,608 units, bringing retail car and truck sales for the first four months of the year to 765,178.

Thirtytwo students, all of them New Jersey residents, will receive the degree of Bachelor of Science in Pharmacy from the New Jersey College of Pharmacy at the fortyfifth annual commencement of that branch of Rutgers University in the auditorium of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company here tomorrow night at 8 o'clock.

Sidney Haven Putnam, a retired partner of G. P. Putnam's Sons, book publishers, of which his grandfather, George Palmer Putnam, was the founder, died yesterday in the Post-Graduate Hospital of a stroke of apoplexy which occurred on Saturday. Mr. Putnam.
J. C. Penney Jr., son of the nationally known merchant, died of pneumonia here today after a three-day illness.

Governor Lehman reminded his commencement audience at Syracuse University that democracy, as we have it and hope to have it, in America was not "an abstract political philosophy" but "the fruit of vital and stirring experiences which had burned deeply into the souls of men."

New York sizzled yesterday in the hottest weather thus far this year. The official thermometer recorded a high of 87 degrees for the day at 3:20 P. M., two degrees more than the previous high for the year that was established on April 28.

Carrying out Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick's drive to collect 310 bail forfeitures due to the city, Colonel Charles E. Greenough of the Controller's staff questioned more than twenty property owners yesterday.

Although Liverpool quotations declined when trading was, resumed there after- the protracted Whitsuntide holiday, prices on the Cotton Exchange here held within a narrow range yesterday and ended unchanged to losses of 2 to 4 points. Showers in parts of the three Western States were offset in part by higher temperatures and generally favorable weather elsewhere.

Another important step in the refunding program of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York system was indicated yesterday when the New York Steam Corporation and Consolidated Edison filed with the Public Service Commission

Premier Edouard Daladier returned to Paris by air this evening from his two-day inspection of French aerial defenses along the southern frontier after having personally given orders for such strengthening of these defenses as to make a successful repetition of Sunday's and yesterday's invasions impossible.
The Judiciary Committee of the Constitutional Convention was called upon today by Mayor La Guardia to draft an amendment which would permit a consolidation of courts In New York City.

A strong field of ten chess experts, representing seven countries, is ready for the international masters tournament, scheduled to open here tomorrow evening. Included in the list is Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, who held the world championship until defeated in a return match with Dr. Alexandre Alekhineu of Paris last year.

Richard M. Bennett and Caleb Hornbostel, two young architectural draftsmen in New York offices, have won the commission for the $500,000 art center to be built at Wheaton College, Norton, Mass., in the competition conducted by the Museum of Modern Art and the Architectural Forum.
Banks were the sellers in a number of the deals involving Manhattan properties announced yesterday. Several of the parcels have recently undergone modernizing or will be altered by the new owners.

Debate opened today in the House on the Second Deficiency Bill, calling for appropriations totaling $272,516,979. The Appropriations Committee, before favorably reporting the measure, eliminated $26,370,465.11 for expenditures recommended in the budget.
Newark ark swept the four-game series with the Orioles, taking the final tonight, 18 to 6. It was the eleventh straight victory for the Bears and the twelfth loss in a row for Baltimore.

Rumors were plentiful yesterday that a battery of high-priced lawyears would be enlisted within the next few days to aid in the defense of James J. Hines, the lower West Harlem Tammany leader, on his recent indictment with eight others in the so-called Dutch Schultz policy ring conspiracy.

Miss Mary Loesch, daughter of George Loesch of the Hudson View Gardens Apartments, Pinehurst Avenue and 183d Street, will be married to Morris Andrew McKenna of Lawrence, Mass., on Saturday morning in the Church of St. Elizabeth, 187th Street and Wadsworth Avenue.

The International Labor Conference committee on generalization of the shorter working week began its session today with a trend toward doing this through three or four conventions instead of a single one for all workers or one for each industry.
The leagueleading Indians gained their first victory of the season at Fenway Park today by blasting out two runs in a rally in the ninth to down the Red Sox, 7-5. Lyn Lary's third single of the day,

Oklahoma Gas and Electric Company-Twelve months to April 30: Net income after operating expenses, taxes and charges, $2,576,459, against $2,547,134 in twelve months to April 30, 1937; gross revenues, $13,324,360, against $12,747,494.

In the annual Netherland Bank report, issued today, President L. J. A. Trip said the outlock was much more serious than the government's budget accounts indicated. A more complete summary of the nation's financial liabilities, he declared, would show The Netherlands could not continue her present policies.
Jens Peter Christensen, known throughout the United States as a dog fancier and breeder of Doberman Pineehers, died. here yesterday in Providence Hospital at the age of 58 years.
The government has requested Germany to arrest Arthur Knofelmancher, who formerly served as consul for Costa Rica in Vienna, for selling false passports and Costa Rican naturalization papers.

Bernard W. Lynch, president of the Standard Gas and Electric Com-' pany, announced yesterday that anorder had' been entered by the United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., approving an amendment of the certificate of incorpora.tion of Standard Gas and Electric and also approving a supplemental trust agreement between .the company and the Guaranty Trust Company of New York and the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Companyr of Chicago, as trustees.

The Board of Education was requested yesterday in a resolution adopted by unanimous vote of the City Council to grant four days' pay to substitute teachers after the school term closes on June 24. 'The resolution had the bipartisan sponsorship of Vice Chairman John Cashmore for the Democrats and Acting Majority Leader Andrew B. Armstrong and Councilman Louis Hollander for the coalitionists.

Suppressed feeling between Senator Harrison and the Administration leadership in the Senate flared up momentarily today when he bluntly told Majority Leader Barkley that he did not "like to get knocked around."

The French hard court doubles crown hove into sight for Don Budge and Gene Mako today as the American Davis Cup combination entered the semi-finals with an easy victory over the British combination of F. H. D. Wilde and D. W. Butler.
Dr. Arlo Ayres Brown, president of Drew University, conferred sixtynine degrees and announced awards at the university's seventy-first commencement exercises this morning.

Activity in Treasury securities, with switching operations causing conflicts in price trends, again featured the bond market yesterday. Trading on the New York Stock Exchange was decidedly more active than on the preceding day, transactions in all bond groups amounting to $4,788,300, against $3.262.276.

At a meeting yesterday of the board of directors of the-J. C. Penney Company a dividend of 75 cents a share on the outstanding common stock of the company was declared. This is a reduction of 25 cents compared to the March 31 disbursemept.
Louis H. Gourley, United States Consul General at Tsingtao, reported to the State Department today that he had taken up with the Japanese Consulate General the shooting of Dr. Frederick G. Scovel of
The injunction asked on March 18 by the British and American oil companies against the application of the expropriation law to their properties was denied today.

Twenty-two young women graduates of Eastern colleges have been accepted as apprentices in statistical and research positions by investment, bond and industrial firms, under a plan developed by the Women's Bond Club.

California's touring nine defeated Yale today, 9-3, to ring up its twelfth victory against two losses during its trip. The visitors from the Pacific Coast took advantage of the wildness of Al Stevens, Yale southpaw, to gain a comfortable margin while Bill Priest held the Elis in check.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange authorized yesterday the listing of 400,000 additional common shares of Loft, Inc., which will be added to the list on official notice of issuance, making the total amount authorized to be listed 1,473,259 common shares.

Creditors of the defunct S. W. Straus Co., which concern dealt in mortgage securities, will receive an additional 5 per cent dividend, according to a decision handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood in Brooklyn.

Professor Charles Francis Horne, chairman of the Department of English at City College, announced yesterday the names of three students as winners of awards in the departmental competition. At the same time, a charcoal and crayon drawing of the professor by S.J. Woolf, '99, of THE NEW YORK TIMES was presented to the department by the members of the English staff.

Captain Zbigniew Burzynski, Polish balloonist, arrived here yesterday on the Gdynia America motorliner Batory to obtain scientific instruments to be carried on a stratosphere balloon flight next September.

A score of women armed with garden hose, sticks, stones and even a wash tub, routed a dozen policemen today in a battle over the location of a cemetery fence. They were pulling up fence posts faster than three workmen could set them when police arrived.

Scenes from the stage play "Susan and God," starring Gertrude Lawrence, were clearly televised in the studios of the National Broadcasting Company at Radio City yesterday, despite static-charged clouds.

A luncheon in honor of Brig. Gen. Sir Harold Hartley, vice president of the London, Midland Scottish Railway Company, director of scientific research since 1930 and director of the London Times Publishing Company, was given at the Hotel Commodore yesterday by Dr.

Professor Charles Francis Horne, chairman of the Department of English at City College, announced yesterday the names of three students as winners of awards in the departmental competition. At the same time, a charcoal and crayon drawing of the professor by S.J. Woolf, '99, of THE NEW YORK TIMES was presented to the department by the members of the English staff.

Captain Zbigniew Burzynski, Polish balloonist, arrived here yesterday on the Gdynia America motorliner Batory to obtain scientific instruments to be carried on a stratosphere balloon flight next September.

After 2 hours and 45 minutes of baseball that was a mixture of loose and brilliant play the Dodgers - today finally emerged on the long end of a 7-to-6 count for their fifth victory in seven games in the West,

The cities committee of the Constitutional Convention voted today to eliminate from the effect of any home rule proposal which it may present to the convention the educational system of the State and the actuarially sound pension systems and retirement funds.

Despite Mayor La Guardia's recent offer to match New York's detectives with the best that Scotland Yard could produce, the great Rikers Island copper mystery continued to baffle the gendarmery yesterday as they searched for the rapscallions who made off with two tons of the metal.
The Nassau County Police sent out an alarm today for a missing girl and a missing horse on which she rode away after renting it yesterday from the Grant Park Riding Academy.
It was rumored today that former Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg would soon be removed from Vienna to Germany to stay there in seclusion.

A surprise was recorded in the Long Island Golf Association's one-day amateur tournament at the Oceanside Golf Club today, when Ralph Strafaci of Shoreview posted a score of 38, 36-74 to beat his wellknown brother Frank by one stroke and take the low gross honors.

A movement to organize property owners by blocks or larger areas in a program of rehabilitation of the city's blighted sections was started yesterday at the headquarters of the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement, 90 Park Avenue.
Henrietta Waerner, 15 years old, of 11 Stevenson Road, Hewlett, was killed this evening when she touched an electric wire carrying 440 volts.

Estate, less than $1,000. To- Elizabeth H. Beck, widow, executrix, 603 W. 140th St. BELETSKY, VLADIMIR (May 20). Estate, $500. To Ann Kuzmuk, 117 E. 7th St., residue. Voldemar T. Kruglak, 151 Ave. A. ,executor.

Daily average gross crude .oil production in the United States last week was 3,107,950 barrels, an increase of 9,300, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 225,350 barrels fewer than the calculation of 3,333,300 daily by the Bureau of Mines for June.
Gene Tunney put his royal stamp of approval on Max Schmeling today and scoffed politely at a suggestion that the German might go stale before his battle with champion Joe Louis on June 22.

The New York Stock Exchange has notified its members relating to-the June 2 notice regarding-th call for redemption.of all outstand ing San Antonio Public Servic Company first mortgage and re funding .6 per. cent Series A gold bonds due in 1952; calling atted tion to the fact that, at the election of the holder, bonds may be pre sented'for-cancellation on any busi ness day prior to Jan. 1, 1939,

Lancaster M. Greene of Lancaster Norvin Greene, Inc., has been elected vice president and a member of the executive committee of the Robert Schalkenbach Foundation, endowed to publish Henry George's works on economics and philosophy.

Ronald MacPherson, relief hurler, led the Flushing H. S. baseball team to a 5-to-4 victory over Jamaica in a ten-inning encounter at Memorial Field yesterday for the Queens P. S. A. L. championship. The victorious pitcher came into the game in the second frame with Jamaica ahead, 3 to 1. In the final stanza his single scored Charles Cuff with the winning run.

Daily average gross crude .oil production in the United States last week was 3,107,950 barrels, an increase of 9,300, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 225,350 barrels fewer than the calculation of 3,333,300 daily by the Bureau of Mines for June.
Gene Tunney put his royal stamp of approval on Max Schmeling today and scoffed politely at a suggestion that the German might go stale before his battle with champion Joe Louis on June 22.

The New York Stock Exchange has notified its members relating to-the June 2 notice regarding-th call for redemption.of all outstand ing San Antonio Public Servic Company first mortgage and re funding .6 per. cent Series A gold bonds due in 1952; calling atted tion to the fact that, at the election of the holder, bonds may be pre sented'for-cancellation on any busi ness day prior to Jan. 1, 1939,

Lancaster M. Greene of Lancaster Norvin Greene, Inc., has been elected vice president and a member of the executive committee of the Robert Schalkenbach Foundation, endowed to publish Henry George's works on economics and philosophy.

The eleventh annual rose festival was celebrated yesterday afternoon at the Brooklyn Botanic Gardens with more than 150 members of the gardens taking part in the ceremonies. Prior to making a tour of gardens, which included an inspection of 300 species of roses,

Syracuse made it three out of four in its series with the Jersey City Giants today by taking the final game, 5 to 3. Ted Kleinhans held the locals to six hits until the ninth, when he weakened with one out and had to give way to Red Barrett.

The 1,371 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $48,243,744,251 par value as of June 1, had a total market value of $42,346,644,435, according to a compilation by the Exchange is- ra sued yesterday.

Students of conditions who have pored through the statistical records of the last few months find nothing to stand in the way of a general recovery in business and industry. Inventories are far below year-end figures, and if the business trend were upward they would be exhausted soon. Prices of raw materials are at the lows for several years.

Premier Benito Mussolini's newspaper, Popolo d'Italia, today replied to Secretary of. State Cordell Hull's Nashville speech of June 3 with an admonition that the United States, before trying to humanize warfare in Europe, should learn to protect its own children.
General Gonzalo Queipo de Llano, one-time "radio general" of the Insurgents, declared tonight that his friendship with Generalissimo Francisco Franco was "closer than ever."

At the commemoration of the tercentenary of the foundation of New Haven colony Governor Crbss, picking two names from a noble sheaf, said that "the fame of two Yale presidents, Ezra Stiles and Timothy Dwight, still lives." Dr. Stiles had no high opinion of his successor.
Richard Archbold and his crew of five flying a scientific expedition seaplane to New Guinea from California alighted in the lagoon of this mid-Pacific coral islet at 7:15 A. M. today.

The lengthy deliberations of the Thu Constitutional Convention in Al- the bany were criticized last night by from Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink, who told members of Iota Theta Law Fraternity at the Hotel Astor that the ideal 'Constitution "should not be much longer than the Ten Commandments."

ONCE upon a time that estimable and amiable actor-playwright, Frank Craven, fashioned an opus entitled "That's Gratitude!" Probably Mr. Craven will take the briar pipe out of his mouth and stare with astonishment and indignation when he learns that Mr. James J. Dykes, manager of the Chicago White Sox, has stolen the very essence of his opus and put it into the Dykes road-company version of a baseball drama.
The members of the State Board of Housing, Louis H. Pink, chairman, will attend a meeting of the State Constitutional Convention's housing committee in Albany tomorrow.

The blood feuds of Kentucky and the mine wars of Harlan County became tangled up today as the government tried to hang the killing of one union organizer and the wounding of another upon former peace officers accused of conspiring with coal operators against the Wagner act.
Before a large crowd gathered the Yale Bowl tonight a cast of 4,000 New Haven citizens portrayed scenes in the city's three centuries of history in a dramatic spectacle.

Miss Robina Protheroe Townes, daughter of Mrs. Willis Glover Townes of Skylands, this place, and the late Mr. Townes, was married at noon today at the home of her mother to Richard Egbert Shoemaker, son of Mrs. R. Steel Shoemaker of Los Angeles and of Richard Woolsey Shoemaker of Woodbury.

Jackie (Kid) Berg, 146, England, outpointed Irish Johnny McHale, 147, East New York,in the feature bout of' eight rounds at the Canarsie Arena in Brooklyn last night. A crowd of 3,600 saw Berg.triumph in a bout which opened the program because of threatening weather.

ABBE-In New Haven, Conn., June 7, 1938, Minnie Holmes Spring Abbe, widow of Charles Colgate Abbe and beloved mother of Mrs. Charles S. Campbell, aged 84 years. Service in St. Paul's Chapel, New Haven, Thursday morning, June 9, at 10 o'clock, D. S. T. Interment in Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, N. Y., at 4 o'clock, D. S. T.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES reported an interview with Commissioner Carey of the Department of Sanitation relative to the controversy over the use of Jamaica Bay for the dumping of refuse, from which the following is taken:

Miss Elizabeth P. Russell, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Francis Russell and niece of Mrs. George Edwin Steel of 390 West End Avenue, will be married to T. Scudder Winslow Jr. on June 27 in All Angels Church. The Rev, George A. Trowbridge, the rector, will perform the ceremony.

The of Invitation Tourr veteran Baby Arizmendi of Los Angeles came from behind to earn a draw with the lightweight champion, Lou Ambers of New York, in a furious ten-round non-title bout tonight. More than 10,000 fight fans were kept in a constant uproar of excitement.

Resumption of trading in the stock market after the long Whitsuntide week- end found most sections cheerful today. In the foreign bond list Austrian loans suffered a sharp decline, but by the close they had recovered from the day's worst levels.
A national political party is in process of- formation in - Brazil. Backing it are several influential States and the armed -forces of the nation.

Wearing a one-hundred-and-fiftyseven-year-old wedding gown, without modification, Miss Elizabeth Varick Howell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Wilson Howell, was married to Donald Farrington Sealy yesterday afternoon in the West End Collegiate Church.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Isabel Douglass Curtis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ellicott Curtis of this city and Litchfield, Conn., to Edward Tinsley Ray, which took place last Friday in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. The Rev. Dr.
President Roosevelt threatened today to revoke licenses or commissions of American airplane pilots or mechanics enlisting in revolts against established governments abroad.

A warning to beware of "peddlers of paganism" was sounded yesterday by Judge John A. Matthews of the Chancery Court of New Jersey at the commencement exercise at the College of Mount St. Vincent, Riverdale. Degrees were conferred upon 117 persons by Cardinal Hayes, president of the college. Among those receiving honors were eight nuns,

Elwood Cooke from Portland Ore., top-seeded player, after experiencing some difficulty in the first set, downed Phil Rubel, 7-5, 6-1, in a fourth-round match yesterday in the Brooklyn tennis championships on the courts of the Terrace Club, Flatbush.

Formation of a nonpartisan organization to be known as "National Rededication," to conduct a campaign for liberty and democracy, was announced yesterday by Hermann Hagedorn, its acting director. Headquarters are at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The engagement of Miss Muriel Florence Zinn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Zinn of 54 Riverside Drive, to Arthur R. Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Lewis of Brooklyn, has been announced by her parents.

Champion Betty Jameson of San Antonio came through handily today in her first round of match play in the women's Trans-Mississippi golf tournament, but Miss Beatrice Barrett of Minneapolis loomed in the path of her effort to repeat her 1937 conquest.

The Leix Gaelic football team ended its United States tour by defeating a strong New York fifteen Ne at Innisfail Park last night, 10 to 6, before a crowd of 2,000. Along with Ne the Cavan players and officials, the Leix squad will sail for Ireland at noon today on the United States liner President Harding.

At an emergency meeting this evening, the Railway Labor Executives Assocation authorized the preparation and introduction into Congress of a joint resolution empowering President Roosevelt to take over and operate the railroads in the event that the dispute over the carriers' demand for a 15 per cent wage reduction should result in a national emergency.
The Swiss Federal Council today sent Parliament a measure for expenditure of 190,000,000 francs on national defense works to be paid for by a "defense tax."

More than 700 amateur gardeners, professional horticulturists and owners of estates attended the annual two-day sweet pea and rose show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society that closed last night. The exhibition was held under the auspices of the New York Horticultural Society in the association's rooms at 598 Madison Avenue.

The local ordinance against the distribution of handbills, on which Governor Lehman summoned Mayor Myle J. Holley to Albany last week, was again invoked today when Chief of Police Joseph A. Lillis caused the service of a summons on Jerry C. S. Rossi, organizer for the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers Union.

A hitherto unknown super wave of electricity that pulses in beats of from ten to thirty minutes each through the human brain under conditions of chemical disturbance in the body was reported to the American Psychiatric Association today by Drs. Robert Cohn and Karl Langenstrass of St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Washington.

The twenty-third Hunter College Summer session, which will begin July 11, will include an enlarged extracurricular program to supplement the class work. Visits to points of civic, vocational and academic importance will be features of the educational-recreational program, Professor Broderick Cohen, director of the Summer session, announced yesterday.

The success of first experiments for extracting flax fiber from plants grown at the Peruvian experimental station near Lima indicates that the growing of flax may become a profitable industry in Peru, according to a report to the Department of Commerce from Lima made public today.

Hogs and lambs continued to work higher today and fat steers and yearlings sold dependably, fully steady, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Native Spring lambs reached $11, a new high on the crop, and top on hogs went to $9. Choice but not strictly prime steers topped at $10.65.

The contract for the construction of the new school of the Roman Catholic Church of the Ascension on the northeast corner of Eightyfifth Street and Sixty-first Road, Elmhurst, L. I., has been awarded to the Patrick Construction Company, reports Brown's Letters, Inc.
The whole Italian press today, with a unanimity that can scarcely be attributed to mere chance, inveighs against France for the part she is playing in the Spanish civil war.

The one unmistakable result of Iowa's primary election is a rebuff for the "elimination committee" which set out to make support of the President's Supreme Court plan an acid test of fitness for membership in the Senate. The present senior Senator from Iowa, Mr. Gillette, opposed the Court Enlargement Bill.

A number of multi-family dwellings and two taxpayers were reported yesterday by brokers as having changed hands in the Bronx. Included was the fifty-five-family apartment house containing ten stores at 3,120-30 Bainbridge Avenue, which was purchased by Joseph Goldstein and Jacob Solomon from the City Treasurer's office, A. A. Berle Jr. as trustee.

Bronx Park Ave, n e c of Tremont Ave, 70.10x25.8; Flora N. Brown against Charles W. Mayne; due, $8,388; taxes, etc., $1,960; to plaintiff for $5,000. By JAMES R. MURPHY 227th St, 651 E, 50x114; Home Owners Loan Corp against Anthony C. Corbi; due, $12,292; to plaintiff for $3,000.
Great Britain's jobless by May 16 had increased to 1,778,805, which was 382,000 more than at that time last year, according to tonight's official returns.

Drastic amendments to the Walsh-Healey Act, which sets labor standards for companies holding government contracts, were passed by the Senate today in the midst of routine consideration of the calendar.
Forty-two years ago come October eleven golfers met at the Newport, R. I., Golf Club and played the first open championship held under the auspices of the newly formed U. S. G. A.

Paul Derringer hurled his eighth victory of the season tonight as the Reds defeated the Phillies, 7 to 5, in a free-hitting battle under the lights. Cincinnati took the lead in the second inning and never was headed.

Congress behaves at times so disappointingly, carelessly or cravenly that, because such acts are always performed in a spotlight, observers and public forget or fail to notice many of its constructive labors.

Brooklyn Law School of St. Lawrence University will confer 478 degrees at its thirty-sixth annual commencement, to be held at 9:45 A. M. today in the R. K. O.-Albee Theatre, Fulton Street and DeKalb Avenue, Brooklyn.

Frederick H. Payne, chairman of the board of the Greenfield Tap and Die Corporation, and Horace G. Roberts, president of the U. N. Roberts Corporation, have been elected directors of the Certain-teed Products Corporation to succeed Walter W. Colpitts of Coverdale Colpitts and Edward A. Le Roy Jr., resigned.
Commencement season a year ago President Hopkins at Dartmouth told the graduating class to cut out the self-pity.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs, in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, makes the common error of assuming that there is a similarity between industrial accidents and those caused by motor vehicles.

Although the press continues to keep silent on the charges of political, religious and cultural oppression lodged with the government by the Polish minority in the Third Reich, government quarters today freely acknowledged the submission of such charges.

ABBOTT--Dr. William H., beloved husband of Grace M., on Wednesday, June 8, at Cambridge, N. Y. Services Saturday, 2:30, at Cambridge. Chicago papers please copy. ABESSON-Augusta, beloved wife of Louis, dear mother of Zelda and Sarah. Funeral from her late residence, 40 Oakland St., Englewood, N. J., 2 P. M. Friday. Kindly omit flowers.

Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commander of the New York National Guard, and Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., clashed today at a hearing of the Constitutional Convention's Committee on Military Affairs over the adequacy of the State's air defense plans.

The Junior -Building Corporation, represented by Schlesinger Krinsky, has purchased a plot 100 by 100 feet at 1,236 Forty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, as the site for a six-story apartment building. Mildred. and Fanny Seldin were the sellers.

More than 1,000,000 trees, plants and shrubs have been purchased by the WPA to beautify and shade parks, playgrounds, streets and public buildings in this city, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday. .

Appointment of a special Senate committee, provided with ample money, to investigate all charges of political use of funds appropriated in the 1938 Relief-Recovery Act was confidently predicted today by three of the ten Senatorial sponsors of the Tydings resolution to this end.
The Commerce Department today blamed misjudgment of currents and excessive speed for the disastrous beaching of the passenger liner President Hoover on a Japanese island Dec. 10.

With the top of $9, big packers continued today to support the highest hog market in recent weeks. Steers, heifers and lambs also sold at new highs on the crop, prime 1,443-pound steers reaching $11, with numerous loads at $10.50-$10.85. Choice Spring lambs also sold up to $1l, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

The stock market went through the motions of "business as usual" yesterday, but at the end of the session net changes in prices were inconsequential and the trading volume was one of -the smallest in nearly sixteen years.

DURING the past few years there has come from certain quarters highly enthusiastic comment upon the work of the Australian-born writer Christina Stead. Her first book was "The Salzburg Tales" (1934), then "Seven Poor Men of Sydney" and "The Beauties and Furies." Now we have a complex novel about international bankers. It is called "House of All Nations." *

In a violet and white amphitheatre constructed on Ohio Field, University Heights, New York University yesterday morning conferred 4,100 degrees in course, seventy three certificates, seven alumni awards and eight honorary degrees, including one to Mayor La Guardia, at its 106th commencement.

Joe Triner, chairman of the Illinois State Athletic Commission, ordered both purses held up tonight after Jimmy Adamick, young Midland (Mich.) heavyweight, rose from a five-count knockdown to knock out Jack Trammell, lanky Negro from Youngstown, Ohio, in the second round of a ten-round bout at Mills Stadium.

It is doubtful whether there is anything within the memory of men now living that quite matches in deliberate, calculated horror the air raids which for twelve successive days have now rained death and destruction on the city of Canton.
BEHIND THAT MASK, by Harry Stephen Keeler.(Dutton, $2.) A mystery novel. ENGLAND'S MUSICAL POET, THOMAS CAMPION, by Miles Merwin Kastendieck.

Guy Guerin Font-Joyeuse, manager of the New York branch of the Paris firm of Marcel Rochas, Inc., took the witness stand yesterday at his trial on a smuggling indictment and told Federal Judge William Bondy and a jury that he had nothing to do with the alleged importation of gowns to this port duty free.

Maurice Rossi, French transatlantic flyer, set three minor world flight records today. They were the speed record for 5,000 kilometers [3,105 miles] without load, and with 500 and 1,000 kilograms [a kilogram is 2.2 pounds] of cargo. His time was 12 hours 27 minutes 38 seconds.

The International Labor Conference's general discussion of the report of the director of the International Labor Office began today with striking agreement among the worker, employer and government delegates speaking that the pressing world problem is the securing of peace and that the outlook is dark both as regards war and the depression.

Candidates in the examination for promotion to the rank of lieutenant in this department whose application numbers are above 2,000, and who are entitled to credit in that examination in record and seniority on account of military service, are directed to report at Room 1,428, Municipal Building,, Manhattan, between 9 A. M. and 12 noon from Monday, June 13 to Friday,

The Yale varsity and junior varsity crews will leave tomorrow for a three-week training period at Gales Ferry preceding the Yale-Harvard races on the Thames River at New London, June 24. Harvard will arrive at Red Top, its training quarters, next Saturday.
Judge Charles Klein approved a distribution today of the estate of J. Dundas Lippincott, by which about $4,000,000 will go to Mrs. J. R. Herbert Boone of New York City.

Brazil has aligned herself in a practical way with the program of the inter-governmental refugee conference inspired by President Roosevelt and scheduled to meet on July 6. Thousands of immigrants who entered Brazil on tourist visas have overstayed their time, fearing to return to the European countries of which they were technically citizens.

A sale inspired by "the generally backward season, plus unemployment and poor business conditions," will begin today in 670 Thom McAn shoe stores in 350 cities, it was announced by the Melville Shoe Corporation yesterday.

A six-year building program, providing for 227 new elementary and secondary schools at a cost of $233,436,954, intended to eliminate congestion and effectively attack the problem of overcrowding, was adopted yesterday by the Board of Education at its regular meeting.

Forced into overtime for the first time this year after they had blown a 7-1 advantage, the Yankees dropped the opening game of yesterday's doubleheader at the Stadium to the White Sox, 11-10. in thirteen innings. Then they remained consistent and dropped the second, 10-6, this one in regulation playing time.

William Henry Abbott, former Brooklyn physician, died here today after a long illness at the age of 63. Born in Ivanhoe, Ill., Dr. Abbott attended Princeton University, where he was a member of the board of governors of the Tower Club.

Lucena del Cid, an important iron and lead mining center, with 4,500 inhabitants, about twenty miles northwest of Castellon de la Plana, was occupied by the Insurgents today as their offensive in the sector between Teruel and the coast was accelerated along the whole fifty-mile front.

In the name of religious neutrality, the Supreme German Army Command has just ordered all former Austrian soldiers now incorporated in the German Army to leave the Catholic soldiers' leagues former Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg established.
Queen Alexandrine was severely bitten on her left leg tonight when she attempted to protect her two foxterrier dogs from attack by a stray mongrel on the beach at Skagen, North Jutland.

Officials of the Lehigh Valley Railroad denied yesterday reports that the company had concluded an agreement with holders of large amounts of its bonds whereby it would default on interest payments without incurring a foreclosure.

Although ingot production remains at last week's rate of 25 per cent of capacity, steel business continues to decline in total volume, according to The Iron Age. In the first week of this month the volume of business dropped below the May average, which, in turn, was lower than that of April.

United States Government securities showed moderate improvement yesterday on the eve of the closing of the subscription books on the exchange offer for the maturing 2 7/8 and 2 1/2 per cent Treasury notes.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 6: CAPTAINS Helm, S. F., title changed to director, Naval Reserve, Third Naval District, New York. N. Y.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:
The Remington Rand Company prepared today to "furlough" 800 new workers and reinstate an equal number of employes who struck in 1936.
