With its driveshaft broken and its brakes out of commission, a bus carrying between thirty-five and forty school children rolled backward down a steep hill for more than 1,000 feet here this afternoon, colliding with an automobile and crashing into a telegraph pole before it stopped.

A tax lien of $16,522, representing a government claim for additional income tax payment from Ignace Jan Paderewski, the pianist, for 1932, was filed in Federal Court yesterday by James J. Hoey, Collector of Internal Revenue at the Custom House.

The fourth annual joint commencement of the University of Newark will be held tomorrow night at the Mosque Theatre for 198 graduates of the College of Arts and Sciences, the School of Business Administration and the School of Law.

Before Hitler made his ten-year truce with Poland, we heard a great deal about the hard lot of the Poles in Germany. The quiescence of the Polish minority since that agreement throws an interesting sidelight on the use of minorities in Central Europe as an instrument of national policy.
The bulk of office, showroom and In store space. leased yesterday was concentrated in the midtown section Manhattan.-Foreign governments figured in two of-the contracts for offices here.

Pig iron production in May as reported by The Iron Age, declined to 1,255,024 gross tons from 1,376,141 tons in April, a loss of 11.7 per cent when figured on the daily rate of 40,485 tons against 45,871 tons in the preceding month.

The stock market here was quiet on the whole today, with moderate optimism prevailing in most sections. Gilt-edged issues were well supported, while among the foreign bonds Japanese loans were in demand and Austrian issues were steady.

The Railway Express Agency, Inc., and the Southeastern Express Company filed jointly with the Interstate Commerce Commission today an application for authority to increase their rates and charges and to make "other modifications of the express rate structure."

Robert Watson, 43 years old, an alien accused of illegal residence in the United States since 1928, was deported yesterday on the Anchor liner California for Scotland. His wife and two daughters stood on the pier after bidding him a tearful farewell.

Mrs. Doris Duke Cromwell, one of the wealthiest young women in the world, was appointed today to the Board of Control of the State Department of Institutions and Agencies by Governor Moore. The State Senate confirmed the appointment tonight. .

Thomas Hardy's birthplace, an old thatched cottage in the hamlet of Higher Bockhampton near Dorchester, has been sold to a farmer, P. F. Parsons, by Lady Hanbury, who is disposing, of her holdings in that district.

Suspension of distilling operations in several plants of the Schenley Products Company recently was a seasonal development customary in the industry, Lester E. Jacobi, vice president in charge of production for the company, announced here yesterday.
The combination of reverses along the Lung-Hai Railway, the loss of Amoy and the bombings of Canton are bringing about the first perceptible breaking in morale among many Chinese leaders in Shanghai.

On their own applications, To take effect 12 midnight, June 8: SERGEANT--Thomas J. Harley, Traffic Precinct N. at $1,750 perannum. Appointed April 14, 1903. PATROLMEN--Cornelius J. Sullivan, 18th Division, 13th Detective District, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 5, 1913. To take effect 12 midnight, June 13:

Frederick W. Hille, former president and chairman of the board of directors of the Merchants Trust Company of this city and last surviving founder of the Hudson Trust Company, died in his home here last night. He would have been 88 years old on July 6.
Tommy Bridges was-in tip-top shape today as he-held the Athletics to five hits, and the Tigers won, 5-1. Bridges struck out ten and was particularly effective in the late innings.

Miss Elsie R. Abrahams, a retired public school teacher, died on Tuesday at the Jewish Memorial Hospital, where she had undergone an operation a month ago. Miss Abrahams lived at 1,043 Trinity Avenue, the Bronx, in the house in which she had made her home for nearly forty years. She was 62 years old.

Degrees were awarded by Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of Brooklyn to sixty-seven graduates of St. Joseph's College for Women in commencement exercises held yesterday on grounds adjoining the college's convent-faculty house at 232 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn. More than 1,200 persons attended the ceremonies.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, sportsman noted for his racing stable, married Miss Manuela Hudson of Monterey, Calif., at the country home here of his mother, Mrs. Margaret Emerson, this morning. The bride is a daughter of George Hudson and the late Mrs. Hudson.
The five-story apartment house at 2,487 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, has been. purchased by a client of I Mannis Neumann, lawyer. The buyer paid. cash above a first mortgage of $121,500.
Jersey City snapped its three-game losing streak by taking both ends of a double-header With the Maple Leafs today, winning the first, 5 to 2, and the second, 4 to 1.
The fifteen-acre estate of the late Gertrude Grace Dwight at Mill Neck, L. I., is to be sold at auction at 11 A. M. on Saturday by Arthur C. Sheridan. auctioneer.
Leonard Hartman advanced to the semi-finals yesterday in quest of his third leg on the challenge trophy in the Brooklyn tennis championship at the Terrace Club of Flatbush.

The Navy Department announced today that a board of five officers had been appointed to investigate and report upon the need for the establishment of additional aviation, submarine, mine and destroyer bases on the coasts of the United States, its territories and possessions.
An adverse majority in the Committee on Suffrage of the Constitutional Convention has tabled the three principal measures designed to curb political activity by radicals, it became known today.

In a precedent-setting opinion Judge Oliver B. Dickinson of the Federal District Court held today that after the National Labor Relations Board had assumed jurisdiction in a dispute involving rival unions, the courts had the right to restrain picketing of the employer's place of business.

The Nieuw Amsterdam of the Holland-America Line, arriving today from Rotterdam via Boulogne and Southampton, has on board Mrs. Alvin T. Fuller, Emile J. Deckers, Mr. and Mrs. Frank K. Van Dyk, Mr. and Mrs. Anthonius J. Thieme,
The Berkeley Divinity School will award nine degrees of Bachelor of Divinity, six in course and three with diploma of graduation, at commencement exercises here tomorrow.

Williamsbridge Rd (15-4088) e s, 101 ft s of Pierce Ave; 50x113; Bertha Cohen to Home Owners Loan Corp. Bronx Park Av (15-3906), n.w cor of 177th St, 44x148; Alice Ross to Francesco Carbone, 333 Bronx Park Ave.

The marriage of Miss Mary Randolph Walker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bailey Walker of this city, to Allan Hartwell Kirkwood, son of Dr. and Mrs. Allan Stewart Kirkwood of Montclair, N. J., took place here yesterday morning in the James Chapel of Union Theological Seminary.

The Wall Street Liquor Corporation moved in Supreme Court yesterday to vacate an injunction issued last December restraining it from cutting prices on liquors price-fixed by Schenley Distributors Inc. under the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act.
George M. Shutt, former president of the New York Cotton Exchange and former Police Commissioner of New Rochelle, died here today at his home of a heart ailment. His age was 74.

GOVERNORS ISLAND 1st Lt. Alterino C. Fantozzi, Med-Res., 304 Cornwall St., Buffalo, N. Y., Bradley General Hospital, is ordered to active duty, effective June 4 at Second Infantry Brigade Communication and Intelligence School, Stony Point Rifle Range, Henderson, N. Y., for training. Date of rank, Nov. 4, 1937. He will revert to an inactive status June 7.

W. L. Russell toured the Upper Montclair Country Club links today in 85 to win the low gross prize in Class D of a tournament for New Jersey seniors. A field of 145 participated in five classes for golfers of 55 and upward.
The Home Owners Loan Corporation will move on July 1 to 270 Broadway, New York City, from the quarters it now occupies in the McGraw-Hill and Empire State Buildings.
The Spanish Insurgent Government announced today it would conduct nine-day tours through the battlefields of Northern Spain as its first bid for tourist traffic.

With the current Valencia crop the largest in history, the California Fruit Growers Exchange is placing an extra advertising assessment of 2 cents a box on these oranges and will spend close to $1,000,000 for its Summer campaign.
The Browns crushed the Senators today, 11 to 5. It was their second triumph over Washington in as many days and it dropped the losers from third to fourth place in the pennant race.

A further readjustment of the assets of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, purporting to increase by almost $6,000,000 the total previously estimated, was presented yesterday at a hearing on the amended reorganization plan of the company under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, before George W. Alger, special master, in the Bar Building, 36 West Forty-fourth Street.

By a unanimous vote yesterday, the Board of Education dismissed James H. White, a teacher of health education in the Theodore Roosevelt High School, from the school system, and barred him from any future employment in the city's schools.

Miss Audre M. Dorson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Dorson, was married to John M. Gingold of London, son of Clarence Gingold of London and Steepleton House, Stockbridge, Hampshire, England, and the late Mrs. Gingold, yesterday noon at the home of the bride's parents, 1,185 Park Avenue.

The American Steamship Owners Association rejected, yesterday an invitation of the New York Maritime Council to attend a conference of governmental and shipping agencies at which controversial matters affecting the peace of the shipping industry would be discussed.

Daniel J. Casey, Director of Public Safety, justified today the "deportation" of citizens from Jersey City if they were "undesirable," if they were causing a disturbance, or if they were in danger of bodily injury from hostile crowds.

The second-place Bisons ended Newark's 11-game winning streak today by walloping the Bears in both ends of a double-header, 19 to 5 and 4 to l. Buffalo slugged Atley 'Donald, Frank Makosky and Phil Page for twenty-one hits in the opener.

Nine hundred women from New York and Westchester visited the Children's Village here today. They arrived this morning and were escorted by the children on a tour of inspection, which included the classrooms, the trade schools, the little theatre, the Scout camp and the twenty cottage homes.

The Chase National Bank, with 76 points, won the seventeenth annual bank officers' golf tournament of the Bankers Athletic League yesterday at the 'Shackamaxon Country Club, Westfield, N. J, and thereby won the first leg on the William S. Gray Jr. Trophy.

Harry Balsamo of Harlem knocked out Andy Melia of Astoria in the first round of their eight-round feature bout before 3,000 fans at the Queensboro Arena last night. After Balsamo had twice floored Melia for counts of nine and eight, Referee George Walsh halted the fight after 2 minutes 57 seconds.

Louisa C. A. Wieners gave to the Manufacturers Trust Co a new mortgage for $10,187 and this was consolidated with a prior mortgage to form one lien for $60,000 on 972-74 6th Ave and extended to June 7, 1943, 5 per cent.

A report to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange disclosed that the Diamond Match Company purchased 70,000 shares of capital stock of the Pan-American Match Corporation at its par value of $25 a share, under an option it held to acquire all or any of the 182,000 shares of the unissued capital stock of Pan-American. The purchase took place on March 30, last.

George S. Bridge, former director of the Chicago Board of Trade and president of the grain commission firm of Bridge Leonard, Inc., died today in Evanston (Ill.) Hospital after an illness of several days.

The marriage of Miss Mildred Clarke von Kienbusch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Otto von Kienbusch of this city, to Kenneth Remsen Morgan, son of Mrs. Frank Carl Dettmann and George K. Morgan, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Resurrection.

The Regional Plan Association sent a letter to the Board of Estimate yesterday objecting to the city's plans for developing an easterly approach to the Triborough Bridge on the ground that they were illogical and uneconomical.
Joseph M. Byrne Jr., Director of Public Property, whom Norman Thomas criticized over the "free speech issue" at a meeting of the City Commissioners today,

Following several days of clear weather, showers over a large portion of the cotton belt strengthened prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the list ended at the top with gains of 9 to 10 points.

The former Strauss estate, consisting of about fifteen acres on the waterfront at Cove Neck, Oysters Bay, L. I., with a large residence, has been sold to H. Hill Anderson of Roslyn for occupancy, by Arthur: C. Sheridan. The buyer paid all cash for the property.

Penthouse apartments were taken by several of the new tenants listed in the rental reports submitted by brokers and agents yesterday. Richard S. Winship leased a rooftop suite at 17 East Ninety-sixth Street through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., who also report leases with Eleanor M. Mellon in the building under construction at 955 Fifth Avenue, with C. Alfred Capen in 25 East Eighty-sixth Street, and with Richard Barrett in 25 East Eighty-third Street.

Mayor La Guardia made economy his principal argument when he appeared before a committee of the Constitutional Convention on Tuesday to support an amendment consolidating the courts in New York City. It was a good point.

A mural painting of "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" on the wall of the playground of the Gramercy Boys Club, 535 East Sixteenth Street, was unveiled yesterday afternoon with appropriate ceremonies. John D. Buckley, director of the club, who was master of ceremonies, said it probably was the first work of art ever unveiled the gashouse district.
RETAIL ALBANY - Peggy Parker: Mr. Mullens, ready-to-wear; 225 W. 34th (Marizon Rosenberg Co.). ANDERSON, Ind.-The Fair: L. L. Simon, ready-to-wear, furs; 128 W. 31st (Kirby Block Co.).

Two of the foreign yachts that have come to this country for the Bermuda race starting June 20 were entered yesterday for the New Bedford Yacht Club's annual Whalers race, which will start in Buzzards Bay on Saturday.

A committee representing the guarantor powers for the two Austrian loans sponsored by the League of Nations in 1933 and 1934 and on which Germany has defaulted will meet here tomorrow under the chairmanship of Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, chief economic adviser to the British Government.

Sponsors of the bill introduced by Senator Maloney which provides for registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission of a national association of over-the-counter brokers and dealers and affiliated organizations are preparing to make every effort to obtain final adoption in the present session of Congress.

Mr. and Mrs. Paul C. Cabot have arrived from Boston and are at the Sherry-Netherland. Mr. and Mrs. Hugh de Haven of Cooperstown, N Y., will give a dinner tonight at the Madison for Dr. Chih Meng, president of the China Institute.

The Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company received the Charles A. Coffin Medal, highest award for electric light and power companies, at the sixth annual convention dinner of the Edison Electric Institute in the Hotel Traymore here tonight.
The wheat market showed considerable hesitation on the buying side today. After an early upturn, reflecting unexpected strength in Liverpool, priors reacted sharply.

A residence of five rooms and' bath. in Clinton. Street, in Westminster Ridge, White Plains, has been purchased by Albert F. Merritt of the Westchester Lighting Company from the County Housing Corporation.
J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, announced early today that the body of the kidnapped boy, Jimmy Cash, had been found. A suspect is being held.

Mrs. D. Le Grand Hedges of the Hedges, Colonia, N. J., has announced the engagement of her niece, Miss Katherine Wood, to Norman Turner Beardsley of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Kid Beardsley of Boston.

Three timely extra-base hits, one a triple by Paul Waner, gave the Pirates a 4-to-1 victory over the Bees today before 2,800 fans. It was the fourth victory against one defeat for Bobby Klinger, formerly of Sacramento, and the seventh loss for Lou Fette.

The Rev. Andrew Fleming, rector emeritus of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Nativity, Ocean Avenue and Farragut Road, Brooklyn, died Tuesday night in his home, 450 East Twenty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, after an illness of several months of bronchitis. He was born in Kilbirnie, Scotland; eighty-six years ago.

President Roosevelt signed the bill requiring disseminators of foreign propaganda to register with the State Department, discussed politics and Federal projects in Missouri with Governor Stark and conferred with 'Charles Edison, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, on plans for the navy's "mosquito fleet."

The first wire test of the semagraph, an automatic typesetting device which its sponsors believe will revolutionize newspaper composingroom practice, was conducted successfully yesterday between the office of THE NEW YORK TIMES and the New York office of The Associated Press at 383 Madison Avenue.
The 98-year-old widow of Jules Massenet, the composer of "Manon," "Thais" and other operas, died here today after she had fallen on a staircase in her chateau near Fontainebleau.
Scholarships for travel and study abroad have been awarded to three graduates of Hunter College, Professor Claudine Gray, head of the Department of Romance Languages, announced yesterday.

The Hudson Manhattan Railroad and residents of the New Jersey communities which it serves, in briefs filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission, disapproved of the recent report by Examiner Irving L. Koch

Following closely the first roundtable conference last week between governors of the New York Stock Exchange and representatives of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the second of the meetings will be held between the two groups this morning, when certain aspects of trading in listed bonds will be discussed.

Close of play scores in English County cricket matches started today follow: Middlesex. 311. (Hart 77, Price 67, Brown 65); Hampshire 36 for one, at Lord's. Kent 400 (Fagg 125, Woolley 78, Todd 66); Lancashire 10 for none, at Manchester. Nottinghamshire 390 for eight (Heane 126, Knowles 114, Staples 61 not out) vs. Worcestershire. at Worcester.

American, British and Australian Champion Don Budge tonight stood two matches removed from the French hard-court tennis crown. The California red-head overpowered Bernard Destremeau of France, 6--4, 6--3, 6--4, in the quarter-finals today and seems to have the title in the bar.

Chief Justice R. A. E. Greenshields of the Quebec Superior Court handed down a judgment repudiating the practice followed by some French Canadian judges in annulling marriages in Quebec Province not performed in accordance with Roman Catholic canon law.

Warners announced today that they will begin negotiations with Metro for the purchase of Sinclair Lewis's "It Can't Happen Here," which was barred from production two years ago because of foreign pressure. Paul Muni has secured the scenario from MGM, owner of the property, and negotiations will be opened if it meets with his approval.

Showing the vaunted speed which characterized his 2-year-old career, Airflame presented his newly married owner, Alfred G. Vanderbilt, with a victory when he came through with an easy score in the $4,000 added Wilmington Handicap at the opening of William du Pont Jr.'s Delaware Park today.

Winding up a contest of fumbling and general ineptitude on both sides with a four-run rally in the ninth inning, the Jolly Dodgers today toppled the Cardinals again by a 7-6 count and set up a brand new season's winning streak of four games.

The Title Guarantee and Trust Company was directed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Thomas F. Noonan to answer a suit brought by thirty-two investors in a guaranteed mortgage who alleged that the bank had obtained their consents to an extension of the lien without disclosing to them the fact that the mortgagor was in financial difficulties.

The Senate Finance Committee today reported favorably a bill to place a 25-cent-a-gallon tax on floor stocks of spirits in the possession of liquor wholesalers and retailers which has been withdrawn from storage up to July 1.

Dr. Alexis Carrel, Nobel Prize winner and co-inventor with Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh of the "artificial heart," revealed yesterday at his office at the Rockefeller Institute that his research work there would be halted, his division closed and his staff disbanded on July 1, 1939, when he reaches the automatic retirement age of 65.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey started a procession of high Tammany Hall leaders yesterday before the Supreme Court extraordinary grand jury investigating the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy racket conspiracy, in which, thus far, James J. Hines,

Otto Berndt, about 40 years old, a member of the brokerage firm of Weed, Hall Berndt, 40 Wall Street, committed suicide last night, according to the police, by shooting himself in the chest with a rifle in his two-room suite in a residential hotel at 1 Fifth Avenue, where he had lived alone for four or five years. No notes were found.

Efforts to increase War Department control over rivers and harbors projects failed in the Senate today as a result of protests by Senator Norris that implied authority might make that department the eventual arbiter of all questions relating to flood control, erosion and similar problems, as well as its primary responsibility of navigation.

Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and detectives of this city sought today for questioning in the Peter Levine kidnapping mystery a building superintendent who vanished from New Rochelle last Wednesday, three days after the 12-year-old child's body was found floating in Long Island Sound.

Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart will write the book, score and lyrics of the musical show that will star Beatrice Lillie next season, it was learned yesterday. Under the aus pices of Harry Kaufman the as yet untitled production is due on Broadway in the late Fall after a tour.

Francis J. Ryan of Yonkers, N. Y. has been elected captain of Columbia's track team, I. C. A. A. A. A. indoor champion for the past two years, it was announced yesterday. He succeeds Ben Johnson, National Collegiate A. A. 220-yard champion, National A. A. U. and I. C. 4-A. indoor sprint champion, and world record holder for sixty yards.

1st Ave, s e cor: 12th St, 28.3x70; Bank of Sicily Trust Co., in liquidation, to Orma Realty Corp., care N. H. Josephs, 90 Broad St. ($40). 14th St, 419 E, 25.1 1/2x103.3; same to same ($5). 2d Ave, s e cor 109th St, 68x66; same to same ($50).
Scoring the largest monthly decline since the 1929 depression, chain store sales last month receded 11.3 per cent under May, 1937, according to the compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Turpentine firm 22 1/4c: sales 32 barrels: receipts 590 barrels; shipments 98 barrels; stock 35,738 barrels. Resin firm: sales 516; receipts 3,028; shipments 600; stock 129,390.

While warm weather during the last few days has been a favorable factor, retail trade here thus far this week has. not materially bettered the poor showing of the last two weeks. Department store volume, with few exceptions, is not running better than 15 per cent under last year, although improved turnover toward the week-end would alter the picture to a considerable degree.

A committee of which William D. Moran is chairman has been formed to represent the holders of the twenty-five-year 5 per cent debentures of the Reynolds Investing Company, Inc., it was announced yesterday.
Wallace J. Bernache of the Passaic County Country Club won the William Henry Beers Memorial Trophy at the Hackensack Golf Club today. He carded a 78, which, with an 11 handicap, gave him a net of 67.

The adoption of a new sanitary code placing rigid restrictions on carnivals, distributors of foods and beverages and builders of sewerage systems was announced today by the Westchester County Board of Health, which has jurisdiction throughout the county except Yonkers, Mount Vernon and New Rochelle.

Two men were wounded last night in Hanover Parish when policemen fired at a rioting crowd. Attempts were made to burn cane fields. The West Indies Sugar Company is said to contemplate closing down factories till conditions become normal.

The weekly report of crop conditions issued yesterday by the government was as follows: In general the weather was rather favorable for cotton. In the eastern belt temperatures averaged considerably below normal, but they were above normal from the Mississippi Valley westward.

Charles Chambers, 19 years old, of 131 Bay Street, Atlantic City, was placed under $500 bail at Atlantic City Hospital today on charges of reckless driving and speeding pending his recovery from a broken collar bone suffered in a bicycle accident.

Gross assets, $16,409; net, $13,997. To wife, Susanna A. Douglass. Chief assets, real estate, $7,245; stocks and bonds, $1,880; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $7,206. Sidney Squire, attorney, 50 Court St.
The body of St. Andrea Bobola, who was canonized by Pope Pius Easter Sunday and designated as protector of his native Poland, was placed aboard a funeral train today to be returned to that country.

America's strong- Wightman Cup tennis team today completed serious practice for the international matches with Great Britain Friday and Saturday. The rival line-ups will not be announced until tomorrow, but it was pretty clear tonight what the selections would be.

Ordinarily one wouldn't expect to find Herbert Hoover, Alfred M. Landon, Matthew Woll, Norman Thomas, Dorothy Canfield Fisher, Owen D. Young and William Allen White, to mention only a few names on a long list, signing the same declaration of principles.

Miss Sally Harrison, daughter of Mrs. Fairfax Harrison and the late Mr. Harrison, who was president for more than twenty-five years of the Southern Railroad, was married today to Dr. Gerhard Dieke of Baltimore.

Continuing ah almost unbroken string of victories in the State National Guard rifle matches being shot at Camp Smith here, the marksmen of the Old Seventh Regiment of Manhattan in the matches run off today retained both the Governor's Cup and the Adjutant General's team match trophies won last year.

Some weeks ago considerable excitement was occasioned in biggame angling circles on this coast when it was reported that the Western Explorer, a Pacific coast tuna clipper, was heading for our waters to scout the Atlantic tuna situation for the West Coast fleet.

A delegate from every post in the United States is expected here tomorrow when the New Jersey Department of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States opens its annual convention in-Hotel President.
Mrs. Helene L. Sommer of this city and Montreal has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elyse H. Sommer, to Herbert Levy, son of Leo Levy of San Francisco and the late Mrs. Levy.

The Michigan Supreme Court held constitutional today an 1857 act prohibiting individuals or groups from "molesting a worker in the lawful pursuit of his vocation." Counsel for the United Automobile Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate, had argued that the statute was an abridgment of the right to picket during strikes.

Miss An-fu Wang, daughter of the Chinese Ambassador; Miss Kathleen Bulow, daughter of Senator and Mrs. Bulow, and Robert M. Lemke, son of Representative and Mrs. Lemke were among the 198 students graduated tonight by George Washington University with the degree of Bachelor of Arts.

Sweeping revision of Federal and State statutes is a pressing need today because many obsolete laws clutter the books, for one thing; and, for another, a number of commendable recent measures are unlikely to survive in their present form, Colonel Cornelius W. Wickersham, president of the Joint Conference on Legal Education of the State of New York, declared yesterday morning.

The first long-term public financing by the Mountain States Telephone and Telegraph Company, an affiliate in the American Bell System, will take place today with the issuance of $30,000,000 of thirty-year 3 1/4 per cent debentures, due June 1, 1968. A banking group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., will offer $27,750,000 of the issue at 102 and accrued interest, to yield 3.147 per cent to maturity.

The complete list of competitors entered in the six-event-fifth anuual Princeton invitation track meet, to be held in Palmer Stadium Saturday, June 18, was announced tonight by Asa S. Bushnell, director of the meet.

More than 500 enthusiastic children filled the roof-garden of the Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway, last night for the annual presentation of awards by the Alumni Association of the Boys Club Department of the alliance. Nearly 200 boys, ranging in age from 10 to 14, received medals and prizes.
138th St, 503 W; 5-story tenement, 25x99.11; Annette B. Behr against Argy Realty Corp, due, $1,816, subject to mortgage of $5,950, to Murray Daumont for $7,852.

Arkansas Natural Gas Corporation and Subsidiaries-For 1937: Net income after operating expenses, taxes and charges, $4,298,870, equal after preferred dividend charges to 39 cents a share on combined 4,082,587 shares of common and 3,522,271 shares of Class A common, against $5,255,062, or 52 cents a combined share.

The Ford Motor Company notified the Sixth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today of its intention to carry to the Supreme Court its contest of a National Labor Relations Board order seeking to require the company's compliance with the Wagner act.

Fatigue, irritability and the low spirits of adults as well as children frequently can be rectified with a piece of candy, three authorities told the National Confectioners Association yesterday at its fifty-third annual convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Mace Ave. 666. dwelling, 25x100; Home Owners Loan Corp against Nicholas Cianelli; due, $12,278; to plaintiff for $1.500. By GEORGE J. KEARNS 220th St, 620 E, dwelling, 16.8x114.3; Home Owners Loan Corp against Lena Nickels; due, $5;339; to plaintiff for $500.

The Maritime Commission approved today the application of the Baltimore Mail Steamship Company to transfer to the intercostal service its five combination passenger and cargo vessels which formerly operated between Baltimore and Norfolk and European ports.

Cautious play marked the opening matches in the international chess masters tournament today. Of the five games scheduled three were decided, all being recorded as draws. The other two were adjourned, to be played to a finish on Friday, the first of three days set aside for the purpose.
Great Britain tonight considered putting squarely before Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy the matter of repeated Spanish Insurgent attacks on British shipping.

The vagaries of golf took two heavy favorites out of the running In the women's Trans-Mississippi tournament today, but left a field of seasoned stars to continue the fight tomorrow into the third round.

Mrs. Harry McNaughton, the former Marion Turpie, was eliminated in the second round of the women's Metropolitan golf championship at the Century Country Club today, thereby losing the title she captured a year ago at Upper Montclair.

The Bank of the Manhattan Company obtained yesterday $1,000,000 of certificates of indebtedness of Utica, N. Y., on a 0.24 per cent interest basis, plus a premium of $7. The certificates will be dated June 9 and will become payable on Nov. 9, 1938.

Manhattan Alterations 5th Ave, 461-69; to 10-story lofts and stores; Mary J. Home, 55 Liberty St, owner; A. F. Winter, architect; cost $60,000. 5th Ave, 681; to 12-story offices and "store; estate of Anna L. Morton, 41 Broad St, owner; R. Berger Jr., architect; cost $15,000.

On the first of June, surplus reserves of private banks in the Federal system were reported as $2,640,000,000. This is larger by $148,000,000 than on April 20, just after reserve requirements had been reduced, and $913,000,000 above the excess in the week before that reduction.

Arrests continue of Jews and others suspected of being hostile to the regime. No official figures are available, but there is little doubt that since Friday several thousands have been arrested and sent to Styria and other parts of the country for public works, while others have been sent to Dachau.

Miss Florence Perlow, a New York attorney, and Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag of the First Judicial District were married at noon yesterday in Temple B'nal Jeshurun by the Rev. Dr. Israel Goldstein.

Germany displaced the United Kingdom as the principal export market for Peruvian cotton in the first four months of the current year, and Japan became a new customer for Peruvian cotton, according to a report to the Department of Commerce from Lima, made public today.

The uncertainty concerning the date of Congressional adjournment increased s tonight after an abrupt about-face in the wages and hours conference committee which produced a call for a caucus of Southern Democratic Senators tomorrow to decide Senators tomorrow to decide

Just when Bob Feiler appeared to have his Boston jinx on the verge of a knockout today, Jimmy Foxx swung into homerun action and inspired the Red Sox to come from behind for a 7-to-6 victory over the league-leading Indians.
The fifty-second commencement of Berkeley Institute, 181 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, will take place tonight at the Memorial Presbyterian Church, Seventh Avenue and St. John's Place, Brooklyn.

Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross, sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star Liner Queen Mary to attend the International Red Cross Conference to be held in London on June 20-24. Mr. Davis heads a delegation of six from the United States-Government as well as being chairman of a group of fourteen from the American Red Cross.

Elon Huntington Hooker, manufacturing chemist, father of Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3d and a descendant of Thomas Hooker, founder of Hartford, Conn., who died at Pasadena, Calif., on May 10, left an estate of $604,078 and no will.

A class of forty-four students from six States will be graduated from Moses Brown School tomorrow at exercises closing the institution's 119th academic year. Headmaster L. Ralston Thomas will present the diplomas and announce the winners of prizes and other awards.

Appointment of twenty new faculty members of Queens College to care for the added enrollment expected next Fall was announced yesterday by Dr. Paul Klapper, president. The new professors and instructors have been drawn from various types of institutions throughout the country.

Social security taxes cost the steel industry $5,800,000 in the first quarter of 1938, for which period it reported an aggregate net loss of about $5,000,000, according to the magazine Steel. The trade journal points out that these taxes meant the difference between a profit and a loss for the period.

Packed with 300 men, women and children who examined, used and asked questions about every one of its many new gadgets, the Broadway Limited, the Pennsylvania Railroad's new luxury train for the Chicago-New York run, yesterday made a preview round-trip run from here to Philadelphia.

Funeral services for David Andrew Kennedy, founder of the Carteret Academy for Boys at Orange, N. J., will be held here at 2:30 P. M. tomorrow at 86 Broadway, the home of his son, the Rev. Chauncey Clark Kennedy, rector of Christ Church.
AX - LES - THERMES, France, June 8.-So far nobody in this border region seems to have any idea of the identity of the nine planes from Spain that bombed Orgeix on Sunday.

Mrs. Ary J. Lamme of Rye and Mrs. John J. Schieffelin of Mount Kisco, seeded first and second, respectively, and favored to meet in the final Friday, led the way into the semi-final round of the third annual women's invitation tennis singles tournament at the Manursing Island Club today. Meanwhile, competition in the doubles got under way.

Miss Elinor Marion Wolfe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles De Kay Wolfe of this place, was married here this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church to Arthur Sydney Waldron Jr., son of Mrs. Waldron of Newton and the late Mr. Waldron.

Miss Zelina Therese Clark, daughter of Mrs. David Crawford Clark of 810 Fifth Avenue, this city, and Bar Harbor, Me., and the late Mr. Clark, was married yesterday in St. James Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, to Donald Peabody Blagden, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Blagden of Upper Saranac N. Y.,

The Chinese military spokesman reported today that the defense forces along the Lung-Hai Railway had virtually completed their withdrawal in accordance with the announced plan and were fighting only rearguard actions against the Japanese on the plains of Honan Province.

Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman of New York and Governor and Mrs. Lewis O. Barrows of Maine were guests of honor today at the 139th graduation exercises of Deerfield Academy. Their sons, John Lehman and Edward Barrows, received diplomas.

The Federal Power Commission will hear evidence on June 23 at a hearing on an application by the Twin State Gas and Electric Company for approval of the sale of its properties in New York State to the New York Power and Light Corporation for $586,000, plus an amount equal to the value of certain net quick assets as they exist

The House today passed and sent to the Senate the Second Deficiency Bill, after increasing its appropriations by $3,275,000. The major increase resulted from an amendment introduced by Representative Scott of California to provide for the restoration of the principle of re-enlistment pay for enlisted men and non-commissioned officers in the army.

Wage cuts of $4.70 a month for 11,703 WPA professional and technical workers, now getting the top security pay of $103.40 monthly, were ordered yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, acting on instructions from executives of the Federal relief agency in Washington.

Commencement exercises of the Hartridge School will be held tomorrow morning in the school auditorium here. Dean Marjorie Nicolson of Smith College will be the speaker. The school tea for the alumnae, the nineteen seniors and their parents was held today following a meeting of the alumnae.

Sales of General Motors cars in May to dealers in the United States and Canada, together with shipments overseas, totaled 104,115, compared with 216,654 in May a year ago, a decline of 51.9 per cent, according to figures made public yesterday by the corporation.
The seventy-ninth annual commencement of Cooper Union will be held at 8 o'clock tonight in the Great Hall at Fourth Avenue and Eighth Street.

Electric power production was lower last week. With allowance for the holiday, the daily average showed a less than seasonal increase and the adjusted index declined to 89.4, a new low for the year, and compares with 90.5 for the preceding week and 108.0 for the week ended June 5, 1937.

Charges that contracts with the Petroleum Corporation of America had been violated by sale of stock of the Delta Oil Corporation to Burco, Inc., were made yesterday by Huntington D. Sheldon, president of the Petroleum Corporation, at the Securities and Exchange Commission's investment trust hearing.

Two scientists who a year ago announced a potential protector against infantile paralysis in a zinc sulphate solution warned today that further investigation convinced them it robbed humans of the sense of smell. .

For some time the Soviet seismographic station at the town of Yalta in the Crimea has been puzzled by the recording of a violent earthquakes here and there about the globe that subsequent checking proved had not taken place.
Four orchestras, two choral ensembles and a band will take part in the semi-annual concert to be given by students of the High School of Music and Art tomorrow afternoon in the school auditorium.

Arthur T. Lumley, former editor of The Police Gazette, who managed John L. Sullivan at the time of the Kilrain battle, died last night in the Kings County Hospital, where he had been a patient for a week. His death was due to ailments incident to age. He was 86 years old.

Despite opposition by the American Civil Liberties Union, an ordinance requiring a permit for a parade or public meeting on public highways in Brookhaven Township was adopted today by the Brookhaven Town Board after a public hearing.
The Senate Agriculture Committee voted today to clear the American Cotton Cooperative Association of all charges raised against it during an investigation started more than a year ago.

Rebelling against obstructionist tactics attributed to Senator Frank Durand of Monmouth County, the Assembly "walked out" on the upper house at 1:30 o'clock this morning, leaving behind for 'consignment to the "morgue" not only the Durand bill to continue Asbury Park under control of the State Municipal Finance Commission but also a Senate bill appropriating $150,000 for New Jersey participation in the New York World's Fair.

The marriage of Miss Cathryn Rita Kenny, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John V. Kenny of this city, to Paul James Hanly, son of Mrs. James Hanly, also of Jersey City, and the late Mr. Hanly, took place this morning in St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church. The ceremony was performed by Mgr. William A. Griffin.
In a vigorous address denouncing American policy, Dr. James Tsunechi Yu, Consul General of China, blamed the people of the United States last night for helping to prolong the struggle in his country.

Authorization for a strike to be called at midnight Friday was voted at a closed meeting here tonight of members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers employed by the Long Island Lighting Company and its operating subsidiaries.

Lawyers for the Port of New York Authority and for New York and New Jersey asked the Supreme Court today to grant a rehearing on its decision of May 23 that three employes of the Authority were subject to a Federal income tax because, the court held, the organization was not essential to the existence of the two States.
Maui Girl, bay mare owned by Lieut. Col. and Mrs. Charles B. Lyman of Meadowbrook, Pa., today was awarded the hunter championship, which brought to a close the twentieth annual West Point horse show.

Land deals of more than 150 years ago in the section of Manhattan now known as Gramercy Park form an interesting-part of a book just published' by the Columbia University Press under the title of "A Revolutionary Conservative"--James Duane of New York.

Three Spanish Insurgent armored ships, escorted by the gunboat Dato and five armed trawlers, landed at Algeciras, Spain, this morning a large contingent of Riffians, Foreign Legionaires and Arabs from Ceuta, Spanish Morocco.

An attractive town house on the East Side which is said to have cost a more -than $100,000 when it was erected -in 1922 changed hands. yesterday when Mrs. Dudley Olcott sold the five-tory residence at- 18 East Seventy-fourth Street.

Appointments which will keep six buyers busy for two days were arranged yesterday by E. M. Rosenthal Jewelry Company of Washington, wholesalers, who advertised yesterday for $600,000 worth of merchandise for the twenty-fourth anniversary sale of the Kay Jewelry Stores.

Another case was added yesterday to the list of assaults on home relief investigators by relief recipients. Mrs. Doris Lee, an investigator, was punched, kicked and slapped while at work in the relief office at 376. Lafayette Street.

The Cathedral of St. John the Divine needs to raise only $125,000 before work can be started on the completion of the interior in time for the World's Fair, Bishop William T. Manning announced yesterday in a new appeal for contributions.

Charles Morelle Bruce, secretary of Arizona Territory in President Cleveland's Administration and for eight years Assistant Commissioner of the United States Land Office under Woodrow Wilson, died here today after a lingering illness at the age of 85.

The probability that American office executives would demand collective bargaining like manual workers was discussed by Professor R. P. Brecht of Pennsylvania University before the nineteenth annual conference of the National Office Management Association here today.

Edwin S. Smith, member of the National Labor Relations Board, and Arthur Krock, Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, will be the principal speakers at the morning session of the Harvard Business School Alumni Association Saturday, June 18, in Baker Library.

The question of the amount of freedom to be granted to President Roosevelt in handling funds in the proposed investigation of monopolies aroused such a division in the Senate this afternoon that Senator Barkley postponed a vote on the question until tomorrow.

Some two-and-a-half years ago, at the crest of a general economic upswing, dark-complexioned, bright-eyed Phillip Guarno was forced to close the door of his modest fruit and vegetable store in Brooklyn.

World production of rayon yarn and staple fiber rose 37 per cent in 1937 to a total of 1,808,740,000 pounds, a new high record, according to figures compiled by Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. The figure compares with a 1936 total of 1,319,075,000 pounds.

The Malmaison Museum, which contains the most notable Napoleonic relics in France, is negotiating to obtain the Emperor's coronation ring, which was missing after his fall and which has found its way into the hands of a private collector in Paris, Lucien Baszanger.

Stocks closed steady and mixed in second slowest trading since July 3, 1922; turnover, 278,410 shares. United States Government and foreign bonds generally higher, corporate issues irregularly lower; transactions, $4,158,300.

The question of gradual retirement of memberships in the New York Stock Exchange will continue to be one of the principal studies facing the new administration of the institution, it was indicated yesterday following a meeting of the board of governors.
The General Accounting Office told Congress today that the navy had entered an "illegal" contract with a private concern that "appears tantamount to a gift of public property."
Deloss C. Shull, a lawyer of this city, who was prominent in Baptist circles and was an honorary trustee of the University of Chicago, died here last night at the age of 80.

A sigh of relief issued from the Ottawa government tonight when news arrived that the Liberal administration of Premier Patterson had been returned to office in Saskatchewan and that Premier Aberhart's social credit invasion of the Province had been beaten off.

While Mayor La Guardia and the Transit Commission united today in presenting to the Constitutional Convention an amended version of the proposal which they feel will let them effectuate transit unification through the purchase of the private properties with city bonds,

King Victor Emmanuel today took advantage of his presence in Forli, where he inaugurated an exhibition of the works of the famous fifteenth century painter Melozzo da Forli, to take a short trip to Predappio, Premier Mussolini's birthplace.
A new international quarterly magazine entitled Freedom, printed in English in Paris, and proposing to unite the democracies of the world in a great force, is being put into circulation here.

Governor Lloyd C. Stark of Missouri, a New Dealer, visiting Washington today, told politicians that Senator Bennett Champ Clark, one of the Democrats who opposed the Roosevelt plan to enlarge the Supreme Court, would be renominated.
Unrelenting Japanese bombardment of this once-prosperous South China metropolis has started huge fires, crippled the city's utilities and pushed the toll of dead and injured above 8,000.

A syndicate headed by Myron I. Bonis has purchased from Charles Walzer, operators, the three-story building at 69-75 Fourth-- Avenue, East Orange, N. J. There are four stores and six apartments in the structure, which stands on an irregular plot about 45 by 103 feet, opposite the Ampere Bank and Trust Company.
Cardinal Hayes will preside and confer degrees here tomorrow at the annual commencement exercises of Good Counsel College. The Rev. J. Harding Fisher will give the commencement address.

The marriage of Miss Helen Gay Rand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leroy Henry Rand of Brooklyn, to Dr. Sidney Edward Lenke, son of Mrs. Melchior Lenke, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Lenke, took place yesterday in the Embassy Suite of the Ambassador. The Rev. Dr. Sidney S. Tedesche performed the ceremony.
The human factors underlying and serving to create the kinds of intense nationalism displayed by Germany were described at the American Psychiatric Association here today by Dr. Frederick H. Allen

The appeal of the Greater New York Fund for $10,000,000 to, supplement the finances of private welfare and health agencies will be carried from one end of the city to the other on the bumpers of 2,500 taxicabs, Frederick W. Gehle, publicity chairman of the campaign, announced yesterday.
A first mortgage of $130,000, running ten years, has been arranged by Samuel Kronsky Co., for Lester H. Brown on the six-story apartment at 3,120-30 Bainbridge Ave, the Bronx.

It would be a cause for major concern if Congress were to adjourn without having taken any measure for dealing with the critical situation in the country's railroads. About 30 per cent of railway mileage is now in receivership.

At its meeting yesterday the Board of Education voted grant substitute teachers the four days of pay that they would otherwise lose because of the early closing of schools. Led by Mrs. Rose Olson of the Teachers Union, about 200 substitutes crowded the board's chambers and loudly applauded the action.
John Hay Whitney's Flying Scot, a high-ranking 3-year-old last year, made his first appearance of the season at Aqueduct yesterday and immediately qualified as a threat in the handicap division.

William J. Bingham, director of athletics at Harvard University, announced tonight that he had submitted his resignation as a member of the American Olympic Committee because he felt that the Olympic Games were "getting into the control of those who would use youth for their own purposes," and because he "could not ask the American people to support a team which was going to a country standing for what Japan stands today."
A redesigned and reconstructed Cooper Park, at Fourth Avenue and Seventh Street, just south of Cooper Union, will be dedicated this afternoon by the Department of Parks.

President Roosevelt today signed a bill intended to curb dissemination of foreign political propaganda in the United States by requiring all employes of agencies so engaged to register with the Secretary of State.

Harry Poole Camden, 38-year-old sculptor of Parkersburg, W. Va., a former instructor at Cornell University, was announced yesterday as the winner of the Federal Government's $10,000 competition for two huge statues to adorn the main facade of the Federal building at the World's Fair.
Two New York college presidents received honorary degrees today as Holy Cross College at its eighty-ninth commencement exercises conferred 249 degrees in courses and five masters' degrees.

Gold medals to sixteen student soloists in piano, violin and voice, and twenty-one silver cups will be awarded by the Music Education League next Thursday evening at the Center Theatre. It will be the league's fifteenth annual presentation of awards.

The Sudeten German party announced tonight that Deputy Ernst Kundt had transmitted to Premier Milan Hozda a memorandum embodying the party's demands which are, in fact, the eight points contained in Konrad Henlein's Karlsbad speech.
The Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation expects to distribute between $7,000,000 and $9,000,000 worth of cotton goods and mattresses to needy families during the next year.

Commencement exercises for sixty-three graduates of the College of St. Elizabeth will be held at the college here tomorrow afternoon. Miss Theodora Blake of Bedford, Ohio, an alumna of the college, will give the address.

This was a day of dramatic surprises and considerable discomfort for several of the coal operators and most of the former deputy sheriffs of Harlan County on trial in Federal court on charges of conspiring to rid their community of union organizers.

Sixteen members of the Long Island University baseball squad have been honored with major letters and sixteen freshman ball players with minor letters, according to an announcement yesterday by Professor Clair F. Bee, director of athletics.

Pratt Institute will award degrees and certificates to 657 graduates of its four schools at the commencement exercises at 2:30 P. M. today in the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Lafayette Avenue and Ashland Place.

The Swedish Supreme Court ordered today Tortsen Kreuger, brother of the-late Ivar Kreuger, "match king," to pay 1,100,000 kronor (about $285,000) to the trustees in bankruptcy of Ivar Kreuger's affairs. .

The net income of the Zenith Radio Corporation for the fiscal year ended on April 30 was $701,477 after depreciation, royalties, Federal income tax and surtax on undistributed profits, according to the annual report, released yesterday for publication.

Lippincott has received word from London that Neil M. Gunn's "Highland River," which the firm published last Autumn, has won the James Tait Black Memorial Prize for the best novel published during 1937. Among former winners of the prize have been Walter de la Mare, J: B. Priestley, E. M. Forster and D. H. Lawrence.

Gold medals to sixteen student soloists in piano, violin and voice, and twenty-one silver cups will be awarded by the Music Education League next Thursday evening at the Center Theatre. It will be the league's fifteenth annual presentation of awards.

The Sudeten German party announced tonight that Deputy Ernst Kundt had transmitted to Premier Milan Hozda a memorandum embodying the party's demands which are, in fact, the eight points contained in Konrad Henlein's Karlsbad speech.
The Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation expects to distribute between $7,000,000 and $9,000,000 worth of cotton goods and mattresses to needy families during the next year.
The New Friends of Music, Inc., which gave its second series of sixteen Sunday concerts at the Town Hall last season, earned a net profit of $338.54, it was announced yesterday.

Reports by 141 Class I railroads to the Interstate Commerce Commission showed for March an aggregate net loss of $28,212,429 after taxes and charges, against a net income of $24,888,844 in March, 1937.
Baroness Florence Sybil Carbonelli, daughter of Wilbur King of Bethlehem, Pa., was married to William Foote Farnham of New Haven, Conn., today by special license before the Budapest Registrar.

Miss Muriel Maria Gerli, daughter of Mrs. Emanuel Gerli of 907 Fifth Avenue, this city, and Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Gerli, has completed the plans for her marriage to Nelson Macy Jr., which will take place the afternoon of July 2 in Christ Church, Greenwich.

Dressed in rags and a battered silk hat, Winthrop Rockefeller, son of John D. Rockefeller Jr., was the target: for much horseplay yesterday afternoon as he was inducted into the Circus Saints and Sinners.

The Republican leadership of the Constitutional Convention today disclaimed any Intention of trying to keep its majority in line, as a matter of party policy, in support of the stand taken yesterday by the Republican-dominated Bill of Rights Committee

With a capacity throng of 42,320 fervently imploring the gods to provide something different from what eventually came to pass, the invading Giants stormed back to first place in the seething National League pennant race today by upsetting the Cubs in both ends of a doubleheader.

Testimony designed to show that the Cement Institute ordered a so called boycott against building material dealers who imported cement from Europe was presented yesterday at a hearing into the Federal Trade Commission's charge that the institute and seventy-five of its member companies conspired to eliminate price competition.

Sir Arthur S. Eddington, one of the world's most famous astronomers, who has not only impressed his scientific colleagues but also has made astronomy intelligible to the general public, was made a member of the coveted Order of Merit in the Birthday Honors announced tonight.

Max Schmeling's sparring partners can't tell one day to the next what sort of man they're going to get in the ring with. One day he bounces them around with rights and the next he does nothing but fiddle and experiment.

Arthur P. Van Schaick, vice president of the American Chain and Cable Company and a former resident of Highland Park, Ill., died today on board the Panama Limited on the way to Chicago from New Orleans. He was 55 years old.

George D. Haskell, employed as an advisory expert by the Aluminum Company of America, was the first witness called by the government in its suit to enjoin that company and its affiliates from alleged violation of the Sherman anti-trust law.
The United States is the beneficiary of the $16,600 estate of Caesar Gerard of 37 Crane Street, this city, according to his will which was- filed for probate here today.

It is hoped it will be possible to include Guglielmo Marconi's floating laboratory. the yacht Elettra, among the Italian exhibits at New York's Word's Fair. The intention is the yacht would be anchored in the Hudson during the fair and made available during the fair and made available to any on wishing to visit it.

The directors of the American Shipbuilding Company at a meeting yesterday authorized an extra dividend disbursement of $1 a share on the common stock, in addition to a payment of 50 cents a common share. On June 26 last year an extra dividend of the same amount was paid.

They timed production of "When Were You Born?" the astrological who-dunnit prepared by Manley Hall and the Warners, to start precisely at 10:45 one Hollywood morning, a propitious moment when the sun, Mercury, Venus and Jupiter were conjunct in the tenth house.

Canadian industry was slightly more active in May because of seasonal influences, according to the Canadian Bank of Commerce. Crop outlooks continued favorable for the most part and building construction increased.

Estate, more than $10,000. To Jeanette G. Rafter, sister, 46 Kensington Ave., Jersey City, N: J., $1,000 in bonds and specific insurance; Frances E. Duffy, sister, executrix, 214 E. 49th St., household, personal effects, specific insurance, interest in real property. stocks and bonds, and residue. EARL, WILLIAM ARNOLD (June 3). Estate, less than $10,000. To Lucretia M. Earl., widow, executrix, 241 Central Park West.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Appleton gave a luncheon yesterday in the garden of the Ambassador for their granddaughter, Miss Patricia Appleton, who returned recently from Milan, Italy. Other guests included Miss Apppleton's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John A. Appleton; Mrs. Livingston Davis of Boston, Miss Tina Appleton, Nathaniel Wales and H. Sargent Appleton.

Julius Brabec, new consul general of Czechoslovakia, was welcomed last evening at a dinner of 200 of his countrymen resident in this city at the Bohemian National Hall restaurant, 321 East Seventy-third Street.

Twelve hundred and thirteen men and women received degrees today from the University of Pittsburgh, which also conferred seven honorary awards, and heard a talk on "Courage" by Dr. Vilhjalmur Stefansson, Arctic explorer, who was made a Doctor of Laws. Others thus honored were:

THEY say that a golf ball stays up in the air a long while out in the Denver region where the knights of the niblick are about to take off in full flight for the national open championship over the Cherry Hills course. Even so, it's where the ball drops that counts, especially that last tinkling drop in the cup.

For knocking over a speakers' stand in Military Park here, on which Norman Thomas, Socialist party leader, attempted to make a speech last Saturday night, a Newark Police Department horse will receive a pound of sugar.

Trading was generally only fair to slow. The markets were mostly steady to lower. Eary trading in kosher meats indicated prices to be about in line with Tuesday's close. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

THEY say that a golf ball stays up in the air a long while out in the Denver region where the knights of the niblick are about to take off in full flight for the national open championship over the Cherry Hills course. Even so, it's where the ball drops that counts, especially that last tinkling drop in the cup.

For knocking over a speakers' stand in Military Park here, on which Norman Thomas, Socialist party leader, attempted to make a speech last Saturday night, a Newark Police Department horse will receive a pound of sugar.

Agawam Park's records for a $2 win pay-off and daily double return were shattered today when the 196-1 Gemwick captured the first race by closing fast during the last seventy yards to nip Choice Goods, the favorite, at the wire.
A colonial dwelling on Harvest Avenue, West Brighton, S. I., has been sold by Mrs. Charles McKnight to Stephen Naples, through Harry S. Clark, broker.
The two-year-old question of a successor to the French Academy seat of the- late Henri Robert was solved today when Charles Maurras obtained Twenty votes, one more than necessary for election.

A writer who might have been a reporter pounded out "copy" on a typewriter in the New York office of The Associated Press last night. As he removed each page, he inserted it into the jaws of a metal contraption and went back to his typing.

Trading continued only fair to slow in most classes of traefer meats. Veal hindsaddles were weak to lower, fresh pork cuts uneven, other classes mostly. Kosher business was light and largely in lamb at about steady prices. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:
Henry D. Collins, assistant stage manager of the WPA Federal Theatre production, ". .. one-third of a nation . .." died Tuesday at St. John's Hospital, Long Island City, Queens. He was 69 years old.
Instead of the dry weather now reported necessary over most of the Cotton Belt, general rains have occurred and prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced sharply $1 a bale yesterday.

Leslie MacMitchell, one of the most promising distance runners ever developed in a New York City public school, will participate in his final race as a schoolboy tonight at the Randalls Island Stadium, where the Public Schools Athletic League will conduct its thirty-fifth annual city senior high track and field championships.

New ideas for curing the country's economic ills are reaching the Farm Security Administration at the rate of 2,500 a year. Most of them outline "back to the farm" movements to be conducted at government expense, officials said today.

Justice Black has already shown "qualities that, combined with circumstances, promise to make him an outstanding figure in the history of the Supreme Court," Professor Harold C. Havighurst of the Northwestern University School of Law asserts in the June issue ofe National Lawyers Guild Quarterly.

Mrs. Sanford Bissell, who has been at the Plaza, will leave today for Nantucket, Mass., where she will pass the Summer. Mrs. Benjamin Austin Cheney of New Haven and Falcon Flight Farm, Litchfield, has come to the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Robert Garrett of Baltimore is at the Biltmore.

Evidence that a new era of harmonious relations among divergent groups in the financial district and also between these groups and the Securities and Exchange Commission was given yesterday, when the first concentrated move toward solving the problem of trading in bonds was made here at a preliminary conference attended by large institutional buyers of bonds and officials of both the New York Stock Exchange and the SEC.

Nathan Vermilyea, 46, of Brooklyn escaped from the Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminally Insane while working on the grounds late today and several hours of searching revealed no trace of him. Dr.

Forty-five Seattle bakeries, producing 95 per cent of the city's bread, were closed early today by a strike. There was no indication how long the strike would last. J. B. Fowler, manager of the bakers of Washing-ton, said that there was sufficient bread on hand to meet normal needs for several days.

The five ships of the Baltimore Maritim Mail Line, whose transfer from the operate transatlantic to intercoastal service was approved by the Maritime Commission on Wednesday, will inaugurate the new service next month.

The Munson Steamship Line service between New York and the east coast of South America will be resumed June 18. when the steamship Southern Cross will sail for Rio de Janeiro, Montevideo and Buenos Aires.

At a luncheon given yesterday in the Terrace Restaurant of Sherry's, Mr. and Mrs. William P. O'Connor of 1,107 Fifth Avenue and Larchmont announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie O'Connor, to James T. Naughton, son of Mrs. Lawrence Naughton of 171 East Ninety-fourth Street and Wavecrest, L. I., and the late Mr. Naughton.
A retired major told an Oxford court today of a would-be kidnapper's plan to seize Viscount Nuffield, millionaire automobile manufacturer, for $500,000 ransom and perhaps drown him at sea.

Battleship, first American-bred and owned horse ever to win the Grand National Steeplechase, returned from England last night aboard the Manhattan of the United States Lines. Reginald Hobbs, trainer, and his son Bruce, 17, who rode Battleship to victory, accompanied the horse.

The merchant ship Arsa of Trieste, flying the Italian flag, is expected to drop down the river here tomorrow from the commercial docks, where she is now taking aboard a shipment of lead, to load a cargo of barrels of asphalt from what were formerly the American-owned Pierce and Sinclair refineries.

James L. Fri, managing director of the Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A., Inc., was elected president of the Trade Association Executives in New York City at a meeting of the board of directors, held yesterday in the offices of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., who heretofore have confined their activities to Manhattan and the Bronx, have opened an office in the Queensboro Theatre Building, at Queens Boulevard and Fifty-seventh Avenue, Elmhurst, Queens. The office is in charge of Louis M. Weiss and Joseph S. Strauss.
More than 13,500,000 trees were planted in the 1938 tree-planting program on all reforestation areas, Lithgow Osborne, Conservation Commissioner, said today.

The British Government was on the defensive today when its representative, Sir John Shuckburgh, Deputy UnderSecretary of State for Colonies, appeared before the League of Nations mandates committee, which began its annual examination of Palestine.

Members of the American Olympic Committee tonight accused William J. Bingham, director of Harvard athletics, of "walking out on them when they needed his support most" by resigning from the committee.

Charles T. Murphy announced yesterday his resignation from the staff of United States Attorney Lamar Hardy and his acceptance of the post as senior attorney for the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Earl Baldwin, former Prime Minister, as chancellor of Cambridge University, today conferred honorary degrees on Dr. Peyton Rous, New York pathologist; T. S. Eliot, author, of St. Louis, and Anthony Eden, former Britishi Foreign Secretary.

The Yankees came out of their ??ail-spin yesterday, hit an air-pocket In the first inning, then coasted ??almly to a safe landing. The Bronx Bombers yielded three runs in the openingg session but straightened put in time to defeat the White Sox, ?? to 3, and thus ended the series with a victory after three straight lefeats.

In the shortest match of a quarterfinal round devoid of surprises Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches scored an impressive victory on the Century Country Club course today to advance another step toward the women's metropolitan golf championship, which she has won on five previous occasions.

Business in the Pittsburgh district showed further decline last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh With the exception of a somewhat larger than seasonal gain in department store sales, all the major lines of economic activity in the district decreased.

McBurney School graduated forty-three students, the largest class in its history, at commencement exercises last night at the West Side Y. M. C. A., 5 West Sixty-third Street. Professor Howard W. Hintz of Brooklyn College spoke.

Speaking in English over a transatlantic telephone hook-up with Barcelona, Juan Negrin, Spanish Premier, told a rally at Madison Square Garden last night that "in Spain has been committed one of the biggest misdeeds of contemporary history."

A British, a French and an unidentified vessel -were bombed in Spanish harbors and off the coast yesterday, with a reported loss of nineteen lives. British leaders considered what action could be taken to protect neutral shipping, but found no practical solution of the problem.

Stocks closed higher with leading industrial shares up 1 to 2 points in largest trading of month; turnover, 587,220 shares. United States Government issues firm and higher, traction securities strong, other bonds irregular; transactions, $4,210,500.

That "portables farm yard" which the Department of Parks takes annually to playgrounds in the congested areas of the four boroughs, where the residents are supposed to be unfamiliar with farm animals and their ways, met with difficulty yesterday at its first stop in the Roosevelt playground, when the s "barn" was set up on Stanton Street, between Chrystie and Forsyth Streets.

Sandys Birket Foster, president of the Bartholomay Company for almost forty years, died last night at his home in Irondequoit after a long illness at the age of 67. Coming to this country from England in 1897, Mr. Foster became a member of the auditing firm of Price Waterhouse in Chicago.

The Hamburg-American liner Deutschland will arrive today from Hamburg and Channel ports. On board are Mr. and Mrs. Jacob F Schoellkopf, Dr. and Mrs. Colin G Fink, Mr. and Mrs. Emilio Iwerson, Mr. and Mrs. John Penningtor Gardiner, Captain Brunke Garrels Edgar Hilgert, Mr. and Mrs. Beverley Matthews and Dr. Frank B. Lusk.
Sherman Ave (9-2453), n w cor of 167th St., 114x94; 19th Ward Realty Co to Larimda Realty Corp. 285 Madison Ave. Creston Ave., 2,730 (12-3315); Adelaide Richter to 'Mary Foody, 953 Anderson Ave.

The Board of Examiners' reports that there have been placed on the eligible lists of holders of license for service as indicated in junior high schools, as of June 7, 1938, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted license, as indicated:
Two days after ne weds Miss Anne Lindsay Clark, John Roosevelt, the President's youngest son, will be an usher at the wedding of a Har vard classmate, Marshall Field Jr of New York.
The Senate overrode its Judiciary Committee today and granted wide powers to President Roosevelt in conducting a projected $500,000 inquiry into monopolies.

The greatest Congressional cow-milking contest since Smith W. Brookhart challenged Magnus Johnson fourteen years ago ended in a dead heat today on Capitol Hill. The contest was held in the Capitol's west pasture, the mall, directly beneath the statue of General Grant, in recognition of his well-known fondness for the beverage.

A charge that G. Elroy Kemp of Mount Vernon, indicted State land agent for the Merritt Parkway, burned some of his papers and records connected with the parkway transactions during the grand jury investigation was made before Judge Alfred C. Baldwin in Superior Court today by State's Attorney Lorin W. Willis.

Mrs. F. J. Holleran and Mrs. P. F. Moore won in the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association's one-day tournament at the Tamarack Country Club today, Mrs. Holleran getting low gross with an 88 and Mrs. Moore the first low net with 91--14--77.

The general level of wholesale prices declined in the week ended on June 4, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, was 77.7 compared with 78.1 on May 28, and 87.1 on June 5, 1937.

One hundred and forty-four cadets who won insignia in Army Spring sports will receive their awards on Saturday, when the annual June Week program gets under way. In addition to distributing insignia, Brig. Gen. Jay L. Benedict,

Executives of-tea and grocery concerns in the East will gather today and tomorrow in the east building of New York University, Washington Square, for the first national merchandising forum on tea ever held in this country.

Up to this morning, with considerable of the Western Exchange bids still to be received, holders of the two issues of June and,September maturing Treasury notes had offered more than 97 per cent of their holdings for exchange,

Once again, this time in dealing with the O'Mahoney joint resolution to investigate monopolies, the Senate has voted to surrender to the Executive a fundamental and ancient prerogative of Congress. Once again, as on the Reorganization Bill,

What has been considered here as a kidnapping on an "American scale" proved to be an accident today when the bodies of two minor sons of the FrancoRussian Surgeon A. E. Simkow were discovered buried in a sandpit near Versailles.

A fair trial was not possible with the jury which recently convicted John R. Longo, anti-Hague Democrat, of election law violation, it is contended in a twenty-three page brief filed today with Judge Robert V. Kinkead by defense counsel in support of a pending motion for a new trial.

Herman Blumenau, head of the realty and insurance firm of L. Blumenau's Sons, Inc., in Brooklyn, which was established by his father, the late Levi Blumenau, in 1856, died on Wednesday night at his home, 2,220 Newkirk Avenue, at the age of 70.

MANHATTAN DITCHETT, SAMUEL R. (Jan. 12. 1938). Gross assets, $28,537; net, $27,074. To Anna A. Ditchett, widow, $10,175; Charlotte V Held and Sylvia K. Fuller, daughters, $8,449 each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $23,305. Tolbert, Ewen Patterson, attorneys, 45 Cedar St.
The General Telephone Corporation reported yesterday that its subsidiaries had a net gain of 1,978 telephones in service during May as compared with an increase of 3,133 instruments in May, 1937.

Presentation of the Paley Amateur Radio Award for 1937 was made yesterday at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to Robert T. Anderson, operator of amateur radio station W9MWC of Harrisburg, Ill. Mr. Anderson is the second recipient of the trophy,
Fears are expressed in many quarters that Anglo-Italian relations wilt soon become strained again if the unrestricted bombing continues in Spain as at present.

Josef Mostert, the Belgian middledistance runner who won fame a year ago by racing three-quarters of a mile in 3:00.4 for a world record, yesterday arrived in New York on the United States liner Manhattan.

A witness for the government was slain in Harlan, eighty miles away, today, while another witness was testifying here at the trial of coal operators and peace officers that bribes had been offered to him to forget that he had seen a killing.

The bonds and revenues of the Port of New York Authority are immune from Federal taxation, according to a statement issued yesterday by Frank C. Ferguson, chairman of the body. The recent decision of the Supreme Court in Helvering v. Gerhardt, requiring certain employes of the Port Authority to pay income tax, did not affect the immunity of the bonds and revenues, Mr. Ferguson said.

Purchases of securities in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on June 4, in which there. were only five trading days, exceeded sales by 14,619 shares. The turnover was unusually small, purchases aggregating only 379,297 shares, and sales 364,678 shares.
Julius A. Rippel, whose retirement as vice president of J. S. Rippel Co. will be announced today, plans to form his own investment business in Newark soon.

Special Notice New "large size" Department of Purchase,. Bureau of Stores, requisition forms (No. 23-B. S. 2) have been forwarded to-deputy chiefs of department for distribution to the various units in their respective divisions. Four sets (five sheets to a set) to each .nit.

Mariano Fanti, 38-year-old feather exporter, who was convicted of first-degree- manslaughter in Kings County Court on May 17 for shooting his secretary and business partner, Mrs. Bertha Nolan, 40, was sentenced yesterday to serve ten to twenty years in Sing Sing a Prison after his attorney had in- s formed the court of proposed financial arrangements for the support of the slain woman's two daughters.

Mrs. Ruth Michaud, 31 years old, ended her life by inhaling illuminating gas in the kitchen of her home at 2 Cedar Street last night and her husband, Richard Michaud, a baker, was nearly killed by the fumes in an attempt to rescue her, according to police.

J. P. Morgan made one of his rare public appearances last-night when he awarded diplomas to 128 graduates at the seventy-ninth annual commencement in the historic Great Hall of Cooper Union, of which he has been a trustee for more than twenty-five years.

MANHATTAN ARMSTRONG, H. WALLACE (May 30). Estate, less than $5,000. To Maude Armstrong, widow, executrix, Hotel Imperial. FISHER, HENRY (May 17). Estate, more than $10,000. To Anna F. Dawson, daughter, Hotel Ansonia. three-fourteenths of residue in trust;
Selfridge Co., Ltd., will open a threepenny, six-penny store same price range as Woolworth's] on Oxford Street on June 20, H. Gordon Selfridge told THE NEW YORK TIMES today.

Both furniture manufacturers and retailers are looking forward to a smaller ratio of decline in home wares sales this Fall than that which featured the Spring season, according to Neil.Petree, president of Barker Brothers Corporation, Los Angeles, operating one of the largest stores in the country selling all types of goods for the home.
Six parcels of improved property and two of vacan land in four boroughs have been sold by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company of Brooklyn, as principal.

William Dowd Meyer, in building under construction at 965 5th Ave, through Kensington Estates, Inc.; Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc., brokers. William A. C. Miller 3d, through Talman Bigelow, Inc.; penthouse in 1,035 Park Ave; Alan T. Schumacher through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., in 9 E 96th St; Frank Philgus in 50 E 78th St; Culver, Hollyday Co., Inc., broker.
