A German fugitive, Peter Foerster, is reported here to have been arrested at Hirschenstand, near the German frontier. He was one of two men who some weeks ago escaped from the Thuringen concentration camp after having killed a Storm Trooper who had been guarding them, according to the German press.
The Rev. Stephen D. Conrad, pastor of the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, has been elected head of the Peekskill Pastors Association, it was learned today.

Raymond Asa Kent, president since 1929 of the University of Louisville, has received an offer to be dean of New York University's School of Education and expects to confer in New York early next week with university officials, it was announced today.

A drastic downard revision of Winter wheat estimates will be necessary if reports received today from the Southwest receive definite confirmation. Experts are now finding that the crop was badly damaged by the three visitations of frost in the early Spring.

As one of the eleven defense lawyears began to argue yesterday on the evidence in the General Sessions trial of two women and nine men accused of a $2,000,000 conspiracy in sales of Slovak Manor property, Judge Cornelius F. Collins dismissed indictments against seven corporations in the case.

The auction sale of the twentythree story Manhattan Towers Hotel, scheduled for yesterday, after several previous postponements, was adjourned again yesterday to June 20. Two other properties in Manhattan were sold in the Vesey Street rooms. The details follow:

The Senate today approved and sent to the White House a House bill levying a tax of 25 cents per gallon on all floor stocks of liquor except brandies held on July 1. The tax, which would be applicable to State liquor dispensaries, was designed as a compensatory levy to meet the increase of 25 cents per gallon in the general tax on distilled liquors which will go into effect July 1.
Justice Department- officials gaped, then chuckled, today when Thurman W. Arnold, Assistant Attorney General in charge of antitrust cases, came to work in his "new" car.
Apartment houses and dwellings on the upper West Side, in Harlem and on Washington Heights, formed the bulk of realty deals reported yesterday in Manhattan.
Alvan Macauley, president of the Packard Motor Car Company, was reelected president of the Automobile Manufacturers Association at that organization's annual meeting here today.

Park P1, 21, 25x75; also 18 Murray St, 25x75; Elinor F. Morgenthau and Margaret F. Josten to Parplace Corp, 1 William St. Bowery, 266, 16.6x98.9; Gold Electric Sign Co, Inc., to Alexander J. Sparrow, 185 Montague St, Brooklyn; 1st mtg. $10,000, 2d $2,612.

After a conference on the railroad situation with President Roosevelt, Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today he saw no prospect of enactment of measures to aid the railroads at this session.

The Cities Committee of the Constitutional Convention has scrapped all of the existing proposals before it extendfng the home rule powers of New York and other cities and is now committed to clarification of those powers and limited rather than drastic extension of them.

Charles P. Northrop, for fortyfive years a New York attorney and a recognized authority on real property law, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital at the age of 71. Mr. Northrop's home was in Great Neck, L. I.
Harkness Edwards's new Dieselpowered auxiliary yawl Wakiva, which is seventy-two feet on- deck, was launched yesterday afternoon from the Jakobson Peterson yard in Brooklyn.

The wedding of Miss Nancy Betty Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Lay Davis of this city, to William Lewis Sachse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Sachse of Santa Barbara, Calif., took place here this afternoon in the garden of the Davis home. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Roy Martin Houghton of this city.

An unexpected bidder for honors in the Long Island amateur golf championship loomed today as Bob Johnke of Hempstead came home with a neat 36, 36-72 to win the medal from a field of sixty-four in the qualifying round over the Garden City Country Club course.

Dr. Chevalier Jackson, the Philadelphia bronchoscopist who has devoted half a century to saving the lives of thousands of children in various stages of strangulation caused by swallowing foreign objects, has decided virtually to abandon that career.

Butter, one of the most important items on the household shopping list, reached its lowest price in three years on the wholesale market a few days ago, and this drop already has been passed on to consumers. Butter now is only 29 cents a pound.

After announcing that he would close "The Circle" tomorrow night, Mr. Brady changed his mind yesterday and said that it would continue indefinitely at his Playhouse. Business, he declared, had improved.

A REPORT from Speculator, seemingly very favorable to the chances of Herr Max Schmeling in his coming debate with Joe Louis, sent this observer off on a hurried investigation of the Pompton Lakes area yesterday. It had to do with the bird situation in and around the rival heavyweight camps.

The total of loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City rose $465,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $7,947,000,000, the largest figure since Dec. 15, according to the weekly report issued yesterday.

Improvement of facilities for rapid radio communication between Scotland Yard and motor vehicles on patrol in the Metropolitan police district has been achieved by the introduction of small loud-speakers in police cars.

The threatened strike of employes of the Long Island Lighting Company and its operating subsidiaries, supplying electrical and power servlce in Nassau and Suffolk Counties and gas service to residents in the eastern section of Queens, was postponed last night until June 22

With a total of forty-four players riding on four fields, the Meadow Brook Club had one of its most active polo sessions today as various teams warmed up for the opening of the club's tournaments a week from Saturday.
ABOOK to borrow, if you're broke, or buy, if you are bogged in cash, is "I'm a Stranger Here Myself,"* the newest work of Ogden Nash.

Michael J. Hearn of New Brunswick, N. J., was elected captain of the 1939 Fordham baseball team by a vote of the lettermen yesterday. John F. Holian of New Haven, Conn., was named assistant manager for next season as Constant A. Debany of Brooklyn automatically stepped up to the managership.

The Citron amendment to the WalshHealey act, greatly broadening its scope, was sent to the House Judiciary Committee today by the Rules Committee. There it will be rewritten to conform to a similar measure which has Dassed the Senate.
Staunton Military Academy's seventyeighth commencement ended

During the week ended June 8 member bank reserve balances Increased $103,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $32,000,000 in money in circulation and $88,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks,

A lot of the discussion in Tresnwater fishing circles these days concerns the proposed formation of a Board of Fish and Game Commissioners in place of the present system, which places the Fish and Game Division under a single head, the Conservation Commissioner.

A $500,000,000O damage suit was filed in Chancery Court here late yesterday by the Howard-Vaughan Company of Niagara Falls, N. Y., against the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), General Motors Corporation, Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Ethyl Gasoline Corporation and the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Company.

While playing handball in a club tournament yesterday, Eric Peet, former national hand-ball champion of the Amateur Athletic Union, collapsed and died on a court at the Brooklyn Y. M. C. A., 55 Hanson Place, Brooklyn.
Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson ordered today the distribution of $918,365 to the holders of notes of the Corporation Securities Company of Chicago, bankrupt Insull investment company.

General Francisco Franco is intensifying his efforts to reach Sagunto and Castellon, and bitter fighting is raging from Teruel to near the Mediterranean coast. Despite desperate resistance the Insurgents again progressed 'today and they now claim to be not more than thirteen miles from Castellon.

The auction sale of the modern library of Robert Dunning Dripps of Germantown, Pa., which began on Monday, bought $1,368 at the closing afternoon session, and $857.25 during the afternoon, at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., 30OEast Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday.
McGraw-Hill will publish in September the fourth edition of "The Financial Organization of Society" by Harold G. Moulton, president of the Brookings Institution.

Lillian Hlavati, 20 years old, who was arrested for the murder of her 52-year-old father, John Hlavati, last Christmas day, pleaded guilty to a charge of manslaughter in the second degree yesterday in Bronx County Court before Judge Lester W. Patterson.

Jacobs, who pulled a nerve in her right arm and may be unable to play for two weeks, the United States women's tennis team was favored tonight at 5-1 to win the Wightman Cup for the eighth straight time in the two-day matches starting tomorrow.

Walter L. Bomer, vice president of the Bristol-Myers Company, will sneak at a luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Tuesday. Mr. Bomer returned recently, from a trip to Australia and New Zealand.

Magistrate Jenkin R. Hockert in Long Island City Court found two men guilty yesterday of distributing advertising handbills in such a way as to litter the ;streets. Mr. Hockert adjudged the defendants under Section 318 of the Sanitary Code.

Chairman Farley of the Democratic National Committee, who has the task of composing the differences in the Democratic party in Pennsylvania, is reported to have told Senator Guffey that he expects him to bring John'L. Lewis, head of the C. I. O., into line for the ticket on which Governor Earle is the nominee for Senator.

The Rev. Wilson S. Hartzell, retired Episcopalian clergyman, died today at his home here. He was 75 years old. Mr. Hartzell was born in Chalfonte, Pa., and was graduated from Pennington Seminary and from Franklin and Marshall College
The Board of Estimate moved ahead yesterday with the extension of the west side highway below Canal Street when it voted $20,000 for construction and alteration of the foundations and superstructure.

The Athletics spoiled Vernon Kennedy's bid for his tenth straightvictory today, handing the Detroit right-hander his first setback of the season. The Philadelphians scored, 8 to 5, with the help of Nelson Potter's great relief pitching in the ninth.

Fewer than 1,450 newly trained dentists, the smallest number in any year since 1921, are leaving college this month. according to the American Dental Association. The graduates from the country's thirty-nine dental colleges number .1,700, but 100 are foreign students.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., June 10, PATROLMEN-Reuben Leibowitz, from 71st Parecinct to 18th Division, assigned to duty as chauffeur. From precincts indicated to 18th Division, designated as third grade detectives:

Reports that have persisted for years that there was a secret clause in the Lansing-Ishii agreement of 1917between the United States and Japan concerning China were officially confirmed for the first time when the State Department tonight published two volumes of "Foreign Relations of the United States" for the year 1922.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday in a unanimous decision denied the petition of the Alleghany Corporation for an injunction to restrain the Guaranty Trust Company from voting impounded stock of the Chesapeake Corporation.

Close of play scores in English County cricket matches started Wednesday follow: Middlesex, 311 and 205 for seven wickets (Roberton 73); Hampshire, 245 (Walker 69, Smith six for 78); at Lord's. Kent, 400; Lancashire, 317 (Hopwood 141); at Manchester.
One of the periodic spurts in local traction obligations was the feature of another dull trading session in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
For the first' time in the history of the New York City Board of Education, the merit system has been extended to include administrative positions in the higher salary brackets.

Major-Thomas Gregory Tulloch, of the founders of the Palestine Potash Company, whose home at Kallia is 1,300 feet below sea level, died here today- at the age of 72. He formerly was aide to the viceroy of India.
Dr. Laurens Hickok Seelye, president of St. Lawrence University, will give the commencement address at Montclair Academy's fifty-first graduation tomorrow at 3:30 P. M. at Unity Church here.

Robert Augustus Young, New York attorney, employee of the united States Solicitor General's office during the administration of President Wilson and secretary of the American Claims Commission under Secretary of State Lansing, died here today at his home of a heart attack. He was 53 years old.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, in its report for the three months ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income of $2,299,336, compared with $1,658,438 for the corresponding period in 1937.
I. Newton Earle, principal of the Roosevelt Junior High School here since 1919, died yesterday at the Roosevelt Hospital, Metuchen,. of a heart attack. He was 53 years old.

Lord Stamp of Shortlands, better known in the United States as Sir Josiah Stamp, arrived yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan, a day after his name appeared in .the King's honor list as one of the empire's newest barons.

Miss Margaret June Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard James Martin of Greenwich, will be married to John Morrill Lashar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Benjamin Lashar of Fairfield, Conn., at Christ Episcopal Church on July 1.

Annual conference, Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the United States, 156 Fifth Avenue. 9:30 A. M. Continues to Monday. Luncheon, American Patriots, Hotel Iroquois, 49 West Forty-fourth Street, 12:30 P. M. Address by Mrs. Elizabeth Dilling.

Wool goods markets this week showed signs of improving, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. More repeat business was written on Fall men's wear suitings and initial orders were booked on some types of women's wear fabrics.
Giant Roderich Menzel of Czechoslovakia was the final barrier tonight between red-headed Don Budge of California and the second trick in his hoped-for tennis grand slam.
Mrs. Eve Beresford Clayton Bickford of Buffalo, who was barred from readmission to Great Britain recently after a trip to Germany, arrived here yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Each of the following Signal Corpa Reserve officers, is ordered to active duty, effective June 26, at Camp Dix, N. J., fot training: 2d Lt. Paul G. Bohlke. 1st Division, Rockefeller Hall, Ithaca, N. Y.

Inquiries which have come into the offices of the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement at 90 Park Avenue within the past ten days indicate that many property owners still are unfamiliar with the favorable terms and varied methods under which they may improve their old buildings.
Turpentine firm, 221/4c: sales 32 barrels; receipts 447 barrels; shipments 185 barrels; stock 35998 barrels. Resin firm; sales 215; receipts 2,355; shipments 104; stock 131,641.

Completing the third leg of an 8;600mile flight from San Diego, Calif., Richard Archbold and five companions put their "flying laboratory," the Cuba, down on the waters of Humboldt Bay, New Guinea, at 1:11 P. M. today. Their arrival from Wake Island was reported to the Pan American Airway station here.

After many delays Mayor Frank Hague finally will be called to the witness stand to account for his alleged violations of the Bill of Rights in Jersey City tomorrow, the seventh day of the trial of the suit by the C. I. O. anal the American Civil Liberties Union in the Federal Court for an injunction restraining the city au-. thorities from interfering with constitutional guarantees of C. I. O. organizers, members and sympathizers.

Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, issued today a statement on Section 810 of the Revenue Act of 1936 which is of concern to employers of eight or more persons who failed to make their contributions to State Unemployment Compensation funds for the calendar year 1936 before April 1, 1937.

Martha Feeley, Inc., millinery, in 6 ?? 53d St.; A. Sheldon Jaffe, broker. Congreve Jackson, real estate, in 342 Madison Ave., Benjamin Gitlow, letter service, in 1,650 Broadway; Hirsch Stieffel, in 193 Eldridge St.; Herbert Mclean Management Corp., broker.

Anne Shirley, the daughter in "Stella Dallas," is being borrowed from RKO by Metro for the leading feminine role in "Three Loves Has Nancy," which is tentatively set as Robert Montgomery's next starring vehicle.

The nine-room English type residence on a quarter-acre plot at 9 Lockwood Road, Scarsdale,. Westchester, has been sold by the.Irving Trust Company to Dr. Franz Staub through Louise o. Meuer, Inc., broker.

President Roosevelt signed the Federal State-aid highway construction bill providing $315,300,000 for the fiscal years 1940 and 1941; discussed plans for a $1,500,000 expansion program for the Charleston, S. C., navy yard with Senator Byrnes and Mayor Maybank of that city, and conferred with Governor Frank Murphy of Michigan on the relief situation in that State.

William Lurle, fourth-seeded, was eliminated from the Brooklyn tennis championship yesterday at the Terrace Club of Flatbush. Dr. Lawrence Kurzrok, veteran southpaw, gained a hard-earned fourth round victory over the clever little Brooklyn player, 6--4, 4--6, 7-5.

Newark College of Engineering will graduate 129 seniors, the second largest class in its history, at' its .sixteenth annual commencement exercises here tomorrow night. In addition, three graduates will receive professional degrees. The exercises will be in the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company auditorium.

Godfrey D. N. Haggard, British Consul General at Paris, has been appointed to succeed Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General at New York, it was announced today. Mr. Haggard will take up his new duties in the Autumn.

The Staten Island Edison Corporation has filed a declaration under the Public Utility Holding Company Act covering $2,000,000 of 4 per cent refunding and improvement bonds. The maturity date of the bonds had been extended to July 15, 1938, and the declaration proposes their further extension to July 1, 1939.

The New Hampshire Water Resources Board, an agency of the State of New Hampshire, has invited bankers to submit bids on Wednesday for $2,300,000 of bonds. Proceeds from the sale of these bonds will meet the cost of the board's initial project for controlling floods and regulating water on the upper Connecticut River.
Lumber production declined last week, but after allowance had been made for the holiday the index remained unchanged at 60.1. This compares with 95.8 for the week ended June 5, 1937.

Robert Watt, speaking for United States workers, put before the International Labor Conference today a more conservative view than it has been hearing from the workers of other countries, most of whom are Socialists.
Is only Soviet science fallible, or can it happen here, too? Violent earth tremors in distant lands have been recorded on the delicate instruments at the Yalta seismographic station in the Crimea.

Mayor La Guardia and Senator Wagner appealed to the housing committee of the Constitutional Convention today to draft a "progressive" amendment which would permit the State to extend its financial aid to a sweeping slum-clearance and housing program.

Marian Anderson, contralto, today will receive the degree of Doctor of Music from Howard University in Washington, D. C. Miss Anderson has just completed- a coast-to-coast tour and will sail Wednesday for a vacation on the Riviera before undertaking a tour in South America and then, in November, her fourth tour of this country.

Evidence of the alleged union boycott of products manufactured outside the city was offered yesterday in the. injunction: suit against Local, 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, through figures purporting to show that General Electric Company sales ..of switch and panel boards dropped from $475,512 in 1930 to $197 in 1937.

The trend of bank credit in the banks in this city was reversed with a vengeance this week. In contrast to the steady reduction in earning assets that had been reported recently, the local member banks showed the remarkable gain of $465,000,000 in loans and investments--a gain which, in one week, wiped out the entire decline of the previous six months.

A class of twenty-three was graduated yesterday at the 152d commencement exercises of the Friends Seminary in the Friends Meeting House, East Fifteenth Street and Stuyvesant Square. Dr. Lynn H. Hough, dean of Drew Theological Seminary, was the speaker.

Mrs. T. E. Beck and Mrs. Oscar Moore, the former Childress sisters of Scarsdale, won the only two singles matches played in the third annual women's invitation tennis tournament at the Manursing Island Club today.

President Paul W. Litchfield said today that the Goodyear Tire-and Rubber Company was willing to sign a contract with C. I. O.'s United Rubber Workers if it was "one under which the company can live" and "operate on an efficient competitive basis" with other manufacturing centers.

Millions of American tattlers ana mothers can go to bed tonight sure that by the lav of averages their children run but an infinitesimal chance of sharing the fate of James Bailey Cash Jr. or Peter Levine. Street accidents and preventable disease are a thousand times the menace that kidnapping is.
Jimmy DeShong pitched the Senators today to their only victory in the three-game series with the Browns. The score. was 6 to 4. DeShong hurled four-hit ball for eight innings.

Owing to a prolonged strike in this country's herring fisheries industry, which usually supplies a third of the European Continent's needs, all stocks are now exhausted. Exporters have been forced to purchase several thousand tons at high prices from Great Britain in order to fulfill their obligations.

Rivalry between the Associated Gas and Electric Company and the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey will come to a head in the next few months when the systems will enter bids at public auction for 712,411 shares of Jersey Central Power and Light Company common stock.

Dr. William Everett Jonah died yesterday at his home here after long illness at the age of 64. Dr. Jonah was born in Eastport, Me.; studied in Acadia University, Nova Scotia, and in Bowdoin College and practiced at the Lying-In Hospital, New York, and Kensington Hospital, Philadelphia. He came here thirty-three years ago.

The Bureau of Internal Revenue's experiment with decentralization in Los Angeles has been so successful that regional offices will be opened in New York on Aug. 1 and in Chicago on Sept. 1, Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury announced today.

Unless business men act at once to eliminate the evils prevalent in their relations with the consuming public, government agencies "will step In and saddle industry with laws and regulations" to solve the problem, William Fellowes Morgan Jr.,

The National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers issued today its monthly report on style trends based on a survey of the trade. It follows: "Fancy back suits continue to slide out of the style picture, and by Fall -many stores throughout the country do not even intend to stock them.

Details of a $7,000,000 loan by the Great Northern Railway Company from the First National Bank of New York are set forth in a letter dated June 2 by F. G. Dorety, vice president and general counsel of the railroad, on file with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 7: REAR ADMIRALS .Marquart. E. J., to Naval Operations, Navy Department, Washington, D. C.. orders of Jan. 15 to Naval War College revoked. Butler, C. S., Medical Corps, to duty as president of Naval Retiring Board, the Board of Medical Examiners, and the Naval Examining Board for officers of Medical Corps, Navy Department, Washington, D. C., July 1;

The detailed plan of merger of the Allegheny Steel Company and the Ludlum Steel Company, to be voted on by stockholders of the respective companies on Aug. 10, shows that W. F. Detwiler, president of Allegheny, is to be chairman, and Hiland G. Batcheller, president of Ludlum, Is to be president of the consolidated company.

The dean's honor list at the College of Mount St. Vincent, Riverdale, was anounced yesterday for the academic year just-closed. In the senior '-class the' list included Catherine V. Connolly, Marjorie D. Coogan, Charlotte M. Crawford, Dolorita M. Curry, Marion I. Donnellan, Kathryn D. Dorris, Margaret M. Fleming, Margaret M.
Dr. W. F. Mumberg, who served as an orthopedic physician at Bellevue Hospital in New York sixty years ago, died of a heart ailment in his home here today at the age of 97.

Justin Sturm, prominent-sculptor and writer, has purchased a hilltop tract consisting of eighteen acres in West Redding, Conn., from Robert Rider. Mr. Sturm plans to erect a studio from his own designs on the property. William E. Hawkins Jr. was the broker.

Charles Clinton Marshall, retired New York City lawyer and the churchman who provided a memorable controversy in 1927 when he challenged Alfred E. Smith's qualifications to become President as a Roman Catholic, died this morning at his estate, Milestone,

Yale's rowing -squad arrived from New Haven about 6 o'clock this evening,- coming down Long Island Sound aboard the Diesel-powered yacht Wild Duck, with her owner, Charles B. Levey of New York, as. host. Also aboard the yacht were Samuel Atkinson, Cord Meyer and Gus Blagden, veteran Yale oarsmen, and the new squad physician, Dr. J. S. Hathaway.

Extensive alterations will be made in the eight-story and penthouse apartment building at 12 and 14 East Eighty-seventh Street, which has been sold by the Sagamore Land Corporation, Walter G. Nelson, president, to Morris Hanlon, president of the Manchester Construction Corporation.

The fat lamb market continued its severe downturns today, with some sales as much as $1 lower on native Spring lambs at $10 down. Fed steers and yearlings held steady, steers topping at $10.75. Hogs ruled active, with top at $9.10, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

The wages of 14,000 WPA clerical workers in this city will be revised, with the "overwhelming majority" getting pay cuts, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday.

Miss Helen Elizabeth Flanders, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph E. Flanders, was married this afternoon to Dr. William Whitney Ballard of Hanover, N. H., at Smiley Manse, the home of her parents here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Raymond A. Beardslee of Springfield, who was assisted by the Rev. Lyndon Beardslee of Westboro, Mass., uncle of the bride.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The great mass of liberty-loving, peace-loving democratic American people certainly accept and whole-heartedly endorse Secretary Hull's remarkable address urging cooperative action for peace before the Tennessee Bar Association.

Bank clearings in the twenty-two leading cities of the United- States in the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $5,887,185,000, compared with $5,552,249,000 in the corresponding week last year, an increase of 6 per cent, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Cooper Square Park, redesigned and reconstructed, green with newly planted shrubbery and gayly bedecked with bunting, was reopened to the public yesterday afternoon by the Department of Parks with music and speeches.

Mrs. Mary E. Baker, who during the World War was director of the hospital supplies service of the Atlantic division of the Red Cross, died of a heart ailment on Wednesday at her home, 606 West 113th Street. Mrs. Baker was the widow of Louis A. Baker, who died in 1934. The couple had no children.

Orlando W. Eggleston, retired, who was a superintendent of construction on the Panama Canal project and a former roadmaster for the New York Central Railroad, died Tuesday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Edna Gallup, on Dutchess Turnpike, at the age of 82.

Dr. Jesse B. Norton, internationally known plant pathologist, died here today at the age of 60. Associated with the Imperial County Agricultural Department twelve years, Dr. Norton was credited with originating the type

Contract awards for the construction of highways in nine States this week raised the volume for this classification to its highest point in five years, with a total of $18,077,000. They were largely responsible for a rise of 47 per cent in public construction over the same period of last year, and of 10.5 per cent in the total of all awards, as compared with the 1937 week, according to The Engineering News-Record.

Although local French fishermen are regarded as Spanish Loyalist supporters they refuse to permit Spanish refugees to take their jobs, so they are threatening a general strike and "reprisals" unless owners of smacks at Hendaye, France, cease employing more than a limited number of these Spanish hands.

All the dire predictions made about the hazards of the Cherry Hills course, scene of the forty-second national open golf championship, came true today when the field of 165 contestants played the first eighteen-hole round of the event.

To demonstrate that steam remains supreme in railway transport, the New York Central Railroad operated from Albany to New York yesterday a streamlined edition of its Twentieth Century Limited behind a locomotive which, in trial runs, had attained a speed of 123 miles an hour.

The Corporation of the Brick Presbyterian Church assigned to the trustees of tile will of Amos R. Eno a mortgage for $40,000 on 37-39 Murrsy St. When Wilfred A. and George J. Openbym sold to Teresa Bernard the house at 116 W 88th St. 15 1/2 ft wide; for $12,000 they tools back a p. m. mortgage for $7,500, due five years Lense at 5 per cent, amortized $50 quarterly.

A two-run rally in the ninth gave the Jersey City Giants a 4-to-3 victory over Toronto today. Frank Reiber's home run in the first half of the ninth with Fred Petoskey on base had wiped out a 2-1 Giant lead, but in their half

President Roosevelt and the New Deal have "utterly failed" to attain 90 per cent of their major objectives, said Dr. Harry W. Laidler, State chairman of the Socialist party in New York State, in an address at the opening session tonight of the annual conference of the League for Industrial Democracy.

The body of Louis Drouin, 58 years old, proprietor of the Melody Music Shop, 59 West Fifty-first Street, was found yesterday morning hanging from a rope in the rear of his store, where he sold and repaired stringed instruments.

With all districts participating in the decline, department store sales throughout the country declined 17 per cent in May from May, 1937, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board.

Shipments of $3,279,000 gold from Europe were received here yesterday, the consignments consisting of $2,714,000 from England to the Bank of the Manhattan Company, and $565,000 from the Netherlands to the Guaranty Trust Company.

The Chicago - owned Shandon Farm, noted for the skill with which the veteran trainer J. J. Greely conditions his horses, won two in a row at Aqueduct yesterday, including the featured Premier Handicap, wherein Gold Flag was first.
President Roosevelt is going to cross the continent next month over an itinerary which will enable him to put in a few words for New Deal candidates for renomination.

Gloria Ware, 18-year-old Brooklyn soprano, Will make her debut singing the role of Micaela in "Carmen" at the Lewisohn Stadium on July 14 and 15 with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, it was announced by the Stadium Concerts, Inc. It will be her first public appearance.

The comedy team of Joe Smith and Charles Dale, whose last appearance in a legitimate Broadway attraction was two years ago in "Summer Wives," are the principal entertainers in the Loew's State Theatre's new vaudeville show this week.

An emphatic protest on the bombing of Lingnan University at Canton was lodged at Tokyo yesterday by the United States. Ambassador Grew conveyed ' Washington's expectation that the incident would not be repeated. Japanese planes spared Canton, but bombed near-by railway stations. [Page 1.]

Miss Celina Robbins, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Bradford Robbins of Boston and Ipswich, was married to Edmund Kellogg this afternoon in King's Chapel by the Rev. Endicott Peabody of Groton and the Rev. Palfrey Perkins.

The fortnightly statement of the Centrial Bank of Argentina for May 31 showed that the ratio of the gold reserve to notes in circulation had increased from 121.43 per cent on May 15 to 122.43 per cent. The reserve ratio of gold to notes and sight liabilities rose from 83.01 to 85.72 per cent.

White, Weld Co., as fiscal agents for city of Cordoba (Argentina) ? per cent dollar bonds due on Aug. 1, 1957, have demanded from officials of that city full payment of principal and interest of the loan and have instituted legal proceedings in the Argentine courts to attach all revenues pledged in the loan contract.

Approximately $5,666,000 will be spent in the United States this year in advertising the vacation attractions of 125 countries, States and resorts, according to a book titled "The Tourist Dollar" published this week by the Wales Advertising Company.

A crowd of 5,000, one of the largest ever at a boxing show at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn, last night saw Pete Cara, 138, Bensonhurst, defeat Pete Mascia, 140, Williamsburgh, in the feature eight-round bout. Sharper punching in the closing rounds gave Cara the verdict.

Formation of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Pollard Co. is to be announced today, with I. B. Pollard and Arthur J. Pollard as partners. The firm will maintain offices at 120 Broadway and will clear through L. F. Rothschild Co.
Charles Dunning, Dominion Finance Minister, gave notice today to the House of Commons of a resolution preliminary to a bill to nationalize the Bank of Canada.

The city Health Department's program to consolidate, centralize and relocate--child health stations for families of low incomes moved forward yesterday when ground was broken at Mount Morris Parkby the PA for the-construction of the seventh-modern- one-story baby health station.

Relief pitcher Mace Brown limited the Bees to two hits in seven innings and got a scratch single with the score tied and the bases full in the sixth today to give the Pirates a 5-to-3 victory and help them sweep the two-game series.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 8: COLONEL Kobbe, H., Cavalry, Fort Des Moines, Iowa, to Los Angeles High Schools, Los Angeles, July 5. LIEUTENANT COLONELS Cheadle, H. B., Infantry, 5 days leave, Jun 11.

The Theatrical Artists Representatives Association, the leading organization of theatrical agents, whose members represent many stages and screen stars, pledged their cooperation yesterday to Paul Moss, City Commissioner of Licenses, in his current drive to "eliminate chiselers' from the field.
Residents of the Belle Haven section of Greenwich lost a preliminary skirmish today for lower taxes, but they immediately began rallying. for what some said promised to be along battle..

John A. Russell, Kane County lawyer, banker and Republican leader, died at his home late yesterday at the age of 83. Mr. Russell was admitted to the bar in 1879, was a former Corporation Counsel for Elgin,
Promoter, one of the favorites for the Hambletonlan at Goshen, Aug. 10, was withdrawn today from the 3-year-old trotting classic by his owner and trainer, Dr. Hugh M. Parshall of Urbana, Ohio.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx accused his colleagues on the Board of Estimate yesterday of trying to inject a Fusion spoils system into the Board of Education, when they approved a resolution creating eight new positions in the construction division of the Education Department.

Following a three-hour debate the House voted today to unseat Representative Arthur B. Jenks, Republican, of New Hampshire, and give his place to Alphonse Roy, increasing the Democratic total to 328 and reducing Republican membership to 89.

Sir Arthur Spurgeon, publisher, whose wireless dispatches from the Carmania brought the first news of the burning of the Volturno with a loss of 136 lives in midatlantic on Oct. 11, 1913, died today in Woldingham, Surrey, at the age of 77.

St. John's Prep clinched the Brooklyn C. H. S. A. A. baseball championship yesterday when St. Michael's Diocesan High bowed to St. Augustine's High, 5 to 1, at the Prospect Park Parade Grounds. St. Michael's was held to three hits by George Klein, winning pitcher, who struck out eight.

Speakers before the Edison Electric Institute here today charged the government with complete responsibility for the depression, but told business, on the other hand, to do less complaining and tackle the task of reconstruction.

Duties collected on imported liquors in April amounted to $2,415,686 as compared with $3,363,102 in the same month last year, James H. Moyle, Commissioner of Customs, said today. Stocks of imported distilled liquors in bonded customs warehouses at the end of April were 3,616,086 proof gallons, as compared with 3,755,008 in April, 1937;
The Red Sox backed Lefty Grove with a fourteen-hit attack today but he didn't need it for he blanked the Indians, 8 to 0, to become the year's first pitcher to-win ten games in the major leagues.

The House Rules Committee voted today to report a bill authorizing the War Department 'to conduct a $2,000,000 development program in planes of the autogiro type. A similar measure was reported favorably today by the Senate Military Affairs Committee.

The stock markets here were quiet and generally weak today. Gilt-edge issues suffered a setback, while in the idle foreign section German bonds were firm. Transatlantic shares improved on better advices from Wall Street and United States Steel went ahead.

The law regulating political and social crimes, that went into -effect last midnight, defines grounds for the expulsion of foreigners from Brazil. The law is the result of the government's receipt action in outlawing foreign political organizations.
Mr. and Mrs. Philip D. Cunningham of this place have announced the engagement ef their daughter, Miss Emily Cunningham, to James Taylor Clark 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Clark Jr. of Newark.
Protest and indignation against bombardment of the Spanish civil population were declared "justified" by the Osservatore Romano, the Vatican newspaper, in its news summary of the Spanish war today.

Between 75,000 and 100,000 children marched in Brooklyn yesterday in the 109th annual parades of the borough's Sunday School Union. Dressed in gay Summer costumes and carrying inspirational banners in keeping with the parade's theme, "Witnessing for Christ," the youngsters marched in twenty-eight divisions before some 200,000

The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended June 9, dated June 8, were announced today: BRIGADIER GENERAL Meade, J. J., when Jischarged from Naval Hospital, Washington, D. C., detached headquarters and ordered to Marine Corps Base, San Diego, as commanding general Base Troops.

Among the gifts aboard the new motor liner Oslofjord of the Norwegian America Line, which is on her way to New York on her maiden transatlantic crossing, is a cushion cover executed in an ancient weaving technique, which will be presented to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

The New York Stock Exchange has stricken from listing and registration the following securities: Grand Union Company--Voting trust certificates for common stock. $1 par value. This security was suspended from dealings on June 2 at the expiration of the voting trust and the common stock was listed on the same day.

The governmental press unanimously launched a campaign today against the Socialist labor unions. It urged their replacement by national organizations not founded on the principle of class warfare. It is reported that the government is preparing a measure against the Socialist unions and that the press campaign is designed to pave the way for it.

An increase in net income of the theatre-operating companies of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation for the first quarter- of this year over the same period in 1936 was revealed yesterday at a hearing on the amended reorganization plan for R.-K.-O. before George. W. Alger, special master, in the Bar Building, 36 West Forty-fourth Street.
Minimum prices under the Ohio Fair Trade Law will be set by the General Food Sales Company, Inc., effective June 27, in that State, Austin S. Igleheart, president, announced here yesterday.

" I am for Mayor Hague 100 per cent," Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens said last night in a speech to more than 400 delegates to the annual convention of the Queens County Council of the Veterans of Foreigan Wars.

After moving cautiously until early afternoon yesterday, the stock market broke out of its narrow trading range and advanced briskly. Closing prices were at or near the day's best levels. Many leading industrial issues were up 1 to 2 points on the day, and a few showed wider gains; railway stocks, as a group, were laggard. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was 587,000 shares. compared with 278,000 the day before. Bonds closed irregular.
Brig. Gen. Asa L. Singleton, commandant of Fort Benning, said today that Major John R. Brooke Jr. was under guard at the post hospital pending further investigation into the death of his wife, Betty.

Prince Fumimaro Konoye, Premier; Seihin Ikeda, Minister of Finance, and General Kazushige Ugaki, Foreign Minister, held a conference today to determine Japan's future campaign in China, particularly in view of the removal further inland of the Chinese Government.
Movements of vessels follow. All dates are June 9 unless specified. Barry, San Diego to San Francisco. Charleston, at Panama City. Hannibal, at Norfolk. Helm, Hampton Roads to Navy Yard, Boston.

Froebel Academy, 176 Brooklyn Avenue, Brooklyn, will hold commencement exercises for a graduating class of sixteen tonight in the Community House of St. Bartholomew's Church, 1,227 Pacific Street, Brooklyn. Dr. Charles U. Clark of City College will speak. The graduates are:

Mrs. Sadie Leslie Monssen, widow of an American naval hero, who faces eviction from her Brooklyn home under a HOLC mortgage, yesterday received an offer from a broadcasting concern to tell -her story over the radio Sunday evening.

For more than five hours yesterday Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora listened to vigorous arguments on the motions of counsel for James J. Hines, Tammany leader of the lower West Harlem district, for a change of venue

An organization to be known as the George Washington Bridge Toll Reduction Association filed incorporation papers with the county clerk today, the second group of its kind to organize in Northern New Jersey in the last few weeks.

Joseph A. Padway, counsel for the American Federation of Labor, was directed by William Green, president of the federation, today to appeal, to the Supreme Court if necessary the anti-picketing injunction issued in Philadelphia.

When Alexander B. Beverly, Vincent E. Ferretti and all other prospective buyers of the Continental Securities Corporation "walked out on" the deal one day in October, last, Lansing McVicker told the Securities and Exchange Commission investment trust hearing yesterday, he telephoned Carl Fuller of the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation and asked to be relieved of all responsibility. Mr.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on May 28 totaled 301,583,000 barrels, according to figures compiled by the Bureau of Mines.
Seventy-five members of the Vassar College faculty, headed by Dean C. Mildred Thompson, asked IPresident Roosevelt tonight to explain the United States' foreign pol. icy with respect to Spain.
With Greg Mulleavy connecting for two homers and a double, Buffalo scored its third victory in a row over the league-leading Newark Bears today. The score was 13 to 3.
President Roosevelt's request that the new WPA appropriation be Increased to $1,425,000,000 won approval of a Joint Senate-House committee late today.

Heavy rains extending over the entire north side of the island have broken a drought of more than six months, filling irrigation reservoirs and insuring water for next year's cane crop, which has been retarded by dryness.

Sir George Thomas, former British titleholder and many times champion of the City of London Chess Club, assumed the lead in the international chess masters tournament tonight. In the second round Dr. S. Tartakower, captain of Poland's international team at Stockholm, bowed before the Englishman, using a Sicilian defense.
Contracts for the purchase of 400 airplanes in the United States for use in the Royal Air Force have been completed, the Air Ministry announced today.

The Board of Transportation awarded yesterday to the Otis Elevator Company, at a bid price of $133,128, the contract for providing and installing additional passenger escalators at several stations on the Independent Subway System.

The Duchess Armand de Richelieu entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Pavillon Marguery for Mrs. Hamilton McK. Twombly, Mrs. Lewis Gawtry, Mrs. J. Sergeant Cram, Mrs. Arthur W. Little, Mrs. William Adams Kissam, Mrs. Pierre C. Cartier, Mrs. Allen M. Thomas and Mrs. Ansel Phelps.
The Finance Ministry is expected to permit the importation of 200 American motion picture films worth $30,000 before the end of this year, although a definite decision has not yet been announced.

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh are settling down in. their new home on remote Iiliec Island, off the coast of Brittany. After quitting Long Barn, theirKentish home in England for twoand-one-half years, they crossed the English Channel yesterday to the: northwest coast of France.

Gerard B. Lambert, retired manufacturing chemist of St. Louis, -has become a special adviser to Stuart McDonald, Federal Housing Administrator, without compensation. Before he became head of the company that bears his name, Mr. Lambert studied architecture.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustment.

An extra dividend of 25 cents together with the regular quarterly payment of 50 cents a share on the Class A stock, and a dividend of 25 cents on the Class B stock were voted- yesterday by the American Bakeries Corporation, Atlanta.
American Telephone and Telegraph Company-April and four months to April 30:

The material task of raising funds to build the projected Temple of Religion as a spiritual center for millions of visitors to the World's Fair was advanced yesterday at a luncheon in the Bankers Club, at which business and financial leaders representing the three major faiths constituted themselves a citizens' executive committee to help build the edifice.

Paragraph 3, Section 2, of the National Labor Relations Act provides that the term employee " * * shall include any individual whose work has ceased as a consequence of, or in connection with, any current labor dispute or because of any unfair labor practice, and who has not obtained any other regular and substantially equivalent employment.

Forty-one young men will be ordained to the priesthood tomorrow morning beginning at 8 o'clock in St. Patrick's Cathedral by Cardinal Hayes. The ordination ceremony, which takes place annually in the cathedral the Saturday before Trinity Sunday, usually takes about three hours.

G. M.-P. Murphy Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, will announce soon the closing of branch offices in five cities, the retirement of some of their sixteen partners and concentration on the investment and underwriting phase of financial business.

Colonel James A. Moss, U. S. A., retired, who is president general 4f the United States Flag Day Association, charged yesterday that "Greater New York is the greatest hot-bed of foreign-isms in the United States," and "it is the national headquarters of nearly every subversive group in the country."
Joe Louis looked like anything but a world's champion today as he went through another sixround drill for his heavyweight title scrap with Max Schmeling in the Yankee Stadium, New York, June 22.

Premier Milan Hodza this morning received three leaders of Konrad - Henlein's Sudeten German party, Deputies Ernst Kundt, Franz Peters and Franz Roche. In the afternoon there was a meeting of the Cabinet's political committee at which a number of questions were discussed, including, of course, that of negotiations with the leaders of the minority nationalities.

With "White Iris," a-one-act play by Roberta Shannon, the Community Workers Auxiliary of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind last night won the Spring drama tournament sponsored by the Federal Theatre Project.

Dudley Leavitt Pickman, a trustee of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, in his youth a noted mountain climber and author of "Some Mountain Views," died today at his home, 98 Beacon Street. His age was 87.

The Board of Estimate made two exceptions yesterday to its general rule of retiring city employes at 70 years -when it granted a two-year extension to Frederick J. H. Kracke, chairman of the Board of Assessors, and a one-year extension to Edward J. McLaughlin, senior accountant. in the Mayor's office.

Formation of the National Council for the Promotion of Father's Day as a permanent advisory body, which will act as a central clearing house for the raising of funds necessary for the proper promotion of: the event, was announced yesterday following a meeting at the offices of the National Father's Day Committee, 515 Madison Avenue.

No sooner had the 1938 Legislature recessed at 2 oclock this morning than reports circulated in the Capitol that South Jersey Republicans might test in the courts appointments made by Governor Moore to the new Local Government Advisory Board.

Colonel Bill Terry's Giants, who appear given to doing things in an amazingly streaky fashion, went streaking out of here today and headed once more in the right direction. To the great dismay of 14,317 onlookers, they streaked three runs

The Administration is not in the coal business and has no intention of going into it, Pleas E. Greenlee, member of the National Bituminous Coal Commission, asserted today before the annual convention of the American Retail Coal Association,.
None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low figure for the year, but the ratio of reserve at the New York bank was at a new high point for 1938.

Exports of hardwood and softwood lumber, including logs, boards and planks, amounted to 333,000,000 board feet in the first four months of the current year, compared with 466,000,000 board feet in the corresponding period of last year, the Forest Products Division of the Department of Commerce announced today.

The three-story apartment building at 112-14 Sixteenth Street, West New York, N. J., has been purchased by the Polk Realty Company, Inc., from the Hoboken Bank for Savings for investment through J. I. Kislak, Inc., brokers.

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended June 8 were announced. today; COMMANDER Kielhernt, L. V., Boston Division, to Headquarters, July 15. JUNIOR LIEUTENANTS Carlson, E. V., the Northland, to the 'Duane, engineering duty, Oct. 1. Giffin A. H., the Dione, to the Mendota.

Willie Turnesa of Fairview, defending champion, led a field of sixty-three in the qualifying round of the Westchester amateur golf championship over the course of the Metropolis Country Club today, posting a 72, one over par.

Japanese forces have taken over the city of Chengchow, junction of the Peiping-Hankow and Lung-Hal railways, according to reports received here today. The Chinese were said to have completed their withdrawal from the city last night.

The latest complaint based on alleged violation of a local ordinance prohibiting the distribution of handbills was dismissed here today when Police Magistrate Salvatore T. Gambino ruled that union handbills were not advertising and found Jerry C. S. Rossi, organizer of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers Union, not guilty.

Word from Akron, Ohio, that the Common Pleas Court there had sustained the contention of candy manufacturers that their product is a food and therefore not subject to a State excise tax on luxuries brought cheers from delegates attending the closing session of the fifty-fifth annual convention of the National Confectioners Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

Bronx Eastern Blvd, a side, 450 ft ?? of Rush Ave, 1-story cinder block garage, auto repair and gas station, 450x100; Robitsek investing - Co, Inc, Hazel Moevus, president, 117 Kirby Place owner; L. M. Rothman, architect; cost, $60,000.

Charles S. Morris, president. of the Rotary Club of New York for 1937-38, was honored yesterday by members of the organization -at a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore. Representatives of rotary clubs in other countries were among the 400 persons present.

Mrs. Leita Wheeler Pearce of Harlei, Haverford, widow of Henry G. Pearce, was married this afternoon to Jonathan Patterson Edwards of Ardmore. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Eugene Kelly in the rectory of St. Colman's Church at Ardmore. The bride was unattended. George W. Edwards was best man for his brother.

Hans Wilhelm Steinberg, exiled German conductor who prepared the Palestine Symphony Orchestra for its concerts under the baton of Arturo Toscanini, arrived yesterday to begin his work as a conductor of the National Broadcasting Company under the Italian maestro.

Having searched Europe for something both sensational and artistic to contribute to the World's Fair, New York, 1939, Morris Gest announced today -he had signed up most of the Lilliputian population of the world for transport to the Flushing grounds for the duration of the fair.

Edwin H. Bellis, Sheriff of Montgomery County, died of pneumonia last night at his home in Jenkintown. He was 56 years old. He was Republican leader of Jenkintown, where he had been active in politics and civic affairs for twenty years.

Miss Helena de Kay Gilder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rodman Gilder, was married to Dr. Robert Allan Phillips of Clear Lake, Iowa, this afternoon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Lyman C. Bleecker, rector of St. John's Episcopal Church of Cold Spring Harbor, at the home of the bride's parents in Laurel Hollow.

American business has "no time to lose" if it wishes to avert complete regimentation by government and must organize without delay to combat far-reaching plans for such regimentation now in contemplation in Washington, George H. Davis of Kansas City, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, told more than 1,000 business man and industrialists yesterday at a luncheon of the Merchants Association of New York at the Hotel Astor.

The bond business today will be transferred from Wall Street to Westchester, when almost 500 investment bankers and bond dealers will desert the financial district for the eighteenth annual field day of the Bond Club of New York at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club.

R. H. Goffe Jr. won the major share of the honors at the New York Athletic Club's monthly one-day golf tournament staged over the links of the North Hempstead Country Club today. More than eighty members and guests participated in the affair, which was designated the Country Store Tournament and sponsored by Fred Paulsen.

Miss Lorena Brooks Rowe, daughter of Mrs. James Gordon Rowe Jr. of this place, became the bride this morning of James Aloysius Corroon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Corroon of Massapequa, L. I. The ceremony, which was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Edward M. Farrell in the Church of the Immaculate Conception, was followed by a reception at the Montclair Golf Club.

Mrs. Maria Griebl was jailed last night as a material witness in the spy investigation after she had completed arrangements to rejoin her, husband, Dr. Ignatz T. Griebl, former Nazi leader wanted as a spy, who fled to Germany.

Formation of the Industrial Research Institute, composed of a group of leading research executives and aimed to put industrial research on a business basis, was announced yesterday by Maurice Holland, acting executive of the institute.

The emergence of a credo that understanding of their own communities, based on Investigation of their facilities, leads. to constructive contributions in civic work featured the sectional conference of the American Association of University Women here today.

The petition presented to Parliament by J. F. Pouliot, Quebec Liberal, asking for annexation of a small-corner of the State of Maine to Canada, has not been accepted because "it is defective in form and in substance;" it was disclosed today.

Senator Joseph T. Robinson, who died last July, left an estate of $35,521.74, an inventory filed by his widow in Probate Court today showed. The inventory listed real estate valued at $13,475; personal property $17,288.74, and "books, papers and evidences of debt," valued at $4,758.

Crushing all opposition, the Westchester County Republican Committee, in convention this afternoon at the Playland Casino here, unanimously endorsed former Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley of Yonkers for the office of county executive, popularly known as president.

With only a small group of friends and relatives attending, Miss Martha Atwood, former Metropolitan Opera singer, and George R. Baker, New York banker, were married this afternoon in the bride's Cape Cod home.

Miss Barbara Whitcomb King, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Earle King of this place, was married here tonight to Lieutenant Enrique D'Hamel Haskins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elias H. Haskins of Brooklyn, in St; Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. George Lawton Barnes.

Congressional adjournment was reset today for not earlier than next Tuesday as the result of a deadlock in the Wage and Hour Bill conference committee and lack of progress among the relief-recovery bill conferees.

The northwest corner of the Grand Concourse and 172d Street, a plot 141 by 184 feet, has been sold by Vincent Astor to the 831 Gerard Avenue Realty Corporation, Julius Wikler, president. H.' Herbert Lilien, architect, has prepared plans for improving the plot with an eight-story apartment house to cost $425,000.

A threat of inflation in the government's current monetary policy was seen today by Howard H. Preston, professor at the University of Washington, Seattle, speaking before the National Association of Credit Men.

The Annalist reported yesterday that wholesale commodity prices had in the week ended on Wednesday their widest advance since the middle of September and that its index reached 80.5, compared with 79.8, the lowest point since 1936, the week before and 92.8 a year ago.

Insulin and metrazol, drugs with which remarkable cures of persons afflicated with the schizophrenic type of insanity have been obtained, cause a marked lowering of the flow of the blood in the brain, it was reported to the American Psychiatric Association in session here today.
Commencement exercises for seventy boy students in the twelve grades of the Grace Church School for Boys will take place at 3:15 P. M. today in the library, of the school at 88 Fourth Avenue.

Colonel William Henry Langhorne, last of three brothers of the five Langhorne sisters, who ineluded Lady Astor and Mrs. Charles Dana Gibson, died this morning at University of Virginia Hospital, after an illness of fourteen months, spent mainly at the Blue Ridge Tuberculosis Sanatorium, near Charlottesville. His age was 55.

Miss Patricia Lavelle, youngest niece of Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, Vicar General of the Archdiocese of New York and for fifty-two years rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, was married in the Lady Chapel of the cathedral yesterday morning to Dr. Basil Cuddihy of Montreal. Mgr. Lavelle performed the ceremony and was the celebrant of the nuptial mass which followed.

New stock companies to the number of 6,899 were chartered in the State this year to June 1, according to figures released today by the Division of Corporations of the Department of State. This total is compared with 8,418 for the same period in 1937.

Luise Rainer, twice designated as having given the best performance for a film actress during a year, in "The Great Ziegfeld" and "The Good Earth," today filed suit for divorce from Clifford Odets, playwright, whom she quoted as saying that "there can be only one career in a family." She charged that he caused her mental suffering.

Police drove ahead with the Jimmy Cash kidnapping investigation today, not satisfied that the case had been solved by the arrest of Franklin Pierce McCall, finding of the boy's body and recovery of $10,000 ransom money.

The Senate took less than two hours this afternoon to pass a flood control bill Involving authorizations for expenditures of more than $576,000,000. It thus cleared its program so that, except for future consideration of conference reports, it had' only one major piece of legislation

Some 2,000 designers and craftsmen are expected to attend an "open house for designers" at the World's Fair site on Tuesday, when Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, will speak on "The New York World's Fair, 1939--The Opportunity of a Lifetime for American Designers," and Robert D. Kohn, chairman of the theme committee of the Board of Design, will speak on "The Far-Reaching Influence of Good Design."

Mrs. Lotta Crabtree. Dearden, wife of Robert R. Dearden Jr., publisher of The United States Review, an insurance trade nagazine, died today at her home in Oak Lane at the age of 62. She was identified with civic affairs and the Republican Women of Pennsylvania.

Dr. Frank Kingdon, president of the University of Newark, conferred degrees tonight upon 202 graduates at the fourth annual joint commencement of the university's College of Arts and Sciences. School of Business Administration and School of Law at the Mosque Theatre here.
Four seasoned campaigners of women's golf. put on the pressure where it was needed today and played their way into the semi-finals of the twelfth annual trans-Mississippi tournament.
Captain Warren G. Child, U.S.N., retired, a pioneer in the development of the aviation arm of the navy, died in the Naval Hospital at San Diego on Tuesday, the Navy Department announced today.

The Treasury announced today an offering of $100,000,000 of 91-day bills to be sold as usual on a discount basis to the highest bidders. Tenders will be received up to 2 P. M., Eastern standard time, at Federal Reserve Banks or their branches.

In the brigade and headquarters team matches of the New York State National Guard contests . at Camp Smith here today, the 102d Engineers and the 107th Infantry, the old Seventh Regiment, both of Manhattan, were the winners in their respective matches, the headquarters and the fifty-third brigade.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,169,000 bales, against 1,173,000 a week ago, 1,203,000 two weeks ago, 1,197,000 three weeks ago and 909,000 a year ago, of which American 769,000 bales, against 777,000 a week ago, 797,000 two weeks ago, 794,000 three weeks ago and 380,000 a year ago.

Charles H. Kapp, 51 years old, an unemployed Paterson silk finisher, was acquitted today of murdering his estranged wife on April 26 at her home, 189 Fifth Avenue, Hawthorne. A jury in Court of Oyer and Terminer before Judge Joseph A. Delaney returned the verdict after deliberating two hours over the evidence submitted in four days of trial.

An action by the Twin Ports Oil Company of Duluth, Minn., seeking $717,471 damages from nine oil companies it charges were involved in illegal price fixing was on file in Federal Diistrict Court here today.

The annual Prize Day exercises of Kent School took place this afternoon, with the Rev. Allan Whittemore, superior of the Order of the Holy Cross, addressing the graduating class. F. J. Humphrey, chairman of the Kent building fund committee, announced that the fund had reached nearly $120,000.

Thirty members of the graduating class of Good Counsel --College received degrees this afternoon at ceremonies on the campus. Cardinal Hayes presided and the Rev. J. Harding Fisher gave the address. About 1,500 persons attended.

The Interstate Commerce Commisstion turned over today to its Division 7 the application made yesterday by the Railway Express Agency, Inc., and the Southeastern Express Company for rate increases which would produce an estimated $5,000,000 annually.

Thirty-six buses were saved today from a fire which destroyed the suburban bus lines garage on Essex Street here and did damage estimated at $60,000. The fire began shortly after 3:45 A. M. Four buses were destroyed.

The House has agreed formally that the symbol of liberty on Bedloe's Island in New York Harbor is a statue-not a statute. The members adopted yesterday an amendment by Representative Wadsworth correcting a typographical error in an item providing $12,735 for maintenance of the statue.

The hunts season will get under way on Long Island today with the annual Spring meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association on the estate of Charles V. Hickox at Roslyn, where one of the best racing cards the association has arranged in years will be offered.
George Edward Brush, descendant of one of the oldest families here, died at his home in Cos Cob today at the age of 69. Mr. Brush had served as town meeting representative.

For all practical purposes the coalition of Mayor La Guardia's supporters in the City Council longer exists, Councilman Louis Hollander, Kings County chairman of the American Labor party, told 2,000 unionized laundry workers at a meeting in Brooklyn last night.

Increases in air express shipments into and out of New York in May were led by clothing, which showed an increase for the month of 35 per cent over May, 1937, according to figures issued yesterday by the Railway Express Agency.

Conferees on the Wages and Hours Bill virtually agreed upon its major provisions today and, unless a hitch develops tomorrow, complete agreement will be announced and the bill will be submitted to the House on Monday.

Member-trading in round lots for own account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on May 14 was 22.86 per cent of total volume, compared with 23.44 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. Total volume,

Daily average sales of variety stores for May were about 9 per cent below May, 1937, according to preliminary estimates of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, based on a constant number of stores.
Mrs. Mallie Musick, gentle-faced wife of a man who preached from the Bible and the gospel of John L. Lewis, told between sobs today how her son Bennett was killed by riflefire poured into her home.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 8: COMMANDER Hudson, M. F., Med. Corps, the Milwaukee, to duty Naval Hospital, San Diego, July 6.

" As homesick," says the latest edition of the Book of Similes, "as a member of the House in even years." Hopeful dates were set for adjournment, for return to the home folks and fences. The second session of the Seventy-third Congress ended June 18, 1934; that of the Seventy-fourth on June 20, 1936.

Secretary Wallace announced today a reduction in domestic and import sugar quotas, in line with a Department of Agriculture order last week reducing estimates of 1938 American requirements from 6,861,671 to 6,780,566 short tons, raw value.
A class Or twenty-nine seniors, the largest the college has graduated, will receive degrees here tomorrow morning at the tenth annual commencement exercises of Sarah Lawrence College.

Charles Walzer, operator, has purchased the eight-family apartment house at 147 Ninth Street, Brooklyn, from a client of Goodson Potts, attorney. There are thirty-two rooms in the building, which recently was renovated by the seller at a cost of about $14,000.

The marriage of Miss Edith Scott Weed, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy J. Weed of this community, and Dr. Ralph Frederick Schneider of New York, took place this afternoon in the Cathedral of the Incarnation. Dean Arthur B. Kinsolving 2d performed the ceremony.

Weighing his words yet giving the impression of restraining himself, Premier Edouard Daladier today told the Finance Committee of the Chamber of Deputies that only a short time ago France had been within a few centimeters of war.

A slow rise in orders was reported by the principal wholesale markets last week, as lowered inventories made replacements necessary to meet the call for Summer merchandise, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.

As had been rather generally expected, yesterday's monthly Government report on the wheat crop forecasts the largest yield in the country's history. Including a necessarily tentative estimate on the Spring-sown crop, based on previous reports of intended planting, the Agricultural Department indicates a harvest of 1,020,623,000 to 1,045,623,000 bushels.

The Securities, and Exchange Commission has postponed until Aug. 12 the effective date of an order granting an application of Market Street Railway Company to withdraw from Exchange its common, 6 per cent cumulative prior preference, 6 per cent cumulative preferred and 6 per cent non - cumulative preferred stocks. all $100 par value.

Complete elimination of the undistributed profits tax, reduction and balancing of the budget and stabilization of our currency were urged today in two resolutions passed by the National Association of Credit Men at the last session of its fortythird annual credit congress at the St. Francis Hotel.

Between 500 and 600 members of the Bond Club of New York met at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club here today for their eighteenth annual outing. Beginning at 8 A. M., with bright skies prevailing, the first of the tenscore golfers teed off and the sports program, which also included tennis and swimming, continued until dusk.

Led by the Rev. Wendell Phillips, 32-year-old rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church here, about thirty young persons from churches' of this community will walk eighteen miles tomorrow to .the French Church du'Saint Esprit, 233 East Sixty-first Street, New York, to commemorate similar pilgrimages by the French Huguenot settlers of New Rochelle 250 years ago.
The New England States women's tennis team will defend the prized Eleonora F. Sears Cup tomorrow in a final match with the Eastern States team.
A fluffy little bundle of black and white fur arrived at the Bronx Zoo yesterday afternoon and New York City became the proud guardan of its first baby giant panda.

The Greyhound Corporation asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to buy in the open market 1,500 additional shares of Northland Greyhound Lines, Inc., at a price not to exceed $27.50 a share so as to increase its holdings from 49.57 per cent to 50.57 per cent of the stock.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 9: COLONELS Harmon, D. W., .Med. Corps, two months' leave, July 1. Edmunds, K. B., Cav., Fort Leavenworth, Kan.. to duty as Assistant Commandant, the Command and General Staff School.

Russell T. Joy, the oldest living ex-choir boy of Trinity Church in this city, died yesterday in St. John's Hospital at the age of 76. A descendant of Thomas Joy, New England builder of colonial times, Mr. Joy was born in Kingston, N. Y.

Miss Edith Francis Biddle, a manager of the Orphan Society of Philadelphia, near Media, who was widely known for her relief work during the World War, died of pneumonia today at The Crossways, her home in Gwynedd Valley. She was 55 years old.

Not enough fed steers or yearlings were received in the I cattle market today to gauge levels, the report of the United States Department of Agriculture said. Hogs continued to advance, but fat lambs were weak to lower.

Miss Audrey Elizabeth Pile, daughter of Sterling Pile and the late Mrs. Jerome Alexandre, was married today in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church here to Harry J. Miller Jr., son of Mr. Miller and the late Mrs. Miller. The Rev. James F. Higgins performed the ceremony.

A double victory in hunter classes by the famous bay gelding, Prince Charming II, from the Claredda Farm of Mr. and Mrs. E. V. Quinn of Shrewsbury, N. J., was one of the chief highlights as the forty-fifth annual Westchester County Horse Show opened today.

Four hundred planes, purchased for England in this country at a price of about $25,000,000, would have made a formidable armada for any nation a few years ago. Indeed, this is about four or five times the number of planes Britain had in 1914.

Professor William H. Cowley of Ohio State University was elected president of Hamilton College today by the board of trustees as successor to President Frederick C. Ferry. Dr. Cowley is to take office as of Aug. 1.

A Chinese official of the pro-Japanese Shanghai Civic Association was shot and wounded in the shoulder today by would-be assassins who escaped in a gun battle which sent bullets whizzing through the Cathay Hotel's crowded arcade at noontime.
A tornado struck this tiny West Texas town tonight, killing at least five persons, leaving possibly several more dead and injuring thirty or forty others.
Spanish Insurgent forces cut the strategic highway between Lucena del Cld and Castellon de la Plana, ten miles north of Castellon, in a two-hour battle today. They captured nearly a dozen hamlets.

The Jewish Theological Seminary A of America will hold its fifty-first commencement exercises tomorrow afternoon at '4:30 o'clock in the quadrangle at Broadway and 122d Street. Forty students will receive degrees from four departments of the institution.

At least eleven of the 271 passengers who arrived yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland were unofficially classed as refugees because they had been forced out of Germany by Nazi regulations.
Romain Rolland, playwright and pacifist, who fought for peace, when the world was at war, returned today to his native France after twenty-four years of exile in Switzerland.

Renewal of reports abroad of the possibility of a further devaluation of the dollar yesterday caused a sharp rally in the leading foreign exchanges. The pound sterling rose to $4.96 1/4, its best price in about three weeks and closed at $4.963-16, up 11-6 cent, while the franc hardened % point to 2.78 1/4 cents.

H. G. Richard has been appointed vice president of the California Packing Corporation. George P. Krug, controller of the Certain-teed Products Corporation, has been elected a director to succeed Robert L. Moore, resigned.

President Roosevelt today had ousted Victor Christgau, hitherto ardent New Dealer, as Works Progress Administrator for Minnesota, and added another confusing element to one of the most baffling political scrambles ever experienced in this State, long used to unusual politics.

Discount selling by manufacturers to employes of large corporations through the corporation's purchasing agent was denounced as a "brazenly unfair" trade practice in a speech by John E. Sloane, president of the Smaller Business Council of New Jersey, at a luncheon today of the Radio Electric Appliance League in the Newark Athletic Club.

The government won another outstanding victory today when G. E. P. Thorneycroft was returned in the Stafford parliamentary by-election necessitated by the elevation of the former W. G. A. Ormsby-Gore to the peerage on the death of his father, Lord Harlech.

Mr. and Mrs. William Payne Meredith of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sylvia Contee Meredith, to Robert Sears Garnett, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Burke Garnett of Mathews, Va.

DOREZ, INC., operating hotel at Chapel Hill, N. J.--Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of about $90,000 and assets of about $95,000. SAVOY STORES, INC., women's apparel, 105 W. 40th St.-Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $14,172 and assets of $9,954. The company operates

Dr. Mary Jones Brewster, formerly resident physician of Smith College for ten years and social service head of the cotton mills at La Grange, Ga., nine years, died yesterday in Wellesley after a brief illness at the age of 76.

William C. Wells, former cashier in New York for the banking firm of August Belmont Co., died today in the Mount Vernon Hospital of a heart ailment. He was stricken yesterday near his home here. His age was 69.

William Morris Poole, associate book editor of the McGraw-Hill Company, has purchased the old George Sherwood house on the Lyons Plains Road, Weston, Conn., from DuBois S. Morris, whose estate adjoins. The Burgoyne Hamilton Company, Inc., was the broker.

Ward'sAutomotive Reports noted a "more cheerful air" over the automobile industry today in estimating production for the week at 40,175 units, compared with 26,980 last week and 118,798 for this week a year ago.
A 16-year-old schoolboy was shot and seriously wounded early last evening, following a chase through Fourteenth Street crowds after he is alleged to have held up a shoe store.

The graduating class at Hunter College will hold its commencement dance tonight in the Gold Room of the Savoy Plaza. About 200 girls and their escorts are expected for the prom, one of the Senior Week events at Hunter.
Brig. Gen. and Mrs. George P. Scriven of Washington are at the Commodore. Mrs. F. Haven Clark has come from Boston to the Weylin. Mrs. Walter Gay of Paris is at the Gotham.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are June 10, unless specified: San Pedro to San Diego: Arctic, Rail. At San Francisco: Barry, Oklahoma. Concord, at San Pedro. Portland, San Pedro to Navy Yard, Mare Island.
Lancashire today defeated Kent by two wickets to advance into position in the county cricket championship. Middlesex retained the lead with a 153-run victory over Hampshire. The scores:

New State and municipal financIng scheduled for next week totals $24,554,579, to be represented by three States and sixty-one municipalities. This compares with the revised total of only $19,418,258 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $27,901,873.
Dr. Vladimir M. Fortunato, physician. and sculptor of medical models, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 609 West 158th Street. He was 53 years old.
