A nation-wide search was in progress tonight for Miss Lucile Wilson, 22year-old school teacher, who disappeared three days ago. Federal agents are aiding State police in the search.

Max D. Steuer, Greater New York chairman of the American ORT Federation, announced yesterday that one-third of the $450,000 fund which the federation is endeavoring to raise to provide technical and agricultural training for Eastern and Middle European Jews, has already been subscribed.
The stock market gave up yesterday about two-thirds of the Thursday gains, on the average. Net declines on the day ranged from fractions to 1 point, and a few leading issues were down 2 points.

A triple tie for first place in the international chess masters tournament occurred today when four adjourned games from the first and second rounds were played to a finish. Sir George Thomas of England, leading last night, was joined by Erich Eliskases of Austria and Paul Keres of Estonia, when they scored in their respective games.

Upon the recommendation of the Yale Undergraduate Athletic Association, twenty-seven varsity letters and 115 minor insignia were awarded to members of Yale Spring sports teams, it was announced today by the board of control of the Athletic Association.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, Democratic State leader of New Jersey and vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, attacked the C. I. O. and allied groups involved in the Jersey City "free speech" fight as part of an

Proposed Federal emergency aid for the railroad industry at this session of Congress was narrowed today at a White House conference to a simple amendment to the Bankruptcy Act intended to facilitate scaling down of capital structures and to ease roads from receivership to solvency.
Eight army airmen were killed here today when a wing of a big bombing plane was torn off as they were about to make a forced, landing in a farm meadow.

President Roosevelt gave notice to States and municipalities today that responsibility for direct relief is wholly theirs, not to be evaded in anticipation of assistance from the Federal Government, which will not be forthcoming.

The men's apparel merchants of the nation "console themselves with an outlook of a better season ahead," the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers said today in announcing that 91 per cent of the national business committee indicated their sales for May averaged more than 20 per cent lower than the same month last year.

Governor Earle and a group of State officials and Democratic party leaders were: accused in a petition filed with the State Supreme Court today of engaging in a conspiracy to "cheat and defraud" the Commonwealth and "extort money and levy

Unless the United States promptly institutes a national program of soil conservation it has less than a century to exist as a "virile nation," Morris Lewellyn Cooke, former chairman of the Mississippi Valley Commission, warned here today.

George Van Nostrand of Oakland eliminated the medalist, Robert Johnke, to gain the quarter-final round of the Long Island amateur golf championship tournament at the Garden City Country Club today. Johnke, whose sparkling 72 led the field in yesterday's qualifying round, fell before the sure-putting Van Nostrand by 3 and 2.

Lord Stamp, president of the Associated British and Irish Railways, announced yesterday that his organization would bring the famous streamlined train, the Coronation Scot, to this country next Spring to participate in the World's Fair. The record-breaking train will .tour. 3,121 miles over -eight American systems, visiting thirtyeight cities, before the Fair opens, he said.

Manhattan riflemen, firing in the annual National Guard matches at Camp Smith here, swept all before them today by running up the high score in each of the four events concluded, two going to the old Seventh Regiment, one to the 102d Engineers and the other to the First Battalion,-New York Naval Militia.

French mint employes this morning staged a sitdown strike in protest against legally decreed overtime work and had to be cleared out by the police. The strike occurred during the morning hours, but it was only at noon that police arrived to clear the premises.
Patrick J. O'Brien, a newspaper reporter, author and World War aviator, died of a heart attack today at his home in Penfield, a suburb. He was in his forty-seventh year.

Shipments of finished steel products by the United States Steel Corporation totaled 465,081 tons in May, a decrease of 36,891 tons from April and 838,958 tons below shipments of 1,304,039 toni in May, 1937.

The refusal of William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, to issue licenses to itinerant peddlers was criticized yesterday as "a usurpation of legislative functions" in a decision by Supreme Court Justice Edward Riegelmann in Brooklyn, directing the Commissioner to grant ice cream vending permits to all qualified applicants.
Greenwich St, 370, 6-story loft store, 25x 100; Greenwich Savings Bank against Margaret H. Scott; due, $22.883; taxes, etc, $410: to plaintiff for $20,000. By ROBERT FISHEL
A single by Buddy Rosar in the eleventh inning with two out scored Jimmy Gleeson from third and gave the Bears a 9-to-8 victory over Buffalo tonight.

Guy Guerin de Font-Joyeuse, manager of the New York branch of Marcel Rochas, Inc., 32 East Sixty-seventh Street, and the corporation itself were found guilty yesterday of conspiracy and smuggling of Parisian dresses into this port.

Arthur Alonzo Schomburg, Negro scholar and curator of the Division of Negro Literature, History and Prints in the 135th Street branch of the New York Public Library, much of which he collected himself and which is said to be the largest and rarest collection on the Negro in the United States, died shortly after noon yesterday in Madison Park Hospital, Brooklyn, after a short illness. His age was 64.
The name of Clarence A. Dykstra, president of the University of Wisconsin, has been added to the list of those under consideration for the post of paid president of the New York Stock Exchange.

A criminal court jury today acquitted five former Tampa policemen of kidnapping Eugene F. Poulnot. It was the third trial for the defendants in connection with the Tampa floggings of 1935 and their second trial in the Poulnot case.

Two of the real siege-gun hitters in women's golf reached the final round today of the thirty-eighth annual women's metropolitan golf championship. Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches, five times a winner, and Miss Charlotte Glutting of Rock Spring, her fellow Curtis Cup appointee, survived semi-final round matches at the Century Club and will meet in the 36-hole title round tomorrow.

Under the auspices of the Greater New York Federation of Churches the fifth annual series of open-air services will be held every weekday except Saturday, beginning on Monday at 12:30-P. M., in Madison Square Park. The meetings will be under-the direction of the Rev. Dr. Arthur Y. Beatie, chairman of the Department of Evangelism of the federation.

Cliff (Harlem) Perry, University of California shortstop, successfully stole home in the eleventh inning as the Bears caught Harvard napping, 5 to 4, today at Soldiers Field. A smart squeeze play had enabled Harvard to come from behind to tie the score at 4-all in the sixth.

With many important men in bond circles away on their annual outing and public interest an almost negligible factor, trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange slumped yesterday to the lowest since Monday and to the second smallest volume of the month. Prices in all groups,

Professor and Mrs. William Howard Doughty of Elscot have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betsy Hart Doughty, to Robert Lord Debevoise, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Debevoise of New York and Greenwich, Conn.

After three days of investigation, following a letter from Mayor Thomas J. Spellacy, Police Court Prosecutor Benedict M. Holden signed warrants tonight for the arrest of four officers and employes of the Hartford Fuel Supply Company, charging conspiracy to defraud the city, the county and the State of thousands of tons of coal through fake delivery slips.

New York motorists last year paid a record high of $61,841,000 in gasoline taxes to the State, an increase of 11.2 per cent over 1936, Edward D. Cray, secretary of the New York Petroleum Industries Committee, announced yesterday.

The newly formed National Council for the Promotion of Father's Day will hold a meeting on July 7 to discuss plans for 1939 and to consider appointment of co-chairmen from the various industries which participate in the event.

Without any debate, and with practically no attention paid thus far to the consequences of its action, the Senate has passed a bill which is a perfect example of the bad practice of vesting high-handed powers in Government of a "personal" kind.

The American Light and Traction Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on April 30 a net income of $5,366,346 after operating expenses, taxes and charges. This was equal after preferred dividend requirements to $1.65 a share on the outstanding common stock. It compared with a net of $5,941,754, or $1.86 a common share, in the year ended on April 30, 1937.

Attempts to collect retroactive Federal income taxes from hundreds of thousands of State and municipal employes all over the nation have been postponed at least until October through the action of Supreme Court Justice Roberts in granting a stay in the Port of New York Authority case.
Theki promotion of Dr. Paul P. Gourrich, director of the research division, to the post of technical adviser was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Federal Reserve Board wrote today that the industrial recession in the United States is the most severe in the world. It added, however, that in other countries the manufacture of war materials keeps many industries busy.

Fifteen thousand persons, a third of whom were children and juniors, attended the annual open-air fair at Greentree, the estate of Mrs. Payne Whitney, here, this afternoon, the largest crowd, according to incomplete reports that has ever attended this fete for the benefit of the babies milk fund of the Family Welfare Association of Nassau County and the New York Hospital.

Frank McLaughlin, merchandise manager of the fashion store of John Wanamaker, New York, has been appointed to the newly created post of merchandise manager of accessories, children's wear, smallwares, piecegoods and shoes for both the local and Philadelphia Wanamaker stores, it was announced yesterday.
Major Rudolf Broz, an officer of the general staff, assured the nation in a radio broadcast this afternoon that an army invading Czechoslovakia would face a difficult task and suffer heavy losses.

Stocks sagged and closed moderately lower in less active trading; turnover, 406,370 shares. United States Government bonds firm and mixed, rail group lower, foreign issues higher; transactions, $3,914,425.

The interest of the late Reginald C. Jenkins has ceased in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Bissinger. Co. Proposal has been made for the retirement on June 30 of Edmondo Gerli and Joseph J. Drasba in the firm of Eric Drevers, and for Howard Eric, general partner, to become a limited partner.

The Rev. Dr. Arthur Rogers, rector emeritus of St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Evanston, Ill., died today in the home of his son, Horatio, in Evanston. He was 74 years old and had lived in retirement. in Newport, R. I., and Evanston since 1930 after completing forty years in the ministry.

A hearing was held yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, on the plan of reorganization proposed by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for Prudence Company, Inc., which applied for reorganization under Section 77-b of the Federal Banking Law on Feb. 1, 1935.

David Kirschbaum, retired clothing manufacturer, prominent for many years in civic affairs, ended his life today by hanging himself in his apartment here. He was 72 years old. Although Mr. Kirschbaum had been suffering for some years from a heart ailment, his physician, Dr. M. J. Karpeles, voiced the opinion

Minford P1 (11-2977), east side, 73 ft south of 173d St, 47x102; Morris Feuerstein to Samuel Simonoff, 1,558 Minford P1; mtg $25,000. Grand Concourse, 2,850-56 (12-3305); Corporation Realties, Ltd, to Evegene Corp, Inc. 300 Madison Ave; mtgs $195,250.

Summer racing on a major, plane came to Southern California today as a crowd of nearly 40,000 saw W. E. Boeing's Air Chute win the $2,500 Hollywood Premier Handicap over six furlongs at Hollywood Park, new $2,500,000 track.
Army and navy officials said today that activities at the century-old arsenal at Watervliet, N. Y., would be expanded because of the nation's new armament program.

Cardinal Hayes presided yesterday at the commencement of the Cathedral High School and counseled the 312 girl graduates "to preserve their piety and ideals and loyalty to country." The exercises were held in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

A copper cylinder containing part of LieutCommander George Washington De Long's record of the Arctic expedition on which the explorer and most of his party perished fifty-seven years ago was found recently by a Soviet scientist on Henrietta Island, which Commander De Long discovered and named, Soviet officials revealed today.

When Earlsmoor Moor of Arden captured the silver trophy denoting best of breed in the sixth annual specialty show of the Labrador Retriever Club today, he completed a remarkable series of victories for himself.

The story of a woman who visited the world on the other side of sanity and came back to write a 400-page journal of her experiences while deranged was given today to the American Psychiatric Association.

Representative O'Toole, New York Democrat, said today he had appealed to Marvin McIntyre, secretary to the President, and John H. Fahey, chairman of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, to stop foreclosure proceedings against the home of Mrs. Sadie L. Monssen, widow of a naval hero.

Builders were active yesterday in Queens, where they purchased tracts of land for improvement with homes in the medium price range. Harold Kaplan, who recently erected about 400 houses in Rego Park, bought twenty-six lots in the Maspeth section for improvement with one-family dwellings.

MANHATTAN FLETCHER, ROBERT J. (June 1). Estate, more than $10,000. To Ramsey J. Fletcher, Flora D. Fletcher and Robert J. Fletcher Jr., executors, 1.311 Madison Ave., personal effects and residue equally. FORRESTER, MARGARET (May 14). Estate, $1,132. To John Forrester, husband, executor, 505 W. 41st St., residue; Our Lady Queen of Angels Church of the Province of St. Joseph, 226 E. 113th St., $100.
The Republican National Committee had a deficit of about $700,000 on May 31, according to a report filed with the Clerk of the House today by G. B. Goodspeed, treasurer.

Alteration of two swastikas into Greek crosses on the 335-foot chimney of the New York Hospital, Seventieth Street and the East River, began yesterday. More than 100 anonymous donors contributed $1,000 for the alteration, which is being made in response to numerous complaints that the swastika has taken on a new meaning since the pre-Hitler days when the chimney was designed and constructed.

Incorporation papers have been filed in Wilmington, Del., for Distillation Products, Inc., which, under the joint ownership of General Mills, Inc., and the Eastman Kodak Company, will engage in the exploitation of inventions, products, processes and machinery in the field of molecular distillation.

Eleven high schools will remain open this Summer to provide remedial training for students who have failed, Frederic Ernst, associate superintendent, announced yesterday. Nearly 600 WPA teachers will be assigned. The Board of Education has allocated $10,000 and twenty licensed high school teachers.

In an effort to win public support in cleaning up certain anti-social abuses in the retail distribution of beer, manufacturers, whose products are allied with the brewing industry, joined today with the brewers in approving an advertising campaign for this purpose.

Definite action toward realization of the Japanese Government's plan to make the country self-sufficient in wood pulp by the end of 1942 was taken by the establishment under official auspices of a national policy pulp company on May 20, according to the Forest Products Division, Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

Captain Lewis Baird, retired army officer, died of a heart attack last night at the age of 68. He was a native of Jeffersonville, Ind. After attending the Naval Academy for two years he entered business.

An eight-year rivalry for supremacy in model yacht racing which required skill in building as well as in competing ended yesterday.on Prospect Park Lake, Brooklyn, with honors going to fleets from Public School 209, Brooklyn, in- finals against friendly rivals from Public School 29, Brooklyn. All contestants were less than 15 years old.

Hugh Mulcahy, the Phillies' big right-hander, who lost eighteen games last season, ended his team's seven-straight losing streak today by hurling steady ball and delivering a timely single to win from Pittsburgh, 3 to 2.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: I have a very keen memory for the baseball days of my youth. As a train newsboy I used to go every Saturday to the old South End grounds in Boston just to see Mike Kelly play.

Rains continued over the larger part of the cotton-producing areas and, with more showers predicted, prices on the local Cotton Exchange again advanced yesterday. Profit-taking, however, canceled the improvement and left the list 1 to 4 points lower than Thursday's close.

Two Japanese destroyers were reported to have been sunk when Chinese planes bombed warships in the Yangtze River off Kweichih and Tatung above Wuhu, Thursday and yesterday. A Japanese fleet is pressing toward Hankow in the vicinity of the bombings.

Wage cuts of 11 to 18 per cent will reduce the pay of 14,559 WPA clerical workers in this city. by $2,187,205 a year, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday. The cuts were made

GOVERNORS ISLAND Ist Lt. Harold J. McLaughlin. Inf.-Res., 3,623 Avenue T, Brooklyn, N. Y., 36th Inf. (R.A.I.), is ordered to active duty, effective July 10, at Plattsburgh Barracks, N. Y., for training. Date of rank: July 10, 1938. He will revert to an inactive status on July 23.

Nearly.500 boys and girls are en-. tered for the Park Department's annual athletic meet that will be held at Randalls Island Stadium this afternoon to pick city-wide champions in track and field events.

MANHATTAN CONE. DAISY M. (Aug. 27, 1937). Gross assets, $77,919; net, $69,157. To Marjorie C. Fischer, daughter, $500 and half residue; Robert Tyson, son, specific bequests and half residue; one other bequest. Chief assets mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $50,695. Proskauer, Rose Paskus, attorneys. 11 Broadway.

After two days of comparative rest, Max Schmeling will resume boxing tomorrow when Promoter Mike Jacobs and Major Gen. John J. Phelan, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, are to visit his camp.

Commencement exercises for a class of thirty-four, largest in the history of the school, were held here tonight in the gymnasium of the Pingry School. Diplomas were presented by Joseph W. Allen, president of the board of trustees, and honors and prizes were awarded by E. Laurence Springer. headmaster.

Leslie MacMitchell, one of the finest distance runners ever to be developed in a New York City public school, supplied a fitting climax to his scholastic career last night by racing to a new mark of 4:23.1 in the one-mile run at the thirty-fifth annual city senior P. S. A. L. track and field championships at the Randalls Island Stadium.

Edward M. Seguine, a lawyer and member of an old Staten Island Family, died on Thursday night at the Staten Island Hospital at New Brighton of a heart ailment. He was 58 years old and resided at 468 Bard Avenue, West New Brighton.

The. Federal Circuit Court .of Appeals, in a decision today upholding' National Labor Relations Board contention, permitted the Ford Motor Company an appeal to the Supreme Court in relation to a Board order of Dec. 22 requiring compliance with the Wagner Labor Act.
Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes of the United States Supreme Court, will sail today on the Italian liner Rex, bound for Mediterranean ports.

A trip to Fort Knox to view, by special permission, a part of the estimated $5,000,000,000 of gold bullion housed in the government's only gold vault, ended the annual convention of the American Institute of Bankers today.

Miss Mildred Pope, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Richard Pope of 480 Park Avenue and Madison, Conn., was married to Henry Hill Pierce Jr., yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square. The Rev. Dr. Karl Reiland, rector emeritus of the church, performed the ceremony in the presence of members of the two families.

A demand for low-end kitchenwares reached the wholesale market here this week from stores in New England, Pennsylvania and Mid western States. The New England retailers purchased goods for special promotions which will be held in a number bf cities through the balance of this month.

Friends of John Roosevelt and Miss Anne Clark disclosed tonight that the President's son would take his bride to Bermuda for a stay at Vincent Astor's estate instead of visiting European countries this Summer.

Frank Speer, 32-year-old heavyweight wrestler and former All-America tackle, died tonight of pneumonia. He entered a hospital last week after aggravating a minor illness by leaving his bed to fill a scheduled exhibition match with Dorv Roche, Scranton, Pa., grappler.

Proportionately to their ability and training, women college graduates have failed to score successes in the executive and financial phases of the business and political worlds, Dr. Susan Kingsbury complained today to her colleagues of the American Association of University Women. Dr. Kingsbury,

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Finding a formula for reducing the costs of medical care has had the benefit of elaborate research during the last several unfortunate years. The search was intended to find a way to reduce the costs and not to increase them.

Wholesalers found business exceptionally slow for a Friday. Steer hinds and ribs were steady to firm, steer cuts steady to lower, veal and lamb sharply lower, bull weak, cow weak to lower, fresh pork cuts mostly steady to slightly higher.

Mrs. Alice Higinbotham Patterson won an uncontested divorce from J. M. Patterson, publisher of The New York Daily News, before Circuit Judge Ralph J. Dady of Lake County today on a charge of desertion. She gave her residence as a farm near Libertyville.

The Rev. Dr. De Witt Miles Benham, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church for the last forty years, died early today. He was 75 years old and in the last four years had suffered a series of strokes, the last one ten days ago.
Joseph McDermott, Monmouth County Clerk since November, 1898, died at his home, Broad Street and Manalapan Avenue, this morning of heart disease. His age was 79.

Miss Marion Duval, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Duval of this place, was married here tonight in the Hitchcock Memorial Church to John Shober Burrows Jr. of New York, son of Mr. Burrows of Baltimore and Grand Lake Stream, Me., and of the late Mrs. Elizabeth Corner Burrows.

Conference of the Harlem Committee of the United Parents Association, Metropolitan Baptist Church, 157 West 128th Street, 11 A. M. Annual dinner of the Class of '98, Stevens Institute of Technology, Hotel Astor, 5:30 P. M.

Kingsboro Mortgage Corp, as principals, have made loans of $300,000 on the sixstory apartment under construction on the north side of Lincoln Rd, 158 feet east of Washington Ave, Brooklyn, to the Elberne Building Corp, Samuel Turner, pres; $150,-

The Yankees did the scalping yesterday in their party with the Indians at the Stadium. Led by the team's spark plug, Bill Dickey, they checked the Clevelanders' march on the Bronx with a familiar demonstration of hitting power, won by 8 to 2 and carved a game off that hitherto depressing lead Oscar Vitt's lads had held in the American League pennant fight.

The watching world blows hot and cold as noncombatants are bombed to bits on two hemispheres. The heart burns with an indignation that goes deeper even than pity for the victims, for humanity itself is outraged by a form of warfare that blasts human flesh as carelessly as sticks and stones.

Quicny Porter, Professor of Music at Vassar College for six years, has been appointed dean of the faculty of the New England Conservatory of Music, Wallace Goodrich, director of the conservatory, announced today.

Cherry St, s s, 25 ft w of Jefferson St, 50x 94; Isidore and Jacob Kauffman and wives to Bernher Realty Corp, 139 E 24th St (quitclaim). Ave C, 56, 24x64.3; Morris Weisberg et al to Louis Weisberg, 2,395 Grand Ave, Bronx.

Don Budge and Gene Mako marched into the doubles final in the French hard court tennis championship today, defeating the Yugoslav Davis Cup: combination of France Kukuljevic and Josip Pallada, 2-6, 6-3, 6-2, 6-2.

Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for a field house and bleachers in Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx, to cost $300,000. Architects also filed for numerous alterations to buildings in Manhattan.

In a unanimous decision, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court affirmed yesterday a decision of Supreme Court Justice Levy allowing the National Bondholders Corporation a claim of $18,385,000 against the old National Surety Company, now in liquidation. The court's action, according

Next week is to be Federal Theatre Project Week, with two openings and both of them products of the Government. On. Tuesday the Caravan Theatre, which passes the Summer in the city's parks and playgrounds, will start out with four shows to be rotated through the various boroughs.

Turpentine firm, 22 1/4c; sales, 9 barrels; receipts, 337 barrels; shipments, 1,930 barrels; stock, 34,405 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 333 barrels; receipts, 2,010 barrels; shipments, 1,186 barrels; stock, 132,465 barrels.

As a result of a request by the New York Stock Exchange last December, urging large corporations to see that shareholders were represented adequately .at annual and special meetings, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has amended its by-laws, effective June
The official record of Mayor Frank Hague's testimony in Newark yesterday follows: Direct examination by Mr. Frazer (Spaulding Frazer, C. I. 0. counsel):

The Federal Trade Commission has served on Excello Fabrics, Inc.,. 118 Madison Avenue, New. York, an order requiring it to discontinue certain alleged misrepresentations in the sale of fabrics to garment manufacturers and other customers.

Maxwell Howard's The Chief, conqueror of Lawrin in the Derby trial at Louisville, where he also equaled the track record, Will make his return to competition today in the Shevlin Stakes, a mile test which features Aqueduct's first week-end program of the meeting.

Why so much fuss about housing at this time? Mayor La Guardia threw some light on this question when he appeared with Senator Wagner before the housing committee of the Constitutional Convention on Thursday.

Competitive drills by cadet companies were held today at the New York Military Academy. B company, in command of Cadet Captain Norman Sweeters of Forest Hills, was judged best by a committee of three West Point officers.

An appeal of William Hayett of 112 East Sixteenth Street, New. York, asking that the Commissioner of Education direct the New York Board of Education to appoint him as teacher of English in Junior High School 171, Manhattan, as of April 25, was heard today before Ernest E. Cole, assistant commissioner. Decision was reserved.
Intensified activity by Federal agents brought prediction today of an early solution to the death of Mrs. John R. Brooke Jr., but no details on the case against her husband, an army major.
Twenty-one students will be graduated from Kingsley School here at the commencement exercises tomorrow. Dean Spaulding Frazer of the

Mrs. Richardson Lindecke, in 53 E 66th St; Charles W. Fowler, in 25 E 83d St; Alan T. Schumacher, through Culver, Hollyday Co., Inc., in 9 E 96th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers. Bushnell Bigelow, in 116 E 63d St; Samuel A. Herzog, broker.
In view of the fact that a rather bearish government report on the wheat crop was expected today after the close of trading, the wheat market maintained a strong undertone most of the session.

Paramount today announced the purchase of a short story by Mark Jerome, New York University freshman, as a vehicle for Irene Dunne, Fred MacMurray and youthful Donald O'Connor; Wesley Ruggles will produce and direct.

Louis Schmidt, violinist and composer, who half a century ago toured the country and brought music to its lovers when he was a concert master under Theodore Thomas, died yesterday afternoon in his home, 43-06 Forty-seventh Street, Sunnyside, Queens. He was 82 years old.

United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation will- break large copy in New York newspapers on June 16 to publicize its "Bargain-Sharing Sale," in which merchandise purchased in a recent dramatic buying session will be placed on sale.
The Spring, 1938, edition of New Writing, the semi-annual "magazine in book form" which is edited by John Lehmann, will be published by Knopf on June 20.

JOSETTE, based on a play by Paul Frank and Georg Fraser from a story by Ladislaus Vadnal; screen play by James Edward Grant; music and lyrics by Mack Gordon and Harry Revel: directed by Allan Dwan; produced by Darryl P. Zanuck for Twentieth Century-Fox.' At the Roxy.
The Dollar Line's luxury passenger ship President Hoover, wrecked Dec. 10 on Hoisho Island near Formosa, is to be converted into shells and bullets for the Japanese Army.
Notre Dame, scoring 37 points by placing in twelve of the sixteen events, won the thirteenth annual Central Collegiate Conference track and field championship tonight.

With the arrival in Egypt today of an official Iranian delegation headed by Mahmoud Jam, Prime Minister, to confirm the engagement of Shahpur Mohammed Riza Pahlavi, Crown Prince of Iran, to Princess Fawzia of Egypt, one of the most important political alliances in the history of Islam is about to be completed.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, announced that he had gotten the sketches for the murals in the Gompers room in the International Labor Office approved today by Director Harold B. Butler and Director-elect John G. Winant.

The reports of the proceedings of the American Psychiatric Association leave no doubt of the revolutionary importance of the chemical methods of treating schizophrenia, hitherto a well-nigh hopeless form of insanity. In 1928 Dr.

The Home Owners Loan Corporation has sold, through Ben Schlossberg, Inc., and William Drost, cobrokers, the three-story apartment and store building and the threecar garage at 79 Maple Street, Jersey City, N. J., to Winslow Borkowski.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 4 amounted to 502,624 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 59,437 cars, or 10.6 per cent,fewer than for the preceding week; 186,363 cars, or 27 per cent,

Following Senate approval yesterday of the O'Mahoney resolution for an investigation of monopolies, with wide powers for the President, the House Judiciary Committee revised its own resolution today to conform with the Senate bill and reported it favorably.

Promotion Display. Inc., display signs, in 23 E. 21st St. through 23 E. 21st St. Corp. and Morgan Barry; Williams Co., brokers. Louis B. Boudin, Sidney Elliott Cohn and Hyman Gllcstein, attorneys, in 20 W. 43d St.; Bedford, Pavitt Co., brokers.
The White Sox went on a 20-hit rampage today at the expense of four rookie pitchers to defeat the Red Sox, 15 to 2, behind the five-hit pitching of Monty Stratton.

Makota Den, chairman of the Tokyo Olympic Games Publicity Committee, said today he would "like to think" there was "some misunderstanding" on the part of William J. Bingham, Harvard Director-of Athletics, when the latter dissociated himself two days ago from the 1940 games in protest against sending a team "to a country standing for what Japan stands for."

Extraordinarily heavy rains early this Spring followed by one of the worst droughts within the memory of man have played havoc with Italian argiculture this year, bringing about a shortage in several staple products, among which that of wheat is felt particularly.

Reversing a. ruling by Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente, the Appellate Division yesterday permitted R. H. Macy Co., the department store, to plead unfair discrimination and, a looseness of definition as defenses in an injunction suit brought. under the FeldCrawford Fair Trade Act.

Mrs. Brinton Page Roberts, widow of Brinton Page Roberts and the former Miss Elizabeth Fisher Wurts of Cedar Hill Farm, Media, daughter of Mrs. Charles Stewart Wurts of this city and the late Mr. Wurts, was married this afternoon to Boyd Lee Spahr Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Spahr of Haverford.

The need for relief work in China is just beginning, Major Arthur Bassett, chairman of the American Advisory Committee for China Famine Relief, declared at a meeting today which had been called to coordinate plans for spending funds that are expected from the United States drive of the United Council for Civilian Relief in China.

Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, conferred today with WPA officials on a plan to handle surplus supplies of men's clothing. The proposal is designed to stimulate reemployment of idle clothing workers and help to stabilize the industry.
President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the nomination of Edward A. Conger to be Judge for the Southern District of New York.

The steady, experienced golf of Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas Gity and the vigorous style of Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis won them today the right to meet tomorrow in the Championship round of the twelfth women's trans-Mississippi tournament.
Austin, Anna M. Bornmann, Albert E. Breen, Michael F. Brewster, Mary J. Brush, George E. Bryson, Florence N. Congleton, Anna G.

Mrs. Edna B. Moore, who died Oct. 1, 1936, left a net estate of $977,816, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. The principal beneficiaries are three daughters, Lorna T. Neidringhaus of Clayton, Ohio; Dorothy T. Potter of 215 East Seventy-second Street and Alice T. Cox of 136 East Sixtyfourth Street.

A drama that might be entitled "Interfering With Progress" was staged here today by the Central Railroad of New Jersey and State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, with three embattled residents of Elizabeth Avenuue in the role of "interferers."

A resolution calling for an investigation of the radio broadcasting industry and of charges that a few big companies have a virtual monopoly was approved today by the House Rules Committee after an open hearing at which testimony was given by Frank McNinch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, and Norman Case, Eugene 0. Sykes and Thad Brown, members.

A building in the Mount Morris Park section of Harlem that has been in the Brokaw family for many years, first as a stable and then as a garage, will make way for a modern store, it was announced yesterday.

Department store- sales in the week ended June 4 were 16 per cent lower than for the same week one year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Sales for the four weeks ended June 4 were also 16 per cent lower than for the comparable four weeks in 1937.
The engagement of Miss- Marie Udell Edwards, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Nathaniel Edwards of this place, to Ensign John Burkhardt Jr., U. S. N., has been announced by her parents.
Although local financiers refuse to become at all excited about the rumors of an impending second devaluation of the dollar, European markets seem to be cultivating the idea strongly.

There isn't much doubt that the weather man is on the side of the weakfish and porgies, but the saltwater anglers have every reason to believe that this week-end may be the one for which they have been waiting.

Pensioned On his own application. To take effect 12 midnight. June 10: PATROLMAN-Samuel G. Patterson, 94th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed July 27, 1910. Temporary Assignments SERGEANT-James P. Diamond, from 81st Precinct to 18th Division, for 5 days, from 8 A. M., June 8.

Turning the tables on the high-scoring Australian cricket team, England piled up 422 runs for four wickets to open the 1938 five-game test series today. The opening day's play for The Ashes was marked by the rout of Australia's highly touted attack.

In spite of some of the most sensational scoring splurges that have ever marked any open championship, Henry Picard, tall, willowy pro at the Hershey (Pa.) Country Club, today maintained his lead in the race for the golf title now worn by Ralph Guldahl.
THERE goes the wind out of another lovely theory! Don't look now, but the St. Louis Cardinals are wallowing about in the second division. After all, it can happen here.

President Roosevelt disclosed today that he had revamped his Summer travel plans to include stops in Colorado, Utah and Nevada and indicated he would have something to say on the Democratic primary elections in those States.

The Maritime Commission as- M. sumed control yesterday of the Panama Pacific liners Pennsylvania, California and Virginia, preparatory to renovating all three ships and operating them in a service to East Coast ports of South America. These new sailings will be inaugurated in September.

HAS any one ever written a historical novel about one. of Manhattan's city blocks? Probably. Though your reviewer has not happened to read it. The story would start with a family of contented Indians cheerily fishing on the spot. Then ("Ugh! Palefaces!") along would come the Dutch with that twenty-four-dollar necklace.
News was received here today of the death in Venice of Miss Constance Fletcher, American-born novelist and dramatist, better known in the world of letters as George Fleming. She was 80 years old.
The State of Massachusetts has invited sealed proposals for the sale on Thursday of $4,000,000 of notes. The issue will be dated June 30, 1938, and will fall due on June 30, 1939.

With one of the finest fields in recent years, the New York Athletic Club will stage its 140th track and field games at Travers Island today, the first event starting at 3 P. M. Practically every star in the East is listed to compete in addition to the seven-man team from the University of California.

Miss Kay Stammers got Great Britain off to a good start in the Wightman Cup tennis series today by scoring an unexpected victory over Miss Alice Marble, 3-6, 7-5, 6-3. The United States, however, took the other two matches of the day, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody
Miss Anna Lucille Morris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Llewellyn K. Morris of this city, was married here today to Woodrow Maloney, also of Reading, in the chapel of Holy Cross Church.

Bernard Delahanty, wanted here on a burglary charge and for questioning in the Peter Levine kidnapping, was delivered to the local department this afternoon by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

After an all-day debate devoted mostly to amendments, the House adopted late today the Agricultural Department Appropriation Bill conference report and sent it to the Senate for approval of slight changes.

Bombing Al Williams and Ed Smith for six hits' and five runs in the fifth inning, the Browns defeated the Athletics, today, 8 to 4. Buck Newsom held Philadelphia to eight hits, one of them a two-run homer by Sam Chapman, in achieving his seventh victory of the season.

The continued high level of HOLC foreclosures and the economic distress of many home owners whose mortgages are held by the Federal agency have led a group of members of the House of Representatives, most of them from New York, to formulate a program to make payments easier for HOLC debtors.

Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, told 185 seniors of Lafayette College today that the principle of intellectual freedom, the spirit of free inquiry, the free expression of opinion and a free press must be preserved in the United States if the philosophies of dictatorships overseas were not to find foothold in America.

Committee for Industrial Organization forces were marshaling their strength today against a provision in the revision of the Merchant Marine Act which would permit training of any men who have been at sea for a year so that they might qualify as able seamen.

The last remaining bracket in the semi-final round was filled in the Brooklyn tennis championship yesterday at the Terrace Club of Flatbush. Elwood Cooke of Portland, Ore., the top-seeded favorite, took his allotted place by defeating Dr. Lawrence Kurzrok, 6 4, 6-3.

Aided by more favorable weather conditions, retail trade here made a substantially better showing this week than last. Department store executives yesterday estimated the volume was running about 14 per cent under 1937, as against a drop of 19.2 per cent for the preceding week. Provided there is brisk

Used in moderation, both tea and coffee are among the most beneficial beverages, particularly for maintaining vitality and inducing sleep, Dr. Walter Eddy, Professor of Physiological Chemistry at Columbia. University, told about 200 tea distributors at a tea forum at New York University yesterday afternoon.
Stevens Institute of Technology will confer ninety-eight degrees at its sixty-sixth annual commencement exercises at 10:30 A. M. tomorrow in the William Walker Hall gymnasium.
Officers of the Seventy-seventh Division Association for 1938-39 were inducted into office last night in the Memorial Building, 28 East Thirty-ninth Street, at a gathering of nearly 200 veterans.

Theodore H. Puitz, who served in the German Imperial Navy and some years later with the United States Army in the Spanish-American War, died in the naval hospital here last night. He was 71 years old.

Miss Margery Anne Bavier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Bavier of this place, was married to. John Hodgart Donald, son of-Mrs...Hugh.C. Donald of Paisley, Scotland, and the late Dr. Donald, this evening at the Bavier residence here. The Rev. Dr. Clifton Macon of New York officiated in the presence of members of the families.

The report of the Italian Superpower Corporation for the first quarter of 1938 shows a net loss of $169,793 after income taxes, debenture interest paid and accrued, and $4,417 loss on sale of securities, as compared to a net loss of $165,170 in the same quarter last year.
The stock markets displayed today a more cheerful tendency and higher prices ruled in several sections, although business still was small. Gilt-edge issues were a shade lower on continued selling.
LEGENDS OF LOUDOUN, by Harrison Williams. (Garrett Massie, Richmond, Va., $3.) An account of the history and homes of a border county of Virginia's northern neck.

The Tigers came from behind for a 7-to-6 victory over the Senators today in a ten-inning opener of a three-game series. A collision between Second Baseman Ossie Bluege and rookie Centerfielder George Case, both going after Rudy York's pop fly, led to the winning run.

Several hundred persons attended a funeral service today at the First Presbyterian Church here for George M. Shutt, former president of the New York Cotton Excharge and former Police Commissioner here, who died on Wednesday at his New Rochelle home at the age of 74.

A decrease of $32,279,000 in Dominion Government deposits was shown today in the Bank of Canada's statement for the week ended on June 8. The decline was attributed to clearing of checks in payment for the $140,000,000 cash and conversion loan.

Representatives of more than thirty large banks and lending institutions urged yesterday that the Federal Housing Administration increase its limit for insuring loans for modernization and repairs under Title I of the National Housing Act from $2,500 to $5,000.
First-quarter operations this year by the Richfield Oil Corporation resulted in a net profit of $547,784 after deductions for all charges, including estimated provision for in Federal income taxes.
The provisions of its regulations dealing with directors' review of actions of trust department committees of national banks were clarified today by the Federal Reserve Board in its current bulletin.

While the sorrowing parents of little James Bailey Cash Jr. stood at his graveside here late today, Franklin Pierce McCall was transferred from Federal Bureau of Investigation headquarters to the county jail, following a full confession, according to J. Edgar Hoover, FBI chief, that he alone was responsible for the kidnapping and death of the 5-year-old son of the Princeton (Fla.) merchant.

The New York Loan and Security Corporation, 60 East Forty-second Street, New York, has filed with the State Banking Department a certified copy of dissolution of its corporate status, according to an official announcement today. The order was granted on June 1.
Union College faculty members today paid tribute in a special memorial service to Dr. Earl E. Cummins, Professor of Economics at the school since 1931, who died last Tuesday after a long illness.

Five large stockholders of the Insuranshares Corporation of Delaware forced its sale to the men alleged to have looted it, Harry M. Blair, former president, said yesterday at the Securities and Exchange Commission's investmenttrust hearing.

A sharp contra-seasonal increase was registered in cotton-mill activity last week, and the adjusted index jumped to 94.1, a high for the year. It stood at 81.3 for the preceding week and at 147.8 for the week ended June 5, 1937.

Unconfirmed reports that the Indian Government will step in to halt the continued accumulation of burlap stocks in the face of slow trading were circulated yesterday in Calcutta, according to cables received here by C. E. Rockstroh Co. The government action,

Trinity -Sunday will be observed tomorrow. In the majority of Protestant churches tomorrow -will be annual Childrens Day, with services devoted to programs by the Sunday school and the presentation of certificates for perfect attendance and memorizing Bible verses.

Point was given to one of the most gracious activities of the Works Progress Administration when Lieut. Col. Brehon Somervell made public figures on the trees and shrubs thus far bought by this agency for the City of New York. More than sixty thousand trees

Professor O. G. Felland, for fifty years Professor of History at St. Olaf College, Northfield, Minn., and one-time pastor of the German Lutheran Church there, died in the home of a daughter, Mrs. A. E. Armstrong, at Bronson, near here, this afternoon.

The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors forbade yesterday any interruption of light, heat or power by the Long Island Lighting Company or its employes. The action was taken as the State Mediation Board began negotiations to avert a threatened strike of the cornpany's workers.

The trial of two schoolboys on disorderly conduct charges was postponed again yesterday in Bronx magistrate's court when Magistrate Overton Harris, who had ordered the mother of one of the youths to whip the boy until she brought out welts on his body, was informed that efforts to have the case dropped had failed and that the case would have to be heard in New York County.

The high point in the celebration of the eighth anniversary of King Carol's return to Rumania was reached today when a group of cyclists arrived from the village of Rev--where the exile arrived from Paris by plane-with a flask of water commemorating the fact that it was a peasant - woman of that village who offered the King his first drink of water on Rumanian soil.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

A government forecast that the 1938 wheat harvest in this country would be 1,020,623,000 to 1,045,623,000 bushels-the largest on record--gave impetus today to preparations for drastic Federal control of next year's crop.
Miss Frances Perkins arrived here today, the first American Secretary of Labor to attend the annual International Labor Conference.
Three companies were cited for efficiency of their products and equipment in a Times Square sidewalk-cleaning demonstration early yesterday, sponsored by the Outdoor Cleanliness Association.

A rehearing of the Supreme Court decision in the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company case, in which the National Labor Relations Board obtained one of its most important victories of the past term, was asked of the court today.

A WPA clerk in the Fire Department division of combustibles; Municipal Building, Brooklyn, was charged yesterday with threatening the lives of three families in the Greenpoint section early on the morning of June 2 by setting cellar stairs afire.

James Roosevelt, son and secretary of the President, rejected tonight a citizens committee's request that he run for Lieutenant Governor of Massachusetts, declaring "I feel that I have an obligation above all else to remain at my duties" in Washington.

Directors of the Singer Manufacturing Company authorized yesterday an extra dividend of $1.50 a share in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of $1.50 on the common stock. On March 31, last, the company distributed $2.50 extra and the regular dividend.

Arturo Toscanini will conduct a "Wagner Festival" concert as a special feature of the International Music Festival which will be held in Lucerne, Switzerland, from midJuly to the end of August, it was announced yesterday.

Marshall Diggs, acting Controller of the Currency, was the prinicpal speaker today at the second day's session of the twentieth annual convention of the District of Columbia Bankers Association at the Homestead Hotel here.

The marriage of Miss Virgina Jeannette Richmond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Wilbert Richmond of Mount Vernon, to Walter Jennings Gano Jr., son of Mrs. Grace Garvin Gano of Mount Vernon and of Mr. Gano of Miami Beach, Fla., took place here tonight in Christ Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Harold F. Hohly.

The Germar default on the Austrian internal. tional debts, made effective by the refusal to pay the debt service charges due June 1, has thus fax been kept strictly. secret in Ger. many, but comes as no surprise to informed quarters here.

Jersey City's Little Giants inaugurated their night baseball season tonight before a crowd of 17,213 by scoring a 4-to-O victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs, their fourth straight in the present series.
Mr. and Mrs. Elton Parks of this city and Katonah have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Parks, to De Witt Peterkin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. De Witt Peterkin of Garden City.

The Federal Power Commission approved today revised rates schedules for the sale of power from the Bonneville Dam project on the kilowatt-year basis proposed by John D'. Ross, administrator; with certain changes agreed upon in conferences between the commission and the administrator.

While total earnings from current operations and total current expenses of member banks in 1937 were at about the same level as in the previous year, net profits were smaller than in 1936 principally because of a reduced amount of recoveries on loans and investments and of profits on securities sold, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
It is not so common nowadays to hear people say that America has been good to them.

The Polytechnic Preparatory Country Day School graduated eighty-four students yesterday at its eighty-third commencement exercises in the Alumni Memorial Chapel, Seventh Avenue-and Nipety-fourth Street, Brooklyn. More than 900 persons attended and heard Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General in New York, deliver the commencement address.

The Aaron Naumburg scholarship for study abroad during the junior college year was awarded to Leonard Canter, a junior at City College School of Business and Civic Administration, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president.

A minimum wage of $16.50 for a forty-five-hour work week affecting about 16,000 women and minors employed in 8,000 beauty shops throughout this State will become law Aug. 1, it was announced yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner.

The New, York City Housing Authority is perfecting the process which will be used to select tenants for the 6,000 apartments to be available in the Red Hook and Queensbridge projects late in the Summer of 1939.
President Roosevelt discussed railroad legislation with Senator Wheeler and Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation; sent to the Senate the
Years of Congressional effort to revamp and liberalize the 50-year-old bankruptcy statutes were marked by passage by the Senate today of a bill already approved by the House.
Brig. Gen. William Horner Cocke, former superintendent of Virginia Military Institute, 1924-29, and veteran of the Spanish and World Wars, died last night at a Richmond hospital at the age of 64.

Miss Katherine Burton Standing, daughter of the late Sir Guy and Mrs. Standing, was married to David Vernon Shaw Kennedy, New York and Chicago sportsman, here today by the Rev. Martingale Woods of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

H. Boardman Spalding of the law firm of Lewis Kelsey and a director in A. G. Spalding Brothers has been elected president of the Better Business Bureau, James C. Auchincloss, chairman of the board, announced yesterday.

William de Krafft will resign as chairman of the finance committee of the United States Rubber Company on June 30 after more than eight years in that post, it was learned yesterday. He plans to sail on a three months' tour of Europe early next month.

The War Department in Washington, it was learned yesterday, has vacated the first lieutenant's commission held in the Medical Reserve of the army by Dr. Ignatz T. Griebl, the former Yorkville physician charged with espionage, who has found refuge in Germany.
Insurgent air raiders in planes of German or Italian manufacture continued today their methodical bombardment of four Mediterranean ports, destroying three British and French ships.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market continues very dull, although there seems to be a somewhat broader movement of wool in the West. Buying is somewhat heavier and consignments are also more general as shearing widens out.

The Rev. Mark Moeslein will commemorate the sixtieth anniversary of his ordination to the priesthood Tuesday at 10:30 A. M. at a special service in St. Michael's Monastery Church, Union City, N. J., of which he is a former rector.
The forty-first annual conference of outgoing missionaries of Presby*terian Church in the United States of America opened yesterday at headquarters of the Board of Foreign Missions, 156 Fifth Avenue.

Conferees on the Relief-Recovery Bill agreed in a brief session today to retain the $175,000,000 Senate increase in the WPA fund, theoretically voted to cover eight months on a pro rata basis, whereas the $1,250,000,000 voted by the House was intended to cover seven months.

An "impartial investigation of conditions at Brooklyn College" will be launched next week by the Brooklyn League of the Citizens Union, Orrin G. Judd, president, announced yesterday. Faculty members and students of last term are to be questioned regarding Communist propanganda in the college.

Mrs. Ary J. Lamme of the home club, topseeded and favored to annex the singles championship, and Mrs. John J. Schieffelin of Mount Kisco, seeded No. 2, won their semi-final matches in the third annual invitation tennis tournament of the Manursing Island Club today.

Before an audience of 1,000 pupils, religious teachers and parents yesterday afternoon Cardinal Hayes distributed a silver loving cup and seven medals to prize winners in the annual diocesan Christian doctrine competition at Cathedral High School, 560 Lexington Avenue.

Alex Kampouris, handsome young second baseman whom Bill Terry frisked out of Cincinnati last Monday night, paid off handsomely on the transaction today when, with the bases full in the seventh, he unfurled a line single that sent two runs scurrying over.

The special Mexican Claims Commission, which \was appointed three years ago to determine the distribution to American claimants of sums paid by Mexico into the United States Treasury on account of damages incurred during revolutions in Mexico from 1910 to 1920, completed its work today by. allowing 1,358 claims in whole or in part out of 2.833 that had been filed.

Commencement exercises for nineteen graduates of St. Agnes Seminary, 2,221 Avenue R, Brooklyn, were held yesterday afternoon in the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Lafayette Avenue and Ashland Place. Mgr. Timothy.

As was expected new bond financing this week showed a sharp drop in volume from the preceding period, amounting to $35,850,000 as compared with $205,394,odo last week, the latter being the largest total for any similar period in more than two years.

Simon Elmore, 57 years old, a house painter, of 54 Metcalf Street, Stapleton, S. I., was found guilty of murder in the first degree in the attack killing of Joan Kuleba, 4, in an abandoned bungalow near South Beach, S. I., by a jury of twelve men in Richmond County Court yesterday afternoon.

Governor A. Harry Moore wil address the sixty-eight graduates o Centenary Junior College at the sixty-third annual commencement tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock in Whitney Hall. Charles H. Lotte o Paterson, president of the board trustees, will present the diplomas Prizes and awards will be an nounced by Dr. Robert J. Trevor row. president.

It is reported here that a raid has been made on the nine-foot barbed wire fence which is being erected for twenty-five miles on the northern frontier to prevent terrorists from coming into Palestine.

After five weeks'of stringency, during which relief has been financed largely out of city operating funds, Cleveland was assured of a breathing spell this week which will last through June. A permanent, or even semipermanent, solution to the State's relief problem is still not in sight.

President Charles Seymour of Yale told a delegation of the American Federation of Teachers today that as far as he was concerned the failure of the university to reappoint Jerome Davis to the faculty in 1936 was a "closed incident."

SPEAKING of Frank Borzage and George Stevens, as we expect to be, brings up the matter of the unsung motion picture director. We remember a poll conducted by one of the theatre circuits not so long ago in which the patrons were Invited to name their favorite stars, pictures, stories and directors.

The Census Bureau reported today that the total of cottonseed crushed in the ten-month period, Aug. 1 to May 31, amounted to 6,041,681-tons, compared with 4,384,738 in the corresponding period a year ago.

Details of the plan for construction of a large garden apartment colony on a seventeen-acre tract in the Fleetwood section of Yonkers were announced yesterday by Walter E. Kelley and Joshua M. Fiero Jr., chief sponsors of the project.
Alexander Robinson, operator of a group of hotel drug stores, died early yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 72.

A TOTAL of 7,631,267 radio sets were sold in this country in 1937, totaling $404,457,150, as compared to 100,000 receivers sold for $5,000,000 in 1922, according to charts issued by the United States Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

Many Americans of no great age will remember the sparkling personality of Yvette Guilbert. Perhaps one had better say personalities, for she peopled with many characters the stage on which she appeared alone.

To say that French eating habits and Parisian menus are being Americanized would be an exaggeration, yet the fact persists that America more and more is exerting-an influence upon gastronomy as this refined art is practiced in France. American dishes,

The friends of Maria Chapdelaine will pay tribute tomorrow to the memory of Louis Hemon, who died before his epic portrayal of the rugged life of French Canada brought fame to the cheery, laborious habitantt" of Quebec.

To the Screen Editor: The current discussion regarding the problems of former child actors illustrates again the observation that "there is nothing-new under the sun." "Hamlet," Act II, Scene 2, gives evidence that child actors were a very real problem in Shakespeare's day.
A new educational philosophy is needed by American schools and colleges which will take into consideration the fact that mass education has displaced the former concent of schooling for the few. Dr.

Henry L. Mencken, Baltimore editor, author and critic, sailed yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Columbus for Germany to spend a six-week vacation. It will be his first visit to that country in ten years.

Sun Dial, 3-year-old trotting colt from the Newbrook Stables, easily won the Class A event, feature of the matinee at Weequahic Park today. Driven by Bert Boylan, Sun Dial, a Hambletonian candidate, defeated Warren Holmes's Swan and William Parkhurst's Calumet Eve in straight heats.

ONE vivid impression stands out from my first visit to the United States. I spent two months here, traveling from New York to Los Angeles by car. Nowhere in this vast country have I seen a single gas-proof shelter, not one poster advising the population on the fundamentals of air-raid protection.. I did not see a regular soldier in uniform.

The Federal Government imprisoned Major John R. Brooke Jr. today on a charge that he murdered his wife, but its spokesmen would not say what motive the government would allege or disclose any of the circumstances of the death.

AKELIATIS--Of Tuckahoe, N. Y., on June 11, 1938, Elizabeth Rudwall, beloved mother of Josephine M. Feeney of 23 Huron Road, Tuckahoe. Service at Scranton, Penna. BERNDT-Qtto, suddenly, June 8, 1938. Funeral service private, Campbell Funeral Church, Broadway at 66th St., Monday, June 13. Kindly omit flowers.
THREE unique and valuable institutions the British have that we in America have not: Magna Charta, the Tower Bridge and Alfred Hitchcock, the greatest director of screen melodramas in the world.

The Associated Industries of Massachusetts report that, despite the general decline in business activity, new industrial construction representing a cost of more than $10,000,000 has recently been completed in that State.
Making his second of three scheduled appearances with the National Broadcasting Company Symphony Orchestra, Bernardino Molinari conducted last night's weekly broadcast from Studio 8H of Radio City.
The Civilian Conservation Corps, set up by the Roosevelt Administration to take idle youth off the street corners, found jobs in private industry for a third of its entire enrollment. last year.

Mrs. Ethel Post Dieterich, widow of Alfred Elliott Dieterich, and James Irving Bush of New York were married here at noon today. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Walter Rockwood Ferris at By Peach-Blossom, his country estate here.

Public relief has been the subject of political charges ever since it was begun in 1933. Lewis W. Douglas, then Director of the Budget, warned when the first major relief appropriations were made that huge expenditures of that kind could, if used to such an end, virtually perPetuate a party in power.
K INGSTON, N. Y.-Throughout the Catskill Mountains resort officials are expecting a restless Europe to provide them with one of the busiest seasons in many years. As a result,

The stock market again showed a modest gain on the week, but at the same time established a fifteenyear record for dullness. Firmness of share. prices reflected business hopes for improvement in the Autumn as a result of bumper crops and the government's spendinglending program.

Yale o'Nine, owned by Thomas D. Taggart of French Lick Springs, Ind., scored his fourth impressive victory in four starts today by defeating Warren D. Wright's Beau James by a head in the $5,000 added Joliet Stakes at Lincoln Fields after a furious stretch drive. The stretch-running 2-year-old son of Peter Hastings, named for his
A continued deficit in the foreign missions work of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America-was reported yesterday by the treasury department of the Board of Foreign Missions.

THE most lonesome road may prove of vast interest in June to the motorist who keeps his eyes and ears open. In fact, the more lonesome the betterif he would enjoy the sights and sounds that greet him.

Tiny, white portable cottages for the use of tubercular patients on hospital waiting lists and convalescents are being built by Works Progress Administration workers and National Youth Administration students as rapidly as possible.

Traditionally, the course of the stock market reflects the state. of- financial and business feeling; sometimes it foreshadows the future. The extreme inactivity of the present security market, with prices varying but slightly, indicates for the most part little but the existing perplexity in both financial and industrial circles. On June 3,

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey of New York County appealed to the Constitutional Convention in a speech here today not to tie the hands of the prosecuting officials and the police and "provide immunity for gangsters and swindlers" by passing two proposals now before that body which would outlaw evidence gained by wiretapping and searches and seizures without a warrant.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: What sound American journalism, and notably your own,-has to say about current British opinion on the fear of war is most encouraging and even surprisingly so to a visiting journalist from the English provinces. I rejoice that the reporting of our views is in your hands and that you do not forget the weight of our steady provincial opinion.

Confronted with the largest wheat crop in the history of the country, President Roosevelt today summoned Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, and Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State, to the White House and asked them to ascertain the status of European wheat conditions, with a view to disposing of some of the surplus through foreign trade channels.

The Japanese Cabinet has sanctioned Premier Fumimaro Konoye's request for a five-Minister conference, which will amount to a wartime super-Cabinet. The press interprets this as giving the five-Minister conference legal status.

WASHINGTON. --Although Congress has abandoned the old shelterbelt project, initiated in the early days of the New Deal, the Forest Service has undertaken, with WPA labor, a new shelter-belt program. Under the old project, little cooperation from the farmer was required

Whatever its permanent effect, San Francisco's first experiment with the town meeting method of attacking industrial relations problems has left the city in a glow of good feeling and mutual congratulations. It seems to have vindicated the contention of the Employers

Leonard Hartman, former Columbia ace, who sought to retire the coveted Brooklyn Cup, which has been in competition since 1918, will have to wait another year at least. He was eliminated by Frank Bowden of the University Heights Club in the semi-final round of the Brooklyn tennis championship yesterday at the Terrace Club of Flatbush, bowing by 6-2, 4-6, 7-5, 6-1.

The United States, re-established as the world's largest producer and consumer of beer following relegalization in 1933, produced 58,748,087 barrels, or 68,932,000 hectolitres, in 1937, according to a report made public yesterday by the United Brewers Industrial Foundation.

Reports and rumors of a complete paralyzation of the automobile industry during July and August received first official recognition this week when directors of the Automobile Manufacturers Association at their annual meeting here issued a statement saying that a substantial percentage of the plants would continue in operation well into August.

Andrew R. Armstrong, coalition leader of the City Council and American Labor party member, said yesterday that Councilman Louis Hollander was speaking only for himself 'in saying that the five Labor party Councilmen had withdrawn from the coalition and constituted themselves an independent unit.

Richard Schmitz, former Christian Social Mayor of Vienna, is reported to have died in the concentration camp at Dachau, following a cancer operation. Together with numerous other well-known Austrian Government. leaders, Herr Schmitz was removed to the Bavarian concentration camp soon after the annexation of Austria.

Miss Natalie Browne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Heckscher Browne of Flushing, L. I., was married to-Charles H. Fitzwilson Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Fitzwilson of Pittsburgh, yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration.

Reporting that Fall buying is considerably delayed, John Block, head of the resident buying office of Kirby, Block Co., in a bulletin to members expresses the fear that "many department stores will be overcautious, with the result that they will all come into the market at the same time to buy goods for early Fall delivery.

One of the largest remodeling jobs ever undertaken in the Washington Heights section is now under way at the Riviera, a thirteen-story apartment structure occupying the easterly blockfront on Riverside Drive, between 156th and 157th Streets.

THE season's chief addition to the cafe society circuit, La Conga, is closing down its main room on Thursday and will content itself with an air-conditioned sidewalk cafe for the warm months. El Morocco will be

PARIS. EVEN in Paris, from a typically Moorish minaret, echoes the century-old cry of the muezzin that Allah is Allah and Mohammed is his prophet. "Come to prayer! Awake, ye sleepy ones, for prayer is better than sleep!" is heard on the Parisian air,

The United Automobile Workers of America are using the Works Progress Administration- in Detroit as a recruiting ground for union membership among Ford employes temporarily on work relief, Victor Reuther, Detroit organizer for the union, revealed today.

After a lapse of almost three months, the difficult situation growing out of the seizure of the foreign-owned oil properties in Mexico is becoming more involved almost daily for the parties most concerned. The failure to make

Municipal Court Justice John M. Lewis, chairman of the dinner being given for Joseph J. Burkard, New York County Commander of the American Legion, announced last night that Police Commissioner Lewis A. Valentine would be one of the speakers at the event Wednesday evening at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Miss Florence Eloise Peck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Nelson Peck of Peekskill, N. Y., was married to George Douglass Gould, son of Mrs. James S. Gould of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Gould, here yesterday morning in the Church of the Ascension. The Rev. Vincent L. Bennett performed the ceremony.

THE man who togs himself out in the latest sports and beach accessories these days is truly an internationalist, at least in so far as those items are concerned. He may wear a Tyrolean or Jippi Jappa hat; Viennese hopsacking neckwear;

Miss Jane Harper Sibley, greatgranddaughter of Hiram Sibley, first president of the Western Union Company, was married here this afternoon to Gordon Auchincloss 2d, whose great-grandfather, Samuel Sloan, was prominently associated with -the building of the railroad systems that serve New York City.
Four men and a woman were killed today when a private plane piloted by William 0. Bashaw, aged 34, Seattle, dived on a farm near here.

A demonstration of what United States fighting planes can do will be given in Great Britain on June 25 by Major Alford J. Williams, American stunt flier, in one of the most unusual "request" performances ever held to create interest in fighting machines.

Mounting taxes and reduced income from real property in this city are cited as perils to ownership by Lawrence B. Elliman, president of Pease Elliman, Inc., in a plea to taxpayers to support the proposed change in the State Constitution creating a State board to hear appeals from assessed valuations. He urged every taxpayer to write

The Nassau Driving Club held its first regular trotting program of the season at the Fair Grounds today, with Allie Cornwell's 3-year-old Prosita, driven by Robert Magee winning the feature event in two straight heats.

The ten thousand volume rare book collection of Mrs. Miriam Lutcher Stark, recently given to the University of Texas, has been installed in the penthouse of the new thirty-story library and main building of the university.

Mail orders received in the wholesale market last week compared favorably with the quantities received during the previous week and, with improved weather conditions, a substantial increase is foreseen in demand for Summer merchandise, according to a special summary of wholesale market conditions

The Murray Prior Lien Law, enacted to permit the city to remodel old-law tenements when their owners are unwilling or unable to do so, was attacked as unconstitutional last week before the Appellate Division by the Central Savwings Bank, the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank and the Dry-Dock Savings Institution.

Alumnae of Wellesley College will enroll June 20, immediately after the commencement exercises, for a three-day venture in adult education. Nine members of the faculty will remain until June 24 to lecture to these "graduate students" on a variety of topics centering in the general theme:
Misfortune still was camping on the trail of Onkel Franz Frisch and. his Cardinals today when suddenly rain fell so heavily that considerable damage was averted.
Pursued by State troopers, Manuel Raposa, 20, of East Providence, drove a stolen car at 90 miles an hour into a rotary traffic island early today and was fatally hurt.
Indian Joe Chitwood of Tulsa, Okla., won the 100-mile Altoona-Tyrone speedway Flag Day automobile race today from a field of twenty-three starters, covering the distance

Shocked by Buffalo's slum areas and critical of the Kenfield Federal Housing Project as not consistent with true lowcost objectives, the housing committee of the Constitutional Convention revealed, after an inspection here today, plans to draft a model housing program for the State.

THE New York Stock Exchange has just passed through a palace revolution that has swept from the positions of power all those who formerly guided it and has brought into being a new form of stock market government. The revolution was in part,

Coming up through the middle of a field of eight, Mythical King yesterday captured the $6,975 Shevlin Stakes at Aqueduct, in which The Chief made his comeback to racing. The former C. V. Whitney colorbearer, now carrying the silks of Maxwell Howard, was a hard going second, a length and a half behind the Pharamond II colt, who scored for B. F. Whitaker.

Mrs. Samuel Theodore Clark of Great Neck, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Anne Joy Clark, to Thomas Allen Shields of Bronxville, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Shields of Cold Spring Harbor, L. I.

Monumental architecture is as essential for the country as is good housing for the masses, declares Ralph Walker of this city, chairman of the city planning committee of the American Institute of Architects.

Native-born Americans who have spent most of their lives abroad are returning to the United States in increasing numbers because they fear persecution or privation in Europe, according to a report prepared by Miss Virginia Murray, executive secretary of the Travelers Aid Society, submitted yesterday to the Greater New York Fund.

A mural depicting the possibilities for good and evil that lie in science will be the unusual gift of the senior class to Antioch College. The artist will be Gilbert H. Wilson of Terra Haute, Ind., who has won recognition for his mural paintings in the Terra Haute High School and in the Indiana State Teachers College there. .

Pointing to the "staggering proportions which public debts of all characters already have reached," and expressing the belief that New York City in particular was in no position to finance an extensive housing program "without endangering other needs," the Merchants Association of New York reported yesterday that it had submitted to the State Constitutional Convention a program calling for rent subsidies to replace direct capital outlays by government agencies for public housing.
