Amid all the ceremony befitting such an occasion, metropolitan baseball fans will see their first major league game at night. on Wednesday. Burleigh Grimes will lead his rampant Dodgers against Bill McKechnie's Cincinnati Redlegs to usher in the arclight campaign at Ebbets Field.

Massachusetts Utilities Associates, Boston, a subsidiary of the New England Power Associates, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a declaration under the Holding Company Act covering the issue of an unsecured note or notes in the amount of $4,000,000 to be dated Aug. 8 and to mature in two years.
The cartel for the distribution of nitrate of soda and synthetic fertilizers in world markets, which expires June 30, will be renewed, it was announced in well-informed circles today.
Riding along on a fresh westerly breeze, Charles B. Rockwell's Belisarius tonight led at the halfway mark on the 105-mile Whalers' race from this port to Block Island and back.
ALEXANDRIA BAY.-A hundred years ago border raids from United States territory were prevalent along the Canadian border. They came near causing a war.
CALLED "The Quaker" because he dressed modestly in gray and black, Jim Wallace grew a bit weary of the reputation his expertness with his guns had won for him in Coman County; and because he
Japanese aviators have horrified the world with their efforts, as explained by-Admiral Nomura, to "insure maximum accuracy in the policy of bombing only military establishments."

The new motor liner, Oslofjord, of the Norwegian America Line will make her first appearance in New York Harbor early tomorrow afternoon, according to announcement yesterday. She will be met at Quarantine by a reception committee appointed by Mayor La Guardia, headed by Wilhelm Morgenstierne, Minister of Norway to the United States.

CLAMAN--HERZ--Mr. and Mrs. Louis Herz, 160 Riverside Drive, announce engagement of their daughter, Helen, to Milton Claman, son of Mrs. Leah Cohen and the late Julius Cohen. DRAPKIN--GOLDMAN-Mr. and Mrs. Si-mon L. Goldman announce postponement of engagement reception for their daughter, Terry Janet, and Mr. Richard L. Drapkin, because of a sudden death in the family.

Sales of single-family homes since Jan. 1 in Bergen County, N. J., by the Alexander Summer realty firm of Teaneck represent an aggregate value of $750,000, reports Mr. Summer. He points out that while the dollar volume is about the same as last year for the same period, the number of deals is greater as the average purchase price today is somewhat less than in 1937.

Escaping carbon monoxide gas from a charcoal cook stove felled seven diners last night in the Rivington Roumanian Restaurant, at 44 Rivington Street. A closed damper on the stove caused the gas to escape into the room.

ALBANIA has issued two silver coins to date in commemoration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of her escape from Turkish domination, which occurred on Nov. 28, 1937. They are 1 and 2 frank ari, or "franc gold."

The marriage of Miss Mary Agnes McGarry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. McGarry of New York, to Dr. Theodor Karl Just of South Bend, Ind., son of Mrs. Alois Just of Krems, Germany, and the late Mr. Just, took place yesterday morning in the Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church.

The eight-story apartment house at 206-208 West Ninety-second Street, east of Broadway, will be sold at auction on Tuesday in the Vesey Street rooms by - Henry Brady. The sale is due to foreclosure proceedings brought by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank

On his own application, to take effect 12 Midnight, June 11, 1938, Patrolman John W. Abt, 7th Precinct, at $1,000 per an num. Appointed April 7, 1913. Transfer Ordered To take effect 8 A. M.. June 13, Lieuten ant Raphael DeMartino, from 11th Division to 18th Division; assignment to desk duty discontinued.

Thirtyeight members of the senior class at the Hun Preparatory School here received diplomas in graduation exercises at which Dr. Frank Mather, former head of the Art Department of Princeton University, delivered the commencement address.

GEOLOGICAL highway markers, placed along highway 77 in the Arbuckle Mountains and to the south, in the area near Ardmore, Okla., have attracted wide interest, Robert H. Dott, director of the Oklahoma Geological Survey, has reported to the Geological Society of America.

The dollar continued yesterday to fall in the foreign exchange market as Europe discussed the possibility of a further devaluation in the United States money. The pound sterling rose 13-16 cents to $4.97 3/8, at which price it was up 2 9-16 cents in the week. The French franc gained 1/3 point to 2.78 3/4 cents, up 1 point in the week.

Thomas J. Healey's Tatterdemalion was the winner today of the second running of the $5,000 added Brandywine Handicap, one of two stakes on the first Saturday card at Delaware Park. The race was a test at one mile and a sixteenth and Tatterdemalion, like El Chico in the Dover Stakes, equaled a track record.

No one of the older generation can think of June-of June brides and college campuses at graduation time--without recalling the mock orange that, through New England and other parts of the Northeast, used to be as common in gardens as the old-fashioned lilac.

ONE hundred miles east of Manhattan, caught between the two elongated prongs in which Long Island terminates-and looking on maps like a choice tidbit in a lobster's claw--is Shelter Island. Until a few days ago, when this long-neglected recreational paradise made headlines, it is likely that many New Yorkers had never heard of the place.

Honorary degrees were awarded to six men prominent in the engineering field by Stevens Institute of Technology at its sixty-sixth annual commencement exercises here today Eighty-eight undergraduates and ten graduate degrees in engineering also were conferred at the exercises held in the William Hall Walker gymnasium.

Patrolman James F. Carberry, attached to Police Commissioner Valentine's staff as an investigator, was found dead of gas poisoning last night, lying on the floor of a hallway in his home at 1,676 East Fifty-first Street, Brooklyn.
Dr. Bradford Knapp, president of Texas Technological College, died today of a heart ailment at the age of 67. He had been in ill health for several months.

Dullness continued to dominate trading yesterday in the bond section on the New York Stock Exchange, with prices generally again tending to softness. Second-grade railroad loans were under pressure, with some sizable losses being registered by obligations in the group. Total sales aggregated $2,378,825, compared with $2,333,900 on Saturday the week before.

The Bermuda Telephone Company is not taking chances even with the Vanderbilt millions, according to a story here. Alfred G. Vanderbilt, who is honeymooning here, wanted to call the United States the other day, according to the story, and explained who he was and what he wanted.

LAKE PLACID.-To add the finishing touch to vacationing here in the Adirondacks-a country of geographic and climatic contradictions in which yachts may approach to within hailing distance of the larger peaks and where ice skating and ski running are among midsummer pastimes-there will soon be "mountain climbing" via elevator.

Following the occupation of Teruel by Loyalist for THE NEW YORK TIMES printed a dispatch, dated Jan. 21, from its Barcelona correspondent telling of evidence gathered by magistrates on the terror in that city while it was held by the Insurgents.
The winning drawing in the national competition for the Paris prize of the Society of Beaux-Arts Architects will be selected tomorrow at the headquarters of the society, 304 East Forty-fourth Street.

The Men's Garden Clubs of America, known as MEGA, will hold its sixth annual convention on Thursday, Friday and Saturday at Jackson, Mich. some of the horticulturists who will take part in the program are A. H. Hottes, Adolph Kruhm, Dr. E. L. D. Seymour and F. F. Rockwell.

ALTCHEK-DAVIDOFF-Mrs. Harris Levit of 725 West 172d St. announces the marriage of her niece, Beatrice Davidoff, to Dr. Emanuel Altchek of New York City, taking place on Sunday, June 12, 1938. CLAYMAN-LEVINE-Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Levine announce the marriage of their daughter, Edna, to Dr. Lawrence H. Clayman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Clayman, on June 11 at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue.

New York State National Guard units will open the Summer training season tomorrow at the two major reservations, here at Camp Smith and at Pine Camp, where all commands will receive two weeks' instruction.

MONTREAL.-One of the outstanding events of the Summer season in Montreal will be held June 23, when the predominantly French population celebrates the birthday of St. Jean Baptist, patron saint of New France. A monster parade

The Joint Congressional Conference Committee voted unanimously today to report a Wages and Hours Bill and will hold a final session tomorrow to make certain that the compromise will go before the House Monday.

The tense situation in Central Europe and the repeated bombings of civilian populations in China and Spain have produced a series of pronouncements and moves in the past two weeks which have sharply focused attention on American foreign policy despite the excitement of the closing days of an important session of Congress and the Senatorial primaries.

AGITATION for the reduction of college enrollment used to be confined to those who believed, along with the late Governor Berkeley of Virginia, that "learning has brought disobedience and heresy and sect into this world." Interests which have reason to fear general enlightenment have always advocated restriction of educational opportunity. Those interests are still at work;

Another coalition between the New Deal and the Farmer-Labor party designed to re-elect Governor Elmer Benson in November in return for the State's liberal vote for the New Deal Presidential nominee in 1940 is believed to be in the making in Minnesota.

What was expected to be a general championship series race today, held by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, turned out to be largely a jumble. It really took the cake for oddity. No one was to blame but the gods of the winds.

FLORENCE. FROM the standpoint of contemporary novelty, the big event of the Fourth Florentive Festival was the launching of Gian Francesco Malipiero's three-act music drama, "Antonio Cleopatra" (after the Shakespeare tragedy).

Joseph W. Catharine, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, has urged the construction of the proposed tunnel from Hamilton Avenue, Brooklyn, to the Battery. "I was greatly surprised," he stated, "to learn that the proposed plan to build immediately the Hamilton Avenue to the Battery tunnel had been shelved.

The use of gas in war is a "relatively humane method of combat," Colonel Adelno Gibson, chemical officer of the Second Corps Area, said yesterday in an address before the New York section of the American Chemical Society at its last meeting of the year at Governors Island.

The Mengel Company declared yesterday the regular semi-annual dividend of $1.25 on the $50 5 per cent first preferred stock. William L. Hoge, president, said the company's strong cash and current position permitted payment of the dividend from capital surplus. The directors also authorized a sinking fund payment to call $100,000 face value of 4 1/2 per cent first mortgage bonds on Sept. 1.

The annual golf outing of the Westchester County Realty Board will be held on Thursday at the Briar Hills Golf Club, Briarcliff Manor. Herbert K. Morrell is chairman of the event, which will include luncheon and dinner sessions.

Presaging early naval and aerial activity against Hankow, synchronized with the army's land push, the commander-in-chief of the Japanese China fleet asked embassies, legations and consulates to warn all foreign shipping immediately to avoid the Yangtze River between

James Bridle and Ivor Novello, who are close rivals with Noel Coward in the race for the largest output, will have new works produced on the London stage next week. Dr. Bridle's play, "Babes In the Wood," coming to the Embassy on Tuesday, concerns itself with a Scots schoolmaster and his wife who live simply and quietly until he writes a technical book which becomes a best-seller.

W. S. Lowndes, director of architecture and building in the International Correspondence Schools, points out that one of the important things to keep in mind when planning to build is the arrangement of closet space. Closets are indispensable and should be installed, he holds, wherever required, as far as the cost of the house warrants.

Although the big 1938 Relief-Recovery Bill, with its approximately $1,500,000,000 for PWA loans and grants, has not yet been enacted into law, the eagerness of local communities to get a share of this gigantic fund already has become so intense that President Roosevelt has felt compelled to warn them that no lobbyists or attorneys are needed to put their applications over.

The title of this story ought to be "The Man Who Won't Stay Dead." He is, or was, Dutch Schultz, born Arthur Flegenheimer. He has been in his grave for nearly three years, but he keeps bobbing up in the prosecutions of rackets, and now
OLITUDE is no longer a specialty at "Robinson Crusoe's Island"-otherwise Juan Fernandez-off the coast of Chile, for American and English tourists have begun to explore it.

The Columbia Pictures Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the nine months ended on March 26 a net profit of $438,268 after depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other charges. This was equivalent,

DOORN. ON June 15, 1888, Frederick III died suddenly at Potsdam after a reign of only 100 days, and his eldest son, Crown Prince William, then an unknown and unready prince of 29, succeeded him as German Emperor and King of Prussia with the title of William II.

THE Will Rogers-Wiley Post Memorial Expedition, which will erect a memorial marker on the spot of the fatal airplane crash of the humorist and his pilot at Wallakpa Lagoon, near Point Barrow, Alaska, made public last week an illustration of the cachet to be placed on mail dispatched from Barrow on Aug. 15, the date of the dedication and third anniversary of the accident.

Construction contracts totaling $283,156,000 were awarded last month in the thirty-seven Eastern States, establishing May as the best building month since July, 1937. Figures compiled by the F. W. Dodge Corporation show that last month's construction volume was 28 per cent higher than the preceding month and 16 per cent over May. 1937.

Mrs. Felix M. Warburg will be hostess on Tuesday at a tea and reception at her home here for women interested in the Westchester feto to be held on Friday and Saturday under the auspices of the Westchester Chapter of the Women's Division of the New York and Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities.
ADMITTING at the start that it doesn't know too many details, this department ventures this morning to guess that Tallulah Bankhead's next vehicle will be a play by Zoe Akins;

A PLAY of exceptional interest, "Glorious Morning," by Norman Macowan, has appeared at the Duchess Theatre. I have sometimes been accused of crabbing a play of substance and quality because I have been at pains, while praising it, to say that it is nevertheless not in the first rank as a work of art.

The process of readjusting Austria's economy to the requirements of the Reich's four-year plan is proceeding at a more leisurely pace than is its political corollary. Political assimilation became simplified once the Anschluss was proclaimed and it is being rushed to completion by an unending series of decrees.

President Roosevelt, in a letter today to Chairman Hatton Sumners of the House Judiciary Committee, denied that he had any "intention of appointing a commission to study the operations of the National Labor Relations Act."

THE new musical score for Paul Green's symphonic drama "The Lost Colony," a pageant commemorating the 350th anniversary of the birth of English civilization in America, has been completed by Lamar Stringfield, flutist in the orchestra of Marc Connelly's "Two Bouquets."
The 161st anniversary of the adoption of the Stars and the Stripes by Congress will be commemorated with Flag Day exercises by patriotic groups here Tuesday.

BATAVIA WITH the announcement ofan expansion in the opernations of the Nitour, or Netherlands Indies Tourist Bureau, the government of the Netherlands Indies is currently making a bid for the large travel trade that has been deflected from zones of strife or tension elsewhere in the world.

Kirawan II, the unusual sloop which her owner, Robert P. Baruch, will sail in the Bermuda race, was launched yesterday at Kretzer's yard on City Island. About 100 were there to watch the 46-foot overall centerboarder enter the water after being christened by Mrs. Baruch.

Harry Jeremiah Moran of 145 West Seventy-first Street, who had been associated with his brother, William Moran, in the business and advertising direction of The New York State Pharmacist, died Friday at the Park West Hospital after a long illness. He was 50 years old.

A large number of out-of-town guests came here for the marriage yesterday noon of Miss Jean Chatfield Clark and Ewing Butler Hawkins, which took place in St. Bartholomew's Church. The Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent, the rector, performed the ceremony.

FOR many of us who have read with absorbing interest the multifold bulletins which have been issued from day to day about the plans for next Summer's World's Fair, there has been a singular and inexplicable omission. We have been told about the

Miss Mary Whalen of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., and Robert Maurice Saul of Rose Valley, Pa., whose engagement was announced last December, took out their license yesterday morning at the Municipal Building and said they would be married on June 25 in the rectory of St. Patrick's Cathedral, this city.

THE Summer is upon us, and now comes the question of filling in the gap in one's already assembled wardrobe. The commuter will hail the advent of sleek, black rayon jersey for allday wear. Frocks of it are just making their appearance. They bring a resounding note from the recent Paris openings: accents on shoulders, hugged-in waistlines and slim skirt silhouettes.

The annual meeting of the House of Delegates of the American Medical Association, which opens in San Francisco tomorrow, will bring to a head -a controversy over health insurance, group medicine and the relationship between the private physician and various public agencies which has been shaking the medical world to its foundations.

PROFESSOR TAUNO H. HANNIKAINEN, conductor of the Turku Symphony Orchestra of Finland, is here as guest of the American Finnish Delaware Tercentenary Committee to appear as conductor of numerous concerts to be given in commemoration of the landing of the first Finnish colonists in America, in 1638.

BROOKLYN may be a borough of churches, baby carriages and awful baseball players, but when the Summer sun shines on Borough Hall it need not pay tribute to Manhattan in so far as roof gardens are concerned.
Class day exercises at Bates College were held this afternoon on the steps of Coram Library. A large attendance of alumni, parents and students witnessed the ceremonies.

Rear Admiral James 0. Richardson, who relieved Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews as chief of the Bureau of Navigation of the Navy Department yesterday, is well known in the navy and in Washington and has had a long and distinguished career.
The allergists met in San Francisco last week to discuss hay fever and other afflictions once dismissed as-mysterious, inexplicable: idiosyncrasies.

Lloyd's Register of American Yachts, which annually in the early Summer is a harbinger of the cruising season ahead, made its appearance last week. Most self-respecting yachtsmen stow it on a shelf on their bridge and some_ Sunday at anchor and after the boating columns in the newspapers are read and digested they thumb its pages and find it a fascinating volume.

Brazil's classic international automobile race will be held tomorrow. Eighteen pilots from five nations have entered. The dangerous "Devil's Trapeze" mountain course, with its twentythree hairpin curves, is 11 kilometers 160 meters long.

More- Summer cottages and cabins have been built this year at the various lake resort communities in the metropolitan area than has been the case for several years, according to recent reports from many of these popular vacation centers. While some of these cottages are of a fairly elaborate character, the majority are simple in type.
NEWPORT, R. I.-The entertainment of royal visitors promises to be one of the features of the season here this year.

THE Symphony Orchestra of Mexico, under Carlos Chavez, will open its tenth anniver sary season of concerts this Friday, at the Palace of Fine Arts, Mexico City. In addition to the regular ten-week series of Friday night events, there will be six free, concerts for workers and as many free concerts for children.

The Hudson River Day Line will operate the first of a series of Sunday "bicycle steamers" to Poughkeepsie, starting today from the West Forty-second Street pier at 9:20 A. M. Passengers will go ashore at Poughkeepsie and mount their bicycles for a ride of nineteen miles to Beacon and Newburgh,

Monroe Miller, broker, has placed two loans of $16,000 for Sunset Estates from the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn on two houses in course of construction at Sunset Drive, near Central Avenue, Lawrence, L. I. These loans make a total of

Miss Dorothy Grace Hughes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hamilton Hughes of Upper Montclair, was married to Henry Barker Fernald Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fernald of Montclair, this afternoon in Union Congregational Church here by the Rev. George C. Vincent.

To satisfy mortgage liens aggregating $9,706,524, a total of ninetyseven Manhattan properties were taken in foreclosure during May, reports the Real Estate Board of New York in its monthly analysis of distress sales. This compares with 111 foreclosures involving $14,087,134 in liens during April.

WASHINGTON. QUIETLY but very swiftly the Bureau of Air Commerce is bringing to completion one of its last major achievements before the new Civil Aeronautical Authority takes over the task of regulating and controlling commercial aviation.
THOUGH the physical background of this novel is for the most part modern Germany, the real background lies in the conflict of the various ideologies fiercely contending for the souls of men.

Thirty-eighth anniversary outing of Xavier Council, 523, K. of C., Elks Club House, Oakwood Heights, Staten Island, 10 A. M. Meeting of the Food Merchants Fair Trade Committee, Center Hotel, 108 West Forty-third Street, 4 P. M.

Sigmund Freud, creator of a new psychology, found another home this week in a land where jackboots and concentration camps are unknown. The entire non-fascist world breathed a sigh of relief when on Monday the slight figure with the omnipresent horn-rim spectacles stepped off the Paris train.

Shmaryohu Leib Hurwitz, since 1927 rabbi, principal and director of the Tiphereth Hagro Talmud Torah in Brooklyn, died yesterday afternoon of heart disease at his residance, 1,350 Eastern. Parkway, Brooklyn. He was born in Kritchev, Russia, sixty years ago.

Commencement exercises at Berkshire School opened last evening with a concert by the school musical clubs, followed by the Junior Prom. The Rev. Dr. Robert Russell Wicks, dean of the University Chapel, Princeton University, delivered the address to the graduating class this morning, and the headmaster, Seaver B. Buck, presented diplomas and prize awards.
Dr. and Mrs. David Baldwin Jewett have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Josephine Jewett, to Dr. John Lantry Mercer, also of this city, son of Thomas M. Mercer of Malone.

The Federal Council of Protestant Churches in Czechoslovakia in an appeal made public here, asserted that Czechoslovak Protestants were willing to go to the limit of sacrifice to preserve the ideals of liberty and democracy and asked for the moral and spiritual support of Christians throughout the weald.

The Westchester County Better Homes Exposition for 1938, which opened last Wednesday at the County Center in White Plains, will continue through Wednesday of this week. One of its outstanding features is the lecture course on home operation and maintenance arranged by the women's committee.

TRADE recovered somewhat last week from its recent sharp slump. More favorable weather conditions brought reports from various sections of the country that demand had turned stronger., Summer goods sold more freely.

Repeating its victory over Great Britain of last year by only a slightly less impressive margin, the United States won the Wightman Cup today for the twelfth time and the eighth year in succession, five matches to two.

Bernard Delehanty, the building superintendent whom local and Federal authorities have been questioning about the kidnapping and murder of 11-year-old Peter Levine, pleaded guilty today to petty larceny and will be sentenced on Monday.

Although declines in retail trade from a year ago were universal in all Federal Reserve Districts, the drop was minor in a few sections. The South, the Southwest and the Kansas wheat section reported relatively small reductions from a year ago. This, together with improve-.

Reveling in the sloppy going, B. F. Christmas's Idle Miss. gained her fourth straight victory today by leading Carlos de la Cerda's Chilean import Shangay Lily by five lengths in the $5,000 added Hannah Dustin Handicap, the mile and a sixteenth feature for fillies and mares, before 17,632 at Suffolk Downs.

ZURICH. BUT for politics, "world philosophy" and such like, Paul Hindemith's "Mathis der Maler" would probably have had its premiere in Germany several years ago. The opera has been ready since 1935, and one of Furtwaengler's most consuming ambitions was to be the first to produce it. Indeed, whether all the facts of

Commending the principles of the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement, representatives of fifty-nine large manufacturers of building supplies in the United States, organized in the Producers Council, yesterday urged an extension of the committee's activities in a "broad-gauge program."

The annual National Collegiate A. A. track and field championships, one of the country's standout meets of the year, will take place Friday and Saturday at the University of Minnesota's Memorial Stadium, Minneapolis.

RICHARD STRAUSS, Ernest Ansermet, Willem Mengelberg and Bruno Walter will conduct this Summer at the international musical. festival weeks scheduled from mid-July through August in Lucerne, Switzerland.

Mr. and Mrs. George W. Haddow of Ossining, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Virginia Haddow, to George Frederick Schnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. William Schnell of Croton-on-Hudson, N. Y.

With many States moving toward larger rural school units and consolidation of schools, Vermont looks with some satisfaction as the school year closes upon the results of a long improvement program that has been typical of the best Vermont and Yankee traditions for thrift and independence.

A general strike was started at 11 o'clock this morning in the State of Puebla in spite of the so-called labor truce agreed to by labor leaders in order to give President Lazaro Cardenas time to solve the problems originating in the expropriation of foreignowned oil properties.

A sum of $95,885,700, the largest for any month this year, was disbursed during April to about 45,142 families in the form of home loans by savings, building and loan associations throughout the country, reports the United States Building and Loan League.

Asserting that the financial plight of American railroads is due: primarily to unsuccessful transactions forced on them by bankers, Alexander F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, last night told 400 members that in defying demands for a 15 per cent wage cut the brotherhood was fighting "a challenge to our society and our democracy."

Holders of common stock of the United States Steel Corporation of record of May 31 numbered 171,456, a gain of 4,184 since March 5, and preferred stockholders of record of April 28 totaled 65,188, a gain of 1,322 since Jan. 28, the company reported yesterday.

The fresh water situation seems to be improving at last, and while the reports from Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont lakes and streams have been consistently good, the local waters seem to have improved only during the past few days.

Friends and relatives of John R. Longo, 24-year-old political opponent of Mayor Frank Hague who is serving a nine-month sentence in Hudson County prison on conviction of election frauds, charged today that he was being overworked and persecuted in the prison.

With the practice of "wholesaleretailing" definitely banned in the jewelry industry as the result of a United States Circuit Court of Appeals decision last week, trade associations will launch intensive campaigns to stamp out this method of selling in their fields, organization executives indicated yesterday.

A 14-year-old Jersey City boy and his aged grandmother died in Dr. Farmer's private hospital early today as a result of a head on crash of two autos near here last night in which six others were injured, two seriously.
Mr. and Mrs. George B. Williams of Glen Ridge have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Edith Williams, to Minott A. O. Stilson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stilson of Bridgeport, Conn.

ONE of the most important yet perhaps least publicized of Hollywood's hierarchy is the motion-picture camera man. Stars look to him to highlight their best features. Directors depend on him to create photographic atmosphere, an important factor in the success of dramatic stories.

Foregoing his customary week-end bruise on Chesapeake Bay, President Roosevelt today invited Senator Gillette of Iowa, victor in the primary over Representative Wearin, New Deal supporter, to be a luncheon guest in the White House tomorrow.

Mount Holyoke College welcomed more than 500 alumnae to the campus today and greeted parents and friends of the graduating class. Mrs. John H. Wells of Providence, leading the meeting of the Alumnae Association, announced the election of Dr. Mary Ely Lyman, associate in religion at Bernard College as alumna trustee.

JUNE, which brings graduation exercises, songs of the rose and the glow worm, news of weddings and. remedies for bugs, usually brings a heavyweight championship fight to the radio, and this month is to be no exception. Joe Louis has an engagement with Max Schmeling.

The Prospect Park National Bank of Prospect Park, Passaic County, N. J., said to be the first lending institution to have made an FHA insured mortgage loan, is for the second time in four years enlarging its quarters, reports Thomas E. Colleton, State director of the FHA for New Jersey.
Of the 6,911,970 persons who registered in the unemployment census, of whom 5,103,046 were totally unemployed and 1,328,104 emergency workers, 2,486,479 were formerly and usually
Preliminary work on the navy's new fuel supply depot at Craney Island, part of $3,000,000 worth of military construction under way or planned in this area, is expected to start soon after June 20.

Led by a sharp increase in institutional copy, eleven out of thirtyseven divisions in local department stores had advertising linage gains in May, according to the breakdown issued yesterday by Media Records, Inc. Total linage for the month decreased to 3,195,556 lines, compared with 3,325,894 in May, 1937.
The twenty-first session of the Smith College School for Social Work, under the direction of Dr. Everett Kimball, Professor of Government, will be held on the Smith campus from July 7 until Aug. 31.
Mr. and Mrs. T. Walter D. Duke have left 993 Park Avenue for Lawrence Beach, L. I., where they have taken the Allan Locke home.

ON assignment from a Bangor newspaper to record the true experiences of his Maine neighbors, Henry Buxton has found as much interesting material in Maine villages and on Maine farms as some of the widetraveled foreign correspondents who lately have written books apparently found in all the world.

An increase of 9.3 per cent during May over April in the amount of money spent for building construction in the nation as a whole will be reported in the June 15 issue of Building, the National News Review of Chicago.

WUCHANG, China (by Mail)-Many friends in America have asked me for my views about China's future. Generally speaking, my views are unpalatable - sometimes unprintable. It is a bit difficult, too, to foresee possibilities through the murk caused by the wrath and

Milton T. Middleton, veteran theatrical press agent and company manager, was found dead yesterday afternoon in bed in his room at the New Regal Hotel, where he had been living for the last three years. He was 73 years old.

The ups and downs of the historic Tompkins Square section of Manhattan are brought to mind by the plan just advanced by the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement to organize the property owners of that district to promote a neighborhood rehabilitation program.
BAR HARBOR, Me. - Signs point toward a busy Summer season on Mount Desert Is land and in its various centers, of which Bar Harbor is the principal resort community.
Supply contracts valued at $8,015,957 were awarded in the week ended on June 9 by eleven Federal agencies under the provision of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor announced today.

The Galveston-Houston Company will sell on or soon after Aug. 1, without notice, all shares of its common stock deliverable by it upon surrender of all scrip certificates outstanding at the time of such sale and issuable under the plan of reorganization of the Galveston-Houston Electric Company and its subsidiaries dated March 1, 1935, A. P. Loring Jr., president, announced yesterday.

With the polling day next Friday, this week-end will be one of intense political activity throughout Eire. No fewer than 1,000 speakers will go into action tomorrow, when some 3,000 meetings will be addressed from end to end of the country.
Yale crews refused today to let a pelting rainstorm and heavy fog balk them in their training for the annual regatta with Harvard on the Thames River, June 24.

Miss Mary Stokes Harris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morrison Harris of Overbrook, was married today to James M. Chadwick-Collins, elder son of Captain James ChadwickCollins, British Army, retired, and Mrs. Chadwick-Collins, formerly of Howe Manor, Dorset, England, and now of Bryn Mawr.

New York City will probably have its most healthful year in 1938, Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records of the Health Department, predicted yesterday in issuing his May report, which recorded several new lows in deaths from various diseases.

John Claflin, retired New York dry goods merchant, formerly one of the leaders in-his field, died here this afternoon at his home, Lindenwold. Death was due to a general weakness incident to his age. He would have been 88 years old on the 24th of next month.

Foreign ideologies alien to the American conception of government do not get support in South America, an official spokesman said here today in behalf of President Getulio Vargas. He declared that President Vargas was in complete accord with the measures

The following double-headers were announced yesterday, through The Associated Press by -the National League: At Boston-June 19. Cincinnati: July 1, Philadelphia; July 3, New York; July 31, St. Louis: Aug. 13-14, Brooklyn.
With the fall of Chengchow, at the junction of two of the three main trunk lines in North China, the road to Hankow is open to the Japanese. The fall of Hankow, too, can be taken for granted.

The Chaco peace conference, after three years of arduous and unsuccessful efforts to settle the territorial dispute between Bolivia and Paraguay, ran into a new impasse this week which threatens a definite breakdown of the negotiations.

Robert D. Dripps, former Director of Public Safety in this city and for several years executive director of the Pennsylvania Economics Council, died at his home in Germantown today. He was 61 years old.

SEATTLE. DURING the last week America has seen or heard of the first flight of two of its most ambitious aircraft designs. Oddly, each made its maiden flight on the same day. One was the new Boeing Clipper, flown for the first time from Puget Sound here at Seattle.

Stewart McDonald, head of the Federal Housing Administration, announced yesterday that the FHA is aiming to produce low-rental housing by encouraging the construction of dwelling units suitable from the start for rent at modest figures rather than by arbitrary restrictions of rents.

Air attack against the civilian population shall be absolutely prohibited; The High Contracting Parties shall agree as between themselves that all bombardment from the air shall be abolished. The International Disarmament Conference. meeting in Geneva six years
INDIANAPOLIS. TEN years ago all that remained of Spring Mill, Ind., was a three-story, nativestone mill that had been erected in 1817, and the foundations of nearly fifty buildings.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TMES: There can be no lasting solution of the railroad problem unless, and until, a major surgical operation is performed to remove the cause of the railroads' chronic ailments. Elisha M. Friedman's recent letter to THE TIMES does not deal, except in a general way, with the fundamental problems confronting the railroads.

Any chance the Yankees had to gain on the Indians yesterday at the Stadium was washed out by rain. Until the last moment the decision to postpone was withheld because the intense interest in the series promised a large crowd.

Summer activities for Boy Scouts who remain in the city will include big league baseball games, beach excursions, inter-troop sport contests, hikes, overnight camp trips and sight-seeing tours, according to an announcement yesterday by Charles M. Heistand, director of the field and educational service of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York.

Members of the Kent School crew of Kent, Conn., sailed for England yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Britannic to race for the Thames Challenge Cup in the Royal Henley Regatta to be held June 29July 2 at Henley-on-Thames.

The engagement of Miss Margaret Geib Taylor, daughter of Mrs. David Taylor of this place and the late Mr. Taylor, to Robert Walsh Emott, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Tuckerman Emott of Morristown, has been announced by her mother.

New York State's new law requiring a medical examination and a blood test as a preliminary to marriage will be effective on July. 1. "See your doctor" is the latest command to the prospective bride and groom.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish. It endeavors, therefore,

SULTRY Summer evenings, once a nightmare for a man in a dinner jacket, need no longer hold any terrors. The latest dinner clothes have been as thoroughly air-conditioned as have business and sports clothes.
Rains have been so plentiful recently in this region, ravaged by drought last year, that even the telephone poles are sprouting.

To the Drama Editor: I Don't know if you had anybody covering the Lakewood opening or not, but just in case you didn't I figured I'd write you and tell you about it, just in case you might be interested.

Miss Rosalie Elizabeth Pender, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Pender of this city, was married today to Norman Barrett Hollister, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Hollister, also of this city. The ceremoney was performed in St. Charles Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. James W. McGrath.
Through Thursday the Commodity Credit Corporation had advanced funds on 5,385,107 bales of cotton from last year's crop, it was announced here yesterday through the New York Cotton Exchange.
Mrs. S. Sloan Colt has been named chairman of the Tuxedo Autumn Ball to be held Oct. 22 at the club. As usual, many of the debutantes of the season from the metropolitan district will attend.

The campaign by the North Jersey Transit Committee to obtain improved transit facilities from Northern New Jersey to New York City received further impetus at a dinner last week of more than 300 chairmen and members of the mayors' and trades committees of the organization in Rochelle Park, N. J.

The Navy Department is experimenting with a surface tank which may make it possible to decompress deep-sea divers after they have been hauled up and thus spare them the inconvenience and danger of remaining in the water at different levels, perhaps for hours.

RAVESEND BAY, the threshold of New York Harbor and once a center of American yachting, will again be dotted with the white sails of pleasure craft if plans of the several yacht clubs in the area are even Dartly fulfilled this season.

THE twenty-first season of the Daniel Guggenheim Memorial concerts by the Goldman Band, under the direction of Edwin Franko Goldman, will be Inaugurated on the Mall in Central Park Wednesday night. The first concert at Prospect Park will take place Thursday night.
LONDON. THERE is no time like late Spring to see London at its sartorial brightest, for then the vernal urge to more vivid hues reaches its highest point.

Six exhibition homes are being built at Malverne, L. I., by Wynn Builders, Sam-A. Harris, president. The firm is developing fifty building plots in Malverne Park Gardens at Hempstead Avenue, adjoining the, entrance to the Southern State --Parkway.

A twelve-foot model of the Hapag Lloyd liner Reliance which was built at a cost of about $20,000 was altered in several details last week to conform to the present appearance of the liner. The Reliance was renovated last year in a German shipyard but the model, which is on display at the line's offices, 57 Broadway, remained as the ship had looked before the changes.

In one of the most unusual finals of the thirty-eight-year history of the championship, Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches captured the women's metropolitan golf crown for the sixth time today, vanquishing her New Jersey rival, Miss Charlotte Glutting, by 10 and 9.

Four lower East Side parcels and a Lexington Avenue corner will be sold at auction this week in the Vesey Street Rooms by B. Hollander Son. On Tuesday they will sell the five-story tenements at 189 Rivington Street and 76 and 78 Thompson Street, and on Wednesday the six-story tenement at 196-198 Mott Street. On Friday they will offer

Setting the stage for a brother vs. brother thirty-six-hole final tomorrow, Frank and Tommy Strafaci of the well-known Brooklyn golfing family survived their semi-finalround matches today in the Long Island amateur championship tournament at the Garden City Country Club.

Several deals in Monmouth County, N. J.,. have been closed recently by Marie Cox, broker, at Port-AuPeck and Red Bank. At Vanderhurg the Phillips farm on Colts Neck-Homedel Road was sold to Mrs. Amy von Geldern of Belmar, who will occupy it as a year-round residence. The farm contains seven and one-half acres and. the residence is about 100 Years old.
A SHEVILLE, N. C.-Asheville's eleventh annual Rhododendron Festival, the Southern amateur tennis championship and the Asheville City golf tournament will be features of the calendar here this week.

More than 50,000 adults are scheduled to participate in a series of exercises marking the close of the Spring term of instruction by the WPA adult education program of the New York City Board of Education, Gustav A. Stumpf,

Two hundred and fifty dollars awaits the identification of the gardener, who several years ago sent certain petunia seeds to David Burpee in Philadelphia.

IMPORTANT to philately is an announcement by the publishers of the American standard stamp catalogue that they are cooperating with the Souvenir Issues Association in the complex task of according or denying recognition to souvenir sheets.

Bill Swift went the route today for the first time this season and hit a homer with two aboard to give the Pirates a 4-to-3 decision over the Phillies. Bill's circuit clout-- came in the second and Pittsburgh sewed up the game in the next inning on an error, Arky Vaughan's single and an outfield fly.
The sooner the Roosevelt Administration is stripped of its power, the sooner the nation will achieve genuine recovery, Senator Edward R. Burke of Nebraska said in Chicago today.

REVERSING all previous decisions that have condemned the buccaneering hawk to be shot on sight as wild life's public enemy extraordinary, scientists are now trying to prepare the mind of hunters, game wardens and farmers for the dictum that hawks, after all, are eminently useful.

Lower box office receipts and the decline in exports of American films were the main factors in the decline in profits of motion picture companies this year, according to a tabulation yesterday of earnings of eight leading companies for the first quarter of 1938.

The French and Portuguese Governments have reached an accord giving France the right to use the Azores Islands as a base for a French North Atlantic aviation service, a source close to the Foreign Ministry said tonight.
This column yields to no one in its detestation of such foreign isms as communism and fascism. They are alien to the very soul

AS a creative artist Gustave Flaubert was the product of a struggle between two schools. A romantic, he hated and inveighed against the monotony of bourgeois life, its stupidity and intellectual sterility, for only the unusual and exotic pleased him, and he had what Andre Maurois calls, in his preface to the new Limited Editions Club's "Madame Bovary," the purest form of romantic illusion--the desire to escape. in space and time.

Mrs. Buel Davis, clutching her baby daughter in one arm, warded off an attack by a mad gray fox today finally choking the animal to death. Mrs. Davis was bitten on the leg and badly scratched on the arm by the animal which attacked her when she went to investigate a commotion in her chicken yard.

English and Australian cricketers prepared for the third day's play of the initial match in their five-game test series with England well in the lead. Declaring with a record-breaking 658 for eight wickets, the home team disposed of three Antipodeans for 138 runs before play closed today.

Miss Helen Frances Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph O. Brown of this place, was married to John Avery Curtis, son of Mrs. Osborn Curtis of Point Pleasant, N. J., and the late Mr. Curtis in the Reformed Church here this afternoon.
ALEXANDRIA BA. AFTER having been planned for many years, a new bridge linking New York and the Province of Ontario, Canada, across the St. Lawrence River, is rapidly being built.
Galloping through heat over - a heavy field,. Harvard's polo team reached the final round of the intercollegiate championship today with a victory over West Point, 12 to 10.

OBVIOUSLY inspired by the Washington pastime of regimenting the alphabet into families of three, creators of men's apparel have established their own program for the Summer season, under a Triple C banner.

Miss Louise Phair Morris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Vincent Morris of Mountain Lakes, was married to Dr. Bertram B. Beneville, son of Mr. and Mrs. Prosper V. Beneville, also of Mountain Lakes, this morning in Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Edward I,. McDonald.

LAKE CHARGOGGAGOGGMANCHAUGGAGOGGCHAUBUNAGUNGAMAUGG is the name of the largest and one of the most beautiful Summer resorts in Massachusetts and is located in the industrial town of Webster close to the Connecticut and Rhode Island borders. Its name is pronounced with ease only by natives of Webster and the Nipmuck Indians.

Three of the five games scheduled n the third round of the international chess masters tournament were played to a decision today and Erich Eliskases of Austria and Paul Schmidt of Estonia recorded victories. Eliskases pulled out of a triple tie for the lead by defeating Dr. S. Tartakower of Poland in a queen's gambit declined in forty moves.

Moving quietly in an effort to evolve a complete program before making public announcement of their activities, small groups of leading industrialists are trying to arrange conferences with labor representatives in an effort to work out a mutually satisfactory labor relations and legislative program for

Increased cooperative advertising in newspapers by savings and loan associations in many parts of the country is resulting in "exceptional expansion" of their business, the Federal Home Loan Bank Review, published in Washington, pointed out yesterday.
A field of thirty, including six Olympians, will participate in the national outdoor saber championship tournament on the walks bounding Hofstra College in Hempstead, L. I., today.

The markets presented an unusual study in contrasts yesterday. Share prices moved narrowly in the slowest trading in nearly twenty years. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was only 107,000 shares, smallest since Aug. 3, 1918, when transactions aggregated but 69,000.
STRIKING beauty has been added to the ships of a Norwegian line plying between Oslo and Antwerp by giving them clipper bows and figureheads draped in long, flowing robes.

A public-bidder law was recently adopted by the State of Iowa and it is said to be proving effective in clearing up titls and tax delinquencies on vacant land and restoring such property to use. When taxes are delinquent for specified period, the county may bid in the

The marriage of Miss Ruth Gilmore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Newton Gilmore of Brooklyn and Babylon, to Duncan Cameron Stevenson, son of the late Mrs. Joseph H. Stevenson of Hewlett, L. I., took place here today in the rectory of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James A. Smith.

The commencement at St. Michael's College begins tomorrow, when the Very Rev. William P. Crosby, a rural dean of the Catholio Church in Vermont, gives the baccalaureate sermon to a graduating class of twenty.

Captain Robert A. (Bob) Bartlett, Arctic explorer and author, announced yesterday he would make his annual Summer cruise to Greenland and the polar regions on his Gloucester fishing, schooner Morrissey, leaving New York about June 22. Captain Bartlett,

Mr. and Mrs. Cleveland E. Dodge gave a tea yesterday at Greyston, their place in Riverdale-on-Hudson, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Dodge. Later in the evening Mr. and Mrs. Dodge gave a small dinner dance for their daughter.

The long history of Europe has been filled with the migrations of peoples, the rise and fall of kingdoms, the extension by one nation of dominion over another. The result is a racial map on which regions occupied by a definite nationality are speckled with other nationalities.

The following Foreign Service changes since May 27 were announced today by the State Department: James L. Park of Indiana, Pa., consul at Colon, Panama, and now in the United States on leave, assigned as consul at Beirut, Syria.

Insignia and trophies won during the year were presented today to Army athletes. Brig. Gen. Jay L. Benedict, superintendent of the United States Military Academy, distributed the awards as part of the ceremonies marking the annual June Week program, to be concluded on Tuesday with the graduation of the first class.

Forty-five advanced degrees and 260 bachelor degrees will be conferred by President Robert C. Clothier at Rutgers University's 172d commencement exercises at 3:30 o'clock tomorrow afternoon in the gymnasium. Honors and prizes

The New Jersey State Board of Tax Appeals today affirmed a $25 assessment levied against the firm of Gaines, Silvey Nichols, Inc., insurance brokers, of New York, by State Tax Commissioner J. H. Thayer Martin under a 1937 law placing a franchise tax on out-ofState corporations doing business in New Jersey.

Randolph Scott, motion picture actor, said today that he and his wife, the former Miss Mariana du Pont Somerville, had separated. He said neither contemplates any legal action now. "The separation is entirely friendly," Mr. Scott said.
John Louis De Ruyter, a stock broker, of Spring Valley, near Nyack, N. Y., died yesterday of pneumonia at St. Luke's Hospital, where he was taken from his home last Thursday. He was 31 years old.

WASHINGTON STAY away from fords-not the motor cars, but the shallows where highways pass through waterways instead of over themis the advice service men are passing out around Washington to motorists who come in with funny crackling noises in their front wheels.

Seemingly more nervous than while he was under the strain of competition, husky Ralph Guldahl pocketed a check for $1,000 and went through the routine of accepting the cup emblematic of the national open golf championship today.
WHAT a strange brew is this new novel by Christina Stead! Never submissive to the conventions of story-telling, she has

BENDHEIM, ADOLPH Z. (May 30) Estate, more than $10,000. To the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, 71 W. 47th St., $2,500; Elsie Rosenbaum, cousin, 751 Walton Ave., Bronx, $5,000; Carrie Bendhelm, cousin, Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, $2,500; Melville Strauss, 610 W. 145th

With the turf put out of commission by the rain, the annual invitation doubles tennis tournament of the Piping Rock Club went ahead, nevertheless, on schedule today as private courts on near-by estates were drafted by Chairman Robert LeRoy.

AT the start of the Summer vacation season, surveys by transportation agencies indicate that the recession has not deterred the travel urge of the American tourist, although he may not spend so much money this season as last. Air travel-about 36 per

Mrs. Margaret G. Keogh, wife of Edward S. Keogh, president of the Citizens National Bank of Freeport, died today in her home here at the age of 65. Born in Brooklyn, she had been soprano soloist at St. Paul's, St. Agnes and St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Churches in BrookIyn and was a charter member and the first organist and soloist at the Church of Our Holy Redeemer, Freeport.

You probably read about Director Henry King of Twentieth Century-Fox, flying his own plane into Newark Airport recently. Well, it was true (not a publicity story); the plane is a four-passenger cabin Waco, 1936 model, and Mr. King is already thinking longingly of a '38 model; that's how time flies.

The "best features" of various amendments presented to the Constitutional Convention providing for State and municipal cooperation in low-cost housing and slum clearance are to be incorporated in a single measure which will be dr fted by a subcommittee of the Housing Committee, of which Joseph C. Bal win of New York is chairman.

The Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., at 742 Fifth Avenue, founded and incorporated in November, 1937, reports that since its first sale in January last it has dispersed at public sale under its management in the four-and-one-half-month period $1,251,917.60 of art and literary property.

When the members of the Constitutional Convention get around to the knotty subject of reapportionment they might pay some attention, if they have not already done so, to a recent ariticle by Professor David O. Walter of the University of Illinois in The National Municipal Review.

PARIS IN RECENT weeks there have been half a dozen new plays, more or less good," and one which is in a class quite by itself. Let us take the half dozen first. The best of them is Maurice Rostand's "Catherine Empereur," which, as you may guess, is about the great Catherine of Russia.

All informed students of the economic situation agree upon the importance of preventing monopoly,. of breaking it up where it appears, of maintaining free markets that will at once permit maximum economies in production and distribution and secure the lowest possible prices for consumers.

A fortune which Dean D. Sturgiss, attorney, estimated "might reach" $500,000 was found in an old safe here after the death of a recluse who lived in a house without running water, electric lights or other conveniences.

The Democratic National Committee reported to Congress today that it was $33,000 "in the red." A report filed with the House clerk showed the committee had to supplement its income from cash donations and Victory and Jackson Day dinners with a $25,000 bank loan. On March 1 the committee was out of debt.

Property owners, brokers and representatives of about 100 realty and trade organizations will gather in Albany on Wednesday to urge limitation of real estate taxation and to protest against any proposals which might add to the burden of levies imposed on their holdings.

Janice, owned by Smith Baker Sr. of Lexington, Ky., registered an upset victory in the fourth running of the $3,000 added Pontchartrain Stakes at the Fair Grounds today. The 3-year-old filly finished a length in front of Dixiana's King's Heir, while Volo Snow, owned by Warren Wright of Chicago, .was third, two and one-half lengths farther back.

Seventy-seven young men, the Class of '38 at New York Military Academy, received their diplomas and commissions from Superintendent Frank A. Pattillo at the graduation exercises this morning. The graduation address was made by John G. Shattuck, '05.

All of us are fond of fine shade trees on the home grounds; yet we want fine green lawns also. It is wrongly supposed that one excludes the other-that the shade of specimen trees means poor grass or none at all beneath them.

From the University of Chicago comes the announcement that the cosmic rays found in deep mines are the heavy X particles, now called barytrons, which were almost simultaneously discovered last year by Drs. Anderson and Neher of the California Institute of Technology and Professors Street and Johnson of Harvard.

Plans are under consideration by the United States and Brazilian Governments to send American farmers to the State of Matto Grosso. The two governments, under the proposal, would share transportation expenses and Brazil would allot large tracts of land to each immigrant.

The third annual Eastern Polo League championship will swing into its second week of competition today with an attractive program of low-goal games in the metropolitan area. Four circuit contests are listed, with the Fort Hamilton and First Division fours making their league debuts.

Camp Huntington, a vacation home for the handicapped, will be the beneficiary of a card party to be held the afternoon of June 22 at the home of Mrs. Charles R. Gay in Huntington, L. I. The camp which is maintained in North Woodhull Street, Huntington, by the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities, provides outings in the country during the Summer months for about 140 blind and crippled persons.

BRUSSELS. LIEGE is seeking to obtain United States representation at the Water Technique In ternational Exhibition which it will stage on the Meuse, against its background of mountains, in 1939. The occasion for the exposition is twofold.

A slowly moving tornado killed thirteen persons in this West Texas village of 700 last night, left several missing, injured at least forty others and shattered twoscore houses. Volunteers searched the debris today, fearful that more bodies lay in the wreckage.

Taking advantage of the wide publicity given to the Federal Housing Administration's program for promoting residential construction work by insurance of loans, s racketeers and swindlers again are reported to have started operations "on a wide scale" to cheat prospective borrowers.

Corporal Robert Doran of the Montclair Mounted Troop gained a leg on the Junior Cavalry of America Challenge Trophy, put in competition this year, in the first day of the fourth annual Rock Spring horse show at the Rock Spring Riding Club today.

New London doesn't have to share yachting honors this season with Newport or any other harbor. There'll be no America's Cup race. This means the old seaport at the mouth of the Thames will bask in all its tradition and glory as host to nearly everything afloat in Eastern waters. The day of days,
No little concern has been felt in certain quarters over the effect upon the assets of life insurance companies and policy holders of the increasing defaults and declining values of railroad bonds.

EVERY now and then a new appraisal of the life and character of Walt Whitman has appeared; but usually the effort to catch and define the man's elusive personality has been like the attempt to imprison a bird with a chain of moonbeams. Sometimes, as in the case

Replying to a Communist's question in the lower house, Premier Hendryk Colijn said the government did not contemplate asking Great Britain and the United States to take joint measures to halt the supply of oil, tin and other raw materials to Japan.

Berlin has been warned that unless Germany reconsidered her decision to default on the Austrian loans and other obligations Britain would institute a clearing arrangement to collect the money from the sums due out of German exports to this country, it was learned tonight.

The marriages consummated in Germany increased from 517,000 in 1932, the year before Hitler assumed the direction of the State, to 739,000 in 1937. The birth rate likewise went up from 1,000,000 to 1,300,000 in 1937.
THERE is a legend abroad that the artists and writers of Soviet Russia, as a class, enjoy material privileges which make their lot all but a paradisean one. This legend has a measure of truth in it.

An order requiring Sonia Rosenberg and her husband, Abraham, to show cause why the dress business of Gloria Vanderbilt-Sonia Gowns, Inc., of 23 East Fifty-sixth Street should not be dissolved because of heavy losses was obtained yesterday by Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt and her twin sister, Lady Thelma Furness, from Justice Peter Schmuck in Supreme Court.

The action of the Kuomintang [Nationalist party] supervisory committee recently in "re-electing" to party membership twenty-six political leaders who either were expelled or resigned during the last ten years is considered void here. It will be "reviewed" by 'the Central Executive Committee, according to Kuomintang leaders.

The New England Telephone and Telegraph Company has been ordered by the Rhode Island Public Utilities Commission to reduce to 63 cents the monthly charge of 75 cents on extension telephones. There are 6,770 such telephones in the State.

Research into the mysteries of heredity and growth will be conducted in a new laboratory of genetics which is to be established at Columbia University, it was announced yesterday by President Nicholas Murray Butler.

Miss Elisabeth Gale Washburn, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Carter Washburn of Greystone Park, was married here this afternoon to Walter Lee Savell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Savell of Forest Hills, L. I., in St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Jay Gould Seacord.

The Princeton invitation meet, which has operated with tremendous success on the theory that good things come in small packages, will be staged in Palmer Stadium Saturday, a swift-flowing, compact set of games that is limited to six events and one hour's time.

The science of officiating at ball games will have educational recognition this Summer when E. C. Quigley, supervisor of umpires, National League of Professional Baseball Clubs, conducts a course called "officiating in football, basketball and baseball" at Teachers College, starting July 6.

Miss Phyllis Crawford of 121 Bank Street has won the $3,000 first prize in the 1938 contest for children's literature of the Julia Ellsworth Ford Foundation, it was announced yesterday by Henry Holt Co., publishers, 257 Fourth Avenue.
Sweeping five of six singles matches, the Eastern States team wrested the Sears Tennis Cup from a crack New England squad today in the final round of the annual women's competition.

Plans for the first comprehensive study of the business of trading in bonds were launched last week when representatives of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the New York Stock Exchange, independent bond houses and large Institutional investors met in a round-table discussion of the question whether some of the dealings in bonds now done over the counter might not well be done on the floor of the Stock-Exchange.

Young rabbis about to serve congregations should not be swayed by the allurements of personal fame, but shouldd dedicate themselves to their communities and "remain for a long time at one post," Rabbi Samuel Fredman of Congregation Beth El, Philadelphia, declared yesterday.

TORONTO. COLD fresh-water lakes and rivers breed the best-flavored and gamiest of sport fish. Canada has nearly 200,000 square miles of fresh water, not including the Great Lakes. More than half that area has never been fished, and all of it is pure, cold water, alive with bass, trout, pike, muskellunge, pickerel, land-locked salmon and all the other fresh-water game fish for which anglers go hundreds of miles.

Eighteen false fire alarms were sounded in Manhattan, and one in the Bronx, from midnight Friday until 11 o'clock last night, the largest number in twenty-four hours since New Year's, when there were thirty-four in Manhattan. It is estimated that every alarm costs the city at least $50 in wear and tear on apparatus and loss of time.
An additional 125,000 acres of alluvial land in the Lower Rio Grande Valley will be brought under irrigation when the great main canal and its many laterals, now under construction, are completed.

Calling the government's German spy investigation "very fishy," Seward Bishop Collins, editor of The American Review and former editor and publisher of the Bookman, put up $5,000 bail for Mrs. Ignatz T.

Reports that bar and grill owners of the city planned a cooperative buying organization through which orders for liquor would be placed directly with distillers, brought a statement yesterday that such a project would violate "both the intent and purpose of the law" from Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the State Liquor Authority.

The Tigers capitalized on long hitting and Roxie Lawson's pitching today to beat the Senators, 7 to 2. It was, their second straight victory of the series. Four triples and a double went into Detroit's attack on the Senators.

Welcomed by George M. Slocum, president of the federation, an advance guard of members of the Advertising Federation of America reached Detroit today, ready for the annual convention from Sunday to Thursday inclusive. More than 2,000 delegates are expected.
TOMMASO ANTONGINI sometimes styles himself d'Annunzo's private Secretary, but he is a writer and indeed a public figure on his own merits. One should think of him as a sort of person who has become

Ralph Guldahl, pro at the Braidburn Country Club, Madison, N. J., came from behind with a sub-par 69 on his final round to retain the national open title at the Cherry Hills course in Denver. Starting his last tour of the links in third place, four strokes behind Dick Metz of Chicago, the pace-setter, Guldahl soon went to the front and finished with 284.

Undiscouraged by the results of previous world economic conferences, Secretary Roper has suggested a "world-wide economic conference in which nations would cooperate for the equitable distribution of the basic raw materials of the world."

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity is back to its low for the year and the current depression. Three declines more than offset an equal number of increases among its components for the -week ended June 4 and the index has fallen to 75.1 from 75.7 in the preceding week and compares with 107.8 for the corresponding week last year.
WHEN Samuel Pepys confided to his Diary some innocent information about the purchase of books, he little dreamed that he was posing a major problem for future collectors.

The intention to resist attempts to subpoena all records of the C. I. O., the American Civil Liberties Union and other organizations by Mayor Frank Hague and his Jersey City co-defendants in the omnibus injunction proceedings brought by those two organizations in Federal Court was announced today by their attorneys.
Not all old buildings need to be demolished to make way for new buildings, but in many cases a minor alteration job may turn out to be unsound, and complete reconstruction may be in order.
Five days of the Securities and Exchange Commission's investment trust hearings here have untangled one of the most complicated messes ever brought before an investigating body.

John Harlan Amen, special assistant to Attorney General Homer Cummings, announced yesterday that Jacob (Gurrah Jake) Shapiro, whom he dubbed the present Public Enemy No. 1, will be placed on trial tomorrow for racketeering in the fancy fur skin industry. The charges are based on violations of the anti-trust laws.

GENOA. CESARE ZAVATTINI is a new name in Italian letters. A little volume of scarcely 100 pages appeared a few years ago under the title "Let's Talk a Good Deal About Me," went through a number of editions, if the publishers may be believed.

Baccalaureate solemn high mass In the university chapel this morning will usher in-Fordham University's ninety-third commencement program and preface five days of graduation activity which will include the first senior week for college graduates and the first separate college graduation.

Ranging from Eddie Cantor to Grover A. Whalen, a list of America's "eleven best-dressed men" was offered yesterday by the Fashion Institute of-America, and a sharp warning was sounded for men to get themselves at least ten suits and ten pairs of shoes and, to quit stuffing things into their hip pockets.

A new market outlet for FHAinsured mortgage loans made on existing construction is provided by the RFC Mortgage Company. Recent changes in regulations enable it. to purchase mortgages covering properties on which construction was completed even before - the National Housing Act established a system of mortgage insurance.

" TRAP-DOOR" spiders such as were captured recently in Florida for the American Museum of Natural History have helped to give the spider a bad name and caused it in many instances to be associated in literature with all that is sinister, villainous and evil.

Signatures of nearly all graduates of the Clarkson College of Technology since the class of '01, are contained -in a 16-volume registry compiled by the late John R. Weston and continued by his associates.

Honorary degrees will be conferred on three laymen at the eighty-fifth annual commencement exercises of Manhattan College Tuesday, it was announced yesterday by Brother Patrick, president. The recipients,

The newspaper Asahi reports that the Soviet Embassy has informed .the Japanese Foreign Office that it had instructed the Secretary of the Soviet Consulate in Hakodate to issue permits to Japanese fishing vessels which desire to go to the Northern Pacific.

CANTON, scene of recent Japanese air raids, was tuned in on a recent morning at 6:30 o'clock, when a feeble wave from the Hong Kong area apparently slid up over the polar regions and down to America. After a short and hurried conversation in Chinese the beam suddenly disappeared. leaving the 9.49

WITH -the arrival of Summer people begin to think of trekking northward. It is surprising how far into the North one can go on a short vacation. Aside from the two or three day trips by motor into Canada, there are salt water Journeys to the farther North where no cars can go-even to the barren, moody coast of Labrador, into waters where icebergs may be floating.

GOVERNORS ISLAND So much to paragraph 3, Special Orders 122, dated May 26, 1938, as relates to the following Medical Department Reserve officers, is revoked: 1st Lt. Lester L. klapper, Med.-Res. (2d M. A.) 1st Lt. Elias Livingston, Med.-Res. (2d M. A.) 1st Lt. Otto Rittner, Dent.-Res. (2d M. A.). 1st Lt. Abe Shainmark, sn.-Res. (2d M. A.).
Miss Julia Kingsland Macy, daughter- of Mr. and Mrs. William Kingsland Macy of New York and Islip, was married here this afternoon to W. Cary Potter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alonzo Potter of New York.

Four liners left the New York side of the Hudson River between noon and 5 P. M. yesterday with 4,230 passengers bound for Europe. The Italian liner Rex carried 1,519, the Cunard White Star motorship Britannic had 1,170, the North German Lloyd liner Columbus, 850, and the French liner Champlain. 725.

Twice within a month supporters of Mayor Frank Hague have filled Journal Square, the heart of Jersey City, with rallies which would have done- credit to the crowd-pulling ability of P. T. Barnum, Tex Rickard, Mussolini, Hitler or Stalin.

A total guaranteed purse of $500 is offered by the Cocker Spaniel Field Trial Club of America for the organization's first Futurity Stake to be run in the Autumn of 1939. For the first-place winner the minimum cash prize will be $250, with $125 for second and $75 for third. In addition there will be a prize of
The U. S. S. Ellet, second of three new destroyers authorized by Congress in 1935 and under construction at the Federal Shipbuilding and, Drydock Company here, was launched today.

State officials were reported today to have been assured that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation would lend the Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission enough funds to go ahead with plans for the $60,000,000 "super-highway" between here and Pittsburgh.

Substitution of college ownership and control of Dartmouth publications for a ninety-nine-year-old policy of complete independence of undergraduate editors is proposed in a report submitted to President E. M. Hopkins by his recently
