Winners of twenty-seven cash prizes, totaling $13,700, in a "Liberty Home" and "neighborhoodplanning" architectural competition arranged by-the American Gas Association, with the assistance of the Architectural Forum, were announced here yesterday.

Among the seniors at Wells College who will receive their degrees tomorrow with honors are these students from the New York City area: Jane Burdick of Jamaica, summa cum laude and with distinction in economics. Ruth Pfeiffer of Brooklyn, with highest honors in history; she received the Eugenia Allison Lee Cup, by vote of the entire student body, as the most representative senior.

BALLADS that were sung a century ago to the accompaniment of the woodcutter's axe in Pennsylvania's virgin forests, and street cries that resounded through Philadelphia's and Baltimore's alleyways when fish women and clam peddlers were in their heyday, will vie with other occupational and racial folksongs in the fourth annual Pennsylvania folk festival to be held next Saturday.

Two British working women passed through New York last week on their way to Bryn Mawr Summer School, where, as holders of scholarships, they will spend seven weeks with sixty-eight other women in industry, discussing problems of economics and the industrial society.

Erected at a cost of $250,000, of which about $100,000 came from the estate of Dr. Ellwood R. Kirby of Philadelphia, the new Kirby Memorial Theater at Amherst College, which has been under construction the past year, is now virtually completed, and will be open for inspection at commencement next week.

Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Doddridge DeWitt of Glen Gardner, N. J., and Panama City, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor DeWitt, to Joshua Allan Rich 4th, son of Mrs. May Anna Rich of New York and the late Joshua Allan Rich 3d.
OF the groups which contributed to'Colonial crafts in New York and its envi rons during the early days, one of the most important was the French Huguenots.
A suppressed petition for a receivership for the Jupp Motor Car Company, reorganized last year, was revealed today when Circuit Judge Allan Campbell ordered a hearing to open Monday.

Departure from the system of property owner control as existing in the villages of New York State when villages became cities and demanded enlarged administrative powers was a great mistake, points out L. D. Garrett, president of the National Property Appraisal Service.

American savings and loan associations are destined to witness a marked expansion within the next decade, according to Nugent Fallon, general manager of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. He points to the rapid growth of the British building societies as a significant parallel.

The marriage of Miss Anna Martha Contant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arie Contant of this city, to Edson Hoyt Nichols Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Nichols, also of Hackensack, took place here tonight in the Second Reformed Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. John C. Rauscher.

Miss Mary R. Sims, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Clark Sims of Chestnut Hill, was married today to James Browning Miles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Miles of Brookline, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Nathaniel B. Groton in St. Thomas Church, White Marsh.
Stifling weather beset the city yesterday, abnormally high temperatures combining with excessive humidity to inflict discomfort. Occasional showers were forecast for today.

The Browns announced tonight the vetiran Jack Knott, pitcher, had been raded to the White Sox for Bill cox, youthful right-hander. The leal which gave the Browns a pitcher seven years younger than he 31-year-old hurler they traded, was a straight player trade.

HALLIDAY SUTHERLAND had to drive a reindeer the first time he ever saw one. And as his Finnish friend could tell him only that he must forget everything he knew about driving a horse, the experience did not lack the quality of adventure.

Melvin Davis, 567 West 113th Street, who was among those signing affidavits supporting the application of James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, for a change of venue, "is not an authorized Christian Science practitioner," it was explained Yesterday by B. Palmer

Discouragement of the sale of American airplanes to Japan because of bombing of civilian populations was disclosed yesterday by Secretary Hull. Manufacturers have been told the government condemns encouragement of such attacks by furnishing material, and most of them are prepared to cooperate.

Husky Charley Whitehead of Plainfield, who recently won the New Jersey amateur championship here, and Ralph Trego of the home club shot a three-under-par 70 to take a twostroke lead today in the opening round of the Canoe Brook Country Club's first invitation golf tournament.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 9: CAPTAIN WVhiting, K., relieved additional duty commanding officer, Fleet Air Base, Pearl Harbor, T. H.; to continue other duties. COMMANDER Capehart, W., the Lexington, to 11th Naval District, San Diego, Calif. LIEUTENANT COMMANDER
The commencement program at Wells College opened today with the annual meeting and dinner of the Alumnae Association and Senior Dramatics.

After the Chinese worker delegate Chu Hsuah fan strongly denounced in the International Labor Conference today Japan's "aggressive war" and was received with --warm applause, the Japanese Government delegate Juitsu Kitaoka implicitly warned that such things might lead to

Monthly production records were broken by six mines, according to the reports for May. New high monthly production was reported by Laguna Gold Mines, Manitoba, for May, when the output was valued at $49,400 from 2,741 tons of ore for an average recovery of $18.02 a ton compared with $49,
THOMAS WOOD STEVENS not only has had to do with drama and the art of the theatre most of his life; he also has written and produced nearly one hundred pageants.
Mount Everest's eternal snows remained inviolate today as bitter weather. forced a British expedition to abandon an assault of the world's highest peak.

THERE is a chance-however slight at this writing-that the Warners will turn their cameras on Sinclair Lewis's "It Can't Happen Here." Metro purchased the story two years. ago, but -shelved it under pressure of protests from interested foreign powers, notably Italy. The Warners'

WELCOMING televisions as a "new and glorious era in the world of the theatre," John Golden, Broadway producer, smiled across the wave lengths on a sizzling afternoon during the past week as he expressed pleasure in being the first showman to present scenes from a current theatrical hit through the radio

Four men were in jail today because a dog wagged its tail at the nice policemen. The friendly dog belonged to Everett Gonzales, 21, whom the police wanted to question about a series of automobile thefts and filling station hold-ups.

Firemen from the Mahopac volunteer fire department made a run in motor boats at 3 o'clock this afternoon to a fire on Canopus Island, in the middle of Lake Mahopac. The cottage in which the fire started was a complete loss, but the firemen and members of the household of Colonel and Mrs. Julius Ochs

UNSCIENTIFIC: A sculptor has been working on the decoration of the peace arch at the .entrance to the Canadian Parliament building in Ottawa. He proposed a beaver and nine beaver kittens, representing the Dominion and the nine Provinces. The proposal was rejected. Beaver litters, it seems, never exceed three or four.

Plans for a cooperative project to establish a California haven for Jews driven from Austria by the Hitler regime were outlined before the anti-Nazi mass meeting here last night. Speakers proposed the pooling of $1,000,000 to help reestablish 800 Austrian refugee familles. Richard Lamber, supervisor
New groups of American industry, hitherto untouched by the National Labor Relations Board, are coming within the board's jurisdiction as complaints pour into its regional offices.

United States Senator Homer T. Bone was named defendant today in a $250,000 damage suit in which operators of Radio Station KOL of Seattle charged him with Using his public office to further a private radio business.

A gift of $10,000 from the International Ladies Garment Workers Union toward the $200,000 quota being sought in this city by the American ORT Federation was announced yesterday by Max D. Steuer, chairman of the campaign here. The ORT is seeking a nationwide fund of $450,000 to provide technical and agricultural training for the Jews of Eastern and Central Europe.

Fall trade will average at least 10 per cent under the 1937 figures, with some degree of improvement likely in the closing months of the year, according to the consensus of several important meetings of retail merchandisers held here last week.

Two local track records were broken today as the Penn-Jersey harness circuit concluded its twoday meet. Symbol Roy, owned and driven by Billy Bull of Melfa, Va., traveled the first heat of a 2:23 pace in 2:06 to slash a full second off the old record. In a 2:17 trot

THE legal action which Mrs. T. Charles Farrelly, previously social director of Crockford's Club, and now at the Regency Club, is bringing against Ely and Josephine Culbertson as officers of the inactive Crockford's, Inc., came to trial last week and was promptly assigned by the judge to a referee.

Ligaroti, the Argentine charger flying the silks of Bing Crosby and Lin Howard, ran to a surprise victory in the inaugural $5,000 Inglewood Mile Handicap today before a turnout of 45,000 fans at the new Hollywood Park.

Stocks drifted aimlessly and closed steady and mixed in the smallest trading since Aug. 3, 1918; turnover, 107,230 shares. United States Government bonds firm and dull, a shade lower, second-grade rails weakened; other issues irregular; transactions, $2,378,825.

Graduates of Babson Institute were advised today by Roger Babson, founder of the institute, to get whatever jobs they. could and not to get married until they had "the philosophy of life straightened out."

Central Park has been a "jungle" for criminals and sinister characters after dark, it was revealed yesterday after the police had made a round-up of midnight loiterers at the request of Park Commissioner Robert Moses.
Miss Augusta Poe, queen of the 1938 Preakness ball had four teeth broken today in an automobile accident a few hours before a wedding in which she was to have been a bridesmaid.

Although the worst drought over the British Isles for l50 years was broken in many areas late in May, the farmers' hopes of a last-minute reprieve have been blighted by - a- succession of chilly nights when the ground temperature sometimes dropped to the to freezing point.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Wien of Brooklyn and Miami Beach, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Irma Arline Wien, to Bernard Theodore Hein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hein of Paterson, N. J.

The estate of M. J. Van Sweringen never can pay any of the $68,000,000 owed to creditors. This was the finding of Judge Nelson J. Brewer today in marking the estate of the railroad financier "closed."

OTTAWA. THE policy of Trans-Canada Air Lines is to proceed with thoroughness and to make haste slowly to the end that a proper foundation may be laid for useful air service, Philip G. Johnson, vice president, told the Canadian Manufacturers Association annual meeting in the Chateau Laurier here.

It is evidently a mistake to presume that the issue between Berlin and Prague has ceased to be dangerous. True enough, the "crisis" of May 22 did not materialize; then the Czechs put 300,000 troops on their frontiers ready to repel any effort at invasion, but the Germans made no move.

BERLIN.-The announcement that the Rhine-Danube Canal, on which construction is getting under way, is to be completed by 1945 without fail may well mean more for the realization of German ambitions than did all the ultimately futile battles of the World War.

The Interest of amateur racing followers turns this week to the Spring meeting of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association, to be held Saturday at Cedarhurst, L. I. The Cedarhurst Grand National, a brush test at two miles, will be the feature of a program of five races.

GENEVA. TO some of us whose job it is to traverse Europe noting the trend of events and endeavoring to understand them and to portray their significance, it seems at times in these days of apprehension and disillusion as though we are passing through a great cemetery.

Increasing interest in every phase of the program of the American Association of University Women was reflected in the report today of Mrs. Adam Leroy Jones of Montclair, director of the North Atlantic section of the organization, at the closing session of the biennial conference at the New Jersey College for Women.

THE only fault to be found with Commander Rosendahl's excellent analysis of airship performance is that it comes too late. Rosendahl is the ablest and most experienced naval officer in lighter-than-air. His sincerity is unquestioned. and he is possessed of qualities which make those who know him have a high regard for his character. The navy may well be proud of his record.

A fire of suspicious origin took the lives of a man and his sister, injured ten persons and routed nearly 100 others at 4 A. M. yesterday as it swept a four-story tenement at 147 Morningside Avenue, near 125th Street.

VOLUSILIS, Morocco. AFTER reposing undisturbed for sixteen centuries, fourscore Roman coins and medals have just been discovered in Volubilis, the Moroccan city which marked "the farthest south" of the Roman Empire. They were found in the walls of a Roman villa and are remarkably well preserved.
The former Mrs. Madeline Force Astor received a decree of divorce today from Vincenzo Fiermonte, a prizefighter, who, it was understood, did not contest the suit, brought on grounds of extreme

Three capsules of carotene in oil a day relieve eye fatigue among one type of industrial workers and improve capacity for work. So announce Drs. Ralph C. Wise and O. H. Schettler in The Ohio State Medical Journal.

The National.Union Company, a Baltimore concern headed by Auville Eager, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering issuance of $10,000,000 of 3 percent twenty-year bonds due in 1958, to be offered to the public at the market or to be exchanged for securities of sixteen mortgage companies.

THE latest developments in television, ultra-short waves and radiotelephony will play an important part in the papers to be presented at the thirteenth annual convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers to be held at the threeday meeting opening on Thursday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The titles on the forty-nine papers listed for discussion indicate the sessions will be highly technical.

One of the first debutante parties of the new season took place here tonight when Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Rice gave a large dance at the Mohawk Golf Club to introduce their daughter, Miss Patricia Rice.

Fifty-one undergraduate students at City College were named officers of fourteen extra-curricular clubs for the Fall semester to begin in September, according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president.

Miss Cynthia Pruden Harts, daughter of Brig. Gen. and Mrs. William Wright Harts of this town, this afternoon became the bride of Lieutenant Alan Boyd Banister, U. S. N., son of Mrs. Eugenis Banister of Oklahoma.

Representatives of Long Beach High School carried off the team honors with a total of 26 points at the annual Nassau-Suffolk interscholastic swimming meet held at the West Pool of Jones Beach State Park today.

Construction of eight homes was started in May in the Chester HillManhasset community under development on a portion of the large D'Oench estate adjoining Plandome Estates, on Plandome Road, in Manhasset, L. I., reports F. J. McGovern, sales manager for the property. The houses are being built for

The building of the National Cancer Institute at Bethesda, Md., will be ready for occupancy in about a year. The site was given a year ago by Mr. and Mrs. Luke I. Wilsen and bids for Construction of $75,000 building will be asked in August.

Motorists and chauffeurs, especially those in Brooklyn, who apply for driving licenses were urged yesterday by Charles A. Harnett, State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, to take their applications directly to the Motor Vehicle Bureau at 320 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, or at 80 Centre Street. Manhattan;

The time has come for the conservative elements of the United States to join in the fight for defense of civil liberties against such assaults as those of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, Grenville Clark told the Nassau County Bar Association at its annual dinner tonight in the Bar Home on Fifteenth Street.

The War Department announced today that Colonel Allen Kimberly of Fort Crockett, Texas, would head a new United States military mission in Brazil, relieving the present mission whose four-year term there has expired.

CZECHOSLOVAKIA continues to commemorate postally the deeds of the Czech Legions in World War engagements. Two 50-haleru light green stamps, each bearing the dates 1918 and 1938, recall fighting in France and Italy, respectively. The first,

Between 30,000 and 40,000 additional business tax returns will be received this year in excess of the number received last year because of the wider application of the tax, according to City Treasurer Almerindo Portfolio.

The value of the $12,888,514 series B-K mortgage certificates issued by the New York Title and Mortgage Company was not impaired by the business recession, the trustees reported yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler.

HOLLYWOOD. DEVIATING from a strict adherence to the Cinderella plot, though not far, Sonja Henie is putting the finishing touches on "My Lucky Star," in which she continues her skating, this time on a department-store ice rink.

JAMESTOWN, St. Helena PASSENGERS visiting this sunny island, where Napoleon ended his days in exile, are taken off the ship at Yamstocks' Isle. In the days when Yamstocks' was administered by the British East India Company, the natives grew vast numbers of yams for ships calling to and from the East. Hence the nickname.

The six-week rush in the children's camping equipment departments of city stores is beginning now. The youngsters come to the stores in droves, swinging tennis racquets, trying on shorts and slacks and sweaters under the watchful eyes of their mothers.

VISITING the teepee of the Cleveland Indians yesterday, it was discovered that Johnny Allen, the sometimes wrathful pitcher, had made a striking move. He had given the shirt off his back for the benefit of the Cleveland club.

UNCLE DAN" Beard's eightyeighth birthday, which falls on June 21, will be celebrated this Saturday by the Boy Scouts. Three to four thousand lads of New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Pennsylvania and other near-by States will participate in a colorful program at Suffern, N. Y.

Miss Jean MacDougall Sinclair, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. A. G. Sinclair of Bloomfield, was married in the First Presbyterian Church here this afternoon to Arthur Lincoln Schade of Cambridge, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Schade of West Englewood. Dr.

Government funds in the form of salaries, relief,, unemployment insurance or direct maintenance figured in the support of more than one-quarter of the city's population, an unofficial survey indicated yesterday.

Do the people of the United States receive adequate medical care? If not, what should be done about it? Tomorrow, when the American Medical Association gathers in San Francisco for its annual convention, the country may hear what solutions the medical profession has to offer.

College students are not entirely carrying out in their campus activities the democratic principles which they are presumably learning in the school room, according to a survey of more than 250 colleges and universities throughout the country, made by a group of stu dents at Stanford University.

Increasing emphasis on development of their own brands of electrical home appliances is being shown by a number of stores throughout the country, it was reported here yesterday. Executives of these establishments said results so far have proved favorable.

WASHINGTON.-American households need 400,000 domestic servants, according to a Department of Labor survey which discloses a wide need for trained chauffeurs, cooks, housekeepers, janitors, laundresses, nurses and other domestics.

The engagement of Miss Margaret Claiborne Fox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Randolph Fox of this place, to James D. Hancock Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Hancock of Dallas, Texas, has been announced by her parents.

Cordial relations with Germany, form the cornerstone of Poland's foreign policy on which Colonel Josef Beck bases his diplomacy of equilibrium between the two great, powerful, rival empires that are Poland's neighbors-the Nazi Reich and Communist Russia.

WELLINGTON, N. Z. AT one time or another nearly every one has felt the urge to go live on an atoll in the South Seas, where the sun shines and fruit drops from the trees, where there are no radios and no golf scores, and where dressing up for Darties is unheard of.
George Arthur McNamara, engineer and writer, died on Thursday in the -Rockefeller Institute forMedical Research of -peri-arteritisnodosum, a rare arterial disease. He was 35-years old.
Miss Marie A. Bender, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Welcome W. Bender of this city, was married to Dr. William A. Tansey Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Tansey of Newark, in St. Catherine's Church this morning.

Mrs. John Rumsey Sanford of Rumsey Hall, Cornwall, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Lillias Rumsey Sanford, to Arthur Hastings MacLeod, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. MacLeod of Eau Claire, Wis.

Through deluges, rushing winds and brilliant sunshine, Champion Nornay Saddler survived to be proclaimed best of 1,380 dogs in the annual exhibition of the North Westchester Kennel Club on the estate of Mrs. T. Whitney Blake today.
As bombs continue to whistle down on Canton and Barcelona, the British Government is making every possible effort to put an end to the practice of bombing undefended civilian areas.

Reorganization of the Western Newspaper Union tinder provision of the Federal Bankruptcy Act was asked in a petition filed in Federal court here today on behalf of stockholders, Herbert McCoy, proprietor of the Inland Press, Omaha; R. Ware Hall, Omaha, and John H. Bartlett Jr. and J. Carlton Jones of Chicago.

FOLLOWING Columbia's excellent lead, the spoken word has received increasing attention of late. Since the two Mercury Theatre production recordings, mentioned a few weeks back, there have been releases from three other sources. All these happen

As part of the observance of the 250th anniversary of the settlement of New Rochelle, in Westchester County, by Hugenots who fled from La Rochelle, France, about the time of the revocation of the Edict of Nantes, a small house which in architectural style is a blend of the Huguenot and early American styles has been erected there.

GROTRIAN HALL, London's chief small concert auditorium, will disappear at the close of the present season there this month. As a result music lovers of that city see the need of an intimate concert hall to seat from 800 to 1,000 persons.

Suppbrt of the program of the "National Rededication" group -by Governor Lehman; William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and L. J. Tabor, Master of the National Grange, is announced.

A movement to appeal to, Vice President John N. Garner to use his influence to check "Wasteful extravagance" of the Federal Government has been started by John G. Hun, headmaster of the Hun School at Princeton, N. J., it was learned yesterday. Dr. Hun has sent out two hundred letters containing such an appeal and urged each recipient to send similar letters to at least ten friends.

THERE'S a hotel near Banbury Cross which was once a fifteenth-seventeenth century mansion and which now boasts every modern luxury and "good food to suit all tastes." There's a unique hostelry on an island. off the coast of Devonshire, where smugglers, and worse, had their caves.

Improvement of the human race through research in biology and chemistry is the objective of a new $1,000,000 gift by the Rockefeller Foundation to the California Institute of Technology, Dr. Robert A. Millikan announced at commencement exercises.
BATAVIA, Java. UP and about at 6 o'clock this morning, fairly cool and composed, what with the early hour, a gentle sea-breeze and nothing much to do but pack a couple of trunks and wait for the

Saskatchewan's abrupt rejection of Social Credit in Wednesday's general election will probably be remembered as a turning point in Canadian political history. Its effects seem likely to prove important and various.

The rose grower who wants a greater visual and practical knowledge of the plants that he is raising will find the answer to most of his questions if he. visits the rose garden at the New York Botanical Garden. Any point that

The session of Congress is coming to a close in a political atmosphere more intense than at any time during the New Deal. Although the business slump persists, although representatives of industry, labor and government are all calling for and pledging cooperation to end it, politics is fully established as the test of everything now being done in Washington. Which means that such cooperation is, for the time being, impossible.
(All time is P. M., Eastern daylight saving, unless otherwise indicated; dial locations are in megacycles.) Today 4:30-Good-will program to Scandinavia, W1XAL, 11.79-Boston.

It was announced today that the number of employed workers and office employes in Germany without Austria had reached 19,850,000, or 1,300,000 more than the previous record high in July, 1929. Consequently the number of unemployed dropped to the record

Donald Budge today easily captured the second of four major titles he has set out to win this year. By defeating the giant Czechoslovak champion, Roderich Menzel, in straight sets in a match lasting less than an hour, Budge won the I French hard-court singles crown in a field that, it is true, did not inelude any stars of the first magnitude. The score was 6-3, 6-2, 6-4.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized John B. Hollister of Cincinnati to serve as a director of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad. It also authorized H. G. Atwood, president of Allied Mills, Inc., Peoria, Ill., to be a director of the Colorado Southern Railway.

Jews were ordered today to make new reports to the government, giving full, details of all possessions exceeding $2,000 in value. An official order said new forms were ready for distribution and must be filled out by every Jew,
China at the end of the month will lose the services of German advisers headed by General Alexander von Falkenhausen, who aided Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in forming his army.
CAPE COD, Mass. -A faster pace has been set for 1938 Summer life on Cape Cod and the vacation islands of Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard.

Garden blooms in the subways are a current cheerful travel note for crowds on the way to work in Manhattan. Sitting by an armful of lilacs or syringa is not an unusual experience; and strap hangers share the. pungent smell from garden-fresh peonies, or the perfume of tea roses, still dewy.

In having permitted the publication of a weekly and annual index of engineering articles between 1927 and 1934 in which $215,730 was allegedly lost, a group of former officers and members of the council of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, among them Charles M.. Schwab, exhibited woeful ignorance of the affairs of the society.

WE read now inthe foreign dispatches of the exhibition conducted by the present masters ("cultural authorities") of Germany, of the "degeneracy" manifested in German and Austrian music by the productions of Jewish composers.

Colonel J. M. Eager's goal with a minute and a half to play gave Governors Island a 9-all tie with the Ramapo Polo Club of Tallman, N. Y., in a game which was one of the features of an army program presented at Governors Island yesterday.

One of the largest business property deals in Mount Vernon in several months has just been closed in the purchase by a syndicate headed by Irving Steinberg, operator and builder of Jackson Heights, L. I., of the southwest corner of East First Street and South First Avenue at the railroad station plaza of

THROUGHOUT the land at this season millions of people make the motions of doing the day's job-actually their thoughts are far away. Even in the streets they move as though in a dream, while one vacation plan after another absorbs their minds to the exclusion of the hubbub around them.
The public is buying less food and the retrenchment has become even more intensified in the last two months, Samuel W. Rice of Newark, president of the Food -Merchants Alliance, said here today.

MANY New Yorkers are planning to visit Maine this year who never before in their lives have gone so far "down East." To such, and to thousands of others who think that New England stops at Boston or thereabouts, the guide to Maine published by the Federal Writers Project is a particularly valuable piece of travel literature.
Investigation by the Senate of the University of Chicago of the policies of Dr. Robert Maynard Hutchins again focuses attention on this youngest of the world's great universities and its president.

The cruise supper dance at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, Greenwich, tonight, sponsored by Auxiliary 8 of the Stony Wold Sanatarium, was attended by 450 persons from Greenwich and other cities. The proceeds will be used in

Acting on information received at Police Headquarters Friday night that there might be a hostile demonstration outside the French Line pier at the foot of West Fortyeighth Street when six Loyalists sailed for Spain yesterday on the steamship Champlain,

An interesting remodeling job is being completed on the twelve-story store and office structure known as the City Hall Office Building, at 261 Broadway, under the direction of the Siack Realty Corporation, Simon Ackerman, president, which in April leased the structure through Adams Co., Inc., broker.
Miss Elizabeth Rosamond Dale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oswald Dale of this place, was married this afternoon to John Murray Wallace, son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Wallace of Fairfield, Conn.

Efforts of the Mormon- Church to take care of its own needy are being expanded and intensified this year, despite published assertions of some church leaders, including President Heber J. Grant, that the church security plan is being handicapped by competition of more attractive government aid.

ONE day last Summer we sat down to write for THE NEW YORK TIMES a piece about our hopes for the Mercury Theatre. Under the caption "Plan for a New Theatre," the article appeared in THE TIMES on Sunday, Aug. 29.

Princeton's ninth-inning rally for two runs after two were out today transformed Yale's 1-0 lead into a 2-1 Tiger victory in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game. A pop fly by Pinch Hitter Bob Riddle which Second Baseman Bill Loveday reached but could not hold stored Fallon with the first Princeton run. Pitcher Monroe Jubitz,

William Kennelly, auctioneer, reports a wide interest in the auction sale of the Frederic A. Juilliard properties to be held tomorrow at noon in the Real Estate Exchange, 18 Vesey Street. The properties, for which Mrs. Henry L. McVickar is the agent, consist of about eighteen acres at Tuxedo Park, Orange County, N. Y.

In spite of rain, 800 Vassar alumnae who had gathered for reunion dinners in the college residence halls last evening arrayed themselves in white this morning with hats, gloves, bags, scarves or other accessories of the red, yellow, blue or green of their class colors and held their annual meeting in Skinner Music Hall.

Breaking a long-standing rule against exhibition game during the regular season, the Giants have agreed to appear this Summer in the up-State village that was home to the late John J. McGraw, their former manager.

THE sensation-mongers of Europe have amused themselves with speculations over two men of mystery. Both of these celebrities have been multi-millionaires. Both have achieved the ethical prestige that Machiavelli shared with Mephistopheles.

The Daily and Sunday Mirror signed a one-year contract yesterday with the New York Newspaper Guild, covering 450 employes in the newspaper's editorial and commercial departments. According to James Whittaker, chairman of the Mirror unit of the Guild, the contract provides increases in pay for more than 360 workers.

The women's Eastern golf- championship will be held Wednesday, Thursday and Friday over the Philadelphia Country Club course at Philadelphia. This tournament, which rotates annually amongNew York, Boston and Philadelphia courses, \is a fifty-four-hole medalplay event sponsored by the Eastern Golf Association.

WASHINGTON.-More than 2,000 volunter workers are cooperating in the Federal program for assembling data on migratory birds, Dr. Ira N. Gabrielson, chief of the Biological Survey, recently told a House committee.

HARD times are often the best times for clear thinking. The malingering economic crisis has conferred a perverse blessing on museums. The loss of income from private endowment that these lean years brought about has been the best if bitterest medicine that the museum has been forced to swallow.

Miss Mary Sherman Mitchell, whose greatgrandfather, Hoyt Sherman, was a brother of General Sherman, was married here at noon today to Paul Harvey Deming Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Deming of this city. The ceremoney was performed in St. Catherine's Chapel of the Church of Saints Peter and Paul by the Rev. John F. Dowdle, pastor of St. Paul's Church in Grosse Pointe.

The job of binding up the wounds of the Democratic Senatorial contest in Iowa is proving a much less difficult undertaking than it might have been in the case of a Wearin victory. Senator Gillette already

As president of the Rabbinical Council of America, Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein at the West Side Institutional Synagogue, 120 West Seventy-sixth Street, yesterday expressed his-thanks to Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, Vicar General of the Archdiocese of New York, for his sermon last Sunday in St. Patrick's Cathedral in which he described anti-Semitism as un-Christian.

Miss Frances Ingersoll Proctor, daughter of Mrs. Charles Anderson Proctor of Boston and Swampscott, was married to John Burke Wilkinson, son of Mrs. Henry Wilkinson of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N. J., and the late Mr. Wilkinson, today in the Church of the Holy Name here. The Rev. Arthur Lee Kinsolving and the Rev. James D. Cummins officiated.

owners of old industrial factory buildings were advised yesterday by S. Earl Honig, president of William S. Sussman, Inc., to take advantage of State legislation granting tax exemption for five years on alterations. Mr. Honig recently was appointed to the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement.

GIBRALTAR. IN crossing Franco-controlled Spain from the Bay of Biscay to the Mediterranearn one finds odd contrasts. In the north and southeast the marks of shell, bomb and fire are plainly visible in many places; yet in some towns

Silver spoons sent to her Wellesley classmates of '17 by Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of the Chinese generalissimo, "to show that a spoon may be licked but China can't," will be used Saturday at the annual reunion of the class.

The 13-year-old Women's Swimming Association sensation, Miss Helene Rains, added to her long string of championships by capturing the Metropolitan A. A. U. 220yard senior back-stroke title at the women's meet held in the Manhattan Beach pool yesterday.

The Athletics came from behind today to score a ninth-inning 5-to-4 victory over the Browns. With one out in the ninth Bob Johnson doubled off Relief Pitcher Ed Linke. Chapman was purposely passed. Mule Haas fanned, but Wayne Ambler singled over second to score Johnson with the winning run and give George Caster his sixth triumph of the season.

Overcast skies and occasional bursts of rain failed to put a damper on the June Week ceremonies here this afternoon, as thousands of spectators gathered to watch the annual presentation of awards and stars to distinguished cadets at the evening parade.

A tornado and further general rains in northwestern sections of the cotton belt caused a sharp upturn in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the list ended the two-hour session with gains of 5 to 8 points.

Defeating Evander Childs, the winner a year ago, by 2 1/2-1 1/2, in the sixth and final round, the De Witt Clinton High School team captured the Interborough High School Chess League championship at the rooms of the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday.
THE pair of objects at left in the photograph reproduced in this column are neither Indian arrowheads nor Brazil nuts, and the strange bent monsters at right do not belong to the caterpillar family.

The use of fuel-saving devices and the substitution of other fuels which require less labor in production have reduced the demand for coal and increased unemployment in the coal fields during the last twenty years, according to a report of the National Research Project of the Works Progress Administration, made public today.

Fatal accidents among men in the home in the age range from 15 to 64 years are about 50 per cent higher than among women in the same age group, according to a report issued by statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Miller, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Miller of this place, to Rector Thomson Davol, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Davol of Stamford, took place here this afternoon in Christ Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Albert J. M. Wilson.

NO Sunday article today. Alas, what misfortune! If everything around the house had gone smoothly, an acceptable article certainly would have been written and handed to the composing room in the normal course of events. But Cleo,

Little Miss Patty Berg has her championship at last. The Minneapolis stylist, often a runner-up, played her smartest golf today to defeat the veteran Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City in the thirty-six-hole final of the TransMississippi tourney, 6 and 5.

A restless House, which was held in session for more than eight hours today and into an evening session by a determined leadership, cleared away most pending routine business in anticipation of probable adjournment by Tuesday or Wednesday night.

Even upon enactment by Congress of wage and hour legislation, which now seems assured, the scope of its application will not be precisely known. The law will apply generally to employers "engaged in commerce." As to many industries

HEARINGS conducted by the Federal Communications Commission during the past week in Washington to help formulate new rules and regulations brought forth a protest from Mark Ethridge, retiring president of the National Association of Broadcasters, that the FCC's proposal to judge the cultural standards of radio programs is inconsistent with the principles of democracy.

Fortified against the drenching rain and arriving in closed cars instead of sports and touring models, members of society, many of whom came from distant places, arrived at the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Charles V. Hickox in the Wheatley Hills colony about noon for a prerace luncheon before the Spring meeting of the United Hunts Association.

Purchase of another old farm in the Jamaica section of Queens was announced yesterday by Jack Druss, president of the Foch Building Corporation, which has acquired from the Batterman Estate a tract of several acres in the Jamaica Estates area opposite the former Hillcrest golf course.

Redshank, who runs in the colors of Miss. Katharine Christie of Philadelphia and was held at 10 to 1, captured the Bowman Steeplechase Handicap at' the Spring meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association on the estate of Charles V. Hickox today to surprise a crowd of 5,000.

King Winter clung tenaciously at the bottom of Niagara Gorge today, despite Summer temperatures over this area. Ice was seen around the rocks in the gorge under Terrapin Trail near Horseshoe Falls, remnants of the jam which wrecked the "Honeymoon Bridge" here last January.

LAKE SUNAPEE, N. H.--New London Village is crowded this week-end with the guests of Colby Junior College, which is celebrating its 101st commencement and also dedicating the cornerstone of a new dormitory.

The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the four months ended on April 30, issued yesterday, shows a net loss, after expenses, taxes and charges, amounting to $1,293,829, contrasted with a net income of $1,710,030 in the first four months of 1937.

THERE have been plenty of rascals in American history, but for the head of the list a better candidate than General James Wilkinson would be hard to find. For nearly half a century at the beginning of national life he was news.
There are many things 'round about the garden, not mentioned in books or articles, which afford the observing lover of plants much entertainment and amusement.

SHORT-WAVE radio alarms are now being used in every forest region under supervision of the United States Forest Service. Since the fire crews in the Pacific NorthWest first adopted radio, the number of sets in use has increased from 300 to 2,500.

Old 952 is getting a beauty treatment. Old 952 is a massive camelback locomotive which towers over the modern streamlined engine like the old high-wheeled automobile rises above the modern low-hung car.
The Constitutional Convention was urged yesterday by the executive committee of the Bronx Board of Trade to submit a fair legislative reapportionment based on population. The Bronx group also

The new president of the General Synod of the Reformed Church in America opposed today organic union with any other denomination. The Rev. Dr. J. Harvey Murphy, 56-year-old minister of the First Reformed Church here, commenting on the union proposal submitted to the Synod's convention last week, said, however, that he would "heartily subscribe" to the "spiritual unity for which Jesus prayed."

The question of medical care for the masses, involving some form of taxpaid medicine for the low-income groups of the nation, confronted the American Medical Association today as thousands of physicians gathered here for the annual meeting.

The pre-Revolutionary Hoyt Mead farm of thirty-three acres at South Salem, N. Y., has been sold by Mrs. Harriet L. Mead to Jack A. Pegler of Lord Thomas. This place has been held by the Hoyt family since 1754.
Mrs. R. Rufus Hosking of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jenette Hosking, to Edward Albert Otto, son of Mrs. Elizabeth Otto of Irvington.
After gaining a 6-2 lead in the first half, the Rumson polo team defeated Princeton University by 11 to 7 today on Herbert Memorial Field at the Rumson Country Club.

ORSON WELLES, 23-year-old actor-director who has intro duced several innovations in the technique of the legitimate theater, has been invited with the Mercury Theatre to produce nine onehour weekly broadcast-dramas over WABC's network, beginning July 11- at 9 P. M.

Models of eardrums fifty times the size of human eardrums are now being used for teaching in the Department of Otolaryngology of Cornell University Medical College. Probably these are the largest artificial devices used-in medical education.
Charles Evans Hughes, Chief Justice of the United States, sailed yesterday on the Italian Liner Rex for Genoa with Mrs. Hughes to take a vacation in Italy, Switzerland and Southern France.

Silver Strings Concert: The world premiere of the gavotte and bourree from Ernest Lubin's "Suite in the Olden Style," which was awarded the Bearns Prize for 1938 by Columbia University, will be presented under the direction of Josef Honti. Also on the program will be Mozart's Quintet for Clarinet and Strings and Alan Shulman's Minuet: WEAF, 12 M.

ARONOFF-Mr. and Mrs. Julius Aronoff (nee Bernice Oestricher) of Washington, D. C., announce the arrival of a son, Martin J., June 2, 1938, at Columbia Hospital. BEBGER--Dr. and Mrs. Murray Berger (nee Thelma Jacobson) announce the birth of Michael's brother, Charles Joseph on June 3 at Doctors Hospital.

AN amendment to the Communication Act designed to give the Federal Communications Commission authority to control diathermy apparatus has been submitted to-Congress by Paul A. Walker, acting chairman of the FCC.

Beds of roses and of irises, with masses of blue. forget-me-nots and white candytuft at their feet, meet the eye of the visitor who at this time of year walks into the small suburban garden of Mr. and Mrs. Wirt E. Darrow of Hollis Park Gardens, Hollis, L. I. Before the roses

A jury in the court of General Sessions convicted yesterday Joseph Schwartz, 35 years old, of 1,571 Sheridan Avenue, the Bronx, and Samuel Schwartz, 33, of 483 Cleveland Avenue, Brooklyn, jewelry dealers at a jewelers exchange on the Bowery, of having received five stolen diamond rings valued at $3,500.

Former Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden tonight made an attack, though only by. implication, on Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's policy of Realism" in foreign relations and its eoncomitant of "European appeasement."

Miss Eleanor Widener Dixon, daughter of Mrs. Widener Dixon of Ronaele Manor, Elkins Park, and of Fitz Eugene Dixon of White Hall, S. C., and Elkins Park, was married this afternoon to James C. Gentle, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Gentle of Brookline, Mass.

The Abraham Lincoln High nine suffered its first setback in nineteen games this season when it bowed to Flushing, 7-2, yesterday at Lincoln Field in the opening contest of their three-game city P. S. A. L. semi-final play off series. The losers had captured the

Glenn Cunningham raced a fast half-mile today over a muddy track at the New Jersey A. A. U. track and field championships, defeating four well-handicapped opponents and then was rushed by private ambulance to Travers Island to run a special three-quarter mile in the New York Athletic Club games.

German National Socialism, which rode to power as the uncompromising foe of Marxism, in limiting profits and wealth and in abolishing privileges is achieving greater equality than the socially minded democratic government was able to achieve, Professor Frieda Wunderlich, German sociologist and editor,

The Homestead, Mr. and Mrs. J. Garfield Buell's country home here, was the setting for the marriage this afternoon of their daughter, Miss Betty Jane Buell, to Vincent Strong Mulford Jr. of New York and Montclair, N. J. The ceremony was performed in the garden by the Rev. Hugh L. Llwyd of the Episcopal Church, Muskogee.
The Chinese Embassy was formally closed today, nearly a year after the start of the Chinese-Japanese conflict, and Y. C. Yang, the charge d'affaires, and his staff of nine left for China.

Bishop William T. Manning will officiate at an ordination service this morning at 11 o'clock in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The Bishop will advance the following deacons to the priesthood: The Rev. Peter C. van der Hiel, the Rev. Arthur G. Walter and the Rev. Matthew A. Curry.

Wherever rivers flow to the sea, wherever there are coves, harbors or inland lakes-in those places, beginning this week, will be found the speed-boat fraternity coaxing faster miles out of their outboards and inboards in preparation for the regatta circuit that from now until October will keep the Jacobys, Fondas, Woods, Robertses and Coopers on the move.

A TLANTIC CITY, N. J.-Some one hundred of the outstanding amateur fencers in the East are expected here to compete in the national invitation fencing tournament next Saturday and Sunday in the Municipal Convention Hall.

The marriage of Missi Rosalie Neilson Williams, second daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Resolved Williams of Windemere, in this community, and New York, to Edward Everett Post, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Otis Post of Morristown, N. J., took place this afternoon in St. John's Church, Far Rockaway. The rector, the Rev. Francis G. Urbano, performed the ceremony.

Cheered as a Presidential possibility for 1940, Judge Arthur H. James, in his keynote speech as the Republican nominee for Governor, told the party's State committee here today that fear, "nursed and cultivated" by the New Deal as the "cornerstone" of its whole set-up, was back of "most of the troubles of Pennsylvania and her people"

The work done by Dr. J. B. Rhine and his associates at Duke University has been severely criticized by some psychologists on the ground that the laws of chance may not be as rigidly true as the mathematicians insist.
Expelled from Venezuela, ten men were recovering today from hardships suffered during months of imprisonment in a labor camp on an island in the Orinoco River.

Notices posted last week for redeeming bonds this month were few in number and consisted of several municipal, State and miscellaneous issues. Among the most important calls were $998,000 State of South Dakota rural credit Series A 4s due on June 15, 1951, called for June 15 at 100: $150.000 Cook County. Ill..

The marriage of Miss Edna Meyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Meyer of Grymes Hill, S. I., to Ernst E. Glassel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernst Glassel of Bremen, Germany, took place last night in Trinity Lutheran Church, Stapleton, S. I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frederick Sutter, pastor.

A prediction that Republicans would gain "at least five" Senate seats this year came today from Senator McNary of Oregon in an interview on his sixty-fourth birthday. "I feel sure that certain things for which the Republican party has stood will again appeal to the sound common sense of the American people," he said.

A motion proposing that the House of Representatives ask President Federico Laredo Bru to explain why the government has not declared the Mexican Charge d'Affaires, Octavio Reyes Spindola, persona non grata because of his action in asserting that a recent Cuban Cabinet communique was untrue was presented tonight.

If the first few days of the furni??ure markets next month bring strong and active buying, an imme??iate advance in prices will result, Louis Bernstein, president of the New York Furniture Exchange, Inc., local showroom for furniture producers, asserted here yesterday.

The Architectural League, which has never conducted an art auction before, will hold one next Thursday afternoon at its headquarters, 115 East Fortieth Street. The proceeds, instead of going to the owners of the property, will be added to one of the league's prize funds.

Miss Rena Rebecca Mettam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Harold Mettam of this place, was married here this afternoon in Trinity Episcopal Church to Willard Frederick Wadt, also of Bayonne, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Andrew P. Wadt of Rochester, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Herbert-Lewis Jones of Boonton, former rector of Calvary Church here, -and the Rev. Revere Beasley, present rector.

Another victory in the championship series of the New Jersey State Cricket League was gained today by the champion Hudson County eleven of the Brooklyn Cricket Club over Paterson at East Side Park by forty-five runs. Batting first,

SUN VALLEY, Idaho.-Sun Valley Lodge and Challenger Inn are preparing to welcome Summer visitors with a variety of recreational facilities. There will be horseback riding, swimming, fishing, skeet shooting and golf on the new course laid out in Trail Creek Canyon, as well as excursions into the hinterlands.

LAKE GEORGE-Every day now the mail boat to Glen Island in Lake George brings evidence that the Robinson Crusoe urge among city dwellers of New York State grows stronger. Applications for permits to camp are pouring in to the forest ranger in charge of the lake's 125 Stateowned islands.

Through the week beginning tomorrow, the Opportunity Shop at 46 West Forty-seventh Street, an activity of the Association for - Improving the Condition of the Poor, will celebrate the thirteenth anniversary of its existence.
The Peddie School baseball team bowed to the New York Stock Exchange today, 3-0. The game was scoreless until the third inning, when Tilly of the Stock Exchange crossed the plate with one run.

Members of the Chamber of Deputies will meet in special session on next Wednesday, it was announced today, to discuss negotiations recently carried on in New York between representative Chilean interests and the Chilean Bondholders Advisory Committee, which led up to the resolution adopted by the latter to withdraw objections of the bondholders and accept the Chilean Government's plan for partial resumption of payment.
Class Day exercises were held this afternoon on the campus of the Drew Seminary for Young Women. The speaker was the Rev. Dr. Howard E. Thompson of Poughkeepsie.
Aerial photographers took pictures today of a wrecked bombing plane to help an army board investigation ascertain what caused the crash and death of a crew of eight.

A Summer school for college boys, conducted along lines similar to the CCC, will be established toward the end of this month by the Lewis Land Corporation on the site of the Nissequoque River at Smithtown, L. I., where it is developing 100 wooded plots, Albert A. Lewis, head of the firm, announced yesterday.

I AM particularly happy to see you state again in your open letter which THE NEW YORK TIMES published on May 22-state again in your own convincing waywhat a few of us modern architects have contended for yearsnamely, that art does not result from accident or whim; that art

SOMETHING new in my experience has been occurring at the Windsor Theatre since the opening of "The Two Bouquets." Something I never even heard of, for that matter. I first noticed it at the first matinee and have observed it at every performance since.

The Spanish Insurgents reported tonight that they had advanced to within three miles of Castellon de la Plana, key objective in the drive on Valencia. The advance was said to have come after the Insurgents had cracked Valencia's main outer defenses by occupying Albocacer, fortified town twenty-seven miles north of Castellon and sixty-seven miles from Valencia.
Young Johnny Vander Meer, the Reds' 23-year-old southpaw from New Jersey, pitched himself into baseball's Hall of Fame today with a no-hit, no-run performance against the Bees.

Miss Jane Henderson Boyden Craige, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Craige of Winston-Salem, and Gordon Gray, publisher of The Winston-Salem Journal and The Twin City Sentinel, were married here this afternoon in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.
Miss Lucy Caruso, defending titleholder from the Ravenhall A. C., defeated Miss Anna Pennino of the Eastern Women's A. C., 21-2, 21-16, in the semi-final round of the women's Metropolitan A. A. U.
DETROIT WITH production again rising following the short Memorial Day shut-down, the industry was back on a more nearly normal basis during the week just closed.

A rock garden, composed of rock and mineral specimens from all parts of the world systematically arranged to form an outdoor geologic laboratory, has been built at Hunter College at the north of Gillet Hall of the Bronx buildings.

Pennsylvania closed its baseball season by losing to California on Franklin Field today, 9-7, before an Alumni Day crowd of 5,000. The Golden Bears got to Relief Pitcher Payson Brickley for four runs in the seventh to break a 5-5 tie. Piper and Daugherty pitched
ODIST: New Haven celebrates this year the tercentenary of its founding, and last week as part of the celebration the Connecticut city marked the

THE PLANETS," an original poetic drama written for radio by Alfred Kreymborg, proved an interesting if somewhat baffling experiment as broadcast a few nights ago against the stellar setting of the solar room of the Hayden Planetarium.

The marriage of Miss Cynthia Harbison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Albert Harbison, to Carl William Heye, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl T. Heye of White Plains, took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Frank Simmons of Spencer Memorial Church, Brooklyn.

Mortgages accepted for insurance by the Federal Housing Administration last month established new records in New York State and throughout the country, according to figures released yesterday by Thomas G. Grace, State Director, and Stewart McDonald, Federal Administrator.

APPROPRIATELY served the contents of this book should be poured into a hollowstemmed glass with a top of large circumference. That the vintage is recent is no reflection on its quality. It has bouquet, effervescence and-the other prime requisite.

This city's- celebration of its founding 250 years ago had a dampened preliminary today when twenty-four youths walked eighteen miles to New York City in pouring rain. The pilgrims, who were following a tradition of the Huguenot founders of this place, were so uncomfortable from the weather that they walked the distance in five unresting hours.

WASHINGTON.-Boys and girls receiving National Youth Administration aid from the Federal Government come from families whose average annual income is about $700, according to figures recently placed before the House Appropriations Committee.

Mrs. John W. Moxon of Mountainside has been chosen by the Associate Alumnae of New Jersey College for Women as president of the association for the coming year. She will represent the alumnae on the board of trustees of Rutgers University.

The marriage of Miss Jean Brewster Carter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Sage Carter of Yonkers, N. Y., to John Willard Morehouse, son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Morehouse of Brewster, N. Y., took place yesterday afternoon in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

THIS New York art world exhibition season is getting to be an almost continuous performance. Some years ago the galleries tentatively came to life late in October and yawned themselves into the Summer doldrums in May. This year, after several
William J. Pringle, an attorney here for forty years and a former Alderman from the old Fourth Ward, died today in Glendale, Calif., one day after his seventy-sixth birthday.

VIRIGINIA BEACH, Va.--An invitation fashion revue and musical tea has been announced for the afternoon of June 20 at the Cavalier Beach Club. On a T-shaped runway of a simulated pinetree hedge arranged in the show-boat foyer of the clubhouse, manikins will display costumes.

WHEN Sam Gompers, 80 years old and nearly blind, was carried out of Mexico, across the Rio Grande, so that he might die in San Antonio and on American soil. he left several pretenders to his throne as president of the American Federation of Labor.

Adding another brilliant chapter to his illustrious ring career, the famous bay gelding Prince Charm ing II, from the Claredda Farm of Mr. and Mrs. E. V. Quinn of Shrewsbury, .N. J.,, today won the title of grand champion hunter to climax the forty-fifth annual twoday Westchester County horse show at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club.

SYDNEY, Australia, AUSTRALIAN bushmen (axmen, drovers and boundary riders) yearly "go to town" to spend their pay checks, and the strange variety of their clothes has added color to city streets. But the old-time dress is passing. Today the calf-skin waistcoat, the pride of the bushman, has almost vanished.

The American Rolling Mill Company, independent steel producer, asserted today that the Wagner act was unconstitutional if it permitted the National Labor Relations Board to question a company's participation in municipal elections.
Jesse Treadwell Lippincott, president of the Cincinnati Union Stockyards for the last twenty-five years, died at his home here today. He was 62 years old.

Despite official Washington denials of any pending change in its currency policy, there was a further flow of capital from New York today. Dollars were freely offered on the foreign exchange market here against gold. After fluctuating between $4.95 3/4 and $4.96 7/2, the pound finished at $4.96 1/2, compared with $4.95 ?? yesterday.
BEIER--Mr. and Mrs. Abraham, announce confirmation of their son, Elliot M. Beier, Saturday, June 18, Congregation Ahavath Chesed, 79th St. and 15th Ave., Brooklyn. At home Sunday, 2 P. M.

HATTERS appear to have gone a little mad this season, but the result is a happy one. The newer straws and Panamas are more comfortable than ever and the new weaves and bands are surprisingly good-looking.

WASHINGTON. --At least one member of Congress does not believe that retention of his seat in the House requires his presence in his district during the period from the adjournment of Congress until election day.

The New York State Rifle Association and New York National Guard and Naval Militia units completed their annual rifle matches at Camp Smith here today in running off the final stage of the State. match and the Naval Militia and Naval Reserve interstate match.
DRAWINGS by Sidney Lazarus may be seen through the month at the Arista Gallery, 30 Lexington Avenue, the most recently opened of New York's galleries.

James B. Frazier, United States District Attorney, said today that the government had begun criminal proceedings against Samuel Evans Massengill of Bristol, Tenn., whose firm manufactured elixir of sulfanilamide. The-elixir came into public notice following a number of deaths last Fall.

THE post-season doldrums seem the natural time to take out the department crystal glass (slightly chipped but still trusty) and explore the musical tomorrows. Here, as close in time and space as next season and the Metropolitan Opera House, comes into view no other than Lawrence Tibbett.

Colonel Theodore Roosevelt Jr., chairman of the United Council for Civilian Relief in China, announced last night that the Governors of eighteen States had issued proclamations setting aside Friday as "Humanity Day," when public attention will be focused oh the plight

The Reynolds Investing Company, Inc., 15 Exchange Place, Jersey City, through its president, Irving Rossi, filed today an answer to a petition recently presented by three holders of its securities asking that it be reorganized under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

Fifty-five settlement houses, participating in the $10,000,000 appeal of the Greater New York Fund, have mapped "in-town" recreational programs for more than 200,000 under-privileged children who cannot be accommodated in the Summer camps maintained by private health and welfare agencies.

EACH year California looms large on the vacation map. whether it is the mecca where one's entire holiday is to be spent, or merely a stop-over on a more extended Western tour, it offers much for the sight-seer. If one's headquarters are near Los Angeles, there is the spin along the new Roosevelt Highway, close to the sea at Santa Monica; there is Malibu Beach and the drive through Beverly Hills to Hollywood.

A thirteenpage will by the late Joshua F. Vogel, retired industrialist, filed today for probation, asks the trustees of his estate to delay investment in securities until the Federal budget has been balanced. Mr. Vogel died May 31.
Only twenty-three strikes were called in April throughout the State, the smallest number for any month since February, 1937, it is reported by the Bureau of Mediation of the State LaborDepartment.
The appointment of Desiderlo X. Parreno of New York as valedictorian, and Wolfgang K. H. Panofsky of Princeton as salutatorian, at the commencement exercises at

The eve of the final municipal elections in Czechoslovakia found the nation calm and anticipating little trouble. However, prepare edness was the keynote, with 300,000 troops ready to be sent to any scene of disorder.

Five years ago, almost to a day, when he was an awkward lad of 21, unknown in the world of golf, Ralph Guldahl missed a four-foot putt that would have - tied Johnny Goodman of Omaha, present United States amateur champion, for the national open title. Today Guldahl,
The Court of Appeals, in a two-toone decision here, held yesterday that persons who bought bank stock after the bank had closed were not liable under the double liability clause.

Roofs are available today, according to a builder, for every style and kind of modern architecture, and these roofs round out the dignity-of the houes. Choice of materials is wide but should be made with an eye to the type of house on which it is to be laid.
EVERY month in the year is open season at the travel information bureaus, but no other time quite equals midJune for the number and variety of questions fired at the men behind the counters.

INCREASINGLY the visitor to California notes the grotesque style of architecture affected by Golden State restaurants. Perhaps the Brown Derby started it. A likeness of Ex-Governor Smith's campaign hat, enlarged to giant proportions, has long been a favorite dining place of Hollywood movie executives, directors, stars, those who aspire to stardom and tourists.
It was made known today that the appointment of a receiver for the Hupp Motor Car Company had been asked for and a full hearing on next Monday had been ordered by Circuit Court Judge Allan Campbell.

Charging that a United Mine Workers parade and mass meeting to be held tomorrow at Kitts, near/here, is intended to "inflame feeling" and to "obstruct justice," the defense in the Harlan County coal conspiracy trial called upon Federal Judge H. Church Ford today
The first earthquake in half a century in these latitudes--and violent enough to break the Brussels seismograph--shook northwestern Europe at noon today for twenty seconds.
Chinese currency slipped today to the lowest figure in many years as banks gave 5.88 Shanghai dollars for one American dollar. The nominal rate has been 5.26.

The retirement from Harvard University of two young professors, Dr. Alan R. Sweezy and Dr. John R. Walsh, under circumstances equivalent to dismissal, cannot be considered merely a local episode. It may turn out to be a matter of national importance.

Mike Belloise and Al Reid, rival Bronx featherweights, will meet for the third time when they appear in the star bout of eight rounds at Dyckman Oval.tomorrow night. Both of their previous clashes ended in a draw.

Miss Christabel Wheeler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Wheeler of Lake Forest, Ill., was married tonight to William T. Priestley Jr. of New York in the chapel of the Church of the Holy Spirit, Lake Forest. A reception followed in the Wheeler home.

Max Schmeling and Joe.Louis may meet for a third time in one of the New York ball parks early in September. Mike Jacobs, who is staging the June 22 heavyweight title bout betwen Schmeling and the champion, visited the German's camp today and announced both principals had agreed to another meeting should this month's battle go the fifteenround limit.

THIS is a bold book, written by a bold mind. While the motivating idea-Miss Bulley shies from calling it a thesis-is rather elliptically conceived and presented, not always relying on the processes of reasoning, yet there is no doubt that "Art and Understanding" is an extremely stimulating, timely and salutary book. It is stimulating,

NORTH CREEK, N. Y. FORESTS, brooks and lakes attract an increasing number of persons each year to the Adirondack and 'Catskill Mountains, vast parks among the few remaining wilderness areas in the East. Intersected by modern highways, they offer free camping facilities for motorists and hikers and provide a Summer vacation far removed from hot and crowded cities.
Miss Melba E. Hamer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry R. Hamer of this city, was married this afternoon to Dr. Edwin Joseph O'Brien Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin J. O'Brien, also of Plainfield.

That District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, elected last Fall after his success as Special Prosecutor of Manhattan rackets, had undertaken the most sensational prosecution of his career was made evident last week by the activities in the defense of Tammany District Leader James J. Hines, indicted as the alleged political "fixer" in the "policy numbers" lottery racket established by the late Arthur Flegenheimer (Dutch Schultz).

Sharply increased agricultural ports coincident with a radical ?? traction in this country's imports so far this year are building up a multiplicity of exchange and trade restrictions which will harase American shippers through the coming Fall and Winter, exporters predicted here last week.

More than 2,000 vacant properties held by the town of Greenburgh, Westchester County, will be offered at auction by Fred Berger next Saturday afternoon at the County Center in White Plains. The plots are located in every section of the township.

Robert Ralston Crosby, a descendant of Philip Livingston and William Floyd, signers of the Declaration-of Independence, died yesterday after a long illness at the home of his sister, Mrs. Alfred Duane Pell, of 910 Park Avenue. He was born in an old mansion on Rutgers Place seventy-five years ago, a son of Robert Ralston Crosby and Jane Murray Livingston Crosby.
Mr. and Mrs. Conrad R. White of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruby G. White, to Alan F. Hardman, son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Hardman of Clinton, Mass.

PROFESSOR WERTEN BAKER finds the contrast that is often drawn between the supposed simplicity of American colonial civilization and the complexity of modern society largely misleading. It is true, he observes,

Dr. Richard Clarke Cabot of Boston gave the commencement day address to the graduating class of the Gunnery School today in the Congregational Church. Dr. Tertius Van Dyke, headmaster of the school, awarded the following prizes:
Three foreign men-of-war, a French escort vessel, a Yugoslav training ship and a Brazilian training ship are scheduled to visit New York within the next month, it became known yesterday.

Miss Jane Charlotte Morton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seth Worth Morton of Albany and this city, was married today to John Henry Griffin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Griffin of Albany, at the home of the bride's parents, Blowing Park, this city.

Two hundred and eight couples received marriage licenses at the Municipal Building yesterday, the last day for persons who plan to apply for licenses on July 1 to obtain them without medical certificates that the couples had passed examinations showing them to be free of syphilis within twenty days of the issuance of the license.

Several chemicals are known to promote rooting of lands. One is indol-3-acetic acid. William G. Cooper of the Department of Agriculture soaked the base of lemon cuttings with this, planted part of them and saw them develop more and stronger roots than did untreated controls.

The marriage of Miss Mary Howard Bruce, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Bruce of Belmont, Elk Ridge, to H. Alexander Smith Jr., New York lawyer, son of Mr. and -Mrs. Smith. of Princeton, N. J., took place here this afternoon in St. Paul's Church.

John Roosevelt and his debutante bride-to-be, Miss Anne Lindsay Clark, will have their Wedding trip without delay. This was made certain today when Mr. Roosevelt, at a press conference, declared he would not attend and act as an usher at the wedding of Marshall Field Jr. on June 20, two days after his own wedding, as had been reported.
While the ending of the partition of Ireland is not a major issue in Eire's general election, nevertheless the people in Northern Ireland are following the trend of the campaign with close interest.

In New York this month American education will present its biggest show. On Sunday, June 26, the seventy-sixth annual meeting of the National Education Association will be called to order in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and sessions will run five days.

Although outside this republic's frontiers little has been heard of the friction between the Czechs and the Slovaks since Professor Vojetch Tuka, then the right-hand man of Father Andreas Hlinka, Slovak autonomist leader, was sentenced to fifteen years' imprisonment on charges of high treason, last Sunday's autonomist demonstration serves as a reminder that the Slovak question still exists.
Under the direction of the Board of Education, and operated with the aid of WPA teachers, fifteen expermental nursery centers have been opened in New York City.

Over a track heavy - from the morning's rains Glenn Cunningham fled to victory in the three-quarter mile run that featured the- 140th games of the New York-AthleticClub in the picturesque Travers Island setting yesterday.
Philip Bishop, 46 years old, alias Two-Gun Bishop who has been in and out of various penal institutions since he was 11, escaped yesterday from Rikers Island Prison.

It took 23-year-old Willie Turnesa only a dozen holes today to capture the Westchester amateur golf championship for the third straight year. By the same score, 7 and 6, with which he won the crown. last Spring, he retained it against the challenge of Charles Shelden of Siwanoy at the Metropolis Country Club.
Police detained Frank E. Bradbury, 78, tonight as they investigated the death of his sister, Harriet Bradbury, 76. No charge had been entered against him.

The United States destroyer Claxton returned to Villefranche tonight after accomplishing a special mission to save the life of a United States consular official by a dangerous voyage along the unlighted coast of Spain.

AN increasing number of auto buyers living in towns and cities distant from the factory are taking advantage of the opportunity to finance a Summer vacation with the savings in freight costs effected by taking personal delivery of new cars at the plant, D. E. Ralston, general sales manager of Oldsmobile, reported last week.

Staging a three-run uprising in the eighth inning, the New York Fire Department baseball team conquered the Police Department nine at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The late rally transformed what had been a tight struggle into a decisive triumph for the smoke-eaters, who subued their fraternal rivals by the score of 7 to 3.

Corn, destined eventually to be "marketed through hogs," stood a few inches high last week on the large, prosperous-looking farms of Iowa, a State whose rich black soil and gently rolling prairies make it the nation's greatest corn producer.
Arthur Prentice Rugg, who rose from poor farm boy to become chief justice of the Massachusetts Supreme Court, died today in his seventy-sixth year. He had been ill of heart disease for a week.

Most of the provisions of the National Mobilization Law are expected to be enforced soon. A press campaign, which bears evidence of government inspiration, urges the people to economize in all possible ways and divert savings to the purchase of government bonds.

Joseph Stalin's native Georgia elected a Supreme Soviet of 237 members today, with Stalin's name topping the list. Armenia also elected a Supreme Soviet with 256 members, and there, too, Stalin, the secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist party, was. the first choice.

April shipments of hosiery from the mills declined 12.3 per cent from the March totals and 6.9 per cent under April, 1937, according to the report issued for publication today by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

Summer merchandise was requested last week in somewhat larger volume than in the previous week in the New York wholesale markets, although action was generally slower than normal for the time of' year.

The cessation of selling for Jewish and emigrant accounts brought firmness to the stock market early last week, but buyers were absent and later anxiety over Spain caused liquidation by professionals, which resulted in

The Federal Symphony Orchestra, under Chalmers Clifton, gave an all-Sibelius concert yesterday afternoon at the WPA Theatre of Music, with Dorothy Minty, violin, as soloist. Miles Kastendieck, music critic of The Brooklyn Eagle, was the commentator.
Although the border controversy between Ecuador and Peru is quieter, it appears that Italy planned to support both sides, or "play both ends against the middle." While the United States,

Rudolf Hess, deputy leader of the Nazi party, accused Czechoslovakia today of being a menace to the peace of Europe. He asserted the little republic was in a condition "practically akin to a state of war."

-With 32 points, Harvard University outdistanced the rest of the field by a wide margin in taking first place in the third annual aviation meet of the New England Intercollegiate Air Conference held today at the Hampton airport, about four miles east of this village. Second place went to Kenyon College, which had 8 points, and Amherst, with - 7i points, was third.

" Against the ever-rising spirit of hate in the modern world, struggling in the throes of change and readjustment, we need compassion and good-will-the forces that were the glory of Christ-if mankind is to emerge into a better life," the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo declared in his sermon yesterday in the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Fortyeighth Street.

Edward J. Tranter of 130 East Seventy-fifth Street, since 1913 president of the Fasig-Tipton Company, 604 Fifth Avenue, one of the leading firms of horse brokers and auctioneers in the United States, died yesterday-in the Doctors Hospital after a long illness.

10th St, 225-227 E, 50x94.9; Herman Levinsohn and wife to Quair Realty Corp. 39 Broadway (quitclaim), ($5). 3d St. 15-17 E; also 66-68 E 4th St, 50x192.5: Burland Catering Corp to Siren Realty Corp. 968 E 156th St. Bronx (50 cents).

The financial and industrial picture did not change last week. Steel production remained at 25 per cent of capacity; weekly car-loadings were 27 per cent below last year, about the average of recent months. But comparison is still being made with high loadings a year ago; they did not in 1937 fall below previous recent years until Autumn.
State Attorney George A. Worley completed today the case which he will present to the grand jury tomorrow, seeking the life of Franklin Pierce McCall in the kidnapping of Jimmy Cash.
The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation announced yesterday the award of .fellowships to ten Latin-American scholars and artists for study and research in the United States.

Alex Ciechanosky, 18 years old, of 240-17 Jamaica Avenue, Bellerose, Queens, was killed and five other persons Were injured, one of them seriously, in a head-on collision of two automobiles on Hollis Court Boulevard near Fiftysixth Avenue, Bayside, early yesterday morning.
A new city ordinance requiring the licensing of peddlers, intended to eliminate "unfair" competition for Yonkers merchants, has been signed by Mayor Joseph F. Loehr
With rousing support by the Pirate batsmen, big Mace Brown won his eighth relief victory of the season today as Pittsburgh pummeled Philadelphia, 11 to 5.

The Young Ireland Gaelic football team, composed entirely of American-born players, lost a hard game to Kerry at Innisfail Park yesterday, 12 to 10. Kerry made 2 goals and 6 points against Young Ireland's 3 goals and 1 point.
