The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 71.9 on June 8, compared with 72.2 a fortnight before, 73.2 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Protestant ministers who preach "private interpretations" instead of the fundamental principles of their religion are responsible for "the complete disintegration of Protestantism in our day from the standpoint of doctrine and morals," Mgr. J. F. A. McIntyre, chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, dedared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Plans have been completed by Miss Elin Anderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. F. Anderson of this place, for her marriage on July 16 to Richard Hartman Haigh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Haigh of Maplewood, N. J. The ceremony will be performed in the First Presbyterian Church of Springfield, N. J., by the Rev. Dr. George Armstrong Liggett, the pastor.

A dozen plainclothes men from New York City's detective squad arrived here today to give Quebec police a hand in surveillance of visitors who will come here next week for the National Eucharistic Congress. The old capital's

The third and the best of Billy Rose's variety bills opened last night at the Casa Manafia. True, the two headliners, Frank Fay and Bert Wheeler, did not contribute much because of their complete.lack of material, but the others on the bill more than made amends. More specifically, the others contributed the first reasonable 1938 comparison with the old bills which once packed the Palace Theatre.
Mrs. Edward Thord-Gray gave a luncheon here today for Miss Beatrice F. Kunhardt and Samuel A. Culbertson 2d, who will be married Thursday in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church, New-York.
Howard O. Hunter, assistant Works Progress Administrator in Washington, denied today that the WPA was misusing Federal funds for political activities in Kentucky.

The Fairfield police and Federal men have established that two of the Peter Levine ransom notes that originated in Fairfield were written on a typewriter stolen from the Fairfield railroad station in January and subsequently dismantled and thrown into Samp Mortor Reservoir of the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company, Police Chief Arthur J. Bennett admitted tonight.

Three new plays by well-known authors turn up today in the bulletins from the Summer theatres. On July 18 the Ridgeway Theatre at White Plains will present "Michael Drops In," a light comedy lately finished by William Du Bols, author of the current Federal Theatre success, "Haiti."

James G. Blaine, chairman of the campaign committee of the Greater New York Fund, announced yesterday that more than 110,000 State, county and city employes in the five boroughs were organized to make employee group contributions toward the drive's goal of $10,000,000.
A. Henry Lefebvre, retired paper manufacturer and inventor of a widely known method of producing newsprint without sulphite, died last night at his home near Black River. His age was 79.

Realty deals announced over the week-end centered in. Harlem, where investors purchased numerous houses. Some of the properties were sold by savings banks. The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, which several years ago renovated the five-story apartment
Major Gen. Sir George Spafford Richardson, known as "the private who became major general," died today at the age of 69.

Dr. Wollmar Filip Bostrom, Swedish Minister to the United States, was one of eight leaders in varied fields to receive honorary degrees at Rutgers University's 172d anniversary commencement exercises this afternoon.

Exports of munitions from the United States in the two and a half years in which licenses have been issued by the National Munitions Control Board were valued at $118,363,700, a study of the board's reports disclosed today.

Trading in hide futures will start tomorrow on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange when the opening gong rings at 9 A. M. The September, December and March contracts will be posted tomorrow and the June delivery will be added within a few weeks.

Joe Gordon suddenly acquired a liking for the pitching of Bobby Feller yesterday. The Yankee freshman formally met the infant prodigy of the American League for the first time, punched a single as a warm-up, then, having got the range, lashed a homer with a man aboard in the eighth to give the New Yorkers a 7-6 victory over the Indians.

A Flag Day ceremony whose purpose was overshadowed at one time by the announcement that it would be a public meeting between Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City and Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens, who recently declared "100 per cent" support for him, was held by the Queens County American Legion at Memorial Field, Flushing, yesterday without Mr. Hague.
Professor William Arthur Bone, one of the leading British experts in the use of coal and fuels, died here today at the age of 67.

Theodore Ahrens, who began his career in Louisville sixty-six years ago as a $3-a-week foundry boy and rose to the presidency of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary iCorporation, world's largest heating and plumbing supply company, died at St. Anthony's Hospital here tonight at the age of 79.
The Bees and the Reds divided a doublekeader today. The visitors captured the opener in an extra inning, 6 to 5, and dropped the nightcap, 7 to 4. before 33.735 fans.

With the completion today of the protracted Czechoslovak elections entailing the expected consequences of a greatly increased Sudeten German vote, the Central European situation is likely again to become acute.

Owners of buildings with vacant living accommodations were reminded of the opportunity to improve their properties in time for the World's Fair under the provisions of the law granting tax exemption for repairs, in a statement issued yesterday by Grover A.Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation.

Stocks slightly higher, for second Consecutive week, in smallest turnover since week ended on July 14, 1923; turnover, 2,218,540 shares. United States Government issues higher; corporation bonds irregularly lower; foreign mixed; transactions, $22,712,625.

Champion Nonquitt Notable. two-andone-half-year-old American cocker spaniel owned by Mrs. Henry A. Ross of Philadelphia, was named best in the record-breaking Ladies Club Dog Show today before a large crowd on the Dedham Country and Polo Club grounds.

Scratch the most sophisticated American and you find a homesick farmer. The farther we are from farm life the more we yearn for it. The yearning is not so strong among actual agriculturists and animal husbandmen who get up, at 3 to milk twenty-one cows before breakfast.

" The Gay Nineties," a review of New York's entertainment from 1895 until today, has been announced by Warners. Dick Powell, Pat O'Brien, Olivia de Havilland, Kay Francis, George Brent, Humphrey Bogart and Ann Sheridan will be in the cast.
Miss Jane Elizabeth Davis, who was graduated from Smith College a year ago, was married this afternoon in Johnson Chapel at Amherst College to Stephen Ellen, an Amherst graduate of last year.

A course of six lectures on symphonic music will be given next season by the Philharmonic-Symphony League of New York, Mrs. John T. Pratt, chairman, announced yesterday. The lectures are planned to give the listener a greater appreciation of the works performed on the programs of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra.

In a light west-southwest breeze today, Henry Sears's new sloop Actaea, built for the Bermuda race, made a splendid showing against some of the boats she will meet in the contest across the Gulf Stream, which will start from Newport on June 21, a day later than planned.

Trade practices proposed for the oleomargarine manufacturing industry have been made public by the Federal Trade Commission and a hearing has been set for July 27 at its offices here, at which any interested persons may express their views.
President Roosevelt and Senator Gillette sat down in their shirtsleeves to a luncheon today and talked of a united Democartic party in Iowa.

Cotton prices moved over a comparatively wide range last week, but finished with only small net gains for the period. On the New York Cotton Exchange the gross fluctuation in prices of future contracts was about 40 points, but net gains for the week were only 7 to 8 points.

In the turbulent world situation today the task of the church at home is as difficult as the work of the missionary abroad, Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers declared yesterday in his sermon in Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.
The purchases of gold on Friday caused excitement here, reviving rumors of a further devaluation of the dollar and a readjustment of other currencies. It is even suggested that...

Bostwick Field had its postponed opening this afternoon, with flagraising, and a parade of Boy Scouts, calling attention to the fact that this first game was for the benefit of the Nassau County Boy Scout fund.

Professor and Mrs. William Howard Doughty were dinner hosts last night at Elscot, Williamstown, in honor of their daughter, Miss Betsy Hart Doughty, and her fiance, Robert Lord Debevoise of New York, whose engagement was announced yesterday.

William J. Hirten, dealer in- religious goods, died yesterday of a heart ailment at the Bay 'Ridge Sanitarium, Brooklyn. His age was 61. Mr. Hirten, a native of Brooklyn, for twenty years was associated with the firm of. P. J. Kennedy Sons, dealers in religious goods. Fifteen years ago he founded his own firm, William J. Hirten Company, of 25 Barclay Street.

Spring sports insignia for 197 Harvard undergraduates, including special awards to seven, were announced tonight. Major letters in minor colors were awarded to eight athletes who had won minor letters three consecutive years.
Mr. and-Mrs. William John Coulson gave a reception yesterday at their home, 84-37 Audley Street, Richmond Hill, Queens, in observante of their fiftieth wedding anniversary. They were assisted in

German chemical research has demonstrated the possibility of extracting 99 per cent pure helium from the atmosphere, Professor Philip Siedler of Frankfort on the Main today told a congress of German chemists at a session here.

Manor Ave, 1,101 (14-3742): Julay Realties, Inc, to Harry B. Lilienthal, 186 Delancey St; $10,000. Cauldwell Ave, 880 (10-1631); John Cuccia to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, extends mtgs to April 17, 1940, at 4 1/2 per cent; $17,800.
Corn made a modest recovery last week at the Board of Trade here, but the trade interest was light, and the strength shown was mainly a reflection of the action in wheat.

Search for Jane Grant Ford, 19 years old, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Grant Ford of Wausau, who disappeared from Vassar College at Poughkeepsie, N. Y., six days ago, was revealed here today when the aid of State and city police in Middle Western States was requested.

Drilling for oil will be demonstrated at the New York World's Fair 1939. A derrick manned- by skilled workers using the most modern equipment will be one of the features of the Petroleum Industry Exhibition building, it was announced yesterday by T. H. Taylor, president of the exhibiting corporation.

Representative Snell, the Republican leader, charged in a statement today that the Seventy-fifth Congress, after establishing a new record for futility and procrastination, was ending its session with the most brazen and shameless playing of politics in the twenty-four years of his membership.
Five hand grenades were thrown at different places in the International Settlement within one hour tonight in a new outburst of terrorism.
The Red Sox closed a long home stand against the West toddy by splitting a double-header with the White Sox before a capacity crowd of 34,500 at Fenway Park.

Miss Katherine Ryan Clark, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Vincent Clark of this city and the late Mr. Clark, has chosen June 25 for her marriage to William Seward Hall, son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Hall of New York.

From the internal political point of view, the decision of the Socialist party congress to support the Daladier Cabinet, and the split within Socialist ranks resulting in exclusion of the extremist faction cannot be considered as unfavorable - quite the reverse.

The fight of the American Medical Association against group medicine, if successful, would lead to the development of such intolerable conditions under a multiple-fee system that it would give enormous impetus to the demand for State control of hospital medical practice, Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, warned yesterday.

Bouncing back behind the four-hit pitching of round Freddy Fitzsimmons today after the Cubs had blasted Van Lingle Mungo for a 9-3 triumph in the first game, the irrepressible Dodgers took the nightcap, 6-0, and finished a remarkably successful Western tour with the record of having won seven of ten tames.

Authority has been granted to the Argentine State Railways to buy seven Diesel mechanical trains, according to a report to the Department of Commerce. This equipment, which will cost approximately $885,000, will be bought in Hungary.
ABRAHAM--Carrie, at Montgomery Ala., June 12, beloved sister of Dr. Joseph H. Abraham, aunt of Mrs. Carolyn Friedman, Mrs. Marjorie Meyer and Jack Abraham.
Ninety-two members of the graduating class of St. Francis Xavier High School attended a solemn military mass in the Church of St. Francis Xavier, 36 West Sixteenth Street, yesterday.

MUNICIPAL SCULPTOR-Two vacancies; $2,400. Duties: Maintain and restore monuments, fountains, plaques, etc. Education and experience requirements. Test: Technicaloral, rated experience. Applications open June 15, close July 7.

The Rev. Artley B. Parson, assistant secretary for foreign mis- sions of the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church, described a conception of the mystery of God in his sermon at Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, yesterday morning.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.7, which compares with 80.5 a week ago, 80.8 two weeks ago, 81.4 three weeks ago and 80.8 four weeks ago.

Luncheon of the Presbyterian social Union of New York, 14 Eas.t Sixtieth Street, 12:15 P. M, Speakers: Dr. James Young, Mrs. R. Park Johnson, Dr. Benjamin Farber. Luncheon of Society of Beaux-Arts "Architects, 304 East Forty-fourth Street, 1 P. M., to select winner in national competition for the Paris Prize.

The future of mankind is not determined in the political capitals or in cabinet sessions but in the hearts of the men and women to whom rabbis and teachers appeal, Professor Louis Finkelstein, provost of the Jewish Tleological Seminary of America, said in an. address at the institution's fifty-first commencement yesterday afternoon. The ex-.

The Giants promised for a time to wind up their second Western jaunt of the year with a flourish today as they routed Lon Warneke to flatten the Cardinals, 8 to 5, in the -first contest of a double-header.

The new synonym for consistency in American golf -big, stoop- shouldered Ralph Guldahl-has no intention of resting upon the laurels he achieved in capturing the National Open championship for the second successive year.
Completion of liquidation of the receiverships of two banks in New York City and one in Newark, N. Y., was reported today by Marshall R. Diggs, Acting Controller of the Currency.
The residents of this city began today the commemoration of the landing of the Huguenots in 1688. They will continue the 250th anniversary celebration daily throughout the week.

The best contribution that the United States can make to the future of the world is by keeping out of the next war, Norman. Thomas, Socialist leader, contended today at the closing session of the annual Summer conference of the League for Industrial Democracy.

Joe Louis played to a full house today. The heavyweight champion of the world, nearing the end of his preparation for his fight with Max Schmeling on June 22, literally packed them in the aisles as he went through one of the hardest sessions of his present training siege.

Miss. Ellen Holmes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph W. Holmes of this place, will be married to Dr. Lloyd seaman Saltus, son of Mrs. Lloyd Salts of Morristown, N. J., June 25 in St. James Church here. The Rev. Frederic L. C. Lorentzen will officiate.

Miss Eleanor Coolidge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Coolidge of this place and Manchester, and Frederick Burnham Chapman, whose engagement was announced last month, will be married here the afternoon of July 9 in St. John's Church. The Rev.
Bela Matavovszky, a rural county prosecutor, received a severe head wound today in a saber duel with Dr. Ferenc Rainiss, deputy leader of the National Front, a Nazi organization.

When Charles Maurras, who has just squeezed into the French Academy, made his first attempt to join the Immortals, Anatole France, who had been his friend, denounced his candidacy as "purely political."

Lack of interest shown by Protestants in religion and failure of wealthy men to support the churches and their work were deplored as serious phenomena by the Rev. Dr. Christian F. Reisner in his sermon yesterday in Broadway Tem-. ple Methodist Episcopal Church, 174th Street and Broadway.

More than 600 persons have been Tcb engaged by the Schuberts and' For- tra( tune Gallo for their season of op- Kai erettas this Summer at the Munic- pla. ipal Stadium, Randalls Island. The mir company will consist of 350, and rest there will be a staff of 250 in addition.
The Bethpage Shamrocks conquered the Pegasus Greens of Rockleigh, N. J., 11-7, at the Bethpage State Park in Farmingdale in one of three Eastern Polo League games played yesterday.

Publication today of the text of the decree setting forth in detail the reguLations for the application of the law of January, 1935, which gave legislative approval fo the plan for partial resumption of interest payments on Chile's foreign debt, has been well received in financial circles here.

Nineteenshow horses, including several blue ribbon winners at recent horse shows, were led safely from the burning stable of the Cedar Brook Farm of Walter Martin after lightning had struck it at about 2:30 o'clock this morning.

Five hundred and forty-two cenverts were inducted into the Roman Catholic Church in impressive ceremonies yesterday at the St. Rose of Lima Church, Parkville Avenue, between Eighth Street and Ocean Parkway. Brooklyn.

Parfums Lepgley, Ltd. importers of per- I fumes, in 680 5th Ave; William A. White Sons, brokers. Hand Knit Co, knit goods; Simon Klein, Venetian blinds, in 36 W 33d St; Tankoos, Smith Co, brokers. Braden Bros. Inc. stationers, in 75 Spring St; Institute of Research in Biography,

Lawrence A.'Appley, supervisor of education and training of the Socony Vacuum Company, Inc., of NewYork, said here today that the only answer to the basic problems now impeding industrial progress was "individual improvement" and that the "more abundant life" would result not from mass schemes ?? movements but from "individual ef fort."

From time to time in these turbulent days we are confronted with the old statement, "religion and politics do not go together," but the need is to unite them, declared the Rev. John Walter Houck in his sermon yesterday in Pilgrim Congregational Church, Grand Concourse at 175th Street, the Bronx.

Business indicators still give evidence of a traderecession, but the realities are not discouraging when the situation is analyzed. The slowing down in certain industries is partly due to the declining export trade and to the completion of large rearmament contracts.

The Foreign Policy Association announced yesterday that Mrs. Vera Micheles Dean had been appointed. research director of the organization. She will-take over part of the work of Raymond Leslie Buell, president of the association, who heretofore had combined both tasks.

Several hundred delegates to the annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America, arriving here today, found gloom being slowly dissipated in this capital of motordom. The convention is to get under way officially tomorrow. Meanwhile,

District Attorney Foley of the gr Bronx was notified yesterday by W, District Attorney Dewey of New Pr York County of the Bronx prosecu- gr. tor's appointment by the New York wi State Association of District Attorneys to the chairmanship of a special committee on the search and seizure amendment now before the constitutional convention.
The Tigers put on two wild scoring sprees today, wiped out an 11-to-1 Washington lead, and went on to win, 18 to 12. The victory gave Detroit a clean sweep of the threegame series.

The ordination of three candidates for the priesthood and six for the diaconate of the Episcopal Church was held yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St: John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street, Bishop William T. Manning officiating. The sermon, delivered by the Rev. Frank Dean Gifford, rector of St. Thomas Church,
had accumulated philanthropic resources aggregating $48,020,714 at the close of 1937, according-to a year-end survey just completed by the New York Community Trust.
The studied aloofness shown by the democratic governments to China in her travail is doing something significant, if not disturbing, to thought here in China.

God's purpose is not t6 destroy man but to lift him into a higher altitude of thought and conduct, the Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig decleared yesterday morning in his sermon in West End Collegiate Reformed Church, Seventy-seventh Street and West End Avenue.

Mr. and Mrs. John F. Kelly gave a bridge party this afternoon to announce the engagement of their daughter, Miss Regina C. Kelly, to William J. McCabe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael McCabe of Haverstraw, N. Y.

Five fairy-tale plays were staged by children yesterday afternoon on the Mall in Central Park. They were presented by the winning groups of each borough in the Park Department's third annual one-act play contest.

As if Mr. Farley didn't have more than trouble enough with the politicians, the phoneticians are snapping at him. A writer in Better English has picked up thirty-four words mispronounced by Mr. Farley in his radio address on Jefferson and Roosevelt.

Lard futures were strong most of last week, with packers credited with buying on several occasions. Receipts of hogs have decreased and, as a result of bad roads in some sections, the movement may be light for a few days longer.
About 587,000 copies of the Summer issue of the Manhattan Telephone Directory are now being distributed to subscribers in that borough, the New York Telephone Company announced yesterday.
Another earthquake shock occurred in Belgium and in the North of France today at 2:25 P. M. but, it was imperceptible in Paris. This shock was considerably less severe than yesterday's.

The Yellow River, "China's sorrow" is becoming increasingly a protagonist in the war against Japan. According to Chinese press reports from Chengchow the waters of the giant river are sweeping through breached embankments at

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,092,845,650. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills.

Of the three kinds of war in simultaneous progress in Europe the military battles, while the most agonizing, are not in the long run the most decisive. When th'e death struggle in Spain comes to an end, the exhausted Spanlards on both sides will discover that nothing is settled by military victory.

A new and simplified method of administering zinc sulphate to nasal passages as a preventive of infantile paralysis was presented to members of the American Medical Association in an exhibit today as more than 7,000 of them gathered here for their annual session.

One of several cowbirds shipped here from Waukegan, Ill., and released here May 27 in an experiment to determine the cowbird's homing instincts, arrived in Waukegan Saturday, covering the 700 miles in thirteen and a half days, it was reported tonight.

Francis T. Stager, director of Public Safety, died today at his home. Four-time member of the Town Commission, he was taken ill during his campaign for re-election in May, 1936. He operated a gasoline station.

Dr. John A. Kingsbury announced his resignation yesterday from the board of managers of the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor as an expression of "sharp disagreement" with what he characterized as the association's "policy of extreme conservatism with regard to its own funds."

The Monmouth County Country Club four went on a scoring spree today and defeated Burnt Mills, 11-5. William Foales paced the winners with six goals in one of the most interesting matches played on the club field this season.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission and the Budget Director are seeking establishment of a WPA white-collar project to study the classifications of 107,000 city employes and determine whether equal pay is being given for equal work in all departments, Paul J. Kern, president of the commission, reported yesterday.

Miss Ann Louise Rosenfeld, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis N. Rosenfeld, was married here today at the home of her parents to Dr. Jonathan L. Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Harris of East Orange. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Jonah B. Wise.

Today's municipal elections-the last of a series of three-passed off quietly according to all the reports received so far. In the German-speaking districts, as expected, the Henleinists again obtained an overwhelming majority of votes.

Mr. Roosevelt presented his detailed "pump-priming" program to Congress a on April 14. Two months have now gone by, and meanwhile Congress has granted to the President practically all that he asked for and more.

Those of you who are eager to get some black-bass fishing before the first of July can run up to Alexandria Bay in the Thousand Islands area and beat the season by two weeks. Because half of the islands are in Canada, .the season will open this Thursday.

Members of the class of '38 of the Academy of Mount St. Vincenton-Hudson will be admitted formally to the Alumnae Association of the institution at the annual June tea and reunion of the organization to be held Saturday in the main study hall of the school. The election of officers will precede the event.

Helen Arden, New York soprano, and Robert Ashton, baritone from Philadelphia, have been chosen by the Music Education League to appear as guest soloists at its fifteenth annual presentation of awards Thursday night at the Center Theatre.

The thirteenth annual meeting of the International Society for the Protection of Children opened here today with thirty nations, including China and Japan, represented by 600 delegates. Forty international experts will address the meeting on the protection of children.
Baccalaureate services in the university chapel yesterday morning opened five days of 'graduation activity at Fordham University in connection with the university's ninety-third commencement.

A late medieval tapestry, "The Redemption of Man," from the Cathedral of Burgos in Spain, is being shown this month in the room of recent accessions at the main building of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Opposition to proposals before the State Constitutional Convention for increasing taxes on real estate was expressed yesterday by William Guthman, president of Bing Bing, Inc., operators of buildings housing about 10,000 tenants.

A request for a hearing on the American Labor party's proposal to change the bi-partisan character of election boards was sent yesterday by Alex Rose, its State executive secretary, to Mrs. H. Z. M. Rogers, chairman of the suffrage committee of the Constitutional Convention. The change would give

Details of the factional troubles in the leadership of -the United Automobile Workers of 'America were put before John L. Lewis by both sides today at a six-hour session which will be resumed tomorrow.

A sharp thunderstorm broke over the city at about 7 o'clock last night, driving down the temperature 15 degrees in twenty minutes after a day of sultry heat in which the mercury rose to a high of 86, within 4 degrees of the record for June 12.

Harry Michitsch of the Trinity Club and Herman Steinmeyer of the home organization gained the final round of the Queens County A. A. U. one-wall handball singles championship yesterday at the Broad Channel Bathing Park.

Mayon volcano, which began erupting June 3, was still spouting fire and smoke today but with less intensity. Five eruptions were recorded in the past twenty-four hours. Paul V. McNutt, United States High Commissioner, planned to fly over the volcano in an army plane tomorrow.
The City feels strongly concerning the German default in Austrian loan payments, and the government is being urged to adopt measures against the withholding of pledged revenues.

Miss Helen Moskowitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Moskowitz of 3,060 Hull Avenue, the Bronx, and George Moerman, son of Mrs. Samuel Moerman, also of the Bronx, and the late Mr. Moerman, were married yesterday afternoon in the Concourse Center of Israel, 2,323 Grand Concourse, by the Rev. Dr. Max Drob.
Governor Lehman will receive the first annual award of the National Council of Young Israel at 10 o'clock next Sunday morning in the Jade Room of the Hotel WaldorfAstoria.
Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, Chancellor of New York University, announced on Saturday t'he promotion of fifty-five members of the faculty in nine schools and; colleges and the university.
The German Theatre Festival Week was opened here tonight with a performance of "Rosenkavalier" in Staatsoper attended by Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Propaganda Minister, who arrived here yesterday.

Miss Shirley Malvina Well, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Weil of 144 West Eighty-sixth Street, married yesterday in the Sky Gardens of the St. Moritz to Harry Giffords, son of Mrs. Barnett Giffords of New Britain, Conn., and Flushing, Queens, and the late Mr. Giffords.

Troops and planes are helping hundreds of families in Northern Sweden who face ruin from floods caused by melting snows, which have submerged thousands of acres and now threaten towns and villages. The damage thus far is estimated at 10,000,000 kronor.
Bernard Destremeau and Yvon Petra of France scored a stunning upset today by defeating Don Budge and Gene Mako for the French hardcourt doubles championship, 3-6, 6-3, 9-7, 6-1.

More than 15,000 persons attended a mass meeting here today to demonstrate the feeling of friendship Cuba has for Mexico. The crowd was entertrained with a musical program by a Mexican Cultural Mission that arrived here yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: British and French protests against bombings in Canton are, perhaps, to be expected, since they serve- the interests of a heavy trade in munitions carried on from and through those countries' and their possessions, a trade now favored by a number of pious people who, not long ago, were denouncing it as diabolical.

Samuel Johnson Duncan-Clark, Chicago news- G paper man and lecturer on social and religious subjects, died last night in St. Michael's Hospital at Toronto, where he underwent an operation on Friday. His age was 63.
The German were wholesale price index for June 1 a ga was slightly easier, being 105.3, against 105.4 the week before. In the first five months of this year the highest point reached by
Robert Frost said tonight that he had submitted his resignation as a member of the faculty of Amherst College because of "misgivings as to my value to the college as a 'no-time' teacher."

The Board of Trade's index of wholesale prices for May, based on the average for 1930 as 100, was 102, against 103.1 in April and 110.7 in May, 1937. The index numbers by groups of commodities compare as follows for a month and a year ago:
The cotton market here was somewhat more active last week, particularly near the close, and prices, after fluctuating narrowly at the start, became decidedly firm.

Miss Evelyn Anna Crowley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Crowley of New York, was married to Clifford C. Lubkert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl D. Lubkert, yesterday afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of St. John by Rev. John P. Haverv.

Members of the graduating class of Packer Collegiate Institute, 170 Joralemon Street, Brooklyn, were urged yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Phillips Packer Elliott of the First Presbyterian Church, Henry Street near Clark Street, Brooklyn, to carry away from school to the world a message of unity and hope.

Following discovery of the fact that candy is the "least advertised food product,' the board of directore of the National Confectioners Association of the United. States, Inc., has approved a plan to enlarge its merchandising and advertising campaign, launched on Feb. 1, with the slogan "Candy Is Delicious Food-Eat Some Every Day."

A chance reception of a Bergen County radio alarm by two patrolmen of the Montclair radio patrol yesterday afternoon brought about the arrest of four men who are accused of being members of a ring which has flooded northern New Jersey with counterfeit $5 bills.
Clarence H. Geist, public utility leader and one of Philadelphia's leading financiers, died today at his home, Launfal, in Villanova, after a short illness.

Twenty-two-year-old Frank Strafac? of Lakeville annexed. the Long Island amateur golf championship today by routing. his brother Tommy, one year his senior, a public links player from Shore View, in the 36-hole final over the sunbaked Garden City Country Club course. The score was. 4 and 3 and, except for the first hole, the victor never trailed.

Five columns of Spanish Insurgents, 20,000 strong, converged today on rich Castellon de la Plana, which finally lay under Generalissimo Francisco Franco's field guns after a bitter seven-week campaign, according to advices received here from Insurgent sources.
The Bourse was extremely dull last week and prices sagged. There was some selling by tired holders of bull positions, while investors continued on the side lines. The latter are being solicited

Real estate foreclosures in eighty-two metropolitan cities, representing about one-third of the country's population, declined 23.2 per cent in the first four months of the current year, compared with the same period last year, Corwin A. Fergus of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today.

Winning the national outdoor saber championship in even-numbered years has become a habit with Dr. John R. Huffman. The New York A. C. fencing ace, victor in this event in 1934 and 1936, today captured the crown for the third time in five seasons in the title competition held on the tree-shaded walks of the Hofstra College campus.

Supreme Court Justice Poletti today disputed the contention of District Attorney Dewey of New York County that constitutional prohibition of the use of evidence gained by wiretapping and searches and seizures without warrants would tie the hands of prosecuting officials and the police and provide "immunity for gangsters and swindlers."
Dizzy Dean was left behind in the care of a specialist when the Cubs left tonight for their swing through the Eastern half of the National League.

Top Notch, chestnut gelding owned by Miss Betty Jane Ferguson of Huntington, L. I., and ridden by Tom Spratt, won the saddle horse championship of the fifth annual Sands Point Horse Show on the Luckenbach estate today.
British authorities here describe the present situation with respect to the Austrian loans as a "deadlock," and refuse to consider the rupture in negotiations as definitive.

Announcement was made here last night of the death last Thursday in Dublin, Ireland, of Miss Marie Nunan, 14-year-old daughter of Sean Nunan, who was Irish Consul in New York from 1932 until his appointment last month as secretary to the Irish High Commissioner in London.

The principal synagogue here, situated in the heart of the city, is being demolished in order to make room for a parking area. Orders for its removal followed a twenty-four-hour 'ultimatum from the Interior Ministry to the Jewish community to vacate the property in return for the payment of 100,000 marks.

Smoothswinging Martin Issler of Rock Spring fresh from a victory in the Montclair invitation last week, today captured the Canoe Brook Country Club's first best-ball invitation golf tournament with Charles H. Achenbach of the home club.

When the earth rocks in England, Belgium and France it is news to the technically uninformed. But not to geophysicists. Their sensitive instruments respond often enough to superficial disturbances, especially in the Rhine Valley and in England.

Three hundred the warn automotive engineers listened intently tonight as Louis Johnson, assistant secretary of war, outlined new policies of the War Department in connection with mechanization of the army at the annual dinner of the Society of Automotive Engineers here.

Miss Jane Marquardt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oswald Frederick Marquardt of this place, has chosen the evening of June 28 for her wedding here to Arthur Gordon Murphy, son of Mrs. A. J. Murphy of New York and Sayville, L. I., formerly of Montclair.

Columbia University announced yesterday the receipt of cash gifts totaling $51,861. The largest contribution on the list, which was made public by Provost Frank D. Fackenthal, was $12,000 from Mrs. Edward S. Harkness to provide for six students at the School of Medicine scholarships of $500 each for their entire four-year course.

Word was received here last night of the death yesterday at his Summer home in Monterey, Mass., of Dr. John Horn of 502 Park Avenue, this city, a specialist in diseases of the ear, nose and throat, who had been on the surgical staff of the Lenox Hill Hospital for nearly forty years.
The government announced tonight that forty-three members of General Saturnino Cedillo's personal bodyguard had surrendered to Federal officers.

Carlos Pintacuda of Italy today won the 279-kilometer Brazilian auto classic for the second straight year. Arzani of Argentina was second, with Oliviera of Portugal third and Nasciemento of Brazil fourth. Eighteen started.

Mrs. Ralph Worthington of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ethel Worthington, to William James Coad Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Coad of Omaha. The prospective bride was graduated from the Ethel Walker School at Simsbury, Conn., attended the Finch School in New York, and studied abroad.

Industry was quiet last week. Comment in party journals stresses the "ominous" decline in private building. The Volkswirt emphasizes the fact that dwellings under construction are 14 per cent below the 1937 level, and even in 1937 only 4 per cent of the

With no fresh disturbing developments on the European Continent, the stock market turned cheerful last week, ignoring foreign trade. factors and regarding the Wall Street outlook as more favorable despite-the poor industrial news.
The wheat outlook is bullish, and it is believed that Europe must increase its purchases in the United States unless the Russian and Balkan crops are heavier than expected.

MORNING EVENTS Class 3 (limit saddle horses over 14.2 hands)--First, Miss May Gardner's ch. g. Beau Kalarama; second, Mrs. Charles M. Allaire's b. g. Last Fling; third, Miss Jean A. Killian's ch. m. Woodland Peter Pan; fourth, Bell Ho Stable's br. m. Miss Wildfire.

Engineers of Station WNYC used New York City's portable relay short-wave transmitter for the first time today when they broadcast the first of a series of chamber music recitals from Music Mountain in the foothills of the Berkshires.

The marriage of Miss Alice Warner, daughter of Mrs. G. E. Warner of this place, and the late Mr. Warner, to James M. Morrison of New York will take place on the morning of June 30 in St. Mary's Church here.

Endowment, student aid, building and current expenses at Princeton University were advanced by $1,011,492 in gifts in the threemonth period from Dec. 1, 1937, to Feb. 28, 1938, it was announced tonight by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.
With only three major pieces of legislation and some smaller matters ahead, Congressional leaders were confident today that Congress would be able to wind up its affairs before the end of the week.

About 300 retail food merchants from Greater New York, meeting under the auspices of the Food Merchants Fair Trade Committee at the Hotel Center 108 West Fortythird Street, called on manufacturers yesterday to sign agreements with them under the Feld-Crawford Act.

Charles Francis Massy Swynnerton and Dr. B. D. Buritt, two African leading authorities on sleeping sickness, were killed in an airplane crash last week near Singida, Tanganyika, it was discovered today. The pilot of the plane, William Bawden, also was killed.

Discovery of the wreckage of the Transcontinental and Western airliner that disappeared with nine persons aboard on the night of March 2 was reported here today to Chief Forest Ranger Forest C. Townsley of Yosemite National Park.

James J. Braddock saw Max Schmeling step briskly through eight rounds of sparring today as the former world heavyweight champion launched the last week of training for his title bid against Joe Louis in New York on June 22and unhesitatingly picked the Brown Bomber to stow the German away in seven rounds.
Canada's newsprint production for May amounted to 207,678 tons, down 33.1 per cent from the 310,650 tons for the same month of last year, the Newsprint Association of Canada reported today.
The navy's disclosure of preparations to build a long range patrol flying boat of possibly fifty tons hinted today at a friendly competition with the army in efforts to get better airplanes.
The latest banking statistics indicate that the recent disturbance in the credit position, due to heavy withdrawals of French balances from Great Britain, now has been almost remedied.

Miss Muriel Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Brown of 12 West Seventy-second Street, was married to Jerry Lobel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Lobel of Atlantic Beach, L. I., yesterday afternoon in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The Rev. Dr.

Walt Disney, creator of "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs," "Mickey Mouse," "Three Little Pigs" and "Donald Duck," will receive academic recognition on June 23 when Harvard University awards him a Master of Arts degree. It's about time, too.

Glenn Merrill Smith, since 1925 a partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Thomas L. Manson Co., with which he had been associated for forty years, died yesterday at his home, 211 Madison Avenue, Flushing, Queens, after a brief attack of heart disease.

Imports by France for the first five months were valued at 19,462,000,000 francs, a gain of 2,877,000,000 over the same period of 1937. Foodstuffs came to 5,102,000,000 francs, a rise of 835,000,000; raw materials, 11,384,000,000 francs. a gain of 1,500,000,000, and manufactures, 2,977,000,000 francs, an increase of 541,000,000.

The Dry Dock Savings Institution sold to the 31 Norfolk St Corp. Joseph L. B. Mayer, president, the flats at 31 Norfolk St for a price shown as $18,000, taking back a purchase money mortgage for $15,250. When David Weiss bought from the Greenwich Savings Bank the premises at 411-13 Grand St for $60,000 he gave back

A report on a wages and hours bill with provisions almost completely changed from the Senate and House versions was signed today by the conference committee, and preparations were begun to present it to the House tomorrow for swift action.

With much jubilant prayer, shouting in unfamiliar tongues and singing of rousing hymns in two-four time, Daddy Grace and his Negro followers dedicated yesterday as the United House of Prayer for All People the old "heaven" of Father Divine at 20 West 115th Street in Harlem, which they had bought for $20,000 cash.

The new Norwegian America Line motorship Oslofjord will arrive at 2:30 P. M. today on her maiden voyage under the command of Captain Kjell S. Irgens and will dock at Pier 4, foot of Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn.

In explaining the referendum in which the American Jewish Congress will seek the- endorsement of 1,000,000 Jews :In this -country on June 25, 26 and 27,- the president of the congressJ, Rabbi Stephen S. WVise, denounced the American Jewish Committee last night for publishing its opposition "on behalf J of Amricans who are Jews."
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period of June 4 to 10 are given in the following tabulation:

The marriage of Miss Sybil Ann Burne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Solden Burne of 444 Central Park West, to Murray Schneck of 10 Park Avenue; son of Mrs. Fannie Schneck of Lawrence, L. I., took place last evening in the Terrace Club of the St. Moritz.

The Federal grand jury will resume its inquiry tomorrow into alleged German espionage in the Eastern part of the United States. It was learned yesterday that several Federal agents were in the Yorkville district interviewing and looking for witnesses. Additional indictments are expected.
Fred Snite Jr. has gone home, still encased in an "iron lung" in which he has been fighting infantile paralysis.

The achievements of all former rectors of Zion Protestant Episcopal Church, Douglaston, Queens, were commemorated and portraits of them, to be hung in various rooms in the church buildings, were received at the 108th anniversary service of the church yesterday morning. The Rev. Lester L. Riley,

Colonel William G. Schauffler Jr. of Lakewood; N. J., came into port here last night with what local fishermen say is the largest broadbill swordfish ever caught off the Jersey coast. It weighed 387 pounds.

While an entertainer was in the midst of her song and forty patrons stood at the bar, a ceiling above the oval bar at Paprin's Restaurant, 60-19 Roosevelt Avenue, Woodside, Queens, fell last night, causing slight injuries to seven persons.
Last week, reduced to four business days by the Whitsuntide holidays, was characterized by an almost complete dearth of transactions. The foreignexchange market was quiet, prices fluctuating little.

The extraordinary fading of crop prospects in the Southwest worked a remarkable change in sentiment in the wheat market in the last few days, activity increasing by leaps and bounds as commission buying on a large scale forced the shorts into rapid retreat.

Mrs. John Crosby of 41 Park Terrace West and Navesink, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Florence Bernedette Crosby, to William McCord Harris Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harris of Riverdale-on-Hudson.

Since 9 o'clock last night London has been unable to get in touch with Moscow on the telephone and inquiries by THE NEW YORK TIMES early this morning indicate that other European capitals also have been unable to communicate with the capital of Soviet Russia.

Warden Michael Gill of Hudson County penitentiary at Secaucus denied tonight that either James F. (Jeff) Burkitt or John R. Longo, political foes of Mayor Frank Hague, had been mistreated or denied privileges accorded to other inmates.

Bishop William T. Manning conducted yesterday afternoon his eighteenth Trinity Sunday service in the Chapel of the Good Shepherd on Welfare Island and administered confirmation to forty patients in the island's community of lame, sick and blind.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange last week; also the new highs and lows and total number of issues for the last three weeks:

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORKE Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbels, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:

Winter wheat in Germany has recovered from the effects of the unfavorable conditions in April and is reported now to be better than last year. With satisfactory weather this month the crop should make a good showing. Rye and the chief root crops and sugar beets also are satisfactory.

The new motor ship Oslofjord of the Norwegian America Line, described as the largest and finest vessel that Norway has ever sent across the ocean, is due to arrive today on her maiden voyage. Passengers from Northern Europe include G. Hilmer Lundbeck, managing director of the Swedish Amerlean Line; Mr. and Mrs. Edward...

Sir Lewis Dibdin, authority on ecclesiastical law, died today at the age of 85. For thirty-one years, 1903-34, he was dean of the arches-judge of the church's famous appeal court. He served as a member of the Royal Commission on Church Discipline and helped in preparing the revised prayerbook.

A lesson was drawn from the biblical story of Gideon, "mighty man of valor," who drove the lawless, plundering Midianites from the land of the hard-working, lawabiding Israelites, in the baccalaureate sermon at the United States Military Academy today.

A letter from President Roosevelt endorsing the' proposal of the National Recreation Association for a n'ation-wide observance on July 28 of "Joseph Lee Day" in honor of its late president, who wvas known as the "father of the American playground movement," was made public yesterday. Mr. Lee died on July 28, 1937,

The Franklin Society sold the twofamily dwelling at 727 East 218th Street, the Bronx, to.a buyer who intends to alter it. The Alfieri Realty Company was the broker. The same broker sold the onefamily house at 1,936 Edenwald Avenue to Walter Votens and a vacant lot on the east side of Hill Avenue, north of Edenwald, to a builder for improvement.

ELDX MORROW is one of those who are sure that parliaments and popular fronts are so much outmoded nonsense. Particularly as applied to Spain, where for nearly two years now the Loyalist forces have been fighting in their behalf. See his "Revolution and Counter-Revolution in Spain,"* a well-documented and fairly sober little book published today.

Elwood Cooke of Portland, Ore? won his second major tournament of his Eastern campaign yesterday when he routed Frank Bowden, former Columbia star, in the final of the Brooklyn tennis championships at the Terrace Club in Flatbush.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. told the members of the graduating class of La Salle Military Academy here today to go forth as the Crusaders of old because "America is still the shrine of liberty." More than 1,500 guests attended the exercises on the campus.

Four blues, including the jumping sweepstakes and the Rock Spring Challenge Trophy class, fell to Midkiff's Melody, rangy chestnut mare owned and ridden by Mrs. Laning Harvey Jr. of Kingston, Pa., during the second and final day of the fourth annual horse show at the Rock Spring Riding Club today.

Frederick. Winthrop Neilson, retired president of the SikorskyAircraft. Company, died today at his home here after a long illness at the age of 42. He also was former president of the United Aircraft Export, was a graduate of the United States Naval Academy and saw naval aviation service.
The Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of the Catholic Archdiocese of New York, dedicated and blessed a new chapel at St. John's Villa Academy, Arrochar, S. I., yesterday.
Bob Johnson collected his fourteenth and fifteenth home runs of the season for the Athletics today as they won both games of a double-header from the Browns, 2 to 3 and 1 to 0.

Announcement was made yesterday by Houghton Mifflin of the award of $1,000 to Miss Maurine Whipple of St. George, Utah, to assist her in completing a novel, "The Giant Joshua," which will cover, when completed, three generations of Mormon life.

The United Mine Workers of America called off a mass meeting planned for today here in celebration of a victory over the Clover Fork Coal Company to avoid any possibility that it would embarrass the government in the trial at London of forty-four individuals and nineteen corporations accused of conspiring against the Wagner Labor Relations Act.
For the second successive year J. Gilbert Hall and Arthur MacPherson won the annual invitation doubles tennis tournament of the Piping Rock Club today.
Mrs. Thomas J. Hickey, daughter of the late Andrew O'Reilly, pioneer merchant of Rondout, N. Y., died at her home here yesterday after a long illness. She was in her seventies. Mrs. Hickey had been

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Warner M. Van Norden of 7 West Fifty-seventh Street of the engagement of their ward, Miss Virginia Bulkeley, to Edward Andrew Wagner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Wagner of Troy, N. Y.
The French wholesale price index for June 4 was 644, the same as On May 28 and compared with 645 on May 21.

The congregation, choir and classes of St. James Lutheran Church, which lost its buildings last week when unable to meet paynents on a mortgage, were welomed yesterday at services in the Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, Central Park West and SixtyHifth Street. More than 400 members of both congregations attended.

Nancy Carroll. actress, in Hotel Plaza, 5th Ave and 59th St. Mrs. Louise F. G. Grimke, in 64 E 86th St. through Samuel A. Herzog. Martha Green. Mario Tamburrelli. Leonard J. Field, John H. Olsen, J. W. Bell, Airs. Merrill M. Stuckey, in Alwyn Court, 7th Ave and 58th St, through Edgar Ellinger, Inc.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Marion Collins Ely, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Griswold Ely of this place and Pelham Manor, N. Y., to Philip Page Johnston, which will take place. here on July 9 in the Old Lyme Congregational Church.

A prediction that next year's automobile business will be about equivalent to the volume of the industry in 1932 if the present downward trend continues, is made by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the General Motors Corporation, in a letter sent today to common stockholders accompanying their 25-cent dividend for the second quarter.

An increase in repressive actions against left wing individuals, organizations and publications by Kuomintang [Nationalist Party] officials is putting a marked strain on the relations between China's Leftists, including the Communists, and the Kuomintang and government leaders.

Edward J. Hirz is in the retail by sales department of Bond Goodwin, Inc., specializing in real estate securities. Irving C. Clark has been appointed agency secretary of the American Surety Company of New York and the New York Casualty Company.

The new Federal Wage-Hour Bill will provide for the establishment of pooh wage boards for each industry. The proposal may have been suggested by our own NRA experiment or by the procedure in Great Britain. The latter is described in an article in the May issue of the Monthly Labor Review, published by the United States Department of Labor.
Manhattan's jitterbugs turned out 6,000 strong at Madison Square Garden last night to swing for charity at the dance carnival sponsored for the benefit of the Los Angeles Sanatorium.

A man later identified by his fingerprints as Jesus Cortez, an exconvict who had served two terms for burglary, was shot and killed at 8:30 o'clock last night in Mosholu Parkway near Webster Avenue, the Bronx, by two policemen from whom he had broken away after having been captured while looting a near-by apartment.

Robert D. Williams Jr. has been elcted vice president in charge of all sales of the Callaway Mills, La Grange, Ga., one of the largest textile manufacturing concerns in the world. Mr. Williams recently has been head of one of the company's New York offices and was formerly in charge of consumer sales.

Collection ratios on open credit accounts receivable of department stores showed a decrease of 4.3 per cent in April, compared with April, 1937, and a loss of 0.4 per cent, compared with March, 1938, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce has reported.
The tendency thus far to leave the railroads to their fate illustrates the complete perversity of the attitude into which Washington has fallen regarding the serious business situation.
The New York Athletic Club nine rallied in the seventh inning to defeat a Trenton team, 9-6, at Travers Island yesterday.
Former Premier Pierre-Etienne Flandin declared today that the Daladier government was prepared to order mobilization to aid Czechoslovakia if she were invaded by Germany.

With Charlie Keller and Bob Seeds rapping two home runs apiece, the Bears today gained a double victory over Toronto, 11 to 4 and 4 to 1. Keller and Seeds hit their homers in succession in both games, the latter increasing his total to 22. Keller has 10.

Bob and Jack Whitbeck of the Bronxville Field Club, last year's winners, repeated in the third annual invitation tennis doubles tournament at the Manursing Island Club today, defeating Lee Norris and Charles Watson of the Rockway Hunting Club in the final, 4-6, 6-3, 7-5.

Arthur De Persia, 28 years old, a political reporter for The Long Island Daily Press, was found dead last night in his room at 166-24 Ninetieth Avenue, Jamaica. He had shot himself with a pistol, according to the police.
Jo Davidson, American sculptor, arrived today to prepare a model of Senora Dolores Ibarruri, Communist leader known throughout Government Spain as La Pasionaria-the Passion Flower.

The Rev. Charles Leighton Steel, rector emeritus of Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, died yesterday at his home here after an illness of more than a year. His age was 75. He had been rector of Calvary Church twenty-six years before his retirement in July of 1936.
A forty-foot statue of St. Patrick was unveiled today overlooking the place where Ireland's patron saint landed more than fifteen centuries ago-to conduct his first mission.

Temporary disappearance of a highly secret document from the archives of the world's premier anti-submarine school on the H. M. S. Osprey here gave authorities the jitters and resulted in a secret court of inquiry last night, it was learned reliably today.

An earthquake helped to create a new type of violin, the invention of Dr. Hugo Benioff, Associate Professor of Seismology at the California Institute of Technology, that is said to have astounded musicians by the depth, volume and clarity of its tones.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 25 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the preceding week if that period were taken at full capacity, not allowing for the holiday, which was generally observed.
The domestic trade position is reflected in continued firmness in the bond market, but last week's rise in British Government issues revived rumors of plans for floating defense loans.

Price lists, effective July 1, of the Oldetyme Distillers, Inc., will give effect to the new Federal tax on distilled liquors of 25 cents a gallon. Raymond M. Dennis, who has been superintendent of flanging at the Lukens Steel Company, Coatesville, Pa., has been appointed general manager of the flanging department.
The Radio City Music Hall disclosed yesterday the romances of four of the feminine members of its staff, three of whom have become engaged to or have married men of the organization.

The Duchess while Mor of Norfolk, wife of the Premier Goldrick, Duke and Earl Marshal of England, gave birth to a daughter at her home here today. The Duchess, before her marriage in January, 1937, was the Honorable Lavinia Mary Strutt, daughter of Lord Belper, third Baron of his line.

Drawing an evenly contested game in the fourth round, Sir George Thomas of London, former British champion, moved-into second place in the international chess masters tournament today. The leader, Erich Eliskases of Austria, adjourned his match in a position favorablee to Paul Keres of Estonia.

Dean Willard L. Sperry of the Harvard Divinity School told the seniors of Vassar College in the baccalaureate sermon today that "in the end it will be left for religion to accom-plish what plainly realistic politics must fail to achieve."

J. Harris, formerly of Harris, Rippe Co., is now with S. Stanley Sogg Co., Inc. The Twenty-third Street Association will hold its last regular luncheon meeting for the Summer on Wednesday in the Cornish Arms Hotel, 311 West Twenty-third Street.

The cutter Spookie, owned by Harold T. White Jr. and flying the colors of the Nantucket Yacht Club, won the annual whalers' race of the New Bedford Yacht Club today, covering the 104-mile course around Block Island in 20 hours 44 minutes 40 seconds corrected time.

Movement of National Guard troops to Camp Smith here and Pine Camp in Northern New York, near Great Bend, got under way early today to start the three months of Summer training in which 21,000 will receive two weeks of instruction.

Flag Day, to be observed throughout the nation tomorrow, was marked yesterday in Brooklyn by parades in Prospect Park, Coney Island, Greenpoint and Bay Ridge. Police estimated that 60,000 persons viewed the 6,000 marchers.

IT appears now that it is going to be a long war-or whatever the Japanese care to call it-in China and the Olympic repercussions in this country are not going to be pleasant. Incidentally, if that isn't a war that's going on in China, it's the best imitation a troubled world ever has seen.
Harry Greenwood Snelling, who at one time was treasurer of the New York Central Railroad, died today at his home in this village at the age of 72.

The engagement of Miss Elisabeth Mary Heinzelmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Heinzelmann of this place, to James Lyle Phillips, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Phillips of Mount Vernon, has been announced by her parents.

Miss Mary Travis, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Thomas Travis of this place, will be married here on June 25 to Robert Allen Arny, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Vinecome Arny. Mr. Travis will perform the ceremony in the Watchung Avenue Congregational Church, of which he is pastor.
Buffalo stopped Jersey City's winning streak at five straight today by taking the nightcap of a doubleheader, 6 to 2, after the Little Giants had won the opener, 4-3, in ten innings.

The thirty-two retired actors and actresses at the Actors Fund of America Home here were entertrained by a group of New York variety-show performers this afternoon at the annual luncheon and party of the board of directors of the fund.

The organization of the William J. Wollman Foundation to administer a $5,000,000 trust fund established for charitable purposes, under the will of William J. Wollman, securities broker and philanthropist, was announced yesterday. Mr. Wollman died March 27, 1937, at the age of 69.
Mr. and Mrs. August C. Wurm of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Edith Wurm, to Samuel Allcorn Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Allcorn of Hillside, N. J.

A program of thirty feature pictures and twelve Technicolor short subjects for release by the United Artists Corporation next season will be announced today by George J. Schaefer, vice president and general manager of distribution here and in Canada,

The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Frederic S. Fleming will give a dinner on June 20 in the Ambassador for their daughter, Miss Mary Louise Fleming, and her fiance, Eugene J. McVoy, whose marriage will take place the next day' in Trinity Church, of which Dr. Fleming is the rector. Dr. Fleming will perform the ceremony.

Convictions were obtained in 75.2 per cent of the 10,316 criminal cases involving major offenses in trial courts of the State of New York in 1937, the Bureau of the Census reported today. The total number of criminal cases disposed of was 11,695.

Death will ride a flat-car from coast to coast if America is ever threatened with invasion from the sea. A new type eight-inch railway gun mount, in which has been embodied all artillery improvements made by the United States since the World War, is practically completed at Watertown Arsenal.

Section 2. (a) The Congress hereby finds that the existence, in industries engaged in commerce or in the production of goods for commerce, of labor conditions detrimental to the maintenance of the minimum standard of living necessary for health, efficiency and general wellbeing of workers (1) causes commerce and the channels and instrumentalities of commerce to be used to spread and perpetuate such labor conditions among the Workers of the several States; (2) burdens

All attendance records for symphony concerts in Uruguay were broken last night for Jose Iturbi's farewell appearance. The Urquiza Opera House was packed to capacity and 500 would-be ticket purchasers were turned away.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Ist Lt. Hule A. Smith, Inf.-Res., 229 East 42d St., New York, N. Y., is relieved from assignment to the 77th Division and is assigned to the 1st Division. 1st Lt. James E. Cavanagh, Med.-Res., 44 Peru St., Plattsburg, N. Y., unassigned, is assigned to the 1st Division.
Retail prices in May declined 0.8 per cent below the April level and were 6.4 per cent lower than at the end of May, 1937, according to the Fairchild retail price index, issued yesterday.

The engineers who will be graduated tomorrow by Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute do not prefer blondes and have been too engrossed in calculus and thermodynamics to keep up with the latest in shag dancing.

Miss Anne Williamson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Williamson, died on Sunday in London, England; after a six months illness, according to word received here yesterday. She was born in Algiers thirteen years ago.

A blood donation by a Joliet, in, mother of five, who, touched by the appeal of parents whose son lay desperately ill in Kings County Hospital, traveled 791 miles by airplane and automobile, failed yesterday to save the life of Hyman Liederman, 16-year-old Brooklyn high school senior.

On the eve of the expected declaration on British foreign policy by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain in the House of Commons, for which the Prime Minister has been preparing today by interviews with Viscount Halifax, Foreign Secretary, Sir Kingsley Wood, Secretary for Air, and other Ministers, an editorial In today's Yorkshire Post is attracting considerable attention.

Negotiations looking to the acquirement by the Tennessee Valley Authority of the Alabama Power Company, the Tennessee Electric Power Company and the Mississippi Power Company were resumed today at a conference between David E. Lilienthal, director of the TVA, and Wendell L. Willkie, chairman of the board of the Commonwealth Southern Corporation.
The wheat market had a reactionary tendency today, which was not regarded as at all remarkable in view of the rapidity of the advance late last week.

A blanket mortgage for $25,000, due according to the bond, was given by Siren Realty Corp, Nathan Stern, president, to Structural Builders, Inc, on 66-68 E 4th St and 15-17 E 3d St. 50x192.5, and four Parcels in the Bronx, n e cor of Union Ave and 160th St, 77-172; n w cor Fulton Ave and 174th St. 54 1/2x90; 796 E 163d St, and 809811 Freeman St.

At 7:30 o'clock this morning an English voice over the long-distance wire to Moscow told London telephone operators that communication had been restored between the two cities. No explanation, however,
The New York Stock Exchange firm of Edward G. Wyckoff Co. will be dissolved tomorrow. The interest of the late Paul Adler in Adler, Coleman Co. will cease tomorrow.

Professor Vladimir Karapetoff of the College of Engineering at Cornell University announced today that he and Miss R. M. Cobb of Winthrop, Mass., and Leonia, N. J., were married on Nov. 25, 1936, at Dobbs Ferry, N. Y.

The government's steadily expanding invasion of the American clothing manufacturing industry affecting, according to trade leaders, the status of both the retailer and the manufacturer, is factually presented in the forthcoming issue of National Clothier, merchandising publication of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers.

Charges that the National Labor Relations Board sometimes is partial in its administration of the Wagner act were denied by Thomas I. Emerson, assistant general counsel of the board, in an address before the Institute of Labor, which began a three-day session here today under the auspices of Rutgers University in cooperation with the New Jersey Federation of Labor and the Workers Education Bureau.

Ellis Ames Ballard, corporation lawyer, public utilities expert and possessor of one of the world's outstanding collections of the works of Rudyard Kipling, died of uremic poisoning early today at his home, Four-Way Farm, Roxborough. He had been ill a month. His age was 77.

A fund of about $65,000,000 will be available when payment of employee benefits commences next January, the New Jersey Unemployment Compensation Commission estimated today in announcing net assets of $43,905,913 on April 30.
Southwestern plain or mountain country-it's all the same to Miss Patty Berg, at 20 a veteran in women's golf competition.

Two American universities and a French institution today defied orders of the Japanese-established North China regime to participate in political parades and mass demonstrations against the Chinese Government of Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek.

One of the largest fields ever listed for the event is expected to compete in the annual senior track and field championships of the Metropolitan A. A. U. at Glen Park, Yonkers, on June 25. Entries will close Friday night with John J. Flaherty Jr. at A. A. U. headquarters, 233 Broadway.

William Allen White, Emporia editor, told the graduates of the Carnegie Institute of Technology today that the only way to create a better world was to make people individually good and that to attain such a goal as much prosperity as possible must be assured all men.
Its avenues bedecked with flags and banners, New Rochelle observed today the second day of its 250th anniversary celebration by opening two historical exhibitions.
The Gaelic Musical Society of America will hold its Joyce Kilmer Night on the mall in Central Park at 8:30 P. M. tonight. Dr. James J. Walsh is chairman of the evening.

Steel operations for the current week are scheduled at 27.1 per cent of capacity, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. This rate represents an increase of 0.9 point, or 3.4 per cent, over last week's level of 26.2.
A 13year-old stowaway arrived here today aboard the French liner Ile de France. He is Alex Gam, son of a New York barber.

Harlee Branch, Second Assistant Postmaster General in charge of Air Mail Service, told President Roosevelt today that the department had virtually completed its "primary" system of air mail routes and was about ready to get into the "secondary phase," which means the feeder routes covering cities not now serviced.

Legislation by which the government would extend financial aid to the railroads was dropped today from the "must" list for this session of Congress as President Roosevelt and his leaders set Wednesday night as the goal for final adjournment.

President Roosevelt's instructions to Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, to seek new markets for America's wheat plethora in European countries, including Germany, are received in political circles and the press here with rather ironic commentaries and little sympathy.

The New Jersey Power and Light Company, an affiliate of the Associated Gas and Electric system, was ordered today by the Federal Power Commission to submit in writing by June 24 detailed information concerning its reported acquisition of 341,350 shares of the common stock of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company, also an Associated Gas company.

A vigorous denunciation of radio as an "octopus" which is strangling national advertising in newspapers enlivened the opening session of the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association convention this morning at the Hotel Book-Cadillac.
The United Lutheran Synod of New York opened Its convention here today. A proposed new church policy on marriage, divorce and sex is expected to provoke heated debate.

With nine days to go before he steps into the ring of the Yankee Stadium to attempt to lift the world heavyweight title from Joe Louis, Max Schmeling today was physically nearly perfect, at least to his own satisfaction, and mentally at ease.
The Hapag Lloyd Line announced yesterday that in 1939, for the first time in fourteen years, it would not send a ship around the world on a pleasure cruise.

Immediate increase in home relief allotments and other recommendations for improvement of home and work relief was urged yesterday by the City Affairs Committee in a bulletin issued through Frederick L. Guggenheimer, executive director of the committee.

Commander Daniel J. Callaghan of Oakland, Calif., will succeed Captain Walter B. Woodson as naval aide to President Roosevelt. He will assume his duties when Mr. Roosevelt reaches the Pacific Coast on his Western trip.

A 9-year-old boy, attempting to pull his bulldog from under the third rail at the Denton Avenue crossing of the Long Island Railroad here, was fatally shocked, then struck by a westbound steam train shortly after 3:30 P. M. today.

President Roosevelt discussed the legislative program with Congressional leaders; sent to Congress a message recommending codification of nationality laws; signed the $463,651,000 War Department Appropriation Bill; sent to the Senate the nomination of Frederick A. Sterling to be Minister to Sweden and discussed expansion of the air-mail service with Harllee Branch, Second Assistant Postmaster General.
Miss Charlotte Glutting of New Jersey will defend her Eastern women's championship starting Wednesday and the New York team its intercity title in the Griscom Cup golf tournament tomorrow.

A few minutes before he was to have been sentenced for violation of the narcotics law, Daniel Scarbetti, a self-confessed member of a ring of narcotics smugglers, fled yesterday from the Federal Building, where Judge Murray Hulbert had already imposed sentences upon other members of the ring who had either pleaded guilty or had been convicted.

St. Matthews, the largest Protestant Church in. Munich, will be razed by July 10. It stands on the route of the future Munich subway and the Evangelical Church had been assured that the church was not threatened, but instead would have its foundations strengthened to meet. the demands of the subway builders.
The general attitude of the country's press toward the Wages and Hours Bill is shown in editorial comment from newspapers from key cities as follows:

The State will pay tribute to Chief Justice Arthur Prentice Rugg, who died of his Sterling home yesterday, at services Wednesday at 3 P. M. at the First Unitarian Church here. The Rev. Dr. Maxwell Savage will conduct the services. Burial will be at Sterling.

Representatives Jerry J. O'Connell, Montana Democrat, and John T. Bernard, Minnesota Farmer-Laborite, announced in Washington tonight that they would claim Congressional immunity and refuse to honor subpoenas served upon them this afternoon by counsel for Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City.

Two dwellings, one of twelve rooms and another of eight rooms at 140-25 Franklin Avenue, Flushing, were sold by Emlen Hall to Abraham Kopelmann of Pittsburgh, who will occupy one of the structures and hold the other for investment.

Despite sharp increases in -the number of traffic accidents and persons injured in-them over the last week-end, fatalities declined last week compared with the figures covering the corresponding period of last year, tables made public yesterday by the safety bureau of the Police Department showed.
Japanese forces yesterday made a surprise attack on Anking, capital of Anhwei Province, from the Yangtze River, and captured the city.
The Queens County Jockey Club, owner of the Aqueduct Rice Track in Queens County, with offices. at 50 Court Street, Brooklyn, applied yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Algeron'I.
The death of Henry Johnson, a leading figure in the rayon industry in England and the United States. was announced today at Coventry. He was 72 years old.

When court reassembles tomorrow to re sume the trial of Captain Stanley Scott, master of the British steamer Stancroft, who is charged with carrying war materials to Spain, it will have decided whether the charge shall be dismissed.

Dr. and Mrs. Eugenio Sturchio of Newark and Spring Lake, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Irma Elodia Sturchio, to Anthony Mascolo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Mascolo, also of Newark.

The Cunard White Star liner Aquitania is due today from Europe. Among her passengers are Dr. Charles MacEachern, president of the International Hospital Association; B. F. Crosfield, managing director of The London News-Chronicle; Martin Van Buren, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Vayo, Mrs. A. T. McLean, Dr. and Mrs. Walter Langer, Dr. and Mrs. Walton Martin and Earl Smith.
Dr. Harry W. Vicker, surgeon and physician here for more than thirty years, died yesterday after a long illness at the age of 66. His brother, Hayes, died on Saturday at Gary, Ind.
A sudden, heavy "downpour of rain drenched thousands of homeward-ound workers yesterday afternoon. The rainfall, measuring 1.62 inches from 4:55 to 7:30 P.' M., caused -little damage.
Two thousand fans cheered Mickey Cochrane today as he took his old spot behind home plate, but the Tigers' manager quickly let it be known he had no intention of working in a major league game.
David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, refused yesterday to submit a plan to the WPA for purchase of surplus stocks of women's and children's apparel.
Theodore Meyer of 603 West 140th Street, a retired silk merchant, died yesterday in the Lenox Hill Hospital after a long period of failing health.
Grant Ford, Wausau Utilities Company officer, announced today that his daughter Jane, 19, who disappeared from the Vassar College campus a week ago, had been located at Allentown, Pa.
Marion P. Lang sold to Sego Estates, Inc., the five three-story flats at 780-88 West Side Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., on a plot 88 by 132 feet.
The search for a boy to replace Sabu in "Gunga Din" has been given up by RKO and an adult player will be assigned the title role. Tests were made today of Sam Jaffe for the part.
A record low interest rate for a Treasury bill offering of $100,000,000 was received on the issue sold today. The average rate was 0.027 per cent, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight.
Japan pointed warships and troops from fallen Anking today for a 215 mole drive up the Yangtze, River against the chines provisional capital at Hankow.

As the University of Virginia dedicated its new million-dollar library today as a memorial to Edwin Anderson Alderman, its first president, announcement was made of a gift of the book and manuscript collections of the late Tracy W. McGregor, philanthropist of Detroit and Washington.

The prevalence of surplus stocks in novelty lines and the lack of distress goods in staple merchandise was demonstrated anew yesterday when six buyers for the E. M. Rosenthal Jewelry Company and the Kay Jewelry Stores began a buying session at the Hotel Astor here yesterday.

Planting first ivy by taking a sprig from the original ivy planted at the university from the arboretum at the new Harry M.
