Ullman annex to the chemistry laboratory, was the privilege of the class of 1938, at Lehigh University today at its class day exercises before the parents and friends of the 279 class members.

Renewal of negotiations for a Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan to effect a reorganization of the Manhattan elevated lines was disclosed yesterday as Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson, sitting in the Interborough Rapid Transit Company receivership case, granted permission to a new bondholders' committee to intervene officially in the litigation.

Isolater, who runs in the colors of Chairman William Woodward of the Jockey Club, made his first start yesterday since his recent campaign in Maryland and accounted for the Waldo Handicap at Aqueduct in very fast time.

Ralph C. Payne, 40 years old, a real estate broker of Baltimre, was killed shortly before noon yesterday when he leaped or fell to the roof of a two-story terrace from the window of his room on the eleventh floor of the Belmont Plaza Hotel, Forty-ninth Street and Lexington Avenue.

Many of the Presbyterian ministers throughout the metropolitan area are planning to forego their annual Summer vacations and maintain "open house" within their churches next year to extend the benefits of religion to visitors to the World's Fair, it was announced yesterday at the June meeting of the Presbytery of New York.

Salary increases totaling about $20,000 annually for forty-eight employes of the Kings County Court were upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles J. Dodd in Brooklyn, one week after Mayor La Guardia had appealed to the State Constitutional Convention's judiciary committee at Albany to free the city's budget of salaries "dictated" by the courts through the power of mandamus.
Daniel F. B. Hickey of Stamford, Republican leader in the 1935 State House of Representatives, was arrested today on a charge of violating the anti-bribery statute.

" Elections" for the supreme Soviets of the forty-two divisions of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, which will be the fore-ordained and inevitable "victory" for "the Stalinist block of party and nonparty Bolshevists," began yesterday in the Georgian and Armenian constituent republics and will end June 26 with balloting in the Russian Federated Republic and White Russia.

Jacob Gruber, assistant general counsel to the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced yesterday that he has resigned, effective on Aug. 1, when he will resume the private practice of law. He will form his own firm.
This being one of two days set apart for rest in the international chess masters tournament, the ten experts accepted the invitation of the local committee to go on an excursion.
After five years as a home mortgage lender, the government owns almost 80,000 dwellings. About half of these were acquired through foreclosure in the last year.

General Michael Polzikoff, former aide de camp of Czar Nicholas of Russia and commander of a Russian artillery division during the World War, died on Saturday in the small frontier village of Wasserbillig. His age was 71.

Robert K. McConnell, treasurer of the Hampton Company, Easthampton Textile Company and of the Hampton Spinning Mills of Clover, S. C., died at a hospital here today after a brief illness. His age was 42.

Unless other wise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.
The first four programs of the Lewisohn Stadium season, which will begin on Thursday evening of next week, were made public yesterday.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 8: A decrease of $30,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans,

Dr. Charles F. Otis died at his home here last night after a brief illness; Dr. Otis was born in Rochester seventy-eight years ago. He was graduated from the Hahne" mann Medical College in Chicago, and began practice here in 1882.

A union dispute among advertising workers turned into a free-forall fight in a southbound Broadway subway as it left 238th Street, the Bronx, early this morning. Three men, who were putting up signs in the subway train, were attacked and beaten by about twenty-five other men.
The Chicago investment firm of Brailsford Co. has been formed to conduct a general investment business specializing in the underwriting and distribution of industrial securities.
Miss Peggy Welsh of Middlebury, Conn., today defeated Miss Barbara Walton of Merion, eighth seeded player, in the first round of the Middle States girls' tennis championships. 7-5. 6-4.

In view of the Mexican Government's confiscation of British oil property in Mexico, the official figures issued here showing the decline in the British importation of Mexican crude oil for the six years ending with 1937 are significant as showing this country's growing independence of that source of supply.
The downward drift of share prices yesterday was unrelieved even by feeble rallies. The market closed around the low levels of the day, with the leaders off 1 to 3 points.
Minority leader Snell weeps in public. His heart is wrung. Republican Representative Jenks of New Hampshire was unseated by the Committee on Privileges and Elections, which seated him in 1937.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 10: REAR ADMIRAL Gherardi, W. R.. Boston, Mass., about July 26. to duty as President General Court Martial, 12th Naval Dist., San Francisco.

Business in chains, super-markets and independent retail grocery stores of the country was off an average of 8 per cent last week compared with the corresponding week last year, according to the American Institute of Food Distribution's weekly summary of conditions in the grocery market.
Turpentine firm, 22 1/4c; sales, 110 barrels; receipts, 473 barrels; shipments, 197 barrels; stock, 34,118 barrels. Resin firm: sales, 632; receipts, 3,473; shipments, 909; stock, 135,089.

" The Road Ahead" will be the subject of the sppech to be made Thursday by Secretary Morgenthau at Temple University commencement exercises in Philadelphia, where he will receive an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws.

The wholesale price level, according to the index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association, rose in the week ended June 1, to 74.4, against 73.8 in the preceding week, 74.4 a month ago and 86.9 a year ago, based on the 1926-1928 average as 100.

The public is welcome at Nahant next Saturday to see President Roosevelt and the June bridal pair, John Roosevelt and Anne Clark, as well as many leading figures in society and national affairs and members of the Roosevelt family through four generations, Nahant town officials said today.

Mrs. Richard Stark, the former Miss Carolin Babcock of Los Angeles, joined the ranks of the metropolitan tournament players yesterday as she started out in a field of forty-four contenders for the New York State championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club, Queens.
An attempt was made this morning on the life of the Syrian Premier, Jamil Bey Mardam, as he was returning to Damascus from his Summer home outside the capital.

BROWN, HERBERT D. (July 10, 1937). Gross assets, $126,755; net, $119,901. To Edith Williams Brown, widow Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $96,189. Sackett, Chapman, Brown Cross, attorneys, 154 Nassau st.
The Harvard varsity crew, paced by three other boats, tonight took its most arduous workout of the current training period for the regatta with Yale June 24.

A class of fifty-two seniors was graduated last night at the commencement exercises of Adelphi Academy, held in Robinson Hall at the school, 282 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn. James G. McDonald, president of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, was the speaker.

Connecticut College is to have a chapel, the gift of Mrs. Edward S. Harkness of New York, who has already given the college Mary Harkness House, one of the modern dormitories erected in the past few years.

Dull, defensive tactics in order to force a draw may be good cricket policy at times, particularly in a test match, but the Australians were subjected to a lot of barracking while stonewalling against England in the initial test match today.

The Commodity Exchange Administration proposed today to limit speculative trading in grain futures, Secretary of Agriculture Wallace said the limitations would not become effective until approved by the Commodity Exchange Commission and this would not be until after July 10, when the time limit for filing exceptions expires.

William M. Stevenson, vice president, director and Pacific Coast manager of the W. J. Sloane Company of New York, house furnishers, was found dead in his bed this morning. He was apparently perfectly well when he retired last night after an automobile ride with his family. His age was 61.

The long smoldering factional fight within the United Automobile Workers of America was brought to a head today when President Homer Martin suspended five officers and cited them to appear for trial before an emergency meeting of the executive board.

The Greater New York Fund appeal for $10,000,000 for the city's private welfare and health agencies centered in the financial district yesterday when William McChesney Martin Jr., president of the New York Stock Exchange, addressed an outdoor rally from the steps of the Subtreasury Building.

Kenneth F. Sutherland, the Democratic leader of the Coney Island district of Brooklyn for the last twenty years, was appointed yesterday as the general clerk of the Brooklyn Supreme Court to succeed the late Thomas A. Dempsey. The appointment, considered a life one, was made by the board of justices for the Second Judicial District. The post Pays $10.000 annually.

In the last few days the newspapers have carried headlines of the repeated bombing of civilians in China. The horror and detestation of the American people at these acts have been expressed in a measure by formal protest from our Secretary of State.

The American Institute of Accountants announced yesterday that it has leased three floors in the sixstory building at 13-15 East Fortyfirst Street for occupancy on or about Aug. 1, and that the fivestory building housing its present headquarters at 135 Cedar Street, which it owns, will be placed on the market.

Miss Alix de Saint Phalle, daughter of Mrs. Duryee de Saint Phalle of 157 East Seventy-second Street, and of Fal de Saint Phalle, also of this city, has completed plans for her marriage to William Cornelius Hall of this city and Newburgh, N. Y. The wedding will take place on the afternoon of June 29 in the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer.

Fifteen hundred barbers in some 425 shops in the Times Square and Grand Central Terminal areas will go out on strike at 8 o'clock this morning, according to officials of the Barbers and Beauty Culturists Union of America.

In common with hundreds of other offices in London's historic "City," whose militia companies or "trainbands" in the past have often changed the course of English history by standing by their arms, THE NEW YORK TIMES London bureau received notice today from the Town Clerk urging it to prepare its offices against gas and explosive bombs.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Patsy Rathborne, daughter of Mrs. J. Cornelius Rathborne and the late Mr. Ratlhborne, noted polo player, of Refuge Plantation, Harvey, La., and Westbury, L. I., to Henry A. Wilmerding Jr.

Thomas Bohan, 39 years old, a former taxicab driver who became a night club owner in Chile while the police sought him for six years, testified in his own defense yesterday in his General Sessions trial on a first-degree murder indictment in the shooting of Lucas Mardesich, 38, in the hold-up of a poker game at 309 West Twentieth Street on Dec. 12, 1929.

Because of last night's rain, which rendered the field unfit for polo, the semi-final match between Yale and Princeton in the college championship tournament scheduled for today at the Burnt Mills Club in Bedminster, N. J., was postponed until tomorrow. The Elis will be strong favorites.
GOYA: RBBELLOUS GENIUS, by Marion Chapman. (Egmont, $2.50.) A novel about the Spanish painter. ILLUSION AND REALITY, by Christopher Caudwell. (Macmillan, $5.) A study of the sources of poetry.

Edward Kenny, 32 years old, a former convict, who was a suspect in several waterfront killings and the murder of the widow of Jack (Legs) Diamond.. five years ago, was on the receiving end of murderous pistol fire last night.

Charles H. Appel, 60 years old, a real estate agent of 806 St. John's Place, - Brooklyn, was fined $500, with the alternative of three months in jail, yesterday by Magistrate Ed-. gar Bromberger in Brooklyn for renting a condemned building.

Accused of obtaining home and work relief funds while they had other means of support, Amedeo Piantedosi of 6,709 Eleventh Avenue, Brooklyn, and his wife, Francesca, were arraigned yesterday before Magistrate De Andrea in Flatbush Court.

A search for Amelia Earhart and her navigator, Fred Noonan, lost last July in the South Pacific, is planned to take place as soon as necessary arrangements can be made, E. H. Dimity, president of the Amelia Earhart Foundation of Oakland, said tNoday.

John L. Conner, Federal labor conciliator, announced last night that maintenance and production employes of the Walworth Company plant here had voted, 832 to 459, in favor of a 10 per cent wage reduction. Workers at the company plant in Greensburg, Pa., recently voted a similar acceptance.
The illness of a juror caused a one-day adjournment today in the trail of forty-four individuals and ninetten coal companies for conspiring cirminally against the Wagner Labor Relations Act.
Patrick Domino, 65 years old, of 93 Ferry Street, Newark, was injured fatally early today on Lincoln Avenue, Colonia, near here, when struck by an automobile.

Patrolman John Twoomb, 43 years old, of the West 100th Street Station, has been missing from his room at the West Side Young Men's Christian Association, 5 West Sixtythird Street, since June 7, it became known yesterday.

Miss Clarissa Pauline Moriarty, daughter of Thaddeus Oswald Moriarty of this city and the late Mrs. Moriarty and a descendant of early Dutch settlers here, was married to Chandler Shaw Mackey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chandler Alexander Mackey of Brooklyn and Newtown, Conn., yesterday morning in the Flatbush Congregational Church, Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. William E. Dudley officiated.

The Society of Beaux Arts Architects announced yesterday that its thirty-first annual Paris prize had been won by 25-year-old Socrates T. States of Washington. The prize,-a $3,600 scholarship, will enable Mr.. States to study abroad for two and a half years.
The international stock market indices for June 11, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:
A list of 117 entries has been received by the Metropolitan Golf Association for the organization's thirty-eighth annual amateur championship starting tomorrow at the Ridgewood (N. J.) Country Club.

The War Department Appropriation Bill was signed by President Roosevelt today carrying $463,651,000, or $44,000,000 more than was voted for the present fiscal year. A fourth of the amount is for aviation, $19,150,000 being for 476 new planes.

The exposition of advertising media, printers, lithographers and other suppliers to the advertising field, being held at the Hotel Statler in conjunction with the annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America, is the largest in ten years, with forty exhibitors, including one Detroit advertising agency.
A few days ago the Majority Leader of the convention extended to me an invitation to address your honorable body. Inasmuch as the rules of the convention provide that communications

Demolition of houses on the site of the Rockaway Beach development began yesterday as 100 men went to work. The first structure to be torn down was the parsonage of the First Presbyterian Church of Rockaway, at Rockaway Boulevard and Beach Ninety-fourth Street.
Many Vienna's public gardens were "cleaned" of Jews today and they were told that in the future to occupy only the benches marked "For Jews." They now are practically banned from all public gardens.

A special dividend of 25 cents together with the regular quarterly distribution of 12 1/2 cents were voted on the common stock of the Automatic Voting Machine Corporation. On July 1 last year a similar special dividend was paid.

Justice McTague's dismissal of a plea for approval under the Ontario Judicature Act of a plan of reorganization for the Abitibi Paper and Power Company-a motion made by the trustee for the bondholders-was upheld today In an Appeal Court decision at Osgoode Hall.
The Reds acquired Pitcher Bucky Walters from Philadelphia today in return for Pitcher Al Hollingsworth, the veteran catcher, Virgil Davis, and cash.

Sol Gelb, Assistant District Attorney who has been interrogating grand jury witnesses in District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's investigation of the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy racket, which already has resulted in the indictment of Tammany District Leader James J. Hines and eight others, openly charged in the Supreme Court yesterday that one of Hines's friends was trying to tamper with one of the witnesses in the case.
The dollar rallied in the foreign exchange market yesterday as another week-end passed without bringing to light anything to support Europe's rumors of dollar devaluation.

Suffolk Downs officials tonight announced that Charles S. Howard's Seabiscuit would arrive tomorrow morning from New York, making possible a meeting with War Admiral in the $50,000 added Massachusetts Handicap on June 29.
Edward R. Hindley has succeeded Henry M. Zweig as general agent supervising the National Fire Group's New York brokerage and service department, F. D. Layton, president, announced yesterday.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., headed yesterday the successful banking group in the purchase of a new issue of $2,468,000 of State of Tennessee refunding, State institutions and county reimbursement bonds.

Six colleges placed men on the official All-America intercollegiate lacrosse team for 1938, according to the selections announced yesterday by the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association. In making known its selections shortly after the season's close, the association established a precedent. In the past the team was not announced until the start of the following year's play.

Death Announced Fireman 1st grade George Dorr of Engine Co. 223, died June 11. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 370 East 35th St., Brooklyn, at 2 P. M., Tuesday. June 14. Interment at Lutheran Cemetery.
Czechs and Sudeten Germans approached a critical stage tonight in discussions over the status of Czechoslovak nationalities, each of which seemed further consolidated in week-end local elections.
Leases in midtown furnished the bulk of the commercial renting activity reported by brokers and agents yesterday. A wide variety of businesses were represented among the lessees of new space.

The last living Civil War veteran of the Twelfth New York Volunteers, Corporal George W. Collier, 95 years old, who served with Company H seventy-five years ago, will be among the guests of honor tonight at the military review of the 212th Coast Artillery (anti-aircraft), National Guard, at the armory at Columbus Avenue and Sixty-second Street.
Dauber, William du Pont's Preakness winner, nursed minor bruises, skin cuts and a broken tooth todayafter leaping from a van en route from a railroad depot to Hollywood Park yesterday.

Slammin Sammy Snead toured the rugged Westwood Country Club course today and established himself as a formidable rival to Ralph Guldahl, national open titleholder, who will start the quest of his third Western open golf championship tomorrow.

Corden Hull, Secretary of State, was urged to discourage the shipment of all categories of munitions of war and raw materials to Japan today by a delegation of missionary and other religious organizations, youth and other groups who conferred with Stanley K. Hornbeck, political adviser to the Secretary of State, and submitted a resolution embodying their views. Five of the delegation, it was announced, will be received by President Roosevelt tomorrow.

Declaring that the current conflict between labor and capital constitutes the gravest problem facing society, Edward F. McGrady, former first assistant Secretary of Labor and now director of labor relations of the Radio Corporation of America, today warned business men that a complete exposition of all factors involved, minus propaganda, is essential for an amicable solution.

A new type of picketing attracted luncheon hour crowds on West Forty-second Street yesterday. Employes of Leeds Restaurant, Inc., 17 West Forty-second Street, which runs through the building to Fortythird Street, staged a protest against the landlord in behalf of their employer.

Instituting a policy of short-term loans "until the financial situation clears up" the Ministry of Finance Friday announced that the government had placed 35,000,000 guilders in threemonth treasury bonds with a Dutch banking group.

As current business indexes reveal, previous government public works expenditures did not put a foundation, under recovery. In the opinion of many distinguished analysts, the new billions about to be appropriated for the same purpose will not lay that foundation, either.

Sales of still wines increased 13 per cent and of beer and fermented beverages sixhundredths of 1 per cent in May, said Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission, in his monthly report today on beverage taxes.
Sweden will mark the eightieth birthday of King Gustaf V next Thursday by establishing a national fund for fighting infantile paralysis.
Weather in the Cotton Belt proved less unfavorable than had been considered probable from Saturday's predictions and prices on the Cotton Exchange here were set back yesterday 8 to 11 points.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended June 9 was 273 compared with 226 in the preceding week and 161 in the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Prospects for early crops were described by the Department of Agriculture today as better than in any Spring since 1929. A record wheat crop is indicated. Conditions have been favorable for cotton and tobacco.

Henry A. Hacker, 50 years old, of 24-32 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, a "professional witness" in accident cases, was sentenced to a six-month workhouse term yesterday in Special Sessions on his conviction last week of petit larceny and perjury.

The Rev. Joseph A. McCaffrey, Police Department chaplain and spiritual adviser to the Police Holy Name Society in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond, announced yesterday the winners of four scholarships in an annual competition among junior high school graduates who are sons of policemen.

The Maritime Commission awarded contracts today for the reconditioning of the liners California, Pennsylvania and Virginia. They will be the nucleus of the new governmentoperated fast passenger fleet between New York and Rio de Janeiro, Santos, Montevideo and Buenos Aires. The service will begin about Sept. 1.

Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt were guests yesterday at cocktails given by the Colonial Secretary, A. W. G. Grantham, and Mrs. Grantham at their home, La Garza, in Paget. Mr. and Mrs. Vanderbilt, the latter the former Miss Manuela Hudson, daughter of George Hudson of San Francisco, Calif., are at the Wendell W. Anderson beach cottage at South Shore.

Mr. and Mrs. Marshall M. Langhorne have arrived from Washington and are at the Pierre before going to Bar Harbor. Mr. and Mrs. J. Macy Willets, who have been in Great Barrington, Mass., are expected to arrive today at the Carlyle.

John Hyde Preston is correcting proofs of his long novel, "The Liberals," which will be published in August by John Day. The scene of the novel is a small manufacturing town and the story is that of a "jam" in which the "liberal" is caught in our present-day industrial civilization.

The wholesale markets opened slow on practically all classes of traefer meats. Steer hinds and ribs were weak, steer cuts steady to slightly lower, cow and bull lower, veal weak, lamb sharply lower, fresh pork cuts uneven, but mostly steady to slightly higher.

In a four-hour fight last night a detachment of police, led by General Maximo Avila Camacho, Governor of the State of Puebla and brother of the Secretary of War, killed General Enrique Espejel and his brother, both of whom were aides of General Saturnino Cedillo, rebel leader in the State of San Luis Potosi.

John L. Lewis moved into Speaker Bankhead's office today and "turned the heat on" Representatives who were led into his presence and whose votes were sought for passage of the Walsh-Healey bill, which would establish a blacklist and bar from government contracts companies which violate the National Labor Relations Act.

William Harman Brown Jr., syndicate manager of Brown Harriman Co., Inc., since that firm was organized in 1934, will become associated tomorrow with Charles R. Dunn, fiscal agent of the Federal Land Banks and Federal Intermediate Credit Banks, as deputy fiscal agent, it was announced yesterday by Mr. Dunn.

Forecasting the city's revenue from emergency relief taxes yesterday for the City Council's Finance Committee, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick estimated that the onecent tax on cigarettes packages would produce $6,000,000 a year instead of the $3,000,000 originally counted upon.

Graduation parade, followed by "recognition" of the plebe class, were the features of today's commencement exercises at the United States Military Academy, where the final ceremony, graduation, will be held tomorrow.
A 32-year-old Negro cab driver sought yesterday to return $49.10 in home relief funds to the city after he had gone back to work following a short stay on the relief rolls.

Lord Stamp, Baron of Shortlands, assured a group of representative New York business leaders yesterday that, while the democracies of today were making mistakes, he believed they would ''pull through."

Thirtytwo acres of orchard land comprising what was once a part of the old Headley farm here, dating back to pre-Revolutionary War days, have been acquired by the Guy M. Rush realty interests of New York City from Russell J. Headley and the Union County Trust Company of Elizabeth.
Morris Goetz, who built many one-family homes and apartment houses in Brooklyn and Queens during the last thirty-five years, died Sunday at his residence in Sea Gate at the age of 70.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended June 8, aggregated $8,454,000,000, or 23 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week, which included five business days in most of the reporting centers, and 2 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

A young engaged couple, who had just returned to the young woman's home in Astoria, Queens, from Sag Harbor, L. I., where a shower had been given in her honor, was held up, kidnapped and robbed by four men early yesterday morning.

A jury had been drawn in Judge Wallace's part of'General Sessions yesterday and Assistant District Attorney Aaron Benenson was ready to outline the State's case on an indictment charging Mrs. Muriel du Pont Bergman with stealing $12,000 from Frank Seitz, superintendent of the apartment house at 123 West Ninety-third Street, when the defendant pleaded guilty to forgery, one of four counts in the indictment.

More than 500 home owners and taxpayers gathered last night at a mass meeting in the auditorium of Washington Irving High School and voted a petition to the Constitutional Convention to oppose all measures designed to fix the city's authority to borrow funds higher than the present 10 per cent of assessed property valuation.
nadian Press).-H. G. Beresford, prominent land surveyor and independent member of the Manitoba Legislature from 1927 to 1932, died here yesterday of a heart ailment. He was 57 years old.
Charles W. Diven Jr. of Sharon today became the first University of Pennsylvania baseball captain in many years to be re-elected. He will be a senior next year.

Miss Cornelia Louise Brown, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Chester R. Brown of this place, was married tonight in the First Presbyterian Church here to George Edwin Griscom 2d of Montclair, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Griscom of Trenton. The ceremony, which was performed by Dr. Wallace Carver,

Frank Foster Dodge, chairman and former president of the Atwood Machine Company of Stonington, Conn., died today in the Westerly Hospital, to which he had been rushed by seaplane after being stricken ill on Friday while on a fishing vacation at Rangeley Lakes, Me. He suffered cerebral hemorrhages. His age was 53.

Johnny Hill, 2 years and 11 months old, who wants to be an engineer when he grows up, was supposed to be. playing in the backyard of his home at 38 South Burnet Street, East Orange, at 11:30 this morning.

A New York State Board of Housing report, issued yesterday, expressed approval of the New York City Housing Authority's $16,000,000 slum-clearance project in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn, but criticized the extreme uniformity of the proposed buildings.

Mayor La Guardia of New York and Miss Mary Van Kleeck of the Department of Industrial Studies of the Russell Sage Foundation recommended at the St. Lawrence University commencement luncheon today a "getting together" of capitalism, industry and labor for a society of service.

The Boston, New York and Southern Steamship Company, Inc., owner of the excursion vessel Mandalay, which sank last month in the lower bay after a collision with the steamship Acadia, filed a libel yesterday against that vessel for $750,000.

City Hall was formally declared in a state of siege yesterday by Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran after he had heard that the Department of Public Buildings and the A. S. P. C. A. had entered into a conspiracy to liquidate Tammany, the pet cat of the building for the last nine years.
Dr. Alexis Aguero, W. H. Hoover, Mrs. Gerald Gordon, Mrs. Stewart Spilman, Erik Charell, in Hampshire House, 150 Central Park S; Douglas L. Elliman Co. Inc, broker.
Degrees were conferred upon 257 seniors at the Vassar College commencement exercises today. Miss Helen Kenyon, '05, chairman of the board of trustees, announced gifts for the year of $212,915.

The vast Montauk Point realty and resort development on which Carl G. Fisher and associates were reported to have spent nearly $12,000,000 before they ran into financial difficulties, has been reorganized by the bondholders and will be run henceforth by a new company to be known as the Montauk Beach Company, Inc.
The first part of the first study ever made of investment trusts by a Federal agency in this country was sent to Congress today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Frederick A. Sterling, Minister to Latvia and Estonia, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to be Minister to Sweden, succeeding Fred M. Dearing. Both are career diplomats.

It was a strong, healthy, sunburned bunch of Americans that this correspondent saw today in their reserve positions well behind the Ebro line. They had had another month of peaceful pursuit, spent in intensive training under a Spring sun, and all the horror of the Aragon retreat had been forgotten.
The large "turnover" of funds tomorrow incident to the Treasury's refunding operations and the usual tax-date payments is expected to cause no disturbances in the money market.

If the American beaver in large numbers goes to work this year in Idaho for the Division of Grazing of the Department of the Interior, as Washington reports indicate, Secretary Ickes need not fear any of those unkind charges of soldiering on the job which have been leveled at some of his other
Congress sent to the White House tonight a bill to relax restrictions on the planting of the 1939 wheat crop.
A young gold prospector who followed a "hunch" led the way today to wreckage of a storm-crashed TWA airliner which vanished with nine persons aboard the night of March 1.

The richest and most brilliant race meeting in the world will start tomorrow when King George and Queen Elizabeth drive through Ascot's golden gates. In four days of competition before the royal family,

The South Penn Oil Company announced yesterday a reduction of 25 cents a barrel in the price of Pennsylvania grade crude oil. This is the fifth cut since September, last year, and they aggregate $1.02 a barrel for oil produced in the Bradford-Alleghany district.
Michel Detroyat, general inspector for the Ministry of Aviation of France, arrived yesterday from Paris on the French liner Normandie with five assistants.

Advices from Washington that Congress will not consider any new railroad legislation at this session set the stage for another rather severe sinking spell in domestic corporate bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

New York City will join the rest of the nation today in celebrating Flag Day with -patriotic meetings and parades and an unprecedented display of the Stars and Stripes, adopted as the emblem of the Union 161 years ago.

Fumes escaping from a gas heater last night overcame Mrs. Helen Norris, 34 years old, wife of the Rev. Baxter Norris, rector of the St. Andrews Episcopal Church-bythe-Sea at Belle Harbor, Queens; and her two children, Theodore, 9, and Richard, 8.
The Federal Wage-Hour Bill as it emerges from conference is in some respects an improvement over either the Senate or the House measure.
A long-term plan for progressive aid to Boy Scouts has been arranged at the Ten Mile River Scout Camps in Sullivan County, N. Y., it was announced yesterday.

Some will pass beneath the flag today with hardly an upward glance at the bright bunting that stands for all they have and are. More, many more, will lift their eyes to it as the living symbol of the will to be free.
A plea for cooperation and understanding was made by Secretary of State Cordell Hull in a statement tonight which was read on his behalf during a special radio program for Brazil.

Albert E. Castle, 56 years old, of 329 East Twenty-third Street, Brooklyn, head of the concreteconstruction company bearing his name, went on trial yesterday in Kings County Court before Judge George W. Martin and a jury on a charge of bribing an inspector of the Finance Department in connection with work performed on a public school yard at 590 Sheffield Avenue, Brooklyn.

With John L. Lewis holding aloof, Democratic leaders took steps here tonight to end factional differences and present a united front to the Republicans in the Fall campaign as Governor Earle, in a radio address, denounced the proposed grand jury investigation of his administration as a "brazen political conspiracy" of the Republican party.

Ralph Talley, 56 years old, chairman of the board of the Charles W. Hoyt Company, advertising agency, at 551 Fifth Avenue, was found dead in his apartment at 83-09 Talbot Street, Kew Gardens, at 1:25 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

Representatives of automobile, trucking and construction organizations urged the Constitutional Convention's Committee on Highways, Parkways and Grade Crossings today to report out an amendment_ which would "gradually" end diversion of revenue from the gasoline tax and motor vehicle fees to purposes other than highway maintenance.

The American Institute of Architects has awarded Edward Langley scholarships for advanced study, travel and research in architecture to seven persons for 1938-39, Edwin Bergstrom, treasurer of the Institute, announced yesterday.

The Wage and Hour Bill in the form reported by the conference committee will bring increases in prices of underwear, will not change prices of cotton goods, will affect only some canned goods among grocery products and will have little effect on foreign trade, according to spokesmen for those industries who were interviewed yesterday.

Corporate Leaders of America, Inc., an investment trust of New York, has filed a registration statement covering $3,600,000 of periodic-payment certificates and $150,000 of fully paid certificates, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Eighty-four graduates of Blair Academy received their diplomas here today from Dr. Charles H. Breed, headmaster, at the ninetieth annual commencement of the school. The commencement address was delivered by Paul F. Cruikshank, headmaster of the Taft School, Watertown, Conn., and a Blair graduate, class of 1915.

A capacity audience of 215 persons attended in the Chapel Theatre here tonight the production of "Yes, My Darling Daughter," starring Blanche Yurka, with which the Chapel Players opened their tenweek Summer season.

Miss Mary Alice Pickett, daughter of Mrs. Ludwell Rector Finch Pickett of Pocohontas, Ark., was married to Oliver Dixwell Knauth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oswald Whitman Knauth of New York, this evening at the home here of her uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Rufus L. Pickett. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. F. Elliot-Baker.
Three runs in each of the seventh and eighth innings gave the champion Yankees a 9-to-3 verdict over the Syracuse Chiefs of the International League before 10,000 fans today. Joe Glenn,
A large multi-family house in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn changed hands in one of the transactions in that borough announced yesterday.

Manhattan College will award 264 degrees in course and three honorary degrees at its eighty-fifth annual commencement at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon on the quadrangle of the campus, Spuyten Duyvil Parkway and 242d Street.

Miss Louise Seyms Thomas, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Edmund C. Thomas of this city, has completed plans for her marriage to James Newman of New York. The ceremony will be performed on June 22 in Castine, Me., by the bride-elect's father, who is rector of St. James Church here.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Barnes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James G. Barnes of Rockville Center, L. I., to Herman E. Schroeder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Schroeder of Brooklyn, took place this afternoon at Hillsboro Center in the Barnes Summer residence, a colonial homestead of pre-Revolutionary War origin. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Ray A. Eusden of Newton, Mass.
E. T. Weir, head of the National Steel Corporation, defended current steel prices today. Lower rates, he maintained, would not bring more orders.

The moral of this story is: "What constitutes a fair catch?" Last Saturday a well-known angler was off shore after the big fellows in the Gluf Stream, which is about 138 miles out from the Barnegat Lightship.

The newspaper Asahi foresees the transfer of the seat of the Chinese Government leading up to a change in the attitude of the powers toward China, more closely linking France and the Chinese Government via the Yunnan Railway and Britain and China via Burma.

A hearing will be held here on June 30 by the Securities and Exchange Commission on the application of Paul V. Shields, Joseph S. Maxwell and Charlton B. Hibbard, as a protective committee for the preferred stockholders of Utilities Power and Light Corporation.

Captain Adolf Ahrens, master of the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, who was questioned on May 27 before a Federal grand jury investigating the so-called spy ring, will not be on the bridge of that vessel when it arrives here today.

WUCHANG, China (By. Mail).The last thing the Japanese want is an organized, prosperous China. They want China, of course, but they themselves want to do any organization that has to be done so that they can control its direction and capture the' possible profits for their own benefit.

BANKS, JOSEPH H. (April 19). Estate, more than $10,000. To Kate E. Banks, widow, executrix, 531 W. 159th St., life estate in residue; John R., Samuel R. Banks of 281 Wadsworth Ave; Edmund R. Banks, 3,494 Cannon Pl., sons, and Edith E. Broman, daughter, 217 Oakwood Ave., Bogota, N. J., daughter, remainders in residue.

Although the Federal Housing Administration now is insuring mortgages on small homes up to 90 per cent of the appraised value of the property, the building and loan associations of the country still believe that their maximum loan should be about 70 per cent.

Eliot Cabot, 39-year-old actor and member of a prominent Boston family, was taken to Morrisania Hospital yesterday in a critical condition from injuries received when he lost his footing while walking along the embankment of the old Croton Aqueduct in the Bronx.

Miss Phyllis I. R. Gillespie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lewis Gillespie of 11 East Eightyninth Street and Newport, has chosen July 2 as the date for her marriage to Alan T. Schumacher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Schumacher, also of this city.

Trading in hide futures here got away to a brisk start this morning, and the opening day's transactions in this product on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange amounted to twenty-three contracts, calling for delivery of 920,000 pounds of raw hides.
Spanish Insurgents announced officially tonight the occupation of Castellon de la Plana and its port of Grao, opening a broad coastal plain for an offensive against Valencia.

James H. Cruikshank, operator, has purchased from the Delos Holding Corporation, Harry Hausknecht, vice president, the three-story private dwelling at 429 West 162d Street, through George H. Janss, broker.
Individual income tax returns filed in the United States for the tax year 1936 numbered 5,488,055, an increase of 821,551 over the previous tax year, the Bureau of Internal Revenue reported today.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey was wrong in expressing doubt that labor was supporting the proposed expansion of the Bill of Rights in the State Constitution to outlaw illegal searches and seizures and wire tapping, Alex Rose, State executive secretary of the American Labor party, declared yesterday.

Governor Lehman asked the Constitutional Convention tonight to write into the State's basic law a "search and seizure" clause which would bar the use of wire-tapping by prosecuting officials until they had obtained a warrant from a Supreme Court justice.

De Witt Clinton advanced to the final of the City P. S. A. L. tennis championship by conquering Erasmus Hall, 3-2, yesterday as the last two singles tests of their postponed match was played at the Mammoth Courts in Brooklyn.

Roosevelt St, 57, and 53 New chambers St, 25 on former and 33.8 on latter; William S. Klinger to East River Savings Bank; consideration $3,000. foreclosure. 115TH ST. 55 E, 26x100.10: Shirley Welts to Harlem Estates, Inc, 370 E 149th St, Bronx, care J. Nass 1st mtg $17,000, 2d mtg $1,000.

Mrs. Mary Scudder Jamieson, a founder of Trenton Chapter, D. A. R., and honorary vice president of the National Society, Colonial Dames of America, died in St. Francis Hospital here last night, after a short illness, at the age of 80 years.

The new motor liner Oslofjord, the pride of Norway of the North Atlantic, arrived yesterday afternoon and docked at the Army Base pier at the foot of Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, completing her maiden voyage from Bergen in 7 days 12 hours at an average spped of 18.25 knots.

The Browns of the American League walloped their farm hands, the Middle Atlantic League Johnnies, tonight, 20 to 7. Beau Bell, Ed Linke and Harland Clift of St. Louis and Lucadello of Johnstown hit home runs.
Prince Louis Ferdinand and his bride, the former Grand Duchess Kyra of Russia, disclosed today that they had hit upon a labor-saving way to keep a diary of their round-the-world honeymoon trip.

The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated June 11: COLONELS Rose, J. B., Ordnance Department, General Staff Corps, two days' leave, June 14. Bamberger, R. S., Adjutant General's Deapartment, Governors Island, N. Y.. to Hawaiian Department, to sail from New York about Sept. 1.

Faculty appointments at the Stevens Institute of Technology, and the award of a group of Charles Hayden scholarships, were announced here today at the close of the sixtysixth commencement season by President Harvey N. Davis.

Automobile production increased last week but did not regain the pre-holiday level. Daily average output showed a contra-seasonal gain, and the adjusted index rose to 41.2 from 33.0. The figure for the week ended June 12, 1937, was 121.8.

Only "a handful" of merchandise has been offered to Butler Brothers, wholesalers, in response to advertising they placed in trade journals and a New York newspaper last week announcing they were in the market for several million dollars' worth of new, clean and exclusive standard quality merchandise for spot cash, Frank S. Cunningham, president, said today.

At Fordham College's first separate commencement in the university gymnasium tonight 170 degrees of Bachelor of Arts and 150 degrees of Bachelor of Science will be awarded to members of the graduating class.

Governor Lehman called today for an investigation of the payroll audit division of the State insurance fund, which was created by the Legislature in 1914 to furnish workmen's compensation insurance to employers at cost.

Millinery style experts who returned yesterday in the French liner Normandie from the fashion shows in Paris and London reported that Fall hats will have high crowns with narrow brims and much trimming: birds, wings, twills in bright color combinations and veils.

Backed by Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, a resolution will be introduced in the City Council today calling for an investigation of the employment methods used by officials of the World's Fair and accusing fair executives of unfair employment practices.
Mrs. Marian Lincoln Perry, widow of Marsden J. Perry of Providence, R. I., died suddenly yesterday morning of pneumonia at her New York residence, 755 Park Avenue.

John Lorimer Worden, 64-year-old member of the New York Stock Exchange, has been missing since last Friday when he sailed for Providence aboard the steamer Comet of the Colonial Line, it was reported yesterday.
Chief Justice Arthur Prentice Rugg of the Massachusetts Supreme Court was one of those judicial personalities who give high authority to the bench.

Luncheon of the Lions Club, Hotel Astor, 12:30 P. M. "The Detection of Counterfeit Money," John J. Fitzgerald. Tenth anniversary luncheon of the Frosted Foods Sales Corporation, Waldorf-Astoria, 12:30 P. M. Speakers: Dr. Carl R. Fellers, Dr. Walter Eddy, Clarence Francis.
Just as any hard-working man is entitled to a day off once in a while, Joe Louis chose today to rest after his strenuous workout of yesterday. The heavyweight champion of the world,

The third annual national exhibition of American art to be conducted by the Municipal Art Committee will be opened with a preview tonight at the galleries of the American Fine Arts Society, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. It will be opened to the public tomorrow.

Wearing a belted white coat, a dark blue shirt open at the neck, a chocolate-hued pair of voluminous slacks and black shoes, Shufflin' Joe Louis was lounging back in an easy chair, acting as referee in a pocket billiard game between a couple of his camp followers.

An estimated 1,000,000 persons have made reservations for the "bowl of rice" parties to be held in more than 2,000 cities throughout the nation on Friday under the sponsorship of the United Council for Civilian Relief in China, Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, national chairman of the council, announced yesterday.

Mrs. Joseph A. Igoe of 322 East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Janie Elizabeth Igoe, to Dr. Henry George Wehmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Cort Wehmann of Brooklyn.
After long smoldering, the problem of socialized medicine broke into fire in the American Medical Association here today.

Miss Barbara Fellows, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. James W. Fellows of this city and New Castle, N. H., will be married on June 27 to Robert Barnes Young, son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto S. Young of Great Neck, L. I. The wedding will take place in Little Harbor Chapel, Portsmouth.

WPA vote coercion was declared a punishable offense in Pennsylvania by Judge Heber W. Dithrich today as he sent two Homestead Democratic leaders to prison and gave four others suspended sentences for election cheating.
Dizzy Dean, Cub pitcher who was left at home because of a sore arm when team-mates headed East, will take treatments for a sinus infection within a few days, club officials said tonight.

The threat of a strike of 3,500 drivers against more than 100 independent milk distributors appeared to have been averted last night when representatives of the Milk Drivers Union, affiliated with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and of the distributors reached an agreement after an allday conference in the Cornish Arms Hotel, 311 West Twenty-third Street.

Industralists, business men and salesmen will meet today to begin a "national salesmen's crusade" in this city. The movement's purpose is the stimulation of business throughout the country and all persons engaged in selling are invited to join.

The Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue, receives $178,615 as residuary legatee of the estate of Bertha Kauffmann Cutter, who died Oct. 19, 1936, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

The final link in coast-to-coast streamlined rail transportation will be completed tomorrow when the Pennsylvania -and New York Central's new modernistic luxury trains, the Broadway Limited and the Century, depart on their - sixteen-hour maiden trips to Chicago.

Miss Annette Beardsley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Glover Beardsley of 31 East Seventy-ninth Street, has completed plans for her marriage to Charles Franklin Wagner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Wagner of Dayton, Ohio, which will take place here on the afternoon of June 22 in Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Rooney of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doris Geraldine Rooney, to Dr. Ranald Edwards Mussey of Troy, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Edwards Mussey of Cohoes, N. Y.

Working under pressure to obtain adjournment by Wednesday night if possible, the Senate received from its Appropriations Committee today the second and last deficiency bill of the session; adopted the conference report on the $745,790,270 agricultural appropriation measure, the last of the regular supply bills and passed a number of lesser measures.

The $529,000 concrete box on the Military Academy Reservation which is the government's new silver depository was officially completed today. Mrs. Nellie Tayloe Ross, Director of the Mint, made a two-hour inspection tour and affixed a plaque at the enttrance.

Mr. and Mrs. Oscar R. Ewing gave a dinner last night in the St. Regis Roof for Miss Elizabeth Dodge, who made her debut last Saturday at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Cleveland E. Dodge, in Riverdale.
Thomas Barclay of Argenti Co. was re-elected president of the New York Wholesale Liquor Dealers Association, Inc., at the annual meeting in association headquarters, 300 Fourth Avenue, yesterday.

Buying for the Fall season caused sales of men's wear cloths during April to show a large percentage gain over those of March, but in actual yardage the volume of sales was unimpressive, according to the monthly bulletin of the National Association of Manufacturers, issued yesterday.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 13 unless specified: At Charleston, June 12: Arkansas, Roper At Manila: Bittern, Finch. Bulmer, at Chinwangtao, June 12.

Two full games ahead, of the Cubs, the pace-setting Giants steamed into town early last night in a happy frame of mind, ready for the home stand at the Polo Grounds, during which they hope to add to their advantage.

Both boxing shows scheduled for New York last night were postponed because of rain. The Dyckman Oval program, headed by an eight-round fight between Mike Belloise, ex-featherweight champion, and his borough rival,
The continued fall of the Chinese dollar threatens to throw Shanghai's foreign. commercial and financial business almost completely out of
Circuit Judge Allan Campbell here dismissed today a suit for appointment of a receiver for the Hupp Motor Car Company. The action was filed by a stockholder, whose name was not disclosed.
The volume of bankers' dollar acceptance outstanding on May 31 amounted to $268,098,573, according to the monthly survey of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, issued yesterday.

Miss Frances Perkins, United States Secretary of Labor, addressing the International Labor Conference here today, stressed its practical and non-political side as making it one of "the many ways in which we in the United States can and do take part in the common efforts of mankind to promote understanding and remove obstacles to the maintenance of peace."

Women's stake in democracy was stressed by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, in an address to a graduating class of seventy-two young women at Elmira College today.

Excluding choice and prime mediumweight and weighty offerings, steers and yearlings sold weak to 15 cents lower, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Larger killing interests were bearish all through the session but supplies were too small to offer much leverage. Hogs again advanced but lambs weakened.

Bernie Friedkin and Orville Drouillard, lightweight rivals, will furnish the action in the star bout of eight rounds at the Canarsie Stadium tonight. They have fought twice in the past, Friedkin winning the first and Drouillard gaining a draw in the second.
New York City and vicinity were represented by nine graduates at the sixty-fourth annual commencement exercises today at Purdue University.
A crisis not of government or of economics but of character confronts the United States, said Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan in an address to the graduating class of Union College today.

Final preparations for the "Night in Old China" party to be held Friday night in Chinatown will be discussed at a meeting of the debutante and junior debutante committees this afternoon at Armando's. Miss Milo Gray heads the debutante group and Miss Ethelette Tucker is chairman of the junior debutante committee.
Beniamino Gigli, Italian tenor, turned fireman tonight in an unrehearsed stage fire during a first-night performance of "La Boheme"--and never missed a note.
Accidents took 106,000 lives in 1937, according to the National Safety Council. This is more than twice as great as the number of American lives lost in the World War.

Francis Coakley and Anton Folinus of the Galloping Hill Golf Club played the Homestead Golf Club course for a best-ball score of 64 to win the pro amateur tournament sponsored by the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association today.

William I. Lyon, ornithologist and president of the Inland Bird Banding Association, died today of a heart attack while meeting with the Waukegan-North Chicago Real Estate Board, of which he was vice president. Member of a pioneer Lake County family, he was 63 years old.
Bronx Powell Ave, s s, 189 ft w of Zerega Ave; 1-story brick dwelling and garage; 18x47 ft; Frank D'Appolo, 2,360 Powell Ave, owner; Anton Pirner, 2,742 E Tremont Ave, architect; cost, $5,000.

Stocks heavy, closed lower in quiet trading; turnover, 326,890 shares. United States Government bonds firm and mixed in slowest trading since Sept. 11, 1930; other groups lower with rails weakest; transactions, $3,636,650.
Hearn Department Stores, Inc., New York, was charged with unfair competition in the sale of women's garments by the Federal Trade Commission in a complaint issued today.

When Justice Holmes can be quoted on one side of an argument and Justice Cardozo on the other side, there is good reason to consider carefully the points at issue. This is the situation in the case of proposals which are now pending before the State Constitutional Convention with regard to the question of search and seizure.
Mrs. Edgerton Parsons was reelected chairman of the American Committee of the Pan-Pacific Women's Association at the annual meeting held yesterday at her home, 555 Park Avenue.
Mrs. George C. Moseley, 44, former sister-in-law of the Duchess of Windsor and socially prominent in Chicago, was found dead in her garage today, with the engine of her automobile running.

The American Newspaper Guild suspended rules today at its fifth annual convention to rush through a resolution condemning any discrimination against Southern workers in the Wages and Hours Bill now up for enactment in Washington.

Josef Beck, Foreign Minister, flew to Tallinn today, where he will be the guest of the Estonian Government for a few days. More than usual importance is attached here to the visit, which follows closely his trip to Stockholm.

Grady Boatwright, Federal secret service agent, said today that silver from the emulsion on old films has been sold to the mint here as newly mined silver, which brings 30 cents an ounce more than old silver.
The stock market here was quiet and generally dull today. Gilt-edge issues were weaker for the most part, while foreign bonds behaved undecidedly.
Two parcels in the former Frederick Juilliard estate at Tuxedo Park, N. Y., were sold at a voluntary auction sale yesterday in the Vesey Street salesroom.

All but $27,841,700 of the $1,214,472,900 of notes for which the Treasury offered last week to substitute issues of notes and bonds were exchanged for the new issues, according to allotment figures made public by the department today.

The constitutionality of the Wages and Hours Bill, as drafted by the Senate and House conferees, can be upheld if the Supreme Court overrules the majority decision in the Hammer v. Dagehart case, the so-called child labor case, and follows the dissenting opinion of Justice Holmes in that case, a special committee of the Trade and Commerce Bar Association asserted in a report issued yesterday.

JEROME FRANK, formerly with the AAA and the RFC, and now a member of the Securities Exchange Commission, has put down in 400 cogent pages his ideas on what is right and what is wrong with the country today. He gives the book the lamentable title of "Save America First,"* but the name is appropriate if not prepossessing. Mr. Frank would save America first-save it from Great Britain, revolution and Republicanism.

Rejection of all plans for the reorganization of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad and affiliates was recommended to the Interstate Commerce Commission today in a report by Examiner Harvey H. Wilkinson.

Jewelry valued at about $10,000 was taken from Mrs. Murray Furman of 15 West Eighty-first Street at 1:30 A. M. yesterday by three armed bandits, who apparently trailed the automobile in which she was riding with her husband and a friend from a New- Jersey night club.

United States Ambasador Joseph P. Kennedy will sail Wednesday on the liner Queen Mary for a nine-day visit in the United States, primarily to attend the graduation of his eldest son, Joseph P. Kennedy Jr., from Harvard.

More than 60,000 persons lined the main thoroughfares here tonight to watch an eighty-minute parade culminating a week's celebration of this city's seventy-fifth anniversary. It was estimated that more than 5,000 persons were in line.

230th St (17-4855), n e cor of Barnes Ave, 105x50; Sylvia Maltese to Elena RuisI, 28 Jefferson St., Brooklyn. West Gun Hill Rd, 36-38 (12-3324A); Louis Rudnick to Fan-Mos Holding Corp, 17 E 42d St; mtg $165,500. De Reimer Ave, 4,318 (17-5058); Frank Macaluso to Louis Galatioto, 4,318 De Reimer Ave.

The international executive board 'of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers of the C. I. O. voted down a resolution today asking a general 10 per cent wage increase and a thirty-five-hour week for about 45,000 employes in the full-fashioned hosiery industry.

Charged with willful and unlawful demolition of buildings which the Federal Government erected in 1935 for a CCC camp in Stafford Township, two army officers were arrested today on warrants sworn out by Firman H. Cranmer, former Mayor of Beach Haven and an officer in the Lake Manahwakin Land Company.

Stuart J. Fuller, United States delegate, made detailed charges before the League of Nations opium advisory committee today that the Japanese Army in China was now importing and distributing raw opium by the tens of tons.

Harvard's student body will be reduced from 3,700 to 3,500 within the next few years. The Harvard Crimson said today, probably by reducing the number of freshmen admitted each year from 1,000 to a figure not yet determined.

Aided by three home runs, including No. 23 by Bob Seeds, the Bears routed Toronto today, 11 to 3, for their fourth victory. in a row. The game was called on account of rain in the eighth with the Leafs at bat, the bases filled on three singles and none out.

The fourth annual Duck Island race of the Norwalk Yacht Club was won today by the auxiliary yacht My Wife, owned by William Harvenal of the Huntington Yacht Club, New York. The victor's elapsed time was 22:30:10. Thirteen craft started.

Records for May building construction here were broken last month when fiftyone permits for a total of $178,375 in new buildings were issued by the Municipal Building Department, headed by Nelson A. Kieb.

The selection of three undergraduates to collaborate in writing the script for the Princeton Triangle Club's fiftieth annual production next Winter has been announced by Sanders Maxwell of Trenton, president of the musical comedy group.

Robert L. Duffus, author and member of THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial staff, in a commencement address at Middlebury College this morning called for a redefinition of democracy and for a firmer resistance to forces which are undermining it.

The Caravan Theatre, which is the system by which the Federal Theatre Project shows free drama during the Summer in the city's parks and playgrounds, will open officially its third season this evening.

Long Jim Barnes, present Long Island open champion and former British and United States open titleholder, paired with Robert Johnke, medalist in the recent Long Island amateur championship, to win the Long Island Golf Association pro-amateur tournament today.

Edward J. O'Shea, 32 years old, of 6813 Juno Street, Forest Hills, Queens, pleaded guilty yesterday before County Judge Cortland A. Johnson here to charges of seconddegree forgery and filing false claims with the State Tax Department.
A license to show the motion picture "Assassin of Youth," intended to portray the detrimental effects of the use of the drug marijuana, has been denied by the Board of Regents.

Barklie Henry, president of the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, repiled yesterday to criticism made public on Sunday in a letter of resignation by Dr. John A. Kingsbury, member of the association's board of managers.
Pensioned On his own application, to take effect 12 midnight, June 15. PATROLMAN--William H. McSweeney, 79th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 15, 1909.

Andrea Luckenbach, 18-year-old daughter of Commodore Edgar F. Luckenbach, shipping magnate of Elm Point, on Manhasset Bay, and New York, plans to be married tomorrow at 5 P. M. in St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Great Neck, to William Dobbs of Forest Hills, a son of Mrs. Henry Reston.
Quadruplets three boys and a girl-were born today to a 29-year-old Liverpool mother. According to a bulletin issued by the municipal hospital, "All are progressing satisfactorily."
Romain Rolland has come back to his native land, from which he has been an exile since the outbreak of the World War.

Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau said at his press conference this afternoon that rumors of forthcoming devaluation of the dollar probably would persist "as long as people can make money out of t them."

Britain's second defense loan amounting to 80,000,000 bearing interest of 3 per cent will be issued Wednesday. The government will then have issued 180,000,000 of the 400,000,000 that the Treasury was authorized to borrow over a period of five years.

Accused of swindling Rear Admiral Yates Stirling Jr., retired, out of $15 for "import duty" on two cases of liquor ostensibly sent by the Chamber of Commerce of Honolulu, Hawaii, George Ruth, 33 years old, of 160 West Sixty-eighth Street, was in police custody last night awaiting arraignment in Brooklyn Federal Court.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 13: BRIGADIER GENERAL Wilson, W. H., Boston, Mass., to command of the First Coast Artillery Dist., Boston, Mass. COLONELS Madison. I. M., Inf., detailed with the Organized Reserves, Seventh Corps Area, in addition to other duties at Minneapolis, Minn., Oct. 20.

Maryland Fund, Inc.-Three months to May 31: Net investment income, $26,794, equal to 2 cents each on 1,781,412 capital shares, compared with $78,396, or 6 cents each on 1,286,045 shares in similar period of last year.
Extension of chain systems and expanding businesses accounted for several of the commercial rentals announced yesterday.

Curt Davis pitched the Cardinals to a 4-to-3 victory over his former team-mates, the Phillies, today. Davis held the Phils to seven hits, six of them coming in the last three innings. He also scored the winning run himself in the eighth on Slaughter's two-bagger after two were out.

The second of the two-out-of-three semi-final series for the city P. S. A. L. title between Flushing High and Abraham Lincoln High, scheduled to have been played yesterday at Flushing Memorial Field, was postponed until today on account of rain.

Miss Elizabeth Anne Warren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Appleton Warren, was married here this morning to Lieutenant Glenn Curtis Thompson, United States Army Air Corps, in her parents' home, where four generations of brides of her family have been wed.

You scatter-gun enthusiasts had better forget your fishing long enough to get in some practice before the 24th of this month, when the tenth annual Great Eastern skeet championships are scheduled to open at Lordship, Stratford, Conn. The shoot will run through Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

Names Corrected The names of the following ununiformed firemen are corrected as follows: Ernie Ulrich, Engine 18, should read Ernest M. Ulrich. Eugene E. E. Diglacono. Engine 26, should read Eugene E. E. DiGiacomo. Thomas P. Sullivan, Engine 35, should read Thomas F. Sullivan.

A long partnership between Don Bradman and W. A. Brown pulled Australia out of a tight hole today and forced a draw in the opening cricket test against England. The next of the five-game series will start in London on June 24.

Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury, after conferring with legal advisers on the estate of her husband, has notified sixty-six of the seventy persons employed at Whitemarsh Hall, the 147-room mansion near this city,

The Spanish Government's harassed central army, striving to block the advance of victorious Insurgent troops toward Valencia, took a new stand today on the Mijares River five miles south of Castellon de la Plana.

The court that is trying Captain Stanley Scott of the British steamer Stancroft adjourned after hearing Denis Nowell Pritt, defense counsel, demand that the charge of carrying war material to Spain be dismissed because there was nothing illegal in carrying cargoes between Spanish ports.

A delegation. of Boy Scouts from Troop 77 here was ushered out of the postoffice building today when they tried to protect the dignity of the bronze seals of the United States that are set in the floor of the lobby of the building.

The consensus of seventy members of the National Lamp and Shade Manufacturers Association, meeting last night in the Hotel McAlpin, was that the coming year would be an extremely good one, with low stocks in stores throughout the country as one cause.

American advertising ideas and technique find ready acceptance in Australia, where newspapers, magazines and other media pattern themselves closely on the publications in this country, Walter L. Bomer, vice president of the BristolMyers Company, said yesterday in an address before the regular luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc., at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Mr.

The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago has called for redemption on July 18 all outstanding bonds of the following series: first mortgage 5s, series A; first mortgage collateral 5s, series A; first mortgage 5s, series B, and first mortgage collateral 5s, series B. Payment will be made immediately at the Bankers Trust Company, acting for the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, successor trustee.

The girls who crack them far and straight off the tee attracted the most gallery respect today as first round matches in the women's Western open golf tournament were rattled off without bringing a single surprise.

" Lucky" was the way Charley Yates continuously referred to his triumph in the recent British amateur golf championship as he was greeted by admirers yesterday upon his return with the Walker Cup team.

The Senate and House today approved the Wages and Hours Bill as reported by the Joint Conference Committee and the measure will go to President Roosevelt for his signature in a few days. The House vote was 290 to 89. No record vote was taken in the Senate.

The fortieth commencement exercises of the Cornell University Medical College will be held at 4 P. M. today in the auditorium, 1,300 York Avenue. The graduating class of sixty-six includes eight women.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler approved yesterday a creditors' proposal for reorganization of the New York Title and Mortgage Company despite objections by stockholders. The plan provides for creation of a new company, with assets of from $9,000,000 to $11,500,000, to engage in the mortgage banking business, ownership being in the hands of the creditors of the old company.

Unification of Canada's two railroad systems, which has been advocated vigorously by Sir Edward Beatty,. president of the privately owned Canadian Pacific Railway, was opposed emphatically today before a special Senate committee by S. J. Hungerford, president of the Stateowned Canadian National Railways. As a substitute he proposed "compulsory cooperation."

The price of galvanized sheets has been reduced $3 a ton by leading members of the steel industry at the conclusion of a long and determined campaign by jobbers to obtain lower prices for one of the principal warehouse products of the industry, it was learned yesterday.

Fordham.University will hold its ninety-third general commencement ceremonies this afternoon, beginning at 4 o'clock, when 537 undergraduate and graduate degrees and four honorary degrees will be conferred by Cardinal Hayes, who will preside.

The second installment of Federal and New York State income takes for 1937 is due today, officials of both government agencies warned yesterday. James J. Hoey, Federal Collector of Internal Revenue, said the remittance for the second quarter must be in tax offices by the close of business today.

A strike of barbers in the midtown zone started at 8 A. M. yesterday, with an estimated 800 out by 6 P. M., according to the Barbers and Beauty Culturists Union of America, Local 1, a C. I. O. affiliate. Adolf Rosenbaum, chairman of the strike committee,

Net profit of department and specialty apparel stores in 1937 dropped to an average of 1.6 per cent, compared with 2.6 per cent in 1936, despite the fact that sales of these stores were 5 per cent greater in 1937 than in 1936, according to figures issued yesterday by H. I. Kleinhaus, manager of the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Federal troops operating in the State of Guanajuato, just south of San Luis Potosi, have killed seventy-six Rebel Irregulars in the past twelve days with four Federal soldiers killed, it was stated semi-officially today.

Roy Lazer, 197 pounds, Paterson, N. J., won an eight-round decision from Joe Walcott, 188, Merchantville, N. J., tonight. Johnny Lucas, 145. Camden, outpointed Gene Buffalo, 150, Philadelphia; Tommy Ricco, 128, Camden, knocked out Mickey Benson, 137, Richmond, Va., in the fourth;

A four-point program for rural Christian life was outlined at the Rutgers University Institute for Town and Country Ministers here today by Dr. Mark A. Dawber, executive secretary of the Home Missions Council of New York.

After a contract for the sale of the Tennessee Public Service Com- Con pany's properties to the Tennessee Valley Authority in Knoxville had a re been signed yesterday afternoon, a meeting of stockholders of the utility company was called for July 11 to vote on the proposal.

The problem of the bombings of British merchant ships in Spanish Loyalist ports by Insurgent airplanes presents unprecedented difficulties and at present there appears to be nothing that Britain can do about it, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain told the House of Commons today.

Senator Key Pittman, chairman of the Foreign-Relations Committee, abandoned today his effort to obtain Senate approval of resolution giving approval to Secretary of State Cordell Hull's 'condemnation of bombings of civilians in fighting abroad.

MANHATTAN GEDNEY, EMMA (April 21). Estate, $40,000. To Harry G. Williams, nephew, 21 Berkeley PI., Montclair, N. J., $10,000; five others $200 each; Richard P. Williams, nephew, executor, 39 E. 60th St., residue.

Past and present members of the Board of Education and members of the Board of Regents paid tribute last night to Walter C. Martin, retiring Superintendent of School Buildings, at a dinner at the Park Central Hotel.

With several vital questions before them, including the fundamental problem of whether the church will return to "pure democracy" with each church having an equal vote in the affairs of the national body, delegates are gathering here today for the biannual meeting of the General Council of the Congregational and Christian Churches.

Ten of the teams that will participate in the coming Meadow Brook Club twenty-goal championship tournament saw action in practice matches in this sector late this afternoon. Games were played on the No. 4 field at the club and Mitchel Field, and a pair of round robins were held on the J. S. Phipps estate in Old Westbury.
Senator Borah asked the Senate today to make a sweeping investigation of speculation in farm products, predicting that it would save "millions upon millions of dollars" for agricultural producers.
Miss Alma Clayburgh, daughter of Mrs. Alma Clayburgh of 21 East Fifty-second Street, was married in St. Bartholomew's Church yesterday afternoon to James Hooper Grew,

President Arturo Alessandri today signed a message to Congress announcing that an agreement had been reached by the Chilean Foreign Office with the Argentine Govornment over the procedure to be followed in the dispute over the islands in Beagle Channel near the Atlantic opening of Magellan Strait.
New Yorkers sailing today for Europe on the French liner Normandie will include the Grand Duchess Marie of Russia, Countess Von Keller, Lord and Lady Stamp of Shortlands,

Miss Rosamond Eddy of 106 East Sixtieth Street and Alvin M. Josephy Jr. of 245 East Seventy-second Street, whose engagement was announced early this month, took out a wedding license yesterday at the Municipal Building and said they would be married on July 15 in St. Thomas Church.
A wedding of widespread interest took place in St. James Episcopal Church here tonight when Miss Elizabeth Wistar Craighill, daughter of the Rev and Mrs. G. Peyton

Torrential rains are continuing in the Yangtze and Yellow River regions and are not only slowing down the Japanese advance but also are threatening lines of communications by causing washouts on highways and railways.

A charge of "invasion of the trust estate" and various objections to tor the proposed plan of reorganization of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act brought to a close yesterday the formal hearings T in this procedure before George W. bar Alger, special master, in the Bar Building, 36 West Forty-fourth Street.

On the 27-story Oliver Cromwell Hotel at 12-18 W 72d St, 100 ft front, the Olicrom Operating Corp, F. Howard Berrett, president, gave two mortgages: A first for $350,000 to the Equitable Life Assurance Society, due ten years hence at 5 per cent, with $2,500. paid off quarterly; the other for $95,000 to Keystone Investing Co, Inc. a second lien due June 15, 1941, at 6 per cent.
Amsterdam Ave, 1,439; 5 story tenemen 27x100; Title Guarantee and Trust C4 trustee, against Jacob Berman: due, $25 925; taxes, etc., $2,942; to plaintiff ?? $18,000.

Last night's performance of "... one-third of a nation ..." the WPA living newspaper play at the Adelphi Theatre, 152 West Fiftyfourth Street, was halted a little before curtain time when about forty stage hands, members of the International Alliance of Theatrical

The third National Exhibition of American Art, an annual event conducted by the Municipal Art Committee of New York, opened with a preview last evening in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

The "battle of proxies" for control of the Chesapeake Corporation cost Robert R. Young of New York control of that holding company at the annual stockholders' meeting here today and resulted in a unanimous vote for its dissolution and for distribution of its valuable holdings of stock of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway.
Funeral services were held today for the Rev. William Hogan, Redemptorist father, who died Friday in his seventy-sixth year.

Behind sparkling six-hit pitching by Rookie John Haley, the Bears handed the Maple Leafs their tenth consecutive defeat tonight, 5 to 2. It was Haley's fifth triumph in a row and also No. 5 of a fresh victory string for the league champions.
The Southern Colorado Power Company proposes to call a special meeting of stockholders to consider a reduction of the amount of capital represented by the Class B common stock.

La Salle Academy will graduate its largest class, 171 students, at the ninetieth commencement exercises to be held tonight in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, Vicar General of the Archdiocese of New York, will preside. The speaker will be William D. Cunningham, attorney.

Tonight a new and gaudy page will be written in Brooklyn baseball history when the Dodgers and the Reds meet in the first night game under the gigantic battery of floodlights whose installation at Ebbets Field has just been completed.

Simultaneously with the announcement that a royal commission will inquire into social and economic conditions in the British West Indies, Sir Arthur Frederick Richards was appointed today to succeed the late Sir Edward Denham as Governor of Jamaica.
