The Maritime Association announced yesterday that Frank D. Denton had retired as a member, director and secretary of the association, because of his proposed retirement from active business.

The Census Bureau reported today cotton consumed during May totaled 425,684 bales of lint and 60,464 of linters, compared with 414,392 and 57,852 during April this year and 669,665 and 72,325 during May last year.

Mrs. Anna V. W. Smith of Long Island City has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Evelyn L. Smith, to Albert E. Christie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel H. Christie of this place, and a member of the Borough Council.

Cooperation between the American Newspaper Guild and the American Association of Schools of Journalism to raise salaries and to improve the professional status of newspaper workers was proposed today by Dean Kenneth E. Olson of the Medill School of Journalism of Northwestern University.

Efforts to clear business before the Senate stopped at 12:31 A. M. failed in the face of opposition approaching filibuster proportions directed by Senator O'Mahoney against the conference report on the $375,000,000 Flood Control Bill.

The Red Sox had two pay-off innings today which gave them a 5-to-3 victory over the Browns. Lefty Grove drove a single to center in the seventh with two down to launch a three-run rally. He left the game in the last half of the inning after the Browns had pushed over two runs to tie the score.

Two former holders of the world's heavyweight championship visited Dr. Joseph Bier's camp today to watch the current possessor of the most valuable title in pugilism prepare for his battle with Max Schmeling. Gene Tunney and James J. Braddock looked on as Joe Louis

Miss Julia Bach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton J. Bach, was married here yesterday to Dr. Jack J. Squire, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo M. Squire of Yonkers, N. Y., at the home of her parents, 1,155 Park Avenue, by Dr. John Lovejoy Elliott of the Ethical Culture Society. The bride was graduated from the Fieldston School and in 1935 from Wheaton College.

Employment methods used by the New York World's Fair, 1939, Inc., are its own concern and cannot be regulated by the City Council, it was said yesterday by Councilman Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d during debate on a resolution criticizing the fair for having failed to seek employes from civil service lists.
Brown University closed its baseball season by defeating the University of Virginia, 13 to 6, at Aldrich Field today. McCullough of Brown allowed eight hits, while two Virginia pitchers gave eleven.

Vice Mayor Erik Morch of La Rochelle, France, participated today in New Rochelle's 250th anniversary celebration by speaking at a flagpole dedication exercise, visiting historical exhibitions and greeting officials at City Hall.

Operating under a suspension of the rules, the House just before midnight tonight passed and sent to the White the House the O'Mahoney resolution calling for a comprehensive investigation of monopolies by a commission made up of six members of Congress, three from each house, and one representative each from the Department of Justice, Treasury, Labor and Commerce, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Trade Commission.

Those actors are out again. After the long Winter, the wheels have been greased on the itinerant stages, and the Caravan Theatr opened the Summer park season last evening. At Silver Lake Park in Staten Island one troupe of grease-paint buccaneers played the Jules Eckert

Archie San Romani, not to be outdone by Glenn Cunningham's twin bill of the mile and the three-quarters in Saturday's invitation track meet here, has applied for permission to match his fellow Kansan in both events, it was announced here today by R. Kenneth Fairman, acting graduate manager of athletics.

Two members of the Board of Higher Education, Arthur M. Howe of 205 Rugby Road, Brooklyn, and Ernest S. MacDonald of 16-10 Jamaica Avenue, Queens, are expected to send their resignations to Mayor La Guardia shortly, it was learned yesterday.

Disposing of 246 building lots through sale contracts that require the purchaser to construct houses on them, the village of Elmsford considered itself launched today on a building boom that would create a new residential section and help local merchants by the increase in population.

The Norwegian America Line was host to about 500 shipping men and persons prominent in public life at a dinner last night aboard the new motor liner Oslofjord, which arrived in port Monday on her maiden transatlantic crossing.

Replying to yesterday's onslaught by the United States, Canadian, Egyptian and Chinese delegates in the League of Nations Opium Advisory Committee, Eiji Amau, the Japanese member, had nothing more to say today against the main charge that the Japanese military authorities were involved in or had been encouraging the narcotic traffic in China than to repeat his denial of yesterday.
The John Newbery Medal, awarded annually "for the most distinguished contribution to American literature for children," was presented this year to Kate Seredy for "The White Stag" (Viking).

The First Voters League, with headquarters at 565 Fifth Avenue, sent out a call yesterday for "all conservative organizations" to join with it in a protest meeting against Mayor Frank Hague, which the league proposes to hold in Journal Square, Jersey City, either on June 23 or June 30.

Candidates for the women's New York State tennis championship spent a busy afternoon yesterday running for the cover of the clubhouse as rain clouds played hideand-seek with the sun over the grounds of the Jackson Heights Tennis Club in Queens.

The rumors of impending devaluation of the dollar will not be downed. Although Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau denied them only on Monday, they cropped up again stronger than ever late yesterday.

The attitude of American doctors toward one of the most controversial public issues in medicine today, health insurance, has been measured by the American Institute of Public Opinion in a special preliminary survey.

Frank Dyer Chester, former consul general to Austria-Hungary, died today in the City Hospital at the age of 68. Mr. Chester was a member of the American Oriental Society, the American Society of International Law, the New London County (Conn.) Historical Society and the Newport Historical Society.

Renewed strong rumors of a devaluation of the dollar and the pound sterling swept through the financial markets yesterday, acquiring force and precision as the day's business neared its close. In response to these rumors the dollar again fell heavily in foreign exchange and the London gold market witnessed a scramble of hoarders.

A group of thirty Negro pastors, teachers and students made their annual pilgrimage yesterday afternoon to the Hall of Fame at New York University in honor of the 127th birthday anniversary of Harriet Beecher Stowe, author of "Uncle Tom's Cabin."

The Interstate Commerce Commission this afternoon reopened the proceeding in which the Eastern railroads asked an increase from 2 to 2 1/2 cents a mile in passenger coach fares and set the matter down for hearing here before Division 7 on June 27.

Samuel Mann of 1 Christopher Street, a retired merchant. died yesterday in St. Vinchant, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital after a brief illness at the age of 73. For forty years he had been in the hosiery manufacturing business under the name of S. Mann Co., retiring in 1925.

Max Schmeling today gave a large weekday crowd three glimpses of the flashing punch with which he hopes to knock out Joe Louis in the Yankee Stadium on the night of June 22. The German star sparred six rounds.

Corporal George W. Collier, 95 years old and the only living Civil War veteran of-the Twelth New York Volunteers, was guest of honor last night at the military review of the 212th Coast Artillery (anti-aircraft), National Guard, in the armory at Columbus Avenue and Sixty-second Street.

Innovations in design introduced by the New York World's Fair of 1939 should inspire a change in men's fashions, unchanged for thirty years, it was suggested yesterday by Mrs. Edna Woolman Chase, editor-in-chief of Vogue.

Adressing a conference designed as a springboard for a campaign to unite the warring factions of labor, management and government, and to revive confidence, Donald Richberg, former NRA administrator, lashed out today at the "bullies and the war-makers in public and private life," and called for classes to unite in a league for peaceful progress.

Thirty-seven lawyers, in a canvass of the legal profession yesterday, raised $11,000 for the United Palestine Appeal for the settlement of Jewish refugees In Palestine, according to a report last night by Sylvan Gotshal, chairman of the lawyers' division of the appeal.

Ten members of the Card and Bill Posters Union, Local 811, C. I. O. affiliate, including James Qual ley, president of the local, were held in $500 bail each yesterday afternoon by Magistrate Frank Oliver in the Bronx Magistrates'

Republican. leaders of the Constitutional Convention worked tonight to draft a "search and seizure" clause for the proposed new State Constitution which would, through presentation as a compromise measure, help defeat the drastic ban on wiretapping that has been sponsored by John J. Dunnigan, one of the Democratic floor leaders.

A Federal Government committee laid before the American Medical Associtation today a demand for concerted action in tackling the problem of providing adequate medical care for "one-third of our people." Written by Miss Josephine Roche, in charge of the Interdepartmental

There were eighty-four deaths of children under 1 year old in this city in the week ended on last Saturday, giving an infant mortality rate of 43.6 to 1,000 live births, it was reported yesterday by Dr. Willian H. Best, Acting Health Commissioner.
Mrs. Allen Nash of Hesperides, this place, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Seymour Nash, to John Whitall Nicholson 3d of Germantown, Philadelphia, and Moorestown, N. J.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Malcolm Muir will give a tea on Friday at their home, 160 East Seventy-second Street, for their daughter, Miss Eleanor Warfield Muir, who has just returned from Europe, where she passed the Winter and Spring. Mr. and Mrs. Muir will introduce their daughter to society at a supper dance later in the season.
Gold imported in May was valued at $52,986,928, compared with $71,236,453. in April and $155,366,073 in May, 1937, the Department of Commerce said today.

Jersey City's Little Giants PROVIDENCE, made. it two out of three in their Brown University present series with Buffalo tonight by defeating the Bisons, 4 to 2, before a crowd of 13,650, including a large ladies' night turnout.

" The Life of Rudolph Valentino," the first picture to deal with the career of a screen figure, was announced today by Edward Small for United Artists release. The film will be the second for Jack Dunn, former skating partner of Sonja Henie.

A total of $11,823 has been raised by the sale of 1,559 tickets to the Westchester Fete, an annual event given under the sponsorship of the Women's Division of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities, it was announced here today by Mrs. Leonard H. Bernheim of Scarsdale, chairman, at a-meeting of 400 volunteer workers at the Summer home of Mrs. Felix M. Warburg.

After a thorough canvass of the Georgia political situation the President may decide not openly to participate in an Administration attempt to deny the Democratic renomination to Senator George of that State.

A $125,000 first mortgage for five years at 41/2% has been placed on the property on the 's w cor of Main St and South Broadway, Yonkers, Westchester County, for Mrs. Alice P. Harrigan, owner. Jcbn J. Reynolds was the broker. A $12.000 mortgage for ten years at 5% on the one-story taxpayer at 262-66 E. 204th St, Bronx, has been arranged by Benry Waltemade, Inc, broker, for Paul Ianotta, owner.

Miss Shirley E. Kellner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gustave Kellner, was married to Fred M. Kraus of Brooklyn, son of- Mrs.. Michael Kraus and the late Mr. Kraus, yesterday noon at the home of her parents, 71 Maple Street, Brooklyn.

When two men were arraigned yesterday in the Tombs Court on charges of violating the new city code prohibiting peddling of pamphlets and other literature in the streets without a license, Magistrate Rothenberg indicated he was inclined to agree with the defendants' lawyer that the law is unconstitutional under a recent United States Supreme Court decision.

The Yale varsity crew defeated the junior varsity boat by more than five lengths late today in a four-mile time trial on the Thames River. The trial, one of the few to be clocked since the Elis began training here for the Harvard regatta June 24,
Miss Doris Robinson, daughter of Mrs. Walter J. Scott, was married to William Cochran Fitch of Kingston, N. Y., in the First Presbyterian Church here tonight by the Rev. James Allen Kestle.

Two women are being held by the government in hidden "protective custody" as vital spy witnesses, it was learned yesterday, as a special Federal grand jury prepared to lift the curtain on a German conspiracy to obtain American defense secrets.

MANHATTAN DEMAREST, JANE A. (March 11, 1938). Gross assets, $29,884; net, $27,019. To John B. Anderson and Margaret Joralemon, cousins, one-half residue each; two other bequests of $500 each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $26,151. Reeves, Todd, Ely and Beaty, attorneys, 165 Broadway.

183d St (11-3209), n s, 100 ft w of Grand Ave, 50x100; Annie M. Delaney to Meige Realty Corp, 53 W 183d St. 156th St, 656 E (10-2628); Mary Barrett to Estella Pagan, 137 W 116th St. Carpenter Ave. 4,435 (17-5066); Rose Saverese to Cornelia Ziliani, 1,631 Garfield St; mtg, $11,800. Purdy St, 1,523 (15-3947); East River Sayvings Bank to Thomas Fitzgerald, 443 E 142d St.

The Trenton Clearing House Association has voted to close Trenton banks on Saturdays during July and August in compliance with the law approved by the Legislature several weeks ago, it was announced here today.

Sir John Reith, the dour, 6 foot 6 inch Scot who for eleven years has been known as the "authoritarian" ruler of the British Broadcasting Corporation, has been appointed to the much-discussed full-time chairmanship of Imperial Airways, Ltd., at % salary of [Pound]10,000.

Plans for the reorganization and expansion of the Board of Education's research bureau,, to place greater emphasis upon-the improvement of teaching methods and evaluate the school curriculum, were announced yesterday by James Marshall, president of the board.

The Senate Judiciary Committee today reported favorably the nomination of William Clark, of New Jersey, to be a judge in the Third Circuit Court of Appeals, but only after lively testimony before a subcommittee.

Tonight the WPA Federal Theatre presents its oft-postponed production of George Bernard Shaw's "On the Rocks." The scene is Daly's Theatre and, in Shavian tradition, the curtain is scheduled to rise early, in fact at 8:15 o'clock. The cast includes Estelle Winwood, Philip Bourneuf, Lyster Chambers, Muriel Starr, Edward Forbes, Doan Borup and Donald Arbury.

Mrs. Amy Webster Crossley of Rye, N. Y., wife of' G. Reginald Crossley, died Monday in St. Luke's Hospital here after an illness of several weeks. Mrs. Crossley, who was president of the Century Theatre Club of New York from 1927 to 1930, was born in New Bedford, Mass., a daughter of the late Lieutenant Charles Everett Webster, U.S.N.

The man who on Sunday fatally shot the Rev. Roger Craig Cumberland, a young American missionary, at his home at Dohuk, forty miles north of Mosul, and then escaped to the desert is believed to be a Kurd who had a grudge against Mr. Cumberland.

Mrs. Alfred F. King Jr. of Apawamis shot a 91 on the Canoe Brook Country Club's tricky north course today to capture low gross honors in the one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

To twelve members of the jury whose acquaintance with interstate commerce in the past probably has been limited to mail order purchases, the government entrusted today the task of deciding whether the Harlan County coal companies accused of conspiring with Sheriff Theodore R. Middleton and twentyone deputies to defeat the Wagner Labor Relations Act were engaged in interstate commerce.

It was only yesterday, in the swift rush by which aviation progress is measured, that pioneers such as Orville Wright and scientists such as Lord Haldane were predicting a very restricted upward limit on the size of aircraft due to loss of efficiency with growth.

The threatened general strike of 3,000 drivers against more than 100 independent milk distributors was averted yesterday when 1,500 members of the Milk Drivers Union, affiliated with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. of L. organization, voted in Beethoven Hall to ratify an agreement reached on Monday with the dealers.

Coordination of the activities in defense of Jewish rights has been agreed upon by representatives of four national Jewish organizations in this country, the American Jewish Committee, American Jewish Congress, B'nai B'rith and Jewish Labor Committee, it was announced yesterday.

Five members of the German weight-lifting team, which will engage in two meets against Americans, arrived here yesterday aboard the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. The team includes G. Liebsch, K. Jansen, R. Ismayer, H. Gietl and J. Mangar.
Much litigation and many important legal judgments will be necessary before the marriage tangle of Enrique de Paats of Buenos Aires with his two American wives is straightened out.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 11: CAPTAIN Gunther, E. L., relieved additional duty as Commanding Officer, Fleet Air Base, Coco Solo, C. Z., to continue other duties. COMMANDERS Ainsworth, W. L., Charleston, S. C., to duty as Professor of Naval Science and Tactics, Tulane University, New Orleans, La. Lowe, F. L., Destroyer Dlv'n. 3, to continue duty in command of the Flusser.
Tammany, the City Hall cat, got an overdose yesterday of the anguish that unusually accompanies publicity, and as a result spent most of his day sulking in the dank recesses of the building's cellar.

Informal discussion of possible candidates for Governor is expected today when the executive committee of the Republican State Committee meets at the National Republican Club on call of William S. Murray, the chairman.

Japan's Ambassador to Great Britain, Shigeru Yoshida, today bluntly declared Japanese air raids on Canton, resulting in an estimated 7,000 casualties, were carried out to. "demoralize the Chinese people."

An assertion by Domei, Japanese press agency, this evening that the Governor of French Indo-China is negotiating with emissaries of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek for the defense of Hainan Island indicates strongly that Japan is planning an attack on Hainan shortly, or at least sending out the report as a trial balloon.
Harold F. Hadden of Hewlett, L. I., a retired silk importer, died yesterday after a brief illness in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 51 years old.
The Works Progress Administration has decided to buy $10,000,000 worth of men's, women's and children's clothing for distribution to people otherwise unable to buy such garments.

There will be no attempt to put through the House an amendment to the Federal Reserve Act which Senator Wagner sponsored in the Senate and which passed that body several weeks ago, Representative Goldsborough, acting chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee said today.

A 15-year-old law prohibiting smoking in manufacturing plants is to be enforced strictly, according to notices being sent out by the New Jersey Labor Department. In several instances summonses already have been issued and fines imposed for violations.

Another of Peter Beatty's turf purchases paid quick dividends today. Foxglove II, whom Mr. Beatty had purchased last night from Prince Aly Khan, won the Ascot Gold Vase, over a two-mile course. Sir Woodman Burbidge's Solonaise was second and James V. Rank's Michoumy third.

After a lapse of twenty-eight years, the Ancient Order of Hibernians will stage a track and field meet at Randalls Island Stadium on Sunday, July 17. Announcement of the meet was made yesterday by Joseph P. McCluskey, New York A. C. ace, who will serve as director of the games and also as a competitor.

The directors of the Western Electric Company took no action on the common dividend at their quarterly meeting yesterday. The latest payment was 25 cents a share paid on March 31. In 1937 the company paid 60 cents on March 31, 75 cents each on June 30 and Sept. 30, and 90 cents on Dec. 28, a total of $3 a share.

Three infield hits, none of which seemed potent enough to knock over a bowling pin, a base on balls and an error by Russ Bauers comprised the rally which brought the home-coming Giants a 5-to-3 victory over the Pirates yesterday at the Polo Grounds. It was hardly the way for the league leaders to assert their superiority but it was, nevertheless,

According to the British press, Joseph P. Kennedy, the United States Ambassador, will display extraordinary powers of concentration during his nine-day stay in the United States at the end of this month. He will sail tomorrow on the Queen Mary and will start back June 29 on the Manhattan.

The City Council, by a vote of 16 to 8; approved yesterday a resolution providing for a broad investigation of relief administration in the city, with particular attention to the activities of the Workers Alliance in representing members who apply for relief.

Judicial review of decisions of administrative officers should be vested in the courts of the State rather than in a separate administrative court, Dr. Roscoe Pound, former dean of the Harvard Law School and chairman of the committee on administrative law of the American Bar Association, declared today at a public hearing of the judiciary committee of the Constitutional Convention.

Victorious in its eighth game of the season today, Lancashire replaced Middlesex at the top of the English county cricket championship. The southern county was defeated yesterday by Yorkshire by seven wickets.
A mere standard of usefulness will not suffice in stocking our mental shelves, Lord Stamp declared today in the Commencement Day address at Johns Hopkins University.
A detailed account of the collection activities of all eighty divisions of the still incomplete Greater New York Fund will be asked at a report luncheon in the Hotel Commodore today.

Miss Mary Ella Waller, educator and author of more than twenty books, died here today in her home. She was in her eighty-fourth year. She had been living in Wellesley for the last twelve years after a career that included the writing of several best selling novels, years of travel through Europe and in her earlier days teaching and conducting a finishing school for girls.

While repudiating responsibility for the Austrian federal debts in principle, Germany has expressed willingness to meet the creditors and the powers guaranteeing these debts halfway and make bilateral agreements with each for the payment of at least part of the interest due.

Awards of $1 each were made yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin to twentyone persons claiming title to the roadbed of City Hall Place between Pearl and Duane Streets as heirs of George Janeway who owned the land in 1794 when the street was opened.

Attorneys for 179 railroads filed suit in Federal court today seeking to restrain an order of the Interstate Commerce Commission requiring installation of automatic stokers on all coal-burning locomotives.
The Cubs kept chipping away at Lou Fette's offerings today until they had piled up five runs, enough to beat the Bees, 5 to 2. The victory kept the Cubs within two games of the league-leading Giants.

William H. Goldey of 2,015 Dorchester Road, Brooklyn, retired real estate broker and secretary and oldest member of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board, died on Monday night in the Caledonia Hospital, Brooklyn, after an illness of several months. His age was 85.

Multi-family houses figured in several of the Manhattan real estate transactions reported yesterday. The three five-story apartment houses at 534-38 West 159th Street, each on a plot 25 by 100 feet, were sold by the New York Savings Bank to the HYA Holding Corporation, an investing client of Isaac B. Wakeman, broker.
Miss Jane H.T. Perry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Perry of 139 East Sixty-sixth Street, will be married to John W. Vandercook of 13 Gramercy Park on Monday in the Church of the Resurrection.

Those black clouds that seem to gather daily over New York have given the city an excess of 2.44 inches of rainfall since the first of this month. But despite the recent excess, the total precipitation since Jan. 1 has been .69 inch less than the average, according to records of the United States Weather Bureau.

The name of the sixth person indicted in the alleged $4,000,000 looting of Continental Securities Corporation was revealed yesterday when the New York Police Department sent out an alarm at the request of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey for the arrest of George H. Clayton broker and Promoter.

The Athletic letics defeated the Tigers, 8 to 2, today, blasting Vernon Kennedy from the mound in the eighth inning with a four-hit, three-run rally. It was Kennedy's second defeat of the year, both at the hands of the Athletics.

Semi-annual commencement exercises of Hunter College will be held this morning at Carnegie Hall, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, at 10 A. M. Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of the college, will confer degrees on about 950 students, presented by Dr. Charles J. Moore, head of the chemistry department. Mrs. Anna Steese Richardson, author and editor, will deliver the baccalaureate address.

With increases previously granted the general freight rate rise authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission on March 8 would yield the Baltimore Ohio Railroad about $10,000,000 annually, Daniel Willard, president, said in his report for 1937 issued yesterday.

President Roosevelt conceded today that the hour of his departure for the wedding of his son John at Nahant, Mass., on Saturday was in the hands of Congress and made it clear that he would avoid saying or doing anything that might interfere with adjournment by tomorrow night.

Staging a thrilling finish, the New York women's golf team, defending champion, defeated the Philadelphia fifteen, 8 matches to 7, over the Spring Mills course of the Philadelphia Country Club today to return the Griscom Cup to New York for another year.

Consumption of crude rubber in the United States in May amounted to 28,947 long tons, compared with 27,984 in April and 51,795 in May, 1937, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association. Gross imports last month were 27,410 long tons, against 30,807 in April and 50,840 in May last year.

Formation of Frosted Foods, Ltd., with a capitalization of ?80,000 and headquarters in London, was revealed here yesterday by Edwin T. Gibson, president of the Frosted Foods Sales Corporation, subsidiary of the General Foods Corporation, and distributors of Birds Eye Frosted Foods.

Patriotic, civic and military groups assembled yesterday at Flag Day ceremonies throughout the city to commemorate the 161st anniversary of the adoption of the Stars and Stripes as the national emblem.
A "revolt" in the taxation committee of the Constitutional Convention resulted today in the committee's holding up a proposal embodying a new taxation article and in an order for a public hearing.
Miss Grace Hayward, daughter of Mrs. Charles Burton Hayward and the late Mayor Hayward of Englewood, was married this afternoon to Lewis Mack, son of Mrs. Lewis Charles Mack and the late Mr.

More than 500 school teachers greeted with enthusiastic applause references to the "Americanism" of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City by speakers at a Flag Day rally held in Town Hall last night by the American Education Association.

Hundreds of small-scale importers will suffer financial difficulties through the unusual provision in the Customs Administrative Bill just passed by Congress which makes rate changes effective "on enactment" rather than thirty days or more after the measure is signed by the President, according to letters sent to Washington officials yesterday by the National Council of American Importers, Inc.

Trading continued slow on all classes of traefer meats. Packers report that all classes of livestock are showing losses and slaughter is being sharply curtailed, especially on cattle and lambs. The steer and lamb markets were lower, veal exceptionally weak, fresh pork cuts about steady. All kosher meats opened weak under slow trade. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Arthur K. L. Watson, 62 years old, son of the late General T. L. Watson, founder of the T. L. Watson Co. banking house here, was found dead of gunshot wounds in the bathroom at the Watson home fronting on Long Island Sound today.
Mayor La Guardia of New York today termed the proposed amendment before the Constitutional Convention to halt the tapping of telephone wires a "new Magna Charta of crime."

Declaring he did not believe in civil liberties for any one working for the overthrow of the government, Mayor Frank Hague advocated today a concentration camp in Alaska for native "Reds," deportation from the United States of alien radicals and suppression of free speech and other constitutional rights for all in this category.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M. June 16: THIRD GRADE DETECTIVES - From 18th Division, 15th Detective District, to precincts indicated, designation as third grade detective revoked: H. M. Connolly.. 68 Vincent A. Reehil.110

After a day of planning and replanning their wedding, which was to have taken place at 5 o'clock in the chapel of St. Paul's Episcopal Church here, with the Rev. Dr. William Grime officiating, Miss Andrea Luckenbach and William F. Dobbs were married at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Garni in Kensington at 5:30, with the Rev. Richard Hegarty, pastor of the Port Washington Methodist Episcopal Church, performing the ceremony.

Formation of a trust institution under State law to act as agent for both brokers and customers, as suggested by W. O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, will be discussed again on Thursday in New York by representatives of the commission and the New York Stock Exchange.

Dr. William Wallace Campbell, astronomer and president of the University of California from 1923 to 1930, committed suicide today by leaping from a window of his third floor apartment. He was 76 years old.

A new stage in the preparation of the minorities statute was reached today when Premier Milan Hodza received a deputation of leaders of Konrad Henlein's Sudeten German party consisting of M Deputies Ernst Kundt, Karl Hermann Franck, Franz Peters, Franz Rosche and Dr. Wilhelm Sebekowsky and their legal expert, Dr. Schicketanz.

The reconstruction of Berlin as an eternal and worthy capital of Great Germany was formally started today when amid appropriate ceremonies and in the presence of Third Reich dignitaries Chancellor Hitler laid the cornerstone of the "House of German Tourist Traffic" in Potsdamerstrasse.
Five branch banks will be closed in Alberta within the next month, bank officials announced today.

Roscoe H. Hupper, admiralty lawyer, was designated yesterday by Judge Mortimer W. Byers, in the Federal court in Brooklyn, receiver for the Munson Line ship Pan America. Mr. Hupper was appointed receiver of the Southern Cross, of the same line, two weeks ago.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 14 unless specified: Arkansas, Charleston to New York. Flack Hawk, Southern Philippines to Bangkok. Bushnell at Canal Zone. Helm, Boston to Navy Yard, Norfolk (hold final trials off Rockland).

Conferences with executives of apparel chains, mail order houses and department stores to induce them to buy only coats and suits which bear the "Consumers Protection Label" will be held soon by representatives of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board.

Dr. Francis Carter Wood, director of the Institute of Cancer Research at Columbia University, told 300 persons yesterday afternoon at the dedication of a modernized X-ray department in the Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn, that the radiological department of a hospital had become its most valuable adjunct. It was most important, he said, not only in diagnosis but in therapy.

One hundred and twenty-three industrial building plans representing investments estimated at $1,939,855 were filed with the State Department of Labor during May, State Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews announced yesterday.

The three-story private dwelling, under erection on the site of the former home of the late Jacob H. Schiff, at 2 East Seventy-eighth Street, has been leased by Dr. Henry Templeton Smith, who will occupy it as his residence.

Charging that C. I. O. operations virtually had ruined his $1,000,000 business, Walter L. Fry, the employer who once matched his workers' sit-down strike with one of his own, announced today that his company would move its manufacturing operations from Detroit to Georgia.
Great Britain and France defaulted on their semi-annual war-debt payments today in notes from their Ambassadors to Secretary Hull.

Strong faith in the future of the International Labor Office was expressed today by its retiring director, Harold Butler, in his last speech to the conference. He was replying to the general discussion of his annual report.

A stockholder's suit seeking to compel present and former officials of Insuranshares Corporation of Delaware to restore about $635,000 to the company's treasury was instituted yesterday in Supreme Court.

While there may be no economic reason for the current recession, uncertainty, created by the Administration policies and widely heralded in the press, has been instilled in the minds of consumers and has prevented them from purchasing goods, W. J. Cameron of the Ford Motor Company, declared today at a luncheon meeting of the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association at the BookCadillac Hotel.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Marjorie Presswell, younger daughter of Mrs. William Lawrence Presswell of London, England, to Alan Dalrymple Warren, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Smith Warren of Bronxville, N. Y. The wedding will take place in Bronxville this Summer.

The same deft touch which carved out a second consecutive national open golf championship for Ralph Guldahl last week brought the Madison (N. J.) professional a one-stroke lead at the end of the first eighteen holes of the seventy-two-hole Western open golf tournament today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: After many years of hit-or-miss development, with rank opportunism and petty politics more often than not the controlling elements, civil aviation in America seems about to get a break. The Seventy-fifth Congress has done a constructive job for it, and now it is squarely up to the White House whether that break is to be for better or for worse.

The Interstate Commerce Commission is preparing a report "approving a final plan of reorganization" for the St. Louis Southwestern Railway Company, commonly known as the Cotton Belt, according to a letter written to Senator William H. Dieterich on June 10 by Commissioner Carrol Miller of the I. C. C.
St. John's Prep of Brooklyn quali-fied to meet st. Peter's High of feating All Hallows Institute, BronxWestchester champion, 3 to 2, in a semi-final play-off game at Fordham Field yesterday.
Seventeen inhabitants of Birobidjan, the Jewish autonomous republic on the Siberian-Manchukuoan border, have been shot as spies and wreckers. The names of seven appear to be Jewish.

Russell, Brewster Co., the oldest stock and bond brokerage house in Chicago, sent today the following notice to its customers: "The firm begs to announce to its friends and clients that after having been in business for sixtysix years, it has decided to retire from active business as of the 30th day of June, 1938.

With the failure of a last-minute effort to obtain House support for the bill to liberalize RFC loans to railroads, all hope of Federal aid for the lines, at the present session of Congress was killed today.

Though the United States has lived for two years under a Neutrality Act which expresses its wish to remain at peace, the American people are not neutral now in any situation which involves the risk of war, nor will they remain neutral in any future situation which threatens to disturb the balance of world power.
Steel ingot output was unchanged last week when a seasonal easing was indicated, and the adjusted index advanced to 33.9 from 33.3. The figure was 105.4 for the week ended June 12, 1937.

Requirements for proposed wheat loans were outlined today in a statement issued by the Secretary of Agriculture and the Commodity Credit Corporation for the benefit of farmers and elevator operators desiring to handle wheat under the loan provisions of the 1938 Agricultural Adjustment Act.

The first complete picture of the financial plight of the hundreds of hospitals and kindred organizations serving the 11,000,000 residents of the metropolitan area was made public yesterday and described the conditions of the institutions as so precarious "that their problems are far beyond the strength and resources of the individual trustee groups to cope with and solve independently."
Pleas for cessation of industrial strife were voiced today by speakers before the annual meeting of the Advertising Federation of America.

After breezing six furlongs in 1:14 2-5 at Belmont Park, War Admiral was placed aboard a special car for Boston late yesterday. ' He will arrive at Suffolk Downs today. War Admiral was accompanied by eleven other horses in the Glen Riddie Farm string, all in charge of Trainer George Conway.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,131,500 barrels, compared with 3,107,950 in the previous week, an increase of 23,550, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Jimmy Dykes and his White Sox, who somehow have become imbued with the fixed notion they can bowl over baseball's world champions most any time and place they meet, were doing a first class job entertaining a gathering of 7,000 today, with the promise of providing some more bowling of the same high order, when plans went amiss.
France prepared today to handle a standing army of 1,000,000 men-the nation's answer to tension in Europe.

Miss Anne Elizabeth Heiss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Augustus Heiss of Little Brook Farm, this place and East Orange, was married here this afternoon at the home of her parents to Carroll Aylsworth Boynton,
The twenty-first season of the free Summer concerts of the Goldman Band will open tonight at the Central Park Mall under the direction of Dr. Edwin Franko Goldman. Mayor La Guardia, Mrs.

The nature of the serious problems confronting the country and college graduates of this year was said yesterday by Edmund W. Flynn, Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Rhode Island, to hold out to graduates of Catholic colleges the greatest opportunity for satisfying service and good work that has been offered in our time.

Andre de St. Phalle, at Wright Paine house, Woodmere; Marie C. Orben, at William H. Pendleton house, Cedarhurst: Dorothy C. Havemeyer, at Reginald Pratt house, Lawrence; J. Walter D. Duke, at Allan Locke house, Lawrence; all on Long Island; Basil Livingston, at Greenleaf property, New Canaan, Conn; Harry Forsyth, at Hodgsdon property, Old Lyme, Conn; Mrs. Edward Stout, Inc, broker.

John S. Egan of Newburgh, a brother of James Egan, who for years has been active in Tammany and Democratic politics in New York, and of Colonel Raphael Egan, formerly commander of the 156th Field Artillery Regiment, N. Y. N. G., died Sunday in St. Luke's Hospital here.

At the end of long night sessions in both Houses Congress early this morning was poised for apparently certain adjournment before another day has passed. The House adjourned at 11:45 P. M. until noon today, and the Senate recessed at 12:31 A. M. until 10 o'clock.

Members of the staff of United States District Attorney John J. Quinn went before the Federal grand jury here today seeking indictments against about thirty contractors and corporations in connection with an alleged plot to defraud the government of $250,000 in bidding to furnish sand,

The Rev. Roger C. Cumberland, a Presbyterian missionary, died on Sunday at Dohuk, Iraq, according to word received yesterday by the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America. A native of La Verne, Calif., Mr. Cumberland was 43 years old.

With the season of outdoor dog shows now at its height, one can observe nowadays to best advantage the astounding skill which man has exercised in molding his best friend to many outward forms. The onlooker can but marvel hope at the patience and nicety of selection that have gone into the perfecting of the many races which vie for the ribbons.

For improvement with sixteen attached one-family homes, a parcel of land consisting of fifteen plots, 25 by 100 feet, on the east side of Boynton Avenue, between Eastern Boulevard and Story Avenue, the Bronx, was purchased by the Boynton Homes, Inc., developers.

Eulogized in song and poem, the slate blackboard, as much a part of the American public school as the pencil, ruler and eraser, is in danger of extinction. An experiment to determine whether a more spritely white, or perhaps green, glassboard is to take its place is under way in the New York City school system.

With Bishop Stephen J. Donahue officiating, nineteen young men, eight of them from New York and vicinity, were ordained in the seminary chapel at Maryknoll here today to the priesthood of the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America.

United States exports to Japan in April were greater than in any other month thus far this year, reaching $28,837,000 and bringing the total value of exports to that, nation for the first four months of the year to $91,409,000, according to preliminary trade figures made public by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

Franklin Pierce McCall, 21-year-old farm helper, pleaded guilty in Circuit Court today to the $10,000-ransom kidnapping of James Cash Jr., 5-year-old son of a Princeton storekeeper, but entered a plea of innocent to the child's murder.

The semi-annual report of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and subsidiaries, including the Firestone Auto Supply and Service Stores, issued yesterday, showed a net profit of $2,429,738 for the six months ended with April.
Reports of black rust in Kansas, Oklahoma, Nebraska and parts of Illinois, announcing actual damage and the prospect for much more harm, turned a weak wheat market into a buoyantly strong one today.

By a vote of eleven to one the judges of the Permanent Court of International Justice today accepted the French Government's contention that since only private companies, and no international controversy, were involved it was not competent to judge the Moroccan phosphates suit brought by Italy.

Jose Maria Sert, Spanish painter and attache of General Francisco Franco's embassy at the Vatican, arrived here yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen to inspect and retouch his frescoes in Rockefeller Center.

Raymond Bookmeyer, vice president of the Dry Dock Savings Institution, will speak on Friday at 4:45 P. M. on the second broadcast over WNEW of a series under the auspices of the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement.
Among the contracts for residential space reported by brokers yesterday were a number for apartments in Park Avenue.

Plans have been filed for remodeling the five-story residence at 125 East Seventy-third Street, which was sold by Mrs. Mildred W. Wickersham, widow of George W. Wickersham, Attorney General in the Taft Administration, to the Layton Realty Company in a deal reported yesterday.
The conference report on the 1938 Relief-Recovery Bill was passed by the House today with two minor changes and sent to the Senate, which was expected to adopt it tomorrow.

Although the number of out-oftown buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday was only slightly less than in the preceding week the total was considerably below the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.
Jan Jansen van Rensburg, pioneer South African Dutch settler of Kenya, died today near Eldoret at the age of 89.

In a move to preserve "airtight" secrecy in the investigation of the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy racket, in which James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, and others have been indicted, District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey shifted the grand jury yesterday from new quarters in the
Returning to action after a lay-off of two weeks, the Amherst baseball Alta, team opened the last part of its schedule with a surprise 6-3 victory over the University of California today.

Sugar-beet acreage contracted for this year is 15 per cent in excess of that at this time last year, W. N. Wilds, president of the American Crystal Sugar Company, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting in Jersey City.

Three railroads reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday amounts received from banks on account of loans. The Delaware Hudson Railroad reported the issuance of a 4 per cent collateral note for $1,000,000 dated May 2 held by the Manufacturers Trust Company.

President Roosevelt plans to build a new retreat to which he can withdraw on his visits to Hyde Park when he wants to avoid the interruptions that sometimes occur at the small study in his mother's home there.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Adams, daughter of Mrs. Rand Adams of 1,245 Madison Avenue, and the late Stuart Corlies Adams, to Hugh H. Butler, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Fenwick Butler, took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. The rector, the Rev. Dr.

The Senators trimmed the Indians' American League lead to half a game today with a 7-to-6 victory here while the second place Yankees were winning. Johnny Humphries, young Cleveland pitcher, was hit hard in his first big league start. He took the loss when driven out during a four-run barrage in the fifth inning, which included two home runs.

Some idea of the progress made in recent years in modernizing building codes throughout the country will be offered when the Bureau of Standards of the Department of Commerce completes a survey which it now is conducting.

Stafford G. Cowan has been elected a director and treasurer of 1 M. E. Cornelius Co., Inc. David A. Gibson, formerly manager of the office of Pelz Co. in Rochester, N. Y., will manage the 1 new branch office at 17 Court Street, Buffalo. Theodore Lawshe succeeds Mr. Gibson as manager in Rochester.

Bernie Friedkin, 136, Brownsville, battled to an eight-round draw with Orville Drouillard, 135 3/4, Windsor, Ont., in the main bout at the Canarsie Arena in Brooklyn last night. In the semi-final of six rounds, Willie Nussbaum, 131 1/4, Flatbush, defeated Freddy Foran, 136, Hartford, Conn.

Running back to his sparkling race in the Metropolitan Handicap, in which he beat Snark and other topnotchers, J. D. Norris's Danger Point showed brilliant speed again at Aqueduct yesterday when he captured the Short Grass Handicap within four-fifths of a second of John P. Grier's 17-year-old track record.

A nature photography exhibition made up entirely of wildlife subjects will open today at the Barbizon-Plaza Art Gallery, Sixth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street. The display arranged by Bird-Lore Magazine, official publication of the National Association of Audubon Societies, will feature nearly 500 prints by twenty-five wildlife photographers.

The investigation of a reported link between politics and Works Progress Administration expenditures, proposed by a group led by Senator Tydings, was changed by Senate Committee action today into a study as to whether any appropriations of public funds find their way into political channels in States electing Senators this year.

Luncheon of the Home of the Daughters of Jacob, 167th Street and Findlay Avenue, 12:30 P. M. Presentation of a plaque to Adolph Lourie to commemorate fifteenth anniversary of his association with the home.

More than seven inches of rain has fallen in the last three days, ending the six months' drought, but has left parts of San Juan without drinking water. Floods weakened the trenches containing the water mains, causing breaks which officials said could not be repaired for three days.

Another class was added to the "long gray line" of West Point's, sons this morning as 301 cadets, at graduating ceremonies, heard Secretary of War Woodring urge them to extend the horizons of the mind.
Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Elsa Ortenblad, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Ortenblad of New York, to Frederick A. Reininger Jr.,

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., will pay today its 200th dividend on common stock. The company has paid dividends continuously since it was organized as the Consolidated Gas Company of New York in 1884.

On a quiet side street, shut off to regular traffic by the police, students in the safe-driving course of the Department of Education of New York University demonstrated yesterday afternoon the standardized course in driving skill that will be presented through the American Automobile Association in forty universities and colleges this Summer.

Sir George Smith, wartime Governor and Commander in Chief of Nyassaland, died today in Ladythorpe, Addlestone, Surrey, at the age of 80. More than any one else, Sir George was responsible for the commercial development of Nyassaland.
Officials of the American Federation of Labor said today the federation would keep hands off the New Jersey civil liberties dispute between the C. I. O. and Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City.

It is pleasant to read of Mr. Roosevelt and Senator Gillette sitting in their shirtsleeves at luncheon when the outside Washington temperature was 95. Moderns don't know their blessings. Fifty years ago many statesmen were encumbered with beards and all wore frock coats in the rages of the mercury.
Miss Shirley Noyes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jansen Noyes, was introduced to society here tonight at a dance given by her parents at their home, 114 South Mountain Avenue.
The embryo television industry had its first labor union worries yesterday. To forestall "any possible claims," the Actors Equity Association, covering theatre actors,
Sir Hubert Wilkins arrived here by airplane this morning from Russia on his way to London and the United States to prepare for a submarine journey under the ice at the North Pole.

After selling- yesterday within 2 points of the 8-cent level for July contracts, prices on the Cotton Exchange made a sharp recovery of $1 a bale and ended with gains of 12 to 14 points, or 60 to 70 cents.

Miss Margaret Geist of Denver was martried here this morning to Lieut. Comdr. David Wells Roberts of Grand Junction, Col., an officer of the United States flagship Omaha, by the Mayor of Villefranche.

James J. Stromyer, 50 years old, of 225 South Forty-sixth Street, West Philadelphia, jumped or fell to his death soon after 10 A. M. yesterday from the seventh floor of the Cornish Arms Hotel, 315 West Twenty-third Street.

Despite an unfavorable position,Erich Eliskases of Vienna drew his adjourned game today with Paul Keres of Estonia from the fourth round of the international chess masters tournament and retained the lead with a score of 3-1. Play lasted for fifty-six moves. Keres, who missed his chance of displacing the Austrian,

The Chinese have a better chance of defending their independence than an impartial observer in 1776 would have thought the American colonies had of winning theirs, Roger S. Greene, former United States consul at several Chinese and Japanese cities, declared here yesterday.

The annual report of the North American Company to the Securities and Exchange Commission showed today that J. F. Fogarty, president, received aggregate remuneration of $71,558 in 1937, compared with $71,668 in 1936.

Councilmen Joseph E. Kinsley, Bronx Democrat, introduced a bill in the City Council yesterday requiring non-resident city employes to pay a city excise tax of 3 per cent of their annual salaries between July 1, 1938, and June 30, 1939, or any part of that period. The bill went to the finance committee, of which Mr. Kinsley is chairman.

After the graduation exercises of the United States Military Academy class of 1938 today, Lieutenant William K. Skaer, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Skaer of Los Angeles, mar. ried Miss Evelyn Land, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Yates A.
The Interstate Commerce Commission disapproved today the plan of the Associated Railways Company and eight other railroads to acquire and dismember the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad Company.

Stocks improved moderately and closed irregularly higher in quiet trading; turnover, 346,450 shares. United States Government bonds irregularly higher, other issues irregularly lower in second largest dealings of the month; transactions, $4,948,600.
Sixty-five delegates attended the quarterly meeting of the American Kennel Club Leld yesterday in this city. They elected the following organizations to membership in the governing body:

Mrs. Claire Burkitt telegraphed to Attorney General Homer Cummings in Washington last night, asking him to investigate immediately comments attributed to Warden Michael J. Gill of the Hudson County Penitentiary, in which her husband, James F. (Jeff) Burkitt, is serving a six-month term for disorderly conduct.

A National Salesmen's Crusade, predicated on the belief that recovery can best be achieved by extra effort on the part of salesmen in all lines, was begun here yesterday when 1,550 sales executives and salesmen were guests of the NashKelvinator Corporation at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Eddie McGeever, 141, Scranton, scored a technical knockout over Honey Melody, 137, Boston, last night at the New York Coliseum before a crowd of 4,500 when his opponent was unable to answer the bell for the third of what was the featured eight-round test.
The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey will file today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering the proposed issuance of $85,000,000 of new securities.

Mrs. Charles King Mallory Jr. and Herschel V. Williams gave a luncheon yesterday in the Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Miss Hildegarde Graham and Miss Marian Kingsland and their respective fiances, Robert Dudley van Roijen and Count Hans SeherrThoss.
Following is the text of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's address in the House of Common on the bombing of British ships in Spanish waters:

Adoption by the Constitutional Convention of an amendment creating a Consumer Department in the State was urged here today by representatives of consumer and social welfare organizations and the American Labor party.

At a special meeting of the Devoe Raynolds Company, Inc., stockholders yesterday authorized the issuance of $2,000,000 of fifteenyear 4 1/4 per cent debentures which have been sold in one lot to the Equitable Life Assurance Society. Proceeds are to pay off bank loans of $1,900,000, the remainder to go into working capital.

The New Jersey Supreme Court refused today to review the conviction and six-month jail sentence of James F. (Jeff) Burkitt, a political opponent of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City. Burkitt was arrested in April for trying to speak in Jersey City without a police permit and was tried in Hudson County on a charge of disorderly conduct.

Jurors will be drawn in Federal court here tomorrow as the trial of the Commonwealth Trust Company of Wilmington, Del., the. Whealton Company of Camden and a number of individuals charged with stock fraud gets under way.

Dr. Miriam Van Waters, superintendent of the Massachusetts Reformatory for Women, who recently succeeded the late Clarence Darrow as president of the American League to Abolish Capital Punishment, was guest at a reception yesterday attended by 100 members of the league at the Parkside Hotel, 18 Gramercy Park South.

To further the harmony' restoration program of Pennsylvania Democrats, Matthew H. McCloskey Jr., co-leader of the Philadelphia Democratic organization and chairman of the State party's finance committee, retired today from active politics.
The Bronx Home Owners Association, an organization formed to aid owners of homes carrying HOLC mortgages, will hold a meeting tonight at Chester Palace, 1,930 Boston Road, the Bronx.
Officials of Lake County, Ind., will receive sealed proposals on July 1 for $1,000,000 of advancement fund bonds for which bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 3 per cent.

The steel industry finds itself in a somewhat more cheerful position this week than last, with June business running slightly ahead of May for some producers and the national ingot rate up a point to 26 per cent, Iron Age says.

Charley Keller connected for a homer and three singles and boosted his season batting average to .421 today as he paced the Newark Bears to a 5-to-3 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs, stretching their winning streak to six straight.

After a short but eloquent exchange, in which art for art's sake, the philosophy of Immanuel Kant, the development of the solar nebular hypothesis and like matters received due mention, Representative Sirovich's bill to establish a Bureau of Arts and Sciences in the Interior Department was defeated in the House today.

F. Bramwell Geddes of the Scars-dale Golf Club, defending champion, today led a field of 117 in the first round of the Westchester Seniors' Golf Association annual tournament over the course of the Westchester Hills Golf Club. He turned in a gross score of 72 to be well under any of his competitors.

Flushing High's nine clinched a place in the final round of the city P. S. A. L. baseball championship tournament by defeating Abraham Lincoln, Brooklyn ruler, 4 to 3, in the second of their two-out-of-three-game semi-final series at Flushing Memorial Field yesterday.

The New York Maritime Council, representing nine maritime unions affiliated with the C. I. O., proposed yesterday the establishment of machinery for arbitration and mediation of labor disputes in the maritime field.

A reduction of the paid-up capital by $4,555,450, through the elimination of unamortized bond premium, discount and expense in a single operation, was approved yesterday by shareholders of the Shawinigan Water and Power Company.

Dr. John J. Kennedy of New York has purchased from the Larpeg Realty Corporastion one and one-half acres of land with a modern residence and several outbuildings on Sleepy Hollow. Road, Briarcliff Manor, Westchester, through I. C. Hotaling, broker. Benjamin Levitan was attorney for the seller.
Metropolitan Museum of Art, 3:30 P. M. "The Exhibition of French Silver," Ethelwyn Bradish. Tea, China Society of America, 570 Lexington Avenue, 4 P. M. Address by the Rev. R. Jacquinot de Besange.

A new name on Viking's list is that of Graham Greene, whose "Brighton Rock" will be published June 24. Subtitled "An Entertainment" the book is described by the publishers as a psychological horror story.

Yale's polo team gained the final of the intercollegiate championship with a 16-to-1 victory over Princeton at the Burnt Mills Club today. The hard-hitting Elis, whose mallet work improved in accuracy as the game progressed, will meet Harvard for the title on Saturday at 4 P. M.
Kneeling before the chancel in the Church of Reformation, twelve young Theological School graduates tonight were ordained as ministers in the United Lutheran Synod of New York.

Miss Janet M. Rath, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Rath of this place, was married tonight to Donald Tregarthen Ruby, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Ruby of Rockville Centre, L. I. The Rev. Dr. Henry I. Stahr, president of Hood College, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

Private residences figured in the bulk of the Brooklyn realty deals reported yesterday. The three-story house at 158 Berkeley Place, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, was purchased for occupancy by Ellen Palleta from J. Bardes, through L. L. Yearsley, broker.
Board of Trade figures for May as follows: total imports o75,390,000; exports of British products o38,160,000; re-exports o7,170,000; total exports o45,330,000; excess of imports f30,060,000.
The Athletics extended their winning streak to five straight as they edged our the Tigers, 7 to 6, in a slugfest today.
The American Newspaper Guild went on record today as favoring the "strengthening" of the Wagner Labor Relations Act by penalizing employers who refuse to sign or negotiate labor contracts.

The 308th Infantry of the Seventy-seventh Division has won the first leg on the Adler Trophy for annual Competition among pistol teams of Live United States Army Reserve officers from regiments of the Organized Reserves of New York, New Jersey and Delaware, it was announced yesterday.

An early conference of men's and women's clothing manufacturers with Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, and other government officials, will be held to discuss procedure involved in the proposed purchase by the WPA of $10,000,000 worth of clothing for the needy, it was reported today.
Rumanian subjects living abroad will lose their citizenship if they take part in political activities directed against the Rumanian State, a royal decree issued today announces.

The Northern States Power Company, Minnesota; the Northern States Power Company, Delaware, and the Northern States Power Company, Wisconsin, of the Standard Gas and Electric Company system, have filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Holding Company Act applications covering a series of transactions designed to eliminate inter-company debts.

John V. A. Weaver, a poet who wrote his verses in the idiom of the street, came out of the gaudy Chicago of Ben Hecht to be a book reviewer in Brooklyn just as the literary renaissance of the Twenties was dawning over New York.
Sycamore Ave (13-3424), e s. 90 ft a of 254th St, 60x140 feet; Sycamore Estates, Inc. to- -Railroad Federal Savings and Loan Association, 441 Lexington Ave; installments, 6 per cent: $14,800.

There is no solace for tired minds like the sound of lake water at night. Dwellers in this noisy town, which New York becomes, once Summer has forced the windows open, may like to be reminded of so sure an anodyne while they are making out their vacation schedules.

Famous trains pulled out of New York's major terminals yesterday clad in a new and shining luxury. Both the Twentieth Century Limited of the New York Central and the Broadway Limited of the Pennsylvania,

Contracts for space in buildings in Rockefeller Center were among the leading business leases reported yesterday. New offices to be used in connection with his personal business were taken in the International Building by Cornelius Vanderbilt Jr.

Nineteen newly commissioned second lieutenants in their new uniforms of dress blue married here today in ceremonies that began soon after the sun rose and continued until after it had set. The first couple were married in the rectory of the Holy Trinity Church at 8 A. M. and the last in cadet chapel.
Franklin Pierce McCall, 21-year-old truck driver, was formally adjudged guilty today of kidnapping little James Bailey Cash Jr., a crime punishable by death.
Representative Hen, B. Steagall, chairman of the House Committee on Banking and Currency, won a renomination in a Third Congressional District run-over primary yesterday.
J. P. Bickel, president of McIntyre Porcupine Mines, Ltd., told stockholders at their annual.meeting in Toronto yesterday that the present dividend policy would be maintained.

Breaks in the Yellow River dikes north of the Lung-Hai Railway between Chengchow and Kaifeng are releasing waters four or five feet deep that are advancing five miles an hour over a five-mile front, according to Japanese reports.

Governor Bibb Graves's office announced today that the American Cyanamid and Chemical Corporation of New York had contracted for "a substantial acreage of land" at Mobile for construction of a manufacturing plant.
The Mercury Theatre's latest acquisition is, of all things, "Close Quarters," the Gilbert Lennox play which employs as cast one man and one woman.

A new betting record was established at Ascot today when $811,380 passed through the totalisator, beating the previous record for a single day's racing by more than $100,000. This sum was in addition to wagers placed with bookmakers.

The editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES today declaring that the United States would join the European democracies in the event of war has attracted considerable attention in Germany, where it is denounced as "open war agitation."

Douglas C. Smith of 410 Grand Avenue, Brooklyn, principal inspector of engineering materials for the United States Navy here and supervisor of civilian inspectors, died suddenly yesterday in his office at 641 Washington Street, Manhattan.

Mr. and Mrs. Hugh De Haven of Cooperstown, N. Y., entertained with a dinner last night at the Madison for Sir Gerald Campbell, retiring British Consul General at New York, and Lady Campbell, who are sailing shortly for England, where they will remain until he assumes his new post in Ottawa next Autumn. er guests were Mr.

LEVINE, NATHAN (July 8, 1935). Gross assets, $25,632; net, $17,187. To wife. Mary Levine, 276 Kosciusko St., one-third of residuary estate; sons, Louis and Abraham and daughters, Lillian Corman, Bertha Goldbaum, Rae Glaubach and Celia Shalita, one-ninth of residuary estate each. Chief assets, real estate, $22,500; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $3,081. George H. Rosen, attorney. 302 Broadway, Manhattan.

Carl B. Fritsche of Detroit, consulting engineer, urged today the creation of new industries using farm crops for raw material as a means to remedy unemployment. He spoke before the Virginia Bankers Association.

Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes and his bride, the former Jane Dahlman of Milwaukee, sailed for New York today aboard the lie de France after a ten-day honeymoon visit to Paris. Mr. Ickes said he was anxious to get back to Washington to find: out. what's going on."

A campaign for Republican support of Frederic H. Bontecou, State Senator of Dutchess County, as a candidate for the Lieutenant Governorship, was started last night at a dinner- of State leaders at the Hotel Plaza.

Eddie Cantor will spend his vacation in England raising funds to transport Jewish children from Germany, Austria and Poland to Palestine. The comedian said today that he was leaving July 6 for London, where he would speak in the interest of the Youth Aliyah.

The Utilities Power and Light Corporation purchased a 20 per cent interest in Chicago Surface Lines bonds in 1929 when it was planning to build a feeder line for the proposed lakefront subway, Harley L. Clarke, former president of the company, disclosed today at a hearing before Harry N. Gottlieb, special master in chancery.

The Rev. Dr. Oscar Edward Maurer, pastor of the Center Church of New Haven, Conn., was elected Moderator of the Congregational and Christian Churches today at the opening of the biannual general council.

Charging in a resolution that political interference is creating uncertainty, disturbing the morale of the people, discouraging business leaders and burdening trade with excessive costs and restrictions, the Advertising Federation of America today concluded its thirty-fourth annual convention by calling upon business and government to cooperate immediately in order to restore confidence and to release American enterprise to do its economical job.

The flagstaff of Lieut. Comdr. George Washington De Long's North Pole expedition has been found at the foot of a high rock cliff on Henrietta Island, visited by the explorer fifty-seven years ago shortly before he and his companions died after the foundering of their ship the Jeannette in the ice of Siberia.

The Lexington School for the Deaf will hold its annual graduation exercises at 8 o'clock tonight at the school, 904 Lexington Avenue. Fifteen deaf-mutes will receive diplomas and eleven students will be graduated from the Teacher Training Course.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City and Morris L. Ernst, C. I. 0. counsel, battled orally for two hours this afternoon in the most exciting session of the three days in which the Mayor has been testifying in the injunction suit brought by the C. I. 0. and the American Civil Liberties Union against continued suppression of free speech for C. I. O. organizers and sympathizers.

Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, former world champion, gained two full points by winning an adjourned game from the third round and another in the fifth round today, but continues to trail the leader, Erich Eliskases of Austria, who defeated S. Landau, the second representative of The Netherlands.

A ninth-inning rally today broke a 6-6 tie and gave the Cardinals a 9-to-7 victory over the Phillies in a see-saw game. The Cards scored three runs off relief pitchers Sylvester Johnson and Al Smith in the ninth after the Phils had driven Roy Henshaw to the showers to tie the score in the eighth.

Miss Margaret Bostwick Bradley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Mersick Bradley of this city, was married this afternoon in Center Church, which is celebrating its 300th birthday, to Friend Allen Sherk,

Steadiness marked trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. After advancing into new high ground the list ended with gains of 2 to 6 points. A sharp rise in Liverpool and nervous fluctuations in sterling exchange reflected uncertainty over monetary developments.

Francis P. Gallagher of Kidder, Peabody Co. was elected yesterday president of the Municipal Bond Club of New York at the annual meeting at the Bankers Club. He succeeds Emil C. Williams of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.
Buildings on the East Side attracted many of the new tenants listed in brokers' rental reports submitted yesterday.
A leading Bronx deal reported yesterday included the sale by a bank of a vacant plot for improvement with a building which was leased from the plans.

Miss Genevieve Owen, 18-year-old Newark girl, who is serving a life sentence for the hold-up murder of William Barhorst, a bus driver, was convicted of the hold-up Dec. 18 of a Lyndhurst filling station in Quarter Sessions Court here today.
This attitude was particularly evident regarding the country's tax laws. Both houses got to work on their own initiative, without urging from the President, and began the work of reform.
THE name has been changed. It's Dismal Dean now. The odd fellow who used to be known laughingly as O1' Dizz has become a famous clinical case and a something of a celebrated cynical case, too.
The Bank of New York and Trust Company, as trustees, sold the five-story building on a lot 20 by 50 feet at 207 Sullivan Street through the J. D. Robilotto Company.

Along the banks of the Thames where Yale and Harvard crews have trained for more than a half century the pace noticeably quickened today in the preparations for the renewal of this oldest of college sports fixtures a week from Friday.

A total of 174 diplomas was awarded at the annual commencement exercises of Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute last night in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Chemistry, science and engineering certificates went to 134 undergraduate students, while thirty-nine masters' and one doctor's degree were presented to members of the graduate school.

The old brownstone and red brick dwelling at 4 West Fifty-fourth Street, which John D. Rockefeller Sr. maintained as his residence for more than half a century, passed into the hands of wreckers yesterday.

Miss George-Ann Jackson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Jackson of 778 Park Avenue, was married yesterday afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church to Jonathan Slocum, son of Dr. and Mrs. C. Jonathan Slocum of Beacon, N. Y.

The sharply disputed question of whether or not to write into the State Constitution a ban on wire tapping and property seizures without legal warrants was unexpectedly placed before the Constitutional Convention today, and debate. was scheduled to start Monday night.

The Temple Owls came from behind in the ninth inning with three hits and as many runs to defeat Princeton, 4 to 3, on University Field today. The victory, the tenth in fifteen starts for the Philadelphians, snapped a four-game Tiger winning streak.
The total collected by the Greater New York Fund to date was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, chairman, as $4,061,423.

Threat of a strike against the per capital tax by United Automobile Worker locals opposed to Homer Martin, union president, grew today as five suspended officers and the Martin side scrambled for control of the U. A. W. treasury.

A communique dealing with yesterday's discussions between Premier Milan Hodza and leaders of Konrad Henlein's Sudeten German party makes the important statement tonight that the Premier declared the Czechoslovak Government was prepared to regard the party's recent memorandum as well as its own nationalities statute as a basis for negotiations.

The swift succession of events preceding passage of the Wages and Hours Bill in Congress left organized labor somewhat breathless today, but nevertheless there was considerable speculation as to the possibility of making changes in the act as soon as possible.

The Spanish Rebels drove against Loyalist positions in three widely separated regions yesterday. On the Mediterranean coast they pushed on toward Valencia by crossing the Mijares River and taking Villareal.

Mr. and Mrs. John J. Clark of 281 Lawton Avenue, Cliffside Park, were killed and Emile Harrier. 50 years old, of Blanche Road, Harrington Park, was injured seriously in a collision between the Clark and Harrier automobiles on Route 9-W near Palisade Avenue here about 9 o'clock tonight.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Jane Fitzhugh Delevett, daughter of Mrs. James M. Delevett of this city and the late Dr. Delevett, to Dr. Victor Lemoine Heuser, son of Mr. and Mrs. L. V. Heuser of Glen Ridge, N. J.

Former Premier Pierre Laval before the Senate Foreign Affairs Commission today charged that the non-intervention agreement is being violated at the Franco-Spanish border and he demanded an investigation concerning war material being sent into Loyalist Spain.

The Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise, chairman of the executive committee of the United Palestine Appeal, left a dinner in Brooklyn last night at which he was to have been the guest of honor without appearing before the diners.

While the United States, birthplace of the skyscraper, is building "Greek temples" to house its government departments, the Latin-American countries are constructing "attractive skyscrapers" for this purpose, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce stated today.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates June 15, unless specified: At New London: Hamilton, June 14; Potomac.

Strengthening of the fair trade practice program of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board to meet changing conditions in the industry was voted at the annual meeting of the board's executive council at the Hotel Astor yesterday:

A campaign against salacious magazines has been started by the Council for Decency in Magazines, with headquarters in the R. C. A. Building, according to an announcement yesterday by Louis C. Haggerty, president of the organization.
Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, declared today at a stockholders' meeting that the Federal Government should "be fair" in its policy toward utilities.

For many of us the most agonizing moments of our school days are associated with orders from Teacher to step to the blackboard and list the capitals of the Middle Atlantic States or demonstrate how many apples John would have left if his mother gave him thirteen and told him to divide eight between Sarah and Ann. Stretching darkly across the front of the room,

Without a single speech in protest, the House today overrode President Roosevelt's veto of the Emergency Farm Credit Interest Bill, which he said had already cost the Federal Government $160,000,000 and would add another $48,700,000 by July 1, 1940, during the period of emergency rates.

Mayor La Guardia will act as chairman and Jessica Dragonette will personally present gold medals and silver cups tonight at the Center Theatre at the fifteenth annual presentation of awards of the Music Education League.
Premier Edouard Daladier won a vote commending his foreign and internal policy from the executive committee of the Radical Socialist party, which he addressed tonight.

The feast of Corpus Christi will be celebrated today at five minutes past noon in St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church, Barclay and Church Streets, which is 153 years old, with a revival of ceremonies of the European tradition.

Boynton Ave (14-3653) e s. 310 ft s of Eastern Blvd, 189x100; A. F. G. Realty Corp to Boynton Homes, Inc, 18 E 41st St. Shakespeare Ave (9-2506), e s, 313 ft s of 168th St, 84x99; Pendale Realty Corp to Abe Aisenberg, 835 Walton Ave. 138th St (10-2550), s s, 937 ft w of Home Ave, 37x100; Helsac Holding Corp to Harjer Holding Corp, 304 W 89th St; mtg $25,000.

Jim Tobin proved himself a better pitcher than orator yesterday. The youthful Pirate right-hander lost every debate with Umpire Tiny Parker but his salary wing spoke with far more effectiveness as he shut out the Giants with five scattered hits for a 2-to-O victory at the Polo Grounds.

The latest revision of the Revenue Act justifies a suggestion which Dr. Joseph J. Klein, taxation authority, attorney and senior member of Klein, Hinds Finke, certified] public accountants, made in 1918, he told the Metropolitan Controllers Association last night at a meeting in the Roger Smith Restaurant, 40 East Forty-first Street.

For the second time in three days John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, went to the office of the Speaker of the House today to ask that an amendment greatly broadening the scope of the Walsh-Healey Act be brought to the floor for a vote. Speaker Bankhead rejected the plea.

Mrs. Hortense McQuarrie Odlum, president of Bonwit Teller, will present a community center and relic hall to St. George, Utah, her birthplace, during a pioneer homecoming celebration Friday and Saturday.

Clipping a stroke off par on his morning round and equaling perfect figures in the afternoon, little Frankie Strafaci of Brooklyn today set a pace that none of the other 114 contestants in the. qualifying round of the annual metropolitan amateur golf championship could follow.
