The first national convention of the Catholic War Veterans, incorporated three years ago, opened last night with a large military ball attended by 4,000 at the 165th Infantry Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street. The organization has about 200 posts in various parts of the country.

The Federal Maritime Commission had the engines of the Panama Pacific liner California "turned over" yesterday as she lay at Pier 61, Hudson River, preparatory to moving her, probably on Sunday, to the yard of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company where she will be renovated for use in a new South American service.

The design for the East River Drive has been completely changed to provide for a roadway along the waterfront between the building line and the bulkhead line, Walter D. Binger, Commissioner of Public Works, disclosed yesterday at a luncheon of the Park Association of New York City, Inc., at the Claremont Inn, Riverside Drive and 124th Street.

A volume of congratulatory letters from Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia, Senators Wagner and Copeland and other leaders in civic and business life was presented yesterday to John J. Cavanagh, president of the Twenty-third Street Association, at a luncheon marking his first year as president and his tenth as an officer of the association.

Stocks of refined copper in the United States, excluding consumers' stock at plants and ware-houses, were 369,809 tons at the end of May, compared with 355,663 on April 30, an increase of 14,146 tons, the Copper .Institute reported yesterday.

Eric V. Bowater, chairman of Bowater's Paper Mills, Ltd., of England, has confirmed in a letter to stockholders the report that $5,500,000 was paid for the 700,000 shares of common stock of the International Power and Paper Company of Newfoundland, Ltd., formerly an indirect subsidiary of the International Paper and Power Company.

The national infant mortality rate for 1937 was the lowest in the history of the Bureau of the Census, according to preliminary figures announced by Secretary Roper at his press conference this after- due noon.

Politics is no solution for Puerto Rican ills, Miles H. Fairbank, Regional Administrator for Puerto Rico of the Reconstruction Administration, told 260 graduating today at the University of Puerto Rico's commencement.
Eighty-nine Class I railroads had estimated operating revenues of $223,599,685 in May, compared with $287,345,551 in May, 1937, and $376,782,025 in the same month in 1930.

The United States received only $171,763.66 out of $1,891,661,670.39 due today on war debt payments from thirteen European governments. Of the amount received $161,935.50 was from Finland, which paid in full as usual, and $9,828.16 from Hungary, which owed $37,410.66 in a new installment and $457,845.75 in arrears.
COCOANUT GROVE, from a story and screen play by Sy Bartlett and Olive Cooper; music and lyrics by Harry Owens: directed by Alfred Santell; produced for Paramount by George Arthur. At the Paramount.

Miss Jane Howie Arnold, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Douglas Perkins Arnold of this city, has selected the afternoon of July 1 for her marriage to David Jameson Bond of Garden City, L. I. The ceremony will take place here in Westminster Church.
The Rev. Dr. Louis C. Washburn, rector of Christ Church for thirty years until his retirement last year, died of heart disease tonight at his home here. He was in his seventy-ninth year.
Slight earth tremors rattled furniture in Central London today for the second time in five days. Shocks were recorded at 2:35 and 2:40 P. M. No damage was reported. Previous shocks occurred Saturday.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 13: CAPTAIN Woodson, W. B., June 20 to duty as Judge Advocate General, Navy Dept.. Washington: to continue additional duty as Naval Aide to the President, until about July 7.
One of the worst cholera epidemics in modern history has taken 12,000 lives in the past seven weeks in the United Provinces, an area in India's extreme north. Two thousand died in one week.

Twenty old men and women, with an average age of 73, left yesterday for Sunset Lodge, the vacation home for aged persons of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor on the Ward Manor estate in Dutchess County.

Testifying today at the opening of o the trial here of two men he accused of being ransom "chiselers," Murray Levine described to a crowded court room the kidnapping of his 12-year-old son, Peter, in The New Rochelle on Feb. 24 and the recovery of the boy's body eighteen days ago.

There was a general exodus of Americans seeking honors on foreign waters yesterday when the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania sailed with the Yale and Harvard 150-pound crews and W. Melvin Crook of Montclair, N. J., an outstanding motor boat driver, while the French liner Normandie left with Joe Burk of the Penn A. C., national and Canadian single sculls champion.

The Maloney bill providing for the registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission of a national association or associations of brokers and dealers in the over-the counter market to exercise self-regulation under supervision of the SEC was adopted today by the House after delaying tactics had held it back until action was seriously threatened.

Gathering four runs in a fourthinning rally in which free passes played a large part, Haryard today avenged its defeat early in the season by Virginia by subduing the Charlotteville Cavaliers, 9 to 8, in a loosely played game at Soldiers Field.

Tonight Manhattan will be visited for the first time this season by one of the Caravan Theatre's troupes. At Corlears Park "Showing Off," a ten-act variety show, plus "Marriage Royal" will be offered.

A bondsman, who for the last seventeen years allegedly used his business of writing bail for defendants in General Sessions as a screen for trafficking in narcotics, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell to serve three years in prison.

After early weakness here and abroad, the dollar recovered yesterday in the foreign exchange market and the gossip of an impending devaluation died down. Abroad, however, the scramble for gold by hoarders continued.
Upton Sinclair said today that he had abandoned the New Deal as inadequate and gone over to the Progressive party under the leadership of the La Follettes.

Charles Toellner, 44 years old, of 216-11 Jamaica Avenue, Queens Village, a letter carrier attached to the Queens Village Postoffice, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Clarence G. Galston in Federal court, Brooklyn, to a year and a day in a Federal penitentiary.

While the government fought today to d establish the jurisdiction of the United States District Court in the Harlan coal conspiracy case, news was received here that early this morning the home of a prosecution witness, who was excused from testifying, had been dynamited.

Controversy between Councilman Abner C. Surpless and the Workers Alliance flared up again yesterday over the Councilman's charge that he had received a threat that the alliance would picket him if he did not receive a delegation at City Hall yesterday afternoon.
Senator Eugene Raynaldy, former Vice Premier of France and member of two Cabinets, died today of a heart attack. He was 68 years old.

Men's clothing factories in the metropolitan district could swing into full production and employ 35,000 workers within two to four weeks if the WPA takes over surplus merchandise stocks for distribution to the needy,

The twenty-ninth annual commencement exercises of Brooklyn Preparatory School will be held tonight in the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Lafayette Avenue and Ashland Place. A class of 110 members will receive diplomas.

BAKER, MARY E. (June 8). Estate, not more than $5,000. To Marioel T. Andrew, 163 Hancock St., Brooklyn, N. Y., and Sudnie T. Esterbrook, 100 Stratfora Ave., Garden City, L. I., half residue each. Grant Esterbrook, 100 Strauora Ave., Garden City, executor.

While more than 2,000 persons gathered outside, occupants of a twenty-story office building in the heart of the financial district at 50 Broad Street, between Beaver Street and Exchange Place, were locked in during the noon hour yesterday while the police searched the structure in vain for three hold-up men.

Mrs. Mary A. B. Wagstaff, widow of a Civil War colonel, Alfred Wagstaff, who also served in the New York State Senate and as clerk of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, First District, died this morning at the Wagstaff family estate, Tahlulah, at West Islip, a day before her seventy-eighth birthday. She had been ill two months.
To Miss Josephine Roche's "overwhelming central fact" that "with poverty goes not only a higher rate of sickness but a deficiency of medical care," the American Medical Association replies:

Thirty thousand Armenians in the Sanjak of Alexandretta are in a state of panic. They are convinced that their position will be similar to that of the Jews in Germany when Turkish troops occupy the region, which is Low held to be a matter of days.

For the second successive time a performance of ". . . one third of a nation . . . ," the WPA living newspaper play at the Adelphi Theatre, 152 West Fifty-fourth Street, was called off last night when stage hands who are members of an A. F. of L. union refused to work because of the employment of Charles Rosenberg, a sound technician who is a member of a C. I. O. union.
Renewed pressure on railroad loans spread to other sections of the bond list in trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange and sizable losses were registered in some leading issues.

Entries for the yacht race to Bermuda, which will start from Newport next Tuesday, formally closed yesterday with forty-four craft named. Should all get away from Brenton lightship on the sail across the Gulf Stream, it would be a record fleet. There were forty-three starters in the last contest two years ago.

George Winthrop Smith of 10 Park Avenue, a security dealer alleged to have "dominated" the Certified 'Royalties Corporation of 527 Fifth Avenue, was enjoined permanently yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Hammer from further dealings in this State.

Last night they turned on the greatest existing battery of baseball lights at Ebbets Field for the inaugural night major league game in the metropolitan area. A record throng for the season there, 40,000, of whom 38,748 paid, came to see the fanfare and show that preceded the contest between the Reds and the Dodgers.
Leopold (Louis) Oppenheimer, an early operator in chain food markets here, died late Tuesday night at his home at 1,175 Park Avenue, after a short illness. He was 64 years old.

Election of Michael F. Costello of the Rhode Island State Liquor Authority as chairman of the National Conference of State Liquor Administrators was announced today at the final session of the: organization's convention here today.

The quantity of fermented malt liquors withdrawn tax-paid in May was 4,555,773 barrels, a drop of 629,789 barrels from the same month last year, the Alcohol Tax Unit announced today. Stocks were slightly higher at the end of May, amounting to 9,587,868 barrels,

They came early and stayed late for the latest of baseball extravaganzas at Ebbets Field last night, and at $1.10 a person considered it a bargain. Of course, the 3,118 bleacherites lucky enough to get into the park at 55 cents each felt it was an absolute "steal."

The estate of Henry Clay Pierce, financier, rival of John D. Rockefeller for years, and whose Summer home had been used by the late President Calvin Coolidge, is insolvent to the extent of $33,800, according to. a petition of Clay Arthur Pierce of Rumson, N. J., son of the decedent and administrator of the estate.
The eighteenth annual convention of the New York State Branch of the Lady Foresters of America, which closed yesterday at the Hotel Commodore, elected the following officers for the coming year:

The Regional Plan Association announced yesterday proposals for twenty-seven general park areas in the five boroughs that it will recommend to the City Planning Commission for inclusion in the master plan of the city which the commission must draft.

Thomas L. Chadbourne, a leading corporation lawyer, noted for his varied interests and liberal views, died at 6:10 last night of a coronary thrombosis in the Lenox Hill Hospital, Park Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, ten minutes after being brought to the hospital in an ambulance by his wife.

2d Lt. Joseph F. Bivona, Inf.-Res., 1,728 65th St., Brooklyn, N. Y., is relieved from assignment to the 77th Division, and is assigned to the 1st Division. 1st Lt. Richard A. Kast, Dent.-Res., 1,627 Abbott Rd., Buffalo, N. Y., is relieved from assignment to the 1st Division (not eligible for assignment, active duty or promotion).

Representative O'Connor's prediction today that Congress will be assembled in extra session this Autumn to go to the aid of the railroads at first suggests that he should at once visit a psychiatrist.

The amount of open-market commercial paper outstanding at the end of May was $251,200,000, according to the monthly survey of the Federal Reserve Bank, based on reports from dealers, which was issued yesterday.
The diplomatic correspondent of The Times, in an article to be published tomorrow, records the quickened uneasiness here over the fate of former Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg of Austria.

A thousand leaders of the South's cotton industry, meeting here today, voted to weld their common interests into a National Cotton Council, designed to put cotton production and cotton commerce on an equal footing with other industries.
The full horror of bombs raining down on civilian populations is not to be sought in the grisly details from Barcelona, Canton, Alicante.

The strike called Tuesday by the Milk Wagon Drivers Union, A. F. of L. affiliate, against the Grandview Dairy of 60 Metropolitan Avenue, Brooklyn, was settled yesterday, it was announced by Thomas O'Leary, president of the union.

Stockholders' suits supplementing proceedings in New York State courts, seeking the return of assets alleged to have been appropriated fraudulently from the Insuranshares Corporation and Burco, Inc., both Delaware corporations with principal offices in this city, were filed today in Chancery Court here.

Stocks eased and closed steady and mixed after slight early gains; turnover, 344,620 shares. United States Government bonds lower and dull; railroad group weakened; other issues irregular; transactions, $4,567,925.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended June 4 totaled 298,266,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines.

The Republican State Convention this Fall will be held at Saratoga on Oct. 3 and 4, the executive committee of the Republican State Committee decided yesterday-at a meeting in the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street.
The House completed Congressional action today on a bill providing :3,000,000 to establish a wild-life sanctuary and recreation area in he-Adirondack Mountains in New Cork State.
Business today saw Governor Blanton Winship's and the administration's hope of industrializing Puerto Rico largely killed by the island's inclusion by Congress in the Wages and Hours Bill.

Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, Vicar General of the Archdiocese of New York, referred last night to the work of Catholic schools and colleges as "the greatest onward march of the Catholic Church in the past twenty years."

Joseph F. Dunn, from 78th Precinct, to Borough Headquarters Squad, Brooklyn and Richmond. assigned to duty in Felony Court, Brooklyn, for 15 days, from 8 A. M., June 16. James P. Diamond, from 81st Precinct to 18th Division, for 5 days, from 8 A. M., June 13.

Retired Fireman Michael J. Furlong, formerly a member of H. L. Co. 27, residing at Ellenville, N. Y., died June 14. Funeral will take place from Cooke's Funeral Parlor, 347 Willis Ave., Bronx, at 930 A. M., Thursday, June 16.

With the announcement that cash on hand for the advance sale to date exceeded $500,000, and displaying an array of figures to substantiate his statement, Promoter Mike Jacobs yesterday looked forward to his first million-dollar gate when Joe Louis defends his world heavyweight title against Max Schmeling next Wednesday night in the Yankee Stadium, and made plans accordingly.

Politically, economically and socially, the United States may have made many mistakes, but no nation has done a better job for its people, Mrs. Anna Steese Richardson, 73-year-old author and editor, said yesterday in the baccalaureate address at the Hunter College commencement exercises in Carnegie Hall, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street.

Miss Edith G. Park, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Darragh A. Park of this place, was married this afternoon to Alastair Bradley Martin, one of the twin sons of Bradley Martin and the late Mrs. Martin of Westbury, at the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Westbury. The rector, the Rev. Richard D. Pope, officiated.

Heavy profit taking met further upturns in the wheat market on- the Board of Trade here today and resulted in a sharp setback from the top prices. Black rust news still was of an ominous character, advices from Kansas indicating that most of the State was well peppered with the infection.
A vocal concert under the auspices of Irma Swift will take place tonight at Steinway Hall. Nine solo vocalists and a vocal sextet will participate.

Francis G. Slater of Brooklyn has been elected captain of the 1939 Fordham track team, it was announced yesterday by John F. Coffey, graduate manager of athletics, who shortly afterward boarded a train for San Francisco, where he will embark, June 21, for a South Sea cruise.

During the greater part of its session today the House of Commons debated on international trade and kindred matters, and the note struck by the debaters almost without exception was that Great Britain must have a trade agreement with the United States.

Louis M. Strauss of 61 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, a wholesale and retail meat merchant who had been active in Jewish charities, w died on Tuesday night of a heart st attack while visiting at the home cc of his daughter, Mrs. Murray A. Mandel, 417 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 63 years old.

The Goldman Band (Edwin Franko Goldman, conductor) began its twenty-first season of free outdoor Summer concerts last night on the Central Park Mall before an audience estimated at 15,000. Known as the Daniel Guggenheim Memorial Concerts, this series has been the gift of the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation for the last fourteen years.
Leo F. Praeger of Woodmere, N. Y., was found dead in a hotel room today. The police were told that he had complained yesterday of a pain in his head. An autopsy was ordered.

The Guaranty Trust Company put the finishing touches on its move to oust Robert R. Young from control of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway yesterday when its nominees voted out Mr. Young as chairman of the Chesapeake Corporation.

Seven institutions were named among the legatees in the will of Mrs. Tessie K. Frank, widow of Leo E. Frank, filed yesterday. Mrs. Frank, who died at her home at 115 East Eighty-sixth Street on June 4, left an estate formally valued at "more than $20,000."

Miss Catherine Lallande, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Gus Lallande of San Juan and New Orleans, was married to Lieutenant Frank J. Caufield, military aide to Governor Blanton Winship, here this evening in San Augustine Church. The Rev. Leo Clifford performed the ceremony.
The Inland Steel Company of this city announced today that it had reduced the price of galvanized steel sheets $3 a ton, effective at once.

Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Charles Harwood, whose marriage took place June 4 in St. John's Church, Fayetteville, N. C., are now on their wedding trip aboard the Santa Paula on a Caribbean cruise. They will return June 26 to live in Park Lane South, Kew Gardens, Queens.

While a truck driver refused to move his truck so-that Miss Ruth Barofsky, a registered nurse of Dorchester, could drive on to keep an appointment, and grinned as he wondered what she would do about it, she leaped from her car and stepped up to the truck to repeat her demand.

The Senate leadership mustered sufficient strength today to break a filibuster which started last night against the conference report on the $375,000,000 Flood Control Bill, but finally forsook its objective of adjourning tonight in the face of determination by members not to be hurried.
The Buffalo Bisons captured their five-game series with the Jersey City Giants, 3 to 2, by sweeping today's double-header, 6-2, and 10-3.

Judge James F. Fardy of the Superior Court today dismissed a suit brought on behalf of stockholders of the old Central Republic Bank and Trust Company seeking recovery of $8,000,000 from the City National Bank and Trust Company, successor to the Central Republic, and Charles G. Dawes, chairman of the new bank.
Wes Piper shut out the Williams baseball team, 5-0, with three hits today for the invading California nine. California staged a four-run uprising against Huff Hadley in its half of the fourth.

The Three-Arts Festival of the Rockridge Theatre in Carmel, N. Y., will be inaugurated Sunday evening with a recital by Grace Moore, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Association, in a natural outdoor amphitheatre which seats 6,000, adjoining the Rockridge Playhouse.

Former District Attorney Martin W. Littleton of Nassau County, speaking at the annual commencement exercises at Adelphi College here today, urged the eighty graduates to fight against un-American issues and to rededicate themselves to the support of constitutional democracy. Dr. Paul Dawson Eddy,

The extraordinary grand jury's investigation of the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy monopoly, it was reported yesterday, has turned to an interrogation of known gamblers on whether, since 1931, they paid anybody involved in the conspiracy to use influence to prevent their establishments being raided.
A Senate-House conference committee cut a $212,000,000 "melon" for farmers tonight, slicing it, in part, in this way:
At the organization meeting of the New York Financial Writers Association, held last night in the Hotel New Yorker, Elliott V. Bell of THE NEW YORK TIMES was elected president.
As had been expected, yesterday's money turnover incident to the Treasury's refunding and other tax-date operations made no impression upon the money market.
Mrs. Helen Hicks Harb lost her chance of fighting on to a second straight women's Western open golf title when she went down to defeat today in a twenty-hole second-round battle at Broadmoor.

Three Scandinavian Kings and Finland's President-met today in Stockholm for the celebration of King Gustaf's eightieth birthday tomorrow. Norway's King Haakon and Denmark's King Christian arrived on the same train.

A decree levying a State transfer tax of $3,138,372 on the estate of Colonel Henry H. Rogers has been entered in the Suffolk County Surrogate's Court, replacing one that was entered on March 21 and vacated recently because disallowable deductions were made "inadvertently" in the appraisal.

Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches, who recently captured the metropolitan title for the sixth time, led a field of eighty-four starters today in the first round of the women's Eastern golf championship over the Spring Mills course of the Philadelphia Country Club. The only player to break 80.

For the first time in the history of the New York bar, a formal schedule of minimum fees to be charged by lawyers for their services to clients was promulgated in tentative form last night by the New York Chapter of the National Lawyers Guild, at a meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $85,000,000 of securities--$50,000,000 of fifteen-year 2 3/4 per cent debentures due July 1, 1953, and $35,000,000 of serial notes, the interest rate on the notes to be supplied later.
CANADA LOOKS ABROAD, by R. A. MacKay and E. B. Rogers. (Oxford University Press, $2.50.) A study of Canadian policy at home and abroad.

Two home runs helped the Red Sox to a 7-to-4 victory over the Browns today in a game marked by the early departure of Gabby Street, Brownie manager; his starting pitcher, Oral Hildebrand, and Buck Newsom.

The rug business has been hit just as hard by the recession as any other, but Olaf Warnicke is not going toilet his eighty-eighth birthday pass today without giving a party for his thirty-three fellow residents at the Odd Fellows Home, 194-10 109th Road, Hollis, Queens.

EUGENE LENNHOFF'S "Last Five Hours of Austria" * is a far better book than might, under the circumstances, be expected. Usually such hot-off-the-griddle opera, thrown into the market to take advantage of public interest in some particular man or event, are sadly undercooked and overwritten.

The sixty-fifth anniversary of the foundation of the Bushwick Savings Bank in Brooklyn was celebrated yesterday with a reception and dinner for officers, trustees and employes of the institution in the Garden City Hotel, Garden City, L. I.

Industrial diseases have become a national health problem of the first magnitude, in the handling of which physicians have not been and are not now being adequately trained, Dr. Rutherford T. Johnstone of Los Angeles said in an American Medical Association session here today.

With returns as yet far below the $1,000,000 total that President Roosevelt on April 15 said he hoped might be raised for Chinese civilian sufferers from the undeclared war in the Far East, the Red Cross terminated today its drive for a special Chinese relief fund.

Kurt Paehlke, "Emperor of Europe" and head "Guoten," whose purpose was to establish "Aryo-Germanic" rule over the entire world, at least over Europe, and propagate "Aryo-Germanic" stock through polygamy, went on trial before the Koenigsberg Superior Court yesterday for subversive activities.

Columbia University's crewmen were out in full force today for the first time in several days as Coach Hugh Glendon shifted the varsity and junior varsity boatloads in preparation for the intercollegiate regatta on the Hudson, June 27. .

Despite a weak undertone in the general fat cattle market, strictly prime weighty steers uncovered a new high for the season today in selling up to $11.10, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

Bodies of all nine victims killed when a TWA airliner crashed into a mountainside March 1 were brought to Wawona today on a mule pack train which plodded by night through twenty miles of treacherous snow country.

A gift from John D. Rockefeller Jr. of a collection of medieval wood sculpture and Rakka pottery to Cleveland, the city of his birth, was featured yesterday at the opening of an exhibition in the Cleveland Museum of Art.

Ominous red placards that appear on all billboards whenever the guillotine has done its work, announced today that Georg and Anna Schwitzer had been beheaded this morning in grim Ploetzensee Prison after their conviction of treason involving military espionage.

President Roosevelt vetoed the bill to extend low interest rates on Federal Land Bank loans and signed fifty-two other bills passed by Congress. Because of the failure of Congress to adjourn, he canceled his plans to leave at noon tomorrow for Nahant, Mass., to attend the wedding of his son on Saturday and tentatively fixed midnight tomorrow for his departure.

A Smith College senior with practically no tournament experience and a former ranking Californian who has been inactive of recent years ousted two of the favorites from the women's New York State championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club in Queens.

Robert Lax of Olean, N. Y., who recently won the Boar's Head Prize at Columbia College for his poem "The Last Days of a City," won for the same piece of work the Mariana Griswold Van Rensselaer Prize awarded annually for the "best example of English lyric verse" written by a degree candidate, it was announced yesterday.

A class of eighty-six boys will receive diplomas tonight at the ninety-third graduation exercises of Fordham Preparatory School, to be held on the Fordham University campus. Robert T. Stewart will be salutatorian and Walter A. Lynch valedictorian.

The first picture under Claire Trevor's new contract with Warners will be a newspaper story, "Murder for Two Cents," in which she will be featured with Edward G. Robinson and Pat O'Brien. The yarn is by Jerry Wald and Richard Macauley.

John Clinton Gorsuch, one of the founders of the Lancaster, Oxford Southern Railroad and builder of the first gasoline-driven engine for passenger cars, died in his home in West Lancaster last night. He was 81 years old.

With an attack upon national long-range planning and a plea for the ending of "backbiting and invective and class hatred," Dr. James Rowland Angell, former president of Yale University, warned 1,579 graduates of the University of Pennsylvania today that the country now is traveling a road which, if followed to the end, may find it with little left of democracy except the name.

Mr. and Mrs. Hobart Chatfield-Taylor, who had been at the Pierre, have gone to their home, Far Afield, in Santa Barbara, Calif. Mr. and Mrs. Henri Morin de Linclays and Miss Jeanine de Linclays have left the Sherry-Netherland for their Summer home in Oyster Bay.
Donita M., conqueror of colts in the National Stallion Stakes, was back in her class yesterday at Aqueduct and made short work of the fillies in the $4,850 Astoria Stakes.
The report of the Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months to May 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $7,741,520 after all operating expenses, taxes and charges.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 14: COLONELS MacDill, L. (Lt. Col.), Air Corps; General Staff Corps. 2 days' leave, June 17.
The stock market here was quiet and generally firm today. Gilt-edge issues weakened after sharing early strength, while among the foreign bonds Austrian loans improved.

A $194,000 appropriation for further improvement of Flushing Bay as a boat harbor to be used in connection with World's Fair activities was included in the second i deficiency bill passed by the United States Senate yesterday. The bill already had passed the House.

The authorities reported today that troops of the Twenty-first Regiment had encountered, near Altotonga in the State of Veracruz, and killed twelve members of a bandit gang that yesterday held up an army payroll, killing the paymaster and his escort of several soldiers.

The Mexican Government has completed a deal for the sale of 10,000,000 barrels of largely expropriated United States and British oil during the next six months in which sixty per cent of the payment will be obtained in German materials and machinery.

Slow, persistent decline has continued to be the chief characteristic of general business activity in the second quarter of this year, as it was in the first quarter, according to Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, writing in- the company's current business bulletin.
Oscar Vitt's Indians snapped their five-game losing streak today by pasting their jinx, young Kendall Chase, for three eighth-inning runs to top Washington, 6-4, and cling to a half-game league lead.

Col. Gen. Werner von Fritsch, former army chief of staff, was publicly rehabilitated today when "in recognition of his great services in reconstructing the Third Reich's army" Chancellor Hitler appointed him honorary commander of the Twelfth Artillery Regiment in Schwerin.

The annual business meeting of the Society for the Advancement of Management will be held this evening at the Town Hall Club. There will be a dinner at 6:30 and a members' reception to newly elected officers at 9 o'clock.

R. H. Marwin Co, as principals, have purchased first mortgages -of $77,500 on 203-7 10th Ave, Manhattan; $2,500 on 298 Thatford St, $2,400 on 432 Ashford St. $3,000 on 798 E 51st St, $5,500 on 377 E 31st St, $6,900 on 245 Court St. $12,000 on 702 Ocean Ave, Brooklyn, and $2,500 on 680 Park St, Long Beach, L. I.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Winona B. Levitch, daughter of Mrs. Florence Levitch of this city and the late Dr. Samuel Levitch, to Lloyd L. Rosenthal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben Rosenthal, also of Poughkeepsie.

Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer dismissed yesterday a separation suit brought by Major Wilheld Para Kennard of Campbell Hall and a counter-suit for separation brought by his wife, Mrs. Velma Kennard.

Plans have been completed by Miss Amy Eno Cole, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Huntington Cole of this city, for her marriage to Charles Hand Anthony, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Robert W. Anthony of New York.

The John G. Paton Company, selling representatives for a number of advertised grocery brands in this district, has added the branded products of the P. J. Ritter Company, Bridgeton, N. J., to its lines, it was announced yesterday.

Manhattan Alterations 51st St, 605-7 W: to 3-story coffee-roasting plant and repair shop; 605 West 51st Street, Inc, 715 11th Ave, owner; H Ginsborn, architect; cost, $7,000. Lexington Ave. 1,864; to 5-story tenement and store; Joseph Wexler, 1,881 Lexington Ave. owner; same architect; cost, S3,500.

Three new streamlined trains were named yesterday in the Pennsylvania Station. Among those present were former Governor Alfred E. Smith, Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commander of the Second Corps Area, and many Pennsylvania Railroad officials.
The 10,000-ton light cruiser Honolulu, fifth of her class, was commissioned in brief ceremonies yesterday afternoon at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn.

Plans are under consideration by the Mexican Government for establishment of a national cooperative canning industry, but owing to the large cost required for necessary equipment it is not expected anything

Net sales of the Davega Stores Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries increased to $10,744,000 in the year ended on March 26 from $10,365,000 in the preceding years, according to the annual pamphlet report made public yesterday by H. M. Stein, president.

If no permit to operate a beach or swimming pool is displayed, its sanitary conditions in all probability are not satisfactory, C. A. Holmquist, director of the division of sanitation of the State Department of Health, said today.

Jackie (Kid) Berg of England, attempting a comeback as a welterweight, was held to a draw by Augie Arellano of Harlem in the star attraction of eight rounds at the Queensboro Arena in Long Island City last night. A crowd of 2,000 was present. Berg weighed 146, two pounds less than his adversary.
Francis N. Silvestris has purchased for occupancy the two-family dwelling at 40 West Forty-sixth Street, Bayonne, N. J., from Anette Hinton throught J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker.

Colonel and Mrs. Royal E. Trumbull Riggs of Gay Hill, this place, and New York, gave a buffet luncheon and garden party at their home here this afternoon for a group of wives and daughters of members of the Society of the Cincinnati, whose triennial convention is being held in New Haven.

It was a case of thirty-six holes behind him, thirty-six holes ahead of him and Ray Mangrum beside him as Ralph Guldahl, the national open titleholder, reached the halfway mark in his quest for a third consecutive Western open golf championship today with the gangling Dayton, Ohio, pro sharing the lead.

John Van Alstyn Weaver, poet, playwright, novelist, and more recently, writer of dialogue for moving pictures, died last night in his forty-fifth year. He had been under treatment for tuberculosis since coming here from Hollywood a few months ago.

ALLAND--Abrum, June 15, beloved husband of Tillie Alland and devoted father of Frank. Services Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1,283 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, at 1 P. M., today. Interment Montefiore Cemetery. BARGAR--On June 14, 1938, Irene P., beloved wife of Willard E., devoted mother of Audrey P. and George W. Bargar. Interment Baltimore, Md.

Kenneth Tucker, 6 years old, son of Harland Tucker of 90 Caryl Avenue, and a chum, Daniel Stem, about the same age and whose family also lives in the same apartment house, were playing on the roof of the house tonight, when the Tucker lad fell six and a half stories, landing on a fence.

Prolonged official criticism of the inadequate and disorganized supplying of consumer goods and food products to the population was followed today by an extensive shake-up in the Commissariat for Internal Trade that entailed the summary dismissal of seven important executives.

The Italian motorship Conte di Savoia will arrive today from Mediterranean ports. Among her passengers are the Hon. and Mrs. Percival de Saint Aubin, Leon Leonidoff, Mr. and Mrs. A. De Jardin, the Right Rev. Victor Rameau,

Brig. Gen. Walter Campbell Short, United States Army, assumed command yesterday of the First Infantry Brigade and of the First Division, United States Army. General Short took up quarters at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn.
In its closing session this morning at the Book Cadillac Hotel, the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association continued its attack on radio.

A delegation representing 10,000 Canadian Jews was told today by T. A. Crerar, Minister of Immigration, that Canada would send representatives to the international conference called by President Roosevelt to deal with the plight of Jewish and other refugees from European and other countries.
With consuming patience, a crowd of 5,000 Chicagoans waited a long time for the White Sox to give them something of a run for their money at Comiskey Park today.

Non-governmental agencies today applied for approximately 80 per cent of Great Britain's pound 80,000,000 national defense loan, part of the government's vast rearmament financing program. Banks, insurance companies and industrial concerns were heavy subscribers.

The six-story Kendal Court apartment house at 521 West 111th Street and the five tenements at 607-15 East Fourteenth Street were among the seven Manhattan parcels sold at auction in the Vesey. Street rooms yesterday. One other parcel was withdrawn.

Deacon Danny Macfayden gave up five hits, all singles, today as he pitched the Bees to a 2-to-0 victory over the Cubs. Not a Cub passed first base as Danny won his sixth victory against two defeats for the year. He fanned three and walked only one.

ON THE ROCKS, a play in two acts by George Bernard Shaw: directed by Robert Ross; settings by Edwin J. Schruers; supervised by James R. Ullman; produced by the Federal Theatre Project. At Daly's Theatre.

Friends of the frog will be distressed to learn of his unhappy status in Arkansas. The North Arkansas Sportsmen's Association has set forth his plight in a resolution addressed to the State Game and Fish Commission. ...

Materialism, defined as "the ambition to make man something without God," is "palpably idiotic," the Very Rev. William J. McGarry, president of Boston College, told 7,500 graduates and their friends at Fordham University's ninety-third general commencement in the Quadrangle yesterday.

The special Federal grand jury that has been investigating the activities of German spies since May 16 completed its work yesterday. and took an adjournment until Monday, when it will probably hold a final session to vote indictments.

Pressure by industry, particularly the steel and aluminum fields, is choking off distribution, cutting down employment and widening the disparity in prices, Thurman Arnold, assistant attorney general charged today,

After deliberating only fifteen minutes, a jury in Kings County Court returned a verdict of not guilty yesterday in favor of Albert E. Castle, 56, of 329 East Twenty-third Street, Brooklyn, head of the concrete contracting company bearing his name, who had been on trial before Judge George W. Martin for allegedly bribing an inspector of the Finance Department in connection with work performed on a public school yard at 590 Sheffield Avenue, Brooklyn.
The seventh annual commencement exercises of Yeshiva College will be held at 4:30 P. M. today in the auditorium of the college at Amsterdam Avenue and 186th Street. Dr. Paul Klapper,

British Minister Guy H. Bullock and Andre Roosevelt, American photographer and explorer, ascended Mount Cotopaxi, 19,613 feet, the highest active volcano in the world, yesterday. The peak is thirty-five miles from Quito, where Mr. Roosevelt, distantly related to the President, makes his home.

In line with its recent policy extending the merit system to the higher salary brackets, the Board of Education announced yesterday that the first competitive examination ever to be held for the position of assistant director of music in the New York City school system would take place early in Fall.

The failure of Congress to adjourn today caused President Roosevelt to cancel plans to leave Washington at noon tomorrow to attend the wedding of his son John on Saturday at Nahant, Mass., and tentatively to fix midnight tomorrow as the hour of his departure.

Miss Jeanne Alexandra Edgar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Arthur Edgar of this place, was married to Roberts Harrison today in the Church of the Redeemer here. Canon Ernest C. Earp performed the ceremony.

Without committing himself concerning policy, Secretary Wallace reminded his press conference this afternoon that the Agricultural Adjustment Act grants the Administration authority to subsidize the export wheat.
All retiring directors were reelected at the annual meeting of stockholders of the George A. Fuller Company. Walter Sievers was appointed assistant cashier of the Bank of the Manhattan Company.

After almost two days of rough-water investigation, we are satisfied that there are broadbill swordfish in the Gulf Stream 130 miles off the New Jersey coast. The broadbill are there, but they seem to be completely disinterested in any bait you offer.
Ralph B. Marean, retired secretary to Winthrop M. Crane of Dalton and previously to his father, the late Senator W. Murray Crane, died last night. He was 63 years old.

" I will positively defend the championship in the United States next September if I defeat Joe Louis next Wednesday night." In this emphatic manner did Max Schmeling speak today in response to the question he probably has been asked more times than he has shaken hands since his training sessions got under way here almost a month ago.

A collection of twenty pictures assembled by the late Philip de Laszlo, the portrait painter, was sold for pound 510 at Sotheby's today. Two Cassome panels of the Florentine school of about 1450 brought the best prices.

Thousands of public employes throughout the country may have to pay back taxes, interest and penalties for twelve years as a result of the recent Supreme Court decision that employes of the Port of New 'York Authority must pay Federal income taxes, according to Commissioner Howard S. Cullman, vice chairman of the Port Authority.

A health insurance program for high school boys and girls, by which the students are to receive limited medical, dental and ophthalmic services by paying 50 cents a year into a general fund, will be introduced here next Fall, it was learned yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Jane Willis, daughter of Mrs. William Willis of 210 East Sixty-eighth Street, formerly of Flushing, Queens, and the late Mr. Willis, to Robert Van Cleve Whitehead Jr. of Trenton, N. J., will take place on June 25 in St.
Falling into the easier half of the draw, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody tonight became a 5-to-2 favorite to win the greatest women's Wimbledon tennis tournament of a decade.

The marriage of Mrs. Beatrice Constant Dorsey of 729 Park Avenue, daughter of Mrs. William Sinclair Constant of New York and the late Mr. Constant, to Walter Rumsey Marvin Jr. of this city and Larchmont, N. Y., took place yesterday noon in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

J. Edward Jones, oil specialist whose difficulties with the Securities and Exchange Commission led two years ago to a rebuke for that organization from the United States Supreme Court, retells his story and charges "persecution" by the New Deal in a book, "And So They Indicted Me," published this week.

In its editorial on the Remington-Rand case THE TIMES maintains its almost perfect score of misunderstanding the Wagner act. After referring to the Labor Board's order that the company must reinstate the strikers, displacing if necessary the strikebreakers hired during the strike, the editorial asks:

Thousands of fan letters, telegrams and telephone communications have been received by Mayor Frank Hague as a result of his testimony in the C. I. O. injunction proceeding in Federal court before Judge Clark in Newark, according to officials at the City Hall here.

The sixty-six men and women who received their Doctor of Medicine degrees yesterday at the fortieth annual commencement of the Cornell University Medical College were advised to shun automobiles, girls and the motion pictures during their interneship.

James G. McDonald, acting chairman of the American group that will participate in the international conference to facilitate the emigration of political refugees from Germany, received-last night the Professor Albert Einstein Medal for Humanitarian Services.

W. N. Clark, president of the Southern Colorado Power Company, announced yesterday that a special meeting of shareholders will be held soon for the purpose of reducing the stated capital represented by the Class B common stock of the company and charging against the capital surplus created by such reduction the following items:
A contra-seasonal increase in daily average electric power production last week lifted the adjusted index to 90.8 from 89.4. The figure was 107.2 for the week ended June 12, 1937.

Simon Elmore, recently convicted for the second time of the murder. of 4-year-old Joan Kuleba last August, was sentenced yesterday to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing Prison the week of July 24.

226th St, 761 E. dwelling. 25x100; Home Owners. Loan Corp against Antonio Russo; due, $10,647; adjourned sine die. Hone -Ave, 3,029, dwelling. 50x100; Home, Owners Loan Corp against Aniello Gismondi; due, $7,044; taxes, etc, $94; to plaintiff for $500.

Pierre Louis Dreyfus of Paris, France, a partner in Louis Dreyfus Co., and Merrill D. Guild of Fairland, Ind., manager of the Indiana Grain Cooperative, Inc., have been elected members of the Chicago Board of Trade.

The finely laid plans of leaders for final adjournment of Congress before midnight went awry today when a five and one-quarter hour fight in the Senate over the conference report on the $375,000,000 Flood Control Bill prevented the scheduled "clean-up."
A quickly subdued disturbance in a relief office today brought a warning from Fred W. Ramsey, city welfare director, that "trouble-makers" would be deprived of all aid.
The constitutionality of the Minkoff rent-control measure, recently adopted by the State Legislature, has been upheld in a decision just handed down by Municipal Court Justice Keyes Winter.
Five persons were wounded, four seriously, this morning, when a man, believed to be an Ethiopian, ran amuck in the center of Rome laying about him furiously with a scimitar.

Two young, well-dressed men, one of them armed, held up Mrs. Margaret Reinig, 50 years old, widow of a patrolman, in her second-floor apartment at 281 Dean Street, near Nevins Street, Brooklyn, yesterday at 3 P. M., tied her up with torn sheets in jackknife fashion, with a slipnoose about her neck, and escaped with rings and jewelry valued at $500 and $9 in cash.

The directors of the Canadian Industrial Alcohol Company, Ltd., have asked its stockholders to indicate whether they would favor a resubmission of the proposal to exchange shares of their company for those of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd.
The General Slocum Survivors Association held its annual memorial services yesterday in Lutheran Cemetery, Middle Village, Queens, with 1,000 persons attending.

When Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City resumed the witness stand for the third day before Judge William Clark in the United States District Court in Newark yesterday, Dean Spaulding Frazer, chief counsel for the plaintiffs, renewed his direct examination.

Demands that there be no extension of the present 2 per cent tax limitation and the 10 per cent debt limit for New York City were presented to the Constitutional Convention today by the Real Estate Taxpayers Federation, a newly formed alliance comprising most of the principal real estate and taxpayers' organizations in the city and many in other parts of the State.
Miss Katherine Maxine Alcott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Alcott, became the bride yesterday of Baron Gustav Wedell Wedellsborg of Hillerod,near Copenhagen, Denmark.
A sentence of eighteen months to three years in Sing Sing was imposed by General Sessions Judge Donnellan yesterday on Malcolm E. Kennedy, 38 years old, of 119 Andover Road, Rockville Center, L. I.,

The trial of Stanley Scott, captain of the British merchant ship Stancroft, was adjourned today until Friday to enable the court to decide whether the charge against him of carrying war materials into Spain shall be dismissed, as the defense pleads.

9th St, 426 E, 25x93.11: Thomas Loudon to Bobalice Limited, 19 W 44th St, care Hirsch Islon; mtg, $34,794 ($1). 7th St; 60 E, 25x100; Central Savings Bank to Modern Realty Co, Inc, 302 W 13th St ($22); Henry L. Minck, pres, gave back p m mtg for $20,000 and nbuilding loan mtg for $3,500; both due on demand at 4 per cent.

Miss Joan Baldwin Folinsbee, daughter of John Fulton Folinsbee, landscape painter, and Mrs. Folinsbee of New Hope, Pa., was married this evening to Peter Godfrey Cook, artist, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Cook of Kingston, N. Y.
At the end of the conference Wage-Hour Bill, now accepted by both chambers, appears a sentence that was not to be found in either the Senate or House version of the bill:

Spain's partisans in Puerto Rico have been banned from broadcasting over station WKAQ. In his final broadcast Dr. Antonio Colorado, a University of Madrid graduate, charged that the station's action worked the greatest hardship on the Loyalist cause and the democratic principles expounded by President Roosevelt because the bulk of the island press is dominated by the Rebels through Spanish merchants' advertising.
Bob Feller kept the Indians a half-game ahead of the winning Yankees today by scattering eight blows for a 4-1 victory over the Senators. It was his seventh decision of the season.

The treasury Procurement Division tolay announced the award of concracts for a total of 54,807,300 yards of textiles for complete shipment Sept. 1. It was the largest single textile purchase the division ever made.

Southern Spain today celebrated the feast of Corpus- Cristi, which General Francisco Franco decreed an official holiday. Banks, shops and factories were closed as workers had a holiday on full pay, which is a new experience for the majority, but employers were forced to comply with the new decree.

The golf team of the Bond Club of New York and other members of the club will be guests today at the sixteenth annual field day of the Bond Club of Philadelphia at the Philmont Country Club, Philmont, Pa.

Broadening activity in the solicitation of employee groups for contributions to the Greater New York Fund was reported yesterday by James G. Blaine, chairman of the consolidated $10,000,000 campaign for the health and welfare organizations of the city.

The Guaranty Trust Company leased to Alfred Michel for occupancy the three-story dwelling on a lot 17 by 100.11 feet at 249 West 103d Street. Slawson Hobbs were the brokers. The Bank for 'Savings leased to Albert and Ann Sullivan Borah the four-story dwelling at 321 West Seventy-sixth Street.

All will be quiet tomorrow on the Potomac. There will be no thwacking of the Speaker's gavel, no buzzing in the corridors, no droning in the committee rooms, not even any conferences in smoke-filled hotel rooms.

Securities with a face value of $700,000 but of undetermined value, owned by Insuranshares Corporation, were removed to Wilmington, Del., a few days before Vice Chancellor Charles M. Egan appointed a temporary receiver to assume control of the company's assets in New Jersey, it was discovered this morning when Morris Bernhard, the temporary receiver, called at the office here to take charge of the properties.

107th St, 315 W, 4 5 story dwenin?? 20x100.11; George F. Bauerdorf, against Eleanor Babcock; due, $21,124; taxes, etc., $2,412; to plaintiff for $9,000. 6th Ave, 972-4, 2 4-story lofts, 49.5x62.6; House of Holy Comforter against Louise C. A: Wieners; Due, $51,319; taxes, etc., 5,948: withdrawn.

unionport Rd (15-4256), n e cor of Sagamore St, 125x100 ft; Louis Katz to A. M, Management Corp., 1,450 Bway; mtge, $168,400. Radcliff Ave (15-4266), n w cor of Rhinelander Ave, 90x75 ft; Workmen's Mutual Fire Insurance Society, Inc., to Avpol Realty. Inc., 274 Madison Ave.

Protest from Catholic organizations followed the opening of the Walter Wanger film, "Blockade," which deals in a veiled manner with the subject of internal war in Spain, at the Radio City Music Hall yesterday.

While the preliminary advertising and promotional plans on floor coverings for the Fall season reflect caution on the part of producers, there is some belief that the coming season will see some sales improvement over the first half of the year. Should this prove to be the case, it is expected that budgets would undergo corresponding revision.

Commencement activities began at Wheaton College today with the annual senior class house party at Manomet, which will continue through tomorrow afternoon. The program opened with a luncheon, at which the speaker was Professor Ralph P. Boas, head of the English Department.

John T. Parker, listed by the United States Customs Bureau as "staff officer," but better known to his friends and acquaintances along the city's longshore miles as "commodore," brought in his last ship yesterday, and after closing his desk at the government barge building at South Ferry bid goodbye to the life of a customs inspector.

Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, former Health Commissioner, who is now president of the Children's Welfare Federation, joined Mayor La Guardia yesterday in opening the organization's eighth annual drive to send poor children to camps for two weeks in the Summer.

The dollar weakened again in foreign exchange yesterday and the scramble for gold in London on the part of hoarders fearing currency devaluations continued. There were only the stale rumors of a coming reduction in the gold value of the dollar and in the dollar value of sterling to account for the renewed pressure against the dollar.

Establishment by the class of 1913 of a lectureship in political economy, to be filled for the next two years by Dr. Oskar Morgenstern, Austrian savant, has been announced by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University.

The proposed monopoly investigation recommended by President Roosevelt became a fact today when he approved a joint resolution by Congress establishing a twelve-member committee to carry on the work and appropriating $500,000 to finance it.
Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury, widow of the financier, denied today published reports that she had discharged sixty-two servants at the Stotesbury residence, Whitemarsh Hall.

More than 2,500 youngsters, including parents and music teachers, filled the Center Theatre last night for the Music Education League's fifteenth annual presentation of awards, and enthusiastically applauded the two and one-half hour program of music which was supplied by the winners.
Former United States Senator Joseph S. Frelinghuysen announced yesterday he had decided not to run I for Republican nomination for the United States Senate in the September primary in New Jersey. Mr.

Mrs. Marie Willmott, 27 years old, of 371 Vanderbilt Avenue, Stapleton, S. I., committed suicide at 5:45 o'clock yesterday afternoon by jumping from a window of her sixteenth floor room at the Forrest Hotel, 224 West Forty-ninth Street.. Her body was found on the roof of the Forrest Theatre adjoining, eleven stories below.

The raising of an American flag on the top girder of the fifteenstory Associated Press Building yesterday marked the completion of steel work on this new unit in Rockefeller Center. In twenty-nine working days more than 6,000 tons of steel were riveted into place, approaching the record set in the construction of the Time and Life Building, also in Rockefeller Center.

Mrs. Elizabeth Huckel, 77 years old, wife of the Rev. Dr. Oliver Huckel of Claremont Avenue, New York City, former pastor here for seventeen years, suffered lacerations of the forehead and contusions of the left side when she fell down a stairway last night at the home of Mrs. Charles D. Lanier in Rock Ridge.

Lance Corporal Norman George McDowell of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, stationed at the door of Canada House today for the first time, was surrounded by a large crowd blocking the entrance, seeking autographs and taking photographs.

Engineering construction contracts awarded this week fell off sharply from the corresponding period of last year, according to The Engineering News-Record. The total of all contracts is $29,187,000, a drop of 64 per cent from the 1937 figure of $80,380,000.

The Alabama Supreme Court affirmed today the death sentence of Clarence Norris, "Scottsboro case" defendant. Death in the electric chair for the Negro, one of nine originally arrested on charges of attacking two white women on a freight train in 1931,
A decrease of $4,336,000 in Dominion Government deposits was shown today in the Bank of Canada's statement for the week ended yesterday. Deposits of chartered banks increased $3,219,000.

In one of the largest realty deals reported in the Gramercy Park section of Manhattan in several years, a realty investing company has acquired the sixteen-story apartment houses at 60 Gramercy Park North and 112-20 East Twenty-second Street, and the ten-story house at 102 East Twenty-second Street, from Clement E. Merowit.

Track and field stars will fight it out for individual and team honors in the National Collegiate A. A. meet tomorrow and Saturday at the University of Minnesota. Authority for a statement that a team picked from the field "would have better than an even chance" of winning an Olympic meet is Lawson Robertson of Pennsylvania, who coached the American Olympic teams in 1928 and 1932.

Edouard Herriot, President of the Chamber of Deputies, had to suspend today's sitting twice when arguments and insults over the Spanish War situation became so hot as to threaten a free-for-all fight.

Between 8,000 and 10,000 officers and men of the "lost" Forty-third Division have crossed the frontier into France, ending the division's historic resistance. These men were blasted out of their positions in the Bielsa pocket by a continuous bombardment in which fifty Insurgent planes took part.

No sacrifice is too great to save China, Shanghai Chinese say in discussing the Yellow River flood, and the writer has yet to find a single Chinese who is perturbed over the prospect of the widespread suffering and death over the North China plain that a serious flood would bring.

CONSCRIPT EUROPE, by Randolph Leigh. (Putnam, $3.) A study of conditions in recent years in Italy, France, Germany and England. DEATH tAKES A DIVE, by Eric Heath. (Hillman - Curl, $2.) A mystery novel.

Gardner Read's "Sketches of the City" and Werner Josten's "Symphony in F" have been chosen for publication by the Juilliard School, it was announced yesterday. They were the winners in the annual competition for an American orchestral work to be published at the school's expense, all fees from sales and performances to go to the composer.

Although a late filibuster by Senator Burke, Democrat, of Nebraska, prevented the Senate's grant tonight of $12,500 of additional funds to the Senate Lobby Committee, alleged to be for an investigation of the press, Senator Minton, Democrat, of Indiana, the committee chairman, ended the hour's adjournment-delaying debate with the threat that the committee "may do it anyway."

Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan ran into stiff opposition yesterday when he sought to -have the Board of Estimate authorize at least one free admission to the World's Fair for every child in the city of school age.

Line Material Company new common stock, $5-par value, has been admitted to unlisted trading on the New York Curb Exchange, in substitution for the old no-par stock, which has been removed from unlisted trading.

Miss Peggy Lashanska Rosenbaum, daughter of Mrs. Harold A. Rosenbaum of 550 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Rosenbaum, was married yesterday afternoon at Sherry's to Peter Gerald Lehman, eldest of the three children of Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman.

Small receipts featured all branches of the livestock trade today. Hogs gathered price momentum from the small run, and top went back to $9.30 with 290-325-pound butchers at $8.65$8.85, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

Miss Mary Anne Vietor, granddaughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. George F. Vietor of New York, and George Draper Arthur Jr., greatgreat-grandson of Stephen Allen, who was Mayor of New York from 1821 to 1824, were married here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. The ceremony was performed by the Right Rev. John T. Dallas, Bishop of New Hampshire.

The third and final session of the Seventy-fifth Congress adjourned sine die early tonight. The Senate quit at 8:23 P. M., locked in a last-minute, openly announced filibuster led by Senator Burke, Democrat, of Nebraska, against a grant of new funds to the Lobby Investigating Committee.

Speaking on behalf of Great Germany, Economics Minister Walther Funk today formally repudiated in principle any legal, economic or moral responsibility for the Austrian Government loans. But he also declared Germany's willingness to negotiate a practical settlement with the powers guaranteeing these loans, "in a spirit of understanding and with the aim of reaching an adjustment in their mutual interests."

William Watson Smith, counsel for the Aluminum Company of America, charged yesterday that Walter L. Rice, special assistant attorney general, who is seeking an injunction to enjoin the company and its affiliates from alleged violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust; Law, was trying to testify for a witness whom he had on the stand before Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey.

John H. Mason, chairman of the reorganization committee of the Peyton Realty Company, Philadelphia, has notified holders of Southeast Corner Sixteenth and Walnut Streets first mortgage bonds of C. Benton Cooper guaranteed by the Peyton Realty Company and second mortgage bonds of the company,

Charles C. James, consulting accountant and member of Stevenson, Jordan Harrison, management engineers, was elected last night as president of the Society for the Advancement of Management at the society's annual business meeting at the Town Hall Club.

Miss Sabiha Gueukschen Honoum, one of President Mustafa Kemal Ataturk's adopted daughters, who distinguished herself as a volunteer in the Turkish air force during the Dersim trouble last year, left Istanbul today on a good-will flight to Balkan capitals.

Mayor niagues light against Line admission of Communists and radicals into-Jersey City was characterized last night as "the battle of the century" by the Rev. Matthew J. Toohey of Newark, New Jersey State chaplain of the Catholic War Veterans. The veterans' organization, which was established three years ago, is holding its first national convention, with 713 delegates present, at 14 East Sixtieth Street.

Congress approved a $12,000,000,000 spending program-the largest in America's peacetime history for the fiscal year beginning July 1. Appropriations experts at the Capitol said tonight it would take a week to figure out exactly how much the money bills totaled, but that the figure probably was about $12,300,000,000. That compares with the $9,356,174,982 appropriated in 1937 and $10,560,833,165 in 1936, the previous peacetime record.

Proudly displaying new streamlined dress, the Twentieth Century Limited of the New York Central System and the Broadway Limited of the Pennsylvania Railroad arrived here this morning, easily completing on time their new sixteen-hour schedules from New York.
Andrea Leeds, who attained prominehce in "Goldwyn Follies" and "Stage Door," will be given her first starring role with Gary Cooper in "The Last Frontier, Samuel Goldwyn announced today.

Robert Underwood Johnson, poet, editor and one-time Ambassador to Italy, left a net estate of $12,929 when he died Oct. 14, according to a transfer tax app lisal filed yesterday. The principal asset of the estate was the equity in his residence at 327 Lexington Avenue, appraised at $10,000.

An investing client of Elgin Shulsky, attorney, has purchased from the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn the two five-story apartment houses at 1,741-3 and 1,745-9 Pitkin Avenue, on the corner of Osborne Street, Brooklyn, for cash above a pur- ar chase money mortgage of $61,500.

Possibility of a general advance in fur prices in July was reported here yesterday in a survey of market conditions made by the City Stores Company. The report pointed out that labor will receive an increase of $5 per week from July 1 to December, and from all indications "skin dealers will tighten up on prices."
The Senate voted a fund of $500,000 today to be used to investigate "misuse" of Federal funds to influence elections in any State where a Senator is to be elected in November.

About 5,000 members of the Children's Dressmakers Union, engaged in piece work, were granted vacations with pay, yesterday, under a decision of Dr. Paul Abelson, impartial chairman of the industry. This is the first instance when workers of this type have received paid vacations.

The Board of Estimate adopted a resolution yesterday imposing on every outside omnibus using city streets a fee of $20 a year for those holding thirteen or fewer passengers, and a $30 fee for those holding fourteen or more, in addition to a mileage fee equal to one cent a mile of bus operation in the city.

Former President Hoover said here during a stopover on an air trip from New York to Chicago that he would take an active part in the Fall campaign. Asked during the interview last night if he would speak for Republican Senatorial, Gubernatorial and congressional candidates, he replied, smiling: "I undoubtedly will."

Calling State -domination of education a "social calamity," Dr. Paul Kiapper, president of Queens College, speaking at the Yeshiva College commencement exercises yesterday, declared that the privately endowed educational institution holds an important place in the American democracy.

Frank H. James, vice president and treasurer of the Hat Corporation of America, was elected president of the Hat Institute at a meeting of that organization yesterday at its offices, 358 Fifth Avenue. He replaces George L. Russell Jr., vice president and treasurer of John B. Stetson Company.

John J. McManus, who asked for a court ruling declaring him to be an employe and not a member of the bankrupt firm of Richard Whitney Co., withdrew that petition and was examined yesterday before Referee Irwin Kurtz as a member of the firm.

BARRY--On Thursday, June 16, 1938, Charles E., husband of the late Dora Havey Barry. Services at Havey's Funeral Home, 107 North Broadway, Yonkers, Saturday, at 11:30 A. M. Interment,Poughkeepsle Rural Cemetery.

Continuing her fast pace, Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches, women's metropolitan titleholder, shot another 76 for a total of 152 and took a seven-stroke lead as the second round of the women's Eastern fifty-four-hole medal play golf championship was concluded over the Spring Mills course of the Philadelphia Country Club today.

On June 13 Captain Walter Chandler introduced into the House a bill to change the name of the dam to be constructed by the TVA near Pickwick Landing, Tenn., and hitherto known as the Pickwick Landing Dam, to McKellar Dam "in recognition and commemoration of the services rendered in behalf of Tennessee Valley by Senator McKellar of Tennessee."

Officials of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation are. negotiating with European banking interests for financing to take care of part of the company's 1939 bond maturity amounting to $37,511,100, it was learned yesterday.

Mme. Jacques Allez and Charles A. Munn have sent out invitations for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Frances Drexel Munn, to George F. Baker of New York and Locust Valley, L. I., on July 9 in Trinity Church, Roslyn, L. I.

The Jewish Labor Committee, repesenting 400,000 organized Jewish workers , at 13 West Sixteenth Street, ratified last night an agreenent for joint action by four naional Jewish organizations, of which the committee is one, on all matters affecting the defense of ewish civil and political rights. The other three organizations are he American Jewish Committee, he American Jewish Congress and B'rith.
Miss Laura W. Drummond, who has been director of home economics at Temple'University, Philadelphia, will become Professor and Director of Home Economics at the Pennsylvania State College July 1.

The suspension this week of five officers of the United Automobile Workers Union by the executive board and their citation to appear for trial may be regarded as a "showdown" in the union's determination to put an end to the activities of "all irresponsible and disruptive groups," Homer Martin. president of the U. A. W. U., decleared yesterday.

Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard indicated yesterday that he doubted the fairness of a plan proposed by the Interstate Commerce Commission for the reorganization of the Louisiana Northwest Corporation. "I can't say," Judge Goddard said, "that a plan is fair when the control of a railroad is given over to a competitor."

Completing an inquiry into the trade practices of customs brokers, W. H. Mahoney, manager of the foreign trade bureau of the Merchants' Association, yesterday issued a statement in which he defended the fees they charge and paid tribute to the high ethical standards prevailing in the profession.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for June 29 on applications by the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration twelve securities.

One of the measures which died in the last hours of the sessoin was the Wiretapping Bill. The measure, in the form of an amendment to the 1934 Communications Act, already had passed the Senate and yesterday the House attached an amendment and sent it back to the Senate, which adjourned without acting on it.

Formation of a re-employment committee was announced by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Representatives of twenty member firms have agreed to serve on the group, which is headed by Robert P. Boylan of Clement, Curtis Co. It will try to obtain positions for unemployed financial workers in other lines of work, if necessary.
From the final hours of the session of Congress which ended last night there emerge a few pictures which ought to be of interest to the average voter. One of them is Mr. John L.

The engagement of Miss Natalle Hays Hammond, daughter of the late John Hays Hammond Sr., internationally remembered mining engineer, to Captain William H. Waters, New York steamship executive connected with the French line. was announced today.

Stocks closed firmer at irregularly higher levels after drifting; turnover, 342,200 shares. United States Government bonds closed strong, rails weakened, other groups irregular; transactions $1,858,300

Close coordination of bank examination a and investment policies with the f national monetary policy was urged today by Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, in a letter to Senator Vandenberg of Michigan.

Following is the text of the more important parts of the address of Economics Minister Walther Funk at Bremen today, dealing with international economics and Austrian debt: International discussions regarding world economic events show lately the same general tendency, namely, fear of a new, grave world economic crisis.

A new bronze tablet bearing the names of 151 French Huguenots who founded New Rochelle after their flight from religious persecution in La Rochelle, France, was unveiled this afternoon on a knoll at Hudson Park, overlooking Long Island Sound. Members of the French diplomatic service attended the ceremony.

Republican leaders of the Constitutional Convention are understood to have decided to have the Bill of Rights Committee report out, without recommendation, the Hirschberg amendment, which would remove the constitutional ban on gambling.

Mrs. Elizabeth Stone Mead, widow of Judge James Rodwell Mead, died in Kingston, N. Y., this morning. Mrs. Mead, a former resident of Greenwich, was born in Brooklyn eighty-five years ago, the daughter of Thomas Stone, wellknown contractor and builder.

Ward Kremer, refunding agent for the city, announced today that the amended refunding plan drawn by Mayor Clarence E. F. Hetrick and members of the. City Council was in operation following its approval by holders of more than 85 per cent of the municipality's securities.

Plans for public financing by the Crucible Steel Company of America in the form of a medium-sized bond issue will be considered by the board of directors on June 22. Negotiations for the loan have been started with bankers.

The Workers Alliance, which obtains its funds from home and work relief recipients here, has pledged itself to raise $625 to pay for the return to this country of five Americans wounded while fighting with the Loyalist forces in Spain.

During the week ended June 15 member bank reserve balances increased $56,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $17,000,000 in money in circulation and $70,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve

Negotiations of a trade agreement as a means of ending discriminatory treatment toward American goods in the Argentine and as a move in forestalling the reported plan for imposing an import quota system in that country,

King Gustaf's supposedly stolid people today abandoned their stolidity for a day to accord -him on his eightieth birthday a triumph such as it is permissible to suppose few rulers before him have ever had in these latitudes.

The process of eliminating Jews from participa- dikes wo tion in German commerce, finance and business entered its final stage chine mu today with the announcement of a "We to series of decrees and ordinances, which were at once put into effect. They virtually spell attrition for Jewish economic and business activities of every sort.
A new modern major league record was established and another tied .today in a torrid game which gave the Red Sox a sweep of their series With the Browns. The score was 12 to 8.

Young men eager to satisfy Park Commissioner Robert Moses's demand for lifeguards who can swim vied with one another in practical tests yesterday at Jacob Riis Park, where a strong undertow and pounding surf occasionally turned a candidate into a subject for lifesaving technique.

A funeral service for Thomas L. Chadbourne, noted corporation lawyer, will be held at 11 A. M. today in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street. Mr. Chadbourne died on Wednesday night at the age of 66.

Sherman Realty Co, Inc, sold to the F. J. H. Realty Corporation, Harry Appleman, president, the premises on the east side of Clinton St, 125 ft north of Rivington St, 75x100, for an indicated consideration of $28,000 over a first mortgage for $35,000, taking back a purchase money mortgage for S15,500, due Feb. 1, 1944, at 5 per cent.

The marriage of Miss Phyllis Goodhart, daughter of Howard Goodhart of 2 East Fifty-fifth Street and the late Mrs. Goodhart, to John Dozier Gordan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordan of Norfolk, Va., took place yesterday afternoon at the St. Regis. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent, rector of St. Bartholomew's Church.

Captain Increase A. Parsell, Westport resident, died in Bridgeport Hospital this morning after a short illness. His age was 84. He was one of the last captains operating produce ships between Southport and New York.

More than half of the total cost of the Wilson, Norris and Wheeler Dams of the Tennessee Valley Authority should be allocated to power production, President Roosevelt was told today by the TVA directors in a report which he sent to Congress as provided by law.

The Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company asked Federal Judge Oliver B. Dickinson today for permission to close five unprofitable mines and dispose of undeveloped lands on which there is an annual tax of $1,000,000.
The weather of the next forty-eight hours was looked upon by Japanese Army engineers today as holding the fate of vast territories of North and Central China as yet undamaged by floods.

Correcting a previous report, the Pennsylvania Railroad informed the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that it had paid enginemen and trainmen for 75,256,573 miles which they did not run in 1937.

About a third of the increase of outstanding credit of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City which took place a week ago as a result of operations connected with the Treasury's quarterly financing was wiped out this week, it was shown in the condition statement of the banks issued yesterday.

John Jarrott, who died at Bellevue Hospital Tuesday night, was identified yesterday as the former vaudeville actor and dancer of that name. Suffering from bronchial pneumonia, Mr. Jarrott had entered the hospital under the name of John Garrett.
Fifty WPA employes started today to uproot and burn several acres of marijuana weed which had been found growing about 200 feet from County Road, west of Tonnele Avenue, here.

Secretary Morgenthau declared before Temple University seniors today that the "major task" confronting the country was to get "our economy- to function on an even keel so that all who are able and willing to work can -find outlets for their creative energies."

In view of the existence of what David Lloyd George called Great Britain's "slum empire" in the House of Commons Tuesday, Germany in a semi-official pronouncement offers in effect to take over the part of the white man's burden in the colonies that seems to be beyond the British strength.

State and city officials who have been invited to a dinner next Thursday at the Hotel New Yorker by the newly formed "New York for New Yorkers League, Inc.," have tried in vain to ascertain the names of. the backers of the organization, it was learned yesterday.

Mrs. Bennie Teabeaut Candler of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. D. Benjamin Teabeaut of Cuthbert and widow of William Candler, was married here this morning to Howell Ross Hanson of Ardmore, Pa., in the Candler Theological Seminary of Emory University.
Sixty students of the Straubenmiller Textile High School will "manage" the Hearn department store on Saturday, June 18. They are all members of a class in merchandising and salesmanship.
