The Treasury settled today for $124,519 a $613,562 deficiency claim against the 1931 income tax of the Electric Bond and Share Company of New York City and its nineteen affiliates.

Fourteen new school buildings, providing seats for 22,240 pupils, will be opened officially this Fall, the Board of Education announced yesterday. This will be-the largest number of buildings to be opened at one time since 1930, board members said.

Satisfied Joe Louis is at his peak for the defense of his title next Wednesday against Max Schmeling in the Yankee Stadium, his managers, John Roxborough and Julian Black, today cut the titleholder's sparring to four rounds. Ji And, with a crowd of 1,105 looking on, Louis stepped briskly over the route.
The President's historic feat in regaining control of a balky Congress in the middle of his second term and during a growing depression is a political miracle.

A long-range program for a separate rapid transit system for commuter traffic throughout the metropolitan area and for a series of interconnecting belt lines to facilitate the operation of trunk line railroads is included in a report to be submitted to the City Planning Commission tomorrow, the Regional Plan Association announced yesterday.

Two international officers of the United Automobile Workers of America and twenty-two members of the union were arrested by police of suburban Dearborn today when they attempted to distribute literature at the gates of the Ford Motor Company's River Rouge plant. Mrs.

Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for separating the Hotel Victoria, northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Fiftyfirst Street, and the adjoining Victoria Annex by erecting a dividing wall.

Four men-of-war are due in New York Harbor today-three American vessels and one French escort ship. The American ships, the battleship Arkansas, commanded by Captain William H. Pashley, senior officer of the three ships,. and the c destroyers Roper and Tillman, will steam to an anchorage in the Hudson opposite Fifty-ninth Street about 8:30 A. M. for a day's stay.
Surging from behind with three-run rallies in each of the seventh and eighth innings, Jersey City registered a 6-to-5 decision over Montreal in the first game of their series today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES'S recent editorial "For Better Motion Pictures" damns with faint praise an important and much needed measure, the Neely-Pettengill bill for the abolition of compulsory block-booking and blind selling of motion pictures.
An other in the weekly series of $100,000,000 Treasury bill offerings was announced tonight by Secretary Morgenthau. Bids for the ninetyone-day bills,

Mrs. Ethelyn Friend Middleton, writer, newspaper woman, lecturer and former actress, died on Wednesday at the Los Angeles home of her daughter, Mrs. Theodore Stearns, wife of the composer, according to word received here yesterday. Her age was 71.

A charge of juvenile delinquency against Liborio Ferrarella, 15 years old, of 2,229 West Seventh Street, Brooklyn, in connection with the fatal shooting on May 13 of his playmate, Frances Ciambra, 17, of 2,239 West Seventh Street, Brooklyn, was dismissed yesterday by Justice Rosalie Loew Whitney in Children's Court, Brooklyn.
" Mr. G.," as he is known on the tennis courts, was 80 years old yesterday. He is even more widely known as Gustaf V, King of Sweden, the Goths and the Wends.
Facts long suspected and widely rumored about the detention of Baron Louis Rothschild by the new Nazi administration of Vienna are revealed by The Daily Herald this morning.

Harmony became the keynote of the General Council of the Congregational and Christian Churches at its biennial meeting today when a mediation effort to prevent an outbreak of the differences between Roger W. Babson, Moderator of the church, and his opponents in the national body appeared to be temporarily successful.

Observers predict a modification of the Japanese attitude toward the Soviet Union shortly, basing their predictions on the imminent conference between Foreign Minister Kazushige Ugaki and War Minister Seishiro Itagaki.

A meeting of investment dealers from all parts of the country will be held on next Monday at the Wall Street Club to confer with commodity experts on the future for commodity prices, it was announced yesterday by Hal F. Lee, vice president of the sales

" Itinerant" merchants operating in this resort only during the Summer henceforth must pay a mercantile license fee ten times that of allyear-round business men under provisions of an ordinance enacted by the City Commission today.

Every one of Britain's 12,000,000 women, aged between 17 and 65, were called on today to join in civilian defense against air raids. They are to be enrolled in the new organization of Women's Voluntary Services and will serve as air raid wardens, nurses, motor drivers and in other capacities such as arranging for the reception and care of refugees from evacuated districts.

A great "clinch" putt 20 feet along a sidehill for a birdie on Broadmoor's deceptive first green earned Mrs. Opal S. Hill, Kansas City veteran, a 1-up, 19-hole, victory over Miss Patty Berg in the women's Western open golf tournament today.

A General Sessions jury in the sixteen-week trial of two women and nine men in the alleged $2,000,000 Slovak Manor land fraud conspiracy was locked up for the night shortly after 11:30 o'clock last night when it had not agreed on a verdict. Judge Cornelius F. Collins, who had turned the case over to them at 5:20 o'clock in the afternoon, directed court attendants to take them in a bus to the Commodore Hotel.

A banking group headed by the Bankers Trust Company obtained yesterday $1,699,000 of relief and funding bonds of Worcester. Mass., on a bid of 101.129 for 1 1/2s. The bonds, dated July 1, 1938, and maturning serially on July 1, 1939 to 1948. will be reoffered today at prices to yield from 0.25 to 1.45 per cent according to maturity.

Germany's attempts to spread her political ideology in Latin America by means of short-wave radio broadcasts not only are proving ineffective but are "backfiring" to the distinct disadvantage of that country, Frank E. Mason, vice president in charge of the National Broadcasting Company's

Business methods of the labor union in the fur industry were attacked by several speakers at a meeting in the Hotel Governor Clinton last night of the recently formed Independent Fur Manufacturers Protective Association, Inc.

Granting an application for a reorganization of the Reynolds Investing Company, Inc., under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, Federal Judge Guy Fake ordered late this afternoon that control of the concern must be vested in a new board of directors which will function at the direction of the Federal court. Hearing on the application started here on Tuesday.

The Buckingham Community model garden apartment colony at Arlington, Va., which has attracted wide attention because it embodies new ideas in community planning and construction work, has a new manager.

Petitions protesting the reported plan to award an honorary degree to Governor A. Harry Moore of New Jersey at the Princeton commencement Tuesday, because of his close association with Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City and his long affiliation with the Hague Democratic machine, were circulated today on the campus.

The close of the third and final session of the Seventy-fifth Congress showed a fairly wide range of important legislation enacted, even though its work did not begin to compare with the larger legislative program of the first session. A summary of the -principal measures adopted, their intent and effect is presented below:

Tommy Bridges limited the Athletics to six hits and struck out eight today as the Tigers gained a 12-to-3 decision for their only victory of the threegame series. Bridges batted in three runs to help win his fourth game of the season.

An abrupt rise in wheat carried The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices up two-tenths of a point to 80.7 in the week ended on Wednesday. The figure compared with 80.5 the week before and 92.2 a year ago. Cotton and silk also moved forward.

Representative Wearin, recently defeated for the Democratic Senatorial nomination in Iowa, said at the White House today that he would not be a candidate for reelection to his present office. Mr. Wearin said that he had come to the White House "just to pay my respects to the chief before I start for the farm."

The North German Lloyd Steamship. Company's report for 1937 said today disturbed world economic conditions had been reflected in the company's business for that year. Wars in China and Spain and the economic crisis in the United States hampered the company's business in various ways, the report said.
Satella S. Waterstone, a founder of the Hedden-Waterstone private school in Orange and composer of children's songs, died yesterday at her home here, after a week's illness.

H. Hentz Co. will open today a branch office at the Nautilus Beach Club, Atlantic Beach, L. I., under the direction of Emile Z. Weinberg. The City Bank Farmers Trust Company, trustee, has asked for tenders for the sale to it by June 29 of sufficient Paramount Pictures, Inc.,

Greenwich St, 55, 34.1/2x40.1?xirreg; racing on Trinity Place, 33.4 1/2; Battery and Trinity Place Realty Corp, Constantine G. Command, president, to Abraham B. klein, 170 Broadway. Canal St, s w cor Eldridge St, 125x75; Morris Levison, et al, to 86 Canal Street Corp, 94 Canal St, mtg $180,000, consideration $500.

Omnibus-operating corporations in the State are to appear before the Public Service Commission on June 28, when Commissioner George R. Lunn will begin an inquiry to determine whether they should be required to adopt uniform rules for redemption of unused tickets.

All but three of the stars invited to appear in the Princeton meet Saturday were on hand today, but workouts were light. Josef Mostert, Belgian miler, put in the only strenuous session on Palmer Stadium's lightning fast track.
Upon recommendation of the synod president, the United Lutheran Synod of New York today deferred for one year action on a revision of church policy concerning marriage, divorce and sex education.

Operations of Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., and all subsidiary companies in the three months ended on April 30 resulted in a net profit of $830,882 after deductions for expenses, interest, provision for depreciation, loss on investments, estimated losses by floods and income and profits taxes, according to a report issued yesterday.

With Monte Pearson and Irving (Bump) Hadley combining their pitching talents to record a one-hitter and Herr Lou Gehrig embellishing the performance with his ninth homer of the year, the Yankees swept majestical ly over Monty Stratton and the White Sox today to bag the final of their series, 5 to 1.
Joseph H. Berke, teacher of commercial subjects at Central High School, Newark, for the last nineteen years, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home here. His age was 45.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey expressed strong approval last night of a proposed amendment to the State Constitution designed to provide "appropriate judicial supervision of wiretapping." The proposed amendment was drafted by Supreme Court Justice Harry E.
On foreign speculators in the exchange market, denials by Secretary Morgenthau and now by the President himself of any plan for further devaluation of the dollar, seem to make no impression.

Miss Patricia Woolsey of New Haven, daughter of Mrs. Theodore Salisbury Woolsey, was married this afternoon to Lionel Stewart Jackson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Day Jackson, also of New Haven. The wedding in Christ Episcopal Church was performed by the Rev. William C. Woods of Kent School and the Rev. C. Clark Kennedy, rector of the church.

End ing a two-day duel with Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City on the witness stand in the Federal Court this afternoon, Morris L. Ernst, C. I. O. counsel, charged that the Mayor's policy of suppressing constitutional guarantees for Communists and similar "undesirables" was a "denial of Americanism"

With to America's finest five-gaited saddle horse geldings competing, Five Star Final, owned by the Trillora Farm of Shrewsbury, N. J., annexed the blue in a spirited competition at the nineteenth annual Troy horse show today.

Trading still slow, although slaughterers getting some action on steer hinds and ribs and lamb carcasses. Fresh pork business also improved. The lamb market was about 50 cents higher; fresh pork cuts steady to slightly higher; cow weak to slightly lower; veal weak to lower; other classes unchanged.

Apartment houses in the Bronx proved attractive to investors in deals reported yesterday. An investor bought from the Romaras Realty Company the sixstory apartment house for sixty families at 2,251 Sedgwick Avenue, near Fordham Road, in a deal negotiated by George Lodes, Inc., broker. The property is assessed at $170,000.
Fire, believed to have started from a short circuit in a defective wire, did damage estimated at $10,000 to the south villa of- the San Alfonso Retreat House, 765 Ocean Avenue, here, today.

After a week of negotiations, a threatened strike of 1,400 employes of the Long Island Lighting Company, which provides gas and electricity for about 750,000 residents of Nassau and Suffolk Counties and part of Queens, was averted early this morning with the signing of an agreement between union officials and representatives of the company.

TIME was (sub regno Coolidge) when Europe was held up to America as a pretty glorious example. The expatriates wrote back on thin blue paper from the rue de l'Universite to explain why they could never return to this land of vulgarians, who didn't know the first thing about the leisurely art of living.

Ralph Victor Wechsler, real estate lawyer and former deputy county clerk in charge of the Bureau of Naturalization, died Wednesday at his home, 575 Park Avenue, after an illness of several months. He was 55 vears old.

After winning his first match in defense of his metropolitan amateur crown with the greatest of ease, Willie Turnesa, recent recipient of a sheepskin at Holy Cross, had to play the west nine holes of the Ridgewood Country Club at a twounder-par clip this afternoon to squelch young Dick Ciuci, former Long Island champion.
Strong resentment was expressed unofficially in British Government circles today at Economic Minister Walther Funk's speech repudiating Austrian loans, though there was no official reaction.

Commencement exercises of the New York Institute for Education of the Blind will be held at 2:15 P. M. today in Schermerhorn Hall at the institute, 999 Pelham Parkway, the Bronx.

The American Medical Association expressed its determination today to stand pat in its present attitude toward socialized medicine. That attitude, which is that neither governmental nor lay bodies should be permitted to take over administration of medical care under any plan,

The annual convention of the American Newspaper Guild agreed today after several hours' argument on a compromise proposal to curb the power of smaller Guild locals to call a referendum on policy matters.

Contracts for two more supertrawlers for General Foods Corporation's "college fleet" have been awarded to the Fore River plant of the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation, Clarence Francis, president of General Foods, announced yesterday.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday that he had asked the city to draw up white-collar projects to give employment to 15,000 additional WPA workers here.

In anticipation of the arrival next month of the first trade commissioner from India to the United States the newly formed India Chamber of Commerce of America installed yesterday its first officers at a meeting held in the Aldine

Fifteen striking barbers, members of the Barbers and Beauty Culturists Union, invaded a barber shop at 119 West Thirty-third Street yesterday while five chairs were occupied by customers and forced the barbers at work to follow them into the street and enter a taxicab.

The government today suspended regulations calling for the use of 20 per cent corn flour in bread and issued a substitute order that wheat flour henceforth be 20 per cent coarser. The use of corn flour had been ordered to conserve wheat as a result of this year's poor crop. ...

Mahieu Costumers, Inc., theatrical costumes, in 242 W. 55th St.; Tankoos, Smith Co., brokers. Borden Co., in Terminal Warehouse, 11th Ave. and 27th St., through John Avlon; Mead Novelty Co., in 225 5th Ave., through Frederic R. Tibbitts, Inc.; Knepper Management Corp., real estate, in 10 E. 40th St.; Marquette Mfg. Co., in 1,841 Broadway; Prescription Shoe Service.

The United States Maritime Commission has offered for sale or charter, under competitive bidding, the Amercan Republics Steamship Line and ?ts fleet of ten vessels, plus the pas?enger liners Virginia, Pennsyl?ania and California, the last to be ?he nucleus of the new service which will be started about Sept. 1 Between New York and the East roast of South America. Bids are returnable July 15.
This column is unshakable in its belief that all this talk of President Roosevelt as dictator is nonsense.

It's getting to be a habit. For the second day in a row the Giants were held to five hits by a Pittsburgh pitcher, Bob Klinger dealing them out in the same parsimonious fashion yesterday at the Polo Grounds that Jim Tobin had used the day before.

Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Reid of 55 East Ninety-third Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margery Reid, to Richard Bolles Paddock Jr., son of Mrs. Anne Cunningham Paddock of 46 Hamilton Place, this city, and of Colonel Richard Bolles Paddock of Chicago.
Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, asserted today that the Federal capital loss and gains tax had failed to produce over a period of years any governmental revenue.

Five matches providing activity for most of the poloists who will participate in the Meadow Brook Club's coming tourney for twenty-goal teams were staged on fields in this vicinity today, with victories by Templeton and Greentree among the highlights.

Since no one expects Hollywood to take sides, Walter Wanger's "Blockade," which is the first fiction film to deal at all seriously with the Spanish civil war, is not to be damned for its failure to mention Loyalist and Rebel, Franco or Mussolini.

The following Marine Corps changes dated June 15 were announced today: COLONEL Lee, S. S., Navy Yard, New York, N. T., about June 23, to command the Marine Barracks, Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, Va.

Cardinal Hayes presided last night at the thirty-first commencement of Cathedral College, the preparatory department of St. Joseph's Seminary at Dunwoodie. The exercises were held in the auditorium of Cathedral High School at 562 Lexington Avenue. Mgr. Michael J.

The Senate marked adjournment day by overriding a veto of a bill carrying what amounts to a $48,700,000 gift to farmers. It followed the lead of the House and thereby made the bill a law without the consent of the President. The vote was 57 to 18.

The Senate today adopted, without send ing to conference, the Maloney bill as amended by the House, and the measure, which provides for registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission of a national association or associations of brokers and dealers in the over-thecounter market, will become law when signed by the President.

The Rev. Richard Gilson Koontz, a retired Methodist Episcopal clergyman, died yesterday at his home at the the age of. 65. His last pastorate before retirement was at Stone Chapel. Surviving are his widow, Mrs. Beulah Benson Koontz; a sister, Miss Mary Koontz of Baltimore, and a daughter, Mrs. George Edward Noland of Spartanburg, S. C.

The New York Housing Authority, created about four years ago to carry out low-rental apartment projects and slum clearance, received its first direct financial assistance from the Federal Government yesterday-a check for $375,000 from the United States Housing Authority.

The Permanent Court of International Justice has given out the text of its judgment, rendered Tuesday, dismissing the plea of the Italian Government in its case against the French Government relative to prospecting for and exploiting phosphates in Morocco.

Leeds Mitchell, a partner in Winthrop, Mitchell Co., a large investment securities firm, announced today that on July 16 the house would close its branch offices in Davenport, Iowa; Rockford, Ill.; Milwaukee and Minneapolis.

Joey Fontana, 129, Bensonhurst, received the decision over Jimmy Lancaster, 129, Wilmington, Del., last night in the feature eightround encounter at the Fort Hamilton Arena before a capacity crowd of 5,000 persons.

Four hundred Fordham seniors last night attended the annual senior ball of the Bronx and Manhattan divisions at the Hotel Astor. George R. McKnight, chairman of senior week, and Edward S. Mortola, chairman of the ball, supervised the evening's events. On the committee were Vito F. Nole, Michael C. Di Fabio,
Miss M. Belle Kilgour, head librarian at Kearny Public Library since 1910 and a widely known lecturer, died today at her home here, following a brief illness.
Senator William H. King of Utah startled the Senate today by bluntly suggesting that the United States sever diplomatic relations with Japan i. protest against the conduct of the war in China.
Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain told the House of Commons today the British Government was ready to cooperate on the subject of disarmament.

Jewish women were asked yesterday by Mrs. Harry H. Tracey, vice chairman of the Greater New York women's division of the United Palestine Appeal, to follow the example set by Italian women during the Ethiopian War and give up their wedding rings, if necessary, to help establish a Jewish national homeland in Palestine.

Miss Rosemary Webster, 21-year-old debutante 'daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David H. Webster of New York City and Stamford, Conn., forsook a $1,000,000 inheritance, today to marry Paul Gilson, 23-year-old bookkeeper in the St. Lawrence County Welfare Home and son of a Canton (N. Y.) tailor.

Professor Paul Langevin, French scientist and member of the Academy of Sciences, has been elected president of honor of the American Society of Biophysics and Cosmobiology, it was announced yesterday. In accepting the election Mr.

A four-acre estate on the Saw Mill River Road, Worthington, Westchester County, known as the Mamie Mount property, has been sold to the Simcam Holding Corporation through Gerety Blackwell, Inc., brokers.
Claude Passeau pitched a six-hit game today and the Phillies defeated the Cardinals, 3 to 2. Relief Pitcher Max Macon's wildness in the eighth inning, after Starter Bill McGee had been
The State Public Utilities Commission ordered the Pennsylvania Railroad today to cancel a proposed change in Summer schedules between Philadelphia, Camden and Bay Head Junction.

Max Silverman, industrial racketeer who recently was convicted of conspiracy to obstruct justice by "fixing" the Samuel Drukman murder case, was sentenced yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Erskine C. Rogers in Brooklyn to serve one year in the county penitentiary and pay a fine of $500.

Herbert Smith, "grand old man" of British mine workers and known to hundreds of Yorkshire miners as "Our Herb," died today at his desk in the headquarters of the Yorkshire Miners Association in Barnsley at the age of 77I.

The WPA Federal Theatre Projects's most successful production, one-third of a nation was closed indefinitely last night by WPA officials after A. F. of L. stagehands refused to work for the third consecutive night because of the employment of a sound technician who is a member

None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low figure for the year. Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury."

With the legality of the Council investigation of relief still in doubt yesterday, Chairman Joseph E. Kinsley of the Council Finance Committee drove the opening wedge Into the relief situation by asking Welfare Commissioner William Hodson to appear before his committee in City Hall on Monday at 1 o'clock to answer questions about relief.
The clan Roosevelt converged on this sea-surrounded town tonight to attend the wedding Saturday of the only unmarried son of the Presidential family, John Roosevelt.

The House as it moved toward adjournment tonight approved the conference report on the $270,000,000 Second Deficiency Bill after turning down to Senate amendments on which the conferees had failed to agree. It recessed at 7:10 P. M. for the second time during a long day of speech-making and voting

Henry Behan, a tall, well-dressed and self-assured man of 43, who was described in the police line-up yesterday morning as an "outstanding jewel thief," was sent back to Sing Sing later in the day charged with violating his parole by marrying and changing his residence without permission, of the Parole Board and by assuming an alias.

A definite stand against fiber identification was taken yesterday in a resolution adopted by the executive council of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board at the conclusion of its three-day convention at the Hotel Astor.

Orders for Fall shoes, following the shows at Boston and Cleveland, have run substantially ahead of expectations of manufacturer, it was said yesterday, and cutting of Fall numbers will begin in about two weeks. While producers had expected a fair amount of size assortments this week,

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders to. day, dated June 14: CAPTAINS (MEDICAL CORPS) David, A. B., 15th Naval District, to Naval Hospital, San Diego, Calif. Heiner, R. G., Portsmouth, Va., to navy yard, Boston, Mass.

Movements or vessels follow; all dates are June 16 unless specified: Southern Philippines to Bangkok: Alden, Barker, June 15; Paul Jones, Whipple. Southern Philippines to Manila: Canopus, Pigeon, S-36, 37, 38, 39, 40 and 41. Southern Philippines to Tourane: Parrott, Stewart.

J. Stewart Baker, chairman of the Board of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, was re-elected president of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York at the annual dinner-meeting held last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Nearly one hundred members of the foundation, representing the five city boroughs, were present.

Judges for the composition contest held by the Silvermine Guild Music Festival Association have been announced as follows: Hugo Kortschak, John Adam Hugo, Donald Tweedy, Howard Barlow, Edward Kreiner, Victor Biart, Samuel Gardner and Philip James.

Miss Bessie May Wald, daughter of Captain and Mrs. George Wald, was married yesterday to Lieutenant Norman Lester Tittle, who was graduated Tuesday from the United States Military Academy, West of Point. The ceremony was held at the Officers' Club at Fort Totten.

Mrs. Henry Dietrich of the Green Meadow Country Club, present champion of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association, won low gross prize today in a one-day tournament of the association over the course of the Greenwich Country Club. She shot an 82.
Counsel for Herbert B. Turner, artist, upheld his client's judgment today as Mr. Turner's widow and three daughters attempted to void A will which left them $103.

Lady Muriel Paget, who for many years devoted herself to welfare and charitable work in various foreign countries, particularly in Russia, where she eased the hardships of distressed British subjects, died in her sleep here last night. She was 61 years old.

The names of sixteen students at City College who will be graduated next Wednesday evening at the ninety - second annual commencement exercises were announced yesterday by Dr. Frederich S. Robinson, president, as winners of prizes and awards for outstanding scholarship.

A series of Summer concerts to be known as "Pops Concerts" will begin Sunday afternoon at the Federal Music Theatre, it was announced by the WPA Federal Music Project. The "Pops" will be given Sunday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday afternoons, with extra programs on Sunday evenings also.

Curtis High's nine gained the final of the city P. S. A. L. senior high school championship by turning back Morris High, ManhattanBronx winner, 8- to 2, at Sisco Park, Port Richmond, S. I., 'yesterday. Jimmy McCarron, winning twirler, allowed only six hits and fanned seven.

The West Side Building Corporation, L. F. Gambardella, president, has leased from the Savings Investment and Trust Company the plot on the southwest corner of Main and Washington Place, East Orange, N. J., for a long term at an aggregate rental of about $300,000.

While Gold Flag captured the featured Yellow Tail Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday with Scrooge and Jockey Sammy Renick in third place, it was of Renick that many of the horse players were talking last night, for he finished with a triple on the day.

Three high school students who rescued drowning persons last year were among fourteen recipients of medals and cash awards yesterday afternoon on the floor of the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street. The Lifesaving Benevolent Association, through Henry L. Satterlee, president, presented the awards.

Herbert I. Losee, duplex terrace apartment in building under construction at 965 5th Ave; Kensington Estates, Inc., owner. J. Frances Thomas. Mrs. Alberta H. Pond, in 41 5th Ave, Robert M. Larimore, in 130 E 19th St, Dr. William Bolt, through Sharp Nassoit, in 26 E 10th St; Wm. A. White Sons, brokers.

One of the chief problems facing industry in the United States is the adjustment of the "attitude" between employers and employes along lines that will end strikes and controversies, Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association of New York, declared yesterday.

Close of play scores in English first-class cricket matches started today follow: Somerset, 290 and 159 for four wickets (F. Lee 81 not out, Gimblett 47); Essex, 308 (Waterman 70 not out, Smith 53, Wade 51, Wellard six wickets for 124); at Chelmsford.

Completion of reorganization of the Standard Gas and Electric Company under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act moved a step nearer today when the company asked the Federal court in Wilmington, Del., to authorize election of a new board of directors to take over the company.

Sickness and an accident today hit the Navy varsity and junior varsity crews, giving Coach Buck Walsh the task of revamping the boats during the training period on the Hudson prior to the Poughkeepsie races.

Lumber production increased last week and on a daily average basis showed a contra-seasonal gain. The Adjusted index rose to 62.1 from ?0.1. The figure was 95.9 for the week ended June 12, 1937. Last week's index, at 60.1, was unchanged from the preceding week.

S. M. (Steve) Crothers of Chestnut Hill won the Double A class trapshooting championship of Pennsylvania today by breaking 150 consecutive targets at the Brinton Lake Club. Cecil D. Wolf of Washington took the Class A title with a similar score.

The Marchesa Delle Chiuse, who passed the Winter and Spring at the Ambassador, will sail tomorrow on the Conte di Savoia to be in Europe for the Summer. Miss Eleanor M. Mellon, who has been at Mayfair House, will leave today for her Summer home at Gloucester, Mass.

We had word yesterday of a real angling accomplishment. Frank O'Brien of Miami, Fla., fishing Tuesday at Guaymas, Mexico, took a 218-pound marlin on a six-ounce tip, nine-thread line and using a 4-0 reel.

Virginia outscored Yale, 8-2, today largely through Al Stevens's ten bases on balls, forcing in five runs and allowing seven tallies in less than three innings. Dudley Humphrey, his successor, issued no passes, held Virginia to three singles and a single run in the remaining six innings.

No disaster in China's history can compare with the war, flood, disease and famine in that country today, the Rev. Robert Jacquinot de Besange, Jesuit priest of Shanghai, declared here yesterday on the eve of the nation-wide "bowl of rice" parties to raise relief funds for Chinese civilians.

Railroad bonds were sold down to new low levels yesterday with many representative issues in the group touching the lowest prices in their history, in somewhat more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Holders of rail obligations,

Horses from the stables of many leading Westchester and Connecticut exhibitiors will participate in the ninth annual Bronxville Riding Club Horse Show to be held at the club's grounds on California Road in Tuckahoe on Sunday.

Senator Prentiss M. Brown of Michigan was appointed today by Senator Barkley, major ity leader, to be chairman of the- Democratic Senatorial campaign committee. The first choice for this post of the Senators facing re-election was Senator Harrison of Mississippi, but he declined.

The Lawrence Gas and Electric Company, Lawrence, Mass., has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering $1,500,000 of first mortgage bonds due in 1968, the proceeds to be used to redeem a similar face amount of 41/2 per cent bonds maturing in 1940.

The greatest finisher in golf painted his masterpiece today as big Ralph Guldahl left a birdie and eagle trail along the final eighteen holes for a sixunder-par 65, a four-round total of 279 and his third straight Western open championship.
With Buddy Rosar rapping out four safeties and seizing the International League batting leadership, the Bears today chalked up their seventh consecutive victory by downing Rochester, 11 to 3.

Although bank clearings in this city increased over the volume of the preceding week and that of the 1937 comparative period, declines at all other cities were so large that the week's total for the entire country failed to reach that of the preceding year.

Miss Vivien Frances Lauer, daughter of Theodore Andrew Lauer of this place, was married here tonight in the Central Presbyterian Church to Lieutenant George William Rhyne, who was graduated on Tuesday from the United States Military Academy at West Point.

The first defeat of Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, former world chess champion, was the outstanding result of the sixth-round play in the international masters tournament today. Paul Keres of Estonia was responsible for the setback of the schoolmaster, one of two representing The Netherlands.
One hundred soldiers of the Sherwood Foresters Regiment were sent to Jamaica on the cruiser York today to reinforce the troops at Jamaica.

Along toward the middle of July, Brian Doherty, who transformed "Father Malachy's Miracle" from a book into a play, will be completing a new comedy, it was learned yesterday. Unlike the show that introduced him to Broadway, this one will be neither an adaptation nor religious in background.

Wheat traders took a little soberer view of the crop damage reports today, and, while the general tenor of advices was no less bullish than recently, selling was more aggressive, and it was more difficult to enlist outside buying support.

Ireland's general election campaign came to a close tonight and the electorate in the twenty-six counties will go to the polls tomorrow. Although there has been no lack of talk, the campaign has been singularly free of strife. The fact that there are no big national issues to stir popular imagination is mainly responsible for the absence of any great excitement.

An advanced course in the coaching of football will be given at the Summer session of Columbia University from July 6 to Aug. 13, it was announced yesterday. Coaches Richard C. Harlow of Harvard, Andrew Kerr of Colgate and Lou Little of Columbia will assist in conducting the course,

Overcoming the desire of Henry H. Curran, Deputy Mayor, for a one-week delay, Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, obtained the approval of the Board of Estimate yesterday for a $23,000,000 plan for the elimination of grade crossings along Atlantio Avenue between East New York, Brooklyn, and Jamaica, the depression of the Long Island Railroad tracks and the elimination of all local stations except that at Woodhaven Junction.
After declining for three consecutive weeks, business in the Pittsburgh district advanced substantially last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

Jacob Roth, banker, real estate man and former vice president of .Roth Co., wholesale and retail meat concern which had more than 100 stores in five States, died yesterday at his home here after an eight-month illness. His age was 72.

Free time hereafter will be given for radio discussions of the Spanish civil war. The time will be divided equally between government and rebel speakers, the radio corporation of Puerto Rico announced tonight following the discontinuance of commercial programs devoted to Loyalist and Insurgent causes.
F. B. Geddes of Scarsdale today won the fourth annual tournament of the Westchester Seniors Golf Association at the Westchester Hills Golf Club to take the title for the third year in succession.
Sales of securities in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on June 11 exceeded purchases by 9,299 shares, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Active dealings in the new British Governmentdefense loan imparted a firm tendency to the stock markets today. Business was on a small scale except in the gold section, where the rush to buy gold against the dollar continued.

From a serious discussion held under the spreading honey locust tree on the lawn of the J. Louis training quarters here today, the conclusion drawn by this tourist is that Herr Max Schmeling is training to fight Shufflin' Joe Louis, but Shufflin' Joe is simply getting ready for a prize fight.

A wedding of interest to society in this city and Chicago took place yesterday afternoon when Miss Beatrice Farnham Kunhardt was married to Samuel Alexander Culbertson 2d in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. The rector, the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent,

Sales of dwellings and flats in Harlem figured in Manhattan realty activity yesterday. Several of the buyers intend to modernize their properties. Bert Evelyn bought for occupancy the three-story brownstone house at 364 West 120th Street from Ernest M. Sekunna.

It wasn't a. case of "caveat emptor" (let the buyer beware) when the Cardinals sold Dizzy Dean to the Cubs, because it appears the buyer was warned. Dean's sore arm has given rise to rumors that Owner Phil Wrigley of the Cubs will try to recover part of the $185,000 purchase price if the pitcher's career is ended.

Winthrop D. Lane, director of investigations of the New Jersey Juvenile Delinquency Commission, announced today his resignation, effective June 30. In a letter to Mayor Benjamin F. Turner of Passaic, chairman of the commission, Mr. Lake requested that he be relieved of his duties because of a teaching engagement at the University of Chicago and to permit him to write a book on parole.

The government closed its case against the coal operators and former peace officers of Harlan County today after an illiterate miner and a 16year-old boy had testified before Federal Judge H. Church Ford and the jury that two of the defendants had offered cash to them to "swear to lies."
City Investing The City Investing Company declared a dividend of $2.50 a share on the common stock. The previous payment was $1 on Jan. 4, while in 1937 $1 each was disbursed on April 27 and Jan. 5.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made known today that E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. gave forty-one officers and employes bonuses totaling $2,332,400 in 1937. The figures were disclosed when the commission denied the company's request to have the data kept confidential.

A well-dressed man, about 25 years old, entered the deserted lobby of the Hotel Roger Smith here at 4:15 A. M. today and asked Paul Brennan, the night manager, and Edward Mallon, a bellhop, if a "Mr. Kelly" was registered.

Approval of sale of part of the bankrupt Auburn Automobile Company's assets was entered in the Federal Court's records here today. Dallas Winslow, Inc., of Detroit, purchased parts and equipment in the plant at Auburn, Ind., for $85,000.

The general level of wholesale prices rose in the week ended on June 11, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, was 77.8, compared with 77.7 on June 4, and 86.7 on June 12, 1937.
As usual, the Government of Finland distinguished itself by sending a check in response to Washington's "please remit" when the June 15 installments of the war debts fell due.

Share prices continued yesterday to edge higher, due not so much to an improved demand as to a scarcity of offerings. In other words, the stock market manifests a desire to move higher, but remains uncertain of the justification of such a step at this time, for all the talk of inflation and of the business depression scraping bottom.
William Woodward's Flares avenged the defeat of his famous brother, Omaha, when he came from behind on Ascot's "Golden Mile" to win the rich Gold Cup today.

A further recovery on the Cotton Exchange yesterday carried prices into new high ground for the month, and May contracts sold up to within few points of 81/2 cents. Large purchases of cotton goods for relief purposes stimulated mill price-fixing,

The National Enameling and Stamping Company, which has been one of Milwaukee's large manufacturers since its establishment in 1899, has authorized Alfred J. Kieckhefer, president, to transfer production from the Milwaukee plant to the company's other facstories.

Harold S. Vanderbilt, thrice skipper-defender of the America's Cup, is going into yacht racing tomorrow for the first time since he laid up the Ranger on shore last year. He has taken over Van S. MerleSmith's international class sloop Seven Seas for a few weeks,

The WPA plan to buy about $10,000,000 worth of men's and boy's clothing had a bullish effect on the market for piece goods this week, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday. Although many merchants are reported to have criticized the government's departure from its usual

The WPA plan to buy about $10,000,000 worth of men's and boy's clothing had a bullish effect on the market for piece goods this week, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday. Although many merchants are reported to have criticized the government's departure from its usual
Johnny Vander Meer went fishing today, "mighty pleased" over his two straight no-hit, no-run pitching performances but happier than all get out over congratulations from Babe Ruth.

Miss Mollie Clyde, granddaughter of the late William P. Clyde of New York, founder of the Clyde Steamship Line, was married here yesterday to Gordon A. Wilson of Pasadena. The couple will sail on June 21 from New York on the liner Europa.

Having interviewed more than, 200 manufacturers' 'representatives, buyers for the Kay Jewelry Stores and E. M. Rosenthal Jewelry Company, wholesalers, completed a four- ' day buying session at the Hotel Astor yesterday in preparation for the twenty-fourth anniversary sale of the Kay stores.

The only dance program of the coming Summer season at Lewisohn Stadium will be given on Thursday evening, July 7, and will present national folk dances and music by arrangement with Dance International 1900-38, it was announced by Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman of the Stadium Concerts, Inc.

Harcourt, Brace received recently from Anne Morrow Lindbergh the manuscript of her new book, "Listen! The Wind," which is scheduled for publication in October. Mrs. Lindbergh has been working on the book since before "North to the Orient" was published, a period of more than three years.

A cloudy day, with little wind, brought excellent water conditions today for the crews of Yale and Harvard in training for their regatta a week from tomorrow. Coaches at both Gales Ferry and Rep Top took full advantage of the opportunity and work was long and hard.

The opposition by pastors of the Evangelical Confessional Synods to taking an oath of allegiance to Chancellor Adolf Hitler is stiffening perceptibly, it is reported, and it is now believed that radical disciplinary measures against the refractory pastors are actively under consideration.
Five investors filed suit in the Federal court here today seeking to recover from the Bancamerica-Blair, Corporations of lNew York and Delaware $34,748 they spent in boomtime stock deals.

With a substantial drop in poultry prices this week almost all foods--meats, seasonably plentiful fish, fruits, vegetables and butter-are moderately or. inexpensively priced. In general, -developments in the food markets are resulting favorably to the consumer in noticeably lower -prices than those that prevailed a year ago.

The Hamburg-American liner Hamburg will arrive today from Germany and channel ports. On board is a group of German sportsmen coming to attend the Schmeling-Louis fight next Wednesday. They include Walter Gratenau, director of the Hanseatenhalle, a large sports arena in Hamburg, accompanies by his wife; Erwin satin Thoma and Karl Kasebach, editors.

Representative Ludlow said today he would seek to revive at the next session his war referendum proposal, including a special reservation recognizing need for prompt military action in defense of Latin America. His proposal was discarded by Congress Jan. 10 after
Daniel R. Coleman, president of the Dentist Corporation of New York, manufacturers of dental supplies, died Wednesday at the U. S. Veterans Hospital. following a long illness, at the age of 42.

The Mark Cross Company has acquired full control of Herman Bag, Inc., of 6 West Thirty-second Street, it was announced yesterday. M. J. Maher, treasurer .of the Mark Cross Company, said that the step was in line with a recent decision to re-establish the wholesale end of the business on a national scale.

New devices and methods for improving overseas radio and broadcasting, including a novel receiving circuit that automatically shuts out interference by partly closing an electrical gate when interference accompanies the program but which opens the door widely for high musical quality when the interference is not present, were described here yesterday at the thirteenth annual convention of theInstitute of Radio Engineers.
The enemy is advancing five miles an hour over a five-mile front. This might be a communique from any of a half dozen war zones in the day's news.
President Roosevelt, in almost identical letters to Speaker Bankhead and Vice President Garner, expressed appreciation tonight for "all that you have done." The letter to Mr. Bankhead was as follows:

Organization of American society as a corporate State, ruled in accordance with Catholic principles of virtue and justice, was urged by student commencement speakers as a cure for our economic ills, as diplomas were awarded last night to 110 graduates of Brooklyn Preparatory School.

As was to have been expected, this week's report for local member banks of the Federal Reserve System reflects the washing out of some of the large temporary increase in bank credit occasioned by the transactions incident to the Treasury financing.

Two libels were filed yesterday in Federal court in Brooklyn against the steamship Western World of the Munson Line. The actions were from brought by the Robins Dry Dock Th Company of Brooklyn. On Tuesday the United States Government filed a libel against the same vessel in the foreclosure of a mortgage of $769,500.

The Yugoslav Premier, Milan Stoyadinovitch, arrived this evening at Venice, where he will spend a few days vacation with his wife. He was met there by Foreign Minister Galeazzo Clano, who arrived by automobile last night after conferring with Premier Mussolini at Rocca delle Caminate.

Franklin Pierce McCall was sentenced to death today for the kidnapping of Jimmy Cash, a crime the presiding judge called "the most cold-blooded thing I ever heard of." The 21-year-old prisoner stood erect with clenched fists resting on a desk and heard his doom without a word or change of expression.

Luncheon, American Patriots, Iroquois Hotel, 49 West Forty-fourth Street, 12:30 P. M. "The Red Invasion of New Jersey," L. Chase O'Connor. Luncheon, Norwegian - American Chamber of Commerce, in celebration of arrival of the Oslofjord, Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, 1 P. M. Speakers:

The United States Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals today upheld the four-to-twelve year prison term given John S. Farnsworth, former lieutenant commander in the navy, for conspiracy to divulge military secrets to Japan.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City resumed the witness. stand for the fourth day yesterday before Judge William Clark in the United States District Court in Newark. His direct examination, which was conducted by Morris L. Ernst of New York, proceeded as follows:

Michael J. Reidy of 85 Crooke Avenue, a retired police captain who served for many years in the Detective Bureau in Manhattan, died yesterday in the Methodist Episcopal Hospital, Brooklyn, at the age of 73.
Mrs. Helen Wills Moody and Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan, United States stars, qualified today for the semi-final round of the London tennis championships.

Several sales and leases arranged by members of the Long Island Real Estate Board were reported yesterday. Included was the sale of 590 feet of business property fronting on Sunrise Highway at the corner of Horton Avenue, Lynbrook.

New regulations of the government of the Straits Settlements will result in the reorganization of the Malayan pineapple industry, according to report to the Department of Commerce from Singapore made public today.

Lifting her game to meet the challenge of a deficit, Mrs. Carolin Babcock Stark overcame the surprising Miss Louise Raymond of Scarsdale yesterday to gain the semi-final round of the women's New York State singles championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis

The American Car and Foundry Company will deliver to the Missouri Arkansas Railway on Sunday two streamlined air-conditioned gasoline-driven railway motor cars named, respectively, the John E. Martineau and the Thomas C. McRae.

A plea for the protection of freedom of speech against intrusions by politicians who try to suppress speakers by falsely accusing them of supporting one ism or another was made today at the opening session of the three-day annual convention of the Disabled American Veterans of the World War. Though names were not mentioned, the controversy in New Jersey came to the minds of many listeners.

A tax lien for- $445,372 was filed yesterday in Federal Court by the Collector of Internal Revenue for the Second District of New York against 'John Barry Ryan of 18 West Tenth Street, an heir of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan.

Mrs. Mary A. Borland, a former public school teacher here and for years active in the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, died yesterday in her residence. Her age was 86. Born in Greenville, she attended Wallkill Academy.

The New York Stock Exchange has received notice of the proposed dissolution of the partnership of Russell, Brewster Co. on June 30. Snyder, Wilson Co. have retired as Stock Exchange members. Charles A. Lindley will retire from Harris, Upham Co. on June 30.

The granting of 127 awards to Manhattan athletes for participation in Spring sports was announced yesterday by Herbert M. Kopf, di- I rector of athletics. Varsity awards were issued for fifty-six members of the baseball,
Presentation of Canada's budget to Parliament today indicated that the Dominion Finance Minister, Charles Dunning, almost succeeded in balancing it.

Robert Louis Hoguet, president of the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, was elected yesterday chairman of Group IV of the Savings Banks Association - of the State of New York at the annual meeting of the group in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Group IV comprises the mutual savings banks of Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester County.

Rufus Finch's Sundown Stables of Seabright captured both hunter events during the first program of the seventh annual Plainfield horse show today. The exhibition will continue for two more days at the Vinebrook Farm.

One school boy was fatally injured and another seriously hurt in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon when they were knocked from the top of a B. M. T. subway train by a street overpass after they had ridden the car-tops for nearly ten blocks.

A-Sing Sing sentence of fifteen to thirty. months was imposed yesterday by General Sessions Judge Streit on Alonzo J. Powers 2d, 29 years old, a Princeton graduate, who stole $4,500 of the funds of the Arbor Inn Club, an undergraduate eating organization at Princeton, of which he was the treasurer.

Diplomas were awarded to thirty-nine boys by the Rev. Dr. Endicott Peabody, rector, at the annual graduation and prize day exercises by Groton School today. Thomas Lee Higginson, in addition to graduating magna cum
Prime teen persons were e Minister Eamon de Valera today carried his demand for a government working majority in the Dail Eireann to Ireland's voters.

Edward V. Hickey, formerly general sales manager of the Gillette Safety Razor Corporation, has been appointed to a similar position with the General Shaver Corporation, manufacturer of Remington-Rand Electric Close-Shavers, it was announced yesterday.

Ladson Butler, from Mrs. Carl Ahlere, cottage in Garrison-on-Hudson. Putnam County, T. Rowan, dwelling in Moore's Mills, Dutchess County; Reginald Call, Tree Tops, the Margaret Mayo residence in Harmon, Westchester County; Frances Spencer, Inc, broker.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 11 amounted to 553,854 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

King Leopold today received in audience Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University. The European committee of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, meeting in Brussels yesterday under the chairmanship of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, sent a special message of gratitude to Secretary of State Cordell Hull at Washington, the Endowment announced here yesterday. The message read:

Recapturing the title she won in 1936 and failed to defend last year, Mrs. Ary J. Lamme of the home club today defeated Mrs. John J. Schieffelin of Mount Kisco, 6-0, 6-4, in the final of the third annual women's invitation tennis tournament at the Manursing Island Club.

Most of the measurement ratings on the forty-four yachts entered in the race to Bermuda, which starts. from Newport on Tuesday, were received by the race committee yesterday. The actual time allowances will not be reckoned until just before the start.

In order to understand the controversy over "search and seizure" which is now in progress in the State Constitutional Convention, it is necessary to recognize that three separate questions are involved:

Harold E. Coe, an insurance broker of New York, died today in Temple University Hospital here. He was 55 years old. Born in Denver, Col., he was the son of Earl A. Coe, who was pubLisher of The Denver Times.

The Schuyler Hudson -Corporation, New York City, has filed a registration statement -in conformity with the Securities Act of 1933 under a plan of reorganization involving 4 per cent ten-year first mortgage bonds due in 1947.

Flying over the high hurdles in recordsmashing time, blond Fred Wolcott of Rice Institute stole a big share of honors from the title-seeking Southern California Trojans in today's qualifying trials of the seventeenth National Collegiate A. A. track and field championships.
A Vatican news service reported today that beatification of Frances Xavier Cabrini, an Italian nun who labored and died in the United States, is expected in October or, at the latest, in January.

Improvement of working conditions up to practical limits in every country in the world "is basic to that increased consumption, to that international trade, and to that stabilization of industrial life so needed for recovery and for security," Miss Frances Perkins,

With a well-balanced card of five races, headed by the Cedarhurst Grand National, the Rockaway Steeplechase Association today will ring down the curtain on the hunts racing season on Long Island with its annual Spring meeting at Cedarhurst.

Although there was no apparent numerical gain in the Princeton student-faculty protest on the reported plan to confer an honorary doctor of laws degree on Governor A. Harry Moore Tuesday, the undergraduate movement obtained a "coordinator" today in the person of J. Harlan Cleveland, '38, of Cincinnati, vice president of the WhigCliosophic Societies.

Mrs. William Dick Sporborg, legislative chairman of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, has accepted the chairmanship of a Statewide committee in support of the establishment of a consumers' department now under consideration by the Constitutional Convention.

John M. Dealy was elected national commander of the Catholic War Veterans last night by acclanation at its first national convention. More than 700-members from the organization's 200 posts are attending the convention. Last night's session, at 14 East Sixtieth Street, was to have been devoted to nominations, with elections tonight, but Mr. Dealy was unopposed for commander.

Three war vessels, two of them American and one flying 'the tricolor of France, reached New York Harbor together. yesterday and passed up the Hudson River in view of thousands of commuters on their way to work.
Harry W. Rextrew, for many years a buyer for the W. M. Whitney Company, died today at his home in Menands. He was 73 years old and had been ill for a month.
Water St, 194, 24.81/2x60.10x irreg; Leopold Friedman to Alfred J. Callahan, 15 Broad St, trustee for certificate holders; consideration $10,000, foreclosure.
The golf team of the Bond Club of Philadelphia defeated yesterday the team of the Bond Club of New York at the annual field day of the Philadelphia club at the Philmont Country Club, Philmont, Pa.

An agreement for coordinating the activities of four national Jewish organizations in the defense of Jewish civil and political rights wherever abrogated or threatened was ratified yesterday by two of the groups, the American Jewish Committee and the American Jewish Congress.
Miss Beatrice Barrett of Minneapolis defeated Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City, 3 and 2, in a semi-final match in the women's Western open golf tournament at Broadmoor today.

The New York World's Fair of 1939 signed a contract yesterday with the Childs Company to take over the frankfurter and hamburger concession which George D. Strohmeyer, president of the Childs Company, described as "the largest meat deal ever negotiated in time of peace."

Frank Hedley, sole surviving voting trustee for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company's stock, has announced an extension to Sept. 30 of the time within which holders of voting trust certificates may call at 165 Broadway to exchange them for stock.

The even succession of days of weakness and days of strength for the dollar which has characterized the foreign exchange market this week was continued yesterday when the United States unit rallied somewhat from its losses of the previous day.
